title: Letter: On Shoreham In the Shadow of Three Mile Island
description: To the Editor:

5 M
description: Five Yonkers men have been convicted of beating two men with baseball bats while shouting antihomosexual epithets at them in Greenwich Village last fall, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: A HISTORICAL DISPLAY OF ARTISTRY IN SILVER
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.

title: Advertising; Behind the Cabbage Patch Kids
description: WHEN someone telephones Richard & Edward's these days to speak to the president, Richard Schwarzchild, he has to assure Mr. Schwarzchild's secretary that he isn't looking for a free doll.

title: BRIEFS
description: American Can Co. said it had signed a letter of intent to acquire Michigan Bulb Co., a privately held mail-order garden and nursery company based in Grand Rapids, for an undisclosed amount.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: Seoul Links Bombing To a Planned Invasion

title: CONTEMPORARY MUSIC: BEAUTY OR PAIN OF TRUTH
description: ''TO court the ear and strike the heart'' is music's aim, reads the text to Henry Purcell's ''Ode to St. Cecelia.'' And for Baroque ears, music did just that. It seduced us with sound and invited our intimacy.

title: CREDIT MARKETS ; INTEREST RATES CLIMB SLIGHTLY
description: Interest rates rose slightly yesterday, with many investors and speculators so uncertain about the outlook that they remained on the sidelines.

title: Greyhound Union Meets With U.S. Mediators
description: Assisted by Government mediators, a union representing striking employees of the Greyhound bus line is considering making a contract counterproposal in an effort to end a 28-day walkout.

title: TEST AT ST. LOUIS GLOBE-DEMOCRAT: U.S. ROLE, IF ANY, IN SAVING NEWSPAPERS
description: NewsAnalysis

title: THE 'NEW' BRYANT PARK: A PLAN OF PROS AND CONS
description: An Appraisal

title: CONSIDER A NEUTRAL, REUNIFIED GERMANY
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl apparently is not impressed by his parliamentary majority in favor of missile deployment. After denouncing the opposition for weakness in the face of the Soviet Union, he now seeks to take not as many but as few of the weapons as possible. A 19th century statesman declared that one can do everything with bayonets except sit on them. The same, Mr. Kohl is discovering, is true of missiles. The argument between the Government and opposition, to be sure, is not about missiles; it is about Germany's future, and the lines are far more blurred than the Government's arithmetic victory suggests.

title: MEXICAN FACES MORE TESTS IN 2D YEAR
description: President Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado completed his first year in office today, governing a Mexico that looks increasingly healthy to foreign financiers but increasingly troubled to people at home.

title: JURORS BEGIN DELIBERATIONS ON EX-E.P.A. OFFICIAL
description: A Federal jury retired this evening without reaching a verdict on whether Rita M. Lavelle, the former chief of toxic waste programs at the Environmental Protection Agency, lied under oath to Congressional investigating committees.

title: Archive Project Traces Actors Equity History
description: Theatrical programs, contracts and other memorabilia documenting the history of Actors Equity, from 1916 to the present, are being installed in a continuing archive project at New York University in Greenwich Village.

title: Argentina Bond Offer
description: The Argentine

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: HOPE FOR BRITISH PRESS SETTLEMENT FADES
description: Hopes for any immediate solution to the labor dispute that shut down Britain's national newspapers over the weekend seemed to have disappeared today.

title: ASTROSYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Yr to Aug. 31
FAREWELL, DR. GLOOM
description: The Chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, Martin Feldstein, is a brilliant conservative economist, a forthright defender of his point of view, and an all-round terrific guy. He ought to quit or be fired.

title: Rep. Zablocki on Critical List After Suffering Heart Attack
description: Representative Clement J. Zablocki, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, suffered a heart attack today and was reported in ''extremely critical'' condition.

title: UNIMAX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $54,900. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $30,900 and an extraordinary loss of $18,300. d-After an extraordinary gain of $132,300. e-After a loss from discontinued operations of $7,353,500 relating to the sale of Barry's Jewelers Inc. in May 1982.

title: Major Insurer Drops Lobby
description: The American Express Company has withdrawn from a lobbying group opposing unisex insurance legislation.

title: Toronto Dominion Sells Coast Bank
description: The Toronto Dominion Bank said it had agreed to sell its California retail banking unit to the American Asian Bank of San Francisco.

title: BATTERY PARK PLAZA DESIGN UNVEILED
description: The design for Battery Park City's 3 1/2-acre waterfront plaza, the public space of the $1.5 billion World Financial Center in lower Manhattan, was unveiled yesterday at the Whitney Museum of American Art by the Battery Park City Fine Arts Committee.

title: ASTRONAUTS PROBE HIGH ATMOSPHERE
description: Sensing instruments on the space shuttle Columbia's Spacelab probed the earth's upper atmosphere today, providing scientists with a comprehensive survey of high-altitude chemistry and the first definitive data on turbulence in the critical zone where upwelling gases interact with solar ultraviolet radiation.

title: Reward for Murdoch
description: Don Murdoch , the former Ranger forward, has been on a 25-game trial with the Adirondack Red Wings of the American Hockey League, but not any more.

title: Southern Cal Tops Missouri
description: Pam McGee scored 33 points and Cheryl Miller 27 to lead Southern California to an 81-79 victory over Missouri.

title: OPERA: 'FAUST'
description: AT an opera performance, a listener does not usually pay too much attention to the race of the singers; it has become less and less necessary to note the appearance of a ''minority'' performer. But black singers have not had an easy time entering the operatic mainstream during this century, and partly because of that, Opera Ebony was founded in 1973.

title: CRAFTS SHOWS OFFER SEASONAL WARES
description: A number of holiday craft shows and sales are being held around the city and in Rockville Centre, L.I., and Lebanon, N.J., some of them beginning today.

title: Mesa Lifts Stake
description: The Mesa Petroleum Company said it and members of its investor group had acquired an additional 705,400 shares of the Gulf Oil Corporation for about $31.3 million.

title: SANDINISTA CULTURE CHIEF REPORTS A DETENTION AT KENNEDY AIRPORT
description: The Rev. Ernesto Cardenal, Nicaragua's Minister of Culture, said yesterday that he had been detained and questioned for three hours at Kennedy International Airport before being admitted to the United States.

title: Senior Managers Shift At Thomson McKinnon
description: Thomson McKinnon Inc., the financial services concern, realigned its senior management preparatory to a planned venture with the Hartford Insurance Group.

title: Back and Forth on Worker Safety
description: Every day some 25 million American workers, a quarter of the work force, are exposed to potentially hazardous chemicals. An estimated 17,000 die each year from cancer caused by the exposure.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
description: Fannie Mae Securities Set for Yield of 12.61%

title: SIGMAFORM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
3,000 Filipinos Protest Policies of Government
description: More than 3,000 peasants and factory workers demonstrated today against President Ferdinand E. Marcos's policies.

title: REAGAN SIGNS BILL FOR RIGHTS PANEL
description: President Reagan today signed a bill reconstituting the United States Commission on Civil Rights as an independent agency but said the Justice Department had expressed ''reservations'' about it.

title: VAST REBUILDING OF BRYANT PARK PLANNED
description: The plans for Bryant Park change it markedly while preserving its best features. An appraisal, page B2.

title: SOCIALISTS FORCED TO USE ECONOMICS OF THE RIGHT
description: Here and in Madrid, Paris, Rome and Athens, Socialist-led Governments are imposing painful austerity measures in an effort to haul themselves back from the brink of bankruptcy.

title: PURDUE SETS BACK LOUISVILLE IN OVERTIME
description: Ricky Hall scored a career- high 24 points tonight, and a teammate, Steve Reid, had 11 of his 17 points in overtime as Purdue beat Louisville, 90-83.

title: A COUNTRY UNPREPARED FOR WAR SURVIVAL
description: To the Editor:

title: HELEN BAKER
description: Helen Baker, an author and former editor of The Church Woman, a publication of a Protestant interfaith organization, Church Women United, died last Thursday at her home in Manhattan.

title: Appeal to the Heart
description: His name is Evan O'Reilly , he is 4 months old and he has undergone two operations that failed to correct a liver malfunction that threatens his life. His only hope is a liver transplant, but Evan is two months too young to receive one, and even if he lives long enough there is no assurance that there will be a suitable organ available.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The World Boxing Association welterweight title fight between the champion, Don Curry , and Marlon Starling has been set for Atlantic City on Feb. 4. . . . James Lofton , who recently became the first Green Bay Packer receiver to gain more than 1,000 yards a season three times, has signed a five-year contract extending through the 1988 season. . . . Two Columbia players, John Witkowski , the quarterback, and Don Lewis , a wide receiver, have been named to the Eastern College Athletic Conference Division I-AA all-star team. Rich Erenberg , the Colgate tailback, was named player of the year in the balloting by the 24 E.C.A.C. coaches. . . . Another Columbia player, Steve Sirtis, a midfielder on the unbeaten soccer team, was voted to the all-Ivy League team for the fourth straight year by the league's eight coaches and was named the league's player of the year for the second time in a row. Five Lion teammates joined him on the team: Gary Escher , goalkeeper; Solomon Gayle , forward; Amer Aly , midfielder; and Greg Varney and Neil Banks , fullbacks.

title: GENOVA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
Debtors in Clover
description: Take note, America: New York is waging a wondrous political brawl over what to do with a financial ''surplus.'' Though deep in debt, the city to which the nation gave its credit seven years ago has recovered its balance and been made to save more than it needs to pay its creditors. Having survived a test of fire, New York's leaders are in danger only of drowning each other in the gravy.

title: RECITAL: ANTON DEL FORNO
description: ANTON DEL FORNO, who gave a guitar recital in Alice Tully Hall on Monday night, is not an untalented player. He has a sensitivity to melodic line and knows how to create a certain kind of mood.

title: BLACK HAWKS DEFEAT SLUMPING RANGERS
description: The Rangers' play was so dull that the fans at Madison Square Garden last night began an unusual chant late in the third period. Punctuated by two hand claps between each phrase, they chanted, ''Wake up! Wake up!''

title: AIDE SAYS HOLMES ISN'T LIKELY TO QUIT
description: An aide to Larry Holmes said yesterday that the World Boxing Council heavyweight champion may be changing his mind about retiring less than 24 hours after stating his intention to quit boxing next week.

title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK
description: IF you sense that every retail establishment, everywhere, is

title: THURSDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Washington Bullets, at Madison Square Garden, 8:05 P.M. The schedule is piling up on the Knicks, who are playing their third game in three nights and their sixth in the last eight. (Television - MSG Cable, 8 P.M., live, and USA Cable, 4:30 A.M., Friday, tape. Radio - WNEW, 1130; 8 P.M.)

title: DANKER LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $3,555. c-Net loss.

title: By George A. Woods
description: AFTER a sound threshing and winnowing of this year's children's book crop here are the good grains that remain, prime seed stock to plant in fertile young minds. With care, nurturing and a little patience these books should produce their own bumper harvest of pleasure.

title: TANDY'S PERSONAL COMPUTER
description: The Tandy Corporation today introduced a personal computer - the TRS-80 Model 2000 - that will be nearly compatible with the International Business Machines Corporation Personal Computer, a machine that is coming to dominate the corporate market.

title: DR. WHEATON J. LANE, WRITER
description: Dr. Wheaton J. Lane, an author and a former instructor of American history at Princeton University, died Tuesday at the Medical Center at Princeton. He was 81 years old and had homes in Princeton, Bar Harbor, Me., and Hampton, N.H., his birthplace.

title: P.& G. Seeks to Build Market Among Blacks
description: Procter & Gamble has named Burrell Advertising, a black-owned agency in Chicago that specializes in ethnic market advertising, to develop a black-oriented marketing effort for its Crest brand toothpaste.

title: VOLUME SOARS
description: Stock prices fell sharply yesterday in reaction to a selloff in two key blue- chip issues and most of the technology group, as volume climbed to its highest level in five months.

title: DANCE: ORIGINALS BY BILL CARTER AND RUTH MEYER
description: SOME indisputably major dance talent joined forces with some distinctly minor choreographers Tuesday night for a program at the Joyce Theater called ''New Dances by Bill Carter and Ruth Mayer.''

title: PARENTS WARNED ON TOY HAZARDS
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission has urged parents to read labels closely and leave on store shelves any toys with sharp edges, long strings or small parts that come loose easily.

title: AMERICAN CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
PLAYERSIra Berkow; A Silent Whistle Is Heard
description: From the window of his house in

title: SEVEN OAKS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Oct. 31
AGNICO-EAGLE MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
'Call to Inward Search'
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: UNITED TIRE & RUBBER CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: SENTRY WITNESS MISSING AFTER GETTING THREAT
description: A missing witness in an $11 million theft trial disappeared after receiving a threat to his life, according to testimony yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: WHO INVESTS WHAT IN THE MARKET
description: Large pension funds and other institutions may have fueled the bull market over the past year, but so too did married, working, college-educated women in their 30's, who were living in large metropolitan areas and were members of households with incomes of just over $30,000.

title: G.& W. Forecast
description: Gulf and Western Industries expects operating earnings for the fiscal year 1984 of between $2.75 and $3 a share, up from $1.67 in the year ended July 31, James Parent, vice president, told securities analysts here. The company reported fiscal year 1983 net income of $3.25 a share, which included capital gains from the sale of securities and other nonoperating sources. Mr. Parent also said the company's net interest expense was expected to drop to about $75 million this year from $167 million in fiscal 1983.

title: Carolina Power $100 Million Issue A $100 million issue of the Carolina Power and Light Company 12 7/8 percent bonds due in 2013 was offered yesterday at a price of 98 1/2 to yield 13.07 percent through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.
description: The bonds, rated A-2/A-, were not scheduled for sale this week, but had been previously registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission under Rule 415. The yield on the bonds was 143 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, greater than the yield on 12 percent Treasury bonds due in 2013.

title: CHAMBER: MASTER GROUP
description: the Master Players Chamber Orchestra of New York is a promising young ensemble, made up of seasoned musicians who play with vigor, discipline and clarity. That said, the orchestra's Tuesday evening concert in the Abraham Goodman House left something to be desired.

title: OIL-DRI CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Capitals to Keep Tax Advantage
description: The Prince George's County Council ''postponed indefinitely'' today a vote on a bill to repeal a six- year tax benefit granted to the Washington Capitals. In August 1982, the council granted Abe Pollin, the team's owner, relief from a 10 percent county amusement tax as part of the condition he had set to keep the hockey team in the Washington area.

title: SHAMIR SAYS U.S. ACCORD WILL AID LEBANON
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said today that the newly strengthened strategic cooperation between Israel and the United States ''can go a long way'' toward restoring Lebanese independence and persuading Syria to give up hopes of dominating Lebanon.

title: SCOUTING
description: Agent Hires Help

title: Iraq Accuses Iranian Forces Of Shelling 2 Border Towns
description: Iraq said today that Iranian forces had shelled the Iraqi border towns of Basra and Mandali, damaging some civilian installations.

title: Crop Prices Increased By 0.7% in November
description: Prices farmers get for raw products rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in November after declining two months in a row, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: A WINDFALL FOR THE CITY
description: NewsAnalysis

title: U.S. POLICY ON NICARAGUA: KEEP THE PRESSURE ON
description: NewsAnalysis

title: Heller Liquidation
description: The Walter E. Heller International Corporation said its shareholders approved a plan of liquidation and the previously announced sale of its American National Bank subsidiary to the First Chicago Corporation for $275 million.

title: Christopher George, 54, Dies; Appeared in TV's 'Rat Patrol'
description: Christopher George, an actor who appeared in television's ''Rat Patrol'' and ''The Immortal,'' died Monday night at Westside Hospital here. He was 54 years old

title: IN HARLEM THEATER 4 DECADES
description: Roger Furman, founder and director of Harlem's oldest active theater company, the New Heritage Repertory Theater, died of heart and kidney disease in his Upper Manhattan home Sunday. He was 59 years old.

title: S.& P. INDEX ADDS A.T.& T. SPINOFFS
description: Surprising many on Wall Street, the Standard & Poor's Corporation yesterday added to its 500-stock index all seven of the regional companies being spun off by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: ISRAEL'S WEST BANK
description: T he much-touted rapprochement between America and Israel notwithstanding, there is one bone of contention that appears to defy resolution: disposition of the West Bank. The Administration seems to believe that Israeli control over the area will make Arab antagonism irreversible. And many of Israel's would-be friends maintain that unless the West Bank is relinquished, Israel will lose its Jewish identity in the flood of a rapidly growing Arab population and will have to resort to ever more repressive measures against the Arab inhabitants, making endless violence inevitable.

title: TOKLAN OIL CORP reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
Union Camp's President Takes Post of Chairman
description: The Union Camp Corporation, a major forest products company based in Wayne, N.J., announced yesterday that Peter J. McLaughlin had been elected to succeed Alexander Calder Jr. as chairman.

title: OIL ROYALTIES SUIT STIRS TEXAS ANGER
description: A tangled $1.7 billion lawsuit, contesting a half-century of royalties from a vast tract of prime oil land, has developed into one of the Texas' most bitter legal and political battles.

title: REQUIEM FOR A VICTIM
description: Among those killed in the crash of a Colombian 747 in Madrid last weekend was a renowned scholar of Latin American culture, Angel Rama. In death as in life, Professor Rama is a reproachful symbol to those who care about standards of freedom and civilization in the United States. For he died a victim of uncivilized American immigration laws and uncivilized bureaucrats.

title: Texas Drug Smuggler Charged in an Assault
description: Jimmy Chagra, who is in prison for drug smuggling, was indicted today on charges of conspiracy and assault in the attempted slaying five years ago of a former Federal prosecutor.

title: U.S. RIGHTS GROUP ASSAILS DENIAL OF VISAS TO 2 LATINS
description: The American Civil Liberties Union today assailed the Government's refusal to let Nicaragua's Interior Minister and a Salvadoran rightist leader enter the United States.

title: HOLIDAY GIFTS FOR THE HOME, BOTH USEFUL AND FANCIFUL
description: AT this time of year, when so many festive occasions are centered on home and family, choosing a gift for someone's dwelling is one of the season's pleasures. It is an opportunity to give something that is practical or fanciful - or both - and to be personal as well as imaginative . A charming handcrafted twig chair might be the perfect choice for a close friend's country-style living room, for example, while hand-painted tumblers are simple enough to coexist with your in-laws' bone china.

title: HOW POLICIES DIFFER AMONG SOUTHERN EUROPEANS
description: All of southern Europe's Socialists have broadly similar economic goals and face some common obstacles, but the policies, priorities and some problems differ from country to country. Here is a summary of those differences.

title: Cyprus Purchase
description: Shareholders of the Cyprus Corporation approved two amendments to the company's bylaws that will clear the way for an $85 million purchase of the Special Metals Corporation from Allegheny International Inc. The acquisition of Special Metals, which has annual sales of about $100 million, will be completed before yearend, the company said.

title: 'CARMEN' BRIGHTENS BEAUMONT
description: ASURGE of ticket sales for Peter Brook's ''Tragedie de Carmen'' has brightened the Vivian Beaumont Theater after five years of darkness. But the success also has rekindled the debate over whether the theater is artistically viable.

title: Slayer of 4 Given 35 Years to Life
description: A porter in an Upper West Side residential hotel who shot four people to death there last February was sentenced yesterday to 35 years to life in prison.

title: Power System Ruling
description: A Federal judge ruled here today that bondholders should be allowed to continue their own securities fraud class action lawsuits against the Washington Public Power Supply System, even though Chemical Bank has a similar lawsuit under way in its capacity as trustee for the bondholders. United States District Judge Richard Bilby refused to dismiss two dozen consolidated suits, although Washington State lawyers argued that the actions were duplicative.

title: U.S. CUTS ESTIMATE OF ITS CORN FOR LIVESTOCK
description: The Department of Agriculture today reduced by two-thirds its estimate of how much Government-owned feed corn is available for a new drought relief program for livestock growers.

title: DIODES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $162,480 for the quarter and $258,159 for the 6 months. c-Includes tax credits of $36,471 for the quarter and $53,435 for the 6 months. The year-earlier 6 months net also includes gain of $280,738 from the sale of a building plus a tax credit on the sale of $210,707, or 27 cents a share.

title: AUTO AIR BAG HEARINGS BEGIN
description: Proposals for the mandatory installation of air bags in new automobiles have been a source of dispute for 14 years, and the testimony presented at a public hearing in Los Angeles this week before officials of the Department of Transportation reflected how divisive the issue still is.

title: SIDESTEPPING THE TELEPHONE COMPANY
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation, the big industrial conglomerate, has a microwave radio system that permits telephoning among its 22 buildings in or around Pittsburgh without using the local phone company's lines. The arrangement deprives Bell of Pennysylvania of $500,000 to $1 million a year in transmission revenues and even more in equipment rentals.

title: DAVIS WATER & WASTE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Applied Magnetics
description: The Applied Magnetics Corporation said its profits for the fiscal first quarter, ending Dec. 31, are expected to be below results of a year earlier. It also said that shipments will be considerably less than anticipated. In last year's first quarter, Applied Magnetics, which makes magnetic recording heads for the computer industry, had per-share earnings of 14 cents on revenues of $18.4 million.

title: URBAN LEADERS REMINDED NOT TO EXPECT NEW U.S. AID
description: The Reagan Administration's top urban affairs official, ending the three-day convention of the National League of Cities here, has reminded local officials that cities must do things for themselves.

title: Son of Officer Held In Drug-Ring Case
description: A son of a Newark police officer was arrested today and held in $500,000 bond as a reputed member of a drug ring that operated under the guise of a charity for the handicapped.

title: Packer Is Suspended
description: Michael Douglass , Green Bay's sixth-year linebacker, was suspended by the Packers yesterday, two days after he walked out of a team meeting and skipped a workout because of criticism of his performance in the Packers' 47-41 loss to the Atlanta Falcons Sunday. ''This is an in-house problem,'' said Coach Bart Starr , who said Douglass had been suspended for ''conduct detrimental for our football team.''

title: HEINEKEN RESCUED IN RAID BY POLICE
description: Ten policemen raided an unguarded warehouse here today and freed the kidnapped brewery chairman, Alfred H. Heineken, and his chauffeur from unheated concrete cells in which they had been chained for 21 days.

title: Banks in Talks on Philippine Loans
description: The advisory committee of 12 commercial banks for the Philippines yesterday opened what are scheduled to be three days of meetings with Prime Minister Cesar Virata and Jaime Laya, governor of the central bank, on the country's financing needs for 1984.

title: WIENER ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Includes a $530,000 tax credit. c-Net loss.

title: Key Rates
description: * Nuveen index, John Nuveen & CompanySalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: S.D. IGNATYEV, CHIEF OF SECURITY LINKED TO A STALIN-ERA PLOT
description: Semyon D. Ignatyev, a Soviet secret police official who figured prominently in behind-the-scenes intrigues about the time of the death of Stalin in 1953, died Sunday, according to a report yesterday by the Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia. He was 79 years old.

title: BEATRICE FOODS BIDS FOR 10% OF STOCK
description: The Beatrice Foods Company said today that it planned to offer $34 a share to buy back up to 10 million shares, or about 10 percent, of its common stock.

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 1, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: DR. KUNG'S FLOCK
description: To the Editor:

title: SCOUTING
description: Watson Charge Is Unresolved

title: BILLY BALDWIN: APPRAISING A MASTER
description: BILLY BALDWIN always insisted that he never originated anything in decorating. Yet, the Baltimore-born decorator, who died at the age of 80 last Friday on Nantucket, left an indelible stamp on American interiors. His rooms sparkled with freshness and a sense of ease, qualities rooted in his love of Matisse, his Southern past and his talent for eliminating whatever he deemed superfluous.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Striving for 'Fame'

title: Colombian Kidnappers Set a Dec. 10 Deadline
description: The kidnappers of Jaime Betancur, the younger brother of Colombia's President, said today that they would kill their prisoner Dec. 10 if the Government did not meet their demands.

title: A WRIGHT HOUSE WON'T BE MUSEUM
description: -style house designed by Frank Lloyd Wright, the Willits House in Highland Park, Ill., has been sold to a private owner, passing beyond the reach of a group of architects who wanted to make it a living museum.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest report of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange.

title: THE 'INTELLIGENT' BUILDINGS
description: -story office building called Cityplace will open in Hartford. With 1.3 million square feet of floor space, it will be the largest commercial structure in Connecticut. It will also be ''the world's first intelligent building,'' according to one company involved, the Building Systems Company.

title: MORNING TV IS THE TALK OF BRITAIN
description: It is 8:35 A.M. Onto the television screen bounds a human- size lamb wearing a pink tutu. The creature executes a maladroit series of pirouettes and doffs its woolly head to reveal a chubby man with a mop of curly hair. He is Russell Grant, the breathless bearer of the day's horoscope, which he reads on his knees.

title: Bridge; Most of the Country's Best Battle in Blue Ribbon Pairs
description: The Fall National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League continued here this afternoon with most of the country's top-ranked players competing in the semifinals of the Blue Ribbon Pairs.

title: Transactions
description: BASKETBALL

title: REAGAN REPORTED TO AGREE ON STEPS TO REPEL MISSILES
description: President Reagan and his senior national security advisers agreed in principle today to proceed with the development of weapons capable of repelling nuclear attacks by destroying incoming missiles, according to an Administration official.

title: New Bombings in Corsica
description: Bombs exploded in law courts and 15 other buildings, including homes and shops, in Corsica early today on the eve of a visit by Interior Minister Gaston Defferre. The police said no one was injured but damage was severe. No one took responsibility for the explosions.

title: Bangladesh Said to Ask Soviet to Cut Embassy
description: The newspaper Ittafaq said today that the Government had asked the Soviet Union to cut its diplomatic staff by half and had ordered the closing of the Soviet cultural center here.

title: Sanyo Computers
description: The Sanyo Electric Company said it would begin marketing personal computers in the United States next year that will be able to use software designed for the International Business Machines Corporation small business models. The Sanyo models, the MBC- 550 and MBC-555, will retail for between $1,000 and $1,400, Sanyo said.

title: HOME DECORATING: HIDDEN MEANINGS
description: IN her new book, Joan Kron has

title: ELLMAN'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
description: b-Net loss.

title: CITY PUBLIC WORKS PLAN GETS MIXED REPORT CARD FROM WATCHDOG GROUP
description: New York City's plan to invest $20 billion in public works will produce ''demonstrable improvements'' in bridges, hospitals, water supply, pollution control and waste disposal by 1992, according to a new study. But streets and public school buildings, it concluded, ''are likely to deteriorate further.''

title: WITNESS TESTIFIES HE HELPED BIEGENWALD DISPOSE OF WOMAN'S BODY
description: A key prosecution witness in the murder trial of Richard F. Biegenwald testified today that he had helped Mr. Biegenwald dispose of the body of an 18-year- old Camden woman in August 1982.

title: Dr. Gloria Warner, 50, Dead; Psychoanalyst and Teacher
description: Dr. Gloria Marmar Warner, a psychoanalyst and an assistant clinical professor of psychiatry at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, died of cancer yesterday at her home in Scarsdale, N.Y. She was 50 years old.

title: I.O.C. Approves Drug Facility
description: The International Olympic Committee's medical commission has granted full accreditation to the doping control center that will test athletes during the 1984 Summer Games, according to the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee.

title: HOME BEAT
description: IT's Elizabeth Eakins's second

title: AUTHOR AWARDED FUNDS FROM AGENT
description: A Federal jury has ordered Lucianne S. Goldberg, a New York literary agent, to pay almost $61,000 to Kitty Kelley, an author who had sued Mrs. Goldberg for withholding money due from foreign rights on her book ''Elizabeth Taylor: The Last Star.''

title: PROBLEMS PERSIST WHEN CITY OWNS HOUSES
description: When Rose Brush owned her house, the walls were falling apart, the front steps and interior stairs were crumbling with age, the water heater was worn out, the windows were drafty and the gas company was threatening to shut off service for nonpayment. Although there were was no mortgage, Mrs. Brush found that with income of $900 a month, medical bills of her own and two disabled children to care for, she could not afford repairs and taxes.

title: AMERICAN MOTOR INNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31

description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association ended a 19-month investigation of the University of Kansas today by putting the Jayhawks on a two- year football probation, which includes only one year of sanctions.

title: CRIMINAL JUSTICE CHIEF
description: ''Criminal justice is a little bit like arms control,'' said Kenneth Conboy, sitting in his 14th-floor office of Police Headquarters. ''It's an area of enormous complexity. It's an area riven with fears.'' For the 45-year-old Mr. Conboy, who was named the city's new criminal justice coordinator by Mayor Koch yesterday, learning how to wade through those complexities and allay that fear will become a fulltime job Jan. 1. He succeeds John F. Keenan, who resigned in October to take a seat on the Federal Court for the Southern District.

title: No 'Games' on Death Row
description: Not content with voting to reject a condemned man's plea for a stay of execution, Chief Justice Warren Burger saw fit on Tuesday to denounce the lawyers who tried to save him. According to his concurring opinion:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: WHAT SIMON SAYS A poor boy from Washington Heights, Neil Simon made good, becoming one of America's most sucessful playwrights and screenwriters. ''The Goodbye Girl,'' ''Brighton Beach Memoirs,'' ''Chapter Two,'' ''Only When I Laugh,'' ''California Suite'' and many more plays - some 20 in 22 years - and movies have cascaded from his pen.

title: MURDERER EXECUTED DESPITE PLEA BY POPE AND FLORIDA BISHOPS
description: Robert Austin Sullivan, a convicted murderer whose fight to avoid execution was embraced by Pope John Paul II and deplored by the Chief Justice of the United States, died today in the electric chair.

description: The Heizer Corporation said its directors at a special meeting concluded that a complete or partial liquidation of the company might be in the best interests of shareholders.

title: JERSEY DROWNINGS: ENIGMA REMAINS
description: The Cooper River ran thick and brown today. Just off Federal Street, near a railroad trestle, about a mile downstream from where the bodies of two children were found, scuba divers in red wet suits slipped into the water and disappeared from view. Upstream on the surface, firefighters and police officers in open, flat-hulled boats towed drag lines across the bottom.

title: Amtrak Silver Meteor Derails in Florida
description: An Amtrak Silver Meteor passenger train derailed today after hitting a truck stuck on the tracks, injuring at least 35 people, the authorities said.

title: PLAYSJames Tuite
description: Coach Kevin Loughery left home without it, but his trainer and traveling secretary did not, and so the Chicago Bulls tried to use an American Express card Tuesday night to put up the required down payment on their protest of a game they lost, 116-110, to the Rockets in Houston. The card, which has been used to purchase such products as jet planes, was deemed unacceptable for the $500 deposit on a National Basketball Association protest.

title: CORRECTION

title: BONN CABINET MINISTER DENIES CORRUPTION CHARGE
description: Economics Minister Otto Lambsdorff, who stands accused of corruption, denied today that as a Cabinet officer he had accepted monies from the Flick holding company and complained that he had been surprised by the seriousness of the charge against him.

description: State Senator David Serotkin, a Democrat, today became the second state legislator in eight days to be voted out of office for supporting an increase in the state income tax.

description: Willie Aikens, the Kansas City Royal first baseman, who was sentenced to three months' imprisonment for the Federal misdemeanor of attempting to possess cocaine, has been turned down in his effort to get the sentence reduced.

title: Gold Courier Reports A $600,000 Robbery
description: A man who told the police he was carrying $600,000 worth of gold and jewels as well as $10,000 in cash was abducted, beaten and robbed at LaGuardia Airport last night before being released without serious injuries, the police said.

description: CITY, suburban; married; living with men, friends, parents, children: women ask about my solitary existence, living and working without other human beings, by choice and in the country besides. What they want to know is how I manage the absence of other people.

description: American Broadcasting Companies has appointed Barbara H. Marks vice president, operations, of its ABC- Publishing division.

title: COAL PANEL URGING WIDE CHANGES IN U.S. LEASES TO STIR COMPETITION
description: A special advisory commission today proposed a long list of preliminary recommendations for changing Federal coal leasing policies to assure more competition and a better financial return to the Government.

description: Simon Wiesenthal, the hunter of Nazi fugitives, was assalted in a courtroom here today as he prepared to testify against a West German accused of bombing his residence in June 1982.

description: For the last seven years, the Chinese Communist Party has been mother and father to a 14-year-old boy whose parents were killed in the earthquake that devastated the northern city of Tangshan.

title: Minister Indicted In Wife's Stabbing
description: A 32-year-old Baptist minister was held in $50,000 bail today after being indicted on charges of breaking into his estranged wife's apartment here and stabbing her, authorities said.

title: NICARAGUA REGIME PLANNING AMNESTY
description: Nicaragua is about to offer amnesty to prisoners jailed for crimes against state security, according to diplomats, opposition figures and a senior Sandinista official.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
description: Gains Posted For Eurobonds LONDON, Nov. 30 (Reuters)

title: U.N. URGES A STUDY OF ANTARCTICA
description: A resolution calling for a study of ''all aspects of Antarctica'' was adopted in the United Nations today.

title: Appointment to F.C.C.
description: Dennis R. Patrick, until recently a White House aide, today was appointed to the Federal Communications Commission by President Reagan. Mr. Patrick, who is 31 years old, was nominated in October. The appointment brings the F.C.C. up to its full complement of five.

title: CALIFORNIA BATTLING MEXICAN FRUIT FLY
description: Miles from the nearest commercial fruit orchard, in a section of central Los Angeles where children grow up against a backdrop of skyscrapers, county agriculture inspectors are examining backyard fruit trees to find the Mexican fruit fly, the latest pest to endanger California's $14 billion agriculture industry.

title: WHAT'S IN A NAME? IN THE NAVY, IT'S POLITICS

title: U.S. DROPS EFFORTS FOR NOTICE OF CHILD'S BIRTH CONTROL USE
description: The Reagan Administration has given up its attempts to force federally aided birth control clinics to notify the parents before prescribing contraception for unmarried teen-agers.

title: NEWSPAPERS SEE RISE OF 14% IN AD REVENUES
description: Newspapers expect advertising revenues to increase more than 14 percent in 1983, which would be the largest annual growth since 1976. Their total ad revenues are projected at more than $20 billion for this year.

title: Noah to Big Apple
description: Yannick Noah , the French Open champion, said yesterday that he was leaving France to escape the harassment of journalists, and would move to New York. Noah told a radio interviewer his position as one of France's leading sporting stars since winning a Grand Slam event last June had made life impossible.

title: WALL FALLS AT EAST SIDE HOUSE NEXT TO EXCAVATION FOR TOWER
description: Excavation at the construction site for a 40-story residential tower on Manhattan's East Side has apparently caused part of a wall of a next-door home to collapse, forcing some residents to flee.

title: CONCERT: KALICHSTEIN PLAYS SCHUBERT WORKS
description: SIXTEEN years ago, when Joseph Kalichstein gave his debut recital here, he was already a powerhouse of a pianist whose musical gifts were evident in spite of his tendency to thump the instrument rather too lustily and to play as fast as he could. His all-Schubert recital last night at Carnegie Hall showed that he has tamed his wilder instincts without losing the fine edge of excitement that marked his youthful style. Mr. Kalichstein, setting himself no low hurdles, chose to devote the second half of his program to the posthumously published Sonata in A (D. 959), a profound but also profoundly taxing work that few pianists play at all in public, let alone play well.

title: FRENCH WARY ON CLOSER TIE TO NATO
description: The creation of a French Rapid Action Force for use in Europe has led to discussion of practical steps to reintegrate military activities into NATO planning. It has also led to heightened French sensitivity about the broadened military relationship with the Atlantic alliance.

title: LION COUNTRY SAFARI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: UNLIKELY ROUTES PROFIT AIRLINE
description: Northeastern International Airways, a two-year-old airline that was started with a $200,000 investment and a single flight linking Long Island and Fort Lauderdale, has turned profitable this year by exploiting other routes that were all but ignored by its bigger competitors.

title: Canadian Steel Decline
description: Canadian steel ingot production in the week ended Nov. 25 declined 2.5 percent from a week earlier, to 308,281 tons, Statistics Canada said today.

title: CHARGES DISPUTED ON 3 MILE ISLAND
description: A seven-month investigation financed by the owners of the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant found little evidence to support charges of mismanagement and safety violations in cleanup efforts there, the head of the inquiry said today.

title: Navy Officer Convicted In Homosexuality Trial
description: Comdr. Gerald M. Vanderwier was convicted today in a court-martial of three counts of sodomy, charges that could mean dismissal from the Navy, loss of pay and benefits, and a 15-year prison sentence.

description: Jari Kurri assisted on all three of his team's goals to equal the National Hockey League record for assists in consecutive games and helped Edmonton to a 3-3 tie with Philadelphia.

title: State Will Get Acid Rain Data
description: A statewide network of seven monitoring stations is back in operation finding out how much acid rain is falling on New York State, officials said today.

title: RUTGERS' FOOTBALL WILL BE UPGRADED
description: Rutgers University, which has had little success in ''big-time'' football during the past decade, announced today it plans to raise from $5.5 million to $6 million to improve its football facilities as soon as possible. This includes increasing the capacity of Rutgers Stadium from 24,000 seats to 30,000, construction of a field house for all-weather practice and other sports and putting an artificial turf surface in the stadium.

title: Robbins Will Dance in 'Nutcracker'
description: Jerome Robbins, the choreographer and co-balletmaster in chief of the New York City Ballet with Peter Martins, will make a rare stage appearance next Tuesday in ''The Nutcracker'' at the New York State Theater. It will be the 1,000th performance of the production, which was choreographed by George Balanchine in 1954.

title: Lockheed Contract
description: The Air Force gave the Lockheed- Georgia Company, a unit of the Lockheed Corporation, a $1.3 billion contract for production of four C-5B transport planes and purchase of materials for additional planes in the new fleet.

title: Czech Leader Visits Warsaw
description: Gustav Husak, the Czechoslovak leader, arrived here today for a two-day visit. Mr. Husak, who was met at the airport by Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, is the third East European leader to visit Poland since martial law was lifted in July.

title: Strikers Moving To Minnesota
description: The Fort Lauderdale Strikers of the North American Soccer League are relocating immediately from Florida to Minnesota, the team's president, Elizabeth Robbie, said today.

title: COLECO SAYS ITS 'ADAM' IS IN VERY SHORT SUPPLY
description: Coleco Industries admitted today that its long-delayed Adam home computer system would be ''in very short'' supply this Christmas, but denied continuing Wall Street rumors that an unusually large number of the computers were defective and that the company was in dire need of cash.

description: A former city real-estate official recently found slain in gangland style was a target of a Federal investigation into the awarding and operation of private concessions on city property, according to law enforcement officials.

description: A French soldier was killed today when his patrol was fired on by an unidentified gunman, a spokesman for the French force here said.

title: Providence Blast Injures 8
description: An explosion at a downtown metal processing company today blew out two walls of the building, injured eight people and sent ammonia spewing into the air, authorities said. Twelve people were inside the Schubert Heat Treating Company at the time of the blast at 9:45 A.M., according to company officials.

description: LAS VEGAS, NEV. SOFTWARE companies seem to have entered a new phase. Rather than trying to come up with new applications for computers, most of the major companies are concentrating on making programs easier to use and on integrating different applications, such as word processing and financial management, into all-in-one packages.

description: Just like political candidates stumping for delegates, the manufacturers of voting machines are crisscrossing the country, making promises they hope their equipment will keep next November.

HELPFUL HARDWARE;
SAFER BATHS FOR BABY

Sinkadink is a plastic sink that hooks to the side of a bathtub (with a rim five inches wide or less) so that toddlers can brush their teeth and wash their hands on their own without being lifted to a standard sink.

title: AIR ACADEMY COUPLE WROTE OF THEIR LIFE'S END IN SNOW
description: As a blizzard howled around their snowbound pickup truck, an Air Force Academy football player and the academy cadet he was dating chronicled their final hours on scraps of paper before succumbing to carbon monoxide fumes.

Friday, according to the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. In both cases, the shuttle should be seen first in a northerly direction and traveling eastward, resembling a moving star.

description: An oil painting by Hans Hoffmann, a 16th- century German artist, retrieved from trash in an attic, was sold today for $610,500, Sotheby Parke Bernet, the auction house, said.

title: CENTRAL PARK BICYCLIST KILLED BY A RUNAWAY RIDING HORSE
description: A runaway horse in Central Park struck a 71-year-old woman riding a bicycle, and she died three days later. Officials pieced the story together yesterday when the woman's family announced burial arrangements.

title: COMMERCE DEPT. OFFICIAL AT ODDS WITH CONGRESS
description: Carlos C. Campbell, the departing head of the Economic Development Administration, has become the focus of a growing dispute between the White House and Congress.

title: Certificate Rates Slip;  Certificate Rates Slide
description: Interest rates on certificates of deposit slipped in New York and fell sharply elsewhere around the country last week, the Bank Rate Monitor said yesterday.

MOSCOW, KEPT IN DARK, IS ABUZZ WITH SPECULATION OVER ANDROPOV
description: Once again, rumors about the Soviet leader's health have become the mainstay of Moscow gossip.

title: ATHLETE, 19 DIES
description: -A 19-year-old freshman at the University of Illinois at Chicago died after collapsing today during a hockey practice, school officials said. The athlete, Mark Nordling, was having difficulty breathing before he collapsed at Wilmette Ice Arena. He was rushed to Skokie Valley Memorial Hospital in full cardiac arrest.

title: Two Top F.B.I. Officials Cleared
description: A judge has wiped out the criminal records of two top officials of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who were convicted of authorizing illegal break-ins of the Weather Underground and were later pardoned by President Reagan.

description: ''I hold no malice to none. May God bless us all.''

title: BRIEFING
description: Table Salt Talks

title: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 1, 1983 International
description: The police freed Alfred H. Heineken and his chauffeur in Amsterdam. Ten police officers raided an unguarded warehouse and released the two men from unheated concrete cells in which they had been chained for 21 days. The police later arrested 24 suspects, all Dutch citizens who are related, and said they were hunting for 4 others. The rescue of the two men, who were said to be cold but in good health, came two days after a ransom payment rumored to exceed $10 milion was made. (Page A1, Column 1.) A Salvador bill was killed as President Reagan pocket vetoed it. The measure would have made continued aid to El Salvador contingent on his assuring Congress every six months that the country was improving its human rights record. (A1:5.)

title: Strong Denial By Dynamics
description: The General Dynamics Corporation today categorically denied reports of fraudulent activities and charges of overcharging in connection with the sale of support equipment or spare parts for the F-16 fighter plane.

title: PAY LESS DRUG STORES NORTHEST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: -consuming part of any wiring job is snaking the wires through wall and ceiling spaces when going from one area to another. The problem arises not only with regular electrical installations but also with home intercom systems, burglar-alarm systems, doorbells, audio systems and telephones. In each case concealing the wires is neater and safer.

title: RUSS TOGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
Money Fund Assets Sag
description: Assets of money market mutual funds fell sharply in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: POLITICAL POLLUTION IN CHINA
description: The campaign in China against ''spiritual pollution'' strikes fear into every Chinese who loves independent thinking and simply does not wish to mouth an official line. It heralds a period of tighter social control and of even greater discrepancies between public actions and private thoughts. It may also ring a death knell for the confidence that intellectuals have been cautiously regaining in the Communist Party since Deng Xiaoping's return to power in 1977.

title: Michael Whitney, 52, Is Dead; Actor Married Twiggy in '77
description: Michael Whitney, the estranged husband of the actress Twiggy, the co-star of the Broadway musical ''My One and Only,'' died after a heart attack in a New York restaurant Wednesday night. He was 52 years old.

title: Unemployment Claims Found to Be Up Sharply
description: New claims for state unemployment benefits rose to 434,000 in the week ended Nov. 19, the highest level in five months, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Musical Alternatives
description: Ned Rothenberg will present new music for woodwinds, using unconventional techniques on saxophones and bass clarinet, tonight at 8 at the Alternative Museum (966-4444), 17 White Street in TriBeCa.

title: New Ahmanson Chief
description: H. F. Ahmanson & Company said today that William H. Ahmanson had asked to be relieved of his post as chief executive officer but agreed to remain chairman. Ahmanson said its board had elected Richard H. Deihl president and chief executive. Mr. Deihl is now president and chief executive of Home Savings of America, the main unit of Ahmanson, a financial holding company.

title: CANADIAN IMPERIAL BANK OF COMMERCE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Canadian Imperial Bank is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: U.S. BIDS GEMAYEL BROADEN HIS BASE TO UNIFY LEBANON
description: The United States today urged President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon to widen his political base and to extend his army's control in the south. He was told that those steps could help persuade Syria to join Israel in withdrawing troops from Lebanon.

title: Ex-Coach Sues Over Reprimand
description: One of seven school employees reprimanded in connection with a football player's death has served notice of a $10 million defamation of character action against the district, his lawyer said today.

description: Apple Computer Inc. and the Bank of America said they had reached an agreement to market jointly a home banking service.

description: Change in Officials Causes a Delay

title: The Reagan-Feldstein Telegraph
description: Just 10 months ago, in his State of the Union address, President Reagan called the Federal deficit ''a clear and present danger to the basic health of our Republic.'' But now the White House visits its wrath and ridicule on the President's chief economic adviser for delivering the same message. What's going on? Has Ronald Reagan, once a Democrat, swung back to believing that big deficits aren't so bad after all?

title: McDonnell Award
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation won a $274.4 million contract from the Air Force for the F-15 improvement program, the Defense Department said. In addition, the Eaton Corporation received a $95 million contract from the Air Force for defensive avionics purchases.

title: VAN DYK RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-earlier figures were formerly reported as those of the third quarter. The company has changed its fiscal year to end June 30.

description: Hefty Heist

title: Navy Chief in Honduras
description: Secretary of the Navy John Lehman met with Honduran and American officials today during a visit to the capital and three military bases in Honduras. Mr. Lehman, who arrived from El Salvador Wednesday, said at a news conference that several proposals and discussions were under way for the improvement of Honduran military installations. He said future exercises involving American Navy and Marine forces were ''a real and attractive possibility.''

title: INDICTMENT CHARGES NEW YORK LEGISLATOR EMBEZZLED $83,000
description: State Senator Joseph R. Pisani of New Rochelle, N.Y., was indicted yesterday on Federal fraud and tax- evasion charges involving the embezzlement of $83,000.

title: SHUTTLE MISSION MAY BE EXTENDED FOR A DAY
description: With the space shuttle Columbia operating smoothly, but its crew clearly overworked, mission officials today weighed the possibility of extending the flight an extra day to provide more time to conduct experiments aboard the Spacelab riding in the vehicle's cargo bay.

title: SOVIET HELP IN SHAPING AMERICA'S IMAGE
description: To the Editor:

title: Hotel Operator Given Jail Term
description: The operator of a single-roomoccupancy hotel in Manhattan was sentenced yesterday to 30 days in jail for contempt of court after a Housing Court judge visited the property and found that repairs to the walls, plumbing, windows and heating system that he had ordered in September had not been made.

title: A BULGARIAN IN ITALY UNJUSTLY IMPRISONED
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA LEARN A LESSON
description: Didanyone care that the press was prevented from witnessing the invasion of Grenada? Certainly the press did. When they were kept from landing with the troops, the news media, from the most pipsqueak to the most prestigious, cried, ''Foul!'' They confidently asserted their historic rights, and reminded all of Thomas Jefferson's famous epigram: ''were it left to me to decide whether we should have a government without newspapers, or newspapers without a government, I should not hesitate a moment to prefer the latter.'' Even President Reagan was moved enough by the uproar to appoint a special commission.

title: OLD PROJECT UNDER CITY COMING UP
description: Back in the early 1970's, when this city's downtown was the envy and example of urban planners everywhere, the prime attraction was an area beneath the central shopping district called Underground Atlanta. Here, amid a six-block area beneath the viaducts that carry traffic through the downtown area, an astonishing array of shops, restaurants and boutiques grew up. In 1972, more than 3.5 million tourists, conventioneers and local residents visited the Underground, where they spent more than $17 million.

title: Building Outlay Off
description: Spending for new construction fell 2.5 percent in October after several months of gradually slowing gains, the Government reported today.

title: Dutch Police Question 21 In Heineken Kidnapping
description: The Dutch police today questioned 21 people held in connection with the kidnapping of Alfred H. Heineken, the brewery chairman. The search continued for three other suspects and about $8 million in unrecovered ransom money.

title: Travenol Venture With Genentech
description: Travenol Laboratories Inc. and Genentech Inc. said they plan to form a joint venture to develop, manufacture and market clinical diagnostic products.

title: SOVIET CUTS PRICES OF SELECTED LUXURY GOODS
description: The Soviet Union lowered prices today on selected luxury goods, ranging from rugs to mink pelts, in a move held up as evidence of the country's economic potential at a time of a tense world situation.

title: TYSON FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
BRIEFS
description: Angelica Corp. said it had agreed to buy the property, equipment and business of X-Clusive Linen, a Stockton, Calif., health care company.

title: AMBULATORY MEDICAL CARE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Comparable year-ago results are not available because the company only went public on Aug. 31.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: From a Ham in Space To Others in Queens

title: Soviet Affirms Stand
description: Marat Gramov, the president of the Soviet Sports Committee and the Soviet Olympic Committee, said today that the Soviet Union would compete fully in the 1984 Olympic Games in Los Angeles. Gramov arrived in Mexico City Wednesday as the head of a Soviet delegation on its way to Los Angeles to tour the Olympic facilities and examine the organization of the Games.

title: BUSY COAST PIANIST JOINS IN SALUTE TO RUBINSTEIN
description: Call it a shared Carnegie Hall debut. Jeffrey Kahane, the West Coast pianist, will be playing there tomorrow night, along with Leonard Bernstein, Jerome Lowenthal and the 11-year-old Israeli prodigy, Elisha Abas. The occasion is the concert of the America-Israel Cultural Foundation honoring the memory of Arthur Rubinstein, who died last Dec. 20.

title: DOMESTIC VIOLENCE IS TERMED 'INSIDIOUS CRIMINAL PROBLEM'
description: A Federal task force on family violence began taking testimony in New York yesterday on what Attorney General William French Smith called an ''insidious criminal problem'' that has ''never received the kind of national attention it deserves.''

title: WASHINGTON IS TAKING GAINS BY EUROPEAN SOCIALISTS IN STRIDE
description: A State Department official said today that the Government decided a few months ago to analyze the phenomenon of the rise to power of Socialist or Socialist-led governments in southern Europe.

title: ST. PETER'S TOPS MICHIGAN ST.
description: St. Peter's, utilizing its quickness and applying unrelenting defensive pressure, upset Michigan State, 73-66, in front of 6,400 fans at Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;  Richardson Testifies
description: Michael Ray Richardson , the former Knick and Net guard, tesitfied yesterday in his own behalf during an eight-hour arbitration hearing at the St. Regis Hotel in Manhattan.

title: ; CRIMINAL JUSTICE: ' CONSIDER A NEW MARK OF CAIN'
description: To the Editor:

title: FLAMES DEFEAT ISLANDERS
description: The Islanders, playing in their second game of a six-city road trip, failed to win for the second straight game, falling to the Calgary Flames, 6-2, tonight at the Saddledome.

title: Garden Antiques Show
description: he second New York World's Fair of Antiques and Collectibles Show is at Madison Square Garden through Sunday.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: RAVEN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CHARMING SHOPPES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: Year-ago results have been restated for a 4-for-3 stock split paid in January.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 2, 1983

title: JACKSON GETS SUPPORT, APPARENTLY WITHOUT POLL OF THE GROUP
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, who has been criticizing A.F.L.-C.I.O. leaders for endorsing Walter F. Mondale's candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination without polling the unions' members, today received an endorsement apparently decided in a similar way.

title: RAN AIRLINE
description: James H. Carmichael, an early pilot and later an airline executive, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 76 years old.

title: THE FLAWS IN A PROPOSAL FOR A U.S. ENVOY TO NORTHERN IRELAND
description: To the Editor:

title: MONORAIL FOR 42D STREET
description: To the Editor:

title: FLICKINGER, S M, CO. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
PULASKI FURNITURE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: The share earnings for 1982 have been adjusted for the 2-for-1 stock split on June 15, 1983.

title: SWIFT INDEPENDENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Includes credits of $700,000, or 14 cents a share, from adjustment of charges recorded in 1982 and $600,000, or 12 cents a share, for a reduction in vacation pay liability from renegotiation of a labor contract. c-Includes reduction of $1.2 million, or 23 cents a share, by a one-time labor agreement incentive payment. The net for the 1982 year also includes gain of $1.4 million from sale of broiler operation and charge of $1.9 million from planned changes in the company's method of product distribution.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: A GOOD DEATH. By Philip Ross. 298 pages. Dodd, Mead. $14.95. APPLEBY AND HONEYBATH. By Michael Innes. 198 pages. Dodd, Mead. $13.95. THE imminence of death, according to some of those who have studied it, puts us in a mood for truth and evaluation. There's no time left for lying, for the denial of the real, which has suddenly become precious. We look at the world with what Walter Benjamin called ''love at last sight.''

title: Dow Declines 0.92 In Lighter Trading
description: The stock market ended its roller- coaster ride yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average showing little movement for the first time since Monday.

title: Opera Shop in Rarities By Mozart, Donizetti
description: An unfinished Mozart comic opera, ''Lo Sposo Deluso,'' and the American premiere of Donizetti's ''Giovedi Grasso'' will be performed in repertory by the Opera Shop of the Vineyard Theater (693-0696), 309 East 26th Street.

title: PROXY FIGHT BEGINS AGAINST SUPERIOR
description: Howard B. Keck, the former chairman of the Superior Oil Company who is seeking a buyer for part or all of the company's shares, began a proxy fight yesterday that he said was intended to overturn an aggressive anti-takeover stance adopted by Superior's board.

title: SHULTZ-GROMYKO MEETING POSSIBLE AT ARMS CONFERENCE IN JANUARY
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz indicated today that he might meet with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, at an East-West conference on disarmament in Stockholm Jan. 17.

title: GREYHOUND STRIKERS SEND A COUNTEROFFER IN BID FOR NEW TALKS
description: The union at Greyhound Bus Lines sent a new contract proposal to the company today in an effort to reopen negotiations in the month-long strike, according to sources close to the talks.

title: JUDGE SETS PAY AWARD IN WOMEN'S SUIT AGAINST WASHINGTON STATE
description: In a landmark wage discrimination case, a Federal district judge said today he would order the State of Washington to pay an amount estimated at $838 million in immediate raises and back pay to women.

title: FASTEST IS BEST AS MESSENGERS PEDAL IN PURSUIT OF A $100 DAY
description: It was Ray. ''Ray!'' shouted a dozen young men, eager to call him by name. ''Ray,'' yelled Mike Nelson, popping the question of the day at the Early Bird messenger service, ''how many'd you do today?'' Without looking up, Ray Williamson answered quietly, ''41.''

title: People
description: * Michael H. Popernick appointed senior vice president, chief financial officer of Marsteller Inc.

title: SOVIET HELP IN SHAPING AMERICA'S IMAGE
description: To the Editor:

title: SOVIET SETS THE DATE FOR PARLIAMENT IN A POSSIBLE CLUE ON ANDROPOV
description: A possible clue in the uncertainty surrounding Yuri V. Andropov became available today with the announcement that the Supreme Soviet, the nominal Parliament, will convene Dec. 28. Mr. Andropov would normally be expected to attend.

title: ALL WORK, NO PLAY FOR SHAMIR
description: ''When my husband is in New York, he works the whole time, and his wife enjoys herself a little,'' Shulamit Shamir, the wife of the Prime Minister of Israel said yesterday.

title: Staub's Coming Back
description: He is old enough to retire, and he has played long enough to retire, but Rusty Staub, the 39-year-old pinch- hitter who completed his 21st major league season this year by batting .296 for the Mets, played a bit too well not to try again in 1984. Staub, who led the major leagues last season with 24 pinch-hits and tied a major league record with 25 runs batted in from pinch-hits, has signed a one-year contract renewal. With an attendance bonus, Staub could earn close to $500,000.

title: NATIONAL BANK OF CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After tax credit of $36.7 million.

title: THE BALDWIN ERA ENDS AT MORGAN
description: Robert H. B. Baldwin, who is widely credited with ushering Morgan Stanley & Company, the whitest of the white-shoe investment banking firms, into a new and more competitive financial era, will retire as chairman at the end of the year, the firm announced yesterday.

title: ART: CHINESE BLOSSOMS BRIGHTEN SEASON AT MET
description: IT'S the perfect time for a show called ''Peach Blossom Spring,'' a profusion of rich gardens, blossoming flowers, verdant trees - and the beautiful birds that frequent them. This lovely switch of seasons occurs at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 81st Street, which has set out in its Douglas Dillon Galleries for Chinese Painting no fewer than 45 works - largely from its own collection and ranging in time from the 12th through the 18th centuries - that deal with the theme of gardens and flowers.

title: PEKING MAYOR DISCOVERS LURE OF DREIDELS AND DELI
description: The Mayor of Peking went to Brooklyn yesterday. He ate latkes and learned what a dreidel was. He marveled at the size of butternut squash, scrutinized a three-bedroom apartment and questioned the manager of a deli counter.

title: CAMBRIDGE BIOSCIENCE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Gulf's Holders To Vote Today
description: T. Boone Pickens Jr., the colorful chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Company of Texas, will be the central figure in a corporate drama unfolding today at a special meeting in Pittsburgh of Gulf Oil Corporation stockholders.

title: ANDREW FREEMAN
description: Andrew Freeman, a partner in the New York firm of Wachtell, Manheim & Grouf and a specialist in international law, died of a heart attack Wednesday at his home in Manhattan.

title: LINCOLN CENTER CHIEF IS RESIGNING
description: Glenn W. Ferguson, after only nine months as president of Lincoln Center, announced yesterday that he was resigning, effective June 30, 1984.

title: NUI to Seek Proxies
description: The NUI Corporation said today that it planned to solicit proxies to elect a majority slate of directors to the board of the New Jersey Resources Corporation and merge the two companies.

title: U.N. Assembly Urges South Africa Sanctions
description: The United Nations General Assembly, strongly condemning South Africa for blocking independence for South-West Africa, today called for comprehensive mandatory sanctions against the republic.

title: Texas 7-Elevens To Get Teller Units
description: The Southland Corporation and First Texas Savings Association said they have signed an agreement to install automatic teller machines in the 1,000 7-Eleven convenience stores in Texas.

title: KING HUSSEIN SAYS HE'D TALK TO P.L.O.
description: King Hussein of Jordan said today that he was prepared to resume talks with Yasir Arafat on a joint Palestinian-Jordanian approach to negotiations with Israel on the future of the West Bank and Gaza.

title: CRIMINAL JUSTICE: 'CONSIDER A NEW MARK OF CAIN'
description: To the Editor: Release of prisoners because of jail overcrowding is wrong.

title: $250 Million Sale By Wells Fargo
description: Wells Fargo & Company sold two issues of debt securities yesterday totaling $250 million. Both issues were part of Wells Fargo's shelf registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission and were awarded after securities firms submitted bids to the company.

title: BROADWAY
description: WHERE are the new American plays? The next time that question comes up, try answering ''Chicago.'' Two prominent American playwrights, David Rabe and David Mamet, are having their new works done at the Goodman Theater before bringing them to Broadway. Mr. Rabe's play, as yet untitled, will be directed by Mike Nichols, reuniting the playwright-director team that was responsible for one of Mr. Rabe's biggest successes, ''Streamers.'' Five of the seven actors have been chosen: William Hurt, Sigourney Weaver, Judith Ivey, Jerry Stiller and Ron Silver. One leading role is still to be cast, that of a former prison inmate turned actor.

title: WOMEN'S ENDORSEMENT SEEMS A 2-WAY RACE
description: Like eager suitors, the Democratic Presidential candidates have been courting the National Organization for Women in the hope of gaining the endorsement next week of the country's largest feminist group. The late entry of the Rev. Jesse Jackson into the Presidential race has stirred not only uneasiness among his rivals but also turmoil within the women's organization.

title: COMPUTER DESIGNED SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: PRESS GROUPS ASK TALKS ON COMBAT COVERAGE
description: After several weeks of intensive legal research and debate about the Reagan Administration's curbs on news coverage of the invasion of Grenada, a group of major national press organizations has decided to try to negotiate with the Pentagon and the White House over procedures for access to combat zones.

title: WILSON FOODS CORP reports earnings for 13wks to Oct 29
description: The latest first quarter results include a charge of $2.2 million in settlement payments to employees of the Marshall, Mo., and Louisville, Ky., plants to be made under the terms of labor contracts.

title: Brown Gains Fame
description: Jim Brown , who starred in lacrosse as well as football at Syracuse, has been elected to the Lacrosse Hall of Fame. Brown, previously elected to the Pro Football Hall of Fame, was named along with two other former lacrosse stars, Norm Webb , an all- American West Point goalie in 1964, and Richie Moran , a Maryland graduate who has coached Cornell to three national championships.

title: SCOUTING
description: No Contest

title: COMPUTER AS LETTERBOX, SINGLES BAR AND SEMINAR
description: Several times a week, Karyn Zoldan, a 35-year- old clerical worker, sits down at a computer in her home here and spends several hours exchanging thoughts on life, love and other matters with people she has never met. She now counts them among her best friends.

title: HANUKKAH, ITS LIGHTS AND ITS LATKES
description: What makes for a great latke?

title: Oklahoma Legislature Refuses to Raise Taxes
description: Oklahoma's special legislative session ended abruptly Wednesday amid predictions that its failure to approve the state's first tax increase in 12 years would force $500 million in budget cuts over the next 19 months.

title: CORRECTION
description: A review yesterday of the Opera Ebony production of Gounod's ''Faust'' misidentified the singer in the title role. He was Thomas Young.

title: Texas Thrift Unit Sets 4-Year C.D.'s
description: The First Texas Savings and Loan Association is offering $50 million of 11.55 percent certificates of deposit due Dec. 15, 1987, at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: NAVY OFFICER IS DISMISSED FOR HOMOSEXUAL AFFAIR
description: The former commanding officer of a Navy frigate was ordered dismissed from the Navy today and fined $100 a month for 12 months for having a homosexual affair with a crew member.

title: KING'S HARASSERS FREED IN SPAIN
description: At a time of rising tensions in the northern Basque region, the Supreme Court handed down milder sentences than expected today in a case of 19 Basque nationalists charged with insulting King Juan Carlos during a royal visit to Guernica two years ago.

title: KNICKS ROMP TO 3D IN A ROW
description: SAM GOLDAPER

title: HARLEM CO-OP CONVERSION PLAN FALTERS
description: When a plan to convert the 536-unit Dunbar Apartments in Harlem to a cooperative was announced last year, it seemed assured of success.

title: ELSINORE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Larry Flynt Arrested After Flying to Alaska
description: United States marshals today arrested Larry Flynt, the publisher of Hustler magazine, after Mr. Flynt violated a condition of a court bond by leaving California. He flew from Los Angeles to Anchorage, and a Federal prosecutor said Mr. Flynt had stated intentions of going to the Soviet Union.

title: JAZZ: HAMIERRT BLUIETT UNIT
description: THE Hamiet Bluiett Quintet is playing at Sweet Basil this week through Sunday, but the group became a quartet in its opening set on Tuesday evening when Mr. Bluiett's drummer, Marvin Smith, did not arrive on time.

title: Ford Recall
description: The Ford Motor Company said it would recall 1,200 employees to its assembly plant in Hapeville next year, starting up the plant's second shift, which was discontinued in August 1979. A Ford official, Henry Nida, said the company will ask the 930 employees laid off in 1979 to return. The remainder will be recruited from other Ford plants.

title: POWER STRUGGLE GRIPS RENEWAL AREA IN ST. LOUIS
description: R. SHIPP

title: ART: SEGUI PAINTS PARIS
description: EVERY so often there comes along a painter who is clearly very good indeed but cannot be placed. No school, no trend, no established mode of expression can claim him. He is himself.

title: Twins Sign Davis
description: Ron Davis, the Twins' prominent relief pitcher, reached agreement yesterday on a contract with Minnesota that is unprecedented for two reasons: It is the richest one ever for a Twins player, and it includes provisions that would prevent Davis from being traded to the teams that sign Rich Gossage and Kent Tekulve, two other prominent relief pitchers, who are free agents.

title: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 2, 1983 International
description: Washington pressed Lebanon to act with more determination. In talks at the White House, American officials pressed President Amin Gemayel to widen his political base and to extend his army's control. The Lebanese leader was advised that such steps could help persuade Syria to join Israel in agreeing to withdraw troops from Lebanon. (Page A1, Column 6.) Security at the Marine compound in Beirut has been radically improved with protective devices ranging from dirt barricades to 100,000 new sandbags since the Oct. 23 suicide truck- bombing of the United States headquarters. The marines came to Beirut as a symbolic ''presence,'' but they are now almost totally isolated from the Lebanese people - hunkered down and concerned primarily with self-protection. (A1:5-6.)

title: HOFMANN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
WASHINGTON
description: THE United States and Israel, as part of an effort to strengthen the links between them,

title: HEALTHGROUP INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
PLAYOFF PICTURE IS SCRAMBLED WITH THREE WEEKS TO PLAY
description: If the National Football League's regular season ended today, the six division winners would be the Miami Dolphins, the Pittsburgh Steelers and the Los Angeles Raiders from the American Conference and the Dallas Cowboys, the Minnesota Vikings and the Los Angeles Rams from the National Conference.

title: FINDING OF FOSSILS IN KENYA ADDS CLUE ON APE-HUMAN BACKGROUND
description: Scientists exploring a desolate region of Africa in northern Kenya have found the 17-million-year-old remains of an apelike creature formerly thought to have existed only in Asia. The researchers theorize that the fossil primate may be one of the common ancestors of humans and the great apes.

title: What's a Salvadoran to Think?
description: Depending on what hour you read the news, here is what the White House has been communicating about El Salvador: It wants right-wing forces to cease their murderous assaults on innocents . . . It wants Congress to stop demanding that American aid be conditioned on human rights progress . . . It wants a free election next spring to legitimize government in Salvador . . . It wants all to know that Roberto D'Aubuisson, the idol of the death squads and nominal winner last year, should not win again.

title: F.T.C. INVESTIGATING PRO FOOTBALL RULE BARRING COLLEGIANS
description: Federal antitrust officials have begun an investigation into professional football's four-year rule denying college players the chance of a professional career until their collegiate eligibility has been exhausted.

title: Gas Forces Evacuation
description: Construction workers sliced through a four-inch natural gas line Wednesday, forcing the evacuation of about 1,000 guests and workers from the Golden Nugget Hotel-Casino in downtown Las Vegas. The 600-room hotel was booked to capacity because of a computer show that has drawn about 80,000 delegates to the city. Firemen cordoned off a block-square area for nearly two hours before allowing guests and employees to return to the hotel.

title: Simms
