description: Coach Bill Parcells said today he had no plans for Phil Simms to practice with the Giants for the rest of the season. He said Simms, once the starting quarterback, was not ready physically.

title: TEXSCAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Erika Hess Wins Slalom
description: Erika Hess of Switzerland, the world slalom champion, scored the first victory of the World Cup ski season today, narrowly outracing Tamara McKinney of the United States on an artificial slalom course.

title: Relative Still Missing
description: Hans Strebel and his son Werner, of Switzerland, searching the wreckage of the Avianca jumbo jet that crashed Sunday near Madrid. The body of Kurt Strebel has not yet been identified, and his family received permission to search for his belongings. One hundred eighty three people died.

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: Faculty Votes Against Hoover Institution Role

title: HELPING WOMEN WHO WORK
description: All but hidden within the $800 billion, 2.9-million-employee Federal Government is a single tiny agency entrusted with the task of monitoring and attempting to improve the status of America's 48 million employed women. The Women's Bureau of the Department of Labor, with a staff of 79 thinly spread among 11 offices around the country and a budget of only $3.6 million, is the single Federal agency specifically devoted to the job-related concerns of women.

title: 'DOOMED TO CO-EXIST'
description: President Reagan need be in no doubt that his ''ash heap of history'' speech, with its colorful phrases pouring scorn on the Soviet system, struck home in Moscow. Eighteen months later, it still rankles. Whether it did any good is another question.

title: RICHARD LLEWELYN DIES AT 76; A WRITER OF NOVELS AND PLAYS
description: Richard Llewellyn, the playwright and author whose 1939 first novel, ''How Green Was My Valley,'' became an international best seller and movie, died after a heart attack in Dublin on Wednesday. He would have been 77 years old this Thursday.

title: LAPOINTE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE FLAWS IN A PROPOSAL FOR A U.S. ENVOY TO NORTHERN IRELAND
description: To the Editor: John C. Dearie argues that appoint

title: ELECTRONIC MODULES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: b-Net income. Results are for 13 weeks and 52 weeks for the latest periods and 14 and 53 weeks for the year-ago periods.

title: RocklandtoWeigh Rejoining A-Panel
description: The chairman of the Rockland County Legislature said today that he would recommend that the county rejoin the task force devising emergency plans for the Indian Point nuclear power plants.

title: Warriors 106, Kings 95
description: Purvis Short scored a season-high 35 points and Darren Tillis, playing for injured center J. B. Carroll, grabbed 16 rebounds and blocked four shots to lead Golden State.

title: STORY OF THE EONS IN NEW YORK'S ROCKS AND FOLDS
description: THE most obviously dramatic features of the New York landscape are monumental skyscrapers and bridges. But rocks throughout the metropolitan area bear witness to past events grander and more awesome than anything to be seen on Earth today.

title: THE STAGE: 'SUCCESSION,' ON CITY LIFE
description: IN ''Success and Succession,''

title: ADVERTISING
description: Account

title: CLONING OF A BLOOD SUBSTANCE MAY AID HEMOPHILIA PATIENTS
description: A biotechnology company asserted yesterday that it had made a significant advance toward artificially producing a blood substance needed by thousands of hemophiliacs to curb excessive bleeding.

title: McCann Wins Account For Cable Information
description: It looks as if McCann-Erickson has emerged triumphant from a creative shootout for the $5 million-plus advertising account of the Council for Cable Information. It has been picked by the agency selection committee but the final decision will be made next week by the board at a Denver meeting.

title: McDougall Associates Named by Velcro USA
description: Having interviewed 25 agencies in New York City, the Boston area and New Hampshire, Velcro USA in Manchester, N.H., makers of tape-fastening systems, has decided to pick a New England shop - McDougall Associates in Salem, Mass.

title: Parents' Debts to Children
description: All too often, a private decision to break up a family causes a public burden in the form of women and children on welfare. In 1981, fewer than half the four million women in the United States awarded child-support payments collected the full amount.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: DEBRA WINGER is on her way to a doctor. She has bronchitis. Or maybe it's nerves that's making her chest feel tight. Because she's in New York doing publicity for ''Terms of Endearment,'' and she hates doing publicity. But she loves ''Terms of Endearment.''

title: COLORFUL COUSIN OF THE JEEP KEEPS MANILA MOVING
description: When a major union of jeepney drivers voiced support recently for President Ferdinand E. Marcos and his wife, Imelda, the action was viewed as a political development of considerable importance.

title: THEATER: 'GLASS MENAGERIE'
description: THE new Broadway revival of ''The Glass Menagerie'' leaves much to be desired, but that fact doesn't diminish the largest aspect of the event. The spirits of Tennessee Williams and Jessica Tandy have been reunited for the first time in a generation, and their partnership, now as in legend, is one of the most fundamental in the history of the American theater. Perhaps some theatergoers will want to hold out for a better ''Glass Menagerie'' than the one at the O'Neill Theater, and no doubt it will eventually arrive. But you pass up Miss Tandy's Amanda Wingfield only at your own peril: You may turn around one day to discover that, in Mr. Williams's phrase, the past has turned into everlasting regret.

title: Jury Fines Opponent of Cults $50,000 in Civil Rights Case
description: Ted Patrick, who has been retained by parents to help get their children away from religious societies, was convicted by a Federal jury Wednesday of violating a man's civil rights. Mr. Patrick was ordered to pay $50,000 in punitive and compensatory damages.

title: Kero-Sun Put In Bankruptcy
description: A Federal judge today declared Kero-Sun Inc. bankrupt. The company is the nation's largest distributor of portable kerosene heaters. Judge Robert Krechevsky issued the order after a hearing in which Kero-Sun tried to get a seven-week-old bankruptcy petition against it dismissed.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: THIS week's theme song could

title: FLOCK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $239,212 for the quarter and $515,063 for the 9 months. c-Including tax credits of $135,000 for the quarter and $233,000 for the 9 months.

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 2, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: U.S. and Soviet Union Meet on Strategic Arms
description: The United States and the Soviet Union held another session here today in the talks on limiting strategic, or long-range, nuclear weapons. They agreed to meet again on Tuesday.

title: GARTNER AND I.B.M. IN ACCORD
description: The International Business Machines Corporation and a small Connecticut-based research company, The Gartner Group Inc., have reached an agreement under which the latter has agreed not to disclose any of I.B.M.'s trade secrets.

title: CLABIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including a gain of $15,000 for the quarter and a loss of $586,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations. Revenues for the latest periods include gains of $13,604,000 for the quarter and $15,696,000 for the 9 months from the partial sales of an associated company and subsidiary. Year-ago share earnings have been restated for a 5 percent stock dividend distributed Jan. 5 and a 10 percent stock dividend distributed April 14.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL;
description: THE excesses of nouvelle cuisine have sent diners in search of old-fashioned, lovingly prepared regional cooking, from both this country and abroad. When it comes to French cuisine, one of the recipes most closely associated with home and hearth is the pot au feu, which is essentially boiled beef with veal and winter vegetables (although every region in France has its own variation, some with chicken or sausage or other main ingredients). It's not easy to find a well-prepared pot au feu in New York because many chefs consider it a peasant dish, too lowly to put on their menus.

title: AUCTIONS
description: THOMAS COLE'S last known painting, ''The Good Shepherd,'' a serene landscape that was inspired by the 23d Psalm, is the most historically important work in two major auctions of American art next week. The Cole, completed shortly before the artist's death in 1848, and never before publicly exhibited, will be up for bidding in the first session of an auction next Thursday at 10:15 A.M. and 2 P.M. at Sotheby Parke Bernet, York Avenue and 72d Street. It depicts a lone shepherd followed by a sheep, under a light-washed sky, amid rolling hills, trees and a winding stream. Louis L. Noble, Cole's biographer, describes the painting as the ''most exquisite and most perfect of his simple landscapes.''

title: FROM GREEK TO KLEZMER, HAVING AN ETHNIC BALL
description: FROM 8 o'clock tomorrow night into early Sunday morning, Hunter College will ring with rare sounds. The kinetic fiddling of the Pontic Greek kementze and the Cretan lyra, the interwoven vocal lines of ancient Albanian and Greek songs, the sighing, sliding tones of the Albanian pizga (a double- reed instrument), Jewish klezmer music and Epirote Greek clarinets will be heard - along with the stamping feet of dancers and the buzz of happy partygoers.

title: Ice Skating Starts at Many City Rinks
description: The ice-skating season has begun at Wollman Memorial Rink in Brooklyn's Prospect Park (information: 965-6561), Parkside Avenue and Lincoln Road, and at the Lasker Memorial Rink in Central Park (information: 397-3142), Adam Clayton Powell Jr.

title: Another Round
description: Larry Holmes , who on Tuesday said that he would announce his retirement next week, and on Wednesday was said to be considering another fight, yesterday rescheduled a news conference for next Wednesday ''to clear up a lot of things,'' his spokesman, Dick Lovell , said.

title: MEN ARRESTED IN THEFT OF GEMS WORHT MILLIONS
description: Three men have been arrested and charged with the theft of $1 million worth of gold and jewels on Oct. 22 from Tira Inc., a jewelry company at 35 West 36th Street, the police said yesterday.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD SHOWS ANGER AGAINST RED LIGHT VIOLATORS
description: In the working-class Queens neighborhood where he lives, William Gregg Jr. was being greeted as a hero yesterday by people who say they are tired of drivers running red lights.

title: Mediator Enters Dispute
description: The Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service yesterday entered the three-month old labor dispute between the National Basketball Association and the union representing its locked-out 29 referees. Ed McMahon, a commissioner in the mediation service's national office in Washington, has been assigned to the case and yesterday he held talks with Russ Granik, the N.B.A.'s general counsel and chief negotiator, and Richie Phillips, the general counsel for the National Association of Basketball Referees, in an effort to determine the availability of both sides for future meetings.

title: MARINES' VIEW OF BEIRUT MISSION: TO 'HUNKER DOWN AND BUNKER IN'
description: Since the Oct. 23 bombing of the Marine headquarters here, security around the American compound has been radically improved. New fortifications have been installed, everything from dirt barricades to 100,000 new sandbags.

title: Manning Out
description: Archie Manning , obtained in September by the Minnesota Vikings as a backup quarterback, will be out for the rest of the season because of a thyroid condition for which he will receive test over the next three weeks. Manning, 34, joined the Vikings after the first-string quarterback Tommy Kramer was injured Sept. 18. Steve Dils has been the No. 1 quarterback since then, and Manning's absence will leave the Vikings with Wade Wilson as Dils's only replacement.

title: POP/JAZZ ; SWEET HONEY IN THE ROCK, A CELEBRATION AT TOWN HALL
description: THE choice seemed to be, in the words of Ralph Ellison, ''to live with music or die with noise.'' Sweet Honey in the Rock chose song. And tonight, at Town Hall, the group of five black women singers will celebrate its 10th anniversary with a program of new and traditional music.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Mayor Joins 2 Celebrations

title: Colombian Abductors Withdraw Death Threat
description: Leftist guerrillas holding the kidnapped brother of the Colombian President today withdrew their threat to kill him if the Government did not meet their demands and said they would free him next week.

title: SOCIALIST GOVERNMENTS IN EUROPE FIND INTELLECTUALS' ARDOR FOR LEFT COOLING
description: In 1936, when France of the Popular Front and Republican Spain exemplified the ideals of democracy and Socialism, the names of their men of culture were Malraux, Picasso, Garcia Lorca, and Gide - artists, combatants, supporters of their struggling Governments.

title: 12% OF THOSE FREED ON LOW BAIL FAIL TO APPEAR
description: Twelve percent of the people released on low or no bail to relieve jail overcrowding failed to appear for court dates and have not been found, the city said yesterday.

title: DEMOCRATS TRY OUT CAMPAIGN IDEAS ON ST. LOUIS
description: House Democratic leaders brought their road show to St. Louis today to try out some of their new ideas for next year's campaign, but their main message was a familiar one. They blamed President Reagan for the soaring budget deficits and warned that they were threatening the economic recovery.

title: SERVICES HELD FOR CADETS WHO DIED IN STORM
description: On the eve of his death in a snow-covered pickup truck, Brian Bullard called the Air Force Academy and spoke with his squadron leader about the heavy blizzard engulfing Interstate 70, which he and Cadet Diane Williams were traveling on their way back to the Colorado Springs school after Thanksgiving weekend.

title: AMERICAN PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss. The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
description: Puerto Rico Bank Issue Is Offered to Yield 10%

title: GULF & WESTERN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including net income from discontinued operations of $4,202,000 for the latest first quarter and $7,152,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: JUDGE RESIGNS AFTER PLEA ON DRIVING CHARGE
description: Judge John Morrissey of Superior Court, who pleaded no contest this week to a charge of drunken driving, resigned today after 15 years on the bench. It was the third time he had faced such a charge.

title: Vote of Confidence
description: Doug Moe , the Denver Nugget coach who was fined $5,000 and given a two-game suspension after ordering his team to stop playing defense toward the end of a game against the Portland Trail Blazers, has received a vote of confidence from the Denver organization. ''I hope people don't judge Doug Moe on this one unfortunate incident,'' said the general manager, Carl Scheer , who reported that Moe still had the total support of the club's owner, Red McCombs .

title: PUBLISHING: VIETNAM REMEMBERED
description: FRANCES FITZGERALD'S ''Fire in the Lake,'' a book critical of United States involvement in Vietnam, was a best seller, won a National Book Award in 1973 and a Pulitzer Prize for general nonfiction. Philip Caputo's memoir, ''A Rumor of War,'' published in 1977, won the praise of reviewers and was also a commercial success. And Tim O'Brien's ''Going After Cacciato,'' which was not a commercial success, won the National Book Award for fiction in 1978.

title: SCOA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: The share earnings for both periods in 1982 were adjusted for a 5-for-4 stock split in May 1983

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Bucks, at Milwaukee, 9 P.M. In their only other game this season, the Nets won, 107-103, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, with six players scoring in double figures. (Television - SportsChannel, 9 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 9 P.M.) Atlanta Hawks vs. Detroit Pistons, at the Silverdome, Pontiac, Mich. (Television - WTBS 7:35 P.M.)

title: WESTERN STEER-MOM 'N' POP'S reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 4
CAPITAL CHRISTMAS SEASON BEGINS
description: Snowflakes have not yet fallen in the nation's capital, but Christmas preparations at the White House are under way.

title: ART: 15 LATER WORKS IN TORRES-GARCIA SHOW
description: Garcia (1874-1949) recurs like a predictable, if not very fiery, comet. This time, it may be viewed in an unusually well- composed show at the elegant new Herstand Gallery, 24 West 57th Street. The display, smaller than one held at Salander O'Reilly in 1981, numbers about 15 canvases dated 1938-48 and a few wood constructions of 1929-30.

title: A Bronx Woman Wins Welfare Suit
description: A Bronx mother of three, who was removed from welfare because she earned too much money, yesterday won a class-action suit that officials said redefines who is eligible for public assistance.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: -pipe-rack look of Cent'Anni - an expression that means good health, good eating and 100 years - along with the restaurant's casual service, seem especially suited to the simple Florentine cooking the kitchen sends forth each evening. Such typical dishes as bistecca Fiorentina (steak), pollo alla diavola (chicken), veal chops with sage and pork loin, all unadorned by fancy sauces, were minimally seasoned with an herb or two and grilled. Sometimes the results were juicy, tender and flavorful; sometimes they were banal. Only fish dishes, for which Florence is not necessarily famous, were consistently good on four visits.

title: 12 Chilean Protesters Held After Clash
description: The police clashed with protesters after more than 1,500 people marched in a legal demonstration against military rule, police said today.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday WBAI FAIR AT COLUMBIA

title: Connecticut Plans Suits on Dumping
description: The Connecticut Attorney General said today that the state would go to court to try to reverse a Federal Environmental Protection Agency decision allowing the city of Springfield, Mass., to dump raw sewage into the Connecticut River.

title: NICARAGUAN REBELS ASK PEACE TALKS
description: Leaders of four guerrilla groups fighting to overthrow Nicaragua's Government today asked Richard B. Stone, President Reagan's special envoy to Central America, to arrange peace talks with the Sandinistas.

title: RAIDERS CLINCH TITLE
description: The Los Angeles Raiders clinched their ninth American Conference West title tonight by routing the the San Diego Chargers, 42-10.

title: VATICAN DOCUMENT ON SEX
description: Following are excerpts from the Vatican document ''Educational Guidance in Human Love,'' which was made public today:

title: KORCHNOI AND KASPAROV DRAW FIFTH CHESS GAME
description: Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland and Gary Kasparov of the Soviet Union drew the fifth game of their semifinal world championship chess match in 21 moves tonight.

title: COACH'S JOB IS ON THE LINE
description: Jerry Stovall's longtime wish was to be the head football coach at Louisiana State University, where he was an all- America running back two decades ago.

title: No Hard Feelings
description: Glenn Carano works out every week against the Dallas Cowboy defense, and his play is considered sharp, but as the third-string quarterback, he doesn't get to play much. He hasn't thrown a pass in a game since 1981, and with both Danny White and Gary Hogeboom ahead of him, it was beginning to seem that his time might never come.

title: KOHL AGAINST HALT IN MISSILE PLANS
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl said today that he favored adhering to the deployment schedule for American medium-range missiles in Western Europe in order to persuade the Soviet Union to return to the suspended Geneva talks on those missiles.

title: FROST & SULLIVAN reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: DANCE: THE SIN CHA HONG TROUPE
description: SIN CHA HONG is a choreographer with a sculptor's feel for shape. She is also a perceptive prober of the human heart. On Wednesday at La Mama E.T.C., where they will perform through Dec. 11, Miss Hong and her Laughing Stone company presented new and recent dances that combined those gifts with a simplicity and lack of pretention that made for a powerful evening of theater.

title: WHEN MUSICAL VARIETY WAS KING
description: ON the surface, ''Here's Television Entertainment'' is another of those compilations of clips introduced by celebrities and giving the network an easy opportunity to brag about an all- star cast. This one, though, on Channel 4 Sunday evening at 9, is a bit more sophisticated. The primary reason undoubtedly is that it was produced by Gary Smith and Dwight Hemion, skilled veterans of television specials involving Barbra Streisand and Shirley MacLaine, among others.

title: CAPITALS DEFEAT DEVILS, 4-1
description: The Washington Capitals responded to Coach Bryan Murray's verbal lashing after a 3-3 first period by rolling to an 8-4 triumph over the New Jersey Devils tonight.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Part of Eiffel Tower Is Coming to Chelsea

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A article Nov. 19 on Congressional misconduct quoted an erroneous statement by the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct, about the status of James M. Beattie, a former House employee. He pleaded guilty to misdemeanor charges under Federal drug laws, was placed on probation for a year and was required to perform 100 hours of community service. At the end of that period, charges against him are to be dismissed.

title: FELDSTEIN VOWS TO STAY IN POST TO HELP REAGAN
description: Martin S. Feldstein, the head of the Council of Economic Advisers, who is under heavy pressure from the White House to end his public campaign for higher taxes, said yesterday that he would not resign unless asked by the President.

title: NATIONAL SHOES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-After tax credits of $575,000 for the quarter and $1,358,000 for the 9 months. c-After tax credits of $532,000 for the quarter and $830,000 for the 9 months.

title: DEMOCRATS ASSAIL REAGAN ON SALVADOR
description: Representative Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House, and other Democrats today condemned President Reagan's decision to veto a bill that would have required continued monitoring of the human rights record of the El Salvador Government as a condition for continued United States military aid.

title: ONE SHOOTER ACCOUNTS FOR TOTAL OFFENSE
description: Allison-Bristow High School is a

title: ADVERTISING
description: Walsh Names Dallas Chief Diane Whitehead, who came

title: Camper Calls the Plays
description: Rick Pitino first met Hubie Brown as

title: No Testimony
description: Neither Martin S. Feldstein nor the Administration's other top economic policy makers will testify at Senate hearings on a $150 billion program to reduce the budget deficit, the White House said today.

title: Bethlehem Plans To Build 2 Casters
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said it has signed a $540 million financing agreement to build two continuous casters for its mills in Sparrows Point, Md., and Burns Harbor, Ind.

title: DANCE: SERIES AT THE JOYCE
description: THE series of concerts called ''New Dances by Bill Carter and Ruth Mayer'' continued on Wednesday night at the Joyce Theater with a program that included a new dance by Mr. Carter and a new dance by Miss Mayer. Both failed to be substantial additions to what appears to be a dismayingly flimsy repertory.

title: GRANT RAISES CITY OPERA PLEDGES TO $12 MILLION
description: The New York City Opera yesterday announced that it had raised $9 million in pledges to match a three-to- one, $3 million challenge grant from the Fan Fox and Leslie R. Samuels Foundation.

title: Trading Quiet In Eurobonds
description: Eurobond trading was quiet today with operators waiting for developments.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If at any time the President wants me to leave, I would of course do so.'' - Martin S. Feldstein. (A1:2.)

title: Ticket Violations Make 3 Ineligible
description: Oregon State University announced today that three of its basketball players, including two starters, would be ineligible to play in the first six games this season because they sold complimentary game tickets in violation of rules of the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: SECURITY MOVES VEXING LOBBYISTS AT THE CAPITAL
description: The John M. Clayton Society may never meet again.

title: F.C.C. COMPLETES STEPS FOR TELEPHONE BREAKUP
description: The Federal Communications Commission today formally approved the steps necessary to complete the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, and the commission agreed to stick by its earlier decision to impose telephone ''access'' charges on consumers, starting April 3.

title: Ashkenazy-Perlman
description: The pianist Vladimir Ashkenazy and the violinist Itzhak Perlman will perform the three Brahms sonatas for piano and violin tonight at 8:30 at the C. W. Post Theater in Greenvale, L.I., on the C. W. Post University campus, Northern Boulevard. Remaining tickets are $20 and $22.50, and more information is available from Friends of the Arts, (516) 922- 0061.

title: BRIEFING
description: Democrats Eager for Fray

title: Key Rates
description: * Nuveen index, John Nuveen & CompanySalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: LITERARY MAGAZINE IS BARRED FROM USING 'YALE' IN NAME
description: The Yale Literary Magazine must stop using the name ''Yale'' in its title, a state judge ruled yesterday.

title: Bridge; Ex-World Champions Lead In Blue Ribbon Pair Finals
description: The ''barometer'' was in use in the Blue Ribbon Pair finals of the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here this afternoon, and the forecast was fine for two former world champions.

title: G.& W.'s Net Jumps 33.6%
description: Gulf and Western Industries, citing improved performances by its three operating groups and a sharp decline in interest expense, reported yesterday that earnings in the fiscal first quarter climbed 33.6 percent on a rise in sales of 7.9 percent. Gulf and Western, which has interests in consumer and industrial products and leisure time and financial services, said net income in the three months ended Oct. 31 increased to $81.2 million, or $1.04 a share, from $60.8 million, or 80 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose to $1 billion, from $927.2 million.

title: MICHIGAN OUSTER VOTES THREATEN DEMOCRATIC CONTROL IN LEGISLATURE
description: A grass- roots tax revolt claimed its second legislative victim in eight days this week, threatening Democratic control of the State Senate and and putting a chill on Gov. James J. Blanchard's efforts to form a bipartisan coalition to spur Michigan's economic recovery.

title: Dome Petroleum To Sell New Equity
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd. said today that it intended to raise $700 million (Canadian) in an underwritten equity-related securities issue next year as part of a new restructuring plan. The plan would replace a $1 billion rescue package put together by Dome's four main Canadian lenders and the Canadian Government in September 1982.

title: AGENCY RENT-A-CAR reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CREDIT MARKETS ; RATES MIXED IN QUIET TRADING
description: Interest rates were mixed and little changed yesterday as activity in the credit markets remained subdued.

title: Rampac Merger
description: Rampac said it had agreed in principle to be merged into a new, privately held corporation to be formed by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, in a transaction valued at about $121 million.

title: BOMARKO INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss. The company is listed on the Midwest Stock Exchange.

title: New Option Expirations
description: Beginning today, the three exchanges that trade stock index options will expand the series of expiration months.

title: Hotel Man Told to Pay $33 Million to Fund
description: A Federal jury has ordered Morris Shenker, the owner of the Dunes Hotel, to pay $33.8 million to a union pension fund because his companies defaulted on loans in the mid-1970's.

title: DRUSE RELIGIOUS LEADER IS SLAIN AT HOME IN BEIRUT
description: The second-highest religious leader of Lebanon's Moslem Druse was slain in his home today by an unidentified gunman. The army, trying to cope with increasing violence, immediately lengthened the nightly curfew here and warned that violators would be shot.

title: VENTURE BY TOYOTA AND G.M. GAINS
description: Staff officials at the Federal Trade Commission have effectively recommended to the full commission that a proposed $300 million auto making venture between the General Motors Corporation and the Toyota Motor Corporation be allowed to proceed.

title: FLEETWOOD ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
Balalaika Night at Tully
description: Balalaika Symphonic Orchestra will present a concert of Russian music and dance at Alice Tully Hall tomorrow night at 7:30.

title: ABC and NBC to Allow Combined Commercials
description: Alberto-Culver announced yesterday that following negotiations, both the ABC-TV and NBC-TV networks have agreed to allow two unrelated product commercials in a single 30- second commercial unit. It is a move decried by many advertisers and agencies who fear that increased commercial clutter on television is diminishing its effectiveness as an advertising medium at the same time the advertising rates are soaring.

title: DANCE: FOR ALVIN AILEY, 25TH ANNIVERSARY GALA
description: SINCE Alvin Ailey's galas are unlike any others, it was a foregone conclusion that his dance company's 25th anniversary benefit Wednesday night at the City Center, as the biggest celebration of all, was going to have a special place in this tradition.

title: VATICAN PUBLISHES SET OF GUIDELINES ON SEX EDUCATION
description: Excerpts from document, page A6.

title: AIDES DOUBT REAGAN IS PLANNING TO RENAME RIGHTS PANEL MEMBER
description: An informal agreement on the future of the United States Commission on Civil Rights began to unravel today, less than 24 hours after President Reagan signed a bill reconstituting the agency.

title: PRESIDENT OF G.T.E. RESIGNS
description: In an unexpected move, Thomas A. Vanderslice announced his resignation yesterday as president and chief operating officer of the GTE Corporation.

title: Bidermann Pact
description: Bidermann Industries USA, the American arm of the French apparel manufacturer, said its parent company had signed an agreement with the designer Karl Lagerfeld.

title: NO GIANT, BUT STEADY NERVES
description: West Germany has made it through phase one of the long- advertised ordeal of installing Euromissiles. But there are five years to go before the planned NATO deployment is complete, in the absence of a Soviet- American agreement.

title: NO FURTHER APPEAL
description: When a black-hooded executioner fired a two-minute surge of 2,000 volts through the body of Robert A. Sullivan, 36, a Roman Catholic from New England, the state of Florida may well have killed an innocent man. That will surely happen again, perhaps numerous times, as various states proceed to execute the 1,268 others now on death row.

title: Teachers on Strike in Duluth; 14,000 Students Get Day Off
description: Public school teachers here went on strike today in a dispute over pay, and classes were canceled for more than 14,000 students.

title: Synthetic Fuel Gets Backing
description: The Synthetic Fuels Corporation, bowing to pressure from Congress and the Reagan Administration, agreed today to consider price supports for the nation's first large-scale synthetic fuels plant, a step that could translate to millions of dollars of additional Federal aid.

title: CHI-CHI'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
IMMUNO NUCLEAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
SCOUTING
description: Proud Father

title: 'Differences' Force Borg Chief to Quit
description: James F. Bere, chairman of the Borg-Warner Corporation, announced yesterday that Jerry E. Dempsey has resigned as president and chief operating officer, effective immediately. Mr. Bere said the resignation was the result of ''some fundamental differences in management philosophy.''

title: Advertising; Ogilvy Gets All Of Gallo
description: THE E.& J. Gallo Winery in Modesto, Calif., announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement with Needham, Harper & Steers to sever their relationship, and that it would consolidate all of its advertising with its other agency, Ogilvy & Mather's San Francisco office.

title: LEROY J. BIERINGER
description: Leroy J. Bieringer, executive vice president of Fleishman-Hillard Inc., a public relations consulting concern, died of cancer on Monday at Memorial Hospital.

title: CONSERVATIONIST LED HUDSON RIVER GROUP
description: Roderick M. Vandivert, an environmentalist and former executive director of the Scenic Hudson Preservation Conference, died of respiratory failure yesterday at his home in Oak Beach, L.I. He was 60 years old.

title: Street Reopened
description: Traffic was allowed back on 61st Street between First and Second Avenues yesterday.

title: Dutch and French Deny Role in Suriname Plot
description: The Dutch and French Governments today denied Surinamese charges that they backed a coup plot against the South American country.

title: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan Split View On Coleco Continues
description: COLECO INDUSTRIES, one of the market's most volatile stocks in the past two years, received mixed reviews yesterday from securities analysts who toured its plants in Amsterdam, N.Y., on Wednesday.

title: REAGAN SAID TO AIM FOR JANUARY DATE
description: President Reagan and his political strategists have decided that Mr. Reagan will declare his candidacy for re-election in the last week of January, White House and campaign officials said today.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Associates Corp. of North America's $100 million issue of 11.85 percent senior notes due in 1989 was priced at par, through Salomon Brothers Inc. The issue is rated A1 by Moody's Investors Service and Ax by Standard & Poor's.

title: ONE DAY OF MEETINGS: A MIXED CHORUS OF VOICES
description: Declaring that the ecological damage caused by acid rain represented a ''failure of intelligence and will'' by Americans, Governor Cuomo gave vigorous support yesterday to a plan to reduce industrial emissions by 50 percent nationally over the coming decade.

title: 10 Drivers Seized In Alcohol Checks
description: Ten motorists were arrested on alcohol-related charges at three Hudson River crossings Wednesday night, the first night of a program designed to catch drunken drivers traveling between New Jersey and New York, officials said today.

title: JURY IN E.P.A. CASE FINDS LAVELLE GUILTY OF PERJURY
description: A Federal jury today found Rita M. Lavelle guilty of perjury and of impeding Congressional investigations of hazardous waste programs.

title: PARTY TROUPERS' NIGHT OUT
description: Jean Guerrand-Herm es arrived at Berthe David- Weill's Fifth Avenue apartment at precisely the right moment. A glass of predinner pink Champagne was slipped into his hand, and as he sipped, weaving his way through a collection of Louis XVI chairs - greeting, bowing, kissing, laughing, embracing - it was suggested that as one of many representatives of Herm es circulating about the city Wednesday evening, his appearance had the air of a state visit.

title: IT'S BEGINNING TO LOOK A LOT LIKE CHRISTMAS
description: THERE are two Christmases: the first one a commercial blitz of jingles and catalogue mailings that starts even before Thanksgiving and the second a private moment that begins when one encounters something - a bar of music, a fold of paper, a turn of phrase - that creates a sense of wonder about Christmas Day. For those in search of the second Christmas, there are many places to find it this weekend, as the season's celebrations start in the metropolitan area.

title: BATTERED WOMAN TELLS OF TORTURE THAT LED TO KILLING
description: The morning of Feb. 25, 1983, began like most days in the trailer that Leslie Ann Emick shared with her common- law husband, Marshall Allison, on County Road 7 near Cuba Lake. As usual, when the alarm went off at 20 minutes past 4, Miss Emick woke up immediately, while Mr. Allison barely budged.

title: CUOMO FOR USE OF M.A.C. AID AT NEW CENTER
description: Governor Cuomo favors using surplus funds from the Municipal Assistance Corporation to make up millions of dollars in cost overruns at New York City's Convention Center, one of his chief aides said yesterday.

title: EMBATTLED ECONOMIC ADVISER: MARTIN S. FELDSTEIN
description: Few American economists of his age - 44 last week - could have brought as rich a reputation to the chairmanship of the Council of Economic Advisers as Martin S. Feldstein did last year, and few of his predecessors have brought more criticism from his employers in the White House. The sniping took on an unusually nasty edge Wednesday, generating widespread speculation that Mr. Feldstein would have to resign. The President's spokesman, Larry Speakes, joked about Mr. Feldstein's limited role in policy making and even mocked the pronunciation of the man's name, alternating between ''Feld-STINE,'' which the economist prefers, and ''Feld- STEEN,'' which many members of the White House staff tend to use.

title: Picassos in Brooklyn
description: More than 250 Picasso prints, never on public display, can be seen through Jan. 8 at the Brooklyn Museum, Eastern Parkway and Washington Avenue.

title: 2 Die in West Bengal Clashes
description: At least 2 people were killed and 54 were wounded in clashes between rival political parties in the state of West Bengal, the Press Trust of India said today. It quoted a police official as saying there had been violence between supporters of the Communist Party of India and Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Congress Party for the past three days.

title: SCOUTING
description: 1-12 Oilers Covet Last-Place Award

title: Wenzel Winner; Stenmark Falls
description: Andreas Wenzel of Liechtenstein won the first slalom race of the World Cup ski season today after Ingemar Stenmark, his closest rival, fell on the second of two runs and was eliminated.

title: Moe to Appeal Fine
description: The coach of the Denver Nuggets, Doug Moe , apparently thinks the National Basketball Association was unduly harsh in fining him $5,000 for letting the defense rest, so to speak, by telling his players not to guard Portland near the end of a game Nov. 22 in which the Trail Blazers scored a club- record 156 points.

title: 3FaceAdults'Trial Over Derailment
description: The Appellate Division of Superior Court has ruled that three teen-agers charged with causing a fatal train derailment in Fair Lawn last summer must stand trial as adults.

title: A HARVEST OF BENEFITS FROM NEW YORK WINE
description: Fifty years ago this Monday, Prohibition was repealed. In New York, its legacy lingers on, to the detriment of the state's wine industry, consumers and the state itself.

title: SALE OF EIFFEL'S SPIRAL
description: On March 31, 1899, the elevators in the newly built Eiffel Tower were not yet working. But Gustave Eiffel, the brilliant French engineer who designed it, wanted to hoist the French Tricolor a thousand feet over Paris at the top of the tower he had always dreamed of building, which was then the tallest structure in the world.

title: Your MoneyLeonard Sloane Pros and Cons Of Bank Cards
description: BANK cards, under the names Visa and Mastercard, have in the past 15 years become ubiquitous. Some 110 million of these cards have been issued, and there were used in 1.5 billion transactions and purchases of $65 billion last year.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Outside Recommendations

title: Mediator Seeking Bus Talks ; Bus Line's Negotiators Sent to Wait for Talks
description: Greyhound announced today that its negotiators were in the nation's capital at the urging of the chief Federal mediator, Kay McMurray, to resume bargaining with representatives of 12,700 striking workers.

title: LINCOLN BOARD TO BEGIN ITS SEARCH FOR PRESIDENT
description: The Lincoln Center board yesterday announced that a search committee would be appointed soon to find a successor for Glenn W. Ferguson, who said Thursday that he was resigning as president of Lincoln Center.

title: BRONX SHOULD TOP M.A.C. FUND LIST
description: To the Editor:

title: Postal Worker Charged In Death of Postmaster
description: A postal employee involved in a job dispute shot the Anniston postmaster to death today and wounded a supervisor, the police said.

title: LAVELLE VERDICT: E.P.A. TRIAL OVER, BUT NOT INQUIRIES
description: After Rita M. Lavelle's conviction on perjury charges, a number of questions remain about the Environmental Protection Agency's management of toxic waste programs in the first two years of the Reagan Administration. Miss Lavelle, who had been the agency's assistant administrator in charge of the waste programs, was found guilty Thursday by a Federal jury of lying under oath to Congressional committees about her continued participation in matters affecting her former employer, the Aerojet-General Corporation.

title: A SOWETO MILLIONAIRE SETS HIS SIGHTS ON CITY HALL
description: Ephraim Tshabalala is, by his own account, a man of ''background.'' And that, he said, is important in politics.

title: Vice Chairman Retires at May
description: Raymond L. Klauer will retire as a vice chairman of the May Department Stores Company, effective Feb. 1. Mr. Klauer, who is 52 years old and has been with the company for 34 years, will remain a consultant with May, concentrating on acquisitions and new business.

title: PRETORIA DEFENDS BLACKS'REMOVAL
description: Louis Nel, South Africa's newly appointed information chief, set out today to convince foreign reporters that there was another side to the well-publicized removal of villagers from a place where they have lived for 70 years to this fledgling settlement of tin huts and frail hopes.

title: DOING THE TIME
description: News item from the Collapse of Civilization Desk: Because of overcrowded jails, the court recently ordered New York City to evict several hundred prisoners awaiting trial, many of whom are ''dangerous, hard- core criminals,'' according to the District Attorney. Now another problem looms. Large numbers of citizens are failing to report for jury duty. City officials warn they face prosecution for criminal contempt, which can result in a 30-day jail sentence.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 17.

title: Lynn Louis Heinzerling Dies; Prize-Winning A.P. Reporter
description: Lynn Louis Heinzerling, a former foreign correspondent for The Associated Press who won a Pulitzer Prize in 1961 for foreign reporting for his coverage of the fighting in the Congo, died of cancer Nov. 21 in Elyria Memorial Hospital in Elyria, Ohio. He was 77 years old and a resident of Elyria.

title: Filipino Foreign Minister Quits for Health Reasons
description: Foreign Minister Carlos Romulo resigned today because of poor health and made a plea for national understanding so the Philippines can overcome its political and economic crises.

title: Japan Profits Outlook
description: Current profits of major Japanese companies are expected to rise 40.4 percent in the six months ending March 31, the Wako Economic Research Institute said in a survey report today. It said sales would rise 6.8 percent.

title: 600 OFFICERS READY, ROCK STAR DRAWS 100 FANS
description: Intent on avoiding a repetition of a rampage by youths after a rock concert in Central Park in July, the Police Department last Wednesday deployed 600 officers for an indoor news conference in the park by the rock star Michael Jackson.

title: Arthur M. Gillick, Top Official Of Channel 21 on Long Island
description: Arthur M. Gillick, president and general manager of WLIW-TV (Channel 21), died of cancer on Thursday at Community Hospital in Glen Cove, L.I. He was 35 years old and lived in Manhasset.

title: COMPUTER PROGRAMMING IS RIGHT FOR CHILDREN
description: To the Editor:

title: THE JOBS ILLEGAL ALIENS TAKE FROM AMERICANS
description: To the Editor:

title: Rockets 125, Sonics 102
description: Rodney McCray and Elvin Hayes led Houston to a victory over Seattle.

title: EAST GERMANY SEEKING $371 MILLION BONN LOAN
description: The East German Government, faced with a severe shortage of cash for its year-end debt payments to Western countries, is seeking hard-currency loans totaling the equivalent of $371.7 million from West Germany, banking sources said Thursday.

title: Taylor Questionable
description: Lawrence Taylor , the Giants' all- pro outside linebacker, was listed as questionable for tomorrow's home game against the St. Louis Cardinals, meaning that Coach Bill Parcells gives him a 50-50 chance of playing. Taylor turned his right ankle in practice Thursday and did not practice Friday. Meanwhile, the Giants, and the rest of the National Football League teams, were given permission by the league to begin negotiating with Warren Moon , the all-star quarterback for the Edmonton Eskimos of the Canadian Football League.

title: PERCHANCE TO DREAM: CATALOGUES
description: IT is probably safe to assume that

title: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 3, 1983 International
description: The successes of Marxism in the Caribbean region are largely a result of right-wing terrorists in El Salvador and Guatemala, Deputy Secretary of State Kenneth W. Dam said. In a speech in Miami at a conference on trade, investment and development in the Caribbean basin, Mr. Dam said ''Somoza's dictatorship in Nicaragua and the pre-1979 'Mongoose Gang' in Grenada helped pave the way for the Marxist-Leninists and their violence.'' (Page 1, Column 1.) The U.S. and Lebanon have agreed to establish joint economic and military committees to provide ''more structure and coherence'' to their efforts to unify Lebanon, and bring about the withdrawal of all foreign forces, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said. Mr. Shultz made the remarks after completing talks with President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon. (4:4.)

title: Michaels, Generals Talk
description: Walt Michaels said yesterday that he was ''still on vacation,'' but the former Jets coach acknowledged he has spoken to Donald Trump, the owner of the Generals, about the possibility of coaching the United States Football League team.

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP $1.6 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve reported yesterday that the basic measure of the nation's money supply rose $1.6 billion in the financial week ended Nov. 23, a gain that left the financial markets still deeply divided over the outlook for monetary policy.

title: CITY BALLET: 'NUTCRACKER'
description: Visions of fairy-tale enchantment returned to the New York State Theater on Thursday night when the New York City Ballet presented what was this season's first performance of ''The Nutcracker'' and the company's 994th performance of the Tchaikovsky classic since 1954.

title: TO QUASH LUPPER, START WITH BRUNCH
description: While Lewis Carroll did not coin the word brunch, Humpty Dumpty coined the phrase ''portmanteau word'' to describe such a word -one that is made up of two others and suggests part of the meaning of each. Humpty Dumpty made up slithy from slimy and lithe, but as it is the most noteworthy egg in the world it would have been fitting for him to have created brunch, a word for a meal at which, unfortunately, it is almost impossible not to eat eggs.

title: Marathon Best Stands
description: Joan Benoit's world-best time in the 1983 Boston Marathon was approved for acceptance by the Records Committee of The Athletics Congress. There had been much discussion since the marathon last April 18 surrounding her time of 2 hours 22 minutes 43 seconds.

title: Bradshaw Is Available
description: The Pittsburgh Steelers plan to reactivate today their longtime quarterback, Terry Bradshaw , who has not played for a long time.

title: ASTRONAUTS' 5TH DAY BLENDS DISCOVERY AND TROUBLE SHOOTING
description: Spacelab scientists grappled with a rash of equipment malfunctions today but continued their orbital research, producing exotic metal alloys and crystals, taking mapping pictures of Europe and observing mysterious stellar objects.

title: KAUFMAN DECLINES TO SIGN SECRECY PACT AS CRIME UNIT HEAD
description: Judge Irving R. Kaufman, chairman of the President's Commission on Organized Crime, has refused to sign a pledge prepared by the White House for all panel members to abide by Justice Department ethical standards and not to disclose information without authorization.

title: SOVIET TALKS OF AIR TRAFFIC PLAN
description: Soviet leaders announced steps today to create a unified air-traffic-control system for the Soviet Union, a step Western diplomats said might be related to efforts to prevent further military attacks on civilian airliners.

title: SCOUTING
description: Drawing Cards

title: FederalJudgesWeigh B
description: A three-judge Federal appeals panel, hearing arguments in the Baby Jane Doe case yesterday, sharply questioned both sides and reserved judgment on whether the Federal Government should be granted access to the infant's medical records.

title: American Medical Outlines Charges
description: American Medical Buildings Inc. said it will have a 1983 fourth quarter charge of $3 million from the sale of certain assets and from the termination of transponder satellite rights.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: 'Applevision'

title: Dorchester Gas Buyout Cleared
description: The Dorchester Gas Corporation, a diversified oil and gas production company that has been the subject of repeated takeover rumors, said its board had approved a leveraged buyout of the company for $22.50 a share, or $396 million. The company said the buyout, which would transform it into a privately held concern, was proposed by a group of investors including George S. Rooker, its 64-year-old chairman, and other members of its senior management.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Award to Arms Opponent

title: Toshio Kimura Dies; Former Tokyo Official
description: Toshio Kimura, a former Foreign Minister and chairman of the Parliamentarians' League for Japan-Palestine Friendship, died of a heart attack at a Tokyo hospital Thursday night, his family said. He was 74 years old.

title: Woman Convicted In Upstate Killing
description: Leslie Ann Emick, who said she shot her common-law husband to death after he repeatedly abused and tortured her, was found guilty of first- degree manslaughter by an Allegany County Court jury late last night in Belmont, N.Y.

title: 2A OVERCHARGE LEADS TO A BILL FOR $115,440
description: Because a customer felt he paid 2 cents too much for a meal, 21 Burger King food outlets in New York City and some suburban areas will be handing out $115,000 worth of food coupons early next year.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, DECEMBER 3, 1983
description: The Economy The jobless rate fell again in November, dropping half a point to 8.2 percent, its lowest level since January 1982, the Labor Department reported. The decline was steeper than the Administration and many private economists had expected. It was seen as further evidence that the year-long economic expansion has continued into the autumn at a brisk pace and is likely to roll on into 1984. (Page A1.) In New York City, the jobless rate fell to 8 percent, the lowest in 35 months. (12.) President Reagan was described as angry at the tone of a rebuke delivered by his spokesman on Wednesday to Martin S. Feldstein, the President's chief economic adviser. Mr. Reagan objected to the manner, a senior aide said, not the substance. The spokesman, Larry Speakes, repeatedly criticized Mr. Feldstein as taking positions contrary to Reagan policy on the Federal deficit. (1.)

title: Home Sales Rise Again
description: Sales of new single-family houses advanced again in October, while prices slid from the record set the previous month, the Government reported today.

title: The Lesson Behind the Lies
description: Nine months ago the Environmental Protection Agency was mired in charges of mismanagement, conflict of interest, favoritism to industry and political manipulation. When its Administrator, Anne Burford, resigned under pressure, President Reagan charged her critics with ''unfair judgments based upon allegations and innuendo alone.''

title: U.S. AIDE ATTACKS RIGHT-WING LATINS
description: Deputy Secretary of State Kenneth W. Dam said today that right-wing terrorists in El Salvador and Guatemala were largely responsible for the successes of Marxism in the Caribbean region.

title: BRIDE AND GROOM, 12 CLOWNS, 21 ELEPHANTS...
description: The bride and bridegroom were led to their wedding reception by a parade of clowns. Also by 21 elephants, 13 tigers, 6 camels and 2 llamas.

title: Hitachi-I.B.M.
description: Hitachi Ltd. said it is paying the International Business Machines Corporation between 500 million and 1 billion Japanese yen a month for the use of IBM's computer software technology.

title: Nicaraguan Rejects an Offer Conveyed by Rebels to U.S.
description: An offer by Nicaraguan rebels to end their guerrilla attacks in return for democratic concessions was immediately rejected by Nicaragua's Foreign Minister.

title: Businessman Shot InHoldupAttempt
description: A 62-year-old Manhattan textile executive was shot and critically wounded yesterday during an attempted robbery outside a bank shortly after he had withdrawn $775.

title: BRINK'S TRIAL IS ORDERED TO WHITE PLAINS
description: A state appeals court ruled last night that the trial of two defendants in the Brink's murder and robbery case should be moved from Orange County to Westchester County.

title: A 'TIDE OF EUTHANAISA' THAT NEEDS STEMMING
description: To the Editor:

title: Up to $170,000 In Gold Is Missing
description: As much as $170,000 worth of gold is missing from the University of Connecticut Health Center's dental clinic in Farmington, state auditors said today.

title: Eugene O'Sullivan, 62, Dead; Stage Director and Producer
description: Eugene O'Sullivan, a theatrical director, producer and teacher for more than 30 years, died of complications following pneumonia on Thursday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived in Manhattan and Tampa, Fla.

title: SPEAKES SAYS HE FOOLED PRESS
description: Larry Speakes, President Reagan's chief spokesman, said today that two reporters ''bit like snakes'' after he planted false memorandums on the desks of aides in the White House press office.

title:
PATENTS;
Navy Offers to License Unpatented Inventions
description: The Navy is offering to grant licenses for the use of more than 100 inventions that have not yet been patented.

title: WILSON FOODS FIGHTS BACK
description: The Wilson Foods Corporation, operating now under Federal Bankruptcy Court protection, will emerge early next year from Chapter 11 as a stronger competitor in the meat slaughtering and processing industry, analysts said.

title: COLUMBIA FIRED UP BY GOALIE
description: Gary Escher had lost most of the sensation in his fingers long before the final seconds, when he fell on the ball and the opposing player to end the game. ''It was a typical way for me to make a showing,'' said the Columbia goalkeeper. ''I like it when the man receives a pass and then as he looks down at the ball for two seconds, I sneak up on him. Then when he looks up, I'm right there and he can't believe it.''

title: CAPITALS' LATE GOAL TIES DEVILS
description: The Devils earned a 2-2 tie with Washington tonight by hanging on through five minutes of overtime dominated by the Capitals.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT RATE FALLS IN NEW YORK AND JERSEY
description: New York State's unemployment rate dropped to 7.6 percent last month, the lowest in two years. A year ago it was at a seven-year high of 9.8 percent. New York City's rate fell to 8 percent in November, the lowest in 35 months.

title: Grove City; Wrong Stand, Wrong Time
description: When will the Reagan Justice Department stop trying to get the courts to make civil rights enforcement harder? Last year the department embraced long-discarded arguments favoring tax breaks for private schools that discriminate by race. The Supreme Court re-discarded the idea, 8 to 1. This year, Justice contends that a school guilty of sex discrimination in one of its parts may nonetheless enjoy Federal subsidy to others.

title: SALVADORAN SAYS U.S. IS GIVING MIXED SIGNALS
description: President Reagan's decision to kill a bill that tied future military aid to El Salvador to an improvement in the country's human rights record has weakened the Salvadoran Government's resolve to confront the problem, according to Salvadoran politicians and political analysts here.

title: PIANO: BARENBOIM PLAYS
description: Piano teachers, who need to be indomitable optimists if they are to be at all successful, are forever exhorting students to make the instrument ''sing.'' That is something it does not naturally want to do. The piano is, after all, a member of the percussion family and is no more designed for producing legato vocal tones than a snare drum. The illusion of a vocal line is, however, possible to create and sustain, if the pianist just happens to be a magician. Daniel Barenboim's recital at Avery Fisher Hall last night was an exercise in just such legerdemain. He had the piano singing from start to finish.

title: 25% STAKE IN AMFAC IS SOLD BY G. & W.
description: Gulf & Western Industries sold its 25 percent stake in Amfac Inc. yesterday for $110.5 million. The sale was part of a continuing effort to sell off some of the large portfolio that had been acquired by G.& W.'s former chairman, Charles G. Bluhdorn.

title: N.C. STATE CAPTURES 15TH IN ROW, 79-60
description: Lorenzo Charles scored 24 points tonight as North Carolina State turned back North Carolina-Charlotte, 79-60.

title: M.T.A. CHIEF IS PLANNING TO SEEK INCREASE IN FARE TO 90A FOR 1984
description: The new chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that he planned to recommend that New York City's bus and subway fare be increased next month to 90 cents, a rise of 15 cents.

title: ANDROPOV CAN RELAX
description: In what promises to be a hot winter for Ronald Reagan, Yuri V. Andropov (or his successor) can play it cool in Moscow. He has done his will in Central America and the Middle East, and can relax in the catbird seat and watch detachedly what Mr. Reagan will do.

title: ASSAYING FELDSTEIN'S ROLE
description: What is the proper role of the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers? Should he counsel the President privately and maintain the party line in public? Or should he speak his mind in public and take what results? Martin S. Feldstein has chosen to speak his mind, an apparently different path from that of his predecessors.

title: TEXT OF NONDISCLOSURE FORM
description: Following is the text of the nondisclosure form that Judge Irving R. Kaufman has declined to sign as chairman of the President's Commission on Organized Crime:

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 40.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: D'Amato on Weinberger

title: U.S. JOBLESS RATE DOWN LAST MONTH FROM 8.7% to 8.2%
description: With 740,000 more people working in November than in October, the national unemployment rate fell again, dropping from 8.7 percent to 8.2 percent, the lowest level since January 1982, the Department of Labor reported today.

title: L.S.U. Ousts Stovall;  Arsparger Is Hired
description: Louisiana State University today dismissed Jerry Stovall as football coach and quickly replaced him with Bill Arnsparger, the defensive coordinator of the Miami Dolphins.

title: Officer Arrested In Slaying of Wife
description: A probationary transit police officer was arrested yesterday at the Police Academy in Manhattan and charged with killing his wife, a New York City correction officer, the police said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is a melancholy truth that the partnership of business, labor and government which was able to coalesce around the city in a crisis no longer exists. It could not survive even a hint of prosperity.'' - Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation. (25:3.)

title: 'Marilyn' Closing
description: ''Marilyn: An American Fable,'' the musical about Marilyn Monroe, starring Alyson Reed as the late actress, will close after tonight's performance. The show, which opened Nov. 20 at the Minskoff Theater, will have given 16 performances and 35 previews.

title: CALIFORNIA'S GOVERNOR GETS AFFIRMATIVE RESULTS BY SAYING 'NO'
description: California, whose last two Governors, Ronald Reagan and Edmund G. Brown Jr., were colorful, charismatic figures who preached with almost religious fervor about the need to reduce the size of government, finally has a Governor who has done what they set out to do.

title: DANCE: ALVIN AILEY TRIBUTE TO BILLIE HOLIDAY
description: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater moved into business as usual on Thursday at City Center, following the tumultuous opening night gala celebration of its 25th anniversary. But business as usual was a top-notch evening of theater and dance.

title: COURT BAN ON WORK AT HOME BRINGS GLOOM TO KNITTERS IN RURAL VERMONT
description: Twenty-five years ago, Anabel Moriarty knitted a plain white hat for her son, Marvin, a member of the National Ski Team. He liked it, as did his teammates, as did the ski shop owners to whom Marvin showed it. One winter, he took orders for 10,000 hats. Mrs. Moriarty began giving out knitting work to other women in Vermont, and thus a cottage industry was born.

title: AT LAST, COMPUTER FORECASTS ON LEGISLATION
description: W. Mark Crain says he has reduced the complexities of Congress to computer software.

title: TO UNJAM CITY JAILS
description: Mayor Koch has treated the forced release of pretrial detainees from city jails as a sudden crisis visited upon his administration by order of a Federal judge. In fact, this last order was not the first - that came in 1980 and was ignored, most likely for political reasons. To put the situation in proper perspective, a number of critical points about the origins of this action, its current impact and possible solutions to the city's jail problems need to be emphasized.

title: Jersey Bank Link
description: Midlantic Banks Inc. said the board of First Peoples Bank of New Jersey had approved a definitive agreement for its acquisition by Midlantic for about $43 million.

title: Flute Quartet to Play
description: James Newton and three other flutists - Henry Threadgill, Frank Wess and Lloyd McNeil - will perform jazz for flute quartet tonight at 8:30 at Carnegie Recital Hall (247-7459), 157 West 57th Street. Tickets are $8.50.

title: TURKISH CYPRIOTS FORM A NEW ASSEMBLY
description: Turkish Cypriots established a 70-member constituent assembly today to draft a constitution for their newly-proclaimed republic and to prepare legislation for presidential and parliamentary elections.

title: Auerbach to Take Less Direct Role
description: Red Auerbach, who has spent half his life with the Boston Celtics, said today that he would step down as general manager after the National Basketball Association draft next year.

title: CELTICS 115, BLAZER 106
description: Larry Bird and Robert Parish combined for 75 points tonight to lead the Boston Celtics to their fourth straight victory, a 115-106 decision over the Portland Trail Blazers.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Houston Rockets at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. Ralph Sampson will be making his first and only visit to the Garden this season. (Television - MSG Cable 7 P.M. and 1 A.M. tape. Radio - WNEW 1130 7:30 P.M.)

title: CENTER A SOCIAL HAVEN FOR ELDERLY
description: Most days, Bessie Zucker is one of the 200 elderly citizens who eat lunch in the yellow cafeteria at the Stein Senior Center.

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 3, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: SURGING BUCKS TOP NETS
description: It was a night when what had been good for the Nets went bad, and what had been bad got even worse.

title: Dow Off 9.86 Points Amid Credit Fears
description: The Dow Jones Industrial average dropped 9.86 points yesterday, to 1,265.24, amid renewed fears that the Federal Reserve Board may soon move to tighten credit.

title: IndianPointTest
description: A test of how local emergency personnel would react to an accident at the Indian Point 3 nuclear power plant was run at 1 A.M. today and described later as a success.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Planning Ahead

title: DANCE: NINA WERNER, 'WIND DEVIL' PREMIERE
description: Nina Wiener and Dancers, who presented the premiere of Miss Wiener's ''Wind Devil'' Thursday night, make up the last entry in the Brooklyn Academy of Music's ''Next Wave'' season.

title: PatentsStacy V. Jones Disk Unit Caption Generator
description: WASHINGTON AN accessory that aids in the replay of programs from disks or tapes on home television screens was patented this week for the RCA Corporation. Charles M. Wine, of the company's technical staff in Princeton, was granted patent 4,418,364 for a caption generator, which displays timing and other instructions for the user.

title: A PALESTINIAN NOT FREED AFTER ALL
description: A Palestinian who was extradited from the United States and sentenced to life imprisonment in Israel for planting a bomb in Tiberius was not released with other prisoners in the exchange last week, a relative said Thursday.

title: BRIEFING
description: Rolling Back the Big Red

title: WITH THE BROKERS AT BOCA
description: After more than a year of a bull market, John S. R. Shad's message to the Securities Industry Association meeting here was understandably upbeat, but with a warning. The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission told the annual convention of Wall Street's leading trade group that if the bull calmed down, the industry could expect a slug of lawsuits and legal bills.

title: BEYOND 'BEYOND THE MELTING POT,' MOYNIHAN AND GLAZER FEEL VINDICATED
description: When two scholars, Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Nathan Glazer, approached Harvard University more than 20 years ago for assistance in publishing a book about ethnic groups in New York City, they were politely turned away. They were told that the subject, the theme of their now classic ''Beyond the Melting Pot,'' was too sensitive.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CINCINNATI (NL) - Signed Jeff Russell, pitcher, to one-year contract.

title: ADJUNCT TO CONVENTION CENTER SOUGHT
description: New York City is about to seek proposals for a development project that would run along the Hudson River from 35th to 40th Street and complement the new Convention Center, officials said yesterday.

title: SCOUTING
description: Traveling Team

title: Bridge:Cohen and Bergen Winners Of Title
description: The winners of the Blue Ribbon Pair Championship set two records at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here Thursday night.

title: No Headline
description: MORE CUNNING THAN MAN. A Social History of Rats and Men. By Robert Hendrickson. Illustrated. 276 pps. Stein & Day. $19.95. THE resemblance between rats and human beings is unsettling.

title: Cavaliers 108, Pacers 99
description: World B. Free scored 33 points as Cleveland beat Indiana for its sixth straight home victory.

title: BONN OFFICIAL LOSES IMMUNITY
description: Otto Lambsdorff, right, West Germany's Economics Minister, voting in favor of a parliamentary motion to strip him of immunity in a bribery investigation.

title: Strike at Oak Ridge By Guards Is Settled
description: Security guards on strike at a top-secret Government nuclear weapons plant and the Oak Ridge National Laboratory agreed to a 6 percent wage increase today and will return to work Sunday night, officials said.

title: U.S. ATTACKS PLAN THAT SETS QUOTAS FOR HIRING BLACKS
description: For the first time, the Reagan Administration today raised with the Supreme Court the argument that affirmative action plans were unconstitutional if they included explicit racial criteria for the selection of employees.

title: Man Is Convicted of Killing Officers to Avenge Paralysis
description: A paraplegic who had vowed to avenge his paralysis, which resulted from a police shootout three years ago, was convicted Thursday of murdering two officers who tried to serve him with an arrest warrant.

title:
PATENTS;
Protein-Classifier Gel For Computer Scans
description: Prof. Robert S. Ledley of Georgetown University in Washington was granted patent 4,417,967 this week for grooved gel, a colloid material that is intended to enable a computer to determine the nature of proteins being examined.

title: Meyer on the Brink
description: Ray Meyer , the head coach of the DePaul basketball team the last 42 seasons, said he couldn't care less, except that a party will be given for him after tonight's game with Illinois State. If DePaul wins, however, Meyer would become only the fifth major-college coach to achieve 700 victories in a career.

title: WEST IS REBUTTED ON MISSILE TALKS
description: The Communist Party newspaper Pravda said today that American nuclear missiles currently being made ready for deployment in Western Europe would have to be withdrawn before Soviet negotiators would resume talks on the issue.

title: Spurs 123, Bulls 94
description: George Gervin and Mike Mitchell combined for 62 points, including 28 in the third quarter, to help San Antonio break a three-game losing streak with a victory over Chicago.

title: KANSAN'S JOURNEY TO LONDON NETS 5 CABBAGE PATCH DOLLS
description: The journey that took Edward Pennington from Kansas City to London in search of a Cabbage Patch Kid for his 5-year-old daughter has come to a happy ending.

title: MAGIC JOHNSON HURT
description: Mark Aguirre scored 42 points and led a final-quarter spurt that carried the Dallas Mavericks to a 133-118 victory tonight over the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: CORRECTION
description: Two picture captions on the first page of Weekend yesterday, identifying Christmas origami displays, were transposed. The tree is at the Museum of Natural History, the panda at Japan Air Lines.

title: SCREEN: WEST GERMANS LOOK AT 'WAR AND PEACE'
description: The 1982 German film ''War and Peace,'' now playing at the Vandam, is a collaboration between the Nobel Prize-winning author Heinrich B"oll and the noted directors Volker Schl"ondorff and Alexander Kluge, along with Stefan Aust and Axel Engstfeld.

title: Sweden Reports Finding More Electronics Gear
description: Swedish customs agents found six more packages of sophisticated American electronics equipment today, and a London newspaper reported that the authorities were holding a man suspected of trying to smuggle the goods to the Soviet Union.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE ;
description: HOME TALENT

title: U.S. AND LEBANON MOVE TO BOLSTER RELATIONS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the United States and Lebanon had agreed to set up joint economic and military committees to provide ''more structure and coherence'' to their efforts to unify Lebanon and bring about the withdrawal of all foreign forces.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Precinct Comes Through

title: Taiwan Votes Today For 71 Assembly Seats
description: After two weeks of spirited political campaigning, elections are being held on Saturday for 71 seats in Taiwan's 371-member legislature.

title: Bernardo Zuleta, U.N. Envoy Who Sought Sea-Law Treaty
description: Bernardo Zuleta, a United Nations Under Secretary General, died of cancer Thursday at New York Hospital. He was 54 years old.

title: 26 From Congress Complain To Reagan on Acid Rain Plan
description: Twenty-six members of Congress from Western states, including five Republican senators, complained to President Reagan in a letter released Wednesday that a leading proposal to reduce acid rain would unfairly tax their region.

title: Soviet Lead Suspected In New Missile Defense
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said today that he thought the Soviet Union had a lead over the United States in developing weapons to repel nuclear attacks from space.

title: ; A POLICE OFFICER'S DAILY WAR
description: To the Editor:

title: ARTILLERY BATTLES ERUPT IN TRIPOLI
description: Heavy artillery exchanges erupted in the northern port of Tripoli today as negotiations for the evacuation of about 5,000 Palestinian guerrillas loyal to Yasir Arafat appeared to be stalled.

title: PICKENS-GULF 1ST ROUND: A CLOSE PROXY VOTE
description: Some 3,000 stockholders of the Gulf Oil Corporation convened here today in a snowstorm for a three-hour special meeting that pitted Gulf's chairman, James E. Lee, against T. Boone Pickens Jr., the colorful chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Company who is trying to split Gulf Oil in two.

title: SMALL TALK CENTERS ON 7-4 SAMPSON
description: On March 19, 1980, the University of Virginia won the National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square Garden, and the center who comes along once in a decade was a freshman. After a 15-point, 15-rebound performance against Minnesota, Ralph Sampson, 19 years old, was voted the tournament's most valuable player.

title: RIBLI AND SMYSLOV DRAW SIXTH GAME OF MATCH
description: A frustrated Zoltan Ribli of Hungary was forced to agree to a draw in the sixth game of his semifinal world championship chess match with Vasily Smyslov of the Soviet Union tonight.

title: Student Charged in Fire At University Dormitory
description: A 20-year-old resident dormitory assistant at the University of Massachusetts, the scene of more than two dozen fires this semester, was arrested tonight in connection with a fire Tuesday after police searched her dormitory, officials said.

title: And Leave the Driving to Whom?
description: ''It smacks a little of what is going on in Poland,'' says a union official. He's referring to Greyhound's apparent determination to replace workers who refuse a 15 percent cut in pay and fringes.

title: Larry Flynt Is Freed on Bond After an Arrest in Anchorage
description: Larry Flynt, publisher of Hustler magazine, who was arrested Thursday for traveling to Alaska in violation of his bail, was freed today on $10,000 bond.

title: DOLE IS CONSIDERING POST OF PARTY LEADER
description: Senator Bob Dole of Kansas said Thursday that he had telephoned 25 to 30 Republican colleagues to express his interest in the party Senate leadership post to be vacated next year with the retirement of Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee.

title: Sun Set to Close Lubricant Facility
description: The Sun Company said it will close the lubricant-aking facilities at its Marcus Hook, Pa., refinery.

title: F.A.A. WILL PUT INSPECTORS ON AIR ILLINOIS FLIGHTS
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said yesterday that safety inspectors would be assigned starting this weekend to ride on each of the 120 or more daily flights of Air Illinois.

title: Pope Meets Czech Official
description: Pope John Paul II met for 45 minutes today with Foreign Minister Bohuslav Chnoupek of Czechoslovakia, a country that has accused the Pope of meddling in Soviet-bloc affairs. Neither the Pope nor the Foreign Minister made a statement after the meeting.

title: ROAD TO CARTER LIBRARY IS PAVED WITH DISSENT
description: Jimmy Carter's gift for landing in controversy has not deserted him.

title: Amtrak Fares Up 4 Percent
description: Travelers planning trips by way of Amtrak found train fares higher by an average of 4 percent starting Thursday.

title: WHAT FLAHERTY WAS
description: In the late 1940's, when I was growing up in the tenements of 17th Street in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn, the death of Joe Flaherty's father was always spoken about in whispers. It would be winter, and on the kitchen table there would be jelly jars filled with rye whisky. I would hear my father talk about how they found the body of Joe Flaherty's father, who was a union president on the Red Hook docks, floating in the Gowanus Canal. When I was older and started to hitch rides on the back of fruit trucks to the public swimming pool down in Red Hook, I always thought about the story as the trucks went by the canal.

title: A YULE LOG
description: In 1956, as I was leaving college for a six- week Christmas vacation, my tutor said, ''Do try to read a book, a big book. Gibbon's 'Decline and Fall' might do.'' I began reading it in the daytime on the steps of the casino at Monte Carlo in early December, and a volume of it lay in my pocket on Christmas Eve in the ancient basilica of Santa Maria Maggiore in Rome, where thousands jostled in the dark until midnight, when candlelight fanned out across the vast church as four cardinals, all scarlet and gold, billowed through the crowd, caroled along by choirboys in white lace and followed by eight men in somber suits carrying on their shoulders a gilded palanquin containing a relic of Jesus' crib. I fancied I could hear old Gibbon grumbling down there in my pocket. But the next day, as I sat reading his vilifications of early Christians on the steps of the temple of Antoninus, a Franciscan friar came along (the temple is one their churches) and sat next to me. Then his eye fell on Gibbon, and he fled.

title: IN AMSTERDAM, MODERNISTS LEFT A REMARKABLE LEGACY
description: One of the great casualties - perhaps the greatest casualty - of the current mood of revisionism that has swept the world of architecture is an understanding of the fact that modern architecture was not a single, unified thing, not an easily categorized and neatly summarized movement, but more of an impulse that manifested itself in all kinds of different ways. Modern architecture was not just the International Style and the Bauhaus, in other words - it was not just glass boxes and harsh concrete battlements. Not that there were not plenty of those - if there hadn't been, Modernism would surely not have gotten the bad name it has come in recent years to acquire. But there were also all sorts of parallel strands to the Bauhaus, and it is these that are so often overlooked right now.

title: STATE NEEDS AN INSPECTOR GENERAL
description: THE State of Connecticut is suffering from a credibility gap. A look at a recent public opinion poll conducted by the University of Connecticut shows that a majority of respondents believe that corruption in government is pervasive and that the Governor and legislature are doing only a poor to fair job. That dim view of government should be cause for great alarm - and action. The loss of public confidence in government stems in large part from repeated reports of incidences of waste, fraud and mismanagement.
