title: DIE MAUS THAT ROARED
description: The Parliament's decision to proceed with deployment of United States missiles, and the arrival of the first Pershing 2's on German soil, has reassured Reagan Administration officials who consider opposition to the missiles a troublesome but essentially manageable minority view. Still, developments in this tiny village less than four miles from the East German border suggest that the Social Democratic Party's recent shift in sentiment reflects a deep popular anxiety about American policy that could ultimately threaten the Atlantic alliance. The party, in 1977, under Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, urged Washington to respond to the Soviet SS-20's aimed at West Germany, but now opposes the United States missiles.

description: Chen Xitong was in New York City on a good-will visit last week, aides back in China announced that about 200,000 of man's outlawed ex-friends had been drowned or clubbed to death in Peking. Health officials said they would no longer put up with ''dogs running about wildly, urinating everywhere and causing difficulties for municipal sanitation.'' title: DARK HORSE FROM CALIFORNIA
description: Robert Lindsey is The New York Times's bureau chief in Los Angeles. By Robert Lindsey ARKNESS IS GIVing way to dawn as a tall, gaunt man crosses Massachusetts Avenue a few blocks from the United States Capitol. He stops at a public park, lies down on the grass, stretches for several minutes, rolls over and stands on his head. A black poodle, unleashed and curious, runs over and sniffs at the upside-down man who wants to be President of the United States. But the man ignores the dog, and after a while it wanders away.

title: JOBLESS DROP CALLS FOR A LOOK AT THE DATA

Her program was made up entirely of unfamiliar material - music by Minoru Miki, Satoshi Ohmae, Akira Yuyama, Masato Tajino, Maki Ishii and Miss Abe.

The composer and pianist Marvin Hamlisch will perform, and all proceeds will benefit the Education Foundation, of which Mrs. Herzog is the international chairman. The goal of the American Friends of the Council for a Beautiful Israel is to assist town planners, architects, botanists, educators and artists in their efforts to preserve Israel's past and present.

title: 'TEH COLD PEACE' DISMAYS ISRAELIANS

title: THE EDUCATION OF THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS
description: Robert Reinhold is a national correspondent for The New York Times based in Houston. By Robert Reinhold HERE IS PERHAPS NO more agreeable place to attend college than the University of Texas at Austin. The sunny, 316-acre campus is a comfortable jumble of buildings, serene old Spanish Renaissance palaces with orange- tiled roofs crowded by newer structures of cream-colored limestone and Texas shell stone. The paths between them are rivers of attractive young people, dressed, on warm days, in a uniform of Ocean Pacific corduroy shorts and Polo tennis shirts.

title: DELAWARE RIVER PROJECT ASSAILED AT HEARING
description: Without a pumping station under construction on the Delaware River near here, water shortages in Philadelphia's suburbs will become more frequent, the project's proponents have testified in an effort to block a Bucks County plan to kill it.

title: MAJOR NEWS IN SUMMARY Reagan BreaksString on Aid
description: For some time, President Reagan has been rankled by his semiannual duty to certify progress on human rights and land reform in El Salvador as a condition for continuing military aid. Last week, he got rid of the obligation by killing a bill extending the certification requirement.

title: UpstateWomanGuilty InCompanion'sKilling
description: A jury in Allegany County Court rejected the ''battered-spouse syndrome'' defense of a 23-year-old woman and convicted her of first-degree manslaughter in the fatal shooting of her longtime companion as he slept.

title: BRIDGE AWAITS TRIP BY BARGE
description: WOODBRIDGE TWP. WHAT looks like the product of a giant erector set lashed against a wharf along the Raritan River here is a bridge. But it doesn't span anything, and it won't until it is finished and floated on two barges to Mystic, Conn., 125 miles away.

title: BLAZERS DEFEAT NETS IN OVERTIME, 128-122
description: After hitting a 27-foot, 3-point shot that tied the game with only 10 seconds remaining in regulation, Lafayette Lever scored 9 points in overtime tonight to lead the Portland Trail Blazers to a 128-122 victory over the Nets at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: OPINION: PROPOSAL FOR ALTERNATIVE ROUTE TO TEACHER CERTIFICATION DRAWS CRITICISM AND APPLAUSE
description: In September, Dr. Saul Cooperman, Commissioner of the state's Department of Education, introduced a proposal to change the way in which teachers are trained and certified. His proposal was backed by Governor Kean.

title: THE JACOBY STYLE
description: Nobody in the history of bridge has had so many career high-points as Oswald Jacoby of Dallas. He was already the youngest actuary in the history of American insurance when he became front-page news throughout the country: In Jan. 1932 he walked out of the Culbertson- Lenz match, leaving the veteran Sidney Lenz to find a new partner. He won a string of national titles, first as a member of the ''Four Horsemen,'' and then, for a much longer period, as one of the ''Four Aces.'' The Aces won the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams four times in a five-year stretch, and won the first world championship in Madison Square Garden, easing up against the French team that held the European title.

title: ORNETTE COLEMAN'S DISCIPLES SOUND OFF
description: All great figures in jazz attract disciples, the best of whom graduate from membership in the master's band and head out on their own. Ornette Coleman has nurtured younger followers in just that way, and two former members of his Prime Time group and one current member have new records out - indeed, one of them has two.

title:
ANTIQUES;
SERENDIPITY FOR THE SEASON
description: Part of the pleasure of antiquing during the holiday season, when shops and shows draw crowds interested in gift-giving as well as collecting, is a compelling unpredictability: to launch or augment a collection by

title: FEW PRISONERS FOUND TO WORK
description: TRENTON ALTHOUGH training in 17 occupations is available to inmates at New Jersey's state prisons, few, according to correction officials, take advantage of it. One official, Lucas J. Filliponi, chief of the Correction Department's Bureau of State Use Industries, said in an interview that acquiring skills and working could lead to earlier release but that only 11 percent of the 13,000 inmates in the state prisons worked.

title: COUNTY ENDS POLICY OF LETTING THE POLICE FIRE WARNING SHOTS
description: The Middlesex County Prosecutor has rescinded a policy that allowed police officers in the county to fire a warning shot in certain circumstances.

title: THE ROLE OF CARDS IN COLONIAL SOCIETY
description: SOMETHING no collector ever really expected to find, a complete pack of hand- painted medieval playing cards, will be sold at auction Tuesday by Sotheby's at its London gallery, part of a major sale of illuminated manuscripts and miniatures. The cards are expected to sell for at least $75,000.

title: DIAGNOSTIC DEVICE IS FOCUS OF DISPUTE
description: THE state's Department of Health is investigating whether a group of Essex County radiologists violated New Jersey's health-planning regulations by buying a $1.5 million diagnostic device without the department's approval.

title: AGENCIES HELPED BY FUND FINDING NEED GREATER THIS SEASON
description: Executive Director The Children's Aid Society

title: POLICE CHIEF DISMISSED, GRENDADA RADIO REPORTS
description: The interim Government on Grenada has dismissed the police commissioner, the Grenada radio reported.

title: 700th Victory For Ray Meyer
description: Coach Ray Meyer won his 700th

title: GUITAR: CHARLIE BYRD
description: Because of zoning restrictions that forbid the use of drums at Village West, the restaurant on Hudson Street near Bank Street, the guitarist Charlie Byrd can be heard under unusual circumstances during his engagement there, which runs through today.

title: TOPICS Private Lives
description: One can't really call them a

title: OF PLASTIC SURGERY AND PLASTIC CARDS
description: Following are answers to some questions from readers of the Personal Finance column.

title:
DINIG OUT;
A FESTIVAL OF COLOR IN MONTROSE
description: JUDGING from the weekend crowd waiting for tables, India House, open for little more than a month, has already been discovered. Owned and attended personally by Simpson Kalaphara and his family, also of the long-established Bengal Tiger in White Plains, India House is still getting into stride. However, its corner of the county has so few places offering good and interesting food that diners might be interested to know about India House even in its nonage.

title:
ANTIQUES;
CARD PLAYING: A HISTORIC PASTIME
description: SOMETHING no collector ever really expected to find, a complete pack of hand- painted medieval playing cards, will be sold at auction Tuesday by Sotheby's at its London gallery, part of a major sale of illuminated manuscripts and miniatures. The cards are expected to sell for at least $75,000.

title: STUDY WARNS OF STATE TAXES ON SOCIAL SECURITY
description: Middle- and upper-income retired people, already facing a new Federal levy on half their Social Security, may also have to pay state income tax on those benefits in most states, an organization of retired people said today.

title:
GARDENING;
COFFEE AND TEA: FROM CUP TO FLOWERPOT
description: MOST of us would find it difficult to get through the day without having coffee or tea. Both contain the stimulant caffein, which partially accounts for our dependence upon them, but their flavors are also appealing. Lingering over a warm cup of either beverage is in itself a means of relaxing or taking a break from our everyday tasks.

title: SECRET SEARCH FOR A BASEBALL COMMISSIONER
description: JACK VALENTI, who served as a special assistant to President Johnson, was skeptical that baseball's commissioner-search committee could keep its pursuits secret.

title: PURCHASE DANCERS IN VAFRIED WORKS
description: AS part of a program that highlights the diversity of styles and techniques practiced by the Purchase Dance Corps, one of George Balanchine's finest ballets, ''Serenade,'' will be offered to county dance viewers today and again next weekend.

title: DEMOCRATS EYE CONVENTION ROLES
description: WITH Democrats required to select their candidates for National Convention delegates by early January, it is not to soon for Long Island Democratic leaders to be taking sides in the Democratic Presidential race.

title: SOME SIMPLE RECIPES THAT COULD RESTORE FASHION TO RICE
description: HAVE we forgotten about rice? So much attention is being paid to pasta these days, that rice seems to have gone quite out of fashion. But recently at a new restaurant in New Jersey, I discovered some excellent dishes made from the long-grain Carolina rice that is available in every supermarket.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary yesterday gave the wrong day for the funeral of Eugene O'Sullivan, a theatrical director who died Thursday. The service was held yesterday.

title: LOBBYING FOR JAPAN INC.
description: THE JAPANESE HAVE an honored custom they call ''descending from heaven.'' It works this way: A Japanese government official retires from his position in the ministry at the age of 55 and goes to work in the private sector. He joins the industry he dealt with while in government, usually doubling his salary in the process. ''Descents from heaven'' help knit together government and corporate officials, forming the united front with which Japanese industry has successfully taken on the world.

title:
GARDENING;
COFFEE AND TEA: FROM CUP TO FLOWERPOT
description: MOST of us would find it difficult to get through the day without having coffee or tea. Both contain the stimulant caffein, which partially accounts for our dependence upon them, but their flavors are also appealing. Lingering over a warm cup of either beverage is in itself a means of relaxing or taking a break from our everyday tasks.

title: CARIBBEAN BOMBINGS POSE QUESTIONS FOR FUTURE OF FRANCE'S POSSESSIONS
description: A recent series of bomb explosions on the island of Guadeloupe in the Carribbean has emphasized a touchy but unanimously accepted notion here: Things are not going well in France's overseas territories.

title: MAJOR NEWS IN SUMMARY
description: Spacelab GetsUp to Business

title: ISLAND HOPPING
description: As you fly into Nassau in a small plane, you can choose your beach from the air, or the location of the hotel you want along Paradise Island, where the breakers look like separate white brush strokes over the aquamarine reefs. We chose the Mayfair, downtown along the beach-lined bay, so we could watch the ocean liners lit like miracle plays and the hourly excursions of the Chalk's Airline seaplane, a Grumman Albatross that flies to and from Miami.

title: FEMINIST BOOKSTORE OPENS IN BERGEN
description: ENGLEWOOD ASTORE featuring books from feminist and alternative presses has been opened by two Bergen County women in a landmark building that originally was a grain warehouse.

title: RALLYING THE MARINES
description: Drew Middleton is military correspondent for The New York Times. N OCT. 26, more than 30 former marines called Lieut. Col. James Bathurst, all wanting to re-enlist. Ordinarily, the commanding officer of Marine recruiting in northern Illinois and northwest Indiana would have expected one call. The number of potential new recruits was up, too, almost double the normal number of calls.

title: ANTI-NUCLEAR GROUP OFFERS QUILT IN RAFFLE
description: PIECEWORK recently became synonymous with ''peace work'' for a group of quilters in Windham County, who are raffling off a 92-inch- square quilt they made to raise money for the Northeast Connecticut Nuclear Freeze campaign.

title: Baseball Enters Computer Age
description: Dave Johnson, the new manager of the Mets, intends to apply the principles of computer mathematics to solving the problems of the Mets, Joseph Durso wrote in last Monday's (Nov. 21) Times. ''I want to feed the history of every player in the National League into the computer,'' Johnson is quoted as saying.

title: Margie Goldsmith Plans to Wed Jack Nusbaum
description: Announcement has been made by Nancy Goldsmith of New York of the engagement of her daughter, Margie Goldsmith, to Jack H. Nusbaum, son of Simon J. Nusbaum of New York and Brussels and the late Regine Nusbaum. The wedding is planned for February.

title: U.S. AIDES DISPUTE SUFFOLK ON SHOREHAM PLANNING
description: Officials of two Federal agencies have disputed Suffolk County's reasons for deciding that emergency planning is impossible in the region around the nearly completed Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: Howard J. Strachman Weds Naomi Cannon
description: Naomi Sue Cannon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert S. Cannon of New York and Pompano Beach, Fla., and Howard Joseph Strachman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alex Strachman of Westbury, L.I., were married yesterday. Rabbi Maurice Aronov performed the ceremony at the Westbury Hotel.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE ;
description: CHORAL CONCERTS

title: PIANO: RECITAL BY DANIEL BARENBOIM
description: Piano teachers, who need to be indomitable optimists if they are to be at all successful, are forever exhorting students to make the instrument ''sing.'' That is something it does not naturally want to do. The piano is, after all, a member of the percussion family and is no more designed for producing legato vocal tones than a snare drum. The illusion of a vocal line is, however, possible to create and sustain, if the pianist just happens to be a magician. Daniel Barenboim's recital at Avery Fisher Hall Friday night was an exercise in just such legerdemain. He had the piano singing from start to finish.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: KNIGHTED CLIMBER

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: The ChurchOn Sex

title: YALE GIVEN MANUSCRIPTS FROM TIBET
description: More than 100 time-worn manuscripts and four unusual religious paintings from Tibet have been added to a collection at Yale University's Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

title: How Sweet It Is
description: According to William Scott , coach of the North Fulton High School girls' basketball team in Atlanta, it was becoming a monster - ''a monster created by the newspapers, radio and TV.''

title: Sports of The Times; The Planning Behind a Trick Play
description: THERE were 18 Jets in the room

title: HOW THE POLL WAS CONDUCTED
description: The latest New York Times Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Nov. 11-20 with 1,309 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.

title: COLUMBIA IS WARY OF UCONN'S DEFENSE
description: Although Connecticut has lost 8 of its 25 games and Columbia has won all 17 of its games, the Lions are not taking the Huskies lightly today when they meet in the semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer tournament at Storrs, Conn.

title: SOVIET AND INDIA BEGIN TALKS ON '84 TRADE PACT
description: Indian and Soviet officials began talks today on a trade agreement for 1984.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a story yesterday about possible fare increases misquoted Robert R. Kiley, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. Mr. Kiley said the M.T.A.'s deficit this year would probably be about $180 million.

title: THE NATION
description: It is little more than bad form in Washington to be caught lying to the press or the public; it is a crime to be caught lying to Congress. A jury last week found Rita M. Lavelle guilty of several such violations in a case that largely ignored the murky doings about which she apparently lied.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Around the World In 80 Days With David Niven, Shirley MacLaine, Cantinflas; directed by Michael Anderson. Warner Home Video 170 minutes.

title: A 'MAGNET SCHOOL' STUDIES HUMANITIES
description: THE thoughts of Descartes, Acquinas, Mill, Picasso, Rodin, Brandeis, Shakespeare, Bach or Mozart may not be on the tips of their tongues, but youngsters in the Daniel Webster Elementary School in New Rochelle are exploring issues equally weighty in a program designed to foster the humanities on a very early level.

title: RANGERS DOWN RED WINGS TO END SLIDE
description: After playing some dreary hockey in recent weeks, the Rangers skated hard tonight as they defeated the Detroit Red Wings, 4-2, at Joe Louis Arena.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: The SmartGet Richer

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
DINER DRAMAS
description: Donna and Frank Vaccari fell in love at the Thruway Diner. This is how, five years ago over a piece of lemon meringue pie, it happened:

title: STUDY FINDS CITY BEST FOR DOING BUSINESS
description: NEW YORK CITY is the most desirable of seven major United States cities in which to do business, according to a recent study by Julien J. Studley Inc., a national real-estate brokerage firm. The study's results were based on the analysis of business costs and benefits in each city.

title: JACKSON DRAFTS PLAN FOR CHANGES IN ELECTING DEMOCRATIC DELEGATES
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson and his key advisers said today that they had drafted an ''action plan'' to change Democratic Party rules that he considers unfair to blacks in selecting delegates to the Presidential nominating convention.

title: TWO WHO WENT BEYOND CUBISM
description: Among the bright young American painters who went to Europe at the turn of the century, Alfred H. Maurer (1868-1932) scored an early success. Arriving in Paris at the age of 29, he blended in his work the styles of Sargent and Whistler, and was soon winning all manner of awards - back home, no less than the Carnegie International Medal for painting in 1901. But through Leo and Gertrude Stein he began to discover Cezanne, and then the new Fauvism dominated by Matisse. He got ''modernist'' religion, and by 1906 had scrapped his early work for a breakaway style that heavily reflected the Fauvist influence.

title: SWAZILAND HOSPITALS NEED DRUGS
description: Swaziland's hospitals, hit by an acute drug shortage, are giving patients diluted medicines. Prime Minister Bhekimpi Dlamini said Friday, ''The situation has become so serious that patients have to be treated with medicine diluted with water to avoid wastage.''

title: ONE PRODIGY WHO HAS DONE THINGS HIS WAY
description: DALLAS

title: Kitty Alexander To Become Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. John David Alexander of Claremont, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Catharine McKinnon Alexander, to William Alan Shirley, son of Lynne Lawlor of Torrance, Calif., and Samuel A. Shirley of Redondo Beach, Calif. The wedding is to be in August.

title: AGENCIES HELPED BY FUND FINDING NEED GREATER THIS SEASON
In Pursuit of Icarus
description: The best time to stop any phase of the arms race is before it begins. Now is the time, therefore, to head off a dangerous, expensive and futile new competition in space. But President Reagan has been struck, like Icarus, by the dream of mastering space. He appears to be pressing the quest for an elaborate Star Wars ''defense'' that might, next century, render Soviet missiles obsolete.

title: SHUTTLE AWAITED BY RADIO LEAGUE
description: AMATEUR radio hobbyists in the county and in Connecticut have been hovering over their scanners since Wednesday, when Dr. Owen K. Garriott, an astronaut aboard the space shuttle Columbia was to begin communicating with ham operators around the world over a hand-held, battery-operated transceiver.

title: TOWN HELPS WOMAN GAIN HER EYESIGHT
description: Margie Brady had lived in the shadows since she was born without irises 30 years ago. But thanks to a gift from a generous town, ''everything is clear'' for Miss Brady today, she said.

title: A TOUGH TEST FOR NASSAU POLICE EXAM
description: Police departments have long been important symbolic targets for civil rights attorneys. Of the 133 hiring discrimination suits filed by the Justice Department against public employers in the last decade, 66 have involved the police.

title: South Africa
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Koosman Stays Put
description: The free-agency road in baseball is turning out to be a fast track home. Jerry Koosman , who filed for last month's re-entry draft after completing his second season with the Chicago White Sox, has become the latest free agent to decide to stay put.

title: PARISIANS MARCH AGAINST RACISM
description: Tens of thousands of Parisians and three Government ministers joined today in the last segment of a march against racism that was begun nearly two months ago in Marseilles by 30 young people, most of them children of North African immigrants.

title: MONEY IS KEY TO PLAN FOR SCHOOLS
description: GERALD N. TIROZZI, the State Education Commissioner, is spending much of his time these days as a salesman, offering his ideas for improving education in the state.

title: HAM RADIO OPERATORS TUNE IN TO SPACE
description: AMATEUR radio hobbyists all over the state have been hovering over their scanners since Wednesday, when Dr. Owen K. Garriott, an astronaut aboard the space shuttle Columbia was to begin communicating with ham operators around the world over a hand-held, battery-operated transceiver.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: After 10 Years,Time Runs OutFor a ConvictThe Pope of the Roman Catholic Church, the Chief Justice of the United States and diverse groups for and against capital punishment all passed judgment last week on the life of Robert Austin Sullivan, a convicted murderer. When the issue was settled, Mr. Sullivan sat dead in a Florida electric chair - a fate he had been facing for 10 years.

title: WHAT MY HOUSE KEEPS TELLING ME
description: now

title: HEADLINERS Mile-Long IndictmentIf a Federal indictment handed down last week reflects the facts, there weren't many pies that New York State Senator
description: Joseph R. Pisani didn't have a finger in. The New Rochelle Republican was charged with 30 counts of fraud and tax evasion in connection with the embezzlement of $83,000 from his political campaign funds, his former law firm and its clients and the New York State treasury. Mr. Pisani denied it all and said he expected to be vindicated.

title: ST. FRANCIS TROUNCES ADAMS IN BOWL, 42-6
description: St. Francis Prep continued the Catholic League's domination of the Metro Bowl and completed an undefeated football season with a 42-6 victory yesterday over John Adams High School in the fifth annual game at Midwood Field in Brooklyn.

title: NINOTCHKA AND TATYANA
description: In Moscow a couple of weeks ago, 200 courageous Russians answered an invitation to come to the residence of the U.S. Ambassador to see a film of the 1930's,''Ninotchka,'' starring Greta Garbo, which spoofs the Communists and embraces romance in the capitalist West.

title: MUSIC: A CELEBRATION OF VAR ESE AT COLUMBIA
description: We are awash this year in celebrations of the milestone birthdays of important composers living and dead, and not the least of those anniversaries is the 100th birthday of Edgard Var ese, the French-American avant- gardist who died in New York 18 years ago.

title: SCIENCE
description: Archimedes' famous claim that he would move the world if only someone could find him a place to stand reflected both his exhilaration in discovering the principle of the lever and his melancholy recognition that we have our limits as earthbound creatures. These restrictions have largely vanished in the last 20 years. The space program has lifted us away from our gravitational imperative and shown us how beautiful a planet we inhabit while the development of plate tectonic theory has given us an understanding of how our Earth operates.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: The latest NBC News White Paper, ''Journey to the Heart of China,'' is the result of 18 months of filming in various corners of mainland China previously unrecorded through Western lens. Tony Potter, the project's executive producer, culled the resultant 350 hours of footage to make the two-hour special, to be broadcast Wednesday at 8 P.M. A unique aspect of the program is that it is a joint enterprise between NBC and independent British TV producers who had obtained access to China.

title: CABARET: 'NUNSENSE' AT THE DUPLEX
description: For some people, perhaps, the mere sight of anybody wearing a nun's habit and uttering risque remarks is enough to provoke gales of laughter. ''The Nunsense Story,'' a whimsical musical-comedy revue that bills itself as an un

title: POLITICAL UNCERTAINTIES
description: In ''The Quantum Mechanics of Politics'' (Nov. 6), Flora Lewis offers the insight that there can be no ''lasting formula'' that releases us from the uncertainties of political life. But are there formulas, of a different sort, that allow us to understand better the nature of these uncertainties?

title: CARIBBEAN CHIEFS PRAISE TRADE PLAN
description: An annual conference here to promote United States investments in the Caribbean region ended Friday night with foreign officials giving high marks to President Reagan's trade initiatives to help develop the economies of the region.

title: THE DANCE: COLLABORATIVE 'WELL WATER'
description: ''Is this a feminist tract?'' a man in the audience murmured on Friday at the Bessie Sch"onberg Theater. Four women did dance ''Midnight Well Water,'' an improvisatory collaboration between the composer Pauline Oliveros and Deborah Hay, a pioneering New York post-modernist of the 1960's who is now based in Austin, Tex.

title: Browns on Move as '83 Nears End
description: NOT since they were known as the Kardiac Kids, for their frequent late-game heroics of 1980, have the Cleveland Browns been so close to a successful season. The Kids finished 11-5, which was the Browns' best record in six years; the current group is 8-5, their best record since then.

title: THE NATION
description: With jobs so hard to come by, picket lines don't seem to be nearly the barriers they used to be. The monthlong strike against Greyhound Bus Lines seemed last night to have been settled.

title: Page Ayres, An Architect, Has Nuptials
description: Page King Ayres, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Davis Ayres 2d of New York, was married yesterday to Nicholas Patrick Thurlow Cowley, son of Maj. and Mrs. Patrick Victor Cowley of Hawley, Hampshire, England. The Rev. Frederick S. Baldwin performed the ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Deborah Boone Plans To Wed a Neurologist
description: Mrs. Clinton C. Boone of Pound Ridge, N.Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Deborah Elizabeth Boone, to Dr. Stewart Jeff Tepper, son of Dr. and Mrs. Clifford M. Tepper of Schenectady, N.Y. A May wedding is planned.

title: WALTON IS BELIEVED CHANGING HIS APPROACH TO JET PLAYERS
description: Joe Walton shrugs and says ''it was no big deal.''

title: MORE OF HUNGRYARE SEEKING HELP
description: Soup kitchens in cities from Miami to Buffalo are feeding an increasing number of people who have lost Federal benefits, representatives from several organizations have told a Presidential study group.

title: FIRST IMPRESSIONS, LASTING EFFECTS
description: A TREASURY OF THE GREAT CHILDREN'S BOOK ILLUSTRATORS

title:
MUSIC;
CONCERT RIVALS UNITE
description: -music audiences - Teaneck Artists Perform and the Leonia Chamber Musicians - will combine for a concert today at 4 P.M. in the ballroom of the newly opened Loews Glenpointe Hotel in Teaneck.

title: IN BONAIRE, AN UNDERSEA WONDERLAND
description: On the island of Bonaire in the Netherlands Antilles, the realms of heaven and hell are reversed. There, 60 miles off the coast of Venezuela, one descends into heaven. In front of an old aloe plantation called Karpata, a single step off a rough stone staircase that leads to the sea transports you from a barren land of cactus and chameleons, a world so dry that even the tap water must be desalinated, into a turquoise paradise of color and life. Corals and sponges of green, orange, tan and purple carpet the sea floor as the reef plunges into the depths.

title: Eagle Comeback
description: New Jersey nearly doubled its bald eagle population last April - with help from humans. The state was down to two mature eagles and a fledgling, and inspection of two eggs in a nest showed that the eggshells were too thin to risk natural incubation.

title: THATCHER STANCE ON GRENADA ATTRIBUTED TO BEING A WOMAN;
description: Margaret Thatcher's opposition to the United States-led invasion of Grenada was related to the fact that the British Prime Minister is a woman, Charles Z. Wick, the director of the United States Information Agency, said Friday night.

title: LANDLORDS INITIATE NEW FIGHT ON FREEZE
description: ANGERED by the rent freeze imposed in October, Westchester landlords are organizing to fight back with a mass of lawsuits that seek to reduce the assessments on their apartment buildings.

title:
ART;
SMALL, APPEALING WORKS THAT NEEDN'T PUZZLE THE WORKER
description: THIS is the season when many of the Island's art galleries feature group exhibitions of small, reasonably priced works designed to attract holiday gift-givers. One such establishment is Gallery East in East Hampton, where a selection of paintings, drawings and watercolors by 40 artists, most but not all of them from the area, is on view through next Sunday.

title: TOPICS
description: LATELY we've been seeing a lot of articles about genetic engineering. People are afraid that future parents will be able to choose the genes that will form their babies.

description: Lawrence Taylor, who

title: Miss Goldsmith Weds Executive
description: Elizabeth Wilson Goldsmith, daughter of Mrs. Jacques Jouvenne Tisne of Chappaqua, N.Y., and John Frank Goldsmith of New York, was married yesterday to Raymond David Hilton 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hilton Jr. of Longmeadow, Mass. The Rev. Herbert G. Draesel performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of Saint Mary the Virgin in Chappaqua, assisted by the Rev. Edd Payne.

title: 'Sweethearts' on the Way
description: Jane Powell will be among the cast for a performance of Victor Herbert's operetta ''Sweethearts'' on Dec. 12 at 8 P.M. at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street.

title: WHAT OBLIGATIONS DO PRO ATHLETES HAVE TO THE FANS?
description: IN America, achievement usually

title: ARAFAT SAYS IT IS TIME FOR HIM TO QUIT TRIPOLI
description: Yasir Arafat said today that he had decided that it was time to leave the city and that he planned to go on to Amman, Jordan, where he said he hoped to resume his talks with King Hussein on a joint approach to Middle East peace negotiations.

title: Nuclear Subpoenas Upheld
description: A Federal judge has ruled that 26 former and current employees of the Three Mile Island nuclear plant must comply with subpoenas issued by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

title: Stevenson Rated City's Best
description: According to a poll taken by the National Collegiate Athletic Association, the city has produced 47 collegiate all- Americans since 1946, more than any other metropolitan area. New York State has produced 79 all-Americans, and also ranks as the leading exporter of high school talent, with 47 of its players having achieved all-America status at 33 colleges around the country.

title: SHOPPING FOR THE HOLIDAY SEASON
description: A survey of holiday craft offerings suggests that many galleries and shops are ''playing it safe'' either with works established as ''collectibles'' or with functional wares.

title: Libby McGarry and Craig J. Albert, Lawyers, to Be Married on Feb. 19
description: Mary Elizabeth McGarry and Craig Justin Albert, both lawyers, plan to be married Feb. 19.

title:
CAMERA;
FIXING AND WASHING PRINTS TO PREVENT FADING
description: George Schaub is a freelance photographer who does all of his own lab work.

title: CELEBRITIES
description: KENNEDY: A TIME REMEMBERED

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
HOLLYWOOD KITSCH AT ITS PEAK
description: Aportrait of Lassie against a sunset, Jane Russell in a pale pink nightgown sprawling seductively on a king-size bed, Ronald Reagan in 1947 sunbathing with Jane Wyman on the lawn of their house in the hills overlooking Los Angeles, Annette Funicello and Frankie Avalon having a serious teen-age discussion on a beach in 1965 - these are not the kind of pictures the average gallerygoer would expect to find at the Whitney Museum of American Art. But they are among the 44 photographs of Hollywood life on view at the Whitney's midtown gallery in the Phillip Morris Building, Park Avenue at 42d Street, through Dec. 30, and the show as a whole is symptomatic of something new in the art photography world.

title: A 'WATCHDOG' FOR THE DISABLED
description: WHEN the White House called Sandra Swift Parrino of Briarcliff Manor last September and asked her to become chairman of the National Council on the Handicapped, she admitted to being surprised. Although President Reagan had named her to the council last year, Mrs. Parrino had never met him.

title: THE WORLD
description: Where East And WestStill MeetSoviet-American relations stayed bad last week, but not all bad. In the absence of the Soviet leader, Yuri V. Andropov, who hasn't been seen in public for more than three months, the Kremlin appeared to be proceeding cautiously. Despite the suspension at Soviet insistence of discussions on medium-range missiles in Europe, the other Geneva talks - on strategic weapons - continued in two sessions, with another meeting set for Tuesday.

title: WASHINGTON'S FEAT ON AGENDA AGAIN
description: AS they have for 31 years, amateur historians and others will gather here on Christmas Day to re-enact the crossing of the Delaware River by George Washington and his troops. Dressed in Continental Army uniforms, they will man rowboats and cross from Pennsylvania to New Jersey.

title: THE REGION
description: Kiley DecidesHow High Is Up

title: East End Indians And Artifacts
description: The article about our Indians of Eastern Long Island exhibition (''How L.I.'s Original Inhabitants Lived,'' Nov. 13) was well done, and we have been pleased by the attention it has drawn to the exhibition.

title: Carriers' Week Proclaimed
description: President Reagan has signed a proclamation designating this week as ''Carrier Alert Week.'' It is intended to bring attention to a program in which mail carriers voluntarily help homebound elderly people by notifying social agencies when mail piles up at a participant's home, often a sign that something is wrong.

title: COMMONWEALTH TIES ENDURE ACROSS CONTINENTS AND CULTURES
description: When London's writ ran around the world, the lands now known as the Commonwealth of Nations formed a red girdle across the map. Today, as befits autonomous countries diverse in geography, politics and culture, the 48 Commonwealth members are marked in many colors. Place names rich in associations that resonate in the imagination testify to their variety - from Mount Kilimanjaro and Victoria Falls in Africa to Pitcairn Island in the Pacific, Montego Bay in the Caribbean, the Canadian Rockies, the Australian outback and the great cities of the Indian subcontinent.

title: Amy M. Moss Will Be Married in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. William John Moss of Garrison, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Margaret Moss, to Glenn William Brown Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Brown of Waynesville, N.C. The wedding is to be April 14.

title: CENTER USED CAT SCANNER WITHOUT STATE ASSENT
description: For nearly two years, the Catholic Medical Center of Brooklyn and Queens violated state health regulations by having its patients X-rayed with a computerized scanner without the required approval and knowledge of state health authorities.

title: PLAYING THE DEMOGRAPHICS GAME
description: -fund money manager, recently sold his company's position in Stride Rite Shoes, a maker of baby shoes, for two-and-a-half times the purchase price. Kinder-Care and La Petite Academies, two day-care center companies, are also realizing handsome gains in his portfolio.

title: Working Class
description: To the Editor:

title: AUGUSTANA TAKES DIVISION III
description: Augustana rallied today to defeat Union, 21-17, to win the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III football championship.

title: Viking Suspended
description: Ted Brown , the Minnesota Viking running back who has missed three games with a shoulder separation, has been suspended from the team without pay for the remaining three games of the season after skipping three days of medical treatment, team meetings and practice. ''I know what I did was wrong, but I think that three games is an awful lot to pay,'' said Brown, who blamed his unexcused absences during the week on mounting ''personal problems'' related, in part, to his family.

title: Topics Still Waiting
description: Bikini's Day After

title: 12 HISTORY BOOKS ON COUNTY OFFERED
description: TO mark the county's celebration of its Tricentennial this year, a publisher has prepared a dozen books that recall the history of several communities and offer maps and drawings of what the region looked like years ago.

title: MUNICPAL OFFICIALS HAVE NO DEFICIT OF IDEAS
description: One day last week at the annual convention of the National League of Cities, the lights went out. The darkness, which fell in the middle of a discussion on how municipal governments could save money by reducing utility bills, and the brief confusion that followed were reminders of conditions many of the 4,400 delegates find in their home towns, operating as they are with fewer Federal dollars and often with few alternative sources of revenue.

title: Flyers 6, Penguins 3
description: Bobby Clarke scored the first of five first- period goals as Philadelphia extended Pittsburgh's losing streak to five games.

title: AMERICANA
description: If the Magi had traveled to Bethlehem bearing picture books, they'd still be en route. The weight alone of this season's megabooks devoted to American life, history and art would be enough to flatten an army of Wise Men, not to mention a mere book reviewer with lower-back trouble. Fortunately, the express mail service has solved the heavy lifting problem these days, and the only remaining question is what we can learn about America from the current shipment. The answer seems to be ''Not much,'' ''Some'' and ''A lot,'' depending on whether the various texts spell out the specifics of the pictures (full captions, please) and make the necessary generalizations and connecting links without which illustrations are just costly bonbons for the eye. TREASURES OF THE SMITHSONIAN

title: ROME'S REMNANTS OF EMPIRE
description: The centers of ancient imperial power, unlike the provinces, often suffered more complete destruction. The glory that was Greece survives less in Greece itself than in Italy - in the temples of Agrigento, Selinunte and Paestum. The material culture of the Carthaginians now exists most tangibly, not in Carthage, but in Sardinia; that of the Byzantines, not in Istanbul as much as in Greece. The grandeur that was Rome is to be found not in Italy but in North Africa.

title: Collapse Kills Factory Owner
description: A factory owner who survived an explosion that nearly leveled his building was crushed to death Thursday when he returned to the scene and part of the rubble collapsed on him. George Schubert, 54 years old, the owner of the Schubert Heat Treating Company, died about an hour after the accident.

title: Irony
description: To the Editor:

title: Giants' Primary Need for 1984: Offensive Linemen
description: Scott Brunner will be the Giants' starting quarterback and Jeff Rutledge the backup when the Giants (3-9-1) meet the St. Louis Cardinals (5-7-1) Sunday at Giants Stadium.

title: AN EXCITING MONTH OF STAMFORD EVENTS
description: IT was a year ago - Dec. 1, 1982

title: Miss Moore, Art Teacher, Is Affianced
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William E. Moore of Old Greenwich, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Carroll Flippin Moore, to William Eugene Spears 3d, son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Spears Jr. of Beaufort, S.C. A March wedding is planned.

title: 'Brainy Borough'
description: To the Editor:

title: Challenges Emerge For '87 Cup Races
description: The Royal Perth Yacht Club of Western Australia, which now possesses the America's Cup, has announced that the next cup races will begin Jan. 31, 1987, midsummer in the Southern Hemisphere, in the Indian Ocean off Fremantle. As many as 10 challengers could be trying to wrest the cup from the Australians in their first defense.

title: ARE VIEWERS LOOKING TO 'VIDEOTEX?'
description: If you talk to salesmen for a new

title: AGENCIES HELPED BY FUND FINDING NEED GREATER THIS SEASON
description: President, Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: As with other first-rate artists who are well-informed early in their careers and then evolve without recognition and in isolation, the work of the American painter Arnold Friedman (1874-1946) is not easy to place. Friedman studied at the Art Student's League with Robert Henri, then spent six months in Paris in 1908, where he ran into the explosive mix of Impressionism, Post-Impressionism, Fauvism and early Cubism.

title: THE WORLD
description: The Bundestag lifted the parliamentary immunity of Economics Minister Otto Lambsdorff last week, clearing the way for his indictment in one of the biggest scandals of West Germany's 34-year history. Mr. Lambsdorff, an important figure in the now-strained ruling coalition, is accused of accepting bribes from one of the country's most powerful concerns.

title: Sara Davis to Be Wed in May
description: Dr. and Mrs. J. Rodney Davis of La Verne, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sara Elizabeth Davis, to Stephen Kenneth Bache, son of Mr. and Mrs. G. Michael Bache of Washington and Lavallette, N.J.

title: THE REGION
description: Many Skip TheirDay in Court

title: Christina Morrow To Become Bride
description: Christina Garnet Morrow, a freelance interior designer in New York, and Eric Stephen Bibler, an assistant treasurer of the Bankers Trust Company in New York, plan to be married Jan. 7.

title: THE NATION
description: O'Neill ShiftsHis Course onImmigrationWhether it was, as aides of House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. insisted, simply a matter of getting iron-clad assurance from the White House, or in fact the slow-to-sink-in realization he had blundered, may never been known. But last week, in a sudden turnaround, Mr. O'Neill said he would allow the House to vote on broad revisions of immigration laws after all.

title: And Bear in Mind
description: Other recent books that in the opinion of the Book Review staff are of particular literary, topical or scholarly interest: ALAN TURING: The Enigma , by Andrew Hodges. (Simon & Schuster, $22.50.) A vivid account of the troubled life of the eccentric English mathematician who was in large part responsible not only for the concept of computers as we know them but also for breaking the German cipher code during World War II - a feat now widely recognized as a key element in the Allies' triumph over the Nazi war machine.

title: VENEZUELANS VOTE FOR A NEW LEADER
description: National elections are being held on Sunday in an atmosphere of uncertainty over how to cope with the nation's moribund economy, rising unemployment and numerous charges of Government corruption.

title: FEW TURN OUT IN SOWETO TO ELECT A COUNCIL WITH INCREASED POWER
description: The black people who live in this vast and crowded township stayed away in large numbers from elections today that were held to choose a town council wielding greater local power than previous such assemblies.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Tony Eason was named to start at quarterback for the New England Patriots today against the New Orleans Saints after Steve Grogan reported sharp pains in his left leg. Grogan, who has been out since suffering a hairline fracture of the leg Nov. 20, had been expected to return to the lineup. . . . Ray Nitschke 's Green Bay jersey number, 66, will be retired before today's game against the Chicago Bears, and Nitschke, a Packer linebacker from 1958 to 1972, thinks it's about time. ''I never did like to see anyone else wear it,'' he said. . . . Five American pole vaulters have entered the Wanamaker Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden Jan. 27: Billy Olson , who holds the world indoor best; Jeff Buckingham , the Ameican outdoor record- holder; Earl Bell , Brad Pursley and Dan Ripley .

title: CITY CENTER'S POPULIST PAST TO BE FONDLY REMEMBERED
description: The City Center of Music and Drama, Inc., is celebrating its 40th anniversary with a gala on Dec. 12, but not quite. Actually, it is a relatively new corporation known as the 55th Street Dance Theater Foundation that has decided the City Center's once-glorious past as a performing arts sponsor should be recalled. And so while the City Center corporation itself does not feel galvanized enough to celebrate the good old days, such distinctions will undoubtedly be lost in what promises to be a veritable orgy of merriment.

title: MILITARY SERVICE: A MORAL OBLIGATION
description: The killing of 239 marines in Lebanon and the invasion of Grenada have reminded Americans of the military's role in pursuit of the nation's purposes and once again have raised the question of the citizen's obligation to do military service when called upon. This question still is before us because of continuing controversy over a law requiring students seeking Federal aid to register for the draft.

title: FEZ PAST AND PRESENT
description: Barely two hours by plane from any of the grand cities of Europe lies a stunning medieval town living today in the unbroken tradition of its history, bazaars, mosques and marketplaces, all more authentically preserved than those of Jerusalem, Istanbul or Cairo.

title: A MENU TO MATCH ELEGANT DECOR
description: FINALLY, the food at La Vigna in Greenvale has become a match for the setting. The handsomely elegant decor was installed several years ago, and lately it has been evident that the kitchen has taken a turn for the better.

title: FIGHT IT OR JOIN IT
description: There are basically two approaches that you can take against an opponent's hypermodern play - either join in with it or violently oppose it.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER ; SELECTING A CITY SIGHTSEEING TOUR
description: A major problem for many visitors to strange cities is how to select a sightseeing tour. They may abhor the idea of being herded about like sheep, yet few would disagree that a good tour can greatly help to overcome the feeling of insecurity, even intimidation, that often accompanies arrival in a metropolis where one has no friends and where the prevalent language is not one's own.

title: HEISMAN AWARDED TO NEBRASKA'S ROZIER
description: The Heisman Trophy publicity campaign began last summer when the University of Nebraska football team reported for preseason practice and Mike Rozier, the Cornhuskers' all-America running back, was featured in publicity releases and on posters and the school's news-media guide. Rozier was a reluctant recipient of all the attention but once the season began to unfold it was his performance and not the news-media blitz that enhanced his standing and made him the clear favorite to win the award.

title: Jennifer Heyman Engaged to Wed C. W. Burchenal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Morris A. Heyman 3d of Mobile, Ala., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Shan Heyman, to Caleb Wells Burchenal, son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph H. Burchenal of Noroton, Conn. A Jan. 7 wedding is planned in New Canaan, Conn.

title: CURBS ON INCENTIVES AFFECT REHABILITATION
description: -story factory building

title: RECITAL: RALPH VOTAPEK PERFORMS GRIFFES SONATA
description: The most striking score in Ralph Votapek's piano recital Wednesday night at Alice Tully Hall was Charles Tomlinson Griffes's Sonata of 1918. Griffes (1884-1920) counts as one of this country's earliest significant composers - a man who blended a vigorous independence characteristic of his native land with a craft and skill comparable to European composers.

title: MARCOS SAYS REVIVAL OF THE SUCCESSION ISSUE IS PART OF A CONSPIRACY
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos, under growing pressure from Philippine businessmen to allow election of a vice president, said revival of the issue is a conspiracy that could weaken his power, according to a statement issued today by the presidential palace.

title: RECITAL: MIGNON DUNN
description: At the center of Mignon Dunn's recital at Alice Tully Hall Thursday night were 18 songs from ''The White Election,'' Gordon Getty's setting of 32 Emily Dickinson poems. The cycle, as Mr. Getty's long and elaborate program notes tell us, is shaped in more or less biographical form and is intended to carry us through the spiritual progress of Emily Dickinson's uneventful, yet intensely felt, life in mid-19th-century America.

title: MUSIC: CHAMBER SOCIETY
description: The Chamber Music Society remembered Morton Gould's 70th birthday Friday night by playing his Suite for Cello and Piano at Alice Tully Hall. The piece was commissioned by the recent New World Festival of Miami and had its first New York hearing here.

title: FIRE I. DEBATING VISTOR FACILITIES
description: THE issue of whether bathing beaches at eight resort communities on Fire Island need public changing and toilet facilities is lingering on into the winter months this year, long after the last tube of tanning lotion was sold.

title: ISLAMIC AIDES MEETING TO DISCUSS P.L.O. RIFT
description: Islamic foreign ministers will discuss ways to end the conflict between rival factions in the Palestine Liberation Organization at a five-day conference of Moslem nations scheduled to open here on Tuesday, conference sources said today.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: This is not only the season for religious music, it also is a season when children are discovered by the musical community. Next Saturday, for example, there are two opera performances in the city particularly for children.

title: STATE TO NAME PANEL TO EXPLORE TEACHER QUALITY
description: Favorable and unfavorable views of the Cooperman plan are on pages 44 and 45.

title: FOR HEINEKEN, 3 WEEKS OF 'TRYING TO STAY ALIVE'
description: Alfred H. Heineken, the brewery chairman rescued this week from kidnappers, has recalled that in his three weeks of captivity he combed his hair with a broken plastic fork, made his bed and cleaned his concrete cell as much as his shackles would permit.

title: SIMULATED NUCLEAR EXPLOSION AWES SPECTATORS IN ARIZONA
description: The earth trembled and a shock wave raced across the desert sky. As the grey smoke of a fireball shot thousands of feet into the air, spectators sat in awe of a simulated 1.5-kiloton nuclear explosion.

title: U. OF CALIFORNIA REJECTS ARMS RESEARCH SHIFT
description: Faculty members of the University of California have rejected a proposal calling for the university to try to redirect nuclear weapons research at two Federal laboratories managed by the university.

title: WHITE HOUSE PARTISANS TAKE AIM AT EACH OTHER
description: For the Reagan Administration, the Christmas season has begun not on a note of hope and fellowship, but on one of acrimony over the President's economic program, illustrating the peculiar relationship between Mr. Reagan and his aides.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Celtics vs. Philadelphia 76ers, at Boston. The defending champions pay their first visit of the season to Boston Garden, where they lost all three games to the Celtics last season. Boston lost the first meeting, 92-91, this season in Philadelphia. (Television - ESPN 7:30 P.M.).

title: FOR CHINA, DISARMAMENT BEGINS AWAY FROM HOME
description: When Canadian Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau brought his proposal for a five-nation disarmament conference to Peking last week, he got little more than tea and sympathy. The Chinese leadership praised Mr. Trudeau's efforts but told him the Soviet Union and the United States had to reduce their nuclear weapons first.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: From their high, sweet-and-sour voices, one might think Kate and Anna McGarrigle are two old-fashioned folk singers. When they play their occasional New York club dates, as they will tonight and Monday at the Bottom Line, they contribute to that impression by giving shows that have the informality of a parlor sing- along.

title: Florida Routs Florida State
description: The Florida quarterback Wayne Peace set a Southeastern Conference career record of 610 pass completions today as he led the Gators to a 53-14 rout of Florida State.

title: IN PARMA, ELEGANCE IS A TRADITIONAL ART
description: WILLIAM WEAVER, an American living in Tuscany, is the author, most recently, of ''Duse,'' a biography of the actress, to be published late next year by Harcourt, Brace & Jovanovich. Ilike to arrive in Parma at night. There

title: Fly-Fishing Convert Spreads Word
description: AFTER having once regarded fly fishing for trout as no more interesting or challenging than hauling mackerel over the stern of a launch wallowing in the open ocean, Anne Voss Bark is now captivated by the sport.

title: UGANDAN GENERAL DIES IN AIR CRASH
description: The Chief of Staff of the Ugandan Army, a confidant of President Milton Obote, has been killed in a helicopter crash, the Uganda radio reported today.

title: Elizabeth Rollnik Plans a Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Morton Rollnik of Bayside, Queens, and Delray Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Gail Rollnik, to Dr. David Paul Friedman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold U. Friedman of Bayside.

title: KENTUCKY DEFEATS INDIANA BY 59-54
description: James Blackmon hit three free throws and grabbed a key rebound in the last 41 seconds as Kentucky defeated Indiana, 59-54, today.

title: DEVELOPERS LOOKING WEST OF SIXTH AVENUE
description: -FIVE years ago this month,

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
THE BOGUS ISSUE OF THE DEFICIT
description: IT is often charged that capital investment in the United States is

title: TODAY'S WORKER TREATED WITH UNUSUAL CANDOR
description: Anew movie entitled ''Heart of Steel,'' which will be broadcast on ABC tonight at 9, offers a valuable reminder that on television there are facts and, then, there are facts. Producers of TV movies are fond of noting that their wares are ''based on fact.'' That brief phrase can cover a lot of territory. CBS's ''Bill'' films, for instance, starred Mickey Rooney as Bill Sackter, a gentle, mentally retarded man in his 60's who had spent, pointlessly, 44 years in an institution for the insane. Mr. Rooney deservedly won numerous awards for his portrayal, but the ''fact'' is he bears little resemblance to the late Mr. Sackter, a quietly humorous Jewish man who wore a large fedora and a flowing beard. To their credit, the two movies concluded with brief glimpses of the real Bill.

title: IRAQ REPEATS WARNINGABOUT IRAN'S SHELLING
description: Iraq, accusing Iran of continued attacks on civilian areas, has repeated a warning that it will again strike targets inside Iran if the shelling continues.

title: Palmer and Dickinson Tied for Senior Lead
description: Gardner Dickinson birdied three of the last four holes and his five-under- par 67 tied Arnold Palmer for the lead at 204 after three rounds of the $150,000 Boca Grove Senior Golf Classic today.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN ADVERTISING;
HOW AMERICA STACKS UP IN CREATIVITY
description: Global marketers are fond of saying that a good idea doesn't care who has it.But American ad agencies care, especially after seeing their creative leadership usurped by the French, English and Brazilians.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Treasures to Stimulate The Spirit of Giving Seven years ago The Teachers' Room opened in White Plains, primarily to serve those involved daily in nursery through elementary education, but the word spread also to parents, grandparents and friends that there was a new source for quality, noncommercial children's books and paperbacks, games, puzzles, tapes, records, clay, microscopes, puppets and toys, along with advice on age groups, creative quality and suitability.

title: HOUSE PANEL MAY BE TOUGHER ON REAGAN UNDER NEW CHIEF
description: The death of Representative Clement J. Zablocki opens the way for a new generation of lawmakers to take more important leadership positions in the House Foreign Affairs Committee, and the panel is likely to be a more aggressive critic of President Reagan when Congress reconvenes in January.

title: GEMAYEL GETS A PEP TALK AND SHAMIR GETS A DEAL
description: WASHINGTON PRESIDENT Amin Gemayel of Lebanon came to Washington last week hoping the United States would have some answers to the problem of putting his country back together again. He is returning to Beirut with sobering news. The Reagan Administration had some modest suggestions such as the formation of joint economic and military committees to facilitate aid requests. But it had no sure solution for ridding Lebanon of the Syrians, who control 60 percent of the territory, or the Israelis, who dominate 30 percent. It had no panacea for reconciling the divided factions, or for reviving the crumbling economy. Mostly what the Americans did was to encourage Mr. Gemayel to hang on and try to be a leader of a nation, not just of downtown Beirut.

title: Medieval Moon Betters Aqueduct Stakes Mark
description: In a stakes-record performance, Medieval Moon carried Antonio Graell and 111 pounds to a 3 1/2-length victory in the $55,900 Petrify Handicap for fillies and mares at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: Company Is Accused Of Illegal Meat Sales
description: The Agriculture Department has charged that a Colorado meat packing company made hamburger from cattle that had died before arriving for slaughter, a department spokesman said Friday.

title: Harriet Lazarow To Wed E.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Lazarow of Atlantic City have announced the engagement of their daughter, Harriet Pogach Lazarow, to Elliot Scott Orol, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan Orol of Jamaica Estates, Queens, and Monroe, N.Y. The wedding is to be in June.

title: 'BENT': POWERFUL AND COURAGEOUS
description: An excellent production of Martin Sherman's poignant drama ''Bent'' is being presented by the Studio Theater in Lindenhurst. The play is a dramatic account of the struggle of homosexuals in Nazi Germany for self-preservation and decency, and has been controversial since its first reading at the O'Neill Playwrights Conference in Waterford, Conn., in July 1978.

title: WHEN YOU SAY THAT, RESILE
description: ''Regarding its position in Lebanon,'' asked the Foreign Minister of Pakistan, Yaqub Khan, ''do you think the United States will resile?''

title: MY EARLY LIFE IN CRIME
description: THE other morning, as I was waking up, I thought for a moment that I was dreaming about a newspaper. As I moved slightly and my eyes focused somewhat, I realized my nose had been pressed against the label protruding from my wife's pillow, that legendary label warning that it is not to be removed under penalty of law.

title: Laurie Carver to Wed Eric Epstein in Spring
description: Mr. and Mrs. Michael Carver of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Laurie Ellen Carver, to Jon Eric Epstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Epstein of Roslyn, L.I. A spring wedding is planned.

title: A WEALTH OF HISTORIC ARCHITECTURE
description: IN 1933, during the Great Depression, the Federal Government

title: HOW BOTTLER HANDLES THE RETURNS
description: NEW ROCHELLE PILES of plastic bags and cardboard boxes filled with empty bottles and cans virtually carpet the concrete floors of the Joyce Beverages Recycling Center. A year ago, empty containers like these would have been thrown out as garbage. But a year ago, New York State did not have a bottle law.

title: THE APPEAL OF ANCIENT CHINESE EXOTICA
description: Richard C. Bull's collection of archaic Chinese jades, ancient bronzes, belt hooks, weapons, tools and archeological fragments is one of the most exotic and esoteric to appear on the market in recent seasons. And some of its selections - a blade, a buckle, a block of marble and a three- legged bronze pot - are awesome in their strength, sophistication and simplicity.

title:
STAMPS;
SPORTS AND ARTS FEATURED ON EARLY '84 ISSUES
description: Now that the program of commemoratives from the United States for the first half of 1984 is practically finalized, it appears that the schedule will be dominated by personalities from the sports world and the arts, plus milestone anniversaries of landmark institutions that were created a half century ago by Franklin D. Roosevelt to help in the nation's recovery.

title: ROWS OF 'IRON CURTAINS' IN THE HISTORY OF CIVILIZATION
description: To the Editor:

title: HOLIDAY SALES SET FAST PACE
description: THE long lines of vehicles inching along the thoroughfares of the Island at a snail's pace these days indicate one thing: The Christmas season has arrived once again in all its frenetic splendor.

title: STUDENT ARRESTED IN MASSACHUSETTS U. ARSON FIRE
description: A student has been arrested and charged with setting one of the 30 small dormitory fires that have disrupted life on the University of Massachusetts campus, but another small fire broke out after the arrest.

title: STATEN I. ZOO WILL REPLACE ITS AQUARIUM
description: The Staten Island Zoo has announced plans to build a $300,000 aquarium that will have 15 tanks and 300 varieties of local marine life, sharks, moray eels, invertebrates and exotic fresh-water fish from the Amazon River and central Africa.

title: HIGH-SPEED NEW YORK-MONTREAL TRAIN SERVICE UNDER STUDY
description: New York, Vermont and the Province of Quebec have started surveys to find out how many people would use a proposed new high- speed train service that would cut the running time between New York City and Montreal to three hours.

title: REPORT GIVES MANY JOBLESS SCANT HOPE
description: A research group has a bleak forecast for millions of American workers in economic distress: They can expect to face chronic unemployment or poverty wages throughout the decade.

title: BOSTON PANEL FINDS FEAR AND VIOLENCE IN SCHOOLS
description: Half the teachers in Boston and nearly 40 percent of the students were victims of crime last year, a special commission has reported.

title: 'WHO WAS I TO TINKER WITH JOHN STEINBECK?'
description: In June 1982, a scriptwriter named Michael de Guzman sat ''terrified'' before a blank sheet of typewriter paper in his Los Angeles hideaway. His task was to translate John Steinbeck's ''The Winter of Our Discontent,'' the last novel of the 1962 winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature, into a screenplay for television.

title: Assist Mark Is Set
description: Glenn Anderson scored three goals, sparking a five-goal second-period outburst, and his teammate, Jari Kurri, set a National Hockey League record for consecutive assist games as the Edmonton Oilers defeated the Los Angeles Kings, 7-3, tonight.

title: READING FOR WORK AND PLEASURE
description: For the Christmas issue, The Book Review asked a number of prominent people what in the last year was the most important book they read for their work and what was the best book they read for pleasure, with a few words of explanation. Clifford Geertz said he imagined a number of respondents might be uncomfortable with the useful/pleasurable distinction, and, in fact, the distinction was ignored more than once. Also, some respondents ignored our superlatives and gave us more than the requested two titles, although the extras were welcome. About the ''few words of explanation,'' some replies had none, while others more than made up for them. Ronald Reagan President of the United States

title: ASSISTANCE IN KEEPING THE HOUSE
description: IT is widely assumed that grandchildren can no longer go ''over the river and through the woods to grandmother's house'' because grandma and grandpa have moved away, most likely to a condominium. Not so. The vast majority of grandparents are still staying put in the old family house.

title: END OF THE LINE FOR A FAMILY BUSINESS
description: ANDREW ROSEN is a personable

title: Olympics Are Changing College Hockey
description: Seventeen of America's best college hockey players are taking this year off to play in the Olympic Games. Eight of them are members of the American squad and nine are playing for Canada. Their departures may pave the way for a national champion from the Central Collegiate Hockey Association, which has never produced one.

title: ; Public Concerts
description: To the Editor,

title: BRIDGEPORT'S CHRISTMAS MEMORIES
description: BRIDGEPORT IN the quiet of early morning an arsonist

title: FOR ALBERT FINNEY, RISK IS EVERYTHING
description: Albert Finney lit out for Rome and Austria in May to play Pope John Paul II for a CBS television special to be shown early next year. He picked up some rolls of flab and shaved his head - getting to be something of a nasty habit with him - flying to England to play an old British thespian in the film adaptation of ''The Dresser.'' Then he quickly dropped off the excess fat, perhaps in an airport locker someplace, and was off to Mexico to don a wig and play a middle-aged alcoholic in ''Under the Volcano,'' a John Huston film.

title: NORTH KOREANS PROTEST EXERCISES
description: North Korea today called three days of joint military maneuvers by the United States and South Korea ''a grave military provocation,'' the official North Korean press agency reported.

title: A CHRISTMAS APPEAL: HELP THE NEEDIEST CASES FUND ;
description: The 72d Appeal

title: DANCE: AYAKO TROUPE
description: Ayako and Company, a group directed by Ayako Uchiyama, a Japanese choreographer, brought two dramatically intense dances to Pace University on Friday night.

title: CHANCE TO FLEE DIVIDES TOWN ATOP A MINE FIRE
description: Not since the secret society of Irish miners known as the Molly Maguires organized to oppose oppressive conditions of life in the mines has this tiny coal town been so divided.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN ADVERTISING;
ADS THAT CELEBRATE THE GLOBAL PRODUCT
description: The world seems more polarized than ever these days, but never have so many of its multitudes thought, felt and acted alike. And never have so many advertising agencies seized on the idea that there are pockets of consumers, regardless of nationality, bound by traits known as ''global commonalities.''

title: FERRY EXTENDING SEASON
description: THE Grand Republic, the $6 million ferry put into service by the Bridgeport and Port Jefferson Steamboat Company last summer, will be crossing Long Island Sound through Jan. 3 this season. For the last 15 years, because the heating system in the company's older ferry, the Martha's Vineyard, was unreliable, the ferry service across the Sound was suspended from mid-October to mid-May.

title: VOLUNTEER, AGE 98, RECEIVES AWARD
description: -year-old Russian immigrant and the teacher is 98. In the last two years, the student has learned English usage, and the teacher has found a way to ''fill the time.''

title: FANTASY THRIVES IN BIRTHPLACE OF CABBAAGE PATCH KIDS
description: Xavier Roberts, the creator of the Cabbage Patch Kids, was happily describing how he had turned his soft sculptures into a national craze when the public relations director of his company strode into the room.

title: CITY LEASING OUT A RUIN AND BUYING A ROBOT
description: The seafaring past and the automated future came into the political present in two unusual items that have been approved by the Board of Estimate.

title: THOUSANDS IGNORE NEW YOK CITY COURT DATES
description: The 75 criminal suspects who failed to appear for court dates in New York City last week after their release from jail to ease overcrowding are part of an army of suspects who daily avoid prosecution by simply ignoring the charges against them.

title: MOVING TO BREAK THE OLD 'FORMAT' MOLDS
description: American creativity may have lost ground to foreign agencies, but there are signs that a few of Madison Avenue's clients are making efforts to break out of the old molds and gamble on more imaginative advertising. New advertising tacks, such as those recently taken by Anacin, Prudential, Nike, Shasta and even Aim toothpaste, strike a blow at advertising's dreaded ''format.'' David K. Vadehra, president of the commercial-testing company Video Storyboard Tests, says that ''the hard sell started with advertisers shouting at you. But the only result for some of them was that they got hoarse. So they tried singing and dancing, and the soft sell began.'' Further distinctions led to ''category formats,'' Mr. Vadehra continues, in which many brands relied on responsible but predictable ''me-too'' advertising. ''Analgesics used hard-sell spokesmen and charts,'' he says. ''Soft drinks gave kids the spice of life - singing and dancing together on a beach - while household cleaners showed tormented housewives how they could have an easier slice of life.'' Malcolm D. MacDougall, whose creative background has taken him to the presidency of SSC&B, says that many advertisers can no longer grow inside these ''format straitjackets.'' Look-alike advertising - where all competitors in a market, say, detergents, are advertised in the same way - might be effective when the market for detergents is expanding. But when the demand for detergent levels off, a company seeking to increase its market share must take sales away from its competitors. To do that, Mr. MacDougall maintains, ''advertising salesmanship has to become creative.''

title:
LEISURE;
MEET THE EXOTIC ELATIVES OF THE PINEAPPLE;
description: Lynne Lamstein is a gardener and freelance writer.

title: CURB ON OIL GEAR FOR SOVIET BARRED
description: President Reagan has rejected a Pentagon- backed plan to ban exports of deep-sea oil-drilling equipment to the Soviet Union, according to Administration officials.

title: An Important Detail: Change of Address
description: I am writing in response to the bittersweet article on the Opinion Page on Nov. 6, ''No Forwarding Address - and a Search Begins.''

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: RIDGEFIELD
description: Many of its neighbors in Connecticut's Fairfield County are changing from sleepy suburban towns to busy corporate headquarters, but one of Ridgefield's proudest claims is that it has stayed more or less the same for much of the last 275 years.

title: MENTALPATIENTS WIN DRUGS RULING
description: Unless found legally incompetent, patients in mental hospitals have ''the right to be wrong'' on their choice of medical treatment and can refuse to take potentially dangerous drugs, the Massachusetts Supreme Court has ruled.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, the acquisition of RIHT Financial was incorrectly stated in last week's Week in Business column. The Bank of Boston has offered to buy the Rhode Island banking concern.

title: IF MARCOS DOES STEP DOWN, WHO'S TO STEP UP?
description: A growing desire to see President Ferdinand E. Marcos go is being matched by concern over who would succeed him.

title:
ART;
SCULPTURE DESIGNED FOR THE FLOOR
description: VISITORS gazing downward at the new veterans' memorial in Washington, moved by the configuration, realize that sculptural projects do not have to direct us toward some affirmation from above. It was in the mid- 1960's when artists began to think in terms of making ground-level pieces for placement on customary walking surfaces (a noble ancient tradition exists in mosaic floor images), and early examples quickly revealed the effects possible and the range of applicable creative ideas.

title: EXPERTS LEARNING ON THE JOB FIGHTING FIRE IN PILE OF TIRES
description: A foul-smelling fire that has been smoldering in a heap of nine million tires for more than a month has scientists ''writing the textbook'' on how to extinguish such a blaze while recovering thousands of gallons of oil oozing from the mess.

title: State Senator to Marry Miss Tabot in January
description: Andrea J. Tabot and State Senator Martin M. Solomon, Democrat of Brooklyn, plan to be married in January. Mr. and Mrs. Seymour S. Tabot of Bayside, Queens, have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Susan Rose Kaplan of Valley Stream, L.I., and the late Harry Solomon.

title: New York City
description: To the Editor:

title: SALUTE TO YVES SAINT LAURENT
description: OMORROW EVENING, the Metropolitan Museum of Art's great halls will echo with festivity as a glittering benefit dinner and dance, expected to be attended by 2,500 people, ushers in the annual opening of its Costume Institute's new exhibition. This show, underwritten by the Abraham silk company of Zurich and opening to the public on Dec. 14, is more than a bit different from its 11 predecessors that have been orchestrated by Diana Vreeland, the institute's special consultant. Instead of displaying historic fashion - such as ''The 18th-Century Woman'' (1981) or clothes of ''La Belle Epoque'' (1982) - it will celebrate a living, exceedingly prolific designer from Paris named Yves Saint Laurent.

title: MOMA'S ANTA
description: Space has been at a premium at the Museum of Modern Art ever since it began its four-year, $40 million expansion and renovation program. Galleries and administrative offices have been reshuffled, last year the museum was forced to reduce the size of its gift shop, and for a time it seemed that there might not be room for the annual Christmas store this year.

title: ALASKAN SCHOOL MAY FALL VICTIM TO PROGRESS
description: Progress is poking into Alaska's back corners, changing those pockets where chainsaws whine and people do pretty much as they see fit.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE Bergen Mall shopping complex on Route 4 in Paramus is again being brought to court by the New Jersey chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union, this time on behalf of the Bergen County Nuclear Freeze Campaign. The 30-member campaign group, part of a national organization seeking an end to the nuclear arms build-up, contends that the mall management has not wholeheartedly honored the right to free speech.

title: County Worker Total Drops
description: The number of people working for county governments nationwide dropped last year for the second annual decline after 35 years of growth, the Census Bureau reported this week.

title: DRAWING THE LINE IN EUROPE
description: Mark Helprin, whose latest novel is ''Winter's Tale,'' recently returned from a year's residence in Italy studying European security.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: THEY are stained glass. They are singular and may well be priceless. But to a lot of people in Mount Vernon, the nine panels in the roof over the Doric Hall in the city's library are just plain dirty.

title: STATE PLAN FOR RIFLE RANGE STIRRING DISPUTE
description: CONNECTICUT sportsmen envision an ambitious new rifle range, with facilities for Olympic-level competition. Plymouth residents who live near the site envision a life of ducking stray bullets and enduring the noise of hundreds of guns being fired.

title: RADIATION IS DETECTED AT 19 HOMES IN JERSEY
description: Last summer, state workers placed scientific instruments in 17 homes here and 10 in adjacent Glen Ridge. This week, residents found out that the instruments had detected radiation levels exceeding Federal safety standards.

title: ACTOR IS HIGHLIGHT AT NEW THEATER
description: WHAT started as a move toward developing a new graduate program at the State University of New York at Stony Brook has evolved into a new concept for a professional regional theater on the Island called the Highlight Theater. Its debut production, John Russell Brown's staging of ''Byron's 'Don Juan,' '' a one-man show conceived and adapted by Mr. Brown and starring Jeffrey DeMunn, will open on Tuesday at the university's Fine Arts Center.

title: Prison Babies
description: A nursery in the Correctional Institution for Women on Rikers Island? The New York Legal Aid Society sued in Federal Court in June seeking one for mothers of newborn babies, so they could keep their infants with them in prison. The City Correction Department had been placing such babies with relatives or in foster homes.

title: HUSSEIN MOVES ONCE AGAIN TO TALK PEACE ACROSS THE JORDAN
description: In his 31 years on the throne, King Hussein of Jordan has survived many political conspiracies and assassination attempts, but his current predicament is as difficult as any he has encountered. Once again, he is the man in the middle in the Middle East, with little room to maneuver.

title: NAVY STAGED RAID
description: Yasir Arafat says that it is time to leave Tripoli and that he hopes to visit Amman for talks. Page 16.

title: A CHANGE TAKES PLACE
description: ''I AM spending the night under the dogwood tree, on the ladder,'' I said quietly to my husband, Marty, as he sprawled on the couch and watched the evening news. He continued to watch for a few minutes, then looked at me and said, ''What'd you say?''

title: ARTHRITIS SELF-HELP GROUP GROWING
