description: SEVERAL years ago, Leah Treacy and Mary Lou Aquilino met in the hydrotherapy pool at the Hospital for Special Surgery in New York City. The women, both of whom have rheumatoid arthritis, became friendly as they compared notes on the disease. When Mrs. Aquinlino and Cathy Davis founded a group for people with arthritis, they asked Mrs. Treacy to join, and the Westchester Arthritis Self Help Group was under way.

title: LIBEL AWARD FOR HOWARD HUNT OVERTURNED BY APPEALS COURT
description: Missing Text

title: Killer Convicted Ninth Time
description: Gerald Stano, an admitted mass killer, has been convicted of first-degree murder for the ninth time. A Circuit Court jury deliberated less than three hours Friday before finding the 32-year-old killer guilty of first-degree murder in the 1973 slaying of Cathy Lee Scharf, 17, of Port Orange, Fla.

title: DANGER ON THE FILM SET
description: Stuart Black is a freelance writer who works out of Los Angeles and New York. By Stuart Black T WAS 2:20 A. M. ON THE 13TH night of filming, and the noise from the Bell UH1B military-type helicopter was deafening. The aircraft hovered 40 feet above Indian Dunes Park, almost 40 miles north of Los Angeles. A Warner Brothers crew had constructed a replica of a Vietnamese village at the base of a hill that rose nearly 100 feet.

title: AMERICAN CONSTRUCTIVISM AT THE STATE MUSEUM
description: TRENTON ''BEYOND THE PLANE,'' the current exhibition at the State Museum here, bespeaks a great deal of work on the part of Joan Marter, the museum's guest curator, and Zoltan Buki, its fine-arts curator, who directed the project.

title: TRUDEAU IN BAHRAIN
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada arrived in Bahrain today from Oman on the third leg of a four-nation Persian Gulf tour.

title: THE REGION
description: RegentrifyingBryant Park

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Leads to Gifts for Book Lovers

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE ADVENTURES OF PINOCCHIO

title: LIBRARY SHOW RECALLS MAN BEHIND TREATY ON GENOCIDE
description: The typed manuscript pages have turned yellow, the cheap copybooks are worn, and the handwritten notes are difficult to decipher.

title: GOOD VALUES AT MIDPRICE
description: Our immoderate age, inclined to dramatic extremes, often takes a condescending view of the middle. But in audio, at least, there is nothing middling about midpriced components. Keep that in mind as our Christmas stereo shopping guide - begun last week with a survey of budget models - moves to the medium range. Components in this group represent the best dollar value and pretty well embody the ancient Greek notion of the Golden Mean as the place where conflicts and contradictions are resolved. Certainly quite a few traditional antagonists can be reconciled through midpriced sound gear: cost vs. performance and aspirations vs. means.

title: 12% GET CITY U. BACHELORS DEGREES IN 4 YEARS
description: About 12 percent of the students entering the City University's four-year colleges and 4 percent of those in the two-year schools graduate on schedule, according to a draft report by a university panel.

title: Fitzgerald
description: To the Editor:

title: A True Jail Outrage
description: To release hardened criminals when we

title: THE WORLD
description: The South African Government struggled last week over what to do with a ''black spot'' that refused to be eradicated. Several hundred black families in the rural village of Magopa refused to obey a presidential decree ordering them off the land they have owned for 70 years.

title: A HUSBAND FINDS HELP FOR A CRISIS
description: FOR Edward B., life had not been full of hardship and suffering. He grew up in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn and went to college in Boston, where he received a degree in business.

title: ROWS OF 'IRON CURTAINS' IN THE HISTORY OF CIVILIZATION
description: To the Editor:

title: TOSSING THE DICE
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Judge in Ohio Delays Ruling On Atomic Waste Shipments
description: A ruling has been delayed until at least mid- January on whether a Federal district judge here has jurisdiction in a lawsuit asking for a delay in the shipment of nuclear waste through Ohio.

title: MUSIC: PHILHARMONIC DIRECTED BY LUKAS FOSS
description: Conceptually, Lukas Foss's current program with the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall is fascinating. He has declined to program a piece of his own. And yet his compositional instincts are reflected not just in the selection of music, stressing a 20th-century composer's views of the past, but also in the way he himself has actually reorchestrated some of the music.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS
description: When Mayor Willard Frederick of Orlando, Fla., visited Tainan on Taiwan in 1982, he invited officials there to visit Orlando. They said they would but would first send a gift.

title: A HUNGARIAN'S ODYSSEY: STALINIST TO SKEPTIC
description: In October 1956, when Hungarians rose in rebellion against the Stalinist Government, their 34-year-old Prime Minister, Andras Hegedus, fled to Moscow.

title: THE ART OF REPAIRING CERAMIC TILE THE NEAT AND SIMPLE WAY
description: ALTHOUGH ceramic tile walls will generally not need any repairs or maintenance for many years, there are times when repairs become necessary - for example, when loose or broken tiles have to be replaced, or when you have to fix a broken ceramic soap dish that is built into the wall inside a tub or shower enclosure.

title: Future Events
description: Dutch and Other Treats

title: Army Develops Robot For Loading Howitzers
description: A howitzer-loading robot capable of handling the work of several soldiers on the battlefield is being prepared for use by American troops in the 1990's, the Army says.

title: FILLING SCHOOL POST A PROBLEM
description: STAMFORD and New Haven have recently learned that a search beyond the school system for a new superintendent can turn up qualified candidates, but can also turn into an unforeseen controversy.

title: A ROUGH WEEK FOR FELDSTEIN
description: The battle between Martin Feldstein, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, and the White House over tax increases and the deficit broke wide open last week. After Mr. Feldstein's office published new statistics supporting his contention that taxes must be raised to reduce the budget deficit, Presidential spokesman Larry Speakes openly reprimanded the chief economist. At a news conference, Mr. Speakes noted that the White House was opposed to any tax increase and Mr. Feldstein should therefore stop campaigning for one - or resign. Despite the pressure, Mr. Feldstein issued a statement that he was determined to stay, unless asked to leave by the President.

title: Illinois Justices Reject Move To Permit Cameras at Trials
description: The Illinois Supreme Court has refused to lift its longstanding ban against the taking of photographs or television pictures inside trial courtrooms.

title: TALENTED ACTORS ENRICH A FINE SCRIPT
description: Let's get one thing straight immediately: James L. Brooks's ''Terms of Endearment'' is not a perfect movie. This comedy about a middle-class Texas widow, her daughter and their respective lovers sort of meanders around a plot that covers approximately 30 years. It contains one more fatal illness than you may want to witness, and every now and then Mr. Brooks's sit-com background (''The Mary Tyler Moore Show,'' ''Rhoda,'' ''Lou Grant,'' Taxi,'' etc.) is apparent in the film's inability to resist a fast response that may not be entirely in character with the person responding.

title: RECITAL: MARTHA ANNE VERBIT
description: Martha Anne Verbit, a thoughtful and perceptive pianist, opened her recital Thursday evening at the Abraham Goodman House with two selections by Franz Liszt. Her performance of one of the composer's ghostly late works, ''To the Memory of Petofi,'' had an appropriately wan quality, while the earlier ''Funerailles'' made its usual clanging, rhetorical effect.

title: CORRECTION
description: An item in the Press Notes column Nov. 20 misidentified the news service operated by The Chicago Sun- Times and misstated its relationship to other newspapers. The Independent Press Service has 143 clients in the United States and 10 in Canada, to whom it distributes articles from The Sun-Times, the Newhouse News Service, The Boston Globe, the Sunpapers in Baltimore and The Dallas Morning News. The Sunpapers joined the service in 1979 and The Globe in 1980.

title: AMOUNT OF L.I.R.R. FARE RISE WEIGHED
description: TRANSIT officials, looking at their ledgers, are once again insisting that fares on the Long Island Rail Road must go up. The rise, they say, must be in the order of 50 percent - an even greater proportion than the fare increase contemplated for New York City's 75-cent token.

title: Reagan Assails Great Society
description: President Reagan said today that social programs were to blame for breaking up families, increasing dependency on welfare and spurring the number of births out of wedlock.

title: INDIAN POLICE RAIDTEMPLE AFTER SIKH CLASHES
description: Policemen firing tear gas broke up warring factions of Sikhs, then stormed the Sikhs' historic temple in Old Delhi today.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: For Booksellers, There Is a Santa Claus

title: IN 'HEARTBREAK HOUSE,' SHAW PORTRAYED THE DEATH OF OPTIMISM
description: George Bernard Shaw's life as a man of the theater began while Victoria still sat on the throne of England and proceeded well into the golden age of talking pictures. There are more than 50 plays in the canon; there is, naturally enough, a Shaw Society and, within academia, a flourishing Shavian industry. As much as the scholarly world can agree on anything about Shaw, ''Heartbreak House,'' which opens Wednesday at the Circle in the Square, is widely regarded as a towering achievement, indeed, along with ''St. Joan,'' one of his two masterworks.

title: Student Prevails In Foil
description: After 22 bouts in 12 1/2 hours, Andrea Metkus won the final bout of the Michael Alaux Grand Open last night. She accepted congratulations from many of the 100 female fencers who had been eliminated earlier in the day, but who had waited for the last exchange. Miss Metkus then left the gymnasium at the Fashion Institute of Technology to phone her home in Northridge, Calif.

title: THE NATION
description: Endorsements in a Presidential campaign often don't count for much, but the Rev. Jesse Jackson could benefit mightily from one he picked up last week. The chairman of the National Baptist Convention U.S.A. Inc. - the largest black religious organization in the country - formally declared for Mr. Jackson.

title: ; WESTERN POLLUTION GRACEFULLY RECEIVED
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 085867 -- No Title
description: A Knoxville, Tenn., woman remembered her hometown of Sault Ste. Marie by bequeathing stocks worth more than $1 million to the city, officials said this week. The will of Augusta Hursley Seal, who died at 97, names the city, a library, a former youth home and St. Mary's Catholic Church , as beneficiaries of 49,000 shares of Dow Chemical Company stock worth an estimated $1.5 million.

title: U.N. PERMITS USE OF ITS FLAG IN P.L.O. PULLOUT
description: The Security Council agreed unanimously today to permit embattled Palestinians loyal to Yasir Arafat to leave the Lebanese port of Tripoli under the protection of the United Nations flag, Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar announced.

title: EDITORS' CHOICE: THE BEST BOOKS OF 1983
description: For the 16th time, in its annual Christmas issue, The Book Review has chosen what it considers the best books reviewed in its pages during the previous year. This year there are 13 titles; last year's list had 12, the same as 1981. The split of last year's 12 was five books of fiction and seven of nonfiction. This year the edge is reversed - seven fiction, six nonfiction.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: LINCOLNIANA ON VIEW, CRUISING THE DANUBE
description: Exhibit Marks 175th Birthday Of Lincoln

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: THE disclosure that, through a kinship with the Morris family, Governor Kean is related to former Presidents Richard M. Nixon and Jimmy Carter is only one of ''many astonishing surprises,'' said Samuel Stelle Smith, a historian of Monmouth Beach, in discussing his recent book, ''Lewis Morris: Anglo- American Statesman'' (Humanities Press Inc., Highlands, N.J. 07716, $15.95).

title: INMATE SAID TO LEAD CULT MIXING SEX AND RELIGION
description: George Feigley, a former retail clerk, is in prison as a sex offender. The authorities say he nonetheless leads a small nomadic cult, made up mostly of women, that combines sex with religion and that may be responsible for the abuse of as many as seven children.

title: RULING PARTY WINS TAIWAN'S ELECTION
description: In a display of its firm hold on political life in Taiwan, the ruling Kuomintang captured 62 of the 71 seats in the legislature at stake in elections held on Saturday.

title: Flynt Arrested by F.B.I. For Ignoring Bond Rules
description: Larry Flynt, the publisher of Hustler Magazine, was arrested by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation tonight at O'Hare International Airport as he left an American Airlines flight.

title:
ABOUT MEN;
FOCUSING ON FRIENDS
description: Steve Tesich is the author of ''Summer Crossing,'' a novel, and of ''Breaking Away'' and other screenplays.

title: DANCE: ALVIN AILEY TROUPE INTRODUCES 'BLUESHIFT'
description: Two important pieces of news emerged from Friday night's performance by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater. One is that Donna Wood and Patrick Dupond danced so terrifically this time around in Mr. Ailey's ''pas de 'Duke' '' that no one should miss their final performance in it tonight before Mr. Dupond, a guest star from the Paris Opera Ballet, returns home.

title: BRITISH PRESS DISPUTE: MORE THAN FLEET STREET AT STAKE
description: New talks are to begin Monday in the industrial dispute that led last weekend to the temporary closing of all of Britain's national newspapers and this week to the worst outbreak of picket-line violence in the country since 1979. The labor unrest, it is widely agreed, has its roots in one of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's most important initiatives: her effort to limit trade-union power. It has therefore become a legal, industrial and political test case, with implications extending far beyond Fleet Street.

title: Hormone Found to Aid Women in Conception
description: Four women whose inability to conceive children had been traced to a certain hormone deficiency became pregnant and had healthy babies under a new treatment, doctors who took part in the process have reported.

title: LAWSUIT FILED IN DISPUTED MIDTOWN ELECTION
description: Two months after an election for Democratic district leader in midtown, which was fought as much in the courts as on the streets, many of the principals are back in court.

title: ; LIFE IN VIETNAM
description: I found Craig Whitney's retrospective, ''A Bitter Peace: Life in Vietnam'' (Oct. 30), provocative. However, I must respectfully disagree with his observation that ''only stones were left where American bases had stood - Camp Eagle, home of the 101st Airborne Division; the military airfield at Phu Bai. . .'' As a former NCO in the 101st who spent a short but incredibly intense part of my life at Phu Bai and Camp Eagle, I know with certainty that more is left there than a few stones - things like honor and comradeship, our former na"ivete and the blood of ourselves and others, in the sand. For those of us who fought there, Phu Bai and Camp Eagle remain something indelible - a place in our minds and memories, not just places on a map. PAUL A. SCIPIONE Metuchen, N.J.

title: SOLAR PLANT JOINS CALIFORNIA'S PUSH FOR NEW ENERGY
description: A large solar energy plant began partial operation here this week as one of hundreds of projects in California's drive to develop alternative energy sources. Some people expect such sources to supply 10 percent of the state's power needs by the end of this decade.

title: RETAILERS HAVING A VERY MERRY SEASON
description: THE year's Christmas shopping season has been under way for only a few days but the signs of a banner holiday business in Connecticut and elsewhere are already clear.

title: CORRUPTION AN ISSUE
description: Campaigning for this month's general election began officially today, with Japan's opposition attacking Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone's Liberal Democratic Party over the issue of political corruption.

title: PORTUGESE BANKS BOMBED
description: Bombs exploded early today outside two banks, in Caldas da Rainha and Leiria north of Lisbon, causing damage but no casualties, the police said.

title: 'Perfect Motel'
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Is Reported Ready To Indict Chicago Judge
description: A Cook County judge whose court chambers were bugged by the Federal Bureau of Investigation will be indicted as a result of a nationwide Federal investigation into judicial corruption, the judge's lawyer confirmed today.

title: No Headline
description: Babette Weil Is Engaged

title: ; THE REVIVAL OF THE PORTRAIT
description: Grace Glueck has chosen Alex Katz, Philip Pearlstein, Alice Neel, Andy Warhol, George Segal, Larry Rivers and Red Grooms as her candidates to illustrate ''The Revival of the Portrait'' (Nov. 6). These artists tend to feel that obtaining a likeness and satisfying clients is secondary to being paid to play their own stylistic games at someone else's expense.

title: THE MAN BEHIND THE MYSTIQUE
description: E. J. Dionne Jr. is a correspondent in The Times's Paris bureau. By E. J. Dionne Jr. DMISSION TO THE fashion collection was limited to those who had received engraved invitations, but the belle epoque ballroom of Paris's Hotel Inter- Continental, its enormous chandeliers and red- flocked wallpaper enhanced by massive floral arrangements, was filled to overflowing. The crush was not alleviated when the audience moved into the equally ornate atrium for the reception that followed. The television and print reporters were there, and they and the rest of those maneuvering around the fountain at the center of the room tried hard not to be rude as they vied for a peek at Yves Mathieu Saint Laurent.

title: THE BRITISH ARE COMING
description: A force of 100 British soldiers - the Black Watch pipes, drums and Highland dancers, supported by the regimental band of the Scots Guards - will march into the Byrne Meadowlands Arena tomorrow evening.

title: Suspect in Robbery Is Killed By an Off-Duty Transit Officer
description: An off-duty transit police officer shot and killed a robbery suspect in Brooklyn yesterday after the suspect lunged at him, the police said.

title: CALIFORNIA AUDITORS SAY PROGRAM TO CLEAN UP WASTE IS TOO WEAK TORRANCE, Calif. Dec. 3 (AP) - For the second year in a row, the California audit office has found deficiencies in the state program to control hazardous waste, despite official reports that significant gains have been made.
description: A report released by the audit office says the state ''still does not adequately protect the public . . . from the harmful effects of hazardous waste.''

title: MANY WOMEN IN POLL VALUE JOBS AS MUCH AS FAMILY LIFE
description: More than ever, American women think their place is on the job, a New York Times Poll shows. They generally regard work and independence as elements of life that are as satisfying as husbands, homes and children. The poll showed that men and women are growing much closer in their attitudes toward work outside the home, pointing up a dramatic shift since 1970, when a national poll sponsored by Virginia Slims found women cleaving to hearth and home. Thirteen years ago, 53 percent of the women surveyed cited motherhood as one of the best parts of being a woman, for example, and in the latest poll just 26 percent did. Work outside the home was more peripheral then, with only 9 percent of the women even listing it as an enjoyable part of their lives. This time, 26 percent did. Among the other key findings in the telephone poll of 1,309 adult men and women, conducted Nov. 11-20, were these: -Even if they could afford it, 58 percent of American working women would rather work than stay home; so would 31 percent of nonworking women. But while 70 percent of men in blue-collar jobs said they would rather work, just 43 percent of women in such jobs said so. They included factory workers, maids and waitresses. Forty-eight percent of working men were in blue-collar jobs, as were 27 percent of working women. -Forty-four percent of American working women said they had been discriminated against in the workplace, either in the present or former job.

title: Barbara Talcott Becomes a Bride In Massachusetts
description: Barbara Geer Talcott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hooker Talcott Jr. of Brookline, Mass., was married yesterday to Douglas Charles Borchard 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Borchard Jr. of Wayne, N.J. The Rev. Donald E. Bitsberger performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Chestnut Hill, Mass. He was assisted by the Rev. Steven Schenk, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: VOTE THIS YEAR IS IN DOUBT
description: Proponents and opponents of a bill that would require a 5-cent deposit on all soft-drink and beer containers sold in New Jersey debated for five hours at an ''informational forum'' on the bill convened by Assembly Speaker Alan J. Karcher.

title: NOTABLE BOOKS OF THE YEAR
description: The following list has been selected from titles reviewed since the Christmas Issue of December 1982. Such a list can only suggest the high points in the main fields of reader interest. Books are arranged alphabetically under subject headings. Quoted comments are from The Book Review. Autobiography & Biography AN ABYSS DEEP ENOUGH. Letters of Heinrich von Kleist, With a Selection of Essays and Anecdotes. Edited, translated and introduced by Phillip B. Miller. (Dutton. $16.95.) ''On the whole, the letters are sensitively translated by Mr. Miller, as are the essays and anecdotes, which include some of the finest pieces Kleist (1777-1811) wrote.'' AN AFRICAN IN GREENLAND. By Tete-Michel Kpomassie. Translated by James Kirup. (Helen and Kurt Wolff/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $14.95.) The author, a native of Togo in West Africa, pursued a boyhood obsession with Eskimos and eventually traveled to Greenland to live among them and report on their modern life.

title: WHAT OBLIGATIONS DO PRO ATHLETES HAVE TO THE FANS?
description: FEW persons, in and out of baseball, are unaware of the extraordinary influence of the

title: A LESSON LEARNED IN HOW TO SURVIVE 4 YEARS OF COLLEGE
description: Yes, college tuition is high. Yes, financial-aid programs have been cut back. Yes, the middle class seems to be hit hardest. So how is a student supposed to get through four years of college? I can tell you how others have done it, but you are not going to like it.

title: 'SO GLAD THEY'RE MAKING BABIES AGAIN'
description: IN the dusk outside the three-man tent where I was rearranging camping clothes, I heard my husband's friend talking to his 20-month-old son and my 13-month-old daughter. His words were indistinct, but his tone was unmistakable; that whimsical, lilting talk that adults often use when they are seduced into the world of the very young.

title: Q&A Proportional Shares Question:
description: I am buying a co-op loft apartment that is one of two units on a floor. One unit has about a third of the floor space and the other about two-thirds. Should the two units have a share allocation and maintenance fee that is equal or proportional? . . . G. Z., Stamford, Conn.

title: TEST CLUE TO BREAST CANCER ODDS
description: A recently developed test may give women with breast cancer a more accurate prediction of their chance for survival and give doctors a better idea of how aggressively to treat the cancer, researchers have reported.

title: RECOVERY GIVING LARGE SURPLUSES TO MANY STATES
description: State governments, which have been cutting services and raising taxes for two years to make ends meet, have suddenly found themselves facing the possibility of accumulating large surpluses because of the economic recovery and new taxes.

title: JERSEY UNION HEAD CRITICIZES PLAN ON TEACHER CERTIFICATION
description: The head of the state's largest teachers' union says a proposal to change teacher-certification procedures in New Jersey would turn untrained people ''loose to experiment'' with students.

title: Article 085910 -- No Title
description: The Governor's budget chief says that state agencies have overspent their allotted budgets by $19.5 million so far this fiscal year.

title: AFGHAN REBELS ARE SAID TO REMAIN DIVIDED
description: MilitaryAnalysis

title: IDEAS AND TRENDS
description: 'Squeal Rule'Is Abandoned

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: A young choreographer noted for breezy dances will be offering two premieres this week. But the week also includes rarely seen works by established choreographers.

title: TRAVEL
description: It wasn't so long ago that sailors were afraid they would fall off the edge of the world if they ventured too far into the Atlantic Ocean; and one early 19th- century explorer believed there was a hole at the North Pole opening into an interior chasm inhabited by albino races. Even in our own century, the maps of Africa and South America, not to mention the Arctic and Antarctic, contained vast interior blanks about which nothing was known. Distance has always held magic for the imagination. Beyond the horizon, there were giants and gods, hell or paradise; the golden city of El Dorado, or tribes with eyes and mouths in their chests. The world consisted of a small, sensible island of the familiar, surrounded by every wild flight of fantasy and nightmare.

title: UNITED PLANS CHICAGO FLIGHTS
description: EVEN as county legislators were taking action last week against what they perceived as expansion at the Westchester County Airport, United Airlines was making plans to become the second major airline to operate scheduled jet flights into the county.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest.

title: A THEATER REUNION FOR THE GOODSPEED
description: AN ''Annie'' was the first person to respond to the invitation; she was followed by a cat named Jenny Any Dots. The invitation, from the Goodspeed Guild of East Haddam's Goodspeed Opera House, was sent to 750 former cast, crew and orchestra members from shows dating back to 1975, the year that the Guild, the volunteer support group for the opera house, was founded. The invitation was for a reunion at the Minskoff Rehearsal Studios in New York City on Dec. 8 from 1:30 to 7 P.M.

title: Salazar Returns
description: Alberto Salazar , the ailing runner who has not run a marathon in 1983, will be among the starters today when he faces Tosihiko Seko and about 125 other runners in the 18th Fukuoka International marathon in Japan. Salazar, who turned in the world's best marathon time, 2 hours 8 minutes 13 seconds, in winning the 1981 New York City event and who also won the 1982 Boston Marathon, has been plagued with injuries since then.

title: No Headline
description: Jody Berger Is Bride

title: EXPANSION ON THE COTE BASQUE MENU
description: For years, Jean Jacques Rachou, the chef- proprietor of La C^ote Basque, had unsuccessfully pleaded his case for expansion of his restaurant in the building at the corner of Fifth Avenue and East 55th Street.

title: A RETROSPECTIVE CELEBRATES 21 YEARS OF MOVIE TEAMWORK
description: Annette Insdorf, an associate professor at Columbia and Yale, is the author of ''Indelible Shadows: Film and the Holocaust.''

title: On Conservation
description: To the Editor:

title: DISPUTE SNARLS CHAPIN BIOGRAPHY
description: RAGE and frustration seep into Peter Coan's voice when he speaks of what he says is an eight-year effort to write and publish a biography of Harry Chapin, the singer and songwriter killed in an automobile accident on the Long Island Expressway on July 16, 1981.

title: TOO MUCH FOOLISH '1984' ING
description: With 1984 just around the corner, an almost irresistible temptation can be discerned: to see everywhere signs of George Orwell's ''1984.'' Indeed, a recent television documentary claimed that more than 80 percent of Orwell's predictions about a nightmarish, centralized, all-seeing bureaucracy have already come true in contemporary America. A plethora of articles invoke Orwellian terms in order to denounce not only authoritarian regimes but also manifestations in Western societies: Military jargon and bureaucratic euphemism are the ''Newspeak'' issued by the equivalents of the ''Ministry of Truth''; modern methods of electronic surveillance, computerized data and closed-circuit TV are the relatives of ''Big Brother''; and anyone who dares challenge these simplistic analogies is guilty of ''Doublethink.''

title: SAYREVILLE IS FIRM ON SCHOOL 'SILENCE'
description: -year-old policy mandating a ''moment of silence'' in public- school classrooms in this Middlesex County community stood unchallenged and generally noncontroversial.

title: TEACHING DIABETICS TO CARE FOR SELVES
description: ''Our approach is a multidisciplinary approach - that's the key,'' said Dr. Richard L. Petrillo, director of medicine at Mount Vernon Hospital. He was explaining the hospital's diabetes program, which is conducted under the auspices of the Einstein- Montifiore Diabetes Research and Training Center in the Bronx, one of six federally financed diabetes-research centers in the country.

title: BLOCK SPEEDING FEDERAL GRAIN TO DROUGHT-STRIKEN FARMERS
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block has loosened eligibility rules for selling Government-owned corn to drought- stricken livestock producers so that feed will be available Tuesday.

title: HOW THE DAIRY LOBBY PUT THE SQUEEZE ON THE WHITE HOUSE
description: When President Reagan last week signed a dairy and tobacco bill that he didn't like, he seemed to be reconfirming some basic tenets of official Washington:

title: THE FAST TRACK OF FUTURES TRADING
description: N.R.Kleinfield is a reporter for The Times. This article is adapted from his book, ''The Traders,'' to be published by Holt, Rinehart & Winston in January.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: MOTORISTS heading west on the Long Island Expressway between Exits 48 and 49 - Round Swamp Road and Walt Whitman Road - have been startled by what appears to be the construction of a suicidally inclined new north service road.

title: PAKISTAN SAID TO ARREST 450 ON 80-MILE MARCH
description: The police have arrested about 450 opponents of Pakistan's military Government to halt an 80-mile protest march in the last few days in Kashmir, an opposition spokesman said today.

title: WESTERN CAROLINA UPSETS HOLY CROSS
description: Western Carolina upset Holy Cross, 28-21, today in a quarterfinal game of the Division 1-AA football playoffs.

title: Simply, Soccer Falls Short
description: I would like to take exception to Lucien Wepper's letter regarding the failure of the North American Soccer League (Mailbox, Nov. 27).

title: 76ER STREAK ENDED BY BULLETS
description: Ricky Sobers scored 29 points and Greg Ballard added 26 as Washington used a fourth-quarter surge to beat Philadelphia, 103-98, tonight.

title:
GARDENING;
COFFEE AND TEA: FROM CUP TO FLOWERPOT
description: MOST of us would find it difficult to get through the day without having coffee or tea. Both contain the stimulant caffein, which partially accounts for our dependence upon them, but their flavors are also appealing. Lingering over a warm cup of either beverage is in itself a means of relaxing or taking a break from our everyday tasks.

title: COMMON MARKET CHIEFS IN CRUCIAL PARLEY TODAY
description: In a meeting that may be crucial to the future of the European Economic Community, government leaders from member nations will gather here Sunday to discuss ways to strengthen the faltering organization.

title: HIGH-SCHOOL FOOTBALL
description: I love sports (''High-School Football: Playing for Keeps,'' by Craig Wolff, Oct. 30). I have raised five sons and three daughters who enjoy sports.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
A DISGUISED 'BONANZA' FOR FARMERS
description: -making has

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Being a wife doesn't say what you are or who you are.'' - Cecilia Bracero of New York City. (66:1.)

title: MORGAN'S BOLD PLAN FOR THE TEAMSTERS
description: LAST month, when executives from Morgan Stanley & Company wereTstill vying for the contract to manage the Teamsters' Central States Pension Fund, they did their best to tone down their image as aristocrats of investment banking.

title: IMMIGRATION BRINGING MORE LEPROSY TO U.S.
description: Carlos immigrated from Mexico in 1969, married and fathered two sons, now 6 and 11 years old. But he keeps a secret from his boys: Carlos has leprosy.

title: PHOTOS FROM TWO ERAS ON EXHIBIT AT WESLEYAN
description: -HENRI LARTIGUE and Cindy Sherman have alighted at Wesleyan University in Middletown much as the sewing machine and umbrella convened on an operating table in the mind of the poet de Lautreamont. The analogy is not as farfetched as it seems, for the extroverted Frenchman is 87 years old, the narcissistic American not yet 30 and all they have in common is the medium of photography and a closing date of Dec. 16.

title: ZONING LESSON SEEN IN WAKE OF BLAST
description: SOMETHING good may yet come from last weekend's fatal fireworks explosion at the Gruccis' Bellport manufacturing operation. ''This terrible tragedy involved a classic zoning failure,'' said Lee E. Koppelman, executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board. ''It could serve as a beacon to all governments to tighten the zoning reins, to examine themselves in a soul-searching way and look at every nonconforming zoning use.''

title: DOING SOMETHING DIFFERENT MUSICALLY
description: WHEN Milton Kraus answered a newspaper ad for a piano accompanist for the Long Island Opera Company two years ago, it was, he conceded, a little out of his usual line of work. Although in his 61 years as a professional musician (his Gold Card with Local 802 of the Musicians' Union dates back to 1922) he had accompanied Eleanor Steber and Robert Merrill, the veteran pianist, composer, conductor and arranger was more at home on the Broadway stage and radio and television than in opera's world of high C's.

title: LOOKING AT FOOTBALL AS IT WAS AND IS
description: IN ''Golden Boy,'' Clifford Odets

title: MONITORS DELIVER MORE THAN TV
description: If a new television set tops your Christmas shopping list, you might consider the alternatives.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY
description: STILL LIFE

title: SOUTH BRONX BOYS FIND INCENTIVE IN SCOUT TROOP
description: A dozen boys dressed in tan and green uniforms gathered around a campfire and tended a foil-wrapped meat loaf cooking in the coals, earning points toward their Boy Scout cooking skill badge.

title: VACATION PREVIEW OF 35 ISLANDS
description: Golden beaches, gentle seas, constant sunshine and dining under the stars are the shared attractions of all of the Caribbean islands, but the differences among the islands can be striking. Some are mere dots on the ocean, literally large enough to contain only one resort. Others are island nations with distinct heritages and a broad range of attractions for the visitor. As the winter tourist season approaches, the region's tourism officials are - as always - optimistic, their worries about the effect of the invasion of Grenada on hotel bookings in the region having receded. The string of Caribbean islands is bracing for the annual migration of ''snowbirds,'' and many resorts are heavily booked for the holidays.

title: WILLIAM ROESCH, AN EX-MECHANIC WHO BECAME HEAD OF U.S. STEEL
description: William R. Roesch, who started in the steel industry as a mechanic and rose to become president and chief executive officer of the nation's largest steel maker, the United States Steel Corporation, died from a brain tumor late Friday night in Montefiore Hospital in Pittsburgh. He was 58 years old.

title: WHERE ARE THEY GOING?
description: President Reagan and Prime Minister Shamir of Israel agreed here the other day to improve their political consultation and military coordination, but it's a vague and limited agreement at best.

title: Jean Gilbane Has Nuptials
description: Jean Marie Gilbane, daughter of Mrs. Thomas Freeman Gilbane and the late Mr. Gilbane of Rumford and Narragansett, R.I., was married yesterday to Robert Alan Cole, son of Mrs. Charles W. Cole and the late Mr. Cole of Warwick, R.I. The Rev. William O'Halloran performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Cathedral of SS. Peter and Paul in Providence, R.I.

title: RAILROADS FIGHT TO SOUND WHISTLES IN FLORIDA
description: The warning whistle of the freight train will no longer pierce the night in some parts of south Florida if local officials have their way.

title: Book on the Life Of Dr. McClintock
description: I am concerned about a possible misunderstanding about my book on the life and work of Barbara McClintock that was invited by the article on Oct. 16 (''Organisms 'Speak' for Nobel Winner''). While it is true that my book is not an authorized biography, it is, at the very least, misleading to say that Dr. McClintock ''disapproved of the book.''

title: ARTS ENDOWMENT STARTS NEW GRANT PROGRAM
description: An experiment in raising funds for the arts, with Federal grants generating local tax dollars, has been initiated here and in 10 other areas of the country by Frank Hodsoll, chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: THEATER UNLIMITED'S 'FANNY'S ARROW' PUTS ACCENT ON YOUTH
description: WHAT would happen if Yente, the matchmaker from ''Fiddler on the Roof,'' carried on her business in heaven, a place where people have mundane jobs? Suppose she then returned to earth to partake of the ''sexual revolution,'' an activity she was denied before she died in her pre-medieval castle several centuries ago.

title: AMERICAN PLAYWRIGHTS MUST WIDEN THEIR WORLD
description: ''We're missing something,'' said the solemn young man to the solemn young woman as they left Vaclav Havel's ''A Private View'' at the Public Theater. ''My God, are we missing something!'' Maybe they had bad colds and were simply yearning for Kleenex. Maybe they were anguishing over their sex lives. More likely, given the setting, their concern was that emotional hothouse, the American theater. To share Havel's wry perceptions of compromise and integrity in bleak Czechoslovakia is, after all, to realize that there are other subjects available to the dramatist than self-discovery, self-fulfillment, and the raveled relationships of husband and wife, lover and lover, father and son, mother and daughter, mother and son, brother and brother, sister and . . .

title: MANAGUA LOOSENS ITS GRIP, TO A POINT
description: The Sandinista Government stepped up its peace offensive last week at a moment when its political power seems secure but foreign alliances are weakening and economic prospects are poor. Insurgent forces pose only a limited military threat but they have contributed to a climate of extreme internal tension. These pressures, together with the urgings of friendly governments and a growing desire to ease the country's intense economic and social conflicts, are apparently behind Sandinistas' concessions to foreign adversaries - notably the United States - and domestic critics.

title: IN EUROPE, IT'S STILL FULL SPEED AHEAD FOR NUCLEAR POWER
description: Despite the oil glut, a marked decrease in energy consumption and slow economic growth, France, Britain, Germany, Italy and many other countries are working to increase their reliance on nuclear power. It is a sign of their governments' conviction that more nuclear energy means less oil dependence, and that nuclear power is a comparatively reliable, inexpensive and safe way to produce electricity.

title: Taking a Cue From Golf
description: I'm a bigger fan of tennis than golf, but I thoroughly enjoyed watching Arnold Palmer, Gary Player, Jack Nicklaus and Tom Watson battle it out head to head for big money in ''The Skins Game'' last weekend.

title: LIMOGES, HOME OF FINE PORCELAIN
description: So allied are the names of Limoges, the town in the Lot region of France, and Haviland, the manufacturer of porcelain, that people have mistaken the former as a trademark of the company. In fact, the production of porcelain in Limoges is something of a cottage industry, while the Haviland firm, founded in 1842 - and by an American, at that - is generally regarded as being among the premier manufacturers. Its artisans have included such notables as Gauguin, Monet and Dali and it numbers among its clients Presidents of the United States as well as heads of state in Europe and Asia.

title: CHOOSING A CHRISTMAS TREE
description: IN A SEASON when shoppers are

title: GIVE PEACE A CHANCE
description: ''Oh Come All Ye Faithful'' and ''Jingle Bells'' may be what you'd expect to hear around Christmastime, but ''All Together Now'' and ''Give Peace a Chance'' might fit right in with the spirit of the holiday too. Words and music for these and other Beatles songs appear in THE COMPLEAT BEATLES, a two-volume, $39.95 boxed set produced by Delilah Communications/ ATV Music Publications and distributed by Bantam Books.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Thomas Dolby: Live Wireless Thorn-EMI Video 58 minutes. $29.95.

title: CUSTODIAN OF HALLWAYS AND HEARTS
description: Who is the most important adult in your child's school? If you ask a kindergartner, you might get a surprising answer. When my daughter started school, she quickly sized up the situation in the classrooms and corridors of her new environment. It was obvious that each teacher was lord or lady of his or her own domain, the individual classroom, but it was also clear that someone else had to be in charge of the realm as a whole. According to my daughter's shrewd observation, that person was Bob, the custodian.

title: SUFFOLK AND SOVIET: WHAT'S TO HIDE
description: SUFFOLK COUNTY now has something in common with Anchorage, Atlantic City, Cleveland, Dallas, Denver, Detroit, Indianapolis, Phoenix and Seattle. Not to mention Hawaii, the entire Mississippi River and Bayonne, N.J. And Long Island officials are in a quandary as a result.

title: NICE TO HAVE A MAN AROUN THE HOUSEF912
description: PEOPLE are watching a red Colonial house on Route 25 in Mattituck these days. The word is that a new character is going to be added to the cast that makes up the holiday displays on the porch and lawn of the Wines' house.

title: Ballet Official Resigns
description: Richard Thomas Sr. has resigned as vice president of the New York International Ballet Competition. The competition is scheduled to take place at City Center next June and July. Mr. Thomas, a noted teacher at the New York School of Ballet and co- founder of the competition with Ilona Copen, its president, cited a disagreement over the selection of a competition judge as his reason for resigning.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: ''KIRK to Enterprise,'' Captain Kirk said into his communicator, with that authoritative wag of his head that tells his audience and the universe, Everything's going to be all right, no matter what happens. The captain looked slightly green, but then so did everything else; our color set was probably as old as ''Star Trek'' itself. I took another fat spoonful of green ice cream.

title: No Headline
description: Alfred H. Heineken , of beer fame, and his chauffeur were apparently none the worse for wear when they were found chained in unguarded concrete cells behind a false wall in a warehouse.

title: EHAT MY HOUSE KEEPS TELLING ME
description: SINCE buying our first home on the Island two years ago, I have learned there are three ''sacred walls'': the Great Wall of China, the Wailing Wall in Israel and a support wall in my home. Any other wall is fair game to my hammer and crowbar. My husband introduces me as his personal ''homewrecker.''

title: EMP CAN'T STOP AMERICAN NUCLEAR RETALIATION
description: To the Editor:

title: THE PAPER INDUSTRY ON A ROLL
description: CANTONMENT, FLA. WINDING its way south, the tractor-trailer roars past stand after stand of longleaf and slash pine, which shoot straight and tall out of the red clay soil. After a 50-mile drive from Alabama, the truck finally reaches the St. Regis paper mill's wood-receiving gate in this northwestern Florida town.

title: Reagan to Speak at College
description: President Reagan has agreed to visit his alma mater, Eureka College, in February to inaugurate a Time magazine program in which people who have appeared on its covers will speak at colleges around the country. An exact date has not been set. Mr. Reagan is a 1932 graduate of the small private school in central Illinois.

title: A PATRON REVISES HIS PLANS
description: Paul Fromm, a retired wine importer, is one of the most important private patrons for contemporary music, having through the Fromm Foundation commissioned more than 150 compositions over the last 30 years. Each summer, Mr. Fromm has also been a co-sponsor of Tanglewood's annual Festival of Contemporary Music, a festival which has become known as ''Fromm Week.'' But Mr. Fromm said in an interview last week that the foundation will no longer be a co-sponsor of the Festival with the Boston Symphony. Moreover, during the last three months, Mr. Fromm has initiated changes in his foundation which are likely to have a strong effect on activity in the new music world. And in the midst of the reorganization he has also endowed a Fromm Foundation Visiting Professorship of Music at Harvard University, which, one semester every three years, will be given to a composer of international reputation.

title: WORLD CHAMPIONS LEADINGIN BRIDGE
description: Six world champions, past and present, were in the lead at the midpoint of the Reisinger Team Championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here tonight.

title: FRESH HERBS MAKE FRAGRANT WREATHS
description: THERE are all sorts of ways to fashion holiday wreaths and every household may have its favorite. But there is something special about those designed by Reba Roorbach of New Canaan. They are made from fresh herbs and they even smell good.

title: U.S. MOVE AWAITED ON WASTE
description: -YEAR dispute between Connecticut and Massachusetts over the release of phosphorus into the Housatonic River might be finally settled this month by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency.

title: With Leverage
description: To the Business Editor:

title: IN EDUCATION PARENTS ARE KEY
description: THREE years ago the Coleman report, a widely published study of American education, demonstrated that a significant difference in the academic achievement of private school students lies in the aspirations of parents and their ability to communicate these aspirations positively to their children. The same holds true for parents of public school students. All parents - regardless of education level and economic status - are interested in the academic achievement of their youngsters.

title: Suit Charges Coroner Erred
description: The parents of a teen-ager killed in an automobile accident have sued the county coroner and a funeral home for $1.5 million, charging they were given the wrong body for service and burial. The bodies of James Pate, 18, and another young man were burned beyond recognition in the May 1981 accident. A parent, Doris Hardy, testified in Circuit Court that she had nightmares and extreme stress since her son's body was misidentified, buried, exhumed and reburied.

title: WOLFPACK TOPPLED BY VA. TECH, 89-65
description: North Carolina State, the defending national champion, was upset by Virginia Tech today, 89-65, and had a 15-game winning streak ended.

title: TIPS FOR TAKING BETTER PORTRAITS
description: The main reason many portraits do not succeed is because the photographer does not get close enough to the subject. Photographs of tiny specks on the horizon do not convey much about the unique characteristics of an individual subject.

title: THE WORLD
description: Japan's members of Parliament last week sallied forth to the electoral wars. Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, bowing to opposition party demands, dissolved Parliament six months ahead of the end of its four-year term and set the vote for Dec. 18.

title: EXILED ARGENTINE REBELS VOW TO RETURN IN PEACE
description: Five exiled leaders of the Montoneros leftist guerrilla movement have announced that they will return to Argentina soon to pursue their political objectives by peaceful means.

title: STATE'S SKIERS ARE OPTIMISTIC
description: NATURAL snow has been slow in coming to Connecticut's recreational skiing centers this season, but operators from the Powder Ridge area in Middletown in the south to Mohawk Mountain in the north expect a good year nonetheless.

title: NEW TRAINING RULES CONFRONT CONSTABLES
description: AFTER closing up his egg farm on Fridays, Kalervo Ruuskanen, a constable in the town of Canterbury, used to patrol the town's 67 miles of roads in his own Chevrolet. He might stop a speeder or someone running a stop sign, in an effort to increase police visibility in a town covered by the state police barracks in Danielson.

title: THE NOVELIST WHO WAS BORN OLD
description: AN AMATEUR LABORER By Theodore Dreiser. Edited and introduced by Richard W. Dowell, with James L. W. West and Neda M. Westlake. Illustrated. 207 pp. Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania Press. $25.

title: IN BATTLE OVER CIVIL WAR-ERA CEMETARY, IT'S RYE AGAINST RYE
description: THE graves of soldiers who more than a century ago fought to preserve the Union are embroiled in another civil war, this time on more familiar ground.

title: WHAT DOES TODAY'S MUSIC OWE TO THIS QUARTET?
description: By an astrological quirk, four of the most influential composers of our time, two dead and two still at work, celebrate milestone birthdays this month. Anton Webern and Edgard Var ese would have been 100 on Dec. 3 and 22, respectively; Olivier Messiaen and Elliott Carter will be 75 on Dec. 10 and 11. Understand, I am talking now about influence these key figures have exerted on other musicians, not necessarily about the current popularity of their music or its chances for enduring. But that sort of influence, if it becomes pervasive enough, can bend the course of musical history even if the public never comes around to agreeing with the insiders' judgment. The diminished but continuing and probably enduring influence of Arnold Schoenberg is a case in point.

title: VOICES, ALONE AND TOGETHER, CAPTURE THE SPOTLIGHT
description: Will Crutchfield is a freelance writer on music and records.

title: L.I. MEDICAL SCANNER READIED
description: FOR the first time on Long Island, a revolutionary machine that can depict the inside of the body without the use of radiation will be available for experimental use on patients. The device, called a nuclear magnetic resonance (N.M.R.) scanner, is scheduled to begin operation later this month at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset.

title: Ronnie L. Bloom Will Wed in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Bloom of Brookline, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ronnie Leah Bloom, to Richard Frederic Summers, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Summers of Merion Station, Pa. A May wedding is planned.

title: LIBEL AWARDS NOT TAXABLE, COURT DECIDES
description: At a time of multimillion-dollar libel judgments, a Federal appeals court in California has some good news for successful plaintiffs: They do not have to pay income tax on the damage payments they collect.

title: Sarah Van Eenenaam Plans to Marry in June
description: Dr. and Mrs. David Owen Van Eenenaam of Watertown, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Grace Van Eenenaam, to Jeffrey Butler Hanson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jon F. Hanson of Bedminster, N.J.

title: POLAND PREPARES FOR UNREST OVER FOOD PRICES
description: The Government said today that in preparation for possible protests this month over food price increases, it was forming a special committee to maintain public order.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN SAN JUAN
description: Puerto Rico has a bewildering, almost schizophrenic quality that makes it virtually unique in the Caribbean: It is half Spanish and half Anglo-American. The primary language is Spanish, but most Puerto Ricans, at least in San Juan, have some knowledge of English and pepper each language with expressions from the other. The colonial area of Old San Juan is typically Spanish while the banking district of Hato Rey could not be more downtown American. The mix is the result of the fact that for 400 years the island was a colony of Spain. Since 1952 when Puerto Rico ratified its own constitution, it has been a commonwealth freely associated with the United States.

title: 3 EX-INSURANCE AIDES GUILTY OF FRAUD INVOLVING FAKE CAR ACCIDENTS
description: Three former supervisors with the company that handles assigned-risk auto insurance applications in New York State have been convicted of fraud charges stemming from a fake- accident ring.

title:
INVESTING;
INVESTING IN WHAT YOU KNOW BEST
description: THE president of Remington Products, clad in a

title: HERE TO STAY
description: He was a grim man and he stared grimly out of the television screen with what he obviously thought was a grim message. ''Like it or not,'' he said, ''the computer is here to stay.''

title: ART DECO BUILDING IN PERIL
description: HARTFORD WHILE a wrecker's ball swings a few doors away, efforts are being made to save the Harvey & Lewis Building, one of Hartford's first Art Deco-style buildings.

title: A.T.&T. HEADS FOR THE UNKNOWN
description: ON Jan. 1, Charles L. Brown will wake up to a new world. The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, which he heads, will have shrunk overnight from the largest business in the world to just another giant company out to prove itself. Its assets, more than $150 billion on New Year's Eve, will have dwindled to roughly $34 billion on New Year's Day. Its revenues and employee ranks will have plummeted, too, with the dawn of 1984.

title: O TANNENBAUM
description: In the Baltic port cities of Riga and Reval in the early 16th century, members of the merchants' guilds had a festive dinner and then carried an evergreen tree adorned with artificial roses to the marketplace where they danced around it and burned it. These were the earliest ceremonies known to involve Christmas trees, according to Phillip V. Snyder, the author of THE CHRISTMAS TREE BOOK: The History of the Christmas Tree and Antique Christmas Tree Ornaments (Penguin, $10.95), an oversized paperback replete with illustrations in black and white and color.

title: 'BEYOND THE FRINGE' IN A WITTY UPDATE
description: MADISON WITH no newly topical, satirical spoofs to speak of, it isn't a bit unsettling to settle for the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival's reworking of ''Beyond the Fringe'' at Drew University, even though this is the festival's third revival in 17 years of the British revue and Broadway success.

title: Judith Dale Nichols to Become a Bride in Summer
description: Mr. and Mrs. William H. Nichols Jr. of Cumberland Foreside, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Judith Dale Nichols, to Karamjeet Singh Paul of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hardyal Singh Paul of Bhopal, India. A July wedding is planned.

title: SOVIET TIGHTENS THE POLITICAL REINS ON UNIFORMED POLICE FORCE
description: The Soviet Union, in an unusual move, has introduced a system of political commissars into the uniformed police force.

title: GUSSYING UP RAVIOLI
description: ORE changes have taken place in the cooking world during the past decade or so than at any other period in living memory. Home cooks are turning out moussaka, gravlax and gazpacho without so much as a second thought that such dishes may well have been totally unknown to their mothers or grandmothers. Croissants, little heard of 10 years ago, have become something of a plague in specialty shops all over the island of Manhattan.

title: SHOULD BLOOD FLOW ON STAGE?
description: ''Is this a dagger which I see before me?,'' is, of course, Macbeth's question, but we have

title: SUNDAY, DECEMBER 4, 1983 International
description: Israel bombed guerrilla bases in Syrian-controlled mountains east of Beirut. Its fighter-bombers struck soon after an Israeli soldier was killed in a guerrilla ambush in southern Lebanon. The bombing was in retaliation for a ''long array'' of attacks on Israeli troops in southern Lebanon, the Israeli military command said. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: QUESTION AND ANSWER
description: Question:

title: THINKING SMALL FOR 'NUTCRACKER'
description: Children always had a special part in the work of George Balanchine. The personal thrill he himself felt when, at 11, he was put on the St. Petersburg Imperial Ballet stage as Cupid in ''The Sleeping Beauty'' always stayed with him. Children are prominent in at least three of his last 10 ballets - in ''Mozartiana'' four girl ballet students accompany the ballerina; in the ''Adagio Lamentoso'' from Tchaikovsky's ''Pathetique'' Symphony, a little boy is the final image; and in the ''Garland Dance'' from ''Sleeping Beauty,'' a chain of 16 small girls weaves through the waltz.

title: TEACHER OF THE YEAR
description: ''IN an when we talk about teacher burnout, we have a man here who is still on fire,'' said Connecticut's Commissioner of Education, Gerald N. Tirozzi. He was speaking of 63- year-old Roger A. Morrissette of West Hartford, the state's new Teacher of the Year.

title: POLITICAL POTHOLES AHEAD FOR TRAVELING DEMOCRATS
description: Two groups of Democratic Presidential candidates will head north and south Monday on a two-day swing that party officials had hoped would raise $1.9 million in a highly publicized festival of unity. Instead, some Democratic leaders privately acknowledge, it has become an exercise in damage control.

title: OUTDOORS: BASS FISHING IN HELL GATE
description: BEFORE first light, the New York City park from which we launch the trailered boat seems much like any semi- wild coastal shoreline with pheasant and rabbits in the bramble and killifish darting about in the clear shallows. Upon sunrise, the incongruity of our location and our purpose becomes apparent. Hell Gate, the narrow East River channel at the near geographical center of the city between Manhattan and Queens, is an autumnal way station for migratory striped bass.

title: PURCHASING AIDES CITE GAINS
description: The economy continued to expand at a brisk pace in November, the National Association of Purchasing Managers said in its monthly report, which was issued for publication today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: From Paper, Things of Beauty

title: A MATTER OF PRESENT VERSUS FUTURE
description: Robert D. Squier is among the growing number of Democratic political thinkers who believe chronology may be more important than ideology in the next Presidential election.

title: TV: SINGING OF DISABILITIES OF 7 WOMAN
description: ''TELL THEM I'M A MERMAID'' is a half-hour musical performed by seven women with physical disabilities. Accordingly, it can be patronized, solemnized or sentimentalized, however one sees fit. Still, free yourself from all that. ''Tell Them I'm a Mermaid'' is a brisk piece of work with an intelligent charm, dandy in its modesty. It will be seen on WNEW-TV, Channel 5, at 8:30 tonight.

title: South Koreans Sink Spy Boat From North
description: South Korean forces sank a North Korean spy boat and captured two armed enemy agents in a clash along the southeastern tip of the Korean peninsula on Saturday, the Defense Ministry announced today.

title: LIFESURANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a tax loss of $52,447 for the quarter and a tax credit of $181,352 for the 9 months. c-Operating loss. d-Net loss.

title: Jody Hermanson Marries Robert Todd Brackman
description: Jody Phillips Hermanson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Hermanson of Wellesley, Mass., was married yesterday to Robert Todd Brackman, son of Audrey Bernstein of Lawrence, L.I., and the late Arthur Brackman. Rabbi Albert Axelrad performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: HONDAS BUILT IN U.S. ACCEPTED
description: Honda is happy that American car buyers are not turning their backs on its popular Accord just because some of the cars are now being made in Ohio and not Japan. The first Japanese-designed cars built in America are being widely accepted by consumers who previously refused to buy domestically produced cars.

title: Sabres 6, Canadiens 2
description: Sean McKenna led the way with two goals. Mike Foligno, Paul Cyr, Mike Moller and John Tucker also scored as the Sabres got the first six goals of the game. Claude Lemieux and John Chabot tallied for Montreal.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Golden Memories

title: Hostage-Taker Out on Bond
description: A man accused of ramming his pickup truck through a gate and taking hostages at a Georgia golf club in an attempt to talk to President Reagan was released Friday on a $150,000 property bond. Charles Harris, 44 years old, of Appling, Ga., was released after a ''number of people'' signed the bond, said Charles Toole, the county jailer.

title: WHY T.V.A. CAN'T LET THE ENERGY DEPARTMENT OFF THE HOOK
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Two Also-Rans

title: ISLANDERS DEFEAT OILERS
description: Each year, since 1980, the Islanders have been the Stanley Cup champions. And, as the years have passed, the Oilers have emerged as a top challenger, with expectations of taking the title away with their speed, finesse and high-scoring lines.

title: CORRECTION
description: A real estate article Friday on the proposed conversion of the Dunbar Apartments in Harlem to a cooperative incorrectly reported the position of the State Attorney General's Office. Because no conversion plan has been filed with the office, it has not taken a formal position.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST MONDAY, DECEMBER 5, 1983
description: Companies American Standard plans to acquire Trane for $512 million in Standard stock. The merger would unite two leading names in plumbing fixtures and air-conditioning equipment. (Page D1.) Honda Accord models built in Ohio are being accepted by buyers. Some dealers had anticipated that customers would only want those made in Japan. The cars are virtually the same. (D4.)

title: TV: DRAMA OF CHURCHWOMEN SLAIN IN EL SALVADOR
description: WHILE conflicting evaluations of the political and military situation in El Salvador continue to flow out of Washington, a television movie on NBC at 9 tonight forcefully makes the case for basic human rights. ''Choices of the Heart'' portrays the country as being run by murderous thugs whose chief victims are the poor and the helpless.

title: INFO DESIGNS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Comparable year-ago earnings figures are not available because the company went public in May.

title: Ballet Theater Troupe Promotes Two Dancers
description: American Ballet Theater has announced the promotions of Robert La Fosse and Susan Jaffe to principal dancers.

title: MET-PRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: A Different Rivalry

title: Reagan Pledges Aid For Israel in the U.N.
description: President Reagan said today that the United States would quit the United Nations if Israel were ever expelled from the world organization.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''What are you Americans doing here? What is everyone in the multinational force doing here - the Italians, the British, the French? You say you come to help us.

title: LFE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
Eastern in Union Talks
description: Eastern Airlines said today that it ''might be getting close'' to completing negotiations with union leaders to help the struggling carrier solve its financial problems. There were indications that an agreement could come early this week.

title: Ellyn Debra Kessler, A Lawyer, Is a Bride
description: Ellyn Debra Kessler, a lawyer in private practice, was married yesterday to Michael A. Gentile, a lawyer for New York State. The ceremony was performed in the Rainbow Grill at Rockefeller Center by Milton Mollen, Presiding Justice of the Appellate Division in Brooklyn.

title: FOR VICTIMS OF AIDS, SUPPORT IN A LONELY SIEGE
description: Cold in a warm hospital room, Stephen Lamb pulled his yellow blanket tighter around his emaciated body.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Asarco Inc. has extended its tender offer for an aggregate of $54,385,000 principal amount of 1976-A and 1976-B series of Nueces River Authority 7 3/8 percent environmental improvement revenue bonds due in 2006.

title: DRESDNER'S INDICTED CHAIRMAN
description: Hans Friderichs, the 52-year-old politician-turned- chairman of the Dresdner Bank who was charged last week with pocketing $140,740 in bribes from the giant Flick holding company while serving as the country's Economics Minister in the mid-1970's, never really cracked the tight group of West German bankers that runs the nation's financial affairs from Frankfurt and D"usseldorf.

title: BANK OF NOVA SCOTIA reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Revenue figures represent interest income. The Bank of Nova Scotia is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: STAGE: 'CROSSFIRE,' ON VIETNAM WAR
description: There is a taut thriller and a thoughtful study of doves and hawks in Vietnam in the body of ''Crossfire,'' a new drama by Theodore Faro Gross being done by Double Image Theater at the Intar on West 42d Street, but, like a sculpture, it has yet to be hewn out of the script surrounding it.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: PITCH DARK. By Renata Adler. 144 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $12.95.

title: 5.4% Growth In G.N.P. Seen
description: A steadily expanding recession-free economy was projected for 1984 by the Conference Board in its annual Economic Forum reports, issued

title: TOP TEAMS EYEING '84 KICKOFF CLASSIC
description: Now that the matchups for the bowl games are set, some of the best teams are looking toward college football's only preseason bowl: the Kickoff Classic at Giants Stadium in the Meadowlands.

title: COAST FEDERAL SAVING & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $1,487,434 for the quarter and $3,341,716 for the 9 months.

title: WOMEN IN STATE LEGISLATURES SPEAK OUT
description: Listen to Martha Ezzard, a former newspaper and television reporter who entered politics as a Colorado State Senator, talking about the tightrope many women feel they walk as women and elected officials: ''You've got to choose your battles carefully if you're going to be effective. It's a hard lesson but crucial. If you run around screaming about women's issues all the time, you lose effectiveness.''

title: MANY OFFERINGS OF HOUSING BONDS
description: The Treasury will not be offering any notes or bonds this week, but state and local governments are continuing to sell tax-exempt issues at a near record pace.

title: FIVE GIVEN KENNEDY CENTER AWARDS
description: Five Americans were honored today by President Reagan with the closest thing that the United States has to Federal recognition in the arts, the Kennedy Center Honors for lifetime achievement.

title: Indiana 3, Virginia 1
description: Mark Laxgang scored two goals today as Indiana, the defending champion, reached the final of the N.C.A.A. tournament for the fifth time in eight seasons.

title: WEINBERGER SAYS U.S. SEEKS TALKS ON THE 2 MISSING FLIERS
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said here today that the United States is trying to get in touch with the Syrian Government for the return of the American crewmen of one of the two downed aircraft, who were believed to have been captured.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Insure Deposits, Not Risks
description: Federal bank deposit insurance is one terrific idea. Since it was established in 1933, hundreds of banks have gone broke, but no depositor has lost a federally insured penny. Nor is any ever likely to. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has $13 billion in reserves, another $3 billion in Treasury credit and a moral obligation from Congress to cover any insured losses. It's not only deposits that are protected. Public confidence is, too. The insurance system prevents ''runs'' on weak banks that could jolt the economy.

title: CLASS ACTIONS PAY FOR SOME LAWYERS
description: For Melvyn I. Weiss, every corporate mishap is a new opportunity.

title: S. D. Melnitsky, a Lawyer, Marries Nancy J. Denholtz
description: Nancy Jane Denholtz, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Myron Denholtz of Maplewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Sheldon David Melnitsky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Melnitsky of Hicksville, L.I. Rabbi Irwin Goldenberg performed the ceremony at the Chanticler banquet facility in Millburn, N.J.

title: WOMEN FROM STATE LEGISLATURES HEAR TWO DEMOCRATIC CANDIDATES
description: Women at the conference talk about their experiences as elected officials. Page B10.

title: U.S. ANALYSTS UPGRADE OPINION OF SYRIAN UNITS
description: Military Analysis

title: SOME BUYERS SHUN LONG-TERM ISSUES
description: The shamans and gurus of the credit markets continue to disagree about the direction of interest rates and are still juggling reasons for expecting rates to fall with reasons for expecting rates to rise.

title: Imports of Chicken Banned
description: Canada and Switzerland, fearing the spread of a new deadly strain of avian influenza, have banned the import ,n01 of chickens raised in Pennsylvania and New Jersey, David Goodman, a spokesman here for the United States Department of Agriculture, said today. He said he would not be surprised if other countries took similar action. Mr. Goodman said he could not estimate the economic effect of the ban on the poultry industry in the two states, where about 4.5 million birds have been killed in an effort to stop the disease from spreading.

title: GRUCCI BLASTS' SEQUENCE THE ISSUE IN L.I. INQUIRY
description: The cause of the fatal explosions at the Grucci fireworks complex here is still eluding Federal and county investigators after more than a week.

title: GIANTS LOSE, 10-6
description: On Oct. 24, the last time the Giants met the St. Louis Cardinals, they played a 20-20 overtime tie in a game that will long be remembered for ineptness. Today, both teams outdid that performance, at least on offense, but this time there was a winner.

title: Publisher Sends Offer To Buy St. Louis Paper
description: A magazine publisher who wants to buy The St. Louis Globe-Democrat says he has sent financial data and a $2.5 million ''full- blown proposal'' to lawyers for the Herald Company, which owns the money-losing paper.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: In match play between two golfers, the third shots of each land on the green. Player A, farther away from the pin, concedes Player B's putt, picks up his opponent's ball and rolls it to him. He then sinks his own putt, but Player B claims the hole is his because Player A tested the green by ''rolling a ball on the green.'' Is he correct?

title: Attack on Israelis Reported
description: An Israeli soldier and two Lebanese civilians were wounded today when a group of armed men threw hand grenades at an Israeli military convoy on the coastal road south of here, local security sources said. But an Israeli Defense Forces spokesman in Sidon denied that any such incident had taken place and said all was quiet in Israeli- occupied southern Lebanon. The security sources said grenades were thrown as three Israeli trucks and a jeep were going through a crossroads about six miles from Sidon.

title: TEKTRONIX INC reports earnings for 12 wks to Nov 12
JAPAN INDUSTRY'S U.S. TEACHER
description: When Japanese industrial leaders gathered recently to honor three of the country's biggest companies, the prize that was bestowed was named for a 79-year-old American engineer whose teachings have been a cornerstone of Japan's vaunted cost-effectiveness.

title: VOTING IN TAIWAN IS A SIGN OF GAINS
description: The Kuomintang's particularly one-sided victory in Saturday's elections for the national legislature represents an acknowledgment by the voters of Taiwan that the ruling party has progressed in three related areas of social change, officials said today.

title: Winning Playwright Arriving for Readings
description: Richard Gordon, who won the 1983 McDonald's Lorraine Hansberry Award for playwrights, today begins one aspect of his prize, a trip to New York, where actors will read his play in a nonperformance workshop.

title: KASPAROV AND KORCHNOI ADJOURN COMPLEX GAME
description: Gary Kasparov of the Soviet Union and Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland adjourned the sixth game of their semifinal world championship chess match tonight in a complex ending.

title: Moscow Issues Report On Downing of Planes
description: The Soviet press agency Tass and the Moscow radio reported today that two American planes were shot down over Syrian- controlled territory in Lebanon.

title: FRENCH ASK TRADE CURB ON THE U.S.
description: President Francois Mitterrand of France called on the Common Market today to further curb imports of agricultural goods from the United States. He said new restrictions were needed because of overproduction by European farmers and the strain that that is putting on the finances of the European Economic Community.

title: Argentina Said to Free 43 Political Prisoners
description: Argentina's military Government released 43 political prisoners this weekend, a week before the country's return to democratic rule, a human rights group said today.

title: SALAZAR PLACES 5TH
description: Amid cheers from his countrymen in the Athletic Stadium, Toshihiko Seko pulled ahead of Juma Ikangaa of Tanzania 150 meters from the finish and won the 18th Fukuoka Marathon in 2 hours 8 minutes 52 seconds today. Alberto Salazar of the United States, who led until the last three kilometers, finished fifth.

title: Resch of Austria First in Downhill
description: Erwin Resch of Austria won the first men's downhill race of the World Cup ski season today, and four other Austrian skiers finished in the top 10.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE ;
description: OH, CINEMA One score and some years ago, the New Wave was rippling through French filmdom. It brought with it such names as Godard and Truffaut and different ways of telling a story. Now there are new generations of movie makers and it is only appropriate that La Maison Fran,caise of Columbia University should be giving New Yorkers a festival called ''20 Years after the New Wave: Young Film Makers in France Today.''

title: MORE STEEL CLOSINGS EXPECTED
description: The production capacity of the nation's steel industry is likely to shrink at least 10 percent over the next two or three years, analysts say. The first of a new wave of plant closings and write-offs, they predict, will be announced by the United States Steel Corporation later this month.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day Nov. 25 about the Getty Oil Company incorrectly reported when Gordon P. Getty became a director. It was in July 1976.

title: Toys 'R' Us Ends Suits
description: Toys ''R'' Us Inc. said that General Mills Inc. and its Izod subsidiary and Federated Department Stores Inc. had agreed with Toys ''R'' Us to dismiss without prejudice the toy chain's suits against them. Toys ''R'' Us had charged the three with conspiring to withhold children's wear from its Kids ''R'' Us discount unit.

title: Senior Hinckley Sets Drive
description: The father of John W. Hinckley Jr. has founded a nonprofit group to inform the public about mental illness. Jack Hinckley speaking at a Friday luncheon of the Virginia Mental Health Association, said the American Mental Health Fund would use advertisements to change what he called negative attitudes about the insanity plea, which his son used after he shot President Reagan.

title: BROWN MAY HEAD AMERICAN LEAGUE
description: Bobby Brown and Yogi Berra, who began their major league careers with the Yankees in 1946, are headed for new jobs this week at baseball's annual winter meetings.

title: CAPITAL MARKET STEP AT MARINE MIDLAND
description: Richard C. Keller, an executive vice president at the Marine Midland Bank, is a manager who has seen the size of his staff increase nearly fivefold in six months.

title: MUSIC: GROUP IS RECREATING 'DANIEL' STORY
description: ''DANIEL AND THE LIONS,'' the Ensemble for Early Music's newest re-creation of 12th-century liturgical drama, has returned for five performances at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine this month. The first on Saturday was a smoothly attractive blending of research and guesswork, mixing ritualistic gesture with more naturalistic acting and featuring singing styles which, in much the same way, lay somewhere between modern vocal technique and the flat primary colors we associate with medieval music.

title: NICARAGUA SAYS MOST EXILES, INCLUDING REBEL SOLDIERS, CAN RETURN
description: The Government formally announced today that nearly all Nicaraguans who had left the country since the revolutionary victory in 1979 were free to return without punishment.

title: NEWPORT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
DANNERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
Pope Pleads With Guerrillas
description: Pope John Paul II appealed to Colombian guerrillas today to release President Belisario Betancur's brother, Jaime, who was kidnapped last month. Vatican sources, noting that the Pontiff had made frequent appeals for kidnapped Italians, said it was the first time he had intervened in the case of a non-Italian.

title: STEEGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Cessna Purchase
description: The Federal Express Corporation said that it had agreed to buy 30 Caravan One aircraft from the Cessna Aircraft Company for use in the small- and medium-sized marketplaces served by Federal Express.

title: Half-Baked Half-Loaf of Lebanon
description: It's hard to know what to make of the past week's negotiations and aerial escalations over Lebanon except that President Reagan and Israel's Prime Minister Shamir have joined in a ''strategic'' plan to lighten each other's political burdens.

title: FOR LEBANESE, CRASH UNCHAINS A NEW HORROR
description: Like most of her neighbors, Isabel Thabet was sleeping this morning when a United States Navy light bomber crashed into the house across the street and exploded.

title: SYRIA ASKS HELP TO STOP 'AGGRESSIVE POLICY' OF U.S.
description: Foreign Minister Abdel Halim Khaddam of Syria called today for international and Arab action against what he called America's aggressive policy in Lebanon and the Middle East.

title: INCOME AND S.A.T. SCORES: 'POSITIVE NEWS'
description: To the Editor:

title: IVORY COAST OUSTS EXILED EMPEROR
