description: The former leader of the Central African Republic, Emperor Bokassa I, has been expelled from his exile in Abidjan by President Felix Houphou"et-Boigny of the Ivory Coast. The French Foreign Ministry announced that Emperor Bokassa arrived today in Paris.

title: MONDAY, DECEMBER 5, 1983 Fighting in Lebanon
description: The U.S. bombed Syrian targets in Lebanon as fighting there increased sharply. Two American carrier jets were shot down, and eight marines were reported to have been killed during an intense artillery attack by Syrian-backed militiamen. Sixth Fleet warships then opened fire on militia positions. The American air raid, which followed an Israeli air strike in the same area east of Beirut 24 hours earlier, was directed against Syrian antiaircraft batteries and involved 28 American fighter-bombers. (Page A1, Column 6.) The U.S. is prepared to strike again at Syrian positions in Lebanon, President Reagan warned, if American forces there are again attacked. Mr. Reagan was said by aides to have personally approved the bombing raid on Syrian antiaircraft batteries (A1:2.)

title: FOES OF NUCLEAR ARMS RACE ORGANIZE FOR '84 CAMPAIGN
description: Several major groups opposing the nuclear arms race are forming new lobbying or political action committees through which they will seek to play an influential role in the 1984 elections.

title: DRUSE FORCES TO LIFT THEIR SIEGE OF CHRISTIAN TOWN
description: A three- month siege of a Christian town in the Shuf Mountains is to be lifted by Druse militia forces, a Druse spokesman announced today.

title: SOVIET DISSIDENTS FEAR NEW LAW MAY ADD TO SENTENCES
description: The Soviet Government has added a new law to its books that dissidents fear will be used to stretch the labor-camp terms of political prisoners.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Interpublic Transfer

title: GRENADA AND LEBANON BRING A RUSH OF MEDALS
description: Since the Revolutionary War, American soldiers have been awarded military decorations for gallantry in battle and participation in military campaigns.

title: MAJIK MARKET SHOPPERS TOLD OF MESA-GULF ISSUE
description: The struggle between the Mesa Petroleum Company and the Gulf Oil Corporation was carried on last week not only in boardrooms but also in convenience stores, courtesy of Dillard Munford, an Atlanta businessman.

title: SICILIANS PROTEST AT MISSILE BASE
description: Antimissile demonstrators formed a six- mile human chain today in an attempt to link Catania with a United States naval base where NATO nuclear missiles are stored, witnesses said.

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 5, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Miss Handman Weds Harold M. Ickes
description: Laura Rose Handman and Harold M. Ickes, both lawyers, were married yesterday. Bernard S. Meyer, Associate Judge of the New York Court of Appeals, performed the ceremony at Roosevelt House at 47 East 65th Street.

title: ACCORD REACHED ON HOW TO USE M.A.C. SURPLUS
description: Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch have agreed in principle on how to spend an estimated $1 billion surplus that the Municipal Assistance Corporation says it will be able to generate over the next five years, top city and state officials said yesterday.

title: ADMINISTRATION IS HOPING TO FORCE COURT TO CONFRONT RACIAL QUOTAS
description: News Analysis

title: Polish Police Break Up Pro-Solidarity Gathering
description: Police officers broke up a gathering of about 500 people at a coal mine in Katowice today as Solidarity activists turned the traditional coal miners' holiday of St. Barbara's Day into a salute to workers in the union underground.

title: Devils Rout Red Wings, 6-0
description: The beleagured Devils, who have come to regard ties as moral victories, defeated the Detroit Red Wings tonight, 6-0, in front of 8,582 fans for only their fourth victory. They have now beaten the Red Wings twice this season.

title: SERVED AS A COUNSEL FOR TWO PRESIDENTS
description: Sherman E. Unger, the general counsel of the Department of Commerce in the Reagan Administration since 1981 and a former official of the Nixon Administration, died of cancer Saturday at Georgetown University hospital. He was 56 years old.

title: AMERICAN STANDARD IN TRANE PACT
description: American Standard Inc. and the Trane Company, two leading names in plumbing fixtures and air conditioning equipment, said yesterday they had agreed to merge in an exchange of stock valued at more than $512 million.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Season for Smiling At Metropolitan Museum

title: SWASHBUCKLING OILERS NOW AIMING AT CONSISTENCY
description: EDMONTON, Alberta

title: MONDAY SPORTS Football
description: Detroit Lions vs. Minnesota Vikings , at Pontiac, Mich. The teams are tied for first place in the Central Division of the National Conference.

title: CONCERT: KATHLEEN BATTLE SINGS BACH
description: KATHLEEN BATTLE'S concert at Alice Tully Hall last night seemed almost a conscious rejection of the song recital format. There were no French or Italian songs, no lieder, no operatic extracts, but in their place, Bach, spirituals and jazz.

title: CALIFORNIA WALKER LOSES SUIT OVER DETENTIONS FOR LOITERING
description: A California man who won a United States Supreme Court verdict overturning a state vagrancy law under which he was arrested or detained more than a dozen times has lost a $120,000 damage suit against the 12 police officers who had arrested him.

title: BARBER-GREENE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Sales figures for both 1982 and 1983 have been restated to reflect deconsolidation of Brazilian operations and discontinuation of mining and industrial market operations.

title: COMMUNITIES IMPERILED BY AIRLINE DEREGULATION
description: To the Editor:

title: A COSTLY POLICY
description: In a series of conciliatory steps the Sandinista Government of Nicaragua has now reached plans for an amnesty for many of its ''counterrevolutionary'' opponents and for an election in 1985 in which they could take part.

title: Washington WatchJonathan Fuerbringer Shifts in Report On Economy
description: WASHINGTON THE Council of Economic Advisers is busy

title: CommoditiesElizabeth M. Fowler Gold Theft Spurs Rise In Silver
description: ASINGLE event involving one commodity often has a rippling effect on another. That happened last week, when the theft of $39 million of gold from a British warehouse caused both gold and silver prices to rise sharply, much to the dismay of those who sold silver short.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*9.82

title: PIEDMONT NATURAL GAS CO reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Medical Services, Milwaukee, has named Allen L. Sampson executive vice president and chief executive officer, R. Max Sampson executive vice president and chief operating officer and Mary Jo Pencikowski vice president.

title: OPPOSITION CANDIDATE IN VENEZUELA WINS EASILY
description: Jaime Lusinchi, the candidate of Venezuela's opposition Democratic Action Party, won an easy victory in today's presidential election.

title: B.B.D.O. Changes Staff At Its Detroit Office
description: James H. Berline, 37, once the No. 2 executive at the Detroit office of Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, is being brought back to run the place.

title: STAGE: 'BABY,' A MUSICAL EXPLORING PARETHOOD
description: ''When you're pregnant, your emotions run all over the place,'' says a mother-to-be in ''Baby,'' the new musical at the Barrymore. ''Baby'' runs all over the place, too, but never so far afield that it forsakes those intimate emotions. At a time when nearly every Broadway musical, good and bad, aims for the big kill with gargantuan pyrotechnics, here is a modestly scaled entertainment that woos us with such basic commodities as warm feelings, an exuberant cast and a lovely score. Perfect ''Baby'' is not, but it often makes up in buoyancy and charm what it lacks in forceful forward drive.

title: Goodyear Pipeline
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company's proposed plan to build a 1,200 mile oil pipeline across the Southwest would probably cost $700 million to $800 million, Robert Mercer, the company's chairman, said.

title: TENTATIVE GREYHOUND PACT STILL CALLS FOR PAY CUTS
description: A tentative agreement in the month- old Greyhound bus strike still calls for a pay cut of 7.8 percent, but the overall package is significantly better than a company proposal rejected last week, union sources said yesterday.

title: Israeli President Plans Visit To 3 African Nations in 1984
description: President Chaim Herzog will visit Zaire, Liberia and Swaziland in January, the Cabinet announced today.

title: JEWELED CUFFS OVER GLOVES
description: This winter there are two accessories every woman will probably want to wear if she isn't already: gloves and bracelets. The gloves should be long; the bracelets should be big. Some will probably want to wear them separately. But the new way to do it is to wear the glove and the bracelet, so big it is known as a cuff, together, with the bracelet on top of the glove.

title: MASSIALAS DEFEATS MARX IN FOIL FINAL
description: The final bout after an exhausting day of fencing left the winner saying: ''I fooled him. I conned him into my plan.'' The loser went off to the side and said: ''This is ridiculous. I can take him and he knows it.''

title: MINERALS ENGINEERING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: COLUMBIA WINS, 4-0, GAINS SOCCER FINAL
description: Columbia became the first Ivy League team to reach the title game of the National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer tournanent, as it scored a 4-0 victory over Connecticut today.

title: DOLPHINS CLINCH DIVISION
description: Tony Nathan ran 5 yards for a touchdown with 3:51 to play today to rally Miami from a 17-7 third-quarter deficit to a 24-17 victory over Houston that clinched the Dolphins' 11th American Conference Eastern Division championship.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption in Business Day Saturday incorrectly identified George Ball. He is chairman and chief executive of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc.

title: HOUSTON IS TELLING ITSELF IT'S 'GOT WHAT IT TAKES'
description: Hard on the heels of an advertising campaign aimed at dispelling any notion elsewhere in the country that Houston is just a broad-shouldered cow town, a group of boosters is raising a million dollars for a campaign to buck up the home folks and reassure them that their city has still ''got what it takes.''

title: DEREGULATION ALTERS BANKING
description: The big spender who thrived on borrowed money has turned into a loser. His opposite, the conservative saver who for years watched his nest egg being nibbled away by inflation, suddenly is a winner. There are other losers, too: poor people, small businesses and homeowners. And there are many winners: travelers, money market funds and people seeking greater convenience.

title: CHOICES FOR NEW YORK ARE DEBATED AT FORUM
description: More than 150 public officials, professors and representatives of private groups gathered this weekend in a mansion on the North Shore of Long Island for a conference that contrasted poverty with plenty in a tale of two New York Cities.

title: F.B.I. Issues Warning On Leftist Theft Gang
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has warned banks and armored car services nationwide that a left-wing group prone to violence may have been responsible for the theft of $582,000 in five robberies, it was reported today.

title: Woman Is Arrested In Heineken Kidnapping
description: The police arrested a female suspect today in the kidnapping of Alfred H. Heineken, but the search continued for three other people in the abduction of the brewery chairman and his chauffeur.

title: THE KREMLIN'S HELP IN U.S. ARMS CONTROL
description: To the Editor:

title: FIVE DEMOCRATIC CANDIDATES CRITICIZE REAGAN FOR AIR STRIKES
description: Five Democratic Presidential candidates criticized the Reagan Administration today for the United States air strikes on Syrian positions in Lebanon.

title: A MESSAGE FOR DAMASCUS
description: News Analysis

title: TEAM USA: A NEW SPIRIT, STYLE AND SUBSTANCE ALL ITS OWN
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn.

title: THANKS GLADLY GIVEN
description: To the Editor:

title: FITNESS IS GOAL OF COACH
description: The game was over, the crowd began filing out, and Team Canada left the ice as satisfied winners. At the opposite end of Kellogg Center in Battle Creek, Mich., however, members of the United States Olympic hockey team suddenly started sprinting up and down the ice.

title: NO SHIELDS BETWEEN YOU AND HIGH PRICES
description: The price of Calvin Klein jeans, Cuisinarts, Lenox china, Danskins, Apple computers, London Fog raincoats, Izod shirts, Van Heusen shirts, Pioneer stereos, Cricketeer suits, Seiko watches and many other name-brand products is likely to rise dramatically if the Administration prevails in a case before the Supreme Court today.

title: Train Derailment in Pakistan Halts All North-South Traffic
description: All rail traffic between northern and southern Pakistan was halted for several hours after a 10-car freight train derailed en route to the capital, the police said today.

title: YARDNEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
OWNER PLANS EXPANSION FOR WEIN AIR ALASKA
description: Wien Air Alaska begins flying to Oakland, Calif., on Dec. 16. For Gene Flood, its owner, the move represents a strategy to survive by expanding ''outside.'' He believes growth opportunities are limited ''inside,'' meaning in Alaska. The state's population is sparse, he points out, and new competitors such as United Airlines are making inroads there.

title: GIANTS LOSE, 10-6
description: The Jets moved a step closer to a berth in the playoffs today, struggling to a 10-6 victory over the Colts.

title: THE 2 WORLDS OF CYPRUS: TURKISH FAMILY'S STORY
description: Until recently you could hear Turkish Cypriot and Greek Cypriot soldiers shouting jokes and insults at each other across the green line, the corridor that divides the island into their separate zones.

title: AWAITING EXECUTION
description: A t 10 A.M. Wednesday, I found it too easy to visualize what Robert Austin Sullivan was going through as he awaited his execution at the Florida State Prison at Starke.

title: SUPPORTIVE HOME CARE FOR CANCER PATIENTS
description: Their lives intersected for only three months, but during that time Eloise Monzillo and the Joe Flahertys were linked tightly together - by jokes and laughter, by curses and rage, by a battle to subdue pain and by the specter of death.

title: SHAMIR CALLS RAID BY U.S. REASONABLE
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said today that the Reagan Administration's decision to bomb Syrian antiaircaft positions in Lebanon was ''reasonable,'' and hoped it would encourage the Syrians to avoid an ''all-out war.''

title: VATICAN SEEKS TO MEDIATE U.S. AND SOVIET RIFT
description: Agostino Cardinal Casaroli, the Vatican Secretary of State, said today that the Vatican was trying to play a mediating role between the United States and the Soviet Union, but did not think ''very conciliatory results'' were attainable.

title: BRIEFING
description: Hawkeye Hustings

title: 76ers Top Celtics In Overtime
description: Moses Malone sparked an 11-2 spurt with two quick baskets in overtime as the Philadelpia 76ers scored a 121-114 victory over the Celtics tonight.

title: WIEBOLDT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Includes a gain of $1.2 million on the sale of real estate.

title: Welcome Focus on Rental Housing
description: The new Federal housing law will create about 100,000 dwelling units. Compared with the need, that's almost trivial. An estimated 27 million people live in rental housing that is either substandard or too expensive. Still, it's progress and constitutes the first comprehensive housing legislation in three years.

title: GLENN'S BACKERS WORRY ABOUT FIELD ORGANIZING
description: In Iowa and New Hampshire, the sites of the first two battles of the 1984 Presidential campaign, a consensus has emerged that John Glenn, the Democratic candidate with perhaps the strongest natural appeal, has one of the weakest campaign organizations in the field.

title: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan Smaller Stocks Struggle Along
description: THE Dow Jones industrial average, which is

title: Bridge; Oswald Jacoby Leads Rally In Final of Reisinger Teams
description: A group of world champions continued to lead in the Reisinger Board-a-Match Team Championship as the American Contract Bridge League's Fall National Championships neared an end here tonight, but one of the game's great veterans was leading a charge by the defending champions.

title: SOVEREIGN CHEMICAL & PETROEUM PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FOWLUPS IN GARDEN
description: THE Garden was packed Saturday night. The last previous time it had been filled for a game against the Houston Rockets was Jan. 6, 1973, when the Knicks were about to win the league championship, and might have filled Madison Square Garden playing a Bantam Division team in the Police Athletic League.

title: CLAUSEN REBUFFED ON U.S. AID
description: Rebuffing an 11th-hour plea from the president of the World Bank, A. W. Clausen, the Reagan Administration has decided to hold its commitment for aid to the poorest countries to a relatively restrictive $750 million a year, according to high Administration officials.

title: Italian Defense Chief Voices Concern Over Lebanon Raids
description: Defense Minister Giovanni Spadolini of Italy voiced concern today over the rising violence in Lebanon as American planes for the first time bombed Syrian Army positions there.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF THE PRESIDENT'S NEWS SESSION;
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news session on the South Lawn of the White House this afternoon concerning the events in Lebanon, as recorded by the White House: OPENING STATEMENT

title: FIRE AT STATEN I. FERRY TERMINAL
description: A two-alarm fire last night heavily damaged a city-owned office building attached to the Staten Island ferry terminal at St. George, S.I.

title: BIG HOLIDAY SELLERS OFFBEAT AND COSTLY
description: With demand high for gourmet dog biscuits at $10 a pound, $75 walking sticks sporting duck ornaments and $2,000 evening handbags, the Christmas shopping season just under way has already produced a list of best sellers ranging from the unusual to the most luxurious.

title: INTREPID BATTLING FINANCIAL TROUBLES
description: Attendance at the Intrepid Air-Sea- Space Museum at 46th Street and the Hudson River has been significantly below expectations, and officials say that more outside financing is needed to keep the converted aircraft carrier open.

title: RACE IS ON TO SAVE OPERA HOUSE
description: Fund-raising letters are being written. The T-shirts have already been designed and printed. Charity concerts are scheduled, as are dances, film festivals and a bake sale or two.

title: VILLAGE SUPER MARKET INC reports earnings for 12 wks to Oct 22
Teen-Age Pregnancies Dip After Sex Education
description: The teen-age birth rate dropped 10 percent in three years in Arkansas schools that offered sex education, officials of the Arkansas Family Planning Council said today.

title: Drug Testing Authorized
description: The Athletics Congress, citing ''a step in the right direction,'' authorized today testing for use of illegal drugs at championship track and field events and at selection meets for teams that compete internationally.

title: VW to Proceed With New Rabbit
description: Volkswagen of America Inc. said that it is proceeding with a $200 million program to introduce a new Rabbit subcompact in the United States late next year. The nation's fifth-largest auto maker said most of the investment will go for equipment at its Westmoreland, Pa., assembly plant and South Charleston, W. Va., stamping facility. The rest of the money will go for training and dealer programs, VW said.

title: ROZIER UNEASY IN HEISMAN GLARE
description: Mike Rozier fidgeted in his seat and asked his mother for the time as the hourlong Heisman Trophy television special continued Saturday night at the Downtown Athletic Club. The feeling was similar to waiting for the stroke of midnight on New Year's Eve, when the suspense seems manufactured and the result inevitable. The Heisman winner was to be named in the final five minutes of the show, but because Rozier was a clear favorite he looked more impatient than nervous.

title: UPSETS IN AUSTRALIA
description: It was a time for strong nerves at the Australian Open tennis championships today, with Pat Cash scoring a dramatic victory, Ivan Lendl struggling to win and John Lloyd registering an upset.

title: Beached Pygmy Killer Whale Is Living, But Experts Worry
description: The last of three rare pygmy killer whales that beached themselves on the Texas Gulf Coast was doing well today, and that worried the marine biologists caring for her.

title: CANADIAN TO HEAD U.S. BOOKSELLERS
description: Bernie Rath, executive director of the Canadian Booksellers Association, has been named executive director of the American Booksellers Association.

title: Accord Reached to Buy Ad Information Unit
description: Interactive Market Systems, a business information company that last summer won the Publishers Information Bureau account from Leading National Advertisers, said last week that it had agreed to buy L.N.A. from the Miller family.

title: RANGERS HOLD OFF NORTH STARS, 6-4
description: The Rangers had labored tirelessly all night, straining especially hard at their defensive chores, and the hard work was paying off admirably, in the form of a 5-2 lead.

title: CROWN BOOKS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
COMP-U-CARD INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: WHEN ONE SPOUSE RETIRES
description: HE has been working a long time. He has gone about as far as he can go at the advertising agency. The days at work follow one another in a circle of boredom. He looks with fondness at the idea of retirement: a time to do all the things he has not had time to do. And the company will make early retirement financially worth his while.

title: CAMBEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $108,000. c-Net income including a tax credit of $28,000.

title: Fighting Unions' Bids Denied
description: A Federal district judge has denied requests from both sides in a dispute between the International Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union and an affiliate, the National Hospital Union.

title: NEEDIEST CASES FUND DONORSCITE WISH TO CARE AND SHARE
description: Explaining why they give to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, many donors cite a need for caring and sharing.

title: DANCE: 2 NEW YORK PREMIERES BY ALVIN AILEY
description: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater's 25th-anniversary celebration continued throughout last weekend. There were two New York premieres by Mr. Ailey - ''Isba'' and an excerpt from ''Au Bord du Precipice'' - at the City Center on Saturday. Three outstanding guest stars, Carmen de Lavallade, Ulysses Dove and Patrick Dupond, who performed at the opening gala, stayed on to dance with the company all week.

title: Advertising; Sock Line Helps New Agency
description: HOW will you remember 1983? At Cluett, Peabody & Company, some may remember it as the year when it tested the national advertising waters in behalf of its Gold Toe socks and then decided to jump in.

title: DISMISSED MINISTER REFUSES TO GIVE UP PULPIT
description: A pastor being sued by his congregation because he refuses to be dismissed led a service in church today while the man chosen to replace him presided over separate worship in the basement.

title: REAGAN ISSUES WARNING; ; 8 MARINES KILLED
description: Fighting in Lebanon increased sharply today, beginning with an early morning American air strike on Syrian targets east of here in which two United States carrier jets were shot down.

title: ASTRONAUT MENDS A SHUTTLE CAMERA
description: Like a tourist going back to a darkened motel room to fix a jammed camera, Dr. Robert A. R. Parker turned out the lights inside the space shuttle Columbia today, zipped himself inside his sleeping bag and freed the stuck film in a mapping camera.

title: STEELERS LOSE BUT RETAIN LEAD
description: On a raw, gray afternoon at Three Rivers Stadium today the Steelers lost again. The Cincinnati Bengals brushed aside the Pittsburgh team, 23-10, giving the Steelers their third straight defeat.

title: ; COMMUNITIES IMPERILED BY AIRLINE DEREGULATION
description: To the Editor:

title: ON THE SIDE OF DEATH
description: Not many Presidents have defined their values by a single act as unmistakably as President Reagan did last week. By an abrupt veto he undercut his own Administration's efforts to curb the right-wing death squads in El Salvador. He considered protection of torturers and murderers a price worth paying for ''victory.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Small Memorial Sprouts in Brooklyn

title: FORD IS PROGRESSING ON HIS ROAD BACK
description: Every summer they all come home.

title: BERRA NO. 1 FOR NOW
description: IN the Yankees' eternal game of musical

title: HOW 2 CONGRESSMEN FORGED LOWER-INCOME HOUSING PLAN
description: When Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut and Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn went to Congress three years ago, they arrived with similar ideas about solving the national housing shortage for low- and middle-income families.

title: Australia to Open Latin Ties
description: Australia has agreed to set up diplomatic relations with Nicaragua, El Salvador and Honduras, Foreign Minister William Hayden said today. Diplomatic offices will not be opened in the three nations, but Australian officials will visit the countries to study conditions and organize humanitarian programs, including accepting political refugees, Mr. Hayden said.

title: 4 Break Out of Baltimore Jail
description: An intensive search was under way Saturday night for four inmates who broke out of the Baltimore City Jail. The police described three of the men as ''very dangerous.''

title: SYNCOR INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: ADVERTISING
description: Ford Hires Burrell

title: COSTLY FARM PRICE SUPPORTS ARE UNDER SHARPER SCRUTINY
description: In theory, the Government's farm support programs, designed during the Depression, are supposed to protect struggling farmers against wildly fluctuating prices at a modest cost to the taxpayers.

title: BRIEFS
description: Anta Corp., Oklahoma City, recommended to shareholders that they reject an offer of $25 a share from Manor Healthcare Corp.

title: RULE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes results from the Danforth Company that was acquired on May 27. c-Includes a gain of $433,000 from settlement of litigation.

title: 50 YEARS OF LEGAL DRINKING MARKED TONIGHT
description: Drinkers can raise a glass tonight to toast 50 uninterrupted years of legal imbibing.

title: Felixberto Olalia, 80, Is Dead; Led a Philippine Labor Group
description: Felixberto Olalia, a Philippine labor leader, died today of complications from a rheumatic heart and pneumonia, his family said. He was 80 years old.

title: REDSKINS TRIUMPH AND LOOK TO DALLAS
description: As Mel Kaufman picked up a fumble and returned it 30 yards for the touchdown that increased the Washington Redskins' lead to 27-0 over the Atlanta Falcons today, the fans in Robert F. Kennedy Stadium began the thunderous chant: ''We want Dallas . . . We want Dallas . . .''

title: JMB REALTY TRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including a gain of $573,109, or 81 cents a share, on the disposition of investment property.

title: The Calendar ;  Monday
description: This will be a week of royal visits at the White House, with President Reagan meeting with King Juan Carlos of Spain and King Birendra of Nepal.

title: PIERCE GERETY ST., EX-U.S. AIDE, DEAD
description: Pierce Joseph Gerety Sr., who was appointed by President Dwight D. Eisenhower to supervise the admission of refugees into this country after World War II and who also headed a ''loyalty board'' that scrutinized United States citizens working for international organizations, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Southport, Conn. He was 69 years old.

title: A LIST OF MISSING IN LEBANON RAIDS
description: The Defense Department has identified these Navy fliers who are missing after they were shot down in the attack on Syrian positions today: Missing LANGE, Lieut.

title: DETROIT'S MAYOR ANGERED BY BRIEF
description: The Justice Department's request that the Supreme Court dismiss the Detroit Police Department's affirmative action plan as unconstitutional has been denounced by Mayor Coleman A. Young as ''an all-out assault by the Reagan Administration on individual and human rights in this country.''

title: ADVERTISING
description: Accounts

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: 'Rough Diamond' in Queens

title: PROTESTERS SMASH MISSILE VEHICLE AT U.S. BASE IN WEST GERMANY
description: Four people, including an American priest, slipped into a United States Army base today and damaged a tractor of the kind used to transport Pershing 2 missiles, authorities said.

title: Vietnam Said to Prepare For Drive in Cambodia
description: Thai military intelligence officials said today that Vietnamese troops armed with Soviet weapons were massing in western Cambodia for an attack against Cambodian guerrilla units.

title: SOME WORDS FROM BERRA
description: There are some stories that, from the seed of a

title: Bell Canada Bid For TransCanada
description: Bell Canada Enterprises said it had agreed to buy Dome Canada Ltd.'s 11.8 percent interest in TransCanada Pipelines Ltd. for $134 million.

title: Fiat Unit and PPG
description: PPG Industries said it had agreed to purchase 65 percent of the stock of Industrie Vernici Italiane S.p.A., a subsidiary of Fiat S.p.A. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Charges by Nixon
description: Norm Nixon , the San Diego Clippers' guard, has told The Los Angeles Times that the Los Angeles Lakers, his former team, had him followed and investigated last summer to determine if he was using drugs, and that their surveillance extended to positioning a car across the street from his house. ''They couldn't find anything,'' Nixon said.

title: The Reluctant Landlord
description: In fiscal terms alone, it's frightening that New York City must spend $150 million a year to maintain occupied dwellings that ought to be paying city taxes. As a recent series of articles in The Times on this problem made clear, the issue is human as well as fiscal.

title: SUMMATIONS COMPLETED IN TRIAL ON $11 MILLION SENTRY THEFT
description: Jury deliberations are to begin today in the Federal trial of four men charged in the theft of $11 million from the Sentry Armored Courier Corparation.

title: MERRY-GO-ROUND, WASHINGTON STYLE
description: When the Rayburn House Office Building opened in 1964, members of the Appropriations Committee surprised their space-hungry colleagues by staying in their cramped quarters in the Capitol. Committee members thought they were sure to be assigned fine rooms in the proposed project to extend the Capitol West Front.

title: U.S. GIVES EGYPT ASSURANCES ON NEW ACCORD WITH ISRAEL
description: The United States has assured Egypt that the new American-Israeli strategic cooperation accord will not impede the search for peace in the Middle East, Egyptian officials said today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Not to Worry, Mr. Mayor

title: Books of The Times
description: J.M. Coetzee's ''Waiting for the Barbarians'' was an astonishment. By relaxing the prose style he had used in an earlier novel, ''In the Heart of the Country,'' and by generalizing his vision, the author succeeded in creating a tragic fable of colonialism that surpassed the boundaries of his native South Africa and made universal the agony of its conscience-stricken European protagonist.

title: Charlotte Curtis An Honor for Philip Johnson
description: THE feisty old Municipal Art Society spends its weekdays out fighting to save beautiful buildings, which may explain why its formidable board selected Sunday, a day on which even the Lord is thought to have rested, to stage its elegant black-tie dinner in honor of Philip Johnson.

title: Jersey Man Held InMother'sKilling
description: An unemployed man has been charged with the fatal beating of his 68-year- old mother in their home here, authorities said today.

title: Ex-Chief of Big Board Promotes Japan Exhibit
description: Japan is mounting an exposition in 1985 to display the futuristic technologies its big corporations have on the marketplace and in the laboratory. James J. Needham, former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange and once a commissioner of the Securities and Exchange Commission, is a staunch believer that American companies ought to be in on it, too.

title: CONTRIBUTORS TO NEEDIEST CITE THE POOR
description: To help the suffering and the unfortunate - that is the reason often given by contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Eva B. Neisser of Vineland, N.J., donated $50 in memory of her husband, Wolfgang Neisser, who died Nov. 23, 1982, and gave this explanation in a letter:

title: GLENN WINS BACKING OF A SOUTHERN GOVERNOR
description: Senator John Glenn won the endorsement of Gov. Charles S. Robb of Virginia today and used the occasion to renew charges that his chief rival for the Democratic Presidential nomination, former Vice President Walter F. Mondale, represented ''the special interests.''

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Daimler Chairman Was Dark Horse

title: CBS-INTRODUCING 5 NEW PROGRAMS
description: -TV, the leader in the prime- time ratings, will introduce five new programs next month. Like similar moves announced last week by ABC- TV and NBC-TV, CBS's midseason changes are an effort to increase its popularity on those nights of the week on which rival programs are achieving high ratings.

title: 7 NORTHEASTERN GOVERNORS SEEKING UNIFORM MINIMUM DRINKING AGE
description: The governors of seven Northeastern states agreed today to work toward establishing a uniform minimum drinking age in an effort to reduce alcohol- related highway accidents and fatalities.

title: Meridian Bancorp
description: Meridian Bancorp said it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire First National Bancorp of Allentown for about $71.6 million in cash and stock. First National has assets of $1.1 billion, and Meridian said the transaction would give it $4.8 billion in assets. It said stockholders would receive either $32.50 in cash or 1.3 shares of a new voting cumulative convertible preferred stock for each First National share.

title: ARGENTINE JUNTA MOVES TO YIELD POWER
description: Argentina's ruling military junta moved to dissolve itself today, according to military spokesmen, as the nation prepared for the inauguration Saturday of President-elect Raul Alfonsin.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE ;
description: VIEWPOINTS New York is full of hidden galleries, exhibitions that could be the centerpieces of institutions dedicated only to the arts but elsewhere are handsome adornments to premises with other primary functions. This is the case with the majestic New York Public Library at 42d Street and Fifth Avenue, where extraordinary exhibits are the rule in a a house dedicated to books.

title: 2 Royals Enter Prison
description: Willie Wilson and Jerry Martin, teammates on the Kansas City Royals last season, reported to the Federal Correctional Institution here today to begin serving three-month sentences for attempting to possess cocaine. The outfielders were among four Royal players who pleaded guilty to drug charges in October.

title: British Price Rise
description: Producer prices of manufactured goods in Britain rose four-tenths of 1 percent in November from October and were up 5.7 percent from November 1982, the Department of Trade and Industry said today.

title: HARNISCHFEGER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $5 million relating to certain foreign operations. c-Net loss. d-After a charge of $23.7 million for the quarter and year for a plant closing.

title: BLACK FAMILIES: BEYOND THE 'DEFICIT MODEL'
description: To the Editor:

title: NABU MANUFACTURING reports earnings for 13wks to Oct 1
description: The year-earlier figures were restated for an accounting change.

title: POLITICAL SURVIVAL: IT'S WOMEN AND CHILDREN FIRST
description: At the beginning of the current Congress, Representative Barbara B. Kennelly tried to interest her male colleagues on the Ways and Means Committee in a bill that would force absent parents to make child support payments. They would not even schedule hearings on the Connecticut Democrat's measure.

title: Miss Hanika Out
description: Ninth-seeded Kathy Jordan of the United States upset second-seeded Sylvia Hanika of West Germany, 7-6, 7-5, today in the quarterfinals of the Australian Open tennis tournament.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Off-Broadway Cats
description: Pedestrians in Times Square are accustomed to seeing homeless people on the sidewalk, but not to talking to them. Why would so many stop to chat with the woman who sits by a trash cart full of belongings, swaddled in layers of sweatshirts, a coat and something that looks like an old sleeping bag?

title: UNITED STATES CAPITAL reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income after extraordinary credits of $436,653 for the quarter and $983,938 for the 6 months.

title: GALA NIGHT AT MET HAILS SAINT LAURENT
description: Yves-Mathieu Saint Laurent, the Paris couturier who started at the top and stayed there, was honored last night at a glittering black-tie dinner- dance at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Guests previewed an exhibition of his work over the last 25 years, which has left a lasting stamp on 20th- century fashion.

title: TV: ADAPTED STEINBECK
description: Tonight's made-for-television movie on CBS-TV is billed by the network as ''John Steinbeck's 'The Winter of Our Discontent.' '' That's not quite true. This is Michael de Guzman's version of the 1961 Steinbeck novel, and at times the differences between the two go far beyond the always nebulous boundaries of ''dramatic license.''

title: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 6, 1983 International
description: An American flier will not be freed until ''the war'' is over and American forces leave Lebanon, Syria's Defense Minister announced. He confirmed a report that the other American airman in the attack bomber shot down Sunday had died and said his body would be delivered to the American Embassy. (Page A1, Column 6.) Moscow condemned the American air strikes against Syrian positions in Lebanon, terming them ''a serious threat to peace in the Middle East and not only in that region.'' (A18:2-5.)

title: Ditka Is Upset
description: An angry Mike Ditka , the Chicago Bears' coach, said yesterday the club was in the market for a new punter. Ditka's ire was raised after it was reported that Bob Parsons , the Bears' punter and a 12-year veteran of the N.F.L., had contacted the Chicago Blitz of the United States Football League about serving as a special teams coach or punter.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: COMTECH TELECOMMUNICAIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income. Results for the latest first quarter reflect a pretax charge of $700,000 from discontinued operations, a loss at the company's government systems division and also start-up costs at its voice communications products subsidiary.

title: Flynt Ordered Back to Coast
description: Federal Magistrate Olga Jurco ordered Larry Flynt, publisher of Hustler magazine, returned to Los Angeles today to face a charge that he desecrated the American flag. The magistrate left the courtroom when Mr. Flynt threw a Soviet flag at her and began swearing.

title: Tandy TV Deal
description: The Tandy Corporation's Radio Shack chain will market the direct satellite-to-home television service started recently by United Satellite Communications, the two companies said.

title: ; DETECTORS OF NEITHER LIES NOR THE TRUTH
description: To the Editor:

title: MONEY FIT FOR THE BLIND
description: To the Editor:

title: Comings and Goings
description: Coach Don Shula of the Miami Dolphins says that Dan Marino , the rookie starting quarterback, is ''very doubtful'' for Saturday's game against the Atlanta Falcons. Marino sprained his knee in Sunday's 24-17 victory over the Houston Oilers. . . . The Devils yesterday returned 19- year-old John MacLean to the junior team from which they had drafted him, the Oshawa Generals of the Ontario Hockey League.

title: TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
SHAER SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Key Rates
description: * Nuveen index, John Nuveen & Company Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SEAL FLEET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: MACHINES THAT CALL YOU UP
description: The best telephone salesman in J. Rudy Martin's insurance office, near Roanoke, Va., never gets angry, never breaks for lunch and, best of all, never forgets a name.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Denver Nuggets , at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. Kiki Vandeweghe and Alex English, two of the National Basketball Association's most prolific scorers, pay their only visit to the Garden this season.

title: 14 PEOPLE KILLED IN BEIRUT BOMBING
description: A car bomb exploded in a crowded quarter of mainly Moslem West Beirut today, killing 14 people and wounding 83 and setting several buildings and 30 cars on fire, the police said.

title: BLACK FAMILIES: BEYOND THE 'DEFICIT MODEL'
description: To the Editor:

title: I.B.M. and Rolm
description: The International Business Machines Corporation has increased its stake in the Rolm Corporation to 19.13 percent, or 4,982,482 shares, of the common stock outstanding, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Rolm, a telecommunications company based in Santa Clara, Calif., was off $1.75, to $54, today on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: NCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
'WINDOWS' AND 'GATEWAYS' LOOM IN NEAR FUTURE
description: IT wasn't easy getting to Las Vegas

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Of Quick Talks and Jargon

title: ADVERTISING ; Regina Restraining Order Is Vacated
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit last week vacated the restraining order that had prevented the Regina Company, maker of floor care products, from using the television commercial in which it quoted favorable appraisals of its products from Consumer Reports magazine.

title: ELECTRONICS CORP OF ISRAEL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PEREZ AND REED TRADED BY PHILS
description: Baseball's 82d winter business meeting opened today with the Philadelphia Phillies continuing to shed senior players.

title: COMMON WEALTH AWARD
description: Jessica Tandy and Hume Cronyn received the 1983 Common Wealth for distinguished service to the dramatic arts in a ceremony last night at Sardi's. The noted acting couple were honored for their many years of service to the Broadway stage as performers, authors, directors and producers. The joint award carries a tax-free prize of $16,000.

title: JUDGE'S 'ULYSSES' RULING STILL A LANDMARK 50 YEARS LATER
description: FIFTY years ago this week, the authorities removed two kinds of prohibitions from American life. The first, more celebrated, case involved alcohol. Less prominent, but perhaps even more significant, was a ruling that permitted James Joyce's ''Ulysses'' to enter the country.

title: Armenian Wounded in Paris
description: Ara Toranian, the leader of the National Armenian Movement, was slightly wounded early today by a bomb attached to his car, the police said. Mr. Toranian, who escaped injury in a similar bombing eight months ago, criticized police handling of the attack and complained that his police protection had been canceled although he has received numerous death threats.

title: RAGAN, BRAD, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Limited Restart Urged For 3 Mile Island Plant
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission's staff recommended today that the undamaged nuclear reactor at Three Mile Island should be reopened at reduced capacity pending an investigation of management integrity at the power plant.

title: RARE SUCCESS STORIES
description: MIDDLE COLLEGE HIGH SCHOOL, a New York City public school in Queens, is a success story. It has been deemed so successful, in fact, that the Carnegie Foundation, in its recent report on what is wrong with American high schools, pointed to Middle College as a school that seemed to be doing something right.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The 51st 'Official' Tree

title: ADVERTISING
description: Ad Association Names Officer With the retirement in sight

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Hyster Offer
description: The Hyster Company has accepted a previously announced offer of $69 a share from the Esco Corporation, the companies said. The offer was structured as a leveraged buyout. Hyster was bid at $65.50 today in over-the- counter trading, up 37 1/2 cents.

title: BAXTER PRESENTS VIEWS IN KEY ANTITRUST CASE
description: The Supreme Court heard arguments today in what could prove to be the most important antitrust case in recent years - a routine private price-fixing dispute that has been elevated by Justice Department intervention into a possible judicial landmark.

title: SOVIET CALLS U.S. AIR RAIDS IN LEBANON A 'SERIOUS THREAT TO PEACE'
description: The Soviet Union today ''resolutely condemned'' the American air raids against Syrian positions in Lebanon on Sunday, calling them ''a serious threat to peace in the Middle East, and not only in that region.''

title: STOCKS MIXED AS DOW CLIMBS 5.29
description: A late recovery enabled the stock market to erase some of its earlier losses yesterday and finish mixed in active trading.

title: A NEW LITTLE BEAR IN NEPAL
description: Evidence of a new species of a ''very agile'' small bear has been found in Nepal by an expedition from the Woodlands Institute of Spruce Knob, W. Va.

title: Soviet Textile License
description: Savio S.p.A., a textile machinery unit of Italy's state energy group, Ente Nazionale Idrocarburi, has licensed the Soviet Union to produce automated systems for textile production, ENI said today.

title: Teen-Age Sex and Tattletales
description: Terriers are hailed for the persistence with which they worry the bone. By dropping the bone that is the so-called ''squeal rule,'' the Reagan Administration is finally behaving wisely.

title: Whittaker Notice
description: The Whittaker Corporation said it had received official notice that the Government of Saudi Arabia would seek competitive bids for the operation in that country of hospitals and other health-care facilities now run by Whittaker. The bidding will be for a contract to begin on March 1 and will be open to Whittaker as well as to others. On the New York Stock Exchange today, Whittaker was the biggest percentage loser, plunging $3.375, to $20.

title: CALUMET INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $54,000.

title: Lucas Joins Spurs
description: Another basketball player, John Lucas , who was twice treated for cocaine abuse and ultimately waived by the Washington Bullets last season, is getting a second chance in the National Basketball Association. Lucas, who played for the Houston Rockets, Philadelphia Warriors and Washington Bullets in his six seasons and was most recently with the Lancaster team in the Continental Basketball Association, has been signed by the San Antonio Spurs as a backup point guard.

title: NEW E.P.A. CHIEF SEEKS MORE FUNDS
description: The head of the Environmental Protection Agency is seeking to restore its budget to Carter Administration levels but is being opposed by White House budget- makers, agency officials said today.

title: Youngest Patient Receives Surgery
description: A 5-month-old Louisiana boy is doing well more than a month after becoming the youngest person ever to undergo surgery for a runaway heart that was beating up to 300 times each minute.

title: SCOUTING
description: Williams Trains For Olympic Bid

title: SYRIA SAYS AIRMAN SEIZED IN U.S. RAID WILL NOT BE FREED
description: Syria's Minister of Defense said today that the American airman captured by Syrian troops after they shot down his aircraft on Sunday would not be returned until ''the war'' was over and American troops left Lebanon.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Abbott Laboratories said that it had reached an agreement with the Internal Revenue Service to settle charges of income tax deficiencies relating to the company's Puerto Rico operations, but that the settlement would not materially affect its financial position.

title: BEFORE HIGH NOON
description: Virtually all arms control initiatives now under negotiation neglect the most fundamental truth of nuclear strategy: It is the quality, not the quantity, of nuclear weapons that determines the stability of the nuclear balance.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Broadchild Securities Corp., an affiliate of D. H. Blair & Co., has appointed John T. Moran president.

title: A NEWLY CONCILIATORY ARAFAT IGNORED BY ISRAEL'S GOVERNMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: SPACELAB, STILL IN ORBIT, ALREADY DEEMED A SUCCESS
description: Two scientists conducted a fluid-physics experiment last week under the most unusual circumstances. They worked shoulder to shoulder, or so it seemed, and yet they were thousands of miles apart in distinctly different fields of gravity. Their experiment and their methods typified a new way of conducting scientific research in a new kind of laboratory beyond the earth in the endlessly mysterious environment of space.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. announced that it would extend through the close of business on Friday its offer to buy below-market- rate home mortgages from thrift and institutional mortgage lenders. Freddie Mac has offered to buy mortgages with coupons as low as 7.5 percent, with the $50 million cap on each lender's aggregate offer removed for the special offer.

title: Bangladeshi Protest Ends
description: Supreme Court lawyers returned to work today after a one-day walkout to protest the arrest of their bar association president and to push for an end to martial law.

title: Suspension Ends
description: Mike Douglass, among the National Football League's leading linebackers, was reinstated by the Green Bay Packers today, five days after having been suspended by Coach Bart Starr. Douglass walked out of a team meeting and missed practice Nov. 28. Starr said then that the suspension was imposed for conduct detrimental to the team.

title: Swedish Steel Talks
description: Talks between Sweden's Government and the country's specialty-steel producers broke down, both sides said today. The negotiations were aimed at merging Avesta Jernverk A.B., Fagersta A.B., Uddeholm A.B. and Sandvik A.B. into two new groups.

title: KOCH FOR LIMIT ON PROJECT CHALLENGES
description: Mayor Koch called yesterday for Federal legislation to limit environmental and legal reviews of major construction projects, such as the Westway.

title: MUSIC: TORADZE ON PIANO
description: ALEXANDER TORADZE, the Soviet Georgian pianist, is making his first American appearances since his immigration to the West, playing Prokofiev's Concerto No. 2 with the Los Angeles Philharmonic on its current East Coast tour. Mr. Toradze and his accompanying Californians arrived at Avery Fisher Hall last night for the first of the orchestra's two concerts here under Andrew Davis - the second is tonight at Carnegie Hall - and the Prokofiev proved as muscularly thrilling as one could hope for.

title: AIRLINES SEE OLYMPIC GOLD
description: A lot of ticket holders to the Olympic Games in Los Angeles next summer seem likely to get a shock from the price of their airline seats.

title: ON IMPERILED MONT-ST.-MICHEL, A TURN IN THE TIDE
description: -ST.-MICHEL, France - From the shore, this island looks like a dark pupil in the gray eye of the sea. The tides, soft irises, contract toward the center, and then expand, with a rhythm, a pulse that seems without end.

title: HOPE FOR THE JETS, PAIN FOR THE GIANTS
description: In their strange season, the Jets are an anomaly: they look bad losing and they look bad winning.

title: HONDURAS BARS U.S. WOMEN FROM ENTERING FOR A PROTEST
description: The Government denied entry today to 92 American churchwomen who planned a three-day protest against manuevers here by thousands of American soldiers.

title: Federal Rules to Apply To Fight on Fruit Fly
description: Warning that the Mexican fruit fly could be as destructive as the Mediterranean one, the Agriculture Department said today that parts of Los Angeles County would go under Federal regulation Tuesday to prevent spread of the insect.

title: 10 Die in 2 Fires In Maine and Ohio
description: Early-morning fires in a rooming house in Maine and a home for the mentally retarded in Ohio left 10 people dead and eight injured yesterday, the authorities said. In Augusta, Me., four men were killed in a fire that broke out in a three-story brick building and burned ''like a chimney.''

title: ELECTRO AUTIO DYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Including a tax credit of $644,000. c-Including a tax credit of $30,000 and a gain on the exchange of debentures of $1,576,000.

title: FELDSTEIN MODIFIES ANALYSIS
description: Martin S. Feldstein, the chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers and recently the target of sharp criticism by the White House, gave a speech today apparently aimed at mollifying his opponents in the Reagan Administration.

title: BRIEFING
description: Cease-Fire Promise

title: Security Pacific's Insurance Plan
description: The Security Pacific Corporation, the nation's 10th-largest bank holding company, is applying for a state charter to open a bank in Sioux Falls, S.D., and start a nationwide insurance business.

title: Bridge: Jacoby Wins a Great Victory In Final of Reisinger Teams
description: Perhaps the most popular victory in the history of bridge concluded the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here Sunday.

title: THE N.F.L. IS HEATING UP
description: For all those Giant and Jet followers who have been wondering

title: Japan Energy Use Rises
description: Japan's energy demand is recovering from continued drops since 1980, the Agency of Natural Resources and Energy said today. Demand rose five-tenths of 1 percent in the July-September quarter as a result of economic recovery, declining oil prices and warm weather, the agency said.

title: Academy Elects Foss, Gross, Lawrence
description: Lukas Foss, composer-conductor; Chaim Gross, sculptor, and Jacob Lawrence, painter, have been elected to the American Academy of Arts and Letters, it has been announced by John Hersey, chancellor of the academy.

title: VACCINE PREVENTING A CANCER?
description: IMAGINE preventing a cancer

title: OPERA: THE MET'S PRODUCTION OF WAGNER'S 'TRISTAN AND ISOLDE'
description: GENUINE Wagnerian singers are always in short supply, and with the gradual fading from the scene of Birgit Nilsson, the heroic soprano category that she represented with such spectacular success for a generation has recently found itself in something approaching a famine condition. But perhaps the fates that watch over opera have been quietly taking steps to remedy that sad state. Last night's performance of ''Tristan und Isolde'' at the Metropolitan Opera, the season's first, showed that the opera world can count on at least one Wagnerian soprano, in the person of Hildegard Behrens. Miss Behrens, though not possessed of the immense column of tone and stentorian volume of a Nilsson, sang the punishing role of Isolde for the first time at the Metropolitan with extraordinary intelligence and an expressive range that Miss Nilsson never commanded in her greatest years.

title: TOMBILL MINES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes pre-tax gains on realization of investments of $528,079 for the quarter and $975,874 for the 9 months. c-Includes tax credits of $73,763 for the quarter and $216,099 for the 9 months and also includes pre-tax gains on realization of investments of $83,406 for the quarter and $155,431 for the 9 months.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: IT took two minutes of conversation

title: JOB PICTURE FOR SENIORS IS BRIGHTER
description: After two of the bleakest years for college graduates in decades, job prospects for June graduates are expected to improve slightly, according to three reports on the college employment market. But competition for jobs will still be stiff.

title: EXILED EMPEROR WILL FIGHT TO STAY IN FRANCE
description: Jean-Bedel Bokassa, the army captain who became Emperor Bokassa I of the Central African Republic and who was later sentenced to death in that country for murder, said today that he would resist all attempts by the French Government to force him out of France.

title: David F. Renwick, a Manager For Reuters in North America
description: David F. Renwick, manager of staff and labor relations for Reuters North America, whose headquarters are in Manhattan, died of cancer Sunday at the New York University Medical Center.

title: ALLEGATIONS AGAINST JUDGE STIR U.S.-NEVADA FEUD
description: Just before Joseph Conforte, formerly the owner of a Nevada brothel, became a fugitive from a prison term for tax evasion, he made contact with a prosecutor and offered to become a Federal witness against officials he said he had bribed.

title: SCIENCE WATCH
description: Iridium and Dinosaurs

title: PLAYER IS DISMISSED AS ARKANSAS WINS
description: Joe Kleine scored 18 points and grabbed 10 rebounds to lead Arkansas to a 79-50 rout of East Tennessee State tonight.

title: FLOWER TIME INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
Disabled Teacher Settles With Store
description: A Brooklyn teacher has obtained a $1,500 settlement from a Manhattan greeting-card store that refused to let her move her wheelchair down its aisles, the city's Commission on Human Rights said yesterday.

title: HOUSE OF FABRICS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
WILL NEW STANDARDS BE UNFAIR?
description: DEMANDS for tougher standards in education have raised fears that excellence will be pursued at the expense of equal opportunity. Many educators are afraid rigid new standards cause more students to drop out and standardized curriculums will alienate good teachers. Critics of get- tough reforms call for the use of the carrot instead of the stick.

title: DRUSE SAY SHELLING WAS NOT RETALIATORY
description: The leaders of the Druse militiamen who killed eight United States marines on Sunday said today that the shelling had not been in retaliation for the United States' air raids in central Lebanon hours earlier.

title: SHAMIR ASSERTS ACCORD WITH U.S. CONTAINS NO SECRET COMMITMENTS
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said today that the recent agreement to seek closer strategic cooperation with the United States did not contain any secret commitments or obligate Israel to take any military action on behalf of American interests.

title: Federal Express Plans to Sell Stock
description: The Federal Express Corporation said it was filing today with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a proposed public offering of two million common shares.

title: CRITICS IN CONGRESS DECLARE REAGAN IS HEADING FOR WAR
description: Critics of the Administration's Middle East policy in both parties expressed fears today that President Reagan was leading the country into war. They renewed calls for the removal of American troops from Lebanon.

title: U.S. DENIES BEIRUT ATTACKS ARE MEANT TO BROADEN ROLE
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that the United States attacks in Lebanon are not intended to lead to a broader American military role in Lebanon or the Middle East.

title: Seoul Says 2 Captives Are in Espionage Unit
description: Two armed North Koreans captured over the weekend are agents assigned to a unit that specializes in espionage and sabotage against South Korea, a Seoul official told Parliament today.

title: MARINE CASUALTIES IN BEIRUT ATTACK
description: The Defense Department has identified these United States marines as killed or wounded by artillery fire in Beirut on Sunday: Killed CHERMAN, Lance Cpl.

title: Attorney General Quits Grenada Administration
description: The Attorney General in Grenada's interim Government, Anthony Rushford, said today that he had resigned and was leaving the island because Sir Paul Scoon, the Governor General, was not doing enough to restore a constitutional government.

title: THINK, AND DIAL MOSCOW
description: U.S. involvement in Middle East fighting has now escalated far beyond anything known before. The Cassandra scenario is moving step by step to foreseeable disaster. But it isn't inexorable.

title: ITALY HINTS AT PULLOUT OF ITS CONTINGENT
description: Prime Minister Bettino Craxi of Italy indicated today that Italy may withdraw its troops from the international force in Lebanon because of the increased fighting there.

title: FIVE-YEAR HUNT LEADS TO ARREST IN MURDER CASE
description: A five-year investigation carried out by detectives who often worked on their own time led yesterday to the arrest of a 25-year-old Brooklyn man for the murders of two children in 1978.

title: TThe U.N. Today; Dec. 6, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: ANIMALS GIVEN A HUMAN GENE
description: SCIENTISTS are setting out to grow breeds of giant mice that are genetically a little bit human. Dozens of such animals have already been born, each carrying transplanted genes for human growth hormone that makes them grow to twice their normal size.

title: Court Bars Tax Suit By Dutch Shell Unit
description: The Supreme Court today refused to permit Shell Petroleum N.V. of the Netherlands to challenge California's approach to taxing the income of domestic corporations with foreign parents.

title: BANK BUILDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a loss of $235,000 for the quarter and income of $4,000 for the year from discontinued operations. c-Net income after a loss of $561,000 from discontinued operations. d-After a loss of $1,370,000 from discontinued operations.

title: NOV. 21-3 CAR SALES ROSE 18.7%
description: New-car sales by the nation's major manufacturers rose by 18.7 percent, on a daily rate basis, in the final 10 days of November, easing concerns among industry analysts that the level was falling off.

title: ALMA SPRECKELS
description: Alma Spreckels, heir to a sugar fortune and member of a California pioneer family, died Thursday after a long illness.

title: WITNESS IN BIEGENWALD CASE SAYS SECOND MAN CONFESSED
description: A defense witness in the murder trial of Richard F. Biegenwald testified in Superior Court here today that a key prosecution witness had confessed the slaying to him and had said he would have Mr. Biegenwald blamed for it.

title: GELMAN SCIENCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Cholera Reportedly Kills 500 In 3 Outbreaks in Bangladesh
description: Outbreaks of cholera in three areas have killed more than 500 people in the last six weeks, a newspaper reported today.

title: Head of Cincinnati Bell Assumes More Duties
description: Cincinnati Bell, one of two Bell System companies not involved in the divestiture of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, announced yesterday that it had named its president, Dwight Hibbard, to the additional post of chief executive.

title: M.T.A.'S PLANS TO RAISE FARES DRAW CRITICISM
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority's plans to increase subway and commuter rail fares were criticized today by public officials and commuters in the first of three public hearings by the agency.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Oct. 31 on the Alfred Hitchcock movie ''Rear Window'' incorrectly reported its television history. It has been shown on television three times - in 1966, 1967 and 1971.

title: CREEDMOOR HOMELESS PLAN DISPUTED
description: The number of homeless men that can be sheltered in the Creedmoor Psychiatric Center in Queens has not reached the level agreed to by the city and the state, but the reasons are in dispute.

title: Stake in Trico
description: TRW Inc. has acquired 1,339,530 common shares, or 16.6 percent, of the common stock outstanding of Trico Industries of Gardena, Calif., according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. TRW said it might propose a merger or make a tender offer for Trico. On the New York Stock Exchange today, Trico closed at $10.375, up 25 cents.

title: Kansas City Bank Sets Debt Offering
description: Commerce Bancshares filed an offering with the S.E.C. today for $100 million of debt securities. The underwriter is the First Boston Corporation.

title: SALONIKA'S JEWS SEEK TO PRESERVE A TRADITION
description: About 1,350 Jews in this ancient center of Sephardic Judaism are working to preserve a tradition that rose to a golden age spanning almost five centuries, but was all but wiped out by the Nazis.

title: INDUSTRY URGES SEAT BELT LAW, NOT AIR BAGS
description: Automobile industry executives are urging the Government not to direct manufacturers to install air bags or automatic safety belts in new cars, but to require drivers and passengers to buckle up instead.

title: Syria Not Obligated To Free U.S. Airman
description: Syria has an obligation under international law to treat the American airman it captured humanely, but apparently has no duty to free him until hostilities between Syrian and United States forces have ended.

title: ATLAN-TOL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Including net non-operating income of $1.4 million recorded during the second quarter. c-Net loss.

title: DAIRY MART CONVENIENCE STORES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CHINA BARS U.S. BIDDING PROJECT
description: China has issued a procurement order that excludes American companies from bidding to supply $60 million worth of fertilizers and other products for a rubber development project financed by an affiliate of the World Bank.

title: SHULTZ ASKS SOVIET TO PRESS SYRIA NOT TO WIDEN CONFLICT IN LEBANON
description: News session excerpts, page A20.

title: Greyhound Striker Killed by Training Bus
description: A Greyhound striker was run over and killed Monday when a group of pickets swarmed a bus being used to train replacement drivers. The striker was hit as the bus slowed for a stop sign.

title: HARRISON WILLIAMS DENIED APPEAL BID BY SUPREME COURT
description: The United States Supreme Court refused today to hear the final appeal by former Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. from his conviction on criminal charges that resulted from the Justice Department's Abscam investigation. The Court's action was unanimous and without comment.

title: Countess Pereira Carneiro; Owned Major Brazilian Daily
description: Countess Pereira Carneiro, owner and president of Jornal do Brasil, one of Brazil's biggest newspapers, died today of a heart attack. She was 84 years old.

title: U.S. COURT REINSTATES JAPAN TV-DUMPING SUIT
description: A Federal appeals court in Philadelphia yesterday reinstated a 13- year-old antitrust and dumping conspiracy case filed by two American television manufacturers against their major Japanese competitors.

title: MUSIC: RUBINSTEIN TRIBUTE
description: Pianists of four generations remembered Arthur Rubinstein in Carnegie Hall last Saturday night. The concert was by and for the America-Israel Cultural Foundation and presented music associated with Rubinstein, who died one year ago.

title: WORKER INSURANCE EVOLUTION
description: Almost 75 years after it began in the United States, workers' compensation insurance is at a crossroads. Employers who pay for it, workers who receive it and insurance companies that handle it are all concerned whether the system, as currently structured, is equipped to handle its new financial burdens.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Soldier's Tale

title: BILL RATES UP SHARPLY AT SALE
description: The Treasury's weekly auction of three- and six-month bills produced another sharp rise in rates yesterday, reflecting increased demand for these instruments.

title: Jets' Defense Messed Up' Last Down
description: Joe Gardi, the man who told the the

title: THE SEARCH FOR CAVITIES
description: DENTISTS are being offered a new tool that children might also appreciate, because it smiles when all is well: a battery-powered machine that uses a painless, low-voltage electric current to pinpoint hidden or forming cavities. The instrument presents its findings on a screen as a smile or a frown, depending on the response of the tooth being measured.

title: SCIENCE WATCH
description: Fetal Listening

title: Cash for Ti-Caro
description: Ti-Caro Inc. said it had agreed in principle to be acquired for $23 a share in cash by an investors group led by Lazard Fr eres & Company. Based on 8.2 million shares outstanding, the transaction has a value of about $189 million. Ti-Caro closed at $21.75 on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, up $2.75.

title: GEORESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
No Headline
description: Nielsen Cable Data

title: U.S., IN SHIFT, WELCOMING NICARAGUA PLEDGES
description: In a shift in the tone of the Reagan Administration's comments on Nicaragua, Secretary of State George P. Shultz today welcomed the Nicaraguan junta's promises of elections in 1985 and an amnesty for most anti-Sandinista rebels.

title: GRIFFIN TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
RAWLEY AND SMALLEY PURSUED
description: Although Billy Martin and Yogi Berra have been the Yankee names most often mentioned the last two days at the Opryland Hotel, Shane Rawley and Roy Smalley were popular topics of conversations today. Rawley and Smalley, club sources said, have been the Yankees most frequently pursued by other clubs.

title: BISHOP GRAPHICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a net loss of $109,000 from discontinued operations and a net provision of $181,000 for disposal of assets and close-down costs.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST TUESDAY, DECEMBER 6, 1983
description: Companies Superior Oil bowed to strong investor objections and rescinded a stock-dividend plan it announced two weeks ago as a way to protect itself from a takeover. But the company rejected a proposal by Howard B. Keck, 70-year-old former chairman, that it put itself on the auction block. (Page D1.) Western Union, preparing for stiff competition in 1984, plans to take a $125 million charge against fourth-quarter earnings and cut its work force by 5 percent. Analysts said the charge would result in a loss of about $102 million for the quarter and $35 million for the year. (D1.)

title: LOSS SEEN IN WESTERN UNION MOVE
description: In two moves to prepare for a great intensification of competition next year, the Western Union Corporation said yesterday that it would take a one-time $125 million charge against fourth-quarter earnings and reduce its staff 5 percent.

title: LANDFILL DECISION IS HAILED IN JERSEY
description: On the morning after the verdict, with the ''bells of justice'' still ringing in his ears, Jim McCarthy pulled out an old piece of plywood, painted on it the message, ''Legler beat Jackson Township,'' and placed the makeshift billboard in front of his house along Route 571.

description: LIFE & TIMES OF MICHAEL K. By J. M. Coetzee. 184 pages. Viking. $13.95.

description: To the Editor:
