NURSING HOME PLANS TO ADMIT VICTIM OF AIDS
description: A Baptist nursing home in Brooklyn said yesterday that it would admit a patient suffering from acquired immune deficiency syndrome, thus becoming the first nursing home in New York City to accept an AIDS victim.

title: LORIMAR reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CALIFORNIA LAW GIVES ALIENS LOWER COLLEGE COSTS
description: Because of a little-noticed law passed last summer by the California Legislature, illegal aliens who can establish residency in this state may be able to attend the state's public colleges next year at the rates paid by other California residents. Those rates are considerably lower than what American citizens from other states pay at those schools.

title: ASTRO-MED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
WESTMILLS CARPETS reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
SKYDIVER'S DEATH BARS PLANE CRASH
description: A master skydiver was killed Sunday in an accident when he apparently leaped to his death rather than allow his partly opened parachute to cause a plane crash.

title: TECHNODYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $1,829,000 from the previously announced sale of the Acton Environment Testing Corp.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We will defend ourselves, as we are doing, but we are not there contending with anybody.

title: Marcos Accepts a Plan For Electing Successor
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos today accepted a compromise formula approved by his ruling party for the election of a successor should the presidency become vacant through his death or inability to continue in office.

title: THE THEATER: 'WEDNESDAY'
description: ''WEDNESDAY'' - an arid word, blank and all but meaningless - is the perfect title for the arresting new play at the Hudson Guild. In this caustic, even cruel domestic comedy about a Lancashire family, an English writer named Julia Kearsley shows us the barren landscape of four lives that are nearly as empty as lives can be.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SHULTZ'S COMMENTS ON THE MIDEAST AT HIS NEWS CONFERENCE
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of Secretary of State George P. Shultz's news conference in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: REAGAN AND KOHL HAIL FLIGHT IN JOINT TELECAST TO SHUTTLE
description: President Reagan and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany today hailed the flight of the space shuttle Columbia, carrying the European-built Spacelab, as an impressive example of international cooperation and perhaps a major step toward further American-European joint space ventures.

title: No Headline
description: Accounts

title: E.E.C. Talks In Discord
description: With France and Britain clashing over important issues, leaders of the Common Market made little progress today to save the 10-nation association from financial collapse.

title: ABC MOVES TO PROTECT ITS OLYMPIC TURF
description: Ahockey game between Team USA and a

title: WORLCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The year-earlier quarter and 6 month periods and the latest 6 month figures were restated to reflect the change to the equity method of accounting for Worlco Data Systems Inc., a 27 percent owned subsidiary of Worlco Inc., from a consolidated basis.

title: 3 YEARS AFTER KILLINGS, NO JUSTICE IN SALVADOR
description: Just over three years ago, four American churchwomen were shot and killed by members of El Salvador's national guard. In the period since their death, the debate on El Salvador in the United States has at once become more intense and more obscure. But one issue that the passage of time has made increasingly clear concerns the epidemic of violence in the last four years.

title: Volcker Sees No Shift in Fed Policy
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said yesterday that there have been no changes in central bank policy in recent months.

title: GELCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $818,000.

title: LEAR SET TO BUY 20% OF BANGOR STOCK
description: Lear Siegler Inc. announced yesterday that it had agreed to buy 20 percent of the common stock of the Bangor Punta Corporation and that it was interested in acquiring all the stock if further agreement could be reached.

title: CABBAGE PATCH KIDS SPUR A BATTLE OVER PARENTAGE
description: Those Cabbage Patch Kids, the Christmas season's fought-over big seller, are of disputed parentage. The dolls are the object of a custody battle between Xavier Roberts, a Georgian who says he is their creator, and Martha Nelson Thomas, a Kentuckian who says he took the idea from her.

title: DAYCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
UNITED STATES TELEPHONE reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss. c-Net income.

title: ADVERTISING ;  Addendum
description: * Modern Maturity magazine increasing its circulation rate base 5.9 percent, to 9 million from 8.5 million; its four-color advertising rates 10 percent, and its black-and-white 20 percent, with the April/May issue.

title: FOES SAY SANDINISTAS DECEIVE WITH MINOR CHANGES
description: Domestic critics of the Nicaraguan Government believe that its recent gestures of conciliation are largely superficial moves aimed at improving its image without greatly changing conditions in the country.

title: 'RATIONAL' DECISIONS PROVE NOT TO BE
description: If human beings ever really believed in their supreme rationality, much of psychological thought has tended to disabuse them of that notion.

title: SCOUTING
description: 22% No-Shows

title: Market PlacePhillip H. Wiggins Junior Growth Stocks Viewed
description: MANY trackers of junior growth stocks expect the bearishness that marked much of that sector in 1983 to give way early next year to a renewal of investor enthusiasm.

title: FISHING FOR BASS: THERE'S GOLD IN THEM THAR GILLS
description: Gary Klein stood over his $15,000 sonar-equipped, high-performance bass boat and talked about the business of being a professional bass fisherman.

title: Storer-Loews
description: The Loews Corporation has acquired a 4.8 percent interest in Storer Communications Inc. and has warrants to buy more stock that would increase its stake to 5.1 percent, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Storer closed unchanged today, at $34.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Homelessamilies Back From Jersey
description: The last 2 of 307 homeless families from New York City housed in New Jersey by the city have returned, city officials said yesterday.

title: TRIAD SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SCOUTING
description: Eye on Gloves

title: PENN TRAFFIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
ILC TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
102 People in Congress Form a Rights Group
description: A group to protect human rights activists around the world has been formed by 102 members of Congress from both parties, the founders announced at a news conference today.

title: House Panel Criticizes Reagan on Education
description: Federal educational assistance to minority and poor children has substantially declined under the Reagan Administration, a House subcommittee said today.

title: HEALTHCARE SERVICES GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MOVIE: RONALD HARWOOD'S 'DRESSER'
description: THE time is 1940, some months after Dunkirk but still more than a year before the United States's entry into World War II. The German Luftwaffe is reducing Britain's cities to rubble and Winston Churchill is rallying the citizens to meet their finest hour. Among those responding are the members of one of the seediest repertory companies ever assembled to carry the Bard to what Margot Metroland would call the lower orders, mostly in the provinces.

title: ADVERTISING ; New England Monthly Publication Set to Go
description: Robert Nylan, publisher of the New England Monthly, which is expected to begin publication next April, has reported that all systems are go.

title: THE TRIUMPHS OF BIGHOUSE GAINES
description: -SALEM, N.C. - A little girl stood before the huge, gray-haired man seated in the bleachers of the C. E. Gaines Center and asked, ''Are you the real coach?''

title: Explosion in Texas Injures 6 And Prompts an Evacuation
description: An explosion and fire ripped through several acres of a chemical plant tonight, sending clouds of toxic fumes into the air.

title: PATIENT'S BID TO REFUSE FOOD TERMED SUICIDE
description: A quadriplegic who wants to starve herself with the cooperation of her doctors and the courts should be denied the right to refuse medical care because it amounts to suicide, a county attorney argued today.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Nov. 24 about advertising circulars misstated the source of a recommendation to raise postal rates 28 percent for presorted third-class mail. It was the Postal Service.

title: KOCH IS SEEKING USE OF M.A.C.'S SURPLUS FOR CONVENTION HALL
description: The Koch administration favors restoring the Convention Center to the size initially planned, with a northern wing and a plaza that were eliminated in an economy move two years ago, city officials said yesterday.

title: Rebuke of Official Contested in Court
description: A Yonkers School District administrator sought in State Supreme Court today to remove a reprimand imposed on him in connection with the death of a football player.

title: The Police Blotter
description: Two men who shot a guard at a Madison Square Garden antiques show were being sought. The men, dressed in work uniforms, gained entry to the rotunda at 5:30 A.M. Sunday and bound the guard, Frank Rofral, 40 years old, after shooting him in the neck.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday on the Kennedy Center Honors program gave an incorrect date for the television broadcast. The date is Dec. 27.

title: Walton Hurt Again
description: One of Nixon's teammates, Bill Walton , the center who seemed to be making a successful comeback from a succession of injuries, became the second player of the weekend to suffer a serious hand injury at the Forum in Inglewood, Calif. Walton's broken bone in the ring finger of his right hand, expected to sideline him for two months, came two days after Earvin Johnson of the Lakers suffered a dislocated right ring finger that will probably keep him on the bench for five weeks.

title: LIONS TAKE DIVISION LEAD
description: Eric Hipple's 10-yard touchdown pass to the rookie Jeff Chadwick, and two long field goals by Eddie Murray helped give the Lions a 13-2 victory tonight over the Minnesota Vikings. Detroit took sole possession of first place in the National Conference's Central Division.

title: Kaufman & Broad Unit Bond Sale
description: The International Mortgage Acceptance Corporation, a subsidiary of Kaufman & Broad Inc., said today that it had filed a shelf registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission to offer up to $125 million of obligations collateralized by the Government National Mortgage Association.

title: Advertising; Spielvogel Wins Red Lobster
description: THE Red Lobster Inns of America announced from its Orlando, Fla., headquarters yesterday that it had selected Backer & Spielvogel to be its agency starting Jan. 4. It will replace D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius, which has been doing the job since 1976.

title: MISGUIDED LAWYERS
description: The American legal profession is declining.

title: E-H INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
STAR-STRUCK VILLAGE GETS FACELIFT BY WOODY ALLEN
description: From Frank's Barbershop on the north end of Main Street to Clausland Bookshop on the south end, there's no doubt about it - Piermont has gone Hollywood.

title: ADVERTISING ;  People
description: * Lester E. Gallagher has joined Creamer Inc., Pittsburgh, as a senior vice president.

title: Most Happy Fella Is Destroyed
description: Most Happy Fella, a pacer whose foals earned enough millions to make him the leading sire among all breeds of horses, was destroyed Sunday night after breaking a second bone in his right leg, the United States Trotting Association said today.

title: 2 Apartment Fires Injure 6 People
description: Six people were seriously injured yesterday as two unrelated fires erupted within minutes of each other.

title: Index Futures Plan Opposed
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission came out today against plans by the Chicago Mercantile Exchange to offer new futures contracts based on four Standard & Poor's Corporation indexes of the stock market.

title: Blind Man Killed In Fall From Roof
description: A blind man attending a bowling league meeting at a Brooklyn center for the visually handicapped was locked inside the building for 24 hours before he wandered to the roof and accidentally fell seven floors to his death, the police said yesterday.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Setting an Example

title: U.S.ElectionPanel Fines LeBoutillier
description: The Federal Election Commission has ruled that former Representative John LeBoutillier, a Republican from Nassau County, violated Federal election laws by accepting a $200,500 campaign contribution from his mother.

title: SCOUTING
description: A Rare Ivy Game

title: Philippine Bank Talks
description: A 12-bank advisory group led by the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company is scheduled to meet in New York with top Philippine officials tomorrow, following what banking sources characterized as ''quite a bit of progress'' toward resolving the country's medium-term financing needs during talks last week.

title: ADVERTISING ; Warwick Advertising Adds Newsletter
description: Frequently ad agencies get into publishing on the side as a way of impressing present clients or winning new ones.

title: KREMLIN AIDE SAYS US. IMPERILS TALKS ON STRATEGIC ARMS
description: A Soviet official said today that the same American tactics that led the Russians to break off talks on medium-range nuclear weapons were now threatening the talks on intercontinental nuclear weapons.

title: MATCH TIED 3-3
description: Fifty-two-year- old Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland blundered and lost the sixth game of his semifinal world championship chess match to 20-year-old Gary Kasparov of the Soviet Union tonight. Their series is now tied at 3-3.

title: Dr.CharlesF.Begg,71; Pathologist at Hospital
description: Dr. Charles F. Begg, former chief pathologist and director of laboratories at St. Luke's Hospital in Manhattan, died of cancer Sunday at the hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Port Washington, L.I.

title: ROYAL VISIT IS A MOUNTAIN OF DETAILS
description: Bhekh Thapa, the Nepalese Ambassador, surveyed the furniture piled in disarray in the blue and gold drawing room of the Nepalese Embassy. ''It looks like a furniture storeroom,'' he said ruefully as another overstuffed chair was carted away for upholstery cleaning. Throughout the residence, painters and carpenters labored with brushes and hammers.

title: Talking Businesswith James of Raymond, James Diversification At Regionals
description: BOCA RATON, Fla.

title: LINK OF DRAFT TO SCHOOL AID TO BE HEARD
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether men in college may constitutionally be deprived of their Federal scholarship aid for failing to register for the draft.

title: A BRAIN CHEMICAL TIED TO BLOOD PRESSURE
description: Doctors are trying to purify a brain chemical that they believe might play a role in causing high blood pressure, a condition that afflicts about 20 percent of adults in the United States.

title: A SETBACK TO ALASKA OIL HOPES
description: Hopes of finding a vast new reserve of oil off Alaska's North Slope were seriously set back yesterday, when the operators of the first exploratory well drilled in the most promising geological formation said they had found no oil.

title: Consultant Assails Bridgeport Police
description: A consultant today recommended total reorganization for the Police Department here and severely criticized the management of its Superintendent, Joseph Walsh.

title: P.L.O. PULLOUT FROM BEIRUT HURT U.S. INTELLIGENCE LINKS
description: United States diplomatic and military operations in the Middle East have suffered as a result of the pullout of P.L.O. guerrillas from Beirut last year, Administration officials said today.

title: WALESA WANTS SANCTIONS ENDED
description: The Polish Interior Minister today disclosed the arrest of a Pole and a West German on charges of spying for the United States and accused Western countries of conducting intelligence activities and subversion in Poland.

title: A PHYSICIAN FOR VENEZUELA'S ILLS
description: Twenty-five years ago, when the exiled Jaime Lusinchi worked at Bellevue Hospital in New York City, a dictator ruled Venezuela and the young doctor was dedicated to his overthrow. Today, with democracy long restored in his homeland, the 59-year- old Mr. Lusinchi, as President-elect, is preparing to take over the reins of power. On Sunday he led the opposition Democratic Action Party to what may be the biggest electoral victory since Venezuela returned to democratic rule in 1958.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES Tranquil Day For Eurobonds
description: Trading in the Eurobond market was quiet today, dealers said, with prices of American issues generally weaker.

title: Georgia Court Upholds Atlanta Deaths Verdict
description: The Georgia Supreme Court today upheld the convictions and life sentences given Wayne B. Williams in 1982 for the slayings of two young black men.

title: 'POISON PILL' PLAN ENDED AT SUPERIOR
description: Responding to strong investor objections, the Superior Oil Company yesterday rescinded a stock-dividend plan announced two weeks ago to protect the nation's largest independent oil company from a takeover.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Turmoil Over the Tower

title: DR. PEPPER BIDDING RAISED BY DPCC
description: The DPCC Acquisition Corporation, an investment group that includes Castle & Cooke Inc., yesterday increased the bidding for the Dr Pepper Company by offering $560 million, or about $24 a share, through a leveraged buyout.

title: Nuclear Power's Worst Enemies
description: France builds nuclear power plants that are half as expensive but just as safe as America's. Japan builds them five years faster. At Three Mile Island, almost five years after the accident, General Public Utilities has neither cleaned up the disabled Unit 2 reactor nor persuaded regulators that it is competent to restart the undamaged Unit 1.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
description: Chrysler Notes Priced

title: WORLD TRADE CENTER TESTING STEAM PIPES AFTER FINDING DEFECTIVE WELDS
description: Engineers have found welding defects in the pipes of the high-pressure steam system that heats the World Trade Center, raising concern about a ''potential hazard'' in the busy Manhattan complex, according to an engineer's memorandum.

title: Printer Is Punished in Insider Case
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced yesterday that a financial printer had been ordered to disgorge about $100,000 of illegal profits made through insider trading on four occasions between March 1981 and September 1982.

title: Express May Be Sold
description: The Los Angeles Express of the United States Football League confirmed today that the owners, Alan Harmon and Bill Daniels , had talked to investors about the possibility of selling the team. ''Over the last four or five months, there have been a number of investors who have approached our owners,'' said Bob Rose , the club's director of public relations. ''Our owners have not looked to sell the team, but they are good businessmen and are willing to listen to some pretty significant offers.''

title: RECOGNITION EQUIPMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $134,000 for the quarter and $564,000 for the year and a gain of $5,752,000 for the year on the sale of land. c-Net loss.

title: AMADAC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Including a gain of $5,000 for the quarter and a loss of $928,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $515,000 for the quarter and $751,000 for the 9 months.

title: EUROPEAN CHIEFS ARE DEADLOCKED ON MARKET ISSUE
description: The summit meeting of European Economic Community leaders ended today in a deadlock over proposed cuts in farm spending and Britain's demand for a $1 billion budget refund.

title: SCOUTING
description: Glittering Cover For Sports Guide

title: N.H.L. President Warns Officials
description: John Ziegler, the president of the National Hockey League, said today he would dismiss any official who goes on strike over the league's handling of the suspension of the Chicago Black Hawk forward Tom Lysiak.

title: 'Unitary' Tax Study by U.S.
description: An advisory panel created by President Reagan made clear today that it opposes major Federal intervention in the issue of how states tax international corporations.

title: Marine Casualties In Beirut Attack
description: The Defense Department today identified these casualties of the artillery attack on marines Sunday in Lebanon, completing the identification: Killed BIDDLE, Cpl.

title: THROUGH THE ARTISTS' LOOKING GLASS
description: In the foreground is a young man on a horse. To his right are two bulls, lazing on a grassy hill. To his left, beyond a few rude houses and toward the horizon, sits a white domed building, bathed in light.

title: Binney & Smith Sees Less Profit
description: Binney & Smith Inc. said it is lowering its earnings forecast for the year because of soft sales during the current quarter. The new estimate is $3 to $3.05 a share, before extraordinary items, rather than the $3.20 to $3.25 a share forecast in September.

title: GERMANS BUY RARE MEDIEVAL BOOK
description: A sumptuously illustrated Romanesque gospel book, described by scholars and collectors as one of the greatest medieval masterpieces remaining in private hands, was sold today to a West German consortium and will return to the region where it was created eight centuries ago.

title: Golf Digest and Tennis Get New Publishers
description: At Golf Digest/Tennis Inc., Howard R. Gill Jr., the president, who is also publisher of Golf Digest, is switching his publisher's flag to Tennis magazine, and James W. FitzGerald, executive vice president and chief operating officer of the company, replaces him as publisher of Golf Digest. Mr. Gill is 61 years old; Mr. FitzGerald is 44.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allied Corp., Morris Township, N.J., has appointed Charles F. Bischoff, Robert J. Geiger and Russell W. Hawkins staff vice presidents.

title: SIX GROWTH PLANS PROPOSED BY CITY
description: The Koch administration hopes to spend up to $400 million for six new economic development programs, including a fund to stimulate housing for middle-class families and a city high school to train students in financial services.

title: DOCTOR REFUSES TO BACK QUADRIPALEGIC'S PLEA TO STARVE HERSELF
description: A doctor who has counseled terminally ill cancer patients to commit suicide testified today that he could not support a quadriplegic's legal battle to starve herself ''in the middle of a psychiatric ward.''

title: NEW PLAN SEEKS TO STEP UP CONVENTION SITE TIMETABLE
description: A key state official said yesterday that he thought six months could be cut from the Convention Center's completion time by the use of a new kind of space-frame construction for part of the project.

title: MISS NAVRATILOVA GAINS
description: Martina Navratilova, the top-seeded woman at the Australian Open, extended her winning streak to 48 matches with a 4-6, 6-3, 6-4 victory today over Jo Durie.

title: Warsaw Again Shuns Talks With Walesa
description: The Polish Government brushed aside the prospect of talks with Lech Walesa today after the founder of the Solidarity union called on the West to lift economic sanctions imposed during martial law.

title: Deere Profits Surge in Period
description: Deere & Company said today

title: JUDGE UPHOLDS LAW FORBIDDING DRUG ITEM SALES
description: A city law barring the sale and display of drug paraphernalia was upheld yesterday by a State Supreme Court judge, and city officials immediately began discussing how to enforce the measure.

title: Whirlpool Closing
description: The Whirlpool Corporation said it would establish a pretax provision of $19.5 million to cover the closing of its room air-conditioner plant in Evansville, Ind. After the closing, which is expected to be completed by the end of next year, the production of room air conditioners will move to Whirlpool's Heil-Quaker subsidiary in Lavergne, Tenn.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: One Member Fewer At the Century Club

title: Two Die in Institution Fire
description: A fire swept through a building today at a home for the mentally retarded, killing two people and injuring four others, three of them seriously, the authorities said. The fire was in the Home Bethesda, one of several buildings that comprise the Bethphage Mission, according to the authorities.

title: ; GERMAN NATIONALISM BORN OF IMPOTENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: BRITISH HOPE FOR RESTORED ARGENTINE LINKS
description: To the Editor:

title: MERCANTILE BANK OF CANADA reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $7.3 million.

title: SHULTZ DECLARES THREATS WON'T INTIMIDATE NATO
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the United States and its allies remained prepared to negotiate with the Soviet Union in any forum, but would not be intimidated by Soviet threats.

title: COUPLE'S STRENGTH GOES BEYOND SPORTS
description: The Greek press has called them ''the strongest couple in the Mediterranean,'' but they concede that they are really less tough than their athletic achievements might indicate. Despite their hopes for success at the Los Angeles Olympic Games next summer, two of Greece's top athletes say they look forward more to being wed and raising a family.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Fordham vs. Columbia , at the Rose Hill gym, Southern Boulevard and Fordham Road, the Bronx, 8 P.M. The last time Columbia beat Fordham, in the 1977-78 season, Tom Penders was coaching the Lions. When he left for Fordham after that season, Buddy Mahar, his assistant, took over as head coach, and the scorecard since then reads: Penders 5, Mahar 0. (Radio - WFUV-FM, 90.7; 8 P.M.)

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: THE POP LIFE
description: MAURICE WHITE, the leader, vocalist, and chief songwriter for Earth, Wind and Fire, describes the sound of his phenomenally successful and long-lasting band as a mixture of ''the feeling that r. and b. brings to music, the melody of pop, contributions from Africa and Brazil, and technology - electronics.''

title: Nevada Suspends Permit Of Las Vegas Casino
description: The state has suspended the Stardust Hotel-Casino's gambling license because of accusations that the resort and its owners were involved in a skimming operation.

title: Matsushita Venture Set
description: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company said today that it planned to establish a joint venture with a company in the Ivory Coast to produce electric appliances for the African market. Matsushita will invest about $54 million of the initial capital for the venture and own 60 percent of the new plant. Matsushita declined to identify the joint venture partner.

title: BRIEFING
description: High Cost of Campaigning

title: Suit Filed to Block Alien Job Restrictions
description: A lawsuit was filed in Federal District Court here today in an effort to block the Immigration and Naturalization Service from putting a policy into effect Wednesday that would prohibit aliens from taking jobs while their applications to stay in this country were pending.

title: SCREEN: 'FIRST CONTACT'
description: ''WE believed our dead went over there, turned white, and came back as spirits. That's how we explained the white man: our own dead had returned.'' Those are the words of a black New Guinea tribesman who had never seen a white man before 1930, when three Australian prospectors, the Leahy brothers, arrived in what they believed was an uninhabited part of the New Guinea highlands. The Leahys were not anthropolgists or serious film makers, but they happened to have brought along a movie camera in case they encountered anything of interest.

title: Eurobonds Up Slightly
description: Eurobond trading was quiet today, with some prices showing slight gains, dealers said.

title: John E. Farrell, 76, a Lawyer And Ex-Head of P. Ballantine
description: John E. Farrell, counsel to the Newark law firm of Shanley & Fisher and former president and chairman of P. Ballantine & Sons, brewer in Newark, died Saturday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 76 years old and lived in South Orange, N.J.

title: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 7, 1983 International
description: Four Israelis were killed and 46 wounded when a bomb, apparently placed by a Palestinian terrorist, destroyed a crowded bus at the height of the lunchtime rush in Jerusalem. It was the worst terrorist attack there since 1979, when 3 people were killed and 50 wounded by explosives packed in a bicycle frame. (Page A1, Col. 6.) Data about Syrian antiaircraft sites in Lebanon was inadequate and American pilots met more intense fire than they expected during Sunday's bombing raid, a senior admiral said. He spoke at a Navy briefing in defense of the raid, in which two planes were lost, one airman was killed and one was captured by the Syrians. The performance of the airmen has been criticized by military specialists at home at abroad, including two former commanders of the Israeli Air Force. (A1:5-6.)

title: SERVICE CORP INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Results for the latest periods include gains of $477,000 for the quarter and $1,597,000 for the 6 months from dispositions.

title: PRESIDENT, NAMING 3 TO RIGHTS UNIT, BARS CRITIC OF HIS POLICIES
description: President Reagan today appointed three more people to the United States Commission on Civil Rights but refused to reappoint a prominent Republican who had criticized the Administration's civil rights policies.

title: CONCERT: CHAMBER ART GROUP
description: ASATURDAY evening presentation at the Vineyard Theater afforded an opportunity to encounter some rare music by Gaetano Donizetti. The Chamber Art Ensemble, which consists of the violinist Hanna Tennen, the pianist Ellen Knafo and the cellist Hanna Brickman, opened the program with sturdy performances of some of the composer's rarely heard instrumental music.

title: VIEWS OF YOUNGER GENERATION SURVEYED
description: The one in three Americans born between 1946 and 1964 - the baby-boom generation - may be less traditional than their elders, but apparently are loathe to discard their ways entirely.

title: ENTWISTLE CO reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $766,000 from the settlement of a lawsuit.

title: HIGH COURT REFUSES CHASE BID
description: The United States Supreme Court refused on Monday to uphold the confidentiality of certain documents involving the Chase Manhattan Bank - and thus opened to public scrutiny an ongoing battle arising out of a fraud at the Irving Trust Company.

title: JULIAN R. FRIEDMAN, PROFESSOR WHO HELD U.S. POSTS IN CHINA
description: Julian R. Friedman, professor of political science at Syracuse University and a former State Department official, died, apparently of a heart attack, on Monday on the university's campus. He was 63 years old and lived in Syracuse.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 7, 1983
description: International A Common Market summit meeting in Athens failed to agree on a single issue despite six months of preparatory work. The breakdown leaves the 10-nation body on the verge of bankruptcy and facing what officials see as the most difficult crisis in its 26-year history. Among the most divisive issues were proposed cuts in farm spending. (Page A1.) The growing cost of farm subsidies has become a major problem for the U.S. and Japan too. (D6.) Iranian delegates plan to appeal to Arab members at an OPEC meeting to use oil as a weapon against the United States in the struggle in Lebanon. But delegates from other OPEC nations said the appeal was likely to be soundly rejected. (D19.)

title: AFGHAN FIGHTINNG SAID TO INTENSIFY
description: Soviet forces in Afghanistan sought last week to drive insurgents out of a valley north of the capital but gave up after suffering heavy casualties, Western diplomats said here today.

title: Biegenwald Jury Is Deliberating
description: A Monmouth County jury deliberated about three hours today but failed to reach a verdict in the trial of Richard Biegenwald, who is accused of murdering a Camden teen-ager.

title: Joseph Bonanno Starts His First Prison Term
description: Joseph Bonanno, who reigned as a Mafia chieftan for 30 years without going to jail, was confined today to a hospital ward of a Federal penitentiary where he began serving his first prison term.

title: Beatty to Be Tried Without a Jury
description: Former State Senator Vander L. Beatty of Brooklyn yesterday waived his right to a jury trial. He will be tried before a judge on forgery and other charges arising from his unsuccessful race for the House last year.

title: SUBSTANCE TIED TO ALZHEIMER'S IN COAST STUDY
description: The prion, the smallest infectious agent known, appears to have links to Alzheimer's disease and several other degenerative disorders of the brain.

title: THE BOOK OF HISTORY
description: Thirty years ago this week, President Dwight D. Eisenhower delivered his Atoms for Peace speech at the United Nations. Reading it again is a reminder of the missed opportunities of the past and the bad manners of present U.S.-Soviet diplomacy.

title: Carr to Play in Italy
description: Antoine Carr, the former Wichita State basketball star who turned down a four-year offer reportedly worth $250,000 a season from the Detroit Pistons, has signed with an Italian League team.

title: Fine Angers Dinkel
description: Tom Dinkel, the Cincinnati Bengal linebacker, has been assessed a $1,000 fine for a face-mask infraction he committed six weeks ago, and he's not happy about it. ''I was totally shocked,'' said Dinkel, who said he would appeal the fine to Commissioner Pete Rozelle of the National Football League, the man who imposed it.

title: CHINA AFFIRMS ZHAO'S PLAN TO VISIT U.S.
description: China said today that an exchange of visits between President Reagan and Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang would go ahead as scheduled despite its dissatisfaction with Washington's replies to Chinese protests over recent Congressional support for Taiwan.

title: Bridge: The Complexities of Bidding Have Increased in 20 Years
description: The language of bidding has been enlarged considerably in the past two decades. In the old days there were many bids that did not and could not have a natural meaning and were therefore never made. Today serious players think up specialized meanings.

title: JOHN ROBINSON, BISHOP, DIES AT 64
description: Bishop John A. T. Robinson, the Anglican theologian whose unorthodoxy drew the wrath of traditionalist leaders of the Church of England, died Monday night at his home in Yorkshire, England. He was 64 years old.

title: Overseas Viewers Get More on Monday
description: Football-starved overseas Americans who subscribe to a mail-order videotape service have been getting something extra this season - a chance to hear what the Monday night football crew really thinks about what is happening on the field.

title: CHICAGO POLITICAL DISPUTE TESTS DEMOCRATIC UNITY
description: Three candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination braved a winter storm and the turbulence of a Chicago political brawl today in an attempt to hoist a frayed banner of party unity over a fund-raising event here.

title: Condec, Dissidents Reach Agreement
description: The Condec Corporation and a dissident group of shareholders said yesterday that they had resolved litigation involving the dissidents' campaign to elect a slate of directors in recent voting.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Fading Zither No thrumming of ''Oh, Come Little

title: CHRISTMAS GIFTS FOR COOKS AND CONNOISSEURS
description: MOST dedicated cooks are, by nature, exceedingly acquisitive types, forever on the prowl for unusual foods, new utensils and elegant serving pieces and accessories to enhance the presentation of their creations. This makes Christmas shopping for food lovers a relatively easy task, assuming you are well attuned to the recipient's tastes and styles.

title: AMERICAN BANCORPORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

description: Greenwich Cheer

title: CABINET OFFICER URGES EDUCTIONAL 'NEW ERA'
description: Secretary of Education T. H. Bell appealed to 1,700 educational and political leaders from across the country tonight to work for a ''new era in American education.''

title: Group W Cable Head Quits Chief Officer Job
description: Group W Cable announced yesterday that William J. Bresnan was stepping down as chief executive while continuing as chairman. Harry F. Murray, an executive with the parent Westinghouse Electric Corporation, was named to succeed him as chief executive.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Angeles Corp.'s offering of 32,500 units, each consisting of $1,000 principal amount of 12.5 percent senior subordinated debentures and 23 warrants, each entitling the owner to buy one share of common stock at $21 a share, was priced at $951.84 a unit, through Bear, Stearns & Co.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: 1,000 FEAST AT 95 FETES TO HELP LIBRARY
description: JAMES BEARD, Marcella Hazan and Alfredo Viazzi were among the chefs cooking up a storm, and Henry and Nancy Kissinger, Tom and Meredith Brokaw, Brooke Astor and Brendan Gill were among the 1,000 guests eating up a storm. It all took place last night as part of ''A Night of 100 Dinners,'' one of the most ambitious and far-ranging benefits in the city's history.

title: SCOUTING
description: Dog Show Trend

title: N.Y.U. CHAIR TO HONOR KING OF SPAIN
description: The establishment of an academic chair in Spanish culture and civilization in the name of King Juan Carlos I of Spain was announced last night by New York University at a dinner in honor of the visiting monarch.

title: Korean TV Venture
description: The Kolon International Corporation and the Korean Electronics Company are planning a joint-venture company to sell television sets in the United States, a Korean Electronics official said today.

title: ELECTION LOSSES MOUNT FOR QUEBEC SEPARATISTS
description: The ruling party of Quebec, the separatist Parti Quebecois, lost two by-elections Monday, bringing to 18 the number of such elections it has lost in a row.

title: Out by New Year's
description: Those 2,000 beleaguered American marines in Lebanon have no military mission. They are passive diplomats in olive drab, flying the flag in a vulnerable encampment. Even if reinforced, they could not hope to compel an end of Lebanon's civil war or the withdrawal of 40,000 Syrian troops.

title: Dow Off 1.22 Points, to 1,269.31
description: The stock market ended slightly lower yesterday in continued active trading, with the biggest price moves made by Metromedia and Diebold.

title: Dr.Sienko,
description: Dr. Michell J. Sienko, a chemistry professor at Cornell and author of many of the leading chemistry textbooks used in high schools and colleges throughout the world for more than two decades, died of cancer Sunday at Tompkins Community Hospital, the university announced Monday. He was 60 years old.

title: VESSELS ATTACKED, NICARAGUANS SAY
description: A Nicaraguan fisherman was killed Monday when his vessel was attacked by Honduran boats and planes, the Sandinista Government said last night. It said the attack came a day after Honduran and Nicaraguan patrol boats exchanged fire in the Gulf of Fonseca.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Sodium and Convenience

title: WINE TALK
description: Pity the poor Bordelais. Let someone so much as mislabel a case or two of table wine in that part of the world and the fact turns up in the press as ''the latest Bordeaux scandal.''

title: A Series for Old-Timers
description: A ''season'' of seven games in nonmajor-

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The City's Lights

title: Panel Report Criticizes Fed
description: Charging that the Federal Reserve Board under Paul A. Volcker has practiced excessive ''secrecy and obfuscation,'' the House Banking Committee today published a report urging tighter Congressional control over the central bank.

title: YOUNG HELPS HOUSTON BEAT L.S.U., 100-91
description: With Akeem Olajuwon in foul trouble, Michael Young took control and scored 25 points tonight to lead Houston to a 100-91 victory over Louisiana State University.

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 7, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: A CO-OP RESTAURANT: ALL FROM SCRATCH
description: BRATTLEBORO, Vt.

title: MARTHA GRAHAM'S YEAR
description: MARTHA GRAHAM will choreograph ''Rite of Spring,'' which will receive its world premiere in her company's season at the New York State Theater in February and March.

title: A TOP CHEF IN FRANCE GUILTY OF TAX FRAUD
description: Charles Barrier, one of France's most famous chefs and restaurant owners, has been convicted of fraud and sentenced to six months in prison for falsifying his tax records.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: -SCHOOL friend was ''allergic'' to the cold. She was embarrassed to go to school on cold, windy days because her face would be covered with raised, red, itchy blotches, commonly called hives, by the time she had walked the four blocks from her home.

title: TV: AN NBC WHITE PAPER ON CHINA
description: ''JOURNEY TO THE HEART OF CHINA'' does not necessarily explain China, and in a way it makes it more remote than ever. On the other hand, China possibly is beyond explanation, at least in conventional Western terms, and a recognition of the remoteness may be the first step toward any understanding. ''Journey to the Heart of China,'' an NBC White Paper, will be seen on NBC-TV at 8 o'clock tonight.

title: BUSINESSMAN GUILTY IN DRUG CASE
description: A Manhattan shipping broker pleaded guilty today to charges he plotted to smuggle $10 million worth of cocaine and marijuana into the United States with the aid of a Nigerian diplomat.

title: RELIGIOUS ALLIANCE AGAINST EXECUTIONS GROWS
description: The unsuccessful plea last week by Pope John Paul II to the Governor of Florida to halt the execution of a convicted murderer was the latest demonstration of a religious alliance against capital punishment that promises to grow stronger with the prospect of more executions.

title: PARAGON COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Results for the latest quarter and 6 months include results of acquisitions made on a purchase basis.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The on-again, off-again fight between Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini and Bobby Chacon is now on again and scheduled for Jan. 14, with coverage by Home Box Office. . . . Dean Steinkuhler , the star offensive guard for Nebraska, has been named lineman of the year in a poll of sportswriters and broadcasters conducted by United Press International. . . . Warren Powers, who has led Missouri to five bowl games in his six years as football coach, has been given a three-year contract extension. . . . In voting by coaches and managers, Keith Hernandez of the Mets has been named first baseman of the National League Gold Glove team for outstanding fielding, and Dave Winfield (outfield) and Ron Guidry (pitcher) of the Yankees have been selected to the American League team. The Sporting News has named Cal Ripken , the Baltimore shortstop, baseball player of the year and Ripken's general manager, Hank Peters , executive of the year.

title: ALEXANDER'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 22
description: b-Including income tax credit of $675,000.

title: AVALANCHE SEASON BEGINS IN ROCKIES
description: Snow lay heavy on the slopes and on the ponderosa pine boughs as Knox Williams scanned the soaring peaks of the Rocky Mountains' Ten Mile Range.

title: Bruno Wins 20th
description: Frank Bruno, an undefeated 22-year-old British heavyweight boxer, knocked out Walter Santemore of New Orleans in the opening minute of the fourth round at the Royal Albert Hall tonight. It was Bruno's 20th victory.

title: U.S. Criticized On Donor Role
description: The European Economic Community, in a note to the State

title: BANKING GOES INTO THE HOME
description: Every Sunday morning after James D. Dana and his wife, Grace, finish breakfast of croissants and coffee in their Upper East Side apartment, Mr. Dana does his banking.

title: ENGINEERING MEASUREMENTS COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Dutch Police Have Half Of Heineken Ransom
description: The police said today that they had found more than half of the $11 million ransom paid for Alfred H. Heineken, the brewery chairman.

HEALTH EXTENSTION SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Brokerage to Sell Mead Corp. Stock
description: The Mead Corporation filed for an offering of 1.1 million shares of common stock that are owned and being sold by the Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company brokerage, the Securities and Exchange Commission said.

title: Clip a Soviet Coupon And 'Vote for Peace'
description: The Communist youth newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda printed a peace message today in the form of a coupon to be clipped and sent to President Reagan.

title: Turkey's Generals Turn Over Power
description: Turkey's ruling generals stepped down today after more than three years in power. President Kenan Evren, who led the 1980 coup, said the military was handing over authority to the newly elected Parliament with ''easy hearts.''

title: THE CONTEST FOR DR PEPPER
description: Castle & Cooke Inc., the Honolulu- based food, real estate and manufacturing conglomerate, wants Dr Pepper for its summertime earnings and management expertise in the soft- drink industry, company officials and securities analysts say.

title: Careers; Recycling And Its Job Potential
description: PROCESSORS of solid waste are concerned that they have not been attracting enough young, knowledgeable people into their industry at the supervisory level.

title: OPERA: 'TRISTAN' AT MET
description: GENUINE Wagnerian singers are always in short supply, and with the gradual fading from the scene of Birgit Nilsson, the heroic soprano category that she represented with such spectacular success for a generation has recently found itself in something approaching a famine condition. But perhaps the fates that watch over opera have been quietly taking steps to remedy that sad state. Monday night's performance of ''Tristan und Isolde'' at the Metropolitan Opera, the season's first, showed that the opera world can count on at least one Wagnerian soprano, in the person of Hildegard Behrens. Miss Behrens, though not possessed of the immense column of tone and stentorian volume of a Nilsson, sang the punishing role of Isolde for the first time at the Metropolitan with extraordinary intelligence and an expressive range that Miss Nilsson never commanded in her greatest years.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THIS week we will endeavor to prove that things are not always what they seem in these parts. The evidence is right here in the mailbag - two letters attesting to the illusory quality of life in New York. The first one comes from the Rev. Leslie Merlin of the Brick Presbyterian Church:

title: ISLANDERS TRIUMPH AND PASS RANGERS
description: Kelly Hrudey, the Islanders' third goalie, has a rookie's credentials but a veteran's wisdom.

title: HUSSEIN, IT'S TIME TO ACT
description: President Reagan has determined that the Middle Eastern conflict is as much an East- West as an Arab-Israeli confrontation, and has committed America, diplomatically and militarily, to an effort to contain attempts by the Soviet Union and its surrogate, Syria, to expand their influence in the region. Israel obviously welcomes this policy, but other pro-Western nations in the area should be equally receptive. First among them should be King Hussein of Jordan, the reluctant peacemaker.

title: Article 094402 -- No Title
description: Metromedia Inc., a major broadcasting chain, said yesterday that four of its top executives, in partnership with an investment firm, had offered to purchase the company for about $1.6 billion.

title: HIGH COURT HEARS MEMPHIS JOBS CASE
description: The Supreme Court was told today by a Justice Department official that Federal judges had no authority to require cities to bend their seniority rules to protect recently hired black workers from budgetary layoffs.

title: BERNARDIN ASKS CATHOLICS TO FIGHT BOTH NUCLEAR ARMS AND ABORTION
description: Excerpts from speech, page B8.

title: CAPITAL OUTLAYS TO RISE AT A SLOWER PACE IN '84 WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) - Business executives plan to keep raising their spending for expansion and modernization in the first half of next year, but at a slower pace than during the post-recession surge at the end of 1983, the Government reported today.
description: Nevertheless, the increase planned in capital spending - 3.9 percent, compared with 6.7 percent in the current half - represents ''a rapid pace'' of investment, Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said.

title: WILSON P. FOSS
description: Wilson P. Foss, a conservationist and a former president and chairman of the New York Trap Rock Corporation, producer of crushed stone for roads and other construction projects, died of cancer Monday at his home in Katonah, N.Y. He was 68 years old. He also had homes in Naples, Fla., and Nantucket, Mass.

title: Noah Leaving France
description: He was the first Frenchman in 37 years to win the French Open, and the pressure of constant adulation following his victory last June was more than Yannick Noah could handle. ''I don't sleep at night, and I just wander through the streets crying,'' the 23- year-old tennis star said at a news conference in Paris, explaining his decision to move to New York.

description: Q.

description: NEWS that the VLI Corporation's Today vaginal contraceptive sponge is being investigated because of a suspected case of toxic shock syndrome in a user sent the stock down sharply yesterday.

description: b-After a writeoff of $1.3 million related to a marine vessel.

description: The Ampco-Pittsburgh Corporation said it is offering 1.2 million common shares at $16.50 a share.

title: The Drizzle of '83
description: During the Blizzard of '88 snow fell for four days, blew into drifts 10 feet high and gave New Yorkers something to brag about for the rest of their lives. The survivors of the Drizzle of '83 may think their accomplishment pretty small potatoes.

title: South Africa Prices Up
description: Production prices in South Africa rose by 8 percent in the first 10 months of the year, their smallest increase in 11 years, the Government's Central Statistical Services said today.

title: STREAK OF KNICKS IS ENDED AT FOUR
description: Kiki Vandeweghe is the second best scorer in the National Basketball Association this season. Dan Issel, at 35 years old and in his 14th professional season, is still probably the best outside shooting center in the league.

title: Rancher Jailed for Cruelty
description: A rancher was sentenced Monday to six months in jail for starving a herd of wild horses he had bought from the Federal Government. The rancher, Joe Corbett of Pittsburg, Tex., was also fined $4,000 in Federal District Court and given five years of probation. Mr. Corbett pleaded guilty in October to reduced charges of cruelty to animals.

title: SPACE TEST JOLTS INNER-EAR THEORY
description: A Nobel Prize- winning theory about the physiology of the inner ear was shaken today in a test conducted by scientists aboard the space shuttle Columbia.

title: Realty World Founder Joins Softwaire Centre
description: William Janeski, who developed Realty World into a major real estate franchise chain, is switching to computer software franchising. Mr. Janeski, 51, is joining Softwaire Centre International as president and chief executive.

title: WESTERN MICROWAVE LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $14,000 for the quarter and $54,000 for the year. c-Including tax credits of $8,000 for the quarter and $27,000 for the year.

title: MICHEL IN WARNING ON MILITARY FUNDS
description: Robert H. Michel, the Republican leader in the House, has cautioned President Reagan against asking Congress for the 22 percent increase in military spending that Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger has discussed with some legislators.

description: b-Including tax credits of $1,254,000 for the quarter and $2,285,000 for the 9 months. c-Including tax credits of $1.7 million for the quarter and $2,950,000 for the 9 months.

description: b-Including a gain of $7,814 from discontinued operations.

BREAK IN WATER MAIN SNARLS CANAL STREET
description: A water main burst beneath Canal Street in lower Manhattan early yesterday, flooding subway tracks and disrupting rush-hour service to tens of thousands of commuters.

title: J P INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $513,000 from the early extinguishment of notes.

title: 3 DEMOCRATIC ASPIRANTS JOIN IN RULES CHALLENGE
description: Three candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination joined the Rev. Jesse Jackson today in questioning the fairness of the party's delegate- selection rules, while edgy party officials tried to talk Mr. Jackson out of making the issue a centerpiece of his campaign.

title: Reagan Hails Venezuelan
description: (UPI) - President Reagan has sent a congratulatory telegram to Jaime Lusinchi, the newly elected President of Venezuela, the White House spokesman said today. The spokesman, Larry Speakes, said that in his message ''the President notes with pleasure the Venezuelan democratic process has once again demonstrated its vitality.''

title: Key Rates
description: * Nuveen index, John Nuveen & CompanySalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: INSULATED COOKIE SHEET
description: ABAKING sheet is something many home cooks take for granted - such a mundane utensil that little thought goes into the purchase. I have learned over the years that the quality of a baking sheet can make a vast difference in the results.

title: DAMASCUS CLAIMS 2 ISRAELI DRONES
description: Syria said today that its air defenses had shot down two Israeli pilotless drones over Syrian positions in eastern Lebanon and southwest Syria. An Israeli military spokesman in Tel Aviv confirmed the loss of one pilotless plane.

title: Nicaraguan Insurgents Reject an Amnesty Bid
description: Nicaraguan rebel leaders today rejected an offer of amnesty to those Nicaraguans who had left the country since 1979.

title: MRS. THATCHER SAYS BRITAIN WILL KEEP TROOPS IN BRITAIN
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher called the increase in violence in Lebanon ''very worrying'' today, but she said her Government did not plan to pull the small British unit out of Beirut.

title: SMYSLOV AND KASPAROV WIN IN CHESS
description: Vasily Smyslov and Gary Kasparov won the seventh games in their world chess semifinals here today.

title: THE POLITICS OF THE NOBEL FOR LITERATURE
description: The Swedish Academy's official ledger of the immortally ignored includes James Joyce, Leo Tolstoy, Henry James, August Strindberg and Joseph Conrad. Add Honore de Balzac: if the Nobel Prize for Literature existed when he was alive, he would have been passed over, too.

title: Florida Power
description: The Florida Power and Light Company filed an offering with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $350 million of first mortgage bonds. The underwriters are Salomon Brothers; Goldman, Sachs & Company, and Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. Proceeds will be added to general funds.

title: Farm Aid Costly for U.S. and Japan
description: The growing costs of rising farm subsidies are not limited to the members of the Common Market. The United States and Japan also maintain costly but politically critical support programs. The disputes over the programs have focused attention on what each group spends.

title: BANKER'S NOTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Net loss.

title: DIETER FICKEN'S DECISION
description: There was a family farm in Bremen, Germany, but

title: Visa Energy
description: The Visa Energy Corporation said it had filed to reorganize under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code after talks for an equity infusion ended without agreement. Visa, an oil and gas company based in Denver, said talks were continuing with outside investors. Visa also said that litigation with the Marshall Exploration Company of Marshall, Tex., had been settled by Visa's sale of certain Texas properties to Marshall for $4.8 million and by a $1 million production payment.

title: Atom Attack Impact Assayed
description: A Government study has concluded that a huge nuclear attack would not destroy the nation's capacity to grow food.

title: Kings 112 Mavericks 103
description: The forwards Mark Olberding and Eddie Johnson combined for 51 points to help Kansas City end an eight-game Dallas winning streak. Olberding scored 26 points, Johnson 25 and Larry Drew had 13 assists as Kansas City handed Dallas its first loss since Nov. 12, dropping the Midwest Division-leading Mavericks to 13-5.

title: County Clears Up Police Head's Role
description: The Westchester County Board of Legislators approved a bill Monday making the Commissioner of Public Safety serve at the pleasure of the County Executive.

title: Possible Guilt, Certain Death
description: Charles Knapp will miss his appointment in Arizona's gas chamber today. The state should be just as relieved as he is that a Federal court has stayed the event. Mr. Knapp may be guilty of child neglect, even abuse, but did he burn his daughters to death? Soberingly, it seems possible that someone else committed the crimes for which he was to die.

title: U.S. REPLACES HEAD OF LATIN AID FUND
description: The head of a Government agency that makes grants to Latin American civic organizations and other groups that sponsor self-help projects for the needy has been dismissed by board members appointed by the Reagan Administration.

title: U.S. SEEKS TO STOP BULLETPROOF VESTS FOR SYRIA
description: The Commerce Department said today that it was investigating whether it could block the shipment to Syria of bulletproof vests made in West Germany from synthetic material manufactured in the United States.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: STONES FOR IBARRA. By Harriet Doerr, 214 pages. Viking Press. $14.95. LET everyone take heart from Harriet Doerr of Pasadena, Calif., who at the age of 73 has published her first novel. Called ''Stone For Ibarra,'' it's a very good novel indeed, with echoes of Gabriel Garcia Marquez, Katherine Anne Porter and even Graham Greene.

title: U.S. ARMS OFFICIAL OFFERS VIEW ON TALKS
description: The Reagan Administration's top arms control official said today that the Russians have given no formal message of plans to break off strategic arms talks in Geneva despite public hints that these talks were in jeopardy.

title: Kenya-Tanzania Agreements
description: Kenya and Tanzania have signed agreements on trade, transportation, tourism and telecommunications, the official Tanzania radio said today. The agreements followed the Nov. 17 treaty the two East African countries signed to reopen their common border, which had been closed since 1977.

title: TEA BREWING: JUST HOT ISN'T HOT ENOUGH
description: To the Editor:

title: PROPOSED RISES IN TRANSIT FARES ARE UNDER FIRE
description: Witness after witness told a hearing yesterday that a rise in the 75-cent subway and bus fares would be disastrous and unfair, but the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority repeated that an increase to 90 cents was all but inevitable.

title: TV: CBS'S 'PROTOTYPE,' A NOD TO FRANKENSTEIN
description: MICHAEL is a humanoid and looks as if he is in his early 20's. Carl is the Nobel Prize-winning scientist who created him (or it, if you want to get technical). When the Pentagon gets involved with Michael's ''programming,'' Carl fears the Government wants to use him for destructive purposes, perhaps a political assassination. Carl kidnaps his creature from the science laboratory and runs away, leaving behind wife, home, friends and colleagues.

title: School Bus Crashes Hurt 47
description: At least 47 people were injured Monday in two school bus crashes in Louisiana.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Democratic Leader Presses His Case

title: VALUATION BY MERRILL LYNCH DISPUTED
description: The Labor Department and Merrill Lynch & Company are caught up in a dispute over whether the nation's largest securities firm compromised its independence in evaluating the assets of an insurance company owned by Allen M. Dorfman, a longtime associate of organized crime figures.

title: VARI-CARE INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
CHURCH, STATE TANGLES
description: ''Congress, '' the First Amendment intones, ''shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof.'' These crisp, elegant phrases seem to draw a clean line between the dominion of the church and the state. But hidden complexities haunt legislative and executive officials seeking to accommodate civil and spiritual concerns, as the Constitution requires.

title: INQUIRY ON CARTER DATA SAID TO FOCUS ON 2 MEN
description: The chairman of a Congressional panel investigating how documents were passed from Jimmy Carter's White House to Ronald Reagan's Presidential campaign in 1980 said he was focusing on Paul Corbin, a political consultant, and William J. Casey, now the Director of Central Intelligence, who was Mr. Reagan's campaign chief.

title: NAVY STUNG BY CRITICISM, DEFENDS COST OF BOMBING RAID IN LEBANON
description: A senior United States admiral said today that information about Syrian antiaircraft batteries in Lebanon was inadequate and American pilots encountered more intense fire than they expected during Sunday's bombing raid.

title: f912
description: To the Editor:

title: AIR POWER IN LEBANON: LIMITS TO EFFECTIVENESS
description: Military operations and intelligence specialists in Washington and other NATO capitals question whether bombing alone or in concert with naval gunfire will halt shelling of the Marines in Beirut. They also question whether such action will stifle missile and artillery antiaircraft fire against American reconnaissance planes.

title: FOR 2 GIVING TO THE NEEDIEST IS TRADITION OLD AS THE FUND
description: A tradition of giving is often cited by people contributing to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, and Evelyn Brand of Manhattan can boast of having been a donor since the fund was started in 1912.

title: MAGNA INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: SHOWTIME New York University is taking on the aura of a theater center tonight, what with three openings, even though it is a coincidence of scheduling. On tap are a musical Shakespeare, a revived Odets and an original study of early American labor leaders.

title: Economic Scene; The Real Rate Of Interest
description: NEWS of the sharp drop in the civilian unemployment rate to 8.4 percent last month, from 8.8 percent in October, produced joy in the White House among those working for President Reagan's re-election. But it brought anxiety to Wall Street, where signs of strength in the economic recovery are disturbing investors.

title: BRIEFS
description: Alexander & Baldwin Inc., Honolulu, said it would enter the macadamia nut business with a planting of 20 acres of trees on the island of Kauai in January.

title: Steinbrenner Keeps Nashville Waiting
description: The man who wasn't here commanded more attention today than most of the people who were here. The man was George Steinbrenner, and a wide variety of people at baseball's winter meetings - from owners to agents - asked throughout the day, ''When is George getting here.''

title: Grey Starts Campaign To Promote Telefirst
description: While generally all pay-television services are tied in to cable systems, Telefirst Inc., which ABC Entertainment will begin to test in Chicago next month, will have all television households as its oyster. But to make customers out of them will require the aid of that old devil - advertising.

title: Douwe Egberts
description: The Consolidated Foods Corporation said Douwe Egberts, a 65 percent owned subsidiary, would offer to buy all the rest of its shares for a total of $100 million. Douwe Egberts, based in the Netherlands, sells coffee, tea and tobacco products.

title: Alcohol Warning Defended by Koch
description: Mayor Koch, saying he was ''shocked'' at objections raised by the National Organization for Women, said yesterday that he would sign a bill passed by the City Council requiring bars, liquor stores and restaurants to post warnings that drinking during pregnancy can cause birth defects.

title: IRANIAN AT U.N.: NO ROOM ON AGENDA
description: In the last 10 days, an Iranian exile opposed to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini went from mission to mission at the United Nations hoping to place a resolution on the agenda of the General Assembly condemning Iran for ''grave violations of human rights.''

title: HOW DEREGULATION ALLOWED GREYHOUND TO WIN CONCESSIONS FROM STRIKERS
description: The Greyhound strike, for which a tentative settlement has been reached, is one of many instances in which deregulation of the transportation industry is forcing concessions on wages and work rules from workers and affecting longstanding labor-management relations. Many trucking companies refuse to pay wage scales mandated by contracts. Thousands of nonunion companies have emerged, and they are paying substantially less than union wages.

title: SAMPLING FOR COOKS FROM '100 DINNERS';
description: The following are recipes for some of the dishes served last night during ''A Night of 100 Dinners'' to benefit the New York Public Library.
