title: Another Marine Dies, Blast's 240th Victim
description: A United States marine has died from injuries suffered in the Beirut bomb blast, becoming the 240th serviceman to die from the terrorist explosion, officials said today.

title: EXCERPTS FROM CARDINAL BERNARDIN'S APPEAL FOR A 'CONSISTENT EHTIC OF LIFE'
description: Following are excerpts from the address yesterday by Joseph Cardinal Bernardin of Chicago at Fordham University in the Bronx:

title: FISCHBACH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results have been restated to reflect the pooling of interest with Electricon Inc. in the fourth quarter of fiscal 1983.

title: Biogen in Venture With the Chinese
description: Biogen N.V., a Netherlands-based biotechnology company, said it would enter a venture to market gamma interferon in China.

title: New Soup Kitchen for Paris
description: The Salvation Army will open a night soup kitchen Wednesday for the estimated 8,000 people who call the streets of Paris home. Two trucks will make regular rounds through the capital, stopping at railroad stations, churches and other known gathering places of the homeless. Last year the Salvation Army served 23,500 meals of bread and soup during the three worst months of winter.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report last Thursday about New York City's role as a landlord misidentified the organization that provided a lawyer for Rose Brush, a woman whose house was seized for nonpayment of taxes. It was the Brooklyn Legal Services Corporation.

title: ADVERTISING
description: People

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: BECAUSE saffron is the most expensive spice in the world, I am often asked if it is really a necessary ingredient. The answer is that while it may generally be dispensed with, some dishes need it for genuine authenticity, among them saffron rice, saffron cake and, of course, a true paella as made in Spain and bouillabaisse as made in Marseilles.

title: THE NODES: WHY THEY HAD FLAWS
description: To produce a hollow steel ball about 8 inches in diameter with 10 holes of various sizes would not seem to be much of a challenge to modern engineering.

title: On Hair Analysis
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Atlanta Fed Picks A New President
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, after searching for a new president since October, announced yesterday that it had found one - in its own institution.

title: Williams Ordered To Enter Prison
description: Former Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. of New Jersey has been directed to surrender Jan. 9 to begin a three-year prison term for bribery arising from the Abscam investigation into political corruption, a Federal prosecutor said yesterday.

title: Iranians to Urge Use Of OPEC 'Oil Weapon'
description: Iranian delegates said today that they would appeal to Arab members at a meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to use the ''oil weapon'' against the United States in the struggle in Lebanon.

title: A SOUTHWEST RANCH LEGEND DIES
description: Gus Raney, a double-murder suspect who said he was 101 years old and depicted himself as a former lawman and cattle rustler, died today at a hospital where he was admitted Thursday night with chest pains.

title: RED SOX SEND TUDOR TO PIRATES
description: John Tudor, one of the most pursued pitchers in the winter talent market, was traded by the Boston Red Sox to the Pittsburgh Pirates today for Mike Easler, the outfielder.

title: Hawks 95, Suns 88
description: Eddie Johnson scored all of his 14 points in the fourth quarter as Atlanta ended a Phoenix rally to post the victory.

title: SCOUTING
description: Honduran Tour

title: Advertising; Gillette Dismisses An Agency
description: THE Gillette Company announced yesterday that it had dismissed Advertising to Women, one of its agencies for six years, because of the Federal tax problems of its former chairman, John L. Ernst.

title: U.S. STEEL MAKERS TRYING TO 'KEEP THE OTHER PLAYERS OFF THE FIELD'
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK UNION CHIEF OPPOSES GREYHOUND OFFER
description: The leader of striking Greyhound workers in the New York area said yesterday that he could not recommend approval of a tentative agreement with the bus line, but he warned that a negative vote might leave strikers without their jobs.

title: A TASK TOO GREAT FOR THE SUPERPOWERS
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: It's Part of the Job, Says the Mayor

title: ABC TO CUT 'NIGHTLINE' TO HALF-HOUR
description: ABC announced yesterday that ''Nightline,'' the network's late-night news analysis and discussion program anchored by Ted Koppel, will be reduced from an hour to a half- hour nightly on Feb. 20.

title: DANCE: MARTIN'S LAST
description: ''FEAR not, I shall not dance,'' Mayor Koch promised last night's State Theater audience at intermission during what was billed simultaneously as Peter Martins's farewell performance with the New York City Ballet, Jerome Robbins's debut as Drosselmeier and the 1,000th performance of George Balanchine's ''The Nutcracker.''

title: Ling-Ling Is Seriously Ill
description: Ling- Ling, the female giant panda at the National Zoo, is ''seriously ill'' with kidney problems and her prognosis for recovery is poor, Robert Hoag, special assistant to the zoo director, said today. Ling-Ling, he said, was suffering from kidney dysfunction and severe secondary anemia. He said she was given a transfusion of blood from Hsing-Hsing, the zoo's male panda, ''to boost her critically low blood cell count,'' and was also being given antibiotics. Mr. Hoag said Hsing-Hsing remained in good health.

title: CONCERT: BRAHMS BY PERLMAN AND ASHKENAZY
description: WHEN Vladimir Ashkenazy and Itzhak Perlman joined forces to play the complete Brahms Violin Sonatas in Carnegie Hall on Sunday night, it was a slightly idiosyncratic composer that emerged. This Brahms was a gentlemanly fellow of no rash inclinations; he only occasionally had anything to say with much urgency.

title: I.B.M. Teller: Exact Change
description: The International

title: ADVERTISING
description: Atari Assigns More to D.D.B. Atari Inc., the troubled division of Warner Communications, announced yesterday

title: NATO WEIGHS SHIFT IN ARMS PARLEYS
description: Defense ministers from the Atlantic alliance's European member countries today discussed the possibility of calling on the United States and Soviet Union to move arms negotiations forward by merging the talks on strategic and middle-range nuclear weapons.

title: GUARD IS CHARGED IN LONDON THEFT
description: A guard for the company that had three tons of gold bullion worth almost $38 million taken from its warehouse at Heathrow Airport was arrested Sunday and charged today in connection with the theft.

title: INSIDE RACK IN RACE FOR BAKER SEAT
description: Senator Bob Dole has a little list. It contains 54 names, all of fellow Republicans in the Senate, and each day the Kansas lawmaker tracks down a few more by telephone and makes the same pitch.

title: ISRAELIS FACE GROWING SHIITE HOSTILITY
description: The Moslem clergyman was unequivocal.

title: CRANSTON CALLS ON THE CITY'S 'MOVERS AND SHAKERS'
description: Senator Alan Cranston did not touch his scrambled eggs and link sausage, sustaining himself this campaign morning with a single glass of orange juice, downed earlier at a ''Good Morning America'' broadcast.

title: Jerseyan Gives Up In Hostage Case
description: A 29-year-old man armed with two handguns surrendered to the police this morning after holding 9 members of his family hostage for more than 12 hours and critically wounding his wife's mother and brother.

title: 4 ISRAELIS KILLED BY BOMB PLANTED ON JERUSALEM BUS
description: Four Israelis were killed and 46 wounded today when a bomb, apparently planted by a Palestinian terrorist, destroyed a crowded bus at the height of the lunchtime rush hour in Jerusalem.

title: Man Pleads No Contest In 6 Alaskan Slayings
description: Louis Hastings, a 39-year-old computer programmer, pleaded no contest Monday to charges that he killed six people and wounded two others last spring in a remote mining community.

title: PEP BOYS-MANNY MOE & JACK reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-1 stock split paid in April.

title: RESTAURANT WINS LIBEL SUIT OVER NEGATIVE REVIEW
description: A Manhattan restaurant owner has won a jury award of $20,005 for libel against the authors and the publisher of a negative review of its food and service in a French-language guide to New York City.

title: Suspension Ended
description: Ric Nattress, the Montreal Canadien defenseman who had been suspended for the season after conviction on a minor marijuana charge, will be allowed to return to the lineup for the club's 31st game, against the Pittsburgh Penguins Sunday. In trimming the suspension from 80 games to 30, John Ziegler, the president of the National Hockey League, said he had been impressed by Nattress's exemplary conduct since the punishment was imposed.

title: Blues 8, Sabres 2
description: Wayne Babych scored three goals, and Brian Sutter and Bernie Federko each scored two for St. Louis.

title: ALASKA OPENS LIMITED HUNT FOR MUSK OX
description: The Alaska Department of Fish and Game has issued permits to 31 of 150 applicants who sought a chance next spring to hunt one of the state's coveted musk oxen, which have risen from extinction to relative abundance in 50 years.

title: SUPPORT PLAZA GETS BLUE CHIP TENANTS
description: When United States Aviation Underwriters Inc. agreed last week to lease 60,000 square feet at One Seaport Plaza, which is nearing completion at 199 Water Street, the deal represented more than just the renting of two more floors - at least to the developer of the building, Jack Resnick & Sons Inc.

title: INTERPHARM LABORATORIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DAWKINS SCORES AS NETS END SLIDE
description: The Cleveland Cavaliers are the kind of team that Darryl Dawkins, at 6 feet 11 inches and 260 pounds, is supposed to excel against but rarely has in his 10 years as a pro.

title: CRONKITE NOW CRITICAL OF CBS NEWS
description: Walter Cronkite, who anchored the ''CBS Evening News'' for more than 18 years, is leveling criticism at his successors on the half-hour nightly news broadcast, saying the program has become more concerned with entertaining audiences and less committed to covering all the important stories of the day.

title: The Police Blotter
description: Margaret Mertz of Jamaica, Queens, died of a heart attack yesterday after being knocked down by a robber at noon in the lobby of her apartment house at 87-15 165th Street, the police said.. She was believed to be in her 70's. The robber fled with her pocketbook. . . . George Rivera, 18 years old, of 1240 Sherman Street, the Bronx, was shot and killed with his own gun in the attempted robbery Monday night of a grocery store at 218 McClellan Street, according to the police.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We intend our opposition to abortion and our opposition to nuclear war to be seen as specific applications of this broader attitude.

title: Short-Term Interest Rates Off; Swaps Mark Slow Trading
description: Short-term interest rates fell yesterday as investors continued to shorten the maturities in their portfolios. As a result, prices in the long end of the fixed-income market showed the largest losses, while those in the area of two to five years were generally unchanged or up by only 1/32 or 2/ 32 of a point.

title: GETTY OIL BYLAWS AMENDED
description: Gordon P. Getty amended the bylaws of the Getty Oil Company today, apparently in an effort to halt the company's legal challenge to his sole voting authority over a family trust that controls 40.2 percent of Getty Oil's common shares. Mr. Getty was joined in his action by the J. Paul Getty Museum, which holds 11.8 percent of the shares.

title: ADVANCED SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
uf3 Letter: On OSHA Making 14 Million Jobs Safer
description: To the Editor:

title: DEERE & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including a gain of $16.2 million for the quarter and year from the favorable settlement of a lawsuit and income of $18.3 million for the quarter and $41.7 million for the year from inventory adjustments. c-Including income of $34 million for the quarter and year from inventory adjustments.

title: GETTING THE GOODS
description: Observations on shopping in department stores:

title: U.S. OPENS HEARINGS ON SHOREHAM PLANS
description: The Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission opened hearings today on developing an emergency evacuation plan for the Shoreham nuclear power plant, an issue that threatens to block operation of the Long Island Lighting Company's reactor.

title: ROBERT ALDRICH, FILM DIRECTOR WHO MADE 'THE DIRTY DOZEN'
description: Robert Aldrich, who scorned his family's banking empire to chronicle a cavalcade of misfits as a film director, died of kidney failure Monday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 65 years old.

title: India Seizes 3 Officers As Military Spies
description: The Indian Government announced today that it had arrested three former senior military officers for passing military secrets on to a foreign government.

title: ROYAL BANK OF CANADA reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
NEPAL, ITS LAND USED TO THE LIMIT, TURNS TO RIVERS
description: Seldom has man's impact on the environment been so starkly evident as in Nepal, land of the stunningly scenic Himalayas and little-tapped hydroelectric riches.

title: MEDICAL ASSOCIATION URGES INSANITY DEFENSE BE ENDED
description: Leaders of the American Medical Association voted today in favor of abolishing the insanity defense in criminal trials despite opposition from psychiatrists and lawyers.

title: FOREST CITY ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income.

title: 7 REPORTED HELD IN LONDON THEFT
description: Seven more people were reported today to have been arrested in connection with the theft of three tons of gold bullion worth $38 million from a security company's warehouse at Heathrow Airport.

title: Stanford Loses a Round On Reagan Library
description: Stanford University officials failed to persuade White House aides today to let Stanford govern President Reagan's proposed presidential library complex.

title: Newark Approves School Bond Issue
description: A $62.6 million bond package has been approved to pay for improvements and additions to school facilities in the state's largest city, officials announced.

title: DRUGS OUTLAWED IN MILITARY
description: President Reagan signed into law on Tuesday a bill that specifically outlaws the use in the military of all drugs that are illegal in civilian life, including heroin, cocaine and marijuana. The law also permits direct Supreme Court review of decisions made by the Court of Military Appeals.

title: Kidde Divestiture Plans
description: Kidde Inc. said it plans a major divestiture program that will result in a loss for the year.

title: KLANSMAN TELLS OF ABDUCTING AND HANGING BLACK
description: A Ku Klux Klansman told a jury today that he and a fellow Klan member abducted a black teen-ager two years ago because he ''seemed like a good victim,'' then strangled him with a rope and left his body dangling from a tree.

title: MUSIC: RUDOLF SERKIN PERFORMS
description: HAS Rudolf Serkin ever played a routine or offhand note in his life? It seems unlikely. The 80-year-old pianist gave another of his fiercelycommitted recitals last night at Carnegie Hall, showing once again what artistry and professionalism in music should be all about. He came onto the stage in his familiar, embarrassed manner, smiling sweetly but with his head hanging as if to discourage the applause. He had come to play Haydn, Beethoven and Schubert for us and wanted to get right at it without delay.

title: GUILTY PLEA IN INSIDER CASE
description: E. Jacques Courtois Jr., a former vice president in the mergers and acquisitions department of Morgan Stanley & Company, pleaded guilty yesterday to charges that he illegally traded on insider information. His plea, in Federal District Court in Manhattan, was a reversal of an earlier plea.

title: EGYPT COOL TO ASSURANCES BY U.S. ON STRATEGIC ACCORD WITH ISRAEL
description: Nicholas A. Veliotes, the new United States Ambassador to Egypt, presented his credentials to President Hosni Mubarak today and tried to assuage Egyptian concerns about the new strategic agreement between the United States and Israel.

title: VICTORIA & GREY TRUSTCO reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: b-Including security gains of $8,223,000 for the latest year and $5,602,000 for the previous year and a deduction of $4,785,000 for the previous year covering a reduction in the carrying value of an investment in Transohio Financial Corp.

title: FOES OF L.I. FARE RISE WARN OF HIGH ECONOMIC TOLL
description: A proposed fare increase of from 20 to 25 percent on the Long Island Rail Road was opposed today by commuters and pubic officials at the last of three pubic hearings held by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: Washington State Mortgage Bonds
description: The Washington State Housing Fi=?nance Corporation entered the credit markets with a $193.5 million issue of mortgage-revenue bonds sold through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE ISLAND OF CRIMEA. By Vassily Aksyonov. Translated by Michael Henry Heim. 369 pages. Random House. $16.95.

title: Arthur Pearce, Ex-Publisher Of Connecticut Newspapers
description: Arthur Williams Pearce, a former Connecticut newspaper publisher, died Monday at St. Vincent's Medical Center in Bridgeport, Conn.

title: Pope Ready to Meet Man Who Shot Him
description: Italian Government officials said today that Pope John Paul II had asked to meet at Christmas with the Turk who shot him in 1981.

title: U.S. SAID TO DRAW PLAN FOR SHIFTING MARINES IN BEIRUT
description: The Joint Chiefs of Staff have begun drafting plans to redeploy the American Marine unit in Beirut away from the airport to safer ground in Lebanon or to amphibious vessels offshore, Administration officials said today.

title: CUOMO OPPOSES USING SURPLUS TO PAY CITY LOANS
description: Governor Cuomo said yesterday that he opposed any attempt by New York City to use an expected $1 billion surplus from the Municipal Assistance Corporation to speed the paying off of federally guaranteed loans.

title: BRIEFING
description: A Matter of Conscience

title: STOVE MAKERS
description: Here is a sampling of wood- stove manufacturers. Some sell their stoves through retailers, while others sell directly to consumers and ship c.o.d.

title: UNICEF IS HOPEFUL ON A HEALTH GAIN
description: Governments and private agencies, by using low cost, readily available methods, could save half of the 40,000 children who die in the world every day if they undertook a ''serious commitment'' to do so, according to a report to be issued Thursday by Unicef, the United Nations Children's Fund.

title: GRANT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
GADGETS FOR TRAVELERS
description: SMALL versions of several appliances regularly used at home will come in handy for travelers.

title: America's Hurtful Parsimony
description: Hiding behind Congress, the Reagan Administration has again rejected pleas to increase America's aid to the poorest countries. At negotiations in Paris tomorrow about expanding the International Development Association, the World Bank's soft- loan affiliate, the United States has decided to offer $750 million a year for three years. That's slightly less than it contributed over the last four years, and much less than is needed.

title: Omnimedical President
description: The Omnimedical Corporation, a medical scanner maker, said it had retained a management consulting firm to help improve financial performance, and had appointed a new president to replace Ronald L. Stoddart, who resigned. Gary R. Mounts, chairman, replaced him.

title: CONSOLIDATED GAS NAMES A PRESIDENT
description: Ralbern H. Murray, who helped the Consolidated Natural Gas Company build sales in its hour of need, has been named president and chief operating officer, effective March 1. Mr. Murray, 54 years old, succeeds G. J. Tankersley, 62, as president. Mr. Tankersley will continue as chairman and chief executive.

title: P.L.O. TRUCE PACT CALLED COMPLETE
description: Yasir Arafat and the rebel Palestinians who have been besieging him and his guerrilla supporters here were reported today to have agreed on the final details of their mutual withdrawal from Tripoli within the next two weeks.

title: Time Inc. Spinoff
description: At a special meeting, Time Inc.'s stockholders approved the spinoff of the company's forest products subsidiary, Temple-Inland Inc. The stockholders also approved plans to reincorporate Time as a Delaware company.

title: HUNGARIAN IN SLOVAKIA FIGHTING FOR RIGHTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Experts Laud Tooth Sealants
description: A thin plastic coating over children's teeth could prevent many from getting cavities and decay if more dentists used the method, a panel said today in a draft statement to the National Institutes of Health.

title: Bullets Defeat Mavericks
description: Jeff Ruland scored 35 points, including the winning layup with 24 seconds left, and Rick Mahorn blocked a shot by Mark Aguirre with 10 seconds to go to give the Washington Bullets a 114-112 victory over the Dallas Mavericks tonight.

title: PROLER INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
GRADUATE SCHOOLS GET AN UNHAPPY ANALYSIS
description: The sun came out today after Tuesday's rain, but it could not dispel the demographic gloom that had gathered over the nearly 100 presidents, chancellors, provosts and deans of major colleges assembled here to ponder what they agreed was the flagging condition of graduate education.

title: OEA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Firestone Net Rises by 80%
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, citing gains in both its North American and international tire operations, said today that net income in its fiscal fourth quarter rose 80 percent from a year earlier.

title: WEST BANK CENSORSHIP
description: To the Editor:

BARRING ALIENS FOR POLITICAL REASONS
description: A week ago the State Department rejected visa applications from Nicaragua's Interior Minister, Tomas Borge, and Roberto d'Aubuisson, the President of the Salvadoran Constituent Assembly.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Berlitz of North America, which operates a chain of language schools, has moved its ad account to Nadler & Larimer, one of the Mickelberry companies.

title: STOCKS UP IN HEAVY TRADING
description: Stock prices rose moderately yesterday in very heavy trading, with some of the technology and airline issues posting strong gains.

title: Viking Reinstated
description: Bud Grant , coach of the Minnesota Vikings, lifted the suspension of Ted Brown , the team's second-best rusher and third-leading receiver. He was suspended last week for missing a practice, a team meeting and two treatments for a separated shoulder.

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 8, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''To be back home still feels like a dream to me.

title: Inter-American Bank in Offering
description: The Inter-American Development Bank yesterday sold $200 million of 12 1/4 percent bonds due in 2008 to underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: Foes of Marcos Schedule Parley to Plan Strategy
description: A national convention of the many opposition political parties and citizens' groups throughout the country has been scheduled here next month to work out a coordinated strategy against President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: 19 From Soviet Enter U.S.
description: Nineteen Soviet citizens have arrived on a friendship mission in a 30-hour trip that avoided the ban on Soviet Aeroflot travel to the United States. The group arrived Tuesday night to be part of a lecture series at Clackamas Community College in Oregon City, Ore., ''Understanding the Soviets: A Path to Peace.''

title: AIDE SAYS GULF BURNING OF WASTES MAY GO AHEAD
description: A Federal official said today that the Government should probably have issued regulations for burning cancer- causing waste at sea and indicated that burning planned for the Gulf of Mexico would go forward.

title: SHOREHAM EPITOMIZES END OF A NUCLEAR BUILDING ERA
description: As it nears completion, the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station on Long Island is being cited as the local example of what industry experts say is the end of an era of reactor construction in the United States.

title: JETRONIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $166,000 for the quarter and 9 months.

title: RATES MIXED IN QUIET SEASON
description: Interest rates were mixed and little changed in quiet trading yesterday. Market participants said many potential investors were waiting until later this month, when the Treasury plans to sell a large amount of notes and bonds.

title: WITH SKYSCRAPERS, A WINDY DAY IS WINDIER
description: A whipping wind swept through lower Manhattan yesterday, a miniature tornado struck Times Square and lesser windstorms knocked around pedestrians on some street corners around town.

title: Lucienne Boyer, a Singer; Popular in Paris in 1930's
description: Lucienne Boyer, the French cabaret singer who reigned as queen of Paris nightlife during the 1930's, died of a stroke Tuesday.

title: BRIEFS
description: Affiliated Bank Corp. of Wyoming said Financial Resources of Wyoming Inc. had terminated its proposed acquisition offer for Affiliated.

title: RICHARDSON ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
MONARCH AVALON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
OPEC to Hold Line In Tentative Pact
description: Oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries tentatively agreed today to maintain the group's prices and production quotas at current levels.

title: HAMILTON GROUP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After provisions of $500,000 for the quarter and $900,000 for the 6 months for losses in guarantee of bank loans and tax credits of $240,500 for the quarter and $545,500 for the 6 months. c-Net loss.

title: Pacific Telesis Rate Increase
description: The California Public Utility Commission granted the Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company, soon to be Pacific Telesis, $446 million of the $828 million it had requested in rate increases.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Education Reform, Revisited
description: The last year has brought a flood of impressive reports on the state of American education. The noise has abated, but the interest in excellence has not. That's evident this week in Indianapolis, where 1,700 educators, officials, business representatives, parents and students have been summoned by the Federal Education Department to assess the reports and focus on ways to make schools stronger.

title: ULTRASYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
ST. LOUIS PAPER'S OWNER TO START SALE TALKS
description: The Newhouse newspaper chain, under pressure from the Justice Department to try to keep The St. Louis Globe-Democrat from closing, said yesterday that it was willing to start negotiations with three possible buyers.

title: Frazier in Tax Fight
description: Challenging an Internal Revenue Service claim for $115,000 in extra taxes, Joe Frazier has argued in court in Philadelphia that a 365-acre South Carolina plantation he bought for his mother in 1971 was a business venture whose expenses qualified as legitimate deductions on his tax returns. The former heavyweight champion brought suit after the I.R.S. disallowed $220,000 in such deductions he took from 1971 to 1976. A ruling was deferred. . . . Larry Frazier, a heavyweight not related to Joe, who was ranked 10th nationally last year, was sentenced in Bakersfield, Calif., to three years for attacking a peace officer while under the influence of drugs.

title: DEMOCRATS' SWEEP THROUGH WEST POINTS UP SOME POLITICAL DISCORD
description: After a cross-country fund-raising tour for their party, six Democratic Presidential candidates scattered today to resume their own campaigning and to assess what they may have gained or lost from the two days of joint appearances.

title: ARMEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
AFTER A CLASH, KOCH CHANGES JUDICIARY PANEL
description: It began with a seemingly routine notification that a vacancy had been filled on the Mayor's Committee on the Judiciary. But a Sept. 26 letter to Mayor Koch from Presiding Justice Francis T. Murphy Jr. of the Appellate Division of the First Department of State Supreme Court in Manhattan touched off a sharply worded exchange. As a result, the Mayor reconstituted the committee yesterday.

title: QUADRIPLEGIC VOICES PLEA TO DIE
description: Elizabeth Bouvia, a quadriplegic making perhaps her final plea, pledged today to do all she could to fight forced feeding if a court refuses to allow her to starve herself to death in a hospital.

title: Car-Truck Crash Kills 2 L.I. Men
description: Two men were killed today when their car and a tractor-trailer collided on Nesconset Highway.

title: NATIONAL AIRPORT: NEW PLANS FOR SALE
description: For years, Washington area residents have complained of the noise generated by National Airport's heavy traffic over their homes and offices. And over the years, local and Federal officials have been coming up with plans to solve the decibel problem without lowering the airport's level of operations.

title: MAKING CONNECTIONS
description: This is the story of a connection. No hint of wrongdoing intended; just a demonstration of how a billionaire capitalist shipowner - who is also an adviser to the Government in Peking - can gain frequent access to, and perhaps influence, a total stranger who is elected President of the United States.

title: Nicaragua Invites Group Barred by Honduras
description: Nicaragua today invited 165 American and Canadian churchwomen to hold a three-day antiwar vigil in this country, two days after the group was refused entry into Honduras.

title: HOMAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $2,819,000 for the latest year and $46,000 for the previous year.

title: 3HasidimIndicted
description: Three Hasidim, including a rabbi, were indicted yesterday on felony assault and riot charges stemming from a melee between a group of Hasidim and the police in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn on Sept. 22. Nine officers were reported hurt.

title: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 8, 1983 International
description: Plans to redeploy the Marine unit in Beirut away from the airport to safer ground in Lebanon or to amphibious ships offshore are being drafted by the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Reagan Administration officials said. They stressed that no consideration was being given to withdrawing the marines. The officials said the plans were being charted in response to military, political and diplomatic pressures, including increasing uneasiness among senior military officers over the Administration's course in Lebanon. (Page A1, Column 6.) A joyful hero's welcome was accorded to 1,800 marines and sailors as they returned home to Camp Lejeune, N.C. They are the survivors of the unit that lost 240 men in a bomb attack in Beirut in October. School bands played, and thousands of yellow ribbons floated from trees, telephone poles and car antennas. (A1:5.)

title: W. Temple Webber, 79, Dies; Former Director of Time Inc.
description: W. Temple Webber, a former chairman of Temple Industries Inc., and a former director of Time Inc., died here Tuesday.

title: Kenilworth Investigation
description: Trustees of the Kenilworth Realty Liquidating Trust are sending a letter to its beneficiaries today in which they deny behaving contrary to their fiduciary obligations.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: SHELLAC is one of the oldest clear finishes known. Originally called spirit varnish, it is made of a natural resin that is secreted by certain scale insects, especially the Lacifer laca species of India. The resin is dissolved in denatured alcohol to make shellac, which in its natural state is a deep orange color. To create clear shellac (called white shellac), the resin is bleached before it is dissolved.

title: Dormer Rochester Professor
description: Dr. Elliott Waters Montroll, a professor emeritus of the University of Rochester and a leading scientist in physics, astronomy, chemistry and materials science, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Chevy Chase, Md., the university announced. He was 67 years old.

title: CONOLOG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
SUPREME EQUIPMENT & SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: CURVE BALL CONFUSES REAGAN RE-ELECTION TEAM
description: Just as things seemed to be falling into place for President Reagan's re-election campaign, a new element of uncertainty is spreading ripples of dismay and confusion through the campaign staff.

title: G.N.P. Rise Predicted
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan yesterday predicted that the gross national product could exceed 6 percent in the fourth quarter. His comment came in response to a question during a meeting with the New York Society of Security Analysts.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective. Corrections, also on this page, continue to deal with factual errors.

title: 90 ARE KILLED AS JETLINERS COLLIDE ON MADRID RUNWAY IN HEAVY FOG
description: Two Spanish jetliners collided in heavy fog on a takeoff runway here this morning, killing about 90 people and injuring more than 30 of the approximately 45 survivors. It was the second airline disaster here in 10 days.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Norwest Corp. announced that a subsidiary had filed with the S.E.C. for the sale of $458 million of bonds collateralized by Government National Mortgage Association pass- through certificates. Underwriters are led by Salomon Brothers.

title: POPE, IN TURNING POINT, RECEIVES A CZECH OFFICIAL
description: The troubled relations between Czechoslovakia and the Vatican passed a milestone on Friday but, according to a Vatican official, made no appreciable progress.

title: TURK WILL FORM FIRST CIVILIAN CABINET SINCE 1980
description: Turgut Ozal, whose conservative Motherland Party won a majority in last month's elections, was formally asked today to form Turkey's first civilian government since the military coup of 1980.

title: GOTHIC VESSELS
description: TOBIAS MOSTEL, a painter, left, has a collection of pottery and porcelain pieces based on architectural motifs. ''The vases are a relaxed reassessment of historical themes,'' Mr. Mostel said.

title: Bridge: An Expert Pays a High Cost ForTwo
description: In the department of opening leads, there are plenty of rules of thumb that make considerable sense. But they must be consumed with a grain of salt: In all cases, for ''never'' read ''hardly ever,'' and for ''always'' read ''nearly always.''

title: Textile Inquiry Halted
description: The Commerce Department said today that it had halted its investigation into allegations of unfair trade practices by Chinese companies exporting cloth and clothing to the United States, after a complaint was withdrawn by American textile makers and unions. Withdrawal of the formal complaint gives officials more time to study the issue, which otherwise would have had to be resolved by midnight Tuesday.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Bit of Personal News

title: PERRY DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
BLOCK REAGAN'S CRUDE ATTEMPT AT CENSORSHIP
description: President Reagan's Directive 84 on ''safeguarding national security information,'' a flagrant piece of right-wing zealotry, would repress or gravely distort First Amendment freedoms. Fortunately, Congress recently provided a temporary reprieve by passing a measure that postpones the effective date of the directive until April 1. President Reagan has signed that measure, perhaps reflecting a dawning awareness in the Administration that this crude attempt at mass censorship should be reconsidered.

title: AVOIDING HAZARDS IN HOLIDAY DECORATIONS
description: As grand and colorful decorations begin to grace American homes during preparations for the holidays, consumer experts are urging that caution temper the joy in the choice of how to deck the halls.

title: LEADER'S BROTHER FREED IN COLOMBIA
description: The brother of President Belisario Betancur of Colombia was freed early today, 15 days after being kidnapped by leftist guerrillas.

title: Better Airline Results Likely
description: George W. James, the chief

title: Ties With Vatican Expected
description: President Reagan plans to establish formal diplomatic relations between the United States and the Vatican, Administration officials said tonight. They said William Wilson, currently the President's personal representative at the Vatican, was the logical person to be named as ambassador. Congress last month removed a prohibition dating from 1867 on the use of Federal funds to support any diplomatic mission to the Vatican, opening the way for the establishment of formal ties.

title: DR. ABRAM S. KAGAN
description: Dr. Abram S. Kagan, founder of International Universities Press Inc., died Monday at Lawrenceville (N.J.) Hospital.

title: THE VICTORIANS AND THEIR LAWNS
description: ''ASUBSTITUTE for mowing with the scythe has lately been introduced in the form of a mowing-machine,'' announced an 1841 English publication, ''Ladies' Companion to the Flower Garden.'' Possibly the ladies wondered at the ''excellent exercise to the body'' the invention was said to provide. But there is no doubt, said Gerald Allan Doell, that the machine was essential for the development of the ''single most important aspect of Victorian landscape - the lawn.''

title: Generals Still Seeking Sipe
description: According to Donald Trump,

title: THEATER: HARRISON, 'HEARTBREAK HOUSE'
description: George Bernard Shaw's masterwork ''Heartbreak House'' is a funny and melancholy portrait of Edwardian England's idle cultured class as it hurtles blindly to self-destruction. In the revival at the Circle in the Square, we watch talented but idling actors wreak destruction on Shaw's play. Thanks to Rex Harrison's wholly delightful Captain Shotover and, to a lesser extent, Rosemary Harris's Hesione Hushabye, this enterprise has its sporadic blasts of Shavian spirit. But when only two of the eight major roles are realized, ''Heartbreak House'' is at best a Heartbreak Bedsitting Room.

title: Lear Siegler Bid For Bangor Punta
description: The Bangor Punta Corporation said Lear Siegler Inc. had made a new acquisition offer in which it would pay cash instead of stock.

title: Pratt & Whitney to Give Back $432,000 on 2 U.S. Contracts
description: The Pratt & Whitney Group, a division of the United Technologies Corporation, has volunteered to refund $432,000 to the Government on two contracts for spare parts, Senator John Tower, Republican of Texas, said Tuesday.

title: PROTESTANT PARTY LEADER SLAIN IN ULSTER
description: A prominent Protestant political leader in Northern Ireland was shot dead today as he walked to a Belfast university classroom to deliver a lecture on the law.

title: Miss Navratilova Reaches Final
description: Top-seeded Martina Navratilova advanced to the final of the $400,000 Australian Open with a 6-4, 6-3 victory over Pam Shriver today.

title: A LITTLE FANTASY ON SETTINGS FOR PLEASENT DREAMS
description: Just in case some people are short on imagination, Porthault asked such as Dina Merrill Robertson, the actress; Phyllis Wagner, the wife of the former Mayor; Adolfo, the fashion designer, and Carleton Varney, the interior designer, to whip up their ideas of a dream bed. The results are on display, and the settings range from antique French to a hunting- lodge atmosphere. In addition there is something for hardy souls who love the outdoors and a little fantasy for canine dreams.

title: FLORIDA ROCK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LESSON IN LEBANON
description: Among the wreckage in Lebanon there is a shattered illusion. That is Ronald Reagan's simple formula for American success in foreign policy.

title: Little Change In Eurobonds
description: Eurobond trading was quiet today with prices generally unchanged to slightly firmer, dealers said.

title: FLAMES LIVE FOR WOMEN WHO SURVIVED PEARL HARBOR
description: ''Billowing black smoke from burning ships'' is how Dec. 7, 1941, is remembered by Lee Harrison Johnson of Staten Island. ''Everything looked to be on fire.''

title: 160 Are Safe As Jet's Gear Fails
description: The right landing gear of American Airlines Douglas DC-10 carrying 160 people failed during landing at Newark Airport last night causing the plane to tilt to the right, an American Airlines official said last night.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
description: California Student Issue Carries Variable Rates

title: PANEL BARS VIEW KOREAN JET SPIED
description: An international inquiry into the downing of a South Korean airliner by a Soviet fighter plane has resulted in a report that rejects the Soviet assertion that the jumbo jet was on an espionage mission.

description: How the U.S.F.L. Landed Williams

title: 3 Top Giant Linebackers Want to Leave
description: The only part of the Giant offense and defense that has held up in this 3-10-1 season is the starting linebacker corps, perhaps the best in pro football. And three of those linebackers - all present or past all-pros - have indicated they want to be traded because they are tired of losing.

description: Nantucket Habit

description: IF there's one thing that the panoply of new books on

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Brae Corp., San Francisco, has promoted Lawrence S. Hershfield to executive vice president of its American Sign and Indicator Corp. subsidiary.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Ogilvy & Mather Gets Five Divisions of Salant

title: CALENDAR: MAKING DOLLS AND GIFT-WRAP
description: Doll Workshops , Atrium of the Citicorp Center, 53d Street and Lexington Avenue, 212-581-2474. On Saturday the Museum of American Folk Art will present free dollmaking workshops for children 6 to 10 years old. Each child will make a doll to take home.

title: SUBSIDIARY IMPERILS HARVESTER PACKAGE
description: International Harvester's tractor and parts subsidiary in France is in ''critical'' condition and could undermine the company's latest financial restructuring package, Harvester said in a statement mailed today to stockholders.

title: Minnesota Power
description: A $65 million financing by the United Minnesota Municipal Power Agency was offered through underwriters led by Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb to yield a maximum of 10.25 percent for bonds due in 2018. For shorter maturities, yields ranged from 6.25 percent in 1985 to 9.5 percent in 1995, to 10 percent for term bonds due in 1999 and 10 1/8 percent for term bonds due in 2003. Moody's Investors Service assigned the issue a medium-grade rating of Baa-1 while Standard & Poor's assigned its highest AAA rating.

title: AMREP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
TARA EXPLORATION & DEVELOPMENT LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $1,137,000 for the quarter and $2,669,000 for the 9 months. c-Including a special gain of $5,019,000 from the waiving of loan interest and commitment fees. Results are in U. S. dollars.

title: THE NEW TRUDEAU AGENDA: PEACE AND JOBS
description: The Government of Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau opened Parliament today with a message outlining a national agenda that emphasized the search for peace and disarmament abroad and the creation of jobs for young people at home.

title: EXPERT TRIES TO SELL SPANISH OPERA
description: The Spanish popular opera, the zarzuela, takes its name from the word ''zarza,'' meaning bramble. For in the 17th century, in the forest beyond El Pardo Palace in Spain, there was a theater situated in the wooded greenery that presented musical plays and dramas for the royalty. The theater took its name from its setting, ''La Zarzuela,'' and the name soon stuck to the repertory as well.

title: Reagan Gains on Rights Panel
description: The House Republican leader, Representative Robert H. Michel, moved today to support President Reagan in the growing dispute over the future of the United States Commission on Civil Rights.

title: FORMIDABLE FARM BLOC SHOWS SOME FRAILTY
description: The ability of this country's farmers to get nearly everything they want from the Government appears to be eroding rapidly, but it is equally evident that farmers are as effective as ever in killing what they do not want.

title: GUILTY VERDICT IN MURDER TRIAL OF BIEGENWALD
description: A Monmouth County jury today convicted Richard F. Biegenwald of the 1982 murder of an 18-year-old Camden woman.

description: PHILLIPSBURG, N.J.

description: To the Editor:

title: TIPPERARY CORP reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $790,000 from the extinguishment of debt. c-Net loss.

title: NEWEST IN A CHAIN
description: THE 13th store in the Pottery Barn home furnishings chain opened last week at 700 Broadway, at the corner of Fourth Street in an older industrial building.

title: REAGAN SAID TO PLAN '85 BUDGET CUT FOR EDUCATION
description: President Reagan's 1985 budget proposal for the Department of Education is certain to be below this year's spending level, department officials say.

title: LONG HUNT IS ALLOWED FOR INDIANS
description: One of the regular rituals across the Middle West in the waning days of autumn is the slaughter of thousands of deer wearing antlers by an equally large number of hunters wearing orange caps, camouflage coats and boots.

title: SCOUTING
description: Success Story

title: PRIVACY THREATS WORRY AMERICANS
description: Americans are increasingly concerned about threats to privacy, and about a third of the public believes the Internal Revenue Service, the Federal Bureau of Investigation and telephone companies ''probably share'' information on individuals with others, according to a poll conducted by Louis Harris and Associates.

title: A VATICAN BLIND TO A GLOBAL CRISIS
description: To the Editor:

title: Waiting for Dupree
description: Marcus Dupree, the star running back who left Oklahoma recently, will have to wait until the 1985 season to play for Southern Mississippi, according to the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: Seales Is Legally Blind
description: Sugar Ray Seales, a former Olympic boxing champion and successful professional middleweight, is legally blind, with no vision in his left eye and only 10 percent vision in his

title: ITALY IS SAID TO TELL SHULTZ IT WILL KEEP ITS FORCE IN LEBANON
description: American officials said today that Italy's Foreign Minister had conveyed to Secretary of State George P. Shultz his Government's willingness to remain in the international force in Lebanon.

title: HOLIDAY TIME INSPIRES GIFTS FOR NEEDIEST
description: The approach of the year-end holiday season, with the recollections of festive holidays past, inspires many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund to memorialize beloved family members and friends as well as others, unknown and uncounted, who have endured misfortune or neglect.

title: CELEBRATING THE RESTLESSNESS OF PHILIP JOHNSON
description: Very few architects have ever been able to speak with any real sense of their own work. In fact, their words often deflect us from a true understanding of their buildings. Even those architects who wallowed in prose, like Frank Lloyd Wright and Le Corbusier, produced what was essentially rhetoric, books and slogans that may be crucial historical documents but that ultimately shed more light on the architects' personalities than on their buildings.

title: Remains of 14 Fliers Recovered After 16 Years
description: The Navy has recovered the remains of 14 servicemen killed 16 years ago when their plane flew into a remote glacier, officials said today.

title: XTRA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Pay'n Save Bid
description: The Pay'n Save Corporation said it had agreed to acquire Schuck's Auto Supply Inc. for about $70 million in Pay'n Save common stock.

title: RANGERS WIN 3D STRAIGHT
description: To the end last night, the Rangers were erratic. They built leads, but they couldn't control the game for too long. As spectacular as their offense appeared, they could not adjust to the constant motion in front of their net.

title: BASEBALL'S TWO UNCERTAINTIES
description: It was difficult to determine today where the White House chief of staff, who has surfaced as a candidate for baseball commissioner, stood in relation to the other candidates.

title: TO STOP IRAN, IRAQ
description: Most people agree that the Iran-Iraq war is terrible, but argue that it does not lend itself to outside influence. This view is wrong. The outside world is in a position to use the ''oil weapon'' against those who invented it.

title: BANK OF AMERICA TO CUT 220 UNITS, 6,000 OF STAFF
description: In a move to streamline its operations and bolster sagging earnings, the Bank of America announced yesterday that it will reduce its staff by up to 6,000 people during 1984 - primarily through attrition - and close about 220 branches throughout California. Bank of America employs about 60,000 in California and has just over 1,000 branches in the state.

title: THE OLD CATCHER'S GLOVE
description: Near the entrance to Yogi Berra's Hall of Fame Racquetball Club, a baseball is perched atop a bronzed catcher's glove, which is in a glass case that also displays some of the proprietor's bats, photos and plaques. As he strolled by in his wonderful waddle, Yogi Berra pointed proudly to the glove.

title: REDPATH INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After a special charge of $8,937,000 for the writedown of an investment. c-Net loss. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Hamilton Fish Honors 12

title: ARMY HAILS NEW HELMETS' VALUE IN GRENADA
description: New helmets of a fiberglass-like material saved the lives of at least two American soldiers in the Grenada invasion, the first time the headgear was worn in combat, according to an Army report.

title: A HERO'S WELCOME FOR BEIRUT TROOPS
description: Greeted with tears of joy and relief, 1,800 marines and sailors, the survivors of a unit that lost more than 200 men to a bomb attack in Beirut, came home today to a rousing hero's welcome.

title: Rockland Moves To Cut Trial Costs
description: The Rockland County Legislature, in an effort to reduce its expenses for the Brink's robbery-murder trial, has voted to stop paying Orange County for security costs for the two remaining defendants as of 5 P.M. Friday.

title: 2 Deaths Linked To Laughing Gas
description: The deaths of two women in a mobile home here were caused by inhalation of nitrous oxide, the dental anesthetic commonly known as laughing gas, the police said today.

title: SPACE SHUTTLE WILL END SPACE TRIP TODAY
description: Scientists had nothing but praise today for the successful operation of the orbiting Spacelab research facility as the crew prepared to return to the earth and thus conclude a 10-day mission.

title: CUOMO AND DEUKMEJIAN DEBATE 1984 ELECTION
description: The freshmen Governors from New York and California, both immigrant sons from the same law school but representing different ends of the political spectrum, debated today the prospects for next year's Presidential election.

title: FRIGITEMP KICKBACKS ADMITTED
description: The former chairman of the Frigitemp Corporation pleaded guilty yesterday to participating in a scheme to pay $5 million in kickbacks to the one- time head of a General Dynamics Corporation shipbuilding unit and his assistant.

title: HERS
description: THE mere presence of a male cardinal can stop my breathing for long seconds at a time. His redness is so brilliant, yet so velvety, that if he were ever to come to my hand I might never be able to let him go. His reddish-yellow beak is set into a black square whose four corners form right angles almost too perfect to allow his claim to wildness. The very way he comports himself tells me that even he knows how special a creature he is.

title: WIDENED CABINET SOUGHT IN BEIRUT
description: President Amin Gemayel was reported today to be planning consultations immediately with Lebanon's factional leaders to form a broadly based Cabinet.

title: U.S. WILL DROP ANTITRUST STUDY OF OIL CONCERNS
description: The Justice Department announced today that it was ending a six-year antitrust investigation of four American oil companies operating in Saudi Arabia because the companies no longer had a major influence over the world price of oil.

title: COMPACT VIDEO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including a gain of $550,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations. c-Net income including a gain of $555,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations.

title: 5 HOPEFULS FIND IT TOUGH TO FOLLOW JACKSON ACT
description: When the Rev. Jesse Jackson, in his third speech of the day, won standing applause from an audience of New Mexico Democrats, Charles T. Manatt, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, seemed impressed.

title: Umberto Terracini, 88, An Italian Communist
description: Senator Umberto Terracini, a leading member of Italy's Communist Party, died at his home here Tuesday, party members announced. He was 88 years old.

title: TEACHER SKILLS AND U.S. ROLE DEBATED AT EDUCATION FORUM
description: Debate over how to attract and train better teachers and whether the Federal Government should have a role in the process dominated discussions today at a summit conference convened by the Department of Education.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Suns, at Phoenix. New York plays its first game on a three-game trip through the Pacific Division. (Television - Channel 9, 9:30 P.M.) Los Angeles Lakers vs.

title: REPORTS OF INSIDER TRADING
description: The New York and American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges.

title: Mack Trucks' Chief
description: Mack Trucks Inc. said yesterday that it had elected John B. Curcio chief executive officer, effective Jan. 1. Mr. Curcio, 48 years old, is currently the president and chief operating officer of the company, which is based in Allentown, Pa. Alfred W. Pelletier, who had been the chief executive, remains chairman.

title: BOOTH INC reports earnings for Year to Oct 1
VAST AGRICULTURAL GAINS SEENS IN PLANT GENETICS
description: A new study of the effects of biotechnology on agriculture has concluded that innovations in plant genetics will add $5 billion a year to the value of major crops over the next decade, an amount that will climb to $20 billion a year a decade later.

title: The Nuggets' Doug Moe Is Doing Fine Despite the Fines
description: Through much of Denver's 117-112 victory over the Knicks Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden, Doug Moe, the Nuggets' coach, was quieter than usual. He sat with his hands clasped in a praying position. At times he yelled, ''Go, go,'' and applauded the shooting of Kiki Vandeweghe and Dan Issel.

title: 'BOOST FOR TOMORROW'S WORKERS' HERE AND NOW
description: To the Editor:

title: Officer Is Slashed; Attacker Slain
description: A police officer in Brooklyn yesterday shot and killed a man who had slashed the face of the officer's partner with a knife, the police said.

title: NATO'S MINISTERS FIRM ON MISSILES
description: Defense ministers of NATO countries said today that holding to the schedule of American missile deployment in Western Europe would be a critical element in bringing the Soviet Union back to the suspended talks on reducing middle-range nuclear missiles.

title: Canada Saves 35 on Ship
description: A Canadian armed forces helicopter rescued 35 people from a sinking Peruvian-registered freighter today off the Gaspe Peninsula on the Gulf of St. Lawrence. The ship, the Unisal, was carrying bunker and diesel fuel.

title: Woman Defeated in Vote For Top Swiss Council
description: The Swiss Parliament, voting in a secret ballot today, rebuffed the candidacy of the first woman ever to run for election to the country's governing body, the seven- member Federal Council.

title: BUFFTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CITY STORES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Net income. Results reflect nonrecurring and extraordinary items. The company is listed on the Philadelphia Stock Exchange.

title: AIRLINES ADAPT TO DECONTROL
description: For Geraldina Galella, just off a People Express flight at Newark International Airport, the deregulation of the airline industry has been a boon. For $23, one way, she can fly to Burlington, Vt., and take a short bus ride to visit her relatives.

title: British Steel Loss Narrows
description: The British Steel Corporation, the nationalized steelmaker, said today that its operating loss in the six months ended Oct. 1 narrowed to $:98 million, or about $142.1 million, from $:486 million in the period a year earlier.

title: Technology; Devices Speed Tests of Blood
description: BLOOD tests can be unpleasant, inconvenient and expensive. And, because samples are generally shipped to a laboratory for processing, test results are often delayed.

title: SMALL HOSPITAL IN HARLEM GETS AN OFFER OF AID
description: Mount Sinai Medical Center has agreed to help rescue North General Hospital, a small hospital in Harlem that serves an impoverished community, officials from both institutions said yesterday.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Dog Lovers vs. Rat Haters

title: Warsaw Pact Meeting Ends
description: Warsaw Pact Defense Ministers today ended a three-day meeting in Sofia, Bulgaria, at which they were believed to have discussed the Soviet bloc's military response to deployment of new American nuclear weapons in Western Europe.

title: SUN CITY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
Sabotage on Track
description: According to legend, moonshiners put sugar in rival moonshiners' gas tanks to sabotage their high-speed whisky runs. According to Bobby Allison , the Nascar racer who won the Winston Cup as the top driver on the 30-race circuit, that is what someone did to his Buick in the final race Nov. 20 at Riverside, Calif.

title: No Scandal in Space
description: Shuttle crewmen performing a test of inner ear function in outer space have probably disproved the hypothesis for which Robert Barany received the Nobel Prize in 1914. Is that a scandal?

title: BUSINESS DIGEST THURSDAY, DECEMBER 8, 1983
description: The Economy The U.S. ended a six-year antitrust investigation of four American oil companies that operate in Saudi Arabia. The Justice Department said the companies no longer had any major influence over world oil prices. Thus ends the last of several efforts, begun in the 1970's when oil prices were soaring, to show that the oil industry was intrinsically anticompetitive. (Page A1.) OPEC members tentatively agreed to maintain current prices and output levels. (D6.) Local telephone operating companies may route undesignated long-distance calls to A.T.& T. rather than having to apportion them among its rivals, a Federal judge ruled. The decision was a victory for A.T.& T., which might have faced a substantial loss of customers. The decision should minimize disruption to consumers because A.T.& T. has more extensive long-distance services. (D1.)

title: Bethlehem to Alter Accounting System
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said yesterday that it is changing some of its accounting practices in a move that will reduce its 1983 net loss by about $250 million.

title: DEVILS WIN, CONTINUING SURGE
description: Moments after the Devils defeated Winnipeg Jets, 6-3, for their second consecutive victory and third straight at home, a somber Tom McVie spoke of the Devils' surprising albeit limited success.

title: WYLE LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net losses after a net loss of $87,000 for the quarter and a net gain of $27,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations and a net loss of $710,000 for the quarter and 9 months on the sale of discontinued operations.

title: REDS SIGN PARKER FOR 2 YEARS
description: Dave Parker, twice the batting champion of the National League, was signed as a free agent today by the Cincinnati Reds as the talent market came alive at baseball's winter meetings.

title: Fed Reports Yen Purchase
description: The Federal Reserve and the United States Treasury, in conjunction with the Bank of Japan, bought the equivalent of $29.6 million of yen on Oct. 31 and Nov. 1 in an effort to stabilize the value of the yen, Sam Y. Cross, executive vice president at the New York Fed, said yesterday in his regular quarterly report on foreign exchange operations.

title: DANCE: BALLET ESPANOL
description: Ballet Nacional Espanol, which ended its first American tour with performances last weekend at Brooklyn College, is proudly Spanish. Yet it can also legitimately call itself a ballet company. Founded in 1978 and directed by Maria De Avila, its members are trained both in classical ballet and in the many dance forms of Spain. And the stylistically varied program that they offered on Sunday afternoon suggested that they are trained very well.

description: The Missing Chickens

KULICKE & SOFFA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COMMON MARKET: GRAVEST CRISIS YET
description: The collapse this week of the Common Market summit talks here has been described widely as the gravest crisis in the trade bloc's 26-year history.

title: Jurors Are Deadlocked In Tennessee Killing
description: A juror who refused to vote for a conviction for three days forced a judge to declare mistrial today for two men accused of hanging an elderly man from an apple tree.

title: PBS HEAD IS NAMED PRESIDENT OF NBC NEWS
description: Lawrence K. Grossman, president of the Public Broadcasting Service for the last eight years, was named president of NBC News yesterday.

title: BOSTON SHOPPERS ON A SPREE
description: The frenzy of holiday shopping began here the day after Thanksgiving in a driving storm of rain and sleet.

description: Olympian Task
