title: Rates Decline on Mortgages
description: Mortgage rates edged downward in November for the second straight month, with fixed-rate loans dipping below 14 percent for the first time since the summer, the Government reported today.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET SEEK TO PREVENT A SURPRISE ATTACK
description: American officials said today that Soviet delegates at the strategic arms talks had joined in a separate working group to devise an accord on confidence-building measures such as advance notice of missile tests and of exercises involving group bomber takeoffs.

title: THE WOOD STOVE GROWS SLEEKER AND MORE EFFICIENT
SMYSLOV AND RIBLI DRAW 8TH CHESS GAME
description: Vasily Smyslov of the Soviet Union and Zoltan Ribli of Hungary drew the eighth game of their semifinal world championship chess match in a 41 move Slav Defense here tonight after 4 hours 45 minutes play.

title: Advertising; Are British No. 1 in Creativity?
description: IT has become fashionable to concede that Britain now rules the waves of advertising creativity. But who says so? And on what do they base the judgment?

title: FASHION DESIGNERS AND SHEETS: NEW NAMES AND NEW PATTERNS
description: WHEN Emilio Pucci became the first fashion designer to enter the home furnishings industry, with a collection of sheets in 1967, a flirtation was set up between two worlds that many thought were made for each other. By the mid-1970's, it reached a peak with Christian Dior, Yves Saint Laurent, Bill Blass, Calvin Klein, Hanae Mori, Vera, Norman Norell, Anne Klein, Halston, Zandra Rhodes and Mary McFadden presenting collections of sheets and towels. In 1978 Giorgio Sant'Angelo even designed a furniture collection for Lane. And there was talk of other designers doing furniture as well.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: New Healthdyne Head Coming From Rockwell

title: ISLANDERS GET 4 IN 3D FOR TIE
description: Mats Hallin, a seldom-used right wing with only one assist in 14 games before tonight, scored his first goal of the season with 2 minutes 10 seconds to play in the third period, bringing the Islanders a 4-4 tie with the Los Angeles Kings at the Forum.

title: 13 Seized at Nuclear Plant
description: Thirteen workers at the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant, including three security guards, were arrested in a drug raid Tuesday on charges of selling cocaine and other drugs. The suspects were charged with making sales on and off the plant site, where 8,000 people are employed.

title: Auto Rental Concerns Answer Safety Charges
description: Major automobile rental companies are denying the accusation that they may be ignoring safety recall orders and renting cars with ''potentially fatal'' mechanical defects.

title: Reagan to Visit New York
description: President Reagan will fly to New York Monday to speak at a luncheon for the Congressional Medal of Honor Society, the White House announced today.

title: SYNTREX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $526,000 for the quarter and $747,000 for the year. c-After an extraordinary charge of $127,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $866,000 for the year.

title: Two Arrested in I.R.S. Bribe Case
description: The Justice Department and the Internal Revenue Service today announced the arrest of two men accused of offering $548,000 in cash and promissory notes to a revenue agent to protect a tax-shelter program.

title: MUSIC: JO SULLIVAN SINGS
description: When Jo Sullivan last gave a cabaret performance in New York five years ago at the Ballroom, her repertory was made up entirely of songs by her late husband, Frank Loesser, who wrote the scores for ''Guys and Dolls,'' ''Where's Charley?'' and ''The Most Happy Fella'' as well as numerous pop hits.

title: DR. BLAISE J. OPULENTE
description: Dr. Blaise J. Opulente, former vice president for personnel services and secretary of St. John's University in Queens, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Garden City, L.I. He was 70 years old.

title: SOVIET LIKELY TO PARTICIPATE IN OLYMPICS
description: The chairman of the Soviet National Olympic Committee hinted repeatedly today that the Soviet Union would participate in next summer's Olympic Games here, but said its final decision would not be made until the spring.

title: COLLINS & AIKMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Bucyrus Closings
description: The Bucyrus-Erie Company said it expects an after-tax charge of $49 million in the fourth quarter and a wider net loss for all of 1983 from the closing of plants and discontinuance of certain businesses. The company said its board had approved closing its construction machinery plant at Erie, Pa., and discontinuing much of that business. The board also authorized the closing of its mining machinery foundry at South Milwaukee, and an additional write-down of the Glassport, Pa., foundry closed in September 1981.

title: MASSACHUSETTS TOWN EXILES PAC-MAN AND ALL THAT
description: For the first time in years, there are no clinks of swallowed quarters, no electronic beeps and flashes in the bars, markets, pool halls and roller rink of this old town on the New England coast. Pac-Man, Tron and Donkey Kong are gone.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Stock Move Profitable For Value Line's Chief

title: 2 COURT CASES WATCHED AS BAROMETERS ON INTEGRATING SCHOOLS
description: In 1972, when Craton Liddell was a St. Louis schoolboy, his mother brought a lawsuit to force the integration of the city's public schools.

title: Key Rates
description: * Nuveen index, John Nuveen & CompanySalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Academy's Students Protest And Face Suspension

title: GOING OUT GUIDE ;
description: IN GOOD SPIRITS Auspicious Spirits: Korean Folk Paintings and Related Objects'' sets the mood starting today in the main gallery of the Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street (288-6400). About 100 works of art are on view, mostly paintings but also screens, ceramics, wood and metal objects, each with its own symbols for good fortune - or evasion of bad - and testifying to religion and history, in the form of fish, animals, flowers, items used by peasants and by scholars, from frisky tigers to a staid dragon carrying a mirror.

title: BELT-TIGHTENING IN EUROPE SQUEEZES WELFARE STATE
description: Postal service has resumed in the Netherlands and garbage is being picked up again. Life seems headed back to the orderly condition that this society prizes.

title: 3 OF 4 CONVICTED IN SENTRY THEFT
description: Three men were convicted yesterday of Federal charges involving the theft of $11 million from a Bronx armored- car company. A fourth defendant was acquitted.

title: REAGAN TO STUDY WALESA APPEAL
description: President Reagan said today that he would give serious study to Lech Walesa's call for an end to Western economic sanctions against Poland.

title: ANDROPOV IS SPOTTED BEING DRIVEN TO WORK
description: American officials said today that Western diplomats had spotted Yuri V. Andropov being driven to work in the Kremlin after an absence since mid-August.

title: DEFENSES THAT RAISE THE RISK OF OFFENSE
description: To the Editor:

title: AUSTERITY PROMISED BY VENEZUELA'S NEW PRESIDENT
description: President-elect Jaime Lusinchi promised austerity measures today to relieve Venezuela's economic crisis, saying, ''We will not shy away from any effort, no matter how tough it is.''

title: CORRECTION
description: The Money table in Business Day yesterday gave an incorrect yield for 90-day Eurodollar time deposits. The yield is 10 percent.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Jacques Demers, Mario Parente, Michel Pietracupa and Terry Hadlow , Canadian Olympic weight lifters accused of illegally bringing in prescription drugs to Canada after the world championships in the Soviet Union in October, pleaded not guilty and were ordered to stand trial Jan. 23. . . . A judge dismissed disorderly- conduct charges against Bobby Valentine, a Mets coach, who last summer confronted prostitutes loitering near his tavern in Stamford, Conn. . . . Mexico's Supreme Court cleared Jose Sulaiman , the World Boxing Council president, of charges that he had smuggled pre-Colombian artifacts out of the country.

title: WATT SUCCESSOR OFFERS OLIVE BRANCH TO CRITICS
description: William P. Clark, the new Interior Secretary, today called for an end to partisanship over conservation issues and offered to make his department more accessible to environmental groups, Congress and the news media.

title: AN AUTHOR IS ACCUSED OF PLAGIARIZING RECIPES
description: Richard Nelson, a cooking teacher and author of ''Richard Nelson's American Cooking,'' published in October, has been accused in a newspaper article of plagiarizing a substantial number of recipes from at least two different cookbooks.

title: ANTARES OIL CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss. Sales figures represent oil and gas sales.

title: EL CHICO CORP reports earnings for 12 wks to Nov 18
description: b-Comparable year-ago results are not available because the company was formerly a subsidiary of Anheuser-Busch Co.

title: HARRY O. PAGE
description: Harry O. Page, former deputy comissioner of the New York State Department of Social Welfare, died of cancer Sunday at St. Peter's Hospital in Albany.

title: GOTT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CROWN RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A Tax Evasion Case for Congress
description: Worldwide unitary taxation: It sounds like an idea that law professors kick around at the faculty club bar. But it's no abstraction. On the contrary, it's an ugly reality. Twelve states now levy unitary taxes; that is, taxes based on the

title: BELL PETROLEUM SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
HEINZ, H J, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
description: Share earnings have been restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in September 1983.

title: Ivan F. Shpedko Dead at 65; Moscow's Envoy in Indonesia
description: The Soviet Ambassador, Ivan F. Shpedko, died of heart failure Sunday, the Soviet Embassy here announced Tuesday. He was 65 years old.

title: Some C.D. Rates Drop
description: Interest rates on certificates of deposit dropped sharply in New York last week, while nationwide rates on the certificates and on money market deposit accounts appeared to stabilize after several weeks of decline, The Bank Rate Monitor said yesterday.

title: GOLDING PINS HOPE ON WORDS
description: William Golding, this year's Nobel laureate in literature, appealed tonight to the writers of the world to ''move man a little nearer the perilous safety of a warless and provident world.''

title: Fordham Defeats Columbia By 78-65
description: In a game that included a bench- clearing scuffle with 1 minute 28 seconds remaining in overtime, Fordham defeated Columbia, 78-65, last night at Rose Hill Gymnasium in the Bronx.

title: Reagan Greets King of Nepal At Start of a Visit to the U.S.
description: President Reagan hailed King Birendra of Nepal today as a champion of peace and expressed sympathy about problems he is encountering in trying to improve the quality of life in his Himalayan kingdom.

title: U.S. Steel Sales
description: The United States Steel Corporation and its mining unit said they had agreed to sell two coal mines, associated reserves and a coal preparation plant to the Consolidation Coal Company.

title: Air-Bag Rule Involves Lives, U.S. Panel Told
description: There may be thousands more needless traffic deaths if automobile makers are not required to install air bags or automatic seat belts in cars, a consumer safety group told a Federal panel today.

title: TABLE TREES WITH FESTIVE TRIMMINGS
description: YES, they're beautiful, those large, luxuriously needled Christmas trees dripping with wonderful baubles and glowing with metallic sparkle and jolly colors. They're also a hassle to get home, a hassle, sometimes, to decorate and a hassle to get rid of without leaving a trail of brittle greenery.

title: NICHOLS, S E, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
85 YEARS OF A FAMILY CRAFTS WORKSHOP
description: BEHIND a purple painted door on West 13th Street is a rare sort of business. Rambusch Studios is a family-run company where for 85 years, craftsmen and designers have shared workshop space. Tomorrow, at the Parsons School of Design, an exhibition of their work will open.

title: 5 Palestinians Criticize Bombing of Israeli Bus
description: Five Palestinian leaders from the occupied West Bank published a condemnation today of a bus bombing the day before in Jerusalem that killed four Israelis and wounded 46 others.

title: TOLL CALL RULING AIDS A.T.& T.
description: The judge presiding over the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company ruled yesterday that the local Bell operating companies being spun off Jan. 1 may keep routing to A.T.&T. all long-distance calls for which customers have not designated a carrier.

title: SCREEN: KAREN BLACK IN 'CHERRY PIE'
description: Henry Jaglom's ''Can She Bake a Cherry Pie?'' is either a two-or a three-character romance, depending on whether you consider the Upper West Side of Manhattan a principal party to the action. Certainly the neighborhood is a key ingredient of the movie's appealing quirkiness, and of its mildly bohemian mood.

title: CITICORP CONTESTS CURBS ON REGIONAL BANKING
description: Contending that regional banking compacts are unconstitutional, Citicorp said yesterday that it had filed suit in Federal court to overturn recent laws that allow banks in one New England state to acquire banks in other New England states, while prohibiting banks from outside the region from doing so.

title: PANELS TO HANDLE TRANSIT VIOLATORS PROPOSED BY KOCH
description: Mayor Koch proposed yesterday that the Transit Authority set up its own administrative panels to prosecute fare evaders and others who violate its rules and regulations. Violators must now appear in the Criminal Courts.

title: Dome and Union Agree on Project CALGARY, Alberta, Dec. 8 (Reuters) - The Union Oil Company of Canada Ltd. said it had reached agreement with Dome Petroleum Ltd. to become a 10 percent partner in a liquefied natural gas project developed by Dome and Japan's Nissho Iwai. Dome said gas deliveries are planned to begin in 1987 under purchase contracts with five Japanese utility customers.
description: Separately, Dome's president, John M. Beddome, said in Toronto that the reaction by bankers to the company's new refinancing plan had been ''quite positive.'' Dome, with $6.3 billion in debt, presented a refinancing plan to its 50 bankers last week.

title: Korea Projects Abroad
description: South Korean construction companies have received foreign orders valued at $9.2 billion so far this year, officials said today. The Government said orders have recovered from a first-half slump and should exceed $10 billion by year's end, still below $13.4 billion in 1982.

title: NEW VENTURE FOR BELL CANADA
description: When Bell Canada reorganized last April into Bell Canada Enterprises, investors bid up its stock on the expectation that the big utility was preparing to follow its distant cousin, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, into a future of unregulated growth in high technology.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The End for Jalopy

title: A CITY'S BATTLE TO PROVE IT'S THERE
description: R. SHIPP

title: SANDINISTAS SAY REBELS TRIED TO SEIZE TERRITORY
description: Defense Minister Humberto Ortega Saavedra says Sandinista forces defeated a guerrilla campaign last month that was aimed at seizing a part of Nicaraguan territory and setting up a provisional government there.

title: Diner's Journal
description: IT may be equivocal whether real men eat

title: UNUSUAL REHABILITATION IN THE SOUTH BRONX
description: If there is cheap long-term money available, people will have housing,'' said David Scharf, an experienced real estate man who is president of the Interstate Capital Company, which makes loans to small business. ''It's as simple as that.''

title: LEGACY BEYOND MERE POLICIES
description: News Analysis

title: POP/JAZZ
description: AN annual Carnegie Hall concert by the folk-pop singer Judy Collins has become a Christmas season tradition, and it is one of the highlights of a weekend that also includes the jazz of Freddie Hubbard, the folk-jazz- classical blending of George Winston and the theatrical pop of Jo Sullivan.

title: Felec Contracts
description: The ITT Corporation said two military contracts valued at about $126 million had been awarded to its Felec Service Inc. subsidiary, which is based in Colorado Springs. The one- year contracts, received from the Air Force, are for the continued operation, maintenance and logistic support of early warning systems.

title: OF ADDICTED AHTLETES AND MAGICAL CURES
description: To the Editor:

title: SOVIET WON'T SET A DATE TO RESUME STRATEGIC TALKS
description: Texts of statements, Page A16.

title: TIME TO CUT LOSSES
description: President Reagan's folly in pledging American ''credibility'' on keeping the Marines in Lebanon is now beginning to come clear. So is the Senate's shortsightedness in approving a war powers resolution that permits him to keep U.S. forces in that impossibly fractious land for 18 months.

title: Port Agency Approves Two Brooklyn Projects
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday approved two projects - a fish-handling and distribution center and a container port - that it said would bring increased business and jobs to the Brooklyn waterfront.

title: BROWN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 20
U.N. Petitioners Ask For Rights Amnesty
description: The United Nations received an appeal today signed by more than 1.3 millon people for the release of ''prisoners of conscience'' held in more than 70 countries.

title: Extortion Is Laid To Store Operator
description: The operator of a children's clothing store in Queens was arrested on charges of extorting $5,200 from an employee by threatening to harm his relatives in Israel and his girlfriend, the authorities said yestersday.

title: SHUTTLE PROGRAM COMPUTER FAILURES BEGAN ON FIRST TEST LANDING IN 1977
description: Balky computers have nagged the space shuttle from its first test landing in 1977, to the countdown for its maiden flight in 1981, to its most recent mission.

title: REPORT SAYS NAVY LACKS CAPACITY TO DEPLOY COMBAT-READY CARRIERS
description: Despite three years of rapidly rising budgets, the Navy is far from ready to deploy fully armed and equipped aircraft carriers and air wings in the event of war, a confidential report by the General Accounting Office says.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Clippers , at San Diego. Bill Walton is injured again, and so the Knicks won't have to contend with him on the second stop of their three-game tour of the Pacific Division. (Television - Channel 9, 10:30 P.M.)

title: DAVIS LEADS SUNS PAST KNICKS, 120-97
description: The Phoenix Suns, usually one of the league's strongest teams, have been having a disappointing season. Tonight, though, the Suns disappointed only the Knicks, handing New York its worst defeat of the season, 120-97, before 10,254 fans at the Veteran's Memorial Coliseum.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Beverly Enterprises, a Pasadena, Calif., health care company, announced that it had entered into an unsecured $100 million revolving credit agreement with First Interstate Bank of California, Morgan Guaranty Trust and Manufacturers Hanover Trust.

title: TRY TO BRING SYRIA AROUND
description: Americans witnessing the alarming escalation of hostilities in Lebanon may well feel they are looking down a tragically familiar road.

title: SOFTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 25
description: b-Includes writeoff of $636,263, or 18 cents a share, related to the Osborne Computer Corporation's Chapter 11 filing.

title: A Stable Day For Eurobonds
description: Eurobond trading was quiet with prices stable, following a lower opening in government bonds in the United States, dealers said today.

title: Mrs. Thatcher Criticizes U.S.
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher told the House of Commons today that the United States had adopted an ''unsustainable'' economic policy that will cause ''great trouble within 12 months.''

title: TRANSACT INTERNATIONAL, DIVISION OF GRAM INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After tax credits of $102,000 for the quarter and $125,000 for the 6 months. c-After tax credits of $75,000 for the quarter and $245,000 for the 6 months.

title: Money Fund Assets Fall Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds fell for the fourth consecutive week in the period ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.
description: The institute said total assets dropped $217 million, to $165.62 billion.

description: Strolling Through History

title: DANCE: AILEY COMPANY
description: THE prize for the worst dance premiere of the year goes to Billy Wilson's ''Lullabye for a Jazz Baby,'' an unspeakable insult to both dancers and audience that had its first New York performance with the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater Wednesday night at the City Center.

description: Quick Answers

description: There will be the patter of tiny feet near the corridors of power when Congress returns in January.

title: MARINES IN BEIRUT SILENCE ATTACKERS
description: The American marines came under heavy attack today from machine guns and rocket- propelled grenades on their perimeter. The marines retaliated with a barrage from rocket launchers and tanks that forced the attackers to hoist a white flag.

title: CONCERT: COLIN CARR, CELLIST
description: COLIN CARR, the young British cellist who won the Naumburg Competition two years ago, paid a visit to Alice Tully Hall Monday night. Mr. Carr's playing was versatile to the point of contradiction. In the Bach Solo Suite in C, for example, all the resonant possibilities of modern cello sound were summoned, and precise note values were often sacrificed for the broad expressive gesture.

description: * Nuveen index, John Nuveen & Company Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: STAGE: 'AS YOU LIKE IT' PRESENTED BY HARTFORD
description: HARTFORD DARK shadows shroud the court of Duke Frederick in Mark Lamos's production of ''As You Like It'' at the Hartford Stage Company. The atmosphere is foreboding, as in a Magritte painting, an aura that is deepened by top-hatted gentlemen gliding across the stage carrying umbrellas and by a huge timepiece that dwarfs the action as a watchmaker's version of a deus ex machina. The forest of Arden moves the play into a field of French Impressionism, an autumnal environment where men wear shapely straw hats while they picnic on the grass.

title: PUBLISHING: WAS THAT HANNAH ARENDT OR NOT?
description: IS Arthur A. Cohen's novel ''An

title: BRUINS DEFEAT CANADIANS, 6-2
description: Gord Kluzak, Luc Dufour and Terry O'Reilly scored goals within 1 minute 42 seconds early in the second period tonight, leading the Boston Bruins to a 6-2 victory over the Montreal Canadiens.

title: Lysiak Penalty Upheld
description: The National Hockey League's

title: Bogus Heroin Brings Illness on the Coast
description: A toxic chemical sold as a synthetic heroin has produced symptoms of Parkinson's disease in more than 120 people in the San Francisco Bay area, leaving some with paralysis, doctors said today.

title: Phibro-Salomon Shifts High-Level Executives Phibro-Salomon Inc., the big securities and commodities trading concern formed through the merger of Phibro Inc. and Salomon Brothers, has named a new president and chief executive for its Philipp Brothers commodities marketing arm. It also named two vice chairmen.
description: Alan Flacks, 53, was named to succeed Thomas D. O'Malley as head of Philipp Brothers. Mr. Flacks, who was named an executive vice president of Phibro-Salomon, has been chairman of the European executive committee of Philipp Brothers.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;  Guilty Verdict
description: -ranked female tennis player in the mid 1960's, has been convicted of negligent homicide in connection with the death of a pedestrian in an automobile crash last February. Miss Bartkowicz, 34, who was found to have a blood-alcohol reading of .22, more than double the legal driving limit of .10, pleaded no contest at her trial in Mount Clemens, Mich., on Wednesday and will be sentenced on Feb. 17.

title: REAGAN TO END BAN ON SALE OF ARMS TO THE ARGENTINES WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (Reuters) - President Reagan will end the ban on United States arms sales to Argentina effective Saturday, when President- elect Raul Alfonsin is inaugurated, the State Department announced today.
description: No actual arms sales are planned, but the ban will be lifted because of a ''dramatic improvement in the human rights situation in Argentina'' in the past year and a half, the department's spokesman, Alan D. Romberg, said.

title: INTERCOLE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including a gain of $2,612,000 from severance of Seaview Refinery processing agreements and a related reduction in Seaview debt and a gain of $675,000 on the sale of the company's Banner Metals division.

ELDERLY PROVE THAT ART IS AGELESS
description: ''I fell in love with senior citizens and their art when I saw them at the senior-citizen center at West 72d Street,'' said Gladys Collins, organizer of the exhibition ''Art Is Ageless,'' which is at the City Gallery of the Department of Cultural Affairs, 2 Columbus Circle, through Monday. ''There were little plump women in aprons, and they were pouring things.

title: AUCTIONS
description: Holiday bidding.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;  Comings and Goings
description: Tracy Austin , who hasn't competed since she was forced to withdraw from Wimbledon with a rib stress fracture last summer, says she has fully recovered and plans to return late next month for the Virginia Slims tournament in Houston. . . . The New York State Racing and Wagering Board said a 60-day suspension for the trainer Philip G. Johnson would start Dec. 15. Johnson had challenged an original ruling, which came after a drug test showed traces of a tranquilizer in the system of Naskra's Breeze after a race at Saratoga in 1981.

title: ESMARK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Including a net gain of $8.9 million for the disposition of holdings in Purex Industries and a tax credit of $6.5 million. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split as a 100 percent stock dividend Dec. 1. Results include operations of Norton Simon Inc. since its acquisition in July.

title: JETS WILL LEAVE A STREAM OF BIT PLAYERS
description: For Dorothy Winer, every Jet football game at Shea Stadium was like a Broadway opening.

title: Advertising; Reforming Political Campaigns
description: BACK in 1978, when Leonard S. Matthews agreed to become president of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, he did it on the condition that the organization would assume a leadership role. That condition happened to coincide with the desire of the membership as well.

title: McEnroe Loses
description: Mats Wilander of Sweden eliminated John McEnroe of the United States, 4-6, 6-3, 6-4, 6-3, today and advanced to the men's singles final of the Australian Open.

title: FIRST, GERMAN SURVIVAL
description: Anyone living here would have trouble finding a desire for reunification. In the unlikely event that the Soviet Union were to permit the reunification of West and East Germany, Germans would undoubtedly leap at the chance. But it is not something Germans worry much about, because they know that the Soviet Union could not now afford it. What worries us today is not the prospect that the two surviving parts of Bismarck's Reich should continue to be divided but whether they will continue to survive.

title: GUATEMALA FORCING EX-LEADERS TO QUIT ARMY GUATEMALA, Dec. 8 (AP) - The military Government is forcing four former Presidents to retire from the army.
description: The move was announced Wednesday in a decree that appeared to be an effort by Brig Gen. Oscar Mejia Victores, the Guatemalan leader, to strengthen his position at a time of reported divisions in the military and frequent rumors of coups.

title: SCOTTS SEABOARD reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Including tax credits of $23,000 for the quarter and $476,000 for the 9 months and a gain of $222,000 for the 9 months from the sale of assets of discontinued wholesale operation. c-Net loss

title: Iraq Says It Has Sunk 6 More Enemy Ships
description: Iraq said today that it had sunk six more ships at the northern end of the Persian Gulf and again warned all vessels to steer clear of waters it has declared war zones.

title: OWNERS EXTEND KUHN TERM TO MARCH 1
description: The owners of baseball's 26 teams voted unanimously today to extend Bowie Kuhn's lame-duck term as commissioner for two months and gave the search committee greater authority in choosing his successor.

title: G.M. Junks New Trucks With $5 Million Value
description: Six- hundred new pickup trucks, worth nearly $5 million retail, are being junked because they rusted while parked at this Florida port for up to a year awaiting shipment, the General Motors Corporation said today.

title: COMMODITIES Comex Begins Trading In Aluminum Futures
description: The Commodity Exchange in New York opened its aluminum futures market yesterday to an enthusiastic crowd of traders, many of whom normally operate in Comex's gold, silver and copper futures rings. Alan J. Brody, Comex president, said the volume held up even after the copper futures markets opened.

title: FILM: 'IMPACT,' WITH CLINT EASTWOOD
description: ''SUDDEN IMPACT,'' which opens today at the Warner Twin and other theaters, is the fourth of the ''Dirty Harry'' films starring Clint Eastwood, but the first of them to be directed by the star. It desperately needs the hand of Don Siegel, Mr. Eastwood's longtime associate who has been responsible for the actor's best films, including ''The Beguiled'' and ''Escape From Alcatraz.''

title: SCREEN: AL PACINO STARS IN 'SCARFACE'
description: ''SCARFACE,'' Brian De Palma's update of the 1932 classic directed by Howard Hawks and written by Ben Hecht, is the most stylish and provocative - and maybe the most vicious - serious film about the American underworld since Francis Ford Coppola's ''Godfather.'' In almost every way, though, the two films are memorably different.

title: FRANCE AND AFRICA: STRAIN BUT NOT ESTRANGEMENT
description: Along all the main boulevards in this capital are tall, leafy trees whose intermingling branches provide relief from the sun.

title: SamuelNaples,ElectionAide A
description: Samuel A. Naples, a longtime Mercer County election official who attended every national Democratic convention from 1920 to 1980, died Tuesday at the Lawrenceville Nursing Home.

title: SOVIET AIDE IMPLIES SAKHAROV IS MENTALLY ILL
description: A prominent Soviet official implied at a news conference today that Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist and human rights campaigner, was mentally disturbed.

title: PIEDMONT NATURAL GAS CO reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
Stocks Drop; Dow Off 11.89
description: Stock prices dropped sharply yesterday in continued heavy trading as rising interest rates weakened most of the list.

title: Ryder Will Sell A Unit to Sohio MIAMI, Dec. 8 (AP) - Ryder System Inc. said it had agreed in principle to sell its Truckstops Corporation of America subsidiary to the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) for more than $85 million.
description: Ryder's president and chief executive, M. Anthony Burns, said he expected the sale to be completed by the first quarter of 1984.

title: CML GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
SPORTS PEOPLE ;  A Heavier Hand
description: The carrot has proved effective but expensive in Joe Torre's antiweight campaign, so Torre, the manager of the Atlanta Braves, has decided to try the stick in his effort to get ballooning Braves to stay in playing trim. Two Brave players, Bob Horner and Bob Watson , have contract clauses providing incentive bonuses for meeting established weight limits, but Torre plans a different approach in extending the weight-control program to other Braves.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the Bank of America misstated the number of branches to be closed in 1984. It is 120.

description: Radar and Lights Cited In Spanish Plane Crash

description: The maximum weekly unemployment benefit in New Jersey will increase to $170 from $158 next year, the State Labor Commissioner, Roger Bodman, said today.

title: James Kemp Is Dead at 71; Held N.A.A.C.P. Presidency
description: James Kemp, national president of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and a labor organizer for a half century, died Monday.

title: Helioscience Deal By Reuters
description: Helioscience General, a joint venture of Helioscience Inc. and General Ener-Tech Inc., said it had recieved a 30-year, $900 million contract to provide electricity to the Navy from geothermal sources. Under the agreement, Helioscience General will construct a 75-megawatt geothermal power plant at the Navy's air weapons training complex at Fallon, Nev., at a cost of more than $100 million.

description: Some of the nicknames muttered within the conspiratorial eddies of the White House are plainly unkind: ''The Gnome,'' ''Baby Bigot'' and worse.

description: Never buy a woman a frying pan for Christmas. It probably won't match any of her sweaters, and she may make you eat it for breakfast.

description: New claims for state unemployment benefits decreased to 388,000 in the week ended Nov. 26, the Labor Department reported today. The department said the total was down 47,000 from the previous week.

title: REAGAN FINDS A LESSER EVIL IN INDEFINITE RECESS OF TALKS
description: President Reagan, playing down the significance of the Soviet refusal to set a date for resuming strategic arms talks in Geneva, said today that the move was ''more encouraging than a walkout'' and that he was hopeful Soviet negotiators would return next year.

title: MARINE CHIEF OPTIMISTIC ON BEIRUT WITHDRAWAL
description: The Commandant of the Marine Corps, Gen. Paul X. Kelley, said today that he was optimistic that the Marine Amphibious Unit in Beirut could be withdrawn from Lebanon early next year.

description: Best Lineman Not Good Enough

title: 'REVELS' SALUTES THE WINTER SOLSTICE
description: John Langstaff declares that ''The Christmas Revels'' program of song, dance and music he is presenting this weekend for the fourth year at the Symphony Space, Broadway and 95th Street, will be uplifting, joyous and spiritual without being religious and celebratory.

title: DIRECTOR'S CUT STIRS DEBATE ON SHAW PLAY
description: When ''Heartbreak House'' opened Wednesday night at the Circle in the Square, something was missing. The character of Billy Dunn, a burglar who appears in Act II and returns to die in Act III, had been excised from George Bernard Shaw's play by Anthony Page, the director.

title: CABARET: MCGARRIGLE SISTERS
description: KATE AND ANNA MCGARRIGLE, who compose and perform original, intensely personal music within a folk idiom and who try - albeit with intermittent success - to sell their music commercially, count as some sort of uncategorizable musical treasure.

title: LTX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
VEECO INSTRUMENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Mexico Seeks New Loans
description: The Government of Mexico will seek up to $4 billion of new loans from the international banking community in the coming year, the country's Finance Minister announced.

title: U.S. IS EXPLORING NEW VATICAN TIES
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it was exploring the establishment of stronger relations with the Vatican.

title: BRIEFS
description: American Medical International Inc. said it had agreed to sell hospitals in Groves, Tex., and Dallas, Ore., to Nu-Med Inc. for $25 million.

title: Australia Trading Curb
description: The Reserve Bank of Australia announced early today that dealing in foreign currencies by Australian banks had been suspended ''for the time being'' except to meet the needs of travelers. Reserve Bank officials declined further comment on the action, but Australian currency dealers said conjecture about an Australian dollar revaluation recently led to sizable buying of the currency.

title: Bethlehem Order
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation's Freight Car division said it had received an order for 225 to 250 coal cars from System Fuels Inc. of New Orleans. The value of the contract was not disclosed. Ronald L. Zimmermann, general manager of the division, said the order would put about 250 employees back to work for the first time in two years.

title: MID-AMERICA PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: BROADWAY
description: London musical Jean Seberg' due here, but not soon.

title: Fehr Elected by Players
description: The executive board of the Major League Baseball Players Association elected Donald Fehr acting executive director of the association

title: East German Says Missiles Hurt Ties With West Germany
description: Prime Minister Willi Stoph of East Germany said today that West Germany's decision to accept the deployment of American missiles had damaged relations between the two German states.

title: SOCCER TEAM GIVES LIONS CHANCE TO ROAR
description: ''Step right up, ladies and gentlemen,'' shouted a man in a skewed Santa Claus hat waving a blue nylon streamer. ''We're going to have a good old-fashioned pep rally here.''

title: Soviet Honors Geologist
description: The title of Hero of Socialist Labor, a high honor, was given today to a geologist, Vasily Podshibyakin, for prospecting oil and gas fields in Siberia's Yamal Peninsula. The fields, extending from northwest to southeast across the peninsula, are expected to become major producers, especially for gas. Production drilling at Novy Port, at the southern end, is already under way.

title: Three Soviet Ships Barred
description: The Coast Guard has closed the port of Galveston to three Soviet freighters until the United States nuclear submarine Dallas leaves. The ships were scheduled to arrive Wednesday and today to pickup wheat. The Coast Guard told the vessels they could not enter the port until Monday.

title: NEW ZELAND LEADER
description: Sir Keith Holyoake, a former Governor General of New Zealand and one of the country's longest-serving Prime Ministers, died today, the Government announced. He was 79 years old.

title: The Unfound Oil Conspiracy
description: ''There wasn't anything there that justified the almost inevitable foreign policy costs of pushing this further.'' Thus concluded William Baxter, the outgoing assistant attorney general for antitrust, as he dropped the Government's six-year investigation of alleged restraints of trade by major oil companies. The explanation sounds feeble, but it does appear as if Government had virtually nothing to gain by hanging tough.

title: U.S. Official Has Talks With Key Sandinista
description: A key member of the United States national security staff met a left-wing Nicaraguan leader today for private talks and said he would report to President Reagan on their discussions.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
description: New San Antonio Issue Will Yield Up to 10.5%

title: CUOMO PROMISES TO RESTORE CUTS IN FUNDS FOR MENTAL CLINICS ACROSS STATE
description: Governor Cuomo says he will restore cuts he made in funds for psychiatric clinics across New York State when he draws up the state budget for next year.

title: Economic Scene; How to Solve Interest Puzzle
description: WHY have ''real'' rates of interest, defined as nominal rates minus the current rate of inflation, remained so high despite the world economic slump and the decline in inflation? James J. O'Leary, economic consultant to the United States Trust Company of New York, says there are several reasons.

title: Chrysler to Buy Preferred Back DETROIT, Dec. 8 (Reuters) - The Chrysler Corporation said today that it plans to repurchase an unspecified number of its $2.75 cumulative preferred shares through Salomon Brothers Inc. if they become available at prices Chrysler considers attractive.
description: Chrysler, which has about 10 million shares of the preferred outstanding, said no purchases will be made before it pays a dividend to holders of the stock by Dec. 15.

title: 3 More Britons Charged In Gold Robbery
description: Three men were charged in a Middlesex court today with taking part in the robbery of $38 million in gold bullion from a warehouse near Heathrow Airport 12 days ago.

title: LIBYA AND ISRAEL CLASH AT THE U.N.
description: A bitter exchange broke out today on the floor of the General Assembly after Libya's chief delegate, speaking in a debate on the Middle East, said that ''Jewish Zionists'' were ''exploiting the American people and trying to debase them.''

title: LOTS ARE DRAWN FOR NEW MIDDLE-INCOME HOMES
description: On a windswept vacant lot in Brooklyn a crowd of public officials and community residents watched yesterday as ground was broken for the first 34 of a new group of 5,000 units of housing to be built for middle-income families in New York City.

title: DISSIDENTS WIN BITTER FIGHT FOR GAF
description: A dissident shareholder group led by Samuel J. Heyman won the bitter contest for control of the GAF Corporation yesterday when a three-judge Federal appeals panel unanimously overturned a lower court decision calling for a new shareholder vote.

title: SEMTECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income. c-Net loss. Year-ago share earnings have been adjusted for a 3 percent stock dividend declared in February 1983.

title: UNFAIR ATTACK ON LAWYERS OF THE DOOMED
description: To the Editor:

title: Vice Chairman Named at J.W.T.
description: The J. Walter Thompson Company, a worldwide advertising agency and the largest unit within the publicly held JWT Group, announced yesterday that Walter J. O'Brien would become vice chairman on Jan. 1 and would be replaced as president and chief operating officer of J.W.T./ USA by John E. Peters. Both men have been with the company here and abroad for their entire work careers.

title: U.S. JUDGE ACCUSED OF TAKING A BRIBE
description: Federal District Judge Harry E. Claiborne of Las Vegas was indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges of bribery, tax evasion, obstruction of justice and filing a false financial declaration.

title: BRIEFING
description: West Bank and the I.R.S.

title: Du Pont Plastic
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company introduced a plastic material, Selar, to replace metal and glass in containers for chemical products such as pesticides, household cleaners and automotive waxes.

title: PENTAGON AIDE VOWS PRESS PLAN
description: The new head of public relations for the Pentagon said today that he would like to arrange for news agency reporters to cover future United States military actions from the moment they begin.

title: Girl, 11, Slain in West Bank
description: Unidentified gunmen firing a rifle from a car shot and killed an 11-year-old Palestinian girl, Aya Behesh, and seriously wounded her sister, Faya, today in the center of the occupied West Bank town of Nablus, Israel radio said.

title: JACKSON'S BATTLE OVER DEMOCRATIC RULES: FALLOUT FROM AN OLD POLITICAL DEAL
description: Complaints by some Democratic Presidential candidates about the party's 1984 delegate-selection rules have focused renewed attention on an important political deal that received fleeting public attention when it took form in 1981 and early 1982. Representatives of Walter F. Mondale, Edward M. Kennedy and organized labor used their voting strength on a commission formed by the Democratic National Committee to create rules intended to make it unlikely that another political outsider would win the nomination over the party's best-known politicians, as Jimmy Carter did in 1976. The commission chairman was Gov, James B. Hunt Jr. of North Carolina.

title: New Fortune Systems Chief
description: The Fortune Systems Corporation, a maker of desk top office computers that has been

title: FRANKLIN SIGNAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bernard Mitchell, 71; Led Perfume Concern
description: Bernard A. Mitchell, a founder of Jovan Inc., a perfume manufacturer, died Monday at the hospital named for him at the University of Chicago medical center. He was 71 years old.

title: ; DEFENSE SPENDING: 'THE REFORMS ARE WORKING'
description: T o the Editor:

title: NEW MT. SINAI FORESEES A GLUT OF PHYSICIANS
description: Medical schools and hospital training programs will double the number of physicians in this country within the next 20 years, producing a glut that will drive up health costs and encourage unnecessary medical care, the new president of the Mount Sinai Medical Center said yesterday.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in Metropolitan Report yesterday misidentified the man placing an academic hood on the gown of King Juan Carlos I of Spain. He was L. Jay Oliva, chancellor of New York University.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: RONALD HARWOOD, who wrote ''The Dresser'' (play and movie), Tom Courtenay who played ''The Dresser'' (play and movie), and Peter Yates, who directed ''The Dresser'' (movie only), are in a hotel room behaving like the Three Stooges, giddy with laughter and reviling one another.

title: SHAMIR CONDEMNS U.N. OVER P.L.O.
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir today condemned the decision by the United Nations to allow Yasir Arafat, head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, to be evacuated with his guerrillas from Tripoli, Lebanon, on ships flying the United Nations flag.

title: KORCHNOI POSTPONES GAME WITH KASPAROV
description: Fifty-two-year- old Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland postponed the eighth game of his semifinal world championship chess match with 20-year-old Gary Kasparov of the Soviet Union today.

title: NEW YORK IN BLACK AND WHITE
description: VISUALLY and otherwise, New York means many things to many people - skyscrapers, traffic jams, street vendors, ethnic neighborhoods, night life, tourists, construction workers, monuments and museums. It's this potpourri of sights that makes the city such a feast for photographers. Besides providing homes and studios for thousands of professional picture takers, it offers its hospitality to all who come here bearing cameras, hoping to take home a memento or two. That is especially true at this time of year, which is, along with the summer-vacation season, peak picture-taking time for Americans. Weekends, it goes without saying, are prime time for photography; they provide the leisure necessary to notice and explore what on weekdays most of us blithely pass by.

title: U.S.C. Wins
description: Pam and Paula McGee combined for 48 points to lead top-ranked Southern California to an 81-66 victory over Tennessee tonight. Pam scored 26 points, sinking 9 of 12 shots, and grabbed 16 rebounds, and her sister scored 22. U.S.C. (6-0) had a 39-31 lead at the half, then pulled away on a 10-0 to start the second half.

title: Red Cross Visits Flier Being Held by Syrians
description: Lieut. Robert O. Goodman of the Navy, the American navigator shot down in Lebanon and held prisoner by Syria, was visited today by the International Committee of the Red Cross.

title: Boudin Trial To Resume Feb. 6
description: The Brink's trial of Kathy Boudin and Samuel Brown has been tentatively scheduled to resume Feb. 6 in Westchester County, officials said today.

title: Leave the 'Left' Alone
description: Why should a Government run by conservatives keep subsidizing do-gooders with tax-exempt donations and grants? That's what a vocal faction of the far right keeps asking. Ever since President Reagan's election, they've been calling on him to ''defund the left.''

title: Panda, Seriously Ill, Regains Her Appetite
description: Ling-Ling the panda, suffering a kidney problem that could kill her, ate a good breakfast of bamboo and apples today as doctors moved life-saving equipment from a children's hospital to the National Zoo.

title: BONN OFFICIAL FORMALLY CHARGED IN BRIBERY CASE
description: Economics Minister Otto Lambsdorff was formally charged today with having accepted the equivalent of $50,000 in bribes. He is the first West German minister accused of a crime.

title: FILM: 'CHRISTINE,' A CAR
description: ''CHRISTINE,'' written by Stephen King and directed by John Carpenter, is about a haunted car that isn't quite haunted enough. Though the car, a 1958 red Plymouth with a wicked grin, is capable of trampling, burning, asphyxiating and squashing its enemies, and though it performs these feats to the sound of vintage rock-and-roll songs, ''Christine'' isn't terribly eerie. Only in a scene in which the car fixes itself, actually smoothing out its dented fenders and crushed doors

title: DONOR ANONYMOUS
description: An anonymous benefactor has given $50 million to the Cornell University Medical College, one of the largest awards ever made to an American medical school, the college announced yesterday.

title: PHILHARMONIC: AN ACCENT ON YOUTH
description: THE New York Philharmonic put itself in the hands of the youth movement last night, comparatively speaking. For a start, instead of Brahms or some other bearded immortal, there was the American composer Joseph Schwantner, who is a mere 40 years old and who won the Pulitzer Prize just four years ago. His prize-winner, a glitteringly orchestrated piece enigmatically entitled ''Aftertones of Infinity,'' set the tone for the evening.

title: Playboy Seeks Delay on Casino TRENTON, Dec. 8 (AP) - Playboy Enterprises has proposed that it be given until 1990 to complete divestiture of its interest in an Atlantic City hotel-casino. The proposal was contained in a petition filed with the state's Casino Control Commission. New Jersey gambling enforcement officials have urged a faster solution.
description: Playboy has a 45.7 percent interest in the $150 million Playboy Hotel and Casino, with the Elsinore Corporation owning the rest. Elsinore, based in Las Vegas, Nev., has been running the Playboy operation for 19 months after the Casino Control Commission found Playboy's chairman, Hugh M. Hefner, and Playboy Enterprises, based in Chicago, unfit to hold a casino license.

title: FLOATING POINT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
ALLIES BACK STAND ON GENEVA TALKS
description: The NATO allies said today that they would stand firm in their negotiating positions at the two sets of arms talks in Geneva and in their deployment of new American missiles in Europe.

title: SHIFT OF 400 EMPLOYEES MIRED
description: From the outside there is little to distinguish the gray brick office building at 250 Fulton Street.

title: G.O.P. PUNDIT LOOKS AT THE '84 RACE
description: On one television channel a Presidential candidate will be seen playing golf or riding a horse. Switch the channel and he will be playing a piano or sitting at an easel. Another switch and he is conversing in Spanish, while on another he is eating blintzes.

title: REAGAN URGES MORE DISCIPLINE IN SCHOOLS
description: President Reagan declared today that lagging American schools could be improved more from ''good old-fashioned discipline,'' tougher academic standards and pay and promotions geared to teacher performance than by an infusion of money from the Government.

title: BELL PROPOSES 4-POINT PLAN TO IMPROVE U.S. SCHOOLS
description: Education Secretary T. H. Bell, declaring that mediocre education ''saps the strength and vitality of the nation,'' today urged the 50 states to adopt a four-point program to improve their schools.

title: COURT TOLD BEATTY PLOTTED TO REVERSE ELECTION LOSS
description: A prosecutor charged in court yesterday that former State Senator Vander L. Beatty of Brooklyn had directed a criminal conspiracy to overturn his loss in a Congressional primary election last year.

title: GERGEN QUITS AS REAGAN'S COMMUNICATIONS CHIEF
description: David R. Gergen, director of White House communications, has resigned to accept a resident fellowship at Harvard University's Institute of Politics.

title: DANIEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FILM: 'THE KNIGHT,' IN POLISH
description: ''THE KNIGHT'' is a haunting, austere parable that has been directed with assurance by Lech Majewski, whose flair for starkly poetic compositions often manages to outshine the elliptical quality of his material. Made in 1980, it has a medieval setting. It follows a knight on his quest for a mythical harp, one which will supposedly heal the ills of his nation.

title: STATEMENTS ON GENEVA TALKS
description: Following are the texts of the Soviet report on today's session of the talks on limiting strategic nuclear arms, as distributed in translation by the official press agency Tass, and a statement by the chief United States negotiator at the talks, Edward L. Rowny: Soviet Statement

title: COMPUTER AND NAVIGATION SYSTEM TROUBLE DELAYS SPACE SHUTTLE RETURN BY 8 HOURS
description: The space shuttle Columbia landed safely today, but almost eight hours late, after a cascade of malfunctions struck and spread concern for the spaceship's critical navigation system.

title: HOLLY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
JURY DECIDES BIEGENWALD SHOULD BE EXECUTED FOR 1982 MURDER OF CAMDEN WOMEN
description: The jury that convicted Richard F. Biegenwald of the murder of an 18- year-old Camden woman decided today he should be executed for the crime, one of five killings for which he has been indicted this year.

title: VOLUME MERCHANDISE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Net loss

title: Albright-Knox Names Schultz as Director
description: Douglas C. Schultz has been named director of the Albright-Knox Art Gallery in Buffalo.

title: 4 ALLIES PLEDGE TO KEEP FORCES IN BEIRUT AREA
description: The United States and the three other countries in the multinational force in Lebanon said today that they would remain there indefinitely to press for a broadly based Lebanese Government and the withdrawal of Israeli and Syrian forces.

title: MINNESOTA FABRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
'ULTIMATE BARARISM'
description: To the Editor:

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday RELIGIOUS FOLK-ART SHOW

title: ART: KANDINSKY'S RUSSIAN AND BAUHAUS YEAR
description: Few major 20th-century artists have flourished in such heavy political weather as the Russian painter Vasily Kandinsky (1866-1944), a pioneer of abstract art.

title: IACOCCA GETS BONUS TO STAY AT CHRYSLER
description: Lee A. Iacocca, who has been working without a contract since he joined the Chrysler Corporation in 1978, has agreed to remain its chairman for at least three more years in return for substantial bonuses of stock and stock options.

title: 2 SCHOOLS PRASISED BY REAGAN WERE ONCE URBAN SORE SPOTS
description: Sy ANDREW H. MALCOLM

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: U. S. Steel Warns Of Plant Closings

title: U.S. TO CUT LOANS TO POOR COUNTRIES
description: President Reagan has decided that the United States should offer no more than $750 million a year as its commitment to a World Bank agency that helps the most desperately poor countries, Administration officials said today.

title: GEORGE B. EISLER
description: George B. Eisler, a publisher and a researcher in Hebrew studies who lived in New York in the years after World War II, died of cancer in Hamburg, West Germany, on Nov. 18. He was 91.

title: ARMS - CONTROL TALKS: HOW THEY STAND
description: Following is a list of arms-control negotiations and their status:

title: ART: WORLD'S GREATEST IN A NEW YORK BASEMENT
description: SOME of the finest pictures painted anywhere in the last 100 years are on view at this moment in the basement of an office building in Manhattan. To see them costs nothing. The show runs through Jan. 21, and the gallery hours are 11 A.M. to 6 P.M., Tuesday through Friday, and 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. on Saturdays.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report last Saturday about the 20th anniversary of ''Beyond the Melting Pot'' misidentified the publisher. It was the Harvard University Press.

title: Ericsson Computer To Deutsch Associates
description: The Ericsson Group, a Swedish telecommunications company operating worldwide, has assigned its Alfaskop computer terminal/work station to David Deutsch Associates, which was already its agency for products for the cellular mobile telephone industry.

title: State Urged to Pay For A-Plant Radio
description: The Westchester County Executive, Andrew P. O'Rourke today asked for a $200,000 advance from the state's 1985-86 budget to finance a communication network in the 10-mile emergency zone around the Indian Point nuclear power plant.

title: SIDELINE BRIGADES
description: Bob Holly has been running the Dallas Cowboy plays in practice this week, but at the same time he has been studying the Washington Redskins' plays. On the remote chance that he is called into the big game at Dallas on Sunday, the Redskin plays are the ones he will be expected to use.

title: BRADSHAW IS 'RUSTY BUT READY' FOR JETS
description: Terry Bradshaw has described himself as ''just a little rusty but ready'' for the Pittsburgh Steelers' game against the Jets tomorrow at Shea Stadium (Channel 4, 12:30 P.M.). That can hardly come as good news to the Jets, who have never beaten the Steelers in the six times the two teams have met.

title: Market PlacePhillip H. Wiggins Bullish Outlook For Fast Food
description: T HEIR names are legion, and in some cases

title: Gambling Raids Net 71 in Brooklyn
description: The police seized 103 illegal slot machines containing $200,000 in coins, confiscated $10,000 in suspected numbers bets and arrested 71 people during raids at 49 Brooklyn locations, officials said yesterday.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Watch Out for Pickpockets

title: EASTERN'S UNIONS AGREE TO PAY CUT AND ACCEPT STOCK
description: Three of Eastern Airlines' major unions agreed yesterday to accept wage cuts and increase productivity in return for a voice in management and stock in the company.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Bus Driver With a Mission

title: RIFT GROWS WIDER OVER RIGHTS PANEL
description: Civil rights groups charged today that they had been ''betrayed'' and ''double- crossed'' by President Reagan and other Republicans who were selecting members of the new United States Commission on Civil Rights.

title: WHAT IS A SUPERPOWER?
description: To most Americans and Russians, the U.S. and the Soviet Union are opposites and the stubborn source of danger. If either ''Communists'' or ''imperialists'' could be tamed, depending which side is talking, the world would work reasonably.

title: 2 WOMEN WIN BIAS SUIT AGAINST FIRE DEPT.
description: Two women dismissed as firefighters by the New York City Fire Department were victims of discrimination and must be reinstated with back pay, a Federal judge ruled yesterday.

title: SYSTEMS ENGINEERING & MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MANY SHARE GOOD LUCK BY HELPING THE NEEDIEST
description: ''My income is very modest, but I feel blessed that I can meet my needs. I am touched by the plight of so many who suffer in our midst. I appreciate this opportunity to help.''

title: Flyers 3, Hawks 2
description: Brian Propp's power-play goal with 3:19 left gave Philadelphia the victory.

title: John T. O'Rourke, 83, Editor Of Washington Paper in 60's
description: John T. O'Rourke, a former editor of The Washington Daily News and a past president of the Inter-American Press Association, died of cancer Wednesday in Vero Beach, Fla. He was 83 years old.

title: Tax-Free Transit Trust Certificates The Southern California Rapid Transit District yesterday offered $18.85 million of tax-exempt equipment trust certificates at yields ranging from 6.50 percent for certificates due in 1986 to 9.10 percent in 1994. Underwriters are led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.
description: Proceeds of the financing will be used to pay for the district's 20 percent share of 447 buses.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;  Vilas Hearing
description: Organizers of an international tennis tournament that was held in the Netherlands last March, told a hear? ing in Rotterdam yesterday that they had no choice but to pay Guillermo Vilas $60,000 in appearance money. The hearing, held by the Men's International Professional Tennis Council, is being conducted on Vilas's appeal of a one-year suspension for violating a Grand Prix rule that prohibits the solicitation and acceptance of appearance money.

title: SKI RESORTS OFFER HEALTH-CLUB ACTIVITIES
description: These days, knowledgeable skiers

title: The Worm and the Apple Red Light for Reckless Bikes
description: What motivates those cyclists who whiz along the blind side of traffic lanes, plunge through intersections against the light and otherwise terrorize New York City drivers and pedestrians? For the worst offenders, the answer is money.

title: The Running Nun
description: A few years ago, looking for a way to relax after a day as a grade school principal in San Rafael, Calif., Sister Marion Irvine took up running. ''I needed to use up some pent-up energy, so I decided to give it a go,'' said the 54-year-old Roman Catholic nun, who was soon going 70 miles a week.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: IT was called ''The Night of 100

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Associated Names President of Caldor

title: UNUSUAL CALL ON MELANSON
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif.

title: RESTAURANT
description: All American and distinctive.

title: Bridge: Sometimes It's Wiser to Put Practicality Before Elegance
description: It can take considerable strength of character to reject an elegant play in favor of a less esthetic plan that offers a slightly better percentage.

title: TERMINAL DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Growing Up

title: WHEN SOLISTI NEW YORK MEETS THE MINIMALISTS
description: The chamber orchestra Solisti New York, under the direction of Ransom Wilson, will open its third season tomorrow night at 8 with an unusual program of 20th-century music at the 92d Street Y. Titled ''Meet the Minimalists,'' the concert will offer premieres of works by Steve Reich and Philip Glass, as well as a performance of ''Grand Pianola Music'' by John Adams.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: OVERNIGHT TO MANY DISTANT CITIES. By Donald Barthelme. 174 pages. Putnam. $13.95. ''OVERNIGHT TO MANY DISTANT CITIES'' is composed of stories separated by italicized spoken interludes, which serve as a sort of mood or atmosphere for the more formal pieces. It seems to me that Donald Barthelme also intends these interludes to function as footnotes to the stories, like T. S. Eliot's notes for ''The Wasteland.''

title: KatharineD.Brownell, Pediatrician,82
description: Dr. Katharine Dodge Brownell, a pediatrician, public health officer and leader of the Citizens Committee for Children of New York, died of a heart ailment Wednesday at St. Luke's Hospital. She was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Trio at Alternative
description: The bassist John Lindberg and two woodwind players and saxophonists, Marty Ehrlich and J. D. Parran, will perform new solos, duets and trios tonight at 8 at the Alternative Museum (966-4444), 17 White Street in TriBeCa. Admission is $6.

title: South African Nun Convicted Of Having an Illegal Pamphlet
description: A judge convicted a Roman Catholic nun today of possessing banned anti-Government literature and sentenced her to four months in prison.

title: ANTITRUST POST LEFT BY BAXTER
description: William F. Baxter will leave as head of the Justice Department's antitrust division next week and will be replaced by J. Paul McGrath, head of the civil division, the department said today.

title: HUSBAND OPPOSES WIFE'S WISH TO STARVE TO DEATH
description: The estranged husband of Elizabeth Bouvia, the 26-year-old cerebral palsy victim who says she wants to starve to death to end a lifetime of severe disability, said in court today that her recent life was a string of setbacks that had made her ''very depressed.''

title: Toledo Edison Bonds at 13 3/8% The Toledo Edison Company's $70 million of 13 3/8 percent bonds due in 1993 were offered yesterday at a price of 100 through First Boston Corporation. The bonds, rated Baa-2/BBB-, yielded 154 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, more than 10-year Treasury notes.
description: The utility said its 1983 construction spending would total about $295 million. Most of the spending has been for nuclear power plants in which it has a 20 percent share as a member of the Central Area Power Coordination Group. The plants are scheduled for completion in the mid to late 1980's.

title: Eagle Star Merger Stalled in Britain
description: Allianz Versicherung, West Germany's largest insurance company, held talks with Britain's Eagle Star Holdings and then announced that it was not yet prepared to raise its bid for the British life insurer.

title: OPEC PRICE AND QUOTAS KEPT DESPITE DISPUTE
description: Amid bitter debate over Saudi Arabia's role as the world's swing energy producer, oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries gave final approval today to their pledge to maintain production ceilings and prices at current levels.

title: DANCE: ISRAELI VISITORS
description: THE Batsheva Dance Company of Israel opened a week's engagement at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night with a program notable for its force and fervor.

title: ISRAELI GUNBOATS BOMBARD ARAFAT FORCES AT TRIPOLI
description: Israeli gunboats shelled Palestinians loyal to Yasir Arafat just north of the harbor in Tripoli this morning, killing one Palestinian and wounding three others, according to a spokesman for Mr. Arafat.

title: ART: THE TIGHTROPE HELEN FRANKENTHALER WALKS
description: FOR more than 30 years, Helen Frankenthaler has been creating paintings that walk a tightrope between spontaneity and self-consciousness, improvisation and deliberation, dissolution and structure. So it is with her recent work, at the Andre Emmerich Gallery, 41 West 57th Street, through Dec. 31.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Chrysler Corp. has elected John D. Withrow executive vice president of product development; Robert M. Sinclair vice president of engineering, and L. Donald Gschwind vice president of program management.

title: SECURITY SYSTEM UPSETS A MANSION'S NEIGHBORS
description: Drumthwacket, the 12-acre site here that the state is converting to a showcase official mansion for New Jersey governors, is upsetting the neighborhood.

title: Sharon'sLibelSuit Is Going to Trial
description: A $50 million libel suit brought by Ariel Sharon, an Israeli Cabinet Minister, against Time magazine was ordered yesterday to go to trial.

title: 13 English Soccer Fans Jailed For a Luxembourg Rampage
description: Thirteen English soccer fans were jailed and fined today on charges of theft, looting and assault in a violent rampage after an international match.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Castle & Cooke Switch

title: Democracy, as Usual, in Caracas
description: Some events deserve notice because they are unremarkable. The democratic succession in Venezuela, for example.

title: 3 Killed and 21 Injured In Chicago Hotel Fire
description: A smoky fire in a downtown hotel killed at least three people today and injured 21, the authorities said.

title: Swedish Paper Reports On Smuggling to Soviet
description: A financial newspaper said today that the police had evidence that at least 11 boxes of sensitive Western computer equipment had been smuggled through Sweden to the Soviet Union, assisted by two or three Swedes.

title: Esmark Net Up 2.4%
description: Esmark Inc., aided by the results of its recently acquired Norton Simon Inc. subsidiary, said yesterday that fourth-quarter earnings rose 2.4 percent, while revenues climbed 85.7 percent.

title: Ford Steel Plant
description: The Ford Motor Company said it would make a ''major announcement'' tomorrow concerning its Rouge Steel Company unit, which company and union sources said involves construction of a new facility. Previously, Ford received wage concessions from the United Auto Workers union after saying it might close Rouge.

title: Robbery Suspect Tied to 30 Killings
description: A 27-year-old Bronx man arrested last night on a robbery charge was identified by the police as a suspect in 30 homicides.

title: COLECO CAN'T SAVOR A SUCCESS
description: Coleco Industries, whose fortunes and stock price have dipped and crested wildly in the last decade, is riding what is arguably the most turbulent sea in its corporate life.

title: Gemayel to Visit Britain
description: President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon will visit London on Tuesday to talk with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and other officials, the Government said today.

title: U.S. SOVIET PANEL SEES NO HOPE IN AN ATOMIC WAR
description: A group of Soviet and American scientists agreed today that a large-scale nuclear exchange could mean the extinction of the human race.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: 1 POTATO 2 INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 9
description: b-Net loss

title: FOR A CITIZEN ABROAD: QUESTIONS, NOT 'SNARLS'
description: To the Editor:

title: MYSTERY, FANTASY, SONG
description: THEY live in a giant apartment complex in Chicago. He, living in the north tower, goes to his window, picks up his binoculars and casually looks across the way. She, living in the south tower, is looking right back at him through a telescope. And so begins ''Through Naked Eyes,'' a neatly crafted made-for-television movie that is on Channel 7 Sunday at 9 P.M.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''A change in the overall strategic situation due to the beginning of the deployment of new American missiles in Europe compels the Soviet side to re-examine all the issues which are the subject of the discussion at the talks on the limitation and reduction of strategic armaments.

title: United Delays Boeing Order
description: United Airlines said it had

title: HEALTH OFFICIALS REPORT HERPES SURGE IN NEWBORNS
description: Public health officials reported yesterday that the incidence of herpes simplex cases among newborns in the United States had been rising sharply, with devastating effects on the infected babies. A second study, concerning adults, cited evidence that the disease could be spread in hot tubs.

title: THE CYPRUS SOLUTION TURKEY WON'T BROOK
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. HOCKEY CLUB BACK AT SITE OF UPSET
description: It was the same locker room, but Phil Verchota put aside any nostalgic thoughts today about the events of the 1980 Winter Olympics.

title: MANY MORE OF ELDERLY MIGRATE TO NEW STATES
description: The number of elderly Americans who reported migrating from one state to another rose sharply from 1970 to 1980, an analysis of new Census Bureau data shows. The increase in the number of elderly migrants in the last decade was four times the increase reported from 1960 to 1970.

title: LONG-TERM BOND PRICES OFF SHARPLY
description: Prices of long-term bonds fell sharply yesterday and interest rates rose, reflecting a growing conviction that chances have faded for a near- term decline in rates.

title: Foss's 'Nutcracker'
description: The complete score of Tchaikovsky's ''Nutcracker'' will be performed by the Brooklyn Philharmonic tonight and tomorrow at 8 and Sunday at 2 P.M. at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: A Return to the Wars From a Publishing Stint
description: Eric Weber, who dropped out of the agency business in order to run a book publishing company he formed, is returning with a vengeance - as executive vice president and head of one of the three creative divisions of Dancer Fitzgerald Sample.

title: Newark Considers Change in Curfew
description: The City Council has given preliminary approval to a measure requiring anyone under the age of 13 to be home by 10 o'clock each night.

title: '84 I.B.M. REVENUE GAIN EXPECTED TO TOP 14.5%
description: An official of the International Business Machines Corporation told securities analysts yesterday that revenue growth in 1984 would exceed the 14.5 percent pace of recent years, suggesting strong profits.

title: EAGLE CLOTHES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $468,000. c-Including an extraordinary gain of $453,000.

title: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 9, 1983 International
description: Strategic arms talks ended in Geneva, and the Russians refused to set a date for resuming the negotiations with the United States. The Soviet delegation said it felt compelled ''to re-examine all the issues'' in view of the deployment of new American medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe. (Page A1, Column 6.) The four-nation force will remain in Lebanon indefinitely to press for a broadly based Lebanese Government and a withdrawal of Israeli and Syrian forces from that country, the foreign ministers affirmed. The statement by ministers of the United States, France, Britain and Italy was issued after a one-hour meeting in the Brussels hotel suite of Secretary of State George P. Shultz. (A1:5.)

title: GANDALF TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
B C SUGAR REFINERY LTD reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Including a special gain of $1,881,000.

title: SCOUTING
description: Aiming Higher

title: Bethlehem Steel
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, citing an increase in business, said it plans to reactivate two steelmaking furnaces at the Sparrows Point, Md., plant and recall about 200 workers. John G. Roberts, the plant's general manager, said one furnace will begin operation on Jan. 9 and the second one on Jan. 16. The furnaces have been closed since early this year.

title: SOVIET INTENTIONS QUERIED IN VIENNA
description: According to Western diplomats in Vienna, the Soviet Union and its Warsaw Pact allies have started giving signals that raise doubts about whether they intend to continue the decade-old talks on reduction of conventional arms in Central Europe.

title: MCLOUTH STEEL BOUNCES BACK
description: McLouth Steel always seems to be a step ahead. It was an industry leader in using advanced technology. When hard times hit, it was the first steelmaker to file for bankruptcy reorganization. And last year, six months ahead of its bigger competitors, it won wage concessions from its workers.

title: SCOUTING
description: The Dotted Line

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 33.

title: REV. LEWIS HENRY DAVIS
description: The Rev. Lewis Henry Davis, former superintendent for the New York district of the United Methodist Church, died of a heart attack Tuesday at his home on Shelter Island, L.I. He was 81 years old.

title: THAW IN COLD WAR
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y.

title: WASHINGTON
description: I NVENTORS and their business

title: U.S. HOCKEY TEAM WINS ON LATE GOAL
description: This time, it was a mini miracle, as the United States Olympic hockey team scored a dramatic 5-4 victory over a Soviet all-star squad tonight.

title: MRS. WALESA PARRIES THE PRESS IN OSLO
description: Danuta Walesa arrived here this morning to accept the 1983 Nobel Peace Prize for her husband, Lech, who had decided not to come himself out of fear that if he left Poland he would not be permitted to return.

title: A Transit Court Bargain
description: New York's police and their prey both consider the prosecution of turnstile jumpers and other transit offenders a joke - and they're right. Mayor Koch would make it more meaningful by creating a new transit court.

title: U.S. WARNS EUROPEANS AGAINST TRADE CURBS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz warned America's European allies today not to try to solve their internal economic problems at the expense of the United States.

title: BRITAIN IS ASSURED BY US ABOUT ARMS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz assured Britain today that the United States would consult ''very carefully'' with it before selling any arms to Argentina now that the American ban on such sales had been lifted.

title: U.S. FLIGHTS OVER LEBANON: THEIR VALUE CALLED INTO QUESTION
description: MilitaryAnalysis

title: ILL-CHOSEN INVESTIGATORS OF CIVILIAN COMPLAINTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 101872 -- No Title
description: A Federal jury awarded more than $5 million today to a woman who suffered paralyzing injuries in an accident caused by defective brakes in her Chevrolet Citation, an X-car.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 15.

title: Suit on Dumping Is Settled Upstate
description: An out- of-court settlement was reached Thursday in a 1980 lawsuit filed by the Federal and state governments against the former Hooker Chemical Company over the cleanup of a Niagara Falls dump site, state officials said.

title: Swiss Wins Race
description: Franz Heinzer of Switzerland won the World Cup men's downhill ski race narrowly today, beating Todd Brooker of Canada by one hundredth of a second. The 21-year-old Heinzer was timed in 2 minutes 1.56 seconds.

title: THE POLICE OFFICER AS VICTIM OF BRUTALITY
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I certainly have no desire to further burden the overcrowded prisons.'' - Former Representative John W. Jenrette Jr., before being sentenced to two years in prison for his Abscam conviction. (11:2.)

title: COMMENTS BY MEESE ON HUNGER PRODUCE A STORM OF CONTROVERSY
description: Comments by Edwin Meese 3d, the Presidential counselor, on reports of hunger in America produced a storm of controversy yesterday. Democratic leaders and some experts on hunger called the remarks outrageous, but the White House said they had been blown out of proportion.

title: Another Greek Ship Is Hit by Iraqis
description: An Iraqi missile hit a Greek cargo ship in the Persian Gulf on Thursday in the second such incident in two months, the ship's owners said today.

title: A Toast to Argentina
description: Break out the champagne for Argentina. A great country, blessed with human and natural riches, returns today to the democratic fold after eight ruinous years of military dictatorships. But credit the departing generals with a sense of drama. Perhaps by inspired design, they chose to have the elected President, Raul Alfonsin, inaugurated on Dec. 10: Human Rights Day.

title: Shadow in the Corner
description: Officially, the principals in tonight's exhibition bout at Andrews Air Force Base near Washington are the former welterweight champion, Sugar Ray Leonard , and an unrelated opponent, Odell Leonard .

title: NEW OLYMPIC IDEAL: JUNK FOOD IN A SOUND BODY
description: With remarkable incongruity, Hostess Cakes, makers of Twinkies, has become an official sponsor of the 1984 Olympics.

title: DAVID ROUNDS, TONY WINNER
description: David Rounds, who won a Tony Award in 1980 for his comic portrayal of Homer, the 40-year-old mamma's boy in ''Morning's at Seven,'' died of cancer yesterday at his home in Lomontville, N.Y. He was 53 years old.

title: THE PINE-TAR RULE IS CLARIFIED
