description: If George Brett hits a home run against the Yankees next season with pine tar reaching more than 18 inches up his bat, the umpires will not call him out. The home run will count, no matter how vociferously the Yankee manager - Billy Martin or whoever - protests.

title: U.N. ACCUSES 3 LATIN NATIONS ON RIGHTS
description: Despite American objections, the General Assembly adopted resolutions today accusing El Salvador, Chile and Guatemala of human rights violations.

title: JUDGE LASKER'S SELECTION
description: To the Editor:

title: MIDSTAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $2,813,000 from tax credits and sale of the company's snowmobile group. c-Including an extraordinary gain of $1,237,000 from tax credits and sale of the company's snowmobile group. Results for the latest first quarter include operations of the Bekins Co. acquired in June 1983.

title: HUSTLER PUBLISHER TELLS JUDGE DELOREAN TAPE WAS A FAKE
description: Larry Flynt, publisher of Hustler magazine, testified today that a tape recording purportedly containing a Government informant's threats against John Z. DeLorean, the automobile manufacturer accused in a $24 million cocaine deal, was a fake.

title: Borman View Of Labor Pact
description: Frank Borman, the chairman of Eastern Airlines, said yesterday that he welcomed the greater worker participation in the management of the company that will result from the company's new labor agreement, though he still believed that the two sides will remain essentially in an adversarial relationship.

title: U.S. SUES SHELL OIL FOR $1.9 BILLION IN POLLUTION CASE
description: The Justice Department sued the Shell Oil Company today for nearly $1.9 billion in damage to the environment the Government says was caused by the company's pesticide factory near Denver.

title: AMERICAN WOMEN'S GOOD LUCK
description: Its good to be home. After nearly six years abroad, I am struck first of all by what a good time it is to be a woman in America. Speak not to me of a gender gap. I have lived for the past four years in London. I now feel a surge of new life akin perhaps to what a ghetto child might experience contemplating an endless expanse of green space.

title: Koch Assails Libya's Envoy Over Remarks Made at U.N.
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that remarks by Libya's chief delegate to the United Nations on Wednesday were ''sheer anti-Semitism.'' The Mayor said the Libyan, Ali Treiki, and his Government were ''a disgrace.''

title: Cuomo, in Bronx, Helps Build Home
description: Governor Cuomo went to the Bronx yesterday to help mark the construction of some new houses on Charlotte Street and to get some advice on how to spend the state's money.

title: CAMPANELLI INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Former Boston Official Charged With Fraud
description: A former city official and a ward leader in Mayor Kevin H. White's political organization was charged Thursday in Federal District Court with mail fraud in connection with his claims for a city disability pension.

title: Birdsong Baskets Stop 76ers;  Nets 100 76ers 93
description: Otis Birdsong scored 21 points on his 28th birthday tonight, including a pair of spectacular jump shots in the final 77 seconds that led the New Jersey Nets to a 100-93 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers.

title: HOUSTON NATURAL GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Portrait Gazing By a Mayor's Family

title: UNTRAINED FOR AN EXPANDING CITY ECONOMY
description: To the Editor:

title: LEBANESE IN DANBURY MOURN FOR HOMELAND
description: Their heads bowed, the parishioners of St. Anthony Maronite Catholic Church prayed out loud for relatives left behind in Lebanon.

title: Ribli Postpones Game In Chess Semifinals
description: Zoltan Ribli of Hungary postponed the ninth game of his semifinal world championship chess match with Vasily Smyslov of Switzerland here today.

title: Dome Poses Peril InSenateChamber
description: Leaded stained-glass panels weighing at least 50 pounds, which make up an ornamental dome atop the State Senate chamber, are weak and could possibly fall 80 feet to the floor, state officials said today.

title: Bonn Parliament Refuses To Demand Resignation
description: Parliament today rejected an opposition motion demanding the dismissal of Economics Minister Otto Lambsdorff, who is accused of accepting bribes to influence a decision on tax waivers for the Flick holding company.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY AGENCY HALTS CUTOFFS OF DISABILITY BENEFITS
description: The Social Security Administration has halted cutoffs of disability benefits while it considers what to do about people it feels are no longer entitled to receive cash payments and Medicare coverage, a spokesman said today.

title: JUST A TOY JUST A TOY JUST A TOY
description: They will always be remembered. The antiwar demonstrations of the 60's. The angry gasoline lines of the 70's. And now, the Cabbage Patch Kid hysteria of the 80's.

title:
PATENTS ;
Way to Introduce DNA Into Mammalian Cells
description: The Department of Health and Human Services received a patent this week for a way of introducing recombinant DNA into mammalian cells, including human cells.

title: 3 LOOSENED CEILING RODS FOUND AT BUS TERMINAL
description: Three hanger rods among hundreds holding up a ceiling in the rebuilt Port Authority Bus Terminal in Manhattan were recently found to have pulled loose, and the authority says engineers are working on a ''corrective design.''

title: Jockey Hurt in Crash
description: Bill Nemeti , a leading New Jersey jockey, suffered a severed spinal cord that has left him paralyzed from the waist down after being thrown from his car in a one-car accident near the Meadowlands track early Thursday morning. Nemeti, who had won two races Wednesday night, was on his way to his home at the Jersey shore when he lost control of his car on Route 3. After treatment at a New Jersey hospital, he was taken to Bellevue Hospital in Manhattan, where he was in fair condition yesterday.

title: DON'T OPERATE SHOREHAM
description: The Shoreham Nuclear Power Station should not be permitted to operate.

title: DALLAS'S FOOTBALL FEVER IS SO CONSTANT ITS'S COOL
description: Football is serious business in Texas, sometimes deadly serious.

title: DANCE: OLD FAVORITES BY ALVIN AILEY TROUPE
description: In addition to a repeat performance of Alvin Ailey's ''Revelations,'' Thursday night's program by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater at the City Center Theater included ''Blues Suite,'' ''Cry'' and ''Rainbow 'Round My Shoulder.'' In other words, it was an evening of old favorites, for all these works are associated with this company and have received deserved acclaim for many a season.

title: TO THE TROUBLES OF IRELAND, ADD YOUNG DUBLINERS
description: The TalkofDublin

title: SLIM PICKENS, KNOWN FOR COWBOY ROLES, DIES
description: Slim Pickens, a onetime rodeo star turned cowboy actor, died Thursday night at a convalescent hospital in Modesto, Calif. He was 64 years old.

title: Man Arrested as Spy Faces More Charges
description: An espionage indictment was returned today against a man charged in October with selling military secrets to a Polish spy.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Observing Amnesty Day

title: U.S. FORCE ON GRENADA REDUCED
description: President Reagan told Congressional leaders today that the United States military force on Grenada had been reduced below 2,700, but he said ''it is still not possible to predict'' when all American forces would be withdrawn from the Caribbean island.

title: FORD PLANS $200 MILLION STEEL UNIT
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it would invest $200 million in a modern continuous slab-casting facility for its aging Rouge Steel complex, just outside Detroit, bringing new life to a plant that was threatened with being closed down earlier this year.

title: SCOUTING
description: Rozelle Warns Against Steroids

title: College Basketball; Iona, Illinois-Chicago in Final
description: Iona had a bit more trouble than it anticipated from Brown tonight before pulling away to a 72-59 victory over the Bruins in the sixth annual Manufacturers Hanover Classic.

title: ; REPORT TO BE FILED FOR GRAND PRIX
description: The promoters of the New York Grand Prix auto race announced yesterday that they would submit a required environmental impact statement to the city early next year. They hope to hold the event in September in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park.

title: SATURDAYSPORTS Basketball
description: Iona vs. Illinois-Chicago or St. Francis of Pennsylvania, championship or consolation game, Manufacturers Hanover Classic, at Mulcahy Gym, New Rochelle, N.Y. Brown is the other team in the tournament, whose championship game will follow the 6 P.M. consolation. (Radio - Iona game only: WFAS-FM, 103.9; 6 P.M. or 8 P.M.) Syracuse vs. North Carolina, at Carrier Dome, Syracuse, 7:30 P.M. (Radio - WNYE-FM, 91.5; 7:30 P.M.)

title: PLAYERSIra Berkow
description: The publication in 1970 of Jim

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: A TOUCH OF FANCY FOR MEN
description: There are always scarfs, of course. And gloves and wallets and neckties and socks and a sea of after-shave lotion. But, somehow, when it comes to imaginative ideas, gifts for men often prove to be a challenge.

title: Toni Morrison to Read
description: Toni Morrison, editor and novelist, will read from her latest unpublished novel in a program called ''In the Tradition: A Celebration of Poetry and Jazz'' tomorrow at 3 P.M., as part of the ''New Bones'' series at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 East 64th Street.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Presidential Contenders And Others, Take Note

title: EX-REP. JENRETTE GETS TWO YEARS IN ABSCAM CASE
description: Former Representative John W. Jenrette Jr., saying alcoholism had made him lose his judgment and accept a $50,000 bribe in the Abscam investigation, was sentenced today to two years in prison and fined $20,000.

title: SGL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After $163,000 writeoff of goodwill not having continuing value. The share earnings in year-ago period was adjusted for 3-for-2 stock split in June and 6 percent stock dividend paid in November.

title:
PATENTS ;
Method and Apparatus To Teach Grammar
description: Paul R. Erwin, headmaster of the Winston School in Dallas, was granted a patent this week on a method and apparatus for teaching grammar, reported to be in use.

title: NEW THREAT OF A NEWSPAPER STRIKE
description: A labor dispute that shut down Britain's national newspapers two weeks ago appeared headed toward a new confrontation today, as negotiations collapsed and the printing union involved was ordered to pay $756,000 in fines for contempt of court.

title: MRS. KENNETH A. GIBSON
description: Muriel Cook Gibson, the wife of Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson of Newark, died of cancer Thursday afternoon in New York Hospital in Manhattan, an aide to the Mayor said.

title: The Kevlar Heart of Commerce
description: A new helmet made of Kevlar, a synthetic material manufactured by Du Pont, saved the lives of at least two soldiers during the invasion of Grenada. The Army is so pleased with the helmets that it plans to buy a million. Now for the bad news: The Commerce Department recently agreed to let Du Pont sell enough Kevlar to make 30,000 bulletproof vests - for resale to Syria.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Before You Ask Where the Train Goes

title: 15 ARE CHARGED IN DRUG CASE
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted 15 people, including a former bank vice president, on charges of running a cocaine ring that laundered more than $1 million through a Washington bank.

title: MATERIALS RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Includes a charge of $4.3 million principally due to start-up costs of an enhanced product and the writedown of obsolete inventory. c-Net income

title: ; ONE CRYSTAL PALACE DESERVES ANOTHER
description: To the Editor:

title: MATTEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Including tax credits of $5.2 million for the quarter and $22.1 million for the 9 months. c-Net income.

title: Israeli Bomb Toll Rises to 5
description: The death toll in the bombing of a Jerusalem bus on Tuesday rose to five today when a 16-year-old girl died of her wounds, the Israeli radio said. The bombing wounded 45 people.

title: DPCC FAILS TO GET DR PEPPER METTING
description: Dr Pepper said yesterday that it had turned down a request by the DPCC Acquisition Corporation, which has offered to buy Dr Pepper, to attend Dr Pepper's special board meeting today in Dallas.

title: UNDER 1983 CHRISTMAS TREE, EXPECT THE HOME COMPUTER
description: This is the year in which the home computer will join the sled and the bicycle under the Christmas tree.

title: Bridge:Routine Ending Gets Tough When Trumps Are Involved
description: One might suppose that all three- card end-positions would be routine, but some very tricky situations can arise when there is a trump element. An example occurred in the 1982 Fall Nationals in Minneapolis, and the contract was four spades reached by a simple route.

title: EGYPT HARDENS STAND ON ISRAELI TIES
description: President Hosni Mubarak indicated in an interview published here today that conditions previously set for the return of Egypt's ambassador to Israel would not be enough. He said even if Israeli troops withdrew from Lebanon there would have to be approval by the Egyptian people of the resumption of normal ties.

title: MANHATTAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
A NOBLEMAN IN NATO JOB
description: Peter Alexander Rupert Carrington, who was named to succeed Joseph M. A. H. Luns as Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization yesterday, has many reasons why he should have remained in a prestigious post in British industry. Money was not one of them. But when the opportunity came to do something for the sorely tried Atlantic alliance and, incidentally, for his own country, Lord Carrington, chairman of the British General Electric Company, decided to return to international political life.

title: NATO URGES SOVIET TO JOIN 'DIALOGUE' ON NEW RELATIONS
description: Text of declaration, Page 4.

title: BIG LOSS AT MATTEL IN QUARTER
description: Mattel Inc. said yesterday that it had a loss of $46.3 million in the third quarter because of large operating losses in its electronics sector. But the deficit was narrowed from the preceding three months by a strong showing by Mattel's toy operations.

title: 3 Patrol Boats Seized On Way to Nicaragua
description: The Commerce Department said tonight that its agents had seized three high-speed patrol boats in Miami before they could be shipped illegally to Nicaragua.

title: Philadelphia Saving Fund
description: The Philadelphia Saving Fund Society reached a definitive agreement to take over Family Financial Services from the General Electric Credit Corporation for about $600 million, the society announced. The takeover must be approved by regulators and by the board of General Electric Credit, which is a subsidiary of the General Electric Company.

title: GULFSTREAM LAND & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, DECEMBER 10, 1983
description: Markets

title: BEEHIVE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,007,462 for the latest year and $866,640 for the previous year.

title: DANCE: 2D BATSHEVA BILL
description: Israel's Batsheva Dance Company, which continues through a matinee tomorrow at the Joyce Theater, has undergone many changes since its founding in 1964.

title: LOST ON THE DARK PLANET
description: Last year there was trouble in Chad. It made me nervous. I am an American; I have an American education in geography. When I heard there was Chad trouble, I thought it had something to do with fish. Maybe the price of shad roe would go out of sight.

title: New Control Of GAF Near By The Associated Press
description: Barring a further court fight, a dissident group of the GAF Corporation stockholders is expected to get control of the company on Tuesday, a GAF spokesman said. GAF, a chemical and roofing-materials company, plans to reconvene a shareholders meeting on that day to officially announce results of the vote on an attempt by a group led by Samuel J. Heyman, a Connecticut real estate developer, to unseat GAF's management, said Robert Button, the GAF spokesman.

title: RICHTON INTERNATIONAL CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $221,000 for the quarter and $486,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss.

title: SPECIAL OPEC MEETING IS FORESEEN
description: Oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries said today that because demand for their crude oil was expected to fluctuate widely in the first half of 1984, an emergency meeting of the group would probably be necessary in coming months to realign its fragile production-sharing agreement.

title: CONGRESS CRITICAL OF MIDEAST POLICY
description: The Reagan Administration held a briefing for Congressmen today on the situation in Lebanon, but the session apparently failed to placate many legislators who are increasingly critical of President Reagan's Middle East policy.

title: Reagan Says 1,000 Terrorists Are Being Trained in Lebanon
description: President Reagan said earlier this week that up to 1,000 terrorists in Lebanon are ''willing to sacrifice their lives in a kamikaze attack'' against American and Lebanese positions.

title: Italian Airports Closed
description: All airports in Italy were closed today by a seven-hour firemen's strike. The firemen, who are negotiating a new contract, stopped work and the airports were closed to comply with safety regulations.

title: PROSECUTION PLAYS EX-AIDE'S TAPES AT BEATTY TRIAL
description: The prosecution at the trial of former State Senator Vander L. Beatty of Brooklyn played tapes yesterday of secretly recorded conversations in which, it said, Mr. Beatty admitted complicity in an election-fraud scheme.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: THE OLD COUNTRY Grassano is a small town in Italy's southern, impoverished Lucania, an attractive looking center, with central piazza, town pump, white brick houses with balconies and stepped streets leading up to surrounding hills. At least that's what Grassano looked like in the 1930's, which is how it is reconstructed, in a wide-stage, small-scale model housed in the large hall one flight down in the imposing Our Lady of Pompeii Church at 25 Carmine Street, near Bleecker Street and Avenue of the Americas.

title: Letter: On Nuclear Power Yes, Open Shoreham - With a Law To the Editor:
description: As one who has never understood the hangup of top New York State officials about nuclear-generated electricity, let me commend The Times for its Nov. 23 editorial in support of opening the Shoreham plant.

title: KEEPING SAFETY IN TOYS
description: TOYS are every child's favorite

title: Swedish Joblessness
description: The unemployment rate in Sweden slipped to 3.3 percent last month from 3.4 percent in October.

title: Sarah Plimpton Is Wed to a Professor
description: Sarah Plimpton, daughter of Mrs. Francis T. P. Plimpton of New York and Huntington, L.I., and the late Mr. Plimpton, was married yesterday to Robert O. Paxton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew W. Paxton of Lexington, Va. The Rev. William Sloane Coffin Jr. performed the nondenominational service in Christ Chapel at Riverside Church.

title: WHY BAY CITY BLUES' WAS BENCHED
description: Death came quickly to ''Bay City Blues'' this season. The NBC program, which was the brainchild of Steven Bochco and was a younger sibling to the popular police program ''Hill Street Blues,'' was spared the lingering months of poor ratings and the weeks of pained discussion by executives that has accompanied the cancellation of several other major programs by the network.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a printing error, part of a paragraph was omitted in some copies yesterday from Vincent Canby's review of the Clint Eastwood movie ''Sudden Impact.'' It should have read, ''The screenplay bears a remarkable resemblance to 'Death Wish,' especially in its impatience with the system of justice that most of us accept because nothing else has been shown to be better, even efficient vigilantes like Harry Callahan.''

title: BAILOR IS PART OF DODGER TRADE
description: Bob Bailor, ranked by many baseball people as the best all-purpose player on the Mets, was expected today to be sent to the Los Angeles to complete the trade for Sid Fernandez.

title: BUT THE TEMPERATURES SURGE IN WASHINGTON
description: There has been a bout of convivial dementia here this week. It is called Redskin fever, and while it may have started out as a low-grade affliction it has become so virulent that schedules have been changed, travel plans altered, people plan to huddle together to combat it and even the unafflicted have been affected.

title: EX-NEW YORKERS AID NEEDIEST
description: New Yorkers present and past have been among the most consistent contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, and their gifts to the fund's 72d annual appeal continue to demonstrate their loyalty to a city they consider their hometown or recall with warmth and good feeling.

title: Her Point Is Over Net
description: She's apparently having trouble making ends meet on the $1.5 million or so she's earned on the courts this year, so Martina Navratilova has lodged a complaint against the size of the purses at the major tennis tournaments. ''The prize money at Wimbledon and the United States Open is pathetic,'' she said.

title: JETS ARE SEEKING ONE MORE AT SHEA
description: Their owner could not wait to get out of Shea Stadium, but now the Jets hope that, perhaps, they can return one more time.

title: N.B.A. AND REFEREES END DISPUTE
description: On the 100th day after locking out its regular referees, the National Basketball Association reached agreement on a new contract with their union yesterday and announced that they would return to work next Friday.

title: Latin Nations Postpone Signing of Peace Treaty
description: Central American nations have postponed the scheduled signing of a regional peace treaty until next year, Panama announced today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Now Appearing Regularly On TV, His Honor

title: SOUTHHAMPTON PRESERVATIONISTS FOGHT MOVIE THEATER PLAN
description: Although she has visited this summer resort area often in the last 20 years, Frances Genovese says she has few roots here.

title: Domtar Project
description: Domtar Inc. said directors had approved a $773 million, six-year project to rehabilitate its fine-papers plant in Windsor, Quebec. The approval requires Government grants for the project and the negotiation of agreements on environmental matters and wood supply. Domtar said the board had also approved a $139 million program to continue modernizing its Cornwall, Ontario, fine- paper complex, to be carried out between 1984 and 1988.

title: TEXT OF DECLARATION FROM NATO'S MEETING
description: Following is the official text of the Declaration of Brussels, which was issued today by the Foreign Ministers of the NATO countries:

title: MIAMI ARCHEOLOGIST RACES BULLDOZER
description: Most Miamians are born elsewhere and even the natives think of the city's past as reaching back no more than 80 years, when it was chartered. For several years, Dade County has been paying Robert S. Carr to prove otherwise.

title: Award for Steinkuhler
description: Dean Steinkuhler , Nebraska's all- America guard whose blocking has been credited with helping his teammate, Mike Rozier , win the Heisman Trophy last week as the outstanding college football player of the year, has received recognition of his own.

title: MASSACHUSETTS LEGISLATORS BALK AT LEADERS' POWER
description: When Representative Lucile Hicks returned from lunch one day earlier this year, she was startled to find her office empty of desk, files and chairs. She saw her potted palm being rolled down the marble Statehouse corridor on a dolly.

title: Your Money; Overambitious Tax Shelters
description: DESPITE the flurry of year-end tax shelters being advertised these days, or perhaps because of it, investors should be particularly careful of these investments.

title: Burma Decrees Death For 2 North Koreans
description: Two North Korean Army officers were sentenced to death today for the bombing Oct. 9 that killed 17 South Korean Government officials and 4 Burmese.

title: MONEY SUPPLY OFF $2.1 BILLION
description: Surprising the financial markets, the Federal Reserve System said yesterday that the basic measure of the money supply declined a steep $2.1 billion in the week ended Nov. 30.

title: ARMS STANCE: CAN IT WORK?
description: News Analysis

title: SCOUTING
description: Berry's Future

title: HOW RUMOR OF A CONVICTED MURDERER'S ALIBI CHANGED AND CIRCULATED
description: Robert Austin Sullivan, a convicted murderer, said he had an alibi. And in the last days of his unavailing struggle to avoid execution, accounts of that statement received fresh currency around the world and further complicated his case.

title: Key Rates
description: * Nuveen index, John Nuveen & Company Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: IT'S CUT - RATE BELUGA AS CAVIAR GLUT HITS
description: No one used to think much about the price of caviar. At whatever price, some bought it and others did not. It was that simple.

title: CBS Pulls Out Of Cable Deal
description: CBS Inc. said it had withdrawn from a six-month-old

title: BEST PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss. Year-ago sales include sales of Basco Stores since acquisition in July 1982 and sales of Modern Merchandising since acquisition in October 1982. Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split to be paid Dec. 15.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a dispatch from Grenada Nov. 6 - citing the manacling and blindfolding of former Deputy Prime Minister Bernard Coard and Gen. Hudson Austin - reported incorrectly that the 1949 Geneva Conventions on prisoners of war outlaw handcuffing and permit blindfolding for only those prisoners who are to be taken through militarily sensitive areas. The operative section, Article 46, says merely that the transfer of prisoners ''shall always be effected humanely'' and that ''the conditions of transfer shall in no case be prejudicial to their health.''

title: BRYANT PARK PLAN: HEED THE PUBLIC INTEREST
description: To the Editor:

title: KNICKS TROUNCE CLIPPERS
description: General Manager Paul Phipps of San Diego says he has not decided whether to pick up the contract option of the often-injured Bill Walton, the part- time center who is out for two months after suffering a fractured right index finger in a game last Sunday against the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: THEATER: IMPROVISATION ON SINCLAIR'S 'JUNGLE'
description: Upton Sinclair's ''Jungle,'' written in 1906, was a scathing indictment of exploitative capitalism, as represented by the meat-packing industry. It was, as Jack London suggested, ''the 'Uncle Tom's Cabin' of wage slavery.'' Understandably, ''The Jungle'' was a source of inspiration for Brecht's ''In the Jungle of Cities'' and ''St. Joan of the Stockyards.''

title:
PATENTS ;
Lit Candle Operates Wax Display Boy Made
description: An 11-year-old Chicago boy received a patent this week for a decorative wax display to be operated by lighting a candle. Alexander Z. Gustafson was only 9 when he applied for patent 4,419,070, which he has assigned to Chicago Digital Inc., a company of which his father, Robert Gustafson, is president.

title: SAFETY FEATURE AT INDIAN PT. 2 FOUND DISABLED
description: The Indian Point 2 reactor ran for more than a month while two water spray systems designed to reduce the consequences of an accident were inadvertently disabled, Consolidated Edison has reported.

title: Pirates Awash
description: When Pittsburgh officials spent $1.5 million on a new playing surface for Three Rivers Stadium this year, they got more than they bargained for - a sinking diamond. According to Doug McCormick , the treasurer of the Pirates, sections of the field, primarily along the first- and third-base lines, have been forming ruts, and after every rainfall the runoff forms a watery outline of the diamond. Pirate executives estimate that as much as 30 percent of the new artifical turf will have to be replaced, but Joseph Massaro , whose company supervised the installation of the new surface, described the problem as ''minor.''

title: 3 Guilty of Conspiracy In Detroit Bribery Case
description: Three guilty verdicts were returned today by a Federal district court jury in a bribery case that Mayor Coleman Young has called an effort to discredit his administration.

title: Bus Line Workers Approve Contract
description: Drivers and mechanics of Liberty Lines, Westchester County's biggest bus operation, have approved a three- year contract by a 405-to-40 vote, officials of Local 100 of the United Transport Union announced yesterday.

title: SOLD: CIGAR BOXES OF LEGAL CUBAN TREASURES
description: ''This,'' said George Warner, standing before a six-foot-high altar of golden cigar boxes containing what he considered ambrosia of the gods, ''is a religious experience.''

title: NEW WAGNERIAN QUEEN HAS EMERGED AT THE MET
description: With her personal triumph singing all three Br"unnhildes for the first time in ''Der Ring des Nibelungen'' in last summer's new production at the Bayreuth Festival, and with her first Isolde at the Metropolitan Opera Monday night - the second of her six scheduled performances of the part is tonight - Hildegard Behrens has suddenly emerged as the leading Wagnerian dramatic soprano of the day.

title: 2 Workers Are Stabbed In Graphic Arts Studio
description: A man walked into a graphic arts studio in mid-Manhattan yesterday and, after a brief conversation, told a photographer there, ''I'm going to stab you in the heart,'' then stabbed him and another employee.

title: CITY'S FIRST MAJOR FISH PLANT SET FOR BROOKLYN WATERFRONT
description: New York City's first large-scale commercial fish-processing operation will be built in a desolate section of the Brooklyn waterfront, and one of the borough's few modern container ports will be doubled in size.

title: Books of The Times British Tales of Murder
description: THE BLACK SERAPHIM. By MICHAEL

title: FROM CHIC TO CLICHE: THE SHORT LIFE OF FAST FOODS
description: Fashions in food, like fashions in clothes, are often determined by current events. And as with clothes, last year's food chic is this year's cliche.

title: INVESTIGATION OF SHUTTLE PROBLEMS COULD POSTPONE FUTURE MISSIONS
description: An investigation began today into the computer failures that delayed the space shuttle Columbia's landing. Officials said they would not clear the shuttles for further flights until the problems were understood and corrected.

title: BRYANT PARK PLAN: HEED THE PUBLIC INTEREST
description: To the Editor:

title: Justin B. Herman Dead at 76; Writer and Producer of Films
description: Justin B. Herman, who produced short subjects for Paramount Pictures and was a writer and cartoonist, died of emphysema Dec. 3 at his home in New Hope, Pa. He was 76 years old.

title: CARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
ENSEMBLE STUDIO MAKES OFF OFF BROADWAY HUM
description: That increasing rarity, a new American play, is running Off Off Broadway at the Ensemble Studio Theater. Michael Brady's ''To Gillian on Her 37th Birthday,'' is sailing along on a wave of critical and popular ap- plause for its director and the cast as well as its author.

title: Dow Declines 1.83; Turnover Increases
description: Stock prices declined yesterday in heavier trading as concern over the direction of interest rates continued to inhibit many investors.

title: ARAFAT, AFTER STRIKE BY ISRAEL, BIDS U.N. GUARD WITHDRAWAL
description: Yasir Arafat appealed to the United Nations today for additional guarantees of security on the sea lanes out of Tripoli after Israeli gunboats backed by helicopters attacked a Palestinian post here early this morning.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Zoo Is Coming Down

title: DEFENSE COULD RULE IN N.C.A.A. SOCCER
description: Goals will not come easily when Columbia and Indiana meet in the 25th championship game of the National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer tournament Saturday night.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bobby Ross , Maryland's football coach, said he had talked to University of Minnesota officials about taking over the football program there but had decided to stay at Maryland. . . . Larry Nance, the Phoenix Suns forward, has signed a new five-and- half-year contract worth an estimated $4.4 million, which club officials said made him the highest-paid player on the team. . . . Joaquin Zendejas, the eldest brother in a family that has produced several top place- kickers, has been signed by New England and will handle the place-kicking chores against the Los Angeles Rams Sunday. . . . Rick Upchurch, bothered by a neck injury, was placed on the injured reserve roster by the Denver Broncos, who replaced the receiver by activating the tight end Riley Odoms . . . . The sentencing of Vida Blue, the former Kansas City Royal pitcher who was convicted of possession of cocaine, a misdemeanor, has been shifted from Dec. 15 to Dec. 19.

title: HIGH RENTS, AN NOT THE LONG YEARS, FORCE A CHELSEA STORE OWNER TO RETIRE
description: Max Draisner has not been much inclined to retire.

title: WISH TO DIE TIED TO BREAKUP
description: A 26-year-old quadriplegic and cerebral palsy victim who wants to be allowed to starve to death is depressed by the breakup of her marriage, a psychiatrist who has not talked to the victim but has examined her medical records testified today.

title: Witness Against a Judge Pleads Guilty to Bribery
description: Joseph Conforte, the key witness in a bribery case against a Federal district judge, pleaded guilty today to bribing a former District Attorney and was sentenced to 18 months in prison.

title: BRIEFING
description: The Hollings Touch

title: CHOCK FULL O' NUTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a loss of $191,000 from discontinued operations. c-Including a gain of $662,000 from real estate transaction, an extraordinary tax credit of $346,000 and a loss of $91,000 from discontinued operations.

title: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 10, 1983 International
description: term relationship that the alliance said could build a peaceful future for the world. In a statement adopted at conclusion of the NATO Foreign Ministers conference in Brussels and officially described as an ''important political signal,'' the alliance members addressed the Soviet Union as a potential partner and said, ''for the benefit of mankind, we advocate an open comprehensive political dialogue, as well as cooperation based on mutual advantage.'' (Page 1, Col. 6.) Signals from the Soviet bloc have raised doubts among Western diplomats in Vienna as to whether the Russians and their Warsaw Pact allies intend to continue the decade-old talks on reducion of conventional arms in Central Europe. One of the indications, the diplomats said, was that the Warsaw Pact side has not accepted a date for resuming the discussions after Christmas. (5:1.)

title: CITY PLANS TO ADD NEW JAIL SPACES FOR 2,200 INMATES
description: New York City will build new jail cells and dormitories for 2,200 prisoners on Rikers Island and in the brig at the Brooklyn Navy Yard at a cost of $154 million, Mayor Koch announced yesterday.

title: Miss Navratilova Wins in Australia
description: Martina Navratilova held off a strong second-set battle by Kathy Jordan to win the Australian Open women's singles tennis title, 6-2, 7-6, today.

title: REAGAN DEFENDS POLICY IN LEBANON
description: President Reagan, in the face of continuing Marine casualties, defended his Lebanon policy today, saying American troops would remain until ''internal stability is established'' and the withdrawal of foreign forces is ''assured.''

title: THE NATION
description: G.O.P. Campaign LicksPresident Reagan took Air Force One out for a campaign-style spin, lighting in Indianapolis and returning for the first time in months to the theme of no-nonsense fundamentals in the classroom.

title: Correction
description: A headline last Sunday on an article about Connecticut finances misstated the amount spent by state agencies above their budgets for this fiscal year. It is $19.5 million.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: First Timers

title: AUTO LEADS A LISTING OF DANGEROUS PRODUCTS
description: The Consumer Federation of America has put the automobile first on its list of 10 most dangerous consumer products.

title: AWARD IS ACCEPTED BY DANUTA WALESA
description: In a glittering and emotional ceremony here, Danuta Walesa accepted the 1983 Nobel Peace Prize today on behalf of her husband, Lech.

title: CHINESE SPOT PROVIDES A BALANCE
description: FOR years restaurants offering Chinese cuisine have attempted to establish themselves in the spot on Lover Central Avenue where the Route 100 overopass approaches Tuckahoe Road, First Wok, the latest occupant, appears to have succeeded where otheris have failed. Run by the management responsible for Human Wok - the avenue's northernmost spot for this cuiesine - First Wok completes the symmetry by marking the southern end of the strip.

title: SWEETENING THE POT WITH JUNIOR STOCK
description: One way that companies sweeten the employee benefits package - giving ''junior stock'' to their most productive managers - is a new twist in executive compensation that some experts herald as an up-and-coming technique of the 80's.

title: LEBANON REKINDLES U.S. FOREIGN POLICY TROUBLES
description: On the surface, much of political Washington reacted numbly at first to the latest spasm of violence in Lebanon. Perhaps the loss of eight more Marines, the first combat death of a Navy flier and Syria's capture of a second flier could not match the horror of the bombing of the Marine compound six weeks ago, but last week marked a new watershed, robbing President Reagan of the foreign policy momentum he had gained after the invasion of Grenada. He was again on the defensive, braced for trouble when Congress returns in January.

title: ; THE DEFICIT
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: ACOMPUTERIZED information system supported by advertising will be introduced in the spring by the state's Division of Travel and Tourism at 12 New Jersey sites still to be determined. Department officials are heralding the new system as a way to solve the problem of raising funds to support the tourist industry without having to ask the state for additional revenue every year. Victoria Schmidt , director of the division, said that the sites would be called Welcome Centers after the computers were added. ''I see Welcome Centers as the foyers to a home,'' she said, ''and we have neglected our Welcome Centers in the past.''

title: Katherine Autera To Marry in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. Michael E. Autera of Ridgewood, N.J., and Southampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katherine T. Autera, to Leonard J. Jardine, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard C. Jardine of Providence, R.I.

title: D. L. Maruska to Wed Miss Reid in February
description: The Rev. and Mrs. Roddey Reid of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Ann Reid, to Donald Lee Maruska, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Maruska of Des Plaines, Ill. A February wedding is planned.

title: HEADLINERS La TechniqueIn a confluence of two celebrated strands of French culture, cuisine and tax evasion,
description: Raymond Barrier , an internationally known chef, was sentenced last week to six months in prison.

title: DE-AMERICANIZE EUROPEAN DEFENSE
description: Imagine that instead of American nuclear missiles, similar weapons belonging to an integrated Western European defense force were about to be installed in Western Europe. Imagine, too, that the Europeans paid the full cost of these missiles. And, finally, imagine that there were no American military bases or troops in Western Europe, so that any peace demonstrations would be taking place at European rather than American installations.

title: STATE ACTION ADDS $2 MILLION EXPENSE TO COUNTY BUDGET
description: WHITE PLAINS ON the day the county's Committee on Budget and Appropriations was voting to restore nearly $700,000 to the 1984 County Budget, an unexpected expenditure, estimated at $2 million, was also being added to the budget by state officials in Albany.

title: A FAMILY IS REBORN IN THE CITY
description: CHRISTMAS was bleak for Jesus O. last year. He and his wife Sylvia and their son Jesus Jr. had just come to New York from Puerto Rico to seek better medical treatment for the paralysis that had left Mr. O. almost helpless for 12 years.

title: THE EMPLOYEE AS SUBSIDIARY
description: Employee benefits do not always take the form of ordinary corporate perks. Some of the most lucrative ones can come in the form of company mergers, buyouts and spinoffs.

title: HOSPITALS WORRIED BY SHORTER STAYS
description: THE time the average patient spends in Connecticut's general hospitals has declined so rapidly in the past year that many have had to close floors or lay off employees. The Connecticut Hospital Association is trying to determine whether these shortened stays are part of a long-term trend.

title: RULES ON DONATING EASEMENTS
description: OWNERS of properties of ecological or historical significance are often eligible for substantial tax savings if they donate an easement to a recognized preservation or conservation group.

title: Jersey Senior Takes Girls' Cross-Country
description: Janet Smith, a senior at John P. Stevens High School in Edison, N.J., was timed in 16 minutes 43.7 seconds for 5,000 meters today and won the girls' race at the fifth Kinney national high school cross-country championships in Balboa Park.

title:
GARDENING;
EVOLUTION OF THE MODERN POINSETTA
description: WERE Don Hernando Ruiz to see the poinsettia that we now use at Christmas, he would hardly recognize it. As one of a group of Franciscan priests who settled in Taxco, Mexico, in the 17th century, he was the first to report this flower and its use in the Fiesta of Santa Pesebre, a nativity procession.

title: Eight Killed as a Fire Sweeps Through House in Baltimore
description: Eight people, including a two-week-old girl and a pregnant teen-ager, killed in a fire Friday that began in a living room and roared through the roof of a row house.

title: WELLS FARGO THEFT, 3 MONTHS LATER: ONLY TANTALIZING LEADS TO $7 MILLION
description: When Victor Gerena drove to work at the Wells Fargo depot here Sept. 12, no one was surprised when he parked his car inside the company garage instead of in the parking lot outside. There had been problems with thefts in the parking lot.

title: Historical Film Secure
description: To the Editor:

title: MIDDLE CLASS SHRINKS AS POVERTY ENGULFS MORE FAMILIES, TWO STUDIES SAY
description: Two new studies report the distribution of income in the United States has become more unequal and that the middle class has shrunk as many families have sunk into poverty or near poverty in the last few years.

title: MAJOR NEWS IN SUMMARY
description: Tense Ending toA Space Story

title: REAGAN MAY SEEK MORE REDUCTIONS IN NONARMS FUNDS
description: Administration officials say they expect President Reagan's new budget to include a cut of about $8 billion in nonmilitary domestic spending, plus reductions of about $4 billion in Medicare and other benefit programs.

title: ARGENTINE LEADER SWORN INTO OFFICE, ENDING ARMY RULE
description: Raul Ricardo Alfonsin was inaugurated President of Argentina today amid joyous celebrations that ended nearly eight years of military rule.

title: ; WHEN MORAL OBLIGATION CONFLICTS WITH THE LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: HIGH SCHOOL COMPUTER CALLS HOMES TO CUT DOWN TRUANCY
description: At West Hill High School, the truant officer is kept in a box.

title: A Correction
description: On the Opinion Page of Nov. 27, type was inadvertently transposed in an article by Dean Gallo, Republican of Parisippany and the Assembly minority leader. The first four paragraphs should have read as follows:

title: 'CARMEN' IS THEATER PURE AND SIMPLE
description: Why are music critics attacking Peter Brook for vandalizing Bizet's ''Carmen'' when not one voice was raised against the violation of George Bernard Shaw's masterpiece ''Pygmalion''? In the musical version, ''My Fair Lady,'' the doltish Freddy becomes a wistful cavalier with his song, ''On the Street Where You Live.'' Professor Higgins wonders, ''Why Can't a Woman Be More Like a Man?,'' although Shaw believed the world would be better off if men were more like women.

title:
CAMERA;
GETTING A YOUNGSTER INTERESTED IN PHOTOGRAPHY
description: Lou Jacobs Jr. is the author of several books on photography.

title: GERMANS FILL CITY THEATERS FOR WAR FILM
description: West Germans have been crowding into movie theaters around the country to see ''The Day After,'' the United States made-for-television movie about a nuclear war.

title: A BUSINESSMAN TURNS TO THEATER
description: FOR William Edgerton, the path to theatrical producing appeared to be an inevitable step in his career as an entrepreneur and patron of the arts.

title: Moslem Nations Assail U.S. Over Air Strikes
description: A conference of foreign ministers of Moslem nations moved toward a close here today with a condemnation of the United States for its attacks on Syrian forces and its new strategic cooperation pact with Israel.

title: CELTICS MINUS BIRD, BUT DOWN HAWKS
description: Robert Parish scored 24 points and had 15 rebounds as the Boston Celtics, playing without their star forward, Larry Bird, defeated the Atlanta Hawks, 104-87, tonight.

title: A Day for Riley
description: He hasn't announced his retirement yet, but after 15 years as a top defensive back, Ken Riley of the Cincinnati Bengals is expected to close out his career after this season. That's why the Bengals have designated today as ''Ken Riley Day'' at Riverfront Stadium and scheduled appropriate halftime ceremonies at the game with the Detroit Lions.

title: TALKS SEEK TO AID HOMELESS YOUTHS
description: Representatives from 28 countries gathered here last week to share their experiences in caring for homeless youths and to begin developing ways to ease the complex problems these youths face.

title: COIN BEARING LIKENESS OF NEFERTITI OF EGYPT IS MINTED IN U.S.
description: Nefertiti, who was Queen of Egypt in the 14th century B.C., has returned to public prominence in this Philadelphia suburb. A private mint struck a new Egyptian gold coin bearing her likeness.

title: CHAIN OF COMMAND: LACK OF GUIDANCE FOR OFFICERS IN BEIRUT
description: In the days immediately after the bombing, the man most identified with the Marine mission in Beirut was the Commandant of the Marine Corps, Gen. Paul X. Kelley. Dispatched by President Reagan to visit the scene, General Kelley reviewed security, visited victims at hospitals and testified before Congress.

title: HELPING THE DISABLED
description: Among the standard one- and two-bedroom townhouses in Glen River, a condominium community now under construction on River Road in Wilton, Conn., are units designed to suit the needs of handicapped occupants.

title: CENTRAL AMERICANS WITH NOTHING IN COMMON
description: To the Editor:

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: WEEK OF THE ARTS

title: HOME DESIGNED
description: GRAND SECLUSION Above: This octagonal log cabin was built out of white cedar and has a spiral wood deck that lifts it off the ground and protects it from heavy snowfalls. Below: The picture windows are facing one of the oldest mountain chains in the country. Right: A mud room acts as the formal entrance. Two skylights - one an octagonal cupola and the other, a nautical hatch, in the bathroom - form a straight line down the middle of the cabin, letting light focus directly into both rooms. CAPTIONS, SECOND SPREAD Left: The interior of the bathroom features log walls and an oversize Italian bathtub. The skylight works like the hatch on a boat, rotating 360 degrees to control the ventilation. Top: A series of picture windows on three walls face south and west, allowing light to heat the main room and opening up the cabin to the landscape. Right: The bedroom area is located on the north side of the cabin. The architect placed the bed in the darkest spot, along the north wall. A blue stained- glass window above the bed is made from two Gothic arches found in an old church in Bethlehem, Pa.

title: Lakers Eyeing Richardson
description: The Los Angeles

title: N. Dakota St. Takes Title in Division II
description: North Dakota State defeated Central State of Ohio, 41-21, today in the Palm Bowl for the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division II football championship.

title: WomanKilledbyStrayBullet
description: A 61-year-old Bronx woman was fatally wounded yesterday when a bullet fired by one of two young gunmen struck her instead of their intended victim, the police said. The woman, Millicent Cohen of 838 Metcalf Avenue, was walking past a building at 831 Soundview Avenue at 6:38 P.M. when the gunmen began to fire at Doland Simmons, 21, of 1460 Bronx River Avenue, the police said. She was shot in the neck and was pronounced dead on arrival at the Bronx Municipal Hospital Center. Mr. Simmons, who was shot in the left ear, was listed in serious condition at the hospital.

title: HONDURANS DISAPPOINTED BY LEVEL OF U.S. AID
description: Government and military officials here say they are increasingly disappointed with the joint military maneuvers with the United States, which they had hoped would be accompanied by new economic aid or guarantees of military security.

title: AMERICA'S CHANGING UNIONS
description: WORKING CLASS HERO

title: FIGHTING PHONE SOLICITORS
description: ''HELLO, is this Ellen Greenberg?'' ''Yes, it is.'' ''Hello, Ellen. My name is Bingly Boop. How are you, Ellen?''

title: The Harley-Davidson Wins
description: The California Highway Patrol is preparing to switch back to the American-made Harley-Davidson from the Japanese Kawasaki.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: CUSTOMERS of Northeast Utilities will soon be able to buy plans for six homes that use solar energy. The plans, which builders said would normally cost $300 to $1,000, will be available for $25.

title: Correction
description: An article on page 25 of the Arts and Leisure section today about the countertenor Paul Esswood gives an incorrect location for Musica Sacra's performances of Handel's ''Messiah'' tomorrow and Wednesday. They will be given at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Memphis State Beaten
description: Kelvin Hildreth sank two free throws with 12 seconds remaining to assure Mississippi State of a 50-49 upset of Memphis State tonight.

title: NEW PANEL SIFTS OLD QUESTIONS ON SHOREHAM
description: HAUPPAUGE WHAT if the bus drivers make the evacuation impossible by refusing to drive their vehicles toward the nuclear plant while an accident is in progress? What if the police leave their posts to make sure their own families are safe? What if panicked automobile drivers cause accidents, and traffic on the antiquated road system grinds to a halt? And why should a county government have to accept an unpopular reactor that it never asked to have built?

title: THE STONY BROOK TRIO AND THOMAS GALLANT ARE AMONG RECITALISTS
description: Judging just from the performance of Beethoven's Trio in G (Op. 1, No. 2), the Stony Brook Trio, which gave its debut in Carnegie Recital Hall last Sunday night, could turn out to be an exceptional young chamber group. The players - Dawn Harms, violin; David Bakamjian, cello; Gwendolyn Mok, piano - treated the music with energy and intelligence. The work's Haydnesque grace was spiced with a sinewy, dramatic imagination.

title: Block Modeling
description: To the Editor:

title: PROSPECTS
description: Consumer Celebration

title: N.Y.U. IS OFFERING CATALAN STUDIES
description: The Catalan culture, for centuries unfamiliar to those beyond its Spanish borders, is receiving new scholarly attention with the introduction this fall of a Catalan studies program at New York University.

title: HOLIDAY MUSIC TO RESOUND
description: IF there's one thing music lovers

title: FOR MADISON PANACHE, IT'S SPACE AT ANY PRICE
description: ''WE are relocating,'' says a sign in the window of 859 Madison Avenue, at 71st Street, the former shop of Elgot appliance dealers. ''We have moved to 33 East 68th Street,'' says the sign in the window at Wallis Mayers Needlework at 780. ''Come see our beautiful new store.''

title: MEDICINE, FALSE AND TRUE Aides for AIDS
description: ''When persons with AIDS come to us, their lives are shattered and their heads twisted,'' says Rodger McFarlane. ''They've usually been fired from their jobs and kicked out of their apartments.

title: Fine for Fighting Clinic
description: Joe Crozier, the coach of the Rochester Americans of the American Hockey League, raised a few eyebrows recently when he used a local television show to conduct a 90-second instructional clinic on fighting for hockey players.

title: POLO ON THE CHEAP-RELATIVELY
description: POLO is a game for the true sportsman: It is expensive, there is no prize money and little glory. Yet its lure lingers, and arena polo - a less costly version played on a walled field, often indoors - is helping to increase its popularity.

title: FRAYNAND FARCE GO HAND IN HAND
description: LONDON

title: FACT AND LEGEND CLASH IN 'SILKWOOD'
description: One night while driving to a rendezvous with a reporter, Karen Silkwood veered off a lonely stretch of Oklahoma highway and hit a concrete culvert at a speed of about 45 miles per hour. She was 28 years old. Her death in 1974 - as subsequently told in books, articles, plays and now a major motion picture - is a tale of nuclear martyrdom in which her employer is key suspect. Miss Silkwood allegedly had documents, never found, that would have embarrassed her employer, the Kerr- McGee Corporation, a rich, powerful energy-based conglomerate that ran a factory, since closed, near Crescent, Okla., for fabricating nuclear fuel out of plutonium, one of the world's most deadly poisons. In ''Silkwood,'' opening Wednesday at Loews Tower East, the National and local theaters, Meryl Streep plays a redneck turned union activist who swears a lot, sleeps around, and pops pills in the course of her quest to expose Kerr-McGee. The dramatic effectiveness of ''Silkwood'' as a film will have to be left to the critics to judge; as a depiction of a scientific subject, however, it can be faulted.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
FORMER SOVIET ARTIST DESIGNSWALESA MEDAL
description: The worldwide impact of Poland's Solidarity movement was dramatized by the selection of its founder, Lech Walesa, to receive this year's Nobel Peace Prize. Its potential impact on Soviet society can now be glimpsed in a smaller but nonetheless highly significant tribute of a different kind - a new medal honoring Solidarity and Mr. Walesa, and celebrating the role they played in leading a young Russian artist to his freedom.

description: New Yorkers who keep the cellophane on their lamp shades and encase their couches in plastic will weep with frustration once they see the R-62, the city's new subway car. If only, they'll be saying to themselves, we can keep it that way.

description: HARRISON THERE is a new way to teach foreign languages at the secondary-school level that is spreading across the country, and a program recently adopted by Harrison High School puts its school district in the forefront of the trend.

description: Unusual sounds of harmony are coming these days from this permanent Atlantic alliance sounding board where American and European dissonance often prevails. The question is how long the situation will last.

title: CALENDAR SETS OFF DISPUTE AT RUTGERS
description: NEW BRUNSWICK ACONTROVERSY has arisen at the Rutgers University campus here over a poster calendar - ''The Women of Rutgers'' - that has nine provocative photographs of 10 students.

title: GIRL AND 2 BROTHERS GIVEN HOPE FOR THE FUTURE
description: ANNA C.'s father had high hopes when he left his home in East Asia to make a new life in the United States. He came with a dream that has motivated many immigrants, a dream of personal success and material well-being.

title: Onions
description: To the Editor: I read with great inter

title: Soviet Replaces Top Official In Machine Building Ministry
description: Viktor V. Krotov has been replaced as Minister of Power Machine Building by his 46- year-old first deputy, Radio Moscow reported today.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: NO PLACE TO HIDE 1946/1984. By David Bradley. (University Press of New England, $8.95.) When Dr. David Bradley was in his early 30's, he was assigned to be a ''radiological monitor'' at the Bikini atomic bomb tests in 1946. ''No Place to Hide'' is the ''singularly well-written diary of his observations'' and our reviewer, William L. Laurence, declared in 1948 that ''it will take its place as an outstanding human document of our times, the firsthand reaction of a sensitive, talented individual, who knows what the score is, to the most terrifying event in man's history.'' Reissued with a new epilogue and a foreword by Jerome B. Wiesner, the book is also available in hard-cover, at $18.

title: DATA ON ADOPTIONS GIVEN OUT BY NEW YORK STATE REGISTRY
description: New York State's adoption registry, where adopted children and their natural parents can learn about each other, went into business on Tuesday.

title: UNIONS MAY WAIT TO MAKE UP FOR LOST TIME
description: One of the more popular buttons worn by delegates to the United Auto Workers Union convention earlier this year read ''Restore Plus More in '84.'' The auto workers had made wage and benefit concessions totaling more than $4 billion to the financially hard pressed automobile companies during the 1979-through- 1982 slump in car sales.

title: John Henry Is Seeking $4 Million Mark Today
description: John Henry, by finishing among the top four in the $500,000 Hollywood Turf Cup Sunday at Hollywood Park, can become the first thoroughbred to earn $4 million.

title: THEATER: 'FISHERMAN'
description: In ''A Song for a Nisei Fisherman,'' Philip Kan Gotanda, a third-generation American of Japanese descent, reflects on the sorrowful life of a Japanese-American of the second generation. As one might expect, that life is shadowed by the experience of being confined in a relocation camp during World War II. One difference between this play and a number of others on the subject that have been presented by the Pan Asian Repertory Theater is that Mr. Gotanda is trying to act more as a poet than as a polemicist.

title: Hormone to Be Tested Against Nerve Disease
description: A hormone that doctors believe may be the first treatment for Lou Gehrig's disease will be tested in a major study at the New England Medical Center, the hospital says.

title: AT AGE 70, TEACHER STILL LIKES CHALLENGE
description: PHILLIPS STEVENS, who lives just off Cornfield Point in Old Saybrook, ordinarily would be living the year round in the tiny Caribbean island of Grenada.

title: THE REGION
description: Divvying UpThe SurplusFrom M.A.C.Prosperity may be just around the corner for New York City, thanks in part to the Municipal Assistance Corporation's anticipated $1 billion surplus, but it has been hard for city and state officials to negotiate the turn. After sharp debate on how to share the spoils, the principal figures - Mayor Koch, Governor Cuomo and Felix G. Rohatyn, the M.A.C. chairman - last week outlined an agreement.

title: No Headline
description: Barbara Lyne Is Married

title: LARCHMONT SAILOR PURSUES OLYMPIC GOAL
description: COMING from a family of sailors and swimmers, it seems like the most natural thing in the world to Peter Quigley of Larchmont to have become a sailor also. Mr. Quigley, 21 years old and a student at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, is taking off what would have been his senior year, to prepare for the Olympic trials. He hopes to represent the United States in the Finn Class competition and spends every day of his leave of absence working toward that goal.

title: ARTS COUNCIL READIES NEW GRANTS ROLE
description: WHEN county residents were surveyed last year about their cultural preferences, they responded that they wanted ''more'' local art and entertainment and ''better quality.'' Now, with an unusual offer from the National Endowment for the Arts in Washington, it may be possible to see if those needs can be filled.

title: Court Upholds Denial Of Tribe's Claim to Gold
description: A Federal appeals court Friday upheld a lower court's rejection of the Oglala Sioux tribe's claim to the Homestake Mine, the largest gold mine in the Northern Hemisphere.

title: SINCERELY YOURS
description: -century paintings gathered around the theme ''Madame in Her Boudoir.'' An oft-repeated scene in the paintings revealed lovely, languid ladies, dressed in flowered gowns, who sat before their desks, pen in hand, in the act of writing.

title: STAGE: MICHEL TREMBLAY'S 'DAMNEE MANON, SACREE SANDRA'
description: The French Canadian playwright Michel Tremblay frequently writes about crosscurrents of the sacred and the sacrilegious. In ''Damnee Manon, Sacree Sandra,'' as translated by John Van Burek, he takes this concern to the point of obsession. Two people, each an outcast from so- called normal society, deliver alternating and occasionally concurrent monologues. Manon (Priscilla Smith) looks prim and nunlike. Sandra (Ray Wise) is a flamboyant tranvestite, as addicted to sex as Manon is to religion. Manon's fervor eventually becomes orgiastic. Sandra's lustfulness has a rhapsodic spirituality. In other words, each employs the signs and symbols of the other's ''religion.''

title: Gretzky Ties Point Record
description: Wayne

title: THE INCREASING COSTS OF NUCLEAR POWER
description: A study of electric generating stations around the world has found that costs have risen so high that, in nearly all countries, a coal-fired plant begun today would be cheaper to build than a nuclear reactor.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: RENEWAL PROJECTS AIDED BY CITIBANK
description: With all the glittery holiday ornaments strung from the telephone lines along Myrtle Avenue in Queens, the cedar benches and inlaid red brick on the sidewalks have attracted little attention from the crowds of shoppers in the neighborhood.

THE LIVELY ARTS;
30 YOUNG ARTISTS GET A CHANCE
description: ''WE don't do paintings to put in the closet. We want our work to be seen.''

description: Who's Cuckoo?

description: ATLANTIC CITY LIKE a bantamweight in the ring with a couple of heavyweights, the Atlantic Electric Company has relied on fast footwork to survive.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Jose Higueras of Spain, Andres Gomez of Ecuador and Jose-Luis Clerc of Argentina have joined six other top tennis players in the field for the $400,000 Volvo Masters championships at Madison Square Garden next month. . . . Tom Harmon, the 1940 Heisman Trophy winner who played two seasons with the Los Angeles Rams before becoming a sports broadcaster, has been named the Walter Camp Football Foundation's ''Distinguished American of the Year.'' In announcing the award the foundation cited Harmon for efforts to curb drug use by athletes. . . . Darrin Nelson and Tony Galbreath will be the starting running backs for the Minnesota Vikings in today's game against the Chicago Bears, but Ted Brown, who had been suspended and then reinstated after missing therapy sessions for a separated shoulder, will also get to play, the club said. . . . Wally English, Tulane's first-year coach, has been given a new contract, according to the school, which disclosed no terms of the pact. . . . Dan Ford, the Baltimore Orioles free agent outfielder, has been offered a three-year contract by the Cleveland Indians.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Kasimir Malevich (1878-1935), the avant-garde Russian painter, did a wonderful series of Cubist costumes for the short but sprightly Futurist opera ''Victory Over the Sun,'' which played a full two performances at the Luna Park Theater in St. Petersburg in 1913. The work was performed again in 1980 at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, and this year in Berlin, Amsterdam and - last month - Brooklyn, as part of the Academy of Music's ''Next Wave Festival.''

title: JERSEY URGED TO ALTER RULES TO MEET LOW-COST HOUSING NEED
description: A Rutgers University study, which shows that municipalities will have to provide about 300,000 housing units for low- and moderate-income families by the turn of the century, suggests a combination of regulatory changes to meet the need.

title: ARSON DOMINATING LIFE AT U. OF MASSACHUSETTS
description: As physical events, the fires have been minuscule: a few pieces of crumpled paper, a scorched carpet, a seared desktop, a length of toilet tissue turned to ashes, some notices burned off bulletin boards.

title: CANADIAN ART MAY BE IN THE EYE OF THE BEHOLDER
description: TORONTO

title: IF ANYTHING, GENDER GAP IS BECOMING EVEN WIDER
description: While other leading political indicators, such as rising approval ratings for the President and squabbling among Democrats, presumably make cheerful reading at the White House, Mr. Reagan's problem with women keeps getting worse.

title: NEW TURKISH PREMIER FACES ECONOMIC CRISIS
description: The sharp rise in the cost of living and the low salaries of the great majority of Turks constitutes the number one problem facing Turkey's new civilian Prime Minister, Turgut Ozal and his Government after more than three years of strict military rule. Ayse, for example, is one of the best students in third-year medical school at Ankara University, but says she is afraid she will have to quit and get a job to help support the family.

description: DONALD F. McCORMICK, chairman and chief executive officer of the Howard Savings Bank, wonders what the institution's founding fathers might think of the changes wrought by deregulation and modern technology.

description: Kathryn Jane Matschullat, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wayne E. Matschullat of Edina, Minn., and Naples, Fla., and Allan Jeffrey Arffa, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley H. Arffa of Woodbridge, Conn., were married at the Players Club in New York yesterday. Rabbi Roy Rosenberg and the Rev. William Starr, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: NEW BACTERIA SAID TO KILL NAGGING BLACK FLIES
description: Black flies - the swarming, biting enemies of tourists in the Adirondack Mountains - can be controlled by a bacteria that is deadly to them and mosquitoes but harmless to other living things, a state researcher said this week.

title: MET OPERA CONTRACT MAY HAVE LONG-TERM EFFECT
description: The Metropolitan Opera's new contract with its orchestra players - an agreement notable for the size of its pension plan and for its early and peaceful settlement - apparently will not work immediate changes in other orchestra contracts nationwide. But players and orchestra managers around the country foresee possible long-term effects.

title: DRUG COMPANY TO CLEAN UP POLLUTED LANDFILL
description: Officials of Sterling Drug Inc. have agreed to begin clean-up work at a contaminated landfill at their plant here, according to the state's Department of Environmental Conservation.

title: MAJOR NEWS IN SUMMARY Common MarketHits an Impasse
description: Western Europe's dreams of economic togetherness grew noticeably dimmer last week. In three days of stormy meetings in Athens, leaders of the European Economic Community's 10 member countries couldn't reconcile their corrosive differences or even pretend they had.

title: Air Force Wins, 9-3, From Ole Miss in Bowl
description: Marty Louthan, the Air Force Academy quarterback, directed a ball-control wishbone offense in the rain to set up three field goals by Sean Pavlich as the Falcons defeated Mississippi, 9-3, in the Independence Bowl tonight.

title: WHEN BATTERED WIVES KILL, DOES THE LAW TREAT THEM FAIRLY?
description: Leslie Emick never claimed that when she fired five shots into Marshall Allison, the father of her two children, it was in the heat of passion. The shooting last February, she said, was a case of self-defense. ''I still believe that if I hadn't shot him that day I'd be the one who was dead,'' Miss Emick told an Allegany County, N. Y., jury, after recounting how Mr. Allison had repeatedly tortured and threatened to kill her.

description: Margaret Croyden is a frequent contributor to Arts and Leisure.

description: The school board has suspended a teacher for following her religion in wearing a turban to work.

title: A SPECIAL MEAL FOR NEW PARENTS
description: THERE were flowers and cloth napkins, wine and candlelight. The broiled steak was declared ''delicious.'' Two of the diners, however, wore robes and slippers. And outside the ''restaurant'' door, newborn babies squalled and a very expectant mother was being rolled by on a wheeled stretcher.

description: Jerry McMillan sank a pair of free throws with 22 seconds remaining tonight to lift DePaul to a 63-61 upset of Georgetown.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: TENAFLY
description: AT a time when many New Jersey municipalities are stretching their zoning regulations to attract high-density housing and commercial developments to their empty land, residents of Tenafly can still enjoy a hike through quiet woods or a picnic in a local park or even plant flowers in a community garden.

title: EXPERTS LIST WAYS TO AVERT ATTACKS
description: Testifying before Congress last month, the Marine Commandant, Gen. Paul X. Kelley, said ''it would require a massive concrete wall to stop'' the Mercedes truck used in the terrorist attack Oct. 23 on the Marine headquarters in Beirut.

title: FILM MAKER BLENDS BAY AND BALLET
description: WHEN Anne Belle received the first ''Distinguished Suffolk County Film Maker Award'' in August, the timing could not have been better. Her recently completed 52-minute feature, ''Reflections of a Dancer,'' had just completed a year of acclaimed national screenings, including a nine-week showing at Joseph Papp's Public Theater in New York and a double bill with Herbert Ross's ''The Turning Point'' in San Francisco.

title: A TALE OF HEROIC ANONYMITY
description: LIFE & TIMES OF MICHAEL K By J. M. Coetzee. 184 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $13.95.

title: Amy Lee Nathan To Wed April 21
description: Mr. and Mrs. R. David Nathan of South Orange, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Lee Nathan, to Howard David Fineman, son of Jean L. Fineman and the late Charles Morton Fineman of Pittsburgh. The wedding is scheduled for April 21.

title: INDONESIA SETTLES ON STATE U. TO TRAIN ITS SCHOOLTEACHERS
description: The Government of Indonesia has chosen the State University of New York to conduct a four-year training program for its schoolteachers, according to State University officials.

title: A GOOD SELECTION OF VEAL DISHES
description: WITH Christmas just two weeks away, Santa has given us an early present: the discovery of a new, good Northern Italian restaurant. And as an extra bonus, Il Villano is in Fairfield County, a part of the state where Northern Italian restaurants have been in short supply.

title: AS DEADLINE NEARS, STATE ACTS ON HAZARDOUS-WASTE DUMPS
description: New York State officials took legal action across the state this week to insure that anyone who had illegally disposed of hazardous wastes answered for it.

title: IONA WINS TOURNEY AS SPRINGER STARS
description: Iona gave up its initial defensive plans tonight because it fell behind, 17-8, using the press. Then the Gaels turned everything around in a hurry and easily defeated Illinois-Chicago, 86-65, in the final of the sixth annual Manufacturers Hanover Classic.
