title: STATE BETS ON MORE GAMBLING REVENUE
description: CONNECTICUT, which draws 5 percent of its revenue from legalized gambling, is seeking to bolster that income.

title: EXCERPTS FROM LECH WALSEA'S NOBEL SPEECH
description: Following is the text of the speech by Lech Walesa delivered here today by his wife, Danuta, who accepted the Nobel Peace Prize for her husband. The speech was translated by the Norwegian Foreign Ministry from the Polish.

title: A LEGAL MIRE OVER POLLUTION ON PUBLIC LANDS
description: In 1942, with the United States newly drawn into World War II, the Army opened the Rocky Mountain Arsenal a few miles northeast of downtown Denver. It began producing, among other things, chemical nerve gas, poisonous phosgene gas, mustard gas and white phosphorous fire bombs.

title:
GARDENING;
EVOLUTION OF THE MODERN POINSETTA
description: WERE Don Hernando Ruiz to see the poinsettia that we now use at Christmas, he would hardly recognize it. As one of a group of Franciscan priests who settled in Taxco, Mexico, in the 17th century, he was the first to report this flower and its use in the Fiesta of Santa Pesebre, a nativity procession.

title: Asparagus
description: To the Editor: Having been in Ger

title: SHULTZ UNDER ATTACK BY ARABS, STRONGLY DEFENDS PACT WITH ISRAEL
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz heard strong criticism today from Arab leaders about strengthened American ties with Israel and responded bluntly in defense of the policy, which he said was not aimed against Arab interests.

title: FAIR HOUSING LAW IS APPLIED IN A SEXUAL HARASSMENT CASE
description: A young couple who said they and their son were evicted from their apartment because the wife refused to pose nude for the landlord or to have sexual intercourse with him have been ruled victims of sexual harassment and are eligible for damages under Title VIII of the Fair Housing Act.

title: Brown Votes Down R.O.T.C.
description: Brown University faculty members have voted down a plan to renew the Naval Reserve Officers Training Corps program that was ended in the antiwar period of the late 1960's.

title: Long Distance
description: To the Editor:

title: TEXAS USING A NEW FORMULA TO GUIDE ITS PRISON RELEASES
description: Parole officials in Texas are using a formula developed by a South American graduate student to try to determine if a convict will remain law-abiding after being freed on parole.

title: SPENDING FUNDS IS A TEAM DECISION
description: THE decision by the state to allow others to help decide how Federal money for social programs should be spent seems to be working out well, say those involved.

title: GIRLS GET A MIXED MESSAGE
description: -IMPROVING times for female runners suggest that, one day, perhaps sooner than we think, the gender gap in sports will close. Joan Benoit's time in this year's Boston Marathon would have won that marathon outright as recently as 1956. Cheryl Miller's ability to dunk a basketball also suggests that women will continue to perform feats previously thought impossible.

title: Ling-Ling the Panda Termed '100% Better'
description: Ling-Ling, the giant panda suffering a potentially fatal kidney ailment here, was reported ''100 percent better'' today, although her recovery uncertain.

title: BRADSHAW'S ARM GIVES STEELERS A LIFT
description: He had not played in a game, against tackling, in 11 months. He had only three days of serious practice this week. His surgically repaired right arm hurt and his passes did not have the old zip. But when Terry Bradshaw left the game at Shea Stadium yesterday, his team, the Pittsburgh Steelers, was ahead, 14-0, and the Jets were headed for defeat. As Bradshaw's coach, Chuck Noll, said, ''He reached down from his experience.''

title: No Headline
description: Susan Byrne to Wed

title: Rutledge Will Start
description: Coach Bill Parcells

title: Judge Dismisses Suit Against a Capital Club
description: A lawsuit to strip an all-male Bethesda golf club of its property tax exemption has been dismissed by a Montgomery County Circuit Court judge.

title: THE NATION
description: UnwelcomeEconomic Advice

title: DEVILS ARE TROUNCED BY THE FLYERS, 8-2
description: The Devils swerved off their new course tonight, but they are no longer panic-stricken by a debilitating string of defeats. They were able to consider tonight's 8-2 loss to the Philadelphia Flyers at Byrne Meadowlands Arena philosophically, even routinely.

title: A SWIM TEAM'S RISE TO PROMINENCE
description: FIVE years ago, John Collins stood before a group of about 40 teen-agers with broad shoulders and bleached blond hair and told them that they would become a competitive swimming power of great distinction.

title: ANOTHER SURPRISE: A BOOM IN JOBS
description: -readers have looked at the economy and found that either their expectations or their meters are out of whack. This causes some discomfort for the experts who examine the economy, make predictions about it and try to make policies based upon the predictions. ''You just don't know where you are,'' said an associate commissioner in the Bureau of Labor Statistics, Thomas J. Plewes. Nevertheless, the statistics suggest little that would poison the spirit of the plastic, tabletop Christmas trees that adorn some of the offices off the resonant stone corridors of Mr. Plewes's agency. If the meters have erred, they have erred at the outer limits of President Reagan's considerable optimism.

title: CRIME
description: John Sherwood's DEATH AT THE BBC (Scribner's, $12.95) takes us behind the doors of the famous British studios. But this concerns the British Broadcasting Corporation as it was, not as it is. The year is 1937, Sir John Reith runs the BBC with an iron hand, and the class system is very much in operation. In addition, Victorian morality prevails. It is all right, for instance, for a man to have a quiet affair or two on the side. But a divorce? Never! That would mean a public scandal and hence resignation from the BBC. Sir John would see to that.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN NEW ORLEANS
description: Contrary to rumor New Orleans is not becoming another Houston, but there are signs around town that the city famous for languor has discovered the work ethic. Construction crews have virtually taken over the downtown section; traffic jams abound; a building boom is moving toward the Mississippi riverfront, the historic warehouse district and the French Quarter. There is a rush to complete large hotels because New Orleans is getting ready for the 1984 Louisiana World Exposition (scheduled to begin May 12) with the kind of energy usually reserved for digging into a platter of boiled crabs.

title: Beyond the Deficit
description: President Reagan has been slow to admit that big deficits are dangerous because he would prefer no one to notice he's spilled a record amount of red ink. But with Democrats plotting to turn this very Republican issue against him, he's got to be thinking of good ways to change the subject. There's a way to hold both parties equally responsible.

title: THE HEAT'S ON THE CITY TO BURN ITS TRASH
description: New Yorkers throw away 8.5 million tons of trash a year, enough to cover every street in Manhattan with 11 inches of garbage. Skeptics say the streets are precisely where it all goes, but in fact the city collects most trash and takes it to landfills. Because these soon will be filled to capacity, officials want to begin burning what they will be unable to bury. Deciding how and where has become a problem that they cannot seem to dispose of.

title: LEGISLATURE NEARING THE END OF ITS SESSION
description: TRENTON AS THE State Legislature nears the end of another two-year session, it has seen more than 620 of its passed bills signed into law by Governor Kean. The number could reach more than 700 by the time the session ends on Jan. 10 and Mr. Kean has put down his pen.

title: DESIGNING A BENEFITS PACKAGE
description: When she filled in her 1983 benefits ballot, Helen Weidenmiller, a copyright administrator with the Educational Testing Service (E.T.S.) in Princeton, N.J., elected to pick from a number of optional benefits: She chose dental insurance, life insurance for her husband, additional life insurance for herself, accidental death coverage, supplemental retirement benefits and an annual physical.

title: KATHERINE DILLON WED TO EDUCATOR
description: At St. Joseph's Roman Catholic church in Providence, R.I., yesterday Katharine Mary Dillon, who teaches history at the Wheeler School in Providence, was married to Peter Hugh Hufstader, assistant headmaster of Wheeler. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Anselm Hufstader, headmaster of the Portsmouth Abbey School and brother of the bridegroom, assisted by the Rev. Normand Demers and the Rev. George Almeida.

title: SHUTTLE LINK MADE
description: THERE were cheers and applause at the headquarters of American Radio Relay League in Newington Wednesday as contact was made by a ham radio operator with the space shuttle Columbia.

title: Amish Jailed 15 Days Over Buggy Reflectors
description: Five Amish men have been given 15 days in jail for refusing to hang reflectors from their horse-drawn buggies because it would violate an Amish ban against displaying bright colors, officials said.

title: SPORTS MUST MAINTAIN ITS PLAC IN AMERICAN SOCIETY
description: WHEN I first came to the National Basketball Association, friends and colleagues of mine reacted in a rather unusual way. Some felt I had found enjoyable employment in the world of sports that would be relaxing to me. I would have the pleasure of attending as many games as I cared to. I would be working perhaps six or seven months a year and I would have all the rest of the time off.

title: 'TIS THE SEASON TO SAY 'HUMBUG!'
description: EARLY this September I wandered into a gardening supply house seeking bulbs, mulch and other fall things. In my innocence, I felt autumn was the time for sticking crocus underground, standing back to admire your handiwork and inhaling the aroma of freshly poured driveway sealer. What I found instead was row upon row of glitter-encrusted Christmas paraphernalia.

title: Steven Pontell Weds Marcy Jo Bodenstein
description: Marcy Jo Bodenstein, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alvin Bodenstein of Tenafly, N.J., was married yesterday to Steven Pontell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Pontell of Oradell, N.J. Rabbi Arthur Hertzberg, assisted by Cantor Kurt Silbermann, performed the ceremony at Tammybrook Country Club in Cresskill, N.J.

title: City's Courts to Work Through the Holiday
description: New York State's court system has announced that it will keep New York City's courts open during a planned Christmas recess.

title: Anne Longley Is Married to Lawrence Longstaff
description: Anne MacRae Longley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Longley of New York, Salisbury, Conn., and Siasconset, Mass., was married yesterday to Lawrence Alan Longstaff, son of Mrs. John McGowan of Fanwood, N.J., and the late Robert Alan Longstaff of Jersey City. The Rev. Dr. John Bishop performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn.

title: 90-YEAR LEASE WEIGHED
description: -owned land to the Robert Martin Company for 99 years was taken last week by the County Board of Legislators, which held a public hearing on the lease.

title: Miss Conroy To Be Bride Of B. T. Leib
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph B. Eastman of Haddonfield, N.J., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Eastman's daughter, Nancy Verga Conroy, to Barclay Thorndike Leib, son of Joan Coffin Whiteman and Gordon B. Leib of New York.

title: Wilander Defeats Lendl in 3-Set Final
description: Mats Wilander of Sweden comfortably beat Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia, 6-1, 6-4, 6-4, at Kooyong today to win the Australian Open tennis championship.

title: HUSTON FILMS A CULT CLASSIC
description: Herbert Gold's most recent novel is ''True Love.'' TALL, BENT OLD man with a distinguished head is perched on a high canvas chair amid the crowd of film makers in El Farolito, a rep lica of a sordid bar in Mexico, 1938. Like much else in the hills outside Cuernavaca, there are few indications that even the 20th century has arrived, except for the trucks and vans of the company filming ''Under the Volcano,'' Malcolm Lowry's famous and famously difficult cult novel about an alcoholic British Consul who courts death and gets his wish.

title: HEARINGS SET ON NEW ADIRONDACK PARK TRACT
description: A dispute over the differences between a ''wilderness'' and a ''wild forest'' will come to a head next week when the Adirondack Park Agency holds a series of hearings on how to classify a newly acquired tract of 10,344 acres in the Adirondack Mountains.

title: IN LONDON'S BYWAYS, THE GAME'S AFOOT
description: The night was dark and chill, the roads all but deserted, as a small group of top-coated men and women huddled beneath the London street lamp. ''I predicted there would be 15 of you,'' Graham Watson announced, shaking his head sadly, ''and there are but 14. Never mind, I'll commence.''

title: Peter Nash, Miss Warner Are Married
description: Alexandra de Peyster Warner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William W. Warner of Washington, was married yesterday to Peter Baird Nash, son of Mrs. Roger Alden Derby Jr. of New York and Upperville, Va., and James Mallory Nash of Warrenton, Va. The Rev. James L. Connor performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Washington.

title: JERUSALEM RECORDS SHUNS THE FAMILIAR
description: Paul Turok writes frequently about recorded music.

title: ENGLISH FURNITURE
description: Not since the 1930's has period English furniture enjoyed such popularity. At auctions, astounding prices for 18th- and early 19th-century British styles are registered with increased frequency. In the shops, Queen Anne through Regency designs are booming. Indeed, these days, the brasses rarely tarnish on the finest examples of Georgian breakfronts, bureaus, desks and chests, so swiftly do they come and go in shops on 57th Street, upper Madison Avenue and lower Broadway.

title: THE CHRISTMAS CARD QUESTION
description: THE first year I felt enormously relieved. The second year I was still relieved and realized how clever I was to have dropped the burden from my shoulders. By the third and fourth years it was routine not to send Christmas cards to the 150 friends, acquaintances and people who had touched my life.

title: GINGER: THE ASIAN SPICE THAT FOUND FAVOR IN THE COLONIES
description: YOU can't generalize about ginger. It is sold in several forms, all of which have particular uses in cooking.

title: LEONARD TO RESUME HIS BOXING CAREER
description: Sugar Ray Leonard, the former undisputed welterweight champion, ended months of speculation tonight when he announced that he would resume his boxing career as early as February and no later than March.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE New Jersey chapter of the Sierra Club has almost doubled its membership in three years, making it the largest and perhaps most influential environmental group in the state.

Several county legislators expressed discontent with County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke's latest suggestion that betting parlors be opened in the county as a means of generating budget revenues.

title: THE NATION'S MOOD
description: DECADE AFTER UNITED States troops left Vietnam and the Watergate hearings gripped the public, Americans are starting to show more trust in their Government and to voice greater support for the freedoms it promises, polling by The New York Times shows. (See selections from the poll on page 89.)

title: V.A.T. Refunds
description: To the Editor: I read with a great deal of interest the article ''How to Stalk and Capture a V.A.T. Refund'' (Travel, Nov. 6). However, Margot Slade failed to mention that there are countries that refund V.A.T. in cash at the airport.

title: 8TH GAME DRAWN IN CHESS MATCH
description: Gary Kasparov of the Soviet Union and Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland agreed to a draw on the 39th move of the eighth game of their semifinal world championship chess match tonight.

title: Q&A 3-Year Lease Renewals Question:
description: You recently wrote that the new Omnibus Housing Law eliminated three-year leases on leases commencing ''on or after'' Oct. 1, 1983. Before Oct. 1, my landlord sent me a written option offering a one-, two- or three-year renewal lease beginning Dec. 1. Is my exercise of the three-year option binding on the landlord? . . . K. M., Manhattan

title: RECORD COMPANIES TAKE A NEW TACK
description: There seems to be wide agreement that some of the smaller independent record companies have made a large contribution to the general health - statistically, at least - of the recorded classical- music industry by employing modern marketing methods in selling moderately priced and budget-priced cassettes. However, it is also true that most of these cassettes consist of reissued material that simply recycles performances that have been around for a generation or more or that have been licensed from companies abroad.

title: A BAROQUE ART: MUSICAL DESCRIPTION
description: Handel's ''Allegro, il Penseroso ed il Moderato'' stands somewhere between the concert and the opera stage and belongs wholly to neither. What is so different about this important piece is its point of departure: Opera, and often oratorio, begin with certain places and people; and when successful, they usually end up saying general things about us all. Handel's long and eloquent musical ode, on the other hand, takes ethical and psychological abstractions at the start and then uses music to help transpose them into concrete images.

title: IN NEW YORK, DOG OWNERS PREFER MONGRELS
description: Mongrels are the most popular dogs in New York State, according to the State Department of Agriculture and Markets.

description: CHILDREN in Ansonia are not only learning about the fragility of nature, but how to care for the animals and plants in it, as well.

title: AMERICAN AIR STRIKE CHANGES THE GAME IN THE MIDDLE EAST
description: BEIRUT, LEBANON THE Middle East received another reminder last week that events in this region are determined not by genteel rounds of diplomatic discourse or reconciliation conferences but by coarse and violent actions on the ground. Earlier calculations had to be changed after the American air strike against Syrian antiaircraft batteries in central Lebanon, which had a much wider impact in the region than many people in Washington seemed to realize. And the bomb placed in a city bus in Jerusalem, followed by Israeli navy shelling near Tripoli, upset Yasir Arafat's plans for a carefully stage-managed exit by sea.

title: ALFONSIN WRITES TO MRS. THATCHER
description: President Raul Alfonsin, who was inaugurated today, replied to a good-will message from Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher with little compromise but much wit.

description: THE HUNGRY ANGEL

title: ENVISIONING THE TRUTH WITHOUT THE CONSEQUENCES
description: Borrowing the brainchild of a World War II tank driver and the techniques of science fiction filmmakers, a small band of designers is helping urban planners get a pedestrian's-eye preview of their handiwork. Within the past few weeks, for example, the California Coastal Conservancy has clearly seen how a group of eight-story, as opposed to three-story, buildings would look against Berkeley's hilly shoreline - and construction hasn't even started. The technique is known as simulation, and its leading practitioner in the United States is the Environmental Simulation Laboratory at the University of California, Berkeley. At the heart of the laboratory, which covers 1,250 square feet, is a camera mounted on ceiling tracks. A computer moves the camera horizontally and vertically above scale models - 30 feet to the inch - of cities or neighborhoods in which designers have placed a working model of a proposed structure - a freeway, bridge, skyscraper or sculpture. The camera has a combination prism-and-lens attachment developed by Paul Kenworthy during World War II to show tank drivers what the landscape looks like from inside a tank. The mechanism became the basis of the snorkel camera, which Mr. Kenworthy invented for the movie industry, so that audiences could glide down the streets of a miniature city as if they were pedestrians touring a life-size metropolis, or stand nearby as larger-than-life monsters battled for control of the planet. A prism lets the camera turn, twist and pivot to mimic the turning of a person's head.

title: SANDINISTAS' OFFER SAID TO CENTER ON PEASANTS
description: The Government's offer of amnesty to those who have left Nicaragua in the last four years is aimed primarily at peasants and small farmers, not industrialists or plantation owners, opposition and Government figures say.

title: WINNING ISN'T EVERYTHING FOR BLACK MAYORS
description: The lot of black mayors in the Middle West - there are about a dozen in cities of at least 25,000 population - isn't an easy one. Their cities have all suffered economically during the region's industrial decline and many have experienced debilitating bouts of ''white flight'' to nearby suburbs.

title: RECITAL: EMELIANOFF, CELLIST
description: Through his work with a variety of orchestras and chamber groups in the area, the cellist Andre Emelianoff long ago earned a reputation as one of the best team players around. Thursday evening, Mr. Emelianoff presented an ambitious solo recital in the 92d Street Y.

description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Sanford E. Klein of Roslyn Heights, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Amy Lynn Klein, to Milton Stuart Kaufman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Kaufman of New York.

title: STUDY DETAILS EXTENT OF CRIME AND ITS RISKS
description: The chance of becoming a victim of violent crime is greater than that of ''being affected by divorce,'' according to a new, nationwide study by the Justice Department.

title: INTELLIGENCE: TOO MUCH INFORMATION, TOO LITTLE EVALUATION
description: The marines, defending the adequacy of security at their Beirut headquarters on Oct. 23, have said they never received intelligence information warning that they might be the target of a suicidal truck-bomb attack. General Kelley, the Marine Commandant, told Congress last month that the marines ''have yet to find a shred of intelligence which would have alerted a reasonable and prudent commander to this new and unique threat.''

title: Enn of Austria Victor In Supergiant Slalom
description: Hans Enn of Austria won the season's first World Cup supergiant slalom race in a driving snowstorm today, finishing nearly half a second ahead of Switzerland's Pirmin Zurbriggen.

title: PLAN TO SETTLE CAYUGAS' LAND CLAIM WEIGHED
description: Cayuga Indians would get about 10,000 acres of unoccupied land in central New York and an unspecified sum in cash under a settlement of their land claim discussed at a task force meeting here this week, a participant said.

title: TWO SPECIAL DANCERS LEAVE THE STAGE
description: Two of the New York City Ballet's most distinctive dancers have ostensibly ended their performing careers with the company this fall and neither retirement should go unnoticed. One is Peter Martins, and the attention surrounding his farewell appearance with the City Ballet last Tuesday leaves no risk that his decision to stop dancing at the age of 37 will go unheeded. It is clear that he will continue to be a center of interest as ballet master in chief with Jerome Robbins at the City Ballet, where he will devote more time to choreography.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
LET'S FINISH THE WORK WE STARTED
description: side economics first caught the attention of the public in 1980, some labeled it as a kind of economic hocus-pocus economics on a napkin, while others saw the genuine validity of our claims that cutting tax rates, stabilizing the value of the dollar and freeing up the entrepreneurial talent of America could maximize our society's economic output and prosperity. Three years have passed, President Reagan has battled a 25 percent personal tax cut through Congress, inflation stands at 3 percent, unemployment is falling rapidly but the financial press keeps reporting a ''surprising'' recovery that ''no one could have foreseen.''

title: WHAT TO DO WHEN VENETIAN BLINDS ARE OUT OF ADJUSTMENT
description: VENETIAN blinds contain two separate operating mechanisms, each of which is actuated by a separate control cord - the lift cord and the tilt cord. Each of these does exactly what its name implies: The lift cord raises the slats from the bottom up when you pull down on the looped end that hangs down on one side of the blind; and the tilt cord serves to tilt the slats open or closed.

title: ESCAPE TO DEVIL'S ISLAND
description: For almost 100 years men periodically braved sharks, treacherous currents and days adrift under a broiling sun trying to escape from three islands that are now shimmering in the distance. Today the traffic goes in both directions as travelers with a taste for the unusual head toward the palm-studded patches 10 miles off the northeast coast of French Guiana. On the map they are the Islands of Salvation (Iles du Salut), the name bestowed by 18th-century French settlers. But to the rest of the world they are Devil's Island.

title: LIGHTING UP A SEASON'S WONDER
description: KILLINGLY MERVIN WHIPPLE of Killingly is a slightly rotund, amiable 55-year- old man, with red cheeks and a hearty laugh and a sparkle in his eyes. There are those who who would say he looks like Santa Claus, and the same people would tell you it is a part he has been growing into for 16 years.

title:
STAMPS;
BOOK OF FACTS AND FEATS MAKES USEFUL GIFT
description: This year the best Christmas present one can give to a collector is a book that every collector would do well to give to himself - if it doesn't turn up in his Yule stocking. The book is ''Stamps, Facts and Feats, a Guinness Superlatives Book.'' Written by John Mackay, a philatelist of eminent qualifications and a gift for words, the 225-page hardcover book ($19.95) is rich in illustrations, both color and black and white, and thoroughly indexed. There is also a paperback edition at $12.95. It is distributed in the United States by Sterling Publishing Company, 2 Park Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10016.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: An unusual aspect of making ''Cook and Peary: The Race to the Pole'' during midsummer in Canada's Northwest Territories and Greenland was that the days can be 22-hours long. Robert Halmi, the TV film's producer, said last week in a phone interview: ''I wanted to take the watches away from everybody and say we'll work till sundown. Unfortunately, union regulations chase one all the way to the pole. What it meant was nobody slept.''

Thus the concert by Steven and Nadya Gordon at Carnegie Hall Thursday night offered a lot of flash and glitz but - despite the obvious musicality of both players - not that much music.

title: LANDMARK DECISION

Now the cafe's landlord, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, wants to expand the number of restaurants in the landmark terminal building and is inviting proposals for sit-down restaurants in three areas of the mezzanine level: (1) a 2,800-square-foot space on the north balcony west of the escalators leading to the Pan Am building, (2) a 3,100- square-foot area on the north balcony to the east of the escalators and (3) a 1,900-square- foot location to the south of the Vanderbilt Avenue entrance.

title: THE WORLD
description: The United States has cooperated with the Vatican for years on world political and humanitarian questions, but relations have been limited by law and the objections of many Protestants. Indeed, many Catholic bishops have opposed formal relations as being a divisive issue for American society. The argument is that such relations would violate First Amendment principles of separation of church and state. Given all that, the Reagan Administration last week was moving cautiously toward closer ties, but not too close.

title: THE BIG BUSINESS OF ILLICIT DRUGS
description: Mathea Falco, a lawyer in San Francisco, was Assistant Secretary of State for International Narcotics Matters in the Carter Administration. By Mathea Falco HE INTERNATIONAL DRUG TRADE IS NO longer a haphazard or even a particularly shady undertaking. In the last 10 years, illicit drugs have become one of the world's most lucrative and dynamic industries, with revenues so enormous and so dispersed over the surface of the globe that they can only be guessed at.

''My dad said 'jump' and my mom jumped,'' said Mr. Goyt, a 34-year-old detective in the Sheriff's Department in Harrison, Mich. ''He always went out hunting and fishing with the guys and left her to take care of us and the house. It wasn't fair.''

title: GIFTS FOR POLAND UPSET AGENCIES

title: A Tale of Heroic Anonymity
description: The literature of conscience is ultimately about the bewilderment of the naive. Why do men carry guns and build prison camps, when the nurturing earth is made for freedom? To the outcast, the stray, the simpleton, the unsuspecting - to the innocent - the ideologies that order society are inane, incomprehensible. To the innocent, comprehension comes unaccoutered, stripped, uninstructed - Huck Finn on the loose, who merely knows what he knows. And what the pariah Huck knows, against the weight and law and common logic of his slaveholding ''sivilization,'' is that the black man is whole, the rightful owner of his life and times.

title: LITTLE GAS OR OIL SEEN IN THE WILDS
description: Most of the land in Federal wilderness preserves has little or no potential for producing oil or natural gas, and only 4 percent of that land has a high probability of containing reserves, Federal geologists have concluded.

title: NOBEL PRIZES PRESENTED TO 5 SCIENTISTS AND A WRITER
description: Five American scientists who pioneered research in physics, chemistry, medicine and economics, and a 72-year-old British writer of dark myth today accepted their 1983 Nobel Prizes from the King of Sweden.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: YONKERS ALBERT ANGRILLI got his button last week. ''It was like receiving a badge,'' he said, grinning, displaying the little pin imprinted with his name and the words Hudson River Museum. ''It was like getting a trophy.''

title: CITY HIGH SCHOOLS PLAN PROGRAMS WITH 2 COLLEGES
description: Beginning next September, Midwood High School in Brooklyn - a public school - will offer special programs for selected students in cooperation with Brooklyn College, the city's Schools Chancellor has announced.

title: AT 300 RAMEAURISES FROM NEGLECT
description: One of the greatest of all composers was born 300 years ago this year, but it cannot be said that our musical institutions have exactly fallen over themselves in celebration of his anniversary. The composer is Jean-Philippe Rameau, the master of the French Baroque. But neither the Metropolitan nor the New York City Opera has staged one of his works (the Met is just getting its feet wet with

title: A CHRISTMAS APPEAL: DONATE TO NEEDIEST CASES FUND
description: The72dAppeal

title: Miss Wood Is Betrothed
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Austin Wood to Wilfred Francis Vallely 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Vallely Jr. of Old Greenwich, Conn., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. James David Wood of Port Washington, L.I.

title: SUNDAY OBSERVER
description: Thinking The Thinkable

title: CONCERT: MELODIES OF PERSIAN ORIGIN
description: Dariush Dolat-shahi, a Persian musician who has studied in Teheran, Amsterdam, Utrecht and New York, brought together ancient and modern technology in a concert of his music Friday at Carnegie Recital Hall. He played four- and six-stringed Persian lutes - the tar and setar, which have a dulcimerlike twang - accompanied by tapes of electronic music.

title: COWBOYS
description: The first time I actually went to a ranch and talked to cowboys, it put me into a state of high indignation. I saw a ranchophile I know and confronted him with what I had found.

title: INTERNATIONAL SIDESHOW
description: LONDON While the semifinal world championship matches pitting Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland against Gary Kasparov of the Soviet Union and Zoltan Ribli of Hungary against Vasily Smyslov of the Soviet Union are going on here at the Great Eastern Hotel, the sponsor, Acorn Computers Ltd., has included two satellite matches on the program.

title: WHEN MORAL OBLIGATION CONFLICTS WITH THE LAW
description: To the Editor: Donald Kagan's assertion that ''pacifists can pursue their beliefs only in free societies and only be

title: CYCLING IOWA'S COUNTRY ROADS
description: Ahead through the fog, the sun was starting to come up, a white eye peeking out beside a tree. The line of bicyclists in north central Iowa rolled quietly on, leg muscles warming up with the day.

title: A Night for Stenerud
description: Tomorrow night could be a big one for Jan Stenerud, the Green Bay Packer place kicker. Stenerud needs only two field goals to break George Blanda's career record of 335, and he could get them in the game against the Tampa Bay Buccaneers.

title: THE U.S. MARINE TRAGEDY : CAUSES AND RESPONSIBLITIY
description: A terrorist driving a Mercedes truck crashed into the United States Marine headquarters near the Beirut airport on Oct. 23, catching the marines unprepared. He detonated the equivalent of six tons of dynamite, and 240 men died.

title: TV HONORS A GRAND DIVA IN A GRAND WAY
description: Maria Callas would have been 60 years old on Dec. 3. During the next two days, an array of complex satellite-relayed technology will bring together the services of several world- renowned singers and conductors, four leading opera houses, twenty-five unions, nine co-sponsors, thousands of assisting participants - all for an unprecedented intercontinental televised commemoration of the life and art of the colorful and controversial soprano.

title: ON LANGUAGE
description: Apostrophe Catastrophe

title: FOLK SINGERS RELAY CULTURAL HERITAGE
description: CONNECTICUT'S tobacco fields flourished back in the 1600's, keeping Puritan songwriters busy warning of the weed's evils.

title: TRENTON IS MOVING TO STRENGTHEN TS CURFEW FOR YOUNGSTERS UP TO 17
description: The police would arrest juveniles under the age of 17 who are found on the capital's streets late at night and fine parents of habitual curfew violators under a proposed ordinance, according to city officials.

title: Dolphins Defeat Falcons
description: Don Strock threw two touchdown passes today to lead the Miami Dolphins to a 31-24 National Football League victory over the Atlanta Falcons.

title: CASINOS JUST A SMALL PART
description: Atlantic City's nine hotel-casinos, the ''busiest business'' at the Shore, account for only 3 percent of the Atlantic Electric Company's peak power demands and only 5 percent of its total sales.

title: STELLA KALKANIS TO WED LIEUT. MATTHEW BOGDANOS
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Evangelis Kalkanis of Astoria, Queens, of the engagement of their daughter, Stella Eva Kalkanis, to Lieut. Matthew F. Bogdanos, U.S.M.C., son of Mr. and Mrs. Konstantine Bogdanos of New York and Hoboken, N.J.

title: WEST SIDE CHURCH DESTROYED BY FIRE
description: An early-morning fire destroyed an 89-year-old Methodist church on the Upper West Side of Manhattan yesterday. Officials said the blaze, which forced scores of nearby residents out of their homes, might have been set.

title: Gvof$50,000atClosing
description: One of the Gucci stores on Fifth Avenue at 54th Street was robbed of $50,000 by a gunman shortly after 7 P.M. yesterday, according to the police.

title:
FARE OF THE COUNTRY;
RIJSTTAFEL, A DUTCH FEAST FROM INDONESIA
description: M any a visitor to Amsterdam has discovered that a ''typically Dutch restaurant'' is not Dutch at all but Indonesian. For Amsterdamers and visitors alike, the rijsttafel, or Indonesian rice table, is the most popular cuisine in town.

title: OLD OPERA HOUSE IS RENEWED BY SONG
description: IN the past, the people of

title: JAMAICA FACES VIRTUAL ONE-PARTY STATE
description: Jamaica, which is struggling to overcome serious economic problems, now appears to be headed for a constitutional crisis as well.

title: GROUP TRIES TO DISCERN FUTURE TO IMPROVE IT
description: Ed Cornish does not have much time to worry about the mundane concerns that weigh heavy on most Americans. He is too busy looking into the future.

title: LIVING WHERE YOU WORK
description: For years architects, artists and designers throughout the city have been living illegally in commercial lofts or setting up businesses on the sly in strictly residential spaces. Despite the current trend of converting commercial spaces into residences, most buildings are legal either as working places or as dwellings.

title: ARTISTS PROTEST NUCLEAR THEREAT
description: In city after city around the country, from cathedrals to cabaret halls, from the poet's lair to the print shop, classical and commercial artists of all kinds are coming together to protest the threat of nuclear war.

title: I.R.S. 'NO' SPURS SEWER TAX DEBATE
description: NOW that a plan to stabilize taxes in the Southwest Sewer District has been blocked by the Internal Revenue Service, homeowners in the district are threatened with a doubling of their tax bill by 1985. Moreover, this presents the county again with the problem of how to pay for the scandal-marred project.

title: ROCK: ALL-STARS AT GARDEN
description: Eric Clapton, Jeff Beck and Jimmy Page - three leading British rock guitarists of the late 1960's - were the focal points of Ronnie Lane's Appeal for ARMS, an all-star jam session to benefit Action Research Multiple Sclerosis. Together with members of the Rolling Stones and the Who and half a dozen other British rock veterans, they sold out Madison Square Garden for two nights last week.

title: 'MAN WHO CAME TO DINNER': MIXED FARE
description: IF the play has penguins in the library, an octopus in the basement and a curmudgeon in the

title: JUDGE UPHOLDS MAN'S CHANGE IN LICENSE PLATE AS A PROTEST
description: A man was within his rights when he changed the ''Vacationland'' slogan on his Maine license plate to ''Radiationland,'' a Superior Court judge has ruled.

title: STUDY ASSAILS HEAD OF POLICE
description: BRIDGEPORT A MANAGEMENT study of this city's Police Department by a consulting company recommended last week that dozens of operational changes be undertaken and severely criticized the Police Superintendent.

title: BARGES TO CARRY A NEW BRIDGE TO MYSTIC
description: WHAT looks like the product of a giant erector set lashed against a wharf along the Raritan River in Woodbridge, N.J., is a bridge. But it does not span anything, and it will not until it is finished and floated on two barges 125 miles to Mystic. The bridge will be for Amtrak's Washington-to-Boston passenger line at the point where the line crosses the Mystic River.

title: GOOD TEACHERS ARE STILL NEEDED
description: THERE are certain ''perks'' and privileges that a college president enjoys, but one is either absent or infrequently present - the privilege, fun and challenge of teaching. Administrative responsibilities come first, as they must, and the yearning to teach often has to be set aside.

title: THE TANGLED FIGHT FOR GETTY OIL
description: LOS ANGELES WHEN legendary billionaire J. Paul Getty died at his English country estate in 1976 at the age of 83, he left behind a mighty business empire, a priceless art collection and an ever- growing family tree to lay claim to his wealth. His business was oil - Getty Oil, one of the nation's largest domestic producers. His art collection was both distinguished and valuable - the museum he founded owns 12 percent of Getty Oil along with it Rubens and Rembrandts. And his heirs - three surviving sons, 21 grandchildren and great grandchildren - share a $2.3 billion trust that owns 40 percent of Getty Oil.

title: ELLEN TARNOFSKY PLANS TO WED R.H. HERMAN
description: Mr. and Mrs. Isaac Tarnofsky of West Orange, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Janice Tarnofsky, to Russell H. Herman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Herman of Montreal. A May wedding is planned.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN;
description: JOAN LEE FAUST This Week:

title: ; 'Sam Holman'
description: To the Editor:

title: Greek Oil Tanker Catches Fire In the Persian Gulf Off Qatar
description: A Greek oil tanker, carrying about 40,000 tons of crude, caught fire in the Persian Gulf today off the coast of Qatar, the Kuwaiti news agency reported.

title: SUBTLE REFINEMENTS REPAY THE BUYER OF COSTLY QUALITY
description: Passion and prudence are nearly always at loggerheads. So if your passion for music is strong, it would go against your nature to niggle about the price of sound equipment. Assuming your finances to be adequately supportive of your taste, we shall advance our pre-Christmas shopping suggestions into the higher regions of audio where cost is subordinate to the pursuit of quality.

title: THE REGION
description: Two FirefightersWin Bias Case

title: SPECIALISTS DEBATE ISSUES IN BABY DOE CASE
description: The obligations of government, physicians, courts and parents in the care of severely deformed infants were among the questions discussed as participants in the Baby Jane Doe case and others joined in a debate last week.

title: PERIPATO-GREEK LIFE ON PARADE
description: Visitors to Greece who find themselves in a small town, village or island on a fine afternoon as the sun drops toward the horizon are likely to encounter a puzzling ritual that can tell them more about Greeks than any guidebook.

title: Vote on Envoy to Israel Ruled Out by Mubarak
description: President Hosni Mubarak said today that he would not hold a national referendum on whether Egypt should return its Ambassador to Israel.

title: Jane Muschamp Wed To a Corporate Officer
description: Jane Muschamp, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Muschamp of St. Louis Park, Minn., was married yesterday to Allen L. Stevens, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen B. Stevens of Port Huron, Mich. The Rev. Dr. Bryant Kirkland performed the ceremony at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: Sensitivity Exercise Is Questioned
description: Lynne Ames (''About Westchester,'' Nov. 27) reports that, in a meeting between students from Westlake High School and disabled students from B.O.C.E.S., a well-meaning guidance counselor proposed an exercise in sensitivity: ''Think of yourself as deaf or blind, and tell us what you would rather be.''

title: WHERE CITY MEETS SEA TO BECOME ART
description: The good news from Manhattan is that if all plans mature the partnership of art, architecture and landscape gardening in Battery Park City is likely to be as innovative as it is intelligent. That was the word at any rate from those who attended the crowded press conference at the Whitney Museum at which the plans in question were made known. As to when those plans will become reality, the word is that the waterfront plaza that was the chief object of interest on that occasion should be completed by mid-1986.

title: Bledsoe Goes to Bills
description: Terry Bledsoe , assistant general manager for the Giants, was named general manager of the Buffalo Bills yesterday. The move had been expected, partly because the Bills seem to have a need for Bledsoe's special talents.

title: Cost of Fuels
description: To the Editor:

title: UNCONVENTIONAL WISDOM REGARDING CONVENTIONAL WIVES
description: ALTHOUGH myriad tales and jokes have been told about the conventioneers, little has been said about the role of the spouse at a business convention. But they also serve who only stand and wilt.

title: MAJOR NEWS IN SUMMARY
description: Missile Talks:Soviet Drops HalfThe Other ShoeThe United States and the Soviet Union won't be talking to each other in Geneva for a while. Two weeks after breaking off negotiations on medium-range missiles in Europe, Moscow stepped up its pressure on Western opinion by refusing to set a date for the resumption of parallel talks on strategic arms reductions after a scheduled two-month recess.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: $11.7 Million forGerman Treasure

title: LAND SWAP PROTESTED ANEW
description: NOTING that the Conscience Point National Wildlife Refuge had been willed to the Federal Government ''to protect it from commercial development,'' Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan recently added his voice to those of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, State Senator Kenneth P. LaValle of Port Jefferson and members of the Southampton Town Board in opposing a controversial land swap proposed by Peter Salm, one of Southampton's biggest landowners.

title: BEGINNER'S LUCK
description: In any sporting or recreational

title: THE WORLD
description: Victor in VenezuelaVenezuela got rid of military rule in 1958. One of the men who helped end the dictatorship of Gen. Marcos Perez Jimenez was Jaime Lusinchi, a pediatrician who turned to politics so successfully that last week he was elected President. Mr. Lusinchi will take office in February and confront economic problems almost as daunting as Argentina's.

title: TEXAS URGED TO REOPEN BLACK ENGINEER CASE
description: Despite increasing pressure, the Dallas County District Attorney's office has ruled out any further investigation of the 1982 robbery that brought a life sentence for a black engineer whose supporters say he could not have committed the crime.

title: DANCE: AILEY TROUPE AND RITUALISM
description: Performed back to back by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, two of the most interesting works in the repertory provided a bit of electric - and revelatory - programming on Friday at City Center. Both Bill T. Jones's recent ''Fever Swamp'' and Elisa Monte's ''Pigs and Fishes'' are ritualistic works within the post-modernist canon. Both are innovative and full of energy. And they reflect upon each other in their different ways.

title: CANCER JET SERVICE SEEKS AID
description: THE Corporate Angel Network, a nonprofit organization that provides free airplane transportation to cancer-treatment facilities around the country, will celebrate its second birthday on Dec. 22. But the group, which is based at Westchester County Airport, is not planning a party.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
WHEN A DISPUTE SHOULD BE KEPT QUIET
description: MARTIN S. FELDSTEIN'S continuing public advocacy of a tax increase in the face of President Reagan's apparent disinclination to push one through Congress has stirred some strong sentiment within the Administration. It has also raised some key questions about the role of the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers and how an administration should coordinate its economic policy.

title: STUDY HINTS EXTINCTIONS STRIKE IN SET INTERVALS
description: A new analysis of fossils has revealed a curious pattern to the mass extinctions of life on earth that scientists can neither explain nor ignore. Over the last 250 million years, it now appears, life forms have vanished in staggering numbers at regular intervals roughly every 26 million years.

title: TAX REVIEW BOARD ACCUSED OF PRYING
description: NOBODY doubts that the style and condition of houses and their Florida rooms, fireplaces, basements, pools, bathrooms and garages contribute to the value of property. Yet when the Board of Assessment Review in Brookhaven brought those items into its review of property tax grievances, it sparked a controversy that could have statewide repercussions.

title: THE CLUB WAY TO SKI CAN BE ATTRACTIVE
description: WITH lift tickets costing $25 a day in some areas, skiers of all abilities naturally look for ways to save money. A few dollars saved here and there can add up to an extra ski trip or two a season.

title: This emperor has no country, at least none that's safe for him
description: Bokassa I , deposed in 1979 as Emperor of what was and is again the Central African Republic, was thrown out of the Ivory Coast last week and sent to France, which said it did not want him either.

title: Israeli Killed in Lebanon
description: An Israeli soldier was killed today by an explosive device as his patrol was moving through the southern approaches to Sidon in southern Lebanon, an army spokesman said. The death brought to 557 the Israeli losses in Lebanon since the invasion of June 1982.

title: PILGRIMS ALL
description: MOST of Long Island went to sleep Thanksgiving night ready for an evening of turkey-sandwich nightmares. Outside, the rain slashed away at our dwellings. At 5:30 A.M. Friday, the rain still knifed through the dark. But three other intrepids and I had made the promise to voyage to Montauk, hike on the shore and glimpse any new species they could add to their avian counts.

title: WARNER SHOWING AN ELUSIVE STYLE
description: Curt Warner pondered the question and gave a surprising answer.

title: LEAGUE UNITES WEST AND EAST CLUBS
description: Seven teams from the Eastern College Athletic Conference Division 1 will join forces with the six-team Western Collegiate Hockey Association next season and form what will amount to a national college hockey league.

title: THE ACCENT HERE IS AMERICAN
description: James R. Oestreich is a former classical music editor of High Fidelity magazine.

title: FOOD
description: WINTER WARMERS

title: YONKERS TO HOLD FIRST TAX AUCTION
description: AN auctioneer will sell off more than 200 Yonkers properties at the city's first big sale on Wednesday, beginning at 10 A.M. at Saunders High School on Palmer Road.

title: CITIES ARE WAKING UP TO WHAT WERE EMPTY PROMISES
description: In the early 1980's, the competition

title: THE NATION
description: William Baxter,The Man Who. . .

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: Sealed AgainstTooth Decay

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: HOFSTRA UNIVERSITY and the Museums at Stony Brook have been named recipients of three-year matching grants from the National Endowment for the Humanities. Hofstra will get $450,000 to strengthen programs of the Hofstra Cultural Center and to enable renovations of the Hofstra Library. The museums will receive $350,000 to increase the endowment for museum operations, to renovate the administration building and to support initial long-term development campaign costs.

title: ReportUrgesHigherSalaries For Some Teachers in Jersey
description: A report released this week recommended that the state pay its mathematics and science teachers more money during the next 10 years to insure an adequate supply of quality teachers in those fields.

title: Life Term in Kidnapping
description: Guillermo Salvador Lacayo, accused of plotting the kidnapping of the wife of a former Salvadoran diplomat, has been sentenced to life in prison.

title: WISEMAN LOOKS AT AFFLUENT TEXANS
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. ''The Store,'' Frederick Wiseman's film portrait of the Neiman-Marcus department store in Dallas, will be shown on WNET/Channel 13 on Wednesday evening at 9. The two-hour study is the award-winning film maker's 16th movie and his first documentary in more than three years. From 1967 (''Titicut Follies'') through 1980 (''Model''), Mr. Wiseman had produced a new film each year, and his work received such critical acclaim that a Wiseman documentary heralded the beginning of each new Public Broadcasting Service season for more than a decade.

title: ARMORED CAR ROBBED IN MIDTOWN
description: An armored truck was held up in midtown Manhattan by a gunman at 12:17 A.M. today after making a pickup at the Ziegfeld Theater on West 54th Street, the police said.

title: NEWCOMER ON THE SEAFOOD LIST
description: AT the Colonnade, a stunning new seafood restaurant in Manhasset, the menu states that all the fish is fresh and never frozen. This is certainly praiseworthy, but even the freshest of fish, if not carefully prepared, will fail to please the discriminating diner.

title: U.S. TO PAY FARMERS WHO PROTECT FRAGILE SOIL
description: -- - The Agriculture Department will make a modest attempt next year to pay farmers who agree to protect their own highly erodible land that they have been planting in wheat and feed grains, Agriculture Secretary John R. Block has announced.

title: CONCERT: FRANK SINATRA
description: Frank Sinatra was in an expansive mood when he took the stage at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena on Thursday night. For one thing, the singer was on his home turf. ''I knew this area better than the guys who built the building,'' the singer recalled in between ''My Way'' and ''Here's to the Band.'' ''It was a great place to play hooky in, and I got a degree in escapism.''

title: SONGS: KITT MORAN
description: A singer who shows imagination and taste in selecting her songs is already ahead of the game. When she has the vocal warmth and clear-eyed, hoydenish beauty of Kitt Moran, she is even farther ahead.

title: A BASKET OF FINANCIAL SERVICES
description: When a top corporate executive who earned a 50 percent bonus needed advice on how to structure the payout, he called Barry Kessler, the tax manager in charge of personal financial planning in the New York office of Touche Ross & Company. And Mr. Kessler's fee was paid by the executive's employer.

title: BAKERY MOTIFS IN LAMPS
description: A few months ago, Hajime Goto, a Japanese sculptor who lives in France, wandered into Mythology , a store on Columbus Avenue, and showed some of his work to Bill Bailey, one of the shop's owners. The pieces were polyurethane lamps, one in the shape of a croissant, the other in the shape of a French baguette.

title: HELP FOR TROUBLED CHILDREN
description: The four-story red-brick Georgian building on the residential street in White Plains was built in the 1920's and looks no different from the other pleasant houses on the tree- lined block. In fact, it is quite special.

title: LIFE BEYOND THE GINZA'S GLITTER
description: Since Tokyo swarms with 11 million people, one might expect that all its urban paths are well-beaten. But Tokyo is, most of all, an organic metropolis, having been built and rebuilt according to small neighborhood patterns rather than any coherent design. It is an urban planner's nightmare come to life. All back streets and dead ends, its aerial map looks like the pictures taken through microscopes that appear in high school biology books. The structure of Tokyo, it is said, is cellular. Mainly for that reason, the city can be confusing. A foreign resident of a few years, in a moment of frustration, observed:

title: THE HIDDEN SOUL OF TOKYO
description: To savor Tokyo, one must approach it in a different way from other cities. One must not, first of all, look upon it as a city, but rather as a federation of villages, each self-contained and bearing a small-town soul.

title: STATE STEPS UP CAR-STICKER CHECKS
description: STATE officials are cracking down on automobile owners and used-car dealers whose vehicles have not been tested for emissions.

title: FICTION IN BRIEF
description: HOUSE OF SLAMMERS

title: BOOK ON INDIANS TOUCHES OFF DEBATE
description: WITH the same dramatic style that he used to describe the destruction of the last great auk in ''Wildlife in America,'' Peter Matthiessen is presenting the case for Leonard Peltier, an American Indian Movement activist who Mr. Matthiessen believes was unjustly convicted of the murders of two F.B.I. agents in June 1975.

title: FICTION IN BRIEF
description: PEGGY SALTE

title: Mitchell to Seek Re-election
description: Representative Parren J. Mitchell, Democrat of Maryland, said Thursday that he would seek re-election next year, ending weeks of speculation about his political future. Mr. Mitchell, 61 years old, who has been a member of Congress since 1971, was hospitalized earlier this year. He said he was now in excellent health.

title: ON THEIR TOES FOR HOLIDAYS
description: IT'S that time of year again. Visions of dancing sugar plums

title: Boo
description: A 29-year-old woman was found stabbed to death in her Brooklyn apartment yesterday, the police said.

title: MET OPERA: NEW CAST IN 'GIOVANNI'
description: Except for Edda Moser's sometimes vocally eccentric yet still authoritative Donna Anna and Christian Boesch's lovable Masetto, the cast for Thursday evening's performance of ''Don Giovanni'' at the Metropolitan Opera was entirely different from that at the first night on Nov. 3.

title: Telling a Child About Adoption
description: ''Adoption: What Is the Age to Tell?'' (Nov. 13) might well have been titled ''Avoiding Reality in Adoption.'' Adoptive parents who ''inform their youngers that they are not biological children'' (!) will leave those youngsters hurt, angry and longing for the biological parents who can tell them that they are real.

title: IN BRIDGEPORT, PUBLIC SCHOOLS ARE 'ADOPTED'
description: AFTER Bridgeport's public schools ''rated 169th in ninth-grade Connecticut proficiency tests, behind every other town in the state,'' in 1981, Mayor Leonard S. Paoletta said, he and the Superintendent of Schools, James A. Connelly, began looking for ways to improve the schools.

title: DIRECT SOCIAL SECURITY DEPOSITS GAINING IN USE
description: The popularity of sending Social Security payments directly to the recipients' banks is increasing dramatically, with more than one-third of the beneficiaries now using the method, according to the Government.

title: ZONING CASE UPSETS NASSAU VILLAGES
description: LAWSUITS challenging the validity of zoning ordinances in East Hills, Hewlett Harbor and Roslyn are beginning to worry authorities in other Nassau County villages. The concern is that that a similar suit might be brought in any village and might result in the loss of its zoning powers, which would revert to the town in which it is situated.

title: SURVEY FINDS MOST DROPOUTS HAVE REGRETS
description: A Government survey has found that 14 percent of the high school sophomores in 1980 became dropouts and that most now regret leaving school.

title: THIRD WORLD DEBTS MEAN FEWER JOBS FOR PEORIA
description: In determining when the third world debt crisis began, historians may pick Thursday, Aug. 12, 1982 - the day Mexican Finance Minister Jesus Silva Herzog told the Treasury Department in Washington that his country would be completely broke in four days. By the following weekend, Deputy Treasury Secretary R. T. McNamar was organizing a $10 billion rescue operation to head off collapse of Mexico's economy and the global banking system.

title: COAL MINER WORKS VEIN WITH 2 PONIES
description: In a computerized, mechanized world, Terrence Johnston still mines coal the old way, shoveling his livelihood by hand into oaken buggies pulled along rusty rails by two sturdy ponies.

title:
GARDENING;
EVOLUTION OF THE MODERN POINSETTA
description: WERE Don Hernando Ruiz to see the poinsettia that we now use at Christmas, he would hardly recognize it. As one of a group of Franciscan priests who settled in Taxco, Mexico, in the 17th century, he was the first to report this flower and its use in the Fiesta of Santa Pesebre, a nativity procession.

title: Mary H. Thomson, Research Analyst, Will Marry Douglas G. Russell in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. A. Lindsay Thomson of West Hartford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Hotchkiss Thomson, to Douglas Gibson Russell, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Gibson Russell of Fairfield, Conn. A May wedding is planned.

title: COLUMBIA IS BEATEN BY INDIANA FOR TITLE
description: Columbia's bid to win the national collegiate title in soccer was thwarted tonight by Indiana, 1-0, on a goal by Pat McCauley 2 minutes 43 seconds into the second overtime.

title: ANIMALS
description: THE RETURN OF THE BROWN PELICAN

title: OUTDOORSNelson Bryant
description: Hunting for the Right Book

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: EDISON FILM FESTIVAL

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Les Ballets Jazz de Montreal, a Canadian company that makes one appearance in New York City next Saturday night at the Beacon Theater, is something of a phenomenon in North American dance history. At a time when modern dance was not as accepted in Canada as it is now, the jazz-dance idiom that sprang out of the fusion of show styles, ballet and modern in this country suddenly took hold in Montreal.

title: BLACK G.I.'S ARE THEME OF DRAMA IN ESSEX
description: MONTCLAIR ABLACK sergeant is shot to death. Everyone in the barracks, black and white, had a motive.

title: Penne L. Brooks and Gray G. Weicker Are Planning to Be Married on June 23
description: Dr. and Mrs. Phillips W. Brooks of Penn Yan, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Penne Lee Brooks, to Gray Godfrey Weicker, son of Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Alexandria, Va., and Greenwich, Conn., and Marie Godfrey Weicker of Greenwich. The wedding is to be on June 23.

title: POPSICLE PANIC
description: DESPITE the current controversy over the failings of our public schools, and the debate about merit pay as an incentive for teachers vs. lengthening the school year, the same thing is wrong with the schools that has always been wrong.

title: Barbara Boehm Is Married
description: Barbara Alice Boehm, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George A. W. Boehm of New York, and Robert Russell, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. George P. Russell, were married yesterday in the First Christian Church in Madison, Wis. The Rev. David Feldt performed the ceremony. Mrs. Russell, who graduated from the Marymount School in New York and the University of Wisconsin, is a registered nurse at Madison General Hospital. Mr. Russell, who graduated from the Manhattan School of Music, is a broadcaster with Wisconsin Public Radio.

title: FOUR AMNESTY GRUPS ACTIVE IN COUNTY
description: WHEN Carmen Popescu stepped into the bright August sunlight beyond her prison last summer in Bucharest, Rumania, guards handed her a food package from Dobbs Ferry.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: At first glance, the photographs in Ruth Thorne-Thomsen's ''Expedition Series'' look like small, somewhat unprofessional 19th-century travel photographs. They have the brownish tones and blank skies of old photographs.

title: PRESSURE IS FELT FOR EXPANSION
description: At times this week, baseball club owners and executives must have felt like Congressmen. ''We've been lobbied very hard,'' said Al Thornwell, executive vice president of the Atlanta Braves. ''Tampa Bay, St. Petersburg, Indianapolis, Denver, Vancouver, Buffalo - they all begin to run together after a while.''

title: MIANUS REPAIRS STIR NEW CONCERN

title:
GARDENING;
EVOLUTION OF THE MODERN POINSETTA
description: WERE Don Hernando Ruiz to see the poinsettia that we now use at Christmas, he would hardly recognize it. As one of a group of Franciscan priests who settled in Taxco, Mexico, in the 17th century, he was the first to report this flower and its use in the Fiesta of Santa Pesebre, a nativity procession.

title: 'JOY OF CHRISTMAN' NEED SPRUCING UP
description: ''THE Joy of Christmas,'' a pageant in its fourth year at the Spinning Wheel Inn in Redding Ridge, is presented in five acts and separated by four courses (soup, salad, entree and dessert.) It covers the musical manifestations of the holiday season, from medieval to modern.

title: ANOTHER CHAPTER IN MOB FOLKLORE
description: The problem with ''The Mob in Atlantic City'' is that the mob isn't really in Atlantic City, at least not in the way we expect it to be, or in any other way, for that matter, in which it is easily recognized, much less easily indicted. On the other hand, whatever else the mob may be, it is a staple for popular journalism, and ''The Mob in Atlantic City'' works nicely as a television program not because WNEW-TV has done a crack investigation, but because it has put together an entertaining news program. The program will be seen on Channel 5 at 9 o'clock tonight.

title: 'BIG MO' HAUNTED BY HISTORIC WORDS
description: After 28 years of sanctuary and retirement, the battleship Missouri is to be reactivated to join her sister ships, the New Jersey and the Iowa, already re-outfitted for active duty.

title: WITH BEGIN RETIRED, ISRAEL ABOUNDS IN POLITICAL STRAINS AND UNCERTAINTIES
description: Menachem Begin's withdrawal from public life, culminating in his resignation as Prime Minister of Israel last October, has not left exactly the political void that his detractors had hoped for and his supporters had feared.

title: HOW SHOULD WE REACT TO VIOLENCE?
description: Does the new ''Scarface'' deserve to be rated ''X'' for violence? Is an ''R'' rating too lenient for ''Star 80''? Should any movie that contains a single usage of one particular four-letter word - the word that the humorist Jean Shepard describes as ''the queen-mother of dirty words'' - deserve an automatic ''R''? Will we ever see the day when it will be possible to give an ''X'' on principle to all of Clint Eastwood's ''Dirty Harry'' movies, including the new ''Sudden Impact''?

title: Wedding Planned By Miss Schwartz

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: AFEW years ago, there was seldom a parking problem in White Plains. Half the city had been torn down for urban renewal, creating block upon block of open-air parking lots. The other half had a generous supply of multi-story parking garages. White Plains seemed to deserve its reputation as a city that had successfully accommodated the automobile.

title: Rabbit Slaughter
description: Two years ago this month some 600 farmers in Jefferson County, Idaho, after losing hundreds of thousands of dollars in hay and grain to voracious jack rabbits, went on the warpath. With horses, motorcycles and much whooping and hollering, they rounded up at least 30,000 jack rabbits and clubbed them to death with baseball bats, ax handles and tire irons. Amid denunciations by national conservation groups, Gov. John V. Evans appointed a Special Task Force on Rabbit Control to consider more humane measures. Rabbits are no big problem this year, says Dr. W. Greg Nelson, the State Veterinarian and chairman of the task force. ''They run in cycles of 10 years,'' he explains, and the latest cycle peaked in the winter of 1981-82. Then predators and diseases like tularemia kill the rabbits, he says.

There were some happy moments, but too often William Koch's direction saw Gilbert and Sullivan's characters not as amusingly fallible but simply as ridiculous.

title: A DEEP POWDER DEBUT IN UTAH
description: Deep powder. To some skiers it is the ultimate experience. To Western ''powderhounds'' fortunate enough to pick and choose their skiing days, it is the only experience. For me powder was, until last winter, elusive. In 15 years of skiing I had made many of the standard pilgrimages - the Northeast, the Colorado Rockies, the Alps, the Sawtooths, even the Cascades. I had steered my skis though hard-packed snow, soft snow, crusty snow, slush, mud and, of course, that sinister, rock-like, icy surface known lovingly throughout Vermont and New Hampshire as ''boilerplate.''

title: Ex-Deputy Gets Four Years

All three were convicted of torturing prisoners to coerce confessions. Mr. Parker was sentenced Thursday to 10 years in prison and the other two received lesser terms.

title: WEEK IN BUSINESS
description: William F. Baxter , saying he was ''burned out,'' resigned as head of the Justice Department's antitrust division, effective this week. The Assistant Attorney General, who perhaps had greater impact on antitrust policy and enforcement than anyone since F.D.R.'s antitrust chief, Thurmon Arnold, plans to return to Stanford Law School to teach. During his tenure, Mr. Baxter ended the Government's two largest antitrust cases - the A.T.& T. monopoly case, which resulted in the coming Jan. 1 breakup, and the I.B.M. monopoly case, which Mr. Baxter dropped. Moreover, just last week he closed the Government's six-year antitrust investigation of the four major American oil companies that are partners in Saudi Arabia's Aramco. Mr. Baxter's successor will be J. Paul McGrath, head of the Justice Department's civil division, but Mr. McGrath has disqualified himself from involvement in the A.T.& T. case since he has worked for the company. Interestingly, that leaves no Reagan appointee heading the Administration's involvement in the largest corporate breakup in history. Staying On. Lee A. Iacocca will not be leaving Chrysler, but will stay on for five more years. The man who turned around the No. 3 auto company has good reason to remain. His new contract will give him a stock bonus of up to 200,000 shares of Chrysler, currently worth some $5.6 million, if he stays the full term.

title: JAZZ: DON PULLEN QUINTET
description: The new quintet that the pianist Don Pullen introduced last week at Sweet Basil was symptomatic of the direction in which one-time adamantly avant-garde jazz musicians are moving to reach a broader audience. Just as Duke Ellington's music provided a bridge to jazz for listeners in an earlier era, the music of Charles Mingus and Thelonious Monk now offers a common ground on which musicians such as Mr. Pullen and an audience that resists screeches and squeals can meet.

title: NEW STIRRINGS OF PATRIOTISM
description: R. W. Apple Jr. is chief of The Times's London bureau. NOT long after the American invasion of Grenada, President Reagan welcomed home hundreds of American medical students from St. George's University on the island. It was an exuberant little ceremony on the South Lawn of the White House, with the students waving small flags and the Marine band playing marches, and President Reagan was clearly delighted. ''What you saw 10 days ago was called patriotism,'' he remarked. What in the world, I wondered, did he mean by that? Did he mean that he himself had acted patriotically by ordering the invasion, because he saw the country endangered by Cuban activities on the island? Did he mean that those who criticized the invasion, saw it as an overreaction or a violation of international law or a cynical piece of pre-election melodrama, were by definition unpatriotic? Did he mean that any red-blooded American ought to feel proud of this demonstration of American might and resolution, and of the speed with which American troops did the job assigned to them? Why was it ''patriotism'' and not a distasteful job, well enough done? Why was he gloating so much?

title: VICTORY OVER SOVIET LIFTS U.S.

title: THIS 'MENAGERIE' IS MUCH TOO COZY
description: Whatever theatrical myth may say to the contrary, the big guns of criticism did not all instantly melt into syrup when Tennessee Williams's ''Glass Menagerie'' first came to warm them, back in 1945. George Jean Nathan decided it was ''rather less a play than a palette of sub-Chekhovian pastels brushed up into a charming semblance of one.'' Joseph Wood Krutch thought its core of shrewd observation was ''enveloped in a fuzzy haze of pretentious, sentimental, pseudo-poetic verbiage.'' And Lewis Nichols of The New York Times, while conceding Williams's ''ear for painfully sardonic dialogue and affection for his characters,'' felt that the principal reason for the piece's success was Laurette Taylor, who played Amanda Wingfield. In fact, it wasn't until Helen Hayes took the same part in 1956 that Brooks Atkinson rebalanced the record in these columns, talking of the depth and charity and ''perfect blend of humor and pathos'' of ''The Glass Menagerie.''

title: COULD A TOSCANINI SUCCEED TODAY?
description: Not long ago, as I sat listening to one of the world's famous symphony orchestras casually dispose of a concert program as if it were a roll of paper toweling, it occurred to me that most of the musicians on the stage had probably come of age too late to know what it means to play, week in and week out, under a great conductor. The symphonic scene today is not devoid of talented, well-schooled leaders, but it looks pallid indeed compared to the efflorescence of baton-wielding masters that took place shortly before and shortly after World War II.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: Scientists FindTantalizing ClueTo Brain DisorderThe smallest infectious agent known has become a leading suspect in several degenerative brain disorders, according to researchers at the University of California. Reporting last week in the journal Cell, scientists identified the prion as a likely cause, in particular, of Alzheimer's disease - a devastating disorder, commonly called senility, that afflicts about two million Americans.

title: BUT CAN THEY TYPE?
description: RUTH BARD'S questioning of ''the point'' of a college education ('' 'Looks Good on a Resume' - But Is That the Point?,'' Opinion Page, Nov. 20) resounds with the noble cry of ''Knowledge for knowledge's sake.'' As John Henry Newman concurs in ''The Idea of a University,'' ''Knowledge is capable of being its own end.'' It is, he says, ''an object in its own nature so really and undeniably good, as to be the compensation of a great deal of thought in the compassing, and a great deal of trouble in the attaining.''

title: CHRISTMAS CARD CRISIS
