description: SEASON OF YELLOW LEAF

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS MASS MARKET Mass market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States. 1
description: CHRISTINE, by Stephen King. (NAL/Signet, $3.95.) A car that kills is at large among a Pennyslvania town's high school set: fiction.

title: 'AMATUERS' TO JOIN HOLIDAY SHOW
description: WHAT are a bank vice president, the head of a college, a politician, and the president of two local radio stations doing in the performing lineup of a Holiday Pops Concert?

title: THIS COUNTERTENOR SURPRISES WITH HIS REPERTORY
description: The singer Paul Esswood, who appears with Musica Sacra in Handel's ''Messiah'' tomorrow and Wednesday at Alice Tully Hall, gave an extraordinary and much-praised recital in London this fall. It included Schumann's ''Liederkreis.''

title: Aid for Fighters Urged
description: Larry Holmes has urged those in the boxing world - members of commissions, managers, promoters and fighters alike - to establish a benefit fund program to help fighters like Sugar Ray Seales , who has lost his eyesight. ''Fighters work so hard for something and things like this happen,'' Holmes said, adding that he would like to see 5 percent of the purse from every fight put into a fund to help fighters such as Seales. ''Fighters do not get the benefits football players, basketball players and all other athletes get, fighters got to do it on their own,'' Holmes said.

title: Marcia Hale Nichols Marries at Harvard
description: Marcia Hale Nichols, daughter of Dr. Frederick Lewis Nichols of Farmington, Conn., and Constance Moeller Nichols of West Hartford, Conn., was married in Cambridge, Mass., yesterday to P. David Trook of Weston, Mass., son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul W. Trook of Hancock and Freedom, N.H. The ceremony took place at the Memorial Church at Harvard University, where the Rev. William B. Abernethy of the Wellesley (Mass.)

title: MIKE USE THIS
description: 1 DECADE AFTER UNITED States troops left Vietnam and the Watergate hearings gripped the public, Americans are starting to show more trust in their Government and to voice greater support for the freedoms it promises, polling by The New York Times shows. (See selections from the poll on page 89.)

title: 100 IN CONGRESS BID REAGAN TAKE UP RIGHTS ISSUE IN TIMOR
description: More than 100 members of Congress, led by Representative Tony P. Hall, Democrat of Ohio, have signed a letter to President Reagan urging him ''to add the suffering of the people of East Timor to America's foreign policy agenda.''

title: AFTER A YEAR, HOMES GET CLEAN WATER
description: MONTVILLE FOR the first time in 15 months, Patricia M. Bourez last week drank water from her kitchen tap and showered in her home on Pink Row in Montville. She had been prohibited from doing those things because the level of chemicals in her artesian well is too high.

title: EL SALVADOR
description: Lydia Chavez reports for The Times from Central America.

title: Haig Joining Amway As a Sales Consultant
description: The Amway Corporation, seeking to expand into new foreign markets, has hired former Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. as a consultant on international business affairs, a company spokesman says.

title: SMITHY SOUGHT FOR RINGWOOD
description: RINGWOOD A METALLURGIST is trying to save a piece of Americana that is rapidly disappearing. At a time when people buy prepackaged items, the metallurgist, 60-year-old Bob Isleib, is talking about making things the old-fashioned way: by hand.

title: Article 100580 -- No Title
description: Women and the Church

title: WHAT'S NEW IN CORPORATE PERKS
description: For many employees, stretching a paycheck becomes more of a challenge every day. So a company compensation gimmick that amounts to a savings-such as a vacation home at discount rentals-is like money in the bank.

title: VIRGINIA WITTER PLANS TO MARRY IN JUNE
description: William David Witter and Susan Rentschler Witter of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Virginia Ann Witter, to Thomas Harrison Woods, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond R. Woods of Stanley, N.Y.A June wedding is planned.

title: STRAWS IN THE WHIRLWIND
description: President Reagan is riding high in the popularity polls these days, partly because his Democratic Party opponents look so dim, but he has some serious problems both at home and abroad.

title:
ART;
EXHIBITION OF SHAKER WORKS EMPHASIZES INDIVIDUALS
description: SHAKER furniture is prized, almost revered, for a high style that is in no way dependent on the vagaries of fashion. The loftiness of Shaker objects comes from their being made by people who had knowledge of and respect for the rich materials of the world, while pursuing lives that were decidedly otherworldly.

title: 'BEST BOOK IN THE WORLD'
description: Some books take a little longer than others to make their way in the world. But 494 years? A major find for next spring is a novel called ''Tirant lo Blanc'' that is coming out in English for the first time. Anyone who cares to dispute its greatness can argue not with me but with Cervantes. In ''Don Quixote,'' the Spanish novelist has one of his characters say, ''I swear to you, my friend, that as far as style is concerned, it's the best book in the world.''

title: MORE AIR TRAVEL RISK?
description: Is air travel getting more dangerous? Advocates of deregulation would say emphatically that it is not; others may be forgiven if they doubt this conclusion.

title: Limits on Worker Suits Upheld in Asbestos Case
description: Indiana's law requiring asbestos workers to file lung ailment claims within two years of their last exposure is constitutional, even though it may take 20 years for symptoms to appear, a Federal appeals court has ruled.

title: Colleen Marie Bohan Wed To Charles M. Sullivan 3d
description: Colleen Marie Bohan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard N. Bohan of New York and Newport, R.I., was married yesterday to Charles M. Sullivan 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sullivan Jr. of Newport. Msgr. Dennis Hayes, the bride's cousin, performed the ceremony at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York, assisted by the Rev. George F. Riley.

title: RICH LANDS BID U.S. STEP UP THIRD WORLD AID
description: Thirty-two of the world's richest nations called on President Reagan today to raise substantially the amount of aid he will ask the United States Congress to give the world's poorest countries in the next three years.

title:
ANTIQUES;
A WIDOW'S LOT WAS OFTEN DIFFICULT
description: WELFARE, in the sense of the government seeing to it that the poor are cared for, was part of local law in every community in colonial and early Federal years.

title: On the Problems Of Pro Soccer To The Sports Editor:
description: When Jay Lippman writes that ''soccer is just too simple and slow moving for sustained interest'' (Mailbox, The New York Times, Dec. 4), I must question his understanding of the game.

title: DRUNKEN DRIVER PROGRAMS ALSO PAY CASH DIVIDENDS
description: A poster produced by the State of Connecticut and distributed in Hartford shows a scowling state trooper standing by his cruiser, and the words: ''Before you drink that one for the road, think about the chaser.''

title: ACTION IS PRESSED ON PLAYBOY CASINO
description: New Jersey's Attorney General is urging the state's Casino Control Commission to force Playboy Enterprises to sell its interest in the Playboy Hotel and Casino in Atlantic City to its partner there by April.

title: CONFESSIONS OF A SELF-IMPROVER
description: Donal Henahan is chief music critic of The Times.

title: STUDY SAYS WOMEN NEDD CALCIUM TO PREVENT HIP FRACTURES
description: Estrogen supplements given to women to offset the symptoms of menopause may not be enough to prevent calcium loss, which can cause curved spines and can lead to fractured hips, according to a study published in The New England Journal of Medicine.

title: TEMIK CONTROVERSY INTENSIFIES
description: FOUR years after the discovery of Temik in East End water supplies, the impact of the pesticide and the controversy surrounding its use and aftereffects continue to mount.

title: SURGERY FOR THE YOUNG
description: ''WHAT kind of a doctor would let a child die?'' ''The answer,'' said Dr. Burton Bronsther, a pediatric surgeon who lives in Hewlett Bay Park, ''obviously, is a doctor who doesn't know how to treat that child.''

title: Give All Owners A Shot at Martin To The Sports Editor:
description: The next commissioner of baseball should be Billy Martin. That way he can be hired - and fired - by all the owners at once, instead of one at a time. THOMASMARIAMKew Gardens, Queens

title: 3 Frenchmen Missing in Iraq; Reported Captured by Kurds
description: Three French technicians employed by a French electronics company have disappeared in Iraq, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.

title: Italian Terrorists Sentenced
description: A Turin court sentenced nine members of the Front Line terrorist group to life imprisonment today, and 15 others to terms of more than 20 years.

title: STAGE: CHILDREN'S THEATER IN 'THE TRIP,' A MUSICAL
description: The essence of a child's picture book is so delicate that it can easily be lost or twisted when it is transferred to another medium. But the First All Children's Theater production of ''The Trip,'' a short musical by Stephen Schwartz and Anthony Stein based on the book by Ezra Jack Keats, retains a communicative magic for an audience beginning with 2-year-olds and has an even deeper appeal for an older audience than the book might have had.

title: D. Lynne White, Reporter, Is Wed
description: The marriage of D. Lynne White, a weather broadcaster and news reporter for WNEW-TV, Channel 5, to Gilroye A. Griffin Jr., vice president, employee relations, for the Bristol- Myers Company, took place yesterday. The Rev. Lee C. Barker performed the ceremony at the Unitarian Church in Montclair, N.J.

title: OPERA: THE ZARZUELA, A SPANISH TRADITION
description: An American with a knowledge of Broadway musicals, operetta or opera will find some aspects of familiarity in zarzuela, the Spanish popular opera that has been the focus for the past week, through today, of master classes, a panel discussion and, on Thursday evening, a concert at Alice Tully Hall that offered a sampling of songs from more than a dozen zarzuelas.

title: CHRONICLER IS AN ASSET FOR BANKS
description: The last article in the banking series is on Page 34

title: REACHING THE TOP IN FOOTBALL
description: WHEN Steve Young graduated from Greenwich High School in 1980, he defined success in a quote beneath his picture in the class yearbook.

title: COOKING
description: THE COOKING OF SOUTH-WEST FRANCE; A Collection of Traditional and New Recipes From France's Magnificent Rustic Cuisine. By Paula Wolfert. Illustrated. 356 pp. New York: The Dial Press/Doubleday & Co. $24.95.

title: JUST HOW FAIR IS AFFIRMATIVE ACTION?
description: The Reagan Administration's attack on affirmative action plans using quotas was pursued on two fronts last week.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: FICTION 116 PET SEMATARY, by Stephen King. (Doubleday, $15.95.) The new family in town discovers the horrors that lie in a neighboring cemetery. 2215 POLAND, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) Seven centuries of history in fictional form. 3325 THE NAME OF THE ROSE, by Umberto Eco. (Helen & Kurt Wolff/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $15.95.) Unraveling the mystery of a murder in a 14th-century Italian monastery. 41015

title: OF THE GRENADA NEWS BLACKOUT AND REACTION AGAINST THE MEDIA
description: To the Editor: I, too, was surprised to discover a public ''exasperation'' with the news media, as revealed by a majority sup

title: COWBOYS AND REDSKINS: BIG ROLE FOT BIT PLAYERS
description: DALLAS RON SPRINGS, who had always been a productive fullback for the Dallas Cowboys, ran and caught the ball so infrequently last season that he thought the coaches were ''phasing me out.'' Mark Murphy, the Washington Redskins' free safety who had intercepted 19 passes in the previous four seasons, including one in Super Bowl XVII, was nearly replaced before this season because the Redskin coaches were so concerned about the overall speed of the secondary.

title: EXIT, PURSUED BY A BEAR
description: THE ISLAND OF CRIMEA

title: DISTINCTIVE VOICES DISPLAY THE VIGOR OF THE CABARETS
description: That there is more to New York's cabaret life than pop singers, comedians and even an occasional girlie show is indicated by three new albums that reveal what else can be found in New York's night clubs from time to time.

title: Correction
description: A chart last week accompanying an article about the American Telephone and Telegraph Company misstated the age of Morris Tanenbaum, the company's executive vice president. He is 55.

title: THE REMAKING OF A WRITER
description: JOSEPH CONRAD

title: Correction
description: In ''What's Doing in Albuquerque'' (Travel, Nov. 20) the toll-free telephone number of the Regent of Albuquerque hotel was given incorrectly. The number is 800-545-4000.

title: SEEKING ENERGY FROM THE SEA
description: DR. BUD BRINKHUIS is a farmer, but he requires no land to grow his crop. And when his product - seaweed - is ready for market, he hopes to turn it into an alternative energy source.

title: 4 Soldiers Wounded By Bombing in London
description: A bomb exploded at the Royal Artillery Barracks in the Woolwich district of southeast London before dawn today, slightly wounding four soldiers.

title: CHILDREN'S CLASSICS ON NEW CASSETTES
description: Although not as numerous as snowflakes on a mountain top, children's video cassettes are increasing in quantity and quality. Here are five recent releases, for example, any of which might be considered for Christmas giving. Each has its own virtues, special appeal and an occasional fault. Fortunately, the faults are not serious enough to hinder the viewer's pleasure.

title: IN THE END, FRUSTRATION
description: For the Jets, each of their 20 seasons at Shea Stadium always opened as brightly as the glow of

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: 'Withdrawal'Or Suicide?

title: AN INSIDER'S VIEW OF THE PHILHARMONIC
description: WHEN Bert Bial walks on stage at Avery Fisher Hall with his New York Philharmonic colleagues, he carries a Leica CL camera neatly tucked in his pocket. In addition to playing contrabassoon, he is the orchestra's official photographer.

title: Bordering on Immigration Reform
description: Over the border, there lies the promised land

title: ARFAT AIDE REPORTS 2D ISRAELI ATTACK
description: An aide to Yasir Arafat said today that Israeli gunboats attacked Palestine Liberation Organization forces here for a second time during the night, but he was unable to provide details or any evidence that the attack had occurred.

title: LEG-HOLD TRAPS SHOULD BE BANNED
description: RECENTLY, there was a newspaper account of Baron, a shepherd-collie mixed breed that had been missing for more than two weeks.

title: COMMUNITY GROUPS CITED FOR IMPROVING THEIR NEIGHBORHOOD
description: The Citizens Committee for New York City distributed cash awards totaling $8,075 to 41 community groups at a ceremony in the Blue Room of City Hall last week for a variety of neighborhood beautification projects.

title: CALL OF THE BULL MEESE
description: The heart-stopping political blunder was spread all across the top of the front page of The Washington Post: ''Discussing Hunger in U.S., Meese Sparks a Firestorm.'' Tom Brokaw led NBC Nightly News with the report that was rocking Washington of a derogation of the hungry by White House Counselor Edwin Meese 3d.

title: THE AFTERMATH OF A CHILD'S MURDER
description: ''You think of all the ways your child could die, and murder never enters your mind.''

title: SUNDAY, DECEMBER 11, 1983;  International
description: Argentina's military rule ended with the inauguration of Raul Ricardo Alfonsin as President amid joyous celebrations. Thousands of people gathered in the streets of Buenos Aires to cheer the President, a political moderate and leader of the Radi? cal Party, whose election has given?the country hope for a new beginning. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: MYOPIC POLICY TOWARD SYRIA
description: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria has emerged from years of isolation and placed himself at the power switch of Middle East policy. As long as his health holds up, no one who seeks influence in the region can afford to ignore him. Yet the United States' reactions to his new power have been sadly shortsighted and simplistic.

title: Couples's Team Takes Mixed Golf
description: Fred Couples and Jan Stephenson shot a final-round 69 today to win the $550,000 Mixed Team Classic with a record 72-hole total of 24-under-par 264.

title: NETWORKS ARE RE-EVALUATING EARLY-MORNING TV
description: News Analysis

title: PENALTY FOILS LATE BID BY GIANTS
description: The Giants lost a football game today that they could not have come closer to winning.

title: Young Is Angry
description: General Manager George Young angrily refused to comment on a CBS- TV report that the Giants might dismiss Parcells after his first season as head coach and replace him with Howard Schnellenberger, the University of Miami coach. ''Bill is the coach,'' said Young.

title: CommoditiesH. J. Maidenberg;  New Aluminum Setup
description: W HEN the Commodity Exchange of New York opened its aluminum futures market last Thursday, it did more than add a new product to its gold, silver and copper futures and gold options markets. It began a process that is expected to change the way the metal has been priced since its usage became widespread after World War II.

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 12, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: MONDAY, DECEMBER 12, 1983 International
description: The Pope joined a Lutheran service in a Protestant church in Rome, the first time since the Reformation that a Pope had done so. The extradordinary ecumenical gesture, marking the 500th anniversary of Martin Luther's birth, was brought about by a spontaneous invitation last year by a board member of the Evangelical-Lutheran Christ Church. The service was held at Christ Church, off the Via Vittorio Veneto. (Page A1, Col. 6.) Lech Walesa remains convinced that his country's problems can only be solved through a dialogue between the Polish Government and Poles. In his remarks, made in the Nobel Peace Prize address read for him in Oslo by an exile Solidarity official, Mr. Walesa also repeated indirectly his appeal for an end to United States sanctions against Poland. He said Poland faced a major economic crisis, with ''dramatic consequences for the very existence of Polish families,'' which could have serious repercussions in Europe. (A1:4.)

title: DESEGREGATION STIRS DISMAY IN 2 TEXAS HOUSING PROJECTS
description: Like most of the other elderly whites who have been ordered by a Federal judge to move out of their apartments and swap places with black tenants on the other side of town, 84-year-old Frank Dale is stunned and angry.

title: KINDERGARTEN FOR ALL IS NOW CITY POLICY
description: In a move that turns tradition into policy, the New York City Schools Chancellor and the Board of Education have decided that a kindergarten education must be given to any eligible 5-year-old whose parents request it.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: If a batter accidentally strikes the catcher's mitt before hitting safely in the same swing, what is the ruling?

title: TIMES BOOK REVIEW PLANS EXPANDED BEST SELLER LISTS
description: Beginning Jan. 1, The New York Times Book Review will introduce revised and expanded best seller lists to clarify categories of book buying.

title: Phoui Sananikone Dies at 80; An Ex-Prime Minister of Laos
description: Phoui Sananikone, former Prime Minister and Foreign Minister of Laos, has died in Paris, according to friends.

title: SUBWAY SOUNDS AND SIGHTS Paint Job
description: The IND-BMT station at Cortelyou Road, in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, is looking better these days because a group of residents, tired of waiting for the Transit Authority, decided to spruce it up themselves.

title: ROHATYN SEES OBSTACLES TO CITY ECONOMY'S GROWTH
description: New York City's economy, which has been fairly robust in recent years, faces new and serious obstacles to its stability and growth in the next several years, according to Felix G. Rohatyn, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in the special Personal Investing section on Nov. 20 about an investment newsletter, The Professional Tape Reader, misidentified its founder. He is Justin Mamis.

title: MUSEUM IS OFFERING A CLOSE ENCOUNTER WITH U.F.O. STUDIES
description: --There are plenty of unidentified flying objects in this Sierra Nevada community, but none of them are flying.

title: DIPLOMATIC TIES WITH THE VATICAN: FOR U.S., AN OLD AND DIVISIVE QUESTION
description: The move by the Reagan Administration to upgrade relations between the United States and the Vatican has reopened an old debate on the meaning of the separation of church and state. Politics, law and religion are factors in an issue that has emerged periodically for decades.

title: A GRIM AGREEMENT
description: Soviet -American relations are at the lowest level since l962, with a major channel of communications - nuclear arms control talks - probably closed at least until after the 1984 elections. But important Soviet-American agreement was recently reached in Washington, as scientists from both nations concurred on the most vital matter of all:

title: BUSH CONFERS WITH ARGENTINE CHIEF
description: Vice President Bush left Argentina today after talks with the country's new President, Raul Alfonsin, that were said to have touched on such sensitive issues as Argentina's nuclear development program, its difficulty in repaying its $40 billion foreign debt, and United States intervention in Central America.

title: WILANDER TAKES CROWN
description: Mats Wilander's 6-1, 6-4, 6-4 victory over Ivan Lendl in the Australian Open final today represented a new level for the 19-year-old Swede and continued frustration for the 23-year- old Czechoslovak.

title: Lynne Meadow Weds a Lawyer
description: Carolyn Elizabeth Meadow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Meadow of New Haven, was married yesterday to Ronald H. Shechtman, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Allen Shechtman of West Hartford, Conn. Rabbis Robert Goldberg and Sheldon Zimmerman performed the ceremony at the Central Synagogue in New York.

title: ISSUE OF REAPPORTIONMENT PERSISTS IN JAPAN
description: No matter what happens in Japan's national elections next Sunday, the odds are good that the courts will eventually declare the results unconstitutional.

title: Britain Seeks to Revive Ties With Argentina
description: Britain said today that it wanted to begin restoring ties with Argentina but repeated its determination not to discuss sovereignty of the Falkland Islands.

title: Smith Fund
description: Before the game, NFL Charities made a $2,000 grant to the Red Smith Writing Scholarship Fund at Notre Dame. Wellington Mara, the Giants' president, presented the check to Joseph Vecchione, the sports editor of The New York Times and chairman of the fund campaign. The scholarship is a memorial to Mr. Smith, a Notre Dame graduate and former sports columnist for The Times.

title: John Henry Wins and Is First to Top $4 Million
description: John Henry rallied in the final yards to capture the $500,000 Hollywood Turf Cup by a half-length today and become the first $4 million winner in thoroughbred history.

title: Kansas City Board Studied
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission is investigating trading at the Kansas City Board of Trade, according to the exchange's president.

title: Isolation Cited in Rate Of Suicides in Alaska
description: One of every 100 residents of northwest Alaska has tried to kill himself this year, and nine people have succeeded in their attempts, officials say.

title: TEXT OF WALESA LECTURE READ AT NOBEL CEREMONY
description: Following is the text of Lech Walesa's Nobel Peace Prize lecture, delivered today by Bogdan Cywinsky, an exile leader of the Solidarity union, and translated by the Norwegian Foreign Ministry from the Polish:

title: Dump Owner Seeks Cleanup
description: A part-owner of one of California's worst toxic-waste dumps has sued the Shell Oil Company, the Dow Chemical Company and the Federal Government, demanding that they clean up materials they deposited there more than 40 years ago.

title: LITTON ASKS PANEL ON LABOR
description: The chairman of Litton Industries has proposed that the company, a major military equipment contractor, attempt to resolve a series of escalating disputes with several employee unions in direct talks monitored by ''a neutral chairman.''

title: MEMORIES OF LOSSES MAY HAVE HURT JETS
description: Do the Pittsburgh Steelers simply have more will to win than the New York Jets? And are the Jets prisoners of their losing past, doomed to repeat their failures in crucial situations?

title: Soviet Tops U.S. In Hockey Series
description: A Soviet all-star team parlayed goals 46 seconds apart in the second period by Vladimir Kovin and Sergei Kharin to beat the United States Olympic Team, 6-1, tonight. The victory evened the six-game series between the teams at 1-1, with the third game Monday night in Cleveland.

title: Margaret-Mary Murphy Wed in Jersey
description: -Mary Murphy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Murphy of Far Hills, N.J., and Groton Long Point, Conn., was married yesterday to David J. Ryder, son of Mr. and Mrs. John William Ryder of Boise, Idaho. The Rev. Michael Alliegro performed the ceremony at St. Brigid Roman Catholic Church in Far Hills.

title: NEW YORK LULLABIES, ON TAPE
description: In a Chinese restaurant on Division Street, the busy proprietors also tend their baby. So, to catch Annie Chu singing ''The Purple Bamboo Flute,'' a haunting lullaby in Mandarin, Julia Lebentritt set her cassette recorder on a table near the pungent kitchen.

title: TRUMP ACE: MICHAELS
description: FROM the ashes of the Jets and Giants this season, Walt Michaels is apparently about to rise as the New Jersey Generals' new coach.

title: A Version in English Of French Magazine
description: George Green, president of The New Yorker magazine, and Daniel Filipacchi, head of Hachette, the major French publishing company, agreed last Thursday to work together to bring out and sell a one-shot English-language version of Elle, the French fashion magazine. The French will be in charge of the editorial content and production, and the Americans will be in charge of advertising sales and promotion.

title: A Puzzle for Peking: Same-Name Children
description: The authorities in northeast China say they are overwhelmed with keeping track of people with the same name, including 4,800 women with the same name, and as a result they have written a guide to naming babies.

title: PLAN FOR BIG DUMP STIRS TAMPA FIGHT
description: A company's proposal to build a huge radioactive gypsum dump near a residential area with a school has brought on a campaign that pits Florida's powerful phosphate and fertilizer industry against its growing health and environmental safety lobby.

title: PAPACY'S POSITION ON NUNS' GARB
description: To the Editor:

title: NOWHERE TO GO BUT UP AS DEVILS MAKE CHANGES
description: -year-old veteran who once played on winning hockey teams with the Philadelphia Flyers and now plays for the New Jersey Devils, a losing team. He has a reputation as a hard worker, but losses rubbed on him until even that virtue began to erode.

title: Common Stock
description: * Abbott Laboratories said its board authorized the repurchase of up to 1.5 million of its common shares on the open market or in private transactions during the next 12 months.

title: FOLK: JUDY COLLINS AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: JUDY Collins explored more than half a dozen different musical avenues in her Carnegie Hall concert on Friday. Opening her two-hour show with Paul Williams's ''I Won't Last a Day Without You,'' she went on to perform a far-reaching repertory that included country-rock songs, Jacques Brel, Rodgers and Hart, Bob Dylan's ''Mr. Tambourine Man,'' and finally, ''Amazing Grace.''

title: THE LESSON OF A JAIL RELEASE PROGRAM
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. MOVE ON NICARAGUA DOUBTED
description: President Belisario Betancur of Colombia said today that he believed the likelihood of imminent United States military intervention in Nicaragua had eased.

title: John Birch Group Marks Its 25th Anniversary
description: Some 1,200 delegates celebrated the 25th anniversary of the John Birch Society at a one-day convention Saturday in the city where the conservative organization was founded.

title: DEADLOCK OVER BANK REGULATION
description: The Reagan Administration's year-long effort to streamline the financial regulatory system is in jeopardy and now appears unlikely to lead to legislative recommendations in 1984.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: 100 Years of the Journal

title: HOLLYWOOD GAMBLES ON VIDEO
description: Some of Hollywood's most important movies this Christmas may be playing on video cassette recorders.

title: Black Officers Settle Milwaukee Police Suit
description: City officials and representatives of a group of black police officers say they will sign a settlement this week that will fully integrate the Police Department and end a two-year civil rights lawsuit.

title: Patrick Mehr, Consultant, Weds Prof. Helen Epstein
description: Helen Epstein, an associate professor of journalism at New York University, was married yesterday to Patrick Mehr, a management consultant with Resource Planning Associates in Cambridge, Mass. Rabbi David Teutsch performed the ceremony at Temple Ansche Chesed in New York.

title: Marybeth Kurdock Is Wed
description: Marybeth Kurdock, an actress, singer and dancer, was married yesterday to Dr. Philip Cohen, chairman of the department of orthopedic surgery at St. Joseph's Hospital and Medical Center in Paterson, N.J. Rabbi Arnold Belzer performed the ceremony at the couple's home in Franklin Lakes, N.J. The bride, who will retain her name professionally, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Kurdock of Hawthorne, N.J. Mr. Cohen is the son of the late Mrs. William Cohen of Philadelphia and the late Mr. Cohen of Manville, N.J. The previous marriage of each ended in divorce.

title: Psychiatrist Fights Cost Of Mental Health Care
description: Jay S. Reibel, M.D., fumes about the cost of corporate mental health care. ''It's crazy for companies to pay extensive psychiatric claims off a claims form without really knowing what they're paying for,'' the 42-year- old psychiatrist-businessman said.

title: RURAL PHONE USERS ASSAILING EQUIPMENT AND SLOW REPAIRS
description: ''Here we are, able to talk to men in outer space, and some of us down here on earth can't even get telephones installed in our own homes!''

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Dec. 12, 1983: MONDAY Bristol-MyersInterco IncBunker Hill Inc Sec

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: HAPPY BIRTHDAY Victor Herbert's operetta ''Sweethearts'' made its Broadway debut just 70 years ago, and its mellifluous, if saccharine, tunes have been addictive to generations of fans ever since. Tonight at 8 o'clock, ''Sweethearts'' will be heard less than a block from Broadway, in concert form, at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street (840-2840).

title: DR PEPPER REJECTS BID FROM DPCC
description: Directors of the Dr Pepper Company have rejected a buy-out offer of $24 a share from the DPCC Acquisition Corporation, a subsidiary of Castle & Cooke Inc., as ''too uncertain as to the price and timing.'' Instead, the soft-drink company's directors plan to ask shareholders to accept an offer of $22 a share made by Forstmann Little & Company, a private New York investment house.

title: BANGLADESH LEADER IN MILITARY REGIME ASSUMES PRESIDENCY
description: The head of this nation's military Government proclaimed himself President today and dissolved his Cabinet. The move appeared to be an attempt to consolidate his power before the presidential election that he has called for next May.

title: FED'S ELECTION ROLE GENERATING DEBATE
description: Every four years, money market economists and investors supplement the regular tools of their trade with speculation about the Federal Reserve's role in electing the next President.

title: FAMILY WAGE-GONE
description: Labor is feeling pressure to bring wages down, in order, it is said, to enhance efficiency and competitiveness. Beset economically, we fail to notice that people's ability to support themselves has declined for some years, and this, too, may undermine the economy, not to speak of society.

title: The Worm and the Apple Subway Sounds and Sights
description: All A-Twitter

title: THE CITY CENTER TO CELEBRATE 40TH BIRTHDAY
description: LIFE at the City Center has never been dull. Helen Hayes was once put up as collateral to save its opera. Maria Tallchief got baked chickens instead of flowers from a fan. The audience used to call ''Hello, Lenny!'' when Leonard Bernstein stepped to the podium. And Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia set the tone from the very beginning one rainy Saturday night 40 years ago. On Dec. 11, 1943, the center's opening night, he took the baton away from Artur Rodzinski and conducted ''The Star-Spangled Banner'' himself.

title: Moscow Police Stop A John Lennon Rally
description: The police seized at least three young people who had gathered in a small, quiet rally today to remember John Lennon, who was killed three years ago in New York.

title: WISHES OF VERY ILL CHILDREN GRANTED BY VOLUNTEER GROUP
description: In a cramped office in this Massachuchsetts mill town, some unlikely dream makers are granting last wishes to children who may never grow up.

title: LEONARD'S RETURN: THE CHALLENGE OF GREATER GLORY
description: The morning after he announced his return to boxing after more than a year in retirement, Sugar Ray Leonard greeted a group of reporters who had been waiting for him and apologized for being late.

title: BRITISH PRINTERS PLAN NEW STRIKE
description: Britain's largest printers' union, embroiled in a prolonged controversy over Britain's new labor laws, has announced plans for a one-day strike on Wednesday to shut down national and regional newspapers.

title: DR. CLYDE W. MASON
description: Dr. Clyde W. Mason, professor emeritus of chemical engineering at Cornell University and an internationally recognized authority on light microscopy, died Thursday at his home here.

title: THE FLAME BURNS
description: It was an extraordinary piece of unintended symbolism: the Soviet Union paying tribute to the power of human rights as an idea. That was the result of a curious event in Moscow last week.

title: Mr. Koch's Affirmative Accounting
description: What's a racial or ethnic quota in hiring? Does Mayor Koch employ the kind of quota he deplores when he demands greater diversity on the committee that helps him choose judges for New York's Criminal and Family Courts? Francis T. Murphy Jr., the Presiding Justice of the First Department, thought he could taunt the Mayor with that reproach while resisting the demand. But here was a case where Mr. Koch had his definitions as well as his priorities right.

title: WASTE BEARING PLUTONIUM FOUND IN A WELL AT UPSTATE NUCLEAR SITE
description: Kerosene contaminated with plutonium has been found in a surveillance well at a nuclear waste dump in West Valley, N.Y. An official said it had apparently leaked from a burial site 60 feet away.

title: THEATER: 'NOISES OFF,' A BRITISH FARCE BY FRAYN
description: PROD them a little, and congenital theatergoers will admit the dark and dirty truth: The most calamitous nights in the theater can be almost as memorable as the most successful. It's strangely involving to watch actors struggle heroically in a ludicrous play. When absolutely everything goes wrong on stage, as when everything goes right, we're treated to drama that is urgent, spontaneous, unmistakably alive.

title: Menorah in Bronx Is Vandalized
description: A 10-foot-wide metal Hanukkah menorah on a traffic island was knocked to the ground and partly smashed over the weekend in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: MUSIC NOTED IN BRIEF;
description: Conservatory Performs All-Beethoven Concert

title: City Is Assessing Damage at Shea
description: Henry J. Stern, the city's Parks Commissionmer, said yesterday that he would send a crew to Shea Stadium today to assess the damage done by angry fans after the final New York Jets football game there.

title: Kupchak Regaining His Form in Return
description: From where he was sitting for much of the last two seasons, more than 25 rows above the court at the Forum, Mitch Kupchak was confused. ''I knew that that was my team down there,'' he said, referring to the Los Angeles Lakers. ''But there was something wrong. I really didn't want to be around them. I'd show up just after the national anthem and leave right after the final buzzer.

title: Government Backs Woman On Race and Custody Issue
description: The Reagan Administration, siding with a white Florida woman who lost custody of her 6-year-old daughter after she married a black man, has told the Supreme Court that race should not be a factor in custody decisions.

title: VIETNAM VETERANS OF AMERICA GROWS IN SIZE AND LOBBYING POWER
description: It was not so long ago that the Vietnam Veterans of America was looking for members, money and recognition. But all that has changed.

title: BEJEWELED CITY GLOWS WITH SPIRIT OF HOLIDAY
description: Night falls swiftly now, the early darkness a splendid backdrop for the city bejeweled for Christmas. Red and green lights glitter atop skyscrapers and in thousands of apartment windows.

title: OILERS WIN SECOND BY BEATING BROWNS
description: Tim Smith caught two touchdown passes, the second a 43-yarder with 6 minutes 17 seconds to play, to lead Houston to a 34-27 victory over Cleveland today.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Fighting Words

title: SMYSLOV APPROACHES VICTORY WITH A DRAW
description: Sixty-two- year-old Vasily Smyslov of the Soviet Union drew a step closer to victory in his semifinal world championship chess match tonight by drawing his ninth game with 32-year-old Zoltan Ribli of Hungary tonight.

title: HOOVER KEPT DAMAGING REPORTS ON MANY IN FILES, MAGAZINE SAYS
description: Thousands of pages of documents from the long-secret files of J. Edgar Hoover, who directed the Federal Bureau of Investigation from 1924 until his death in 1974, contain defamatory reports on many of the nation's most powerful political figures, it was reported today.

title: No Headline
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be reported this week. Monday

title: 49ERS RALLY TO BEAT BILLS, 23-10
description: The San Francisco 49ers dressed for the weather. Several players wore panty hose under their uniforms and most had gloves, and the space heaters were set up next to the bench. Although it was not that cold at Rich Stadium, 28 degrees, perhaps the warming measures were effective today, because the 49ers were a hot team in the second half against the Buffalo Bills.

title: DONORS TO THE NEEDIEST CASES WANT TO GIVE HELP TO ELDERLY
description: The contrasting images of holiday gaiety and the distress of the city's poor and lonely come together at the Christmas season. Seeking to brighten lives and ease the distress, contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund often ask that their gifts be used to help the vulnerable elderly.

title: Fire Bomb Is Thrown Into Russians' Estate
description: A gasoline-filled bottle was thrown onto the grounds of an estate here used by the Soviet Mission to the United Nations early today, setting off a small grass fire, the Nassau County police said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We long for unity, and we strive for this unity without letting ourselves be discouraged by the difficulties that may pile up along the way.'' - Pope John Paul II in the Evangelical-Lutheran Christ Church. (A1:6.)

title: NELA RUBINSTEIN: MAKING A LIFE OF HER OWN
description: When the pianist Arthur Rubinstein met Aniela Mlynarska in Warsaw in 1926 he described the meeting as a ''coup de foudre'' - a thunderbolt. Rubinstein was nearly 40 years old and Nela (a diminutive of her name, which means angel in Polish) was 18. She was the daughter of Emil Mlynarski, director of the Warsaw Symphony, and had come backstage during a Rubinstein concert.

title: Thousands Slain, Indonesian Charges
description: Indonesia's death squads may have killed up to 4,000 suspected criminals in a drive against crime in the last nine months, the country's leading human rights activist said today.

title: MUSIC NOTED IN BRIEF;
description: Miss Cain and Roy Kral In Cy Coleman Program

title: CITRUS FARMERS HOLD OF REAGAN PLANS
description: Under pressure from growers, the Reagan Administration has reversed itself and plans to continue a 50-year-old Federal policy that permits farmers to control the volume and price of certain crops by agreements among themselves.

title: BALLET: 'BACH PARTITA,' TWYLA THARP PREMIERE
description: The American Ballet Theater has started its first week here at the Kennedy Center with the equivalent of a fireworks display. There have been a cluster of revivals, new stagings and premieres. The most important so far was Friday night's world premiere of ''Bach Partita,'' an ambitious and eye-filling ballet by Twyla Tharp.

title: HONG KONG'S SHAKY REBOUND
description: The hotels are packed. The stores are teeming with shoppers. Exports are streaming toward foreign markets.

title: HOUSING VOUCHERS SUPPORTED BY U.S.
description: The Reagan Administration is seeking to make a major change in the way it helps poor people pay for rental housing by expanding an experimental system of vouchers, Administration officials said today.

title: HOLMES YIELDS W.B.C. TITLE
description: Larry Holmes resigned his World Boxing Council heavyweight title today and said he would fight as champion of the fledgling International Boxing Federation.

title: NETS BEAT NUGGETS IN SHOOTOUT, 141-130
description: The Nets got involved in a playground shootout with the Denver Nuggets tonight and came away with several season, individual and team scoring highs and a club record for field goals in a game.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Lighting Up the Holidays

title: TREASURY OFFERINGS REMAIN LIGHT
description: The credit markets will enjoy another week of respite from Treasury financings: this week's only sale of Government securities is the regular weekly auction of three- and six- month bills.

title: Diocese of Pittsburgh Installs Brooklyn Cleric
description: Some 2,000 people jammed St. Paul's Cathedral today to witness the formal installation of the Most Rev. Anthony J. Bevilacqua as bishop of the Diocese of Pittsburgh, the nation's third largest.

title: WALESA APPEALS IN NOBEL LECTURE FOR POLISH TALKS
description: Lech Walesa, who was awarded the 1983 Nobel Peace Prize in absentia here Saturday, said today that he remained convinced that his country's problems could only be solved through a dialogue between the Polish Government and the people.

title: Tanzania Derailment Kills 20
description: A train loaded with schoolchildren heading home for the Christmas holidays was derailed by vandals, killing at least 20 people and seriously injuring 79, the Tanzania said today. The police said the death toll could rise as rescue workers search the wreckage for bodies. The state-run press agancy quoted Tanzanian Railway officials as saying vandals placed an iron bar across the tracks.

title: NEEDED: SUMMIT TALKS
description: As a result of my discussions with Russian and American arms negotiators, I found the Soviet Union's decision last week to suspend the strategic arms reduction talks unfortunate but not surprising. The fact is, as both sides concede, the Start talks had already stopped. They may resume, but they cannot succeed unless President Reagan and the Soviet leader, Yuri V. Andropov, meet face-to-face.

title: Market PlaceMichael Blumstein Awaiting a Lift From Earnings
description: A DROP in interest rates fueled the bull market in August 1982, but in recent months, some analysts have been predicting that corporate profits would overshadow interest rates and determine the market's fate. So far, it does not seem to have happened.

title: DOLE SETS HEARINGS ON DEFICIT
description: Senator Bob Dole, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, upset with the failure by Congress to approve a deficit-reduction package before adjourning for the year, plans to get a fresh start on the subject Monday.

title: FAST-FOOD CHAINS TRY NEW MARKETS
description: The nation's fast-food chains, their unit sales squeezed by proliferating competition and every-corner-in-the- nation siting, are looking with a new appreciation at two of the country's last major untapped markets - the military and institutions.

title: THIS YOUNG FOUNDATION HOPES TO HELP THE OLD
description: In a city that abounds in foundations and associations, one fledgling hopes to efface whatever negative connotation the word ''old'' has and to give it dignity, luster and a meaning in American life that will transform stereotyped attitudes about the country's millions of elderly citizens.

title: Medical View On Leonard
description: When Sugar Ray Leonard announced plans Saturday night to resume his boxing career after more than a year's retirement, he gave special thanks to Dr. Ron Michels, whom he credited with restoring his left eye ''back to normal.''

title: AID IS STRAINED IN UPPER VOLTA
description: A young American Peace Corps volunteer in Diapaga, a village near the Niger border, recently asked her students what would happen if the long-awaited rains did not come and the crops failed.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Lincoln Center's Circus

title: KNICKS TOP LAKERS WITH EASE, 109-98
description: They used to call them Showtime. But for the Los Angeles Lakers, who are playing without the injured Earvin (Magic) Johnson until January, it's intermission.

title: DELAYED SHUTTLE LANDING RUINS SOME EXPERIMENTS
description: Some valuable medical research was lost because the delay in landing the space shuttle Columbia left its Spacelab crew too tired to perform important post-flight experiments, a scientist says.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in some editions of Weekend on Friday misidentified the composer of ''Vermont Counterpoint.'' He is Steve Reich.

title: POPE, CITING HOPE FOR UNITY, TAKES PART IN LUTHERAN RITE
description: Text of Pope's sermon, page A12.

title: Jupiter Symphony Plays Works By 2 Composers
description: To feel the joy of re-creation - as presumably performing musicians do - is not the same as to convey it. And it is this rare talent that makes Jupiter Symphony concerts events to be anticipated. Saturday night's audience at Alice Tully Hall, at any rate, seemed to share in the intense happiness felt by these young musicians on stage as they made music with their conductor Jens Nygaard.

title: Stephanie Lederman Weds Alan Adolph, Lawyer
description: Stephanie Lederman, daughter of Nathan Lederman and the late Ruth Lederman of Forest Hills, Queens, was married yesterday to Alan Adolph, son of Helen Adolph and the late Dr. Seymour Adolph of Riverdale, the Bronx. Rabbi Jon Hadden, dean of the School of Sacred Music of the Hebrew Union College in New York, performed the ceremony at the Tappan Hill restaurant in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: CARNEGIE HERO COMMISSION HONORS 21 FOR THEIR BRAVERY
description: Steven Faulkner says he did not consider the cold or the danger when he plunged into the Skagit River in Washington to save a woman from drowning.

title: Borrowers Must Be Choosy
description: Partnerships formed in adversity frequently crumble in the gleam of unexpected wealth. For a time, that seemed the destiny of the entente born in bankruptcy among New York City, New York State and their crisis broker, the Municipal Assistance Corporation. Now that much of the new wealth has been properly identified as borrowed, perhaps the partnership can continue.

title: NEW VENEZUELA LEADER SEES DEBT AS NO. 1 ISSUE
description: After a landslide victory last week, Venezuela's President-elect, Jaime Lusinchi, has promised decisive action to relieve a growing economic crisis, with his first priority the renegotiation of Venezuela's $34 billion of foreign debt. But even with firm political leadership and a debt restructuring, analysts say the nation faces years of tight living.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Chief's Market Plan At Castle & Cooke

title: $120,000 Robbery Of Armored Car
description: An armored car collecting theater receipts was hijacked in midtown Manhattan early yesterday by a gunman who escaped with $120,000 after pistol-whipping a guard, the police reported. A second guard was hurt when he leaped from the moving truck, which rammed a parked car.

title: IN SALVADOR, BUSH ASSAILS DEATH SQUADS
description: Vice President Bush told Salvadoran officials tonight that if the Government here did not ''honor basic human decencies'' it would ''lose that crucial battle for the support and approval of the people.''

title: 2d Death Trial Set for Biegenwald
description: Richard F. Biegenwald, who was sentenced to death last week following a murder conviction, will stand trial in February for another of the four killings for which he has been indicted, officials said.

title: GLENN SHIFT IS SOUGHT ON HOMOSEXUAL ISSUE
description: The State Senate Minority Leader, Manfred Ohrenstein, said yesterday that he would try to persuade Senator John H. Glenn to reverse his opposition to proposed Federal legislation banning discrimination against homosexuals.

title: FIGHTING ERUPTS NEAR BEIRUT, ENDING A 2-DAY LULL
description: Heavy fighting broke out south of here and continued for five hours tonight, disrupting two days of relative calm in the region after a cease-fire arranged in Damascus on Friday.

title: The Machine Tool Behind the Gun
description: Machine tools are not really tools but sophisticated equipment, sometimes computer-controlled, for making everything from jam jars to jumbo jets. Because they are integral to industry, one should pay heed when producers say foreign competition threatens the national security. They want machine tool imports cut by about half, to 17.5 percent of the American market.

title: Saints, in Overtime, Beat Eagles, 20-17
description: Morten Andersen's 50-yard field goal gave New Orleans a 20-17 overtime victory over Philadelphia today and kept alive the Saints' hopes for a playoff berth.

title: MOVIEGOERS' LIKELY HOLIDAY CHOICES ARE STUDIED
description: It is still about two weeks until Christmas, but Hollywood does not want to wait to discover what goodies will fill its Christmas stocking.

title: AN OLD PRO'S POINTERS FOR DEMOCRATS
description: Robert S. Strauss, a salty-tongued Texan who served as Jimmy Carter's Presidential campaign chairman in 1980, is something of a honey tree of political advice in the nation's capital. His private counsel is sought by Democratic Presidential candidates, including most of the current contenders, and what he tells them is one of the better kept secrets in Washington.

title: 2 San Diego Boys Killed As Old Shell Explodes
description: Two boys were killed and another was injured by a mortar shell they set off while playing in a canyon used by the Marine Corps for exercises in World War II, the officials said today.

title: Washington WatchJonathan Fuerbringer Negotiations In Textile Fight WASHINGTON
description: S ENATOR Strom Thurmond, Republican of South Carolina, Senator Jesse A. Helms, Republican of North Carolina, and other leaders of the Congressional textile caucus will call on President Reagan at the White House tomorrow, intensifying speculation about forthcoming decisions in the dispute with China over textile imports.

title: National Zoo Fears Panda May Not Be Able to Conceive
description: National Zoo officials said today that the panda Ling-Ling's life-threatening kidney problem can be treated, but they are not certain she will recover or, if she does, whether she will be able to conceive.

title: Miss Zayak Wins Figure Skating
description: Elaine Zayak of Paramus, N.J., and the Skating Club of New York won the senior women's title in the Eastern figure skating championships at the Wissahickon Skating Club.

title: Pop: At Savoy, Spandau Ballet
description: SPANDAU BALLET is one of many English pop groups that have been labeled ''new romantics'' because their self- presentation affects a supper-club elegance and their songs embrace a traditional pop sentimentality. Like other ''new romantics,'' the group doesn't merely recreate an older pop ethos; it wants to update pop romanticism with contemporary guitar and synthesizer arrangements and an ''international'' rhythmic palette that includes light funk, calypso and assorted Latin dance grooves.

title: ATLANTIC CITY MAYOR'S OFFICE IS RAIDED BY FEDERAL AGENTS
description: Federal agents seized scores of documents from the office of Atlantic City's Mayor last week, and a Justice Department official said yesterday that the action was part of an inquiry into allegations that Atlantic City officials have taken bribes from developers.

title: Advertising; Next: Crop Chemicals Directory
description: TELL a publisher that his new operation will have neither editorial nor circulation costs, and he will probably think he has died and gone to heaven.

title: NOW THE REAL TEST BEGINS
description: News Analysis

title: Medtronics Aide Indicted MIAMI, Dec. 11 (AP) - An executive for the world's largest producer of heart pacemakers was indicted by a Federal grand jury on Friday in connection with a plan to sell trade secrets to a rival company.
description: James J. Krieger, an international marketing director for the Medtronics Corporation in Minneapolis, was arrested in Miami last month while delivering 19 confidential documents to an undercover agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, according to the indictment.

title: LOSS OF KEY PLAYER STYMIED COLUMBIA
description: The absence of Amr Aly from midfield because of a leg injury and the inability to get the ball to Dexter Skeene early on attack were the primary reasons why Columbia suffered its first defeat this season in its first national collegiate soccer final.

title: Children's Dance Program
description: Jacques D'Amboise and 80 children from his National Dance Institute will perform at a ''Meet the Artist'' children's program and party in Alice Tully Hall Dec. 22 at noon.

title: 18 COUNTIES LISTED AS TOO 'IMPACTED' FOR MORE REFUGEES
description: The Federal Government today identified 18 counties with high concentrations of refugees and recommended that newcomers to the United States be settled elsewhere to obtain a better geographic balance and improve chances that the refugees will become self-supporting.

title: THE MESS AT MIDFIELD
description: IRVING, Tex.

title: British Seize Computer
description: British authorities today seized American computer systems that they suspect were bound for Czechoslovakia, customs officials said. Six systems worth $750,000 were believed to have come from the United States under a license that banned their resale to any Communist country.

title: PERSHINGS STIR ACCIDENTAL-WAR FEARS
description: As American Pershing 2 missiles are deployed in West Germany just minutes away from the Soviet Union, new attention is being focused on an aspect of nuclear weapons technology that some experts say might eventually lead to an accidental war.

title: Lubovitch Dance Schedule
description: The Lar Lubovitch Dance Company will celebrate its 15th anniversary with a week of performances at City Center Jan. 31 through Feb. 5.

title: TEST CASES CHOSEN IN HERBICIDE TRIAL
description: Five Vietnam veterans, three of whom are dead, have been chosen as test cases in the multibillion-dollar lawsuit against the manufacturers of the wartime herbicide Agent Orange.

title: YEAR-END QUEST FOR FACTS TAKES MANY IN CONGRESS AROUND GLOBE
description: The Caribbean and Western Europe are favored destinations for senators and representatives going on fact-finding missions over the two-month Congressional recess.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: Kissinger Panel to Visit Mexico and Venezuela

title: ; 'ONE CRIMINAL, ONE CELL SHOULD BE THE GOAL'
description: To the Editor:

title: Edward C. Burks, 62; A Journalist 4 Decades
description: Edward C. Burks, a reporter and editor of The New York Times, collapsed and died this morning at his home in Manassas, Va. He was 62 years old.

title: PLAN THREATENS HISTORIC CROSSROADS
description: If there is a gateway to the tradition and aristocracy of this 300-year-old Southern city, it is in the heart of the historic district at the Four Corners of Law.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about Coleco Industries incorrectly described the period for which Morton E. Handel, an executive vice president, predicted a profit. It was all of 1983.

title: COLUMBIA WILL GET A SOCCER STADIUM
description: Lawrence A. Wien, one of Columbia University's largest contributors, has pledged $1 million for a new soccer stadium for the Lions.

title: BULGARIAN EXILES GET REMINDER FROM MOTHERLAND
description: With some trepidation, Stefan Svirdlev, a former colonel in the Bulgarian secret service, saw his wife and 13- year-old son depart from the railway station here on a chilly Saturday last month.

title: Crime Down in China
description: Crime rates in Peking dropped 50 percent in October compared with July, the month before a national crackdown on criminals began, People's Daily reported today. Nationally, recorded criminal cases decreased 46.7 percent from August to September, the paper said.

title: Haig to Advise Amway On Foreign Operations
description: Alexander M. Haig Jr., former Secretary of State, has added the Amway Corporation to the list of companies for which he is a consultant.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Snow Crime

title: BUSINESS DIGEST MONDAY, DECEMBER 12, 1983
description: The Economy

title: MUSIC: SOLISTI PLAYS MINIMALIST WORKS
description: IT was somewhat sad to listen to

title: OUTDOORS: BIRD AND GUN TEST A DOG'S SKILLS TO THE UTMOST
description: WALLKILL, N.Y.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Auction of Edibles

title: ReturnofBarCars Weighed in Jersey
description: N.J. Transit, the state's mass-transit agency, is considering bringing back bar cars on a trial basis after an absence of nearly three years.

title: BRIEFING
description: Postcard Protest

title: Bridge: A Boom for Hotels Presents A Problem on Tournaments
description: The boom in convention business is no doubt a profit for New York City and its hotels, but it is a source of irritation to local organizations seeking space for their functions. The Greater New York Bridge Association, which stages three regional tournaments a year, is one of the victims.

title: WHAT STROKE REHABILITATION INVOLVES
description: To the Editor:

title: REDSKINS ROUT COWBOYS AS THEISMANN, RIGGINS STAR
description: The Washington Redskins waited 15 weeks to get even with the Dallas Cowboys, and they did today, convincingly.

title: The Calendar ;  Monday
description: The Christmas season officially gets under way this week, with the lighting of trees at the Capitol, on the Ellipse and in the White House. Nancy Reagan gives members of the press a preview of Christmas decorations at the White House at 11:30 this morning. In late afternoon, children of foreign diplomats stationed in Washington will be entertained at the first of a series of parties to be held at the White House between now and Christmas.

title: YOUNG STARS SHINE IN CITY SHOW
description: Backstage, there was chaos.

title: A FLOOD OF FUTURE DEFICITS WORTH OUR IMMEDIATE ATTENTION
description: To the Editor:

title: Secret Hitler Archives Exist, Fooled British Paper Asserts
description: A British newspaper, one of two publications fooled by fake Hitler diaries this year, said today that it had established that some of the Nazi leader's secret archives survived a plane crash at the end of World War II.

title: ARABS ASSAIL U.S. POLICIES
description: News Analysis

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Banctexas Group, Dallas, has named Richard L. Ripley president and chief executive officer of Banctexas Dallas and H. W. McNabb executive vice president of the new Houston regional office.

title: MARINE CHIEF DISAVOWS REMARK ABOUT WITHDRAWAL FROM BEIRUT
description: The Commandant of the Marine Corps, Gen. Paul X. Kelley, has disavowed a remark attributed to him on Thursday in which he said he was ''optimistic'' that the Marine Amphibious Unit in Lebanon could be withdrawn early next year.

title: Passenger Shot InHolduponTrain
description: A 23-year-old Norwalk man shot and wounded a passenger on a Metro- North train early yesterday during a holdup in which at least three other passengers were robbed, the Norwalk police said. Minutes later, the police said, the suspect killed a South Norwalk man while trying to break into the victim's apartment.

title: DAMAGE EXTENSIVE
description: Bombs exploded outside the United States Embassy in Kuwait, a residential complex used by Americans and other foreign personel and at the airport there early this morning, the State Department said.

title: NEW LEGAL AID CHIEF WARNS OF BAD TIMES
description: A few weeks ago, Arthur L. Liman, the new president of the Legal Aid Society, called together members of the city's top law firms and pleaded for their help. Without it, he warned, the society's future was in doubt.

title: REPORT CITES ANTIAIRCRAFT MISSILES AT WHITE HOUSE
description: Ground-to-air missiles have been installed near the White House to guard against air attack, Time magazine reported in its latest issue.

title: St. John's Wins
description: With starters Chris Mullin and Ron Stewart on the bench with tendinitis in their right feet, St. John's (4-0) struggled to beat United States International, 69-55, yesterday at Alumni Hall in Jamaica, Queens.

title: MAVERICKS: YOUNG, HUSTLING AND ON RISE
description: THE strangest thing has happened in Dallas the last six weeks. The Cowboys, whose history of success has assured fairly complete attention from Dallas sports fans for two decades, suddenly are sharing their top billing and some of their season-ticket holders with, of all things, a basketball team: the Mavericks.

title: THEFT IN NEW YORK AN ORGANIZED AFFAIR
description: In the dank basement of a Brooklyn warehouse, piled high in teetering disorder, were dusty boxes of handwoven towels, toys, instant coffee and racks of clothing with Saks Fifth Avenue labels. In another warehouse, elsewhere in Brooklyn, were rugs, electronics equipment, appliances and cartons of dinner plates marked for the Helmsley Palace Hotel.

title: NOVEMBER SALES UP AT AREA STORES
description: Retail sales for New York City showed the biggest year-to-year increase last month since June, aided by a strong start of the Christmas shopping season, according to a spot- check of the city's seven biggest department stores.

title: TEXT OF JOHN PAUL'S SERMON AT A LUTHERAN CHURCH
description: Following is the text of a sermon delivered by Pope John Paul II today in the Evangelical-Lutheran Christ Church here and translated by The New York Times from the German:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: BERLIN GAME. By Len Deighton. 345 pages. Knopf. $15.95.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Memories

title: KOHLBERG COLLECTS COMPANIES
description: Who's next? That's the question that seems to spring up most often about Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company. Whom are they going to buy next?

title: MONDALE REVISES FOREIGN STRATEGY
description: Aides to former Vice President Walter F. Mondale who had expected the Reagan Administration's economic policies to dominate the 1984 Presidential campaign are now convinced that foreign policy is emerging as a key, perhaps central, issue.

title: Texas Woman Is Killed As Tornadoes Rip South
description: A string of tornadoes tore through eastern Texas over the weekend, severely damaging homes, farms and businesses and tearing down power lines.

title: Drawings by Leonardo Coming to Met Jan. 20
description: An exhibition of Leonardo da Vinci's anatomical drawings from the Royal Library at Windsor Castle will open at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Jan. 20 and continue through April 15.

title: Mondale Reports He Raised $1.5 Million in One Evening
description: The finance director of Walter F. Mondale's campaign for the Presidency said today that the campaign received about $1.5 million in donations from fund-raising parties held Saturday night.

title: Soviet Grain Purchase
description: The Soviet Union has bought an additional 650,000 metric tons of American wheat and corn for delivery in 1983-84 under a long-term agreement that took effect Oct. 1, according to the Agriculture Department.

title: COUPLES' VACATION PROBLEMS
description: -year-old

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: -TERM RATES

title: West Bank Settler Detained In Shooting of Arab Girl, 11
description: An Israeli settler in the occupied West Bank was ordered detained by a magistrate in Netanya today as a suspect in connection with the murder of an Arab girl in Nablus on Thursday.

title: GAPS TO BE MADE IN FENCE IN WYOMING SO ANTELOPE CAN EAT
description: A rancher has agreed to the partial elimination of a fence that has kept about 1,500 antelope from reaching their winter range.

title: Islamic Meeting Denounces U.S. Policy
description: Foreign ministers from the world's Islamic countries failed today to agree on crucial issues dividing them but were unified in their criticisms of Israel and of Washington's policies in the Middle East.

title: Kopp of Leo Burnett To Retire as Chairman
description: C. R. (Jack) Kopp, 62, is retiring Jan. 1 as chairman of the Leo Burnett Company, the Chicago advertising behemoth and America's seventh- largest agency.

title: ONCE-ROBUST LABOR PUBLICATIONS SHOW SIGNS OF MAKING COMEBACK
description: A substantial effort is under way in some places to improve labor unions' newspapers, long regarded as dismal even by many people in the labor movement.

title: MONDAY SPORTS Football
description: Tampa Bay Buccaneers vs. Green Bay Packers, at Tampa, Fla. The Packers, led by the quarterback Lynn Dickey and his acrobatic corps of receivers - James Lofton, John Jefferson, Paul Coffman and Gerry Ellis - have an outside shot at the playoffs if they win this game and their next.

title: F.B.I. Reports Decline For Bombings in U.S.
description: The number of bombings in the United States dropped sharply for the first six months of 1983 but the bombs have killed seven people, injured 53 and caused $38 million in damage, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

title: Dr. Harold Black, 85; Inventor at Bell Labs
description: Dr. Harold S. Black, an inventor and scientist at Bell Laboratories in Murray Hill, N.J., died Sunday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 85 years old and lived in Summit.

title: REVLON'S THREE-YEAR SLUMP
description: Until 1981, when his company's earnings headed downward for the first time, Michel C. Bergerac, chairman of Revlon Inc., was eager to talk about the cosmetics and health care giant he was building.

title: MILITARY OF U.S. 'STANDING TALL,' REAGAN ASSERTS
description: President Reagan honored the nation's military heroes yesterday and declared that while ''tyrants are tempted'' by weakness, his military rebuilding program now has the armed forces ''standing tall.''

title: West Bank Censorship Is Criticized in Report
description: A report issued yesterday said that it had found ''pervasive'' censorship of Arab publications in the occupied West Bank that ''mirrors the larger struggle between Palestinians and Israelis.''

title: MICROBIOLOGICAL SCIENCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
POLKA: JIMMY STURR ORCHESTRA AT CARNEGIE
description: The polka may be considered too trivial for devotees of the classics, too corny for rockers, too ethnic for the upwardly mobile. But that hasn't prevented Jimmy Sturr and his Orchestra, today's most popular polka-flavored band, from selling out Carnegie Hall for five consecutive holiday-season concerts, the fifth of which took place Sunday evening.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Scare at 1 Police Plaza

title: Equitable Files Realty Bonds
description: The Equitable Realty Assets

title: DON'T GRAB A FIG LEAF AND RUN
description: It is true that the Marines acquired their sitting-duck role at the Beirut airport in a fit of absent-mindedness. It is true that Syria and its motley Lebanese allies hold the better cards. It is also true that some kind of deal will have to be struck with President Hafez al-Assad of Syria. It does not follow, however, that the United States should pick up the first available fig leaf and run. There is first of all a matter of principle that great powers can ignore only at their peril: You don't wave a big stick and then slink out after you have been slugged. To cut and run does not exactly boost a nation's reputation - and, alas, ''reputation'' is not just the figment of a macho imagination. In the affairs of nations, it is an important source of power, crucial for keeping friends and influencing opponents. After the Syrian attack last week on two American reconnaissance planes, the Lebanese contest changed profoundly. It is no longer Syrian surrogates who are shooting at Marines and dispatching kamikaze trucks. It is the Syrians, allied with the Soviet Union and Iran, who have thrown down the gauntlet, calculating that the American public has no stomach for fighting on behalf of ambiguous interests in faraway places. They may well be right, but, if so, no one should delude himself about the consequences of American disengagement. Not only the Syrians but everyone else in the Middle East would gather that the United States is not willing to back up its interests with force.

title: SPAIN DENIES THE AIRPORT AT MADRID IS UNSAFE
description: The Government today denied accusations by critics that a poorly marked runway and faulty signal lights were key factors in last week's collision on the ground of two Spanish passenger planes at Barajas airport here.

title: JUSTICES WILL HEAR CASE ON GRAND JURY FOREMAN
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a Federal criminal conviction should ever be overturned on the ground that blacks or women were denied an equal chance to serve as foreman of the grand jury that returned the indictment.

title: BRIEFS
description: Cronus Industries, Dallas, which makes metal buildings and agriculture-related equipment, said its board had approved the divestiture of its agricultural equipment business, resulting in a ''modest'' charge to fully diluted earnings per share for 1983.

title: PUBLISHER RECALLING A HUTTON BIOGRAPHY BECAUSE OF MISTAKES
description: Random House announced yesterday that it was recalling 58,000 copies of a book about the late Barbara Hutton, the heiress to $26 million of the Woolworth fortune, because of errors about one of the physicians who treated her.

title: Cotton Crop Outlook
description: The 1983 cotton harvest is estimated at 7.62 million bales, a 2 percent improvement from the outlook a month ago but still one of the smallest harvests of this century, the Agriculture Department said today. The new estimate, based on Dec. 1 surveys, is 36 percent below the 1982 cotton harvest.

title: KASPAROV DEFEATS KORCHNOI AND LEADS 5 1/2 TO 3 1/2
description: Gary Kasparov of the Soviet Union defeated Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland in the ninth game of their semifinal world championship chess match tonight in 3 hours and 46 minutes. Now, with a 2-point advantage, he is strongly favored to win their series.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Kansas City Power and Light plans to sell $20 million of pollution-control revenue bonds, through E. F. Hutton.

title: STUDENT IS SHOT IN FACE IN HER FORDHAM DORM
description: A .38-caliber bullet smashed through the window of a Fordham University dormitory last night and struck a 21- year-old student in the face as she was combing her hair. She was reported in stable condition in a Bronx hospital, but doctors said they could not repair her damaged right eye and would have to remove it today.

title: GRADUATE SCHOOL: 'SIGNS OF TROUBLE'
description: AFEDERALLY appointed panel has found ''signs of trouble, signs of erosion, in the nation's graduate capacity - signs that in some areas point to serious distress.''

title: Alexander Upset By Pate of U.S.
description: David Pate, a little-known American, scored the upset of the first round of the $125,000 New South Wales Open tennis championships today, eliminating the defending champion John Alexander of Australia, 6-1, 5-7, 6-4.

title: ARGENTINE RIPPLES TOUCH NEIGHBORS
description: When Wilson Ferreyra Aldunate, an exiled Uruguayan opposition leader, came here as a specially invited guest for the inauguration Saturday of President Raul Alfonsin, he was interviewed by a leading Uruguayan newspaper.

title: Racer Is Killed
description: Ken Stevenson, a 36-year-old powerboat racing champion from Mentor, Ohio, was killed Sunday in the Bahamas Grand Prix. He was leading the third heat when his boat became airborne. He was thrown from the boat and broke his neck.

title: Demoted Man Gets Sabbatical WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) - The Nuclear Regulatory Commission's chief internal inspector, demoted after he was accused of being ''derelict in his duty,'' is being sent to school for a year at full salary.
description: Agency officials confirmed today that James J. Cummings, formerly director of the Office of Inspector and Auditor, will begin an 11-month academic sabbatical Jan. 16 to study accounting at the University of Virginia. He is to receive his salary of $66,500 plus $13,800 for expenses.

title: REWARDS OF THE AMERICAN LOOK
description: Thin cotton or linen coats have the swashbuckling dash of trench coats. Long skirts, narrow or full, have a languorous look as they descend almost to the ankles. Silk or cotton sweaters serve as vests over thin blouses or are worn alone. Unconstructed jackets fly in the wind.

title: BRITISH PRINTERS ARE ORDERED TO CALL OFF STRIKE
description: A judge ordered the country's largest printers' union today to call off a nationwide 24-hour strike that the union had set for Wednesday.

title: Bird Still Out
description: The Boston Celtics will be without the star forward Larry Bird at Madison Square Garden tonight for their third meeting of the season with the Knicks. Bird strained the ligaments in his right knee Friday night when he slipped on the freshly waxed floor of the Hartford Civic Center after scoring 17 points in the first quarter against Denver.

title: TWO BRITONS ACCUSED IN COMPUTER SMUGGLING CASE
description: Two Britons were charged today with trying to smuggle United States- manufactured computers to the Soviet bloc in violation of Western bans on the export of certain high-technology items.

title: 2 Men Lost and 6 Hurt As Scalloper Capsizes
description: Two commercial fishermen were lost when their 80-foot boat capsized in 18-foot waves yesterday in the Manasquan Inlet on the Jersey Shore, the Coast Guard said. Six other crewmen were injured and five of these were hospitalized.

title: TOWN WILL SHUT 11 OF 12 SCHOOLS TO CUT ASBESTOS
description: Officials said today that 11 of the city's 12 schools would be closed on a rotating basis over the next month so that all potentially hazardous asbestos could be removed.

description: About 1,000 paratroopers of the 82d Airborne Division, the last United States combat forces to have fought in the invasion of Grenada, were flown off the Caribbean island today, a Defense Department spokesman said.

description: The National Football League playoff picture has cleared a bit, with one more team clinching a position in the tournament leading to Super Bowl XVIII, scheduled for Jan. 22 in Tampa. That leaves four positions to be filled during the final weekend of the season, which begins Friday night when the Jets play the Miami Dolphins in Miami.

description: Barnard College announced yesterday that it had received a gift of $1 million and that it would be used to endow the Helen Goodhart Altschul Professorship.

description: President Daniel arap Moi marked the 20th anniversary of Kenya's independence from Britain today by assuring Uganda and Tanzania of friendship and pardoning 7,000 petty criminals.

title: Trade of Bailor Is Made Official
description: Bob Bailor was added to the Los Angeles roster yesterday and was formally identified as the second player sent by the Mets to the Dodgers in the trade for Sid Fernandez.

title: N.F.L. PLAYOFFS: THE POSSIBILITIES
description: Six teams have gained the National Football League playoffs, with the remaining four berths to be determined this weekend. Here is a division-by-division rundown sible: A.F.C. EAST: MIAMI has clinched the division title with the best overall record. BUFFALO can get a wild-card berth only with a victory over Atlanta, coupled with a loss by Cleveland and a tie between Seattle and New England because that's the only way the Bills would have the best record among the Browns, Seahawks and Patriots. NEW ENGLAND would gain a wild-card berth with a victory over Seattle and a loss by Cleveland, because the Patriots beat Buffalo twice. Even if both Cleveland and Buffalo win, New England can qualify with a victory if it has the best average of net points - the difference between points scored and points allowed - in conference games. New England has a net average of plus-13, Cleveland's average is minus-4 and Buffalo's is minus-20.

title: BIOLOGISTS SAY EMERGENCY ACTION IS NECESSARY TO SAVE STRIPED BASS
description: Conservationists and biologists said today that emergency measures were needed to save the striped bass, the storied ''striper'' of the Atlantic Seaboard, from the danger of extinction.

title: Massey-Vickers Talks
description: Massey-Ferguson Ltd. said today that it was negotiating with Vickers P.L.C. to buy a British plant of the Vickers Rolls-Royce division, which makes diesel engines of about 1,000 horsepower, mostly for trucks, tanks and small locomotives. Massey said the price probably would be about $29 million.

title: A LIFE SPENT BEHIND SOMEONE ELSE'S WHEEL
description: ''I rode my life away,'' Jeffrey Davis said the other day, glancing through barred windows overlooking the Hudson River. In a nine-year criminal career, he said, he stole more than 300 cars in the city.

description: Castle & Cooke Inc., perplexed by the Dr Pepper Company's rejection of a $560 million acquisition offer, is expected to have a further announcement on its offer as early as today, sources close to the situation said yesterday.
