description: Tony Kraber put on a very old scarf last night. It was the gray checkered one, his gift for acting in the Group Theater's play ''Men in White'' 50 years ago. Both the scarf and the Group Theater, Mr. Kraber discovered, had worn well.

description: The capital is in a curious mood. The Smithsonian Institution has just completed an extensive symposium on the resonance of George Orwell, which it called ''The Road After 1984: High Technology and Human Freedom.''

description: Henry A. Kissinger, chairman of the Presidential commission on Central America, has clashed with some Democrats on the panel who favor making new American aid to El Salvador conditional on an end to right-wing death- squad violence, commission officials said today.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE Longstreth, a Democrat, To Leave S.E.C. Early Bevis Longstreth, a Democratic member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has informed President Reagan that he will leave the commission on Jan. 13, nearly five months before his term expires. The announcement yesterday by Mr. Longstreth came as no surprise because he has been telling associates that he would leave early.
description: The vacancy will mean that the President has two non-Republican appointments to make to the five-member panel. By law, no more than three members may come from one party, and there are three Republican incumbents.

description: WHEN it comes to buying a home computer for the children, the question of which one to get has a way of becoming moot.

description: Britain's Press Council censured The Sun today for publishing details of Prince Andrew's romance with Kathleen (Koo) Stark, who has appeared in erotic movies.

description: Governor Cuomo disclosed today that he was abandoning a plan to lay off 1,000 state employees, a threat that some had either forgotten the Governor had made or assumed he had abandoned long ago.

title: Marx Panel Planned in Paris

The topic of the discussion will be Marxism and developing societies and the contribution to economic theory made by the 19th-century German, who was the chief theorist of modern Socialism and Communism.

description: ANEW study takes issue with the notion that nothing significant can be done to stem the slow rise of the earth's temperature - a trend that threatens to cause ice caps to melt, oceans to rise, coastal cities to flood and some agriculture to come to a halt.

title: China Lists Foreign Debt PEKING, Dec 12 (Reuters) - China's first published foreign debt figures show the country owed a total of $3 billion at the end of September.
description: The latest issue of the official magazine China Finance also said China owed $3.43 billion at the end of July and $2.96 billion at the end of August.

title: The Ultimate Collector

''He has a fabulous collection, one of the best in the world,'' Brett said of Halper's eight rooms of baseball items.

He said foreign currency exchange rates will keep 1983 sales at less than $3 billion. Last year, Abbott, a maker of health-care products, had sales of $2.6 billion.

description: Two separate bond issues to finance waste disposal facilities in Florida are being offered this week. One is from Pinellas County, the other from Palm Beach County.

description: Mayor Koch deserves credit for promising $154 million to accelerate New York City's jail construction. But the move should be understood for what it is: crisis management of a problem that deserves more long-range planning.

description: The Supreme Court today removed the final legal obstacles to the scheduled Jan. 1 reorganization of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

description: The American Express Company announced yesterday that its earnings for 1983 would be 10 percent below the 1982 level, because it had added $230 million to the reserves of the Fireman's Fund Insurance Company, its insurance subsidiary. In 1982, the company earned $581 million, or $3.02 a share.

description: The Australian Government was criticized today for refusing to allow a British aircraft carrier to undergo repair at a drydock because the Government said that the ship might be carrying nuclear weapons.

title: Times Mirror To Sell Unit LOS ANGELES, Dec. 12 (Reuters) - The Times Mirror Company said today that it had agreed to sell all the stock of its Times Mirror Satellite Programming Inc. subsidiary to Showtime/The Movie Channel Inc. The price was not disclosed.
description: The unit will end operations Feb. 1. Times Mirror, which publishes The Los Angeles Times and Newsday, on Long Island, said the sale would not have a significant effect on earnings.

title: 2 Japanese Boats Detained
description: North Korea said today that it had detained two Japanese fishing boats for ''illegally intruding'' into the country's 200-mile economic zone extending into the Sea of Japan. The two vessels were captured by naval patrol ships Saturday, according to a brief North Korean broadcast that was monitored in Tokyo.

title: GEORGIA BOARD WEIGHS PARDON OF JEW LYNCHED 70 YEARS AGO
description: In an outburst of anti-Semitism, a furious mob lynched Leo M. Frank in 1915 after the Governor of Georgia commuted his death sentence for the murder of a 13- year-old girl. Now the state is weighing a posthumous pardon for Mr. Frank.

title: Auto Racer Flees From His Trial
description: John Paul Sr., the 44-year- old former world endurance driving champion, failed to appear this morning for his attempted-murder trial, and a warrant was issued for his arrest.

title: HUNGER PANEL CANCELS FINAL MEETING
description: Under the original plan, President Reagan's commission investigating hunger in America was to have met for the last time this week, so members could discuss the contents of their final report.

title: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 13, 1983 International
description: Vehicle bombings in Kuwait demolished the American Embassy and damaged the French Embassy and four other sites. A total of five people were killed and 62 injured in the attacks, which were attributed to an Islamic extremist group with ties to Iran. (Page A1, Column 6.) Consideration of retaliation by the United States, perhaps in coordination with France, is probable if an investigation proves that a pro-Iranian group was responsible for the bombing of the American Embassy in Kuwait, according to a senior American official. (A18:1.)

title: Coast Guard Fires Shots To Intercept Drug Ship
description: A Coast Guard cutter fired a warning volley of machine-gun fire today to stop a ship whose Haitian crew was suspected of trying to deliver about 25 tons of marijuana to New England, the authorities said.

title: Edsel B. Ford 2d Gets Ford Advertising Post The Ford division of the Ford Motor Company has chosen a new advertising manager with an old name: Edsel B. Ford 2d, a great-grandson of Henry Ford, was promoted to the advertising position from his former job as marketing product plans manager for the division.
description: Mr. Ford, 34, who joined the company as a product analyst in 1974 and has held sales and marketing posts in this country and was assistant managing director of Ford's Australian subsidiary for two years, is the son of Henry Ford 2d, who ran the company from 1945 until stepping down as chief executive in 1979. Henry Ford 2d remains chairman of the finance committee of the board of directors.

description: Three teen-agers and a man believed to be their drug dealer were arrested in the slaying of a 14-year-old girl who was killed because of fears that she had reported on a junior high school drug ring, officials said today.

title: REGAN SEES CONTINGENCY TAX PLAN
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said today that President Reagan, to reduce future budget deficits, will include a tax increase proposal in the 1985 budget that he will send to Congress in January.

title: THE BETTER WAY OF REIMBURSING A HOSPITAL
description: To the Editor:

title: STRICT PENALTIES FOR CRIMINALS: PENDULUM OF FEELING SWINGS
description: In the 1970's, a consensus developed among liberals and conservatives, prisoners' advocates and prosecutors that the wide disparity in the punishment of criminals who had committed similar crimes was unfair and that sentences should be made more nearly uniform.

title: FAMILIES' HARDSHIPS EVOKE CONTRIBUTIONS TO AID THE NEEDIEST
description: A single account of hardship often inspires a contribution to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, and the case of Beverly B. and her 4-year-old daughter, Jodi, living in a South Bronx welfare hotel, reported Nov. 24 in The Times, evoked an especially warm response.

title: SIEGLER, BANGOR TO MERGE
description: Lear Siegler Inc. and an initially reluctant Bangor Punta Corporation announced a merger agreement yesterday under which Lear Siegler is to buy all af Bangor Punta's common shares for $27.50 each, $1.50 more than Lear Siegler offered last week.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: Allegheny International Inc., Pittsburgh, has appointed Anthony D. Shanagher executive vice president and chief financial officer.

title: OF QUAKES, REFORMERS AND WORK
description: For more than two decades, scientists have warned Californians that powerful forces were accumulating on the San Andreas Fault, a crack in the earth's crust hidden beneath the state's famous beaches, mountains and palm trees, and that some day these forces would be released in a great earthquake.

title: MEXICANS ANGERED BY STEEL COMPLAINT
description: As Mexico's steel industry sees it, the United States Steel Corporation is demonstrating ingratitude on a colossal scale.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Dan Marino of the Miami Dolphins is still unable to run on his sprained left knee, and Coach Don Shula said the rookie quarterback would probably skip the game Friday night against the Jets. So Don Strock probably will start a second straight game. . . . Bryan Trottier , the Islander center, was named the National Hockey League's player of the week for his five-goal, three-assist performance in three games. . . . The San Antonio Spurs have waived the rookie Kevin Williams , a 6-3 guard from St. John's. . . . Two quarterback coaches with National Football League teams, John Hadl of the Denver Broncos and Paul Hackett of the San Francisco 49ers, have withdrawn as candidates for the vacant Stanford University head coaching position. That leaves three candidtates: Jack Elway , San Jose State head coach; Jim Sochor , head coach at Cal-Davis; and Bill Meyers , offensive line coach of the Green Bay Packers.

title: U.S. SAID TO SEEK CENSURE OF SOVIET
description: The United States, noting that an international inquiry had rebuffed a Soviet theory that the South Korean airliner shot down Sept. 1 was on a spy mission, was reported yesterday to have called anew for a world condemnation of the Soviet Union for destroying the plane.

title: Savings Gain To Be Record By The Associated Press
description: Savings institutions are headed for a record $100 billion gain in deposits this year, the United States League of Savings Institutions said yesterday.

title: NEW BLASTS: MASTER PLAN?
description: News Analysis

title: U.N. HUMAN RIGHTS CHARTER: SIX NEW STAMPS OF APPROVAL
description: They rank among the shortest, briefest - and certainly the smallest - messages to be delivered at the United Nations.

title: SOLAR AGE MANUFACTURING reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MONTREAL CITY & DISTRICT SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
SWISS SKIER WINS GIANT SLALOM RACE
description: A Swiss Olympic hopeful, Max Julen, easily won the ski season's first World Cup giant slalom race today, beating a teammate, Pirmin Zurbriggen by over a half second. Yugoslavia's Jurij Franko was third, more than a full second behind the winner.

title: Johan C.K. Preus, 102, Dies; Was Official of Lutheran Body
description: The Rev. Dr. Johan C. K. Preus, a former official of the Evangelical Lutheran Church, died at Luther Hall in Minneapolis last Thursday. He was 102 years old.

title: JAPANESE SCHOOL IN QUEENS FOLLOWS TOKYO'S LEAD, WITH U.S. TOUCHES
description: It was time for her seventh-grade mathematics class to begin. Mitsuko Kimura walked to the front of the room and bowed deeply. The students, standing by their desks, returned the bow and declared in unison, ''Onegai shimasu,'' which means roughly, ''Thank you for teaching us.''

title: SCOUTING
description: Fans' Favorite

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A 2d Cuomo Passes the Bar

title: BANGKOK AWASH: WORST FLOODING IN 40 YEARS
description: For more than two months this rainy season, and for more than three months in some areas, this city's six million residents have suffered the worst flooding the capital has seen in 40 years.

title: WHAT AMERICA IS DOING TO HELP AFRICA'S DROUGHT VICTIMS
description: To the Editor:

title: MARCOS AIDE LOST HIS JOB, KEPT HONOR
description: As the erect, gray-haired man in a white sport shirt and slacks strode down the center aisle to his place in the front pew for the evening mass, which had already begun, the priest interrupted the service to pronounce a special public prayer for ''Vice President Fernando Lopez,'' Iloilo's most illustrious son.

title: TO KNOW THE SCHOOLS, IT SEEMS, IS LIKE TO THEM
description: EVERY time the pollsters ask people how they feel about the schools, the answers tell the same story: Those whose children use the schools like them much better than those who are not directly involved. Lack of familiarity may breed contempt.

title: MILASTAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $132,000 for the quarter and $272,000 for the 6 months. c-After a non-taxable gain from reorganization of $1,159,000. The year-earlier share earnings and shares outstanding were adjusted to reflect the 4-for-1 stock distribution in January 1983.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST TUESDAY, DECEMBER 13, 1983
description: The Economy

title: ADVERTISING ; TV's 'Business Times' To Kelley & Wallworth
description: With audible chortling, the management of 19-month-old Kelley & Wallworth of Boston announced that they had won the $2 million account of ''Business Times,'' a two-hour daily business news program on the ESPN cable network.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: . . . And Takes the Cakes

title: Activision Expects Loss
description: ctivision Inc. said it expects to post a loss for its third quarter, ending Dec. 31, on sales that are sharply lower from those of a year earlier. In last year's third period, when Activision was privately held, the company was profitable, on sales of $50.1 million.

title: ICY RAINS CAUSE ROAD ACCIDENTS NORTH OF THE CITY
description: An icy rain glazed roads in the northern suburbs of New York City this morning, causing highway accidents and traffic jams, delaying commuter railroad lines and closing schools.

title: SAXTON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $8,900.

title: DIVORCE'S STRESS EXACTS LONG-TERM HEALTH TOLL
description: DIVORCE can exact a greater and in many cases longer-lasting emotional and physical toll on the former spouses than virtually any other life stress, including widowhood.

title: A 'COMPENSATORY RULE'
description: A man is standing at a bus stop. He is carrying a portable television set wrapped in a shirt and he is trying to hitch a ride. Someone calls the police and says that the man looks suspicious.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in Metropolitan Report yesterday misidentified Board of Education officials at a City Council hearing. They were Lorraine Monroe, chief executive for instruction; Steven Schwager, chief administrator for business and finance, and JoAnn Ascuitto, special assistant to Mrs. Monroe.

title: FORDHAM DEFEATS ST. FRANCIS
description: George Jones, a freshman, came off the bench to score 16 points, and Jerry Hobbie added 15 to lead Fordham (6-3) to an easy 77-61 victory over St. Francis of Brooklyn last night.

title: MAXWELL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
HIGH COURT DECLINES TO HEAR BABY JANE DOE CASE
description: The Supreme Court today refused a request by the one-time guardian for Baby Jane Doe to order a Long Island hospital to perform corrective surgery on the seriously deformed and retarded infant.

title: NUCLEAR PROTESTERS ARRESTED
description: Dozens of people were arrested in Britain and West Germany today during demonstrations protesting the deployment of nuclear missiles in Western Europe.

title: ; A GREYHOUND DRIVER'S WORTH
description: To the Editor:

title: TV: 'NOVA' EXAMINES 40 YEARS' NUCLEAR POLICY
description: -television series, is offering tonight the thinking person's ''The Day After.'' It is ''Nuclear Strategy for Beginners,'' an examination of 40 years of nuclear policy, ''The Day Before,'' so to speak, and how we got there. The one- hour program, informed and compelling, will be seen on Channel 13 at 8 P.M.

title: Holtz Inquiry
description: James Martin, the president of the University of Arkansas, says he will check with ''the appropriate people'' to see whether Lou Holtz , the football coach, violated school policy in endorsing the re-election of Senator Jesse Helms , Republican of North Carolina, in two television commercials. ''Our faculty and staff are certainly citizens and can express their opinions,'' Mr. Martin said.

title: SCIENCE WATCH
description: Flies on Ice

title: HCW OIL & GAS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
SEALES, NEARLY BLIND, STILL LOVES THE RING
description: The winner of a 1972 Olympic gold medal and a veteran of 452 amateur and professional fights, Sugar Ray Seales today is nearly blind.

title: LEBANON'S A SWAMP; LET'S QUIT
description: We appear to be drifting into a war in Lebanon that few Americans understand or will support for long. Our Marines are taking casualties almost daily, but Washington does not seem to know what we want to achieve or what consequences may flow from expanded military action. We have three options: to increase our military forces significantly, to maintain our forces at the present level or to withdraw.

title: Thais Rebuff North Koreans
description: The Thai Government has put off indefinitely a request by North Korea to open an embassy in Bangkok, official sources said today.

title: JUDGE PREPARES TO RULE ON DEATH PLEA
description: Even in December a hot, dry wind blows through this Southern California city, past the county hospital where Elizabeth Bouvia sits in a locked ward, hoping the coming hours will bring a judge's order to grant her death wish.

title: A TEST FOR DIPLOMACY: BROOKLYN VISITORS AT THE U.N.
description: The question was direct, a bit angry: ''Why do the African countries always vote with the Arabs against Israel?''

title: TRUCKING'S GREAT SHAKEOUT
description: In the last three years, the trucking industry has been through its most severe shakeout since the Great Depression.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Well, our days of weakness are over. Our military forces are back on their feet and standing tall.''

title: Justice Dept. Sues Sears WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) - The Justice Department sued Sears, Roebuck & Company for $2.8 million, charging that the company reneged on paying part of a settlement of Government claims that the retailer illegally sold Japanese television sets below fair market value.
description: The suit said a 1980 agreement obligated Sears to pay $14.3 million in settlement of customs duties and civil penalties under Federal antidumping laws. The duties and penalties stem from Sears's sale of Japanese television sets from June 1971 through March 1979.

title: Bradford Talks
description: The Bradford National Corporation said it is beginning preliminary talks with several parties that have expressed interest in acquiring it.

title: JOSEPH PADUR BAUKE
description: Prof. Joseph Padur Bauke, a former chairman of the department of Germanic languages at Columbia University, died of a heart attack last Tuesday.

title: Sex, Luck and the Facts of Life
description: More often than not, a pregnant teen-ager will drop out of high school. Because she has less education, she'll earn less than half the income of women who become mothers in their middle to late 20's. Their children will have an edge on hers. Her baby is more likely to have a low birth weight, have a lower I.Q., repeat at least one grade in school and not do as well on achievement test scores. The odds are 2 to 1 that she'll need welfare.

title: SUGAR RAY'S RULE OF THUMB
description: When he announced 13 months ago that he would never box again following surgery for a detached retina in his left eye, Sugar Ray Leonard talked about how ''I will not come back and that's it . . . the feeling is gone.'' But now the feeling obviously has returned, as it so often does to the best boxers. Now the 27- year-old former world welterweight champion has made another announcement - that he will box again.

title: CITY BALLET: BALANCHINE'S 'NUTCRACKER'
description: There are few things that live past a child's dreams into an adult experiencing of magic, and few ballets that seem as newly magical every year. But George Balanchine's ''Nutcracker'' proved to be that in performances by the New York City Ballet on Saturday and Sunday afternoons at the New York State Theater. Decently if unspectacularly danced for the most part, the ballet was as fresh and as full of surprises as ever.

title: Advertising; Needham's Cityscape For ITT
description: AMONG the 12 commercials that the ITT Corporation will run tonight during ''Cook and Perry: The Race to the Pole,'' a two- hour, made-for-TV movie on the CBS network, is a 60-second spot in which a city will grow before your very eyes. As the camera - seemingly in a helicopter - sweeps quickly from block to block, buildings materialize where empty lots had been.

title: Players Charged
description: Bryce Oglesby, Oregon State's leading rusher this season, and James Burton, a defensive back for the team, have been charged with the attempted rape of an 18-year-old student at the university. Both players were released on bail Saturday, having been arrested earlier in the day, and are scheduled to appear Thursday in Benton County Circuit Court.

title: DOW CLIMBS 1.53 POINTS, TO 1,261.59
description: The stock market, saddled by a variety of uncertainties, finished with minor price changes yesterday in much slower trading.

title: DANCE: AILEY COMPANY PERFORMS 'PHASES'
description: Alvin Ailey's ''Phases'' is a four- part suite to music by Pharoah Sanders, Donald Byrd and Max Roach that choreographically presents four ways of having a good time. A revival of the work opened Sunday night's performance by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater at the City Center, and it got the evening off to a warm, mellow start.

title: Harvester Unit Obtains Loan CHICAGO, Dec. 12 (AP) - The International Harvester Company's French subsidiary has obtained a loan for about $12 million to finance its operations until its debt can be restructured, a company spokesman said. The loan was obtained from five French banks, the French Government and the parent company, Harvester said. It said that the money is to provide interim financing until the financial and operational restructuring plans of the French unit are in place.
description: In a proxy statement released to stockholders last week, Harvester said that even if the $12 million loan were obtained, the French subsidiary ''will experience significant cash shortfalls during fiscal 1984, in which event it will likely default under its loan agreements.''

title: U.S. Beats Soviet, Lead Series, 2-1
description: Scott Bjugstad and Pat LaFontaine each scored two goals tonight as the United States Olympic hockey team defeated a Soviet all-star team, 4-2, in the third game of their series.

title: AMATEURS FADING IN WORLD OF CAR THEFT
description: On the afternoon of Oct. 18, police officers on a routine inspection of automobile body shops dropped by Juan Aponte's business in the Crotona Park section of the Bronx.

title: NEW CONFIDENCE ON MOON ROCKS' SAFETY
description: AHAUNTING anxiety, ever since the Project Apollo astronauts brought back 843 pounds of material gathered on the moon at vast experience and high personal risk, has been the possibility of losing the rocks through some form of natural disaster, sabotage or theft.

title: AMERICAN BUILDING MAINTENANCE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
COAL MINERS TAKE HARD LINE ON CONCESSIONS
description: Rich Trumka, president of the United Mine Workers, using an emotional appeal that paid immediate dividends, told 1,400 delegates to the union's convention today that they had no right to roll back agreements forged by their elders.

title: GRUMMAN TO EXPAND ON L.I.
description: The Grumman Corporation, the largest employer on Long Island, announced plans today to construct a $15 million computer operations building in the Town of Brookhaven.

title: ADVERTISING ; Stronger Rise Predicted For Industry Revenues
description: Robert J. Coen, the closest thing in adland to a court seer, yesterday increased his estimates yet again for this year's domestic ad spending. He forecast outlays of $75.1 billion, up 12.7 percent from 1982; he predicted a 9.2 percent rise in January, and he revised that upward to 11 percent in July.

title: A Solzhenitsyn Makes Vermont Piano Debut
description: An 11-year-old Russian-born pianist best known as the son of the reclusive Nobel laureate Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn attracted his own share of admiration at his orchestra debut over the weekend.

title: Article 108628 -- No Title
description: This year, for the first time in 12 years, the United States will have a deficit in trade with the European Economic Community, a United States trade official told a Senate hearing today. The deficit would be caused by a more rapid rate of economic recovery in the United States, a stronger dollar and a reduction in farm exports, he added.

title: Governor Opposes Law On Preference in Hiring
description: Gov. Ted Schwinden today endorsed a proposal to end Montana's ''absolute preference'' law.

title: Bid for Thrift Unit
description: The Beverly Hills Savings and Loan Association said Werner K. Rey had agreed to acquire a controlling interest in the thrift unit for $26.8 million. His acquisition follows a statement by Paul Amir, another stockholder, that he intends to seek majority control of the thrift unit. Beverly Hills Savings, which had assets of $820 million last Dec. 31, has said it opposes Mr. Amir's bid.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Koch Plays Carson . . .

title: SCOUTING
description: Help for Duke

title: MOONLIGHTING SENATORS RACE FOR YEAR-END INCOME
description: The Great Honorariums Rush of 1983 is at full throttle. Although the Congressional recess is ostensibly a time for senators to get reacquainted with their constituents, many are spending their time racing across the country, speaking to business groups and trade associations that conduct business before their committees.

title: SCIENCE WATCH
description: Organic Superconductors

title: SCIENCE WATCH
description: SOME bats have peculiar social habits, a scientist has discovered. While investigating the animals' breeding habits, John Hermanson, a biologist at the University of Florida, found a huge colony of bats in the attic of a house near Gainesville.

title: Business and the LawTamar Lewin U.S. vs. Bank Of Nova Scotia
description: T HE Bank of Nova Scotia was caught in a dilemma. On the one hand, an American grand

title: New Chief Discusses Disease Center Policy
description: The new director of the national Centers for Disease Control says a top priority is solving the mystery of AIDS, but that warning people about environmental hazards is almost as important.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: A.T.& T. President To Retire April 1

title: COACH KILLED IN CRASH
description: Rex Dockery, the head football coach at Memphis State University, and three others were killed tonight when their twin-engine plane crashed about 10 miles north of Lawrenceburg, authorities said.

title: Panda Continues to Regain Health
description: Ling-Ling the panda ate most of her bamboo meals today and showed continuing signs of improvement from a potentially deadly kidney infection.

title: Wometco Buyout
description: Wometco Enterprises Inc. said it had signed a definitive agreement for its previously announced acquisition by a group of investors led by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company in a transaction valued at more than $1 billion.

title: Shawmut Plan
description: David F. Bolger, who controls about 5 percent of the common stock of the Shawmut Corporation, said he had submitted to Shawmut a proposal for presentation at its annual meeting that would deter management from making takeover attempts more difficult. In addition, he said his proposal seeks to prohibit the bank-holding company from entering into any business combination that would lower the book value or per-share earnings of the surviving entity below that of Shawmut before the transaction.

title: MARK FOR STENERUD
description: Jan Stenerud, who had already set a league career field-goal record, kicked a 23-yarder 5 minutes 7 seconds into overtime to give Green Bay a 12-9 victory over the Tampa Bay Buccaneers tonight.

description: * Nuveen index, John Nuveen & Company Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

description: Israeli officials have been using veiled threats and brinkmanship in an effort to foil a plan for evacuation of Yasir Arafat, head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, from the northern Lebanese port city of Tripoli.

title: Southwestern Bell Increase
description: The Southwestern Bell Telephone Company said that it had

title: INSTALLMENT DEBT RISE SETS MARK
description: Despite high interest rates, consumer installment debt rose in October by a record $4.89 billion, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Burroughs, Telex Venture DETROIT, Dec. 12 (AP) - The Burroughs Corporation and Telex Computer Products Inc. said today that they are planning a joint venture to build and sell flat panel display screens for computers.
description: The first product of the new company, which will be called the Plasma Graphics Corporation, would be a 1 1/2- inch thick, 4-inch-by-7-inch screen that can display the same quantity of information as a 25-line, 80-character cathode ray tube, the companies said. Burroughs, based in Detroit, manufactures business machines; Telex Computer Products, a Telex Corporation subsidiary, is in Tulsa, Okla.

title: Princeton Weighs $13,900YearlyFee
description: Undergraduate students at Princeton University would pay approximately $13,900 to attend the school in 1984-85 under a proposal confirmed today by the university's priorities committee.

title: NEW ATTACK ON GALILEO ASSERTS MAJOR DISCOVERY WAS STOLEN
description: -SIMMERING criticism of Galileo as

title: Getting Poorer
description: ''Are you better off now than you were four years ago?'' That was Ronald Reagan's powerful question in the 1980 campaign. With the 1984 campaign under way, the question is appropriate again, notably from the perspective of the people who most need to be better off. New data, offered by economists Frank Levy and Richard Michel of the Urban Institute in Washington, must trouble those who contend that President Reagan's policies are effective - or fair.

title: RETALIATORY MOVE BEING MENTIONED
description: A senior American official said today that if an investigation proved that a pro-Iranian group was responsible for the bombing of the United States Embassy in Kuwait this morning, the United States would probably consider retaliation, perhaps in coordination with France.

title: TO PROTECT A GOOD SAMARITAN FROM LAWSUITS
description: To the Editor:

title: CBS SCORES WITH 'GAME OF THE YEAR'
description: It has been a season of declining ratings and increasing speculation about whether professional football has reached the saturation point in popularity and as television entertainment. The dramatic loss of 4 ratings points on ''Monday Night Football'' on ABC has become the barometer that some advertisers are using to speculate about the future appeal of pro football, even though CBS and NBC have not shown a sharp decline in viewers for Sunday afternoon telecasts.

title: 4 Surviving Quints PutonRespirators
description: Doctors were optimistic today that respirators would help four surviving quintuplets overcome a lung illness that claimed the life of one of the infants.

title: Morgan, A's Close
description: Soon after being released by the Philadelphia Phillies several weeks ago, Joe Morgan , the 40-year-old veteran second baseman of 19 National League seasons, said that he wanted to spend his summers in Oakland, Calif., where he lives, and would therefore either sign with the A's or retire. Apparently retirement will have to wait. The A's have scheduled a news conference for today, and it was reported that the purpose was to announce that Morgan had agreed to terms.

title: TANTI A HIT WITH CANUCKS
description: Too little. Too weak. Too slow. There was a

title: Baker Puts Tennessean On Civil Rights Panel
description: Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee, the Senate majority leader, today named Francis F. Guess, the labor commissioner of Tennessee, to fill the remaining open seat on the eight-member United States Commission on Civil Rights.

title: HEIGHTS FINANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
BANGLADESH TO KEEP MARTIAL LAW
description: Lieut. Gen. Hussain Mohammed Ershad, who proclaimed himself President Sunday, said today that martial law would remain in effect in Bangladesh until after presidential and parliamentary elections scheduled for next year.

title: TV: 2 WHO RACED TO THE NORTH POLE
description: ONCE again, television docudrama is plunging into murky biographical waters. Tonight's illustration, on CBS at 9, is ''Cook and Peary: The Race to the Pole.'' It is billed by the network as a dramatization of the bitter controversy that erupted over two men who individually claimed to have completed, in the first decade of this century, the quest of being first to reach the North Pole. In fact, the film constitutes a total endorsement of the case for one of those men: Dr. Frederick A. Cook.

title: ADVERTISING ; 2 Creative Executives For Laurence, Charles
description: Laurence, Charles & Free, a Mickelberry company, has reached outside the agency for two new creative directors.

title: ADVERTISING ; Bates Begins Service For Hispanic Market
description: As the Hispanic market in the United States grows, more marketers are looking for advertising specifically designed to reach the Spanish? speaking population. There are now about 20 to 25 independent specialty agencies, but there are also specialty divisions at some of the top general agencies. Ogilvy & Mather was the latest to join the latter group, which includes McCann-Erickson, J. Walter Thompson and Young & Rubicam.

title: TRIPOLI IS CLEARED FOR ARAFAT'S EXIT
description: Lebanese security officials said today that the harbor was now ready for the evacuation of Yasir Arafat and his followers, and they can leave Wednesday if international guarantees for their safety are received by then.

title: BSD MEDICAL CO reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
BRINKMAN, L D, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
U.S. SEEMS TO BE TARGET OF NEW STRAIN OF TERROR
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that this mornings's truck-bomb attack against the United States Embassy in Kuwait appeared to be linked to recent warnings of possible terrorist strikes against American installations here and aboard.

title: JEWEL COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 5
description: b-Including a pretax gain of $4.8 million from the sale of Mass-Feeding Corp. in August 1983.

title: GEESE GROW FONDER OF THE NORTHEAST BUT SHUN CAROLINAS
description: AMAJOR shift in the migratory pattern of Canada geese, many of which are not flying as far south as they used to for the winter, is being studied by wildfowl experts along the Atlantic flyway from the Canadian border south to the Carolinas.

title: No Headline
description: FIRST PERSON SINGULAR. Writers on Their Craft. Compiled by Joyce Carol Oates. 280 pages. Ontario Review Press. $15.95.

title: LLOYDS TO ACQUIRE SCHRODER
description: In a major expansion into West German banking, Lloyds Bank P.L.C. said today that it had agreed to buy out Schr"oder M"unchmeyer, Hengst & Company.

title: New Cabinet Ministers Appointed in Uruguay
description: Uruguay's military rulers announced a partial shuffle of the Cabinet today in advance of elections promised for November 1984.

title: The Yale Way
description: A. Bartlett Giamatti , the president of Yale University, says he never considered replacing either Athletic Director Frank Ryan or Coach Carm Cozza this football season, which the Elis finished at 1-9, their worst record in 111 years.

title: BRIEFING
description: Judging the Presidents

title: BORMAN'S INC reports earnings for 12 wks to Nov 5
description: b-Net income including extraordinary tax credits of $240,000 for the 12 weeks and $1.1 million for the 40 weeks.

title: LANDMARK PARK AVE. CHURCH ASKS PERMISSION TO CHANGE A BUILDING
description: St. Bartholomew's Church, a Park Avenue landmark, yesterday asked the city's permission to alter the church's community house so a 59-story office tower could be built on the site.

title: Oshkosh Africa in Shift
description: Oshkosh Africa, a subsidiary of the South African industrial group Barlow Rand, said today that it had ended production of Oshkosh trucks in South Africa. The trucks were built under license from Oshkosh of the United States.

title: WASHINGTON STATE'S BANNING OF VOTER POLLS IS CHALLENGED
description: The three largest television networks, The New York Times and The Everett (Wash.) Herald sued yesterday to overturn a new Washington State law aimed at stopping news organizations from questioning voters as they leave polling places.

title: Italians End Inquiry On Bulgarian Role
description: The Italian magistrate investigating the possibility of a Bulgarian connection to the 1981 shooting of Pope John Paul II has finished his two-year inquiry, it was reported here today.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Dec. 3 about the 20th anniversary of ''Beyond the Melting Pot'' misidentified the publisher, who was also named erroneously last Friday in a correction. The book was published by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology Press. The publisher who was first approached by the authors for help in putting out the book was the Harvard University Press.

title: Required Reading A Toast in El Salvador
description: These right-wing fanatics are the best friends the Soviets, the Cubans, the Sandinista commandantes and the Salvadoran guerillas have. Every murderous act they commit poisons the well of friendship between our two countries and advances the cause of those who would impose an alien dictatorship on the people of El Salvador. These cowardly death squad terrorists are just as repugnant to me, to President Reagan, to the United States Congress and to the American people as the terrorists of the left.

title: BRIEFS
description: Boise Cascade Corp., Boise, Idaho, said it would close permanently three plywood mills in Oregon, idling 300 workers. The company cited depressed demand for plywood.

title: Plan to Get Team Outlined by City
description: New York City officials have drawn up plans for a $4.3 million training center at Queens College as part of their attempt to lure a professional football team to Shea Stadium.

title: Smyslov Postpones Chess Semifinal Game
description: Vasily Smyslov of the Soviet Union postponed the 10th game of his semifinal world championship chess match with Zoltan Ribli of Hungary today.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: METROCARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $6,000 for the quarter and $15,000 for the 9 months.

description: ANCE TIGHTENS SECURITY AROUND ITS TO P OFFICIALS

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Airborne to Nova Scotia

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: SWATCH DE SOIE The most magnificent swatches in town may well be the four-score pieces of original silks on exhibition, along with two Gobelin tapestries and Napoleon's campaign tent, furnished, that are now on exhibition in the attractive downstairs gallery of the Fashion Institute of Technology's Shirley Goodman Resource Center, on Seventh Avenue at 27th Street (760- 7760).

title: SOME PREFER TO SEND GIFTS ANONYMOUSLY TO AID THE NEEDIEST
description: Many contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, including some of the largest, are made anonymously.

title: RETALIATION MOVE BY U.S. IS POSSIBLE
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, angered by the seeming impunity of those responsible for recent explosions like those in Kuwait on Monday. said today that, if the attackers could be identified, ''there will be ways of getting at them.''

title: Recruit Investigation
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association is reportedly looking into whether Texas A&M officials improperly lured a star freshman basketball guard, Todd Holloway , away from Wagner College.

title: Boxer in Coma
description: Salvatore La Serra , a 25-year-old boxer who collapsed Saturday night after scoring his 10th straight victory and earning a chance to fight for the Italian bantamweight title, is in a coma at a hospital in Milan, Italy. La Serra has undergone surgery to remove swelling in his brain, and doctors said his condition was critical. Mario Sturia , who was the physician at ringside when La Serra fought Maurizio Lupino , said La Serra had not appeared to be taking a beating.

title: DISSIDENTS ELECTED IN GAF FIGHT
description: The bitter contest for control of the GAF Corporation came to a formal end yesterday with the election of a new board nominated by dissident shareholders.

title: Crime Panel Official Named
description: James D. Harmon Jr., a Federal prosecutor from New York, was named today as executive director and general counsel for the President's Commission on Organized Crime.

title: Pilot and His Passenger Die In Crash in Greenwich Swamp
description: The pilot of a single-engine airplane and his passenger were killed tonight when the craft crashed and burned in a swamp here, shearing off treetops and scattering debris over a remote residential neighobrhood, officials said.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Old New York

title: CITY CENTER'S 40 YEARS CELEBRATED WITH GALA
description: There were nearly four hours of celebration, and the ranks of participants included Leonard Bernstein, Beverly Sills, Bess Myerson, Natalia Makarova, Jerome Robbins, Kitty Carlisle Hart, John V. Lindsay and two sets of dancers who spent their time either spinning on their heads - the New York City Breakers - or throwing themselves to the floor - the Paul Taylor Dance Company.

title: WHITE HOUSE AND STANFORD AT ODDS ON REAGAN LIBRARY
description: The impasse between the White House and Stanford University over the Ronald Reagan Presidential library complex widened today as the university board of trustees voted to accept a Reagan political institute on the campus only ''within the normal academic structure of the university.''

title: DWI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 23
description: b-Net income.

title: No Headline
description: Texas Utilities Cited by S. & P. The only three electric utilities in the nation rated triple-A

title: SURVIVAL TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CONCERT: 'MESSIAH' BY HANDEL
description: ''MESSIAH'' is only partly about Christmas, but it is this particular season that takes Handel's great oratorio to its heart and makes sure that we are reminded at least annually of its power and beauty.

title: POWERTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
JEWISH YOUTH IS CHARGED IN BLAZES AT SYNAGOGUES
description: A 17-year-old Jewish youth, a member of a synagogue that was damaged by arson last summer, was arrested here today and charged with that fire and three others.

title: AS MOSCOW FURTHER CURBS HUMAN RIGHTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Progressive Corp. Stake
description: Owners of 39 percent of the Progressive Corporation said they would not sell the stock for six months without the approval of a majority of the group. The American International Group, which like Progressive is an insurance holding company, has 7.9 percent of Progressive and plans to buy 12.4 percent more from the American Financial Corporation.

title: KDT Files Plan
description: KDT Industries said it had filed a plan for reorganization, based on a merger with the Ames Department Stores, with the bankruptcy court. The plan calls for the distribution of cash and voting convertible preferred stock of Ames to holders of secured, unsecured and trade debt of KDT, an operator of discount department stores. KDT shareholders would receive shares of Ames common stock valued at $1.5 million.

title: BASED WORKS ON HISTORY OF GREECE
description: Mary Renault, whose books based on the history and legends of the Grecian age represented the highest aim of the historial novel - to give the reader a new insight into the past - died yesterday at the age of 78.

title: CITY ADOPTS NEW PLANS TO COMBAT CHILD ABUSE
description: Mayor Koch yesterday announced a range of new programs, training and closer cooperation between city agencies to combat child abuse.

title: BERRY FINDS COMFORT IN 'PURGATORY'
description: Two games with Kilgore this season show just how much Walter Berry means to San Jacinto College.

title: PENRIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The latest first quarter revenue figure includes $500,000 contributed by the Triplett Corporation, acquired two weeks prior to the end of the quarter.

title: BROOKINGS THINKS ABOUT ITS FUTURE
description: The Brookings Institution, a 56-year-old community of scholars whose work provided the underpinning for the Marshall Plan, the Budget Reform Act and dozens of other legislative initiatives, used to be the only game in town. In recent years, however, there has been a proliferation of research institutions, and Brookings now finds itself competing for funds, prestige, publicity, and the ability to make a mark on this capital city.

title: S.E.C.'s Court Role
description: A move within the Securities and Exchange Commission to reduce the agency's role in corporate bankruptcy proceedings has touched off a battle.

title: SALES RISE SHARP 1.9% AT RETAIL
description: Retail sales climbed by a strong 1.9 percent last month, the Commerce Department reported today, rising to a seasonally adjusted $102.5 billion, from $100.6 billion in October.

title: SOVIET STUDIES GAIN SUPPORT FROM THE U.S.
description: President Reagan and Congress have come to an agreement on an impending national shortage: a lack of experts on the Soviet Union.

title: Advertising; A Shift In Direct Marketing
description: DIRECT marketers estimate they had $137.5 billion in sales last year, and that was without any purchases by the untold millions of Americans who wouldn't dream of buying by telephone or through the mails.

title: Holiday Inns' Budget Chain
description: Officials of Holiday Inns Inc.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: THIS is the time of year to eat too much, drink too much, work too hard and stay out too late, with ''acid indigestion'' the all-too-frequent result. For some, the holidays mean a worsening of year-round indigestion that often prompts them to chew an acid-neutralizing tablet, swallow a chalky liquid or drink a fizzing antacid solution. For others, acid indigestion, ''sour'' stomach and heartburn are only occasional problems, brought on by the dietary excesses and irregularities of the holiday season.

title: THEFT PLAGUES CHINESE CULTURAL CENTER IN OREGON
description: The fact is, the idea of a sister-state relationship between Oregon and Fujian Province in China had bad luck from the start, and the burglary of the Chinese cultural center and its historic displays here was just another hardship along the way.

title: ROBOTIC VISION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: The latest year loss includes a non- cash charge to operations of $103,000 related to the grant of certain compensatory stock options.

title: Democracy's Elite
description: The indictment of United States District Judge Harry Claiborne of Nevada is a rarity in history, a felony charge against a sitting Federal judge. There have been barely a handful of such cases in the life of the Republic. Why so few? The answers tell something important about American democracy and an American elite, the Federal judiciary.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: 76ers vs. Milwaukee Bucks , at Philadelphia. (Television - USA Cable, 8 P.M.) Local College Games : Merchant Marine Academy at New York University, 7 P.M.; Southampton at Dowling, 7:30 P.M.; Siena at Wagner, 8 P.M.; C. W. Post at Queens, 8 P.M.; Lehman at Staten Island, 8:05 P.M. (Radio - WNYE-FM, 91.5; 8 P.M.) Hockey Rangers vs.

title: GUERARD IS FINED IN FALSE LABELING
description: Michel Guerard, one of the masters of French cooking and the owner of one of this country's great restaurants, has been found guilty of false advertising in connection with the sale of food products bearing his name.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
description: Norwest Unit Offering $447.2 Million in Bonds

title: NEW DETAILS GIVEN IN GETTY DISPUTE
description: A lawyer for Gordon P. Getty has added new details to charges that the Getty Oil Company orchestrated the current campaign to diminish Mr. Getty's control of its largest shareholder trust.

title: Union Pacific
description: An antitrust challenge brought by the Union Pacific Corporation to the planned combination of the holding companies that own the Southern Pacific and Santa Fe railroads was rejected by a United States District judge here and a panel of the United States Court of Appeals. In dismissing the complaint from his court, District Judge Thomas H. Flannery said the issue belonged before the Interstate Commerce Commission. Stockholders of Santa Fe and Southern Pacific are to vote today on whether to form a combined Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation.

title: ESTERLINE CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
WEIRD GOAL STARTS ROUT OF RANGERS
description: The hockey goaltender is always

title: BASE TEN SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
U.N. Presses Soviet On Korean Airliner
description: The United Nations civil aviation agency urged the Soviet Union today to start cooperating with an investigation of the downing of a South Korean passenger jet by Soviet fighters.

title: BRITAIN'S PRINTERS 'SUSPEND' A STRIKE
description: A 24-hour strike against Britain's national newspapers was ''suspended'' today amid signs that the challenge by the leading printers' union to tough new labor laws was fading.

title: People
description: * Alec Gerster has been promoted to executive vice president at Grey Advertising.

title: FILM: KAREN SILKWOOD'S STORY
description: TAKING many of the facts of the life of Karen Silkwood, the young laboratory worker and union activist who, in 1974, died in an automobile crash that some believe to have been murder, Mike Nichols has directed a precisely visualized, highly emotional melodrama that's going to raise a lot of hackles.

title: REAGAN SEEKS CUTS IN FUNDS FOR HEALTH IN '85
description: President Reagan's new budget, as drafted by the Office of Management and Budget, seeks to cut spending for immunization of children, for the treatment of venereal disease and for the medical care of people exposed to toxic wastes, Administration officials said today.

title: EPILEPSY AND VIOLENCE HAVE NO CONNECTION
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. COURT UPSETS CURB ON POLITICAL ACTION GROUPS
description: Conservative groups planning to spend as much as $20 million to help President Reagan's expected re-election campaign have been given a legal green light from a three-judge Federal court in Philadelphia.

title: AT A HONDURAS BASE, MORE QUESTIONS THAN ANSWERS
description: In a valley near the hamlet of El Aguacate, about 130 miles east of this capital city, Honduran and American soldiers are closely guarding a military base that an anti-Sandinista rebel has decribed as a supply base for the guerrilla forces fighting in Nicaragua.

title: New Xerox Entity Gets a President
description: The Xerox Corporation announced yesterday the consolidation of two corporate organizations into a new division and the appointment of a new president to head it.

title: POWER TEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income The share earnings for 1982 is adjusted to reflect the 5 percent stock dividends of April 1983, and October 1983.

title: Victim of Shooting Loses Right Eye
description: A 21-year-old woman who was shot in the face while dressing in her dormitory room at Fordham University Monday night underwent surgery yesterday at Jacobi Hospital for the removal of her right eye and bullet fragments in her nose.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: hot? What you do is, you get up very early in the morning and you go to 235 East 57th Street, where you press your little nose against the glass of the St. Honore P^atisserie and wait for the baby breads to pop out of the oven.

title: POP MUSIC: GEORGE WINSTON
description: SHOELESS and wearing a plaid work short and overalls for his Sunday night solo concert at Avery Fisher Hall, the West Coast pop pianist George Winston took the stage looking like a refugee from a Tom Robbins novel. And sure enough, the music he played - on the guitar and the harmonica as well as the piano - had the same spirit of quaint, quirky rusticity that runs through Mr. Robbins's prose.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the Xerox Corporation misstated the basis for a contingency payment that Xerox will make in acquiring Van Kampen Merritt Inc. It is the earnings of Van Kampen Merritt.

title: Mets Hire Aide
description: Darrell Johnson, former manager of three major league teams, signed with the Mets yesterday as the coordinator of instruction for their six farm clubs. Johnson, 55 years old, will supervise the training program for the clubs and will serve as manager of the Mets' team in the Instructional League next fall.

title: Soaking Flatware
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:The suggestion to soak flatware in a bowl of soapy water (''The Successful Dinner Party: A Game Plan,'' Nov. 23) is an unfortunate one. Whereas sterling or silver-plated spoons and forks are unlikely to have any problems, sterling or silver-plated knives with steel blades, if left in water for a length of time, may very well develop stains and eventually spots, which are difficult to deal with and unsightly.

title: HRT Favors McCrory Offer LOS ANGELES, Dec. 13 (Reuters) - HRT Industries said it had decided that a stock purchase and funding offer from the McCrory Corporation is better than an earlier offer made by the Schottenstein Stores Corporation. HRT, which is in bankruptcy proceedings, said the McCrory offer is more likely to be approved by creditors, shareholders and the court.
description: HRT said McCrory had amended its plan to include a cash tender offer for the shares to be issued to creditors and shareholders under the reorganization plan. McCrory, a unit of the Rapid-American Corporation that operates variety and clothing stores, offered to pay the same per-share price that it would pay for the 55 percent it plans to purchase outright, HRT said. McCrory has offered $18 million for 55 percent of the issued stock, while Schottenstein, which is based in Columbus, Ohio, has offered $12 million.

title: Bomb Planted in London
description: The police evacuated a London shopping street today and blew up a bomb that had been left in a brown satchel outside a restaurant.

title: LANGLEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
KINDER-CARE LEARNING CENTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 25
Bangladesh Politician Sets Terms for Talks
description: An opposition figure set conditions Monday for talks with Lieut. Gen. H. M. Ershad on restoring civilian rule to Bangladesh.

title: NETS TOP WARRIORS FOR FOURTH IN ROW
description: Showing complete dominance in the frontcourt, the Nets opened their five- game, eight-day trip with an easy 133- 122 victory tonight over the Golden State Warriors before 7,315 fans at the Oakland Coliseum Arena.

title: 8,000 Soviet Personnel Are Said to Be in Syria
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said today that the Soviet Union had organized air defense units among its 8,000 military personnel in Syria.

title: Beirut and the Balkans
description: The truck-bombers of Kuwait, like those of Beirut, are suicidal fanatics, hard to block with normal defenses and hard to punish with conventional military power. President Reagan and Secretary of State Shultz are right to warn that they will retaliate, and also wise not to act on mere suspicion. Sooner or later they'll come upon evidence showing whether these terrorists are freelance lunatics or agents of some country like Iran.

title: Christian Democrats Of World Rally in Chile
description: Christian Democrats from 15 countries sponsored a major rally here Monday night and called on Chile's military rulers to move toward democracy.

title: BASTIAN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Sometimes You Can't Win

title: Bridge:Goldberg Is Leaving Post As League Administrator
description: The adminstration of tournament bridge in North America requires a complex bureaucracy. The Memphis headquarters of the organization responsible for it - the American Contract Bridge League - is concerned with nearly 200,000 members, more than 345 local organizations, 4,200 clubs and nearly 800 annual tournaments.

title: A New Insurer For Tax-Exempts The Financial Guaranty Insurance Company, a new concern that will insure tax-exempt bonds and offer other kinds of financial guarantees, was introduced at a luncheon yesterday to investors and traders in tax-exempt bonds. Standard & Poor's has said that bonds backed by the New York-based insurance company would carry the highest AAA rating.
description: The use of outside insurance on municipal bonds has been growing rapidly, rising to an estimated $13 billion this year, from $2.9 billion in 1980.

title: CASTLE & COOKE GROUP RAISES DR PEPPER BID
description: In an effort to meet objections from the Dr Pepper Company, an investor group headed by Castle & Cooke Inc., the big West Coast food producer, last night raised its offer for Dr Pepper by $21 million, to $581 million in cash.

title: British Saatchi Makes A Public Offering
description: As it promised it would, the British Saatchi & Saatchi Company, which owns Compton Communications and McCaffrey & McCall here, made a public offering yesterday of 1.4 million American depositary shares at $22 a share.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Tastes of the Season

title: BITTER FIGHT OVER WATER NEAR END IN NEW MEXICO
description: A struggle over water rights between the Pueblo Indians and descendants of Spanish settlers who came here before the Pilgrims' landing is approaching resolution in Federal District Court, and bitterness on all sides is the only likely outcome.

title: SALVADORAN SAYS U.S. HELPS REDUCE KILLINGS
description: The former President of El Salvador, Jose Napoleon Duarte, today credited the Reagan Administration with helping to reduce right-wing killings in El Salvador with recent public denunciations, but he warned that violence could increase during the coming Salvadoran presidential election campaign.

title: BUELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
DR. BROWN'S THIRD CAREER
description: Dr. Bobby Brown sees the concern in the faces of his patients as he prepares to wind down his cardiology practice and become president of the American League.

title: HUNT, J B, TRANSPORT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of $846,000 for the quarter and 9 months from discontinued operations. c-Including gains from discontinued operations of $95,000 for the quarter and $196,000 for the 9 months.

title: MOTHER AND FOUR CHILDREN DIE IN AN ARSON FIRE IN BUSHWICK
description: A 27-year-old pregnant woman and her four children died last night when a fire that the police said had been deliberately set trapped them in their third- floor apartment in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn.

title: ARGENTINA'S NEW PRESIDENT SAYS JUNTA CHIEFS WILL BE PROSECUTED
description: President Raul Alfonsin announced tonight that he would prosecute Argentina's former military rulers for spreading ''terror, pain and death throughout Argentine society.''

title: Unfair Judging Abroad Of American Ads Seen
description: When it comes to judging American advertising European creative types tend not to be fair minded, according to Ronald K. Sherman, chairman of the recent International Film and TV Festival of New York that was held here last month.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Now, H.S. for Writing

title: Careers; Giving Investors An Edge
description: IN today's complicated investment environment, brokerage houses need all the help they can get in their battle to give their customers that little extra edge. That help comes in the form of a new breed of specialists whose job titles probably did not exist at brokerage firms five years ago.

title: SERVAMATIC SOLAR SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $193,100 for the quarter and 6 months. c-After an extraordinary credit of $593,000.

description: b-Net loss

description: IT is an inevitable dilemma, one

title: LOUISIANAN DIES IN ELECTRIC CHAIR
description: Robert Wayne Williams was executed early this morning in this tiny backwoods community, becoming the 10th person punished by the death penalty since the Supreme Court upheld capital punishment in 1976.

title: 'YELLOW RAIN': THE HOLES IN A BEE-EXCREMENT HYPOTHESIS
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Bombs Are Set Off At L.I. Naval Office
description: Two bombs exploded in the stairwells of a four-story office building housing a Navy recruiting office here, moments before the lunch hour today.

title: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan Investors Back Xerox Tactics
description: O N Sept. 21, 1982, when the Xerox Corporation announced plans to acquire Crum & Forster, a property and casualty insurer, for $1.6 billion, traders on the New York Stock Exchange quickly registered dismay. Xerox's common stock plunged 3 1/4 points that day, to 31 3/8, to yield more than 9 percent.

title: KISSINGER WANTS OUTSIDERS TO LEAVE CENTRAL AMERICA
description: The chairman of President Reagan's commission on Central America, Henry A. Kissinger, said today that external influences should be removed from the area and the rest of its problems should be ''worked out by the people concerned in their own manner.''

title: Kodak Diskettes
description: The Eastman Kodak Company's Spin Physics division introduced a 5 1/4-inch floppy disk for microcomputers that it said can store up to 3.3 million bytes of data. The Isomax HD600 diskette, combined with a high-performance disk drive that is in production, will have more storage capacity than any system of similar size now commercially available, Kodak said. The diskette is designed for use in a high- performance disk drive that is being manufactured by Drivetec Inc. of San Jose, Calif.

title: Pop Concert: Solo Percussion
description: RESTRAINT was the most distinctive characteristic of the percussionist Gerry Hemingway's solo concert at Roulette last Friday night. Despite Mr. Hemingway's formidable arsenal of instruments - a modified set of trap drums, cymbals, chimes and assorted noisemakers - the decibel level of his concert remained within comfortable perimeters.

title: PASQUALE FOOD CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: b-Net loss Share earnings reflect a 100 percent stock dividend paid in August 1983.

title: ROOTS OF 'ASSASSINS': HASHISH AND THE YEAR 1090
description: Assassination, a form of violence originating in the Middle East's turbulent past, has emerged as a pervasive and deadly weapon for which no one has an answer. That is the view of intelligence analysts and scholars reviewing the tactics used in a series of truck- bomb attacks in Lebanon and Kuwait against American diplomats and the Marines and French soldiers.

title: HUTTON BOOK RECALL SHOCKS PUBLISHERS
description: BOOK publishers are stunned by Random House's decision to recall and destroy 58,000 copies of a biography of the late Barbara Hutton because it contained errors about a Beverly Hills doctor.

title: SALVADORANS VOTE LAND PROGRAM CUT
description: A coalition of rightist parties pushed through a constitutional measure tonight that cuts by about half the amount of land available for future land redistribution in El Salvador.

title: NATIONAL SERVICE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
U.S. Asks Court Action On Meditation in School
description: The Reagan Administration asked the Supreme Court today to consider for the first time whether a ''moment of si- lence'' for prayer or meditation in public school classrooms was constitutional.

ALVARADO BEING TESTED BY SHORTFALL IN CITY SCHOOLS BUDGET
description: News Analysis

title: COMMISSION URGES 21 AS DRINKING AGE
description: The Presidential Commission on Drunk Driving recommended today that Congress deny Federal highway funds to states that fail to set the minimum drinking age at 21.

title: Leonard's Return to Restore Vitality
description: Marvelous Marvin Hagler is apparently at the rear of the line and Roberto Duran may be near the back. Sugar Ray Leonard's return, so fiercely opposed by some people who otherwise find no trouble in accepting boxing as a dangerous business, has at the very least restored vitality to a sport that has been sorely lacking major attractions.

title: Reagan Plans Textile Limit
description: President Reagan told a group of Southern Congressmen today that he would take unspecified action by Friday to limit the amount of textiles imported into the United States.

title: INTERSTATE BAKERIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 12
description: b-Including tax credits of $375,000 for the quarter and $692,000 for the 6 months. c-Including gains of $271,000 for the quarter and $1,128,000 for the 6 months from tax credits and the exchange of a portion of the company's convertible debentures for common stock.

title: THE A.P. APPOINTS CHIEF IN WASHINGTON AS EXECUTIVE EDITOR
description: Walter R. Mears, vice president and Washington bureau chief of The Associated Press, was appointed yesterday as the news agency's executive editor. He will remain a vice president.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE 'LIBERATORS.' My Life in the Soviet Army. By Viktor Suvorov. 202 pp. New York: W. W. Norton. $13.95.

title: Showboat Hotel
description: Showboat Inc. said it expects to begin construction within eight months on a 500-to-700-room hotel- casino and bowling center in Atlantic City that would be similar to its complex in Las Vegas, Nev. Completion is scheduled for the fall of 1985. Showboat, based in Las Vegas, said earlier this fall that it had signed a 99-year lease with Restorts International Inc. for 10 acres on the Boardwalk.

title: THE TRAUMA OF A FAMILY ROBBED AT HOME
description: Larry Steinberg - one of a score of people linked by Federal authorities to a major burglary and jewelry fencing ring operating out of New York - did not remember the robbery of Dr. Irving Malis's home in southern California the way Dr. Malis remembered it.

title: Mine Union Head Loses In Bid For More Power
description: Delegates to the United Mine Workers convention gave a stunning personal setback today to Rich Trumka, the union president, rejecting constitutional changes that would have given him virtually unlimited power.

title: Debt Issues
description: * American Medical International Inc. said it had executed new credit agreements covering $300 million medium-term unsecured financing with syndicates of domestic and international banks.

title: MAGNETIC TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31

description: A new 22-member civilian Government headed by Prime Minister Turkut Ozal took office today after the President, Gen. Kenan Evren, approved the Cabinet list.

title: Successes Reported For Afghan Rebels
description: Western diplomats said today that Moslem rebels had killed two senior Afghan Army officers.

description: Underground Support

description: ''If the offenders can be clearly identified, there will be ways of getting at them.'' - Secretary of State George P. Shultz, speaking of terrorist bombers. (A9:1.)

PARCELING OUT THE SOFTWARE
description: Softsel, the industry leader in what has been one of the fastest-growing segments of the personal and home computer business, was virtually unheard of four years ago.

title: 47TH STREET: A CENTER FOR STOLEN JEWELRY
description: A single 600-foot block in the heart of Manhattan - a block of sidewalk barkers and welcoming smiles, neon signs and showcase windows - has become the central transfer point for much of the jewelry stolen each year in the New York metropolitan area.

title: LARSEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Glenn Won't Alter HomosexualStand
description: Senator John H. Glenn of Ohio, a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, refused yesterday to change his position opposing Federal legislation barring discrimination against homosexuals.

title: NEW ROLE SEEN FOR RAIL LINES IN THE SUBURBS
description: Commuter railroads in the New York metropolitan area will be required to provide increased service over the next decade as greater numbers of suburbanites find jobs outside New York City, according to a study released yesterday.

description: Amateur Again

title: MOYNIHAN SEES 'REAL' THREAT OF BOMBINGS IN U.S. IN 1984
description: Terrorist bombings similar to those at the United States Embassy in Kuwait and the Marine headquarters in Beirut may well occur in the United States in the coming year, according to Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan.

title: TV: 'THE STORE,' A WISEMAN FILM
description: THE question about ''The Store,'' Frederick Wiseman's new documentary, is what is Mr. Wiseman trying to tell us about Neiman-Marcus? The question is trickier than it seems because Mr. Wiseman keeps his purpose to himself. His film says only that here is Neiman-Marcus, this is what it is. As a cinematic record, this may be valuable, although as television i: is scarcely compelling. ''The Store'' will be seen on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock tonight.

title: PETROLEUM ACREAGE CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net income. Year-ago results are for the year ended Feb. 28, 1982.

title: RED CROSS REPORTS ISRAELIS RENEGED
description: The International Committee of the Red Cross said today that Israel had released most but not all of the 4,500 Palestinians and Lebanese prisoners it had agreed to exchange last month for six captured Israeli soldiers.

title: Jersey Mother Indicted InDeathsof4Children
description: A Camden County grand jury today indicted a 25-year-old woman on charges she murdered her four children by pushing them into the Cooper River here.
