description: To the Editor:

title: YOUNG TEXAN IS THE MAN BEHIND MONDALE'S IMAGE
description: It was in Austin, Tex., in 1972 that Roy M. Spence Jr. walked into the offices of a liberal Democratic candidate for Senator, Ralph W. Yarborough, to volunteer the services of his new advertising agency.

title: JACKSON'S 'SILLY' COMPLAINT ABOUT NOW
description: To the Editor:

title: Recital: Emanuel Ax
description: EMANUEL AX'S piano recital in Alice Tully Hall Sunday night began with Haydn and went chronologically no further than Brahms, yet there was a satisfying symmetry to this contained and restricted world of musical style.

title: MONY MORTGAGE INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After gains from sale of investments of $459,000 for the quarter and $463,000 for the 6 months. c-After losses from sale of investments of $466,000 for the quarter and $463,000 for the 6 months.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: ''THE bar does close at 1 A.M., but we will be playing until 1:30,'' Duke Ellington announced toward the end of a 1957 dance performance in Carroltown, Pa., a typical night-on- the-road for the great composer-arranger and his orchestra. Chairs were heard scraping on stage and off as musicians and audience members headed for the bar. ''So,'' Mr. Ellington added, perhaps unnecessarily, ''let's - be fortified.''

title: Guatemala Reports Clash With Guerrillas
description: Soldiers killed 25 guerrillas who set off land mines in an ambush attempt near Guatemala's northern border with Mexico, the army said today.

title: UNIVERSITY GRAPHICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FIRE AND EXPLOSION ON SPACE SHUTTLE WENT UNDETECTED IN LANDING
description: The space shuttle Columbia was on fire as it landed last Thursday with six crew members and the European Spacelab on board, but the fire and an ensuing explosion were not detected until the next day, officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.

title: U.S. SHIPS ATTACK SYRIAN POSITIONS IN BEIRUT REGION
description: Two United States planes reportedly on a reconnaissance mission were shot at today by Syrian surface-to-air missiles. American warships then opened fire on Syrian antiaircraft batteries in the mountains east of Beirut.

title: POLAND 2 YEAR LATER
description: Two years after Gen. Wojiech Jaruzelski's military crackdown, the ''normalization'' of Poland has worked only superficially. Unlike the successful ''reconstituted'' regimes imposed 27 years ago in Hungary and 15 years ago in Czechoslovakia, General Jaruzelski's Government is clearly uncomfortable. Opposition to his rule is widespread, the Communist Party is in shambles, Government-sponsored trade unions are largely ignored by the workers and the economy is floundering.

title: THE MEDIUM THAT CURES
description: When an irate nation finally wreaks its vengeance on the capricious and insolent media, I pray that one medium will be spared. This is The Inquirer and Mirror, published weekly every Thursday on Nantucket Island, and, at a cost of $20 for an annual subscription anywhere in the United States, the biggest bargain in raging-blood-pressure therapy this side of shipwreck on a desert island somewhere east of Samoa.

title: TV: 'IN PERFORMANCE AT WHITE HOUSE'
description: TONIGHT'S presentation of ''In Performance at the White House,'' on Channel 13 at 8 o'clock, is not set in the White House. Taped on Dec. 1, it takes place a couple of miles away in Washington's Shiloh Baptist Church. The program, with Leontyne Price as host, consists entirely of spiritual and gospel music. As is usual with this outstanding series, President and Mrs. Reagan are sitting in the front row.

title: FILM: 'EYES, MOUTH,' FAMILY'S GRIEF
description: ''THE EYES, THE MOUTH,'' by Mario Bellocchio, takes the form of a morose post- mortem, as an Italian family grieves for a young man who has committed suicide. The dead man, Pippo, has left behind a mournful mother, as well as a pregnant young madonna-to-be, Wanda. He has also left a twin brother, Giovanni. The film is Giovanni's story, to the extent that it is anyone's at all.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: ; A SOVIET ECONOMIC DEBATE FAR SHORT OF UPHEAVAL
description: To the Editor:

title: ST. PETER'S DOWNS SETON HALL BY 71-60
description: An unbeaten record and a victory against a nationally ranked team has cast St. Peter's in a new light among its fans and opponents, especially the New Jersey schools it plays. So the Peacocks were expected to defeat Seton Hall tonight, despite the fact that the Pirates are a member of the powerful Big East Conference.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 14, 1983

title: A SOVIET ECONOMIC DEBATE FAR SHORT OF UPHEAVAL
description: To the Editor:

title: 2onCapsizedBoatDie In New Jersey Hospital
description: Two men from an 80- foot fishing boat that capsized in rough seas in the Manasquan Inlet died in a hospital today, and the Coast Guard called off a search for two missing crew members.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Interest Rates Post Big Rise;  Retail Sales Spurt Is Cited
description: Short- and long-term interest rates rose sharply yesterday morning and traded around those higher levels for the rest of the day.

title: U.S. JUDGE PLEADS NOT GUILTY
description: Federal District Judge Harry E. Claiborne pleaded not guilty in Federal District Court here today to charges of obstruction of justice, bribery, tax evasion and filing a false personal financial statement.

title: AVANT-GARDE COMPUTING reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $47,000 for the quarter and $87,000 for the 6 months. c-Including a tax credit of $48,000.

title: PRESIDENT SEEMS NEAR COMMITMENT ON SPACE STATION
description: A fire and a small explosion occurred on the space shuttle Columbia as it landed, NASA officials said. Page A28.

title: PISTONS, NUGGETS SHATTER MARKS
description: In the highest scoring game in the history of the National Basketball Association, the Detroit Pistons defeated the Denver Nuggets, 186-184, in triple overtime tonight.

title: REV. ALEXANDER SCHMEMANN, DEAN OF ORTHODOX SEMINARY
description: The Rev. Alexander Schmemann, dean of St. Vladimir's Orthodox Theological Seminary and widely acclaimed as an ecumenical leader and teacher, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Crestwood, N.Y. He was 62 years old.

title: BOMBARDIER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Music: Concert of Ragas
description: THE classical music of northern India has survived there for centuries as a sacred Hindu tradition. Across the border in Pakistan, a Moslem country, the same ragas are played by secular musicians.

title: Defaulted Victory in Jamaica
description: There's no suspense about the outcome of tomorrow's election in Jamaica. Prime Minister Edward Seaga's ruling Jamaica Labor Party has already won 54 of 60 seats in Parliament by default. The opposition People's National Party, led by former Prime Minister Michael Manley, decided to boycott the election, charging violation of a bipartisan understanding on election reform. As a result, the English-speaking Caribbean's largest and most important democracy now seems headed for a spell of one-party rule.

title: Phone Stocks: Special Listing
description: In a box with the New York

title: CABLE TV INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
REAGAN'S CASUAL PROMISES
description: In his latest weekly radio broadcast President Reagan said, ''Once internal stability is established (in Lebanon) and withdrawal of all foreign forces is assured, the Marines will leave.''

title: ADVERTISING
description: Y. & R. to Get Hamm's Beer The Pabst Brewing Company, Milwaukee, is going to consolidate some of its beer

title: HEALTH MAGAZINE IS IN FINE SHAPE
description: Nobody shirks at American Health magazine.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in Metropolitan Report Monday with an article on stolen property incorrectly described a sting operation run by the Bronx District Attorney's office. It was a simulated fencing office intended to catch thieves.

title: EMBASSY GUARDS KEEP REVOLVERS
description: The United States marines who guard American diplomatic buildings around the world are usually armed with .38- caliber revolvers that have a round in the chamber, a State Department spokesman said today.

title: Tanker Capsizes in Gulf
description: A blazing Greek tanker carrying 46,000 tons of crude oil capsized in the Persian Gulf Monday night after burning for four days, a port official said today.

title: SCOUTING
description: Money Isn't All In Seeking Sims

title: TROUBLE STIRS IN THE SOUTH AFRICAN HINTERLAND
description: A white farmer who lived and fought in Rhodesia's war and then moved to this remote place in the north of South Africa, almost within sight of his former home, was talking one recent day with an Afrikaner friend about their common prospects.

title: 20 Escape From Rumania
description: Twenty Rumanians hid in a sealed truck container stowed behind boxes of ball bearings to escape to Austria where they asked for political asylum, the police said today.

title: U.S. DIPLOMATS TELL OF 'THREATS' BEFORE BOMBING
description: France has acted to head off possible attacks on its leaders by Middle Eastern terrorists. Page A13.

title: Stocks Decline in Active Trading
description: Stock prices declined yesterday in accelerated trading as favorable economic news spurred concern that interest rates may continue to rise.

title: ASPIRING CHEERLEADERS THROW BODY AND SOUL INTO THEIR TRYOUT
description: ''Think,'' said a spokesman for the New Jersey Generals football team. ''What is something that New York, the largest metropolitan area in the country, still doesn't have and obviously wants and needs?''

title: LEORA DANA, 60, STAGE ACTRESS
description: The actress Leora Dana, who won a Tony Award in 1973 for her Broadway role in ''The Last of Mrs. Lincoln,'' died of cancer yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital. She was 60 years old.

title: 6 BANKS TO SHARE MACHINES
description: The Chemical Bank yesterday announced the banks in its proposed network of automated teller machines.

title: Reagan Plans News Session
description: President Reagan will hold a nationally broadcast news conference next week, his first in two months, a White House spokesman said today. Other aides said the President had set aside Tuesday night for his final formal news conference of the year with White House reporters. The news conference will be his seventh for the year and the 21st of his Presidency.

title: SCOUTING
description: Home and Away

title: CORE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
CORRECTION
description: A listing in the Finance/New Issues column of Business Day yesterday misidentified the underwriter for a financing by the Palm Beach County Solid Waste Authority. It is Prudential-Bache Securities.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Giving Again and Again

title: IN DALLAS, THREE SUPERB RESTAURANTS
description: DALLAS ADOZEN years ago I would have summed up the restaurant scene here in a phrase: ''Not worth a detour.'' There were dozens of barbecue restaurants and places where you could eat Tex-Mex cooking, but these were prevalent throughout Texas. There was one French restaurant of repute: La Vieille Varsovie, the Old Warsaw. It still exists.

title: COMPUTERS CATCH NEW YORK CITY TAX EVADERS
description: New York City officials, alarmed for years by the widespread evasion of city business and income taxes, are collecting millions of dollars through a computerized program aimed at thousands of residents and businesses that have avoided payment.

title: IRAN, IN U.N., WARNS OF FURTHER 'RETALIATIONS'
description: Iran's delegate to the United Nations warned today that the United States involvement in Lebanon would lead to ''further retaliations'' against its forces there.

title: A Drug-Alcohol Center Treats Elizabeth Taylor
description: Elizabeth Taylor has been undergoing treatment for chemical dependency at Eisenhower Medical Center, a hospital spokesman said Monday.

title: G. & W. Forecast
description: Martin S. Davis, chief executive of Gulf and Western Industries, predicted yesterday that the recently slimmed-down conglomerate would earn $3 a share in the fiscal year ending July 31. In the 1983 fiscal year, the company earned $1.70 a share on continuing operations excluding special charges and write-offs. G. & W. had $260 million in after-tax earnings in 1983, but a one-time $472 million charge, which was part of its divestiture program, resulted in a $212 million net loss.

title: RIVALS START TO PREY ON IBH'S MARKET
description: The collapse of West Germany's IBH Holding A.G. has punched a sizable hole in Europe's construction machine industry. But already, a number of strong contenders - from the United States and Japan as well as Europe - are jockeying to fill it.

title: Metromedia's Founder Begins New Challenge At the age of 68, John W. Kluge is taking Metromedia Inc. on yet another financial adventure.
description: Mr. Kluge and four of Metromedia's top executives, along with the investment firm of Boston Ventures Ltd. Partnership, plan to take the big communications company private by purchasing it for $1.6 billion.

title: Key Rates
description: * Nuveen index, John Nuveen & CompanySalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SCOUTING
description: Jets Honor Mehl

title: Martin Marietta
description: The Energy Department has given the Martin Marietta Corporation a five-year contract to manage four nuclear facilities at Oak Ridge and Paducah, Ky.

title: U.S. SAYS IT PRESSED SALVADOR ON CHURCHWOMEN
description: A former Federal judge and Deputy Attorney General has filed a report rebutting criticism that the Administration failed to press for swift prosecution of the killers of four American churchwomen in El Salvador, Congressional sources said today.

title: CABLE TV WEIGHS INCREASE IN CHARGES
description: Cost pressures are mounting for cable programming services, according to industry executives gathered at a pair of annual conventions this week in southern California. With advertising dollars falling short of projections, the executives are trying to figure out how to pass on more of the costs to the industry's 34 million subscribers.

title: Brynner Vows to Beat Lung Cancer Diagnosis
description: Yul Brynner said today that he was determined to beat lung cancer, even though in September doctors gave him only two months to live.

title: STAR WARS-PIE IN THE SKY
description: President Reagan may soon follow up his ''star wars'' speech of last spring. This is what I wish he would say:

title: Atlanta Slayer Asserts He Was Falsely Accused
description: Wayne Williams, linked by the police to the slayings of 24 young Atlanta blacks, broke a long silence on the case today by telling reporters he has been ''wrongly accused and connected with a series of heinous crimes.''

title: MASSACHUSETTS BATTLES LAWYER OVER $332,441 RIGHTS CASE FEE
description: Nearly everyone agrees that civil liberties are worth fighting for. But when it comes to determining how much the tab should be, that is a different story, as Laurence H. Tribe can attest.

title: MEAT PRICES: LOW NOW, BUT GOING UP
description: ANYONE who diligently follows supermarket advertisements knows that prices of certain foods can be as volatile as March weather. Often this is the result of unexpected surpluses of produce or meats that a store wants to liquidate quickly, or it could be a sales technique to lure customers into the store in the hope they will buy other items as well. The significantly lower prices of meat nationwide in recent months, however, have more deeply rooted causes, and consumers now have an ex

title: THE MAYRO IS 'AWAY'
description: The whereabouts of Mayor Michael J. Matthews of this resort city remained a mystery today as a Federal grand jury in Camden opened an investigation into charges of corruption in the city government with testimony from Kitty Johnson, administrative assistant and secretary to the Mayor.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: WITH the holiday season at hand, this seems an appropriate time to offer recipes for dishes that are of a special nature but can be prepared in a limited time. Elegant seafood mousses seem particularly suitable: they add style and flair to almost any occasion but do not have to be complicated.

title: ADVANCE CIRCUITS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
description: b-Net loss.

title: CRACKDOWN OF '81 MARKED IN POLAND
description: The second anniversary of the military crackdown against Solidarity passed today with memorial masses in churches and with Lech Walesa, its former leader, placing his Nobel Peace Prize medal at a Roman Catholic shrine.

title: TOUCH-AND-TELL MONEY
description: To the Editor:

title: A DEMOCRATIC HOTEL MAN IN A REPUBLICAN CITY
description: The Talk of San Diego

title: WINE TALK
description: Did you know that the French Government approved the appellation Sancerre for the wine of that region in 1936 and that 14 communes, with names such as Bue, St.-Satur and Menetou-Ratel are entitled to use it? Neither did I.

title: Bulls 96, Bucks 88
description: The rookie guard Ennis Whatley scored 10 of his 16 points in the fourth quarter to rally te Chicago to a victory over Milwaukee, ending the Bulls' eight-game losing streak.

title: WARS OVER THE YEARS
description: In the squishy mud in the geometrical center of Bryant Park, Thomas Faulkner hammered the final touches yesterday on the rough planks of his antiwar sculpture.

title: JURORS FAIL TO AGREE AT THE BRIBERY TRIAL OF DETROIT CITY AIDE
description: The three- month Federal bribery trial of the former director of this city's Water and Sewer Department and five others ended today with the jury unable to reach a verdict on a majority of the charges.

title: THEATER: 'INHERITORS,' WITH GERALDINE PAGE
description: SUSAN GLASPELL'S ''Inheritors'' is about protecting the environment from greedy real-estate developers, professors who give up their principles under pressure from administrators, dark-skinned people who are harassed because they are ''foreigners,'' the rights of Indians to their traditional lands, Federal vigilantes who exercise thought control and conscientious objectors who oppose war.

title: Economic Scene; An Innovator's Rich Legacy
description: NO woman has yet received the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science - and none is likely to for a while, since the strongest contender, Joan Robinson, professor emerita of the University of Cambridge in England, died last August at the age of 80. But there is little danger that Mrs. Robinson will be forgotten, as was evident at the symposium in her honor last weekend at Barnard College of Columbia University.

title: CHAMBER: EMERSON QUARTET
description: THE concerts given by the Lincoln Center Chamber Music Society seem to have fallen into a routine. What can be expected is playing that is dutiful but without much conviction, polished without being inspired.

title: Brookshier Penalized
description: Tom Brookshier , the CBS-TV pro football commentator, has been removed from his assignment to cover the Philadelphia-St. Louis game next Sunday because of a remark he made last Sunday in the Philadelphia-New Orleans telecast.

title: MUSIC: A TRIBUTE TO ELLIOTT CARTER, 75
description: THE first American performance of Elliott Carter's ''In Sleep, in Thunder,'' presented by Speculum Musicae in the 92d Street Y Sunday night, was a fitting birthday tribute to the composer. For Mr. Carter, who became 75 years old Sunday, is not just the most important living American composer, he continues to astonish and to challenge. And this 1981 work, a setting of six poems of Robert Lowell, might be called Mr. Carter's autumnal ''Songs of Experience'' - subtle and powerful settings that like the poems themselves speak of aging and loss, bitterness and despair evoked with wry irony.

title: STRATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Irsay Off the Hook
description: When Robert Irsay , the owner of the Baltimore Colts, was asked the other day about his star running back, Curtis Dickey , who has reportedly been offered a five-year, $3.3 million contract to jump to the San Antonio Gunslingers of the United States Football League, Irsay suggested that he was willing to let Dickey go because he had been negotiating with a potential replacement - Bo Jackson, Auburn's star sophomore running back. ''He wants out,'' Irsay said of Jackson, ''and I can get him for $2.5 million.''

title: HELLENIC LINES IN CHAPTER 11
description: The troubled international shipping industry got another jolt yesterday when Hellenic Lines Ltd., the largest container ship company in Greece and one of the world's five largest privately owned ship companies, announced that it had filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: Comings and Goings
description: As expected, 40-year-old Joe Morgan, who thought he had played his last major league game less than two months ago when Philadelphia lost the World Series, signed a one-year contract with the Oakland A's, the only team he'd said he consider playing for. . . .Bobby Chacon, the lightweight scheduled to challenge Ray Mancini next month, and Don King, the promoter, have dropped their lawsuits against each other, setting Chacon free to make deals with any other promoters. . . . . Erhardt Kapp, a former Connecticut star who was the Cosmos' first-round draft choice in 1981 but was released this fall, signed a one-year contract with the Pittsburgh Spirit. . . . Stan Parrish, quarterback coach at Purdue this season, has been hired as head coach at Marshall University, succeeding Sonny Randle, who was dropped after five losing seasons at the school, which has had 18 losing seasons in a row. . . . , . . . The Montreal Expos said they had broken off negotiations with their free-agent second baseman, Manny Trillo.

title: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 14, 1983 International
description: American warships opened fire on Syrian antiaircraft batteries in the mountains east of Beirut after two United States jets reportedly on a reconnaissance mission were fired on by Syrian surface-to-air missiles. Neither plane was hit. Farther north, Israeli gunboats shelled strongholds of Yasir Arafat's Palestinian guerrillas around Tripoli. (Page A1, Col. 6.) The American Embassy in Kuwait received ''general and specific threats'' over the last several months that prompted officials to take ''as many precautions as possible,'' according to embassy officials. But they said they had not acted on several proposals designed to improve security at the embassy compound, the main target of Monday's bomb attack, because of budgetary and other constraints. (A1:5.)

title: VILAS AND TIRIAC OFFER DENIALS
description: Guillermo Vilas and his manager and coach, Ion Tiriac, testified at a public hearing yesterday that they had not solicited or received appearance money to guarantee Vilas's participation in a tennis tournament last March in Rotterdam, the Netherlands.

title: AID AUTO STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including income of $2,515 for the quarter and a loss of $35,149 for the 9 months from discontinued operations.

title: SALVADOR REBELS REVILE LATE CHIEF
description: The patriarch of El Salvador's revolutionary movement, Salvador Cayetano Carpio, ordered the murder of a rival this year after becoming ''blinded by his political ambitions,'' according to a guerrilla communique published here today.

title: U.S. RENEWS ACCORD ON AZORES AIR BASE
description: The United States and Portugal signed agreements today extending American rights to use an air base in the Azores for seven more years and in return pledging increased military and economic aid.

title: LOWER MANHATTAN DRAWS NEW BACK OFFICE MARKET
description: Officially, it is called the Lower Manhattan Mixed Use District. But more commonly, the elongated triangle below Canal Street, west of West Broadway and north of the World Trade Center, is known as TriBeCa, Lower Hudson or, on occasion, Washington Market.

title: ST. JOHN'S TROUNCES MANHATTAN, 62-39
description: With its star player, Chris Mullin, watching from the bench, unbeaten St. John's defeated Manhattan College last night, 62-39, at Alumni Hall for its fifth victory of the season.

title: SPAIN'S 'NEW' POLICE: HARDLY LOVED BUT HATED LESS
description: A strange thing happened at a Madrid rally against Basque violence some weeks ago. A contingent of policemen walked by and to the surprise of thousands, including the policemen themselves, they were applauded.

title: EX-AIDE ASSERTS BEATTY TOLD HER HOW TO RUN VOTE FRAUD
description: A longtime aide to former State Senator Vander L. Beatty of Brooklyn testified yesterday that Mr. Beatty had personally showed her how to carry out an election-fraud scheme after he lost a 1982 Democratic primary race for Congress.

title: KNICKS LOSE ON GOALTENDING
description: On a call that satisfied neither team, Cedric Maxwell was credited with the winning basket when Marvin Webster was charged with goaltending with 5 seconds remaining, giving the Boston Celtics a 102-100 victory at Madison Square Garden last night.

title: MGM/UA, Begelman Settled for $732,000 An automobile and $732,000 - that's what David Begelman got from the MGM/UA Entertainment Company to settle his contract after he was dismissed in 1982 as head of the United Artists unit.
description: The terms of the settlement were disclosed in a proxy statement for the annual meeting Jan. 14. The statement also reported settlements with two other former top executives, Joseph A. Fischer and Donald Sipes.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Blue Chip Stamps Inc., Los Angeles, has named Charles T. Munger, chairman, to the additional post of chairman and president of its Wesco Financial Corp. subsidiary and Wesco's Mutual Savings and Loan subsidiary.

title: GRETZKY BREAKS RECORD
description: The hero of the night was supposed to be Wayne Gretzky, premier point- maker of the Edmonton Oilers, and he fulfilled his mission of scoring in his 31st consecutive game.

title: FRUITCAKES: SOLID EVIDENCE OF CHRISTMAS
description: BREATHES there a man with tastes so dead who never to himself has said, on having yet another holiday fruitcake delivered to his doorstep, ''What ever happend to the

description: BASEBALL

title: SEAGRAM CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: All figures are in U.S. funds.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: -wanted gift was a video game. This year it's either a minicomputer or a Cabbage Patch doll, both of which are in short supply.

title: Villanova Revival
description: The board of trustees

title: EARLY START PAVES WAY FOR A LITTLE-FUSS BUDGET
description: In the Office of Management and Budget, memorandums, graphs, charts, reports and a calculator are strewn on the desk of the director, David A. Stockman. Four people are assigned to help him organize his work.

title: Brazil Halts Most Imports RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 14 (AP) - Brazilian authorities have suspended virtually all imports for the rest of the month to keep dollars from flowing out of the country, a Government spokesman said today.
description: The ban affects all imports, ''with rare exceptions for absolutely essential products that can't wait till next year,'' said Sergio Ribas Camara, a spokesman for Cacex, the Government's import-export agency. He did not specify which products would be allowed in.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Jay Rockefeller said he had been approached about becoming commissioner of baseball but had told the owners' search committee that he was happy as Governor of West Virginia. . . . Blair Kiel , Notre Dame's senior quarterback, who lost his starting job early this season to a freshman, Steve Beuerlein , has been named as the starter against Boston College in the Liberty Bowl on Dec. 29. . . . Billy Cannon , the former Heisman Trophy winner and professional football star, wants a reduction in his five-year sentence for counterfeiting, and a hearing on the application has been set for Jan. 6. . . . Joe Delaney , the former Kansas City Chief back who drowned last summer while trying to save three children from a pond, has been honored by the National Collegiate Athletic Association with its Award of Valor.

title: Ceiling Collapses; No Pupils Injured
description: Two- thirds of a ceiling in a school auditorium collapsed at 8:52 this morning, shortly before students were to have used the room for a music rehearsal, officials said.

title: Eurobonds Steady In Quiet Trading LONDON, Dec. 14 (Reuters) - Eurobonds were steady today in quiet trading, dealers said.
description: American convertibles traded in a narrow range after slight declines early on.

title: Dow Off 9.24; Trading Heavy
description: Stock prices dropped broadly in active trading yesterday as investors' concerns over rising interest rates continued to take its toll.

title: NO-WIN TO NO-LOSE
description: The new Reagan-Shultz policy for the Middle East re-recognizes Israel as our only proven ally in stopping Soviet-Syrian-P.L.O. aggression. This hard-learned policy is being resisted fiercely by the very people whose pro-Arab assurances brought us into a shooting war.

title: NEW IMAGE OF THE MILKY WAY HINTS BLACK HOLE IS AT CENTER
description: Observations with 27 antennas strung out in a large Y pattern on a barren plain in New Mexico have charted the heart of the Milky Way galaxy in great detail for the first time. The resulting images, produced by several researchers in recent months, reveal three curving streams of gas that some astronomers believe are falling into a black hole in the very center.

title:
GARDENING;
SAFE WINTER VACATION FOR HOUSE PLANTS
description: -dotted beach for a winter vacation may mean leaving your own potted palms or other house plants untended. Here are a few simple methods of keeping indoor plants watered for up to two weeks.

title: U.S. BIDS SALVADOR EXPEL THOSE TIED TO MURDER SQUADS
description: The United States has demanded that the Salvadoran Government exile or expel a number of civilians and military officers involved in right-wing death squads, according to Salvadoran political sources.

title: Hoyas Triumph By 97-67
description: Patrick Ewing scored 14 points and Gene Smith added 13 as Georgetown defeated South Carolina State, 97-67, tonight.

title: SUN ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After tax credits of $105,000 for the quarter and $703,000 for the year. c-After a tax credit of $705,000 for the quarter and year.

title: F.B.I. HEAD SAYS TERRORISM IN U.S. IS DOWN BUT FEAR RISES
description: The Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation said Wednesday that there was rising concern over terrorism in the United States but that such incidents dropped to 30 this year, as against 51 last year and a peak of about 100 in 1977.

title: Entire Cabinet Quits in Bolivia
description: The entire Bolivian Cabinet handed its collective resignation to President Hernan Siles Zuazo today, Foreign Minister Jose Ortiz Mercado said.

description: Crafts in the Armory '83 , New York

title: Todd Says Jets Had Letdown;  Some Players Not 'Hungry'
description: Richard Todd, their quarterback, says that complacency is a major reason why the Jets have suffered through one of their most disappointing seasons.

title: PRICES THAT NO ONE IS FORCED TO PAY
description: To the Editor:

title: DEVILS GET TIE ON GAGNE GOAL
description: Paul Gagne's goal in the third period gave the Devils a 3-3 tie with the Sabres tonight.

title: ANALOG DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: The share earnings have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split in March 1983.

title: Argentina in Plea on Debt BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 14 (Reuters) - Argentina has asked its steering committee of foreign banks to extend a Dec. 15 deadline for refinancing $9 billion worth of public sector external debt, the Economy Minister, Bernardo Grinspun, said today. Mr. Grinspun told reporters after his first meeting with representatives of the steering committee in Buenos Aires that the banks would reply by Thursday.
description: He did not say how long a period he had sought to complete the refinancing.

title: Cosmos Defeated By Rowdies, 6-3
description: Mark Karpun scored two goals in the fourth period as the Tampa Bay Rowdies defeated the Cosmos, 6-3, tonight in a North American Soccer League indoor match.

title: ROBERT WHITE 2D, MRS. CROLIUS WED
description: Peggy Lee Crolius of Washington and Birmingham, Ala., and Robert M. White 2d, editor and publisher of The Mexico (Mo.) Evening Ledger, were married yesterday.

title: HERS
description: TWO friends accompanied me to the stillness

title: BATTLESHIP'S GUNS SHELL SYRIAN SITES IN LEBANESE WAR
description: The battleship New Jersey opened fire for the first time against targets in Lebanon today, hurling 1,900-pound shells at Syrian antiaircraft positions in the mountains east of here.

title: Rockland Electric Proposes Rate Cut
description: The Rockland Electric Company sought permission today from the Board of Public Utilities to reduce its rates for residential heating customers by 6 percent, largely because of falling oil prices.

title: KASPAROV AND KORCHNOI DRAW IN 10TH GAME
description: Gary Kasparov of the Soviet Union inched closer to victory in his semifinal world championship chess match by making a draw in the 10th game with Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland tonight.

title: Ban on Fraternity in Death
description: Omega Psi Phi fraternity has been banned from campus activities at Tennessee State University for at least three years, the university announced Tuesday. The body of a member, Van L. Watts, 20 years old, was discovered the morning after an initiation party Nov. 29, with five times more alcohol in his blood than is necessary to be considered legally intoxicated in Tennessee, the medical examiner ruled.

title: Bridge: Edgar Kaplan and His Team Continue Their Fine Record
description: There are perhaps a hundred players with serious ambitions to represent the United States and become a world champion. At each national championship they fight desperately to win a major team title, and thus qualify for the playoffs that determine the American team.

title: IF ONE AMERICAN IS GOING HUNGRY, REAGAN SAYS, IT'S 'ONE TOO MANY'
description: President Reagan said today that while ''it must be true'' that some undeserving people lined up at charity soup kitchens, his Administration's policy was that even one American going hungry was ''one too many.''

title: WESTERN ELECTRIC, 114, PUT ON RETIREMENT LIST
description: After more than 100 years of corporate life, first as an independent company and then as the manufacturing arm of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the Western Electric Company will be dissolved on Jan. 1, A.T.& T. said yesterday. The giant company's people and plants will spread among other divisions of the new A.T.& T.

title: 3 CHICAGO JUDGES FACE BRIBE CHARGE
description: Three present and former judges were among 10 men indicted today on charges of corruption after a three-and-a-half-year Federal investigation of the Cook County Circuit Court.

title: New Boxing Title Is Won by Camel
description: Marvin Camel won the International Boxing Federation's first world cruiserweight title fight Tuesday night by beating Roddy MacDonald on a disputed technical knockout at 2 minutes 49 seconds of the fifth round.

title: WASHINGTON SCIENTIFIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for 12 wks to Nov 20
HUBBARD REAL ESTATE INVESTMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including gains of $129,000 for the quarter and $578,146 for the year on the sale of real estate. c-Including a gain of $11,486 on the sale of real estate.

title: ACME GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
No Headline
description: The Polls at the Polls The state of Washington, like other Western states, has an infection-by-projection problem. It concerns exit polls, those illuminating surveys that tell so much about why people vote the way they do. Exit polls can have another effect; sometimes, indirectly, they might discourage Westerners from voting. And so Washington enacted a blunt remedy: it banned them.

title: Textile Trade Warning WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 - President Reagan, now considering additional protection for the textile industry, was warned today by the head of the Senate Finance Committee that such action could set a precedent for a ''multitude'' of similar complaints endangering American global trading relationships.
description: Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, whose committee has responsibility for trade, injected himself into the textile trade controversy within 48 hours of an expected decision by the President in an unfair trade case involving imports from China.

title: ENERGY METHODS CORP reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $65,000.

title: Advertising; Neophyte Agency's Client List
description: DURING the six months it has been in business, Fredericks Kullberg Amato Pisacane has made only one television commercial. With it, though, it won a gold award at the recent International Television and Film Festival of New York.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Advertising column in Business Day on Nov. 30 misstated the findings of a survey of company executives on the subject of corporate advertising. A majority disagreed with the statement ''Corporate advocacy advertising is a blatant misuse of stockholder money.''

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;  First Women's Bank Names Top Exzecutive After seven months without a president, The First Women's Bank announced yesterday that Jill M. Considine, has been named president and chief executive officer effective Jan. 1.
description: Miss Considine, 39, is vice president and division head for commercial loan operations at Bankers Trust Company, where she is responsible for the administration of the commercial loan portfolio for New York, Nassau and the International Banking Facility.

title: ADVERTISING ; 3 of 9 Investigations Result in Ad Changes
description: Only three of the nine investigations of national advertising claims were resolved in November when the advertisers in question either changed or dropped the advertising.

title: TOPPS & TROWSERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
PICO PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Soviet Lofts a Satellite In Animal Space Study
description: The Soviet Union announced today that it had launched a satellite to study the effect of space flight on living organisms. An East German report said that the craft carried two monkeys and 18 rats.

title: SCHRADER, ABE, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
WORTHINGTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
; HOW LIVES CAN BE THREADED FOR STATE CONTROL
description: To the Editor:

title: KISSINGER FAVORS WIDE LATIN TALKS
description: Henry A. Kissinger said today that his commission on Central America favored ''greater specificity'' for the Contadora peace process and a ''general negotiation'' involving both the Nicaraguan Government and the American-supported rebels.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE ;
description: -studded West 47th Street, between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas, and, indeed, the second floor of the Gotham Book Mart and Gallery, at 41 West 47th Street (719- 4476), may have the only tree worth stopping to stare at on this block whose sparkle is all business.

title: U.S. LENGTHENS BATTLESHIP'S STAY IN MEDITERRANEAN UNTIL THE SPRING
description: The Navy has extended the Mediterranean tour of the battleship New Jersey, which fired 16-inch guns at Syrian missile launchers in Lebanon today, until she is relieved by the battleship Iowa next spring, Defense Department officials said today.

title: MINERS' LEADER AFTER A YEAR: SUCCESSES, BUT OBSTACLES REMAIN
description: News Analysis

title: REAGAN PREDICTS ROLE TILL BEIRUT STANDS OR FALLS
description: News session transcript, Page B12.

title: West German Output
description: West German industrial production in October was ''practically unchanged'' from September, after seasonal adjustment, the Economics Ministry said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Living Section on Dec. 7 about food gifts for Christmas misidentified a piece of equipment in the Windsor's Choice Home Brewery Kit. It is a hydrometer.

title: ADRIAN J. PINSINCE
description: Adrian J. Pinsince, former president of Ayerst International Inc., a pharmaceutical subsidiary of the American Home Products Corporation, died of cancer Saturday at his home in Ivoryton, Conn.

title: TOPPS CHEWING GUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
ANGLICAN ASSESSES RELIGIOUS RIGHTS IN CHINA
description: The Most Rev. Robert Runcie, Archbishop of Canterbury, said today that Chinese Christians were enjoying greater safeguards in trying to build a church, but he stopped short of suggesting that they had achieved religious freedom.

title: TAB PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
DUPLEX PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
THURSDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Chicago Bulls , at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. The Knicks' loss to Boston Tuesday night gave them two straight home defeats for the first time this season.

title: New Elway at Stanford
description: Jack Elway was named yesterday as the head football coach at Stanford, where his son John had been an all-America quarterback before joining the Denver Broncos this year.

title: THATCHER VICTORY ON FLEET STREET
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher won a major victory today when the Trades Union Congress, the powerful central body of British labor, withdrew its support for a proposed 24-hour strike by a printers' union against all the national newspapers.

title: IRAQ FIRES MISSILES AT IRAN TO AVENGE KUWAIT
description: Iraq said yesterday that it had responded to the car-bomb attacks in Kuwait, one of its staunchest supporters in the war with Iran, by firing surface-to- surface missiles against five Iranian towns on Tuesday.

title: TRIANGLE MICROWAVE reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
TV: PREMIERES OF TWO ACTION SERIES
description: It's Glen A. Larson time on ABC this evening and that means action- adventure. Mr. Larson has been associated, in various capacities behind the camera, with series such as ''McCloud,'' ''Magnum, P.I.,'' ''Quincy,'' ''Battlestar Galactica,'' ''Manimal'' and ''The Fall Guy.'' Now Larson Productions, in association with Twentieth Century-Fox TV, has two new candidates for escapist addicts. ''Automan'' and ''Masquerade'' are having their 90-minute premieres tonight.

title: COMMONWEALTH FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The year-ago results reflect the combined performance of First Continental R.E.I.T. and M & T Mortgage Investors, acquired in August.

title: COACH AT COLUMBIA LIKES HIS FREEDOM
description: It amazes Aladar Kogler that it takes just 30 seconds to place a call from his office at Columbia University to a friend's home in Los Angeles. ''Beep, beep, beep, and you are speaking,'' he said. ''In Czechoslovakia you could spend sometimes one hour to reach someone in the same city.''

title: Toshiba Profit Up 41% in Half
description: The Toshiba Corporation, which makes electronic and electrical equipment, said today that its earnings in the six months ended Sept. 30 rose 41 percent, to $112 million, from $79 million a year before.

title: Playwright Prize Awarded
description: Nina Shengold, a New York writer, was named winner of the first ABC Playwright Award yesterday for ''Homesteaders.'' The play, 1 of 10 nominated by producers from Broadway and Off Broadway, had its debut in Albany. Anthony D. Thomopoulos, the president of the ABC Broadcast Group, presented the $2,500 award.

title: Bell's Nephew Gets 15 Years
description: Bryan Bell, the nephew of Bobby Bell, the former Kansas City Chiefs' linebacker, was sentenced today to two concurrent 15-years-to-life terms for the stabbing death of Frank Seurer Sr., the father of the University of Kansas quarterback, Frank Jr.

title: Steinbrenner Offers No Clue On Martin
description: George Steinbrenner

title: VALLEY RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Rail Holding Units' Merger Delayed
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission today barred for up to 15 days the proposed merger of Santa Fe Industries and the Southern Pacific Corporation, parents of two major railroads that themselves are seeking to combine to create the nation's third-biggest rail system.

title: PRESIDENT MOVES TO PATCH RIFT WITH HIS SENIOR ECONOMIC ADVISER
description: President Reagan today appeared to be trying to patch things up with his chief economist, Martin S. Feldstein. The chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers has been publicly criticized in recent weeks by the White House spokesman, Larry Speakes, for his remarks on the Federal budget deficit, taxes and military spending.

title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES
description: Olympic Aggravation

title: '84 GROWTH PUT AT 4.5% BY OFFICIALS
description: The Reagan Administration's top economic officials have drafted an economic forecast showing moderately strong growth of about 4.5 percent in 1984 and a small decline in the unemployment rate to less than 8 percent.

title: Write-Off Planned At Ingersoll-Rand
description: The Ingersoll-Rand Company said yesterday that it will take a special charge of $138 million in the fourth quarter as a result of plant closings and consolidations and the restructuring of its international operations.

title: Plagiarism by Reporter Leads to a Suspension
description: A reporter for The Plain Dealer was reprimanded and suspended for three days for plagiarizing part of a 1981 Washington Post column by Carl Rowan, the Cleveland paper said today.

title: BAYLY CORP reports earnings for 16 wks to Oct 29
description: b-Net loss.

title: FED ACTS TO CURB 'NONBANK BANKS'
description: The Federal Reserve Board moved today to close what it called a ''loophole'' in the 1956 law that has allowed a growing number of commercial and industrial concerns to enter the banking business by the backdoor.

title: COLLINS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Filipino Rebels Kill 8
description: Gunmen believed to be Moslem separatist rebels ambushed an army truck on Mindanao Island, killing six soldiers and two civilians, including a 2-year- old boy, the Philippine News Agency reported today. One of those wounded in the attack, in Lanao del Sur Province, 500 miles southeast of Manila, was the father of the boy who was killed, the report said.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Polaroid Officer Becomes President

title: Swan Offering Breaks Ground
description: The Swan Brewery Company Ltd. (Australia) has arranged the first speculative-grade debt offering in the United States by a foreign borrower.

title: DEEPER AND DEEPER
description: Day by day the United States moves deeper into the Lebanese quagmire: Marines, artillery, bombers, now the battleship New Jersey. Why? As the situation visibly deteriorates, why are we keeping the Marine force there?

title: SCOUTING
description: A $10 Mistake

title: SCHOOL OFFICIALS GET LEGAL TIPS ON SPORTS RISKS
description: From all over the state they came, 350 of them, superintendents and coaches, athletic directors and school business agents, all responsible for their high school districts' sports programs.

title: SUPER VALU STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 3
description: The results include operations of Pantry Pride Enterprises Inc., from the date of acquisition, Sept. 30.

title: SERVICE AGENCY HELPS CHILDREN GET 900 COATS
description: Maurice Harpe, dazzling the eye in his new tan coat, succinctly summed up the deeper meaning behind the good-hearted pandemonium swirling around him yesterday.

title: CITY WON'T EVICT THOSE WHO REJECT APARTMENTS
description: The Koch administration has dropped its plan to evict from its shelter program homeless families who refuse to accept any of three apartments, city officials said yesterday.

title: Fight Over Jet Crash Costs
description: The District of Columbia wants Air Florida to pay almost $1 million for a rescue and salvage operation after an airplane crash in the Potomac River and 78 people died. Lawyers reached a settlement of $70,000 Tuesday for damage caused to the 14th Street Bridge when the jet plunged into it Jan. 13, 1982, but the city's lawyers said they would press for more because of the salvage and rescue costs.

title: U.S. WEIGHS UNESCO PULLOUT OVER BUDGET AND POLICY FIGHT
description: The Reagan Administration is seriously considering withdrawing the United States from Unesco, State Department officials and American delegates to the organization said yesterday.

title: MANY INMATES FREED ON LOW BAIL SKIP DATES IN COURT IN MANHATTAN
description: Four of every 10 Manhattan defendants freed from jail last month to ease overcrowding have missed court appearances or have been arrested on new charges, according to figures released yesterday by the Manhattan District Attorney's office.

title: NBC REVISES PRIME-TIME SCHEDULE
description: -time schedule yesterday in yet another effort to improve its popularity with viewers. This television season, like the last eight, NBC has lagged behind CBS and ABC in the audience ratings for the evening hours.

title: WEST POINT-PEPPERELL reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
KINGS EDGE BLACK HAWKS, 6-5
description: The Kings defeated the Black Hawks, 6-5, tonight for the first victory by Los Angeles in Chicago since March 5, 1981.

title: PROVIDENT INSTITUTION reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Bogota Fund Shift Traced
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Dec. 14

title: COM SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: ALTERNATIVE ALLIANCE
description: The cruise and Pershing 2 missiles have come. The United States is pursuing an interventionist policy. The Russians have walked out of arms control talks in Geneva. Yuri V. Andropov has announced the acceleration of new nuclear arms programs in Eastern Europe and in the seas adjacent to the United States. Our most nightmarish predictions seem to have come true.

title: Grand Jury Calls Atlantic City Aide
description: As F.B.I. agents examined municipal records, a second City Hall aide was ordered today to appear before a Federal grand jury investigating accusations of corruption against Mayor Michael Matthews.

title: AIRLINE IS CLOSING UNDER U.S. THREAT
description: Air Illinois, under threat of being shut down by the Federal Government for safety reasons, has agreed to halt its operations voluntarily as of today, Federal aviation sources said last night.

title: Dr Pepper Critical Of New Offer DALLAS, Dec. 14 (AP) - The Dr Pepper Company criticized a new acquisition offer of $581 million by the DPCC Acquisition Corporation, saying the proposal was not as serious as that of a rival group's bid.
description: -products concern based in Honolulu, increased its offer by $21 million on Tuesday in an effort to meet objections by Dr Pepper that the original offer of $24 a share was actually worth only $23.12. The Dr Pepper board supports a rival bid of $22 a share, or $513 million, made by a group headed by Forstmann Little & Company, a New York investment banking concern.

title: COMPUTRAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income.

title: SALMON FISHING MORATORIUM IS SOUGHT
description: Citing a continuing decline - which reached a new low this year - in the world's Atlantic salmon stocks, officials of the Atlantic Salmon Federation have called for a five-year moratorium on saltwater harvesting of the species.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST THURSDAY, DECEMBER 15, 1983
description: The Economy Top Presidential advisers forecast moderate growth next year and a small drop in the jobless rate. The aides are concerned, however, that the Fed's tightening of monetary policy could erode these gains, a development that might become apparent just before the election. (Page D1.) Henry Kaufman of Salomon Brothers presented a grim outlook for interest rates in his 1984 forecast. (D8.) President Reagan appeared to be trying to patch up differences with his chief economist, Martin S. Feldstein. (B12.) The Fed moved to assert control over the nonbanking companies that are starting to offer banking services. It approved a rule requiring such concerns either to submit to its jurisdiction or to divest themselves of subsidiaries engaged in banking. (D1.)

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Fan Gets His Chance

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Gloves for the Needy

title: Flooding Grows in Malaysia
description: Monsoon rains forced the evacuation today of 15,000 people from flood-ravaged east coast states, officials said. Heavy rains continued to fall in the area, where most of Malaysia's rice is grown. Ten people have drowned since the December monsoon hit.

title: Mahres Back in U.S.
description: Phil Mahre , the World Cup ski champion, and his twin brother, Steve , have abruptly left the European circuit and returned to the United States, apparently to concentrate on training for the Winter Olympics in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia.

title: COMPUTERS FIRST
description: To the Editor:

title: STUDY INDICATES ANTICLOT THERAPY SHARPLY CUTS HEART ATTACK DEATHS
description: Squirting a clot-dissolving drug into the arteries of heart attack victims brought a two-thirds reduction in their chances of dying in the first 30 days after the attack, researchers have reported. They concluded that the therapy should be used routinely by hospitals that can administer the drug.

title: MARINES IN KUWAIT GET FIRING ORDERS
description: The six American marines responsible for internal security at the United States Embassy here have been ordered to shoot to incapacitate intruders at the embassy compound, American officials said today.

title: THEFT NEVER LETS UP IN THE GARMET CENTER
description: Jack Mirojnick was arrested Tuesday morning for the first time in his life.

title: Giants Appraise A Difficult Task Have a Lot To Gain
description: Given their juxtaposition in the league standing, how can the Giants (3-11-1) beat the Redskins (13-2) in Washington on Saturday? Half a dozen replies were elicted from the Giant locker room today, and they ranged from Pete Shaw's, ''Sure,'' to Harry Carson's ''I don't know.''

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * American Broadcasting Companies announced that its vice chairman, Elton H. Rule, who is leaving the company as an officer at the beginning of 1984, will continue to serve as a consultant for two years.

title: MSI ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Year to Sept 30

FINANCE/NEW ISSUES Moore Is Offering A 9.8% Preferred Moore McCormack Resources Inc. is offering 1.25 million shares of convertible preferred stock through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company. The shares, priced at $25, are offered with a $2.45 dividend equaling a yield of 9.8 percent.
description: The preferred stock is convertible into common stock at a price of $28.82, about a 20 percent premium.

title: Approval of President Surges
description: Optimism about the economy and favorable reaction to the invasion of Grenada have given President Reagan his highest approval rating in over two years in the Gallup Poll.

title: Chile Blasts Cause Blackout
description: Dynamite explosions knocked down at least five high tension electricity towers tonight near Santiago and Valparaiso, blacking out areas inhabited by more than five million people.

title: P.L.O. Says It Has Captured Africans Fighting in Lebanon
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization has captured Africans who were sponsored by Libya to fight against it in Lebanon, a senior P.L.O. official said today.

title: C.D. Rates Edge Up After several weeks of decline, interest rates on the most popular investment products offered by banks edged upward in New York and around the country in the latest week, The Bank Rate Monitor reported yesterday.
description: The Monitor's average of rates offered on six-month certificates of deposit by 10 major New York banks and thrift institutions rose six basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 9.61 percent. Last week the rate was 9.55 percent, and the week before it was also 9.61 percent.

title: Eaton Debentures
description: A $75 million issue of Eaton Corporation convertible subordinated debentures due in 2008 is being offered at par with an 8 1/2 percent coupon through underwriteres led by Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc. The debentures are convertible into Eaton's common stock at price of $63 1/4 a share, about a 20 percent premium over the stock price.

title: GRETZKY SCORES 3 AS OILERS WIN
description: The Edmonton Oilers, losers to the Islanders the night before, continued their dominance of the other New York team last night. They defeated the Rangers at Madison Square Garden, 9-4, featuring what had been expected but was not shown the previous night: stunning play by their star, Wayne Gretzky.

title: Earnings Rise in Britain
description: Average earnings in Britain rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in October from September, seasonally adjusted, and were up 8.7 percent from a year earlier, the Department of Employment said today.

title: Remember Grenada?
description: The Departure Matters as Much as the Landing

title: Memorial for Peter Coffield
description: A memorial service for the actor Peter Coffield will be conducted in the Circle in the Square theater, 50th Street and Broadway, Friday at 12:30 P.M. Mr. Coffield, who died Nov. 19, had appeared in ''Tartuffe'' and ''The Man Who Came to Dinner'' at the Circle in the Square. The memorial service, which will be led by Ellis Raab, will be open to the public.

title: Bangladesh Leader Frees 200 Prisoners
description: Bangladesh's military ruler, Lieut. Gen. H. M. Ershad, released about 200 political detainees today in what Government officials said was an effort to pave the way for talks with his opponents early next month.

title: MISS QUARIO OF ITALY TAKES CUP SLALOM
description: Maria-Rosa Quario of Italy, who had made a public promise to redeem herself after a bad start this season, was true to her word today in racing to victory in a World Cup slalom.

title: CAVCO INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
JUDGE ORDERS STATE OF WASHINGTON TO HALT WAGE BIAS IMMEDIATELY
description: A Federal district judge today ordered the State of Washington to end wage discrimination against women employees immediately, a task expected to cost at least $140 million in the current two-year fiscal period.

title: FEDERATED GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Corbett Out as Head Of Labor in the State
description: Raymond R. Corbett has resigned as president of the New York State A.F.L.-C.I.O., effective Jan. 17.

title: A CHILD-SUPPORT BILL BLIND TO POOR FATHERS
description: To the Editor:

title: WILLIAM G. WEEKLEY
description: William George Weekley, an aeronautical engineer who was author of the 1947 novel ''The Ledger of Lying Dog,'' died Sunday in Nyack Hospital. He was 93 years old. His book, which was well received, tells the story of a shipwreck and murder in the South Pacific. Mr. Weekley is survived by his wife, Celeste, of West Nyack, N.Y., and a daughter, Rosemary, of New York

title: Black-Majority District Is Voted in Louisiana
description: A reapportionment plan that creates a Congressional district with a majority of black residents in Louisiana for the first time since Reconstruction cleared its last legislative hurdle today and went to the Governor's office.

title: OF ARAFAT, THE P.L.O. AND AMERICANS' MISDIRECTED SYMAPTHY
description: To the Editor:

title: 2d Tennis Upset
description: Robert Seguso of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., scored an upset for the second straight day when he beat Tim Gullikson, seeded 11th, in the third round of the New South Wales Open tennis tournament today.

title: Plans for Leonard
description: Sugar Ray Leonard 's comeback fight will be a 10-round bout in February that will be televised by Home Box Office, the president of the HBO entertainment group said yesterday. ''Ray is as big a superstar as there is in the entire entertainment industry,'' said the executive, Michael Fuchs , in announcing the bout.

title: RESEARCH-COTTRELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
SELECTING A CUT OR LIVE CHRISTMAS TREE
description: ABOUT this time of year, city folk can hardly see the buildings for the trees, what with evergreens springing up from the sidewalks. The question now is how to select a suitable Christmas tree from this city thicket - and, once home, how to keep it alive.

title: CATHOLIC FORUM ON ECONOMICS
description: Contentiousness is commonplace here at Notre Dame, the home field of the Gipper. And when dozens of business leaders, theologians and academics lined up against each other at the university this week, the debate over the economy was fought as hard as any gridiron encounter.

title: PROMOTION FEES CITED IN TENNIS
description: Promotional payments to tennis players, presumably in exchange for their services publicizing a tournament, are ''illusory and are really appearance money,'' an attorney for the Men's International Professional Tennis Council yesterday told a panel that is hearing Guillermo Vilas's appeal of his one-year suspension and $20,000 fine.

title: Problem Confirmed
description: Eddie Lee Ivery , the Green Bay Packer running back who has been on leave for seven weeks to deal with a personal problem, confirmed yesterday that the problem had been cocaine and that he had undergone 26 days of treatment at the Hazelden Foundation rehabilitation center near Minneapolis.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: Q.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Week in Review on Sunday about trash disposal misstated the position of Dr. Barry Commoner, director of the Center for the Biology of Natural Systems at Queens College. He opposes the burning of trash containing plastics because he says such burning produces dangerous dioxin emissions. Although some American treatment plants do separate some components of trash, Dr. Commoner says none yet effectively separate paper from plastic so the paper alone can be burned.

title: F.C.C. TAKES LOOK AT AN ISSUE OF SEX
description: The Federal Communications Commission moved today toward regulating call-in sex services.

title: MCRAE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Net income

title: POWER OF VOODOO, PREACHED BY SORBONNE SCIENTIST
description: With a bachelor of science from Cornell and a master's in chemistry from the Sorbonne, Max Beauvoir never imagined he would succeed his grandfather as a voodoo priest.

title: BLACK MAN'S CASE REOPENED IN TEXAS
description: Lenell Geter, a 26-year-old black engineer who was given a life sentence last year for an armed robbery his supporters say he did not commit, was granted a new trial today and released from prison on $10,000 bond posted by a co-worker.

title: WRITERS OF MYSTERIES COMPARE NOTES
description: It was supposed to be a discussion of mystery and suspense fiction, moderated by William F. Buckley Jr., and to a large extent it was. But, somehow, politics also entered the discussion. To nobody's surprise.

title: No Headline
description: The Tools for War in Lebanon The Navy's arduous duty in Lebanon is to project a limited military presence for political ends. This week its ships effectively bombarded Syrian antiaircraft batteries that fired on American reconnaissance planes. But last week's raid on Syrian targets was a mixed success; 2 of 28 bombers were shot down. Is the Navy well equipped for its difficult role?

title: DIGICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income including an extraordinary credit of $802,000. Year-ago results have been restated.

title: T.W.A. Plan Trans World
description: Airlines directors approved a three-year profit-sharing plan beginning in 1984 that would be available to employee groups that make what the company called ''meaningful'' concessions to lower the carrier's costs and improve its productivity. The airline is currently involved in discussions with its salaried employees and pilots on wage, benefit and productivity changes that are designed to reduce costs by about $104 million. The carrier is also negotiating with its flight attendants, machinists and other ground workers for similar concessions.

title: 'BETRAYAL,' 'TERMS' HONORED
description: ''Betrayal'' and ''Terms of Endearment'' have been named co-winners of the best film of 1983 by the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures, an independent organization that celebrates its 75th anniversary this year.

title: APPLIED SOLAR ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $380,000 for the quarter and $1,126,000 for the year.

title: A MEDIATOR FOR SHOREHAM PANEL: JOHN HARMEN MARBURGER 3D
description: STONY BROOK, L.I.

VALSPAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CONNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 13
VAIL ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The year-earlier figures are restated.

title: ONE SLAYER EXECUTED, WITH ANOTHER TO DIE TODAY
description: In this remote corner of southern Louisiana, Robert Wayne Williams went to his death in the state's electric chair today saying, as he had for nearly five years, that he never intended to kill the man for whose life he paid with his own.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
TREE LIGHTS, OLD OR NEW
description: SOME new and unusual lights are available for the Christmas tree this year. If you are looking for variety, Just Bulbs, 938 Broadway (22d Street), sells only light bulbs and carries a big and unusual selection of Christmas tree lights old and new.

title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK
description: THOUGH no candidate for canonization, I covet the

title: Pope Reported to Set Date on Agca Meeting
description: Pope John Paul II, during a Christmas-week visit to a Rome prison, will meet privately Dec. 27 with the Turkish terrorist who tried to kill him, Italian news agencies reported today.

title: CHANGING THE SUBURBAN HOME
description: CITY apartment dwellers tend to think of suburbanites as inhabiting a kind of nirvana - at least as far as space is concerned. They imagine rambling houses with room- size closets; dens that allow for theater-size movie viewing, bathrooms like spas and kitchens that professional chefs would be happy to work in.

title: TREASURY RATES UP MODESTLY
description: Interest rates on short- and long- term Treasury securities rose modestly yesterday and, for many issues, prices closed at their lowest levels since early August.

title: BOOK CIRCLE NOMINATES 25
description: John Updike, Philip Roth, Nicholas Gage, Cynthia Ozick, Raymond Carver, Seymour M. Hersh and William Kennedy are among the 25 authors whose books were nominated by the National Book Critics Circle for the best books of 1983.

title: STARTED NEWPORT YOUTH BAND
description: Marshall Brown, a trombonist and teacher who organized and led the Newport Youth Band, which became an incubator of young jazz stars in the 1950's and 60's, died at his home, 170 West End Avenue, on Tuesday. He was 62 years old.

title: DELICATE GILDING: GETTING IT REPAIRED
description: WHILE the process of adding gold leaf as ornamentation in a room or on furniture or frames is usually called gilding, other metals can also be used for the process.

title: MOSCOW BROADCASTER WHO ALTERED SCRIPTS IS RETURNED TO WORK
description: A Moscow radio announcer who altered official news bulletins to portray Soviet forces in Afghanistan as ''invaders'' has been returned to work in broadcasting after psychiatric treatment, a senior Soviet radio official said today.

title: COMPUTER HORIZONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
GIFTS TO THE NEEDIEST AID CHILDREN
description: ''Our two kids have everything - this is for children in need of basic food, clothing, shelter.''

title: TRANSCRIPT OF REAGAN'S WHITE HOUSE NEWS PARLEY
description: Following is a transcript the text of President Reagan's news conference held in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: CITY POLICE DEPT. IS TIGHTENING SECURITY AT ALL OF ITS BUILDINGS
description: The Police Department is taking steps to tighten security at its headquarters building, which was the target of a terrorist bombing last New Year's Eve, and at its station houses throughout the city.

title: AREA STORES' MERRY SEASON
description: They are seeing it in the elegantly dressed shoppers, already lugging their brightly wrapped holiday gifts and packing the aisles in Saks and Bloomingdale's and Macy's and Lord & Taylor. They are seeing it in the weeknight crowds that have crammed the parking lots to overflowing at Kings Plaza in Brooklyn, and Roosevelt Field on Long Island and the Bergen Mall in New Jersey.

title: THE SEX DISCRIMINATION WOMEN ACCEPT
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: * BankAmerica Corp. will sell its 30 percent stake in the Commercial Bank of Malawi, the second-largest bank in the central African country, to the Malawi Government, the official Malawi news agency announced; no terms were given.

title: Los Alamitos Deal
description: Los Alamitos Race Course said it had sold its race track here to Hollywood Park for $27 million, or $24.25 a share. Hollywood Park also agreed to buy for $31 million about 100 acres of land owned by Los Alamitos Race Course's president, Mildred N. Vessels, and her son.

title: Honda's Thailand Plans
description: The Honda Motor Company expects to start producing and selling cars in Thailand early next year, industry sources said today. They said Honda was making arrangements with the Bang Chang General Assembly Company of Thailand to assemble 3,000 to 4,000 units of Honda's Accord model annually.

title: Chock Full o'Nuts In Acquisition Bid The Chock Full o'Nuts Corporation, a coffee and food-products company, said it had signed a letter of intent to acquire the Chase & Sanborn Corporation for $10.25 million, of which half would be paid in Chock shares. Chase & Sanborn, based in Miami and New Orleans, is primarily in the institutional coffee business.
description: Formerly known as the General Coffee Company, Chase & Sanborn is operating under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. The Chapter 11 filing was made in May, following the personal and corporate bankruptcy filing by Alberto Duque Rodriguez of Miami, a coffee importer. Chase & Sanborn was one of 15 companies owned or controlled by Mr. Duque.

title: STAGE: PEGGY LEE SELF PORTRAIT
description: DRESSED in a flowing gown of white and silver, her head crowned by a halo of glitter, Peggy Lee takes to the stage of the Lunt-Fontanne like a high priestess ascending an altar. And ''Peg,'' the ''musical autobiography'' that Miss Lee has brought to Broadway, is nothing if not a religious rite.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''A country is not strong because of the size of its armies and it is not powerful because of its great balance sheets.

title: INVENTORIES GROW 0.4%
description: Inventories held by businesses increased four-tenths of 1 percent in October from the September level while sales rose by the same amount, the Commerce Department said today.

title: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 15, 1983 International
description: The battleship New Jersey fired for the first time against targets in Lebanon, hurling 1,900-pound shells at Syrian antiaircraft sites in the mountains east of Beirut. The battleship has been cruising offshore since September, but had not fired her heavy guns in combat since the Vietnam War. A Marine spokesman said the New Jersey and two other American warships began firing five minutes after a pair of Navy reconnaissance planes were fired on from Syrian-controlled territory. (Page A1, Col. 6.) An extension of the New Jersey's tour in the Mediterranean was announced by Pentagon officials. They said the battleship would remain there until she has been relieved by the battleship Iowa next spring. (A18:3-4.)

title: GHR Sues Banks
description: The GHR Energy Corporation, operating under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, said it had filed two lawsuits totaling more than $3.6 billion against 14 bank creditors, including Chase Manhattan and Continental Illinois. The suits charge the banks with forcing GHR to make fraudulent transfers, wrongfully dominating GHR, to the company's detriment, and conspiring to prevent the company from obtaining credit elsewhere. GHR is a privately held crude-oil refining company.

title: No Headline

title: FINAL REPORT BY SHOREHAM PANEL CRITICIZES PLANNING AND HIGH COST
description: The Long Island Lighting Company should never have built the Shoreham reactor and is not ready to run the plant, a special state panel said today.

title: IT'S WALL STREET BONUS TIME
description: At Goldman, Sachs & Company the top people will get at least 25 percent of their annual salaries. At Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. they will collect as much as 20 weeks' pay. But at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company everyone will have to wait until February, when the firm's final fiscal figures are in.

title: TELEVIDEO SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Beirut Death Toll Is 241
description: The death toll in the bombing of the Marine compound in Beirut on Oct. 23 has risen to 241, a Pentagon spokesman said today.

description: A bus carrying mentally retarded passengers overturned early Wednesday, injuring 28 people.

title: HONDURAS SAID TO SNAG LATIN PEACE BID
description: A four-nation mediation group's attempt to end armed conflicts in Central America has been slowed by new questions raised by Honduras, according to Latin and European diplomats based here and in other regional capitals.

Debt Issues
description: * People Express Airlines Inc. filed for an offering of $60 million of convertible exchangeable subordinated debentures due in 2008, through Morgan Stanley & Co.

title: Yale Seniors Limit Use of Class Fund
description: Yale University seniors have overwhelmingly voted to keep investments from a special class fund out of companies that do business in South Africa.

title: Harvester Loans
description: All but a few of the International Harvester Company's 220 lenders have indicated they will accept a plan to reschedule the company's $3.5 billion debt over three and a quarter years, company officials said. Harvester's current debt-restructuring plan will expire at midnight Thursday and the giant heavy-equipment manufacturer has said approval of a new agreement is crucial to its survival.

title: BRITISH TELL GEMAYEL THEY DON'T PLAN TO PULL OUT
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and her top advisers reportedly told President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon here today that Britain had no plans to withdraw its 100-soldier contingent from the multinational force in Beirut but that the commitment was not an indefinite one.

title: Panhandle's Gas Purchases
description: The Panhandle Eastern Corporation said its Trunkline Gas

title: TWO MORE ERRORS CITED IN BARBARA HUTTON BOOK
description: Random House said yesterday that there were two more errors in ''Poor Little Rich Girl: The Life and Legend of Barbara Hutton'' by C. David Heymann, the book that it recalled earlier this week under threat of a lawsuit.

title: REVCO DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 12
TENTATIVE GULF 'LOOKING AT' SUPERIOR
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation, which has $6 billion in cash at its disposal, told Wall Street analysts yesterday that it was ''looking at the economics'' of buying the Superior Oil Company, worth nearly $4.5 billion.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: SHULTZ'S WEEK
description: On a refueling stop Tuesday at Ireland's Shannon airport, Secretary of State George P. Shultz, on his way home from an eight-day overseas trip, was steered by his wife, Obie, away from the sweaters and smoked salmons to a V.I.P. room where his staff had prepared a surprise party.

title: JAPANESE PREMIER CAMPAIGNING HARD
description: In speech after speech across the country, Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone is telling voters that Japan's standing in the world will decline if his party loses in Sunday's elections.

title: YEW, ENDURING WOOD, RETURNS TO POPULARITY
description: Yew, very slow in growing, is one of the most enduring trees. It is often found thriving in the graveyards of old English churches; as an evergreen, it is supposed to symbolize the triumph of everlasting life. The trunk is generally fluted, as if many stems had joined themselves together into a clustered column.

title: HOME BEAT
description: YOSHIKO EBIHARA speaks softly but decidedly. ''They're all very, very famous in Japan, but unknown here,'' she said of the Japanese designers and architects whose work is being shown in ''Design Message From Japan'' at Gallery 91 in SoHo through Dec. 23.

title: Ford Planning Recalls Of 300,000 Vehicles
description: The Ford Motor Company today announced five recalls involving nearly 300,000 automobiles and trucks, including most of its 1984 passenger car models.

title: DAYTON MALLEABLE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 4

title: OPERA: TENNSTEDT LEADS 'FIDELIO'
description: THE Metropolitan Opera is not famous nowadays for the quality of the conductors it attracts, but last night could stand as an exception to that statement. Even before Klaus Tennstedt lifted his baton to make his American opera debut as the leader of the season's first ''Fidelio,'' he was given a long, fervent ovation. The cheering was repeated at every subsequent opportunity, perhaps as an expression of the audience's gratitude at finding one of the world's foremost conductors in the Metropolitan's pit, even if as a passing guest. Mr. Tennstedt responded by leading a high-tension performance of ''Fidelio'' that often stretched the dramatic line near the breaking point, particularly in a passionate reading of the ''Leonore'' Overture No. 3, gratuitously played as usual before the final scene.

description: Terry Bradshaw, the Pittsburgh Steelers' quarterback

description: Ever hear of a ''prestigious marketer of cough drops?''

title: Spain Says It Planned To Upgrade Airport
description: Spain's Transport Ministry said today it had already drawn up plans to improve equipment at Madrid's Barajas Airport before last week's runway collision that killed 93 people.

title: Bomb Threats Empty 7 Buildings in Region
description: At least seven public and private buildings in New York City and its suburbs were evacuated for up to two hours yesterday after anonymous bomb threats had been telephoned to the police, newspapers or one of the companies involved. No bombs were found, authorities said.

title: Eastern Airlines
description: Eastern Airlines said it is banning the use of portable computers on its flights because it wants to be sure the gadgets do not interfere with sophisticated aircraft equipment.

title: FOILING OF AN ESCAPE WINS SENTENCE CUT FOR ARMED ROBBER
description: Shortly after he was sentenced to 25 years in prison Tuesday, a convicted robber disarmed a fellow prisoner who had snatched a deputy's gun and was rewarded with an 11-year reduction in his sentence.
