title: ANIXTER BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Lehrer Has Heart Attack
description: Jim Lehrer, one of the two co-anchors of ''The MacNeil/Lehrer Newshour,'' public television's nightly discussion and news analysis program, suffered a mild heart attack on Tuesday, a top official of the program said yesterday. Al Vecchione, president of MacNeil/Lehrer- Gannett Productions, said that Mr. Lehrer was expected to return to the program ''after some weeks of convalesence'' and that ''the prognosis for his full recovery looks good.'' Mr. Lehrer is 49 years old. Mr. Vecchione said that the program's three other correspondents, Judy Woodruff, Charlayne Hunter-Gault and Kwame Holman, would fill in for Mr. Lehrer until his return.

title: PROSECUTORS CALL FOR A NEW LAW ON CHILD ABUSE
description: A proposal to make it easier to get convictions in cases involving sexually abused children won strong support yesterday from prosecutors and child protection agencies at a hearing in Manhattan.

title: Massachusetts Court Bars Vote on Pay Cut
description: A proposed referendum that would cut legislative salaries and trim the powers of House and Senate leaders cannot go on the 1984 ballot, the State Supreme Court ruled unanimously today.

title: TOXIC DEADLINE IN U.S. MISSED BY MANY STATES
description: Federal and state governments may have lost their chance to collect huge sums of money for pollution of the environment caused by toxic wastes, Government officials said today.

description: MICHAEL T. KAUFMAN

title: 10-DAY AUTO SALES POST 21.1% INCREASE
description: Sales of new cars by domestic auto makers rose by 21.1 percent in the first 10 days in December, the manufacturers reported today.

title: BIRD RETURNS AND HITS WINNER
description: Larry Bird, who had missed the previous two games with a knee injury, came off the bench and scored on a 20-foot jump shot with four seconds remaining tonight to lift the Boston Celtics to a 110-108 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: DEMOCRATS' IMBROGLIO: CALL IT RULE-ISHNESS
description: In past Presidential campaigns, Democrats have warred among themselves over issues that ordinary people cared about, like busing and Vietnam. Today, they are embroiled over the burning issue of party rules. The most intractable rule involves the date on which Iowa should be allowed to hold it caucuses.

title: Mediq Convertible
description: A $30 million offering of Mediq Inc.'s 9 1/2 percent convertible debentures due in 2003 was offered yesterday at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. The debentures are convertible into the company's common stock at a price of $18.60 a share.

No Headline

title: Georgetown May Cancel Game
description: A basketball game scheduled to be played in Las Vegas Dec. 30 between Georgetown and Nevada-Las Vegas may be in jeopardy because of a conflict over whether another game between the two schools must be played next season. CBS, which is scheduled to televise the Dec. 30 game starting at 11:30 P.M., Eastern standard time, expects to hear from the schools by Friday about whether the game will be played.

description: A man worried that college texts could be used to design nuclear bombs has admitted taking more than $60,000 worth of books from eight libraries, the authorities said today.

description: President Raul Alfonsin's surprise announcement Tuesday that he would prosecute former military leaders drew widely favorable reaction among Argentines today. Military officials had no immediate comment.

title: MALFUNCTIONS SPUR EXTENSIVE SPACE SHUTTLE STUDY
description: The plague of malfunctions that struck the space shuttle Columbia in its final hours of flight last week has forced engineers to inaugurate the most extensive trouble-shooting operations since the shuttles began flying in April 1981.

title: POET SUES PUBLISHER FOR $3.7 MILLION
description: An author who says his collection of verse was withheld from bookstores on orders from its publisher after the parent company had objected to language in two poems in his anthology, filed a $3.7 million lawsuit yesterday for breach of contract.

description: President Raul Alfonsin, whose Government replaced a military junta, today forced more than half the army's generals to retire and abolished the post of commander in chief in the three services.

title: E.E.C. Near Steel Accord BRUSSELS, Dec. 14 (AP) - Industry ministers of the European Economic Community agreed today on most new emergency measures to rescue their troubled steel industry.
description: The most controversial point at the meeting was a proposal for a system of certification aimed at monitoring the flow of steel trade within the Common Market.

title: DANCE, MUSIC AND STAGE TRIPLY COMPLEX MATING
description: BY a fascinating coincidence, during the week that Rina Schenfeld, an Israeli modern dancer, offered a concert of solo dances in the Lepercq Space of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, ''Victory Over the Sun'' was at the Academy's Carey Playhouse. Both events implied something about man's relationship to the environment, and each came to a different conclusion.

title: FIREWOOD AND KINDLING: SOME SOURCES IN THE CITY
description: FIREWOOD and kindling will soon be in demand for fireplaces and stoves. Following is a sampling of some companies in Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island that carry seasoned logs. A face cord is the term used to describe a one-log-deep layer of a cord of wood (8 feet wide by 4 feet high). Cannel coal, a tough bituminous coal, is also suited for fireplaces and stoves. Most of the suppliers will deliver free with a minimum order.

title: TRAFALGAR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29

description: The directors of Reuters, the 130-year-old international news agency that has recently become wealthy distributing financial information electronically, voted today to sell stock in the company to the public.

description: Attorney General William French Smith and Foreign Minister Siddhi Savetsila of Thailand signed a new extradition treaty today that replaces a treaty signed 60 years ago.

description: THE Elements Gallery, which moved last year from Madison Avenue to a large, airy space in TriBeCa, is now able to accommodate larger-scale shows than before. The current exhibit features works by Edward Moulthrop, who works in wood, and Douglas Fuchs, who works in fiber.

title: New Regional Postal Chief
description: Edward E. Horgan Jr. will become regional postmaster general for the Eastern region Jan. 21, Postmaster General William F. Bolger said today. The region covers Pennsylvania, Delaware, Maryland, Virginia, West Virginia, the District of Columbia and parts of New York and New Jersey.

title: Support for Howe
description: Commissioner Bowie Kuhn 's decision on Steve Howe isn't expected until today, but the Los Angeles Dodger relief ace has received a vote of confidence from one of his bosses. ''We're behind Steve, and we're not going to trade him,'' said Al Campanis , the Dodgers' vice president for player personnel, who added that whatever Kuhn's ruling, it would not affect the team's stance.

title: $14 Million Voted For Jersey Cities
description: The New Jersey Senate gave final passage tonight to a bill that would provide $14 million to help 335 municipalities balance their budgets.

title: ATLANTIC CITY MAYOR REPORTED UNDER INQUIRY
description: A Federal investigation into corruption in the Atlantic City government is also examining reported ''contacts'' between Mayor Michael J. Matthews and organized crime, a Justice Department official said today.

description: Share earnings reflect a 4-for-3 stoxk split distributed Feb. 1.

title: Chicken Flocks With Flu
description: Tests have confirmed that six more flocks of chickens in Lancaster County have contracted avian influenza, a Government spokesman said. This brings the number of infected flocks in Pennsylvania to 146 and the total number of birds to 6.9 million, the spokesman said Wednesday, adding that one flock in New Jersey had also been stuck by the virus.

title: EARPLUGS: CURE FOR CITY NOISE
description: In much the same way that stereo headphones once began appearing on the ears of subway riders, replacing the screech of skidding steel wheels with Beethoven or the Rolling Stones, earplugs are now showing up in the ears of New Yorkers.

title: Cindy Nelson Injured
description: Cindy Nelson , a leading American skier, has suffered a knee injury in a World Cup race in Switzerland that could keep her out of the Winter Olympic Games in February. The 28- year-old Miss Nelson, the oldest woman competing on the World Cup circuit, tore several ligaments in her right knee when she fell during the giant slalom at Les Diablerets, Switzerland, on Monday.

title: GRANGER ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
description: b-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $348,000.

title: POLLSTER SEES REPEAT OF 1980 THEMES
description: Although his business is a form of prognostication, Robert M. Teeter prefaces any political predictions with a smile and a reminder that he has fallen on his face in the past.

title: ARGENTINA ASKS DELAY ON ITS DEBT
description: Argentina's newly elected Government, seeking breathing space to repay the developing world's third-largest foreign debt, asked its foreign creditors today if it could defer for six months payment of the more than $12 billion that is due in that period.

title: Kodak Spending
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said it had budgeted $1.089 billion for capital spending in 1984, down 20 percent from what it budgeted for this year but up 10 percent from what Kodak estimates it will actually spend in 1983. Kodak said it slashed actual 1983 capital spending about 27 percent below the budgeted amount - to $985 million, from $1.358 billion.

title: GETTING A TREE IN THE COUNTRY
description: With only nine days to go before Christmas, there is still a chance for nostalgic city and suburban dwellers to visit a nearby tree farm this weekend to choose and cut their own tree for the holiday. But, the growers warn, call in advance to find out if they still have trees available and to get directions and hours. Some farms close early.

title: NASA TO SEEK OBSERVERS TO FLY ON SHUTTLE
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced today that it would propose regulations ''very soon'' on how it will select private citizens to be passengers on the space shuttle.

title: NEW ROLE DISCOVERED FOR KEY HEREDITY SUBSTANCE
description: Scientists have discovered that a key substance of heredity, ribonucleic acid, or RNA, carries out an important biological function it had never previously been known to perform.

title: HOTEL INVESTORS TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
FILM: 'D.C. CAB,' HUMOR
description: ''D.C. CAB'' is a musical mob scene, a raucous, crowded movie that's fun as long as it stays wildly busy, and a lot less interesting when it wastes time on plot or conversation. There's a lot of talent in the large cast, and Joel Schumacher, the director, generally keeps things bustling.

title: ANDROPOV LINE AFFIRMED IN REBUKE TO A STATE
description: The Soviet Communist Party denounced the leaders of a Soviet republic today in a move that seemed related to attempts to stiffen confidence in Yuri V. Andropov's policies.

title: NEW TWIST IN CAREER OF JIMMY WEBB: A CANTATA
description: THE world premiere Sunday of ''The Animals' Christmas,'' an hourlong cantata by Jimmy Webb, opens a new chapter in the musical career of the former wunderkind of Los Angeles pop. The cantata, which tells the Christmas story from the point of view of animals, will be performed at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine by a 35-piece orchestra, conducted by Mr. Webb, and will feature the cathedral's children's chorus, the pop tenor Art Garfunkel and the composer's sister, Susan Webb. The concert will benefit the T. J. Martell Foundation's research into children's leukemia.

title: BROADWAY
description: -character play titled ''Open Admissions,'' presented in the Ensemble Studio Theater's annual marathon of one-acters, arrested audiences with a dynamic picture of the perils of urban education. On Jan. 29, a full-length version of that play opens at the Music Box Theater, representing the Broadway debut of its playwright, Shirley Lauro. After the Ensemble Studio success, an expanded version was staged at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven. For the Broadway production, Mrs. Lauro has rewritten the play and has reunited with her original collaborators, the actors Marilyn Rockafellow and Calvin Levels (who was also in the Long Wharf production) and the director Elinor Renfield. She wants to make it clear that ''Open Admissions,'' which now has two acts and 10 characters, is a full-length play ''

title: REAGAN RATING SLIPS AFTER A SHARP RISE, HARRIS POLL REPORTS Overall approval of President Reagan's handling of his job has begun to slip again after rising sharply after the invasion of Grenada, according to the Harris Survey.
description: In a national poll taken from Dec. 8 to 12, 49 percent of the public said Mr. Reagan was doing an ''excellent'' or ''pretty good'' job as President, while 50 percent said his performance was ''only fair'' or ''poor.'' In a Nov. 9-14 poll, Harris found 52 percent favorable as against 47 percent negative, while an Oct. 28-31 poll found 56 percent positive and 42 percent negative ratings.

title: U.S. STUDY ADVISES ON CONTACT LENSES
description: People wearing contact lenses who buy them from optometrists or opticians, rather than physicians, are able to save up to one-third of the cost without sacrificing quality, according to a Federal Trade Commission report today.

title: ALVARADO REQUESTS $440 MILLION INCREASE IN BUDGET
description: Anthony J. Alvarado, in his first formal budget request since becoming City Schools Chancellor, asked yesterday that $440 million be added to the Board of Education's $3.5 billion budget, for reduced class size, improved instruction and more support for troubled students.

title: INQUIRY INTO LEAK SAID TO FAIL
description: An Administration official said today that an investigation into the source of unauthorized disclosures about United States options in Lebanon had been ended after it failed to find the source of the disclosures.

description: In the rectory of St. Paul's Church in East Harlem yesterday, Sister Joan Hart took another step toward bringing the Roman Catholic bishops' recent pastoral letter against nuclear arms to the attention of priests working in the field.

Festivities get under way this weekend with programs starring Johnny Cash, John Schneider and Perry Como.

title: COMMERCIAL SHEARING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 3 percent stock dividend payable Jan. 3, 1984.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption on Wednesday, with an article on the police in Spain, misinterpreted a banner at a police union office. It called for discussions with Interior Minister Jose Barrionuevo.

title: SHOREHAM PLANT DRAWS CRITICISM AT L.I. HEARING
description: Governor Cuomo, who has called the Shoreham reactor a mistake but has not said whether he feels it should be put into operation, listened today to scores of speakers at an emotional public hearing on the future of the nuclear plant.

title: Shad Favors Tighter Rules John S. R. Shad, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, told a Senate subcommittee on securities yesterday that the commission would consider forcing large shareholders in newly public companies to disclose more details about their backgrounds.
description: Under current S.E.C. rules, officers and directors must disclose any criminal record in registration statements. Mr. Shad told the subcommittee, which was investigating abuses in the new issues market, that he would support widening that rule to include the large shareholders who often stand to profit from new issues but are not necessarily officers or directors.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Nets vs. SuperSonics, at Seattle. This is the first meeting between the teams since last season, when the Nets swept both games behind Buck Williams's average of 22 points and 15 rebounds.

title: Jersey Man Charged In 2d Fatal Stabbing
description: A Morristown man being held in the stabbing death of a 25-year-old woman was charged today with fatally stabbing an 18-year-old high school student, the authorities said.

title: SCOUTING
description: D'Amato's Coffers

title: INDUSTRIAL INCENTIVES
description: Industrial policy is criticized, even by liberals and Democrats, as requiring a degree of political integrity and wisdom on the part of the Government that America cannot hope to achieve. There may be something to such criticisms, but an intelligent industrial policy could get around them. Such a policy would rely on incentives rather than on Government planning and control, and would reward particular economic activities (capital formation, research and development, more effective use of human resources) rather than selected industries (computers, bio-technology) - and thus probably could work even in our less than perfect society.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: All Over Town, The Radiance of Christmas

title: NAT SHAPIRO, WRITER, PRODUCER OF RECORDS AND ARTIST MANAGER
description: Nat Shapiro, a writer, record producer and artist manager who was active in numerous aspects of the music and recording fields, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in his office at 157 West 57th Street. Mr. Shapiro, who lived in Manhattan, was 61 years old.

title: FOR MARY LOU WILLIAMS AND JAZZ FOR YOUNGSTERS
description: ACONCERT Celebrating Mary Lou Williams With Jazz'' tonight at Symphony Space, Broadway and 95th Street, will do more than pay tribute to the late pianist, composer and teacher. It will be a step toward accomplishing her desire to involve children in jazz as a means of keeping the music alive. And it will feature two musicians who were particularly close to her - the trumpeter Dizzy Gillespie, now 66, who was her friend for more than 40 years, and the 31- year-old pianist Hilton Ruiz, who met her when he was 18 and whom she taught without fee on a basis that he describes as ''friendship and love.''

title: SCOUTING
description: Consistency

title: Military Link Charged In Aquino Slaying
description: The blue airport uniform worn by the purported assassin of Benigno S. Aquino Jr. came from a wardrobe of disguises maintained by the military, a lawyer for the accused man's family said today.

title: BRIEFING
description: Pre-debate Debate

title: Back to Work For Referees
description: The National Basketball Association's regular referees,

title: QUESTIONS ABOUT METHODS USED IN CHICAGO COURT INVESTIGATION
description: Troubling questions are being raised about the way the Federal authorities, including the Federal Bureau of Investigation, went about looking into suspected corruption in the Cook County Circuit Court. To obtain indictments against 10 men, including three judges, telephone conversations were secretly recorded, a judge's chambers were bugged, one judge worked as an agent, wearing a microphone in his cowboy boot, and as many as 100 bogus cases were brought to court with agents posing as victims, defendants, defense lawyers and prosecutors.

title: Money Fund Assets Rise After four weeks of decline, assets of money market mutual funds inched up in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.
description: The institute said total assets rose $7.5 million, to $165.7 billion. In addition, it revised last week's report of a decline in assets, to $192 million, from the previously reported $216 million.

title: LAST AMERICANS IN COMBAT ROLE LEAVE GRENADA
description: The last 190 men of the United States combat force in Grenada, along with their commanding general, flew home today, an American spokesman said. That left about 300 American noncombat soldiers to support Caribbean peacekeeping forces here.

title: THE NAME OF THE GAME?
description: They were introduced as ''the kings of sport,'' and

title: RecordLottoPrize Claimed Upstate
description: A 60-year-old sheet-metal contractor from Orange County said tonight that he had the winning ticket for Wednesday's $7.1 million state Lotto drawing - the largest jackpot to go to a single individual in the history of the New York State lottery.

title: DR. HEERY KUNKEL, A LEADER IN IMMUNOLOGY, IS DEAD AT 67
description: Dr. Henry G. Kunkel, whose research laid the groundwork for the classification of immunoglobulins, keys to the human body's defense against disease, died Wednesday at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., of complications after vascular surgery. He was 67 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: THE NEW JERSEY AGAIN OPENS FIRE
description: The United States battleship New Jersey fired its five-inch guns today in support of marines who were under attack from Moslem Druse militia positions in hills overlooking Beirut.

title: Hutton Appoints Two Presidents
description: E. F. Hutton announced yesterday that it had named two presidents - Thomas P. Lynch for the E. F. Hutton Group, which is the holding company, and Scott Pierce for E. F. Hutton & Company, the securities firm.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Time Appointments

title: REAGAN ENCOURAGES TRUDEAU ON EAST-WEST TALKS
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada received what he said was encouragement from President Reagan today for his efforts to reduce tensions and renew the arms control discussions between the Atlantic alliance and the Soviet Union.

title: MARKETING SPRINT: FIRST, LOWER FEES
description: The GTE Corporation announced yesterday that it would drop the monthly service fee it charges users of its long-distance Sprint service on Jan. 1 and replace it with a minimum monthly charge of $5.

title: Chilean-Argentine Quake
description: An earthquake measuring 5.8 on the Richter scale struck the Chilean-Argentine border area on Wednesday, a National Earthquake Information Service spokesman said today. The spokesman, Russ Needham, said the quake struck at 9:22 P.M. mountain standard time. It was centered 120 miles north of Santiago.

title: WHEN A DEMOCRACY MAKES A MILITARY CHOICE
description: To the Editor:

title: CONCERT: PHILHARMONIC AND PINCHAS ZUKERMAN
description: BARTOK'S Second Violin Concerto, composed in 1938, is not a conventionally seductive work. Although it is shot through with his usual Hungarian folk rhythms and allusions to folk tunes, the score steadfastly refuses to cuddle up to the listener, not even in the tranquil slow movement, which is as austere in its own way as either of the quicker movements. Nevertheless, the piece is so cunningly made that it can exercise a powerful kind of fascination on the listener when the right violinist has it in hand. Pinchas Zukerman, who played the concerto last night with the New York Philharmonic proved to be that right violinist.

title: GEORGIA MAN BECOMES SECOND EXECUTED IN 26 DAYS
description: John Eldon Smith, a 53-year-old insurance salesman convicted of a double murder, went to his death on this brilliantly blue morning after nine years of appeals. He was the second man to be executed this week.

title: Fair on 141st Street
description: A brownstone holiday fair, at which the authors Paule Marshall and Beatrice Nivens will autograph copies of their latest books, will be offered tomorrow and Sunday from 1 to 6 P.M. by the Inner City Housing Improvement and Development Council.

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 16, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: RESTAURANTS
description: LE PETIT ROBERT has almost all the ingredients of a favorite little hideaway in an out-of-the-way Parisian arrondissement: excellent dishes, as well as mediocre ones, reasonable prix-fixe dinners, along with a la carte selections, and a decor that suggests the space had a less glamorous life before it became a restaurant. Where this West Village spot parts company with a Paris bistro is in the service. Here it is often careless and sometimes startlingly rude.

title: Nuclear Accident in Britain
description: A misunderstanding between managers at a nuclear plant led to the discharge of radioactive waste into the sea nearby, the chairman of British Nuclear Fuels, Con Allday, said today. He said managers at Windscale, the world's biggest nuclear reprocessing plant, had failed to consult a log book to determine whether radioactive particles had been eliminated from the waste.

title: DRESSER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
KISSINGER PREDICTS U.S.-NICARAGUAN CONSULTATIONS
description: Henry A. Kissinger, expressing what he described as a ''personal view,'' said here today that there would be talks between the United States and Nicaragua ''in the short term.''

title: CUT IN FARM EXPORTS AT CORE OF PROBLEM IN PRICES AND SUPPLY
description: All through the 1970's American farmers set one record after another in selling their goods abroad.

title: UNITY BUYING SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss The company said that the revenue includes membership fees of $1,024,723 for the latest quarter compared to $1,992,749 for the year-earlier period. The revenue for the latest 9 months includes membership fees of $2,070,938 against $3,530,898 for the year-ago period.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Perhaps the greatest myth surrounds the President's attempt to fight poverty without resorting to the rubber bullets and blank checks that were enlisted in similar wars in the past.'' - Edwin Meese 3d. (A26:4.)

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Vice Chairman Leaving At Bank of America William H. Bolin, vice chairman of the Bank of America and executive officer for the world banking division, announced yesterday that he planned to take early retirement.

title: Officer Accused Of Racial Assault
description: A 23-year-old white police officer was arrested yesterday and charged with assaulting and menacing a black man while off duty and in civilian clothes on a street in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn.

title: A PLAN TO HELP THE STATE FIGHT CRIME IS URGED
description: A group of top law-enforcement officials in New York State said yesterday that the criminal-justice system ''is not serving the public'' and proposed a $232 million program to build jails, appoint new judges and expand efforts to apprehend criminals.

title: Bamberger's Names Head
description: Rudolph J. Borneo has been named president and chief operating officer of Bamberger's, the New Jersey department store chain that is a division of R. H. Macy & Company.

title: FILM: MCKELLEN IN ''KEEP''
description: IN 1981, a film maker named Michael Mann made a pretentious, achingly poetic and overscored movie called ''Thief,'' with James Caan. Now, after a gestation period just a little longer than that of an elephant, he has brought to the screen a woozily symbolic horror film called ''The Keep,'' which opens today at Loews State and other theaters.

title: AN UPGRADING OF SOVIET JETS IS REPORTED
description: The North Atlantic alliance's preoccupation with Soviet nuclear weapons has diverted attention from qualitative and quantitative improvements in the Soviet Air Force, intelligence analysts in Washington and other NATO capitals report. For example, Jane's All The World's Aircraft 1983- 1984, the standard reference work, says in the latest edition that the Soviet Union is producing three new fighters each day. It does not say how many are used within the Warsaw Pact as opposed to being sold to foreign buyers.

title: Key Rates
description: * Nuveen index, John Nuveen & Company Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: WELDOTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
GREAT ATLANTIC & PACIFIC TEA CO OF AMERICA (A&P) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 3
description: b-Including tax credits of $2,650,000 for the quarter and $10,650,000 for the 9 months. c-Including tax credits of $2,830,000 for the quarter and $7.8 million for the 9 months.

title: KOCH TELLS OF F.B.I. VISIT IN WEINBERGER CASE
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation went to City Hall last week seeking to learn his source for a translation of a Lebanese newspaper article that sparked a long-running dispute with Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger.

title: 25SculpturesbyMoore To Be Shown Outdoors
description: Twenty-five monumental sculptures by the English artist Henry Moore, worth an estimated $15 million, will be lent to New York for outdoor exhibitions in the five boroughs.

title: CONDEC CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a loss of $2,407,000 from discontinued operations and a loss of $31,000 from the disposal of discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $2,690,000 from discontinued operations.

title: U.S. Steel Pursues Talks With British David M. Roderick, the chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, met in New York Wednesday with Robert Haslam, the chairman of the British Steel Corporation, to continue their negotiations over U.S. Steel's efforts to import steel from the British company, a U.S. Steel spokesman said. The joint venture involves importing slab steel from Scotland for finishing at U.S. Steel's Fairless Works near Philadelphia.
description: The spokesman said the two sides had not reached an agreement and would meet again after Jan. 1. The main obstacle has been U.S. Steel's demand that, in exchange for its purchase, British Steel help pay for modernization of the Fairless facilities.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Company News report in Business Day Wednesday on Gulf and Western Industries misstated factors reflected in its earnings in the fiscal year 1983. Earnings excluded special gains and charges.

title: HOMOSEXUAL DISPUTE PROMPTS OHRENSTEIN TO QUIT GLENN DRIVE
description: The New York State chairman for Senator John H. Glenn's Presidential campaign resigned yesterday because of Mr. Glenn's stand on the rights of homosexuals.

title: WARD LAMB JOHNSON
description: Ward Lamb Johnson, a former co- principal of Miss Porter's School in Farmington, Conn., died Tuesday at his home in Essex, Conn.

title: CASEY'S GENERAL STORES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
GIANTS' TAYLOR IS WEIGHING HIS OPTIONS
description: Lawrence Taylor of the Giants, regarded by many as the best defensive player in professional football, said today he had talked with the New Jersey Generals about a future contract. Although he repeated his contention that the Giants were not paying him what he was worth, Taylor said he had not signed anything with the Generals.

title: 'TO BE OR NOT TO BE,' WITH MEL BROOKS
description: EVERYBODY can relax. Mel Brooks's remake of Ernst Lubitsch's 1942 classic, ''To Be or Not to Be,'' is smashingly funny. I'm not at all sure that it's a classic, but it's so good in its own right, in the way it preserves and revives the wonderfully farcical situations of the original Edwin Justus Mayer screenplay, that you leave the theater having a brand-new high. It opens today at the Criterion and other theaters.

title: AIR ILLINOIS HALTS OPERATIONS AFTER U.S. THREAT OVER SAFETY
description: Air Illinois, threatened with having the Government summarily halt its operations, stopped all flights yesterday under an agreement with the Federal Aviation Administration that the airline hopes will permit it to start up again early next year.

title: Required Reading
description: The Medicare Problem

title: DIVIDEND TO BE HALVED
description: The Crocker National Corporation, the nation's 12th-largest banking organization, said yesterday that it will report a loss of about $57 million for the fourth quarter and a loss of about $10 million for the entire year.

title: E.E.C. Farm, Budget Crises Grow Worse
description: The European Parliament voted today to withhold a payment of more than $1 billion due to Britain and West Germany on their contribution to the Common Market's $22 billion budget.

title: M.T.A. Surveys Commuters on S.I.
description: The Metropolitan Transit Authority conducted a six-hour survey yesterday among commuters of the Staten Island Rapid Transit system in what the agency said was an attempt to improve service.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Shift at General Signal Nathan R. Owen, chairman and chief executive of General Signal, said yesterday that he intended to retire next spring at the age of 65.

title: VOICE FROM A LOST AFRICA RECOUNTS END OF EMPIRE
description: Sir Roy Welensky, one-time Prime Minister of a great mass of land and people called the Central African Federation, was once taunted by an interviewer about how a man of such lowly origins could qualify for such heights of power.

title: FEDERATED GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
ADVERTISING
description: Kenyon Chairman

title: Israel Denies Reneging On Prisoner Exchange
description: Israel has rejected a demand by the International Committee of the Red Cross to free several prisoners the committee says were left behind in last month's prisoner exchange with the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: ; GIVE FARMERS INSURANCE, NOT SUBSIDIES
description: To the Editor:

title: JOHNNY BRIGHT, A STAR OF FOOTBALL IN 1950'S
description: Johnny Bright, the former tailback who twice led the nation in total offense at Drake University and was inducted into the Canadian Football League Hall of Fame in 1970, died at University Hospital Wednesday of a heart attack while awaiting knee surgery for a football-related injury. He was 53 years old.

title: BOWNE & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $473,000 for the quarter and $962,000 for the year. c-After a loss of $344,000 from discontinued operations and a loss of $403,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations. Results have been adjusted for discontinuance of Bowne Information Systems.

title: TRUCK HIJACKING: A HIGHLY ORGANIZED AND SPECIALIZED CRIME IN NEW YORK
description: On Feb. 23, as on many other days since he became a driver for the Rujac company seven years ago, Nicolas Estrella was at the wheel of an 18-foot truck laden with television sets, video recorders, microwave ovens, radios, business machines and vacuum cleaners valued at well over $100,000.

title: Jersey Youth, 18, Sentenced to Die
description: An 18-year-old Neptune youth today became the youngest person sentenced to death in New Jersey, following his conviction on charges of murdering an Asbury Park woman.

title: Chile's Foreign Minister Quits After 10 Months in the Post
description: The Chilean Foreign Minister, Miguel Alex Schweitzer, resigned tonight after 10 months in office in which he defended the record of President Augusto Pinochet's military Government before the international community.

title: Argentine Military Loses Security Role
description: Argentina's new Government, having forced more than half the generals and two-thirds of the admirals in the armed forces to retire, said today that it was removing internal security from military hands.

title: HEAR THE SOUNDS OF CHRISTMAS
description: FROM the churches to the concert hall and the stage, from the streets and the parks to the lobbies of the city's office buildings, New York offers distinctly urban settings for Christmas music. The city might not have the snowy fields, jingling sleighs or carolers on the lawn of a Currier and Ives scene, but it compensates, as it does in every season, with its variety and vitality.

title: DEFENSE WITNESSES IN BEATTY TRIAL DENY VOTE FRAUD SCHEME
description: Defense witnesses at the election- fraud trial of former State Senator Vander L. Beatty testified yesterday that they had not seen any illegalities committed by Mr. Beatty and his campaign aides at the Brooklyn offices of the Board of Elections in October 1982.

title: Spirit of Giving
description: Lionel Aldridge , the former defensive end for the Green Bay Packers, has had his troubles in recent years, but he also apparently has some friends.

title: American Savings To Buy Brokerage
description: American Savings and Loan Association of Miami said it had agreed to acquire Kaufmann, Alsberg & Company, a New York brokerage firm. It will pay $25 million in cash, provide a $2 million note due in two years and pay an unspecified premium based on future earnings.

title: TALKS ON CUTTING FORCES IN EUROPE ARE BROKEN OFF
description: East-West talks on reducing conventional armed forces in Central Europe were recessed today, and the Warsaw Pact nations refused to agree to a date for their resumption.

title: SCOUTING
description: Detective Seeks Ranger Alumni

title: Little Education, Science or Culture
description: For good reasons, the Reagan Administration is thinking about quitting Unesco, the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization. Unwieldy not only in name, it has become a babel of words notable for their muddiness and dishonesty. A United States withdrawal would not harm any democratic cause or global understanding. If fairly explained, it might even promote scientific and cultural values.

title: Hughes Satellite
description: Hughes Communications Galaxy Inc. asked the Government for permission to build and operate a new type of communications satellite with several times the data capacity of those now in use.

title: Distinction for Marino
description: Dan Marino , the Miami Dolphins' rookie standout, has been named the American Football Conference's starting quarterback for the Pro Bowl game in Hawaii on Jan. 29, the first time a rookie quarterback has been given such a role since the Pro Bowl began in 1950.

title: NOVEMBER INDUSTRIAL OUTPUT UP
description: Domestic industrial output rose a modest but encouraging eight-tenths of 1 percent in November for the second consecutive month, but a separate Government report shows that the deficit in foreign trade set a record last summer.

title: COWBOYS COULD DETERMINE PLAYOFF FOE
description: The complex procedure that the National Football League uses to break ties among teams competing for playoff berths has created a situation in which the Dallas Cowboys could determine which of two clubs they will play if, as expected, they are a wild-card team.

title: THOUSANDS OF CHRISTIANS FREED AS DRUSE END SIEGE
description: A three-month siege of this ancient mountain town was lifted today and 2,500 Christian militiamen were evacuated along with the first of several thousand civilians.

title: THE SCREEN: TRAVOLTA IN 'TWO OF KIND'
description: CAN it really have been that difficult to find a passable screen vehicle for John Travolta and Olivia Newton- John? Any old romantic fluff should have sufficed, and yet something as horrible as ''Two of a Kind'' has been tailor-made for its stars. The results are so disastrous that absolutely no one is shown off to good advantage, with the possible exception of the hairdressers involved. The coiffures don't always upstage the material, but when they do, it's a blessing.

title: DE KOONING RETROSPECTIVE OF 60 YEARS AT WHITNEY
description: IT isn't often that a painter can celebrate a 60-

title: I.M.F. Seeks Loan Rate Cut
description: Jacques de Larosi ere, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, said today that he would try to persuade commercial banks to

title: MICROSEMI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
CITICORP'S THRIFT UNIT BID BACKED
description: Citicorp, the $130 billion New York bank holding company, received permission today from the Federal Home Loan Bank Board to acquire the First Federal Savings and Loan Association of Chicago, whose assets of $3.95 billion make it one of the largest thrift institutions in Illinois.

title: ISLANDERS TRIUMPH
description: The line of Butch Goring, Bob Nystrom and John Tonelli, known for its scrappy, rough-skating style, scored three goals tonight to lead the Islanders to a 4-2 victory over the Detroit Red Wings at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Big Band Concert
description: The Globe Unity Orchestra, a 12- piece avant-garde big band, featuring Albert Mangelsdorff and George Lewis on trombones, Toshinori Kondo and Kenny Wheeler on trumpets and Bob Stewart on tuba, will perform tonight at 8 at the Public Theater (598- 7150), 425 Lafayette Street. Tickets are $10.

title: VALUE LINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
3 JETS MAKING N.F.L. FINALE
description: Johnny Lynn is leaving for more money and a team closer to his home, but he still looked and sounded today as if he would have been happy to remain with the Jets.

title: Williams Plan
description: Williams Companies' chairman, Joseph H. Williams, said the diversified energy concern had developed plans for restructuring its balance sheet and reducing its exposure to floating rate debt incurred in its recent Northwest Energy acquisition. Mr. Williams said the combination of a recent sale of equity, the planned sale of certain assets and planned swap transactions will reduce exposure to floating rate debt by about $700 million by the end of 1984's second quarter. He also announced plans to sell about $200 million of properties.

title: COOK UNITED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 5
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $67,000 for the quarter and $706,000 for the 9 months. c-dAfter losses from discontinued operations of $188,000 for the quarter and $792,000 for the 9 months and an extraordinary credit of $523,000 for the 9 months. Results have been restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: Housing Message From Texas
description: Federal Judge William Wayne Justice of Wrightsville, Tex., knows one sure way to achieve racial balance: by the numbers. After finding that the local housing agency intentionally segregated tenants by race, he ordered that 26 families in an all- black housing project swap apartments with 26 in an all-white project.

title: CHARLES RIVER BREEDING LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
THE HARDEST TRUTH
description: Is ''civil defense'' against nuclear war possible? The Federal Emergency Management Agency professes to think so, as did its predecessor, the Defense Civil Preparedness Agency. With a little faith and a lot of planning, they've been saying for years, as much as 80 percent of the American population can survive nuclear attack.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
description: Guam Bonds Sell Briskly A $450 million bond sale by

title: Mitterrand in Yugoslavia
description: President Francois Mitterrand of France began a three-day visit to Yugoslavia today. He was met at Belgrade airport by President Mika Spiljak and Prime Minister Milka Planinc.

title: SLUGGISH NETS FALL TO BALZERS, 118-105
description: When Coach Jack Ramsey was asked tonight if his Portland Trail Blazers were ready to challenge the Los Angeles Lakers for Pacific Conference supremacy, he paused before saying, ''I don't know about that, but I'll tell you what . . . we're close.''

title: More Data Asked At Vilas Hearing
description: Having heard five days of testimony in the Netherlands and New York, a three-member board hearing Guillermo Vilas's appeal of a one- year suspension and a $20,000 fine has ordered lawyers for the Argentine star and the Men's International Professional Tennis Council to submit briefs on the case.

title: COPPER LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including net income from discontinued operations of $6,229,000 for the quarter and $16,985,000 for the year. c-Inclucing net income from discontinued operations of $6,149,000 for the quarter and $14,471,000 for the year.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: In the hearing room at the Board of

title: U.S. NEWS WEEKLY IS TARGET OF OFFER
description: U.S. News & World Report Inc. is considering an offer from an undisclosed bidder to buy the company.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Archie Griffin , the 29-year-old former Ohio State star and two-time Heisman Trophy winner who spent eight years as a running back with the Cincinnati Bengals, has been told by the Bengals that the team will not make him an offer when his contract expires after this season. . . . Doug Plank , who retired last year after eight years as a safety for the Chicago Bears, has reportedly accepted a $1 million, three-year contract with the Chicago Blitz of the U.S.F.L. The Blitz declined to verify the report but scheduled a news conference for today to announce the signing of ''a former N.F.L. starter.'' . . . Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini will defend his World Boxing Association lightweight title against Bobby Chacon Jan. 14 in Reno.

title: Diner's Journal; Brunches to Samba By
description: NOT long ago, restaurant Sunday brunches usually meant eggs Benedict, pancakes, bacon, fruit cup and maybe a Bloody Mary. In recent years, the brunches have been getting more exotic as ethnic foods have become increasingly popular - feijoada first thing in the morning? That's one of the items on the brunch menu at Sounds of Brazil, 204 Varick Street. The restaurant also offers French toast made with coconut milk, or Brazilian crab omelet. Here are a few other new brunches around town: Pesca, 23 East 22d Street (between Park Avenue and Broadway), serves such entrees as red-snapper hash with pan-roasted potatoes, chicken and shrimp strudel, and fresh tuna carpaccio; Vanessa, 289 Bleecker Street, has American caviar and cr eme fra^iche omelets and brioche French toast with Calvados and apples; Texarkana, 64 West 10th Street, near Fifth Avenue, features scrambled eggs with fried oysters and green chili hash.

title: Bridge: Manhattan Club Is the Site For a Fine Duplicate Game
description: One of the strongest duplicate games in the New York metropolitan area is played each Monday night at the Manhattan Club, 27 West 72d Street. It is supported by a group of young stars headed by Brian Glubok, although that situation may change if Glubok's plans to open a club of his own come to fruition.

title: 2 CANOEISTS END A TOUR OF AMERICA
description: A local band blared Dixieland music and a bitter wind blew across the Grand River as Verlen Kruger and Steven G. Landick came home today, completing a three-and-a-half-year, 28,000-mile journey by water in and around North America.

title: Mississippi Governor Takes University Post
description: Gov. William Winter said today he would become chancellor of the University of Mississippi instead of challenging Senator Thad Cochran, a Republican, for his seat in Congress.

title: Block Those Entitlements. Which Ones?
description: The three usual proposals for cutting the immense Federal deficit are to reduce military spending, increase taxes and hold down the growth of entitlements. The growth of what? Entitlements, a label so broad that it encompasses nearly half of all Government spending - and so fuzzy that it mixes cruel cuts with sensible ones. To be imprecise on this subject risks punishing the poor.

title: KNICKS THAWARTED BY BULLS' BACKCOURT
description: Coach Kevin Loughery's plans for rebuilding the Chicago Bulls do not include the guard Reggie Theus, a five- year player, who is a favorite of the fans and the team's management.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Short-Term Rates Are Mixed
description: Short-term interest rates were mixed yesterday, while yields for most Treasury note and bond issues declined slightly.

description: ABOUT 200 Radcliffe College

description: Consumer prices in the 24 nations

description: Rapid-American Files $706 Million Financing

U.S. WARNS SALVADOR OF LOSS OF SUPPORT
description: The Reagan Administration is prepared to drop active support for the Salvadoran Government if it does not take specific action against death squads by Jan. 10, according to Salvadoran politicians.

title: TIGERS, EVANS IN ACCORD
description: The Detroit Tigers reached an agreement in principle on a multiyear contract with the free agent Darrell Evans tonight, according to Evans's agent, Jerry Kapstein, and the Tigers.

title: Topics Haunted Happenings
description: History's Grip

title: JIFFY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Share earnings adjusted for a 2-for- 1 stock split on Nov. 15, 1983.

title: 200 Arrested in Los Angeles In Drug Sales at High Schools
description: Young undercover police officers have arrested more than 200 people suspected of selling drugs to teen-age students and seized heroin, marijuana, cocaine, LSD and other drugs in raids at nine high schools, the authorities said Wednesday.

title: Economic Scene; Large Deficits: Pressure Rises
description: SENIOR advisers in the Reagan Administration are drafting a forecast for economic growth of 4.5 percent next year, as measured from the fourth quarter of this year to the fourth quarter of next year. Beyond 1984, the Administration is assuming that the economy will grow by an average of 4 percent a year through 1989 as a basis for its long-term budget planning. But even with such optimistic assumptions, huge budget deficits loom.

title: GREATWEST HOSPITALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including extraordinary gains for the quarter and year. c-Net loss after an extraordinary loss.

title: Buckeye Takeover
description: The Buckeye Financial Corporation said it had reached a definitive agreement to be acquired by a subsidiary of the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company for $13.50 a share, or a total of about $28 million. Buckeye said the purchase price could be raised, subject to certain conditions. Buckeye owns the Buckeye Federal Savings and Loan Association, which has 18 branches in Ohio and total assets of about $1 billion.

title: COMPUTER TERMINAL SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: HURCO MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
LEFT HAND, RIGHT HABD
description: For years now, U.S. foreign policy in Central America has been undermined by private or semi-private U.S. groups encouraging the extreme right to disregard official Washington warnings.

title: Colombia Crash Toll Lowered
description: The authorities said today that 16 people were killed Wednesday in the crash of a cargo jet that slammed into an industrial park shortly after takeoff. They denied earlier reports of a higher death toll. They said 30 people had been injured, including 12 in critical condition.

title: 15Plants Searched For Illegal Wastes
description: The city has conducted 15 surprise inspections of Brooklyn plants that clean and recondition drums containing hazardous wastes, the Department of Investigation said yesterday.

title: SMYSLOV NEARING A VICTORY
description: Vasily Smyslov of the Soviet Union had an easy time drawing the 10th game of his semifinal world championship chess match with Zoltan Ribli of Hungary tonight.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Rejected Gorilla Finds a New Life

title: UNEXPLODED BOMB IS FOUND IN FRONT OF QUEENS BUILDING
description: Two attache cases with the word ''bomb'' stenciled on them were removed by police bomb experts from the front of a Honeywell Inc. building in Queens early yesterday after an telephone caller warned a news service that two bombs would go off at the building.

title: ADVERTISING
description: JWT Pays $315,000 To Settle a Lawsuit

title: By Francis Steegmuller;
description: PARIS. By John Russell. Foreword by

title: HELEN ROSE SCHEUER
description: Helen Rose Scheuer, a philanthropist and the mother of Representative James H. Scheuer, Democrat of the Bronx and Queens, died of cancer yesterday at her home in Manhattan.

title: TEXAS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The 1982 share earnings adjusted for a 4 percent stock dividend paid in May.

title: MARSHALL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $5,000 for the quarter and $37,000 for the 6 months.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A $2 Offense

title: DIOXIN STRATEGY ADOPTED BY E.P.A.
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today announced a nationwide plan to address the problem of dioxin, which it called ''one of the most perplexing and potentially dangerous chemicals ever to pollute the environment.''

title: A.& P. Net Up 12.5%
description: The Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company said today that third-quarter earnings rose 12.5 percent, to $9 million, or 24 cents a share, from $8 million, or 22 cents, a year earlier. But A.& P., the nation's fourth-largest supermarket chain, added that price competition had slowed its rate of growth. Revenues in the period, which ended Dec. 3, rose 12 percent, to $1.20 billion, from $1.07 billion.

title: Washington State Rating in Danger Washington State is in danger of loosing its double A minus bond rating because of a recent Federal court decision finding the state guilty of sex discrimination, according to analysts at the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
description: The rating agency noted that a court order filed on Wednesday would require the state to raise salaries about 31 percent for 15,000 employees, costing an estimated $140 million in the current two-year budget period.

title: O.& M. and Doremus Starting New Divisions
description: Ogilvy & Mather Partners, part of O.& M. International, and Doremus & Company, part of BBDO International, have started new units.

title: LAW-FLOUTING COURIERS To the Editor:
description: Your Dec. 2 news article ''Fastest Is Best as Messengers Pedal in Pursuit of a $100 Day'' dealt with the problem of wild and dangerous bike- riding messengers as if it were some interesting and benign cultural phenomenon, glossing over the extreme hazard these self-styled entrepreneurs pose to the public at large.

title: ARMY ENGINEERS TO END FISH STUDY A YEAR EARLY
description: The Army Corps of Engineers said today that its study of the impact of the Westway project on striped bass in the Hudson River would be completed this winter, a year earlier than planned.

title: SCOUTING
description: Practice Spying

title: AFTER A STARTING FLURRY, THE JUSTICES FALL SILENT
description: The Supreme Court's Christmas recess that began this week follows the least productive start to a High Court term in recent memory.

title: MARINES FIRE AT A U.S. TV CREW
description: United States Marine guards fired on a North Carolina television crew when the crew's car approached the wrong gate of the Marine base at Beirut airport today. One reporter and the driver were slightly hurt.

title: BRITON TILTING WITH UNION: SELIM JEHAN SHAH
description: The newspaper publisher Selim Shah says he hated flying so much that he decided to take lessons. Now, four years later, he is a member of the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association and is intent on flying to the United States in his tiny Piper Seneca. ''It still terrifies me,'' Mr. Shah said, ''but at least I am in charge of my own destiny.''

title: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 16, 1983 International
description: Major U.S. military aid for Israel has been agreed on, according to Reagan Administration officials. They said Israel would receive $1.4 billion in military assistance in the next fiscal year, none of which has to be repaid, as part of a global policy shift in disbursing military funds. Egypt is to receive $1.1 billion in grants. Breaking with the approach of lending money to governments at prevailing market rates to buy American military equipment, the Administration now intends to give the assistance either free of charge or at subsidized rates. (Page A1, Column 6.) The battleship New Jersey fired its five-inch guns in support of marines who were under attack from Moslem Druse militia positions in hills overlooking Beirut. No American casualties were reported. Earlier, members of the French and British contingents in Beirut were also attacked. Two French soldiers were killed and three were wounded. (A1:3.)

title: Michigan State Defeats Brooklyn
description: Sam Vincent scored 22 points to lead Michigan State to an 85-72 college basketball victory over Brooklyn College tonight.

title: REAGAN CENSORSHIP PACT REMAINS UNSIGNED BY MOST GOVERNMENT OFFICIALS
description: In March, expressing ''grave concern'' about disclosure of Government secrets, President Reagan signed an order requiring more than 128,000 Government employees and contractors to agree to lifelong censorship.

title: Films on Soviet Jews
description: ''Hidden Lives'' and ''Soviet Jews,'' two photographic exhibitions that examine Jewish life in the Soviet Union, can be seen through March 4 at the Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92d Street.

title: CARME INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Jamaica Laborites Sweep Boycotted Elections
description: The Jamaica Labor Party swept national elections boycotted by the Socialist opposition Thursday, giving Prime Minister Edward Seaga an unprecedented one-party Parliament.

title: NEWPORT PHARMACEUTICALS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
STAGE: NEW 'ROMANTIC' BY WENDY WASSERSTEIN
description: IN her new, improved version of

title: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan Spinoff Tests Fund Manager
description: C AN an independent unit of a big bank find happiness - and superior market performance - in managing assets for institutional investors? That's the challenge facing 39-year-old Samson Wang as president of the Beacon Capital Management Company.

title: INTERNATIONAL HARVESTER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a provision of $468 million for operational restructuring costs, a loss of $373 million from discontinued operations and extraordinary income of $22 million.

title: CHASE MANHATTAN'S ROLE IN COLOMBIAN ISSUE
description: To the Editor:

title: WALESA, IN TALK HE CAN'T DELIVER, REBUKES RULERS
description: The text of a speech that Lech Walesa had hoped to make was passed to Western reporters today. It accuses the authorities of treating workers in the manner of ''19th-century capitalists.''

title: DEVELOPER AND WEST SIDERS COOPERATE
description: When Nathan and Daniel Brodsky, the father-and-son development team, announced plans two years ago to build a 32-story condominium at 45 West 67th Street in Manhattan, their proposal seemed destined to arouse controversy.

title: CITY ON COAST FIGHTS RUSH TO TAP OIL
description: With long stretches of white beach on one side of town and a sweeping panorama of green mountains on the other, this pleasant community in southern California has been blessed with more than its share of beauty. It is now trying to get used to having more than its share of oil.

title: CHARVOZ-CARSEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $461,000.

title: SOUTH AFRICANS MAKE OFFER TO ANGOLA
description: South Africa proposed a ''disengagement'' of hostile forces in Angola today as a first step toward solving the dispute over the granting of independence to South-West Africa, the territory administered by South Africa.

title: Bauhaus Period Music
description: The Guggenheim Museum, in conjunction with its exhibition of Kandinsky paintings, will present music from the Bauhaus period Sunday at 3 P.M. The pianist Veronica Jochum will perform and speak about pieces by Stravinsky, Wolpe, Hindemith, Krenek and Busoni. The museum is at Fifth Avenue and 89th Street. Tickets are $5, and the number for more information is 360-3500.

title: Ex-Weehawken Mayor Is Guilty of Conspiracy
description: The former Mayor of Weehawken, Wally P. Lindsley, was found guilty today by a Federal jury of conspiring to extort $600,000 from developers who wanted to set up businesses on Hudson River waterfront land controlled by the Weehawken Municipal Port Authority.

title: ART: PORTRAITS OF ARTISTS AS SEEN BY THE ARTISTS
description: GIVEN the limits of academic portraiture, ''Artists by Themselves,'' which is at the National Academy of Design, 1083 Fifth Avenue, near 89th Street, through Dec. 31, is a solid and informative exhibition.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: IN ''To Be or Not to Be'' (reviewed on page C10), Tim

title: Warner Wary on Ownership Warner Communications Inc. has cautioned Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, which owns 7 percent of Warner's shares, that further stock purchases could jeopardize Warner's cable television franchises in New York and Boston. Representatives of the two companies met last Friday, according to Judith Thompson, director of investor relations at Warner.
description: Mr. Murdoch's ownership of newspapers and magazines in the two cities, combined with his sizable holding of Warner stock, was said by Warner to be a threat to the franchises.

title: LUBY'S CAFETERIAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
MET OPERA: 'FIDELIO'
description: THE Metropolitan Opera is not famous nowadays for the quality of the conductors it attracts, but Wednesday night could stand as an exception to that statement. Even before Klaus Tennstedt lifted his baton to make his American opera debut as the leader of the season's first ''Fidelio,'' he was given a long, fervent ovation. The cheering was repeated at every subsequent opportunity, perhaps as an expression of the audience's gratitude at finding one of the world's foremost conductors in the Metropolitan's pit, even if as a passing guest. Mr. Tennstedt responded by leading a high-tension performance of ''Fidelio'' that often stretched the dramatic line near the breaking point, particularly in a passionate reading of the ''Leonore'' Overture No. 3, gratuitously played as usual before the final scene.

title: GREECE PLANS TO SEND SHIPS TODAY FOR ARAFAT
description: Greece said today that it would dispatch five ships on Friday for the evacuation of Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, and his loyalists besieged in the Lebanese port of Tripoli.

title: BEIRUT NEEDS A U.N. FORCE
description: With the Lebanese conflict possibly escalating toward a superpower confrontation, why have the United States and its three European partners in the multinational force shown no willingness to replace their troops with a United Nations peacekeeping force?

title: MASONITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes income of $3.6 million on completion of the sale of almost all of the company's remaining domestic timberlands and $415,000 from discontinued operations. The share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective Dec. 22.

title: Readings by Moriarty
description: The actor Michael Moriarty will read from works by Shakespeare and his own writings tonight at 8 at the Greenwich House Music School, 46 Barrow Street. Mr. Moriarty recently starred in the Broadway production of ''The Caine Mutiny Court-Martial.'' Tickets are $5. Information: 242-4770.

title: SCREEN: 'GORKY PARK,' MURDERS IN MOSCOW
description: THE colorless, frozen setting against which ''Gorky Park'' unfolds has been oddly but compellingly rendered in Michael Apted's screen version of Martin Cruz Smith's best-selling novel, even though the movie's peculiarities ultimately pose some problems. Substituting Helsinki for Moscow, and having the leading character, a Russian police inspector, played by an American actor affecting a British accent, Mr. Apted has certainly tailored the material in provocatively idiosyncratic ways.

title: 'UNCOMMON VALUE,' WITH GENE HACKMAN
description: ''UNCOMMON VALOR'' is about a Vietnam veteran, Col. Jason Rhodes. whose son has been missing in action for more than 10 years and who returns to Southeast Asia in hopes of rescuing the boy. Even though the colonel is played by an actor as intelligently resourceful as Gene Hackman, and even though the plot sounds as if it might have some psychological dimension to it, ''Uncommon Valor'' is mostly an action movie, and not much more.

title: HARVESTER FINISHES 3D RESTRUCTURING
description: The International Harvester Company and its credit subsidiary today completed a $4 billion financial restructuring that lengthened the maturity of loans - repayable today - totaling $3.1 billion. It was Harvester's third restructuring in as many years.
To the Editor:

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday FREE BEETHOVEN PARTY

title: Baldwin Is Selling Piano Unit
description: The Baldwin-United Corporation, long the builder of one of the world's most popular pianos, announced yesterday that it was selling that business, the Baldwin Piano and Organ Company, to a group of the company's executives for an undisclosed amount.

title: U.S. Olympians Tie Soviet Team
description: Ed Olczyk's third-period goal gave the United States Olympic hockey team to a 4-4 tie with a touring Soviet Union all-star team in an exhibition game tonight.

title: Air Raids on Iran Reported by Iraq
description: Iraq said its jets attacked ''selected targets'' today in the southwest Iranian city of Ilam and the border town of Dehloran.

title: IMC MAGNETICS reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
SOME GIVERS BELIEVE THE CITY'S NEEDIEST ARE ITS STREET PEOPLE
description: ''Please, if possible, let the enclosed contribution go to help the homeless and mentally ill people who have to sleep on the streets and in the subways of the city.''

title: Advertising; Management Revamped At DYR
description: THE budding international agency network that is the joint venture of America's Young & Rubicam and Japan's Dentsu is changing its name to just plain DYR from Young & Rubicam/Dentsu and is also getting overall top management for the first time.

title: Russell (Big Chief) Moore; A Trombonist in Big Bands
description: The jazz trombonist Russell (Big Chief) Moore, who played with Louis Armstrong and Lester Lanin, died yesterday of diabetes at Nyack Hospital in Nyack, N.Y. He was 70 years old.

title: MEESE ASSAILS 'MYTH' THAT REAGAN HAS WEAK RECORD ON POOR
description: President Reagan's counselor, Edwin Meese 3d, today defended the Administration against the ''myth'' that it is ''penny- pinching'' toward the poor. He contended that the campaign against poverty in previous administrations encouraged broken families and social disruption with Federal ''fool's gold.''

title: SOVIET, AFTER STUDIES, SHELVES PLAN TO TURN SIBERIAN RIVERS
description: After decades of study, the Soviet Union has quietly shelved a project to reverse the flow of Siberian rivers.

title: China Joins Fiber Pact
description: China was admitted today to the Multifiber Arrangement, the international treaty governing more than 80 percent of the world's trade in cotton, wool and synthetic fibers. The move reflects China's recent development as a large textile exporter, according to officials of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which administers the fiber agreement.

title: PRESIDENT ORDERS CURBS ON EXPORTS TO LIBYA
description: President Reagan has asked the State Department to urge other nations to join in curbs on exports to Libya. particularly items that may help the Soviet Union.

title: VLI Halts Filing Of Stock Offering IRVINE, Calif., Dec. 15 (Reuters) - The VLI Corporation said it would not file a registration statement for a secondary offering of common stock because the firm has not been able to find enough selling stockholders.
description: Late last month, VLI said it planned an offering of two million shares, all to come from selling stockholders who are primarily early investors in the company.

title: DANCE: TRISLER TROUPE
description: WHEN Joyce Trisler died in 1979, the members of the Joyce Trisler Danscompany decided that the greatest tribute they could offer their company's founder was to go on dancing. As a result, the Danscompany has been dancing ever since, under the direction of Milton Myers.

title: Phone Rates: Baxter View
description: William F. Baxter, the departing head of the Justice Department's antitrust division, said today that a 50 percent rate increase for basic local telephone service under the impending divestiture of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company should not be regarded as gouging.

title: PUBLISHING: CHECKING FOR ACCURACY
description: THE publishing industry is still analyzing Random House's recall this week of of C. David Heymann's ''Poor Little Rich Girl: The Life and Legend of Barbara Hutton,'' which the publisher acknowledged contained factual errors. Some of the discussion is in the nature of self-examination, but most publishers think that procedures for insuring accuracy in books, while clearly not foolproof, may be as good as it is possible to get.

title: Dow, Off 9.86 More, Ends at 1,236.79
description: Stock prices, caught in the throes of rising interest rates, year-end tax selling and portfolio adjusting, fell broadly yesterday for the second consecutive session.

title: Florida Asserts Pesticide Is Found in More Grains
description: The toxic pesticide EDB has been found in more samples of grain products, state officials said today.

title: Bronx Excursion
description: An all-day excursion in the Bronx, with stops at the zoo, the New York Botanical Garden and the performance center at Lehman College, is planned on Sunday by the botanical garden.

title: IRISH CHRISTMAS WITH THE CHIEFTAINS
description: Lately the Chieftains have been thinking big. The Irish folk group has an Oscar to its credit (for the score of ''Barry Lyndon'') and fans around the world; it has played on the Great Wall of China and performed in Dublin before a million people as an opening act for Pope John Paul II. Instead of making their New York show just another concert, the Chieftains are turning their performances at the Felt Forum tonight and tomorrow night into ''A Traditional Irish Christmas,'' with dancing, carol singing and a guest appearance by the celebrated actress Siobhan McKenna.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 16, 1983

title: 2 CLASH IN DEBATE ON SECRECY RULES
description: A Reagan Administration official and a prominent First Amendment lawyer clashed here this evening about whether the Administration's secrecy program was a reasonable safeguard for national security or a radical assault on free speech.

title: COLLEGE OVERSEER URGED
description: Claiming that abuses in intercollegiate athletics have detracted from the credibility of higher education, the American Council on Education opened a campaign today to gain support for its proposal that a committee of college and university presidents be given the power of veto over many, if not all, rules of the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: PROF. JAMES R. MEEHAN
description: Prof. James Robert Meehan, a former dean of administration at Hunter College, died Wednesday at a nursing home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 79 years old and lived in Scarsdale.

title: COMMERCIAL ALLIANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
BRIEFS
description: Elscint Ltd., an Israel-based producer of nuclear medical products, said it had agreed to acquire Xonics Inc.'s X-ray sales and services operations and certain other assets for $10 million.

title: WHY PROGNOSTICATORS STRAYED
description: Now they know why it happened: Consumers took the tax cut and spent it. People started buying houses and automobiles, and businesses accelerated production, so the economy boomed. Profits soared, relieving industry of pressure to raise prices, and some companies, such as Greyhound and Eastern Airlines, dug in their heels against wage increases, so inflation abated.

title: NORTH HILLS ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The latest third quarter and 9 months results include operations of Displex Inc. from May 1, 1983.

title: KUHN BANS 4 PLAYERS FOR A YEAR FOR DRUG USE
description: Bowie Kuhn, the commissioner of baseball, imposed one-year suspensions without pay yesterday on four players involved with the use of illegal drugs: Willie Wilson, Willie Aikens and Jerry Martin, all of whom played last season for the Kansas City Royals, and Steve Howe of the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: PARTYING FOR DE KOONING
description: Big social parties in New York have become so big it's sometimes impossible to find your friends. And who wants to stand around a huge room with no one to talk to? So it's now become de rigueur to have preparty parties before any major event.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Alcan Australia Ltd.'s $100 million issue of floating rate notes due in 1994 was priced at par, through Swiss Bank Corp. International Ltd. Interest will be set at 1/4 percent over the six-month London interbank offered rate.

title: PRECISION THAT MAKES CHAOS FUNNY
description: When Michael Blakemore read the script of ''Noises Off,'' Michael Frayn's slam-bang British farce now convulsing audiences on Broadway, the prospect of staging it made him feel quite faint. ''It made me want to go and lie down at once,'' he said.

title: TOUGHER SECURITY WAS SET IN KUWAIT
description: The State Department said today that it had approved enhanced security arrangements for the United States Embassy in Kuwait just a week before a truck- bomb attack there killed 5 people and injured 37.

title: AUCTIONS
description: SOTHEBY PARKE BERNET, the giant auction house, yesterday changed its name to Sotheby's, added eight members to its board, announced that its sales for the first four months of this season were up more than 70 percent over last year and disclosed that profits for the fiscal year ending Aug. 31 were somewhat higher than had been anticipated.

description: b-After extraordinary gains of $14,000 for the quarter and $50,000 for the 6 months. PLANTRONICS INC(N) Sales 33,410,000 27,331,000 Net inc 2,259,000 1,585,000 Share earns .34 .24 6mo sales 60,114,000 53,776,000 Net inc 3,361,000 3,058,000 Share earns .51 .47

title: U.S., IN NEW POLICY, MAKES AID ON ARMS A GRANT TO ISRAEL
description: The Reagan Administration has agreed to give Israel $1.4 billion in military aid in the next fiscal year, none of which has to be repaid, as part of a policy shift for military assistance worldwide, Administration officials said today.

title: Koch Says Inquiry Clears Miss Frank
description: Mayor Koch's office said yesterday that a background investigation of Susan Frank, Commissioner of the New York City Department of Ports and Terminals, had found ''nothing which would require Susan Frank's removal.''

title: BALANCE COMPUTER CORP Qtr to Oct 31 reports earnings for 1983
M.T.A. RAISES FARES AND TOLLS BY 20% ACROSS THE BOARD
description: The cost of a ride on the city's subways and buses was raised yesterday to 90 cents, a 15-cent increase. The new fare, to take effect next month, is the first increase in two and a half years.

title: HEINICKE INSTRUMENTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
GREECE SENTENCES CYPRIOT WRITER TO 2 YEARS AFTER LIBEL CONVICTION
description: A Cypriot journalist working here was convicted today of libeling and defaming the publisher of Greece's largest-selling newspaper and was sentenced to two years in prison.

title: 2 LATE INTERCEPTIONS HELP TROUNCE JETS
description: The 25th and 26th interceptions that Richard Todd had thrown this season - the highest total in the National Football League - were turned into touchdowns 61 seconds apart tonight as the Jets' season ended in a 34-14 loss to Miami.

title: THE MISSING LOOP IN NEW YORK'S SUBWAY
description: To the Editor:

Anthony Sisti Is Dead at 82; Boxer Who Became an Artist
description: Anthony J. (Kid Tony) Sisti, a boxer turned artist who painted President Franklin D. Roosevelt and other well-known people, died Thursday. He was 82 years old.

title: Charles J. Mylod, 81, Of Goelet Realty Co.
description: Charles J. Mylod, a real-estate executive in New York for more than half a century, died of a heart attack Thursday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 81 years old.

description: b-Net income

CITY WARNED ON HOUSING DISPLACED IN UNFIT HOTEL
description: New York City's program of placing homeless families in rundown hotels is being threatened by state rulings that the hotels do not meet minimum living standards, the State Commissioner of Social Services warned yesterday.

description: b-Including net income from discontinued operations of $6,229,000 for the quarter and $16,985,000 for the year. c-Including net income from discontinued operations of $6,149,000 for the quarter and $14,471,000 for the year. Corrected from Friday's editions.

description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 50 percent stock dividend paid in November 1983.
