description: BASEBALL

title: Federal Officials Say Crash Tests Support Use of Car Seat Belts
description: Federal highway safety officials today emphasized the importance of seat belts, even though tests have shown a high likelihood of serious injury or death in a head-on crash between two vehicles traveling 35 miles per hour.

title: Texas Lease Fight Settled by Mobil
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation agreed today to pay more than $500 million in a settlement involving south Texas oil and gas leases, state officials said.

title: PENTAGON TO CLOSE OFF TUNNELS
description: New antiterrorist security measures being imposed at United States Government facilities around the world include the closing of traffic tunnels under the Pentagon, according to a building circular.

title: EX STAR OF BACKFIELD WAS 32
description: Doug Kotar, the retired New York Giant running back who had fought an inoperable malignant brain tumor for 16 months, died in his sleep yesterday at Montefiore Hospital in Pittsburgh. He was 32 years old.

title: CHOIR: ST. THOMAS 'MESSIAH'
description: There are at least two ways of considering the performance of Handel's ''Messiah'' given by the St. Thomas Choir and Concert Royal under the direction of Gerre Hancock at St. Thomas Church on Tuesday night.

title: BRIDGEPORT POLICE SUPERINTENDENT FORCED OUT AFTER 22 YEARS AT TOP
description: Joseph A. Walsh, Bridgeport's Superintendent of Police for the past 22 years, was forced into retirement this week, and his ouster came with the suddenness of a coup d'etat.

title: GRANTREE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 3
description: b-Including tax credits of $107,000 for the quarter and $22,000 for the year.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bruce Curry , the World Boxing Council's super lightweight champion, will meet Billy Costello , the No. 6 contender, in a title bout on Jan. 29 at a site to be named. . . . Jarmila Kratochvilova , the Czechoslovak runner who set world records in the 400- and 800-meter runs, was named world women's athlete of the year by Track and Field Magazine after a vote by a panel of experts.

title: Books of The Times
description: ROLLING NOWHERE. By Ted Conover.

title: NETS LOSE TO SONICS
description: For 13 years, Fred Brown was known as ''Downtown'' for his scoring sprees from the outskirts of the basketball court. But this year he has been forced into a new role, and his place in the spotlight has been taken by younger players.

title: SCOUTING
description: Rushing Bonus

title: YOGI'S BACK IN STYLE
description: Yogi Berra's second regime as Yankee manager

title: Your Money Stock Trades At Year's End
description: AS the year draws to a close, some investors suddenly become aware of the possibility of obtaining tax benefits by last-minute securities transactions. Such advantages are best realized, however, with a full understanding of how the timing of these market moves might affect your personal investment strategy.

title: PLEA BY PATIENT FOR STARVATION BARRED BY COURT
description: A paralyzed woman, who says her life of complete physical dependence on others is not worth living, today was denied her request to starve to death in a hospital.

title: Moscow Changes Envoys
description: The Soviet Ambassador to Angola, Vadim P. Loginov, has been ''relieved of his duties and transferred to another post,'' the official press agency Tass said today.

title: 2 APPOINTEES FILL U.S. RIGHTS PANEL
description: The Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., today appointed two people to fill the last two vacancies on the new United States Commission on Civil Rights

title: TRAFFIC IN DRUGS LOWERING THE LOWER EAST SIDE
description: The Lower East Side. Just saying it conjures up visions of more than 100 years of immigrants - Irish; Jewish and other Eastern and Western Europeans, including Italians; Chinese; Puerto Ricans; blacks. They struggled to succeed, contributing their religious faith, family values, culture and love to New York. Open markets for fish, vegetables, fruit, flowers. Discount stores for everything from designer clothes to refrigerators, from furs to socks.

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: Missouri Dioxin Suit Seeks $1.8 Billion

title: MONEY SUPPLY JUMPS BY $5.5 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve reported yesterday that, as expected, the basic measure of the money supply rose by $5.5 billion in the financial week that ended Dec. 7.

description: Some may fret because there are only eight shopping days left before Christmas. But for church choirs, the concern is that there are only eight singing days left.

title: CORRECTION
description: A listing of Christmas music programs in Weekend yesterday gave an incorrect time for Christmas Eve at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. The program begins at 10:30.

title: PLAYER REACTIONS MIXED ON MARTIN
description: When the Yankees changed managers yesterday, replacing Billy Martin with Yogi Berra, some of last season's players appeared happy with the change, others were not inclined to talk publicly about it and at least one, Rich Gossage, was indifferent.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Milwaukee Bucks, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. Dec. 17 has sometimes meant a lot of scoring in Knick games. On this date in 1957, Richie Guerin got 42 points against Boston, and in 1978 Bob McAdoo had 41 against Atlanta. The current Garden's pro scoring record is 44 points, set against the Knicks on Dec. 17, 1974, by Rick Barry of Golden State. (Television - MSG Cable, 7:30 P.M., live, and 1 A.M., Sunday, tape. Radio - WNEW, 1130; 7:30 P.M.)

NEWSPAPER WORKER-OWNERS
description: When Henry P. Slane decided to sell his family's newspaper company, The Peoria (Ill.) Journal Star Inc., he wanted both a good price and a local buyer.

title: Ashland Sued On Payments
description: An Ashland Oil shareholder has filed suit in Federal court in Kentucky charging the oil company and most of its top management with making $44 million in illegal overseas payments in 1980 and 1981 in conjunction with Middle Eastern oil sales.

title: U.S.C. Women Make Record 10-0
description: Cheryl Miller scored 31 points Thursday night to lead the nation's top- ranked women's basketball team, the University of Southern California, to its 10th consecutive victory without a loss, 82-74 over third-ranked Georgia (5-1).

description: A steady 10-year decline in New York City's welfare rolls has ended, and in the last year the number of people on welfare has risen to more than 900,000.

description: Officials at Argentina's major creditor banks in the United States sought yesterday to clarify a request by Argentina that it be allowed to delay for six months payment of interest and principal due on its foreign debt.

title: Reagan on Death Penalty
description: President Reagan ''believes in the people's right to impose capital punishment for most serious murder offenses'' but he thinks it is a matter to be dealt with by the states, according to the White House spokesman, Larry Speakes. Mr. Speakes was asked Thursday about Mr. Reagan's position in light of the increase in executions.

title: BRITISH PAPER RETURNS A LEAKED MEMO
description: A British national newspaper complied today with a high court order and returned to the Government a leaked copy of a secret memorandum dealing with the handling of public information on the first cruise missile deliveries this fall.

title: 2-Year-Old Names Murder Suspect
description: A 2-year-old witness to the killing of her teen-age sister led detectives to the suspected assailant by repeating his name over and over, officials said yesterday.

title: Hollings Names Director
description: Senator Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina, today announced the appointment of J. Curtis Moffatt, a Washington lawyer, as campaign director of the Hollings for President Committee. Mr. Moffatt, 32 years old, a partner in the Washington law firm of O'Neill & Haase, served as national scheduler for the Presidential nominaation effort of Gov. Terry Sanford of North Carolina in 1972 and was a Sanford adviser in 1975-76.

title: MILLER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
MCDONNEL TO PURCHASE HUGHES HELICOPTER UNIT
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation, one of the nation's largest manufacturers of military equipment, said today that it would acquire Hughes Helicopters Inc. for about $470 million in cash.

title: Celtic Streak Ends at 6
description: Joe Kopicki, pressed into action after Jeff Ruland fouled out, scored 4 points in the final minute and the Washington Bullets withstood a Boston comeback tonight to score a 100-93 victory that ended a six-game Celtic winning streak.

title: BLASIUS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $200,000 for the quarter and $347,000 for the 6 months. c-Including tax credits of $124,000 for the quarter and $194,000 for the 6 months.

title: RAKING THE EMBERS
description: When I was 14 or so, my visions of how I would sin when I grew up were shaped by the movies. In that era, movies were filmed in black and white for a square screen and the actors almost always dressed formally for dinner. That is, they wore what was then called a tuxedo, or a tux.

title: SPAIN'S COMMUNISTS: WEAK AND WRENCHED APARTC
description: The Spanish Communist Party, which rose to fame as a fighting force in the Civil War and then to legend as an underground resistance in the Franco dictatorship, is facing its most severe crisis since it was legalized in 1977.

title: Dow Advances 5.38 On Inflation Report
description: Stock prices, recently under pressure, finished with moderate gains yesterday as encouraging inflation news helped bolster the list.

title: Utility Blocked On Refinancing
description: The Philadelphia Electric Company said the Pennsylvania Public Utility

title: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 17, 1983
description: International

title: Yet Another Shoreham Failure
description: ''A report on Shoreham that did not reveal strong differences of opinion about basic facts would not be honest.'' That's how John Marburger rationalized his special commission's failure to reach any useful conclusions about the nearly completed nuclear plant on Long Island.

title: Mrs. Peron Returns to Spain
description: Former President Isabel Martinez de Peron left for Spain today but said she would return to Argentina next month to take command of the opposition Peronist Party.

title: SAN FRANCISCO BALLET OPENS NEW HEADQUARTERS
description: The San Francisco Ballet, one of the oldest and most successful of American dance companies, celebrated another distinction today by moving into its handsome new headquarters opposite the San Francisco Opera House, where it performs throughout the year. The new facility is the first building in the United States to be designed and constructed exclusively for the use of a major ballet institution.

title: The Police Blotter
description: One person was killed and dozens were left homeless when a three- alarm fire yesterday afternoon swept through a six-story apartment house at St. Nicholas Avenue and 157th Street. The identity of the dead person and the cause of the fire were not immediately known. . . . A Queens College student was arrested yesterday in connection with three sexual assaults on women in Astoria. The student - Vasilios Diakakis, 19 years old, of 32-15 31st Avenue in Queens - was charged with sodomy, sexual abuse and weapons possession, said a spokesman for the Queens District Attorney, John Santucci.

title: Hospital Aide, 43, Slain Entering Car
description: A 43-year-old nursing supervisor at Presbyterian Hospital was beaten to death yesterday morning trying to fight off a robber as she got into her car in Washington Heights to go to work, the police said.

title: ARGENTINA SETS UP INQUIRY FOR 6,000 WHO DISAPPEARED
description: President Raul Alfonsin said today that he had set up a commission to investigate the disappearances of more than 6,000 Argentines during the military Government of the last several years.

title: GREAT AMERICAN MANAGEMENT & INVESTMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
2 Die in Ireland in Rescue Of Kidnapping Victim
description: A policeman and a soldier were killed today during the rescue of the chairman of a supermarket chain who was kidnapped by the Irish Republican Army three weeks ago, the police said.

title: U.S. Sums Up Reasons For Invading Grenada
description: The Reagan Administration, in a 44-page report summarizing its rationale for the invasion of Grenada last Oct. 25, said today that United States forces found ''almost 900'' personnel from Cuba, the Soviet Union, North Korea, Libya, East Germany and Bulgaria on the island.

title: JanetCookLoeb,80,IsDead; Founder of Adoption Service
description: Janet Cook Loeb, a social worker who was a founder and the first president of the Adoption and Children's Services of the Family Service of Westchester, died Wednesday in San Diego, a day before her 81st birthday.

title: POLICE IN POLAND PREVENT PROTESTS
description: Riot policemen filled the streets here and in other major cities today, blocking demonstrations that had been called by underground Solidarity leaders. The rallies were called to mark the shooting of scores of workers protesting food prices on this date 13 years ago.

title: Military Contracts
description: Litton Systems Inc.'s Ingalls Shipbuilding division received a $325.5 million contract from the Navy to build two guided-missile cruisers, the Defense Department said. The National Steel and Shipbuilding Company, a unit of the Morrison-Knudsen Company, was given a $165.3 million contract from the Navy for a hospital ship, the department said. In addition, it said the General Dynamics Corporation had received a $137.2 million Air Force contract for spare parts for A-7 aircraft.

title: HOTEL DISASTER INQUIRY ENDS
description: Prosecutors said today that a two-year investigation had produced ''insufficient evidence'' for criminal charges in the collapse of skywalks at the Hyatt Regency hotel that killed 114 people and injured more than 200.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Private Practice After a Public Squabble

title: JAPAN OPPOSITION HOPES TO TRIM RULING PARTY'S LEAD
description: Leaders of Japan's opposition parties, out of political power almost without interruption since World War II, say they are hoping Sunday's national elections will enable them to restore a balance to government.

title: FAMILY MEMBERS' GENEROSITY RECALLED BY GIFTS TO NEEDIEST
description: The memory of loved ones known in their lifetimes for their generous natures, or sometimes by their own need for help, is often recalled by contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: BAY FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $1,695,000 for the quarter and $3,015,000 for the 6 months. c-Including extraordinary credits of $551,000 for the quarter and $712,000 for the 6 months.

title: CATERING A BUSINESS REVIVAL
description: The typically lavish, traditional menu, put together by Breadline, a Manhattan caterer, for a party last week featured turkeys with sage and sausage stuffing, glazed hams in pecan sauce, sauteed cinnamon apples, sugared cranberries in gin, and profiteroles - tiny cream- or custard-filled pastries - stacked in the shape of a Christmas tree. The party, for around 100 employees of the Merona Sport Company, was held in a loft decorated in authentic turn-of- the-century French trappings.

title: Danish Parliament Dissolved; Election Is Scheduled Jan. 10
description: Queen Margrethe II dissolved Parliament today and scheduled elections for Jan. 10 after the Government's proposed budget was rejected by both rightist and leftist opposition parties.

title: METRORAIL, NOW 7, BRANCHING OUT
description: Construction of this city's 101-mile Metrorail subway system is to reach the halfway mark Saturday with the opening of a new extension and four new stations in Virginia.

title: ENRICO MANFREDINI
description: The Archbishop of Bologna, Msgr. Enrico Manfredini, was found dead in his bed today, church officials announced.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Sports Pages on Thursday about Aladar Kogler incorrectly described the experience of his son, Attila, in the national junior fencing championships. He competed this year and finished second.

title: COGENIC ENERGY SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income.

title: RICHARD PRYOR OUSTER OF BLACKS CRITICIZED
description: Richard Pryor has dismissed Jim Brown, the former football star turned actor, and three others from his production company ''due to creative differences,'' Columbia Pictures said Thursday.

title: BERRA REPLACES MARTIN AS YANKEES' MANAGER
description: Billy Martin's third term as manager of the Yankees ended with his dismissal yesterday, almost a year after it began. And Yogi Berra's second term began, 19 years after his first one ended.

title: RISE IN A YEAR SMALLEST SINCE '64
description: The Producer Price Index, the leading gauge of industrial price changes, declined two- tenths of 1 percent last month, the first drop since spring, the Government reported today.

U.S. INSISTS ON BIG CHANGES IN UNESCO
description: A high- ranking Reagan Administration official said today that if the United States decided to remain in Unesco, it would ''insist on some major changes'' in the organization.

description: ''It will kind of take the fun out of playing the lottery.'' - Vincent Coda, who won $7.1 million. (27:2.)

title: WARM CURRENT CUTS COAST FISH HAUL
description: David Yablonski, skipper of the 33- foot Space Cowboy, took in more than $50,000 last year trolling the Pacific for salmon, herring, rock cod and other fish. This year he expects to gross less than $15,000.

title: BRIEFING
description: Fruitful Tradeoff?

U.S. Team Beats Soviet Squad, 4-3
description: Pat LaFontaine, returning to his hometown, scored two goals and assisted on another in leading the United States Olympic hockey team to a 4-3 victory over an all-star team from the Soviet Union.

title: Oil Tanks Explode, Injuring 3
description: Five oil storage tanks erupted in a giant fireball today in a a series of explosions, the authorities said.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE ;
description: -of-the-century New York leaps to the eye in the 163 modest- sized prints of photographs in a gallery of the New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, at 77th Street (873-3400). They are an unusual pictorial inventory of what the city and its environs looked like in those days when, as in these urban days, old was giving way to new.

title: E.P.A. PROPOSES RULES ON BENZENE BUT WANTS TO CANCEL OTHERS
description: The Environmental Protection Agency announced new rules today to reduce harmful emissions of benzene into the air, but it also proposed to withdraw other pending benzene rules, saying they were unnecessary.

title: Newspaper in St. LouisSets Back Closing Date
description: The St. Louis Globe-Democrat, which had been scheduled to close Dec. 31, will publish at least two weeks beyond that deadline, the first sign of serious negotiations to sell the newspaper.

title: Basques Set Off 2 Bombs
description: Two bombs exploded at a military installation in northern Spain today, wounding three servicemen and causing extensive damage, the authorities said. E.T.A., the Basque guerrilla group, said in a call to a newspaper that it was responsible for the bombs and that four other bombs were at the site. Military sources said a third bomb was discovered under a propane gas tank and defused.

title: EllisVanRiperIsDead; Led T.W.U. Local 100
description: Ellis Van Riper, former president of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union, died at his home here today. He was 72 years old.

title: ART: VENETIANS OF 1500'S AT BRITISH ROYAL ACADEMY
description: As to which is the best Old Master exhibition of the winter season in Europe, there would seem to be no contest. The prize can only go to ''The Genius of Venice 1500-1600'' at the Royal Academy of Arts in London.

title: Reagan Names New Director Of Liaison With the U.S. Jews
description: President Reagan has announced the appointment Marshall J. Breger to direct the White House liaison with American Jews. Mr. Breger replaces Michael R. Gale, who will serve as a special assistant to the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, Samuel R. Pierce Jr.

description: b-Including a gain of $1,171,064 from tax recovery. c-Net loss including a tax credit of $832,000.

title: POSSIBLE STUFF OF PLANETS FOUND ORBITING STAR
description: A band of solid material has been discovered orbiting the star Fomalhaut, the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif., announced yesterday. This is the second star other than the Sun now known to be surrounded by relatively cool, solid material, perhaps the stuff of planets in some early stage of creation.

title: STEMMING THE TIDE OF STOLEN GOODS: MANY IDEAS BUT LITTLE OVERALL STRATEGY
description: In his office at Police Headquarters - amid color-coded charts of criminal conspiracies and city maps that show even alleyways and building configurations - Capt. Arthur Katz keeps a quote from Jonathan Swift:

title: Iran Says Its Artillery Killed 95 Iraqis in Attack
description: Iran said today that its artillery killed 95 Iraqi soldiers in retaliation for Iraqi air raids earlier in the week, the official Iranian press agency said.

title: Court Blocks Northeast Bid
description: A Federal District Court in Connecticut dismissed a suit yesterday that would have cleared the way for the Bank of New York Company to acquire Northeast Bancorp.

title: KASPAROV BEATS KORCHNOI TO WIN CHESS SEMIFINAL
description: Gary Kasparov of the Soviet Union crushed Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland in the 11th game and won their semifinal world championship chess match tonight.

title: Speculation in Houston
description: The Houston Oilers have refused to comment on a published report that Hugh Campbell , the coach of the Los Angeles Express, is the leading candidate to take over as the Oilers' coach next year, and Campbell has described the report as ''news to me.'' Ladd Herzeg, the general manager, said, ''My position since Day One has been that we won't discuss the situation until the season is over.''

Aircraft Is Controlled By Single Force Stick
description: An aircraft control system employing a multi-axis force stick was patented this week for the United Technologies Corporation, Hartford.

title: COOPERBIOMEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31

First City Bancorp Expects a Loss HOUSTON, Dec. 16 (Reuters) - First City Bancorp of Texas said it expects to report a loss of about $14 million for the fourth quarter, after a provision for loan losses of about $100 million. The company said it expects to report full-year net income of about $50 million, or about $1.25 a share, down from $120.3 million, or $3.52 a share, in 1982.
description: First City said the fourth-quarter provision for loan losses will increase the year-end allowance for loan losses after net charge-offs to more than $200 million, or about 2 percent of total loans outstanding. Of the fourth- quarter provision, about $85 million is attributable to First City National Bank of Houston, the largest of the company's 65 member banks. The company cited the continuing weakness in oil prices for the large provision. It also said it does not believe the losses will affect its proposed merger with Cullen/Frost Bankers Inc.

title: PLANT USE RISES TO 79.2%
description: The nation's industrial plants operated at 79.2 percent of their capacity last month, the highest level in more than two years, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: A NEW REAGAN ERROR ON LATIN AMERICA
description: The firing of Peter Bell as president of the Inter- American Foundation last week is the latest signal that the Reagan Administration dangerously misunderstands the nature of United States interests in Latin America.

title: FLAGG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $8,000 for the quarter and $74,000 for the 6 months and losses from discontinued operations of $93,000 for the quarter and $177,000 for the 6 months.

title: Kush Accused
description: Frank Kush , the Baltimore Colt coach who was dismissed from his job at Arizona State after he was accused of punching one of his players in 1978, has been accused of taking a poke at Derrick Hatchett , the former Baltimore Colt cornerback who was waived by the Colts last month. Kush, who was cleared in court of the charges leveled at him at Arizona State, has denied the latest accusa? tion.

title: Boy Guilty in Bomb Case
description: A 14-year- old boy pleaded guilty today to sending Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher a letter bomb, which was defused by the police at a postal sorting office. The judge, Sir John Lloyd, accepted the plea and postponed sentencing until after Christmas so that a probation report could be prepared.

title: Jets Top Devils, 4-1
description: Robert Picard and Dave Babych scored power-play goals in the opening period as part of a three-goal splurge, sending the Winnipeg Jets to a 4-1 victory over the Devils tonight.

title: HEAVY SNOWS RESULT IN DEATHS IN DEEP SOUTH By The Associated Press
description: An unexpected storm spread snow up to nine inches deep yesterday from Texas to Alabama, causing chaos on highways and closing schools in cities poorly equipped to handle such weather.

title: KENTUCKY ROMPS, 66-40
description: Melvin Turpin and Sam Bowie combined for 27 points and choked off Wyoming's inside game as Kentucky crushed the Cowboys, 66-40, tonight in Kentucky's invitational tournament.

title: CITGO CUTS PRICE IT'LL PAY FOR OIL
description: The Citgo Petroleum Corporation announced yesterday that it had cut the price it would offer for crude oil by $1.50 a barrel, to $28.50, a move analysts said could push down the price of oil both in the United States and abroad.

title: Nina Shengold Wins ABCPlaywrightAward
description: Nina Shengold, a New York writer, was named winner of the first ABC Playwright Award Wednesday for ''Homesteaders.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Northern Ireland Above Times Square

title: Nebraska Distracted
description: Tom Osborne, the Nebraska coach, is trying to get his players to focus on the Orange Bowl game against Miami on Jan. 2, but some of his seniors are apparently being tempted to look to their professional futures.

title: AFRICA GUERRILLAS PLANTED 2 BOMBS
description: The African National Congress took responsiblity today for two bombings in South Africa on Thursday, the eve of the 22d anniversary of the guerrilla group's decision to take up arms against white minority rule.

title: CITICORP'S BISCAYNE BID GAINS
description: Citicorp, the nation's largest bank holding company, received permission today to acquire the New Biscayne Federal Savings and Loan Association of Miami, thus moving closer to gaining a long-sought entry into the lucrative Florida market.

title: India Reports Arrest Of 2,100 in Punjab
description: The Indian Government announced today that it had arrested more than 2,100 people in search operations for Sikh terrorists in northern Punjab since it took direct control of the administration there in October.

title: SHOWTIME-PARAMOUNT PACT Showtime/The Movie Channel, the nation's second-largest pay television service, has acquired exclusive rights to the films produced by the Paramount Pictures Corporation for the next five years, the two companies announced yesterday.
description: Industry officials estimated that the agreement would cost Showtime $500 million. It will begin in February with the presentation of the film, ''Flashdance.''

title: 10-Year Pact for Crum
description: Denny Crum , now in his 13th season as the Louisville basketball coach, has signed a 10-year contract through the 1992-93 season. In his first 12 seasons, Crum led Louisville to one national championship, in 1980, and to the Final Four five times, including three out of the last four seasons. ''It's gratifying to know that the university appreciates my efforts enough to warrant this kind of commitment,'' said Crum, who was an assistant coach under John Wooden at U.C.L.A. before coming to Louisville.

title: U.S. PRAISES PRETORIA ON ANGOLA MOVE
description: The United States said today that South Africa's decision to withdraw its troops from southern Angola could lead to an improved climate for ending the stalemate in the negotiations on finding a formula for the independence of South- West Africa.

title: NUTRI/SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
; HOUSING: A CITY BURDEN BECOMES A RECOURSE

description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 17.

title: RECORD LOTTO WINNER: 'JUST VINNIE' NO MORE
description: ''Whenever I do something,'' Vincent Coda said today, ''I go all out. I couldn't have just won a couple of hundred thousand dollars. Oh, no. I had to go all the way. It's a calamity we'll just have to bear.''

title: Bridge: Winter Regional Is Starting Today, Due to Hotel Crush
description: Beginning a regional tournament on a Saturday is rare and, in New York City, unheard of. But because of pressures on hotel space, the Winter Regional of the Greater New York Bridge Association begins today - instead of the familiar Friday - at the New York Hilton Hotel.

title: PREGNANT WITH COMMENTS
description: As a sociologist, I have always known that attitudes toward reproduction vary from society to society, but it was not until I became pregnant that some of the distinctions were really brought home to me.

title: THE CITY
description: Officer Suspended In Killing on S.I.

title: PLUM PUDDINGS: THE FLAVOR OF CHRISTMAS
description: ''The pudding was out of the copper. A smell like a washing-day! That was the cloth. A smell like an eating house and a pastry cook's next door to each other, with a laundress's next door to that! That was the pudding!''

title: MORLAN INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $235,200 from settlement of litigation. The company is listed on the Philadelphia Stock Exchange.

title: DRIVER IN EMBASSY BOMBING IDENTIFIED AS PRO-IRANIAN IRAQI
description: The driver of the truck that exploded in an attack on the United States Embassy in Kuwait on Monday has reportedly been identified by Kuwaiti investigators as a pro-Iranian Moslem fundamentalist from Iraq.

title: MANY POLES LOSE BIDS FOR ASYLUM
description: The applications of hundreds of Polish nationals for political asylum in the United States have been rejected by Federal authorities trying to clear a backlog of applicants.

description: A Judicial Proposal

title: Arthur Murray Request
description: The Justice Department told a Federal court today that Arthur Murray International no longer has a monopoly on giving dancing lessons and should be released from a 25-year-old court order restricting its dealings with finance companies. The department joined the company and Educational Credit Business Inc. in asking the United States District Court in Kansas City, Mo., to terminate a 1958 consent decree that settled a Government antitrust suit. The public was given 60 days to file any comments on the proposed termination.

title: Koreans to Visit U.S.
description: South Korea's Commerce and Industry Minister, Kum Jin Ho, will lead a major purchase mission to the United States next March to help promote trade between the two nations, officials said today. A Commerce and Industry Ministry spokesman said Government officials and businessmen would visit several cities seeking to combat what they perceive as a growing mood of protectionism against Korean goods in the United States.

title: JOHNNY AYERS MERRITT, SIXTH IN VICTORIES OF COLLEGE COACHES
description: John Ayers Merritt, who ranked sixth in number of victories among all college football coaches, died at Vanderbilt Hospital Thursday night, soon after collapsing at his home. He was 57 years old.

title: Jamaica Premier Won't Agree To Hold New Elections Early
description: Prime Minister Edward P. G. Seaga, whose Jamaica Labor Party now controls all seats in Parliament, said today that he would not bow to pressure to hold a new election early.

title: REAGAN DECIDES TO TIGHTEN CONTROLS ON TEXTILE IMPORTS
description: President Reagan today came out in favor of tighter controls over imports of textiles, after persistent pressure from the powerful domestic industry.

But there's no simple answer. Most of the overruns were beyond his control.

title: HEALTH GROUP FOCUSING ON IMPACT OF HUNGER IN NEW ENGLAND
description: At a soup kitchen in New Haven, Deborah Frank, a Boston pediatrician, smiled at a boy who had come with his mother for a free midday meal. He seemed bright and articulate for his age, which she guessed from his size to be 4.

title: H. Roy Hamey, ExecutiveWith Yankees From 1960-64
description: H. Roy Hamey, a former general manager of the Yankees and two other major league clubs, died of a heart attack Wednesday in Tucson, Ariz., where he had lived since retiring as a Yankee executive in 1964. He was 81 years old and had remained active with the Yankees as a scout.

title: GEMTEC CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
TEXAS UTILITIES
description: The Texas Utilities Company said the estimated completion date for Unit 1 of the Comanche Peak nuclear plant had been changed to mid-1984 from this month. It also raised the estimated cost of the plant to $3.89 billion from the $3.44 billion estimated in 1981. Texas Utilities, which owns nearly 88 percent of Comanche Peak, said the delay resulted from the company's annual review of its system construction program.

title: MITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $1,280,000 from flood loss, net of insurance proceeds and income taxes.

title: CITICORP STRATEGY IN BUYING THRIFT UNITS
description: ''Traditionally, the only way commercial banks looked at the thrift industry was down our noses,'' Hans H. Angermueller, vice chairman of Citicorp, said in a speech earlier this year. But that attitude obviously has changed. Yesterday, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced that Citicorp had won the bid to acquire the New Biscayne Federal Savings and Loan Association of Miami, which has assets of almost $2 billion.

title: NEW CEASE-FIRE GOES INTO EFFECT IN LEBANON WAR
description: A new cease-fire went into effect in Lebanon today.

title: OPERETTA 'SWEETHEARTS' AT TOWN HALL
description: ''Sweethearts,'' unlike most operettas, was created for a purpose aside from the customary hope of making some money. Victor Herbert tailored it to the exceptional voice of Christie MacDonald as a follow-up to her tremendous popular success in ''The Spring Maid'' three years before ''Sweethearts'' was produced in 1913.

title: SCOUTING
description: Dallas May Get Indoor Soccer

title: KETTERING INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Rumsfeld Visits Israel; No Promise on Arafat
description: Donald Rumsfeld, the United States special envoy to the Middle East, conferred with Israeli leaders today, but Israel made no commitment on allowing the evacuation of Yasir Arafat and his guerrillas from Lebanon.

title: Breaking a Mold in Argentina
description: For eight years, generals and admirals terrorized Argentina with their lawless rule. Now, along with the civilian terrorists who provoked the repression, they are to be legally held to account. Argentina's newly elected President, Raul Alfonsin, is off to a brave and bold start.

title: MOTOR SCOOTERS SET A TREND IN CITY TRANSPORTATION
description: ''I drive straight into my loft with the scooter,'' says Peter Arnell, a New York designer. ''And I bring it up to my office on the back elevator. It costs me about $1 to $1.50 a week to drive.''

title: COOPERVISION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend in October.

title: SURPLUS MOBILE HOMES FOR THE HOMELESS
description: To the Editor:

title: ...SHORTCUT TO RESCUE IN OFFICE TOWERS
description: To the Editor:

title: 'CLOWN' TURNS SERIOUS
description: Losing isn't everything. But Jeff Chandler

title: ECHLIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
DEP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
G.E. To Sell Unit To Black & Decker
description: The General Electric Company said yesterday that it had signed an agreement in principle to sell its small-appliance business to the Black & Decker Manufacturing Company for about $300 million in cash and notes.

title: DEFINE BRAIN DEATH
description: New York State needs a statutory definition of death. It lacks one now. Beyond that, the state should recognize brain death as a legally acceptable standard for pronouncing death. Until then, families confronted with the loss of loved ones who are declared neurologically dead will be forced to deal with the confusing and erroneous assumption (supported by an outdated common law) that while the heart beats there is life and hope of recovery.

title: Anthony Lewis Is Honored
description: The Aspen Institute for Humanistic Studies has presented the ninth annual Arthur D. Morse Fellowship in Communications and Society to the New York Times columnist Anthony Lewis. The award will allow Mr. Lewis to participate in studies of his choice at Aspen.

title: MGM GRAND HOTELS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, DECEMBER 17, 1983
description: The Economy Producer prices fell 0.2 percent in November, the first decline since spring, the Labor Department reported. It attributed the decline to 1 percent drops in both food and energy prices. The Producer Price Index has risen less than 1 percent for the last 12 months, its smallest increase since 1964. Experts in and out of the Administration said the current outlook for inflation is much better than they had foreseen. (Page 1.) Industry ran at 79.2 percent of capacity in November, the highest level in more than two years, the Federal Reserve Board reported. It noted, however, that recent gains were more moderate than those of last spring and summer, a slowing welcomed by economists as a safeguard against any flareup of inflation. (32.)

title: Girard Bank Bid In Jersey Fought TRENTON, Dec. 16 (AP) - State banking officials in New Jersey and Pennsylvania said they would ask the Federal Reserve Board to prevent the proposed acquisition by Girard Bank, based in Philadelphia, of the Heritage Bank of New Jersey. But, officials of the Mellon National Corporation in Pittsburgh, which owns Girard, and of Heritage, a subsidiary of the Heritage Bancorporation in Jamesburg, N.J., said they do not believe the states' positions will block a merger.
description: The New Jersey Banking Commissioner, Michael M. Horn, said, ''New Jersey statutes definitely prohibit out-of-state banks from maintaining a branch office, transacting business or acquiring a New Jersey bank either by merger, acquisition or through a holding company.''

title: NBC AND MUDD STILL AT ODDS ON ROLE
description: A brief speech by Roger Mudd on the NBC-TV prime-time variety special ''Christmas in Washington'' Thursday night marked only the third time since Sept. 5 - his final night as co-anchor of the ''NBC Nightly News'' - that the well-known correspondent has appeared on the air.

title: THE NATION
description: More ProtectionFor Textiles

title: SCHOOL AND TOWN IN HOUSING PLAN
description: THE town of Mansfield has a housing shortage. The Mansfield Training School has a surplus of space, created by an effort to place its mentally retarded clients in group homes. Now, each one's problem may be the other's solution.

title: FALLING PRICES (AND OTHER JOYS)
description: Consumers were still spending , businesses were still prospering and inflation was still under control through the end of November. A slew of indicators on the nation's economy underlined the fact that the recovery is still on track and that seasonally adjusted merriment is in order. Prices at the wholesale level actually fell in November, leading to what will be the best year for wholesale prices since 1964. A 1 percent drop in energy and food prices pushed the Producer Price Index down two-tenths of 1 percent. Retail sales jumped far beyond economists' expectations, rising 1.9 percent in November, while consumer installment debt - such as credit card buying and auto loans - rose by a record $4.89 billion in October. Strong auto sales were behind both statistics, and the Big Three reported that dealers continued to move vehicles in December. Sales were up 21.1 percent over the year before in the first 10 days of the month.

title: SHOREHAM APPROACHES ITS DAY OF RECKONING
description: Few problems have proven as intractable for Governor Cuomo as what to do about the Long Island Lighting Company's virtually completed nuclear power plant at Shoreham. Should he help Lilco to open the $3.5 billion reactor? Should he back the plant's opponents, who want it abandoned? In any case, whom should he make pay for what now seems to almost everyone an epic miscalculation: the utility's customers, its stockholders or the citizens of New York State?

title: STATE PLANS TO GIVE DEPRIVED YOUTHS A BIT OF COMPUTER BASICS
description: Computer training would be offered to 1,000 children, most of them underprivileged, across the state this summer under a $350,000 program being planned by the state's Urban Development Corporation.

title: Quake Rocks Central Asia
description: A strong earthquake rocked Soviet Central Asia near the borders with China and Afghanistan on Friday, but no deaths were reported, the Soviet press agency Tass said today. It put the epicenter near Lenin Peak in the Tien Shan mountain system of Kirghizia.

title: Melanie Gulden Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Gulden of Windham, N.H., and Barndoor Island, Lake Winnipesaukee, N.H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Melanie Kay Gulden, to James Thomas Gerry, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Thomas Gerry of Randolph, N.J. Miss Gulden and her fiance, graduates of Colgate University, plan a June wedding.

title: LOUISVILLE DEFEATS N.C. STATE BY 83-79
description: The Louisville basketball coach Danny Crum does not like the new rule that gives a team two free throws on a deliberate foul in the last two minutes, but that rule change helped his Cardinals to an 83-79 victory over North Carolina State today.

title: Melissa J. Hilson Is Married
description: Melissa Jan Hilson, daughter of Mrs. John T. Beaty of Greenwich, Conn., and John S. Hilson of New York, was married yesterday to Howard Alfred Parker Jr., son of Mrs. Parker of Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Mr. Parker. The Rev. Alistair Votaw performed the ceremony at the Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich.

title: THE WORLD
description: Trading BasesFor Money

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ''Baby,'' the new musical at the Barrymore, has a flaccidly structured, sit-com book - but, in exchange, it offers some of the best new songs Broadway has heard in recent seasons. The composer David Shire and the lyricist Richard Maltby Jr. have some wise, even trenchant, observations to make about the joys and travails of modern parenthood.

title: WHO IS ON 'OUR' SIDE?
description: Yogi Berra, upon appointment to his second term as manager of the New York Yankees, flashed his familiar lopsided grin and waggled a finger at his friends in the press: ''You guys ain't gonna get too much from me.''

title: Dogs Attack Antelope Herd
description: Family dogs are attacking herds of antelope that were driven by severe snowstorms to seek refuge among the homes and fences in Rawlins subdivisions, officials say. Dennis Smith, a Wyoming Game and Fish Department warden, said the dogs posing the danger to antelope were household pets, not wild or abandoned dogs.

title: AT NEBRASKA, TOM OSBORNE IS ROLE MODEL FOR SUCCESS
description: THE proud citizens of Nebraska had come

title: 3 CHALLENGE GRANTS AWARDED IN COUNTY
description: CHRISTMAS has come a little bit early this year for Sister Brigid Driscoll, president of Marymount College in Tarrytown.

title: GRETZKY'S SIX POINTS LEAD OILERS IN ROUT
description: Wayne Gretzky scored one goal and registered five assists to lead the Edmonton Oilers to an 8-1 victory over the Quebec Nordiques tonight.

title:
STAMPS;
SEMI-POSTALS TO HELP THOSE IN NEED
description: In keeping with the Christmas

title: DANCING WITH THE AUDIENCE
description: ''In a good performance there is electricity

title: NOUVELLE CUISINE: HERE TO STAY
description: WAS IN A SAUNA one afternoon recently, and a man sitting next to me spoke up. ''You're the food writer?'' ''Yes,'' I answered. ''What do you think's going to happen to cooking over the next 10 years?''

title: NEW TACK IN GETTING HOMES BUILT
description: houses in the Windsor Terrace section of

title: LICHTENSTEIN HAS NOT LOST HIS POWER TO PROVOKE
description: Roy Lichtenstein turned 60 this year. Though in no way weakened or diminished by the passage of time, he has arrived at the age at which people begin to take stock of themselves. ''Who am I?,'' they say, just as they had said 40 years earlier. The answer may not have crystallized, but at least the dossier is fatter. And Roy Lichtenstein at this moment and through Jan. 14 has two substantial exhibitions in New York that may help us, whether or not they can help him, to find the answer.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: MUSIC

title: THE DECLINE IN COLLEGE STANDARDS
description: Arnold Beichman has a rather twisted notion of the advances in higher education in the 1960's. From his perspective, the admission to universities of people of color, women and people of limited means represented not an advancement of opportunity, but a decline in educational standards; the critical analysis of American society and culture resulted not in more humane and just policies, but in the subversion of traditional values, and the growing acceptance of alternative life styles led not to greater personal freedom, but to the erosion of morals. JOHN W. COLE GERALD F. REID Department of Anthropology University of Massachusetts Amherst, Mass.

title: WOOD STOVES CALLED PERIL TO NEW ENGLAND AIR
description: The smoke that billows from wood-burning stoves has joined acid rain as a leading environmental problem in New England, a Dartmouth College professor says.

title: INDIANS IN FLUSHING BLEND 2 CULTURES
description: As others who have left India to live in the United States, Pritam Singh Bindra struggles to maintain the old traditions in a new land.

title: Amy Susan Finkelstein Plans to Be Married in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Finkelstein of Ossining, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Susan Finkelstein, to Matthew Howard Adler, son of William R. Adler of Willingboro, N.J. The wedding is planned for October.

title: FARCE KICKS UP ITS HEELS AGAIN
description: Farce, it's said, is a dying form; and the reason for its disappearance from our stages is not hard to find. It cannot easily breathe in a permissive atmosphere. People don't often cram their lovers under beds or their mistresses into closets these days: they're more prone to introduce them to their spouses with a ''By the way dear, there's someone I'd like you to get to know.'' And that is bad, very bad for farce, which thrives on fear and dismay and worse. Ideally, it requires a sort of bug-eyed brinkmanship between panic and disaster.

title: Bishop Plans to Buy House That Led Parishioners to Sue
description: An Episcopal bishop has decided to buy an expensive waterfront home that was the subject of a legal battle after the church bought it for his use last August.

title: ARREST IN WEST HARTFORD FIRES ENDS TENSION FOR JEWISH NEIGHBORS
description: WEST HARTFORD SINCE August the large Jewish community of this affluent suburban town had been badly shaken.

title: Referees Return to Hugs, Heckles
description: As Lee Jones and Mike Mathis walked out on the floor about 20 minutes before the start of the San Diego-Los Angeles game Friday night in Inglewood, Calif., a smiling Norm Nixon interrupted his shooting drill to welcome Jones back with a bear hug.

title: 1899 LANDMARK SPRINGS TO LIFE
description: In 1899, when the Bayard Building, the only New York City structure designed by the noted Chicago architect Louis H. Sullivan, was completed at 65 Bleecker Street between Broadway and Lafayette Street, its Greenwich Village setting was one of the city's most desirable commercial and residential areas. Regarded as a skyscraper at the time, the 13-story office building represented a contrast to other structures of its era with its open interior construction and organically ornamental cornice and facade.

title: THE WORLD
description: Walesa Puts HisPrize to Work

title: FOUNDATION PLANS GRANTS FOR PREVENTING WAR
description: The Carnegie Corporation, searching for ways of reducing the risk of nuclear conflict, has approved a multimillion- dollar program that seeks to tap the talents of American scientists, scholars, military experts and policy analysts outside of Government.

title: 2 OPPOSITION LEADERS EMERGE IN NICARAGUA
description: As the Nicaraguan Government embarks on a policy of accommodation with its domestic critics, two new opposition leaders have emerged who seem dedicated to liberal democracy and determined not to flee the country.

title: THE $.02 PLAIN PAPERS: A TALE OF 2 POETS
description: BAYONNE FOR MORE than 25 years, Herschel Silverman, who owns a luncheonette and candy store across the street from Bayonne High School, has been carrying on a pen-pal correspondence with one of the foremost poets of the century, Allen Ginsberg.

title: Army Works on a Blinding Laser
description: Officials at the Pentagon said today that the Army was developing a portable laser beam weapon capable of blinding enemy soldiers.

title: EDITORS' NOTES
description: A chart in The Week in Review on Nov. 20, illustrating the high cost of military spare parts, cited prices quoted for radar antenna parts. It mentioned a sale that was canceled after a Senate committee investigation.

title: F.T.C. Says Lawyers' Group Illegally Raised Fees to Poor
description: The Federal Trade Commission has charged a Washington lawyers' group with conspiring illegally to get higher rates for defending the poor with a boycott that backlogged court dockets.

title: AMERICAN TEACHING ITALIANS OPERA
description: In this small Tuscan hill town near Lucca last week, Alessandro Melani's opera ''L'Empio Punito'' had its second performance, 314 years after its premiere in Rome. The work was revived, arranged for performance and conducted by Herbert Handt, an American tenor-musicologist-conductor and guiding spirit of musical life in this area.

title: Bomb Threat in Hotel Ended
description: About 180 guests at a downtown hotel were evacuated early today after a man who said he wanted ''to die with dignity'' because he was terminally ill barricaded himself in his room and threatened to set off a bomb. A four-hour standoff ended around 4 A.M. when the man unlocked the door of his ninth- floor room and collapsed from a drug overdose, the police said. No explosives or weapons were found and no one was injured.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bobby Allison , the stock car driver who just won his first Nascar championship, has been named Olsonite driver of the year in balloting by a panel of motor-sports writers and broadcasters. . . . Michael Jeffries of Duke University has won the Robert R. Hermann Trophy as college soccer's player of the year, and James Swanner of Clemson has been named the top senior goalkeeper by the Intercollegiate Soccer Association of America. . . . Honoring a superhuman performance, ABC-TV's ''Wide World of Sports'' has named Australia II as ''the athlete of the year.'' . . . Dave Lapham , an offensive guard with the Cincinnati Bengals of the National Football League, plans to sign with the New Jersey Generals of the United States Football League, according to his wife. . . . John Rosenberg , a former Harvard linebacker who has been a backfield coach for the Philadelphia Stars of the U.S.F.L., is expected to be named head coach at Brown, replacing John Anderson , who resigned after 11 seasons.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: From Head to Toe, For All Ages and Sexes Forty-eight years ago Kaplan's opened in Port Chester as a medium- priced department store and its original formula of sportswear to dressy clothing has not essentially changed: everything but shoes for women and children; and men's furnishings - all but shoes, suits, jackets and outerwear. Major American brands are carried in all departments and the fitting rooms are individual. Boxes and gift-wrapping are free yearlong and alterations are done without charge for boy's and men's slacks.

title: TOWNSHIP DEBATES EXTRA SCHOOL DAYS
description: SMITHVILLE THE Galloway Township Board of Education plans to extend the 1984-85 school year by at least 20 days, and even more in the next six years.

title: Louise Nayer, a Poet, Is Married in San Francisco
description: Louise Bedford Nayer, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Herman R. Nayer of New York, and James Joseph Patten, son of Josephine Lorenz Patten of Buffalo and the late Harry S. Patten, were married yesterday in San Francisco. The Rev. David Burr of the Universalist Spiritualist Church performed the ceremony at the Noe Valley Ministry.

title: MISTAKEN IDENTITY CONSIDERED IN DALLAS CASE
description: A Dallas County prosecutor said today that his office was investigating the possibility that a 22-year-old armed robber could have committed the robbery for which Lenell Geter was convicted in October 1982. But he said he doubted the investigation would change his belief that Mr. Geter was guilty.

title: Elizabeth Gardella Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James R. Gardella of the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Gardella, to John David O'Connor, son of Dr. and Mrs. Jeremiah A. O'Connor.

title: His Final Battle
description: Alexis Arg"uello , the former three- time boxing champion, has said that on Christmas Day he will join rebel combat forces trying to overthrow the Sandinista regime in his native Nicaragua. ''You may never see me again,'' Arg"uello said at a retirement party in his honor in Atlantic City.

title: SHORT CLASS DAYS DISPUTED IN JERSEY
description: Education Commissioner Saul Cooperman says that holding half days of school so teachers can attend training sessions cheats students of instruction time and should be abolished, but a teachers' group has defended the practice as beneficial.

title: 2 CANADIAN PARTIES AGREE ON MEDICARE BILL
description: A new consensus has emerged over Canada's system of universal public medical insurance, which has been threatened by underf inancing and growing use of private fees.

title: SHADOW OF TERRORISM FALLS ACROSS THE U.S.
description: WASHINGTON THE images of the past week tell the story. The battleship New Jersey firing its 16-inch guns into the Lebanese hills, the debris in the truck-bombed American compound in Kuwait, the concrete highway dividers being placed around the State Department in Washington and in front of the United States's Mission to the United Nations in New York. Violence is being answered not only with force but with anger, frustration and worry.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: Broad ApproachPromised OnDioxin CleanupCalling dioxin ''one of the most perplexing and potentially dangerous chemicals ever to pollute the environment,'' the Environmental Protection Agency last week announced a national plan to locate and clean up contaminated sites. Just how much money might be spent on the project was unclear, however.

title: Chicago Club Plans Challenge
description: The Chicago Yacht Club is preparing to challenge for the America's Cup, and the group's skipper is likely to be Buddy Melges, the Olympic gold medalist who is considered one of the world's foremost helmsmen.

title: BALANCHINE BALLET KEPT
description: Eighteen ballets choreographed by the late George Balanchine will be preserved through graphic notation in a project just announced by the Dance Notation Bureau. The bureau has received a total of $150,000 in grants from the National Endowment for the Arts and the Ford Foundation. The three-year project was endorsed by Mr. Balanchine, who died in April, and will be undertaken with the cooperation of the New York City Ballet.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's difficult to understand the minds of people who can do that. There are very evil people in our society and we have to do everything we can to catch them.'' - Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, after the bombing in London. (1:6.)

title: AT BURN CENTER, PAINSTAKING VICTORIES
description: VALHALLA THE nurses and visitors in the isolation room come and go dressed in sterile gowns and masks. Here a mother cannot kiss or even touch her burned son - a precaution against infection, which the patient's body cannot fight. In the sunlighted rooms of the Burn Center at Westchester County Medical Center here, patients are immobilized in splints or in traction to protect their skin grafts, to prevent contractures and to speed a slow healing process.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: WAKING. By Eva Figes. (Pantheon, $4.95.) A novel by Eva Figes, whose ''Patriarchal Attitudes'' was a study of feminism, ''Waking'' examines one woman's life by revealing the thoughts she has in the quiet time between sleeping and waking at a variety of stages - childhood, adolescence, pregnancy, divorce, middle age, the empty-nest period and old age. In his review, D. M. Thomas wrote, ''The atmosphere of silence, the relationship of a woman to her body . . . one's sense of the changing, darkening seasons of life - these are beautifully evoked.''

title: CITY PEGS ITS HOPES ON NEW COURTHOUSE
description: WHEN Derby residents approved the issuing of $3.5 million in bonds to build a state courthouse last weekend, they gave impetus, officials say, to the revitalization of the lower Naugatuck Valley city's stagnant business district.

title: JOYOUS SOUNDS OF THE SEASON
description: IT is once again time for Herr

title: MOVING AGAINST THE DRUNKEN DRIVER
description: IT is the season for family gatherings, for revelry and for accidents on the road. Every year at

title: BROWN GIVES TEAM EDGE AGAINST NETS
description: After 13 successful years in the league, Fred Brown knew exactly what he was seeing during the final minutes of his team's game against the Nets Friday night.

title: Madeline Parrish To Become Bride
description: Mrs. James Scott Parrish of Richmond has announced the engagement of her daughter, Madeline Beaumont Parrish, to Daniel Kimberly DesMarais, son of Mrs. Hubert DesMarais of Menasha, Wis., and the late Mr. DesMarais.

title: Officials at School Intercept An Antinuclear Class Letter
description: More than 100 letters written by sixth-graders seeking to eliminate nuclear weapons have been intercepted by school officials who refused to allow the letters to be mailed.

title: CRIME
description: The past few months have seen several mysteries in which dogs shared top billing. They include Ted Wood's ''Death in the Water,'' Barbara Moore's ''The Doberman Wore Black'' and Thomas Perry's ''Metzger's Dog.'' The latest are McGARR AND THE P.M. OF BELGRAVE SQUARE by Bartholomew Gill (Viking, $13.95) and DEAD IN THE WATER by Ted Wood (Scribner's, $11.95). A trend?

title:
ANTIQUES;
REMODELING AN OLD FARMHOUSE
description: -century farm in a still-bucolic part of Hunterdon County in 1965, Bob and Fran Durst realized a long- held dream.

title: NEW DANCES THAT MADE AUDIENCES THINK
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festival has helped make this autumn rich in modern dance and multimedia theater. Productions were unusual and often surprising, and one of them, ''The Gospel at Colonus,'' the gospel music version of a Greek tragedy, is back at the Academy for a return engagement through Dec. 31. As a result of the emphasis upon collaborations between choreographers and visual artists, Next Wave productions were good to look at and, in addition to giving visual pleasure, they provided food for thought.

title: ORIGINS OF MYTH-MAKING MAN
description: HISTORICAL ATLAS OF WORLD MYTHOLOGY

title: JOYOUS SOUNDS OF CHRISTMAS
description: THE county has once again draped itself in twinkling lights. The scent of pine is pleasantly aspirated into the lungs, and downtown White Plains appears to sink a few inches under the weight of shoppers and automobiles. Emanating from the county's hundreds of churches are the joyful rehearsal sounds of Handel and D'Aquin, Bach and Dupre, Britten and Sweelinck and Howells and Hobson, Praetorius and T. Tertius Noble. It is Christmastime.

title: Slips
description: To the Editor:

title: SATELLLITES ASSIST PACIFIC FISHERMEN
description: California fishermen have begun using space satellites to help them catch tuna, salmon and other species of fish in the Pacific Ocean.

title: JAPANESE STANDS TO GAIN FROM A BIG VICTORY FOR NAKASONE
description: For Americans, Japanese politics can evoke memories of what it was like to follow the New York Yankees of the 1950's. There is never a question about who will win, only what the final score will be. After a while, even that can stop being interesting.

title: REGENTS MAY EASE 'RIGID' PROPOSALS
description: The State Board of Regents, which last summer proposed tougher academic standards and a longer school year as part of its five-year plan to improve education in New York, will revise some of its proposals and may drop others, according to board members.

title: WOMAN LOSES CUSTODY FIGHT WITH HER PARENTS OVER DOG
description: A family dog is a piece of property, like a washing machine or a television set, a Superior Court judge has ruled in denying a 20-year-old woman's bid to wrest a dog from her parents.

title: Elizabeth Frawley Weds Smith Bagley
description: Elizabeth Anne Frawley, daughter of Judge and Mrs. John D. Frawley of Elmira, N.Y., was married yesterday to Smith Walker Bagley of Washington and St. Simons Island, Ga., son of Nancy Susan Reynolds of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Henry Walker Bagley of New York, Palm Beach, Fla., and Paris. The Rev. Peter Donahue performed the ceremony in St. William's Roman Catholic Church on St. Simons Island.

title: REVIVING THE GERMAN QUESTION
description: James M. Markham is chief of The Times bureau in Bonn. ALONG THE 752- MILE metal-and-concrete barrier that separates East Germany from West Germany, sturdy wooden platforms have been erected on the West German side, usually at the end of roads that go nowhere. Clutching binoculars, West Germans clamber to the top of the platforms and, like forest rangers looking for wisps of smoke, peer intently into East Germany. Sometimes they are so close that they can hear chickens clucking in East German barnyards, dogs barking, border guards coughing.

title: DINING OUT: CRITIC'S CHOICES
description: -taking of restaurant fare has arrived. The encouraging results will help provide the answer to the frequent request for the names of best restaurants in the area. This year was a good year for restaurantgoers. Some old favorites have grown more wonderful, and a handful of exciting new faces has added sparkle to the dinner hour.

title: 5 KILLED IN LONDON AS BOMB EXPLODES OUTSIDE HARRODS
description: A car bomb exploded here today in a street crowded with Christmas shoppers outside Harrods, the department store, killing 5 people and wounding 91 others.

title: SCIENTISTS SEEK REPELLANTS FOR DEER
description: ALMOST 30,000 deer live in Connecticut. Sighting these elegant and graceful animals in the wild can mean different things to different people.

title: If There's One Hungry American . . .
description: What should a sensible politician say to calm the flap that Edwin Meese, the White House counselor, caused with his clumsy comments about hunger and cheating?

title: Elizabeth A. Saunders Wed to G. T. Anderson
description: Elizabeth Ann Saunders, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Walker Saunders of Pelham Manor, N.Y., and Pinehurst, N.C., was married yesterday to George Thomas Anderson, son of Mary Anderson of Havertown, Pa., and the late Harry Dennis Anderson. The Rev. Francis V. Boyle performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church in Pelham Manor.

title: MURRAY SIEGEL
description: Murray Siegel, executive director of the West Side Chamber of Commerce and founder in 1977 of the annual Columbus Avenue festival, died yesterday at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx after a long illness. He was 67 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: Australia Agrees to Let British Ship Use Dock
description: Australia has bowed to British and American pressure and agreed to let a British ship, reportedly carrying nuclear weapons, use a Sydney dry dock, it was reported here today.

title: Glasgow
description: To the Editor: It was a pity that R. W. Apple's fine piece on ''Glasgow's Treasures'' (Travel, Nov. 6) was marred by an error in the picture cap

title: JAPAN ELECTS NEW LOWER HOUSE TODAY
description: A two-week campaign dominated more by personalities than broad national issues ended tonight as Japanese voters prepared to elect a new lower house of Parliament on Sunday.

title: Ruth Porat Wed To Law Student
description: Ruth Porat and Anthony Paduano were married yesterday at the Hotel Pierre by Rabbi Bruce Goldman and the Rev. Louis Gioia, a Roman Catholic priest.

title:
ART;
A MUSEUM COLLECTION THAT REFLECTS PATRONS' TASTES
description: AMUSEUM'S permanent collections are its heart and soul, the core that remains after temporary exhibitions have come and gone. Seldom, however, does the individual donor's personality assert itself in a large institution's holdings, where the scope of collections has evolved beyond the resources of any one collector or benefactor.

title: ENGINES OF MODERNIZATION
description: METROPOLITAN CORRIDOR

title: OUTDOORSBruce D. Stutz

title: TRIUMPH FOR BENJAMIN
description: LONDON Joel Benjamin, a Brooklyn international master and a United States junior co- champion, won his match with the top under-20 British international master, Nigel Short, 18, in overwhelming style. Benjamin, 19 years old, won four games and drew three with Short, earning $:400 from the sponsor, Acorn Computers Ltd.; Short received $:300.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORTS;
WHEN A BOXER RETIRES, IT RARELY ENDS HIS CAREER
description: EXPERIENCE keeps a dear school, Poor Richard tells us, but fools will learn in no other. Sports reporters are bad students. The fact that the best-laid retirements in boxing go awry is not exactly stop-press news, but reporters and their editors are shocked when it happens.

title: TOPICS
description: CAN individuality survive in the computerized electronic world? How can you have a personal style when you have so little control? Computers process in minutes information that in the past would have required days or weeks of work, yet you can't get hold of it instantly. Your bank statement comes near the end of the month even though it covers transactions up to and just beyond the first. The statements go to a mid-Island computer for processing, and after the information goes, there's no access to it until the statements emerge.

title: 'JEAN SEBERG' ON THE LONDON STAGE
description: Michael Billington writes frequently about British theater.

title: Advice to Cooperman: Go After the Chiefs
description: Although there may be considerable merit in Dr. Saul Cooperman's proposals for upgrading education in New Jersey, he should know what any fisherman knows: The rotten fish stinks from the head.

title: WEAKER BUMPERS ON MOST NEW CARS
description: While the Government has lowered its strength requirements for car bumpers, many manufacturers are keeping the stronger bumpers on at least some of their 1984 models, a consumer group says.

title: Caroline Oakes Becomes Bride Of Bank Officer
description: Caroline Kennington Oakes, daughter of Col. and Mrs. John Hawley Oakes of West Point, N.Y., was married at the Cadet Chapel of the United States Military Academy there yesterday to Reid Stanley McCarthy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cooper Reid McCarthy of Severna Park, Md. Thomas H. Wright, retired Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of East Carolina, performed the ceremony, assisted by Chaplain Richard P. Camp Jr.

title: TOKYO IN NEW YORK: 5 MEN OF POWER
description: MAMORU Tabuchi considers it a good week if he eats dinner at home twice. Most nights, the president of Mitsui's American subsidiary is driven in a chauffeured Cadillac to the Yale Club in midtown New York to pick up his wife, Seiko, and begin an obligatory round of social engagements.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE DREADFUL FUTURE OF BLOSSOM CULP

title:
NUMISMATICS;
WORKSHOP IN MEDALLIC ART OFFERED AT PENN STATE
description: Efforts to advance the cause of medallic art will receive a major boost next summer when Pennsylvania State University holds a three- week workshop on this often neglected art form. The program, billed as the International Medallic Art Workshop, is said to be the first of its kind ever offered in this country.

title: MONDALE-GLENN MARGIN WIDENS TO 47% to 19%
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale has significantly lengthened his lead over Senator John Glenn in their contest for the Democratic Presidential nomination, according to the latest Gallup Poll.
