title: FOR SALE
description: Since Northeast Utilities hung a ''for sale'' sign on the 101-year-old lighthouse it owns in Stamford Harbor, the utility has received some 24 bids on the dilapidated 80-foot, cylindrical structure, which comes with 10 acres of submerged property.

title: DIVISION I-AA TITLE TO SOUTHERN ILLINOIS
description: Rick Johnson passed for two touchdowns and ran for one and Greg Shipp intercepted four passes as Southern Illinois easily defeated Western Carolina today, 43-7, to win the Division I-AA championship.

title: SPICY VEGETABLE DISHES FIT TO ACCOMPANY MEAT OR FISH
description: SPICY vegetable dishes, so much a part of the cuisines of India, the Middle East and parts of Asia, are generally overlooked in Western cooking. But there are dozens of dishes that go beautifully with roast chicken, a grilled piece of fish, steak or lamb chops.

title: Affluence and Aid On Campus
description: I wish to comment on the opinions expressed by Kay McKemy in her essay ('A Lesson Learned in How To Survive 4 Years of College,'' Opinion Page, Dec. 4).

title: 'MERRY WIDOW' AT ITS MERRIEST
description: TO come right out with it, the Darien Dinner Theater's felicitous production of ''The Merry Widow'' may well be the best thing that has happened to dinner theaters in an eon. Indeed, anyone who relegates such a theater form to second-class status ought to have a look at and a listen to this classy and snappy interpretation of what could be a tired stock package.

title: REPORT SAYS PRESS FREEDOM DECLINES AROUND THE WORLD
description: Press freedom is deteriorating sharply and journalists are threatened by jail or death in the Soviet bloc, most of Asia, Latin America and Africa, the International Press Institute said today.

title: No Headline
description: The72dAppeal

title: Death of Commuter Laid to NJ Transit
description: On Nov. 29, an Eatontown resident was killed while commuting homeward on a southbound North Jersey Coast Line train. He was killed not by a person or a train, but by an entity known as NJ Transit.

title: Miss Crysler Has Nuptials
description: Sophia Godwin Taliaferro Crysler and Clifford Awtrey Hart Jr. were married yesterday at Bruton Parish Episcopal Church in Williamsburg, Va., by the Rev. Dr. Cotesworth Pinckney Lewis and the Rev. Timothy Pickering. The bride is a daughter of Rosemary Godwin Crysler of Haverford, Pa., and Edwin Walter Crysler Jr. of Philadelphia. Mr. Hart is a son of Lieutenant Commander Hart, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Hart of Williamsburg.

title: A CLASS STUDIES VIETNAM LEGACY
description: THE oldest students in David Rood's class on the Vietnam War were 6 years old when the Paris peace accords were signed in January 1973. Today, they are juniors and seniors at Ward Melville High School in East Setauket, their interest in the Vietnam War kindled by today's news.

title: IN DHAKA, TENTATIVE STEPS TOWARD DEMOCRACY
description: To some people, Lieut. Gen. H. M. Ershad's action in proclaiming himself President of this grindingly poor, overpopulated country is another bit of evidence that he intends to remain in power indefinitely. But a more benign construction can be placed on General Ershad's surprise move - that it is part of a serious game of give-and-take and consensus-building that could lead to democracy rather than perpetuation of another third world dictatorship. That outcome could bring a stability unknown to Bangladesh's 95 million people since they won independence from Pakistan in 1971.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: ALWAYS LIVE BETTER THAN YOUR CLIENTS

title: CHRISTMAS IN THE CAPITAL
description: The holiday season is a little more festive this year than last in most places in America, but along the Potomac, there is a difference.

title: GLENN CAMPAIGN STRUGGLES TO PUT IMAGE IN FOCUS
description: A moment earlier John Glenn had been speaking from atop a tree stump at a backyard Texas picnic, but now, as the line formed for hot dogs and chili sauce, he saw a woman pushing through the crowd toward him.

title: A CHANCE TO PUT SCHOOL BUILDINGS TO GOOD USE
description: DURING the past year, much publicity has appeared in New Jersey newspapers concerning the closing of schools and the selling of school real- estate because of declining enrollments.

title: ST. JOHN'S TROUNCES WAGNER BY 89-60
description: St. John's schedule has been so favorable in a time of numerous injuries that Coach Lou Carnesecca said last night, ''My athletic director should get a big raise for making up this schedule.''

title: DEBATE COACH WINS PRIZE
description: -winning debate team of Hendrik Hudson High School in Montrose, describes herself as ''just a parent'' who got involved with her children's activities. But in the four years she has coached the team it has reached the national finals of two major debating leagues. And this year, Mrs. Schecter was voted ''Coach of the Year'' by her peers, the coaches of other high school teams in the East.

title: THE REGION
description: With so many computers being illicitly broken into these days, it's reassuring to see that they can still catch a crook or two. New York City's Finance Commissioner, Philip R. Michael, said last week that during the past two and a half years 55,000 people and companies had anted up about $43 million after a computerized search discovered their failure to pay taxes.

title: ISLANDERS THRASH RANGERS, 7-1
description: The drama did not go out of the Rangers- Islanders confrontation until there were less than 10 minutes left in the third period. But when it left, it left in a hurry. The Islanders scored five goals in the last 9:25 tonight at the Nassau Colliseum to defeat the Rangers, 7-1.

title: YOUR DOLLARS IN THE SUN
description: Chaos in the economies of favorite winter vacation places will mean a bit of confusion for travelers this winter, but it can mean big bargains as well. In Mexico and in many Caribbean vacation spots, the dollar has never been worth more - and getting top value for it has never been more bewildering. In Europe, to the delight of tourists and the dismay of finance ministers, the dollar continues to show record or near-record might against the pound and the franc, giving Britain and France added attractions for visitors as well.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: THE MAKING OF THE NEW DEAL

title: Professional Secret
description: It has been an open secret that the Soviet Union's supposed amateur athletes are really full-time professionals, but now it has been acknowledged by one of the nation's top young hockey players. Vyacheslav Bykov , a 23-year-old center on the Soviet national team, made the admission in a Swedish courtroom Thursday during his trial on shoplifting charges.

title: A HOUSE THAT CHAMPAGNE BUILT
description: FRANK J. PRIAL is a correspondent in the Paris bureau of The Times.

title: Ridgefield Trains
description: To the Editor:

title: SELECTING THAT FIRST VCR --SOME QUESTIONS TO KEEP IN MIND
description: Every culture has its particular rituals, and in our age the purchase of your first video cassette recorder has become something of an initiation rite. And with good reason. These ingenious machines - called VCR's for short - launch you into the mainstream of an emergent medium, giving access to a vast and growing library of prerecorded tapes. They also make you independent of broadcast and cable television program scheduling, letting you create your own personalized prime time for whatever you want to watch.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: YONKERS CHRISTMAS is around the corner/So buy your tree and put it in the living room/Before you come/To your doom.

title: '71 PLAN FOR HOMES STIRS NEW CONCERN
description: BACK in 1971, when condominiums and population density were problems only for city people, a real-estate developer asked the Southold Town Board for approval to build what amounted to a small town in the open fields of Greenport.

title: Claudia Leslie and Dr. Louis B. Lipschutz to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Stanley D. Leslie of Fayetteville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Claudia Leslie, to Dr. Louis B. Lipschutz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Lipschutz of Penn Wynne, Pa. A September wedding is planned.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
AMERICAN LIFE FILTERED THROUGH TWO DISTINCT SENSIBILITIES
description: Robert Frank's ''The Americans'' is a tough act to follow. Its grainy, off-center black-and-white photographs set a new style in art photography and epitomized a generation's love-hate relationship with one of the world's greatest and most powerful nations. No photographer is ever likely to duplicate this achievement. But as time passes, America remains a fascinating subject to people all over the world, and other attempts are made to capture its character photographically. Two such efforts are currently on view in New York, one by Eve Arnold, the other by Tom Arndt.

title: Childbirth
description: To the Editor:

title: CONCERT: JULLIARD QUARTET
description: The Juilliard String Quartet brought along two friends to Carnegie Hall Wednesday evening for a program of chamber music by Mozart and Brahms. Thomas Riebl, a violist, joined forces with the four members of the Juilliard - violinists Robert Mann and Earl Carlyss, the violist Samuel Rhodes and the cellist Joel Krosnick - for a performance of Mozart's Quintet in C (K. 515).

title: GIRL, 4, WITH HERPES IN SCHOOL IN KANSAS AFTER BITTER DISPUTE
description: A 4-year-old girl with herpes has been admitted to a school for the handicapped after nearly a year of debate over whether other children could contract the disease from her.

title: U.S. PILOT PROGRAM IN SALVADORAN AREA IN DANGER OF FAILING
description: A six- month-old American-planned military and civic pilot program to bring peace to a key eastern province in El Salvador is in danger of failing, American officials said this week.

Routh Jr., son of Mr. Routh of Delray Beach, Fla., and Carol O'Neil of Greenwich, Conn., were married yesterday. Msgr. James P. Cassidy performed the ceremony at the chapel of the Convent of the Sacred Heart in New York.

title: U.S. FINDS RICH UNDERSEA DEPOSITS OF COBALT
description: Undersea deposits of cobalt at twice the concentrations found in the past have been discovered in the Pacific Ocean, the United States Geological Survey says.

title: CHICAGO MAYOR LOSES ON BUDGET TO COUNCIL FOES
description: On Friday the City Council did something it has never done before. It adopted a budget over the Mayor's objections.

title: Judge and Witness
description: Judge Jerome M. Becker of New York City Criminal Court was walking in lower Manhattan in August 1982 when he spied a robbery suspect fleeing from the police. The judge and his 14-year-old son gave chase and collared the suspect.

description: WHEN she became music director of Greenwich Academy's top choral group, the Madrigal Singers, last September, Deborah B. Eickstaedt knew she was taking over a choir with a wealth of talent. But she did not know it had a reputation that would reach the White House.

description: An American group that came here three weeks ago to investigate human rights conditions found a ''continuing pattern'' of abuse, much of it attributable to agents of President Ferdinand E. Marcos's Government, a member of the group says.

title: Linn Cary, an Executive, Is Married To Ved Mehta, Writer, at Cathedral
description: Linn F. C. Cary, an assistant program officer at the Ford Foundation, and Ved Mehta, the writer, were married yesterday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. The Very Rev. James Parks Morton, Dean of the Cathedral, performed the ceremony.

title: Attacks on Rwandans In Uganda Reported
description: As many as 200,000 people of Rwandan origin may have fled or been killed after being attacked in Uganda in the past two days, according to official reports reaching Rwanda today.

title: Bonnie Weins Is Wed to a Film Editor
description: The marriage of Bonnie Lynn Weins, an assistant account executive at Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York, to Gregory Edward Sheldon, a freelance film editor, took place yesterday at Grace Episcopal Church in Manhattan. The Rev. Ross Wright performed the ceremony.

title: STATE TRIES TO KEEP UP WITH NEEDS OF VOCATIONAL EDUCATION
description: WORD processing was not mentioned two years ago when the state was updating its master plan for vocational education, recalls Elizabeth Schmitt of the State Education Department. Miss Schmitt, who heads the department's bureau of vocational planning and development, said that the department did not even use the words ''high technology'' in 1981.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE ;
 SUFFOLK SKIES
description: There's a little bit of something for almost everyone in ''Skies Over Suffolk,'' the current show at the Vanderbilt Museum Planetarium. For in putting together a tribute to Suffolk's tercentenary, the planetarium's professionals are drawing upon the county's natural history and its past as a backdrop for exploring its astronomical present. The total picture is recreated in the Sky Theater, with its 60-foot diameter dome, with visual projections, an original sound track and special effects. ''Skies Over Suffolk'' is shown at 1, 2:30 and 4 P.M. Sundays; 8:30 P.M. Fridays and 2:30, 4 and 8:30 P.M. Saturdays at the planetarium, 180 Little Neck Road in Centerport. Admission is $2.50, or $2 for children and the elderly. MUSIC IN THE GALLERY

title: LABOR COSTS A KEY IN RAIL FARE RISE
description: A20 PERCENT fare increase is looming for Long Island Rail Road commuters in the new year, and one of the key reasons is high labor costs. How to cut labor costs is a nettlesome matter because of union contracts. The railroad has been seeking to deal with this situation by trying to increase the productivity of the work force.

title: JETS END A SEASON OF PROBLEMS
description: At 5 o'clock yesterday morning, Marty Lyons got off the plane from Miami, called his wife, Kelley, and told her he felt like crying.

title: QUANDARY IN BEIRUT
description: To the Editor:

title: Putting the Arm on Miss Liberty
description: The Statue of Liberty's right arm, the one that holds the torch, has been so shaky since the Black Tom munitions explosion of 1916 that ordinary visitors are not allowed to climb it. That's only one of many frailties that trouble the 97-year-old statue and the unused Ellis Island immigration station, which together constitute the Statue of Liberty National Monument.

title: Miss Steiner Captures Slalom Event in Italy
description: Roswitha Steiner of Austria won a World Cup women's slalom today, finishing 28-hundredths of a second ahead of Malgorzata Tlalka of Poland.

title: AMERICAN STEEL HELD HOSTAGE TO PROBLEMS OF FOREIGN NATIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. WOLF REGULATIONS FOR MINNESOTA CHALLENGED
description: Fifteen environmental organizations are seeking to set aside proposed Federal regulations that would allow hunters to trap 50 to 160 timber wolves each year in Minnesota, which, according to environmentalists and the Interior Department, has the only viable wolf population in the lower 48 states.

title: Tennessee Takes Citrus Bowl, 30-23
description: Johnnie Jones, the only Tennessee player to rush for more than 1,000 yards in a season, scored twice on short runs barely two minutes apart early in the fourth quarter tonight to give the Volunteers a 30-23 victory over Maryland in the Florida Citrus Bowl.

title: TOYS MAY CHANGE BUT NATURE OF GOOD AND EVIL DOESN'T
description: THE Incredible Hulk and his mother live in the woods. She buys him G.I. Joe, the Dukes of Hazzard, and all the He Men in the collection.

title: Subway Snackers Arrested
description: Efforts to keep the new subway system here sparkling have included a campaign against riders who eat on trains. Two riders, a 16-year-old boy accused of sucking on a lollipop, then throwing it at a Mass Transit Administration police officer, and a passenger eating potato chips, have been arrested so far, a spokesman said. Eating or smoking aboard a train is punishable by a fine of up to $250.

title: A NONSPORTS FAN
description: THE height of the 1983 Super Bowl frenzy, I got into a Washington cab and the driver, a small man with a raspy voice and a lobster-meat complexion, offered what he probably thought was the perfect conversation gambit: ''What do you think about those Redskins?''

title: PLAN APPROVED TO AID ATLANTIC CITY HOUSING
description: The Casino Control Commission and a task force of state and local officials approved a seven-year, $246 million plan this week to improve housing and conditions in the city's Inlet section.

title: ISLAND HOPPING IN THE LAGOON
description: HELEN GIAMBRUNI is an art historian who has recently completed a study of the early work of Pierre Bonnard. She has also written on the crafts.

title: PANEL CASTS VOTE TO PRESERVE PAST
description: Residents who want to preserve some of this old port city's history have won a victory in a fight against a proposed annex to the Federal Courthouse, but they were not quite ready to lay down their arms and end the battle.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER
description: Little can be more frustrating than trying to find the lowest possible air fare to suit one's taste. It is a bigger challenge than most individuals and even many travel agencies can successfully undertake, even with highly sophisticated computers. Even the experts produce different answers, and to become an expert requires a rare combination of skill at the computer plus intimate, up-to- the-minute information on which airlines go where, at which points they interconnect and whether they are actually operating the flights they promise.

title: Q/A Small Buildings Bill Question:
description: As the owner of a four-family brownstone, I am concerned over legislation that I understand seeks to recontrol three-, four- and five-family buildings. What can you tell me about this bill and the degree of support it has? . . . R. J. R., Brooklyn

title: STATE TO ENFORCE CODE FOR BUILDING
description: It will cost the state $1 million to enforce a new Uniform Fire Prevention and Building Code for 70 local governments that will not take action on their own, Secretary of State Gail S. Shaffer has said.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Sid Caesar, the comedian whose mastery of the TV comedy sketch earned him unanimous acclaim in the 1950's, says variety shows as he knew them have been killed by talk shows. Now, he explained in a recent telephone interview, ''it's a stand-up, sit-com world. Comedians, singers, whatever, wanted to have exposure, so they went on these talk shows. If you can get a comedian to stand up and do five, six minutes, and a singer to stand up and sing a couple of songs, you don't need any scenery, you don't need any props, you don't need anything. It's much cheaper, you get 'em for a buck. Everything is based, unfortunately, on the profit motive. Pretty soon all we're going to have is just the bottom line, nothing above it, nothing below it, just the bottom line.''

description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Tiffany of Pelham Manor, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Ellen Tiffany, to John Eric Cross, son of Clifford H. Cross of Rensselaer, N.Y., and the late Mrs. Cross. An April wedding is planned.

title: 78 KILLED AND 21 HURT IN A MADRID DISCOTH EQUE FIRE
description: Seventy-eight people died and at least 21 were injured and hospitalized early today when a fire spewed thick fumes in a popular basement discoth eque with hundreds of young people.

description: A tentative contract that could end a 17- day strike by public school teachers here was reached Friday night, teacher and school board representatives said.

description: The Burlington Northern Railroad has been ordered to pay nearly $12 million to a couple whose truck was hit by a freight train nine years ago.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN ROSYLN
description: -century essayist, poet and New York Post editor, was also one of Long Island's first commuters to Manhattan. A 1842 advertisement for the property in Roslyn he was to buy boasted ''public conveyances to and from the city,'' which meant travel by rail, stage and steamboat, depending on the season.

title: EllisVanRiperIsDead; Led T.W.U. Local 100
description: Ellis Van Riper, former president of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union, died at his home here today. He was 72 years old.

title: CHINA STILL ALLOWS SOME ALTERNATIVES TO ATHEISM
description: Last Sunday afternoon, as hundreds of Chinese Christians converged on Peking's Chongwenmen Protestant Church to hear the visiting Archbishop of Canterbury, a church elder intercepted a nervous young man coming up the steps. The young man, a Communist Youth League member, confided that he wanted to see the church service. He was promptly turned away and his identification card was examined by a police plainclothesman waiting in the alley. ''He can't come in if he is not a Christian,'' the elder told a bystander.

description: Women who have made great progress in their careers are, in disproportionate numbers, ignoring a concomitant area that is of equal importance. So says Julia Walsh, a woman who should know and who makes the statement with some regret.

description: A West German Army expert in low-altitude parachuting has died in a jump to demonstrate a developmental parachute at Fort Bragg, N.C., but his jumping partner, the commanding general of Fort Benning, still believes the triple-canopy parachute may be ''a real lifesaver'' in combat.

description: Emily Anne Grob, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David Grob of Roslyn, L.I., was married there yesterday to Dr. Mark Steven Hochberg, son of Dr. and Mrs. Sidney Hochberg of New York. Rabbi Joseph P. Sternstein performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Sholom.

title: KEAN SAYS STUDY PANEL SAVED STATE $102.5 MILLION
description: Business executives who studied the operations of state government helped New Jersey avoid spending $102.5 million in the current state budget, according to Governor Kean. A final report by the executives was presented to the Governor this week.

title: Accuser of U.S. Judge Sentenced in Tax Case
description: A former Nevada brothel owner who is the principal accuser of a Federal judge indicted on bribery charges was resentenced Thursday to 15 months in prison on four convictions of income tax fraud.

title: CHANDLER STOPS MUNIZ IN 7TH TO KEEP BANTAMWEIGHT TITLE
description: The case containing his World Boxing Association bantamweight championship belt was singed, but Jeff Chandler was fired up today as he avenged his only professional loss by stopping Oscar (The Boxer) Muniz in the seventh round.

description: In a snarling disquisition on euphemisms this past summer (

title: MASSACHUSETTS GIVES BIRTH CENTERS APPROVAL
description: Expectant mothers in Massachusetts will soon have an alternative to the alienating sterility of the hospital operating room. Nonhospital birth centers are on the way.

title: Schools Replace Moses With Words on Bible
description: The public schools here, ordered not to display the Ten Commandments in the classroom, have replaced them with quotations about the Bible made by American Presidents.

title: THE CITY HOUSING PROBLEM THAT'S SPREADING HERE
description: SINCE the late 1950's, the demographics of New York City have changed enormously. Through a process of integration, white flight and resegregation, great portions of the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens have changed from neighborhoods into what might be called disaster areas.

title: WHILE THE DEMOCRATS DASH, REPUBLICANS LOLL
description: Most analysts agree that the best way to run for President is to be President already. The reason is illustrated by comparing the campaign headquarters of any of the eight Democratic candidates to the stylish offices of Reagan-Bush '84.

BUSINESS FORUM;

title: PROGRAMS PROVIDE A SENSE OF HOPE ALONG WITH A HELPING HAND
description: Executive Director, Catholic Charities, Diocese of Brooklyn

title: COUNTY WEIGHS PROBLEMS IN TRANSFER OF BRINK'S TRIAL
description: WHITE PLAINS RESENTFUL yet resigned, county officials last week wrestled with problems of security and cost imposed on them by a court order transferrring the Brink's trial across the Hudson River from Orange County.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article on the Atlantic Electric Company last week, the number of customers was incorrect. It should have been 380,000.

title: NO PLACE LIKE HOME
description: DURING THE PAST DECADE, the classical column became a symbol of change for architects and interior designers - change away from the straight lines and austerity of the so- called modern movement. An oversize column placed as a decorative - rather than structural - element in an otherwise stark room signaled a new appreciation for the past, a reference to tradition and history. The problem was that such columns often looked self- conscious and almost cartoonlike. Not to mention flimsy, as though they could topple over and knock you out.

title: VERMONT CURTAILS ASSISTANT JUDGES
description: A decision by the Vermont Supreme Court has further reduced the powers of this state's assistant judges, who have dispensed justice for 200 years without any legal training. Two of the Supreme Court judges denounced the ruling, saying it would clog court dockets and cause trouble for years to come.

title: THE DECLINE OF COLLEGE STANDARDS
description: The student graffito from 1969 that Mr. Beichman cites - ''Make them teach you only what you want to learn'' - is not a political slogan but is rather of a kind with other demands for freedom from traditional restraints and obligations, demands that the generation of 1968 made by burning draft cards, by smoking marijuana, by promiscuity, by raucous, physical music, by indecorous dress and manner. The bitter fruits of excessive luxury, yes; Marxism, no.

title: Linking Three Articles
description: I was haunted by a common thread that linked three of the articles in the Nov. 13 issue of The New York Times Magazine: ''Reagan, Power and the World'' (by Leslie H. Gelb), ''John Glenn: The Hero as Candidate'' (by Howell Raines) and ''Death Row on Trial'' (by Robert Sherrill). The thread is the dominance of the white Anglo- Saxon Protestant ethic in determining United States domestic and foreign policy.

title:
ANTIQUES;
'83 WAS A GOOD YEAR FOR FINE ITEMS
description: ARAB sheiks and their agents have retreated from the American antiques markets; interest rates are lower, no longer juggled up and down; the stock market continues slowly upward and is making more, if not ''extra'' money for investors.

title: Miss Eisenbeis, A Radio Editor, Becomes Bride
description: Catherine Dore Eisenbeis, daughter of Ceil Pulitzer of St. Louis and the late George Culver Eisenbeis, was married yesterday to Matthew Day Hanson, son of Walter Sewell Hanson of Colorado Springs and Sally Day Hanson of Tumacacori, Ariz. The Rev. Timothy Horner offered the nuptial mass at the Basilica of St. Louis the King Roman Catholic Church in St. Louis.

title: THE WORLD
description: War and PressWhat remained of the American combat force in Grenada went home last week, leaving behind a few hundred technicians and military policemen.

title: THE NATION
description: New Fronts inPolitical WarOver HungerThe matter of Americans who might or might not have enough to eat continued to vex the Reagan Administration last week.

title: 2,500 Search Woods For Gunmen of I.R.A.
description: More than 2,500 Irish policemen and soldiers combed a wooded area today for Irish Republican Army gunmen who escaped after battles with security forces who rescued a kidnapped businessman.

title: VALOROUS FLIPPANCIES
description: THE COLLECTED STORIES OF NOEL COWARD

title: CELTICS DOWN PISTONS
description: Kevin McHale, a reserve, scored 30 points tonight and led Boston to a 129- 115 victory over Detroit.

title: Transfer Players Help Two Schools
description: In college hockey, Division I varsity players transfer from school to school infrequently. The few who do are usually marginal players and rarely have a dramatic impact on their new teams.

title: Helen A. Fox Engaged To Dana John O'Brien
description: Mr. and Mrs. Francis E. Fox of Manchester, N.H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Helen Ann Fox, to Dana John O'Brien, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward T. O'Brien of Garden City, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: THE DEMOCRATS AND FOREIGN POLICY
description: FOR ALMOST TWO DECADES, the Democratic Party has been tearing itself apart over foreign and defense policy, first over Vietnam and later over detente with the Soviet Union. Now, to listen to the Democrats tell it, their views are more compatible than at any time in the last two decades and they are offering more cohesive ''Democratic alternatives'' to President Reagan's policies. The candidates and their advisers think President Reagan's style of conservatism and his policy flip-flops have made the world a more dangerous place, that the bulk of the American public is worried and that the peace issue will be at the top of voter concerns, along with the economy, in the 1984 elections.

title: ART HISTORY OF OLD LYME IS STILL GROWING
description: THE purchase of the John Sill mansion in Old Lyme for the new home of the Lyme Academy of Fine Arts is the beginning of another chapter in the small coastal town's rich art history.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: ST. GEORGE AND DRAGON

title: SOME GIFT SUGGESTIONS FOR THE PHOTOGRAPHER
description: ''Tis the season to be merry - and to be wary.'' The annual extravaganza of gift buying is here, with consumers looking for bargains, while retailers attempt to boost sales (and sometimes prices) to carry them through the leaner months that will follow. Unfortunately, some dealers will try to capitalize on the unwary by advertising a popular item as a ''loss leader'' (less than the dealer's cost) and then will substantially boost all other prices to make up the deficit.

title: music ; FROM A 'MESSIAH' TO 'NUTCRACKER'
description: STAGINGS of Tchaikovsky's ''Nutcracker'' ballet dot the calendar right until the end of the year, while what seems to be this area's last complete 1983 performance of Handel's ''Messiah'' takes place this afternoon at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Fairfield. Since Thomas Crawford, music director at the church, is also music director of the Fairfield Chamber Orchestra, this fine professional ensemble will be joining the church's own St. Cecilia choir for the oratorio, starting at 5 o'clock.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ART

title: LINKING THREE ARTICLES
description: Leslie Gelb's article reflects the popular impression that the measure of success in foreign policy is the achievement of formal agreements or treaties.

title: 75 RECORDS DISPLAY FURTW"ANGLER'S CRAFT
description: Wilhelm Furtw"angler was obviously the sort of musician about whom legends insist upon growing. After his sudden death in 1954, only months before an eagerly awaited United States visit, Furtw"angler achieved the reputation of an erratic, Faustian icon of the podium. He was said to have had little technique, to have rewritten whole passages of any score that displeased him, and to have taken everything he conducted at the proverbial snail's pace. Yet his performances, more often than not, had such power, such an inexorable sense of sweep, that Furtw"angler was likened to a pure fool, divinely inspired. No less shrewd an esthetician than the painter Oskar Kokoschka once referred to Furtw"angler as ''an ambassador from another world.''

title: EDITORS' NOTES
description: The main article in The Times Magazine today, about the United States Women's Ski Team, mentions its senior member, Cindy Nelson. On Monday, after the magazine had gone to press, Miss Nelson injured her knee in a World Cup race. It is uncertain whether she will participate in the 1984 games, to be held in February in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia.

title: 2 Die as Flames Sweep Through Home on L.I.
description: Two people died and three firefighters were injured here in an early morning house fire on Crown Street, police and fire officials reported today.

title: MOSLEM WORLD IS UNSETTLED BY SURGE IN FUNDAMENTALISM
description: Almost five years after an Islamic revolution toppled the Shah of Iran, a resurgence of religious fundamentalism is unsettling the Moslem world from Africa through the Middle East and into Asia, according to scholars and government officials.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE tabling last week of an Assembly bill requiring deposits on cans and bottles has been denounced by James Lanard, lobbyist for the New Jersey Environmental Lobby, as ''a disgrace.''

title: DANCE: JOYCE TRISLER TROUPE IN WORKS BY MYERS
description: The Joyce Trisler Danscompany, at the Joyce Theater through today, is a celebration of sleek, alert bodies engaged in a flow of all-out dance. And if the program the company performed Wednesday was a little short on choreographic interest, it served admirably as a showcase for these beautifully trained and rehearsed young dancers.

title: A MORE RELAXED ATMOSPHERE
description: established restaurant in Bridgehampton, became Reatherford's Plum. That was not the only change. As Ron Reatherford, who bought the restaurant three years ago, explained it, he and his partner, Gail Rose, wanted to appeal to a year-round audience, not just a vacation crowd.

title: APPLYING LESSONS FIREFIGHTERS LEARN
description: ON the day of the explosion at the Grucci fireworks complex in Bellport, 43-year-old Tom Brennan of West Sayville - captain in the New York Fire Department, deputy chief instructor at the Suffolk County Fire School in Yaphank and newly appointed editor of the 107-year-old magazine Fire Engineering - spent his day surveying the devastation.

title: INSIDE STUFF ABOUT BOWS, VALVES, KEYS AND FROGS
description: Writing about music can seem a peculiar and sterile exercise, rather like dissecting a bird to find out why it sings. But that has never slowed down any really dedicated writer on music. It is a breed not easily discouraged by reality. In fact, when you consider that music is widely conceded to be next to impossible to write about to anyone's satisfaction, the diligence of musical authors is worth clinical study. Perhaps if it were easy, no one would think it worth bothering to do. As it is, everyone wants to take a shot at it.

title: CORRECTING THE PAST

title: NEW YORK CITY TO GET $2.5 MILLION REFUND IN UPSTATE TAX CASE
description: After 17 years of litigation, New York City will be repaid nearly $2.5 million in excessive property taxes on a city- owned pumping station on the Hudson River in Dutchess County, Mayor Koch's office has announced.

title: AS APPEALS HIT FINAL STAGE, LIFE ON DEATH ROW RUNS OUT
description: When months or years passed between executions, the death penalty, despite the heated political and philosophic debate surrounding it, remained something remote and abstract. But last week two executions in a 30-hour period, plus a last-minute stay in a third case, made capital punishment quite real. The electrocutions of Robert Wayne Williams in Louisiana and John Eldon Smith in Georgia followed by just two weeks Florida's execution of Robert A. Sullivan. They brought the number of executions this year to five, more than in any year since 1965, when seven convicted murderers were put to death.

title: WHITE HOUSE GETS MORE CHINAWARE AS A GIFT
description: The White House has accepted a gift of 215 place settings of gold-rimmed china, worth at least $23,650, for use in an aides' dining room, on Air Force One and at Camp David.

title: THE REGION
description: Alvarado WantsA Lot More forThe SchoolsHaving had more than seven months to learn the ropes at the Board of Education, Schools Chancellor Anthony J. Alvarado tested his pull at City Hall last week. He asked that $440 million be added to the school system's $3.5 billion operating budget.

Derby, a neurologist, told a New York State investigating committee that CAT (computerized axial tomography) scans of boxers' heads should be mandatory before they were allowed to fight. No action was taken.

description: Theodore James Jr. has written many books on gardening.

description: The following article was written by Gerard C. Smith, who headed the United States' delegation in the first strategic arms limitation talks, which resulted in the SALT I agreements; Paul C. Warnke, who headed the SALT II delegation; and John B. Rhinelander, legal adviser to the SALT I delegation. All are members of the Arms Control Association's board of directors.

description: Veterans and the handicapped should have no more than a limited advantage in applying for state and local government jobs, the Montana Legislature decided today after six days of debate.

description: Andrea Beth Chachkes, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jacob Trister Chachkes of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday to Thatcher Alden Stone, son of Mrs. Phillip M. Stone of Arlington, Va., and the late Mr. Stone. Rabbi Steven Rossman performed the ceremony at Waveny House.

title: GROCER TO THE QUEEN - AND DICKENS, TOO
description: Charles Dickens didn't mention it, but if Scrooge really was converted by the Spirit of Christmas, and the fear of judgment prised wide his purse, then surely the basket of goodies and foodstuffs he purchased for the Cratchit family and Tiny Tim came from Fortnum & Mason.

description: Pope John Paul II urged the Guatemalan Government today to restore democratic institutions, which he said would be a sure sign of lasting peace in the troubled Central American country.

description: LAKE HOPATCONG in Morris County is big, beautiful, busy - and in trouble. Large blooms of algae on the surface and intensive growth of weeds along the bottom have become commonplace in recent years, and the Mayors of the four small communities around the lake fear that water quality will continue to diminish unless corrective action starts soon.

description: Associate Justice William Hubbs Rehnquist of the United States Supreme Court and Mrs. Rehnquist, who live in Arlington, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Janet Rehnquist, to Joseph Emmet Lynch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Edward Lynch of Auburn, N.Y. A March 24 wedding is planned.

title: IN ORIGINAL CAST ALBUMS, THE SHOW'S NOT ALWAYS THE THING
description: Because they serve up the musical meat without the trimmings of book and production, original cast albums of Broadway shows enjoy separate artistic lives from the extravaganzas they memorialize. The cast album of Stephen Sondheim's ''Merrily We Roll Along,'' for instance, reclaimed a great score from a misguided production. ''The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas,'' on the other hand, was a better show than the album might suggest, since Carol Hall's score was the weakest element in a production that boasted inventive choreography by Tommy Tune and a sturdy book by Larry L. King.

description: ''IM WALLY MICHAEL. My guest tonight on 'Stopwatch' is Saint Nicholas, one of the most famous, yet least- known, figures in our culture, a man who is more popularly known by the alias Santa Claus.

title: REAGAN'S NEW BUDGET TO REFLECT CAUTION
description: Three years in a row, President Reagan's budgets have been wrapped like gift packages, each in a fresh concept to strike the fancy of Congress and the public. The ''new beginning'' in 1981, emphasizing tax cuts, led to the ''new federalism'' in 1982, an elaborate scheme to transfer programs and tax resources to the states. In the budget proposed for fiscal year 1984, sent to Congress in February, a vast freeze on Federal spending was proposed.

title: 2 Men Killed in Crash Of Airplane in Jersey
description: A pilot and his passenger were killed today when their single-engine plane lost power and crashed in a heavily wooded area near this Hunterdon County community, officials said.

title: CAMBODIA'S REBELS GROW CONFIDENT
description: Sometimes it is easy to walk into Cambodia to visit an encampment of guerrillas loyal to Pol Pot, the Prime Minister who was deposed by Vietnamese troops five years ago.

title: TO KEEP IT A FESTIVE SEASON, TAKE SOME SAFETY PRECAUTIONS
description: HOLIDAY lighting and decorations will add greatly to the festive atmosphere in many homes during the next couple of weeks, but this is also a period when carelessness can lead to an unusual number of accidents and injuries.

title: MERGER OF 2 'Y'S' SET FOR THE SPRING
description: Y.W.H.A. of Metropolitan New Jersey and the Y.M.- Y.W.H.A. of Morris/Sussex will go into effect next spring with the establishment of a new central agency called the United Jewish Center of Metro-West.

title: NEW BULKY FURS
description: New, bulky furs designed by the Fendis of Rome are drawing second looks on New York City's main shopping streets these days. Attracting attention is the use of a long-hair and a short-hair fur in one coat, or the combination of flat python skin with long-haired lamb.

title: 1,665-PAGE COUNTY HISTORY FOR 'DIPPERS' AND SCHOLARS
description: AS Westchester concludes its Tricentennial celebration, it is instructive to remember that in America local history came before national history. In 1781 the French legation at Philadelphia asked Thomas Jefferson to explain his country. His response was ''Notes on the State of Virginia,'' not notes on the United States of America. If, with the growth of the Republic, national history is now the norm, interest in local history remains strong.

title: BAD WATER UPSETS PATTERN OF LIVING
description: DURING the last three months, everyday routines such as bathing and cooking have changed dramatically at 15 Shore Drive in Mastic Beach, where Anne Mutschler lives with her 16-month-old daughter, Jessica.

title: HOSPICES: NEW RULES QUESTIONED
description: -year-old Frank Walczak worked his vegetable garden through his grandson's hands. From the porch where he lay paralyzed from cancer, Mr. Walczak directed the planting and the tilling of his final crop.

title: IT SEEMS TIME TO CELEBRATE CINEMATIC TOGETHERNESS
description: We are approaching that time of year when all groups of two or more persons take it upon themselves to certify their opinions by voting awards of one sort and another. It's a year-end ritual, as much a part of the season as holiday depression, overdrawn bank accounts and plastic Christmas trees. It's something in which some of us participate with a certain amount of feigned diffidence, as if it weren't seemly to express such preferences so blatantly. This year, however, the diffidence may not be all that feigned, at least in connection with one category of movie awards.

title: CONSERVATIONISTS HOPE THIS WON'T BE THE SPECIES THAT GOT AWAY
description: To sportsmen, the striped bass is a creature that commands respect. To commercial fisherman, it is a valuable commodity. To diners, it is a delight.

title: CHINA PARTY HEAD APPEARS CENSORED
description: The selective omission of a key remark by Hu Yaobang in China's official press this week has created a cloud of confusion around the Chinese Communist Party leader.

title: ORGANIZATION AIDS BROOKLYN GROUPS
description: A group in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn needed to train ambulance drivers. A Canarsie organization wanted to teach Soviet emigres English. A third group, in the Sunset Park section, wanted to clean up its neighborhood to attract new residents.

title: STUDENTS SUCCEED IN RADIO PROJECT
description: DOBBS FERRY WHEN Tom Brandt was a student at Mercy College, he decided the school should have a radio station of its own. So he began one.

description: The Justice Department is suing the Cleveland Fire Department for what the Government says is discriminating against women in the hiring of firefighters.

description: OVER the centuries, Christmas has inspired countless musical responses from composers throughout the Western World.

title: ARABESQUES IN A RETROSPECTIVE
description: RETROSPECTIVE exhibitions definitely have a place in college gallery programming. Scrutiny of an individual artist's decisions and growth can be of substantial educational value, especially when the work reinforces creative experimentation, encourages confidence and demonstrates why and how new ideas are executed.

title: FOOD STAMPS TIED TO SEEKING WORK
description: Most county governments in New Jersey are requiring certain able-bodied residents to seek work in order to continue receiving food-stamp benefits, according to state officials.

title: ABOUT PORT AUTHORITY INSPECTIONS
description: THE fatal accident in the Journal Square PATH station in Jersey City last Aug. 8, when a portion of the ceiling collapsed, killed two people and injured 12 others. Had it happened at the height of the morning rush hour - only an hour earlier - the consequences are almost unimaginable.

title: THE LOW ROAD ISN'T THE ONLY PATH TO SUCCESS
description: Looking at NBC's schedule these days purely from the point of view of content, even the most sympathetic observer is likely to conclude that the network's programming department has been afflicted with a peculiar strain of entertainment schizophrenia. While taking the high road and winning deserved applause for series such as ''Hill Street Blues'' and ''Cheers,'' the network has also taken the low road this season and stumbled badly on dreadful concoctions like ''Manimal'' and ''Mr. Smith,'' starring an orangutan in what the producers desperately hoped would be a ''contemporary fable.'' Unfortunately, ''Mr. Smith'' is merely dumb. One week the Monday TV movie is a ridiculous piece of racist ''yellow peril'' trash entitled ''Girls of the White Orchid.'' The next, in ''Choices of the Heart,'' it's a moving and important account of the four churchwomen who were murdered three years ago in El Salvador.

title: 100 PALESTINIANS START EVACUATION OF TRIPOLI BY SHIP
description: Nearly 100 wounded Palestinian guerrillas and civilians loyal to Yasir Arafat were evacuated from this city today aboard an Italian ship chartered by the International Committee of the Red Cross.

title: Miss Fleischmann to Wed in February

description: The ''Vacation Costs'' item accompanying an article on skiing at Vail, Colo. (Travel, Nov. 27), included an incorrect air fare supplied by United Airlines. A spokesman for the carrier says its round-trip super saver fare for New York-Denver is $336 on any day.

title: Nerve Gas Story
description: Work on a deadly liquefied nerve gas called VX was halted at the Umatilla Army Depot in Hermiston, Ore., on March 31 after a technician had accidentally smashed a glass vial of it containing three-tenths of a gram. No one was injured, the Army said, because workers in the sealed mobile laboratory were wearing gas masks and rubber outfits.

title: MINNEAPOLIS ASKED TO ATTACK PORNOGRAPHY AS RIGHTS ISSUE
description: The Minneapolis City Council is considering an amendment to the city's civil rights ordinance that would define pornography as a form of discrimination against women.

title: 'WHO ARE THESE SMILING KILLERES?'
description: THE outbreak of terrorism worrying American leaders is likely to worsen because the world has entered a period of fundamentalism that spawns acts of fanaticism, according to researchers into violence and its causes. These students of terrorism agree that it is virtually impossible to prevent killings by fanatics who are themselves willing to die.

title: OBSTACLES BLOCK GIFT OF CROP SURPLUS TO NEEDY

title: AZTEC ART EXHIBIT AT NATIONAL GALLERY
description: Shortly after the Spanish conquest of Mexico in 1521, the art of the ancient civilization of the Aztecs was systematically destroyed or packed off to Europe. The National Gallery of Art has now gathered pieces of what remains of the art of Aztec culture and mounted an exhibition that has become, surprisingly, one of the most popular in this city of ambitious art showings.

title: 2 Youths in Theft Case Held at Parents' Behest

title: AMID CLAMOR, CAROLERS CHEER SUBWAY RIDERS
description: There was a long wait, as usual, for the RR train. Once aboard, the clarinetist, who was providing inspired accompaniment for ''Angels We Have Heard on High,'' almost lost his footing. To be heard above the subway rumbling, it was necessary to sing with more than the usual amount of holiday spirit.

title: CUOMO, IN QUEBEC, DISCUSSES BUYING MORE CANADA POWER
description: Governor Cuomo met here with Premier Rene Levesque for two hours Friday before announcing that the two men had reached ''a mutual assertion of desire'' to have Quebec sell New York an additional 2,000 megawatts of hydroelectric power.

Gelb50The Democrats and Foreign Policy James M. Markham52Reviving the German Question Divided Germany seems likely to outlast Bismarck's Reich, but the dream of unification still haunts both East and West.
