Photograph by Bruce Benedict.

title: Doctor as 'Captain': Another View
description: The letters to the editor (Nov. 20) by the nurses in regard to Dr. Joseph De Junco (''For a Young Cardiologist, an Essential Rx Is Compassion'') strike me as self-serving.

title: WHAT'S HOLDING BACK AIRBAGS
description: Peter Passell writes about economics and regulation for The New York Times's editorial page.

title: REDSKINS CLINCH DIVISION BY BEATING GIANTS, 31-22
description: The bottom line is that the Giants lost today. The Washington Redskins beat them, 31-22, and clinched the Eastern Division title in the National Football League's National Conference.

title: Trillo Going to Giants
description: Another free agent, Manny Trillo, the second baseman, said he had turned down an offer that would have kept him with the Montreal Expos and planned to sign a three-year contract with the Giants Tuesday. ''As far as I know, everything is settled,'' said the 33-year-old Trillo, whose plans were verified by Giant officials.

title: PROGRAMS PROVIDE SENSE OF HOPE ALONG WITH A HELPING HAND
description: General Director, Community Service Society of New York

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
description: NLIKE WINE makers, wine drinkers never have a bad year. Was the Sonoma vintage a disaster? Drink Napa. Did frost kill everything that grows in St. Emilion? Drink Pomerol. Old-timers still talk about the terrible vintages of 1963 and 1965 in Bordeaux, but certainly no one will ever claim to have been thirsty because of them. There is never a shortage of wine.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS MASS MARKET Mass market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States. 1
description: CHRISTINE, by Stephen King. (NAL/Signet, $3.95.) A car that kills is at large among a Pennyslvania town's high school set: fiction.

title: 2 WAYS TO PUSH CLAY TO ITS LIMITS
description: TWO different attitudes toward pushing clay to its limits are exemplified in hand-built sculptures by Marion E. Held and painted stoneware plates by John Santerineross.

title: THE WORLD
description: Washington seems more impatient by the day with the obstacles El Salvador is putting in the way of democratic reform. Last week Vice President Bush presented one of the most drastic demands yet - three years of exile for right-wing terrorist suspects that the United States Government, and presumably the Salvadoran Government, know about. Mr. Bush handed Provisional President Alvaro Magana a letter from President Reagan stressing the importance of ridding the country of the death squads, which are blamed for thousands of civilian killings and the alienation of much of the population.

title: THE DECLINE OF COLLEGE STANDARDS
description: Arnold Beichman may be correct that left-wing analysis has become the canon in many American university social-science departments; what he doesn't realize is that very little of that analysis sticks with students once they leave college. What does stick, though, is the experience of having been around people who are contrary, utopian, unrealistic and eloquent and it doesn't matter if they are that way from the right or the left. DAVID BROWN Philadelphia

title: Teacher Shot in Classroom
description: Sharon Mundt, a substitute teacher at Boylan Central Catholic High School, was shot in the neck Friday at the front of her classroom with a .357-caliber handgun, the authorities said. Michael Graham, a 15-year-old student whom she had disciplined, was charged with attempted murder and aggravated battery. Classmates said that he had talked of shooting her for a week but that they thought he had been joking.

title: HEADLINERS
description: Paddle Power Verlen Kruger and Steven G. Landick completed a 43- month canoe trip from Lansing, Mich., to Lansing, Mich., last week. They took the long way - across the Great Lakes, down the East Coast, across the Gulf Coast, up the Mississippi River and into Yukon Territory, down the West Coast from Alaska to Baja California and back up the Colorado River through the Grand Canyon. Mr. Kruger, 61 years old, and Mr. Landick, 30, called it the ''ultimate canoe challenge'' and they were probably right; it seems nobody else has traveled more than a third of their 28,000 miles by light boat and paddle.

title: Boys and Girls Can Compete
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: UNEQUAL PARTNERS
description: THE ALLIANCE

title: PROGRAM SEEKS INCREASE IN EXPORTS
description: MORE than 20 companies from around Connecticut hope to be celebrating the Christmas season with orders from foreign customers, thanks to a program at Quinnipiac College in Hamden that was designed to increase exports.

title: A VICTORY CAN REDEEM SAINTS
description: NEW ORLEANS ''WHO dat say dey gonna beat dem Saints?'' You can't wander too far around this part of the country without that question being put to you in some form or another.

title: CHRISTIANS, JEWS AND JESUS
description: THE SACRED EXECUTIONER

title: Josephine Howell To Wed in Spring
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. R. Robert Charles Howell of Denver and Beaminster, Dorset, England, of the engagement of their daughter, Josephine Thalia Howell, to John Joseph Kmetz, son of Mrs. John J. Kmetz of Islip, L.I., and the late Mr. Kmetz. A May wedding is planned.

title: WHEN HALCYON DAYS GRACE WINTER'S BIRTH
description: SOMETHING special happens around the winter solstice, which falls on Thursday this year, and it's a gift to all who heed its presence. Everyone has heard of the ''halcyon days,'' but most associate them with a bygone time of peace - a carefree season. However, the real halycon days occur a week or two before the shortest day of the year, and sometimes even after it.

title: BREAKING UP WITH JAKE
description: PITCH DARK, By Renata Adler. 144 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $12.95.

title: EVER ONWARD
description: WORSTWARD HO

title: William G. Chase, 43; Tested Memory as Skill
description: Prof. William G. Chase, a Carnegie-Mellon University psychologist who gained national recognition for his experiments demonstrating that good memory is an acquired skill, died Friday while jogging. He was 43 years old.

title: A NEW TWIST IN PENSION PLANNING
description: MOST workers begin to receive their pensions immediately after retiring, and those who want benefit payments to continue after their deaths usually designate their surviving spouses as beneficiaries. But some employees - typically wealthy executives of closely held companies who don't need the cash - defer receiving their pensions and name very young heirs as beneficiaries to save taxes.

title: CHICAGO INQUIRY SHOWS THE COURTS' HIDDEN SIDE
description: The stack of grand jury documents is nearly two inches tall. It is full of dates and names, whereases and such dry phrases as ''in violation of Title 18, United States Code, Section 1341.''

title: Woman Jailed in Alien Case
description: A businesswoman's two-year prison sentence and $10,000 fine for conspiring to transport illegal aliens mark the first time an employer has been jailed for hiring undocumented workers, the Federal prosecutor in the case said. Helen Mahard, 52, was sentenced Friday after Government agents found illegal aliens at her rural egg farm who had worked 66-hour weeks for weekly take-home pay of about $84.

title: KNICKS DEFEAT BUCKS
description: After struggling for three quarters, Ray Williams found his outside shot in the final period last night, scored 14 of his 23 points and led the Knicks to a 102-96 victory over the Milwaukee Bucks at Madison Square Garden.

title: INSPECTORS CHECK TOYS FOR SAFETY
description: WHILE shoppers are busy trying to buy toys for Christmas that will make children happy, three state inspectors are checking toys on store shelves to make sure the items are safe.

title: EX-NAVY AIDE'S FORMER EMPLOYER WAS AWARDED NO-BID CONTRACTS
description: George A. Sawyer, when he was Assistant Secretary of the Navy for shipbuilding and logistics, approved large noncompetitive contracts for the companies that employed him immediately before and after his Government service, according to public records.

title: FOR SUPREME COURT'S CALENDAR, A RHODE ISLAND NATIVITY SCENE
description: Downtown, across the street from the Peerless Company department store, the plaster figures of Joseph, Mary, the baby Jesus, some sheep, a camel, the Four Kings and a trumpeting angel stand in a stable scene on a piece of parkland near the Seekonk River.

title: Alice Scovell to Marry Stuart Coleman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Melvin E. Scovell of Newton, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alice Hannah Scovell, to Stuart Hayden Coleman, son of Donald H. Coleman and Melissa Hayden, the ballerina, of Winston-Salem, N.C.

title: POETS GROUP HAS TIES TO STATE
description: U. S. 1, that historic highway that stretches from Maine to Florida and runs through New Jersey like the track of a wayward snake, is also a name that befits a group of central New Jersey poets.

title: PEACE GROUP IN SCHOOL DRIVE
description: PISCATAWAY WHEN Lenore Duensing carried her peace message to juniors at Monroe Township High School recently, it was only one of many such presentations given by the organization she formed three years ago: the Visions of Peace project.

title: THE NAME IS CARRI ERE, AND THESE DAYS, IT IS EVERYWHERE
description: If the name Jean-Claude Carri ere

title: 51 HURT AS CAR JUMPS THE CURB ON 5TH AVENUE
description: A car sideswiped by another mounted a crowded Fifth Avenue sidewalk in midtown yesterday and plowed 75 feet through throngs of holiday shoppers, the police said. No one was killed, but at least 51 people were injured, three of them seriously.

title: HEARINGS RECALL INDIAN POINT
description: WHAT if bus drivers make the evacuation of a nuclear plant impossible by refusing to drive their vehicles toward the plant while an accident is in progress? What if the police leave their posts to make sure their own families are safe? What if panicked automobile drivers cause accidents and traffic on the antiquated road system grinds to a halt? Why must a county government accept an unpopular reactor that it never asked to have built?

title: Courtly Lessons
description: In addition to practicing fast breaks and defensive tactics, basketball players at Marshall University in West Virginia are being taught special skills that should give them an edge over other college players, but not on the basketball court. In a self- improvement program started by Coach Rick Huckabay , the players are learning such social skills as how to tie a tie, how to select a wardrobe, how to use a dinner knife and how to speak to reporters.

title: JOSEPH CAMPBELL: 70 YEARS OF MAKING CONNECTIONS
description: For almost 50 years Joseph Campbell has been writing major studies of mythology. His ''Hero With a Thousand Faces'' and four-volume ''Creative Mythology'' are classics in the field, and the long list of his publications includes not only many other volumes on myths but poetry and editions of other scholars' works. He was interviewed by D. J. R. Bruckner, an editor of The New York Times Book Review.

title: SPLENDOR ON A LARGE SCALE
description: Harrods is to British retailing what Bloomingdale's, Lord & Taylor, Hammacher Schlemmer and Zabar's would be to New York if they were all under one roof.

title: Vikings Defeat Bengals
description: Tony Galbreath dived for a pair of fourth-quarter touchdowns, both on fourth-down-and-inches, as the Minnesota Vikings rallied to beat the Cincinnati Bengals, 20-14, in their National Football League season finale.

title: FIRE IN DUTCH SEX CLUB KILLS 13
description: A fire at a sex and gambling club here killed 13 people and injured 25 overnight, the police said today. They said a former club employee had been charged with setting the blaze.

title: 'ROADSIDE,' THEATRICAL CARTOON, REVIVED
description: ''ROADSIDE,'' currently being presented by the Nassau Repertory Theater, is a revival of a 54- year-old play by Lynn Riggs, the man best known for his play ''Green Grow the Lilacs.'' That's the play that was made into the musical ''Oklahoma!''

title: REBELS AND THEIR CAUSES
description: THE PERCYS OF MISSISSIPPI

title: DISJOINTED COMMAND STRUCTURE'S CHIEF PROBLEM
description: To the Editor:

title: SCHOOL DRILL HELD NEAR INDIAN POINT
description: Westchester County officials this week tested an emergency plan for evacuating schools in the event of an accident at the Indian Point nuclear power plants.

title: For Pocantico Hills, A Luxury Project
description: A 151-ACRE tract in the hamlet of Pocantico Hills that is largely occupied by the Rockefeller estate is the site of a proposed $60 million development of luxury single-family homes, town houses, and water-front villas to be known as Pocantico Lakes.

title: CHRISTMAS PAST IS STILL PRESENT
description: IT is undoubtedly in the spirit of

title: CULTURAL CHANNELS JOIN FORCES
description: ARTS, the cable television cultural network, and the Entertainment Channel, a cable network that folded last March, are going to merge, the owners of the two services announced last week. The new service, called the Arts and Entertainment Network, will be available in more than 9 million homes across the country starting Feb. 1.

title: FUND PROPOSED BY REAGAN FACES CHALLENGE
description: Former Senator Eugene J. McCarthy of Minnesota and former Representative John B. Anderson of Illinois, both onetime Presidential candidates, have claimed $18 million that Congress appropriated for a National Endowment for Democracy.

title: NASSAU POLICE EXAM: TEST FOR U.S., TOO
description: IT will probably be six months before some 20,000 Nassau County

title: IN THE LAND OF BATAKS
description: WILLIAM FINNEGAN, a writer who lives in San Francisco, is working on a book about South Africa to be published by Harper and Row.

title: WEST SIE CONVERSION
description: For more than 50 years the bay-windowed row houses at 237 and 239 West 108th Street served as a Roman Catholic religious residence, first for a group of Jesuits and then for members of the Assumptionist order. Earlier this year, the residence, originally among seven row houses designed by Thomas Graham in 1899, was sold to L.A. & S., a development company, for conversion into a 24-unit cooperative to be called the Cloisters.

title: 'Silence'
description: To the Editor:

title: MONDALE IS AHEAD IN CAMPAIGN FUNDS
description: Two months before the first 1984 Presidential primaries and caucuses, former Vice President Walter F. Mondale has raised more money in New York than Jimmy Carter amassed in the state over the entire campaign in 1980, aides say.

title: DEMOCRATS RUN INTO A PROBLEM ON REDISTRICTING
description: -passing frenzy here is gathering momentum as the Jan. 10 deadline for action by the 200th State Legislature draws near.

title: GRUCCIS SEEKING NEW SITE
description: THE Grucci family has enlisted the aid of Brookhaven Town officials in re-establishing a Grucci fireworks factory within town borders, but at a new and suitably remote location.

title: BRIDGEPORT BOON
description: Until it closed last year, the Pix Drive-in Theater operated on 10 acres of land on River Road near Route 25 in Bridgeport, Conn. Last month, Glenport Main Corporation paid $600,000 for the site to develop a $5 million industrial park.

title: Mitchell Livingston WerBell; Anti-Communist Arms Dealer
description: Mitchell Livingston WerBell 3d, soldier of fortune, former international arms dealer and former operator of a counterterrorist training school near Atlanta, died Friday. He was 65 years old.

title: Space Station in the Ballot Box
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has long lobbied for a manned space station. Come election year, it may get its $20 billion wish.

title: A CERTAIN AGE
description: THERE are no more toys under the couch. I no longer have to watch Captain Kangaroo or go to Scout picnics. It's been a long time since I ran alongside a two-wheel bike supporting the back seat because the training wheels had just come off. It's been even longer since I held a little one by the hand and showed him how to move his head from side to side before he put one foot into that street.

title: Insights Into Infancy: A Reply
description: My staff and I feel our program and goals have been unfairly represented in Ann Crittenden's article ''New Insights into Infancy'' (Nov. 13). We are offering service to a population that has been ignored - the healthy infant and parent who have well- baby physical checkups but do not have the corresponding emotional care.

title: Hellon L. Swoopes and Kenneth R. Moore Marry
description: Hellon Lenora Swoopes, daughter of Harriet Atkinson Swoopes of New York and Paris Baker Swoopes of Roosevelt, L.I., was married yesterday to Kenneth Robert Moore, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Moore of Dallas. The Rev. Elliot Ellison performed the ceremony at the Grace Lutheran Church of Uniondale, L.I.

title: STATE ACKNOWLEDGES WORKERS ILLEGALLY CUT TREES IN PRESERVE
description: The State Department of Environmental Conservation said today that some of its employees had illegally cut down more than 100 trees - including some 100-to-200- year-old hemlocks - at the state- owned Belleayre Mountain ski center in the Catskill Forest Preserve.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: DANCE

title: The Decline of College Standards
description: Having reviewed thousands of garbled postgraduate applications as a director of the Fulbright Scholarship program, I can confirm the decay in fundamental university standards of literacy and cultural education (''Is Higher Education in the Dark Ages?'' by Arnold Beichman, Nov. 6). Symptomatic is the common failure to require European history, with the immense vacuum this leaves in understanding ourselves and the world.

title: HEADLINERS
description: Headliners Free for the HolidayNo gun, fingerprints, clothing or other physical evidence connected Lenell Geter to the 1982 robbery of a Texas fast- food restaurant, and nine of his colleagues said Mr. Geter was at work 50 miles from the scene when the crime took place. But after five witnesses picked the 26-year-old engineer out of a line-up, he was convicted of armed robbery.

title: U.S. BIDS TO SEND SINDONA TO ITALY
description: The Justice Department is seeking court approval to extradite Michele Sindona, the imprisoned Italian financier, to Italy so that he can be prosecuted there on charges of conspiring in a Milan murder.

title: LEADING WAY IN ARTIFICIAL JOINTS
description: IN the 1960's, elbow and hip joints

title: MAYORS UNDERTAKE EFFORT TO CHANGE STATE-AID FORMULAS
description: MOUNT VERNON MAYORS and other representatives of Westchester's cities met here last week to enlist taxpayer support for a major change in state aid to localities. Their effort could be part of the most radical change in Albany's financing formulas since their origin in 1946.

title: New Orleans Restaurateur, Germaine C. Wells, Is Dead
description: Germaine Cazanave Wells, who for three decades operated Arnaud's, a landmark restaurant in the city's French Quarter, died late Wednesday night after a brief illness, family members said. They would not disclose her age.

title: SYRACUSE BEATEN BY MARQUETTE, 79-68
description: Kerry Trotter scored 21 points, including two key baskets in the final two minutes, to help Marquette post a 79-68 victory over Syracuse today.

title: U.S. GIVES DETAILS OF MISSILE PACT WITH BONN
description: The Defense Department today made public the text of an agreement with West Germany under which Bonn will acquire Patriot antiaircraft missiles with conventional warheads to replace Nike Hercules nuclear missiles in service there now.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: FICTION 117 PET SEMATARY, by Stephen King. (Doubleday, $15.95.) The new family in town discovers the horrors that lie in a neighboring cemetery. 2216 POLAND, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) Seven centuries of history in fictional form. 3416 WHO KILLED THE ROBINS FAMILY?, created by Bill Adler and written by Thomas Chastain. (Morrow, $9.95.) The publisher offers a $10,000 prize to the reader who submits the best answer. 4326

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective. Corrections, also on this page, continue to deal with factual errors.

title: Correction
description: In a review of animal books (Dec. 11), the name of the publisher of Grzimek's Animal Life Encyclopedia was incorrect. The publisher is Van Nostrand Reinhold.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN VERMONT
description: DAN GILLMOR is a writer who lives in Montpelier, Vt.

title: THE NEW SIDEWALKS OF NEW YORK
description: FOR the observant pedestrian, sidewalks as well as the rest of the ever-

title: REACHING FOR THE TOP
description: Herbert Burkholz is currently finishing his sixth novel.

title: JEANETTE DUNN BETROTHED
description: The engagement of Jeannette Sheila Dunn to Paul Francis Kendall has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Paul Richard Dunn of Ramsey, N.J., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Albert Kendall of Kensington, Md. A June wedding is planned.

title: ATLANTIC CITY'S POOR WAIT TO BE DEALT IN
description: After a six- year spin of the roulette wheels, a commissioner of the state agency that oversees casino gambling said last week, this old resort has become ''a city where nine Taj Mahals flourish in the midst of a war zone.''

title: BREAKING RECORDS AT 81
description: Athoughtful and generous gesture paid a big dividend earlier this month. For the prestigious Reisinger Board-a-Match Team Championship in Miami Beach, the defending champions, Edgar Kaplan, Norman Kay, Bill Root and Richard Pavlicek asked a fifth player to join them as playing captain. The invitation was accepted with predictable alacrity.

title: THE 3-WHEEL LIVE I: A CAR OF THE FUTURE
description: -slung design and metallic silver exterior, the three- wheeled vehicle looks as if it could be in an automotive design center for the 21st century, but instead it sits in a Norwalk garage, awaiting certification before it goes on the road.

title: STEERING GREYHOUND THROUGH THE STRIKE
description: PHOENIX ''GREYHOUND Is Rolling,'' proclaims a huge banner at the Greyhound Corporation headquarters here. And that fact has brought national attention to the nation's largest bus company and to its tough chairman, John W. Teets. He has kept Greyhound buses moving despite a strike by employees, an achievement that has won him both praise and scorn. The praise comes from Wall Street analysts and other executives who applaud his defiant anti-union stance. The scorn comes from union members and their supporters - ''Fire Teets'' is scrawled on many a depot wall.

title: TOW TRUCK RULES DEBTED
description: THE issue of who may tow cars from scenes of accidents in Brookhaven will be the subject of a hearing Tuesday at 7 P.M. at the New Village Recreation Center.

title: U.S. COURT UPSETS $30,000 AWARD TO THE FAMILY OF A MURDER VICTIM
description: The parents of Bonnie Joan Garland, a college student bludgeoned to death six years ago by her former boyfriend, may not recover damages from him for their emotional distress, a Federal appeals court in New York has ruled in overturning a lower court's decision.

title: THREE CHURCHES RECALL THE GLORY OF VENICE
description: OLIVIER BERNIER is the author of ''Lafayette, Hero of Two Worlds'' (E. P. Dutton).

title: AUTHOR WORSHIP
description: In an essay in her forthcoming book, ''One Writer's Beginning,'' Eudora Welty recalls the pleasure she took in being read to as a child. She also recalls how ''startling and disappointing'' it was ''to find out that story books had been written by

title: CONCERT: 'L'ENFANCE'
description: It must be difficult now for young admirers of ''L'Enfance du Christ'' to realize that it was unknown in this country until 1951 when Thomas Scherman and the Little Orchestra Society gave the first American performance here in New York nearly a century after Berlioz composed it.

title: BOXING CANNOT BE JUSTIFIED
description: Salvatore La Serra, a 25-year-old boxer, has been in a coma in a Milan hospital since last Sunday. He collapsed shortly after a fight that he won and underwent a brain operation. This article is a translation of an editorial published last Thursday in the Vatican newspaper L'Osservatore Romano. The translation was done by Henry Kamm, the chief of The New York Times bureau in Rome.

title: HOW ONE MUSICIAN STAYS IN TUNE
description: As the New School audience applauded a concert led recently by Alexander Schneider, three of his colleagues - Felix Galimir, Michael Tree and Jaime Laredo - suddenly marched up an aisle with a piper, all wearing kilts, fiddled ''Happy Birthday'' on stage and put a Scottish beret on Mr. Schneider's head.

title: Evans a Happy Tiger
description: As he signed with the Tigers for what is believed to be a three-year contract for an estimated $2.25 million, Darrell Evans said in Detroit yesterday that the opportunity to play for a potential pennant-winner was a bigger consideration than money. Evans, a 36-year-old third baseman, picked the Tigers over 17 other teams after being selected in the first round of the free agent re-entry draft last month.

title: NO PULLOUT DATE FOR GRENADA G.I.'S
description: No date has been set for the withdrawal of the 300 American soldiers who are remaining in Grenada to help provide security, their commander said today.

title: BEDFORD WINDMILLS MAY RISE
description: IT seemed for a while that the

title: 2d-Century Mosaic Of Bacchus Is Stolen
description: Thieves using sophisticated archeological tools stole a second- century mosaic of the Roman god Bacchus from the restored ruins of an ancient city, authorities said Thursday.

title: THERE'S STILL NEWS ON THE RADIO
description: ALBERTA EISEMAN, a writer who lives in Connecticut, is a native of Venice. hat news on the Rialto?'' asks a character in ''The Merchant of Venice,'' seeking to know the fortunes of his friend Antonio, the hapless merchant. In Shakespeare's day, the question was akin to saying, ''What did Wall Street do today?'' When Venice was a republic, the Rialto - the area surrounding the celebrated bridge - was the commercial heart of the city, a major center of international trade and finance. People came from all over Europe to buy gold, luxury fabrics, spices and perfumes from the Orient; to hear reports on the treasure-laden argosies that sailed the great trade routes and sometimes ''wrack'd on the narrow seas,'' causing the ruin of investors like Antonio.

title: A BOUQUET OF NEARBY 'NUTCRACKERS'
description: There are other ''Nutcracker'' acts to catch than New York City Ballet's Christmas tree that grows. No fewer than six different professional ballet companies, in fact, celebrate the holiday classic within caroling distance of New York.

title: 2 ROLES FOR SCHOLAR
description: NEW BRUNSWICK PETER WOLF, a member of the music faculty at Rutgers, the State University, will give a harpsichord recital of French Baroque music Thursday evening in Merkin Concert Hall at Abraham Goodman House in Manhattan.

title: DANCE: MIMI GARRARD
description: Mimi Garrard called one of the pieces ''Vivace'' on a program of her works performed by her company on Friday at the Garrard Studio in SoHo. With another choreographer, that choice of titles might have raised an eyebrow, for what happened on stage was certainly not brisk or spirited as the musical term implies. But Miss Garrard specializes in measured movement and even dynamics, and ''Vivace'' was the evening's most buoyant offering.

title: Amy Beth Schulman Plans June Wedding
description: Prof. and Mrs. Philip Schulman of Bayside, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Beth Schulman, to Ronald Marshall Queler, son of Dr. and Mrs. Norman Queler of Canarsie, Brooklyn. The wedding is planned for June.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
AN INSPIRED IDEA, BUT UNREALISTIC
description: ''MACRO'' reminds us of the heroic works that have contributed to our nation's greatness - the canals, the railways, the mighty dams and tower-studded metropolises - and calls for a renewal of the courage and imagination that is made manifest in such projects. We cannot live on ''high- tech'' alone. Our needs are enormous, our problems are daunting, and our response, says author Frank P. Davidson, should be equally giant in scale. Not only the United States, but all the nations of the world, will benefit from a renaissance of macro-engineering. This appeal is nothing less than inspirational, but I question what relation it bears to reality.

title: 5-Year Term in Vandal Killing
description: A 47-year- old man has been sentenced to five years in prison for shooting to death a bat-wielding teen-ager who had vandalized a car. The sentence was imposed Tuesday by Judge Ralph Person on Nicholas J. Cascione, who in June 1982 shot and killed Keith Brown, 17 years old, after seeing a group of youths smashing the windows of a car near his home. The jury returned a manslaughter verdict, punishable by a maximum 15-year prison term.

title: ACTING'S NEW BREED: COMMUTERS BETWEEN STAGE AND SCREEN
description: There is a scene in the play ''Once in a Lifetime'' in which a Hollywood actress asks, ''What the hell

title: Alison M. Gwinn Wed To Glenn P. Kramon
description: Alison Marie Gwinn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Gwinn of Shawnee Mission, Kan., was married yesterday to Glenn Peter Kramon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy A. Kramon of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Longboat Key, Fla. Cantor Raymond Smolover performed the ceremony at the Scarsdale home of the bridegroom's parents.

title: JACOB DORON
description: Jacob Doron, a former Israeli diplomat, died Friday in Jerusalem. He was 69 years old.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: IT HAPPENED IN PINSK

title: GEORGE VECSEYSports of The Times Football Fashion Note
description: MORE than 1,000 fans were waiting around midnight when the Washington Redskins returned to their headquarters in the Virginia suburbs after trouncing Dallas last Sunday in Texas. Some of the fans were already sporting the very latest fashion to hit the capital - army fatigues and combat boots.

title: IVORY COAST AND GHANA RE-ESTABLISH CONTACTS AFTER 2 YEARS
description: A visit here by the Ghanaian leader, Flight Lieut. Jerry J. Rawlings, has re-established contacts between the two countries after a two- year break. But there was no indication that it had improved relations between between the West African neighbors.

title: PRO BONO LAWSUITS AT PARK AVENUE PRICES
description: When the Civil Rights Attorney's Fees Awards Act of 1976 was being debated in Congress, Senator James Allen of Alabama very nearly managed to filibuster it to death. To him, the bill was little more than ''a bonanza for the legal profession.''

title: BOMBING SHATTERS KUWAIT'S REPUTATION
description: KUWAIT GIANT jagged slabs of concrete scattered on the ground, twisted fragments of metal, blood-stained rubble - the scene at the United States Embassy compound last week was all too familiar. It could have been the American Embassy in Beirut in April or the Marine headquarters there in October, targets of nearly identical suicide-bombings.

title: NEW YORK STATE COURT SYSTEM ASKS $125 MILLION BUDGET RISE
description: The state's court system has asked Governor Cuomo to raise its budget by $125 million to cover raises for judges, 30 new judgeships and an overhaul of deteriorating courthouses.

title: ABC'S BRANDON STODDARD BIDS FOR THE LRGER SCREEN
description: Early one morning not long ago, Brandon Stoddard, the president of ABC Motion Pictures, was taking his usual run around a local college track. Suddenly, a stranger appeared running alongside him. ''Are you Brandon Stoddard?'' he asked. Mr. Stoddard nodded. ''Here,'' said the man, pulling a typed film script from inside his warmup suit and thrusting it into Mr. Stoddard's hands.

title: 18 Food Outlets Cited by City For Violations of Health Code
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 18 food establishments last week for violating the health code.

title: JUNIOR LEAGUE HAS NEW ROLE
description: ''MANY PEOPLE in the state do not know what viable community services their local Junior League offers,'' said Susan Scheuermann of Montclair, chairman of the State Council of the Junior League of New Jersey.

title: Some Tame, Some Wild
description: DONALD BARTHELME clearly loves New York. There are, to be sure, some allusions in this new collection of short fiction to the minor nuisances city dwellers must learn to endure - roaches, muggings, greedy landlords ''slipping little rent bills into the mailboxes, slip, slip, slip, slip, slip.'' For the most part, though, the stories, uneven as they are, reveal a consistently affectionate attitude toward the place this Texas native now calls home.

title: JOURNALISTS ATTACK LISBON PRESS LAW PROPOSAL LISBON, Dec. 17 (Reuters) - A draft press bill proposed by the Portuguese Government has sparked widespread criticism, including charges that parts of it go beyond the harsh laws of the right-wing dictatorship that was overthrown in 1974.
description: The Union of Journalists has denounced the 73-page bill as ''the most violent attack on the freedom of the press committed since the revolution.''

Kingsbery of Rolling Hills, Calif. The Rev. Edward Pritchard, the bride's cousin, performed the ceremony at St. Catharine's Roman Catholic Church.

title: TAX-BREAK ZONES PROGRESS SLOWLY
description: Almost three years after the Reagan Administration proposed giving blighted city areas tax advantages as its way of revitalizing them, legislation to put such aid zones into effect appears to face a difficult path in the House Ways and Means Committee, according to Administration and Congressional officials.

title: IS THERE A MORAL LIMIT TO THE VIOLENCE IN FILMS?
description: ''The practice of violence, like all action, changes the world,'' wrote Hannah Arendt in her essay, ''On Violence,'' and she added, ''but the most probable change is to a more violent world.'' She was, of course, thinking of the actions of governments, but the point applies to mere moviemakers, too. From James Bond to Dirty Harry, from ''Straw Dogs'' to ''Scarface,'' there has been unsettling progress over the past few decades in the efficiency of the delivery of violence, more bangs for more bucks. Maybe it's time for an arms freeze in the directors guild.

title: Anglican Ends China Visit
description: The Archbishop of Canterbury, the Most Rev. Robert Runcie, arrived in Hong Kong today for a three-day visit after his first official trip to China. Dr. Runcie said that he held talks with political leaders in China on a variety of issues but that the question of Hong Kong's future was not raised.

title: SUNDAY, DECEMBER 18, 1983;  International
description: A car bomb explosion in London killed 5 people and injured 77. It occurred outside Harrod's department store in an area filled with Christmas shoppers. The police said they were convinced that the Irish Republican Army was responsible. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: DO CONCERTOS SELL?
description: Astudy from the University of Minnesota's Department of Economics draws some interesting parallels between a major symphony orchestra's programming policies and its general financial health. The report is by Takatoshi Ito and Dale Domian, and it says that, in general, the more precarious an orchestra's economic situation, the more prone the orchestra is to schedule concertos and guest soloists for its concerts.

title: NEEDS OF HOMELESS STRESSED
description: BETWEEN 4,000 and 6,000 people may be at least temporarily homeless in the county at some time during the period of a year, according to Karl Bertrand, director of the Sharing Community shelter in Yonkers, which is turning away 15 to 20 homeless people nightly.

title: DAPHNE LEFEAVER TO WED C.R. BALL
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Harrison LeFeaver Jr. of Chevy Chase, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Daphne Bradley LeFeaver, to Christopher Russell Ball, son of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Ball of Palo Alto, Calif. The wedding is to be in July.

''She turned to me and said, 'Get those marines out of there, they have to come home,' '' the Democratic lawmaker recalled. ''And I think other members are encountering that sentiment very, very frequently.''

description: State geologists have announced the discovery of fossils of an algae-like plant called stromatolite in the Adirondack Mountains. It was, they said, the first time that a fossil of any kind had been found in the Adirondacks.

Snyder of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Daniel Robert DeGrace, son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. DeGrace of Durham, N.H. The Rev. Edward R. Danks performed the ceremony.

title: AQUINO, ON THE FUTURE OF THE PHILIPPINES
description: Last September, the Philippine opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. returned to Manila from self-imposed exile in the United States and was shot to death on the airport tarmac as he descended from the plane. Before he left, he spoke for several hours with Spencer A. Sherman, a reporter for United Press International, about the choices facing President Ferdinand E. Marcos. This article is adapted from a longer interview in the current issue of Mother Jones magazine.

title: ROUSING, FOOT-STOMPING 'BLACK NATIVITY'
description: NEWARK ALTHOUGH in its 13th season, the Theater of Universal Images is doing its first Christmas show, and it's a winner: Langston Hughes's free- flowing musical ''Black Nativity.''

title: RUBINSTEIN'S EARLY 78'S GET AN LP REPRISE
description: When Arthur Rubinstein returned to the United States in 1935 after a long absence, his particular brand of pianism had been preceded by his records. His career wasn't made by recordings, but they certainly helped. In America during the middle 1930's, Rubinstein was the first pianistic hero of the electrical period of recording - more than Alfred Cortot, more than Vladimir Horowitz (who at that time did not have many records), more than Artur Schnabel. In those days, if you went to a symphony concert at which the Tchaikovsky B flat minor Piano Concerto was being played, you could count on many in the audience starting to rise at a certain point in the first movement and then settling back with silly grins. They were getting up to change the first disk in the Rubinstein recording.

title: MAJOR NEWS IN SUMMARY
description: Another SliverOf Hope forThe LebanesePressure for reconciliation in Lebanon mounted last week amid hints the warring parties might be ready for another try at compromise. There was talk in Beirut of reviving the intra-Lebanese talks in Geneva. After 16 days of heavy shelling between factions, a cease-fire was announced. The airport, where American marines are encamped, was reopened to civilian planes.

title: AFTER DECADES, HUNT GOES ON FOR THE LAST CHRISTMAS TREE
description: WHEN I was a child, our family never chose a Christmas Tree. We always bought whatever was left. During the 30's, we waited till Christmas Eve and, depending upon age and availability, someone in the family walked a block West to Columbus Avenue and 64th Street, paid 50 or 75 cents (never more than a dollar), and took whatever was left. Whatever the size or shape, everyone in the family always agreed, ''Looks good to me.''

title: SCOUTS HELPING POLICE FORCES
description: PASSAIC TOWNSHIP EVERY afternoon and evening, 21 young men and women 14 to 21 years old don police uniforms, complete with shields, and report for duty at Police Headquarters in this Morris County community.

description: In her article, State Representative Julie D. Belaga (''Giving Metro- North a Chance,'' Nov. 13 ) suggests that commuters wait six or seven months to ''assess the program'' that Peter Stangl has proposed for the Metro-North Commuter Railroad. Six or seven months from now, the only appreciable difference on Metro- North will be a rate increase. We commuters are anxiously awaiting the decision that will be made next month.

title: ALZHEIMER'S CASE TOUCHES ENTIRE FAMILY
description: RETIREMENT, for Sam and Mary T., was to be a time to relax after a life of hard work. With the children gone, the two of them might have lived comfortably on his pension from the railroad and enjoyed the rewards so long deferred. These days, Mary, 67 years old, does not think about what might have been. She takes life one day at a time. And she prays that ''God be merciful and take Sam.''

description: United States warships bombarded Syrian- controlled areas in the hills above Beirut today after two United States F-14 warplanes were fired on by Syrian antiaircraft batteries.

title: RAMS WIN, GAIN PLAYOFFS
description: In one of the most improbable games of the National Football League season, the Los Angeles Rams ended the playoff hopes of the New Orleans Saints today by winning, 26-24, on a 42-yard field goal with two seconds left to play.

title: CASTLE BID FOR PEPPER EXTENDED
description: An investor group led by Castle & Cooke Inc., the big West Coast food concern that is trying to buy the Dr Pepper Company, said yesterday that it has extended the deadline on its takeover bid until the end of the month.

description: Last April, Governor Cuomo formed a commission to study the Shoreham nuclear power plant and asked its 13 members to answer questions about the economics and safety of the plant.

title: MusicNoted in Brief; The Vienna Choir Boys Return to Carnegie Hall
description: The Vienna Choir Boys returned to Carnegie Hall Thursday night surrounded by friends from the adult world. There were the tenors and basses of the Chorus Viennensis, a collection of former Choir Boys who appear often with their young colleagues in Austria.

title: Wendy Liff Married to Christopher Flynn on L.I.
description: Wendy Liff, daughter of Hudas Liff of Huntington, L.I., and the late Dr. Julius Liff, was married yesterday to Christopher E. Flynn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Flynn of Manhasset, L.I. Rabbi Barton Shallot performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's mother.

description: AMY KAISER made her debut as the music director and conductor of New York's venerable Dessoff Choirs Thursday evening at Alice Tully Hall with a concert of English music of the past and present.

title: ON U.N. PEACEKEEPING
description: T he crisis in Lebanon has raised fundamental questions about the concept of peacekeeping - the use of military personnel for control of international conflicts. The success of peacekeeping depends on a sound political base, a well-defined mandate and objective, the cooperation of the conflicting parties, firm but politically sensitive command, and the attitude and understanding of their task by the peacekeeping soldiers.

title: 19 Are Dead in Senegal In Clashes With Police
description: Clashes between Senegalese security forces and southern secessionists left at least 19 dead and 80 wounded here today, officials said.

title: MUSIC: 9 PIECES BY HAL FREEDMAN
description: HAL FREEDMAN'S compositions usually end up someplace entirely different from where they began, getting there by way of eccentric melodic loops and swerves and subtle changes of texture. Wednesday at Symphony Space, he presented nine pieces, three of them choreographed by Alice Farley, that warped the boundaries between chamber music and jazz.

title: MOOD GLUM FOR GREEK SHIPPING INDUSTRY
description: In this port city, the capital of the Greek shipping industry, the mood is decidedly glum.

NEW YORK HOSPITAL PLANNING TO HELP FACILITY IN JAMAICA
description: New York Hospital, one of the city's largest teaching hospitals, has agreed in principle to extend more medical and financial assistance to Jamaica Hospital, a financially distressed community hospital in a poor and medically underserved area of Queens, according to officials of both institutions.

title: MUBARAK ASSESSES U.S.-ISRAEL ACCORD
description: President Reagan's special Middle East envoy, Donald Rumsfeld, met for two hours today with Hosni Mubarak and gave the Egyptian President a detailed explanation of last month's American- Israeli strategic cooperation agreement, Government officials said.

title: BUILDING OF 2 SHIPS LIFTS HOPES IN U.S.
description: In a move that may point to a revival of the dormant American passenger cruise industry, a $230 million contract has been signed by the Marine Power and Equipment Company of Seattle for construction of the first luxury liners to be built in the United States in more than two decades.

title: Smith Chief to Retire
description: Lloyd B. Smith, chairman and chief executive of the A.O. Smith Corporation, said Friday he would retire from both positions by next July. A.O. Smith manufactures automobile and truck frames, along with water heaters and electric motors. Mr. Smith, 63 years old, said he would step down as chief executive officer Jan. 1, and as chairman next June 30. He has held those positions since 1967. He said he would be replaced in both positions by Thomas I. Dolan, 56, currently president and chief operating officer.

title: Philips Plans Takeover Of Grundig AMSTERDAM, Dec. 18 (Reuters) - A consortium led by the Dutch electronics giant NV Philips Gloeilampenfabrieken and including several European banks will take over Grundig of West Germany next April, Philips said today.
description: Philips, the largest home electronics producer in Europe, will take control of the day-to-day management of Grundig and at the same time increase its indirect holding to over 25 percent, a Philips spokesman in Eindhoven said. He did not elaborate.

title: WOMEN ARE SHUNNING SENATE RACES
description: After Nancy Stevenson completed a four- year term as Lieutenant Governor of South Carolina earlier this year, some Democratic Party officials encouraged her to oppose Senator Strom Thurmond, the senior Republican who faces re-election in 1984. But Mrs. Stevenson recently decided to bow out.

title: China Ship Talks Fail PEKING, Dec. 18 (UPI) - Negotiations between the United States and China on renewing a shipping agreement have collapsed, industry sources said today. As a result, they said, Peking is expected to impose new restrictions on American vessels that use Chinese ports.
description: No formal announcement was made, but in Washington, Harold Shear of the Transportation Department, who headed the United States delegation, confirmed that the talks had broken down.

description: Urs Raeber, a 25-year-old Swiss, scored his first World Cup victory today by winning a downhill race.

description: Frank Broyles, the Arkansas athletic director, announced today that he had accepted the resignation of Lou Holtz, the football coach for the last seven seasons.

title: U.S. TO ASK 'FAIR' TRADE IN SERVICES
description: The United States, pressing for reduced barriers to stimulate the $350 billion- a-year international trade in services, has laid out for the first time what it hopes to get from any new round of multilateral negotiations.

title: WHY LEONARD CAN'T RESIST THE RING
description: HE would rise early in the 6-bedroom, $1 million Tudor house he bought recently in Potomac, Md., a suburb of Washington, put on a sweat suit and go out and do about five miles of road work, pattering through the quiet, leafy streets.

title: BRIEFS
description: Amfac Inc., primarily a food-products concern based in Honolulu, said it had ended negotiations to sell its plumbing supply distribution operation to two of the unit's executives.

title: SCORES ON READING TESTS GIVEN CITY'S SCHOOLS
description: The Board of Education has released scores on reading tests given in 623 public elementary and 181 junior high schools in April 1983. District 26 in Douglaston-Little Neck, Queens, ranked highest in the city, and District 7 in the South Bronx ranked lowest. The center column shows the percentage of students reading at or above grade level; right-hand column gives each school's citywide ranking.

title: ECONOMISTS OPTIMISTIC ON '84
description: After a year of robust recovery, with higher growth and lower inflation than had been forecast by most experts, many leading economists predict that 1984 will be a year of continuing, but somewhat slower, economic expansion.

title: ADVERTISING ; Digital Plans to Shift Its Corporate Account
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation of Maynard, Mass., a major computer manufacturer, confirmed Friday that it is starting to look for an agency to replace Benton & Bowles on what it calls its corporate account? But this will not affect the other work the agency does for Digital Equipment, such as the international, direct marketing and health care advertising. The agency will continue?to be the agency of record for television, according to Richard O. Berube, corporate communications director.
