description: The Economy

title: Rangers Unsure What Is Wrong
description: Shaken again, the Rangers are still confused about what ails them. And now they are suddenly fearful that the remedy might come in the form of trades.

title: Surgery, Not Aspirin, for Salvador
description: It's taken three years for the Reagan Administration to lift the rocks in El Salvador and confront the wormy spectacle beneath. For compelling reasons, the President is finally demanding that San Salvador rid itself of the patrons of right-wing terror. He offers the carrot of more aid. But after so many false certifications of progress, he also needs to brandish the stick of cutting aid.

title: GUNMAN KILLS 2 WOMEN IN CORNELL DORMITORY
description: A New York City man carrying a rifle invaded a dormitory at Cornell University in Ithaca, N.Y., late Saturday night and, after briefly holding seven students captive, shot and killed two of them, the authorities said.

title: 9 Policemen Suspended After Suspect Dies
description: Nine District of Columbia police officers have been placed on paid administrative leave in connection with the death of a man who was not charged with a crime until five hours after he died in police custody.

title: RED WINGS TIE FLYERS ON LATE GOAL
description: Steve Yzerman shot a loose puck through a group of fallen players with one second left in regulation tonight to give the Detroit Red Wings their second 3-3 tie with the Philadelphia Flyers in two nights. The two teams had played in Detroit Saturday night.

title: PASTOR CONFIDENT OF 'MIRACLE' TO HELP REBUILD BURNED CHURCH
description: The church organist played on a portable electric keyboard balanced on his lap. The parishioners sat on cold metal chairs and listened as the pastor delivered his sermon from beneath a basketball hoop.

title: DANCE: ANDREW JANNETTI
description: ANDREW JANNETTI'S heart was surely in the right place at Friday night's performance by Andrew Jannetti and Dancers at the Merce Cunningham Studio. But Mr. Jannetti did not always possess sufficient choreographic imagination to make his personal feelings theatrically convincing.

title: RAINY PERIOD LIKELY TO CONTINUE
description: Unusually strong winds from the west have brought a succession of storms across the New York area, and the prospects for the next month are for a continuation of more-than-average rainfall, according to Dr. Donald L. Gilman, chief of the prediction branch of the National Weather Service's Climate Analysis Center in Maryland.

title: WESTON C. PULLEN Jr.
description: Weston C. Pullen Jr., a retired vice president for broadcasting operations at Time Inc., died Friday at his home in Old Lyme, Conn. He was 66 years old.

title: GOOD FENCES, BAD IDEA
description: This nation's wide open political system is threatened by the physical closing of its Government.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Season's Greetings

title: William Meyer Is Dead at 68; Ex-Congressman of Vermont
description: Former Representative William Meyer, a liberal who rose from political obscurity to become the only Democrat to represent Vermont in the House of Representatives, died Friday at the age of 68.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Allied Products Corp. announced the extension of its tender offer to acquire $5 million of its 7 percent senior subordinated debentures to January 9. Previously, the offer was scheduled to expire December 14.

title: MONDAY, DECEMBER 19, 1983 International
description: Japan's Liberal Democratic Party suffered one of its worst postwar election setbacks, losing its majority in Parliament's powerful House of Representatives. Japan's ruling conservative party must now seek support from independent conservatives to retain control of the 511-member lower house, which elects the country's Prime Minister and originates all significant legislation. The results are seen as a serious blow for Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone. (Page A1, Column 6.) U.S. warships off Beirut bombarded Syrian-controlled areas in the hills above the city after two American F-14 fighter jets were shot at by Syrian antiaircraft gunners. (A1:3.)

title: Beckman Sets Layoffs
description: Beckman Instruments Inc. said today that it will lay off up to 300 workers next month, most of them at its Brea plant. It would be the second mass layoff at the medical products firm in three months.

title: FILM SOCIETY TO HONOR CLAUDETTE COLBERT
description: Claudette Colbert, whose breezy comedic roles won her the acclaim of critics and movie fans for two decades, will be honored by the Film Society of Lincoln Center on April 23 at its annual spring gala at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: CONCERT: ST. CECILIA ENSEMBLE
description: DAVID RANDOLPH'S busy weekend of conducting at Carnegie Hall began on Friday evening. Scheduled for Saturday and Sunday were multiple performances of Handel's ''Messiah'' with his Masterwork Chorus, but Friday's concert was with another group, the St. Cecilia Chorus and Orchestra, and the music was by Haydn, Mozart and Beethoven.

title: GIANTS SCATTER AND LOOK TO FUTURE
description: The Giants, their disastrous season over after the 31-22 loss Saturday to the Washington Redskins, dispersed today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Fragment as a Foundation For New West Pt. Chapel

title: No Headline
description: Gov. David C. Treen has said he will sign into law a bill creating this state's first Congressional district with a black majority, in answer to a Federal court order.

title: Revised Version OfHowCarHit51
description: A car that mounted a crowded Fifth Avenue sidewalk and injured 51 people Saturday afternoon was not hit by another vehicle, as had earlier been thought, a police investigator said yesterday.

title: AMERICAN NUCLEAR INDUSTRY'S MILLSTONE
description: To the Editor:

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: In a game of straight pool, Player A, leading by 49-47 and needing one ball to win, has an open table containing eight balls. He shoots and misses, but leaves Player B no clear shot and no possible way to play a safety, which requires touching a cushion with a ball. Player B table- scratches - that is, puts the cue ball into a pocket. He loses a point but also leaves Player A without an open shot. Player A again attempts a safety, but this time leaves the table open for his opponent to run four balls and win the match. Was Player B's table-scratch legal?

title: 'Peg' Closes
description: ''Peg,'' a musical autobiography with Peggy Lee at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater, closed Saturday night. It ran for 13 previews and 5 performances.

title: 7 Are Suspended for Drugs
description: The International Amateur Athletic Federation, the world governing body for track and field, announced lifetime suspensions today for seven athletes who it said had used illegal drugs during competition.

title: Carrie Smith Performs 'Blues and Whatever'
description: For almost a decade, Carrie Smith has been trying to shed the association with the great blues singer Bessie Smith that she acquired when she sang with great success some Bessie Smith songs as part of a Carnegie Hall program on the career of Louis Armstrong.

title: Fali Time Wins $1 Million Futurity
description: Fali Time, a California-bred colt, captured the $1,049,725 Hollywood Futurity for 2-year-olds, the richest race in thoroughbred history, at Hollywood Park today. The purse surpassed the Arlington Million's guaranteed $1 million.

title: MARIJUANA URGED AS MEDICINE
description: Research by several states shows marijuana is effective for treating the nausea that often accompanies cancer therapy, according to a Congressman who is sponsoring legislation to allow medical use of the plant.

title: SETBACK IN SYRIA ON LEBANON TALKS
description: Efforts to resume talks aimed at reconciling Lebanon's warring factions suffered a setback today when the Foreign Ministers of Syria, Saudi Arabia, and Lebanon failed to agree on a date for a second round of negotiations.

title: Teacher Pact Approved In Duluth, Ending Strike
description: The Duluth School Board voted 5 to 4 tonight to approve a new contract with teachers who have been on strike 18 days.

title: Fehr Stand Regrettable
description: IN the last months of his reign, Bowie Kuhn has put every major league baseball player on notice that illegal-drug involvement will not be tolerated. But instead of supporting the Commissioner's suspension of four players and putting its own membership on notice, the Major League Baseball Players Association has criticized his ruling as ''both unfortunate and regrettable'' - surely an unfortunate and regrettable reaction.

title: CARTOON SLEUTH PROWLS AT LIBRARY OF CONGRESS
description: Beware, book-nappers. Sherlock Searcher and his trusty hound, Peek-a-Boo, are on the prowl around the Library of Congress.

title: COMPANIES BATTLE AIRLINES ON BONUSES
description: Many corporate travel departments say they have all but given up trying to get their employees to turn in the bonus travel points they get from the airlines' frequent flier programs.

title: LOOPHOLE IN LAW RAISES CONCERN ABOUT PRIVACY IN COMPUTER AGE
description: Telecommunications experts are expressing concern that the Federal wiretap law does not make it a crime for anyone, whether private citizen, law enforcement officer or foreign spy, to intercept the millions of messages transmitted around the United States each day by computer.

title: U.S. AND MEXICO TO EXPAND COOPERATION ON AGRICULTURE
description: The United States and Mexico have signed an agreement to expand their cooperation in the science and technology of agriculture and natural resources.

title: The Islanders Are Better, Not Older
description: THE weather forecast said that a mass of cold Canadian air was spreading across the United States, heading for Long Island. A blast of pure hockey brilliance got there first, nearly blowing the Rangers out of the building and invigorating any Islander fans who might have thought there was nothing left to cheer but a fifth Stanley Cup.

title: BUSY GERALD FORD ADDS ACTING TO HIS REPERTORY
description: Former President Gerald R. Ford makes his acting debut Wednesday night, playing himself in an episode of ''Dynasty,'' a prime-time television soap opera set in a world of wealth and high finance. It is a world, associates say, that Mr. Ford is beginning to know well.

title: Accord Set At Peugeot On Layoffs PARIS, Dec. 18 (Reuters) - The French Government announced a compromise agreement today with the auto maker Peugeot S.A. to lay off almost 2,000 workers at its Talbot plant west of Paris, paving the way for an end to a strike over layoff plans.
description: The management had threatened to close the Talbot plant at Poissy and shelve a 1.2 billion franc, or $100 million, modernization program because of Government hesitancy at approving 2,905 planned layoffs.

title: SUPER-SALESMAN BEHIND DR PEPPER
description: Once, Dr Pepper was a regional drink in Texas and the Southwest. Woodward W. Clements made it a nationwide seller and the big soft drink company that it is today.

title: U.S.-SOVIET CONTACTS REMAIN STRONG AT LOWER LEVELS
description: Soviet-American contacts at the nongovernmental level have shown remarkable resiliency despite the breakdown of official negotiations in such areas as arms control and a decline in cultural exchanges organized by the two Governments.

title: OIL RESERVE'S CONFIDENCE HIGH
description: Just outside town, an unpaved road leads to a swamp dotted with aged cypress stumps, a playground for skittering white egrets and a thriving population of alligators.

title: RECITAL: MARK PESKANOV
description: MARK PESKANOV is a tremendous young violinist, and his Friday evening concert at Carnegie Recital Hall was a triumph. Mr. Peskanov, who was born in the Soviet Union, has lived in the United States since 1973 and has appeared with the National Symphony, the Chicago Symphony and many other orchestras. Friday night, accompanied by the skilled and unusually assertive pianist Rita Sloan, he offered bravura performances of music by Mozart, Beethoven and Prokofiev.

title: ON GIVING: TO WHOM AND WHY
description: not just to family, friends and building maintenance staffs, but also to the good-works groups and others who cajole, compel or otherwise move us to give. There is the Salvation Army outside stores and the American Red Cross appealing through the mails, along with hundreds of other worthy causes. There is the neatly dressed woman asking for spare change at the subway entrance, the violinist playing for his breakfast at the foot of the subway steps, the homeless huddled in doorways along our way. All clamor for attention and donations. But do we give, to whom and why?

title: No Headline
description: Berry Replacing Ogilvy As O.&M. Creative Chief

title: A HUB OF TERRORISM 'MOST FAVORED' BY US
description: To the Editor:

title: HOW U.S. LABOR IS TACKLING THE 'FIX' IT IS INT o the Editor:
description: ''Self-Help for Troubled Labor,'' Leo Perlis's Nov. 28 Op-Ed article, is faulty in a number of facts as well as conclusions.

title: Marcos Accuses Clergy Of Plotting Against Him
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that the Roman Catholic clergy and middle class were plotting to topple his 18- year-old regime.

title: Hitachi Yields On Software
description: Hitachi Ltd. has conceded that the operating software used in its supercomputer infringes on copyrights held by the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: AMERICANS ASSESS 15 YEARS OF FEMINISM
description: After 15 years of feminist activism, a quarter of the American public believe that the women's movement has made their own lives better, according to a New York Times poll. On the other hand, two-thirds say the movement has done nothing to improve their lives.

title: Frieda Kittay and A. Phillip Goldsmith Are Wed
description: Frieda Kittay of Rye Brook, N.Y., widow of Sol Kittay, chairman of the B.V.D. Company, was married yesterday to A. Phillip Goldsmith of New York, former president of Julius Kayser & Company, a leading manufacturer of women's apparel.

title: Spain's Education Bill Attracts New Protests
description: About 100,000 Spaniards marched in this southern city today in the third consecutive day of protests by teachers, parents and students against an education bill opposed by the Roman Catholic church, the police said.

title: Father Objects to Black As Pageant Escort
description: A father who did not want his white daughter escorted by a black student at a beauty pageant withdrew her from the contest, said Richard Babb, principal of Parker High School.

title: A NOVELTY TREAT FOR THE DOG THAT HAS EVERYTHING
description: Is a dog expected to survive year in and year out, Christmas or no, unbrightened by the sort of pleasures humans can have just by visiting the nearest premium chocolates counter?

title: Most-Wanted Irish Terrorist Slips Through Police Checks
description: Ireland's most-wanted terrorist slipped through a dragnet of several hundred policemen and soldiers today, frustrating some of his pursuers by forcing them to strip at gunpoint.

title: BRIEFING
description: Golden Apple Award

title: TEXAS ENERGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
BLACK STUDENTS TO DO RECRUITING
description: When Jamie Lofton, a Detroit native, entered Michigan State University three years ago, a counselor warned her not to be alarmed if she was the only black student in some of her classes. ''I knew right then that there weren't enough blacks at Michigan State,'' Miss Lofton said.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Good Neighbors in Blue

title: A FIRST FOR A HISPANIC WOMAN
description: A Yale University senior has become the first Hispanic woman to win nomination for a Rhodes Scholarship, joining 31 other students named today as American recipients of the prize.

title: POLISH FUGITIVE URGES 'LONG MARCH'
description: An underground Solidarity leader says he believes Poles must embark on what he calls a ''long march'' of resistance to the Government, building clandestine organizations in schools, factories, scientific institutions and cultural life.

title: Warriors 99 Clippers 97
description: Lester Conner made several outstanding defensive plays in the closing minutes and Mickey Johnson made the go- ahead shot as Golden State handed San Diego its 29th straight loss on the road, three short of the National Basketball Association record set in 1953-54 by the Baltimore Bullets.

title: SPANISH MODERATE LEADS COMMUNISTS
description: The Spanish Communist Party re-elected its Secretary General today in a defeat for the party's pro-Soviet faction that had challenged the present leadership.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Claim to Fame

title: LEBANON AND VIETNAM
description: Lebanon is not Vietnam: So we are told by those who support the deepening U.S. military involvement. They are right. The geography, the society, the interests at stake are all very different in Lebanon.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Making the Best of Things

title: UNIVERSITY PATENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The revenue in the latest quarter includes a nonrefundable payment of $500,000 under the terms of a licensing agreement received by the University Genetics Co., a majority-owned unit of University Patents.

title: FACTS PERPLEXING IN TEXAS ROBBERY
description: To George Hairston, an N.A.A.C.P. attorney, it has become almost a holy war against a judicial system he characterizes as ''callous, uncaring and racist.''

title: FOR PARIS, IT'S TIME TO WOO MOSCOW
description: France is trying to step up its contacts with the Soviet Union at a time that President Francois Mitterrand has described as one of unusual gravity in East-West relations.

title: THE COACHING ROLE IS CHANGING WITH THE TIMES
description: FOOTBALL as war is a popular metaphor among the players and coaches and even many of the television and newspaper reporters who cover the games. The head coach is depicted as the commander-in-chief with unquestioned authority. The players are troops being sent into battle on the football field. Linemen engage in hand-to- hand combat in the trenches and quarterbacks are field generals. Running backs are the infantry.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Water Works Co., Wilmington, Del., has named James V. La Frankie president, and Loren D. Mellendorf executive vice president.

title: STANG HYDRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: A PROGRAM TO HELP MEN STOP BATTERING WOMEN
description: For some of the men, it had been a good week: They had not struck their wives, nor even felt the threat of uncontrollable anger. For others, it had been more difficult. They had not been able to keep the lid on fury, but they had not hit anyone physically, and that was a good sign.

title: TOPICS: Anonymous Samaritans
description: As she arrived from Atlanta to spend a four-day holiday in New York with her husband, the woman expressed doubts about the city. The next day, a group of anonymous New Yorkers resolved them.

title: Back to the Ritual of Death
description: The execution of two convicts last week brought America to a grim threshold. With appeals fast running out for more than a thousand prisoners on death row, official murders are likely to happen almost weekly next year. Now still sensational, they may soon become routine.

title: ERRORS ARE FEWER FOR RAY WILLIAMS
description: Every coach has his way of dealing with players.

title: DUCK HUNTING IN STYLE, FOLLOWING A BIG BREAKFAST
description: CEDAR ISLAND, N.C.

title: SAM A. LOPIN
description: Sam A. Lopin, a longtime paper company executive, died Saturday at his Manhattan home.

title: Chocolate Chip-Off
description: As the year heads into the stretch, a friend of ours nominates something she hopes will die with it. In years past she has wished extinction on a fad, pet rocks; a song, ''You Light Up My Life,'' and a phrase, ''state-of-the- art.''

title: No Headline
description: New Johnson Shampoo Is Its First in 30 Years

title: Gasoline Use Turns Higher LOS ANGELES, Dec. 18 (AP) - A long decline in gasoline consumption has begun to turn around, Dan Lundberg, an industry analyst, said today.
description: During August, the most recent month for which figures are available, consumption in the United States rose 4.7 percent from August 1982, to 9.1 billion gallons, Mr. Lundberg said. That increase followed a cumulative decline of 12.5 percent since 1978.

title: STREETWISE COMITY
description: To the Editor:

title: Roberta Brown, a Lawyer, Is Wed to Sylvan I. Zeiden
description: Roberta Brown and Sylvan I. Zeiden, both lawyers, were married yesterday at Temple Emanuel in Beverly Hills, Calif., by Rabbi Sanford Ragins.

title: SALES RISE FOR WORLD'S STORES
description: In England, goggles to wear while chopping onions are a big Christmas item. In Japan, it is fancy ski suits. And almost everywhere except Spain, home computers are among the most popular gifts to put under the tree this year.

title: RENT-A-CENTER reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The results for both periods are restated to give effect to the acquisition of interests in 22 limited partnerships.

title: VENEZUELAN WORKERS FIND THE WELL HAS RUN DRY
description: In a working-class neighborhood of Maracay, an industrial center 50 miles west of this capital, Libardo Solorzano's dream has bumped to a stop.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Ogilvy Weighs Acquiring Rolf Ogilvy & Mather International, a publicly held company,

title: Nuclear Weapon Tested
description: A major underground nuclear weapon test was conducted in a shaft 1,690 feet below the Nevada Test Site Friday. The device had an explosive force of the equivalent of 20,000 to 150,000 tons of TNT.

title: OVERCHARGES SEEN IN LOVE CANAL JOB
description: State investigators say they have uncovered what they described as overcharges that may amount to as much as $5 million in an emergency cleanup of toxic wastes at the Love Canal in Niagara Falls, N.Y.

title: TRAPP FAMILY, OVERCOMING ADVERSITY AGAIN, REOPENS LODGE IN STOWE, VT.
description: ''Sch"on, mama?'' asked Johannes von Trapp, steering his mother through the new Tyrolean lodge, frosted with a layer of fresh snow. ''Beautiful, Johannes,'' agreed his mother, the 78-year-old Baroness Maria von Trapp. ''I am constantly overwhelmed.''

title: SWANTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,093,000 for the quarter and 56 cents a share from discontinued retail operations for the 9 months. c-After a loss of $406,000 from discontinued operations. d-Net loss

title: 2 Cabbies Found Slain in Brooklyn
description: Two gypsy-cab drivers were found shot to death early yesterday in different neighborhoods of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Nestle Leaving Burnett

title: No Headline
description: dear nasa your administrator james beggs says there s room for civilian passengers on next year s shuttle flights and asks for applications

title: CALIFORNIA CITY WORKERS TOLD TO GIVE BACK SOME WAGES 13SANTA CLARA, Calif., Dec. 18 (UPI) - Not only will there be no Christmas bonuses for 350 city employees here, but officials also say the employes have been overpaid all year long and must give the money back. The overpayments range from $200 to $1,000 a person.
description: ''It wasn't our mistake,'' a secretary, Shirley Dias, said last Wednesday when she heard of the decision.

title: Navy and Shipbuilder Agree On $170 Million Settlement
description: A 13-year contract dispute between a Mississippi shipbuilder and the Government has been resolved with a saving to taxpayers of $170 million, officials say.

title: Soviets Top U.S.A.
description: Vladimir Kovin scored three goals and assisted on another tonight as a touring Soviet Union all-star team defeated the United States Olympic team, 6-2.

title: SYNOD OF BISHOPS' PROPOSALS REFLECT ITS AMBIGUOUS ROLE
description: The Roman Catholic Synod of Bishops has given Pope John Paul II a package of proposals on strengthening the practice of confession, and the Pope's handling of the proposals reflects the rather ambiguous role of the Synod.

title: The Calendar ;  Monday
description: With the approach of Christmas, official Washington will be moving at a slow pace this week. Congress is still away, the Supreme Court is in recess, and President Reagan's schedule is unusually light. But Nancy Reagan will be on the move today, flying to New York to visit 7-year-old Ahn Ji Sook and 4-year-old Lee Kil Woo, the two Korean children she brought to the United States last month for heart surgery at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, L.I.

title: No Headline
description: Aurson Acquires Cohn

title: PROVIGO INC reports earnings for 12wks to Nov 5
description: The year-ago results were restated.

title: UNDERINSURED HAVE TROUBLE FINDING DOCTORS STUDY SAYS
description: About 12 percent of Americans are medically disadvantaged and have serious difficulty obtaining health care, often because they lack insurance, a Robert Wood Johnson Foundation study released today said. However, most Americans have access to a physician, clinic or other source of medical care, the study said.

title: ATLANTA'S LACK OF PUBLIC TOILETS SPURS DEBATE
description: The growing number of homeless people in central Atlanta has touched off a sharp local debate over whether the city ought to provide public toilets.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''People are just walking around in a daze, sort of comforting each other as best they can.

title: Output Off in Belgium
description: Industrial output in Belgium fell 2.2 percent in September from a year earlier, the National Institute of Statistics said.

title: Gunman Shot to Death By Grocer in the Bronx
description: The owner of a Bronx grocery store shot and killed one of two gunmen who had scooped an undetermined amount of money from the cash register last night, the police said.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Accounts

title: Neighbors Lose Suit On Christmas Display
description: Al Copeland says that since a judge has rejected his neighbors' complaints about his $35,000, 250,000-bulb Christmas light display, he wants to make it even bigger.

title: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan Rate Worries And Optimism
description: I NVESTORS are in a quandary these days when

title: MIDEAST BOMBERS: HARD TO PIN DOWN
description: Seven months after the United States Embassy in Beirut was destroyed in a suicidal truck-bomb attack, senior intelligence officials say they still have no firm idea who was behind the attack or four similar truck bombings in the Middle East since then.

title: HOLIDAY SALES THRIVING AT MET MUSEUM
description: WITH six shopping days until Christmas, some of the busiest cash registers in New York are in the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: NEW TEACHER PLAN IN NORTH CAROLINA
description: After two years of study and debate, the Charlotte-Mecklenburg school system has approved a sweeping teacher- training and career program that includes sharply higher pay and is being watched by educators elsewhere because of its smorgasbord of techniques aimed at raising teacher quality.

title: I.R.A., ADMITTING BOMBING, SAYS LEADERS DIDN'T PLAN IT
description: The Irish Republican Army said here tonight that its members planted the car bomb outside Harrods department store in London that killed 5 people and wounded 91 others Saturday.

title: RIO GRANDE DRILLING reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: Kidnappers Send an Ear To Rome Jewelry Family
description: The people who kidnapped an heiress to the Bulgari jewelry stores and her son sent a severed ear to the family, saying it was the boy's and warning they would kill him and his mother if their ransom demands were not met, officials said today.

title: MONDAY SPORTS Football
description: 49ers vs. Dallas Cowboys , at San Francisco. The Cowboys already have a wild-card berth in the playoffs, and the 49ers are assured one but can win the National Conference's Western Division title with a victory.

title: Malaysian Airliner Crashes
description: A Malaysian Airlines jet believed to be carrying 233 people crash-landed in heavy monsoon rains a half-mile short of the Kuala Lumpur airport today, airline officials said.

title: TRUE HUNGER AND MALNUTRITION CASES ARE GROWING PROBLEMS, EXPERTS SAY
description: People who run soup kitchens and food banks across the country report a marked increase in demand for food, and they say the need is, without question, genuine.

title: NEW PROSPERITY BRINGS DISCORD TO THE EAST VILLAGE
description: A French bakery opened off East Ninth Street this summer, where a coffee shop used to be. It is so new it does not yet have a name, but its specialty is a pastry called mirroir cassis.

title: Door-to-Door Hunt Pressed In Kidnapping of an Infant
description: About 40 Federal Bureau of investigation agents and city police officers conducted a door-to-door search today in an attempt to find a newborn baby abducted from a hospital by a woman masquerading as a nurse.

title: No Means Test Sought, One U.S. Official Says
description: The Reagan Administration has considered steps to restrict the distribution of free food from Government surpluses so that a larger proportion of it goes to those who truly need it, a senior official said today.

title: U.S. RULE ON BANK FEES DRAWS FIRE
description: The Comptroller of the Currency has quietly adopted a regulation to prohibit states from curbing the fees that national banks may charge for consumer services, effectively reversing a century of allowing the states this latitude.

title: LIONS AND U.S.F.L. BOTH SIGNED SIMS
description: Billy Sims said today he had signed two five-year contracts - one on July 1 with the Houston Gamblers of the United States Football League and a second on Friday with the Detroit Lions of the National Football League.

title: POSSIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a gain from discontinued operations of the plastics equipment of $31,852 and a gain of $300,990 from the sale of the plastics equipment group. c-After a gain of $21,080 from discontinued operations of the plastics equipment group.

title: TREASURY'S LIST HEAVY THIS WEEK
description: The Treasury, after a three-week lull in auctioning new notes and bonds, has a heavy list this week. It will sell $8.25 billion of two-year notes, $8.25 billion of one-year bills and three- and six-month bills totaling $12.8 billion.

title: JETS' LINEUP TO CHANGE BY 1984
description: It was more than the last team meeting of 1983, Coach Joe Walton warned his players today. For many of them, it would be their last meeting as Jets.

description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: Washington WatchJonathan Fuerbringer Regan Adding Columnist Role
description: WASHINGTON T REASURY Secretary Donald T. Regan,

title: NETS BEATEN BY NUGGETS, 122-118
description: The Nets dropped their third straight game tonight, losing by 122-118 to the Denver Nuggets before 7,799 fans at McNichols Arena, and then complained about the officials as they were dealt another frustrating defeat in what has been a disappointing season.

title: TV: VAN DYKE AND CAESAR IN MOVIE
description: THE casting is promising as it teams for the first time Dick Van Dyke and Sid Caesar, two of television's more renowned comedians. And the director is Bill Persky, a veteran whose Emmy Awards cover the ''Dick Van Dyke Show.'' However, ''Found Money,'' originally titled ''Max and Sam,'' the made-for-television movie on NBC tonight at 9, keeps tripping over its own good but obvious intentions.

title: BALLET: DANCERS SWITCH ROLES IN 'NUTCRACKER'
description: THE ballet regulars may refer to it affectionately as ''Nuts,'' but they turn up just the same at the New York State Theater to see George Balanchine's ''Nutcracker'' performed by the New York City Ballet. Part of the lure is the chance to watch dancers test themselves in new roles. And performances on Thursday and Saturday afternoon offered several of those opportunities.

title: MUSIC/NOTED IN BRIEF;
description: The concert presented by Music Today in Merkin Hall on Wednesday night displayed an intriguing range of attitudes to the musical past in a program that surveyed disparate 20th- century styles.

title: 280 Escape Injury In Canadian Jet Fire
description: An engine on a Northwest Orient DC- 10 caught fire as the plane was being started at Winnipeg International Airport today, forcing 280 people to flee the jet, officials said.

title: WINNEBAGO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
Seafirst Names Vice Chairmen
description: The Seafirst Corporation, a Seattle bank holding company that is now a unit of the BankAmerica Corporation, said it has appointed two vice chairmen in a move designed to further refine the company's management structure.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Cosmos Homecoming

title: ABOARD BEIRUT-BOUND SHIP: A 'B' MOVIE
description: Each evening, at 10 or thereabouts, a motor vessel known as Sun Boat nudges out of the wintry chill of Larnaca, Cyprus, heading for Beirut.

description: His Biggest Fight

title: WHY TURN THE SCREW?
description: The Reagan Administration is pressing the International Civil Aviation Organization for a new and harsher indictment of the Soviet Union for the shooting down of Korean Air Lines Flight 7 Sept. l. Other than providing President Reagan one more opportunity to denounce the ''evil empire,'' what good will that do?

title: BONN STORM: KOHL DIGS IN
description: News Analysis

title: SURGERY HELD UP BY PROCRASTINATION
description: To the Editor:

title: N.I.T., IN DANGER AGAIN, MAY SEEK FOREIGN TEAMS
description: The National Invitation Tournament, which has been threatened with extinction many times but always survived, might include foreign teams in an effort to overcome the latest threat to its existence.

title: FILM: 'REUBEN, REUBEN,' FROM THE DEVIRES BOOK
description: THE character of Gowan McGland is pure Peter DeVries, and ''Rebuen, Reuben,'' adapted from the DeVries novel by Julius J. Epsteinand directed by Robert Ellis Miller, is one of the most buoyantly satiric fables yet made from a DeVries work. It's a small, unpushy movie of rare wit.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Chrysler Tokyo Expert Fights G.M.-Toyota Tie

title: Allis to Reset Aswan Blades
description: American engineers from the Allis-Chalmers Company of Wisconsin will start work on replacing the turbine blades of Egypt's Aswan Dam in January 1985, a United States official said today.

title: SALVADOR RIGHTIST TO RUN FOR PRESIDENCY
description: Roberto d'Aubuisson, the leader of the far-right National Republican Alliance, won his party's nomination to run for President of El Salvador today.

title: No Headline
description: Regionals' Ad Unit

title: LAST FOUR BERTHS IN PLAYOFFS ARE SETTLED
description: The last four teams for the National Football League's playoffs were determined yesterday after the Seattle Seahawks gained the second and last wild-card position in the American Conference and the Detroit Lions, Los Angeles Rams and San Francisco 49ers all qualified in the National Conference.

title: BRONX COMMUTER BUS LINE STRUCK
description: Four hundred drivers and mechanics went on strike against the New York Bus Service at 12:01 A.M. today after contract negotiations failed.

title: SPW CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income c-After an extraordinary charge of $1,090,000 relating to work in Iraq.

title: JAZZ: ARTIE SHAW RETURNS AT 73
description: AFTER 28 years on the sidelines, Artie Shaw, the clarinetist who was one of the most celebrated band leaders of the Swing Era in the 30's and 40's, was back on the bandstand over the weekend leading a newly formed Artie Shaw Orchestra in such hits of his heyday as ''Begin the Beguine,'' ''Frenesi'' and ''Any Old Time.''

title: CommoditiesH. J. Maidenberg Updating Training Of Traders
description: A S dramatic as the growth of the futures and options markets was this year, it could have been much greater but for the dearth of talent in all areas of the industry. The reason is that many of the new markets, such as those in financial and stock index futures and options, are highly complex and require specialized knowledge and trading skills.

title: At Least 6 Die In Detroit Fire
description: An old apartment building housing mostly elderly and handicapped people caught fire early today, killing at least six people, the authorities said.

title: Advertising; Henderson, Graf, Doyle In Merger
description: A RARE three-way ad agency merger was accomplished in the wee hours Friday morning, creating a $28 million shop named Henderson Friedlich Graf & Doyle. The new combination has particular strengths in the financial, high-technology and travel advertising fields.

title: A Bitter End
description: The high price of charity has forced the end of the pro-celebrity British Golf Classic after four years and angered some of the people who suffered financially in its wake. Bob Hope , the entertainer, was the target of criticism after it was disclosed that he was paid $186,750 and received $112,500 in expenses to lend his name and likeness to the charity tournament held annually in England.

title: CONCERT: ROBERT MCDUFFIE
description: THE violinist Robert McDuffie gave a thoroughly professional recital at the Metropolitan Museum on Saturday afternoon accompanied by the pianist Sandra Rivers. Mr. McDuffie, a graduate of Juilliard where he studied with Dorothy DeLay, obviously never needs to think much about either technique or intonation. In fact, so polished and poised is he, that there was almost a sense of nonchalance about his playing.

title: COLUMBIA'S GORGE IS FOCUS OF BATTLE
description: From the Skamania County Courthouse to the corridors of the nation's Capitol, battle lines are being drawn over one of the Northwest's most scenic areas: the Columbia Gorge.

title: G.M. and Toyota Hit F.T.C. Snag
description: The Federal Trade Commission this evening abruptly canceled a Tuesday morning meeting at which it had been expected to approve a venture by the General Motors Corporation and Japan's Toyota Motors Corporation to jointly produce a Japanese-designed subcompact car in California, officials at the agency said.

title: CUOMO STAYS OPEN TO SHOREHAM PLAN
description: Governor Cuomo said yesterday that if the Federal Government provided enough manpower and other resources New York State might participate in a plan to evacuate residents near the Shoreham nuclear power plant on Long Island, even if Suffolk County refuses to cooperate.

title: PREMIER INDUSTRIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
GERMAN IS CRITICAL OF LIMITS ON EUROPEAN USE OF SPACELAB
description: The first foreigner on a United States spaceship said today he was pleased with the scientific results of the latest Columbia mission. But he criticized the National Aeronautics and Space Administration for not letting the Europeans make greater use of Spacelab, which they built and donated.

title: History As Justice
description: Like history, justice is a uniquely human notion, so deeply rooted in the consciousness of mankind that its rejection is properly called inhuman. The recent rash of terrorism in the world is a reminder of the outrageous deformation that results, however, when the two are confounded.

title: Prices Steady For Eurobonds
description: Prices on the Eurobond market were steady in very quiet trading today.

title: GLENN TEAM FIGHTING WITH BACKS TO WALL IN NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: With Walter F. Mondale far ahead in local opinion polls and boasting a strong New Hampshire organization, Senator John Glenn is striving to avoid a damaging setback to his Presidential ambitions in the nation's first primary, nine weeks from now.

title: Grigori Alexandrov, 80, Dies; Was Director of Soviet Films
description: Grigori Alexandrov, a Soviet film director who worked with Sergei Eisenstein in the 1920's, has died at the age of 80, Tass, the Soviet press agency, said today.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: BellSouth Head To Retire April 1

title: Actor's Death Called Suicide After Telephone Call to Wife
description: Joseph Massengale, a stuntman and supporting actor, committed suicide while pleading on the phone with his estranged wife for a reconciliation, the authorities said today.

title: GENERAL INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
AMERICAN GREETINGS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
NEW STUDY POINTS TO CANCER GENE ACTION
description: ONE of the much studied cancer genes has proved to be so closely tied to the natural processes of cell growth that it can be turned on by the normal signals that govern cell division and reproduction, according to a new scientific report.

title: EMOTIONAL DEPRIVATION SEEN AS DEVASTATING FORM OF CHILD ABUSE
description: WHEN Judy hurts herself, she cowers in a corner of the classroom and cries. After a while, she sidles over to the teacher, gradually inching closer until she is almost on the teacher's lap. But she will destroy her work rather than ask the teacher for help, and she almost never plays or works with the other children.

title: FOR GIRLS AND BOYS
description: To the Editor:

title: Texas Loses 2 More
description: Two more players have quit the University of Texas basketball team, the second and third players to leave the team this month. Don Ellis , a senior, and Mike Hess , a freshman, both part-time starters, told Coach Bob Weltlich yesterday of their decisions.

description: To the Editor:

title: Chess: Karpov Captures First Place In Netherlands Tournament
description: Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union stretched his unbroken skein of triumphs to five in the Interpolis International Tournament series in Tilburg, the Netherlands, by once more taking first prize in the prestigious competition, which was being held this year for the seventh time.

title: 14 POISONINGS LAID TO EATING OF MUSHROOM
description: Fourteen Laotian refugees who ate a type of poisonous mushroom for which there is no known antidote remained in intensive care, hospital officials said today.

title: SCOUTING
description: Leonard Is Cool To Arum, King

title: Sony's Profit Off 35%
description: The Sony Corporation said today that fourth-quarter earnings rose to $54.2 million on sales of $1.28 billion. But profit for the year dropped 35 percent, to $127.3 million, on flat sales of $4.75 billion.

title: Allis-Chalmers Names A Chief Executive The Allis-Chalmers Corporation said yesterday that it had elected Wendell F. Bueche chief executive.
description: Mr. Bueche, 53, has been president and chief operating officer at the Milwaukee-based company since 1981, while Allis-Chalmers was going through difficult days.

description: T HE Bessemer Trust Company, which manages $3.3 billion for wealthy individuals and

title: END OF MOST TOOTH DECAY PREDICTED FOR NEAR FUTURE
description: PUBLIC health officials are predicting the virtual end of tooth decay among children and young adults by the turn of the century because of new developments in dental technology, the wider application of discoveries already made and the fluoridation of municipal water supplies.

title: LOWERY LEAVES POST AT CENTER FOR SEATTLE JOB
description: The executive director of the public corporation established to market and run New York City's new Convention Center has resigned.

title: RHODES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Bridge: Manfield Team Takes Title In Superlative Performance
description: Perhaps the best performance ever in New York by a team consisting of two mixed pairs occurred Sunday in the Knockout Team Championship of the Winter Regionals of the Greater New York Bridge Association.

title: West German Prices
description: Producer prices in West Germany rose two-tenths of 1 percent in November from October, and 1.4 percent from November 1982, the Federal Statistics Office said today. The year-to-year increase compared with a 1.2 percent rise in October and 1.5 percent in September.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. SAYS TV SHOWS GET POSITIVE RESPONSE SO FAR
description: An official of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. says preliminary research has found that both union and nonunion families were interested by a major effort by organized labor to present its message on television.

title: DOUGHERTY BROTHERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
SHOPPERS: HARRIED BUT CHIC
description: Holiday shoppers started earlier this year and bought more, according to the economic indexes. But still, as the countdown to Christmas approached, there were last-minute chores. By noon the fashionable shopping area around 57th Street and Fifth Avenue has been filled these last few days, enough to make people gridlock seem imminent.

title: Shell Canada Cut
description: Shell Canada Ltd. said its 1984 investment spending will total about $610 million (Canadian), down sharply from expected 1983 spending of about $865 million.

title: Charlotte Curtis The Mouse That Staggers
description: MAN has smashed the atom and stood on the moon, yet neither achievement even remotely resembles the challenge represented by the workings of what Dr. Gerald M. Edelman calls ''that most complex material on earth'' - the brain. And while scientists don't expect to find all the answers, the study of the brain goes on, a mysterious activity to most people, including some who fund the research.

title: TELESPHERE INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income.

title: YONKERS BOARD VOTES TO MEET BUDGET GAP BY SHUTTING SCHOOLS
description: The Yonkers Board of Education voted tonight to close public schools for three weeks in January to try to close a $12 million budget gap - a move that would lock the district's 20,000 students out of class.

title: Holmes Hires Ex-Trainer
description: Richie Giachetti, who for 10

title: U.S. AIDE IN GUATEMALA IS SAID TO HAVE FLED
description: A United States official investigating the slaying of a Guatemalan working in a United States-financed program has left Guatemala in ''fear for his life,'' an official for the Agency for International Development said today.

title: ISRAELI SHELLING CAUSES A DELAY IN ARAFAT'S EXIT
description: Israeli gunboats pounded the Tripoli harbor area today, and the planned evacuation of Yasir Arafat and 4,000 of his supporters who have been besieged here by Palestinian rebels for six weeks was put off for another day.

title: Sony Videodisk
description: The Sony Corporation will market its videodisk players for consumer use beginning next spring, a Sony official said, adding that it would offer the laser type of player that it has been producing for commercial use. The RCA Corporation has been a leading maker of videodisk machines.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: PERCENTAGES
description: With his challenge of the Democratic Party's delegate selection rules for 1984, the Rev. Jesse Jackson has been making life uncomfortable for Charles T. Manatt, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee.

title: NORDSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $336,000. The share earnings reflect 3-for-2 stock split to be paid Jan. 3.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Nets vs. Hawks , at Atlanta. The Nets won the only previous meeting between the clubs this season on opening night at the Meadowlands.

title: PACKERS DISMISS STARR AS COACH Bart Starr, the former quarterback of the Green Packers and their coach since 1975, was dismissed yesterday with his entire staff.
description: And Chuck Studley of the Houston Oilers resigned, saying that he did not want to ''sit around'' while club officials decided who would coach the team next season. He had replaced Ed Biles on an interim basis Oct. 10.

title: TV: FINAL INSTALLMENT OF 'VIETNAM'
description: ''Vietnam: a Television History'' presents its 13th and final installment tonight. It is called ''Legacies,'' the title suggesting, one supposes, the series's unwillingness to abandon neutrality and take a partisan point of view. Therefore, it is ''Legacies,'' not ''Lessons'' or ''Conclusions,'' and the suggestion that Vietnam is still too much with us for a neat summing up. The program will be seen on PBS.

title: BUSINESS OF CHRISTMAS FUELING THE ECONOMY
description: Holiday partying sharply increases the need for maids and bartenders, while a surge in shoplifting vastly improves the security guard business.

title: NAHAMA & WEAGANT ENERGY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income.

title: MANY DONORS TO THE NEEDIEST MOVED BY POVERTY THEY SEE
description: Moved by the poverty and distress they see around them, many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, New Yorkers and nonresidents alike, are starting what they hope will be a tradition of sharing with others less fortunate.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Abraham & Straus has promoted Chaim Edelstein, senior vice president of women's apparel, to executive vice president for all merchandise, effective Jan. 15. A. & S. has 15 stores in the metropolitan area.

title: Water Panel Will Lift Drought Curbs Today
description: A drought warning that limited the water New York and New Jersey take from the Delaware River will end Tuesday, officials have said.

title: CREIGHTON'S CENTER LEARNS TO LISTEN
description: Benoit Benjamin went home to Monroe, La., in Aug. 1982. He was home to see his mother, Carolyn, one last time before his life would really begin. He would soon be off for Creighton University, his choice out of the 300 schools that were eager to gain his acceptance. And then, beyond college? With his 7-foot size and his basketball skills, and with Willis Reed, his new coach, to point out a route to the riches of the National Basketball Association, it seemed that Benoit Benjamin's new world was prepared to offer anything he wanted.

title: STILL NEED SOME GIFT IDEAS?
description: WHAT do you give the consummate computerist for Christmas? A computer? He already has one of those. Besides, maybe you had in mind something a little less munificent. Software? That's not unlike buying a record for a hi-fi enthusiast. However, the problems are parallel. What if the individual already has the program you proffer? How do you know he or she will really like the package you've chosen? Well, here are a few last-minute add-ons and accouterments to dodge that problem.

title: ADVERTISING ; Living Anew Appoints An Editorial Director
description: Living Anew - The Magazine for Living On Your Own is scheduled for publication in the spring by the Lafayette Publishing Corporation, which was founded by Robert J. Lafayette, formerly of Parade Publications.

title: SANCTIONS: DO'S AND DONT'S
description: United States economic sanctions are still in vogue. They remain in force against Cuba, Poland, Libya and Nicaragua. Yet their record is checkered at best, and their misuse seems to have been growing rapidly in recent years.

title: Newman Wait Jr., President Of Bank in Saratoga Springs
description: Newman E. Wait Jr., president of the Adirondack Trust Company in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., died in a fire Sunday at his summer home in Lake George, N.Y. He was 61 years old and lived in Saratoga Springs.

title: Kuwait Creates Court To Try 10 in Bombing
description: Kuwait formed a state security court today to try 10 members of a Moslem fundamentalist group who were arrested in connection with the bombing of the United States and French Embassies last week, a Government spokesman said. They are to be tried within a week.

title: What 90 Cents Will Buy After all the speakers at public hearings denounced a New York transit fare increase, a reluctant majority of the M.T.A. board voted to raise the fare and most of its bridge and tunnel tolls by 20 percent. That will mean a 90-cent ride on city buses or subways.
description: The violent feelings of passengers on commuter trains - many of whom can escape into cars - held their increase slightly lower than predicted. But the figures in the M.T.A.'s 1984 budget speak louder than protesting voices. By law, the budget must be balanced. The Legislature's 1982 subsidies were known to carry the 75-cent fare only to the end of this year. The rest has to come from passengers.

description: To the Editor:

title: GREAT PACIFIC INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: SMALLEY GETTING A 5-YEAR PACT
description: George Steinbrenner took two steps last week that added evidence to the growing lore about his penchant for spending money: He dismissed Billy Martin with four years remaining on his five-year managerial contract and he approved a new five-year contract for Roy Smalley.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in some copies of Business Day Saturday about the Mobil Oil Corporation's settlement of a lawsuit by the State of Texas and a Texas rancher misstated the terms. Mobil will transfer most of its interests in a disputed oil and gas lease to an unidentified third party, who will make cash payments and other concessions to the plaintiffs.

title: U.S. Makes Sharp Cut In Its Aid to Zimbabwe
description: The Reagan Administration today sharply reduced economic aid to Zimbabwe, citing Congressional cuts in overall appropriations, according to Joseph W. Reap Jr., a State Department spokesman.

title: CHINA'S PREY, 'SPIRITUAL POLLUTION,' PROVES ELUSIVE
description: A visitor to a Peking municipal office was recently barred from entering because her hair touched her shoulders. The doorkeeper, in justification, pointed to a posted edict that said women who work in the office must not wear long hair, makeup or jewelry.

title: ASA LTD reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: Net income figures represent net investment income.

title: R. R. - FOUND IN 'ERROR'
description: Did you know that Trident missiles are recallable, that Leonid I. Brezhnev invented the nuclear freeze idea, that sex education leads to veneral disease and that there's more oil in Alaska than Saudi Arabia? You didn't. Good for you. Because all these statements are untrue, yet were made by Ronald Reagan.

title: HACIENDA RESORTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ARGENTINE UNIONS CRITICIZE ALFONSIN
description: President Raul Alfonsin faced his first major political battle today as leaders of most of Argentina's powerful unions condemned the size of a Government wage increase and legislation calling for union elections.

title: Wolverine Sale
description: A management group of the Wolverine Aluminum Corporation, led by the company's president, Gregory Smith, said it had agreed to acquire the company for $26 a share. Based on about 1.3 million shares outstanding, the transaction has an indicated value of about $34 million. Mr. Smith said he had reached an agreement with the Synalloy Corporation, a metal fabricator; the Worldmark Corporation, and Barry Cohen, a New York investor, to merge Wolverine with a new company to be owned by the four parties.

title: GREECE AND RUMANIA IN APPEAL
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou of Greece and President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania made a joint appeal to the United States and the Soviet Union today to suspend the deployment of nuclear missiles in Europe and return to the negotiating table.

title: 2 MCA Executives Resign
description: A shakeup at MCA-Universal affected two more executives today when Robert Rehme resigned as president of the motion picture group and Charles Glenn, a vice president in publicity, departed. MCA announced the resignations. Thom Mount recently resigned as MCA's president of worldwide film production.

title: PUBLISHER RULES OUT REISSUING HUTTON BOOK
description: Random House said yesterday that it would not reissue ''Poor Little Rich Girl: The Life and Legend of Barbara Hutton'' by C. David Heymann, the book it recalled last week because it contained errors about a Beverly Hills doctor.

description: b-Net loss c-After an extraordinary tax loss of $9,778. d-After an extraordinary tax benefit of $28,060.

description: The slugging first baseman Willie Aikens admitted today that he was addicted to illegal drugs during the 1983 season to such an extent that he often did not care whether his team won or lost.

Central Maine Power Fills Top Officer Post John W. Rowe, a 38-year-old lawyer from the Middle West, will take over as president and chief executive of the Central Maine Power Company on Jan. 9. He will fill the post occupied since last August by Charles E. Monty, 55, a career executive with Central Maine Power for more than 30 years.
description: Mr. Monty, a director and vice president of the utility since 1971, assumed the post of interim president last August when E. W. Thurlow took early retirement at age 59, after the Maine Public Utilities Commission proposed that the utility be held in criminal contempt for a 1982 incident in which false testimony was given to the commission by one of the utility's executives.

title: SALE OF SITE TO HOMOSEXUALS PLANNED
description: A city-owned building would be offered for sale to the Lesbian and Gay Community Services Center for use as a health, counseling and social facility, under a tentative agreement announced yesterday by city officials.

description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, has reached the midpoint of his first term. He has gained a reputation for dealing with such local issues as transit, housing and Federal grants to communities.

title: Laos to Allow a U.S. Group To Look for American Dead
description: Laos has agreed to allow a United States Government team into the country to examine the site of an air crash for the bodies of American servicemen, the State Department said today.

The department also said it had given the Boeing Vertol Company, a unit of the Boeing Company, a $62.2 million contract for helicopters for the Army.

description: Barely 13 months after Yuri V. Andropov took power in the Kremlin with a vow to get the Soviet economy moving, the country is heading for the best year in industry and agriculture that it has had since 1978.

title: MOSCOW'S MIDEAST VIEWPOINT
description: Many Americans are tiring of the Reagan Administration's rhetoric, which weaves events in Grenada and in Lebanon and the downing of the South Korean jetliner into a tapestry of conspiracy made-in-Moscow, and insists that our Marines in Beirut are holding the line against Soviet-backed aggression throughout the Middle East.

title: Defense Plant Explosion In Arkansas Injures 18
description: An explosion and fire today at a plant that manufactures military wares injured 18 people, including five severely burned in the magnesium flash, the authorities said.

description: Czechoslovakia defeated Canada today, 4-2, in the Izvestia international hockey tournament. Yaroslav Benak scored twice for the winners.

title: ARCHITECTURE: A LOUIS SULLIVAN JEWEL RESCUED
description: The buildings of Louis Sullivan, the architect who more than any other led the struggle to give form to the American skyscraper, have been an anachronistic presence in many cities. Chicago, Sullivan's home, tore down his Stock Exchange. St. Louis saved his Wainwright Building, but turned it into state offices and altered it dramatically. And for years Buffalo watched with indifference as what may be Sullivan's greatest commercial building, the Guaranty, slipped into emptiness and dereliction.

title: U.N. DENOUNCES U.S.-ISRAEL PACT

description: Apple Polishing

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Love Story

title: Missile Crashes Into Pacific
description: A Navy Tomahawk cruise missile crashed into the Pacific Ocean Sunday after launching on a test flight from a destroyer off southern California, officials said. The failure was the first since last March and broke a string of 12 successful sea launchings.

title: GENERALS NAMING MICHAELS TODAY
description: After many days of rumor, speculation and reports more well-founded, the Generals are finally ready to announce today the appointment of Walt Michaels as coach.

title: KOREA JET REPORT DENIES SOVIET PLEA
description: Unless the Soviet Union can come up with some strong new evidence, the International Civil Aviation Organization is not expected to change its preliminary conclusion that the shooting down of a South Korean airliner Sept. 1 was unjustified, aviation officials said.

title: SCIENCE WATCH
description: The Mobile Caddis Fly

title: BOK ASSAILS EASY DEGREES FOR COLLEGE ATHLETES
description: IF a college hands out degrees without requiring any academic effort,

title: TV: 'THE GIFT OF LOVE,' FILM ON CBS
description: ''THE GIFT OF LOVE,'' a made-for-television movie on CBS, is subtitled ''A Christmas Story'' and, not surprisingly, it is unabashedly sentimental. The movie - which will be shown at approximately 9:30 tonight, depending on the length of President Reagan's news conference - is described by the network as an ''uplifting drama about an embattled woman who discovers that the power of love can help overcome the most despairing experience.'' That's only the half of it.

title: STRESS, AND HOW TO DEAL WITH IT, IS A PART OF COACHING
description: Two days after he was dismissed as football coach at Louisiana State, Jerry Stovall fell asleep on the couch while watching a professional game on television.

title: PLAGUE OF FIRES OVER NATION BRINGS 21 DEATHS IN 48 HOURS
description: Fires struck rural homes in Texas and Ohio yesterday, killing six people, five of them children, and bringing to 21 the death toll in a 48-hour national plague of fires in homes, apartments, house trailers and a hotel.

title: JAPANESE EXPECT LITTLE SHIFT IN ECONOMY BECAUSE OF VOTE
description: Economists and Government officials said today that the ruling Liberal Democrats' setback in the election Sunday appeared likely to result in a slightly more stimulative economic policy and to slow progress on resolving trade conflicts with Western nations.

title: INJURED MARINE WELCOMED LIKE GENERAL IN HOMETOWN
description: When the Mayor heard that Lance Cpl. Jeffery Nashton, a survivor of the truck bombing of the Marine compound in Lebanon, was coming home for Christmas, he knew right away that this small upstate town had to do something. He just wasn't sure what.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Swiss Accuse Italy Of Violating Sovereignty
description: Switzerland accused Italy today of repeatedly violating its sovereignty by conducting unauthorized criminal investigations on Swiss territory.

title: ELECTRONIC 'POLLUTION' PLAYS HAVOC WITH MODREN DEVICE
description: S By JOHN HOLUSHA

title: DWG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $864,000 for the quarter and 6 months and a realized gain of $4 million for the quarter on sales of marketable securities, net of income taxes, minority interest and unrealized losses. c-Including $3 million of realized gains and recovery of unrealized losses on marketable securities, net of income taxes and minority interest. d-Including a realized gain of $1.2 million on sales of marketable securities, net of income tazes, minority interest and unrealized losses.

title: Sullivan Nominees
description: Ten athletes were nominated Monday by the Amateur Athletic Union for the James E. Sullivan Award, given to the outstanding amateur athlete in the United States.

title: Derailment in California
description: About 20 cars on a Southern Pacific freight train heading for southern California from Seattle derailed Sunday, causing no injuries but forcing a detour and long delay for Amtrak passenger trains. The line said the derailment and detour would add anywhere ''from four to 10 or 12 hours'' to the travel time for Amtrak's Pacific Coast passengers.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Interest Rates Drop Modestly
description: Interest rates declined modestly yesterday in extremely light trading.

title: Steel Output Up 1.5% By The Associated Press
description: Steel production rose to 1.72 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, an increase of 1.5 percent from the previous week's 1.69 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute said yesterday. The industry's production amounted to 59.5 percent of capacity during the week, up from 58.6 percent in the previous week.

title: UNIMED INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: The company said that included in the fiscal 1983 net was income of $3.5 million from the sale of certain trademarks and marketing rights.

title: 2 Bulgarian Judges End Visit To Rome in the Papal Case
description: Two Bulgarian judges who questioned Mehmet Ali Agca, the man who shot Pope John Paul II, returned home today after two weeks here, officials said.

title: KENAI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income including $611,000, or 13 cents a share, from the cumulative effect on prior years of a change in depreciation methods. Revenues have been restated to reflect discontinued businesses.

title: CORRECTION
description: A table by The Associated Press, published on Saturday with an article about subway, bus and commuter rail fares, included erroneous information about the Harlem and Hudson rail lines. A corrected table appears today on page B9.

title: PAPER MILL IS FINED AFTER WORKERS TAMPER WITH STATE POLLUTION TEST
description: The Boise Cascade Corporation has paid $100,000 to the Minnesota Pollution Control Agency because of three employees who, the concern said, tampered with a state test of waste water from the corporation's paper mill in International Falls. The employees were dismissed.

title: Starts Rise In Housing By The Associated Press
description: Housing starts climbed 67 percent in the third quarter from the period a year ago, when mortgage rates were close to record highs, F. W. Dodge said yesterday.

title: ADVERTISING ; Gold Star Electronics Picks TBWA Agency
description: TBWA Advertising has been named to do advertising for Gold Star Electronics International, a subsidiary of a Korean company that makes consumer audio and video equipment as well as kitchen appliances.

title: Nuclear Follies in Tennessee An unresolved dispute between two Federal agencies is making both nuclear fuel and electricity more expensive. President Reagan, who promised to get Government off the citizen's back and to help revive the nuclear industry, could do both at once by ending this ridiculous impasse.
description: The dispute concerns electricity that the Department of Energy ordered from the Tennessee Valley Authority to run the uranium enrichment plant at Oak Ridge. The department grossly overestimated demand for the nuclear fuel. Nonetheless, it must still pay ''demand charges'' for the electricity it ordered but no longer needs. The charges will total $1.23 billion over the next decade, significantly raising the cost of enriched uranium to utilities.

title: Brazil Paying Some Interest
description: Brazil is paying commercial banks about $540 million of overdue interest on its foreign debt, American banking sources said today.

title: G.S.A. Chief Shifting Jobs
description: Gerald Carmen, chief of the General Services Administration, is leaving his position and is likely to be named the United States delegate to the United Nations office in Geneva, a White House official said today. Mr. Carmen, 53 years old, played a key role in President Reagan's 1980 Presidential campaign victory in New Hampshire. The G.S.A. is the Federal agency that provides Government supplies and operates Federal buildings.

title: Retirement at Blue Bell
description: Blue Bell Inc., a maker of jeans and other clothing, said yesterday that its chairman, L. Kimsey Mann, planned to retire Feb. 1. Mr. Mann has been with the Greensboro, N.C., company for 37 years. Blue Bell did not immediately name a replacement.

title: Pirates Sign Otis
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates need help in the outfield after the recent departures of Dave Parker and Mike Easler , and yesterday they moved to strengthen that position by signing Amos Otis , a free agent, to a one-year contract. Otis, 36 years old and a right-handed batter, hit .261, with four home runs, and drove in 41 runs in 98 games with the Kansas City Royals last season.

title: SYNBIOTICS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
description: $318 Million of Bonds Priced for Puerto Rico

title: Union to Aid G.M. on Car
description: The United Automobile Workers

title: SMITH LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a loss of $325,000 for the quarter from the early retirement of long-term debt and a tax credit of $3,831,000 for the year. c-Comparable year-ago results are not available because the company was in a development stage until November 1982.

title: POLAND SHOWING 'DAY AFTER'
description: ''The Day After,'' the ABC-TV film about the aftermath of nuclear war, is scheduled to be broadcast on national television in Poland tonight - the first time the film has been shown in a Soviet-bloc country - the film's distributor said yesterday.

title: Dow Up 2.44, to 1,244.61; Volume Off
description: Stock prices closed mixed yesterday as year-end sales for tax losses diminished and bargain-hunting increased.

title: Princess Caroline to Wed
description: Princess Caroline of Monaco will marry an Italian businessman, Stefano Casiraghi, on Dec. 29, her father, Prince Rainier III, announced today.

title: STAGE: 'PARADISE LOST' BY CLIFFORD ODETS REVIVED
description: Soliloquies are seldom heard these days and nights in the theater, possibly because modern playwrights fear that they will be accused of making large, nondramatic statements. Understatement is more in style.

title: KIT MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income.

title: 6 RELIGIOUS GROUPS BANNED BY SYRIA
description: Syria has banned six religious societies that the Government said had been engaged in illegal political activities, a senior Syrian official said today.

title: The Worm and the Apple; Bronco City
description: Why not privatize New York City's streets? Deregulation to favor private market forces seems to be the fashionable remedy for every other transport problem. And nothing else seems to be working to improve the condition of the roadways.

title: BIG BOARD'S CHOICE AS CHIEF
description: John J. Phelan Jr., a second-generation trader who helped to bring modern electronics to the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, was nominated yesterday to be the new chairman and chief executive of the Big Board.

title: DeadlineforJersey On Redistricting
description: A Federal court panel said today that if the New Jersey Legislature and Governor Kean could not agree on boundaries for the state's 14 Congressional districts by Feb. 3, the judges would decide the issue.

title: Indiana Man Convicted Of Killing Father-in-Law
description: A 35-year-old man was convicted today of murdering his father-in-law and cutting up the body, which was found in garbage bags along the Lake Michigan shoreline.

title: VW Sees a Loss
description: Volkswagenwerk A.G. predicted that it will post a group loss of about 300 million marks, or about $108 million, in 1983, but said it may return to profitability in the new year. The company lost 300 million marks in 1982 and reported a 147-million-mark deficit in the first half of this year.

title: OCEANEERING INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: b-Net income.

title: ADVERTISING ;  People
description: * Gerry Linda named senior vice president, director of business and human resource development at Marsteller Inc., Chicago.

title: Australian Resigns After Agents' Hotel Raid
description: A raid on a hotel by men wearing clown masks may have toppled the head of the Australian Secret Intelligence Service.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Socks Spiel

title: RICHARD C. KLEIN
description: Richard C. Klein, former co-publisher, with his brother, of seven weekly newspapers in Monmouth and Ocean Counties, died of a heart attack Sunday at the Monmouth Medical Center in Long Branch, N.J. He was 67 years old and lived in Allenhurst, N.J.

title: 49ers TROUNCE COWBOYS, 42-17
description: The National Football League's playoff picture took its final form tonight as the San Francisco 49ers routed the Dallas Cowboys, 42-17, to win the Western Division of the National Conference in the last game of the regular season.

title: SALVADOR'S WAR ON COMMUNISM IS NO 'MADNESS'
description: To the Editor:

title: Princess Rooney Is 2d
description: Princess Rooney, once considered a superstar after winning the first 10 starts of her career, struggled home second tonight in an allowance race at Meadowlands Race Track.

title: SOUTHERN HOSPITALITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
VICORP RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
Key Rates
description: * Nuveen index, John Nuveen & Company Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SCIENCE WATCH
description: Britons Dig for Steam

title: U.S. 'EXPECTS' ISRAEL TO STOP HINDERING ARAFAT EVACUATION
description: The United States said today that it had told Israel that it ''hopes and expects'' the Shamir Government will halt its military actions around Tripoli and allow Yasir Arafat and his Palestine Liberation Organization fighters to be evacuated from the city.

title: Hipple Sidelined
description: Eric Hipple , the Detroit Lions' starting quarterback, will miss the team's first playoff game Dec. 31 because of an injury to his left knee.

title: GIFT BASKETS FOR ALL SEASONS
description: A green and yellow basket, a black and white basket or just about any color basket may be ordered from a new gift service called A Tisket a Tasket.

title: HUNGER AS AN AMERICAN REALITY
description: To the Editor:

title: JAPAN'S TOP PARTY CLINGS TO POWER DESPITE HUGE LOSS
description: The ruling Liberal Democratic Party, which lost its majority in the lower house of Parliament in elections Sunday, clung to power tonight with eight independent legislators joining it to give it a three- seat majority.

title: MCDONNELL, TYMSHARE END TALKS
description: Tymshare Inc., operator of one of the nation's largest data transmission networks, announced yesterday that it had ended talks with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation on the companies' earlier plans to merge. McDonnell was to take over Tymshare for $378 million in cash.

title: 50 Evacuated in L.I. Fire
description: A fire heavily damaged a block of shops last night in Bethpage, L.I., forcing the evacuation of more than 50 people from apartments above the stores and halting service on the Long Island Rail Road's Hicksville line as firefighters stretched hoses across the tracks to fight the blaze. The Nassau County police said 10 fire departments fought the fire, reported at 10:15 P.M. at Broadway and Baldwin Place. The police said one person had been taken to the Nassau County Medical Center in East Meadow, but it was not known whether the victim was a firefighter.

title: No Headline
description: The Enserch Corporation said it expects to charge $14 million against 1983 earnings. Enserch, a diversified energy concern, said the charge will result from its early application of a Securities and Exchange Commission accounting rule relating to oil and gas exploration costs. The company estimated that 1983 earnings will be less than $1.60 a share; last year, it earned $2.70 a share.

title: 400 JERSEY TROOPERS PLAN HOLIDAY CHECK ON DRUNKEN DRIVERS
description: Governor Kean said today that 400 state troopers would begin special patrols Wednesday in a holiday campaign against drivers who drink.

title: VALLEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
RAMPAC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
BECKER IS FINED BY BIG BOARD
description: A.G. Becker Paribas Inc., one of Wall Street's major investment banks, has been fined $300,000 by the New York Stock Exchange - the second-largest fine in exchange history.

title: Helms an Issue in Holtz Move
description: Lou Holtz, who on Sunday resigned as the Arkansas football coach, said today that his decision had been prompted by personal reasons that he would not discuss.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE ;
description: JAZZ Jazz, one of the most enduring of musical institutions to be found in Manhattan, is played mostly in the most ephemeral of New York places, the nightclub. Clubs come and go, they change names and owners. The natural habitat of nightclubs has been Greenwich Village, and it is there that the Village Vanguard, the most permanent club of its kind, still operates, one short flight down at 178 Seventh Avenue South, near West 11th Street (AL 5-4037), under the aegis of its founder, the equally durable Max Gordon.

title: ADVERTISING ; Mickelberry Planning Acquisition of Ventura
description: The Mickelberry Corporation, a publicly held company composed of three ad agencies, has entered into an arrangement with Ventura Associates, a sales promotion agency with some $35 million in annual billings, that could lead to the acquisition of Ventura.

title: ALLNET COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Allnet Communications Services Inc. was formerly named Combined Network Inc.

title: HOUSE STUDY FINDS OFFICERS AT FAULT IN BEIRUT BOMBING
description: The House subcommittee that investigated the truck bombing of the Marine compound in Beirut has concluded that ''very serious errors in judgment'' by officers on the ground and up through the chain of command had left the marines vulnerable to attack.

title: Broadcast by Reagan Is Scheduled Tonight
description: President Reagan will conduct a news conference at 8 o'clock tonight in Washington.

title: LIABILITY PROPOSAL FOR NUCLEAR ACCIDENTS
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission recommended today that Congress remove the limit on how much the nuclear industry might have to pay victims of an accident at a reactor. Current Federal law limits the liability to $570 million.

title: JUSTICE OFFICIAL IN PUERTO RICO RESIGNS IN RIFT
description: The crisis within the Administration of Gov. Carlos Romero Barcelo over revelations that the police may have killed two suspected terrorists while they were begging for mercy deepened today with the resignation of the Cabinet's third Secretary of Justice in five months.

title: VLI Toxic Case
description: The VLI Corporation said the Food and Drug Administration had received reports of one confirmed and one possible case of toxic shock syndrome in users of VLI's Today contraceptive sponge. The company, based in Irvine, Calif., said that the F.D.A. would step up its monitoring of the product and that VLI would change the information provided with the product to ''more clearly alert consumers to the symptoms of toxic shock.''

title: L.S.U. Overcomes Houston Baptist
description: Leonard Mitchell's rebound basket with 18 seconds to play enabled Louisiana State to escape with a 60-59 victory over Houston Baptist tonight.

title: CARHART PHOTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

$65.2 Million Issue For Mobile, Ala. A $65.2 million Mobile, Ala., general obligation refunding warrant issue was tenatively priced with yields ranging from 5.75 percent to 11 percent yesterday by E. F. Hutton.
