description: The issue was rated A by Moody's and triple-A by S.& P. The issue is insured by the Municipal Bond Insurance Association on all maturities except for the term warrants due in 2007.

title: 2 Companies Buy 7.9% of Castle Two companies disclosed in a joint Securities and Exchange Commission filing that they had purchased 7.9 percent of the stock of Castle & Cooke Inc., the food-products concern based in Honolulu that is trying to buy the Dr Pepper Company. The United Financial Corporation of Houston said it had bought 4.1 percent of Castle & Cooke, while MCO Holdings Inc. of Los Angeles said it owns 3.8 p rcent. The two companies said the stock position was for investment purposes, but added that they might buy more and might meet with Castle & Cooke's management.
description: United Financial is owned by the United Savings Association of Texas, a thrift institution with 90 branches and assets of $3.3 billion.

title: CHINA'S LUXURY HOTEL BOOM
description: The Great Wall Hotel borrowed its name from China's ancient landmark and there the similarity ends. The operators of the new 22-story building, its exterior sheathed in reflective glass, say it is China's most modern hotel, which is hardly an exaggeration considering the state of hotels in this country.

title: No Headline
description: ENEMIES OF PROMISE. By Cyril Connolly. 265 pages. Persea Books. $6.95, paperback.

title: VAST SHIFT SEEN IN U.S. GRANTS TO STATES AND MUNICIPALITIES
description: There has been a major change under the Reagan Administration in both the regional distribution of Federal grants to state and local governments and the purposes for which the money can be used, according to a new study.

title: SOME BIRDS, AT LEAST, AREN'T NECESSARILY BORN NAVIGATORS
description: THE magnetic compass sense of some migratory birds is innate. But their ability to use the stars and other celestial signs to help them find their way is learned, experiments in Sweden suggest.

title: Whittaker Net Climbs 67.5%
description: The Whittaker Corporation

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: More on the Tower . . .

title: Debt Issues
description: * Echlin Inc., a Branford, Conn., automotive parts manufacturer, filed a shelf registration for $100 million of debt securities, to be sold from time to time with terms set at the time of sale.

title: FRANCES QUINN O'NEILL
description: Frances Quinn O'Neill, the mother of Gov. William A. O'Neill, died today.

title: CRIME RISES IN A DARKENED WASHINGTON SQ. PARK
description: They come from Brooklyn and the Bronx every afternoon to conduct their business each night in the dark of Washington Square Park.

title: Tomlinson Debt
description: The Tomlinson Oil Company said it is seeking to restructure its loan obligations with its lender bank and that, if negotiations are not successful, it may seek Chapter 11 protection from its creditors. Tomlinson, an oil and gas exploration concern, said it is experiencing a severe and continuing cash flow problem and that it expects to be in default on its secured obligations to the Mellon Bank in a matter of weeks.

title: Superior Oil Proxy Bid
description: Howard Keck, former chairman of the Superior Oil Company, said yesterday in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that his efforts to block a company plan to issue new convertible preferred stock had become largely moot. He said he was ending further active efforts to solicit proxies against the plan because the company had abandoned the proposal. Mr. Keck had contended that the cost of the dividend to be paid on the issue of stock would thwart potential takeover bids.

title: BirdsWorth$5,000 Stolen From Zoo
description: Twelve birds worth about $5,000, including a scarlet macaw worth $2,500, were stolen from the Prospect Park Zoo in Brooklyn early yesterday, authorities said.

title: Avalanche Kills Patrolman
description: An avalanche Sunday killed a 28-year-old ski patrolman at the Copper Mountain ski area. It was the first avalanche death in Colorado this winter. A spokesman said that the victim, Mickey Johnston, was skiing with five other patrolmen doing avalanche control work outside the boundaries of the ski area when he was caught in the slide.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: IN the world of fashion retail, at

title: Nebraska Home Bonds Priced A preliminary price was set for $58.72 million of Nebraska Investment Finance Authority single- family mortgage revenue bonds yesterday by E. F. Hutton. The yields ranged from 6.50 percent to 9.90 percent.
description: The issue had serial bonds maturing from 1985 through 1996. The serial bonds due in 1985 were priced at par to yield 6.50 percent.

title: CPI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 12
AMERICAN RANCHER IN HONDURAS FUROR
description: Temistocles Ramirez de Arellano came to this remote corner of Honduras from his native Puerto Rico 23 years ago and has been working hard ever since to build out of jungle land and seacoast a $13 million meat and shrimp packing business. For the last six months he has been fighting to save his land and livelihood from an encroaching American- built military base.

title: COPING WITH NEW COMPUTERS
description: Marlene Lassberg, an account executive for Merrill Lynch in Dallas, keeps two computers on her desk: her old Radio Shack machine and her new I.B.M. She still cannot make the new machine do everything the old one did.

title: FAITH AND FATALISM MIX IN SECURITY-WARY CAPITAL
description: As on every morning this Christmas season, Rita Warren set up her large plastic figures of the Nativity scene on the windswept steps of the Capitol today, but only after the police had upended the figures of Mary, Joseph and the three kings to check inside for hidden explosives.

title: HARDING CARPETS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $399,756. c-Net losses. d-Including a gain of $1,475,593 on the sale of property and tax credits.

title: FARAH MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $1,428,000 for the quarter and $6,258,000 for the year. c-Including extraordinary gains of $3,179,000 for the quarter and $5,156,000 for the year.

title: Mayor of Atlantic City Meets U.S. Prosecutors
description: Mayor Michael Matthews of Atlantic City met with Federal prosecutors in Camden today amid speculation he might resign.

title: Turkish Leader Offers Friendship to Greece
description: Prime Minister Turgut Ozal, outlining the program of his newly formed Government today, said that Turkey was extending its ''hand of friendship towards Greece'' and expressed hope that longstanding problems between the two countries would be solved in time ''through peaceful means.''

title: ENZO BIOCHEM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $257,000.

title: CONCERT: MARILYN HORNE OFFERS VARIED PROGRAM
description: ASINGLE voice has two ways of commanding a hall the size of the Metropolitan Opera House. There is conquest by sheer volume; or else one can persuade the space itself to contract, causing 4,000 seats to shrink until they seem like 400. Marilyn Horne's recital at the Met Sunday evening did a little of both.

title: BRIEFING
description: Seeking Stamp of Approval

title: TEMCO SERVICE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $3,906 for the quarter and $16,956 for the year. c-Including extraordinary tax credits of $26,100 for the quarter and $41,100 for the year.

title: 3 Estonians Sentenced
description: Three dissidents in Soviet Estonia have been sentenced to terms of up to six years in labor camps by the Supreme Court in Tallinn for anti-Soviet activities, the Aid Center for Political Prisoners in Estonia said today. The prosecution said the three had signed appeals and protests with anti-Soviet content, including an open letter to Soviet and Scandinavian leaders on a nuclear-free zone in northern Europe, and a con gratulatory telegram to Lech Walesa.

title: UNLIKELY THREAT TO PORTUGUESE DEMOCRACY
description: To the Editor:

title: UPTURN IN THE AUTOMOBILE INDUSTRY EXCITES ST. LOUIS
description: The recent upturn in the nation's automotive industry has caused a wave of excitement here that ripples from City Hall to union halls.

title: FATIGUES TOO HOT, SOLDIERS COMPLAIN
description: The Army is going ahead with the purchase of more than $400 million worth of new camouflage battle-dress uniforms despite widespread complaints, particularly from the Grenada invasion force, that the uniforms are too hot and heavy.

title: Increase in Draft Registration
description: The shooting down of a South Korean jetliner by the Soviet Union, the bombing of the Marine Corps headquarters in Beirut and the invasion of Grenada coincided with sharp increases in draft registrations, Selective Service System figures show.

title: MIDEAST OIL STATES CUT BANK FUNDS
description: Weak oil prices and a resulting decline in revenues for Saudi Arabia and other Middle Eastern oil producers are forcing those nations to withdraw cash from Western banks at an accelerating pace, the Bank for International Settlements reported today.

title: General Mills' Net Off 12.2%
description: General Mills Inc. said yesterday that its profits for the

title: BLUE GETS 3 MONTHS ON COCAINE CHARGES
description: Vida Blue, one of baseball's top pitchers in the 1970's, was ordered today to spend three months in prison and to pay a $5,000 fine for possession of about a tenth of an ounce of cocaine, a Federal misdemeanor. The 34-year-old former star will also be on probation two years.

title: Connors Wins
description: Jimmy

title: DR. WILLIAM REINMUTH
description: Dr. William H. Reinmuth, a professor of chemistry at Columbia University and coordinator of its general chemistry course, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Manhattan.

title: SALVADOR ARREST REPORTED IN KILLING OF AMERICANS
description: The national police were reported to have arrested a Salvadoran Army captain today in connection with the 1981 slayings of two United States land- redistribution advisers.

title: DILEMMA FOR CBS OVER LOUISVILLE GAME
description: Just over a week ago, CBS Sports officials could

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Diversion for the Homeless

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 20, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Auto Safety Group Files Suit Over 'Crumbling' U.S. Bridges
description: A private group that watches automobile safety sued the Government today, charging that motorists were endangered by ''tens of thousands of crumbling, outdated bridges'' around America.

title: MRS. REAGAN PAYS A CALL ON CHILDREN IN HOSPITAL
description: They hugged and kissed on the floor at the foot of the Christmas tree as they unwrapped shiny packages tied with silver-and-gold ribbon.

title: FULL POLICE POWERS URGED FOR E.P.A. LAW ENFORCERS
description: Law enforcement officials from Pennsylvania and New Jersey testified before a House subcommittee today in favor of the Environmental Protection Agency's request for full police authority and the right to carry arms for its criminal investigators.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: . . . And the Caviar War

title: ISRAEL'S SECURITY CITED IN BOMBING
description: Lax security was partly responsible for the success of last month's suicide bombing of an Israeli military compound in Tyre, Lebanon, according to an Israeli Army report issued today.

title: THE PERILS OF WINTER PROVE RIFE
description: Another small plane went down over the Rockies last week. It was carrying three people from Denver to a funeral in Salt Lake City. The wreckage has not been found, and its passengers are presumed to be dead.

title: HOWARD UNIVERSITY DEAN NAMED PRESIDENT OF MEDGAR EVERS COLLEGE
description: Dr. Jay Carrington Chunn 2d was named president of Medgar Evers College in Brooklyn yesterday by the board of trustees of the City University, ending a yearlong search to find a leader for the most troubled campus in the 18-unit system.

title: CONCERT: GRANDE BANDE AND BOYCHOIR
description: CHRISTMAS has a way of nourishing our sense of the past, and Saturday night's collaboration of the Grande Bande chamber orchestra and the American Boychoir at Alice Tully Hall celebrated the season as Christians of the Baroque might have done. To begin, Frederick Renz conducted his small ensemble of period instruments in Corelli's familiar ''Christmas'' Concerto and then joined his excellent soloist, David Hart, in a Pergolesi Concerto for Transverse Flute.

title: COLD, SORROW AT KOTAR RITES
description: In front of the Kotar family's tan brick house on a quiet street in the village of Muse, a few miles from here, there is a cardboard cutout of Santa Claus and four reindeer. On the windows are other Christmas decorations, and there is a tree inside. Christmas is just a few days away, but this morning, a cold morning here, the activity had nothing to do with the holiday season.

title: Mississippi Governor Rejects University Job
description: Outgoing Gov. William Winter withdrew today from the University of Mississippi chancellorship he had accepted last week, but he declined to say whether that meant he would be a candidate for the United States Senate next year.

title: A Quake Made in Japan The sharp electoral setback to Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party speaks more to that nation's domestic problems than its foreign affairs. Relations with the United States and the Western alliance were insignificant issues in the campaign and may not be much altered by it.
description: The Liberals are in fact a conservative party and have ruled Japan since 1955. Their popular vote Sunday was only slightly less than usual. But opposition groups pooled their strength and took the largest number of seats ever from the Liberals - who lost their majority in the House of Representatives, the dominant chamber of the Diet.

title: WHITTAKER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
U.S. KEPT AS DEFENDANT IN AGENT ORANGE SUIT
description: A Federal district judge in Brooklyn refused to exempt the Government yesterday from being a party in the lawsuit by Vietnam War veterans against makers of the herbicide Agent Orange.

title: GOLDIN URGES TRANSFER OF 457 SANITATION DEPT. JOBS TO CIVILIANS
description: New York City streets could be cleaner or its municipal treasury fatter if the Sanitation Department used civilian employees for 457 jobs now being done by uniformed sanitation workers, the City Comptroller's office said yesterday.

title: Wigan to Honor Orwell With Pier Renovation
description: The bleak industrial town of Wigan plans to erect a memorial to George Orwell during 1984 and refurbish the drab pier that the writer made world-famous.

title: POP: CYNDI LAUPER SINGS WITH A BAND
description: ONE of the year's most heavily promoted female pop personalities, Cyndi Lauper is a singer with considerable drive and theatricality and a flamboyantly exotic appeal. Miss Lauper, who was born in Brooklyn, used to lead a group called Blue Angel.

title: ADVERTISING ; GTE Starts Campaign For Mobile Telephone
description: Is it beginning to seem that the major beneficiaries of the A.T.& T. breakup and communications deregulation are ad agencies and the advertising media?

title: INDEX FUTURES PROPOSAL STIRS BATTLE
description: A plan by the Chicago Mercantile Exchange to offer new stock-index futures contracts in energy, high-technology and utility stocks has touched off a bitter turf battle involving the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission and a Congressional committee.

title: EASY ON THE CONCRETE
description: Washington's response to the present spate of terror bombings is the concrete barricade. I imagine the bombing community is pleased. Commanding only old-fashioned T.N.T. and a handful of fanatics, they see concete evidence that they can bully a thermonuclear superpower. A mighty nation crouches behind concrete barricades.

title: ISRAELI DESCRIBES TACTICS IN TRIPOLI
description: An Israeli Defense Ministry official said tonight that the order to permit the evacuation of Yasir Arafat and his guerrilla supporters from the Lebanese port of Tripoli had been given only after the Greek transport ships and their French escorts were on their way there.

title: Pillsbury Net Up 70%
description: The Pillsbury Company said today that its second-quarter profit soared 70 percent, to $52.1 million, or $1.20 a share, from $30.7 million, or 71 cents a share, a year earlier. Pillsbury, a consumer foods and restaurant concern, said sales for the quarter, ended Nov. 30, climbed to $1.124 billion, from $986 million.

title: STARTS RISE IN HOUSING BY 6.4%
description: Construction of new housing rose by 6.4 percent last month, rebounding from a two-month decline and putting such building activity 29 percent above the period a year ago, the Commerce Department said today.

title: INTELEPLEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MORE ON ALZHEIMER'S
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:In response to the ''Personal Health'' article addressing ''Guidance for those caring for patients with Alzheimer's'' (Nov. 30), I was pleased to see acknowledgement made of the burden of care placed on the family members. Even going to the supermarket can be an impossible task.

title: Q & A
description: Q.

title: Man Jailed in Infant's Death
description: A man who put his 2-month-old daughter in a dresser drawer because she was crying, then closed it and let her suffocate, has been sentenced to five years in prison. The man, Steven Holt Green, 23, was sentenced Monday in Broward Circuit Court for manslaughter in the death of Rachel Stephanie Paulin on April 5. He pleaded guilty in October.

title: REAGAN SAYS MARINES IN LEBANON ARE TRYING TO PROVIDE 'STABILITY'
description: Transcript of news session, page A22.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: WE'VE all been taught that it's the thought that counts, not the gift, and that gift horses should never be looked in the mouth. The latter saying, like the fruitcake that no one eats, keeps on popping up year after year.

title: PAY 'N PAK STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Jerusalem Bus Toll Now 6
description: Serina Sussman, 60 years old, a tourist from the United States, died in Jerusalem during the Sunday night from injuries sustained in the terrorist bombing of a city bus on Dec. 6, raising the death toll from the blast to six. Mrs. Sussman had traveled from Anderson, S.C., to visit two sisters and a brother who live in Jerusalem.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
description: Debt Rating Unchanged At Bell System Units

title: AMERICAN MEDICAL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
LIONS SUE EX-AGENT FOR SIMS
description: The Detroit Lions are suing Jerry Argovitz, the former agent of Billy Sims, their star runner who has signed multimillion-dollar contracts with two teams in different leagues.

title: TEXTS OF SUMMARY OF INVESTIGATION INTO ATTACK ON MARINES AND OF DISSENT
description: Following are the texts of the summary of findings and conclusions issued Monday night by the Investigations Subcommittee of the House Armed Services Committee on the Oct. 23 bombing of the Marine compound in Beirut and a statement of panel members' dissenting views, issued today, that are to be incorporated into the subcommittee's report: The Summary

title: BILL BRANDT, 79, PHOTOGRAPHER OF FOREBODING IMAGES, DEAD
description: Bill Brandt, a British photographer known for his eloquently foreboding vision, died yesterday in London. He was 79 years old.

title: WINE TALK
description: THE last frantic hours of the Christmas shopping rush hold no fears for the wine enthusiast, and shouldn't for anyone buying him or her a gift. The list of possibilities is long and the chance that any of them have run out is slim. Moreover, many of the things that seem tailor-made for a wine fancier will flatter equally someone who rarely touches the stuff.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Baxter Travenol Laboratories, Deerfield, Ill., announced that Victor M. G. Chaltiel had been appointed chairman, president and chief executive officer of its affiliate, Omnis Surgical Inc.

title: FLORIDA CYPRESS GARDENS INC reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: b-Including a gain of $645,419 from discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $6,862 from discontinued operations.

title: PILLSBURY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split.

title: BISCAYNE UNIT IS IN BAD SHAPE
description: The New Biscayne Federal Savings and Loan Association of Miami, a troubled thrift institution that regulators last week agreed to sell to Citicorp of New York, is in much worse financial condition than previously disclosed. According to documents made available today, New Biscayne lost 21 percent of its deposits, or $374 million, from April 6 to Oct. 31.

title: APPLIED MATERIALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: b-After a net loss of $45,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net loss after a tax reduction of $4,581,000 and a net gain of $205,000 from discontinued operations.

title: LATIN GROUP RENEWS PEACE TALKS
description: The foreign ministers of the four-nation Contadora group began a fresh round of talks today on a 21-point peace plan for Central America.

title: Firefighters Trace Shouts for Rescue
description: Two Brooklyn firefighters traced screams to rescue a man who could not walk and was trapped by smoke and flames in his apartment building, the authorities said yesterday.

title: FLIMSY GROUNDS FOR DISOBEYING THE LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Mayor Denied Shorter Sentence
description: The former Mayor of Union City, Robert Botti, lost a bid today to have his 18- month Federal prison term reduced, but was granted a two-week stay before surrendering to begin serving the sentence in a bid-rigging scheme.

title: WAUSAU PAPER MILLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
More on Alzheimer's
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:In the first of her two articles on Alzheimer's disease (''Personal Health,'' Nov. 23), Jane E. Brody said that we know little more about the disease today than we did soon after its discovery 75 years ago.

title: BOSTON FIVE CENTS SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: b-After a securities loss of $3,298,000. c-Including a securities gain of $461,000 and an extraordinary gain of $1,581,000.

title: City's Plan to Collect Overpayments Is Barred
description: A judge today ordered the City of Santa Clara to halt its plans for collecting a year's worth of salary overpayments from 350 employees.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Fairleigh Dickinson vs. Hofstra , followed by Rutgers vs. Michigan , at Byrne Meadowlands Arena; first game, 7 P.M. The last time Rutgers and Michigan met was in the Final Four of the 1976 national tournament.

title: MANHUNT STILL INTENSE IN '81 SLAYING
description: Every day for two years, a contingent of New Jersey state troopers has come to a makeshift command post in the basement of Town Hall here, waiting for the tip that will crack their biggest investigation in a half-century.

title: NAKASONE'S FUTURE: SOME DOUBT RAISED
description: NewsAnalysis

title: ITALY READY TO CUT ITS FORCE IN LEBANON BUT PLEDGES TO STAY
description: Defense Minister Giovanni Spadolini announced today that Italy would gradually reduce the number of its soldiers in Beirut, where 2,100 Italians are serving in the multinational force.

title: A Funds Shift In Philippines
description: The Philippines central bank said today that its foreign exchange reserves showed an inflated figure until last Septemger but have since been readjusted.

title: CRACKDOWN ON DRUGS IN THE MILITARY FOUNDERING OVER CHALLENGES TO TESTS
description: A crackdown on drug abuse in the military services is foundering in dissension and confusion because of disputes over the accuracy of urine tests administered to three million servicemen a year.

title: TRP ENERGY SENSORS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
DJILAS'S CONTRADICTIONS ON YUGOSLAV POLITICS
description: To the Editor:

title: CLOTHESTIME INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
MGM/UA Offer
description: The Tracinda Corporation said it would include in its offer for the MGM/UA Entertainment Company the purchase of 2.9 million MGM/UA warrants to buy the company's common stock at $20 a share. Tracinda, which is owned by the entrepreneur Kirk Kerkorian, is offering $9 face value in convertible debentures for the warrants; terms on the debentures put the actual value at about half the face value. Mr. Kerkorian offered on Monday to buy the 49.9 percent of MGM/ UA that he does not control for $452.2 million.

title: Keeping G.M. and Toyota Chaste
description: What's the poor Federal Trade Commission to do? If it permits General Motors and Toyota to get together to build small cars in California, that might reduce competition between the world's No. 1 and No. 3 automakers. But if the commission says no to their joint venture, that would deprive G.M. of cost-reducing technology and discourage Toyota from setting up job-creating production facilities in America.

title: A CHRISTMAS PAST, AN UNEXPECTED GIFT
description: Mark Helprin is the author of ''Winter's Tale'' (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich).

title: GROWING NUMBER OF CHILDREN SENDING GIFTS TO AID NEEDIEST
description: Often inspired by their parents, more and more children are expressing their concern for the poverty they see around them and becoming a new generation of contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: PRESIDENT DOUBTS MARINES' LEADER MISLED CONGRESS
description: Texts of House subcommittee's report and of dissent, page A18.

title: FOX TO SELL RIGHTS TO PLUG GOODS IN FILMS
description: Within the next few weeks, 20th Century-Fox will become the first major studio to offer manufacturers a specific display of their brand-name products in movies in return for cash. Fees will run between $10,000 and $40,000 a movie.

title: ANNE FOX
description: Anne Fox, a constructor of crossword puzzles whose work has appeared in The New York Times Magazine each Christmas since 1965, died of cancer Nov. 21 at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. She was 72 years old and lived in Far Hills, N.J.

title: SECURITY CAPITAL CORPORATION reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extraoridnary credit of $2.8 million.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: License Given Unit At Supply System

title: Theismann Is M.V.P.
description: Joe Theismann, Washington Redskin quarterback, has been named the National Football League's most valuable player by The Associated Press. In an overwhelming selection by a nationwide panel of sports- writers and broadcasters, Theismann received 58 of the 84 votes cast. . . . Mike Rozier, the Nebraska running back who won the Heisman Trophy, was named as the recipient of the Maxwell Award as the outstanding collegiate player .

title: 5 Children Die in Fire On Wisconsin Farm
description: A fire raced through a family's rural home today, killing five children.

title: ENNIS BUSINESS FORMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
CONCERT: CHRISTMAS FOR THE AGES
description: THE Canticum Novum Singers welcomed the holiday season with nine centuries of Christmas music at Merkin Hall on Saturday night. While the concert was a bit incomplete, including only a small selection of 900 years of Yule compositions, the chorus, under the direction of Harold Rosenbaum, sang with its customary clarity and graciousness, with chords and voices balanced and individual lines attended to without the ensemble being slighted.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: Memo for Christmas '83: One-size-fits-all Doesn't fit me.GEORGETTE M. GILMORE

title: TOYOTA, G.M. SNAG UNSNARLED
description: Roger B. Smith, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, said today that the company was willing to sign a consent order promising not to violate antitrust laws in its planned venture with the Toyota Motor Corporation.

title: 2 CHARGED WITH SELLING ITEMS OF HIGH TECHNOLOGY TO SOVIET
description: Customs agents seized high-technology items today and charged two businessmen with illegally selling the equipment to the Soviet Union.

title: AFFIRMATIVE ACTION: FROM BAAKE TO A CHALLENGE IN DETROIT
description: To the Editor:

title: Arkansas Eyes Hatfield
description: Ken Hatfield, the Air Force football coach, is paying a visit to his alma mater, the University of Arkansas, and may be in line to replace Lou Holtz, who has resigned. Hatfield, who played for the Razorbacks from 1961 to 1965, said he had cut short a recruiting trip to the West Coast to make the visit to Arkansas at the invitation of the school's athletic director, Frank Broyles . . . . Dave Currey, whose pass-minded teams had a 40-36 mark in seven years at Long Beach State, accepted the coaching job at Cincinnati, the third coach there in three years. He succeeds Watson Brown, who left for Rice after a 4-6-1 season.

title: Dr. Richard J. Sullivan Dies; Led Democrats in Rockland
description: Dr. Richard J. Sullivan, a physician and former Democratic chairman of Rockland County, died of cancer yesterday at Good Samaritan Hospital in Suffern, N.Y. He was 65 years old and lived in Stony Point, N.Y.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Late Trading Lowers Prices;  Dealers Cite U.S. Actions
description: Prices of fixed-income securities tumbled in late trading yesterday after the Treasury announced its terms for next week's $15 billion of off-cycle refunding issues. The late selling sent prices at the long end of the market down an eighth to a quarter of a point, while rates on short- term bills rose a few basis points.

title: U.N. Calls on Pretoria To Pull Out of Angola
description: The Security Council, with the United States abstaining, approved today by a vote of 14 to 0 a resolution demanding South Africa withdraw its troops from southern Angola and pay for damages inflicted by their attacks.

title: MORRISON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 20
GENERAL DYNAMICS' ELIGIBILITY ON CONTRACTS STUDIED BY NAVY
description: In the wake of a criminal kickback case against two top former officials of the General Dynamics Corporation, the Navy is investigating to determine whether the company should remain eligible to receive Navy contracts, according to Lieut. Comdr. Mark Neuhart, a Navy public affairs official.

title: 2 HURT IN WEST BANK VILLAGE
description: A Greek Orthodox nun and a Moslem muezzin were injured this morning when two booby-trapped grenades went off in the Arab village of Al Eizariya, also known as Bethany, near here.

title: LAFLEUR AND SHUTT LEAD ROUT OF DEVILS
description: Guy Lafleur scored his 500th career goal and Steve Shutt his 400th to lead the Montreal Canadiens to a 6-0 victory over the Devils tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: KEEPING THE ELDERLY FIT
description: The nation's largest organization of older people and a health screening group said they were introducing a program to advise older Americans about how to stay healthy and avoid hospitalization.

title: Davis Feints His Way Closer to Mancini
description: Saying one thing while meaning another is as basic in boxing as the left jab. So while a news conference, held in a dignified Waldorf-Astoria ballroom, was called yesterday to announce that Howard Davis Jr. would fight Jimmy Paul of Detroit Jan. 27, there was no doubt in Davis's mind that he would fight someone else.

title: Norwest Offering
description: Norwest Financial Inc. filed an offering with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $500 million of debt. The securities will be offered periodically through underwriters or sold directly by the company. Proceeds will be added to the general funds of the company, which is based in Des Moines.

title: Cuomo Now Opposes Licensing Shoreham
description: Governor Cuomo said yesterday that, ''given present circumstances,'' he opposed the licensing of the nearly completed nuclear power plant at Shoreham on Long Island. He said at a news conference that he did not believe adequate measures had been taken to protect residents living nearby.

title: Differing Views
description: Mayor William Donald Schaefer of Baltimore said that he was ''not at all happy.'' As far as Simon Gourdine was concerned, ''That's good from our perspective.''

title: Belgian Jobless Rate Up
description: Unemployment in Belgium rose to a rate of 12.2 percent during the first two weeks of December, the Government said today. The rate had declined for two consecutive months, to 12.1 percent, at the end of November. In mid- December 1982, the rate had been 11.5 percent.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Bill of Rights Strikes Out

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some copies of Business Day on Friday about the GTE Corporation's Sprint telephone service misstated the charge for business customers. They pay a minimum of $25 a month.

title: PUBLIC LIBRARY TO REOPEN HALL FOR EXHIBITION
description: The New York Public Library will mount a major exhibit on censorship next year to open its newly renovated D. Samuel and Jeane H. Gottesman Exhibition Hall in the Central Research Library on 42d Street, library officials announced yesterday.

title: ARGENTINA INDICTS ITS RECENT PRESIDENT
description: Former President Reynaldo Bignone was indicted today on charges connected to the disappearance and presumed deaths of two Communist draftees in 1976.

title: JAZZ: GLOBE UNITY ORCHESTRA
description: THE Globe Unity Orchestra's two sets last Friday at the Astor Place Theater proceeded like a lot of other big- band concerts - bruising full-band ensembles alternated with featured solos. The difference was that all the music was improvised on the spot.

title: POP: INCIDENT AT FOLK CITY
description: THE most ephemeral pop music trends of the 1960's are helping to seed a contemporary bohemian pop climate that turns the artifacts of the past inside out. The Bleaker Street Incident, a folk trio led by a rising young cabaret performance artist, Ann Magnuson, is one of the more inspired exponents of what might be called nihilistic nostalgia.

title: A PICKUP IN HOLIDAY JOBS
description: By day, John Hadity is a programmer in an advertising agency in Manhattan. By nights, this Christmas season, he is on the fifth floor of Bloomingdale's, hawking a $10 toothbrush that plays an electronic rendition of ''Silent Night.''

title: 'IT'S A BUM RAP'
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

title: PALESTINIAN URGES FACTIONS TO MEET
description: A Palestinian leader said here today that he and other prominent Palestinians were trying to organize an emergency meeting of all factions of the Palestine Liberation Organization to prevent the 19-year-old group from disintegrating.

title: NONSTICK ELECTRIC WOK
description: THE arrival of electric woks some years ago was a welcome addition for cooks who enjoy Oriental cuisine. Wok cookery demands a very high, even source of heat that can be quickly modified and this cannot always be achieved on small kitchen ranges, especially electric ones.

title: SUPER FOOD SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 19
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 5 percent stock dividend paid Dec. 15.

title: COURT LIMITS A DEFENDANT'S RIGHT IN SOME OF STATE'S LOWER COURTS
description: A defendant charged with offenses punishable by as much as a year's imprisonment has no constitutional right to have his case heard by a judge who is also a lawyer, New York State's highest court ruled yesterday.

title: U.S. SPLIT ON LOAN TO KOREA
description: In an unusual intervention, the Commerce Department has asked the Export- Import Bank to turn down a loan of more than $100 million that the bank is considering to finance sales of American-made equipment for a South Korean steel works.

title: DEMOCRATS REACH ACCORD IN DISPUTE ON DELEGATES
description: Charles T. Manatt, chairman of the Democratic Party, agreed today to allow the Rev. Jesse Jackson to present his demand for new delegate-selection rules at the January meeting of the Democratic Executive Committee.

title: Blame for the Marines' Tragedy
description: A House subcommittee that inquired into the massacre of 241 marines in Lebanon eight weeks ago found their security inadequate and blames it on their officers in Beirut and in the chain of command all the way back to Washington. That there are important lessons to be learned from this tragedy is certain. But pointing fingers at individuals seems less useful.

title: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30

Convertible Bonds Of Japan Climb LONDON, Dec. 20 (Reuters) - Japanese convertible bonds rose today and held their gains in active trading, bolstered by the stronger yen and a technical adjustment to Monday's sharp declines on the Tokyo stock market, dealers said.
description: Monday's losses were seen as an overreaction to the failure of Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party to win a majority in Sunday's general election, dealers added.

title: Key Rates
description: * Nuveen index, John Nuveen & Company Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: AEL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 25
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $524,000 for the quarter and $2,160,000 for the 9 months. c-Net losses after losses of $795,000 for the quarter and $3,016,000 for the 9 months from businesses held for sale.

title: KEITHLEY INSTRUMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Net income for the latest quarter and year include extraordinary credits.

title: Astros Sign Walling
description: The Houston Astros have retained Denny Walling, a free agent who was drafted by eight other clubs, by signing him to a three-year contract worth $1.025 million. The 29-year-old outfielder-first baseman batted .296 last season, but is considered by General Manager Al Rosen ''one of the premier pinch-hitters in the game.'' . . . In an effort to give younger pitchers a chance, Milwaukee has traded Jim Slaton , a 33-year-old pitcher who has spent 11 of his 12 major league seasons with the Brewers, to California for the outfielder Bobby Clark , 28, who has a career fielding mark of .991 with only five errors in 309 games. . . The Mets have named Mike Cubbage , their former infielder, manager of their farm club at Lynchburg of the Class A Carolina League.

title: ANTHONY GIORDANO
description: Anthony Giordano, co-owner of Lawn Doctor Inc., a nationwide lawn-care franchise with offices in Matawan, N.J., and Dallas, died of a heart attack Saturday at Riverview Hospital in Red Bank, N.J. He was 48 years old and lived in Colts Neck, N.J.

title: SYSTEMATICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Judge Dismisses Suit On Prison Financing
description: A lawsuit challenging the state's financing plans for building more prison cells by using Urban Development Corporation bonds has been dismissed by a State Supreme Court justice.

title: PARK ELECTROCHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
description: Share earnings reflect 50 percent stock dividends paid May 31, 1983 and Oct. 24, 1983.

title: CBS-Comsat Study
description: CBS Inc. and the Communications Satellite Corporation said they had agreed to explore the formation of a venture in satellite-to-home television service. They said they would seek other potential partners as well as continue development work on a direct broadcast system, including home equipment design, program acquisition, project financing, technical operations and marketing and distribution support. The direct-broadcast business involves transmissions from a satellite to small rooftop dishes.

title: ENERGY CAPITAL DEVELOPENT reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: A COLLEGE PROFESSOR AND HIS 2 CHILDREN FOUND DEAD UPSTATE
description: The bodies of a Potsdam State College professor and his two teen-aged children were found Monday night at their home here, and the police chief termed the deaths a murder-suicide.

title: The 22 Universal Pictures Gets 2 Presidents
description: More changes were announced yesterday at the MCA-Universal Motion Picture Group as Frank Price, the new chairman, continued a shake-up.

title: U.S., QUIT UNESCO
description: A State Department review of America's relations with Unesco - the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization - has firmly recommended that the United States withdraw from that organization. If the United States withdraws, there will be important implications for Unesco - good ones, in my opinion - and for American relations with the rest of the United Nations system. If it does not withdraw after such a recommendation, the view widely prevalent in Unesco - that the United States is a paper tiger - will be greatly strengthened and the United States' credibility there will be extremely low.

title: LILIENTHAL'S 'MR. WONDERFUL'
description: THE German director Peter Lilienthal has filmed ''Dear Mr. Wonderful'' on what, for him at least, is alien territory. The film is set in New York and Jersey City, yet it has a fascinatingly incongruous European texture. Mr. Lilienthal's film, which opens at the Film Forum today, isn't always succinct, but even when it drifts it does so in intriguing ways.

title: QUADRIPLEGIC MAY BE FORCE-FED TO END FAST
description: A defiant Elizabeth Bouvia, who has been refusing to take any nourishment since Monday, was told by officials of Riverside General Hospital late today that she could either eat or go home, but that they would not help her die.

title: KENTUCKY WINNER IN 24-11 SLOWDOWN
description: Melvin Turpin and Sam Bowie had only 6 points each but they led all scorers tonight as the Kentucky outlasted a stalling Cincinnati for a 24-11 victory.

title: THE DEMOCRATIC SILVER LINING IN THE PHILIPPINES
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge; Tournament Year Finishes A Little Late in New York
description: Slightly later than usual, the New York tournament year ended Monday night at the New York Hilton Hotel, where the Greater New York Bridge Association's Winter Regionals were concluded.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 21, 1983

title: CREDIT CRUSH ON FARMERS EASES, BANKERS SAY
description: After three years of hard times, the credit rating of American farmers has been improving in recent months as the recession has receded, and the number of farm foreclosures and bankruptcies seems to be declining, according to bankers and Agriculture Department officials.

title: EASTERN EUROPE HEARS V-EFFECT'S ROCK
description: VEFFECT, a rock band that has been associated with the experimental music scene on Manhattan's Lower East Side, recently returned from a European trip that included performances in Czechoslovakia. Western rock bands have rarely ventured into Eastern Europe because governments there tend to be suspicious of rock. Yet a little-known New York band, with no record company or high-powered manager to back it up, succeeded where many rock stars have failed.

title: Demolition to Begin On Times Sq. Project
description: Demolition for the $1.6 billion Times Square redevelopment project will begin within two weeks, Mayor Koch announced yesterday.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: New Chairman Named At Marks & Spencer Coinciding with its centennial next year, Marks & Spencer P.L.C., Brit- ain's foremost retailing chain, will have a new chairman, Lord Rayner of Crowborough. Lord Rayner, 57, will add the chairman's duties to those of his present job of chief executive when he succeeds the present chairman, Lord Sieff, next July.

title: Prince Abdallah of Morocco; Younger Brother of the King
description: Prince Moulay Abdallah, the younger brother of King Hassan II of Morocco, died of a liver ailment yesterday at the royal palace in Rabat, the Government announced.

title: LOS ANGELES COUNTY ORDERED TO PROVIDE SHELTER TO HOMELESS
description: A state judge ordered Los Angeles County today to stop using lack of identification as a reason to deny shelter to the homeless.

title: Healthier Quarterback
description: Injuries to quarterbacks are hampered some National Football League teams going into the playoffs, but the situation is improving for the Miami Dolphins. Dan Marino , the star rookie, said his injured knee was responding well.

title: STATE IS PENALIZING CITY OVER SHELTER CONDITIONS
description: State officials said yesterday that they had started levying financial penalties against the city for failing to meet safety and fire standards in four city-run shelters for homeless people.

title: Suddenly, It's Layers
description: What happened to Indian summer this year in New York? There wasn't one. Indian summer, to be technical about it, means a spell of mild weather after the first freeze - and the first freeze in Central Park didn't come until the night before last. In other words, it's been mild all fall, but now, suddenly, it's winter. Suddenly, it's layers.

title: Ban on Oil Search
description: The Readington Township Committee has voted in a three-year moratorium on oil and natural gas exploration in the town.

title: REGAN SAID TO OPPOSE A CONTINGENCY TAX PLAN
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan has advised President Reagan to omit any specific proposal for a contingency tax in his budget next month and to plan instead to raise additional future revenue through a redesign of the income tax, Administration sources said today.

title: NETS DROP 4TH IN ROW, FACE SHAKE-UP
description: Stan Albeck has had enough. After the Nets committed 26 turnovers at the Omni against Atlanta tonight - 5 in the final 4 minutes - and dropped a 98-87 decision for their fourth straight defeat and their lowest point total of the season, the Net coach decided it was time for a change.

title: Cornell Indictment
description: A Queens man has been indicted on charges of murder and attempted murder in the death of two Cornell University students and the taking of four other students as hostages, District Attorney Benjamin J. Bucko of Tompkins County said today.

title: AS EUPHORIC GRENADIANS RECOVER, THE MOOD IS 'YANKEES, DON'T GO'
description: Like President Reagan, the owner of Mama's Restaurant on a dirt road outside town likes to refer to the American landing two months ago not as an invasion but as a rescue mission.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IF I were to name the most ''American'' dishes, my choices would most certainly include eggs Benedict, a dish that is the staple for that typically American institution, Sunday brunch.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
description: Group Widens CATS' Market Salomon Brothers said yesterday that it had organized a

title: STAGE: 'ACCENT ON YOUTH' REVIVED
description: NEW HAVEN IN ''Accent on Youth,'' a famous

title: Rights Unit Asks Greece To Act for Reporter
description: A New York-based American organization, Freedom House, has asked the Government of Greece to nullify a two- year prison sentence for libel imposed on Paul Anastasiades, a Cypriot reporter based in Athens.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;  Kuhn Delays Review
description: Commissioner Bowie Kuhn said that at the request of Federal prosecutors he had put off his review of Vida Blue 's involvement with drugs until after the trial next month of 12 suspected cocaine dealers arrested in the same investigation that led to the conviction of Blue and three other players who were with the Kansas City Royals this summer. Blue, who pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor, was sentenced to three months in prison Monday.

title: IN SPITE OF THE COURT, THE LEGISLATIVE VETO LIVES ON
description: The legislative veto is alive and well, contrary to a Supreme Court decision and a raft of obituaries.

title: FAMILY FEAST AT A NAPA VINEYARD
description: Charles Perry is a food writer based in Los Angeles.

title: Soviet Turns Over 83 Items From Downed Korean Airliner
description: Soviet authorities turned over to Japanese and American officials today 83 items, but no bodies, from the South Korean jetliner that was shot down by a Soviet fighter plane on Sept. 1.

title: HEATLESS TENANTS COMPLAIN TO CITY
description: Thousands of New York City residents complained of heatless apartments yesterday as temperatures plunged into the teens.

title: TIME IS RUNNING OUT FOR U.S. TO DECIDE WHETHER IT SHOULD LEAVE UNESCO
description: Sometime before the end of the year, the Reagan Administration will decide a question with wide-reaching international implications: whether to withdraw from Unesco.

title: MAKING SURE 'THERE ARE NO SNAFUS'
description: She has gone without sleep for 48 hours straight, shown up at embassy dinner parties in jeans having lost her luggage en route, eaten C-rations with the troops in Germany and traveled by flatbed truck in South Korea.

title: PRETORIA AND MOZAMBIQUE CONFER IN SWAZILAND ON ENDING ATTACKS
description: Representatives of South Africa and Mozambique met today in neighboring Swaziland, reportedly to discuss ending hostile actions against each other.

title: POLICY MAY CURTAIL STUDENT LOANS
description: Some college students may find next year that Government-guaranteed student loans are less available because of a new policy at the United States Department of Education that makes it more difficult for state authorities to help finance such loans.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Toll for Elephants

title: SOVIET BLOC RIFT REPORTED BY U.S.
description: State Department officials said today that a rift had broken out within the Soviet bloc over how to respond to the deployment of the new United States missiles in Europe and the suspension of the Soviet- American talks in Geneva.

title: ISLANDERS SET MARK FOR GOALS
description: The message to the Islanders was clear from the start of the season - they could not wait until the playoffs to produce.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE STORY OF HENRI TOD. By William F. Buckley Jr. 254 pages. Doubleday. $14.95. THE best part of ''The Story of Henri Tod,'' William Buckley's fifth suspense novel, is his portrait of former President John F. Kennedy. His rendering of Nikita Khrushchev is quite good too, and this tempts me to suggest that Mr. Buckley seems most at home when he projects himself into the minds of heads of state.

title: CLEANUP GOVERNS ARSENAL'S FUTURE
description: For years fishermen knew the lakes at the Army's Rocky Mountain Arsenal harbored some of the biggest and meanest bass in metropolitan Denver. Five- pounders could be caught out of those lakes, but they could not be eaten. They were contaminated.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Dickens and 72d Street

title: Quake Strikes Off California
description: A strong earthquake struck under the Pacific Ocean about 60 miles off the Northern California coast early today but caused no damage. The quake registered 5.4 on the Richter scale of earthquake magnitude at the University of California in Berkeley.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Santa Came, After All

title: Mobil-Texas Pact Put Off LAREDO, Tex., Dec. 20 (AP) - The signing of a legal settlement between the Mobil Corporation, the state of Texas and a south Texas rancher, Clinton Manges, was postponed today after the Exxon Corporation contested the settlement.
description: Exxon filed a claim in a state court in Laredo on Monday night asking that the courts determine the validity of the settlement and hear Exxon's claim that it is entitled to some of the revenues involved.

title: BRIEFS
description: Blessings Corp., a Piscataway, N.J., diaper service and plastic film manufacturer, said it had signed a letter of intent to sell the assets of its diaper service division to an unidentified buyer for about $13 million in cash.

title: Hope Off for Lebanon To Entertain Troops
description: Bob Hope left on a military cargo plane today for his first overseas U.S.O. Christmas tour since 1972, a weeklong series of performances to entertain American troops in Lebanon.

title: 4,000 PALESTINIANS EVACUATE TRIPOLI ON GREEK VESSELS
description: Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, sailed from this northern Lebanese port today in a white-hulled Greek ferry escorted by French naval vessels. In all, five Greek ships took about 4,000 Arafat loyalists away from Tripoli, the second evacuation of P.L.O. fighters from Lebanon in 16 months.

title: Chicago Paper Reports Its Sale Is 'Definitive'
description: Amid reports that a new offer had been made for The Chicago Sun-Times, Field Enterprises announced today that it had signed a ''definitive agreement'' and was near completion of its previously announced $90 million deal to sell the newspaper to the Australian publisher Rupert Murdoch.

title: SCOUTING
description: Re-Programming

title: WYOMING RAMPAGE LEAVES SIX KILLED
description: A spurned suitor went on a rampage today, killing five people, including two children and a police officer, before blowing himself up with a homemade bomb, the authorities said. He was holding hostage the woman who rejected him and she was wounded, they said.

title: Eastern's Losses
description: Eastern Airlines lost $62.1 million in October and November when it raised the possibility of filing under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code and was urging its unions to make concessions. The loss put the carrier's total loss for 1983 so far at $191 million, compared with a loss of $117.9 million in the period a year earlier. The figures were in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission submitted as part of a $367 million rescue plan agreed to by Eastern's three major unions.

title: Advertising; Ultrasport: A Rugged Readership
description: AN observant person would probably conclude that marathon runners are not poor, and rarely blue-collar. Athletic activity that borders on self-induced torture seems to attract the well-to-do, the type that advertisers look for.

title: ICAHN SEEKS ACF IN $337 MILLION DEAL
description: Carl Icahn, the Wall Street investor, who owns 27.2 percent of ACF Industries, offered yesterday to buy the rest of the company for $337 million in cash and stock. ACF, which makes oilfield equipment, railcars and auto parts, said it would study the offer.

title: Convicted Robber Vows to Do Worse
description: A man who was convicted of robbing commuters at the Freeport train station, and who threatened to kill witnesses and blow up a police station, was sentenced today to up to 30 years in prison and vowed to ''come back and do worse.''

title: AAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Atom Plant Reports Cracks
description: Ultrasonic testing ordered by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has found cracks in the welds of two small water recirculation pipes at Boston Edison's Pilgrim nuclear power plant, the utility said. There have been no leaks from the pipes, according to a utility spokesman, who said all of the affected pipes would be replaced.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: SING ALONG If you've been a regular for the last 15 years, you probably know the words by heart for the 16th annual ''Messiah Sing-In,'' which, with a full house, should fill Lincoln Center's Avery Fisher Hall with 3,000 voices at 7:30 P.M. today.

title: U.S. Surgical Auditor Resigns The United States Surgical Corporation said Ernst & Whinney had resigned as the company's independent auditor and was withdrawing its opinions from U.S. Surgical's 1981 and 1982 financial statements.
description: Ernst & Whinney, in its letter of resignation, said that records and statements furnished to it in a 1981 audit relating to tooling - molds and dies - were not reliable and that disclosures made to it following the audit were either late or incomplete, U.S. Surgical said in a statement.

title: BIRTH CONTROL: STERILIZING RELIED ON
description: Voluntary sterilization is the most widely used method of birth control in the United States, according to a study released this week by Ms. magazine.

title: PRESIDENT'S NEWS CONFERENCE ON FOREIGN AND DOMESTIC ISSUES;
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news conference last night as recorded by The New York Times OPENING STATEMENT

title: Japan Video Recorders
description: Japan's production of videotape recorders will jump 16.3 percent, to 20.7 million units, in 1984, the Electronic Industries Association predicted today.

title: POWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
REQUIRED READING
description: Hidden Crisis

title: Boston Edison
description: The Boston Edison Company said the previously anounced problems at its Pilgrim nuclear power plant will take about 35 weeks to repair and cost about $100 million. The utility said it discovered the problems, which involve cracks in small-diameter pipes, when it closed the plant for refueling on Dec. 10.

title: SCOUTING
description: American Soccer

title: CONCERT: JEANNE BAXTRESSER, FLUTIEST
description: IN a transcription of Chopin's

title: MRS. KIRKPATRICK 'SATISFIED' ON U.N. SESSION
description: The American delegate to the United Nations, Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, said today that American positions came out ''reasonably well'' in the three-month session of the General Assembly.

title: REAGAN DENIES GOVERNMENT SOCIAL PROGRAMS ARE PREJUDICED
description: President Reagan, dealing with the marginal standing that polls indicate he has with women and minority groups, said tonight that he had not ''picked on anyone'' in his Administration's social programs.

title: DANCE: FESTIVAL BALLET AT THE EMANU-EL Y
description: THE Manhattan Festival Ballet is likely to have played a memorable role in the life of any reasonably adventurous dancegoer in New York in the mid and late 1960's. You might feel as if a dancer were about to land on your lap with every lunge on the tiny stages on which Manhattan Festival performed. Some of the dances were distinct misadventures. But the company was rarely uninteresting in its presentations of new choreography. And its intimate evenings of chamber ballet - an unusual concept then - were presented with taste, quiet humanity and a contagious love for dance.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A table in Business Day on Monday showing economic forecasts for 1984 misstated some of the predictions made by Donald H. Straszheim of Wharton Econometrics. For the end of 1984, he forecasts an unemployment rate of 8 percent, a long-term Treasury bond rate of 11.4 percent and a three-month Treasury bill rate of 9.5 percent.

title: A WAY TO TACKLE DEFICITS
description: TheUnited States has passed a melancholy milestone: the highest Federal deficit in history - more than $195 billion in fiscal 1983. Deficits of similar magnitude, or larger, are expected in years to come. Meanwhile, Washington is paralyzed and divided against itself, and the political and economic impasse will become even more crippling as elections draw near. So it is critical that we try, now, to find a way out.

title: Cigna Buys Insurance Unit
description: The Cigna Corporation said that it had agreed in principle to acquire the American Foreign Insurance Association for $215 million. Cigna said the acquisition, by its Cigna International subsidiary, requires completion of a definitive agreement by Jan. 31, and approval by various regulatory authorities.

title: Snow Sweeper Driver Killed By Jetliner in South Dakota
description: An Ozark Airlines DC-9 jetliner struck a snow sweeper after landing at an airport today, ripping the right wing off the plane and starting a fire. All 82 people aboard the plane escaped injury, but the sweeper's driver was killed.

title: Mrs. Thatcher Assails Americans' Aid to I.R.A.
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today condemned the aid that the Irish Republican Army gets from Irish-Americans and said their help was ''possibly'' responsible for the bombing at Harrods department store on Saturday that killed 5 people and wounded 91.

title: SYNERGISTIC COMMUNICATIONS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income.

title: NEW HOSE; WATERTIGHT SONG BOOK
description: 1.*Holing Up

title: SUMMIT ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Economic Scene; Cutting Deficit: Key Hurdles
description: THE real issue about Federal budget deficits is not whether to reduce them, but when and how. The answer to when, provided by most politicians, appears to be: not until after the election, and probably not until the 1986 budget.

title: ROBBINS & MYERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss including income from discontinued operations of $40,000.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: West Side Sweet Shop

title: SCOUTING
description: Backman Stays In Mets' Plans

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan Assaying Phone Stocks
description: Jan. 1, 1984 - fast approaching for the seven regional holding companies created by the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, most of A.T.&T.'s 3.2 million stockholders still wonder what, if anything, to do about buying or selling shares of the new Bell offspring.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: Latino Rock From East Los Angeles

title: HOUSING NIGHTMARE MARS DREAM LIFE
description: The Talk of Santa Fe

title: Dispute Over Dr Pepper Offer W. W. Clements, the chairman of the Dr Pepper Company, said that an investor group headed by Castle & Cooke Inc. ''rejected another opportunity this past weekend'' to look at the company's books to help arrange financing to buy the soft-drink producer. Ian W. Wilson, president of Castle & Cooke, primarily a food products concern based in Honolulu, immediately denied the report.
description: Mr. Wilson said that once his offer was accepted, Dr Pepper's lawyers asked Castle & Cooke to sign papers saying that it had received the same information given to Forstmann Little & Company, which has agreed to buy Dr Pepper for $22 a share, or $512.5 million. He said Castle & Cooke refused, saying it had no way of knowing if that were true. The Castle & Cooke group has offered $24 a share, or $581 million, but Dr Pepper regards the bid as uncertain, since its bankers will only grant the financing if it can see Dr Pepper's books.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are being forced. Now we have nowhere to fight.'' - Abdul Bari, a P.L.O. fighter leaving Lebanon.

title: Massey-Rolls Deal
description: Massey- Ferguson Ltd. said it had agreed to acquire Vickers P.L.C.'s Rolls-Royce Diesels International division and merge it with Massey-Ferguson's Perkins Engines division. The transaction, which had been under discussion for several weeks, is valued at about $28.5 million, and involves the acquisition of net assets valued at about $45 million.

title: COMPUTERCRAFT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Net income.

title: J. Delafield DuBois, 80, Dies; Ex-Morgan Guaranty Official
description: J. Delafield DuBois, former senior vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, died Sunday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 80 years old.

title: GENERAL MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
ADVERTISING ; New Executive, Clients At Martin, Sturtevant
description: Martin, Sturtevant, Silverman & Marshall took time out yesterday from its busy pre-Christmas schedule to announce a new executive in the creative department and two new clients, as well.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: Joe was the oldest of five boys in a rural Minnesota family. Having recently graduated from college near the top of his class, he was on his way back to the family farm after attending his best friend's wedding when an oncoming car veered into his lane and struck his car head on, demolishing it and killing Joe. The driver, tests showed, was drunk.

title: NANTUCKET INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 3
COMPUSCAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $325,000 for the quarter and $518,000 for the 6 months. c-Including tax credits of $207,000 for the quarter and $667,000 for the 6 months and a gain of $296,000 for the 6 months on the extinguishment of debt.

title: PEACE ON EARTH?
description: It's not easy and to many people may seem silly this Christmas to write about peace and good will on earth.

title: Republic Air
description: Republic Airlines Inc. said it had asked its 14,000 workers to extend a previously approved 15 percent wage cut and freeze through 1986 and establish lower pay and benefit scales for newly hired workers. The request also calls for profit-sharing provisions. It said that Republic employees already hold nearly 20 percent of the company's common shares outstanding and that the proposed new plan would increase that ownership to more than 30 percent.

title: Fotomat Has Loss
description: The Fotomat Corporation, a film processor and developer, said it lost $13.6 million in the latest quarter and is near default on $12.5 million in bank loans.

title: SALVADORAN HELD IN MURDERS
description: Police and military spokesmen said today that the police had arrested a Salvadoran Army captain accused by subordinates of ordering the killing of two American civilian advisers in 1981.

title: CLEVETRUST REALTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of $1,934,000 on the sale of real estate. c-Including a gain of $1,103,000 on the sale of real estate and an extraordinary credit of $1,787,000.

title: AGAINST EXECUTION: A CASE IN POINT
description: To the Editor:

title: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 21, 1983 International
description: Yasir Arafat was evacuated with 4,000 of his men from the Lebanese port of Tripoli. Mr. Arafat, who had been under siege for six weeks by Syrian-backed dissidents within his Palestine Liberation Organization, sailed aboard a Greek ferry escorted by French naval vessels. He left without a farewell message to sympathizers or a final public appearance, heading for exile, probably in Tunisia, as a guerrilla chief without a battlefront for his followers to contest. (Page A1, Column 6.) A Palestinian leader in Damascus said that he and other prominent Palestinians were trying to organize an emergency meeting of all factions of the Palestine Liberation Organization to prevent the 19-year-old group from disintegrating. The statement was made in an interview by Khaled Fahum, chairman of the P.L.O.'s parliament. (A1:5.)

title: CONCERT: HANDEL'S 'MESSIAH'
description: ''IF I were a member of the House of Commons,'' George Bernard Shaw wrote, ''I would propose a law making it a capital offense to perform an oratorio by Handel with more than 80 performers in the chorus and orchestra.'' Shaw was used to hearing more than 4,000, in fact, but he might have proposed no less a penalty after hearing the Masterwork Chorus and Orchestra give its 100th performance of Handel's ''Messiah'' under the direction of David Randolph in Carnegie Hall on Sunday night.

title: Vatican Won't Sanction Caroline's 2d Marriage
description: The second marriage of Princess Caroline of Monaco will not be recognized by the Roman Catholic Church, which holds her first marriage to be valid unless an annulment is granted, church sources said today.

title: Poland Postpones 'The Day After'
description: Polish television authorities have indefinitely postponed their plan to broadcast the ABC-TV film about the aftermath of nuclear war, ''The Day After,'' ABC officials said yesterday.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Phibro Resources Chief Is Bullish on the Basics John J. Lee says he does not fully believe all he reads about Smokestack America being in trouble. Mr. Lee, president and chief executive of the Phibro Resources Corporation, heads an investor group that is taking four units of the corporation private.

title: Gerber Baby Cereal Recalled in California
description: The Gerber Products Company recalled 48,000 jars of baby cereal after a California couple found aluminum slivers in two jars purchased at different stores, a company offical said today.

title: CHEMLAWN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
Mayor Matthews Explains Absence
description: Mayor Michael J. Matthews returned to City Hall today and said that during his 11-day absence, which began after an F.B.I. raid on his office, he was on a golfing vacation in Florida.

title: Dow Drops 2.64; Trading Is Active
description: Stock prices declined yesterday, despite some favorable economic news released by the Government. Trading was more active.

title: Blast Rocks Turkish Capital; No Casualties Are Reported
description: A large explosion rocked a central district of Istanbul early today, hours after the Turkish military authorities said they found a car bomb in the Aegean port of Izmir between a United States officer's club and a French cultural center.

title: FOIS GRAS GOES AMERICAN
description: ''FOR me it's like a new toy,'' said Andre Soltner, excitement evident in every word. ''It's fantastic.'' The ''it'' of which he spoke so warmly was a one-and-a-half pound, beige moulard duck liver. But by the time it has reached that weight it is no longer just a liver: it is foie gras, the food over which the French have been swooning for years and for which Americans have gladly paid $10 an ounce in a can, even though canned foie gras bears little resemblance to fresh.

title: NEW U.S. WEAPONS BEYOND 'LEVERAGE' NEEDS
description: To the Editor

title: A TREE FOR ALL SEASONS
description: To the Editor:

title: Finding on Brazil Steel
description: Carbon steel from Brazil is causing material injuries to American steel producers, the United States International Trade Commission said today in a preliminary finding. The finding sets off a Commerce Department investigation to determine the extent of underpricing and Brazilian Government subsidies for the steel exports.

title: 4 NEW TOWERS FOR TIMES SQ.
description: An Appraisal

title: Bell Canada Stake
description: Bell Canada Enterprises Inc. said it had increased its stake to nearly 43 percent of TransCanada Pipelines Ltd.

title: ARTISANS ELIGIBLE FOR STATE FELLOWSHIPS
description: For the first time, artisans will be eligible for fellowships financed by the New York State Council on the Arts and given annually for the last 14 years to resident artists to encourage innovative art in the state.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Reluctant Farewell

title: OLD FRENCH FEUD IS BACK: WHO WILL RUN SCHOOLS?
description: From Lille in the north to Marseilles in the south, thousands of people have taken to the streets in protest in recent weeks. But not, as in Britain and West Germany, against cruise missiles and Pershing 2's. A commentator here said, ''It's just another battle in France's oldest war.''

title: Rape Conviction Voided Over Suit
description: An appeals court yesterday reversed the rape conviction of a record-company executive because the prosecutor had failed to disclose he knew the victim was going to file an $18 million suit.

title: DANCE: MIA BORGATTA
description: THE four brief works that made up ''Instinctive Shorthand,'' the dance event that Mia Borgatta offered last Saturday night in the Kiva Studio, consisted of little squiggles of movement to scores by Carolyn Romberg and Wayne Horvitz.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: Turntable Wizards Making a New Niche

title: KITS THAT HELP DEVELOP A NOSE FOR WINE
description: ENOLOGISTS have estimated that wine's aroma is composed of at least 300 components, and for many wine enthusiasts, identifying these components is a favorite game. But familiar smells can become elusive when intermingled, and identifying even commonplace odors can be astonishingly difficult. Does it smell of vanilla? Is that clove? Coffee? Is it reminiscent of tar or cedar? Mushrooms? Perhaps truffles?

title: Study Finds Progress And Repression in Cuba
description: The Cuban Government has made progress in providing health, food, education and jobs but remains intolerant of dissent and has virtually eliminated political opposition, according to a new report issued today.

title: E.P.A. AIDE DEFENDS AGREEMENT ON CLEANING UP DUMP IN INDIANA
description: A top Environmental Protection Agency official today rejected charges that the Government had made a ''sweetheart deal'' on cleaning up a toxic waste dump at Seymour, Ind.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A dispatch by The Associated Press from Boston Dec. 8 on a hormone under investigation as a possible treatment for amyotrophic lateral sclerosis misnamed the hormone. It is thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH).

title: WESTMILLS CARPETS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: GOSSAGE WON'T RETURN TO YANKS
description: Rich Gossage, who joined the Yankees as a free agent six years ago, crossed them off his free-agent list last night, saying he would ''not return to play for George Steinbrenner.''

title: TV: 'HOBSON'S CHOICE,' AN ADAPTATION ON CBS
description: ''HOBSON'S CHOICE'' finally may have run out of gas. It started out as a three-act play, written in 1916 by Harold Brighouse and set in the Lancashire, England, of 1880. Then, in 1954, David Lean directed a film version starring Charles Laughton, John Mills and Brenda De Banzie. There was even a 1966 Broadway musical, called ''Walking Happy,'' based on the play. Now, television has decided to adapt the story to its own special needs, and the disappointing result can be seen tonight at 9 on CBS.

title: COMPUTONE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
BRIEFING
description: Holiday Preparations

title: 2D U.S. AGENCY ASSAILED BY JUDGE AS INSENSITIVE
description: For the second time in a few months, a Federal District Court judge has criticized a Federal Government agency as being insensitive in pursuing the collection of debts against individuals.

title: ASSISTANTS LIVE AN UNCERTAIN LIFE
description: Howard Brown, who was a football player and then assistant football coach for many years at Indiana University, died unexpectedly in April 1975. He was a popular man, affectionately known as Mr. Indiana. Less than half an hour after Brown's fatal heart attack, Lee Corso, then the head coach at Indiana, received a call from an assistant coach at another university.

title: THE BANK OF BOSTON'S GAMBLE
description: William L. Brown is a crusty, impatient man who is moving rapidly to change the character and prospects of one of New England's most venerable institutions, the Bank of Boston.

title: 180 UNITS FOR ARTISTS IN UNUSED BUILDINGS PLANNED BY THE CITY
description: A program to create living and working space in unused city buildings for up to 180 sculptors, painters, actors and musicians was announced yesterday by Mayor Koch.

title: THEATER: 'JUNE MOON,' REVIVAL OF '29 COMEDY
description: ''JUNE MOON,'' the Manhattan Punch Line's revival of the 1929 comedy by Ring Lardner and George S. Kaufman, may show its age, but it does so in the best way: it evokes laughs and giggles, not at it but with it. It is not much of a play in terms of story or depth, but it is joyfully replete with bits and tones that are vintage New York humor.

title: SHONEY'S INC reports earnings for Year to Oct 30
description: b-Including a nonrecurring gain of $5.4 million, or 28 cents a share, on an exchange of stock.

title: Newman Wait Jr., President Of Bank in Saratoga Springs
description: Newman E. Wait Jr., president of the Adirondack Trust Company in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., died in a fire Sunday at his summer home in Lake George, N.Y. He was 61 years old and lived in Saratoga Springs.

title: PROPERTY INVESTORS OF COLORADO reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
MUSIC: BACH ENSEMBLE AT MET MUSEUM
description: AT Christmas time, the Metropolitan Museum likes to move music from its customary place in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium to the museum's Medieval Court. Monday night, it was Joshua Rifkin's Bach Ensemble that played, surrounded on three sides by a large and attentive audience and with the Met's 19th-century Neapolitan Christmas tree as a background.

title: COMMEDIA PICTURES PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: CONNER HOMES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
description: Year-ago revenue restated to reflect a change in accounting principles.

title: Generals Introduce Michaels
description: The appointment of Walt Michaels as head coach of the Generals was formally announced at a Giants Stadium news conference today, 10 months after he had resigned under strained circumstances as coach of the Jets.

title: Devil's Bag Syndicated
description: Devil's Bag, a 2-year-old who has won his five career starts in impressive fashion, has been syndicated for a record value of $36 million, according to Claiborne Farm, the Lexington, Ky., thoroughbred nursery. The figure is the highest value that has ever been placed on a 2-year-old and the third highest for any race horse.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Citicorp said an average rate of 9.869 percent was set at the weekly auction of its 91-day commercial paper, up from 9.861 percent last week. A rate of 9.791 percent was set on the 182-day paper, down from 9.835 percent last week.

title: Careers; Handling Personnel Problems
description: ANDREW SHERWOOD, president of the Goodrich & Sherwood Company, a management recruiting and outplacement firm, believes that every department head, office supervisor or manager of a small group should ''be a personnel manager'' on his or her own. ''It is a good time to think about the human relations aspect at the end of the year,'' he said yesterday.

title: No Headline
description: McCaffrey Is Chosen

title: BOOKSTORES SUED OVER HUTTON BOOK
description: Lawyers for Dr. Edward A. Kantor have filed suit against a number of California bookstores, asserting that the stores had failed to comply with Random House's request that they return unsold copies of ''Poor Little Rich Girl.'' The book, by C. David Heymann, wrongly identified Dr. Kantor as having prescribed excessive drugs for the late Barbara Hutton.

title: PERSONAL INCOME UP BY 0.7%
description: Americans' personal income rose seven-tenths of 1 percent last month, the smallest gain since August, the Government reported today.

title: Real Estate; Helping Banks Add Locations
description: JOSEPH SCHLANG was observing from retirement in Florida the swift changes moving through the banking industry and decided that a real estate brokerage firm catering exclusively to the needs of financial institutions would be profitable and exciting.

title: AN INQUIRER INTO BOMBING: WILLIAM FLYNT NICHOLS
description: One of the men in Congress most familiar with the horrors of battle is Bill Nichols, the Alabama Democrat who heads the House Armed Services subcommittee that issued a report Monday on the bombing of the Marine compound in Beirut. It was in Germany, 39 years ago, that Mr. Nichols, then a husky 26-year- old United States Army officer, stepped on a land mine during the fighting in the H"urtgen Forest. He spent the next three years in a series of hospitals, recovering from the loss of his left leg, damage to his right leg and severe internal injuries.

title: COMPREHENSIVE CARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
NEXUS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 5
description: b-Including a tax credit of $63,000.

title: GIFTS TO NEEDIEST HONOR DEAD
