description: For many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, the year-end holiday festivities contrast sharply with memories of hardship or death that are a legacy of World War II.

title: RAIDERS WILLING TO TALK TO CITY
description: The Los Angeles Raiders are willing to discuss a move to New York, city officials said yesterday.

title: NEWHALL LAND & FARMING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including income from operations distributed to two limited partnerships of $1.2 million, or 14 cents a share, for the quarter and $5.3 million, or 60 cents a share, for the 9 months.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allied Corp., Morristown, N.J., has appointed H. Drummond Murdoch president of its C & D Batteries Co.

title: ROOM FOR COMPROMISE ON UNITARY TAXATION
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Thompson To Close Lansdowne
description: ALTHOUGH he is not scheduled to become president and chief operating officer of J. Walter Thompson U.S.A. until Jan. 1, Jack E. Peters has already participated in a major management decision with Burton J. Manning, chairman and chief executive. They have decided to close down Lansdowne Advertising, a division since the summer of 1978.

title: CITY STEETS THROUGH GRIDLOCK ALERT
description: SUZANNE DALEY

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: Taft Plans to Sell Amusement Parks

title: Paying the Wrong Piper in Manila
description: American policy has not caught up with the sea change in Filipino politics since the murder of Benigno Aquino four months ago. The outcry against President Marcos has spread from Manila to remote villages. It will intensify with economic hardship. Yet Washington, preoccupied with vital bases, shows a foolish neutrality between a discredited dictator and his democratic challengers.

title: REPAIR AND CARE OF ANTIQUE TRAYS
description: The wooden tray, a Dutch invention that was adopted by the English at the end of the 17th century, reached the height of popularity in late Victorian times.

title: STATE AND EX-ADMINISTRATOR ACCUSE A HOSPITAL IN QUEENS OF DEFICIANT CARE
description: The former administrator of a financially ailing Queens hospital and a monitoring group charge that the hospital admitted patients unnecessarily and gave them treatments they did not need.

title: Bridge: Winkle Helped One Team Gain in Summer Nationals
description: The winkle is a small shellfish popular with visitors to English resorts. The difficult task of removing the edible material from the shell is usually performed with a pin.

title: Rise in British Gas Price
description: British gas prices will be increased by 4.3 percent on Jan. 1, the state- owned British Gas Corporation said today. But a spokesman said there would be no rise in standing charges and that industrial contract customers would not face the increase until April. British Gas said the new prices had been fixed by the corporation and not by the Government.

title: Hoffmeyer Verdict Due
description: Brian O'Neill, the executive vice president of the National Hockey League, has conducted a hearing at the league's office in Toronto to consider further disciplinary action against Bob Hoffmeyer, the Devil defenseman who was suspended for striking Brian Bellows with a stick during a game against the Minnesota?North Stars last Saturday. O'Neill is expected to announce his ruling today.

title: PANEX INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $40,000 for the quarter and $470,000 for the year.

title: SCOUTING
description: Fading Stars

title: Decision Delayed
description: and 3,000-meter runs at the world track and field championships last summer, said she would wait until after the Olympic trials in June to decide whether to compete in both events at the Olympics.

title: Toyo Kogyo Net Up by 1%
description: The Toyo Kogyo Company, maker of Mazda vehicles, said today that its profit for the latest fiscal year rose 1 percent, to the equivalent of $114 million.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: ARAFAT AND HIS LAST DAYS IN TRIPLOI
description: The dirty white Jeep ranch wagon with bullet- proof windows charged through the nearly deserted streets of Tripoli, engine roaring, tires squealing. As it screeched to a stop, it would pitch forward, the doors would pop open and out would step Yasir Arafat, invariably dressed in olive drab, invariably grinning.

title: IRAQIS APPARENT TARGETS
description: Bombs reportedly directed at Iraqis exploded early today in Ankara and Istanbul. Three people were wounded in Istanbul, and hundreds of windows were broken in the two cities.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
description: Initial Yield Set at 9.5% On GATX Convertibles

title: BRIEFING
description: The 'Glean Machine'

title: CENTRAL SOYA CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $900,000 for the latest first quarter and $300,000 for the year-ago first quarter. Year-ago results have been restated.

title: Israeli Asserts Shcharansky Should Be Sent to a Hospital
description: Dr. Zwi Schlesinger, an Israeli cardiologist, said yesterday at a news conference in New York that Anatoly B. Shcharansky, who is serving a prison sentence at Chistopol in the Soviet Union, suffers from a heart condition and must be hospitalized.

title: NO MODERATES ALLOWED
description: This is a column about a friend. His name is Walid Khalidi, and he is an academic: professor of political studies at the American University in Beirut and research fellow at Harvard's Center for Middle Eastern Studies. He is also a Palestinian, born in Jerusalem in 1925. That is his burden.

title: Vasquez Loses Suspension Plea
description: A Federal appeals court upheld yesterday a one-year suspension of the jockey Jacinto Vasquez for attempting to bribe another rider before a 1974 race at Saratoga.

title: Tulsa Is Seeking Aid From League
description: A decision on the future of the financially troubled Tulsa Roughnecks, outdoor champions of the North American Soccer League, was put off yesterday when the team's players agreed to go to Vancouver for their indoor game there tomorrow despite not having received their paychecks last week.

title: HERS
description: EXCEPT for my dogs, I try to live near wild creatures. Wild, the principal occupation of the hours of their lives is seeking sustenance and shelter. Wild, they are also prey to creatures on the next rung up the food chain, and even eagles cannot be certain that the next day will find them well-fed. But their wildness is their being free, their independence of humankind. Not needing us for their food or cover, wild creatures can be themselves as domestic creatures can never be.

title: EARLIER DATES LIKELY FOR IOWA CAUCUS AND NEW HAMPSHIRE PRIMARY
description: After months of bitter dispute with state party leaders, the Democratic National Committee appears ready to reverse itself and advance the dates of the Iowa caucus and the New Hampshire primary, the first major contests of the 1984 Presidential campaign.

title: No Headline
description: BASEBALL

title: Turkey's Trade Gap
description: Turkey's foreign trade deficit widened by 10.3 percent, to $2.85 billion, in the first 10 months of this year because of a slowdown in exports, the Trade Ministry said today.

title: Toxic Shock Case In 2d Sponge User WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) - The Food and Drug Administration said that a second case of toxic shock syndrome has been confirmed among users of a new contraceptive sponge manufactured by the VLI Corporation of Irvine, Calif.
description: The agency said it is working with VLI to increase surveillance and provide more detailed warnings to consumers. The first case was reported early this month. Last week VLI, which went public in October, canceled a secondary offering of common stock.

title: E.E.C. Backs Steel Link
description: The commission of the European Economic Community said today that it had authorized the British Steel Corporation and the TI Group P.L.C. to merge part of their seamless steel tube activities into a joint company. The British steel concerns will form Seamless Tubes Ltd. in a bid to remain internationally competitive for smaller-diameter hot-finished seamless tubes.

title: A Nutmeg Coup Of Sorts in Grenada
description: An American company is going to buy from Grenada 1.1 million pounds of nutmeg that was destined for the Soviet Union before the United States invasion of the island in October, the Commerce Department said today.

title: 2 BOMBS IN BEIRUT KILL 19 AT A HOTEL AND A FRENCH POST
description: A pickup truck packed with explosives blew up outside a French military command post in East Beirut tonight five minutes after a bomb exploded in a crowded hotel bar in the western part of the city.

title: A SEASON WHEN GROUSE TO TAKE OVER Now that the blaze orange battalions of deer hunters - and I was one of them - have left the woods, many New York State sportsmen have turned to the possibly less intense, and certainly less visible, pursuit of ruffed grouse, cottontail rabbits and varying hares.
description: Throughout the state, except for Long Island, the grouse season continues through Feb. 29; the bag limit is four birds a day. On Long Island, the season ends Dec. 31, and the daily limit is one bird.

title: WILLIE WILSON, CITIZEN
description: Willie Wilson was interviewed from the Federal penitentiary in Fort Worth last Monday by Bill Kurtis on the ''CBS Morning News'' telecast.

title: NEW PROPOSALS IN SYNDICATION TALKS
description: The three television networks and Hollywood producers are devising new proposals for a compromise on the dispute over the right to own and sell reruns of prime-time television shows, according to officials familiar with the negotiations.

title: EGYPTIAN SEES NEW HOPE IN REAGAN PLAN
description: Foreign Minister Kamal Hassan Ali of Egypt met today with President Reagan and said later that the departure of Yasir Arafat from Lebanon had opened the way for a new ''political approach'' to settling Middle East issues.

title: Austrians Seize False Gold Tied to London Bullion Theft
description: The Austrian police announced the arrest today of 5 men and the discovery of 10 counterfeit gold bars stamped with numbers and refiner's name to match 6,000 real bars stolen in Britain last month.

title: ANADITE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Ex-Brokerage Aide Enters Guilty Plea
description: A former stock-dividend manager for Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. pleaded guilty in Manhattan yesterday to Federal charges involving the embezzlement of more than $18 million.

title: KIRKLAND DENOUNCES REAGAN: MONDALE SEENS AS BEST CHOICE
description: Lane Kirkland, the president of the A.F.L.- C.I.O., said in a recent interview that it was ''of the utmost importance'' that President Reagan be defeated in 1984.

title: ADVERTISING ; Lessner Slossberg Gahl To Push Reform Pens
description: The Reform brand pen is known in Europe, Latin America and parts of the Far East, but not in the States, and that has become the problem of Lessner Slossberg Gahl & Partners in Avon, Conn.

title: Arthur Rubinstein Remains Are Buried in Jerusalem Plot
description: An urn with the cremated remains of the pianist Arthur Rubinstein was buried in a fenced plot overlooking forested hills today, the first anniversary of his death at the age of 95.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''No compelling governmental purpose justifies a prosecutor's use of peremptory challenges solely on the basis of race.'' - Judge Eugene H. Nickerson of Federal District Court in Brooklyn. (A1:3.)

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
description: S.& P. Reduces Utility Ratings The Standard & Poor's Corporation yesterday reduced the

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Innovative Christmas

title: PERFECT PITCH FOR A TEAKETTLE
description: THE teakettle of the season must be Alessi's ''Bollitore,'' a striking brass and chrome object designed by Richard Sapper, the Milan-based designer who is also the consultant for product design for International Business Machines. ''My relationship to the teakettle has always had to do with their whistles,'' Mr. Sapper said.

title: BIFLYX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Christmas Spirit in a Cab

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Scott Paper Officer Shifts to SCA Services Charles W. Schmidt has been named president and chief executive officer of SCA Services Inc., the nation's third-largest waste disposal concern.

title: Seoul Announces Amnesty For 1,765 in 'Reconciliation'
description: The South Korean Government announced a year-end amnesty today for 1,765 people.

title: MICHIGAN TOPS RUTGERS, 97-69
description: Bill Frieder, the Michigan coach, said that he been concerned about his team's chances tonight against Rutgers in Byrne Meadowlands Arena because St. Peter's had upset Michigan State here on Dec. 1. ''And Michigan State is favored to win our Big Ten Conference,'' he noted apprehensively.

title: ONETIME NAVY AIDE DENIES HE FAVORED A FORMER EMPLOYER
description: George A. Sawyer, former Assistant Secretary of the Navy for Shipbuilding and Logistics, said today that while he was in the Government he had removed himself from all contract decisions affecting his former employer, John J. McMullen Associates.

title: CHASE, FOR $308 MILLION TO BUY ROCHESTER BANK
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to purchase Lincoln First Banks Inc., a large Rochester-based bank holding company, for $308 million.

title: SOME CITY WELFARE HOTELS FOUND BELOW STANDARDS
description: Some hotels that the city uses to house displaced families fail to meet minimum living standards set by state regulations and a State Supreme Court order, according to a private study released yesterday.

title: 76ERS EDGE SPURS
description: A steal and a layup by Maurice Cheeks with 43 seconds left lifted the Philadelphia 76ers to a 122-121 victory over the San Antonio Spurs tonight, despite George Gervin's 43 points.

title: MANOR CARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including a gain of $125,000 on the sale of property.

title: REXON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AROUND THE WORLD
description: Polisario Says Morocco Has Begun Major Drive

title: Swedes Vote Stock Funds STOCKHOLM, Dec. 21 (AP) - Parliament voted today to establish funds that will use tax money to buy equity positions in Swedish companies, overriding intense opposition from businesses and the non-Socialist parties.
description: Although polls said much of the public opposed the funds, the outcome was expected, given the Socialist bloc's majority in Parliament. The measure passed by a vote of 164 to 158, with 21 members abstaining and 6 absent.

title: 2 Reported Held In Trophy Theft
description: TV Globo and TV Manchete, private Brazilian television networks, said Tuesday that two men, who once worked for the Brazilian Soccer Federation as janitors, had been arrested in the theft of the Jules Rimet World Cup, which is valued at $47,000 and honors the tournament winner. But a Federal police spokesman would say only that ''the chief inspector is taking care of the case right now.''

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE CARAVAGGIO CONSPIRACY. By Peter Watson. 321 pages. Doubleday.

title: GALA TO BENEFIT CARNEGIE HALL
description: For nearly a quarter of a century, New Year's Eve has meant something special on stage at Carnegie Hall. Continuing a tradition established in 1960, when the violinist Isaac Stern and others helped save Carnegie Hall from the wrecker's ball, a gala benefit concert will be held this year beginning at 8 P.M. on Saturday, Dec. 31.

title: RATES OFF A BIT ON G.N.P. DATA
description: Interest rates fell modestly yesterday, with all of the declines occurring early in the day after the release of data showing that the economy is growing less rapidly than expected and that inflation remains low.

title: Harvester Accord
description: The International Harvester Company and Zahnradfabrik Passau G.m.b.H., a West German transmission maker, said they had signed a letter of intent to establish jointly owned companies in France and England. The operations will manufacture and assemble transaxles for agricultural tractors. Harvester officials said in a statement that the West German company would have a majority stake and operating control of the companies, and provide design and manufacturing technology for new transaxles.

title: ST. PETER'S COACH IS CONTENT WITH JOB
description: What Bob Dukiet says he enjoys about his job is how closely his days parallel those of the average working man. On most mornings, he will stop at the same restaurant for a doughnut and coffee, and with the exception of the woman behind the counter who might question him about the previous night's game, Dukiet is another face in the crowd on the way to work.

title: YONKERS COUNCIL AND SCHOOLS AT ODDS
description: FRANKLIN WHITEHOUSE

title: BRIEFS
description: Bear Creek Corp., a producer of fruit, gourmet foods and garden plants, said its shareholders had approved the acquisition of the company by a unit of R.J. Reynolds Industries for $39 a share, or about $74.1 million.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Flags From All Over

title: GOLDEN WEST HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
description: b-Net loss.

title: A CELEBRATION OF 19TH-CENTURY FURNITURE
description: THERE is romance, history and more than a bit of exuberance dramatizing two parlors and a gallery of 19th-century revival furnishings that opened last weekend in the American Wing of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: PROFESSOR AND EX-DIPLOMAT
description: Prof. C. Clyde Ferguson Jr. of Harvard Law School, a former United States diplomat and an authority on human rights in international law, was found dead yesterday in his apartment in Boston, apparently from a heart attack. He was 59 years old.

title: Snow and Ice Storms Cover Middle of Nation By United Press International
description: Snow and ice storms struck the Southwest and the Midwest on the eve of winter yesterday, nearly shutting down Dallas, blacking out 68,000 homes in Arkansas and making roads slippery from Illinois to Louisiana.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: AMONG the home improvement products and tools introduced in recent months, these should prove of special interest to do-it-yourselfers:

title: The Color of Terrorism
description: A common and ignoble color marks the new surge of terrorism in the Middle East, El Salvador and now Britain. Whether the victims are marines or trade unionists or Christmas shoppers, the ultimate sponsors pretend their death squads are acting strictly on their own. Color that kind of terrorism yellow.

title: SCOUTING
description: There's No Rest For the Weary

title: PUBLIC SERVICE DETERRENT
description: To the Editor: Townsend Hoopes clearly stated how the Reagan Administration ''censorship'' plan jeopardizes the First Amendment rights of those who've served in Federal Govern

title: Rojas Wins Title
description: Refugio Rojas carried the opening rounds and survived Alberto Mercado's late counterattack tonight to win the United States Boxing Association's featherweight title in a 12-round split decision. Judge Tony Castellano gave Mercado a 7-6 edge on points. Judges Donald Nodecker and Donald Ackerman awarded Rojas the bout 7-5 and 8-4, respectively.

title: STARRETT WINS ITS CASE ON IRAN EXPROPRIATION
description: The Starrett Housing Corporation announced yesterday that it had won the first expropriation case against Iran to be settled by an international claims tribunal in The Hague.

title: WARNER WILL SELL EXISTING CONTRACTS
description: Acting to trim its mounting short-term debt, Warner Communications Inc. signed an unusual agreement today to sell $350 million in completed contracts not yet registered in its balance sheet.

title: REWARD FOR ISLANDER ROOKIE
description: UNIONDALE, L.I.

title: Mother Denies Killing 4 Children
description: A pregnant 25-year-old woman pleaded not guilty today to charges she murdered her four children on Nov. 11 by pushing them from a railroad trestle into the Cooper River.

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 22, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: ; REAGAN'S NECESSARY AND REASONABLE DIRECTIVE 84
description: To the Editor:

title: BACKING SALVADOR: 'INSANITY'
description: President Reagan ought to do two things immediately. First, he should reinstate the draft. Second, he should send United States ground troops to fight in El Salvador.

title: CENTER GIVES NEW MUSICALS ROOM TO DEVELOP
description: THE old places to learn how to write a musical were at a summer resort, in a workshop or on the road tour of a new show. Then the resorts began hiring stars for their playhouses, the workshops began inviting investors and the out-of-town tryouts became too expensive to entrust to untried talents. The stakes of failure, simply, were often reckoned in six figures.

title: COMPUTER RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: CITY ASKS AGENCIES FOR HIGHER AND LOWER BUDGETS
description: Trying to smooth the roller-coaster ride that can plague municipal budget making, the Koch administration has ordered city agencies to prepare not only for a possible cut in money next year but, also, for the first time, an increase as well.

title: TWO MEN TAKE $1,000,000 IN HOLDUP AT TIME INC.
description: Two holdup men apparently slipped past security guards at the Time & Life Building at lunchtime yesterday, tied up two workers in an upstairs office and stole more than $100,000 from a petty-cash drawer before fleeing, the police said.

title: Nodding in the Wine-Dark Sea
description: Scholars are again disputing why Homer, the epic poet of ancient Greece, often calls the sea ''wine-dark'' when anybody not in his cups can see that it isn't. One school holds that the Aegean does in fact sometimes turn the color of claret, justifying poetic license.

title: MEASUREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
description: b-Including a tax credit of $1,035,000 for certain foreign subsidiaries. c-Net loss.

title: DISTRIBUTED LOGIC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
MEMOIRS DESCRIBED AUSCHWITZ SINGING
description: Fania Fenelon, whose memoir of her experiences singing in the inmate orchestra at Auschwitz was made into a controversial television movie, died of cancer Tuesday in the Kremlin Bic^etre Hospital in Paris. She was 74 years old.

title: PAN AM TO INSTALL SMOKE DETECTORS
description: Pan American World Airways announced yesterday that it would install smoke detectors in all lavatories on its 141 airliners by early spring.

title: Husky Oil Cuts
description: Husky Oil Ltd.'s subsidiary in the United States, the Husky Oil Company, said it will cut the price paid for crude oil over a wide area of the Rocky Mountains and the Great Plans by $1 to $2 a barrel, effective Jan. 1. A spokesman said most of Husky's crude price postings will be cut $1.50 a barrel, matching the cuts posted recently by the Citgo Petroleum Corporation, a unit of the Southland Corporation, and Ashland Oil Inc.

title: Buffalo Will Get Empire Finals
description: Governor Cuomo announced yesterday that the finals of the annual Empire State Games, which have been held in Syracuse since they were started six years ago, would be shifted to Buffalo in 1985 and 1986.

title: YANKS STILL HOPE ON GOSSAGE
description: Perhaps they are indulging in a game of wishful thinking, but some members of the Yankee organization are not prepared to give away Rich Gossage's seat in the team's bullpen.

title: JAZZ: HEMPHILL INTRODUCES A TRIO
description: IN one of his infrequent local appearances as a leader, Julius

title: ADVERTISING ; Van Lines Unit Goes To Doremus Chicago
description: North American Van Lines has switched the consumer advertising assignment for its Household Goods division to Doremus & Company in Chicago.

title: FICTIONAL CHARACTERS DERIVED FROM REAL PEOPLE;
description: BECAUSE it is not the real Dr. Edward A. Kantor who appears in C. David Heymann's new biography of Barbara Hutton, but instead an unintentionally fabricated version of the man, publication of ''Poor Little Rich Girl: The Life and Legend of Barbara Hutton'' has been canceled and 58,000 copies of the book recalled from bookstores and distributors around the country.

title: Joan Miro Given Last Rites
description: Joan Miro is in stable condition today after receiving the last rites from the Roman Catholic Church two days ago, a member of his household said. The 90-year-old painter has been ill for two years.

title: SPAIN'S CHIEF PRESSES FRANCE ON MARKET
description: Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez of Spain met with President Francois Mitterrand here on Tuesday to ask for help in speeding his country's admission to the Common Market, according to French Government sources.

title: 743 ACRES GIVEN BY ROCKEFELLERS FOR A STATE PARK
description: The Rockefeller family today turned over 743 acres of its woodland estate for use as a New York State park. A thousand more acres of the 3,500-acre property - maintained by the Rockefellers for six generations - will be added to the park in future years.

title: SummationsAreGiven In Beatty's Fraud Trial
description: Final summations were delivered yesterday in the trial of former State Senator Vander L. Beatty of Brooklyn, who is accused of election fraud.

title: Soviet Club Wins
description: The favored Soviet Union beat Czechoslovakia today, 5-2, and captured the Izvestia hockey tournament, the last major international tournament before the Olympics next February at Sarajevo, Yugoslavia. The United States team, which this month took a six-game series from a Soviet B squad touring North America, did not compete.

title: COSTS LAST MONTH UP 0.7% IN NEW YORK AREA
description: Consumer prices in the New York- northeastern New Jersey area rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in November, more than double the increase of three-tenths of 1 percent nationally, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: Coleco Stock Falls Following Report Coleco Industries' stock fell $4.375, to $18.50, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange after Consumer Reports published a highly critical review of the company's Adam computer in its January issue. The magazine, which evaluates a broad range of consumer products, said that it had purchased four of the first Adam computers to reach retail stores, and could not make any of the them work. The magazine said that in a future issue it would compare the Adam with other home computers if the editors could find a model that ''works the way it should.''
description: At Coleco, Morton Handel, executive vice president, said production problems encountered in making the first Adam computers ''have all been rectified.'' He said the company's defect rate was ''now well within industry standards.''

title: Andropov's Pen Pal Is Off to See Japanese
description: Samantha Smith, the 11-year-old Maine schoolgirl who traveled to the Soviet Union last summer, left New York yesterday for a 10-day trip to Japan.

title: CONSUMER PRICES UP BY 0.3%
description: Consumer prices, restrained by the sharpest drop in gasoline prices since the spring, rose only three-tenths of 1 percent in November, the Labor Department reported today.

title: PLAYSJames Tuite; Cincinnati Uses Stall To No Avail
description: ''We were out to win the game, not to please the crowd,'' said Tony Wilson of the University of Cincinnati basketball team. ''If you want to please the crowd, you bring in the Harlem Globetrotters.''

title: Federal Judges Remap A Mississippi District
description: A panel of three Federal judges ordered today that the lines of Mississippi's Second Congressional District be redrawn to increase the district's black population.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a production error, the TV Sports column on Tuesday omitted the last two sentences of a remark by Jim McKenna, vice president and general manager of CBS Sports, concerning Tom Brookshier's derogatory reference to the University of Louisville basketball team. The omission gave an unintended meaning to the paragraph that followed. Mr. McKenna, saying that the network had properly apologized to the university, added: ''CBS's purpose in Raleigh is to cover a basketball game. That's the business we're in.''

title: THE VALUE OF A LEBANON PARTITION
description: The United States is in a fix in Lebanon. Our central security interest in the region is not Lebanon, but preserving Western access to the oil-rich regions around the Persian Gulf and preventing the Arab-Israeli conflicts from exploding. That should limit United States engagement in Lebanon, and argues strongly against becoming directly embroiled with Syria. It also gives the United States some flexibility in deciding when our interests would be best served by reducing our commitment or withdrawing. In particular, we should consider the possibility that a de facto partition of Lebanon is the best achievable outcome.

title: CAROLINA UTILITY STOPS A-PLANT
description: The Carolina Power and Light Company said today that it was cancelling construction of a nuclear generating unit that was due to be completed in 1990 and instead speeding up construction of a coal-fired generator.

title: GULTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
description: b-After a loss of $640,000 from discontinued operations.

title: STAGE: A BOY AND HIS DREAMS IN 'TAP DANCE KID'
description: SOME boys dream of becoming athletes or astronauts, but Willie, the title character of ''The Tap Dance Kid,'' will have none of that. Willie (Alfonso Ribeiro) wants to be a show biz dancer and, even at age 10, he has decorated his bedroom on Roosevelt Island with posters of Astaire and Bojangles.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Attica's Green Guards
description: New York's Attica prison, as overcrowded as any in the state, has been restive all year. More prison cells eventually will offer relief, but for now Attica suffers from a side effect of the prison expansion program: inexperienced guards.

title: ISRAEL VOWS TO ATTCACK GUERRILLAS TEL AVIV, Dec. 21 (Reuters) - Israel said today that it would continue to strike at guerrilla bases in Lebanon despite the departure of Yasir Arafat and 4,000 guerrillas loyal to him.
description: Briefing Parliament within minutes of an Israeli air strike against a Shiite militia camp deep in Syrian-controlled Lebanese territory, Defense Minister Moshe Arens pledged that there would be no slackening in the Government campaign.

title: 4 BOMBING SUSPECTS ARRESTED IN RAIDS BY THE LONDON POLICE
description: Detectives made a series of dawn raids this morning, arresting four suspected sympathizers of the Irish Republican Army in connection with the explosion outside Harrods last Saturday.

title: U.S. SHIPS OFF LEBANON: NO SITTING DUCKS DESPITE MISSILES IN SYRIA
description: s

title: KEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: American Satellite Names a President

title: MAN WHO TRIED TO COMMIT SUICIDE WINS SETTLEMENT
description: A man who tried to commit suicide by throwing himself in front of an oncoming subway train has won a $650,000 settlement from the New York City Transit Authority.

title: Trillo Signs Giants Pact
description: Manny Trillo and the San Francisco Giants made it official yesterday when the free-agent second baseman signed a three-year contract. No financial details were disclosed, but Trillo was understood to have been seeking $800,000 a year before reducing his demands.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Caribbean Harmony

title: FOTIU AND LAROUCHE HELP RANGERS WINN
description: Pierre Larouche, the team's leading goal scorer, and Nick Fotiu, who had not scored a goal in close to a year, each had two as the Rangers defeated the Pittsburgh Penguins, 6-1, last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: 2% Sales Tax Voted in Rockland
description: The Rockland County Legislature has adopted a $176.9 million budget for fiscal 1984 and voted a 2 percent sales tax, the first time the county has enacted such a tax.

title: Beatrice Net Jumps 61.6%
description: The Beatrice Foods Company said today that its fiscal third-quarter profits surged 61.6 percent from a year earlier on a 7.4 percent sales gain. Profits for the quarter, ended Nov. 30, rose to $137 million, or $1.33 a share, from $84.8 million, or 81 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 22, 1983
description: International

title: A RICH PRESENT FOR RETAILERS
description: A higher-than-expected swell of Christmas buying across the country is expected to present the nation's retailers with their own holiday gift - their best profits in recent years.

title: EX-NIAGARA FALLS AIDE SUED BY STATE
description: State officials, in a civil suit, yesterday accused a former city manager of Niagara Falls and a construction company of ''fraud and collusion'' in the 1978 awarding of a toxic-waste removal contract at the Love Canal.

title: German Car Output Up
description: West German auto assembly lines produced 351,800 passenger cars and station wagons in November, up 14 percent from 309,202 in November 1982, the Auto Industry Association said today.

title: E-TRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $168,302 relating to the contract of the company's former president- treasurer. c-Net income.

title: JAZZ: TOSHIKO AKIYOSHI BANK
description: IN the year since Toshiko

title: Roving Gang Injures 4 In Times Square Area
description: A gang of eight youths who were ejected from a Times Square movie house where a Mr. T movie was being shown rampaged through the area, hitting passers-by with a tire iron or punching them, the police said yesterday.

title: SURINAME SHAKEN BY LABOR UNREST
description: An estimated 4,000 workers have walked off their jobs at Suriname's two largest industrial enterprises to back demands for talks with Government officials about lowering taxes.

title: 4TH-QUARTER G.N.P. ESTIMATED TO RISE AT A RATE OF 4.5%
description: The Government reported today that the economy's lively growth seemed to have moderated in the last three months of the year to a pace that the Reagan Administration said could be sustained through 1984 and beyond.

title: SCOUTING
description: A Michaels Fan

title: SPIRITS WITH A WHITE HOUSE TOUCH
description: When Rutherford B. Hayes was President, he banned the serving of alcoholic beverages in the Executive Mansion, prompting someone to suggest that ''buttermilk will flow like water at the White House.''

title: First Downhill For Miss Wenzel
description: Hanni Wenzel of Liechtenstein scored the first World Cup downhill victory of her career today.

title: HRT Industries' Reorganization A new proposal for reorganizing HRT Industries, which has been operating under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws, was made by the Abraham Zion Company, a New York-based investment company. HRT, based in Los Angeles, operates Zody's department stores and Karl's Shoe Stores.
description: The proposal includes the purchase by Zion of 51 percent of the common stock of HRT for about $12 million.

title: De Matha Wins
description: In a game billed as one between the country's best high school teams, De Matha of Hyattsville, Md., beat Mater Dei of Santa Ana, Calif., 66-51, tonight. Quentin Jackson scored 20 points for De Matha (7-1), and Matt Deeunsaert led Mater Dei (9-1) with 20 points. In the opening game, Fountain Valley (Calif.) lost to St. John's College High School of Washington, 55-50.

title: RICHARDSON REINSSTATED BY THE NETS
description: For the Nets, mired in their longest losing streak since early last season, today was a day of changes. Just hours after Coach Stan Albeck said he was benching starters Albert King and Darwin Cook, the team announced that it was reinstating Michael Ray Richardson, the former all-star guard.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The caption for a photograph published Sunday of John and Dorothy Hover and a young girl buying a Christmas tree misstated the relationship of the three. The girl, Molly, is the daughter of Mr. Hover by a previous marriage.

title: U.N. CHIEF QUESTIONS EFFECTIVENESS OF BEIRUT FORCE
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar said today that a United Nations peacekeeping force would be more effective than the present international force in preserving order in the Beirut area.

title: A.T.&T. TO BUY 25% OF OLIVETTI
description: In a major move into the European market, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company has agreed to pay $260 million for a 25 percent stake in Ing. C. Olivetti & Company, the big Italian office equipment maker, with an option to increase its share to 40 percent after four years.

title: Market PlacePhillip H. Wiggins Bell's Rivals: Outlook Bright
description: A S the American Telephone and Telegraph Company scatters its legions across the country, two independent telephone concerns have joined forces to expand their share of an increasingly competitive and diffuse communications market.

title: JUDGE ORDERS 2 WOMEN BACK TO FIRE ACADEMY
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn yesterday ordered the City Fire Department to reinstate ''forthwith'' with back pay the two women it dismissed as firefighters last September.

title: People Express
description: People Express Airlines Inc. is selling $75 million of convertible, exchangeable subordinated 10.56 percent debentures due in 2008 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Axia Divestiture
description: Axia Inc. said it is divesting itself of its Amprix Electronics division and taking a write-down on its investment in the division.

title: Officer Indicted In Auto Death
description: A Haledon policeman has been indicted in the death of an elderly school crossing guard and injuries to three schoolchildren struck by his car, authorities said.

title: Mattel to Sell Publishing Unit Mattel Inc. said it had signed an agreement in principle to sell its Western Publishing Company unit for about $75 million plus the assumption of certain liabilities to Richard A. Bernstein, a New York investor, and certain members of Western Publishing's management. Mattel, which is based in Hawthorne, Calif,. said it will take a write-down of its investment in Western Publishing of about $45 million in its fourth quarter, ending Jan. 31.
description: Western Publishing, with headquarters in Racine, Wis., produces juvenile books and operates a commercial printing business. Mattel is primarly a designer and producer of toys and hobby products.

title: BULGARIAN FREED FROM ITALIAN JAIL
description: A Bulgarian charged with complicity in the shooting of Pope John Paul II was released from jail by Rome magistrates today and placed under house arrest because of health problems said to require medical treatment.

title: Mexico Debt Restructured Mexican finance officials signed 11 agreements yesterday with a group of international banks to complete the restructuring of almost $23 billion, or 98 percent, of Mexico's public sector debt falling due between August 1982 and December 1984, Banque Nationale de Paris announced.
description: The French bank served as the agent for the agreements signed in New York, which cover the restructuring of more than $323 million of debt owed by 11 industrial affiliates of the Fisomex group, a Mexican public sector financial group.

title: CONCHEMCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $39,000 for the quarter and $202,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $430,000 for the quarter and $1,163,000 for the year.

title: Circuit Maker Posts Profit The National Semiconductor Corporation yesterday reported net income for its second quarter, ended Dec. 11, of $13.2 million, or 15 cents a share, contrasted to a $3.5 million loss a year earlier. Second-quarter sales rose 32.9 percent, to $369 million, from $277.5 million a year earlier.
description: For the first 28 weeks of its fiscal year, the manufacturer of integrated circuits and transistors, based in Santa Clara, Calif., earned $24.1 million, or 29 cents a share, contrasted to a deficit of $3.4 million in the year- earlier period. Sales rose to $801.5 million, from $627.9 million in the corresponding period of 1982.

title: Most C.D. Rates Climb
description: Interest rates on certificates of deposit rose nationwide for the second consecutive week, but New York rates declined slightly, The Bank Rate Monitor reported yesterday.

title: SCOUTING
description: Trophy Askew

title: Eurobond Prices Little Changed LONDON, Dec. 21 (Reuters) - Eurobond prices were virtually unchanged today in quiet trading. Some dealers have already halted operations for the Christmas holiday, dealers said.
description: Fixed-interest dollar bonds were little changed. The report of the 4.5 percent gain in the United States gross national product in the fourth quarter had no impact on prices.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;  U.S.F.L. Bid to Stabler
description: The Memphis Showboats of the United States Football League said they had offered Ken Stabler , the New Orleans Saints' 37-year-old quarterback, a $1 million salary to join them next year, but only if he could pass a physical examination after undergoing knee surgery next month. Stabler said he knew nothing about the offer, but his agent, Henry Pitts , said he would challenge the Saints to match it.

title: U.S. DIAMOND INDUSTRY 'MAGLIGNED BY INNUENDO'
description: To the Editor:

title: Leonard's Foe Chosen
description: Kevin Howard , who has beaten only Richard Nixon, a journeyman junior middleweight, in his last three fights, will earn the biggest purse of his career when he meets Sugar Ray Leonard on Feb. 25 in the former welterweight champion's first fight in two years. Howard, a former welterweight contender from Philadelphia who has lost to Marlon Starling and Mark Medal this year for an overall 19-4-1 record, will earn ''six figures,'' according to Mike Trainer , Leonard's lawyer.

title: Wilson Foods Sets Debt Accord OKLAHOMA CITY, Dec. 21 (Reuters) - The Wilson Foods Corporation said it had reached agreement with the official creditors' committee in the company's Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings on a plan that will provide full repayment of all trade creditors' claims against the company. Wilson said its debts subject to the agreement total about $31 million. The company said terms of the agreement call for repayment of claims with interest at 9 1/2 percent calculated from April 22, the date the company filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.
description: It did so in an effort to shed costly labor contracts. At the end of last month, the company said it had resolved its last labor dispute and could emerge from Chapter 11 early next year.

title: THE TWELVE WHAT-IFS
description: A Chinese pundit, surveying American politics, would have to conclude that this is the time of the Three Certainties.

title: AGRICULTURAL BANKER RETIRING AFTER 38 YEARS
description: Walter Minger, head of the Bank of America's worldwide agribusiness relationships, announced yesterday that he plans to retire on Feb. 1.

title: 16 HOUSE DEMOCRATS WARN REAGAN ON ACTION ON DEFICIT
description: Sixteen House Democrats warned President Reagan today that unless he participated in ''good-faith'' efforts to reduce the growing budget deficit next year, they might vote against legislation to increase the Government's borrowing authority.

title: T.W.A. Confirms Cuts
description: Trans World Airlines confirmed today that it is planning to lay off several hundred of its flight attendants early next year, a move the flight attendants union called ''blackmail pressure tactics.''

title: MUSIC: PIANIST AT TULLY HALL
description: RAVEL'S ''Miroirs'' was the work best suited to Christopher O'Riley's sterling pianistic gifts at his recital Monday night in Alice Tully Hall presented by Young Concert Artists. Each of these pieces emerged delicate and refined, Mr. O'Riley creating a ''dry'' pianistic sound subtly used for coloration, the figuration of ''Noctuelles'' sweeping along in bursts of impulse.

title: AMERICAN MEDICAL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 4-for-3 stock split paid Feb. 2.

title: Johnny Cash a Patient At Betty Ford Center
description: Johnny Cash, who underwent ulcer surgery last month, is seeking to avoid drug dependency at the same treatment center in which Elizabeth Taylor is a patient, Mr. Cash's sister Reba Hancock said today.

title: MERCHANTS COOPERATIVE BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including a nonrecurring gain of $7 million on the sale of mortgage loans. c-Net loss.

title: Car Sales Up in E.E.C.
description: Sales of passenger cars in the European Economic Community rose by more than 3 percent in 1983, and sales of commercial vehicles increased by 1.5 percent, according to industry figures released today.

title: More Barriers Erected To Guard White House
description: Carrying on what President Reagan called ''just normal security precautions,'' workmen increased White House fortifications today by erecting concrete barriers on Pennsylvania Avenue to thwart potential terrorist car bombers.

title: A SOUTH BRONX TASK MADE A LITTLE PLEASANTER
description: To the Editor:

title: THRIFTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
FEDERAL JUDGE BARS ANY EXCLUSION OF JURORS SOLELY BECAUSE OF RACE
description: Prosecutors cannot systematically exclude people from serving on juries solely on account of their race, a Federal judge in Brooklyn ruled yesterday.

title: CPC International To Shut 2 Plants CPC International said it would phase out two of its largest plants, resulting in an after-tax charge against 1983 earnings of about $55 million. The company, based in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., is closing the plants, which will be rebuilt ahead of schedule, to accelerate a previously announced investment program.
description: James W. McKee Jr., the chairman and chief executive, said the move ''is prompted by our determination to speed the multiyear expansion and productivity improvement program, to pay more of its costs now rather than later, and to receive the benefits earlier.''

title: BEATRICE FOODS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Reflecting a gain of $21 million from the sale of businesses and a reduction of divestiture reserves of $23 million.

title: Jakarta Trade Surplus
description: Indonesia registered a trade surplus of $1.94 billion for the first eight months of 1983, the Trade Ministry said today. The value of exports during the eight months was $13.43 billion, while imports came to $11.49 billion.

title: TV Employees Arrested; For Showing Picture
description: Obstruction-of-justice charges against four employees of a television station were dropped today. The station, WCSC-TV, had broadcast a picture of a man charged with a series of rapes and murders after the police asked that the photo not be used.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: ENCORES Back in the 1950's, Japanese motion pictures drew attention to intellectual and artistic directions that were emerging in that country from the wreckage of World War II. These films, hailed by critics and audiences in art film houses, symbolized a resurgence sparked by one studio in particular that is being honored in reruns in a series, ''A Tribute to Daiei,'' by the Japan Society, 333 East 47th Street.

title: O.E.C.D. GLOOMY ON EUROPE
description: Strong economic recoveries next year in the United States and Japan will not be sufficient to bring an equivalent resurgence in Western Europe, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today.

title: CLOTHESTIME INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: Corrected from Wednesday's editions.

title: F.C.C. SEES A RISE OF $6.80 ON PHONES
description: The average household will pay about $6.80 more a month for local telephone service in 1989 because of various Federal Communications Commission decisions over the last few years and the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, a commission study predicted today.

title: FLORIDA'S BAN ON 26 FOOD PRODUCTS PROMPTS E.P.A. PESTICIDE INVESTIGATION
description: The Environmental Protection Agency said today it was investigating reports that high levels of a cancer-causing pesticide, ethylene dibromide, were being found in flour, pancake mixes and other widely used food products.

title: Pollin Accused in Suit
description: Abe Pollin , the principal owner of the Capital Centre in Landover, Md., has been accused of diverting $1 million of the arena's revenues to its two main tenants, the Washington Capitals and the Washington Bullets, both of which he owns. The charge, which Pollin called ''groundless,'' was made in a lawsuit filed last week in Prince George's County Circuit Court by Arnold Heft , a real estate developer who owns a one-third interest in the arena.

title: COUNTRYWIDE CREDIT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
No Headline
description: People

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Snow Arrives Early in Park

title: REAGAN SIGNS PAPERS SAYING HE WILL RUN IN 2 STATE PRIMARIES
description: President Reagan, in another step toward what his aides say will be a formal declaration for re-election, signed papers today certifying that he intends to seek the Republican nomination for President in the New Hampshire and Illinois primary elections.

title: TechnologySteven J. Marcus Solar Power Market Grows
description: devices that convert sunlight directly into electricity - have been available for decades but were far too expensive for general use. In the early 1960's, they began routinely powering space satellites, where durability and light weight were essential, at prices of about $600 a watt. At that time, capital costs for obtaining electricity from conventional power plants were less than 50 cents a watt.

title: 2 HITACHI AIDES PLEAD GUILTY IN I.B.M. CASE
description: Two of nine employees of Hitachi Ltd. who have been listed as fugitives pleaded guilty today in Federal court to charges of conspiring to transport computer trade secrets stolen from the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: BLOUNT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30

HELPFUL HARDWARE;
SPECIALIZED GADGETS
description: GADGETEERS are a special breed. Many like a gadget almost as much for the ingenuity of its design as for the job it actually does.

title: ADVERTISING ;  Addenda
description: * Ms. magazine increasing its newsstand price 25 cents, to $1.75, beginning with the February issue.

title: ORWELL'S UNDERSTATEMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: SEA RIG SINKING CALLED AVOIDABLE
description: A broken porthole, short-circuited controls and poor human response caused the sinking of the giant drilling rig Ocean Ranger two years ago, the Coast Guard concluded today, adding that better training and safety procedures might have prevented the accident in which 84 lives were lost.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in New York Day by Day on Dec. 12 about the lighting of evergreens on Park Avenue misidentified the original sponsor of the tree plantings and decorating. He was Edward B. Lockwood.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 22, 1983

title: Key Rates
description: * Nuveen index, John Nuveen & CompanySalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: I.B.M. Receives Navy Contract WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (Reuters) - The International Business Machines Corporation received a $683.4 million contract for six sets of advanced submarine combat systems, the Navy said. The Air Force said it had given the Martin Marietta Corporation a $139.3 million contract for continued flight test support as well as design and development of transportation and handling equipment for the MX missile.
description: The Boeing Company also received an Air Force contract, for $86.2 million, for the production of two KE-3A aircraft for Saudi Arabia. The Army said it had given an $82.6 million contract to the Magnavox Government and Industrial Electronic Company for high-frequency radios. Magnavox is a unit of the North American Philips Corporation.

title: TRAVELODGE INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Inquiry Focuses On Stadium Beer
description: Federal authorities are investigating the Anheuser-Busch brewery in connection with its apparent near-monopoly in supplying beer to major league baseball stadiums.

title: SCREEN: GERMAN 'MALOU,' A DAUGHTER'S MEMORIES
description: ''Malou'' was shown as part of the 1982 New Directors/New Films Series. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review that appeared in The New York Times on April 25, 1982. The film opens today at the 72d Street East, at Second Avenue.

title: VOLUME UP
description: Stock prices rose sharply yesterday and volume swelled, with investors newly optimistic about interest rates in the wake of two Government reports showing moderating economic growth and low inflation.

title: A TALE OF THREE CHRISTMAS PRESENTS
description: which I ordinarily envision as a 25-day marathon toward the base of a fir tree - my faith in the truth of Christmas wavers. In this expansive season of belief, good works and candles set against the darkness, I am always tempted to constrict my vision and put my faith in the one person I can count on to pull Christmas off - myself.

title: Reagans' New Year's Eve
description: President and Mrs. Reagan will travel to California two days after Christmas to ring in the New Year with old friends at the estate of Walter Annenberg in Palm Springs, aides said today. The Reagans will attend a traditional New Year's Eve party with other members of the Cabinet and friends from their Hollywood days.

title: A NOT SO MAD RACE FOR DELEGATES ON CAPITOL HILL
description: The selection of the first delegates to the 1984 Democratic Presidential convention will take place early next year not in the chill air of Iowa or New Hampshire, as has been the case for many years, but in the temperature-controlled back rooms of Capitol Hill.

title: GREYHOUND BUSES ARE ALL OPERATING
description: Greyhound's full fleet of 3,800 buses rolled today for the first time since the start of a strike Nov. 2. The company said ridership was ''reported strong,'' although some buses were nearly empty and at least one run was canceled.

title: Debt Issues
description: * United Brands Co. filed for an offering of $75 million of senior subordinated debentures due in 1999, through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

title: DANCE: HAWKINS'S HOLIDAY PROGRAM
description: -week holiday children's program, which opened on Tuesday at Symphony Space, as an alternative to ''The Nutcracker.'' Mr. Hawkins's modern dances are about as far from classical ballet in technique and mood as one could get. Yet, like the New York City Ballet's ''Nutcracker,'' this fine program's two dances do look back to another time, are about essential human emotions, and never condescend to their audiences.

title: OH, WHAT A LOVELY WAR! THE BATTLE OF CAVIAR PRICES
description: IT is not unusual for large wars to

title: Israelis Arrest Journalist
description: Israeli forces arrested a Lebanese correspondent for Agence France-Presse in southern Lebanon, a spokesman for the agency said today, and accused him of terrorist activity.

title: Israeli Army Women Told Not to Hitchhike
description: Israel has banned army women from hitchhiking on open roads because of a spate of sexual attacks on them and the killing of an army woman who hitchhiked.

title: MAKING THE MOST OF CHRISTMAS PLANTS
description: but watching it slowly drop all its leaves and die is not. Some species are doomed from the start and deserve to be discarded, but others will give pleasure for years.

title: Continental Air In Contract Rift HOUSTON, Dec. 21 (AP) - A demand by striking Continental Air Lines pilots that those pilots who ignored the walkout be displaced by returning strikers led to the termination of contract talks, company officials said. Representatives of the Air Line Pilots Association and company representatives had been meeting in Los Angeles before Continental broke off the talks Tuesday.
description: The strike began after Continental filed for Chapter 11 under the Federal Bankruptcy Code, then slashed its route structure, laid off many employees and cut pay sharply for workers kept on the job. A Continental spokesman, Bruce Hicks, said the negotiations had been making progress and airline negotiators were encouraged before the pilots' demand on displacing working pilots.

title: DESIGNERS' SLEIGHT OF HAND: MAKING SMALL SPACES LARGER
description: FOR many New Yorkers interior design is not a matter of what to do with spacious apartments that have abundant light and dramatic views, but simply how to make a small, dull apartment, often with a low ceiling, more livable. Even in New York's high- rent districts, there are many studio and one-bedroom apartments needing remedial design attention because of their bleak combination of unimaginative layouts and small size. In some cases, the remedy is a matter of inches borrowed from the entry and lent to the living room; in others, extra space can be found only in illusion.

title: UNION'S STAND CLOUDING U.S. STEEL MILL'S FUTURE
description: On a cold morning this week, as biting snow swirled in the air, two men in a dilapidated car stopped by the 83d Street gate of the South Works, the vast United States Steel Corporation plant on Chicago's South Side.

title: EDWARDS, A. G. & SONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Allied to Sell Fertilizer Unit
description: The Allied Corporation and E.F. Hutton & Company said they had signed a letter of intent for the sale of Allied's liquid fertilizer business to a newly formed company. Terms were not disclosed, but Allied said the sale will result in a charge to 1983 net income of $140 million.

title: CONCEPT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $44,000 for the latest first quarter and $35,000 for the year-ago first quarter. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect a pooling of interest in 1983.

title: FOTOMAT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income.

title: AID TO QADDAFI IN '71 CHARGED
description: A former American intelligence analyst said today that United States Embassy officials in Tripoli, Libya, betrayed military officers plotting to overthrow the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi in 1971 and that this led to the execution of the plotters.

title: COURT TO WEIGH CUSTODY IN COAST STARVATION CASE
description: A state judge agreed today to consider a request by Riverside County to place Elizabeth Bouvia in the custody of a public conservator to make decisions regarding her health and safety.

title: NICARAGUA SAYS BISHOP WAS HELD AND APPARENTLY SLAIN BY REBELS
description: The Government said today that an American-born bishop had been kidnapped by rebels along with nearly 500 residents of a northern village. Later the Government radio said ''it appears'' that the bishop was killed by his captors.

title: 'YELLOW RAIN' IN NEED OF RE-EMAINATION
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. - SOVIET SPACE RACE: 'HARE AND TORTOISE'
description: A Congressional study has concluded that, while the United States leads the Soviet Union in most areas of space technology, it could profit by emulating the Russian program in at least two respects: its more clearly defined long- range goals and the more evolutionary way in which it develops new systems out of old ones.

title: THREE DIFFERENT APPROACHES TO PRESCHOOL EDUCATION
description: -year- olds snacked on pineapple juice and fruit bars, Shirley Lanser, a teacher at the City and Country School in Greenwich Village, read aloud from a book about a trip on a thruway. As she held up the page picturing a tollbooth, a flaxen-haired girl interrupted. ''This juice has pineapple in it,'' she observed.

title: REPORT DISPUTES MARINE AN ATTACK
description: The House subcommittee that investigated the bombing of the Marine compound in Beirut issued the full text of its report today. It disputed several key explanations that Gen. Paul X. Kelley, the Marine Corps Commandant, offered in Congressional testimony last month.

title: Continental Talks Ended LOS ANGELES, Dec. 21 (UPI) - Contract talks between Continental Air Lines and striking pilots have broken off, but spokesmen for the company and union differed today on the cause of the new stalemate.
description: A Continental spokesman, Bruce Hicks, said the two sides were at an impasse because the pilots' union made a demand that would force dismissal of some pilots who have been flying during the strike.

title: CRITICS PICK 'ENDEARMENT'
description: ''Terms of Endearment,'' James Brooks's adaptation of Larry McMurtry's mother-daughter story spanning 30 years, was voted the best film of 1983 by the New York Film Critics Circle yesterday. ''Fanny and Alexander,'' Ingmar Bergman's vision of a turn-of-the-century Swedish childhood, was voted best foreign film, and Mr. Bergman was voted best director.

title: MUSIC: WORKS BY 4 COMPOSERS PLAYED
description: COMPOSERS from England, Denmark, San Francisco and New York brought pieces to The Kitchen on Sunday.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Carl Yastrzemski , the Boston Red Sox slugger who just retired after 23 seasons, will join the sports staff of the Boston television station WNEV, and plans to begin his duties at spring training. . . . One of his teammates last year, the outfielder Tony Armas , had three bone chips and a bone spur removed from his right elbow yesterday and will wear a cast for about a month. . . . R. H. (Buzzer) Hadingham , a 68-year-old former sporting goods manufacturer, became chairman of the All-England Club, which sponsors the Wimbledon tournament. . . . Al Secord , the Chicago Black Hawk wing who has missed 25 games this season, said he would sit out the rest of the season because of a persistent stomach ailment he believes he developed in a fight during the season-opener against the St. Louis Blues. . . . The Boston Bruins will lose Dave Silk for six weeks and Keith Crowder indefinitely. Both forwards were injured in a victory over Hartford Tuesday. Silk separated his left shoulder and Crowder sprained his right knee.

title: Bid for Eagle Star
description: The London Takeover Panel ruled that the competing bids for Eagle Star Holdings P.L.C. cannot be increased after Dec. 30. In the third round of bidding for Eagle Star, a life insurer, B.A.T Industries P.L.C., a tobacco and retailing concern, on Dec. 14 offered $9.52 a share, or a total of about $1.32 billion. Allianz Versicherungs A.G., West Germany's largest insurance group, earlier that day had bid about $9.38 a share.

title: MARK IV INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After a loss of $97,025 for the quarter and a gain of $178,185 for the 9 months from discontinued operations. Year-ago share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split on Oct. 27, 1983.

title: BOBBIES LOSING THEIR PLACE IN LONDONERS' HEARTS
description: For the Metropolitan Police Department - universally known as Scotland Yard because its first headquarters was on a short street where, in the 12th century, Scottish kings stayed while in London - this has been a hectic month.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Nets vs. Dallas Mavericks, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 8:05 P.M. In the clubs' only earlier meeting this season, at Dallas, Jay Vincent beat the Nets by hitting the winning basket with 11 seconds left.

title: Q & A
description: Q.

title: Sweden Bars Computers On Way to Soviet
description: Sweden barred a shipment of 30 tons of American-made computer components from being sent to the Soviet Union today, classifying the cargo as ''war material.''

title: IN ELMHURST, CAROLERS IN SARIS, LETTERS TO EL NINO, SNACKS FOR PAPA NOEL
description: Sweet are the uses of Yuletide diversity.

title: RIGHTS ISSUE PERILS CITY-SALVATION ARMY PACT
description: Programs run by the Salvation Army under a $5 million contract with New York City are in jeopardy because the Army failed to comply with a mayoral executive order that contractors with the city not discriminate against homosexuals in hiring.

title: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 23, 1983 International
description: A Pentagon inquiry into the bombing of the Marine compound in Beirut on Oct. 23 has concluded that serious failures in the Marine chain of command contributed to the tragedy, according to Reagan Administration officials. One official said that ''generals and admirals'' in the European Command were included in the ''sharp criticism.'' (Page A1, Col. 6.) The U.S. Marines and French troops in Beirut were warned in an anonymous telephone call to leave Lebanon within 10 days or face a major attack. The caller said he represented a Moslem terrorist group. (A8:1-2.)

title: REAGAN'S NEXT BUDGET COUNTS ON STORNG G.N.P.
description: President Reagan's next budget, for the 1985 fiscal year, will assume a strong 4.5 percent growth of the economy next year, slightly higher inflation and slightly lower interest rates, the Administration said today.

title: WHOM THE U.S. LETS IN
description: To the Editor:

title: MARCUS CORP reports earnings for 12 wks to Nov 10
; A BASIC EDUCATION TOOL STILL NEGLECTED: LIBRARIES
description: T o the Editor:

title: SCOUTING
description: Seeking Strength

title: SCREEN: GOSPEL CONCERT
description: THERE is some wildly exhilarating music to be heard in ''Gospel,'' a concert film featuring some of the finest performers in gospel music. Filmed on the concert stage of a theater in Oakland, Calif., where the film's acts perform before an enraptured audience, ''Gospel'' offers the neophyte an exciting sampler of pre-eminent gospel musicians. For the already converted, the film captures these performers vividly and at very close range.

title: 3 DESIGNS FOR PROPOSED WETSWAY PARK DISPLAYED BY STATE
description: Plans for a 93-acre Westway State Park to run along the Hudson River from Battery Park City to 34th Street were announced yesterday by state officials. The park, with plazas, esplanades, playing fields, lawn areas and benches overlooking the waterfront, would be built over the proposed underground highway.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Christmas message in Harlem, the good news to the poor, is that 'you're not going to be poor anymore.'

title: Ford's Son Is Penalized
description: The driver's license of Jack Ford, son of former President Gerald R. Ford, has been suspended for six months on a reckless driving conviction in San Diego County, the state Department of Motor Vehicles said today. Mr. Ford, 31 years old, of Leucadia, was arrested on a drunken driving charge Aug. 16 by a highway patrolman, who said he saw Mr. Ford's car weaving and speeding. Mr. Ford, who refused to submit to a chemical test of his blood, breath or urine as required by state law, later pleaded guilty to reckless driving in a plea bargain.

title: COUNCIL PANEL DEBATES BILL TO BAR CLUB DISCRIMINATION
description: Discrimination would be prohibited by New York City in clubs other than those that are ''distinctly private'' under a bill debated yesterday by a City Council panel.

title: REVERBERATIONS SEEN IN RULING ON RACIALLY BASED BAN OF JURORS
description: The direct impact of a judicial ruling Tuesday that prosecutors could not systematically keep blacks off juries is difficult to assess, in part because no one knows how widespread the practice is. Prosecutors studying Judge Eugene H. Nickerson's ruling in Federal District Court in Brooklyn in McCray v. Abrams acknowledge privately that for a variety of reasons - tactical and demographic, as well as egalitarian - they are increasingly unlikely to seek an all-white jury such as the one that, in 1980, convicted Michael McCray, a black, of robbing a white Pratt Institute student two years earlier.

title: SCOUTING
description: His Own Man

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Hawks, at Atlanta. The Knicks are on a road-game roll, winning their last two, three of their last four and four of their last six. They have the third-best road record in the league this season, behind Philadelphia and Boston. (Television - WTBS, 8:10 P.M.)

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: O ALBANY! Improbable City of Political Wizards, Fearless Ethnics, Spectacular Aristocrats, Splendid Nobodies and Underrated Scoundrels. By William Kennedy. 402 pages. Illustrated with photographs and maps. Washington Park/Viking. $25.

title: KEAN, AT MIDTERM, CITES SUCCESSES AND FAILURES
description: As he arrives at the midpoint of his four-year term, Governor Kean says he is elated about the prospects of major economic development along the Hudson River waterfront, but wary of a return of the economic problems that greeted him when he took office.

title: U.S. GRANTS $15 MILLION FOR HOUSING IN THE CITY
description: The largest housing grant in New York City's history, $15 million, was presented yesterday to a civic organization for 1,100 units of middle-income housing.

title: F.C.C. ALTERS POLICY ON TV FOR CHILDREN
description: The Federal Communications Commission yesterday approved a new policy that could change the obligation of commercial television stations to provide programming for children.

title: A DECISION FOR ONLY THE FALKLANDERS TO MAKE
description: To the Editor:

title: Sweden Asks 2 Envoys From Soviet to Leave
description: Two Soviet diplomats been asked to leave Sweden on suspicion of spying, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said tonight.

title: Police Dept. Test Upheld by Court
description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday upheld the validity of a new oral section of the New York City Police Department's test for selecting lieutenants.

title: UNITED FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Year-ago share earnings have been restated to give effect to a 100 percent stock dividend. Year-ago results have been reclassified.

title: INTENTIONALLY OR NOT, IT SEEMS, A SIGNAL WAS SENT
description: Three weeks ago, President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon left his talks with President Reagan feeling he had firm American backing and understood what Washington expected. But lately, he has been so confused by pronouncements and signals from Washington that he phoned his ambassador here to find out what was going on.

title: WARDS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Net income for the latest quarter and 9 months include $265,000 of tax benefit amortization. Year-ago net income figures have been restated and increased by $340,000 for the quarter and $490,000 for the 9 months as a results of tax credits arising from the June 1981 merger with Lafayette Radio Electronics.

title: DEBT REDUCTION METHOD IS APPROVED BY S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today approved on a 4-to-0 vote an accounting device to let companies dress up their financial condition and show higher earnings by wiping long- term debt off their balance sheets.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: TRIAL MEMENTO
description: For several days this week, Edward Boyar, the prosecutor in the election-fraud trial of former State Senator Vander L. Beatty, carried a large, shiny hard-cover book among the papers he lugged to the Brooklyn courtroom each morning.

title: AMERICAN FURNITURE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 3
VICORP RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for 14 wks to Oct 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in August 1983.

title: Bell Atlantic In A.T.& T. Fight WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) - One of the seven Bell companies to be spun off from the American Telephone and Telegraph Company has signed a $30 million contract to sell the Federal Government the 200,000 phones it now leases, touching off an unexpected court battle with its current parent.
description: In a complaint filed in Federal court here, A.T.& T. maintains that Bell Atlantic has violated the terms of A.T.& T.'s antitrust settlement. Under the settlement, the leased equipment that Bell Atlantic is selling is supposed to be transferred to A.T.& T. on Jan. 1, the company said.

title: NEW STYLE OF HOUSING IS GOING UP IN HOEARD BEACH
description: The Howard Beach section of Queens is familiar terrain to Leon Weinstein: He built ranch houses there in the late 1950's.

title: RECITAL: DONNA ROLL
description: DONNA ROLL was billed a ''dramatic soprano'' at her recital at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday night, and so she turned out to be. Miss Roll, who studied with David Blair McClosky at Boston University and who was accompanied by the pianist William Merrill, had both the vocal power and the dramatic skill to give convincing performances of selections ranging from Wagner's ''Du bist der Lenz'' to Strauss's ''Einerlei.''

title: NATIONAL SEMICONDUCTOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 11
description: b-Net loss.

title: LOTTERY'S 'FAT ONE' SHOWERS CASH ON SPAIN
description: For weeks, if not months, Spaniards have been waiting breathlessly for the arrival of ''El Gordo'' - ''The Fat One.'' And they are not talking about Santa Claus.

title: WIC WESTERN INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
No Excuses for the Princess
description: When a race horse with a fancy reputation suffers a resounding defeat, many an owner's first impulse is to run to the telephone and send out for a veterinarian and an X-ray machine. Defeat is easier to bear, and can even be recast into gallantry, if it can be excused by a previously undetected injury, no matter how insignificant.

title: 5,000 Thai Rebels Reported to Surrender
description: More than 5,000 Communist guerrillas and their sympathizers surrendered to the authorities today at a formal ceremony in northern Thailand.

title: STANDUN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including income of $62,000 for the quarter and a loss of $455,000 for the year from discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $4,000 from discontinued operations.

title: COMMON MARKET TO END SANCTIONS IT IMPOSED ON SOVIET OVER POLAND
description: The European Common Market has decided against renewing the economic sanctions it imposed on the Soviet Union after martial law was declared in Poland in December 1981, a senior executive of the trade bloc said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: A film review yesterday of ''Malou'' incorrectly listed the theater where it is playing. It is Guild's Embassy 72d Street 1, on Broadway.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Carols for Commuters

title: Hoffmeyer Suspended
description: The National Hockey League has suspended Bob Hoffmeyer, a defenseman for the Devils, for six games for a stick-swinging incident

title: FRENCH OFFICIAL BACKS BEIRUT ROLE
description: France's Minister of Defense, reacting to the latest attack on French troops in Lebanon and the threat of new raids, described France today as ''the indispensable Western power in the Middle East.''

title: STANDARD MICROSYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Midnight Concert
description: The S.E.M. Ensemble will perform a free program of classical and 20th- century music tomorrow at midnight at the Paula Cooper Gallery, 155 Wooster Street in SoHo.

title: Driver With 'Gift' of 2 Rifles For Reagan Seized in Capital
description: A Maryland man, bearing what he said were ''gifts for the President,'' was arrested outside the White House today on charges of carrying unregistered weapons, the Secret Service said.

title: 6 Firehouses Ready to Close AsKeanMeetingIsCanceled
description: Six Newark firehouses were preparing today to shut down Friday after a meeting between Governor Kean and Democratic legislative leaders seeking a solution to their plight was called off.

title: FRENCHMEN WHO SAW ASSAD SAYS SYRIAN IS CONVALESCING
description: A French magazine editor, who interviewed President Hafez el-Assad of Syria this week, said today that the President had told him he was convalescing but had not specified the nature of his illness.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Hardly a King's Ransom

title: Rod Cameron, Actor, 73; Career Spanned 30 Years
description: Rod Cameron, a Canadian-born actor who starred in many Hollywood films in the 1940's and 50's, died at a Gainesville hospital Wednesday after a long illness.

title: Declaration on Display
description: One of the 22 copies of the first printing of the Declaration of Independence, dating from July 1776, has gone on permanent display at the Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street.

title: GOVERNMENT SHUTS A DOOR TO CAREERS
description: To the Editor:

title: JIM WALTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
DURABLES ORDERS UP LAST MONTH
description: Orders placed with factories for durable goods rose 4 percent last month, but the overall showing masked a disappointing drop for capital goods used by businesses, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: OFFICIALS ACCUSE 11 BEER DEALERS OF TAX EVASION
description: New York City officials yesterday accused 11 beer distributors and some of their officers and managers of evading millions of dollars in city beer taxes.

title: PARDON DENIED FOR LEO FRANK IN 1913 SLAYING
description: The State Board of Pardons and Paroles today denied a posthumous pardon to Leo M. Frank, a Jewish factory superintendent who was convicted of the murder of a girl in Atlanta in 1913 and who was lynched two years later by a furious mob in one of the nation's worst outbursts of anti-Semitism.

title: HOUSING WOES LESSEN ALLURE OF THE CROWDED SILICON VALLEY
description: A young engineer was recently recruited by a major computer maker here. His house back home in South Carolina was worth $67,000, but the engineer and his wife could find nothing comparable near his new job here for much less than $235,000 - far more than they could afford on his new salary of $45,000.

title: BRIEFING
description: Mrs. Brunson's 113th

title: GANDHI CALLED AN INSPIRATION BEHIND A GIFT TO THE NEEDIEST
description: ''Poverty imposes its own obligations, as Gandhi well knew, and one of them is that the poor must support one another.''

title: Labor Dept. Post Filled Robert A. G. Monks, a former chairman of the Maine Republican Party and a substantial contributor to Vice President Bush's 1980 campaign, has been named administrator of the Labor Department's pension and welfare benefits program.
description: The $57,000-a-year job will make Mr. Monks, an energy entrepreneur and sometime candidate for the Senate, the Government's chief monitor of the way business manages $600 billion of private pension fund assets.

title: Jobless Benefit Claims Down ; Jobless Benefit Claims Lowest Since Mid-'79
description: Initial claims for state jobless benefits dropped 40,000 in early December to 365,000, the lowest weekly total since mid-1979, the Labor Department reported today.

title: BELGIAN EX-NAZI ADMITS WORKING FOR U.S. INTELLIGENCE AFTER 1945
description: Robert Jan Verbelen, a former Belgian Nazi leader, admitted today that he was a spy for the United States in Vienna for eight years after World War II, heading a network of 100 agents.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;  St. John's Star Honored
