description: St. John's University, which has developed a number of great basketball players, made its claim to fame in a new category yesterday. Todd Jamison , its talented passer from Huntington, L.I., was named as the starting quarterback on The Associated Press?Little All-America college football team. Jamison, who completed 128 of 238 passes for 1,631 yards and 18 touchdowns, was among the nation's leaders in total offense and passing efficiency with 212.4 yards a game.

title: Quake Hits 4 Cities in Guinea; 10 Die Amid Heavy Damage
description: An earthquake struck the West African nation of Guinea today, and the Guinean state radio said it caused extensive damage in 4 cities and killed 10 people.

title: GREECE BARS STUDY ON 6 JOURNALISTS
description: The Government has rejected a request from Greece's largest-selling newspaper for an investigation of six Western journalists on charges that they are involved in a conspiracy against ''the freedom and interests of the Greek people.''

title: American Express Adds to IDS Bid By Reuters
description: The American Express Company will add a 10-year, $40 million note to the price for the proposed purchase of the Alleghany Corporation's Investors Diversified Services unit, the companies said. They said that the note would be added to the previously announced cash and stock transaction to offset the impact of the decline of about 15 percent in the price of American Express stock since the deal was announced in September. Yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, American Express rose 75 cents, to $32.375.

title: Reagan Choice Heads Panel
description: With two Democratic-sponsored members dissenting, the newly reconstituted Civil Rights Commission concurred Wednesday in President Reagan's designation of Clarence M. Pendleton Jr. as its chairman.

title: Money Fund Assets Drop Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds declined in the week ended Wednesday, but short-term yields on the funds rose sharply, the Investment Company Institute and Donaghue's Money Fund Report said yesterday.
description: The institute said that total assets fell $761 million, to $164.94 billion. In the previous week, assets rose $7.5 million, to $165.7 billion, after four consecutive weeks of decline.

title: GODFREY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
STUDY FIRST, PLAY LATER
description: It was Saturday morning and Daniel Cooper

title: S. & P. Warning On Xerox Debt Ratings for short- and long-term debt of the Xerox Corporation, the Xerox Credit Corporation and Xerox's overseas financing subsidi=?ary may be downgraded, Standard & Poor's announced yesterday.
description: The rating agency said Xerox's earnings are now five times higher than interest payments, compared with 10 times higher two years ago, while return on capital has declined by half since 1980.

title: 2 Beirut Dead Identified
description: The last two bodies from the Oct. 23 Marine headquarters bombing in Beirut, Lebanon, have been identified.

title: WHAT THE DEMOCRATS REALLY HAVE TO FACE
description: After tedious months of internecine political boredom, Democrats are now seeing some bare-knuckled combat. The two front-runners - Walter F. Mondale and John Glenn - are hammering away at one another.

title: SUPER RITE FOODS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
SHARON FREEMAN BACK WITH HOLIDAY JAZZ SUITE
description: SHARON FREEMAN'S jazz suite for five voices and instrumental ensemble, ''A Christmas Celebration,'' which made its debut last December at Sweet Basil, is having its second annual presentation this week through Sunday in the club at 88 Seventh Avenue South.

title: Drunken Driving Law Upheld in California
description: California's drunken driving law was unanimously upheld today by the state Supreme Court.

title: RITE AID CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
ARAFAT EMBRACES MUBARAK IN CAIRO IN RECONCILIATION
description: Yasir Arafat, who was evacuated from northern Lebanon Tuesday with 4,000 of his followers, met in Cairo today with President Hosni Mubarak.

title: U.S. HAILS ARAFAT-MUBARAK TALKS, PROMPTING A DISPUTE WITH ISRAEL
description: The Reagan Administration praised the meeting between Yasir Arafat and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt today as ''an encouraging development'' toward reviving stalled peace efforts in the Middle East.

title: ON WHOSE SIDE?
description: When Secretary of State Shultz recently observed that American reporters were not ''on our side'' but seemed ''always against us,'' the White House press secretary, Larry Speakes, told reporters: ''I do not think that reflects the attitude of the President.'' Larry, you should have known better.

title: LA QUINTA MOTOR INNS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
New Haircuts, Vintage Shop
description: Evan! Enrico Vezza shouted over his bullhorn, consulting the next name on his yellow legal pad, with the skill of a traffic policeman, he directed the youngman to a just-vacated barber chair toward the rear of the shop.

title: MILITARY TIES WITH CHINA
description: For the last five years, senior American officials have intermittently explored prospects for a military relationship between the United States and China. The Reagan Administration seems to have concluded that the opportunities are limited and that we should not seek too much. This judgment is almost certainly sound.

title: Christmas Brings Extra Work for East Harlem Minister Helping the Poor
description: There is a man in East Harlem called ''black Jesus'' by many in the neighborhood. The Rev. William James said such a description of him was foolishness, but admirers tell tales of his works as remarkable to them as some in the Bible.

title: REPEAL OF ARGENTINA'S AMNESTY IS NEAR
description: An amnesty decreed by the previous military Government for crimes in an antileftist campaign in the 1970's was all but repealed tonight in the first law to be passed by Argentina's new Congress.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST FRIDAY, DECEMBER 23, 1983
description: Companies

title: BROADWAY
description: OF all American novels, Mark Twain's ''Adventures of Huckleberry Finn'' has probably been the most fascinating and the most elusive to American dramatists and composers. Currently, there is something of a logjam on the Mississippi with three theatrical rafts - a musical, a play and a play with music - running the rapids of out-of-town tryouts.

title: 40 Percent of Venice Flooded As High Tides Sweep the City
description: High tides washed over Venice today, and city officials said 40 percent of the city was flooded.

title: CLARK TELLS OF REALIGNING INTERIOR DEPARTMENT JOBS
description: William P. Clark, the new Secretary of the Interior, announced today that he was realigning his department's land, water and energy agencies and that he had selected a new Under Secretary.

title: Texas Town Struggles While Doctor Is Jailed
description: The only doctor in this Central Texas town of 5,500 residents was placed behind bars Wednesday for failing to make family support payments, and the sheriff had to escort him at least once to the hospital for an emergency.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: Tuscan cooking, good and healthy. REMEMBER the bowl of tangerines and walnut-stuffed figs that you pass on the way to your table at Il Cantinori. You may want some for dessert. Not that such desserts as little nut biscuits dipped in sweet wine and a soothing custard with anise- flavored biscuit crumbs (cream Bain Marie-style) at this charming Greenwich Village restaurant aren't delicious. But the simplicity of the fruit and the fig-nut combination marinated in Grand Marnier is the essence of Tuscan cooking - ''buona, sana cucina,'' ''good, healthy cooking.''

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Sondra Locke and her career as sidekick.

title: PUBLISHING: COST OF RECALLING A BOOK
description: AFTER Random House announced that it was recalling 58,000 copies of ''Poor Little Rich Girl: The Life and Legend of Barbara Hutton'' by C. David Heymann, several other publishers independently tried to figure out how much the recall would cost. The figures they came up with, for a printing that size, ranged from $150,000 to $200,000.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;  Top Rating for Leonard
description: When Sugar Ray Leonard makes his return to the ring, he will be ranked as the leading contender for the welterweight championship, according to Jose Sulaiman , president of the World Boxing Council.

title: Cosmos Win, 9-8
description: Andy Parkinson's second goal of the game, 5 minutes 29 seconds into overtime, gave the Cosmos a 9-8 victory over the Chicago Sting last night in a North American Soccer League game before a crowd of 3,681 at Madison Square Garden.

title: W. Virginia Tops Kentucky, 20 -16
description: Jeff Hostetler, who failed to connect on 10 first-half passing attempts, threw two touchdown passes in the second half to lead West Virginia to a 20-16 victory over Kentucky in the Hall of Fame Bowl tonight.

title: SENSORMATIC ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effective May 31, 1983.

title: SCOUTING
description: Rutledge on List Of U.S.F.L. Club

title: FOR MCGUIRE AND NEW OFFICERS, FAREWELL AND HAIL
description: Observing that ''this is a bittersweet experience,'' Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire, who will leave office next week, took part yesterday in graduation ceremonies for 1,144 probationary officers.

title: Black & Decker
description: Black & Decker Inc.'s plans to buy the small appliance division of the General Electric Company led analysts at Standard & Poor's to warn yesterday that Black & Decker's Ax rating on its senior debt might be reduced. The rating agency said the $300 million purchase - to be made with a $100 million three-year note, plus cash and bank borrowings - ''will increase debt leverage from currently moderate levels.''

title: CALLER TELLS U.S. AND FRANCE TO LEAVE BEIRUT IN 10 DAYS
description: The United States marines and French paratroopers here were warned today to leave Lebanon in 10 days or face an attack as powerful as ''a real earthquake under their feet.'' The warning was made by an anonymous telephone caller who said he represented an Islamic group that has attacked both forces before.

title: Bus Wrecks on Icy Road
description: A Greyhound bus overturned on an ice-packed road in southeast Missouri Thursday, injuring at least 20 passengers, some seriously.

title: WHERE'S GOOD NEWS
description: Whatever happens to the good news? Isn't there any seasonal cheer to be found thinking back over a year of dismal headlines about violence, death and disaster?

title: Advertising; Muppet Post for An Adman
description: FOR Robert H. Savage, who has been involved in advertising for all of his working career, the move from Madison Avenue and 58th Street to 117 East 69th Street was more than geographical. He was leaving your standard large agency milieu and had entered a netherworld where table legs might seem to have real feet, where pigs sing and all manner of unworldly creatures are hatched.

title: ART: VERSAILLES 'WRAPAROUND' AT THE METROPOLITAN
description: THE new thing to see at the Metropolitan Museum is the panorama of Versailles by John Vanderlyn. Painted in 1818-19, it is a huge environmental painting that envelops the visitor the way Claude Monet's no less huge paintings of waterlilies envelop the visitor to the Orangerie in Paris.

title: Raybeats at Danceteria
description: The Raybeats, an instrumental rock quartet, will appear tonight at Danceteria (620-0515), 30 West 21st Street. Their set will begin at approximately 2 A.M.; admission is $6 before 11 P.M. and $10 afterward.

title: Betty Carter Singing
description: The jazz singer Betty Carter is appearing through Sunday at Fat Tuesday's (533-7902), Third Avenue and 17th Street. Sets begin tonight and tomorrow at 9 and 11 P.M. and 1 A.M., with a $10 cover and a $7.50 minimum. Sunday, there are sets at 9 and 11 P.M., with an $8.50 cover and a $5 minimum.

title: WITH A DART PAST THE MOON, ROBOT CRAFT GETS NEW MISSION: TO OBSERVE A COMET
description: Before the International Sun-Earth Explorer 3 disappeared behind the moon yesterday, the little robot spacecraft had spent five years observing the flow of charged particles coming from the sun, the solar wind.

title: U.S. Judge Upholds Bible Proclamation
description: The constitutionality of President Reagan's proclamation of 1983 as the Year of the Bible, which was challenged by the American Civil Liberties Union, was upheld today by a Federal district judge.

title: SOFTWARE AG SYSTEMS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
BRANCA, EXPERIMENTAL AND EXCITING
description: GLENN BRANCA, a serious experimental composer, is appearing tonight at the Ritz, the popular rock nightclub at 119 East 11th Street, but those who like the visceral energy of rock need not stay away. Conducting an ensemble of nine musicians and a sound engineer, Mr. Branca will perform - ''Lesson No. 1 for Electric Guitar'' (1979) and ''Indeterminate Activity of Resultant Masses'' (1981), as well as the last movement of his recently completed Symphony No. 4 (''Physics'').

title: ASPEN INSTITUTE REORGANIZES HUMANISTIC STUDY OPERATION
description: The Aspen Institute for Humanistic Studies, in a major reorganization of its resources and staff, has decided to make Wye Plantation on the Eastern Shore of Maryland its principal campus for year-round activities, including seminars.

title: Diner's Journal
description: THE sporadic waves of Soviet immigrants to New York in recent years have added another bright patch to the city's ethnic quilt, and one of the more palpable assets they have brought is their cuisine. Actually, it is difficult to define Russian cuisine, for many of the dishes we associate with it have roots in Georgia, the Ukraine or other formerly autonomous areas of the present-day Soviet Union.

title: AMERICAN SOLAR KING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Share earnings reflect 2-for-1 stock and 3-for-2 stock splits paid in fiscal 1983.

title: Man Hurt in Chemical Leak
description: A man was injured after a 55-gallon drum containing a highly toxic chemical was punctured by a forklift and leaked its contents on a Port Elizabeth dock this afternoon, authorities said.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Show Will Go On

title: FED SEEKS U.S. BANK WRITE-OFFS
description: The Federal Reserve Board proposed yesterday that American banks be required to write off portions of loans to countries that are deemed by banking regulators to be in serious financial trouble. Similar proposals are being issued by the other Federal bank regulators.

title: 3 Officers in Air Force Released by Zimbabwe
description: The Government today released three air force officers with dual British-Zimbabwe citizenship who had been kept in detention despite their acquittal in August of sabotage charges.

title: Union Approves Airline Plan
description: Eastern Airline's largest union, representing 12,000 machinists, is voting more than 2 to 1 in favor of a $367 million employee bail- out plan to keep the financially ailing carrier in the air, a union official said today.

title: CHRISTMAS IN CHURCHES
description: TAKING its traditional note of Christmas, television is suspending normal operations briefly for religious observances.

title: Court Sentence Brings Food and Toys to Needy
description: Dozens of families lined up for free groceries, toys and clothes today, beneficiaries of a wealthy businessman who agreed to spend $90,000 on the needy to stay out of jail for financial irregularities.

title: KENNEDY, ASSAILING REAGAN, URGES NEW DRIVE ON HUNGER
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, describing President Reagan's policies on food assistance as ''inhumane'' and ''indecent,'' called today for a $2.5 billion increase in Federal spending to combat hunger in the United States next year.

title: WHEAT GROWERS ARE SHUNNING GOVERNMENT EFFORTS TO REDUCE CROPS
description: Winter wheat growers, demonstrating a widespread lack of interest in Federal efforts to reduce production, seeded 65 million acres this fall, the Agriculture Department announced today.

title: Not Just Young Drunks, Either
description: The Presidential Commission on Drunk Driving chose the right season to urge a wider attack on the major cause of highway deaths. More than 250,000 Americans have been killed in alcohol-related accidents over the last 10 years. This holiday season accounts for a large portion of the annual toll.

title: SCHOLASTIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $718,000 for the quarter and $3,872,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income.

title: 30,000-Unit Issue
description: The U.S. Playing Card Corporation is offering 30,000 units of notes and warrants to buy common stock at $1,000 per unit through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. Each unit consists of $1,000 of 9 7/8 percent subordinated notes due in 1993, plus 61 warrants to buy an equal number of common shares at a price of $16.375 a share.

title: MEETING OF SCHOLASTIC GIANTS
description: There was considerable reservation among high school basketball experts earlier this month when a national poll ranked Mater Dei of Santa Ana, Calif., the nation's No. 1 team ahead of DeMatha of Hyattsville, Md., and Dunbar of Baltimore.

title: JAZZ: DAVID MURRAY'S STRING ORCHESTRA
description: DAVID MURRAY is determined to do something different with jazz and strings. His string orchesappeared Monday at Sweet Basil (where it will return next Monday) using two basses, two cellos and three violins, plus drums and tympani to create an atmosphere of ethereal dissonance.

title: MRS. FERRARO FOR VICE PRESIDENT
description: Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro is having the political time of her life.

title: NO GLUT OF DOCTORS IN UPSTATE NEW YORK
description: To the Editor:

title: CHURCH BELLS: TINTINNABULATION AROUND THE CITY
description: BELLS are ringing all over New York this weekend, from the lowly plink of doorbells to the insistent clang of vendors' handbells. There are bicycle bells, sleighbells, evocations of silver bells. Every few blocks, church bells chime.

title: ROBESON INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 25
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $572,600 for the quarter and $854,500 for the 9 months. c-Including extraordinary credits of $313,225 for the quarter and $373,225 for the 9 months. Year-ago share earnings have been adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend paid June 1.

title: Jordan Agrees to End Trade Boycott of Egypt
description: Jordan has agreed to end a five-year trade boycott against Egypt and will sign an economic protocol lifting trade restrictions between the two nations, a visiting Egyptian official said today.

title: CHRIS-CRAFT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including a gain of $67,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Flyers Shut Out Devils
description: Ray Allison scored twice less than two minutes apart and assisted on a third goal tonight to lead the Philadelphia Flyers to a 5-0 triumph over the Devils.

title: STAGE: 'GIFTED CHILDREN'
description: IN Donald Margulies's ''Gifted

title: NICARAGUA'S BITTER HARVEST: WAR IN COFFEE FIELDS
description: School vacation began last week, but for many Nicaraguan students there will be no relaxing days at the beach or nights on the town. More than 15,000 of them will spend the next two months as farm laborers.

title: TINY METAL SLIVERS BLAMED FOR SPACESHIP FAILURES
description: Computer problems that delayed the space shuttle Columbia's landing two weeks ago were caused by tiny pieces of solder and gold that touched off short circuits, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.

title: DELAY IS URGED ON ARMY UNIFORMS
description: Representative Joseph P. Addabbo, chairman of the House Defense appropriations subcommittee, today asked Army Secretary John O. Marsh to review plans to buy new camouflage fatigue uniforms after their use in Grenada showed them to be too heavy for the tropics.

title: G.M.-TOYOTA PLAN FOR JOINT VENTURE APPROVED BY F.T.C.
description: A sharply divided Federal Trade Commission decided today that the General Motors Corporation and the Toyota Motor Corporation could jointly build Japanese- designed subcompact cars in California without violating antitrust laws.

title: Building Fudge Out of Fudging
description: The City Planning Commission and the corporation counsel, F.A.O. Schwarz, deserve credit for finding a graceful way out of a complicated mess involving a new office building on Third Avenue built by Kenvic Associates.

title: ART: 'AUSPICIOUS SPIRITS' OF KOREA
description: ''AUSPICIOUS SPIRITS: Korean Folk Paintings and Related Objects'' is both an appropriate and misleading title for the remarkable exhibition that is at the Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street, through Jan. 22. On the appropriate side, ''auspicious'' suggests the pleasure with which Korean artists conjured up bearded dragons, flying turtles and round-faced tigers, and turned them loose in their screens and scrolls. The artists believed that these creatures, like the red suns that hover over their fabulous world, could ward off evil.

title: Cincinnati Bell By Reuters
description: Cincinnati Bell Inc. has agreed to repurchase the 33 percent of its stock held by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company for an average price of $38 a share, the two companies said.

title: Dow Declines 1.32 In Heavy Trading
description: Stock prices ended slightly lower yesterday in heavy trading, with some of the airline issues under pressure because of fears over intensifying fare wars.

title: Wardwell Leaving Post As Head of Asia Society
description: Alan Wardwell will step down as director of the Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, between Jan. 1 and June 30, when the search committee expects to find a successor.

title: Article 130372 -- No Title
description: About $100 million in new commitments will be available for low-interest loans to home buyers in some 21 cities, including New York, the Federal National Mortgage Association has announced.

title: A RAPID ASCENT FOR FETZER
description: Sharp price cutting and a subpar crop of 1983 grapes have eased a worrisome oversupply for many California wine producers, but here on a pastoral Mendocino County hillside, a more appealing problem persists for the Fetzer Vineyards.

title: ISLES WIN 6TH IN A ROW
description: The Islanders have found nearly the perfect offensive balance. They score up and down their lineup, from all four lines - forwards and defensemen alike. And tonight, they almost scored from the penalty box.

title: IRAN SETTLES $472 MILLION BANK CLAIM
description: The Treasury Department announced yesterday that the BankAmerica Corporation would receive a $472 million loan repayment settlement from Iran, the largest claim payment announced since the Iranian revolution in 1979.

title: TRain-Slick Road in Newark
description: Three men were killed and a fourth was critically injured yesterday when a car and a truck collided on a rain- slickened road in Port Newark, the Port Authority police said.

title: NETS BEAT MAVERICKS, 101-98
description: When Coach Stan Albeck decided to take Albert King out of the Nets' starting lineup, it was to ease some of the pressure King felt during the team's recent slide. But when the pressure was on again tonight against the Dallas Mavericks, King was in the game with a chance to seal the Nets' first victory in 11 days.

title: U.S. Landowner Loses Honduras Suit Appeal
description: A Federal appeals court ruled today that the United States can continue to house and train Salvadoran soldiers on land privately owned by a United States citizen in Honduras.

title: CORRECTION
description: A table in Business Day last Friday about long-distance telephone companies misstated the status of Combined Network. The company, which has changed its name to Allnet Communications Services, had revenues of $85 million last year and serves 80,000 customers in 27 cities.

title: ORANGE-CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $19,000. c-Net loss after a loss of $540,000 from discontinued operations.

title: BEATTY IS GUILTY OF A CONSPIRACY IN VOTE FORGERY
description: Former State Senator Vander L. Beatty of Brooklyn was found guilty yesterday of forgery and conspiracy charges stemming from his unsuccessful effort to reverse his defeat in a 1982 Congressional primary.

title: NINA BING
description: Nina Schelemskaya-Schelesnaya Bing, a former ballet dancer and the wife of Sir Rudolph Bing, died Wednesday of complications resulting from a stroke at her apartment in the Essex House.

title: DAMSON OIL CO reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
THE THEATER: 'A CHRISTMAS CAROL' BY FOOLS COMPANY
description: IN lavish productions, ''A Christmas Carol'' has become a seasonal favorite at America's regional theaters. In New York we have become accustomed to chamber dramatizations by such actors as Charles Ludlam and Orson Bean. This year's mini-Scrooge comes directly from England, a one- man show by Rob Inglis, a veteran of the Royal Shakespeare Company. Mr. Inglis's version, adapted from Dickens's own performance script, can be seen mornings through Dec. 31 at the Douglas Fairbanks Theater.

title: A New Trial Is Ordered In Sears Wrench Case
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit today ordered a new trial in a patent infringement suit against Sears, Roebuck & Company by the inventor of a quick-release socket wrench.

title: Action Is Begun In Youth's Death
description: The mother of a high school football player who collapsed and died in a game has started legal action against the city and the school board, charging them with responsibility in the death, officials said today.

title: CHILDREN'S THEATER: PLAYS AND PUPPETS TO OPERA AND DANCE
description: IN a darkened theater filled with young parents and their children,

title: ART: SHOW HONORS DE KOONING
description: IT'S the season for group shows,

title: Economic Scene; Classical Laws Debated Anew
description: ECONOMICS is a body of laws of dubious validity. In his recent Henry Carter Adams Lectures, Prof. Gardner Ackley, who served as chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Johnson, tried to sort out the economic laws that have survived the test of time from those that have flunked it. He gave the speech on the occasion of his retirement as professor of economics at the University of Michigan.

title: Gulf Oil Settles Uranium Case
description: The Tennessee Valley Authority ended what it called one of the nation's largest antitrust cases by settling a uranium price-fixing suit against

title: TIME AND CHANGE STRIP CANE FROM HAWAII FIELDS
description: Fundamental economic and social change in the past quarter century has caused a rapid decline in sugar and pineapple plantations, which confronts Hawaii's business and political leaders with the problem of finding new uses for an increasing amount of land that lies fallow.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: AIDS Baby Gets Home But Is Too Ill to Move
description: An abandoned infant stricken with AIDS has found a new home but is too sick to leave the hospital in time for Christmas, health officials said today.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: WEEKEND IN NEW YORK

title: SCOUTING
description: Hobbie the Hero

title: DONATELLO SALE DUE IN MARCH; Donatello sale due in March.
description: AN extremely rare painted terra-cotta relief of the Virgin and Child by Donatello will be auctioned by Sotheby's in early March and is expected to bring as much as $1 million. The work, which was out of public view for decades, turned up three years ago in the home of Francis Michael Cryan, a retired New York stockbroker, in Boca Raton, Fla.

title: Judge Rules Against Dirks
description: Raymond L. Dirks, a

title: SANDINISTA MOVES THAT ARE MORE THAN COSMETIC
description: To the Editor:

title: STERN TAX LETTERS FOR SAVERS
description: Many investors and savers nationwide are discovering, to their surprise and confusion, that their holiday mail contains warning letters from their bank, broker or a company whose stock they own.

title: INTEREST RATES MOVE LOWER
description: Interest rates declined yesterday as fears subsided that the Federal Reserve might tighten monetary policy and raise interest rates.

title: MARK WORKMAN
description: Mark Workman, a former all-America basketball player at the University of West Virginia, died Wednesday at his home after a long illness.

title: Steel Accord At E.E.C.;  E.E.C. Reaches Steel Accord BRUSSELS, Dec. 22 (AP) - Industry ministers from the 10 nations in the European Economic Community reached agreement today on an emergency program to stop cutthroat competition that they say is destroying their steel industry.
description: The program sets minimum prices for products that make up 40 percent of the steel output in the Common Market. The goal is to prevent price wars that have broken out in recent years among producers trying to sell excess production on markets already burdened by a steel glut.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;  Comings and Goings
description: Lawrence Taylor of the Giants was the top vote-getter on the all-National Football Conference team selected by a poll of sports writers for United Press International. . . . Bob Kuechenberg , a Miami Dolphin guard, has been added to the American Conference for the Pro Bowl game Jan. 29. He replaces John Hannah of the New England Patriots, who is scheduled to undergo surgery for a torn rotator cuff next Tuesday. . . . Kenny Roberts , three-time motorcycle road racing champion, is retiring to become a consultant with Yamaha USA . . . Martina Navratilova has withdrawn from a Virginia Slims tournament in Washington Jan. 2-8 because of exhaustion and a sore left shoulder. . . . Moses Malone , who sprained his right ankle in a collision with a Philadelphia 76er teammate, Andrew Toney , Wednesday night, will miss tonight's game against Detroit.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: As Santa Explains Supply vs. Demand

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in the Business People column yesterday about the American Satellite Company misstated the age of Emanuel Fthenakis. He is 55.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Two Days to Go

title: BILL WOULD RENOVATE 27 SUBWAY STATIONS FOR USE BY DISABLED
description: A proposal was announced yesterday that would make 27 subway stations accessible to the disabled and elderly and that would clear the way for the modernization of 88 stations throughout the city.

title: CITY SIGHTS: HOLIDAY SURPRISES WORTH LOOKING FOR
description: IN New York, there is a Christmas less obvious than the window displays along Fifth Avenue, the Christmas tree in Rockefeller Center

title: Necklaces Of Collectibles
description: Jesse Karp, who is 14 years old, has what his mother calls an important comic-book collection and more than 400 airline rescue-instruction sheets, all neatly filed away. His 3-year-old sister, Amy, is also an assiduous collector - she has already amassed quite a number of Do Not Disturb signs from hotels.

title: Beached Whales Are Shot
description: Five beached pilot whales were shot to death here today because it was impossible to save them, while six other stranded whales died of natural causes, a National Marine Fisheries Service official said. Gene Proulx, the official, said the five whales would have been crushed to death against rocks if they had not been shot in the brain. ''If no humanitarian rescue is possible, then we euthanize the animals,'' he said.

title: JUDGE SIGNS ORDER FOR QUADRIPALEGIC
description: After winning approval from a state judge, hospital officials late today began intravenous feeding of Elizabeth Bouvia, the cerebral palsy victim who is seeking to starve herself to death, a spokesman for her attorneys said.

title: ISRAEL DEPLORES CAIRO MEETING
description: Israel denounced Egypt's warm reception for Yasir Arafat today as a ''severe blow to the peace process in the Middle East.''

title: U.S. IS SAID TO FIND OFFICERS AT FAULT IN BEIRUT BOMBING
description: A Pentagon commission has concluded that serious failures in the Marine chain of command contributed to the Oct. 23 truck bombing of the Marine compound in Beirut, Administration officials said today.

title: HOLIDAY MOVIES: WHAT FAMILIES CAN SEE TOGETHER
description: PARTISANSHIP rules the moviegoing habits of most families, even in this season of togetherness. It would be nice for the family to go see a film en masse, but are the children ready for ''Scarface''? And if they're not, can Mom make it through something starring a mouse? Family moviegoing always means compromise, at this time of year more than ever. Here is an informal guide to who in the family can be expected to tolerate what, and for how long.

title: Dr. David Gordis to Take Post On Jewish Committee in July
description: Dr. David M. Gordis, the vice president of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America and of the University of Judaism in Los Angeles will become the executive vice president of the American Jewish Committee in July, the committee's president, Howard I. Friedman, has announced.

title: Derailment Snags IRT for 5 Hours
description: A subway train derailed yesterday morning as it pulled out of the 125th Street station on the Lexington Avenue IRT, causing a disruption of service for more than five hours, the Transit Authority reported.

title: WHY GESTATION PERIOD OF 'BABY' TOOK SO LONG
description: ''Baby,'' the new Broadway musical, took so long coming into the world that its lyricist and director, Richard Maltby Jr., thinks, ''I was only 35 years old when we went into rehearsal.'' He is now 46.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
description: Moody's Lowers Rating On U.S. Steel Issues

title: No Headline
description: Eight years ago the Seattle Seahawks played their first season in the National Football League. Like most expansion teams, it was a patchwork group. There were has- beens but also several promising youngsters who would somehow succeed and survive through this surprising season.

title: Market PlacePhillip H. Wiggins Guarded Outlook For Sensormatic
description: F OR the Sensormatic Electronics Corporation, the

Naval Institute Press. $45. THE 16-inch guns of the battleship New Jersey have been thundering over the hills of Lebanon and, for a moment, there is a naval remembrance of things past brought to today's headlines.

title: IF MONEY HAD HOLES
description: To the Editor:

title: The End of the P.L.O.
description: Yasir Arafat's second evacuation from Lebanon was compelled by Syria, brokered by Saudi Arabia and the United States, tolerated by Israel, conducted by Greece, monitored by France, destined for Egypt and certified by the United Nations. Doubting that even the Palestine Liberation Organization has any lives left, the world gave the occasion all the ritual of a funeral.

title: TUBE PRICE CASE ENDS IN ACQUITTAL
description: A Federal jury yesterday found three companies and six executives not guilty of conspiring to fix copper tubing prices over a six-year period from 1975 to mid-1981. The verdict came at the end of a nine-week trial before Judge Daniel Huyett in United States District Court in Philadelphia.

title: City Cracks Down On Flea Markets
description: City inspectors have cracked down on New York's burgeoning flea markets and issued summonses to 64 dealers, the Department of Consumer Affairs said yesterday.

title: Second Victory For Miss Wenzel
description: Hanni Wenzel of Liechtenstein won her second World Cup race in two days today, taking a giant slalom. Maria Epple of West Germany finished second.

title: Raiders to Stay on Coast
description: Despite indications to the contrary from Mayor Koch's office, a

title: Officer Guilty in Theft
description: An East Orange police lieutenant was found guilty today of engineering the theft of nearly $10,000 from a bank by having a fellow officer pose as a courier for a delivery company and pick up the cash.

title: MAXWELL FELLER
description: Maxwell Feller, a retired vice president for industrial relations of the International Latex Corporation, died of a heart ailment on Tuesday at his retirement home in Lake Worth, Fla.

title: CONSUL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $18,000 for the quarter and $83,000 for the 6 months.

title: Topics Christmas Revisions
description: A Live One

title: PALESTINIANS FAULT ARAFAT FOR EGYPT MEETING
description: The chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization's nominal parliament said today that Yasir Arafat had ''lost his legitimacy'' as chairman of the P.L.O. by meeting today with President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt.

title: Key Rates
description: * Nuveen index, John Nuveen & Company Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;  Suit Accuses Coaches
description: A lawsuit in Medina, Ohio, accuses two high school football coaches of having team members physically abuse a former player in a discipline drill during practice. Ronald Dorko, 15 years old, and his father, John , are seeking damages from the Buckeye High School coach, Kenneth Woodruff ; an assistant coach, Scott Tipton and the Buckeye School District Board of Education.

title: WORRY RISES ON CLERICS IN NICARAGUA
description: The State Department expressed concern yesterday over the well-being of two American Roman Catholic clergymen, one of them a bishop, who have been missing in a remote area of northeastern Nicaragua since Tuesday.

title: TOP U.S. OFFICIAL QUOTED AS RIDICULING TRUDEAU
description: Canadian newspapers reported today that Lawrence S. Eagleburger, Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, told a meeting of some 100 people three weeks ago that Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's attempts to spur arms reduction talks were ''akin to pot-induced behavior by an erratic leftist.''

title: Tekulve Re-signed by Pirates Angels Talk
description: While Rich Gossage continued to seek a new baseball home, Kent Tekulve, the other attractive relief pitcher in the free agent market, decided yesterday to remain in Pittsburgh, signing a three-year contract for $800,000 a year.

title: SNOW AND FREEZING RAIN HIT EAST AS RECORD COLD IS FELT IN THE WEST By The Associated Press
description: Winter arrived yesterday with bitter storms, bringing snow and freezing rain in the East and punishing the Great Plains anew with bitter cold that brought a wind-chill reading in North Dakota of 75 degrees below zero Fahrenheit.

title: APicassoIsStolen From a Marquis
description: A painting by Picasso, said to be valued at $1 million, has been reported stolen from the Manhattan apartment of a member of the Spanish royal family, the police said.

title: Building Is Closed After PCB Spill
description: Authorities closed a downtown office building today after the explosion of a transformer switchbox at 9:35 P.M. Wednesday, and tests showed that a fluid spewed into a main city street contained high levels of toxic PCB's.

title: Bridge: The Negative Double Poses A Problem of Interpretation
description: About three decades ago tournament players found themselves facing the Roth-Stone system, which introduced many ideas that have since become standard in serious competition. One of these is the negative double, which does, however, lend itself to varying interpretations.

title: Baby Doe Defeats Severe Infections
description: The lawyer for the parents of Baby Jane Doe, the focus of a legal storm over the treatment of her severe birth defects, said today that her ''life-threatening infections and pneumonia are no longer present.''

title: Mitterrand to Visit U.S.
description: President Francois Mitterrand will visit the United States March 21-27 at the invitation of President Reagan, a French Government spokesman said today. No schedule of his itinerary was disclosed.

title: BRIEFS
description: American Hospital Supply Corp. said it had received a $650 million, three- year contract to provide hospital supplies to Voluntary Hospitals of America.

title: STAGE: 'LENNY' IN MUSIC
description: ''LENNY AND THE HEARTBREAKERS,'' which opened at the Public Theater Thursday night, is subtitled ''a new American opera.'' More accurately, it is a gussied-up old American musical, and pretty old and creaky it is, too, despite the sometimes dazzling high-tech flair that surrounds it.

title: OHIOAN LIGHTS A VALLEY VRO CHRISTMAS
description: All Carl Rudd has to do is flick a switch and the quiet landscape changes: Cars, vans, pickup trucks and church buses start filing through this hamlet of about 25 families.

title: DANCE: A COLLABORATION
description: TUESDAY night's performance at the Kitchen demonstrated that music specifically written for dance can add special excitement to dance concerts. This concert, an event in the Kitchen's Musicdance series, brought together four choreographers and four composers, and the results were four interesting collaborations.

title: Repairs to Reduce No. 2 Service
description: The Transit Authority said yesterday that it would suspend service on the IRT No. 2 line to some Brooklyn stations while crews made track and structural repairs.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;  Gamblers Strike Back
description: The Houston Gamblers, trying to prohibit the Detroit Lions from keeping Billy Sims , told a Texas district court that the Gamblers would probably suffer ''devastating'' losses if they did not get the services of the fleet running back. The new United States Football League club and the Lions of the National Football League both hold contracts with Sims, and the Lions have filed a suit in Detroit seeking to void his contract with the Gamblers, signed last summer.

title: DEPAUL RALLIES TO BEAT PURDUE
description: Tyrone Corbin scored 24 points to rally unbeaten DePaul to a 68-61 victory over Purdue tonight.

title: MUSIC: SERIES ALL ON MOZART
description: -concert traversal of the complete Mozart sonatas at the Abraham Goodman House Tuesday night. In this first installment, Miss Rich essayed the first six sonatas, K. 279 through K. 284, all written in 1774 and 1775, when the composer was still a teen-ager.

title: Italy Jobless Rate Rises
description: Italy's unemployment rate rose to 10.2 percent for the three months ended Oct. 8 from 9.8 percent in the previous quarter and 9.2 percent in the period a year earlier.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Well, Fancy That!

title: INQUIRY CLEARS U. OF MASSACHUSETTS STUDENT OF DORMITORY FIRES
description: The county District Attorney today dismissed charges against a University of Massachusetts student who was accused of setting one of more than 40 dormitory fires reported this semester.

title: NO HEAT, MAN DIES
description: A 93-year-old blind man, whose gas was shut off in June for nonpayment of bills and whose apartment walls were ice covered, has died of exposure, the police and medical examiners say.

title: CHIEF OF F.A.A. QUITS TO RETURN TO HIS BUSINESS
description: J. Lynn Helms, the Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration, submitted his resignation today, saying he wanted to resume his business consulting work.

title: SCOUTING
description: Small Numbers On the Big Fight

title: American Insurer Wins Iran Award The American International Group Inc., an insurance holding company based in New York, said it had received an award of about $14 million from the Iran-United States claims tribunal that is meeting at The Hague. The award was made as a result of Iran's nationalization of the company's 35 percent stake in an Iranian company, Iran American, that American International helped establish in 1975. Iran American was nationalized in June 1979.
description: Separately, American International said it had pulled out of an agreement to acquire a 12.5 percent interest in the Progressive Corporation, another insurer, from the American Financial Corporation. American's president, M. R. Greenberg, said the decision was made after Progressive said it opposed the purchase. The sale would have increased American's stake in Progressive to more than 20 percent.

title: BASSETT FURNITURE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
REAGAN REQUESTS MONEY FOR HUNGRY
description: President Reagan formally asked Congress today for the $50 million it had already appropriated to help state and local agencies distribute surplus food to the poor.

title: South African Rates Up
description: Nedbank, Barclays and Standard Bank said today that they are raising their prime rates to a record- equaling 20 percent, from 19.5 percent. The rise by Nedbank and Barclays is effective immediately and Standard Bank's new rate will be effective Tuesday. South African banks last raised their rates 10 days ago from 19 percent, and bankers said there has continued to be heavy pressure on short-term rates.

title: FRANKLIN RESOURCES reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
MONEY SUPPLY SHRINKS BY $2 BILLION IN WEEK
description: The Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that the basic measure of the nation's money supply dropped $2 billion in the week that ended Dec. 14.

title: STATE DEPARTMENT BIDS REAGAN ACT TO LEAVE UNESCO
description: The State Department has recommended that President Reagan file notice that the United States will withdraw from Unesco in 1985 unless the United Nations agency curtails what the Administration regards as questionable political activities.

title: Christmas Tree Procurement
description: The decorations on Senator William Roth's odd Christmas tree are nuts, diodes, wrenches and other spare parts used by the Department of Defense. Each carries two prices, that paid by the Pentagon and that charged by the neighborhood hardware store. Merry Christmas.

title: U.S. Confiscates 12,000 Guns Being Shipped to Guatemala MIAMI, Dec. 23 (Reuters) - Customs agents said Thursday that they had confiscated 12,000 Mauser rifles shipped to Florida from Israel for eventual delivery to Guatemala.
description: The bolt-action rifles from World War I were in four cargo containers that were unloaded from the Israeli vessel Zim New Orleans in Fort Lauderdale on Monday. No arrests were made.

title: BUYING YOUR OWN TELEPHONE
description: WITH the savings associated with buying your own telephone contributing to mounting sales, consumer groups are advising people to try to check claims made for various kinds of telephones.

title: ATLANTIC CITY CHURCHES FALLING ON HARD TIMES
description: Two years after the Civil War, St. James Episcopal Church opened its doors here at Pacific and North Carolina Avenues. Decade after decade, generations of wealthy tourists returned each summer to worship. St. James prospered.

title: TECHNOLOGY MARKETING reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income including an extraordinary tax credit of $67,000.

title: SLEIGH RIDE
description: Setting: The Cabinet room. The President is meeting with his Three Wise Men - Caspar W. Weinberger, Balthazar Shultz and Melchior Casey; also, the Joint Chiefs of Staff and their chairman. At odd moments, the Mondale-Glenn carolers and Jesse Helms, the Republican countertenor, can be heard singing on the White House lawn.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 17.

title: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 24, 1983;  International
description: The U.S. withdrawal from Unesco in 1985 has been recommended by the State Department if the United Nations agency does not curtail what the Administration regards as questionable political activities. The recommendation has been sent to the White House in anticipation of a formal deadline of Dec. 31 by which President Reagan will have to decide whether to file notice of withdrawal. (Page 1, Column 6.) The Pentagon withdrew a report on the truck bombing of the Marine compound in Beirut 30 minutes before it was to have been given to reporters. A spokesman said Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger needed more time to review it and prepare recommendations for President Reagan. There were indications that the Administration is divided over how to deal with it. (1:4.)

title: Confession Upheld In Jersey Killing
description: Prosecutors may use as evidence a confession by a murder suspect even though officials failed to tell him of his right not to incriminate himself, a state appeals court ruled today.

title: FOR GRUCCIS' NEIGHBORS, EFFECTS OF EXPLOSIONS LINGER
description: Ever since Jessica Cordes and her husband moved to this town nearly three decades ago, the couple's extended family has celebrated Christmas around a tree in front of their fireplace.

title: RANGERS WIN ON POWER PLAYS
description: The Rangers scored two power- play goals in a span of 53 seconds in the second period against the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden last night. The goals, one by Ron Greschner at 5 minutes 40 seconds and the other by Pierre Larouche at 6:33, gave the Rangers a 3-2 lead that stood up the rest of the night.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Christening

title: MAN HELD IN DEATH OF EMIGRE
description: A 28-year-old Brooklyn man has been arrested and charged with murder in the Sept. 21 shooting of the owner and publisher of a weekly newspaper for Haitian emigres, the police said yesterday.

title: POPE CONDEMNS MISSILE BUILDUP
description: Pope John Paul II said today that the deployment of more nuclear missiles in Europe worried people on the continent, and rightly so.

title: Guilty Plea Given In Jockey's Slaying
description: A Brooklyn man has pleaded guilty in the shooting death of a jockey on the New Jersey Turnpike last month, the authorities said.

title: BUSH GROUP'S PROPOSALS ON BANKING REGULATION
description: An Administration working group has agreed on a long list of changes meant to simplify Federal regulation of financial institutions, according to a statement from Vice President Bush's office.

title: Seahawks to Open Playoffs;  DeBerg Back In Lineup For Broncos
description: ''I'm in terrible shape,'' Steve DeBerg said the other day, and that could portend a long afternoon for the Denver Broncos Saturday in the American Conference wild-card game against the Seattle Seahawks.

title: A BEVY OF BRUISES
description: Athigh. A neck. A leg. Is it an

title: WHY ONE MAN'S SANTA CLAUS BEARS ARMS
description: To the Editor:

title: Arrows Lose, 4-1
description: Ricky Davis scored two goals to lead the St. Louis Steamers to a 4-1 victory over the Arrows in a Major Indoor Soccer League game tonight. The Steamers ended a six-game losing streak. The defender Val Tuska scored the only goal for the Arrows, in the third quarter.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Maryland vs. Boston College, at College Park, Md. Boston Eagles is 7-0 under Coach Gary Williams, a Maryland alumnus. Maryland has lost only once, to Ohio State, in its seven games.

title: NEW RULES ON LEGAL AID: TWO VIEWS
description: New restrictions on Federally financed legal aid for the poor have provoked a dispute over the motives of the officials in charge of the program.

title: SCOUTING
description: Oversized Draft

title: ACME PRECISION PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $68,000 for the quarter and year from discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $54,000 for the quarter and year from discontinued operations.

description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: CORRECTIONS

title: Petrolane Is Suing American Medical LOS ANGELES, Dec. 23 (Reuters) - American Medical International Inc. said it had been sued by Petrolane Inc. for terminating talks earlier this year to buy Petrolane's Raleigh Hills alcoholic treatment centers. Petrolane's suit charges breach of contract and seeks damages of $27 million.
description: The damages are based on the difference between the price Petrolane said it should have received for Raleigh from American Medical and the price paid later when it was sold to the Horizon Health Corporation. American Medical said it would file a counterclaim seeking recovery of expenses incurred in its review of Raleigh. Petrolane's sale of Raleigh was part of its plan to divest itself of its nonenergy operations.

title: APPLIED CIC?UIT TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss.
