description: To the Editor:

title: HOSPICES FOR THE DYING SHOW DRAMATIC GROWTH
description: The hospice movement, just a decade old in America, is growing dramatically as a way to take care of the terminally ill.

title: PLAYERSMalcolm Moran; A Life Without Football
description: Doug Wilkening planned on spending Christmas at home in Colorado this year. His plans included some time at home with his mother and some skiing with his friend Deena Finn. A week from Monday would be perfect for skiing, he said, because the slopes become much less crowded when others watch the college football bowl games. Wilkening said he does not plan on watching any bowl games.

title: FIGURES SHOW A SPURT, THEN A DROP, IN DENIALS OF ASYLUM FO
description: R POLES

title: Youth Says He Killed Father After Years of Mistreatment
description: A 16-year-old boy who says he endured years of beatings by his father acted in self-defense when he killed his father with a 12- gauge shotgun as the man slept, the boy's lawyer says.

title: THE 'HOLIDAY BLUES' ARE OVERSTATED ILL, HEALTH EXPERTS FIND
description: After years of hand-wringing over the ''holiday blues,'' a form of depression once thought to afflict vast numbers of Americans, mental health experts now stress that Christmas actually intensifies most major emotions of everyday life, joyous or sad.

title: Holiday Bowl to B.Y.U.
description: Steve Young, the all-America quarterback, ran 14 yards after catching a pass thrown by the halfback

title: WRONG 'MRS. CLAUS' ANSWERS THE CALL
description: Jo Forrester, a telephone operator in Midland, came home from work one December day last year to find her phone buzzing with calls from children wanting to talk to Mrs. Santa Claus.

title: CABRE EXPLORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Judge Revokes the Bail F O 7 S
description: A Federal judge has revoked bail for the reputed head of the anti-Castro terrorist group Omega 7, ruling there would be ''an undue risk of danger'' if he were released.

title: Five Killed in Milan Fire
description: A flash fire in a crowded downtown restaurant killed five people today and injured at least six, the police said. Firemen said the fire started when a liquid gas container exploded at lunchtime at the restaurant, Toscano da Ilia, near Piazza della Repubblica.

title: Toshiba Satellite System
description: The Toshiba Corporation said today that it will start marketing, on March 1, a home system that can receive super- high-frequency television broadcasts from satellites.

title: DETROIT'S CALL FOR BETTER STEEL
description: Detroit auto makers, prodded by Japanese competition and the need to produce lighter cars, are demanding higher- quality steel from their domestic suppliers. And the steel industry, still looking for a turnaround formula, is responding with an investment of more than $200 million in high-efficiency, high-profit machinery to produce stronger, lighter and more rustproof materials.

title: 'PROVINCETOWN PLAYS' OF 1915
description: ''The Provincetown Plays,'' a re- creation of the original program of the Provincetown Players in 1915, will be presented next Wednesday through Friday in the National Portrait Gallery in Washington.

title: LAWSUIT OVER ADS FOR SUGARED CEREALS IS ALLOWED ON COAST SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23 (AP) - The California Supreme Court has given the go-ahead to a lawsuit that accuses the General Foods Corporation of deceiving children in its advertising for sugared cereals.
description: The unanimous decision Thursday, written by Justice Allen Broussard, relaxed previously stringent requirements for filing such a suit, including specific details for each alleged instance of false or misleading advertising. Justice Broussard's decision said it was only necessary to show that ''members of the public are likely to be deceived.''

title: Rostow Unable To Be Law Dean
description: Eugene V. Rostow, who was to become dean of the New York Law school, will be unable to do so because of ill health, the school announced yesterday.

title: Dow Drops by 3.15; Tax Selling Cited Grumman Off; Alleghany Up
description: Stock prices fell slightly yesterday in sluggish pre-holiday trading.

title: U.S. and Rumania Sign Pact
description: The United States and Rumania signed an agreement on cooperation in science, education, television and other fields, the United States Information Agency announced today. The two countries have had such agreements for 10 years.

title: NEW YEAR, SAME YEARNINGS: BOB HOPE TREATS TROOPS
description: Lance Cpl. Russell Biffle, from Mississippi, watched today as Bob Hope told jokes, Brooke Shields burst into song and Cathy Lee Crosby cavorted in a slinky red dress.

title: That Shape in the Fiscal Fog
description: It's budget time in Washington, which means much jockeying, much posturing and mighty little concern, in all the fiscal fog, for reality. But reality this year looms up out of the fog.

title: HEI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 3
2 MOSCOW MEETINGS MAY LIFT THE VEIL ON ANDROPOV
description: Two major political meetings next week may help dispel uncertainties that have surrounded the leadership of Yuri V. Andropov since he fell ill and disappeared from public view more than four months ago.

title: POLITICAL REALITIES AND KOCH'S DECISION TO NAME BLACK POLICE COMMISSIONER
description: News Analysis

title: DANCE: AN EXPERIMENTAL VENTURE IN CONCERT
description: The Musicdance series at the Kitchen this week featured different sets of composers and choreographers together in concert. Because choreographers and composers often collaborate, this format is hardly startling. Nonetheless, the fact that the Kitchen's artists are usually classed as experimental does give a different edge to a standard idea.

title: THE GIFT BEHIND THE GIFT
description: The most splendid Christmas gift, the most marveled and magic, is the gift that has not yet been opened. Opaque behind wrapping or winking foil, it is a box full of possibilities. An unopened present might be anything - gems, crystal, oranges, a promise of devotion. While the present is unopen, it can rest under the tree to be regarded and speculated upon at length, becoming whatever the recipient wishes.

title: Chile Airline Compliance Set
description: Chile's national airline

title: Anacomp Default
description: Anacomp Inc. said it is in technical default on its bank loans totaling $44.6 million and is holding talks with lender banks about increasing the loans and restructuring their terms. The company, which provides computer and data center services, said that while the banks had indicated a willingness to consider a restructuring, no agreement had been reached.

title: Official in Puerto Rico Quits Over Slaying Case
description: Puerto Rico's police chief announced today that he would resign next Thursday, making him the second top official to step down amid a police scandal.

title: Rain Kills 26 in India
description: Heavy rain in the southern state of Tamil Nadu, over 15 inches in some areas, killed at least 26 people today and left thousands homeless, the Press Trust of India news agency said. Most of the deaths occurred when rain- soaked mud walls of houses and huts collapsed on their inhabitants, it said. The state capital, Madras, received 6.8 inches of rain, but that area is recovering from a drought and the water was welcome.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Mayoral Palate

title: NO ONE WILL 'WRECK' ST. BARTHOLOMEW'S
description: To the Editor:

title: Japanese Video Recorders
description: Japanese exports of videotape

title:
PATENTS ;
New Duplicator Lowers 4-Color Printing Cost
description: Joel Green, chairman of the Cymaticolor Corporation, Edison, N.J., said a patent granted this week for a color offset printing machine demonstrated that the cost of four-color process printing has been reduced to a level competitive with black-and- white and spot-color methods.

title: AMERICAN HOME PATIENT CENERS reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
GOING OUT GUIDE ;
description: NEW YORK YULE There are special Christmas spirits in New York, spirits that lurk in the feel of a big city, spirits if not at rest, then at least at peace for the fleeting moment of observance between the frenzy of shopping and the agitation of taking things back to the store. This spirit is one evoked by the Rev. Clarke Clement Moore, who in 1822 wrote ''A Visit From St. Nicholas.''

title: Seafirst Debt Case
description: A Federal judge today ordered Clinton Manges, a south Texas rancher-oilman, to pay about $34 million to a Seattle bank that lost hundreds of millions of dollars in bad energy loans.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: First Things First

title: ST. JOHN'S GOES TO 7-0 AS MULLIN RETURNS
description: Chris Mullin returned last night for his first game in 3 weeks, scored 19 points and took 8 rebounds in 25 minutes of play and helped undefeated St. John's score an 89-71 victory over Niagara in Alumni Hall.

title: Jet on Wrong Runway Hits Plane, Injuring Six
description: Six people were injured today when a Korean Air Lines DC-10 cargo jet attempting takeoff from the wrong runway smashed into a twin-engine commuter plane waiting on the ground for heavy fog to lift.

title: Options Unit Ends Bell Bid CHICAGO, Dec. 23 (AP) - The Chicago Board Options Exchange said today that it had withdrawn its request to trade listed options on the stocks of the seven regional telephone companies to be created by the Jan. 1 breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.
description: Walter E. Auch, C.B.O.E. chairman, said in a statement that the decision to withdraw the filing from the Securities and Exchange Commission ''leaves hanging the question of which exchanges will trade options on which of the regional phone companies, but that's a question the exchanges will have to sort out later.''

title: COMPUDYNE CORP reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $581,419 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary gain of $585,217. c-After a loss of $10,607 from discontinued operations.

title: Marble Hill Plant Closing Endorsed INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 23 (AP) - A task force's recommendation to scrap the Marble Hill nuclear power plant being built by the Public Service Company of Indiana was endorsed by the state's Governor, Robert D. Orr. He also said he would ask for resumption of hearings on the utility's request for a rate increase to pay for the project's investment to date. The company owns 83 percent of the project, while the Wabash Valley Power Association owns the rest.
description: Construction of Marble Hill, near Madison, is in its fifth year and $2.8 billion has been spent so far.

title: FOOD MAKERS FAIL TO STOP GRAIN BAN
description: A Federal district judge denied a request from the food industry late today to stop Florida from enforcing its ban on grain products with traces of the pesticide ethylene dibromide.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;  Decision for Rose
description: A jury in Federal District Court in Cincinnati has ruled for Pete Rose in his suit against the Internal Revenue Service, which had refused to allow him a $36,303 tax deduction for the cost of nine Jeeps that he gave to coaches and others on the Cincinnati staff while he was with the Reds in 1978. Rose, at 42 one of the oldest players in baseball, had argued that the extra fielding and batting practice afforded him by the recipents of the gifts had prolonged his career. The I.R.S.'s contention was that the recipents were already being paid by the Reds and that Rose was therefore not required to compensate them.

title: CSP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Ex-Player Acquitted
description: A jury in Morgantown, W. Va., needed only 15 minutes' deliberation yesterday in acquitting Mark Raugh , a 23-year-old former football player, of negligent homicide in the death last month of Andre Gist in an auto accident. Raugh, the leading pass receiver in West Virginia history, recently signed with the United States Football League's Pittsburgh Maulers. Gist, a guard, was a teammate of his at the university and played last spring for the U.S.F.L.'s Tampa Bay Bandits.

title: MOREHOUSE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income.

title: RIPLEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Belgian Prices Up 0.2%
description: Consumer prices in Belgium rose two- tenths of 1 percent in December from November and were up 7.2 percent from a year earlier, the Economics Ministry said today.

title: FED VOTED NO POLICY CHANGE
description: The Federal Reserve Open Market Committee, a group of 12 Fed officials who set monetary policy, decided at its Nov. 14-15 meeting to make no change in monetary policy.

title: PRESENTS' ABSENT
description: Presents won't be piled so deeply under the Christmas tree this year. Luckily, it's by our choice, not by necessity.

title: BLACK LAWYER PRESSING KLAN APPEAL FOR PARADE
description: Twice, local officials told Ray D. Morris and the Knights of the Ku Klux Klan that they would not be allowed to march through downtown Chickasaw.

title: Governor Commutes 7 Inmates' Sentences
description: Governor Cuomo has commuted the prison terms of six state inmates so that their minimum sentences officially ended today, and the term of a seventh inmate so that it will officially end in March.

title: Laos Turns Over Bodies Of U.S. Servicemen
description: Laos has handed over to a United States team the bodies of some American soldiers who were reported missing in action in the Vietnam War, the Laotian press agency said today.

title: NEWARK, LOW ON CASH, LAYS OFF 78 FIREFIGHTERS AND SHUTS 6 STATIONS
description: The city's Fire Director ordered the closing of 6 firehouses and the layoff of 78 firefighters today despite assurances by the President of the State Senate that money would be coming to avert the move.

title: INTEGRATED CIRCUITS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
FREDA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
FOOTHILL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $1,551,000 for the quarter and $1,500,000 for the 6 months. c-Including tax credits of $1,612,000 for the quarter and $1,387,000 for the 6 months.

title: Ford to Pay $1 Million in Case
description: The Ford Motor Company has agreed to pay at least $1.1 million to the mother and sister of a young woman who died when the gasoline tank of a 1974 Mustang II caught fire in a 1980 crash.

title: 'Dance Hurrah' Today
description: ''Dance Hurrah for Children and Other Sophisticated Persons,'' a performance with dance, music and masks, will be presented by the Erick Hawkins Dance Company today at 11 A.M. and 1:30 P.M. at Symphony Space, Broadway and 95th Street.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Delayed Guilt

title: AMERICAN STATES LEASING CORP reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Including a provision for doubtful accounts of $215,000 and a loss of $40,000 from discontinued operations. c-Including a provision for doubtful accounts of $250,000.

title: ENTERPRISE TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Comparable year-ago results are not available because the company was formed in October 1982.

title: BUTLER NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
SALE OF GLOBE-DEMOCRAT IN ST. LOUIS ANNOUNCED
description: A 30-year-old magazine publisher and his wife announced today that they had signed a contract to buy The St. Louis Globe- Democrat.

title: DINNER 'SPECIAL' GAME: TOO MUCH TO REMEMBER
description: Ask someone to assume the role of restaurant captain and play this little game by reciting the dinner specials: ''For this evening we have for a first course vongole alla Capri, spiedini, cappelletti in brodo or taglierini with truffles. The taglierini is also available for a main course. Or you may have crostacei marinara, cotoletta Milanese, bocconcini di vitello, zuppa de pesce, fegato di vitello Veneziana, cervella dorata. And the chef has prepared a special fritto misto this evening. If I can answer any questions. . . . ''

title: Bankruptcy Petition
description: Steve Howe , the Los Angeles relief pitcher whose problems with cocaine use led to three suspensions by the Dodgers and a recent suspension for the 1984 season by the commissioner, has filed for bankruptcy in Federal Court in Los Angeles. Howe and his wife, Cyndy , who live in suburban Agoura and have an infant daughter, listed $340,000 in debts and $267,600 in assets in the bankruptcy petition, which said Howe earned $325,000 last season.

title: Boeing Orders Up
description: The Boeing Commercial Airplane Company said its order list for 1983 stands at 148 planes, an increase of 40 aircraft from last year but still well below pre-recession totals.

title: ADMINISTRATOR IS NAMED FOR 2 LARGE CITY PARKS
description: An administrator for Pelham Bay Park and Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx, two of the city's three largest parks, was named yesterday. A swearing-in ceremony was held at City Hall to underscore the importance of the appointment.

title: Many Stranded Whales Die on Cape Cod
description: About 20 pilot whales were stranded on a 15-mile stretch of Cape Cod beaches today as rescue workers fought harsh winds and freezing temperatures to save the large animals. Members of the International Fund for Animals sighted 21 large whales in an aerial survey of Cape Cod today, said Liz Kay, a spokesman for the New England Aquarium.

title: FILM: DAVID BOWIE CONCERT, 'ZIGGY STARDUST AND SPIDERS'
description: a film of a 1973 David Bowie concert at the Hammersmith Odeon in London at which the singer announced a short-lived retirement from performing - will fascinate Mr. Bowie's fans. It will also exasperate them.

title: Frigid Weather Shuts 3 Tracks
description: Frigid weather and poor track conditions caused Keystone, Penn National and Hawthorne to cancel their thoroughbred racing cards yesterday.

title: French Retail Prices Up
description: Retail prices in France rose four-tenths of 1 percent in November from October, the National Statistics Institute said today. November's figures brought inflation to 8.9 percent for the first 11 months of 1983, surpassing the official French target of 8 percent inflation for the year.

title: NEW CAR SALES SHOW 25.2% INCREASE
description: The nation's major auto manufacturers reported today that sales of new cars in the Dec. 11-20 period rose 25.2 percent from the incentive-buoyed pace of a year earlier.

title: PENTAGON DELAYS PUBLISHING REPORT ON BEIRUT ATTACKS
description: President Sandro Pertini said Italy should withdraw its military contingent from Beirut. Page 4.

title: Missouri Reactivation Set
description: The battleship Missouri, on which the Japanese signed the terms of surrender in 1945, is to be reactivated by October 1984, subject to Congressional approval, the Navy announced today. The Missouri, which is at Bremerton, Wash., will undergo refurbishing at Long Beach, Calif., the Navy said. The cost is estimated at $325 million.

title: CONTINENTAL HEALTHCARE SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $83,000 for the quarter and $164,000 for the year.

title: PACESETTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Dickens Stacks The Deck
description: In ''A Christmas Carol,'' Charles Dickens tells the story of a man of principle being corrupted by a series of supernatural events. As always, Dickens spins a good yarn, but after being digested this one leaves a sour taste in the mouth.

title: SOUP KITCHENS
description: Had enough three-martini expense- account lunches? Looking for something different during this holiday season? Take a tip from Edwin Meese 3d, counselor to President Reagan, who said that some people went to soup kitchens ''because the food is free'' and ''that's easier than paying for it,'' and head for your local soup kitchen.

title: CELTICS SHOOT 73 PERCENT IN FIRST HALF AND TOP KNICKS
description: For the Nets, achieving a victory with a revamped lineup against a team like the Dallas Mavericks, as they did Thursday night, was one thing. But playing the quicker and stronger Celtics at Boston Garden tonight was another thing entirely. The Nets lost, 125-113.

title: Mrs. Thatcher, in Ulster, Vows to Defeat I.R.A.
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher visited Northern Ireland for six hours today and said Britain and the Irish Republic were determined to beat the Irish Republican Army's ''bombs, bullets and terrorists.''

title: Books of The Times
description: CHILDLESS BY CHOICE. Choosing

title: $2 Million Award For Malpractice
description: A State Supreme Court jury has awarded $2,025,000 in malpractice damages to a woman whose 32-year-old husband died of a cerebral aneurysm that was misdiagnosed as a viral infection.

title: SCOUTING
description: Worthwhile Trip

title: 6 in Poland Indicted In Union Activist's Death
description: A Warsaw prosecutor has indicted two police officers and four other people in the beating death of a 19-year-old Soli? darity union supporter, the official Polish press agency reported today.

title: COMPANY NEWS Ailing HRT Picks A Joint Venture
description: HRT Industries' chairman, Edward Solomon, said at a bankruptcy court hearing yesterday in New York that the company had rejected an offer by the Abraham Zion Corporation in favor of a joint venture made by the Schottenstein Stores Corporation and the McCrory Corporation, a unit of the Rapid American Corporation. The court then approved the contract between HRT and the joint venture.

title: Isuzu Earnings Drop by 12.4%
description: Isuzu Motors Ltd. said today

title: JEWISH ALLIANCE ASSAILS U.S. STAND
description: The Reagan Administration's endorsement of the meeting in Cairo Thursday between Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, and President Hosni Mubarak was criticized today by the leader of a group representing American Jewish organizations.

title: Transactions
description: BASKETBALL

title: PatentsStacy V. Jones Simulator Of Gravity For Space
description: WASHINGTON A N astronaut who is a physician has invented a suit to simulate in space the effects of normal gravity on the human circulatory system. The invention allows normal movement in a spacecraft.

title: CMC INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We will be facing the most serious time of the year with the fewest number of firemen in the history of the city.

title: South Africa Lifts Curb
description: Sweeping relaxations in South Africa's import controls were announced today by the Industries and Commerce Minister, Dawid J. de Villiers.

title: A Dispute Leads To Man's Death
description: A Brooklyn man was fatally stabbed yesterday during a dispute on a Manhattan street in the neighborhood where both the victim and the assailant worked, authorities said.

title: Marilyn Horne to Offer 'American Songbook'
description: -soprano, will sing her favorite songs by American composers on Wednesday at 8:30 P.M. at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: U.S. Backs Bank On Bid for Insurer WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) - The Government said it had given approval for the first purchase of a credit life insurance company by a national bank. The office of the Comptroller of the Currency said it had approved the plan of First and Merchants National Bank in Richmond to buy the Security Atlantic Life Insurance Company.
description: The insurance corporation underwrites credit life insurance policies sold only in Virginia, the Comptroller's office said in a release. In reaching the decision, the Comptroller's office said the sale of credit life insurance ''is clearly incidental to the business of banking'' and that banks traditionally have offered such insurance to borrowers in order to protect ordinary loans on personal property.

title: VICON FIBER OPTICS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
YANKEES AND STEINBRENNER FINED $250,000 BY KUHN
description: Commissioner Bowie Kuhn, putting an expensive end to the pine-tar affair, has fined George Steinbrenner and the Yankees $250,000. The fine is believed to be the largest ever assessed a sports team and an owner.

title: THINKING BIG AT QUALITY INNS
description: Robert C. Hazard Jr. enjoys telling folks here about the party he threw last fall in New Orleans. He filled a fleet of silver limousines with 996 formally attired guests, threw in a motorcycle escort and drove the whole show into the Superdome. He rolled out a real red carpet. Champagne flowed. Henry Mancini led the orchestra.

title: Key Rates
description: Nuveen index, John Nuveen & Company Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: ZIYAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
The Salvation Army Dilemma
description: As a matter of religious conviction, the Salvation Army refuses to qualify for New York City's financial support by pledging not to discriminate against homosexuals. As a matter of fact, the army says it does not discriminate in hiring or in welfare work.

title: A Weekend of Bach
description: Recordings and live performances of works by Bach will be heard all weekend on WKCR-FM (89.9), the student-run radio station at Columbia University. The broadcast, an annual event, will last through 11 P.M. Monday. Among the performers whose recordings will be played are Pablo Casals, Yo-Yo Ma, Glen Gould, Trevor Pinnock and Dame Janet Baker.

title: Blackout Is Likely For Cowboy Game
description: After spending the week wondering why they were badly beaten in their last two games, the Dallas Cowboys found another question to ponder today: Why are there 7,000 tickets unsold for their playoff game Monday?

title: STREAK ENDED AT 6
description: The number is 7, and for the Islanders, the best defensive team in the National Hockey League last season, it certainly isn't lucky. For the third straight time this season at the Capital Centre, the defending Stanley Cup champions allowed the Capitals 7 goals, and, consequently, saw their six-game winning streak end in a 7-3 loss tonight to their Patrick Division rivals.

title: DeLorean To Liquidate
description: John Z. DeLorean, who faces

title: U.S. STORES SEE A 1.3% SALES GAIN
description: Christmas sales in 1983 have been the strongest in the last five years. With only one more sales day to go, stores across the country were reporting gains averaging 13 percent over December 1982, when the increase was 8 percent.

title: Bridge: Solution of a Card Problem May Appear in Wee Hours
description: Insomniacs the world over worry ceaselessly about problems to which there is no solution. Bridge insomniacs are somewhat better off: In the small hours they can sometimes find solutions that eluded them in practical play.

title: TALK OF NEW CURRICULUM SETS OFF FUROR AT BROWN
description: On many campuses, a faculty committee meeting on the subject of the college curriculum would not generate enough energy among students to empower a yawn. But this is Brown University.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 24, 1983

title: BRIEFING
description: Fight for Gergen's Office

title: Zimbabwean Temperate On U.S. Aid Cut
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe gave a carefully worded reaction today to the announcement this week that the United States had cut this year's aid to Zimbabwe by $35 million.

title: AUTOCLAVE ENGINEERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income.

title: STAODYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
description: b-After an unusual charge of $231,480 for the quarter and 9 months from the revaluation of assets. c-Net income.

title: FOR SOME FAMILIES, AID TO THE NEEDIEST IS A YEARLY CUSTOM
description: Among the many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund who are continuing a tradition begun years ago is Lionel Koppman of Jackson Heights, Queens.

title: NATURA ENERGY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: OPERA: 'HANSEL' OPENS ITS HOLIDAY VISIT AT MET
description: Engelbert Humperdinck's ''Hansel and Gretel,'' which re-entered the Metropolitan Opera repertory for its now annual holiday run Thursday night, seems to be a near-guaranteed charmer. Certainly it was so perceived by the majority of the children and doting parents who made up the bulk of Thursday's audience.

title: Holiday Mail Nears Record
description: This year's volume of holiday mail will climb to a record of more than 10 billion pieces, the Postal Service said Thursday. By Monday, the agency had processed about nine billion pieces of mail during the holiday season, which began Nov. 26 and runs through Saturday.

title: CANADA'S NEXT GOVERNOR GENERAL
description: Jeanne Sauve, who was nominated today by Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau to be the first female Governor General of Canada, was once regarded as something of a political outsider by many of her male colleagues. That was three and a half years ago, when she was Canada's first Speaker of the House of Commons to be a woman. There was, some recalled, a palpable atmosphere of resentment toward her in the male-dominated lower house.

title: No Politics for Holtz
description: When Lou Holtz resigned under pressure as head football coach at Arkansas early this week, it was clear that a major reason was the furor raised there over his television commercials endorsing the re-election of Senator Jesse Helms , the conservative Republican of North Carolina. Now, having taken over Thursday as Minnesota's coach, Holtz has wasted little time in making at least one thing clear.

title: Arthritis Drug Causes Cancer in Tested Mice
description: Oraflex, the controversial drug for arthritis, causes an increased incidence of liver cancer in laboratory mice, Eli Lilly and Company said today, adding that clinical studies on the drug had been suspended.

title: PENGO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,042,000 for the quarter and $19,688,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $48,311,000 for the quarter and $39,463,000 for the year. Year-ago results have been restated for discontinued operations.

title: WEST AFRICA QUAKE IS REPORTED TO LEAVE 200 DEAD IN GUINEA
description: An earthquake in Guinea on Thursday destroyed 16 villages, killed more than 200 people and injured at least 300 others, the Guinean state radio said today.

title: REPORT SAYS CITY HOMELESS MAY DOUBLE IN TWO YEARS
description: The Partnership for the Homeless, an interdenominational coalition, predicted yesterday that the city's homeless population could double within the next two years because of what it called the failure of the Reagan Administration to provide affordable housing for the poor.

title: Lilco Wins Uranium Suit The Long Island Lighting Company said that a Federal bankruptcy judge in Albuquerque, N.M., had decided in its favor in a $50 million lawsuit brought by a uranium company.
description: The suit had been brought by the Bokum Resources Corporation, a company with which Lilco contracted in 1976 to provide uranium fuel for Shoreham and two other nuclear reactors then on the drawing boards, but later canceled.

title: JAPANESE PHENOMENON: TEEN-AGE IDOL-SINGERS
description: In her line of work, You Hayami, at the age of 17, has only a few years left.

title: IDLE WILD FOODS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 3
To Name Coach
description: The Green Bay Packers have scheduled a news conference at noon today to name the head coach to repalce Bart Starr, who was dismissed last Monday after nine years. There was no indication who the packers had selected for the job. Mike White, coach at the University of Illinois, said that he had been contacted by someone from the Packers about the job but said he was not interested.

title: RESOLVE OF CHELSEA STORE OWNERS WILL BE DECISIVE FOR THEIR BLOCK'S FUTURE
description: Spike-heeled, pointy-toed and dusty now, dozens of shoes are still scattered around the basement at 145 Eighth Avenue. These days, Robert Chisholm and Lucas Prats run an antique-poster gallery at the address, but once the space was home to a shoe store.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a computer malfunction, a line was omitted on Thursday from the Hers column in The Home Section. The second sentence in the second column should have read: ''Anyone who lives in the country knows that, birds aside, human beings encounter nondomestic animals, large or small, mainly by inadvertence.''

title: E.E.C.'s Steel Price Floor BRUSSELS, Dec. 23 (AP) - The European Economic Community set minimum prices today for steel in an attempt to end damaging price competition in the trade bloc's steel industry.
description: The price floors were set under an emergency plan adopted Thursday evening in Brussels by the industry ministers of the community's 10 member nations.

title: Devils Defeated in Overtime
description: Randy Carlyle's goal 2 minutes 12 seconds into overtime gave the Penguins a 6-5 victory over the Devils tonight before a crowd of 7,720 at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: EXCERPTS FROM INTERVIEW WITH SYRIA'S PRESIDENT
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with President Hafez al- Assad of Syria by Michel Colomes, the foreign editor of Le Point, a weekly newsmagazine in France, and Mireille Duteil, a reporter for the magazine. The interview, which was made available to The New York Times, is to appear in the French magazine this weekend. The conversation with the 53-year-old President, which was believed to be his first with Western journalists since he became ill in November, took place on Tuesday at a villa in Ghuta, about 20 miles from Damascus, where Mr. Assad has been recuperating. His Health

title: PATENTS
description: Treating Currency

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 41.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Allianz Versicherung, West Germany's largest insurance company, has matched the bid by B.A.T Industries, a tobacco and retailing concern, in the battle for control of Eagle Star Holdings, Britain's sixth-largest insurer. Both companies are offering about $9.59 a share, or a total of nearly $1.32 billion.

title: IT WAS A PROSPEROUS YEAR FOR NATIONAL NETWORKS
description: When you are driving across the country these days, you are more likely than ever to hear the same disk jockeys and radio newscasters in Montana, Tennessee or California as in New York City.

title: SEABOARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 12
Skier Critical After Surgery
description: Csilla Apjak of Hungary, who fractured her skull and right arm when she skied into a wooden barrier Wednesday in a training run before a World Cup downhill race at Haus, Austria, was still in critical condition at a Salzburg clinic today. Miss Apjak, 17 years old, underwent surgery on her skull Thursday and has not yet regained consciousness.

title: Indiana National
description: The Indiana National Corporation said it had sold is leasehold interest in the 37-story Indiana National Bank Tower to an affiliate of the JMB Realty Corporation, resulting in a gain of about $32.1 million. Indiana National, a holding company that owns the Indiana National Bank, said $19 million of the gain will be recognized in this year's fourth quarter.

title: EATON VANCE INVESTORS FUND INC reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split effective Nov. 22, 1983.

title: Madrid Fire Toll Rises to 81
description: Investigators have found two more bodies in the burned ruins of a Madrid discoth eque, bringing the death toll from the fire last week to 81, authorities said today. The police, using specially trained dogs, were still searching for the remains of another person who may have perished in the fire, a spokesman for the team investigating the fire said.

title: KNICKS LOSE BY POINT IN TWO OVERTIMES
description: Wayne (Tree) Rollins, the 7-foot-1-inch center, has not been noted for his scoring since joining Atlanta as its top draft choice in 1977. But it was his hook shot with 45 seconds remaining that proved the margin of victory tonight as the Hawks defeated the Knicks, 114-113, in double overtime.

title: IN RUMANIA, ALL HAIL THE CHIEF, AND DRACULA, TOO
description: ''Ceau- ses-cu! Peace!'' people packed into the Grand National Assembly chanted, clapping their hands in rhythm.

title: PATENTS
description: Christmas Tree Device

title: BASQUE CONFLICT SPILLS OVER INTO FRANCE
description: The terrorist violence that has long plagued the Basque region of northern Spain has spilled into southern France. The development has aroused fears of a ''dirty war'' fought across the mountainous border by Basque separatists and right-wing Spanish extremists.

title: Dickey Stays a Colt
description: Curtis Dickey , the 27-year-old Baltimore Colt halfback, has ended weeks of speculation about whether he would jump to the United States Football League by agreeing to stay with the National Football League club for five more years. Dickey, who rushed for 1,122 yards during the season, agreed to a ''memorandum of understanding'' late last night, said Ernie Accorsi , the Colts' general manager.

title: BETHLEHEM IS MELANCHOLY, NOT MERRY
description: -Occupied West Bank, Dec. 22 - The little town set about decking itself, sparsely, in tinsel today, trying not to let political and budgetary complaints mar its Christmas cheer.

title: PATENTS
description: Gamma Ray Timing

title: Valve at Indian Point Fixed
description: Consolidated Edison reduced power overnight at its Indian Point 2 nuclear power plant here to repair a regulator valve in a non-nuclear part of the plant, a spokesman for the utility said today. The spokesman said output was reduced, from the normal 890 megawatts to 100 megawatts, beginning at 8 P.M. on Thursday. The plant was at full power by 9 A.M. today, he said.

title: WHITAKER CABLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $82,618 for the quarter and 6 months and a gain of $1,082,627 for the quarter and 6 months on the settlement of debt. c-Net loss.

title: INTERNATIONAL MULTIFOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Results for the latest third quarter include gain equal to approximately 50 cents a share from sale of doughnut franchising business in Japan.

title: RAIL LINK S CLEARED BY I.C.C.
description: Santa Fe Industries and the Southern Pacific Company merged into a new holding company yesterday afternoon, hours after the Interstate Commerce Commission lifted an order blocking the combination.

title: Building Epitomizes Manhattan Problem
description: An exhibit in the office of the New York City District Postmaster, George F. Shuman, helps explain Manhattan's difficult mail-sorting and delivery problems.

title: TO COMBAT HUNGER, THIS WINTER AND NEXT
description: To the Editor:

title: Dale Danenberg Wed To Fred Scrutchfield
description: Dale Joan Danenberg, daughter of the late Leigh Danenberg of Westport, Conn., and the late Elsie N. Danenberg of Fairfield, Conn., was married yesterday to Fred L. Scrutchfield, son of Helen Scrutchfield of Guthrie, Okla., and the late F. L. Scrutchfield. The Rev. Dennis Clark performed the ceremony at the First Christian-Disciples of Christ Church in Guthrie.

title: MANILA'S ACCOUNT OF OPPOSITION LEADER'S MURDER IS DISPUTED
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines said today that the claim that his Government was involved in the assassination of Benigno S. Aquino Jr., his political rival, was a lie spread by political opponents and the ''recalcitrant rich.''

title: Your MoneyLeonard Sloane Trading Rules On A.T.& T.
description: A KEY point of confusion among stockholders about the Jan. 1 divestiture by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company concerns the purchase and sale of ''old'' A.T.& T. shares. Starting yesterday, all trading in this stock has included an attached ''due bill,'' which represents the appropriate shares of the regional holding companies that are being separated from A.T.& T.

title: Space Shuttle Flight To Be Put Off Till Feb. 3
description: The national Aeronautics and Space Administration said today that it would delay the next flight of the space shuttle challenger from Jan. 30 to Feb. 3 so that the agency could replace all three auxiliary power units to avoid a malfunction like the ones that plagued the last shuttle flight.

title: THE YOUNG DRESS UP: SNEAKERS, LACE, PEARLS
description: They start planning what they will wear to the Gold and Silver Ball six months ahead, and the dresses they choose are known from that day on as their ''Gold and Silver'' dresses.

title: '83 Eurobonds: $44.2 Billion
description: Eurobond issues in 1983

title: U.S. RANKED LOW IN SPENDING ON AID
description: The United States gave proportionately less of its wealth to poor countries during 1981- 82 than almost any other major non- Communist nation, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development says in a new report.

title: Acquitted Judge Asks Court To Halt Colleagues' Inquiry
description: A Federal district judge in Miami who was found not guilty earlier this year of criminal charges asked a Washington court today to stop an investigation of him by his judicial colleagues in the South.

title: First Boston's Rumasa Role
description: The First Boston Corporation and Credit Suisse-First Boston have been appointed brokers in the sale of the assets of Rumasa, Spain's largest business group, it was announced today.

title: OFFICIALS CALL POSTAL DELAYS WORST SINCE 1980
description: Mail service in New York City has gone through its worst year of delays since 1980, according to United States Postal Service figures, but officials say the problems abated in time for improved Christmas deliveries.

title: ITALIAN CHIEF CALLS ON ROME TO PULL FORCES OUT OF BEIRUT
description: President Sandro Pertini said today that the Government should withdraw Italian military forces from Beirut.

title: Boggs Indicted
description: Tommy Boggs , the former Atlanta Brave pitcher, was among 23 people indicted by a county grand jury in Decatur, Ga., on charges stemming from what the authorities there described as a multimillion-dollar sports gambling ring. Boggs was charged simply with gambling, a misdemeanor, but could face a one- year prison term if convicted.

title: 'ON YOUR TOES' INVESTORS SUE, CHARGING FRAUD
description: A group of investors in the Broadway musical ''On Your Toes'' have filed a lawsuit charging that they were defrauded by the musical's producers, including Andre Pastoria and Roger L. Stevens, who is also the director of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington.

title: CRASH OF CHURCH BUS KILLS 10 AND INJURES 20 ON TEXAS ROAD DEVERS, Tex., Dec. 23 (AP) - A church bus crashed head-on into a tractor-trailer truck on a rain-slick highway tonight, killing nine people and injuring more than 20 others, a Department of Public Safety spokesman said.
description: The collision occurred about 7:45 P.M. on Texas Highway 61, two and a half miles south of Devers, a small community on U.S. 90 about 50 miles northeast of Houston.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective. Corrections, also on this page, continue to deal with factual errors.

title: SFE TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
SYKES DATATRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $569,000 for the quarter and $2,554,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income.

title: Henderson's Choice
description: Steve Henderson , the free-agent outfielder formerly with the Mets but most recently with the Mariners, says Oakland, Montreal, Toronto and Milwaukee are all bidding for him. But, he adds, what he really wants to do is stay in Seattle, where he led the Mariners in batting last season with a .294 average.

title: Reagans' Christmas Plans
description: President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, will spend Christmas Day at the White House, and be joined for a roast turkey dinner by their two children, close friends and a member of the President's senior staff. Among the guests will be the Reagans' children, Patti Davis and Ron Reagan, and Ron Reagan's wife, Doria.

title: Soviet Accuses Sweden of Spying on Military
description: Tass, the official Soviet press agency, accused Sweden today of using reconnaissance planes to spy on Soviet military movements.

title: U.N.'S TRIED AND FAILED EFFORTS IN LEBANON
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day yesterday on a proposal by the Federal Reserve Board misidentified one nation whose loans might have to be partly written off by American banks. It was Nicaragua, not Nigeria.

title: LITTLE PRINCE PRODUCTIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.N.'S TRIED AND FAILED EFFORTS IN LEBANON
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Lights Out

title: FEDERAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
10 at Paris Restaurant Wounded in Explosion
description: An explosion outside one of France's best known restaurants, the Grand Vefour, near the Palais Royale in Paris, wounded 10 people Friday night, officials said.

title: Canada Says 8 Plotted To Take Over Guyana
description: Seven Canadians and an American have been arrested and charged with plotting to overthrow the Government of Guyana and set up a new regime in the South American country, the police said today.

title: TIME OUT TO CUT U.S. MILITARY LOAD IN EUROPE
description: To the Editor:

title: Pengo Agreement
description: Pengo Industries said it had signed a letter of intent with its principal secured creditors to execute a 15-month standstill agreement.

title: FULL-TIME GOAL FOR SOVIET TEAM
description: MOSCOW VIKTOR TIKHONOV is a man with an obsession born of loss. In barely six weeks the Soviet ice hockey team will play its first game in the XIV Olympic Winter Games at Sarajevo, Yugoslavia. Tikhonov, who was the coach of the team defeated by the United States in the 1980 Lake Placid Olympics, is fine-tuning the squad he has molded to remove the solitary blot on an impeccable coaching career.

title: WHY SOME SYSTEMS CAN'T GO WITH THE FLOW
description: Winter arrived with a splash last week, capping the wettest 12 months in the 114 years that such records have been kept in New York City. The storm further soothed the brows of those responsible for supplying drinking water, but it also highlighted the vagaries of the region's water systems and weather patterns.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS
description: Bartering Energy

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: AS he handed out the Governor's Awards for Outstanding Volunteer Service in Alcohol and Drug Abuse recently, Governor O'Neill received some unexpected advice.

title: STAGE V
description: The malaise that grips the New York theater did not go away in 1983, but who would deny that the year ended with a jolly bang? The explosion was Michael Frayn's ''Noises Off,'' an ingenious English farce that is not only giving Broadway some welcome hilarity, but is also providing a much needed reminder of the theater's ability to endure in the midst of disaster. ''Noises Off'' is a play about theater professionals who somehow make the show go on even when the show is terrible and the scenery is all but falling down. Mr. Frayn didn't write his farce as a parable about the New York theater, 1983, but it could most hearteningly serve as one. During the past dozen months, our theater artists struggled, often with success, to reaffirm their most durable traditions in the face of mounting imaginative and economic calamities.

title: Arafat Is Reported En Route To Saudi Port City of Jidda
description: Yasir Arafat, who was forced to flee Lebanon, is aboard a Greek ship en route to the Saudi port of Jidda, an official of the Palestine Liberation Organization said today.

title: CENTER OF ATTENTION
description: AN ELABORATE COIFFURE AND COSTUME JEWELRY DRAW ATTENTION TO A BEAUTIFULLY MADE-UP FACE.

title: REFLECTIONS OF DEAR OLD DAD
description: THE whole family was sitting in the den: my wife and I and our two sons, ages 7 and 8. The boys and my wife were watching television and I was reading the newspaper, when all of a sudden it hit me: ''I am a stereotyped father, doing a stereotyped, fatherly thing.''

title: South Korean Captures I.B.F. Flyweight Title
description: Kwon Sun-chon of South Korea became the first flyweight champion of the International Boxing Federation today by knocking out Rene Busayong of the Philippines in the fifth round of a scheduled 15- round fight.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Billie Holiday, Carmen McRae and Zoot Sims is a jazz package that is pretty hard to beat. That's the combination that opens at the Bluenote, 131 West Third Street, on Friday and continues through New Year's Eve and until Sunday, Jan. 8.

title: Anne Sneath To Be Bride Of Executive
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Scott Sneath of Riverside, Conn., and South Londonderry, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Martense Sneath, to Gregory deFontaine Islan, son of Alfred F. Islan Jr. of Cos Cob, Conn., and Vieques, P.R., and Audrey T. Robinson of Tucson, Ariz. A May wedding is planned.

title: TOYS-MIRRORS OF THE IMAGINATION
description: NEITHER my graduate work in Greek metaphysics nor my son's collection of Star Wars paraphernalia makes me an expert on how the American mind connects with outer space. But watching children mythologize about the cosmos during the last decade has convinced me of several things.

title: A LUCKY DRAW FOR REHABILITATION
description: When the Federal Government phased out Ginnie Mae/Tandem financing for Section 8 housing rehabilitation projects two years ago, the remaining funds that had been authorized were allocated by lottery among qualified projects. One of the winners was a major renovation of a 24-unit dilapidated, fire-scarred apartment building in Mount Vernon, N.Y. The Department of Housing and Urban Development recently approved a $1.16 million Ginnie Mae/Tandem 40-year mortgage for the project, with 7.5 percent interest during construction and 11 percent for the remainder of the term, well below market rates.

title: THE INTENT WAS NOT TO SHOCK BUT TO PLEASE
description: This was not a year of strange architecture, of bizarre new forms; it was not even a year in which newness played a very major role at all. If anything, 1983 was a year of celebration of the old, the venerable and the lasting in the landscape. It is ironic, for this was also the year in which Buckminster Fuller, the great apostle of the new, died at 87; Fuller's certainty that new architectural forms would transform our lives seems like a quaint relic from the past. But so does any kind of futurism: though we are at a moment of ever greater use of technology, we are no longer as interested in symbolizing it in our architecture. The classicizing building in which carved granite walls mask computer systems within is the real architectural icon of this time.

title: Clarifying 'Home' In Hospital Care
description: In ''A Touch of Home in Hospital Care'' (Nov. 27), Barbara J. Berg describes the success of the New York University Medical Center's Cooperative Care Unit, which treats more than 6,000 patients annually.

title: Elizabeth Doering to Marry
description: Mrs. Rogers Montgomery Doering of Scarsdale, N.Y., has announced the engagement of her daugher, Elizabeth Doering, to Michael Carson MacKenty, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Edmund MacKenty of Scarsdale and Edgartown, Mass. The wedding is planned for next fall.

title: TURMOIL PERSISTS IN SALE OF CHICAGO SUN-TIMES
description: The bidding to buy The Chicago Sun-Times may be over, but the turmoil seems to have just begun.

title: THE NATION
description: Pentagon at WarOver Drug Tests

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''You are here, and you are called peacekeepers. And my prayer is that finally we will find peace for the people in this troubled land.'' - Capt. Eli Takesian of the Navy, the Marine Corps chaplain, in Beirut. (10:2.)

title: Business Ethics
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 134261 -- No Title
description: The Transportation Department said Friday that it had approved a $1.25 million grant to study the feasibility of building a high-speed rail line between Los Angeles and Las Vegas, Nev.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: THE WHITE PLAGUE. By Frank Herbert. (Berkley, $3.95.) A distinct change of pace for the author of the Dune science-fiction best sellers, ''The White Plague'' is set in the near future and focuses on John Roe O'Neill, a molecular biologist who unleashes a disease fatal to women - and thus to the human race - after his wife and children are killed by a terrorist's bomb. ''Never has the mad scientist been portrayed with such loving care,'' Gerald Jonas said in his review of this ''intellectual disaster novel,'' a brilliant meditation on the war between our tendencies toward self-destruction and our instinct for self-preservation.

title: MUSIC: HANCOCK AND BAND
description: Herbie Hancock, the jazz keyboardist and composer whose musical interests have ranged from Mozart to several styles of jazz-fusion, has added another feather to his cap. On Tuesday, Mr. Hancock and a band that included the ''scratch'' disk jockey Grand Mixer D. Street appeared at the Ritz, where they recreated the snap, crackle and pop of the electronic dance music album ''Future Shock.''

title: WHAT DID CHICO SAY ABOUT 'SANITY CLAUSE'?
description: A Christmas quiz:

title: Kentucky Defeats Illinois on Last Shot
description: James Blackmon hit a 9-foot bank shot with a second left to give Kentucky a 56-54 victory over Illinois in a game between unbeaten basketball teams today.

title: Queen in Plea for Poor
description: Queen Elizabeth said today that modern technology should be harnessed to bridge the gap between rich and poor countries, saying this was the greatest problem facing the world. In her traditional Christmas message to Britain and the Commonwealth, she said this would require less nationalism and more interdependence.

title: ABATEMENT FOR BUILDERS IS REPEALED
description: FOR seven years, builders of commercial projects from offices to shopping centers have been routinely granted an abatement of their county real-estate taxes on 50 percent of the assessed value in the first year.

title: LOW-CALORIE HORS D'OEUVRES FOR HOLIDAY NIBBLING
description: AROUND the middle of the holiday season, today for example, calorie fatigue begins to set in. The relentless succession of dinners, cocktail parties, open-house gatherings, brunches and office celebrations accompanied by massive quantities of rich and tempting food and drinks suggests that 1984 will have to begin with a diet.

title: COPING WITH THE KREMLIN
description: SOVIET POWER

title: Miss Motes Affianced To William Bennewitz
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Hogan Motes 3d of Paris have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathleen Elizabeth Motes, to William Scott Bennewitz, son of Beatrice Smoot Bennewitz of Westport, Conn., and the late Don H. Bennewitz. An April wedding is planned.

title: A NEW RESTAURANT FOR THEATER ROW
description: Among the structures being transformed along Theater Row on West 42d Street are three adjoining low-rise tenements at the southwest corner of Ninth Avenue. Over the next few months, they will be turned into a 200-seat restaurant to be called Jolson's.

title: THE REGION
description: A Solution forThe Disabled?

title: Pope Appoints Archbishop
description: Pope John Paul II has named Bishop Daniel W. Kucera the new Archbishop of Dubuque, Iowa, the Vatican announced Tuesday. Bishop Kucera, who is 60 years old, replaces Archbishop James J. Byrne, who retired Aug. 23.

title: FINDING A BENEFIT IN ENERGY PROBLEM
description: ''IVE seen a large transition in the gas industry, from an industry based on coal and oil to an industry based on natural gas from wells,'' said Eugene H. Luntey.

title: REDISTRICTING: DRAWING BOARD BECKONS AGAIN
description: TRENTON THE judges who first struck down New Jersey's map of its 14 Congressional Districts have given Governor Kean and the State Legislature until Feb. 3 to come up with a new one.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: JUST in time for the New Year comes ''Predictions 1984,' by Kim Long and Terry Reim (Putnam, New York, $3.95), a potent little volume that promises to tell ''everything you need to know for tomorrow . . . today.'' These include such things as mortgage rates, job openings, investments, fashions and income taxes.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
THE 'ROUND POUND' SURVIVES A SHAKY START
description: Eight months after its somewhat inauspicious debut the United Kingdom's new one- pound coin appears to be shucking its image as a British equivalent of the ill-fated Susan B. Anthony dollar. Dr. Jeremy Gerhard, deputy master of the British Royal Mint, reports that the coin, widely referred to as the ''round pound,'' has now ''gained reasonable acceptance'' and seems well on its way to attaining a permanent spot in U.K. coinage.

title: DEATHS OF 2 BRITONS IN FRANCE BELIEVED LINKED
description: On Nov. 28 John Robert Graham, a 27-year-old British accountant, arrived in Paris for a day of business meetings. He spent the night at the H^otel d'Ath enes near the Gare Saint-Lazare and, the next morning, went to work.

title: 3 Years in Floral Fraud
description: James R. Hollingshead Jr., a florist accused of trying to swindle more than 1,200 health care facilities by billing for flowers never ordered and never sent, has been sentenced to three years in prison. The 42-year-old Mr. Hollingshead pleaded guilty to Federal mail fraud and swindling charges. Each of the florist's bills was for $31.50.

title: THE DEFICIT
description: To the Editor:

title: 31 Killed and 215 Injured In Zimbabwe Derailment
description: A locomotive and 13 coaches ran off the tracks today and plunged into a ravine, killing 31 people and injuring 215 others, the Government said.

title: Miss Morgan Plans to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by David E. Morgan of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., of the engagement of his daughter, Alexandra Patricia Morgan, to Giuseppe Ciardi, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francesco Ciardi of Rome. A spring wedding is planned.

title: MANY FROM EASTERN BLOC SEEK YUGOSLAV ASYLUM
description: Many hundreds of Soviet-bloc citizens have sought political asylum in Yugoslavia in the last two years, posing awkward political and logistical problems for the Belgrade Government, according to United Nations and Yugoslav officials. The officials said that of the 2,919 people who sought asylum in Yugoslavia in 1982, the bulk - 1,830 - were Rumanians, and most of these crossed the frontier by swimming the Danube, which demarcates roughly half of the 346-mile border. In the first half of this year, the Belgrade office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees registered 628 people who crossed the border from Soviet bloc countries and Albania seeking asylum, and 365 of them were Rumanians. Recently, according to officials here, the Government of President Nicolae Ceausescu has intensified efforts to apprehend Rumanian escapers, most of whom are young unskilled workers. Rumanian border patrols have recently crossed into Yugoslav territory in pursuit of them, bringing protests from Belgrade that have not until now been publicized. In general, Rumania and Yugoslavia have had good official relations since 1964, but the issue of violations was brought up by President Mika Spiljak during the Yugoslav's meeting with President Ceausescu in Bucharest in November, according to Belgrade officials. The Government in Belgrade has made a policy of not publicizing the number of escapes or the routes used, but the figures are made public in annual United Nations refugee reports. Until now Yugoslavia has provided permanent asylum to only a handful of the escapers, according to United Nations officials, and houses the great majority in two transit camps or Belgrade hotels until they can be moved to other countries.

title: INDY CAR SURGE CALLED THREAT
description: The resurgence in Indianapolis-car racing over the last few years has drawn attention of an unwelcome sort from international racing authorities.

title: CAN REAGAN DEFUSE THE 'FAIRNESS' ISSUE
description: A year ago, the public relations engineers at the White House, concerned about President Reagan's re-election chances in the face of what politicians call the fairness issue, vowed to make strides in 1983 on improving the President's troublesome standing among women and blacks. The strategy was to Platonize the problem, describing it as a matter of perception separate from reality, with such factors as the economic recovery expected to slowly make converts among Reagan critics.

title: Article 134507 -- No Title
description: Olympic officials have presented a check for $3.9 million to city officials to pay the first installment of the tax collected on tickets for the 1984 Summer Games.

title: LESSER IMPACT HERE SOUGHT
description: WHILE business analysts ponder the effects of the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company on the growing telecommunications industry, New Jersey residents are wondering what it will mean in terms of money and possible inconvenience.

title: EX-TYPEWRITER 'CAPITAL' SEEKING A NEW INDUSTRY
description: The factory is dark and quiet now. Its cracked and pitted concrete floors, where more than a mile of conveyors once ran, are largely empty. Here, in a village that once called itself the ''typewriter capital of the world,'' the Smith- Corona plant has closed.

title: ZORACH IN 2 AND 3 DIMENSIONS AT SUMMIT
description: SUMMIT THE exhibition of William Zorach's sculpture and drawings at the Summit Art Center - one of a series about modern American masters - promises to be the center's most prestigious effort this season.

title: ON THE ROAD FROM NAZARETH TO BETHLEHEM
description: AMALACHI MARTIN's latest book, ''There Is Still Love,'' will be published in April by Macmillan. fish. On a map that shows such things, that is what the topography of the land between Nazareth and Bethlehem reminds you of. A giant fish - or, more exactly, the skeleton of one - with its tail up there in the north, forked around the lower end of Lake Galilee, and its head resting in the south on the sandy edges of the Sinai desert. The long ridge of mountains and high ground that runs down the center of the land is like that fish's spine. Its ribs are splayed out on either side, creating ridges and valleys - called wadis in this part of the world - that on the western side lead to the coastal plain and, on the east, into the lush Jordan River valley.

title: ENVIRONMENT IS KEEPING CANADA AND U.S. AT ODDS
description: Manitoba's concern over what is happening across the border has receded a bit after a recent meeting in Ottawa of Canadian and United States officials. The two sides agreed to name a joint committee of experts. They will review a long-proposed land reclamation and irrigation project for which ground has been broken in North Dakota.

title: The Legacy of Rhodes
description: -McQuade's article ''The Legacy of Rhodes'' (Nov. 20) revived many happy memories of the Americans I knew at Oxford when I went up as a Rhodes scholar from India 20 years ago. She states quite rightly that most American Rhodes scholars see great value in their Oxford experiences; what she modestly leaves out - and non-American Oxonians will be the first to mention - is that Oxford is the better for welcoming 32 American scholars each year.

title: The Copper Penny Is a Misnomer
description: The Dec. 11 article ''Let's Hear It for the Penny Before It's Gone'' was intriguing, but contained a factual error of import and another minor inaccuracy.

title: MUSEUM SUBSIDY ARGUED AS DEADLINE ON BUDGET NEARS
description: WHEN the proposed 1984 County Budget was unveiled more than six weeks ago, one of the most innovative and ultimately controversial recommended expenditures was $960,000 for the Hudson River Museum. Although nationally recognized, the institution's fate was uncertain because it was about to lose its subsidy from the city of Yonkers, which was facing even greater fiscal peril.

title: STATE LOOKING INTO STREET 'GIVEAWAY'
description: ATLANTIC CITY SHINN TERRACE was not a household name, even here, until recently. But all that has changed.

title: FOR 13TH YEAR SANTA BRINGS A PAIR OF UNWEARABLE PANTS
description: Roy Collette knows what his brother-in-law gave him for Christmas, but he has not unwrapped it and is not likely to get at it for some time.

title: IN THE HILLS OF JERSEY, THE CRASH OF ARTILLERY SHELLS
description: The rolling hills of the Kittatinny Mountains, less than 40 miles northwest of New York City, often reverberate with the boom of explosions from artillery pieces or with the staccato fire of machine guns as Army and civilian engineers test the latest in military weapons.

title: CHILDREN JOIN THEIR PARENTS IN HELPING OUT THE NEEDIEST
description: Christmas has a special meaning for children, and many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are young people who wish to help those who are less fortunate.

title: CLARIFYING 'HOME' IN HOSPITAL CARE --
description: Barbara Berg's article on New York University's Cooperative Care Unit was interesting. We at the Medical College of Virginia have had such a facility for more than 13 years.

title: Linda Beaty Marries an Art Consultant
description: -2-18 Linda Mackay Beaty, daughter of Mrs. Henry Guettel of New York and Julian B. Beaty Jr. of Water Mill, L.I., was married yesterday to Klaus Ottmann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Ottman of F"urth, West Germany. Rabbi Richard Chapin of Temple Emanu-El performed the ceremony in the Manhattan apartment of the bride's grandmother, Mrs. Richard Rodgers, widow of the composer.

title: TECHNOLOGY INVIGORATED YESTERYEAR'S CLASSICS
description: The biggest news in classical recordings during 1983 was neither music nor musicians but technology - the arrival of the compact disk. Most of the actual CD releases were of performances issued a year or two earlier on LP. Hence they had already been candidates for previous best-records lists, and the actual technology is more Hans Fantel's concern than mine. Still, for many record collectors, a greater amount of time and money than usual was spent on technological questions - and on reexperiencing the standard repertory in a new medium.

title: SCIENTISTS PRODUCE ANTIBODIES TO FIGHT OTHERS
description: Synthetic chemicals have been used to make extraordinarily fine adjustments in the immune defense system in new research aimed at finding a way to treat diseases in which those defenses have gone out of control.

title: HOLIDAY DESSERTS
description: ALTHOUGH WE ATtempt to avoid repeating recipes on these pages, on occasion, particularly at year-end holiday time, we do indulge ourselves in the re-creation in our own kitchen of preparations that have given us pleasure over the years.

title: A BRISK TRADE IN TRANSOCENAIC ACCUSATIONS
description: Economic resentment on both sides is straining relations between the United States and Western Europe, threatening collisions not seen since the 1930's. ''The relationship is at its postwar low,'' said Harald B. Malmgren, a United States trade negotiator in the Nixon Administration. ''The climate is marked by decreasing confidence in the judgment of each side by the other and is now being compounded by the horrible outlook for employment in Europe.''

title: THE DEMAND WAS SIMPLY FOR THE BEST
description: Whether it was a medieval book or a Georgian coffee pot, antiques enthusiasts in 1983 demanded and acquired the finest examples at premium prices. title: Testing Means, and Meanness
description: What's the Reagan approach to hunger? The Administration displayed it last week in both theory and practice. The President himself articulated the theory, in defending his cuts in social service programs. ''It wasn't that we were feeding too many of the needy,'' he said. ''We were taking care of too many of the non-needy.'' That puts the matter plainly. When given a choice between feeding the hungry and catching cheaters, his Administration would rather catch cheaters. The Department of Agriculture, meanwhile, was putting the theory into practice. It promulgated new regulations concerning surplus food. States must now impose ''income-based standards'' to insure that only truly needy people get free food, in bulk or at soup kitchens. In other words, it's no longer enough for poor people to wait in the cold for five hours to get a $7 slab of surplus cheese. It's no longer enough to wait three hours for a soup-kitchen lunch. Now when they get to the head of the line, they're to be subjected to some sort of means test. They'll have to certify somehow that they are poor. Think about that for a minute. There's nothing outrageous about the idea of means-testing. It makes eminent sense in a program like food stamps, intended only for people under the poverty level. But that's vastly different from the ragged, right- now hunger at soup kitchens. True, some states have distributed surplus food to the elderly, poor or not, producing grotesque anecdotes.

title: TOYOTA AND G.M. GET A GREEN LIGHT
description: The Federal Trade Commission decided in a three-to-two vote that the General Motors-Toyota joint venture to produce subcompact cars does not violate antitrust laws and the two companies can proceed with their production plans. Thus, the F.T.C. ended an investigation that had dragged on for 15 months. The final approval came only after the two big companies agreed to a consent decree that limits production to 200,000 subcompacts a year. Even so, the the five-man commission was split, with the three Reagan appointees pitted against the two appointed during the Carter Administration. ''A plain and unambiguous violation of the antitrust laws,'' said Michael Pertschuk, who was chairman of the F.T.C. under President Carter and voted against the Toyota-G.M. deal. The venture was also opposed by the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation, which argued that because of their size, G.M. and Toyota could use their venture to dominate the subcompact market. The consent decree is intended to prevent such domination.

title: The Chicanery of 'Silkwood'
description: ''Silkwood'' is a delightful movie with fine performances by Meryl Streep, Kurt Russell and Cher. Like other docudramas, it is also a perversion of the reporter's craft, which it simulates. As a genre, it deserves vigorous protest. Karen Silkwood worked as a technician in the Kerr-McGee plant at Crescent, Okla., where plutonium was fashioned into fuel rods for a breeder reactor. An active union member, she protested the safety conditions at the plant, and was herself contaminated with plutonium, but in ways that suggest it was possibly by her own hand. She gathered evidence that the quality control photographs of the fuel rods were being touched up - which they were, but to conceal dust spots, not defects. She died in a car accident, on Nov. 13, 1974, en route to meet a New York Times reporter, David Burnham. The case became an important strand in the national debate about nuclear power, with Miss Silkwood's adherents contending that she was murdered, their opponents that she fell asleep at the wheel while on tranquilizers. By using real names, the film purports to be a documentary account. But it makes only gestures toward presenting all facets of the case, and leaves the overwhelming impression that Karen Silkwood was murdered. The truck headlights blazing through the rear window on her final journey afford the clearest possible hint that she was forced off the road. A written epilogue that the police ruled her death a single-car accident makes only a fractional counterbalance, and tends, if anything, to corroborate the film's implied authenticity.

title: FOR A CHANGE, A MUSICAL MAKES A STAB AT REALITY
description: Broadway has always been a self-absorbed place, with a profound affection for shows about show people, and most especially about show people who are also Broadway people; but just now it must be breaking its own records for rapturous narcissism. Look at the opportunities for vicarious dreaming it is currently offering the stage-struck and starry- eyed. He or she can identify with spangled hoofers in ''A Chorus Line,'' an overnight dancing and singing sensation in ''42nd Street,'' high-octane chanteuses in ''Dream Girls,'' a jazz-fixated ballerina in ''On Your Toes,'' an eminent movie director in ''Nine,'' a nightclub transvestite in ''La Cage Aux Folles.'' Until last weekend, the list would also have included Miss Peggy Lee in her short- lived musical autobiography, ''Peg.'' A little before that, there was the late Miss Monroe, epicenter of the calamitous ''Marilyn''; by the time you read this, an itchy-toed tot in ''The Tap Dance Kid'' should have reached Broadway. Is there to be no rest from what Anthony Newley, his wits perhaps turned by a glut of big musicals about big musicals, once called the roar of the greasepaint, the smell of the crowd?

title: MUCH TO SING THE PRAISES OF
description: Whatever one's pleasure - historical or contemporary, Modernist or Post-Modernist, art appreciation or financial appreciation - 1983 turned out to be a surprisingly satisfying year. When it began it was easy to feel that traditional, ''straight'' photography had been pushed out of the limelight, which had been grabbed by the self-consciously fabricated tableaux and stolen imagery of an artistic avant-garde wearing SoHo-designed clothes with a Post-Modernist label sewn on. While undeniably high on energy, the young artists of this persuasion seemed to lack any regard for photographic tradition; in some eyes the medium was in danger of being totally consumed by the capacious maw of the art world. As if to confirm this notion, the boom in collecting photographs seemingly had gone bust, taking with it a number of photography galleries.

title: UNREQUIRED READING
description: One day, much too late in whatever adult stage of passage I was in, I had an unsettling insight: I had substituted literature for life. Now, that's a revelation usually reserved for shy adolescents who haven't had much experience to substitute anything for, and who desperately want to ''live'' before they turn 18 and it's too late. But why did it take me so long to catch on? Actually, if I had paid close attention, I would have found plenty of caveats about such a confusion in literature itself, which is forever trying to write itself out of itself and back into the big wide world.
