description: SOME retirees who draw Social Security benefits and many workers who make payroll contributions will be paying more taxes next year as a result of a host of changes designed to restore fiscal solvency to the nation's retirement system. The major provisions of the Social Security Amendments of 1983 that take effect next week, as well as automatic changes mandated by earlier laws, are summarized below.

title: ANXIETY UNDERLIES GRENADA'S SENSE OF RELIEF
description: Despite a sense of relief among many Grenadians that life on this Caribbean island is returning to normal, there is also a underlying uneasiness here.

title: VIEWS ON HUNGER ARE DECRIED
description: ENGLEWOOD DESPITE the views of some Federal officials on hunger in this country, the Center for Food Action in New Jersey has found a continuing need for its services.

title: 35 YEARS LATER, STUDENTS HONOR RETIRED MENTOR
description: HOW is this for a warm hearted Christmas story? Once upon a time, five teen-agers in Allston, Mass., met in the class of a music teacher named Helen Barry. Such was the joy she took in sharing her love of music, that four of the youngsters were inspired to become professional musicians and the fifth (a lawyer) still maintains high-level performing skills as an amateur trumpeter. Thirty-five years later, the five decided to throw a holiday surprise party for their mentor, now in her 70's and living in retirement near Boston. They invited her to attend a concert in the county, where three of them now live.

title: Tea in London
description: To the Editor: In response to the let

title: LAYING BALL, AND HARDBALL, WITH MOSCOW
description: ''We used to watch our Polish brothers with envy as they said what was really on their minds,'' a Hungarian intellectual said, reflecting on the heyday of Solidarity as he relaxed in the research institute where he advises his Government. Then he added softly, ''But perhaps we were right after all.'' Hungary and Poland are at the opposite extremes of the way Eastern Europeans have dealt with ''the reality'' - a local euphemism for the overriding fact of Soviet hegemony.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: THEATER

title: WHAT'S DOING IN PASADENA
description: A week from tomorrow, 125 million television viewers will get their annual glimpse of Pasadena during the Tournament of Roses parade and the Rose Bowl game. Each year about 100,000 of them throw away their snow shovels and move west, lured by the same sunshine and blue skies - now besmirched by occasional smog - that attracted 19th-century settlers. Originally an orange-growing center, Pasadena became a fashionable refuge for wealthy families from the East and Midwest and endowed itself with colleges, museums, concert halls, a chamber orchestra and a repertory theater.

title: Correction
description: In ''What's Doing in San Juan'' (Travel, Dec. 4) it was mistakenly reported that one of the city's museums, La Casa del Libro (House of the Book), has a Gutenburg Bible. The museum has a page from a Gutenburg Bible.

title: THE NATION
description: A Go-Ahead forGeneral Toyota

title: IN BETHLEHEM, CHRISTMAS SPIRIT IS NATURAL
description: BETHLEHEM MAYBE it is the towering spruce bedecked with lights each year, or the post office crowded with people using its special hand stamps on their Christmas mail. It could be the appealing tranquillity of the Benedictine Monastery on Flanders Road, with its elaborate cr eche displayed in an old stable, or the way the Village Green, lined with 18th- and 19th-century homes, looks when it is freshly blanketed with snow.

title: Corrections Director Named
description: Attorney General William French Smith has announced the appointment of Raymond C. Brown as director of the National Institute of Corrections. Mr. Brown, the previous chairman of the California Board of Prison Terms, will replace Allen F. Breed, who retired on Aug. 20, Mr. French announced Monday. The corrections institute, an agency supported by the Bureau of Prisons, assists state and local agencies.

title: SOUND CHRISTMAS PEACE VIA RADIO
description: Growing older extends the memory, and it feels strange to have been alive at a time that now seems very long ago. For example, I remember a Christmas half a century back. I can pinpoint the year - 1933 - by the fact that in the country across the border from my native Austria a new government had just come into power. It was the first Christmas darkened by the shadow of Adolf Hitler. I also remember the occasion because of my father's new radio.

title: Arias to Face Kriek In Opener of Masters
description: Jimmy Arias will meet Johan Kriek in the 7 P.M. opener of the Volvo Masters tennis championships at Madison Square Garden on Jan. 10. The second match will pit Jose Higueras against Jose-Luis Clerc.

title: 'WRONGHEADED' EFFORTS AT WATER DIVERSION
description: To the Editor:

title: THE PLEASURES OF CENTRAL PARK
description: Donald Knowler is a British journalist. This article is adapted from his book, ''The Falconer of Central Park,'' which will be published in the spring by Karz-Cohl.

title: OPERA PEOPLE AND OPERA EVENTS DOMINATED THE SCENE
description: The impulse to look back is always irresistible, though not always a good idea. For taking one last glimpse at Sodom, Lot's wife was turned into a pillar of salt, becoming medical history's first recorded instance of death by sodium overload. Orfeo, also a heart case, could not resist looking over his shoulder at Eurydice and thus lost his beloved nymph forever. Dire precedents, those. Still, Satchel Paige's wise advice (''Don't look back, something might be gaining on you'') is difficult to heed at this time of year. So, at the risk of who knows what calamity, let me swivel about and look the past year squarely in the eye.

title: I.R.S. STARTS HUNT FOR TAX EVADERS, USING MAIL-ORDER CONCERNS' LISTS
description: The Internal Revenue Service has obtained a computerized mail-order list of the estimated incomes of two million American households and has begun to test whether it can help track down people who fail to pay their taxes.

title: CHINA HONORS MAO WITH SELECTIVE FANFARE
description: Seven years after his death, Mao Zedong is being extolled anew in films, newspaper and magazine articles and reminiscences by old comrades-in-arms.

title: Oklahoma Town Loses Right to Finance Paper
description: The state Supreme Court has ruled that the town of Forest Park, with a population of 1,140, violated the First Amendment by using public money to publish its newspaper, The Forest Park News.

title: GRAND PRIX IN TRACK PLANNING 15 MEETS
description: The 1984 USA/Mobile Indoor Track and Field Grand Prix, a competition based on points scored in 15 meets, will begin Jan. 13 with the Ottawa International Indoor Games.

title: TREASURES OF ILLUMINATION
description: John Canaday, the former art critic of The New York Times, is the author of ''Mainstreams of Modern Art.

description: To the Editor:

description: IT may not be just the holiday spirit, but Lowell

title: DEEP FREEZE GRIPS CITY FOR HOLIDAY
description: Bitter cold and high winds gripped the snow-dusted New York area on Christmas Eve, bringing thousands of complaints about heatless apartments and hampering last-minute shopping.

title: Animal Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: ATHLETES' TRANSITION TO THE 'REAL' WORLD NEVER EASY
description: DURING seasons past, we associated their names with postseason honors and awards. This year, however, Randy Gradishar of the Denver Broncos, Ken Riley of the Cincinnati Bengals and Dan Dierdorf of the St. Louis Cardinals share something else: They have announced their retirement from professional football.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: Italian Jewelry Heiress Is Freed by Kidnappers

title: THE MEN OF THE YEAR
description: The most successful organization in the capital of the United States in 1983 was, without question, the Washington professional football team. The reasons for its success are worthy of analysis and emulation by other Washington institutions.

title: Reagans Will Spend Christmas in Capital
description: President Reagan is spending Christmas weekend at the White House with family and friends.

title: THE NATION
description: Jackson KeepsThe DemocratsUnder PressureCharles T. Manatt, the chairman of the Democratic Party, made further efforts last week to contain the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson's challenge to party rules. Almost immediately, there were signs that his concilatory gesture might prove insufficient.

title: RED LAUGHTER
description: In St. Petersburg on Jan. 9, 1905, thousands of Russian workers assembled in front of the Czar's Winter Palace to protest peacefully against poverty and hunger. The demonstration was not peaceful for long.

title: Influences
description: To the Editor:

title: 10,000 SEAMEN GET KNIT GIFTS
description: At the Seamen's Church Institute at the Battery, the wrapping for Christmas begins in September. And because of the sheer number of packages to be delivered, the knitting of gifts - mostly sweaters, hats and scarves - is a year-round proposition.

title: EL SALVADOR ELECTS NEW LEADER OF ASSEMBLY
description: The Vice President of El Salvador's Constituent Assembly has been elected to succeed Roberto d'Aubuisson, the rightist leader, as Speaker.

title: BRITAIN BRACES FOR NORTH SEA'S EBB
description: LONDON

title: Amanda M. Asch To Marry in June
description: Dr. and Mrs. John J. Asch of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amanda Marie Asch, to Peter Hiram Halle, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger Halle of Pound Ridge, N.Y.

title: WITH SANTA LEADING THE WAY, CHRISTMAS ARRIVES
description: DURING the darkest month of the year, the county fills with festive lights, old customs and yuletime song. Mostly, Santa Claus comes to Westchester County on a fire engine. It's true that the ''right jolly old elf'' descends on Rye in his helicopter, and in the village of Katonah, he steps off the train. Last year, Santa trotted into White Plains on horseback but this year he was back riding a hook- and-ladder fire truck to Gedney Park. Wherever he goes, crowds follow.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: THE HANDBOOK FOR LATCHKEY CHILDRENAND THEIR PARENTS

title: Patricia L. Collins To Wed in August
description: -1-18, 2 lines cut Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William Collins of Yorkville, Ohio, of the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Lynne Collins, to John Mark Murdock, son of Barbara Murdock of New Rochelle, N.Y., and the late Rev. John Graham Murdock.

title: DANCER OUTLINES NEW CAREER MOVES
description: ''ICAN do that.'' Those four words propelled Wayne Cilento, a Mamaroneck resident, to the front rank of Broadway ''gypsies.'' As Mike in the original cast of the milestone musical, ''A Chorus Line,'' he sang, tap danced and talked about the time he used to watch his dancing sister from the sidelines - and concluded that he could ''do that.''

title: A NATIONAL CRISIS IN ETHICAL VALUES
description: ASICKNESS is increasing on our university campuses. Under the general rubric of careerism, in a society with increasing emphasis on material values, some students are embracing the notion that to get ahead, anything goes.

title: Views and Overviews Of the Bottle Bill
description: Complaints by Sidney P. Mudd, president of Joyce Beverages Inc. in New Rochelle (and other local distributors or retailers who are opposed to the New York State Returnable Beverage Container Act, the ''Bottle Bill''), that have been quoted recently (''How Bottler Handles Returns,'' Dec. 4) are premature, at best.

title: PRETORIA STARTS NEW DRIVE ON NAMIBIA REBELS
description: South Africa has begun a new offensive in Angola against guerrillas fighting for the independence of South-West Africa, according to defense officials.

title: MARINE CHRISTMAS: 'GOOD TRY, BUT...'
description: Christmas seems to have caught up with Lebanon despite itself.

title: ALL AT SEA IN THE CARIBBEAN
description: LESLIE MAITLAND WERNER, a reporter in the Washington bureau of The New York Times, covers the Justice Department. By LESLIE MAITLAND WERNER

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Holiday services will be televised Sunday from three churches: one on Fifth Avenue, one at Wisconsin and Massachusetts Avenues in Washington, D.C., and one thousands of miles out in the Pacific Ocean - in Honolulu. From the 144-year- old Kawaiahao Church, of the United Church of Christ in Honolulu, ABC-TV will continue its annual custom of presenting Christmas specials that the networks says ''reflect the ethnic values of various religious groups and races.'' Yesterday's Christmas Eve service will be edited down to 58 minutes by Sid Darion, the executive producer and a church official ''so we make sure we don't cut the wrong thing out.'' Fed by satellite from the 50th state, the service will be broadcast Sunday from 12:30 to 1:30 P.M.

title: CONCERT: MISS BEARDSLEE IN SCHOENBERG 'BUCH'
description: Bethany Beardslee is a phenomenon. A soprano who has probably done more than any other singer in America to aid the cause of difficult 20th-century vocal music, she gives the lie to the oft-heard contention that the singing of such things ruins the voice. On Wednesday night, 34 years after she made her New York debut, Miss Beardslee came to Goodman House to open a series of three concerts she is giving there this season and proved handily that her voice is doing very well - this at an age when most standard-repertory sopranos have long since retired.

title: 'A Great Joy'
description: The story begins very simply. A man and his pregnant wife are on a journey. They had planned to stay at an inn but because all the rooms are gone they take shelter in a stable.

title: Miss Ross Plans To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Porter Ross of Summit and Loveladies, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Natalie Anne Ross, to Peter Adam Spiegelman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Morton Spiegelman of Garrison, N.Y.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: BY and large, I tune out mass- market Christmas carols; but sometimes a raucous ''Rudolph'' crashes, or an old favorite seeps, through the barriers. ''I Heard the Bells on Christmas Day'' did the latter to me early this month, and frequently since then I've become aware of its solemn organ notes winding through my head.

title: CLARIFYING 'HOME' IN HOSPITAL CARE --
description: I was a patient in New York University Medical Center's Cooperative Care Unit last year and can attest not only to the excellent medical care and pleasant surroundings but to the dedication and caring attitude of every single staff member I came in contact with.

title: KLAN DISPUTE IN COURT
description: IN trying to prevent the Ku Klux

title: FINGERPRINTING OF CHILDREN GAINS
description: THE great majority of Nassau County elementary schools have been fingerprinting children, more than 130,000 since last April, responding to parents' concern for greater safety.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Curtis Dickey has signed a five- year contract to remain with the Baltimore Colts, who had feared they might lose him to the United States Football League. Dickey, the team's leading rusher this season, had been negotating with the Houston Gamblers.

title: The Deficit
description: To the Editor:

title: Selling American Films Abroad
description: As a trade association, presently comprising 62 foreign-sales agents, the American Film Marketing Association represents the overwhelming majority of those selling the independent English-language feature film overseas (''Selling American Films Abroad,'' by Karen Stabiner, Nov. 20).

title: Mrs. Gandhi's Nominees Lead in Several Elections
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's nominees headed for victory today in special elections to provincial legislatures and Parliament, pushing aside a strong challenge by the opposition.

title: THE BEST OF THE YEAR
description: THIS being near the year's end, and Christmas Day to boot, it is an appropriate time to recollect the restaurant pleasures and surprises we experienced in 1983.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN;
description: JOAN LEE FAUST This Week:

title: MAJOR NEWS IN SUMMARY
description: A ComeuppanceFor Nakasone

title: ON CANVAS, YES, BUT STILL EYESORES
description: It was bound to happen, given the art world's relentless search for new amusements and investments. And it did. After a long and scurrilous underground career, graffiti has surfaced on the chaste white walls of galleries and museums. The belligerent signatures, or ''tags'' - Toxic, Daze, Crash, Koor, Noc 167, Blade and Ramm-El-Zee among them - so offensively spraycanned across subway walls and cars are now to be found on canvas, and trendy collectors - who may or may not use the trains - are taking into their living rooms (or buying for speculation) the visual mayhem that daily assaults the eyes of those who do.

title: NEW WORKS NEW DANCERS CAME TO THE FORE
description: This year, for the first time in a decade, the ballet world could choose, like modern-dance, from a cluster of new choreographers who had emerged as major talents. The dearth of developing choreographers in classical ballet suddenly seemed less worrying. It was also a year of individual and collective strengths. Entire companies seemed to make a comeback or to weather crises with resiliency. A brilliant array of new dancers - chiefly young foreign ballet stars - appeared on the scene.

description: PARIS IN THE SPRING

title: A SEPTEMBER WEDDING FOR DANETTE CENTOURI
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Dante A. Centuori of Livingston, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Danette M. Centuori, to Charles D. Whelan 3d, son of Patricia L. Whelan of Findlay, Ohio, and the late Charles D. Whelan. A September wedding is planned.

title: I.R.S. SEARCH FOR OFFICE SPACE MIRED IN PROBLEMS
description: THERE is no shortage of office space in the Village of Hempstead. But after concentrating on Hempstead for five years, the Federal Government is still looking for a site to convert into a Nassau County headquarters for the Internal Revenue Service.

description: Following are excerpts from President Reagan's interview Friday with news agency reporters:

title: IND Car Jumps Tracks In19thDerailingof'83
description: An IND subway train derailed in Queens early yesterday, knocking out service for more than half a day on part of the A line in Far Rockaway. It was the 19th derailment this year, and the second in a week.

title: MUSIC: DANCE AND SOUND AT KITCHEN
description: Dancers had the upper hand - and foot - over musicians at the Kitchen on Monday. Opening a five-night series of collaborations between composers and choreographers, the program featured vamps accompanying fully worked-out dances.

title: REMEMBERING THE THE REAL OLD THEATER
description: Roger Copeland teaches drama at Oberlin College.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article Nov. 20 on a murder charge against a professor at Tufts Medical School incorrectly identified a Harvard Medical School professor who was convicted of murder in 1850. He was John W. Webster.

title: New Drug for Bleeding Is Given Mixed Reports
description: Doctors have expressed disappointment that a new drug thought to be effective against excessive bleeding caused by liver disease has fallen short of expectations, according to a report published in The New England Journal of Medicine.

ANTIQUES;

description: Dr. Rosalind Gould Starobin, clinical professor of psychology at New York University and a practicing psychoanalyst, died of cancer Friday at her home in Newtown, Conn.

title: AMERICAN ASSENTS
description: Tom D. Crouch's history of American ballooning, THE EAGLE ALOFT: Two Centuries of the Balloon in America (Smithsonian Institution Press, $49.50), begins on Aug. 27, 1783 in Paris, where the world's first gas balloon is being demonstrated. In the crowd watching are 16-year-old John Quincy Adams and 77-year-old Benjamin Franklin.

title: Q AND A Air-Conditioner Fees Question:
description: In the summer of 1981, the landlord of our rent-stabilized building told us we would have to pay him an additional $10 every month for each air-conditioner. Until the summer of 1982, the landlord paid for electricity. Last summer the $10 fee was removed, our rents were reduced and we began paying our own electrical bills. Last week the landlord wrote us that our air- conditioners were illegal because we did not have permission to install them, and that we must again pay $10 each month. Is this true? . . . M. B., Kew Gardens, Queens

title: NEW YORK GROUPS AID CRIME VICTIMS
description: On Nov. 18, Brenda Dawson was mugged for the first time in her life, and she says she is still suffering the consequences: severe, recurring headaches, dizzy spells and a fear of strangers.

title: HEADLILNERS

title: Sylvia M. Bullock Is Engaged to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. H. Ridgely Bullock of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sylvia Marian Bullock, to David Choate Huffard of New York, son of Mrs. Clarence J. Dauphinot of Nassau, the Bahamas, and George Choate Huffard of Rio de Janeiro.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: Major Hollywood studios will soon begin to offer a shot at stardom to brand-name products - for a fee, of course. The big deal is expected to replace traditionally casual barter, in which movie moguls got free use of a can of beer, say, while the brewery saw its goods on the silver screen.

title: STIFFER GUIDELINES SET FOR EMISSIONS
description: Stricter emission standards for older cars and trucks in the New York metropolitan area, effective Jan. 1, were announced this week by New York State officials.

title: Suzanne Nutt to Wed Stephen Yablon in July
description: Announcement has been made by Lorna Anshen Nutt of Tenafly, N.J., and Dr. Robert L. Nutt of Teaneck, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Suzanne Nutt, to Stephen B. Yablon, son of Dr. and Mrs. Sanford Yablon of Charleston, S.C. A July wedding is planned.

title: JAPAN'S HEIR APPARENT HAPPY TO WAIT
description: Akihito, Japan's next Emperor, has not been required to do much as Crown Prince except bide his time. There are those here who wonder what kind of a job this is for a man who just turned 50 years old.

title: HUNT WIDENS FOR THE KILLER OF EX-OFFICIAL
description: On the evening of Nov. 14, Enrico P. Mazzeo, a former city official, told his mother, with whom he was living in Bayside, Queens, that he was going out for a while.

title: IMPRESSIVE ACTING AND HEFTIER SCRIPTS WERE HIGH POINTS
description: Typically, television year 1983 was a disconcerting affair. Whatever one may think of it generally, the medium is unique in its sheer quantity and variety. Huffing and puffing to offer sports, news, game shows, soap operas, movies, situation comedies, talk shows and action-adventure romps, television goes right on mixing the sublime with the silly, the snootily elitist with the grossly popular. The result, depending on your vantage point and your viewing habits, can be either somewhat dazzling or decidedly infuriating. Only one thing is certain: It cannot be ignored.

description: WHITE PLAINS IT is 10 o'clock on a Wednesday

title: Death Toll Rises to 300 In Guinea Earthquake
description: The death toll from an earthquake that hit Guinea has risen to 300 and tremors continued to shake parts of the country today, the Conakry radio reported.

title: EMILY T. KINGSLEY ENGAGED
description: Emily T. Kingsley of New Canaan, Conn., has announced the engage- ment of her daughter, Roberta E. Kingsley, to Lester J. Kaplan, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Kaplan of Palm City, Fla. An April wedding is planned. The future bride is a daugh- ter also of the late Robert E. Kings- ley.

title: A Sad Note
description: Paul Mahre had his headphones on and was listening to music; he never heard the approach of the snowcat, a machine used to groom ski slopes. Mahre happened to be skiing at the time.

title: 30-ACRE GIFT TO BE TRADED
description: LIKE many people on this Christmas Day, the members of the Nature Conservancy in Bedford have a gift that is wonderful but not exactly right. And like many people, the members of conservancy are going to exchange part of it, with the giver's blessing.

title: WHEN EXPECTATIONS RUN AFOUL OF COSTS
description: Another tale to be added to the growing library of stories about cable television and lowered expectations: Just two years ago, Scottsdale, Ariz., seemed like a succulent cable franchise. The city's population was near 100,000 and growing. Its affluent neighborhoods were exemplars of Sunbelt prosperity. And when the city accepted plans for a 65- channel cable system complete with the most sophisticated technological trappings, it seemed that Scottsdale had done quite well for itself.

title: BELL HERE IS EXPECTED TO GROW
description: ONE week from today, New Jersey will discover that the presence that was once Ma Bell will not have diminished, as many expect, but will have grown larger within its boundaries.

title: DANCE: COLLABORATIONS
description: Anyone who's anybody in dance these days seems to be ''collaborating.'' Collaborations among choreographers, composers and visual artists are, of course, nothing new. But a number of arts institutions have chosen to celebrate the collaboration this year, among them the Kitchen, which offered four collaborative efforts on Wednesday, midway through its ''Musicdance'' series.

title: HOPES UP FOR WORLD FAIR IN '84
description: Buzz Price says that some of the American travel industry's biggest hopes next year lie in two events - the Louisiana World Exposition in New Orleans and the Summer Olympic Games in southern California.

title: CHINA'S COURTSHIP OF CAPITALISM
description: XIAMEN, China WHEN imperial China lost the Opium War to Britain in 1841, this scenic port was one of the first forced open to trade with the West. It was called Amoy then, and foreign merchants built their tile- roofed mansions among the banyan trees on the lush, granite-studded Gulangyu Island.

title: REPORT CRITICIZES TRANSIT AUTHORITY ON PRODUCTIVITY
description: The Transit Authority is losing millions of dollars in productivity savings by failing to revise work quotas and rules as allowed by a 1982 arbitration ruling, according to an audit by the State Comptroller's office.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: The Christmas celebration continues this week mainly in the opera house. Aside from the Metropolitan Opera's traditional performances of Humperdinck's ''Hansel and Gretel'' on Monday, Thursday and Saturday, Victor Herbert's ''Babes in Toyland'' is being played by the Light Opera of Manhattan at the Eastside Playhouse Tuesday evening through Saturday, and - also in the festive spirit - there will be Strauss' ''Fledermaus'' at the Amato Opera on the Bowery on Thursday, Friday and Saturday.

title: Susan Cameron Ellison Plans to Marry in August

title: It's a Snap
description: Mike McDonald says he was doing ''a lot of beer drinking and fishing'' when the Los Angeles Rams called on him. The Rams, who face the Cowboys tomorrow in a National Football League playoff game, found themselves without a long snapper for punts after Doug Barnett suffered an injured knee.

title: THE MAN WHO MADE DECOYS AN ART FORM
description: AFRIEZE of ducks stenciled on the walls of the foyer introduces the current exhibition at the Museum of Art, Science and Industry in Bridgeport. ''Shang Wheeler and the Housatonic Decoy,'' which runs until Jan. 8, celebrates the art of decoy carving and the life of a Connecticut man whose work set new standards of excellence in the field.

title: Airline Gets Backing For Wage-Cut Plan
description: Eastern Airlines' nonunion workers have overwhelmingly endorsed a financial program that would allow employees to buy one-quarter of the airline through wage investments.

description: Some AcreageFor EveryoneIn WestchesterGovernor Cuomo accepted 743 acres of prime Westchester real estate last week and said the meadows, streams and rolling woodlands would soon be open to one and all. A better park a Rockefeller's money couldn't buy.

title: REDWARE POTTERY CATERED TO THE THRIFTY
description: TODAY collectors think of early redware pottery in terms of country farmhouse living. Actually, at the height of its popularity, redware was more of a major Northeastern industry geared to service a large, lower-income city clientele.

title: TEXAS PASTOR DIED AS HE LIVED, SERVING HIS CHURCH
description: The Rev. Leo Walters's church was his life. In 1974 he tore down the aging building and rebuilt a white frame structure with his own money.

title: PINE TAR AND KEELS: SITUATIONS WERE NEW
description: WHILE enlarging the sports vocabulary, several strange new phrases stirred new controversies in 1983 - pine tar, winged keel, no tarpaulin, salary cap and rooted leaf. No, this was not an inventory for a hardware and garden supplies store. This was simply a good year for situations that were new and different.

title: Mayoral Comments On Quality of Life
description: In the article, ''A Profile of Westchester County's Quality of Life'' (Nov. 27), portions of New Rochelle, Yonkers and Mount Vernon were placed in the lower quintile of census tracts in the county by the Westchester Community Service Council.

title: Sharon Saul, Artist, to Marry Peter Bain in June
description: -2-14 The engagement of Sharon Elizabeth Saul, a freelance artist in New York, to Peter Lanning Bain, a member of the class of '84 at Harvard Law School, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. B. Francis Saul 2d of Chevy Chase, Md., and Osterville, Mass., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. St. John Bain of Cincinnati.

title: Hospital to Discharge Woman Seeking Death
description: Elizabeth Bouvia, the quadriplegic who lost a court suit demanding that hospital officials allow her to starve to death, will no longer ''properly be a patient'' at Riverside General Hospital after tonight, county officials said today.

title: Poll Finds Most People Rejecting Higher Taxes
description: With the public more aware than ever of the large Federal deficit, 70 percent of Americans prefer further spending cuts as a way of reducing the deficit and 16 percent prefer increased taxes, according to a poll conducted by the Gallup organization.

title: SUNDAY, DECEMBER 25, 1983;  International
description: The Middle East peace inititative taken by President Reagan 15 months ago has a good chance of being revived, the President said in a year- end interview with wire service reporters at the White House. He said ''we are optimistic'' about the possibilities in the Middle East as the result of the split in the ranks of the Palestine Liberation Organization and last Thursday's meeting in Cairo between Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O. chairman, and President Hosni Mubarak. (Page 1, Column 6.)

description: WHILE it sleeps, White Plains is a city of 47,000 residents. Then, as the sun rises on weekday mornings, office workers and shoppers stream into town by bus, train and car, transforming the Westchester County seat into a bustling city of about 300,000.

title: Woman Told Not to Remarry
description: Joyce Arlene Greene, 30 years old, who had pleaded guilty to manslaughter for shooting her abusive husband, Robert, on Aug. 3, was sentenced Friday to three months in jail and orderd not to remarry or live with a man after her release without the permission of her probation officer and her psychiatrist. The judge, Cheryl Hendrix of Maricopa County superior court, told Mrs. Greene, I want you to be angry enough at the situation that got you into jail that you will not ever allow it to happen again.

title: ARGENTINE PRESIDENT COMES ON STRONG
description: Argentine soccer fans chant ''dale duro,'' or ''give it to them hard.'' In his first 15 days as President, that is just what Raul Alfonsin has been doing. He has challenged the country's most powerful and recalcitrant institutions, the military and organized labor, in a bold attempt to break a 50-year cycle of union thuggery and military coups.

title: MANAGUA, DENYYING BISHOP'S REPORT, LINKS INDIAN EXODUS TO C.I.A.
description: The coordinator of Nicaragua's governing junta said today that the United States Central Intelligence Agency was behind the exodus of 1,300 Indians from Nicaragua to Honduras. He denied a United States-born Bishop's claim that all had left the country voluntarily.

title: Bringing Up Baby
description: In my own life ''before baby,'' I would ordinarily have turned to the fashion section or Russell Baker's column, after scanning the index of The New York Times Magazine, but this day I turned immediately to Daniel Menaker's article ''Bringing Up Baby, or Vice Versa'' (Nov. 27). Mr. Menaker's insights were right on the mark - amazing, given his lack of sleep and recent schedule. I can only add to his comments that in the short time since my daughter was born, she has taught us far more than we her. CARRIE TUHY New York City

title: A RETURN TO YUGOSLAVIA
description: David Binder, Belgrade correspondent for The Times from 1963 to 1966, is assistant news editor of the newspaper's Washington bureau.

title: Anne F. Franke Engaged to Wed
description: Mrs. Edward Philip Franke Jr. of Baltimore has announced the engagement of her daughter, Anne Florence Franke, to Dr. James Kennedy Porterfield, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin H. Porterfield Jr. of Martinsburg, W.Va. A March wedding is planned.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: DESPITE record revenues in what its manager called ''our best season ever,'' the Long Island Philharmonic is not sold out for the rest of its season. With an increase in the number of concerts this year from six to seven and a jump in ticket prices, there has been a 10 percent drop-off in subscriptions, said Howard Grant , orchestra manager.

title: THE MEDIUM WAS AT ITS BEST ON BREAKING STORIES
description: Nonfiction television - a loose, barely definable category, previously made up of news, information, documentaries, docudramas, commentary, interviews, analysis, self-help, how- to programs and contests of all kinds - proliferated this last year, even to expanding the boundaries of the genre. ''The Day After,'' ostensibly fiction, was exploited, interpreted and discussed as if it were nonfiction and became, in the process, a news story in itself. ABC's vision of thermonuclear horror, seen by 100 million American viewers (and since then exported; it is now being shown as a movie in European theaters, for example) was esthetically shabby but politically important. It made a major statement.

title: Electronic Jail Keeper Tested
description: A county judge says an experiment to confine a traffic offender to his home for 48 hours attached to an electronic jail keeper was a ''qualified success.''

title: CHRISTMAS IN WILLIAMSBURG
description: The familiar sights and sounds and smells of Christmas were everywhere. The front doors were decorated with wreaths fashioned of holly, apples and persimmons, and each window had a single candle that was lit each evening at dusk. The sweet smell of a nearby wood fire permeated the air, and the voices of carolers could be heard moving from house to house. Presents lay under the Christmas tree.

title: Israeli Aide in Malta Reports Attempt to Assassinate Her
description: The Israeli charge d'affaires in Malta, Esther Millo, said today that she was the target of an assassination attempt in Valletta Friday night.

title: GOING FOR BROKE WITH A BUMPER CROP
description: From the living room window of his farmhouse near Pratt, in central Kansas, all Earl Rosenbaum could see last week were his fields cuddled in new snow.

title: BRITISH SHOWN HITCHCOCK FILM ON HOLOCAUST
description: An Alfred Hitchcock documentary on the Nazi Holocaust - a film the British Government deemed too grisly for release after World War II - has received its public debut on British television.

title: HAVANA IS RESCHEDULING HALF ITS DEBT TO THE WEST

title: WOOING THE CORPORATE TRAVELER
description: The nation's major airlines have discovered that most business travelers - or at least the companies that pay their expenses - like discount fares as much as vacation travelers who pay their own way. An estimated 85 percent of all domestic air travel this year was at a discount, and carrier executives are determined to reduce this as sharply as competition will allow.

Protocol reflected power. Syria seems very much where it has long sought to be - in the driver's seat.

title: FRUITCAKE IS FOREVER
description: Thirty-four years ago, I inherited the family fruitcake. Fruitcake is the only food durable enough to become a family heirloom. It had been in my grandmother's possession since 1880, and she passed it to a niece in 1933.

description: As a recent graduate of Christ Church College, I must point out that the correct resting place of Cardinal Wolsey's hat, as well as the original manuscript of ''Alice in Wonderland,'' is in our own library, and not that of our neighbor, Oriel College.

title: HEAVY FIGHTING ERUPS IN BEIRUT AS FRENCH SHIFT
description: Lebanon's eight-day cease-fire was broken here tonight in a Christmas Eve battle between the Lebanese Army and Shiite Moslem militiamen. It was the most serious fighting since the cease-fire was declared Dec. 16.

title:
DINING OUT;
FRENCH MENU IN COLONIAL SETTING
description: THIS year L'Hostellerie Bressane (erstwhile Dutch Hearth Inn) in Hillsdale celebrates the 200th anniversary of the construction of the elegant brick Colonial house. For the last 13 years skiiers from nearby Catamount ski slopes and music lovers attending the Berkshire Music Festival at Tanglewood have been among those who have enjoyed the hospitality of Jean Morel, the chef, and his wife, Madeleine.

title: A POWER BROKER WHO HELPED SHAPE AMERICAN MUSIC
description: For the last 50 or 60 years, negotiation, hustling and internecine warfare have been common practice among American composers struggling to get their works performed. Modern Music, a magazine published in the 20's, 30's and early 40's, made it possible for composers to do an important part of their work: publicize themselves and pick the right fights. But Modern Music did more than that. A vehicle for reportage, it conveyed information, ideas and standards to an intelligent, non-specialized audience. And those composers whom it celebrated most - Aaron Copland, Roger Sessions and Virgil Thomson - are the grand old men of American music today.

SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
ANOTHER CHRISTMAS, ANOTHER WORLD

It was there that my husband and daughter and I spent last Christmas with my son, a Peace Corps volunteer.

title: AGENCY SUSPENDS GLOBAL'S FLIGHTS
description: The Federal Government, intensifying its campaign to prevent airline accidents, has ordered an emergency suspension of flights by Global International Airways, citing a ''substantial question'' about the safety of its operations.

title: Karen Warburg Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ralph M. Warburg of Englewood, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Karen Ann Warburg, to Kenneth Marc Reiner, son of Rabbi and Mrs. Jacob Reiner of Belle Harbor, Queens. Rabbi Reiner is spiritual leader of Congregation Ohab Zedek in Belle Harbor and professor of Jewish history at Yeshiva University. Mr. Warburg is president of the Arco Products Corporation in Englewood. An April wedding is planned.

title: FOR A FESTIVE YULETIDE, COLOR IT EVERGREEN ;
description: Once upon a time, picking out an evergreen tree and hauling it home to decorate was a family's holiday ritual whether Christmas was spent at grandfather's farm or back in town. Now this age-old tradition is being revived as the number of cut-your-own tree farms expands throughout the Northeast.

title: AFTER A SLOW BEGINNING, A ROUSING CONCLUSION
description: The year 1983 was not exactly a vintage year for films, but now, at the end, it looks to have been a lot better than it promised to be during the spring and summer. At that point it appeared quite possible that the makers of plastic monsters and directors-as-puppeteers had taken command of the commercial film industry. The prospect was scary without being in the least bit exciting, like second-rate horror films.

description: Ray Bryant has such a lovely, airy way of playing the piano - stepping gently into a melodic line, mulling it for a chorus and then moving into rhythmic passages that seem to be all smiles - that one might transfer to him an album title that was used by Erroll Garner in 1956, ''The Most Happy Piano'' (in deference to Frank Loesser's ''Most Happy Fella,'' which opened that year).

The 6-foot-9-inch Mr. Ross had enrolled at the elementary school after recognizing that despite his years at Creighton University in Omaha, he lacked the most basic educational skills.

title: ENERGY AND CREATIVITY ADDED UP TO EXCITING POP
description: Michael Jackson's performance simply leveled the commercial competition in 1983, the most change-filled year in recent pop-music history. His album ''Thriller'' (Epic) sold more than 15 million copies, and six songs from it became top-10 singles. ''Billie Jean'' was the song one heard everywhere, thanks in part to the brilliant video that went with it. Directed by Steve Barron and spotlighting Mr. Jackson's exceptional talents as a dancer and mime, the ''Billie Jean'' video finally brought black music to MTV, softening up the influential cable television channel, and rock radio, for other black music. Mr. Jackson's incendiary appearance on the Motown 25th Anniversary Special was the program's highlight and another television triumph for Mr. Jackson.

title: PHYSICIST-DANCER AT HOME IN 2 WORLDS
description: NEW BRUNSWICK ''ICAN'T see myself doing anything but physics, because that's one of the things I'm better at,'' said Elizabeth Sexton, a senior at Rutgers, the State University, shortly after donning a purple leotard under her street clothes and throwing a pink tutu into her purse.

title: A REAL CHRISTMAS FOR TV STAR
description: ON the small stage of a darkened set in a CBS television studio, Christmas decorating was getting under way in the house of Betsy Montgomery, the soap-opera heroine. Between glances at her infant daughter and at Craig, her troubled husband, Betsy was stringing ornaments on the family tree.

title: STINE OR STEEN?
description: White House spokesman Larry Speakes had a bad day last month. He had been ordered to slap down the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, Martin Feldstein, who had been differing a little publicly with the Reagan party line on budget deficits. (As the antideficit wags say, Ronald Reagan is destined to be the only President with his picture on a postage- due stamp.) But instead of merely castigating Professor Feldstein for wandering off the reservation, Mr. Speakes appeared to make fun of the pronunciation of his name.

description: ALTHOUGH many people would be reluctant to try to make their own repairs on a priceless antique or on an expensive piece of custom-built furniture, there are a number of simple repairs that the do-it-yourselfer can safely tackle on many ordinary pieces of otherwise serviceable furniture.

title: FRANCE'S GAUMONT TAKES AIM AT THE AMERICAN MARKET
description: Louise Lief is a freelance writer based in Paris.

title: JAPANESE PREMIER PLEDGES TO END TANAKA'S INFLUENCE
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, in a statement designed to insure his continuation in office, today attributed his party's poor showing in parliamentary elections to the controversy over former Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
WINTER FAMILY DAY
description: For a change of pace this holiday season, the Y.W.-Y.W.H.A. of Suffolk is staging a Winter Family Day today at its Commack center. From 1 to 4 P.M., the Y will host a slew of activities, including a magic show by Irwin Erstling, illusionist; Israeli dancing; crafts, drama and games. The Y is at 74 Hauppauge Road. Admission is $6 a family or, for members, $3.50 a family. For information: 462-9800. SECRET HIKE

title: FOREIGN POLICY EMERGING AS A BIGGER DOMESTIC PROBLEM
description: WASHINGTON IN the 1980 Presidential campaign, Ronald Reagan

title: DETERRENCE HARDLY DETERS
description: The contention that we need a large stockpile of weapons so that they will never be used does not conform to the lessons of history, which show that wherever there has been a growing stockpile of weapons they have in fact been used.

title: ILLUSIONS OF GRANDEUR
description: WHILE FEW WOMEN HAVE THE OCCASION, OR THE RESOURCES, TO OWN GOWNS SUCH AS THESE, THAT DOES NOT SPOIL THE DREAM OF JUST ONCE MAKING A GRAND ENTRANCE CLAD IN SOMETHING SO SPLENDID.

title: PUNCH LINES AND POLITICS
description: HUMOR OF A COUNTRY LAWYER

title: ARAMAIC, JESUS' LANGUAGE, IS STILL SPOKEN IN SYRIA
description: There is no indication that Jesus ever set foot in this village whose houses are carved out of the salmon-colored stone of Mount Qalamun. But here in this Christian enclave in the mountains of Socialist, predominantly Sunni Moslem Syria, the ancient language that He and His disciples spoke can still be heard.

title:
GARDENING;
HOUSE PLANTS NEED HOLIDAY CHEER, TOO
description: NOW that the presents have been opened, there may be a few minutes to check out your house plants while waiting for the turkey to roast. It's all too easy to neglect them during the hectic days of holiday preparation.

title: DOWNTOWN MOVE
description: The national office of the Young Women's Christian Association has been searching for a new home ever since its need for more operating revenue prompted the 125-year-old organization to sell its headquarters building at 52d Street and Lexington Avenue two years ago.

title: DICKERSON AT HOME IN DALLAS
description: Eric Dickerson returns home Monday to the stadium where he earned all- America honors, but the Dallas Cowboys will not be in any mood to welcome him home.

title: LOUISVILLE DEFEATED BY HOUSTON, 76-73
description: Akeem Olajuwon, playing with 4 personal fouls, scored Houston's last 6 points to lead the Cougars to a 76-73 victory over Louisville today.

title: Pudding Catches Fire At Tower of London
description: A Christmas pudding burst into flames at the Tower of London today, sending firetrucks racing to the medieval fortress on the Thames.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: A Game to Remember

title: Enthusiastics
description: Americans' speech is age-dated. What do they say on opening a welcome present or hearing some surprising good news? Their exclamation often betrays their generation.

title: A HI-TECH CONTEST IGNORED BY NEW YORK
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK STATE RETIREMENT FUND PLANS VENTURE-CAPITAL INVESTMENT
description: The State Comptroller, in a departure from tradition, committed part of the state's Common Retirement Fund today to venture-capital investments in emerging and expanding companies.

title: UNINTERRUPTED U.S. TIES TO PAPAL STATES
description: To the Editor:

title: ACCIDENTS LINKED TO ALCOHOL DIP FOR 18-YEAR-OLDS
description: Alcohol-related automobile accidents among 18-year-olds in New York State decreased more than 20 percent in the six months after the state raised its drinking age to 19, according to preliminary statistics.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Legal Thicket In Bryant Park

title: Four in One Family Killed in Plane Crash
description: Four people who had flown to Georgia to pick up a kitten for a Christmas gift were killed when their small airplane crashed in rugged woodlands, officials said today.

title: TWO PATHS TO PAINLESS DEATH
description: To the Editor:

title: STICK TO POETRY: SOVIET CRITIC TELLS YEVTUSHENKO
description: Yevgeny A. Yevtushenko, one of the Soviet Union's most popular poets, has come under the harshest criticism of his career for his first novel, ''Berry Patches,'' among other things for the book's critical treatment of Stalin's mass roundup of land-owning peasants in the 1930's.

title: MODERN MUSEUM CLOSING UNTIL MAY
description: On Jan. 4 the Museum of Modern Art will close for four months to complete the $55-million expansion and renovation project that began in the fall of 1980.

title: BIG JOB FOR NEW PLAYER
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C.

title: Gifts of This Season Evoke Dreams of Next Season
description: PEOPLE from the world of sports also looked under their trees yesterday. And many of them found just what they were looking for. The gifts didn't necessarily guarantee a faster time or more power or victory. And yet, for a number of sports figures, the gifts were perfect symbols of what they needed, or of what they thought they needed.

title: TO AMERICAN FRIENDS OF HARRODS BOMBING
description: Let every American who contributes money and arms to the terrorists of Northern Ireland share in the responsibility for the despicable pre- Christmas bombing of innocent civilians in the crowded streets of London.

title: Denmark Prices Up
description: Consumer prices in Denmark rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in November from October and 5.4 percent from November 1982, the Government's Bureau of Statistics said. It was the second consecutive month that consumer prices rose on an annual basis by less than 6 percent.

title: AFGHAN AREAS SHOW HOW WAR CUTS FABRIC OF LIFE
description: During a two-month trek through northern Afghanistan with a group of Afghan rebels, an American film maker visited two areas that were only 30 miles apart but appeared as different as separate countries because of four years of war.

title: GRENADA AVOIDS POLITICAL MOVES FOR TIME BEING
description: Two months after the killing of Prime Minister Maurice Bishop and the United States-led invasion that followed, Grenada is a nation without a firm leader. Many Grenadians, still shaken by the upheavals, say that, for now, they do not want one.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: In a soccer match, a shot by an advancing forward strikes the goalkeeper in the stomach and rebounds near the forward, who then kicks the ball into the net. Is the goal legal, since the goalkeeper was incapacitated by the blow to the stomach?

title: UP TO A POINT
description: The headline in the Daily Express read: ''Woman stamps budgie to death - Staff saw pet-shop horror, court told.'' The woman was Margaret Hastick, 21 years old, a customer who lost her temper and took it out on a budgerigar (parakeet). Charged with ill-treating an animal, she was released on bail.

title: GUIDES TO PRICING ANTIQUES
description: ANTIQUES price guides have mushroomed in recent years as the boom in antiques buying continues. The latest editions of two of the oldest price guides have just appeared. In both, the information on the antiques listed is limited. Although some expensive antiques are included in each, these are not books consulted by connoisseurs of period decorative arts. Indeed, antiques shoppers should use these guides as a starting point, insisting on other information about the quality of craftsmanship and the condition of the object before they decide the worth of period pieces and whether to buy.

title: SALVADOR CLERIC SAYS 6,096 DIED
description: The Roman Catholic Auxiliary Bishop of San Salvador said today that 6,096 people had died in El Salvador's political conflict this year, most of them killed by the armed forces and right- wing death squads.

title: MONDALE STAFF WORRIES: WILL VOTERS PICK HIM?
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale leads the Democratic Presidential race in national polls, money raised and straw votes won. But as the election year nears and the campaign accelerates, Mr. Mondale and his staff remain nervous about the question that has dominated the campaign.

title: A FRIGID NEW YORK WARMED BY SEASON
description: Colder than most, whiter than some, Christmas was a day of blinding sunshine and searing wind as bundled and huddled New Yorkers made their way to the warmth of familiar hearthsides or to rooms full of homeless strangers.

title: SPECIALISTS DETAIL 'NUCLEAR WINTER'
description: Detailed arguments for the hypothesis that a catastrophic ''nuclear winter'' might result from concerted missile attacks on major cities and be followed by the annihilation of much, if not all, of the human species have been presented for the first time in a scientific journal.

title: Woolen Stocking Tales
description: WHEN first looking into my Christmas argyle, the one without the hole in the toe, I came across a number of foot notes, as it were, on moments during the sports year that I didn't use in stories for one reason or another, but liked.

title: COWBOYS TRYING TO RECOVER
description: Since 1960, when Tom Landry became coach, the Dallas Cowboys have been a model of success in the National Football League.

title: REDESIGNED BUSINESS PLANES
description: The companies that make aircraft for business use and individuals are finishing their worst year since 1952. But the industry is spending hundreds of millions of dollars developing new planes in the hope that the market is beginning to recover.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Creating at Another Level

title: Jogger Reports Abduction
description: A woman reported that a motorist abducted her while she was jogging, kept her prisoner in his car on a six-hour drive, sexually assaulted her and then tied her to a tree, officials said Saturday. The 23-year-old woman told the police the ordeal began at 2:30 Friday afternoon when she was approached by a motorist seeking directions, Montgomery Township Detective Roger Morrison said.

title: Taxes, Budgets And the Deficit
description: THE assemblers of the 1985 budget that President Reagan will send to Congress at the end of January have finished the major spending decisions and have made preliminary estimates, according to officials, that the deficit for the 1985 fiscal year will be about $180 billion and that the one for 1988 will exceed $80 billion but be less than $100 billion.

title: Stacking Juries With Bias
description: Exclusion from jury service because of race is one of the most repellent forms of bias. It deprives defendants of a representative jury and deprives justice of legitimacy. But the bias is so easily disguised and so hard to cure that the courts have simply despaired of dealing with it.

title: CONSERVATIONISTS TARGET DEMOCRATS
description: Conservationists, who have been concentrating most of their political wrath on James G. Watt and other Reagan Administration officials, are now shifting some of their fire to the seemingly unlikely target of House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. and other leading Democrats.

title: Dancers and Musicians To Aid Carey Erickson
description: Twenty-eight dancers, musicians and dance companies will participate in a dance benefit for Carey Erickson, a dancer-choreographer paralyzed in a recent accident. The benefit will consist of two programs, presented at 6 P.M. and 9 P.M. on Jan. 7 at St. Mark's Danspace, Second Avenue and 10th Street.

title: MADRID'S ARTS CIRCLE PLANS CHANGES
description: A new board of directors of Madrid's prestigious Circle of Fine Arts has ambitious plans to modernize and revitalize that venerable institution. It has already helped to arrange a police raid on the gambling room.

title: Gandhi Party Defeated In a Stronghold
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi won elections in four northern states today, but her estranged daughter-in-law led opposition parties to victory in the Indian leader's stronghold of Utter Pradesh.

title: A RISKY ANALYSIS OF STATE VS. RELIGION
description: To the Editor:

title: POLAND FREEING 30 POLITICAL PRISONERS
description: Jozef Cardinal Glemp, Poland's Roman Catholic Primate, said today that 30 political prisoners were being freed by the Government as a gesture to the Roman Catholic Church.

title: CITY SAID TO OVERPAY SLUDGE HAULERS
description: The city's Department of Environmental Protection bases its payments to two private sludge-removal companies on measurements by the companies rather than its own readings, according to the New York City Comptroller's office.

title: FERNANDEZ LETS OTHER PEOPLE WORRY
description: Sid Fernandez went surfing in the Pacific Ocean near his home in Honolulu recently, and left the mystery to others: Is he the best left-handed pitcher in the minor leagues and the next prodigy of the Mets? Or is he a fat 21-year-old with a tired left arm who was cleverly dumped on the Mets by the wily Los Angeles Dodgers?

title: DANCE: 4 COLLABORATIONS
description: THE Musicdance series of collaborations between dancers and composers concluded Friday night at the Kitchen with what could be termed a program of choreographic social studies.

title: BROWN OF A.T.&T. ON UNFAMILIAR PATH
description: At midnight on New Year's Eve, when the biggest divestiture in corporate history finally takes effect, Charles L. Brown, the chairman of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, plans to be spending a quiet time with his wife and toasting his employees.

title: MONDAY, DECEMBER 26, 1983 International
description: Lebanon's Army said it defeated attacks by Shiite and Druse militiamen that broke out in Beirut over the weekend. The fighting took place near bunkers occupied by United States Marines and put the marines on battle alert. There were no reports of them participating in the fighting, though 50 rounds of smalls-arms fire were reportedly directed against them. (Page A1, Column 6.) The Rev. Jesse Jackson said the Syrian Government had invited him and a group of American clergymen to Syria to ''discuss Middle East issues and the specific question of your concern,'' the release of a captured American flier. Mr. Jackson, a Democratic Presidential candidate, sent a telegram last week to the Syrian Government asking for the release of a Navy flier, Lieut. Robert Goodman, who was shot down Dec. 4 in a bombing raid on Syrian positions in Lebanon. (A13:1.)

title: French Car Price Rise
description: French automobile manufacturers intend to raise their average prices by between 1.5 percent and 2 percent, according to industry sources. Renault raised its average prices 1.5 percent last week, and the sources said both Peugeot and Citro"en would raise their prices by between 1.8 and about 2 percent respectively, beginning this week.

title: Reagans and Friends Share Holiday Dinner
description: Members of President Reagan's family celebrated their third Christmas in the White House with a few close friends and their families and a roast turkey dinner that included ''turnip sleighs with spiced apple puree'' and ''packages with ribbons made of sherbet.''

title: The Calendar ;  Monday
description: Washington remains in a festive holiday mood this week, marked by a scarcity of major Government business with the exception of the expected release at some point of a special Pentagon report on the bombing of the Marine compound in Beirut.

title: U.S. Children Discuss Peace With Chinese
description: A dozen American children brought a Christmas Day message of peace to Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang today.

title: For Estridge of I.B.M., Smart Timing on PCjr Texas Instruments threw in the towel on home computers two months ago, saying that $500 million in losses was enough. Four days later, the International Business Machines Corporation, apparently unfazed by the price cutting that brought T.I. and others to their knees, said it would jump into the market with its long- awaited PCjr.
description: If I.B.M.'s mop-up timing proves exquisite - and most industry analysts expect it will - the credit goes to Philip Donald Estridge, the president of I.B.M.'s aggressive new Entry Systems division. Mr. Estridge is betting that I.B.M. is entering the home computer market just as the carnage is ending.

title: PRESIDENT, IMAGINE WHAT THE RUSSIANS THINK
description: To: President Reagan

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: COUNTDOWN The day after Christmas is usually not a bad one, weather permitting, to get out of the house. This you can do in a constructive way today up at beautiful Wave Hill, the 28-acre park in Riverdale, where they will be counting birds all afternoon.

title: Women's Credit Accord
description: Two major consumer finance concerns have agreed to pay $140,000 to settle charges that they discriminated by refusing to consider credit applications from women who did not have jobs, according to the Federal Trade Commission.

title: PEACE CORPS IN HONDORAS: PRACTICAL AND BASIC
description: In villages and towns all over this mountainous and undeveloped Central American country, 210 Peace Corps volunteers are trying to help Hondurans make better use of their skills and resources and improve their lives through better nutrition, business methods and education.

title: JUDGE BARS FITNESS RULES FOR NUCLEAR GUARDS
description: A Federal district judge has halted enforcement of the Government's new physical fitness rules for guards at federally operated nuclear facilities until he can determine whether the rules were properly developed.

title: ROCK MUSIC'S BUSY PHONE-IN 'STORE'
description: The commercials show a telephone plugged into an electric guitar. Viewers who have been watching rock video on MTV, the popular all-music cable television channel, seem to be getting the message: they don't have to trek down to the local record store to buy the latest hits; they can just pick up the phone, call in their orders and have Hot Rock Inc. drop the albums or cassettes in the mail.

title: POPE BIDS WORLD FIGHT HUNGER NOT WAR
description: Pope John Paul II urged world leaders today to spend less on arms and to turn their attention to the ''unspeakable sorrow'' of starving children.

title: Rubell Advances In Junior Tennis
description: Jason Rubell of New York won two matches today and advanced to the third round of the boys-14 division on the opening day of the Rolex International junior tennis championships.

title: HOME-SHARING PROGRAM MATCHES THE NEEDS OF YOUNG AND OLD
description: Two years ago, Irene Kimball shared her home with a young man attending the University of Wisconsin law school. This year, her housemate is a graduate student in urban planning, a tall, bookish 29-year-old named Robert Cook.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Speeding on Slopes

title: SWEDEN LEADS, 1-0, IN DAVIS CUP FINAL
description: Mats Wilander gave Sweden a 1-0 lead over Australia today in the final of the Davis Cup tennis competition with a 6-3, 4-6, 9-7, 6-3 triumph over Pat Cash in a three-of- five-set match.

title: A RUTGERS GRADUATE STUDENT, 23, IS FOUND SLAIN IN HER APARTMENT
description: A 23-year-old graduate student at Rutgers University was found slain in her apartment in New Brunswick, N.J., early yesterday morning, the police said.

title: REQUIRED READING
description: The Depth of the Debt

title: Pickens On Attack T. Boone Pickens Jr. made a lot of headlines and money in 1983 by scaring a number of powerful oil company executives.
description: However, the 55-year-old founder and chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Company, who tilted this fall against his largest takeover target yet, the Gulf Oil Corporation, has yet to show that his well-publicized acquisition plans are more than well-calculated bluff.

title: West German Church Burns
description: A fire early today destroyed a 14th-century Roman Catholic Church a few hours after 500 worshipers had attended a Christmas Eve mass.

title: CHASTITY RULE EVOKES ANGER AFTER MAN ACCUSED OF RAPING GIRL WINS APPEAL
description: The State Supreme Court is likely to be asked to decide whether a man's having sexual relations with a consenting 12-year-old girl is a felony or a misdemeanor under Florida law.

title: EXPERT ON ENGLISH MIDIEVAL CAROLS
description: Dr. Richard Leighton Greene, a scholar of medieval literature and professor emeritus of English at Wesleyan University, died of a heart attack Friday night in his New Haven residence. He was 79 years old.

title: RUMANIA'S ENFORCED AUSTERITY
description: Nearly unable to pay its debts two years ago, Rumania is now determined to retire the $10 billion it owes the West within a few years.

title: 4 YEARS OF AFGHAN BATTLE: NO VIETNAM FOR MOSCOW
description: MilitaryAnalysis

title: A GROUP THAT HAS A WAY OF CREEPING INTO POLICY
description: When President Reagan was pushing early in his term for a return of authority to state and local governments, big hunks of his ''new federalism'' speeches came almost verbatim from an obscure but durable little agency called the Advisory Commission on Intergovernmental Relations.

title: GAS SERVICE INTERRUPTED FOR 270 QUEENS FAMILIES
description: Hundreds of Queens residents were without heat Christmas Eve and much of the day after water seeping from a broken main blocked a gas line serving an 11-block area of Hamilton Beach, authorities said.

title: Iacocca's Rewards Lee A. Iacocca's transformation of the Chrysler Corporation from a gas guzzler into a slimmed-down economy model paid off handsomely this year - for him and the company.
description: Chrysler is expected to earn $800 million in 1983, compared with recent losses that were as large as $1.7 billion in 1980. And Mr. Iacocca recently agreed to remain chairman for three more years, at his current salary of $365,000, plus a big stock bonus at the end of the three years.

title: OIL BENEATH MUD FLATS STIRS FIGHT IN ALABAMA
description: When the Chamber of Commerce here deeded an expanse of submerged tidal flats in Mobile Bay to the University of South Alabama in 1974, school officials were grateful but not enthusiastic.

title: Seahawks Hailed For Intensive Play
description: The game had been over for barely two minutes, and Charley Winner was still on his feet, shaking his head.

title: Woman Told Not to Remarry
description: Joyce Arlene Greene, 30 years old, who had pleaded guilty to manslaughter for shooting her abusive husband, Robert, on Aug. 3, was sentenced Friday to three months in jail and ordered not to remarry or live with a man after her release without the permission of her probation officer and her psychiatrist. The judge, Cheryl Hendrix of Maricopa County Superior Court, told Mrs. Greene, ''I want you to be angry enough at the situation that got you into jail that you will not ever allow it to happen again.''

title: Sweden Tops U.S. In Junior Hockey
description: The Swedish national junior ice hockey team defeated the United States, 4-1, today in the opening round of the world championships.

title: A Mystique No More
description: ''The problem lay buried, unspoken, for many years in the minds of American women,'' begins a book that was published in 1963. ''It was a strange stirring, a sense of dissatisfaction, a yearning that women suffered in the middle of the Twentieth Century in the United States.''

title: Poetry Project Planning New Year's Day Benefit
description: One hundred poets, dancers and musicians will perform in the St. Mark's Poetry Project annual New Year's benefit on Jan. 1 at St. Mark's Church, Second Avenue and 10th Street.

title: AN INTERVIEW WITH FORMER VICE PRESIDENT WALTER F. MONDALE
description: Following are excerpts from the transcript of an interview with Walter F. Mondale by Bernard Weinraub:

title: TOUGH TALK PREVAILS FOR GREYHOUND'S TEETS
description: Labor unions were put on the run in 1983, and one man who led the hounds in the chase was John W. Teets, chairman and chief executive officer of the Greyhound Corporation.

title: British Trade Surplus
description: Britain had a merchandise trade surplus of $:107 million - about $153 million - in November, compared with a deficit of $:429 million in October.

title: NOVEMBER TOOL ORDERS DOWN 21%
description: Orders for machine tools in November dropped 21 percent from October, but were nonethless more than double the level of orders in November 1982, according to a trade association report released yesterday.

title: Italians Voice Hope For Maimed Youth
description: Hundreds of policemen with dogs hunted today for the kidnappers who freed the Bulgari jewel heiress and her son. Doctors said they would try to re-attach the boy's right ear, severed by the abductors.

title: SCIENCE PROMISES REVOLUTION IN FARMING AND ITS PRODUCTS
description: Imagine the farm of the future. Such an operation might fight insects less by bombing them with huge doses of chemicals than by blending sex attractants into insecticides to halve pesticide use.

title: LOAN RATES HIGHER IN WESTERN U.S.
description: Consumers in the Western United States have been paying substantially higher interest rates on loans than individuals elsewhere in the country, according to two recent surveys.

title: CommoditiesH. J. Maidenberg Year-End Futures Accounts
description: T HE margin accounts of futures

title: Frances Rosenstein Is Dead; Assisted Numerous Charities
description: Frances Fried Rosenstein, a philanthropist and the first president of the women's division of the American Technion Society, died Thursday at John F. Kennedy Memorial Hospital in Lake Worth, Fla. She was 88 years old and lived in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is almost a rare thing to die a natural death in this country.

title: STUDIES OF FOSSILS MAY SHED LIGHT ON ANCIENT DIET
description: A handful of young archeologists have found new ways to analyze fossils that may ultimately resolve competing theories of how diet has affected human evolution.

title: 3 Injured in Explosion Of a Gas Stove on L.I.
description: A gas explosion in a house in Elmont, L.I., injured three people yesterday and led to the evacuation of homes in a six-block area, the Nassau County police said.

title: LEBANESE TROOPS REPORT SUCCESSES IN HEAVY FIGHTING
description: The Lebanese Army reported successes today after fierce overnight battles with Shiite and Druse militiamen that followed a French pullout from positions in the southern suburbs.

title: CONSUMER COMPLAINTS ON SERVICE PLAGUE CABLE TELEVISION INDUSTRY
description: As cable television companies spend millions of dollars to install new, high- technology systems around the country, the industry is plagued by a growing problem that even state-of-the-art gadgetry may not cure: poor service to consumers.

title: COURTING THE HISPANIC MARKET
description: Castor Fernandez, the president of Castor Spanish International, one of the nation's largest Hispanic advertising agencies, has a copy of John Naisbitt's book ''Megatrends'' on a small coffee table in his office. He keeps it handy as evidence of an important trend in marketing and advertising.

title: Astaire TV Programs Presented at Museum
description: ''Fred Astaire: The Television Years,'' a new exhibition at the Museum of Broadcasting, 1 East 53d Street, will feature 25 hours of dance specials and dramas.

title: INFLUENCED ART FOR 60 YEARS
description: Joan Miro, universally acknowledged as an artist of the first rank who played an important role in the imaginative life of the 20th century for more than 60 years, died yesterday at his home in Palma, Majorca. He was 90 years old.

title: BEN-GURION RECALLED
description: It is 10 years since the death of David Ben-Gurion, Israel's first Prime Minister and a catalytic force who directed and shaped Israel's policies during its early turbulent years.

title: Bishop Arrives in Milwaukee
description: A Wisconsin-born Roman Catholic bishop reported to have been killed while leading Indian refugees out of Nicaragua last week arrived here Saturday to spend Christmas with his family. Bishop Salvator Schlaefer, 63 years old, was accompanied by the Rev. Wendelin Shafer, 64, formerly of Milwaukee, who joined him on the three-day march with the Miskito Indians to Honduras.

title: IRAN ORDERS EXPULSION OF 3 FRENCH DIPLOMATS
description: The Foreign Ministry said today that three French diplomats had been ordered to leave Iran in the latest round in the diplomatic feud between the two countries.

title: WILD WINDS KNOCK TOWN FOR A LOOP
description: Many of this town's 6,000 residents spent Christmas morning in cold and darkness after 80-mile-per-hour winds battered the town for more than a day, damaging hundreds of homes and businesses.

title: ADA C. FRANKLIN
description: Ada C. Franklin, publisher of the black-oriented weekly newspaper The Kansas City Call, died Saturday at a local hospital after a long illness.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Computer Lag

title: MONDAYSPORTS Basketball
description: College tripleheader , at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. First game, 4:30 P.M., Trenton State vs. New Jersey Tech, followed by Rider-Lafayette and Seton Hall- Rutgers.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Thursday about the annual awards of the New York Film Critics Circle misidentified Joy Gould Boyum. She is a film critic of Glamour magazine.

title: He Shoots Himself at Store
description: A man grabbed a 12-gauge shotgun and shells off a rack in a discount store crowded with shoppers Saturday and ran into a storeroom, where he fatally shot himself, store personnel said. Sheriff Fred Huffman of Knox County identified the man as Alvin S. Green, 40 years old, of Vincennes.

title: ROLE OF MENTORS FOR WOMEN IN ACADEMIA
description: The road to success is paved with knowledge and hard work, but the distance traveled depends not only on what you know, but whom you know. This, according to a recent paper issued by the Project on the Status and Education of Women of the Association of American Colleges, is especially true, and especially difficult, for women in academic circles.

title: BOMB INJURES 2 LONDON STROLLERS
description: A small bomb exploded tonight outside a major department store along London's Oxford Street retailing center, slightly injuring two pedestrians.

title: OVERZEALOUS TACS DEMANDS TAXES, DUE OR NOT
description: To the Editor:

title: SWEDEN'S REVAMPED ASEA
description: One of the first things Percy Barnevik noticed when he took over in the spring of 1980 as president and chief executive officer at ASEA A.B., Sweden's largest electrical engineering company, was that the parking lots at the headquarters were crowded on Saturdays.

title: URBAN AID SKIRMISH BETWEEN KEAN AND LEGISLATURE RESUMES MONEY WAR
description: News Analysis

title: WEATHER IS LIKELY TO FAVOR HUSKIES
description: The University of Washington coaches are hoping for perfect weather for their Aloha Bowl matchup Monday against Penn State.

title: Packers Mulling Schnelker Return
description: Forrest Gregg, the Green Bay Packers' new coach, said today he might ask Bob Schnelker to return as offensive coordinator.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Corruption of Honduras
description: An avalanche of military assistance can skew a poor country's priorities and corrupt its politics with dreams of avarice. It is happening in Honduras, where an increasingly militarized government wants American arms even more than it wants regional peace. And the United States continues to be an eager accessory in thus overloading a fragile democracy.

title: Perkins Learns in First Year at Alabama
description: Ray Perkins's first season at Alabama has ended the same way Paul (Bear) Bryant's last one did - with an 8-4 record and a successful bowl trip.

title: ; ASSASSINS HOOKED ON HASAN, NOT HASHISH
description: To the Editor:

title: Afghans Protest Grenada
description: A demonstration by more than 100,000 students and workers marched in the Afghanistan capital today to protest the United States-led invasion of Grenada, the Kabul radio reported.

title: JACKSON IS INVITED TO SYRIA FOR TALKS
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, a Democratic Presidential candidate, said yesterday that the Syrian Government had invited him and a group of American clergymen to Syria to ''discuss Middle East issues and the specific question of your concern'' for the release of a captured American flier.

title: Underground Economy Cited
description: A new Congressional study estimates the so- called underground economy at 7.5. percent of the nation's gross national product, or about $222 billion.

title: WILLIAMS HELPS KNICKS DEFEAT NETS IN OVERTIME
description: Coach Hubie Brown of the Knicks says he believes in power basketball, getting the ball inside to his big man. But when the game is on the line, his clutch player becomes Ray Williams, a guard with the best one-on-one moves on the team.

title: Upper Volta Prepares Big Political Trials
description: Two former Presidents of Upper Volta and as many as 36 former ministers are to be tried for corruption and mismanagement, official sources said today.

title: HAITI IS ALIVE WITH RUMORS OF SUCCESSION
description: -AU-PRINCE, Haiti - When a new Constitution was rushed through Congress in a just a matter of hours recently, two tiny sections in all the small print seemed to open a crack in Haiti's hermetic palace politics.

title: ALBANY AIDES SEE UNEXPECTED GAIN IN STATE REVENUE
description: New York State will end its fiscal year with up to several hundred million dollars in unexpected tax revenue, according to estimates by fiscal aides in the Legislature.

title: ZIMBABWE REBELS RENEWING CHALLENGE TO MUGABE
description: The slaying of four members of a white farming family in Matabeleland Province last week seems to signal renewed activity by rebels challenging Prime Minister Robert Mugabe's Government.

title: No Headline
description: Dave Anderson Tigh Sheehan At Christmas

title: Last Decade's Weather Termed Strange Indeed
description: A Government researcher has confirmed what many Americans had suspected: The weather in recent years has been very odd.

title: Theft of Dogs From Lab Claimed by Group
description: Animals used in research were stolen from a medical center early today, and an animal rights group claimed responsibility.

title: BAY SANCTUARY PROPOSAL DISPUTED IN PUERTO RICO
description: La Parguera, a tranquil marine area known for its luminous bay and lumbering manatees, has become the focus of a Federal-Commonwealth land dispute growing out of the perennial debate over the island's political status.

description: The Economy

title: MONDALE CALLS FOR CUTS IN SPENDING AND ARMS
description: The New York Times today publishes an interview with former Vice President Walter F. Mondale, the first in a series of interviews with candidates for the Presidency.

title: BRIEFING
description: A 'Blackmail Attempt'

description: Out of the Past With Francis Parkman

title: Kincaid Won't Go To Memphis State
description: The Wyoming football coach, Al Kincaid, said Saturday that he had withdrawn his name from consideration for the head coaching job at Memphis State.

description: The Talk of Ridgewood
