description: AFTER mailing the invitations,

title: IRAN-U.S. TRADE UP FROM 1980 PLUNGE
description: While diplomatic contacts between the United States and Iran, never warm in recent years, seem to be worsening again, direct trade between the two nations is edging up, as is indirect trade conducted though third parties. And indications are that the volume of trade, which fell sharply in post-revolution Iran, could increase in the coming years.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Christmas Message From a City Bureau

title: NOSTALGIA CAN INSPIRE GIVING FOR NEEDIEST
description: ''To an ex-New Yorker now living in Cape Cod, Christmas in New York means the show at Radio City, the tree, the windows on Fifth Avenue and The Times Neediest Cases.''

title: HAWAIIAN BEAUTY MASKS THE EVER-PRESENT THREAT OF DISASTER
description: Behind its mask of tropical beauty, this is a naturally dangerous place where sudden huge sea waves, flaming rock or earthquakes can maim and kill.

title: THE RIGHT STUFF
description: The most graphic testimony to economic recovery was the stores crowded with Christmas shoppers. And the season's overflowing materialism suggests that the election year now fatefully upon us may turn primarily on issues of foreign policy and national security.

title: Egypt and Jordan Sign Accord Reviving Trade
description: Egypt, still technically on an Arab boycott list, signed a new protocol with Jordan today that focuses on reviving economic ties between the two countries.

title: U.S. SEEKS STEEL CURB ABROAD
description: The United States is pressing for an agreement among industrialized countries to eliminate subsidies in export credits for steel mills built in the third world.

title: 8131 Bridge: Hard Work in Preparations Profited Cohen and Bergen
description: To be consistently successful at the national level both members of a partnership must of course have individual talent. But that is far from sufficient.

title: SHOPPING IN LONDON AND PARIS FOR TRADITIONAL MEN'S CLOTHES
description: The only thing difficult about shopping for traditional men's clothing in London and Paris these days is that there is so much to choose from. Prime ministers come and go. Governments rise, fall, are extended and removed, but the high quality of the men's stores continues almost unaltered.

title: OUTDOORS: ON WATERFOWLING IN NORTH CAROLINA
description: FAIRFIELD, N.C.

title: Entertainment Events Music
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Humperdinck's ''Hansel and Gretel,'' 7. Y CHAMBER SYMPHONY, Gerard Schwarz, conductor, 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue, 8.

title: PLANT IMAGERY INSPIRED NOVEL ON VIETNAM WAR
description: Until the color green floated into his unconscious, Stephen Wright, the new winner of the annual Maxwell Perkins Prize for ''a first novel of exceptional promise about the American experience,'' was struggling to find a focus for his story of war and its aftermath. The word green suddenly came to him when he was in the middle of still another revision. Then green became a metaphor for nearly everything that he wanted to say through fiction.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Baseball at Olympics

title: Conference on Dance Set Jan. 13-14; Conference on Dance Scheduled Jan. 13-14
description: Representatives of seven international dance companies will participate in ''The Diversity of Dance: An International Overview,'' a conference on Jan. 13 and 14 at the Asia Society. The conference sponsor is the International Dance Council, the American division of Unesco's dance service organization, formed to encourage an international exchange of information on dance.

title: PROBLEMS CITED IN PUMPING WATER TO A-PLANT
description: Pumping millions of gallons of water from the Delaware River to a nuclear power plant would probably result in soil erosion and flooding, an administrative law judge of the State Public Utility Commission has ruled.

title: Thousands in UruguayProtest Military Rule
description: Thousands of Uruguayans celebrated Christmas with noisy protests and peaceful street demonstrations against 10 years of military rule, witnesses said today.

title: JORDAN SETTLES INTO SUCCESS AS A TAR HEEL
description: The 7-year-old slapped the side of his head in mock disbelief, then gave Michael Jordan his best worshipful stare. It is not every day that a boy has a chance encounter with his hero, a person whose exploits he is accustomed to watching on television or from the seats overlooking the basketball court in Carmichael Auditorium, the arena North Carolina rooters call ''blue heaven.''

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: A PARTISAN VIEW. Five Decades of the Literary Life. By William Phillips. 312 pages. Stein & Day. $19.95.

title: A HI-TECH CONTEST IGNORED BY NEW YORK
description: To the Editor:

title: ISRAEL SAYS POSITION OF U.S. ON ARAFAT WON'T AFFECT TIES
description: The Israeli Cabinet Secretary said today that all the American-Israeli contacts and cooperation agreed upon in Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's visit to the United States last month would continue despite Israel's unhappiness about Washington's approval of the meeting between Yasir Arafat and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt.

title: South Africa Price Data
description: Consumer prices in South Africa rose by five-tenths of 1 percent in November from October and 10.6 percent from November 1982, according to the Government's Central Statistics Services. November's figures indicated a slight downward trend in South Africa's inflation rate. Consumer prices moved up by 10.7 percent in the year to October 1983 and by 1 percent in October from September.

title: No Headline
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be reported this week.

title: TV: BALLET VERSION OF 'MERRY WIDOW' PRESENTED
description: FOR an operetta that was initially greeted with lukewarm reviews, Franz Lehar's ''Merry Widow'' has proved to be a remarkably sturdy entertainment vehicle. Its hero and heroine, Prince Danilo and Sonia, have been featured in several films, played by John Gilbert and Mae Murray, Maurice Chevalier and Jeanette McDonald, and Fernando Lamas and Lana Turner.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: A Star May Not Race

title: DOROTHY LOUDON JUGGLES SARDINES AND SLAPSTICK
description: Dorothy Loudon doesn't eat sardines anymore. ''I used to love them,'' she said wistfully. ''Now I don't want to see them.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Boy Scouts Keeping Up

title: Jefferson Humanities Speech To Be Given by Sidney Hook
description: The National Endowment for the Humanities has announced that Sidney Hook, emeritus professor of philosophy at New York University, will deliver the 1984 Jefferson Lecture in the Humanities May 14 at the Departmental Auditorium on Constitution Avenue here.

title: PLAYSSam Goldaper; Williams Rekindles Memories
description: With every steal he makes, Ray Williams, in his second time round with the Knicks, is rekindling memories of Knick teams of the late 1960's and early 1970's, when Walt Frazier's steals brought him the nickname of the fastest hands in the East.

title: Indonesia Military Chief Appeals to Timor Rebels
description: Indonesia's armed forces commander has called on members of the Fretilin Independence Movement fighting in the former Portuguese colony of East Timor to surrender and promised to treat ''humanely and sensibly'' those who do.

title: LEBANESE ARMY FIGHTS A 3D DAY AT FRENCH POSTS
description: For a third successive day, Lebanese Army units battled today with Moslem militiamen opposing their takeover of positions abandoned by the French around Shatila, a Palestinian refugee camp on the southern edge of the capital.

title: MORE HOMEWORK, LESS LEARNING
description: To the Editor:

title: Comings and Goingss
description: Carl Lewis, Edwin Moses and Mary Decker are the Americans left in the running for the Jesse Owens International Amateur Athletic Award. The other candidates left from the original list of 12 are Jarmilla Kratochvilova of Czechoslovakia and Zhu Jianhua of China. . . . Moses Malone, the Philadelphia 76ers' center, who missed the game against the Detroit Pistons Friday night with an injured ankle, was cleared by team doctors to play tonight in Kansas City against the Kings. . . . Coach John Robinson of the Los Angeles Rams was named the National Conference's coach of the year by United Press International. . . . John Haines , the Texas defensive tackle, suffered a knee injury in practice and will miss the Cotton Bowl, Jan. 2, against Georgia. . . . Clem Haskins , the Western Kentucky University basketball coach, injured a tendon in his left knee during a practice yesterday and will undergo surgery today. He was expected to remain in the hospital for two or three days and be back in time for Western Kentucky's next game, against Middle Tennessee Friday.

title: WILDLIFE RETURNING TO PARTS OF URBAN AMERICA
description: -shouldered hawk, perched on

title: Girl Returning to Hospital
description: Pamela Hamilton, a 13-year- old girl with a rare form of bone cancer, was to return tonight to the Children's Hospital in Knoxville for more court-ordered chemotherapy after spending Christmas at home.

title: ; AS NEW YORK CITY CONTINUES TO THRIVE ON ETHNIC DIVERSITY
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR 4 PROMOTED IN MOSCOW, UNCERTAIN ROADS TO POWER
description: Following are sketches of the four men appointed to positions in the Communist Party Politburo and Secretariat:

title: ANDROPOV MISSES MOSCOW MEETING OF PARTY LEADERS
description: Yuri V. Andropov, who has not been seen in public for more than four months, failed to attend a meeting today of the Communist Party's Central Committee. The occasion is normally obligatory for a Soviet leader, but Mr. Andropov is widely thought to be seriously ill.

title: Quaigh Theater Offers Fourth Dramathon
description: Works by William Inge, Peter Schaffer, Lanford Wilson, T. S. Eliot and Edward Albee will be among those presented at the Quaigh Theater's fourth annual Dramathon this weekend.

title: DEVELOPMENT OF BAYOUS: WILDLIFE HAS ITS FRIENDS
description: She is known as Queen of the Swamps, and no one questions Annie Miller's self-appointed task of fending civilization away from one tall cypress deep inside a marsh near Big Bayou Black.

title: ITALY TOASTS RAPHAEL'S 500TH YEAR
description: Belatedly but in bewildering profusion, Italy is gathering its considerable forces to celebrate the fifth centennial of one of the seminal painters of the Renaissance, Raffaello Sanzio, known to the English- speaking world as Raphael.

title: AIDED ISRAEL'S WAR FOR INDEPENDENCE
description: Nahum A. Bernstein, a New York lawyer who was active in Israel's war for independence, died yesterday at New York Hospital after a long illness. He was 76 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: SCIENCE WATCH
description: Magnetic Field Weakening

title: ENROLLMENT IN COLLEGES REMAINS HIGH
description: -expected and much-discussed decline

title: VIOLENT PLAY BY SPANIARDS
description: The famed Barcelona soccer club, with over 100,000 members, is the largest in the world, and it's a safe bet to say that each died a small death on the afternoon of Sept. 25.

title: TOP OBJECTIVES ELUDE REAGAN AS EDUCATION POLICY EVOLVES
description: Education Secretary T. H. Bell arrived in Washington in January 1981 with as much furniture as he could cram into a drive-yourself trailer and a firm expectation that within a year he would have worked himself out of a job and be back in Utah.

title: PENN STATE WINS, 13-10
description: D. J. Dozier scored from 2 yards out with three minutes left and lifted Penn State to a 13-10 victory over Washington tonight in the Aloha Bowl.

title: Suns Triumph In Overtime
description: Walter Davis scored 10 of his 40 points in overtime, and Alvin Scott sank two free throws in the closing seconds as the Phoenix Suns defeated the slumping Denver Nuggets, 140-133, tonight.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: TO look back at the notes taken in

title: CONTTIBUTORS TO THE NEEDIEST REMEMBERING NOT TO FORGET
description: For many years, the annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has contained a reminder: ''To delay may mean to forget.'' As the holiday season progresses, many donors have noted their resolve not to forget.

title: Grand Jury Investigates Corruption in Indiana
description: A Federal grand jury is investigating allegations of ticket fixing and court corruption in connection with thousands of drunken-driving arrests in Lake County, Ind., a published report said today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE ;
description: ON THE BOOKS The Pierpont Morgan Library, behind its classical facade at 29 East 36th Street (685-0008), is, it appears, an inexhaustible storehouse from which an exhibition may be fashioned on any topic at all. What it does not have, it can send out for and show in its quietly elegant bookish precincts.

title: ALSOP ASSISTS FRIEND IN ART
description: Joseph Alsop is Washington's ultimate connoisseur, an expert of such dimensions on so many subjects that the world usually has to track him to his lair. Yet the 73-year-old former columnist departed his civilized art- filled digs in the middle of the holiday rush and ventured north to New York to honor an accomplished friend, the late Duncan Phillips, the collector who, unaided by dealer or adviser, single-handedly assembled the critically acclaimed Phillips Collection.

title: Business and the LawTamar Lewin When Ads Quote Ratings
description: B ECAUSE of a Federal appeals court ruling earlier this month, the ratings from Consumer Reports are probably going to show up in a lot more ads from now on - and Consumers Union of the United States Inc., which puts out the magazine, is none too happy about it.

title: A YARD CAVE-IN ROUTS HUNDREDS FROM BUILDING
description: The occupants of 244 apartments were forced out into subfreezing temperatures and evacuated to a nearby school last night after a section of lawn collapsed in front of their building.

title: Peru's Maoist Guerrillas Hurl Dynamite at Lima Restuarant
description: Maoist guerrillas attacked a luxury restaurant in Lima today, causing damage but no injuries, a civil guard spokesmen said.

title: 2d Quake in Guinea Kills 143
description: A new earthquake has killed 143 people and injured at least 200 in the same area of northwestern Guinea where an estimated 300 people died in a quake earlier in the week, an official radio report said today. The Guinea radio said the second earthquake destroyed most of the houses in the town of Koumbia and five nearby villages on Saturday night. An earthquake Wednesday night in the same area of the West African nation killed an estimated 300 people, injured 150 and left 200 people missing as it destroyed 16 villages.

title: GLENN FAVORS A SURTAX TO CUT DEFICIT IF NEEDED
description: The New York Times today publishes an interview with Senator John Glenn, Democrat of Ohio, the second in a series of interviews with candidates for the Presidency.

title: 'SEX IS NOT FOR CHILDREN'
description: To the Editor:

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Bulls , at Chicago. In their last meeting, the Bulls won, 113-107, at Madison Square Garden. (Television - Channel 9, 8:30 P.M.) Nets vs. Washington Bullets , at Landover, Md. The Nets split the six-game series with the Bullets last season and won their only meeting this season, 127-110, in New Jersey. (Television - Sports Channel 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:30 P.M.).

title: BIRDERS' SPIRITS SOAR DURING WAVE HILL COUNT
description: Nothing troubled the silence in the dun-colored woods framing a hawk's-eye view of the Hudson River and the Palisades beyond. But there were tracks to be seen in the light dusting of snow. Surely, the birders were not far away.

title: Spock Grandson Dies at 22
description: Peter F. Spock, 22 years old, grandson of Dr. Benjamin M. Spock, the childhood expert, died on Christmas Day in a parking lot near the Children's Museum, where his father, Michael, is director, the family said today.

title: Dempsey Takes Post
description: Rey Dempsey, who led Southern Illinois University to the 1983 Division 1-AA football championship, was named coach at Memphis State in place of the late Rex Dockery, who was killed with three others in a plane crash in Tennessee two weeks ago. ''I want to carry on where Rex left off,'' Dempsey said.

title: A MOVE BY REBELS INTO NAMIBIA SEEN
description: South Africa, which began a major military operation in Angola last week, asserted tonight that as many as 1,000 nationalist guerrillas were poised to move into South-West Africa.

title: SEEKING RESEARCH FUND FOR AIDS
description: Hospital wards and laboratories are not the only places where the battle is being waged against acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS.

title: BUSINESSS DIGEST TUESDAY, DECEMBER 27, 1983
description: The Economy

title: TREASURY ISSUES TO DOMINATE WEEK
description: The Treasury sector will be the focus of attention in the credit markets this holiday-shortened week. Besides the regular weekly auction of bills totaling $12.8 billion, the Treasury plans to sell $6 billion of four-year notes, $5.25 billion of seven-year notes and $3.75 billion of bonds due in about 20 years.

title: Vietnam Moves Troops Into Thai Border Area
description: Vietnam has moved troops, tanks and armored personnel carriers into an area near the eastern border of Thailand and is apparently preparing to attack Cambodian guerrillas, Thai military officials said today.

title: ARAFAT AND 1,000 FOLLOWERS ARRIVE IN YEMEN
description: Yasir Arafat, accompanied by 1,000 of his guerrillas, arrived in Yemen today amid reports that he would meet Palestinian Liberation Organization officials to report on his recent talks in Egypt.

title: Officers Kill Deputy's Son
description: The police shot and killed Berry G. Jackson, son of a Los Angeles County sheriff's deputy, on Friday. They said the 16-year-old had run through a residential area with his father's loaded pistol and fired at pursuing officers. According to the police, he seized the gun after quarreling with his father.

title: Man Decapitates Son 'For Sins of the World'
description: A 14-month-old boy was decapitated by his father, who believed his son was Jesus and had to die ''for the sins of the world,'' the Baltimore County police said today.

title: FED SEARCH FOR MONEY POLICY
description: Seventy years ago last Friday, the Federal Reserve System was created and charged with maintaining an ''elastic currency.'' Today, the central bank is still searching for just the right amount of elasticity in the nation's money supply without causing too much inflation.

title: Required Reading Beirut Hindsight
description: With the unbelievable loss of marines to a single fanatic with a truck full of explosives, many questions have been raised about the level of security around the Marine compound (in Beirut), how the leathernecks were armed, did they have clips in their M-16's, could an M-16 have stopped the truck, and so on. Obviously, no serious perimeter warning system was in use, at least nothing that worked. Again, all the marines' sophistication in weapons and the latest hardware were foiled by one man in a truck, just a few miles from the shores of Tripoli.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Changing Lanes

title: MIGRAINE HEADACHES: PROMISING TREATMENT INVESTIGATED
description: that

title: Debt Issues
description: * Claremont Associates announced the offering of $344,859,750 of serial zero coupon notes due from 1984 to 2007, through E. F. Hutton & Co. The notes are priced from 6.39 percent to 12.40 percent of par with yields ranging from 10.20 percent to 12.40 percent and will be payable from lease rentals guaranteed by the Security Pacific National Bank.

title: Argentine Ex-President Barred From Leaving
description: Former President Reynaldo B. Bignone has been forbidden to leave Argentina by a federal judge investigating the disappearance and presumed death of a man in 1978.

title: TELEVISION: 'OPIUM OF THE PEOPLE'
description: Last May, a network evening news team came to campus to film Washington College's awarding of the Sophie Kerr prize - reputedly the largest gift for an undergraduate with ''writing promise'' in the whole wide world. Later, we huddled round our television sets, glimpsed our academic procession in the opening tease, and then, following the commercial break, watched with bafflement as the news marched on without a word about the Sophie Kerr winner. What had happened?

title: DOG'S DEATH WILL ENRICH A VETERINARY SCHOOL
description: A feeble old dog named Musketeer is the last surviving member of a group of 150 dogs made millionaires 15 years ago by a woman's will.

title: RobotExhibitionOpens Jan. 13 at Craft Museum
description: An exhibit about robots, that includes ''Meet the Robot'' days, will open Jan. 13 at the American Craft Museum II, 77 West 45th Street at the International Paper Plaza.

title: Derailment on IRT
description: The 20th subway derailment of the year delayed service on the Broadway local line in Manhattan last night, the Transit Authority reported.

title: EXCERPTS FROM ANDROPOV REMARKS
description: Following are excerpts from a speech read today for Yuri V. Andropov to the Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union, as distributed in translation by the Soviet press agency Tass:

title: VIOLET CARSON
description: Violet Carson, who played Ena Sharples in the long-running British television soap opera ''Coronation Street,'' died today at her home. She was 85 years old.

title: GIRL, 2, WANDERS OUT AND FREEZES
description: A barefoot, 2-year-old girl wearing nothing but pajamas froze to death early Christmas morning outside her parents' home in Ghent, N.Y., the state police reported yesterday.

title: Rutgers Defeats Seton Hall, 93-78
description: John Battle scored 22 points and Chris Remley added 20 as Rutgers coasted to a 93-78 victory over Seton Hall tonight.

title: LOOKING INTO ANTI-AMERICANISM
description: I am frequently asked whether anti-Americanism prevails among the young people in Germany - and if so, why. Most Germans with whom I have talked about this subject claim that it does not exist in any large measure, that opposition to the policies of the Reagan Administration must not be interpreted as an expression of anti-Americanism, and that even where significant anti- Americanism actually exists, it would be a mistake to identify it with pro-Sovietism. In my opinion, these judgments are broadly valid. But I also believe that the question of anti- Americanism requires deeper probing.

title: Australia Leads by 2-1
description: Australia took a 2-1 lead over Sweden in the Davis Cup tennis final with a victory today in the doubles. Paul McNamee and Mark Edmondson defeated Anders Jarryd and Hans Simonsson, 6-4, 6-4, 6-2, on the grass at the Kooyong Club.

title: Inmate of L.I. Jail Is Found Hanging
description: An inmate tried to hang himself in his Nassau County jail cell today and was hospitalized in fair condition, authorities said.

title: 90 Million Tax Forms Going Into Mail Soon
description: Millions of Americans will be receiving at least one more traditional holiday package this week, their Federal tax forms.

title: NICARAGUA OPENS OFFENSIVE AGAINST REBELS
description: Nicaraguan Army troops have opened a major military operation against anti-Government rebels operating in the remote northeast area where a Wisconsin-born bishop had joined an Indian exodus to Honduras, military officials said today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Bangers and Mash For Boxing Day

title: Richardson Ready
description: Michael Ray Richardson has passed a drug test and will be in uniform for the Nets tonight against the Washington Capitals in Landover, Md., Fritz Massmann , the team's trainer, said yesterday. The Nets placed the 28-year-old former all-star guard on waivers Oct. 11 for what they said was his refusal to enter a treatment facility after he had admitted to a relapse of the emotional problems that caused his cocaine addiction.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: On the Growl at Gracie

title: NEW YORK CENSUS CHALLENGE TO CONTINUE NEXT TUESDAY
description: The legal challenge by New York City and State of the 1980 Federal census will resume next Tuesday. But officials expect that any political or financial gains that result are likely to count more for the next census, in 1990.

title: TV: KENNEDY CENTER AWARDS NIGHT
description: Among all the awards shows that float across the television screen each year, ''The Kennedy Center Honors: A Celebration of the Performing Arts'' has established itself, in a relatively short time, as one of the most distinguished. The sixth annual presentation of these awards, taped on Dec. 4 in the Kennedy Center's Opera House in Washington, can be seen tonight at 9 o'clock on Channel 2. This year's five recipients are Katherine Dunham, the dancer-choreographer; Elia Kazan, the director-writer; Frank Sinatra, the singer; James Stewart, the actor, and Virgil Thomson, the composer.

title: BEIRUT SHELTERS: TREE AND LOCKER ROOM
description: Issam Kanj, his wife and their five children maintain two residences in Beirut. One takes the form of a sheltering tree in the central public gardens. It is wet when it rains, as it did Sunday night, but safe because of its distance from the city's shifting battle lines.

title: BUFFALO STUDIES MOVING ITS PORT
description: When Bethlehem Steel shut its mammoth plant in Lackawanna this year, it left behind an industrial eyesore - 1,300 acres of property on the Lake Erie waterfront crammed with rusted buildings and idle machinery.

title: TO STOP DEATH SQUADS
description: Can the United States stop death squad activity in El Salvador? Do we have the leverage to do so? These are the questions raised by Washington's recent criticism of the death squads. Certainly, it would require more than words to eliminate their violence: What's needed are difficult, concrete actions, involving major risks for both Washington and San Salvador.

title: GLENN HAS THE GLAMOUR, BUT STILL MUST CATCH UP
description: In early spring, in the gymnasium of a high school that bears his name in the quiet community of New Concord, Ohio, John Glenn announced his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: New Suit Is Filed In Baby Doe Case
description: The lawyer who started the court battle to force surgery for the severely handicapped infant known as Baby Jane Doe said yesterday he has filed a new suit to determine if her civil rights have been violated.

title: Chess: Tony Miles Defeats Karpov AndWinsBathTournament
description: Tony Miles, a British grandmaster, won the 1983 BBC Master Game Tournament in Bath, England, by defeating the world champion, Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union, in the final.

title: CIRCULATION BUREAU UNDER FIRE
description: For 70 years, the Audit Bureau of Circulations has worked at one job: verifying circulation claims of newspapers and magazines. The task is important to advertisers, who decide how to spend more than $20 billion of advertising, and to publishers, who peg their ad rates to circulation.

title: COWBOYS DEFEATED BY RAMS, 24-17
description: When the Dallas Cowboys took fierce beatings from the Washington Redskins and San Francisco 49ers the last two weeks, people wondered if the once- mighty team had slipped that much. Apparently it has.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''People out here don't know they're in New York. They think they live in the rural Midwest.''

title: CHICAGO COURT'S POLITICS AND SIZE FEED FEARS CORRUPTION IS ENDEMIC
description: R. SHIPP

title: EXECUTIVES
description: Algonquin Gas Transmission Company , Boston, has elected Richard D. Morel president and chief executive officer.

title: Miro to Be Buried Thursday In Family Tomb at Barcelona
description: The body of Joan Miro, the Spanish Surrealist artist who died Sunday at age 90, will be buried in the family tomb in Barcelona Thursday, a member of his family said today.

title: City Tries to Block School Closings
description: The City Council in an emergency session today voted unanimously to take the Board of Education to court as a last- ditch effort to block school closings next month.

title: Schuck's Head Bullish On Pay 'n Save Merger Stuart M. Sloan and his father-in- law, Samuel Stroum, built the family business - auto supply stores - into a 58-unit chain in Washington, Oregon and Idaho.
description: But when they sought to expand, they found they needed capital, and that need has led to a merger of their Schuck's Auto Supply Inc. with the Pay 'n Save Corporation. The merger is scheduled to be completed on Sunday, Jan. 1.

title: DEREGULATION HASN'T DIMINISHED AIR SAFETY
description: To the Editor:

title: Group Calls U.S. Blind To G.M. Autos' Defect
description: A consumer group asserted today that a Federal agency was refusing to continue investigating possible acceleration defects in 19 million General Motors cars. The company denied there were any problems with the cars.

title: ON STATEN I., THOUGHTS OF AN ISLAND ENTIRE OF ITSELF
description: They don't want to be a part of it, New York, New York.

title: Cosmos Win, 4-3
description: Stan Terlicki scored every goal for the Cosmos today in a 4-3 victory over the Chicago Sting. Terlicki put in the game-winner at 12 minutes 14 seconds of the fourth period.

title: MILITARY INVESTIGATING ELECTRONICS COMPANIES OVER TESTING OF PARTS
description: The Government is investigating at least half a dozen companies in the semiconductor industry to see if they falsified records related to the testing of electronic components used in missiles, ships, planes and other weapons, Defense Department officials said today.

title: Satellite Watched For Signs of Life
description: Europa, a satellite of Jupiter 400 million miles from the Earth, is ''the last hope'' for finding life in other parts of the solar system, according to Bruce Hapke, a professor of planetary sciences at the University of Pittsburgh.

title: SCOUTING
description: Yale's Darling Makes a Choice

title: U.S. Wary About Trip To Syria for Jackson
description: The White House voiced reservations today about the Rev. Jesse Jackson's plans to fly to Damascus this week to discuss the release of an American flier shot down by Syrian gunners in Lebanon.

title: SALVADOR REPORTS 50 REBELS DEAD
description: A Salvadoran Army commander asserted today that soldiers killed at least 50 guerrillas in weekend fighting in the northeast where 2,000 troops are conducting a sweep.

title: CORDERO SURPASSES $10 MILLION MARK
description: Angel Cordero Jr. capped a record- setting season yesterday by becoming the first jockey to ride the winners of $10 million in one year.

title: MOST U.S. CITIES ARE TAKING NO SPECIAL MEASURES TO CURB TERRORISM
description: Concern about the threat of terrorism that has prompted heightened security in the nation's capital is not yet being felt around the country, according to law- enforcement authorities in 10 major cities.

title: IF NOTHING IS FASTER THAN LIGHT, WHAT'S GOING ON?
description: PERHAPS the most fundamental theoretical underpinning of the world of modern physics is the conviction that nothing moves faster than light.

title: Bottle Nipples and Pacifiers Are Facing Stricter Standard
description: The Food and Drug Administration and the Consumer Product Safety Commission say they are requiring manufacturers to reduce the amount of nitrosamines in baby bottle nipples and pacifiers.

title: 2romNiagaraFalls
description: Two men trapped in their small boat in the ice in the Niagara River were rescued today by icebreakers two and a half miles from the American Falls, the police said.

title: Patricia L. Jones Is Bride Of Frank Edward Modic
description: The marriage of Patricia Lynn Jones, a third-year student at the Columbia University Law School, to Frank Edward Modic, a member of the class of '84 at Columbia's College of Physicians and Surgeons, took place in Tarrytown, N.Y., yesterday. Town Justice Joseph M. White of Greenburgh, N.Y., performed the ceremony at the Tappan Hill Restaurant.

title: Paris Seeks to Persuade U.S. to Stay in Unesco
description: France has made diplomatic moves to try to persuade the United States not to withdraw from the Paris-based United Nations Educational, Cultural and Scientific Organization, diplomats here said today.

title: Playoffs Schedule
description: Following is the schedule for

title: No Headline
description: Q.

title: ATTACKS ON FED MAY GROW
description: Last week, after more than a year of relative calm, the Reagan Administration began jawboning the Federal Reserve to relax its grip on inflation and give the economy easier credit in order to sustain the recovery. It was the first sign of what many economists suspect is a new outbreak of attacks on the Fed by the White House and its many other critics.

title: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 27, 1983 International
description: Yuri V. Andropov failed to attend a regular meeting of the Communist Party's Central Committee, an occasion normally obligatory for a Soviet leader. But officials at the meeting approved the promotion of four of Mr. Andropov's loyalists to key posts in the Soviet party hierarchy. He has not been seen in public for more than four months, and is widely believed to be ill. Reports have circulated in Moscow that he is suffering from a serious kidney ailment. (Page A1, Col. 6.) Lebanese Army units battled for a third successive day with Moslem militiamen opposing their takeover of abandoned French positions around a Palestinian refugee camp on the southern edge of Beirut. (A1:5.)

title: Taking the Law for a Subway Ride
description: In explaining why the New York City Transit Authority is paying $650,000 to a young man who tried to get run over by a subway train, Richard Bernard, the authority's general counsel, took an unfair swipe at the law. He complained that New York's law of ''comparative negligence'' allows sizable damages even to plaintiffs like Milo Stephens, whose suicide attempt was the main cause of his serious injury six years ago.

title: No Headline
description: Miss Moonka Is Married

title: 3 OF MAO'S COMRADES SHARE HIS NICHE
description: The Chinese leadership observed the 90th birthday of Mao Zedong today by adding to his mausoleum memorial rooms for three deceased contemporaries - Prime Minister Zhou Enlai, President Liu Shaoqi and Marshal Zhu De.

title: AFTER A YEAR OF CRITICISM, WHITHER THE SCHOOLS

description: Selecting the year's best in sports

title: Advertising; Changes at Mechanix Illustrated
description: MECHANIX ILLUSTRATED, No. 3 in a three-way race, is going to be coming out of the gate in 1984 with a new look and a new publisher with a good track record.

title: China-A.M.C. Jeep Plant
description: The first joint car-making venture between China and an American company is to start operations ahead of schedule next month and investors say they expect it will turn a profit the first year. The American Motors Corporation and the Chinese Government-run Peking Automotive Works have joined together to outfit a plant to build 20,000 four-wheel-drive jeeps during 1984.

title: AN INTERVIEW WITH JOHN GLENN, SENATOR AND FORMER ASTRONAUT
description: Following are excerpts from the transcript of an interview with Senator John Glenn by David Shribman:

title: Now Set
description: All Trucks Free Deregulation is a bust, says the trucking industry. Just look to the numbers: 72 companies out of business since 1978 . . . hundreds more squeezed to the edge of bankruptcy . . . 32 percent of all union drivers laid off.

title: Story of 1896 Olympics Shot in Athens
description: A new television mini-series being filmed here revives the long-forgotten story of a group of American college students with little athletic training who triumphed in 9 out of 12 events at the first modern Olympics here in 1896.

title: IN TEXTBOOKS, STEREOTYPES OF ARABS
description: Some Israeli experts say they have found that Hebrew textbooks are replete with negative stereotypes of Arabs and that the curriculums in Israeli Jewish schools have done little or nothing to eradicate prejudice.

title: ADVERTISING ; Bradford National Shifts to Brouillard
description: The Bradford National Corporation, which supplies a multitude of computer programs to banks, has moved its advertising account to Brouillard Communications, the J. Walter Thompson division that specializes in corporate, financial and industrial advertising.

title: PHONE FEES WORRY ADMINISTRATION
description: The Reagan Administration has begun to seek a way to minimize a rise in consumer phone bills. Its interest reflects a growing recognition that the price of telephone service could become a 1984 campaign issue.

title: FISH FARMS GROW MORE PRACTICAL
description: THE age of fish farming is upon

title: FILM: BUNUEL'S BRONTE
description: OF all of the Mexican films that Luis Bunuel made for the mass market of Spanish- speaking audiences, his 1954 screen adaptation of Emily Bront"e's ''Wuthering Heights,'' called ''Abismos de Pasion'' when released in Mexico, is probaby the work that's most full of riches for those of us who consider Bunuel one of the great film directors of all time. It opens today at the Public Theater, a premiere of sorts, though it was shown by the Museum of Modern Art in 1976 and may have been shown at Spanish-lanuage theaters here in the 1950's.

title: U.S. STEEL CLOSINGS EXPECTED
description: The United States Steel Corporation is expected to announce several major plant closings after a directors meeting scheduled for today in Pittsburgh. Steel analysts say the expected writeoffs may total $1 billion.

title: Egypt Cutting Suez Oil Price
description: Egypt today shaved 50 cents off

title: ONCE EXTINCT IN THE STATE, MOOSE RETURN TO NEW YORK
description: THE stately moose, one of the

title: BACTERIUM MAY BE CAUSE OF KAWASAKI
description: KAWASAKI disease, which afflicts children, may be caused by a common bacterium and may be spread by the house-dust mite, a tiny creature less than a millimeter long, Japanese researchers have reported.

title: RIGHT TIME FOR GOING PUBLIC
description: Televideo Systems Inc. of Sunnyvale, Calif., shipped its first video display terminal in March 1979, but last year annual sales of terminals and microcomputers hit $98.5 million, and company officials decided it was time to go public.

title: Where the Next War Will Start
description: Last week all eyes were turned to the Battle of Beluga on Manhattan's West Side. Zabar's fired the opening salvo when it lowered the price of the Russian caviar to $149.95 for a 14-ounce tin. Macy's counterattacked with $145, then $139.95. Zabar's replied with $129.95 and at last report was claiming victory at $119.95, compared with Macy's $125.

title: Bridge: Even Experts May Not See A Chance to Foil the Enemy
description: To have an opportunity for a lead that would rate a place in any collection of great opening leads and miss it would be be a cloud on anybody's day. A small silver lining would be provided by the fact that almost any expert would fail also.

title: SCHICKLE DROPS P.D.Q. DOWN CHIMMNEY AGAIN
description: He has scrambled onto the stage pursued by a large gorilla, been carried in on a stretcher by white-coated medics and swung down from the first balcony on a rope. Once there, his instrumentation is as likely to include a kazoo, a Coke bottle or a small owl that goes ''whooooo'' when you blow on a tube coming out of its stomach as it is the more conventional orchestral accoutrements.

title: Fund for Beitia
description: Officials of the Offtrack Betting Corporation have authorized a donation of $5,000 to a memorial fund to assist the family of Eric Beitia, the jockey killed last month on the New Jersey Turnpike, the corporation said today.

title: No Headline
description: CORYDON by Andre Gide. Translated by Richard Howard. Farrar, Straus, Giroux. 135 Pages. Hardcover, $15.50. Paperback, $8.25.

title: QUADRIPLEGIC WILL APPEAL ORDER ON FORCE-FEEDING
description: Lawyers for Elizabeth Bouvia, the quadriplegic who has vowed to starve herself to death, worked through the holiday today to prepare an appeal of a court order permitting doctors to force- feed her.

title: Uncultured Politics
description: The United Nations has come a long way since the exciting days of the founding conference in San Fransisco, but too often on the wrong road. World War II was ending, and the surviving statesmen were trying to put together an organization that could keep the peace better than the ill-fated League of Nations. They didn't expect utopia, but shared hopes were high.

title: 5 GOALS IN FIRST BEAT RANGERS
description: The Rangers handled the Pittsburgh Penguins last week as if they were schoolboys, racing over them in a 6-1 victory at Madison Square Garden. But tonight was a complete reversal, a 7-4 loss to the Penguins at the Civic Arena.

title: A MUDDY SATURN MOON
description: In the minds of scientists, the surface of Titan, Saturn's largest

title: RENATA ADLER TAKES ARTISTIC RISK
description: ''I don't think much of writers in whom nothing is at risk,'' says a character in Renata Adler's first novel, ''Speedboat.'' Miss Adler's second novel, ''Pitch Dark,'' has just been published and it is about nothing if not risk, personal and artistic. For writing fiction, Miss Adler says, ''is like sending a heat-seeking missile at your own life.''

title: STEINBRENNER WARNED AGAIN
description: Commissioner Bowie Kuhn has warned George Steinbrenner that ''any future improper conduct'' could result in a suspension for the Yankees' principal owner.

title: No Headline
description: SSC&B Promotion

title: DR. VICTOR DELUCCIA, A THORACIC SURGEON AND NIXON ADVISER
description: Dr. Victor C. DeLuccia, a thoracic surgeon who was a medical consultant to President Richard M. Nixon, died of a heart attack Saturday. He was 63 years old and lived in Yonkers.

title: SIPE SIGNED BY THE GENERALS
description: After months of secret and not-so- secret meetings, the New Jersey Generals of the United States Football League will announce today the signing of their new quarterback, Brian Sipe, a 10-year veteran from the Cleveland Browns.

description: When the soft dawn comes each day to Israel, it gradually reawakens ancient patterns of distrust.

description: They can cost $40 at an accessories bar or $4,000 in a designer dress department. They have been seen glowing, reflecting the lights, at tiny restaurants and gala black-tie evenings.

title: SMALL PARTY JOINS NAKASONE CABINET
description: Yasuhiro Nakasone was formally elected today to a second term as Japan's Prime Minister. The action by Parliament came after Mr. Nakasone formed a coalition Government to strengthen his parliamentary hold.

title: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan Electric Utility Uncertainties
description: E LECTRIC utility issues, thanks to their relatively high returns and steady pattern of dividend increases, have long been regarded as ''safe haven'' stocks eminently suitable for conservative investors.

description: The little boy was not a Brownsville Bible Mission Cadet, but he hoped to be. He was new and he was late.

title: JAPAN'S NEW BREED OF 'OFFICE LADIES'
description: To some, they are a privileged class, rather affluent and carefree. To others, they are the victims of latter-day Dickensian exploitation and sexual discrimination.

title: MASSACHUSETTS OUTLAWING LABORATORY USE OF PETS
description: Dorothy Checchi O'Brien, who takes abandoned cats and injured ducks into her home in Plymouth, Mass., once inspected a Harvard Medical School facility for research animals and found a shivering, crying kitten. ''If I'd had the power to put that kitten to sleep I would have,'' she said.

title: Assaulted 'Angel' Dies of Injuries
description: A Guardian Angel, wounded this summer while on patrol in the South Bronx, has died, and a suspect was charged yesterday with his murder, the police said.

title: Walesa Says Prisoners Are Freed Temporarily
description: Lech Walesa said today that Polish political prisoners released by the Government at the request of the Roman Catholic church have only been given a temporary leave and will have to return to prison.

title: DEATHS OF 14 IN CITY LINKED TO RECORD COLD
description: Record cold temperatures over the holiday weekend contributed to 14 deaths in New York City, according to hospitals and the police, the city's Chief Medical Examiner said yesterday. The Medical Examiner, Dr. Elliot Gross, said that six of the victims had died from exposure in subways, in abandoned buildings and on the streets.

title: NOTED NUTRITIONIST AT M.I.T.
description: Dr. Robert S. Harris, professor emeritus of nutritional biochemistry at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, died of Alzheimer's disease at a nursing home in Wellesley, Mass., Saturday. He was 79 years old and lived in Waban, Mass., and Wolfeboro, N.H.

title: 2 Ineligible for Bowl
description: Dick Crum, the football coach at North Carolina, said that two of his players, the starting fullback Eddie Colson and the reserve defensive back Tim Morrison, had been ruled ineligible by the university for Friday's Peach Bowl game against Florida State.

title: Hartford Fixing Slipping Bridges
description: Reinforcement of two Interstate 84 bridges in Hartford found slipping off their concrete supports should be completed by Tuesday and there is no danger of collapse, state officials said today.

title: ANECDOTES AND THE IMPACT THEY'VE HAD ON POLICY
description: President Reagan and his counselor, Edwin Meese 3d, have both described the evidence of hunger in America as ''anecdotal,'' suggesting that the Government would need more facts to justify a change in its food-assistance policies.

title: New Yorker Beaten to Death In Mexican Jail, Inquiry Finds
description: A New Yorker died in a penitentiary here Dec. 16 as the result of a beating by fellow inmates, not from pneumonia, as previously reported, a prison official said today. The authorities at the Santa Marta Prison had reported they had found the victim, George Irving Urbach, 58 years old, dead in his cell.

title: OLDEST PEACE CORPS VOLUNTEER, 81, IS IN HAITI
description: Odilon Long lives in a remote area of southwest Haiti where there is no plumbing or electricity and few roads are paved. His diet is rice and beans with occasional fruit, corn and wild greens. For relaxation, he listens to a shortwave radio or reads by lantern.

description: Ahmed Iskandar Ahmed, Syria's Information Minister and one of President Hafez al-Assad's closest aides, died tonight after a long illness, a hospital spokesman said.

title: An Alaskan Challenge For Wright Executive In the weeks that C. Larry Walker has been in Anchorage as president and chief executive of Arctic Slope/ Wright Schuchart Inc., he says he hardly had time to notice that the sun rises at 11 A.M. and sets by midafternoon behind the distant mountains.
description: Mr. Walker, who was executive vice president of Wright Schuchart Inc., a large construction company based in Seattle, volunteered for the busy Alaskan job, a joint venture with a Barrow-based native regional corporation.

title: SchoolsCalled
description: City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin's office reported yesterday that a survey of five high schools in October showed that nearly one-fifth of their varsity and junior football and soccer players played without the required authorization.

description: A Long Island plastic surgeon was suspended from practice yesterday on the ground that he represented an ''imminent danger'' to his patients.

title: Q&A Q.
description: I am a beginning cook and have been experimenting with tomato sauces. Most of the recipes call for canned tomatoes, but they rarely specify whether the tomatoes should be drained or not before adding them to a saucepan. When I do not drain the tomatoes my sauce always seems a bit watery. What do you recommend?

title: ARABS AND JEWS OF ISRAEL: THE BIGOTRY RUNS DEEP
description: The 11-year-old Arab girl has freckles on her nose and wears a red ribbon at the top of a long braid that swings to and fro along her back. Her name is Amal Abu al-Jamiyya. Amal means hope.

title: Amnesty for Military Repealed in Argentina
description: President Raul Alfonsin signed into law today the repeal of an amnesty decree issued by the former ruling junta to protect security police officers from prosecution for excesses against suspected leftist rebels.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: -end lists of best records often differ so substantially from lists of the year's most popular records as determined by sales and radio play? One answer is that critics and ''average listeners'' hear music somewhat differently and expect different things from it.

title: MODERN MEDICINE IS QUICKLY GAINING ACCEPTANCE
description: It is considered a measure of India's achievements that 36 years after independence many of the most obvious causes of death and disease, like tetanus, have been eliminated from villages such as this one in the Indian countryside or brought under control through Government action.

description: By saying today that no military officers should be punished for security lapses at the Marine compound in Beirut, President Reagan was apparently acting within his capacity as Commander in Chief.

title: Cranston Is Recuperating
description: Senator Alan Cranston is recovering quickly after diagnostic lung surgery and is expected to be released from a Maryland hospital this week, the Democratic Presidential contender's campaign office said today.

title: SORE THROAT: A SYMPTOM NOT A DISEASE
description: CHANCES are that one morning in the next month or two - maybe even this week - you will awaken with a sore throat. In most of the nation, winter is unquestionably the sore throat season, and sore throats seem to spread like so many good wishes during the highly social holiday season.

title: ANDROPOV, AILING, WINS STRONG SUPPORT
description: The Communist Party's Central Committee ended a two-day meeting today with a strong endorsement of Yuri V. Andropov's policies. But the principal legacy of the gathering appeared to be to foster new doubts about his health and his capacity to function as the Soviet leader.

title: Chester Retiring
description: Raymond Chester , the 35-year-old tight end who played for Oakland and Baltimore of the National Football League before joining the Oakland Invaders of the United States Football League last season, has announced his retirement. In a 13-year career, he had 432 receptions for 5,964 yards and 53 touchdowns.

title: NEW COMPETING SKYLINE IS RISING AT MEADOWLANDS
description: From the crest of the Route 3 bridge over the Hackensack River in New Jersey, it is possible to see across the low-lying salt marshes of the Meadowlands to the steel skeletons of three office buildings, totaling 820,000 square feet of space, taking shape to form a new skyline.

description: FOR lawyers with a background in the sciences, or vice versa, the growing field of patent law can provide a challenging career option.

title: A Technology Index
description: The Pacific Stock Exchange said yesterday that trading in its new index option product, the Technology Index, will start Jan. 13. The index is based on 100 stocks of companies in the technology field. The option is the first new product offered by the Pacific exchange since it began trading options on individual stocks in 1976.

title: Copter Tips Over At Newark Airport
description: The pilot and all seven passengers aboard a helicopter escaped serious injuries today when it fell on its side on takeoff at Newark International Airport, the authorities said.
