title: ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT MARKS A DECADE OF GAINS
description: There are 148 whooping cranes alive in the world today, up from 15 of the big, snowy wading birds that were living in 1941.

title: THE SENSE OF LOSS AT MA BELL
description: They gather at Bill Fisher's place every Sunday. Several of them bake pies. Sometimes Mr. Fisher whips up a stew. He's 82 and still frisky. The rest of the clan has trouble keeping up with him.

title: BRIEFING
description: Looking Toward Pasedena

title: A SWEDISH NEW YEAR'S FEAST
description: HOLIDAY celebrations come and go, but the one that has always meant the most to me is New Year's Eve. It seems a naturally bouyant occasion, the welcoming in of a brand-new year, and for as long as I can remember, I've marked it by inviting good friends to join me for a special feast.

title: S.E.C. GETS TOP RANKING
description: The New York Times computer that ranks college football teams has found that of the nine conferences in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's strongest division, the most powerful this year was the Southeastern.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Telephone and Telegraph Co. has elected to its board Michael I. Sovern, president of Columbia University, and Joseph D. Williams, president and chief operating officer of the Warner-Lambert Company.

title: STANDARDS DIFFER IN PHONE CALL TAPING
description: For many years the tape-recording of conversations by one participant without the knowledge of the other has been a source of contention, a crime in some states but not in others, and generally under an ethical cloud.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Ampex Reorganization

title: EAST EUROPE IS UNEASY OVER MISSILES
description: Across Eastern Europe, especially in Czechoslovakia and East Germany, there are signs of popular as well as official disquiet over the announced deployment of Soviet short-range nuclear missiles.

title: The Betting Addiction Connecticut Is Dangerously Hooked
description: Connecticut does not yet have New Jersey's problems, but the danger signals are there. It has more forms of legal gambling than any other state. Its gambling enterprises press to expand. Its regulators aim to raise the take for the state treasury. Legislators propose new ventures each year.

title: Debt Ratings
description: * American Hoist and Derrick Co.'s ratings on its Duluth and St. Paul, Minn., industrial revenue bonds was lowered to Ba2, from Baa3, by Moody's Investors Service, which also reduced the company's rating on its two subordinated debentures to B1, from Ba2.

title: BUT WHAT ABOUT 2020?
description: For the benefit of youngsters afflicted with an American education, let me note that George Orwell was the pen name of an Englishman named Eric Blair whose extensive writings included the novel ''1984.'' His idea for the book was conceived in 1943 when Britain was at war with Nazi Germany. It was completed in 1948 and published in 1949.

title: JACKSON NOT SURE HE WILL VISIT SYRIA
description: The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson said today that he might cancel plans to visit Syria to seek the release of a captured American flier if President Reagan asked him not to go.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the Audit Bureau of Circulations misstated the organization's numberof field auditors. It is 80.

title: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 28, 1983 International
description: The President accepted full blame for the lack of security measures that permitted the terrorist bombing of the Marine compound in Beirut. While acknowledging that the marines were ill-prepared to deal with the Oct. 23 truck bombing that took 241 lives, Mr. Reagan said their commanders ''have already suffered quite enough'' and ought not to be punished. Officials said that a 166- page report by a special Pentagon commission that has not been made public concluded that the entire military chain of command, including admirals and generals, shares blame for failing to take proper security precautions. (Page A1, Column 6.) The American marines guarding the Beirut airport went into their highest state of alert after artillery shells landed near their compound. The alert lasted 90 minutes and, according to a spokesman, there were no American casualties. (A9:1-3.)

title: The Betting Addiction New Jersey Gambled - and Lost
description: Give us casinos in Atlantic City, said supporters of a 1976 New Jersey referendum, and we'll produce jobs, housing for the poor and elderly and a rich run of revenue for the state. And we'll do it all while keeping out organized crime.

title: Malpractice Award Cut to $1.5 Million
description: A man whose childhood deafness was mistaken for retardation by state doctors is entitled to $1.5 million in damages, not the $2.5 million he was awarded in 1982, an appeals court ruled yesterday.

title: Advertising; Magazine For Latin America
description: HECTOR TIMERMAN, 30-year- old middle son of the Argentine publisher Jacobo Timerman, has founded a publishing company here and is preparing to bring out a new monthly magazine in March or April.

title: GREEKS AND TURKS CLING TO THEIR SUSPICIONS ALONG THE BORDER
description: The 80-mile border stretching south from this ancient capital of the Ottoman Empire to the Aegean Sea is once again a sensitive nerve registering tension between Turkey and Greece. The declaration of an independent state in the Turkish sector of Cyprus in November has brought to the surface the age-old suspicions that separate the nominal allies.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: KENSEI. By Steven Schlossstein. 320 pages. Congdon & Weed. $14.95.

title: ISRAEL MAIL WORKERS ON STRIKE
description: Israeli postal workers went on strike and income tax collectors on a slowdown today as labor unrest grew worse over an inflation bite that has reached double digits for two straight months.

title: Subaru Corp.'s Yacht A Dealer Incentive
description: Drivers along the lower Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive in Manhattan just before Thanksgiving were treated to the sight of a luxurious 157-foot white yacht called the Empress Subaru, with a Japanese auto of the same name parked on the after deck. It was tied up near the South Steet Seaport.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
description: New-Home Mortgages Seen Reaching Record

title: COWBOY LOSS POSES QUESTION
description: Coach Tom Landry was afraid the Dallas Cowboys slumped too much in the two previous weeks. He was afraid that if they did not raise their concentration and intensity, they would be in trouble Monday against the Los Angeles Rams.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Interest Rates Fall Modestly;  3-Month Bill Brings 8.94%
description: Interest rates fell modestly yesterday, despite the heavy supply of new Treasury issues auctioned and scheduled for sale today and tommorrow.

title: Houston Chemical Plant Fire Forces the Evacuation of 400
description: Fire swept through a chemical plant here tonight, forcing the closing of a shopping mall and the evacuation of up to 400 people for three miles around because of toxic gases released by the blaze, officials said.

title: Greece to Re-evaluate U.S. Broadcast Services
description: The Greek Government announced today that the status and operations of the Voice of America and United States military broadcasts in Greece are to be re-examined and revised.

title: IN PALESTINIAN CAMP, ANTI -JEWISH TRACTS ABOUND
description: -Occupied West Bank - Despite the efforts of Israeli censorship, the residents of this camp seem to have everything they want in anti-Zionist and anti-Jewish political tracts.

title: U.S. STEEL PLANS CLOSINGS, LOSS OF 15,430 JOBS
description: The United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest steelmaker, announced today that it was closing three major plants and parts of more than a dozen others, eliminating 15,430 jobs.

title: FILM CREDITS STIR DEBATE
description: Nearly 20 names are crammed into advertisements for the movie ''Christine,'' and some film industry executives say the cascade of credits is as out of control as the movie's murderous sedan.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Planning for the Millennium The new year?

title: Hawks 112 Mavericks 109
description: Dominique Wilkins scored 23 points and Dan Roundfield came off the bench to score 22, including 18 in the second half, to lead Atlanta past Dallas. Atlanta led 52-42 at halftime but Dallas tied the game, 79-79, after three periods. The Mavericks led 101-98 with 3:54 left in the game but Atlanta took the lead for good at 103-101 with 3:22 remaining on a layup by Wilkins. Roundfield scored 10 points in the final quarter after being held out of a starting role for the first time this season with an injured right wrist. Mark Aguirre led Dallas with 32 points while Brad Davis finished with 21.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Magazine Ad Pages Up

title: Charge at Inland
description: The Inland Steel Company said it will have a nonrecurring charge of $35 million in the fourth quarter from the closing of a coal mine near Nicktown, Pa. As part of a restructuring of its raw materials operations, Inland had previously announced a $15 million charge in the quarter for closing the Jackson County Iron Company in Wisconsin. Inland, the nation's sixth- largest steel producer, lost $71 million in the first nine months of 1983.

title: EL SALVADOR GIVES 60,000 MORE TIME TO BUY LAND
description: The Constituent Assembly tonight approved an extension of one part of the country's land redistribution program, giving about 60,000 peasants another chance to buy land.

title: Chinese Textile Output
description: The value of China's textile production for the first 11 months of the year rose 6.7 percent from the 1982 period, to $34.4 billion, the official New China News Agency said today.

title: HOUSING OFFICIAL NAMED
description: Donald Bachmann, a Manhattan accountant, has been appointed chairman of the New York State Housing Finance Agency by Governor Cuomo. Mr. Cuomo said today that Mr. Bachmann would receive $25,000 a year for the part-time job, which also makes him head of three related state agencies - the Medical Care Facilities Finance Agency, the Project Finance Agency and the Municipal Bond Bank Agency. His term as chairman expires Jan. 1, 1985.

title: JACKSON'S PLAN STRESSES NEGOTIATIONS, NOT ARMS
description: The New York Times today publishes an interview with the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson, president of Operation PUSH, or People United to Serve Humanity, another in a series of interviews with candidates for the Presidency.

title: Liberal Vote Gains in House
description: The Americans for Democratic Action said today that the House had the most liberal voting record this year since 1975. The average score in the liberal organization's annual ranking of members of Congress was 49, up six percentage points from 1982.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Accounts

title: Coast Thrift Unit Sues to Block Bid BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Dec. 27 (AP) - The Beverly Hills Savings and Loan Association said it had filed a Federal suit to stop a takeover attempt by a dissident shareholder, Paul Amir. Mr. Amir, a real estate developer, got clearance last Friday from the Federal Home Loan Bank Board to acquire more than 10 percent of the association's stock, his attorney said. He then demanded a Jan. 27 shareholders' meeting to vote on removing the association's board of directors.
description: The suit charges that Mr. Amir and the Amir Development Company ''have violated the Federal securities and banking laws in connection with their apparent accumulation of approximately 15 percent of Beverly Hills Savings' stock,'' the association said. Beverly Hills Savings said it has assets of $1.6 billion.

title: THE RITUAL OF COUNTRY HAM AND BISCUITS
description: John Egerton's latest book, ''Generations,'' was published this fall by the University Press of Kentucky.

title: BIG COMEBACK FOR BIG PEARLS
description: If 1983 is remembered for anything in fashion circles it may just be remembered as the year when big, and obviously fake, pearls made a comeback. And it looks as if that trend is here to stay, at least until summer.

title: A LIFE AGAINST VIOLENCE, AND 3 VIOLENT DEATHS
description: A. Steven Giannell de Jannell, a psychology professor at the State University here, was outraged by violence - so much so that he devoted his professional life to the study of violent behavior and crime, so much so that he wrote letters to local newspapers denouncing aggression of any kind.

title: U.S. CALLED READY TO LEAVE UNESCO
description: President Reagan has decided to give notice that the United States will withdraw from Unesco at the end of next year unless the group substantially alters practices that the Administration found objectionable, State Department officials said today.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET HUNT FOR SUBATOMIC PARTICLE
description: Soviet scientists are preparing to walk out on the ice of Lake Baikal in Siberia to lower long strings of subatomic-particle detectors into the lake. Meanwhile, American scientists in Hawaii are preparing a similar experiment to be conducted thousands of feet beneath the sea.

title: Quakes in Madagascar
description: Two earth tremors hit Madagascar Monday and today, but there were no reports of casualties or on the extent of damage. The tremors were felt in the capital but their center was about 155 miles away, the observatory on this Indian Ocean island said.

title: REAGAN'S TIMING AND REASONS: PROTECTING CORPS
description: President Reagan has, in effect, removed the issue of individual accountability from the Defense Department's review of the terrorist attack that killed 241 American servicemen in Beirut. Mr. Reagan announced today that military commanders should not be punished for security failures in Lebanon that left the marines vulnerable to the truck bombing on Oct. 23. The President acted before the Defense Department's review was completed and before publication of a Pentagon report on the bombing, senior officials said, to head off disciplinary actions the services were considering and to reduce the negative impact the report might have on the marines and on American policy in Lebanon.

title: Bridge: Familiarity With a Problem Does Not Mean It's Simple
description: The weak two-bid has been around for 50 years and has been standard in tournament play for 30. The experts are entirely accustomed to bidding against it, but this does not by any means mean that they always solve the problems created by it.

title: Heroin Is Seized at Airport
description: Customs officers seized 11 pounds of heroin concealed in false-bottom suitcases at Kennedy International Airport over the holiday weekend and arrested two men from Pakistan, the authorities said yesterday. Marza Beg, 44 years old, a freight forwarder from Lahore, was arrested Christmas Day, and Ali Miin, 28, an ice cream salesman from Karachi, was arrested Friday. The authorities said that Mr. Beg had five pounds of the drug, valued at $5 million, in his possession and that Mr. Miin was carrying six pounds of heroin.

title: FRIENDS AND RELATIVES HONOR MIRO AT A SERVICE ON MAJORCA
description: Hundreds of friends and relatives of Joan Miro packed San Nicholas Roman Catholic Church here today for a private memorial service for the painter hailed by many critics as the greatest modern artist since Picasso.

title: CITGO HALTS BID TO CUT OIL COST
description: The Citgo Petroleum Corporation announced yesterday that it had rescinded its previously announced reduction in the price it will pay for domestic crude oil. The reversal was in part a reaction to the increase in fuel prices that has been caused by recent bitterly cold weather nationwide.

title: REQUIRED READING Race and Class
description: Remarks of the Rev. William Sloane Coffin, senior minister at Riverside Church in New York City, in a recent article in Perspectives, the quarterly publication of the United States Civil Rights Commission:

title: 3-YEAR DELAY SEEN IN CHOOSING NUCLEAR DUMP
description: The Energy Department said today that it would be at least three years late in meeting a Congressional deadline for selecting a site for the nation's first nuclear waste burial dump.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If there is to be blame, it properly rests here in this office and with this President.

title: BRITISH STEEL SEES MILL CUT, BUT UNION ASKS IMPORT CURBS
description: The decision by the United States Steel Corporation and the British Steel Corporation to end their talks on a joint venture will put the British company under renewed pressure to close one of its three strip-steel mills, officials at British Steel said tonight.

title: WINE TALK
description: Some lines in this column recently on the Loire River Valley and Sancerre evoked comments to the effect that Muscadet is really the best known of the Loire wines and thus merits more attention that it usually gets. Muscadet may not be the best wine of the Loire - it isn't the worst either - but it may well be the best value of all the wines from that beautiful part of France. It is not considered proper to make invidious comparisons but here is one anyway, turned into an aspiration: if only some American wine region could turn out a sharp, clean, fresh white wine like Muscadet and - here's the rub - for about the same price.

title: PHILADELPHIA UNDERWORLD AWAITS FELON'S RELEASE
description: A deadly four-year struggle over the spoils of drug-dealing, loan-sharking and gambling in the Philadelphia area's once peaceful underworld has claimed its 21st casualty, a killing that led to still another death, the suicide of a jeweler whose only apparent problem was kinship to felons.

title: DANCE: HOLIDAY FESTIVAL
description: THE Theater of the Open Eye is calling its third annual Holiday Dance Festival a ''Four Way Split'' because it features works by Jean Erdman, Kelly Holt, Muna Tseng and the collaborative choreographic team of Laura Glenn and Gary Lund. The festival got under way Monday night with a pleasant program of dances by Miss Erdman and Mr. Holt that included the premiere of Mr. Holt's ''In Repeating.''

title: Economic Scene; Some Clouds Beyond 1984
description: THE economic outlook for 1984 is good here at home and in the world economy generally.

title: POPE MEETS IN JAIL WITH HIS ATTACKER
description: Pope John Paul II and the gunman who gravely wounded him in 1981 sat in a prison cell for 20 minutes today, alone, in quiet conversation.

title: U.S.I.A. DIRECTOR ACKNOWLEDGES TAPING TELEPHONE CALLS IN SECERT
description: The following article is based on reporting by William Safire and Jane Perlez and was written by Miss Perlez.

title: Bond Traders Sentenced By The Associated Press
description: The former head of government securities trading at Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis Inc. and a former vice president of a smaller investment firm were sentenced yesterday to prison for a $700,000 fraud scheme.

title: SLOWLY AND HESITANTLY, INDIA ADOPTS BIRTH CONTROL
description: More often than in the past, there comes these days what one Government official calls ''a very philosophical moment'' for the couples who live in villages like this one in northern India when they decide not to have more children. The moment signifies to some who face it a radical break with centuries-old attitudes on life and birth.

title: STEEL CLOSINGS WILL MEAN GRIEF FOR MANY
description: News Analysis

title: Liberty Bowl Gaining Attention Again
description: What others refer to as a controversy is just another publicity windfall for Bud Dudley, the chairman of the Liberty Bowl committee. While some college football fans and Notre Dame alumni argue that the Fighting Irish should be looking for a new football coach instead of accepting a bowl bid, Dudley, a Notre Dame alumnus, enjoys reading all about it in the nation's newspapers.

title: ELECTION PROJECTIONS: THE UNANSWERED QUESTION
description: To the Editor:

title: AUTOPSY PERFORMED ON SPOCK GRANDSON, BOSTON POLICE REPORT
description: The police said today that they were awaiting an autopsy to help determine whether the death of the 22-year-old grandson of Dr. Benjamin M. Spock, the child-rearing expert, was suicide or an accident.

title: U.S. IS INVESTIGATING EXCLUSIVITY IN TV ADS
description: The Justice Department is investigating the legality of a practice among television broadcasters of promising some advertisers that competitors' ads will not appear on the same programs.

title: Reuters Service
description: Reuters, the international news agency, is offering a new service aimed at commodity traders and officials of financial institutions. Called the Reuter Monitor Executive Home Service, it will provide such information as foreign exchange rates, gold and other metal prices and coffee, cocoa and sugar prices, plus summaries of overnight and early morning developments. Reuters said the new service was not available to individuals, but had to be arranged through employers.

title: ADMINISTRATION SCORES A QUIET COUP
description: With less controversy and more success than in the drawn-out fights over the Civil Rights Commission and the Legal Services Corporation, the Reagan Administration is quietly putting its mark on the Inter-American Foundation, a respected but little-noticed Latin American aid program designed to be nonpartisan.

title: OPPOSES PUNISHING OFFICERS
description: President Reagan said today that he accepted full blame for the lack of security measures that permitted the terrorist bombing of the Marine headquarters in Beirut. He said he does not believe any of the Marine commanders ought to be punished.

title: U.N. PITY FOR TERRORISTS
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Chairman, 66, Cuts R.J. Reynolds Role

title: 6 ARE KILLED AND 70 INJURED IN PROPANE BLASTS IN BUFFALO
description: At least 6 people were killed, 4 of them firefighters, and more than 70 civilians were injured last night when two propane gas explosions at a warehouse heavily damaged a four-block section of downtown Buffalo, fire officials said.

title: TAR HEELS ROMP
description: It was the ''city game'' when the city used to mean only New York and when the game was played more on the floor than in the stratosphere. Or when ''every shot was magic,'' as Lou Carnesecca said last night after his undefeated St. John's team had scraped by Fordham before 16,846 spectators at Madison Square Garden.

title: Interstate Bakeries Puts Consultant Into Key Job The Interstate Bakeries Corporation, the manufacturer of Dolly Madison cakes, Millbrook bread and other products, annnounced yesterday that Emory D. Ayers, a member of the board for three years and before that a management consultant to the company, will become chairman on Jan. 1.
description: Mr. Ayers, 55, is described by associates as both deliberate and action-oriented. He is one of two managing directors at the management consulting firm of Ayers, Whitmore, which is a division of Main Hurdman, the nation's ninth-largest accounting firm.

title: NETS LOSE TO BULLETS, 116-106
description: Losing, something the Nets have been doing a lot of lately, can drive a coach to desperate measures. Stan Albeck of the Nets promised before the game tonight against the Washington Bullets that Micheal (not Michael) Ray Richardson, his newest guard, would play. But what he did not say was that Richardson's playing time would come at a critical point.

title: Theft Charged to Wills
description: Maury Wills, the 51-year-old former manager of the Seattle Mariners, and before that the base-running star of the Dodgers, was arrested in a stolen car in Los Angeles yesterday morning. Seized from the car was a vial that the police said contained a small amount of cocaine.

title: HARDSHIP AND COMRADESHIP MARK AREAS DEEP IN FREEZE
description: On the impoverished Pine Ridge Indian Reservation in South Dakota, tribal volunteers delivering firewood to elderly women found them out of fuel and burning their clothing to fend off the subzero cold.

title: Suicide by Subsidy
description: Lenin is often quoted to the effect that capitalists would always be eager to sell the rope to hang themselves. There is some doubt about whether he really said it, but he might as well have. It seems an apt description of our current inclination to subsidize the construction of foreign steel mills in the midst of a chronic steel glut.

title: WESTCHESTER BUDGET WITH 9.2% TAX RISE IS VOTED BY THE BOA
description: RD

title: Murder Suspect Is Found Dead
description: A Long Island businessman, charged last month with fatally shooting his wife after kissing her goodbye, was found dead today, apparently a suicide, according to the Nassau County police.

title: Clippers End Road Drought
description: Terry Cummings and Norm Nixon scored 28 points each as

title: Robert H. McBride, 65, Was U.S. Ambassador
description: Robert H. McBride, a retired Foreign Service officer and former Ambassador, died here Monday. He was 65 years old.

title: Robert W. Hemphill Is Dead; Ex-Congressman and Judge
description: Robert W. Hemphill, formerly a Congressman and a Federal district judge, died of a heart attack Christmas night at his home, a family spokesman said Monday. He was 68 years old.

title: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 28, 1983 News Summary
description: Companies

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Beep-Beeps, but No Bumps

title: If It Please Your (Ignorant) Honor
description: Under New York's Constitution, the judges on the Court of Appeals, the state's highest court, must be lawyers. They are - and these lawyer-judges decided the other day that it's perfectly all right for a judge who's not a lawyer to send someone to prison for a year. Their Honors have matters upside down.

title: 3 Die in South African Mine
description: A rock slide killed 3 miners, left 2 missing and injured 57 others at the West Driefontein gold mine near Johannesburg today, officials said.

title: Mitsubishi Net Rises by 1.8%
description: The Mitsubishi Corporation said today that its profit for its first

title: 11 Iranians Expelled By Paris Government
description: France said today that it had ordered the expulsion of 11 Iranians in the last few days, including three diplomats and eight people working for a cultural center.

title: Finalco Inquiry
description: Finalco Group Inc., which is primarily engaged in tax-advantaged equipment-leasing transactions, said it had received a letter from the Internal Revenue Service saying the company's transactions will be reviewed with respect to I.R.S. provisions against ''abusive tax shelters.'' The company said that if the I.R.S., after its review, decides to seek an injunction against Finalco's activities, its ability to conduct business would be impaired and the likelihood of investor claims against it would be increased. Finalco was the second-biggest percentage loser on the over-the- counter market today, plunging $3.625, to $5.50 bid.

title: TROJANS ARE ON TOP AGAIN
description: When the top- ranked University of Southern California women's basketball team defeated third-ranked Georgia by 82-74 recently, Cheryl Miller scored on a layup, a follow-up and an eight-foot, turn-around bank shot.

title: THE PERSISTENT QUESTION
description: In his last news conference of 1983, President Reagan took a cautiously optimistic view - some would say an unrealistic view - of United States relations with the Soviet Union and the Middle East.

title: ; HOW TO SPEND AND KEEP $7.1 MILLION
description: To the Editor:

title: PESTICIDE CURBS ARE UP TO STATE, COURT DECLARES
description: A New York State appeals court ruled yesterday that only the state could regulate the use of pesticide and that a Long Island village had exceeded its authority in prohibiting the aerial spraying of pesticides by property owners in the village.

title: California Court Rebuffs Appeal of Quadriplegic
description: The California Supreme Court refused today to hear an emergency appeal seeking to stop a hospital from force- feeding Elizabeth Bouvia and to block it from discharging the quadriplegic, who wants to starve herself to death.

title: NAKASONE RENEWS PLEDGE TO RAISE ARMS SPENDING
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone said today that he would keep a pledge to the United States to raise Japan's military spending, but he suggested that increases might not be as high as Washington would like.

title: NEW DAMAGE FOUND FROM CAVE-IN AT COMPLEX
description: Most tenants of a Washington Heights apartment complex who were evacuated after part of a garden terrace caved into an underground garage late Monday night were permitted to return yesterday.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Abbott Laboratories said it had agreed to market exclusively Continental Healthcare Systems Inc.'s Pharmakon computerized pharmacy system to hospitals nationwide.

title: Frank Orchard, 69, Is Dead; Trombonist With Armstrong
description: Frank Orchard, a jazz trombonist who played and recorded with Louis Armstrong, Jimmy Dorsey and Jimmy McPartland, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan after a lengthy illness. He was 69 years old.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Coming In From the Cold

title: 8-Artist Show to Open At City Museum Jan. 10
description: Original prints and posters of New York City by eight noted artists will go on view Jan. 10 at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street.

title: INSENITIVE TO BLACKS' HEALTH
description: In the 1950's, much of the sociological literature on poverty attributed the economic plight of blacks and other minorities to what it said was inherent laziness and intellectual inferiority. This deflected attention from the virtually insurmountable walls of segregation that blocked social and economic mobility. Today, the same thinking attempts to explain away the discrepancies in cancer and mortality rates.

title: FINDER ISN'T KEEPER
description: An unemployed woman found $2,747 in an envelope on a downtown street, searched in vain for the owner and then gave the money to the police.

title: SCOUTING
description: Tonelli's Cure

title: IN NEW ORLEANS, GASTRONOMIC TRUTH ON THE HALF SHELL
description: NEW ORLEANS WHAT they talk about at the Acme Oyster House on Iberville Street is how many oysters Sam Adams might have shucked in the 37 years he opened them behind the black and white tile counter. Sam, a Cajun, died four years ago and Ralph Brossette Jr., his successor, estimates that in just four years he has opened 2,568,000 oysters ''or thereabouts.'' So Sam ''must have opened billions, who knows?'' says Anthony Latino, who manages the 90-year-old oyster bar.

title: Weeks's Slump Deepens
description: The numbers are going up for Steve Weeks, but not his stock. Mounting losses and a ballooning goals-against average do not provide an admirable index for a goalie.

title: WAGNER QUITS TO TAKE HARVARD POST
description: Mayor Koch's chief policy adviser, Deputy Mayor Robert F. Wagner Jr., said yesterday that he was leaving the administration for a fellowship at Harvard University as ''a respite and an opportunity for reflection and hopefully for some writing.''

title: 'Foreign Hand' Meddles In Inquiry, Manila Says
description: The Government said today that a ''foreign hand'' was interfering in its inquiry into the killing of Benigno S. Aquino Jr., President Ferdinand E. Marcos's chief political rival.

title: HARVEY S. SIEGEL
description: Harvey S. Siegel, safety director of The New York Times, died of a heart attack Monday at his home in East Brunswick, N.J. He was 61 years old.

title: Steel Output Down by 6.8%
description: Steel production fell to 1.6

title: G.M. - TOYOTA STEP TOWARD MONOPOLY uf912
description: To the Editor:

title: DALLAS RESPONDS TO LOSS WITH ANGUISH
description: J. C. Kelly was in the stands at the Cotton Bowl when the Dallas Cowboys made their National Football League debut, a 35-28 loss to Pittsburgh in 1960. He has followed the team ever since, but he can't remember a feeling quite like the one he has now.

title: DAVIS CUP TO AUSTRALIA
description: Pat Cash clinched the Davis Cup for Australia today with a 6-4, 6-1, 6-1 victory over Sweden's Joakim Nystrom in their singles match.

title: 2 Records Broken At Track Meet
description: Bruce Ward of New Rochelle High School and Tony Sampson of Overbrook in Philadelphia posted meet records today in the Christmas City Relays at Lehigh University's Rauch Fieldhouse. The track and field program featured high schools with student enrollments of more than 750.

title: Queens, St. John's Win
description: Anne Leo, recovering from torn ankle ligaments, hit on a jumper with 29 seconds left as Queens College rallied from a 33-27 halftime deficit to defeat Bucknell, 61-60, last night in the Queens College Holiday Tournament at FitzGerald Memorial Gymnasium in Flushing.

title: PARTIES AND PRESENTS FORGONE TO CONTRIBUTE TO THE NEEDIES
description: With gifts both large and small, people are sending donations to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund instead of spending money on such holiday traditions as office parties, greeting cards and personal gift-giving.

title: Damage in Oil Blaze Stands at $10 Million
description: A Texas concern that specializes in fighting oil fires entered the battle today against a three-day-old oil tank blaze that has caused more than $10 million in damage, officials said.

title: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan Upward Trend For Trucking
description: T HE intensely competitive climate ushered in

title: KNICKS BEATEN BY BULLS
description: Coach Kevin Loughery's commitment to the rookie starting backcourt of Ennis Whatley and Mitchell Wiggins, an unpopular decision with the Chicago Bulls' fans, got another boost tonight.

title: Buying Is Faulted By Miss Bellamy By The Associated Press
description: The Transit Authority has wasted $2 million by not trying to find more suppliers of spare parts for subway cars, Carol Bellamy, the City Council President, charged yesterday.

title: SOUTH AFRICA MOVING TO WIDEN CONSCRIPTION
description: Young white immigrants and other foreigners who live here would be required to serve in the country's armed forces or lose the right to work here under a new bill proposed by the Government last week.

title: THOUSANDS OF YOUTHS JAILED WITH ADULTS EACH YEAR DESPITE REFORM EFFORTS
description: In communities throughout the country, tens of thousands of juveniles are locked up each year in adult jails in spite of a Federal law that discourages this and a Federal court ruling that has found such incarceration unconstitutional.

title: Stasys Lozoraitis, 85; Prewar Lithuania Aide
description: Stasys Lozoraitis, a Foreign Minister of independent Lithuania between the two World Wars, died Saturday at his home in Rome. He was 85 years old.

title: Extension Given In Murder Appeal
description: A white man who was convicted of slaying three Buffalo area black men in 1980, has won a fourth extension for filing an appeal, officials said today.

title: SCHOLARS TO EXAMINE MELVILLE TREASURE
description: TWO HUNDRED scholars will begin today to examine a trove of new Herman Melville letters, fragments of short stories and chapters of the first draft of a novel that were found in two old leather trunks and a wooden chest in an upstate New York barn early this year. The papers, acquired last summer by the New York Public Library for an undisclosed sum, are regarded by experts as one of the most important literary discoveries of the last 25 years.

title: Layoffs Predicted At Warner Amex The loss-plagued Warner Amex Cable Communications Inc. is expected to lay off as many as a quarter of its 4,000 employees soon, according to industry sources. Lynne D. Abraham, a Warner Amex vice president, declined to confirm or deny the reports but said: ''We're looking toward 1984 and assessing our needs while we change from a construction to an operational phase. We are reevaluating our staffing needs. The bottom line is customer service.''
description: Earlier this year, Warner Amex, a joint venture of Warner Communications Inc. and the American Express Company, laid off almost 500 workers. Although analysts say the company's long-term prospects are favorable, it has been losing money, largely because of the high costs and relatively low income from conducting many of its cable television operations in large urban areas.

title: THE REGION;
description: Driver on Tracks Killed by Train

title: CENTER STUDYING DIET'S LINKS TO AGING
description: At a combination hotel and laboratory in downtown Boston, guests are cloistered for months while scientists feed them with painstaking care.

title: Merrill Lynch, Dean Witter Settle Merrill Lynch & Company and Dean Witter Reynolds said they had settled their legal battle over central assets accounts. The securities firms said that Dean Witter had paid Merrill Lynch $1 million, while Merrill Lynch had released Dean Witter from all claims related to patents on such accounts owned by Merrill Lynch.
description: Central assets accounts combine a traditional brokerage margin account with check-writing and charge- card privileges tied to a money market fund.

title: Six Hurt in Spanish Clashes Of Police and Steelworkers
description: The police battled hundreds of steelworkers and their families today during a strike against the partial shutdown of a steel plant, leaving six people, including three policemen, injured.

title: Studley Joins Dolphins
description: As expected, the Miami Dolphins chose Chuck Studley as their new defensive coordinator to replace Bill Arnsparger, who recently agreed to become head coach at Louisiana State. Studley helped to mold the defense of the San Francisco 49ers, which figured in the team's Super Bowl march two years ago, then became defensive coordinator for the Houston Oilers, who appointed him head coach on an interim basis this year when Ed Biles resigned at midseason.

title: A Freight Train Is Dynamited By Guerrillas in El Salvador
description: A group of leftist guerrillas dynamited a freight train and other insurgents battled soldiers conducting an antiguerrilla sweep in the northeastern region of El Salvador, Government officials said today.

title: 18 NOW IN CUSTODY
description: Seven more people have been arrested in connection with bombings that killed four people at the United States Embassy and elsewhere in Kuwait on Dec. 12, increasing the number of suspects to 18, the Government said today. A 19th suspect died in one of the bombings.

title: Future Uncertain For Castle Bid An investor group headed by Castle & Cooke Inc. appeared yesterday to be close to abandoning its bid to buy the Dr Pepper Company. But sources close to Castle & Cooke denied this, saying the group was ''simply applying pressure'' on directors of the Dallas-based soft-drink company to give its offer more consideration.
description: Ian R. Wilson, president of Castle & Cooke, a food-products concern based in Honolulu, told Dr Pepper in a letter dated Dec. 23 that because of ''extraordinary opposition,'' its interest in the company had ''just about run its course.'' He asked the company, nevertheless, to ''review the entire situation one more time.''

title: JACKSON WINS ATTENTION BUT STRENGTH IS UNCLEAR
description: Whether he is jousting with the entire Democratic Party over the fairness of its delegate selection rules, haranguing big unions or waging oratorical war on his seven opponents for the Presidential nomination, the Rev. Jesse Jackson has succeeded in focusing attention on himself and on his issues.

title: Pennzoil Seeks 20% Of Getty Restructuring' Is Intention of $1.6 Billion Bid
description: The Pennzoil Company, jumping into a family feud that has shaken the Getty Oil Company, last night offered to buy 16 million shares of the West Coast oil producer for $100 each. The $1.6 billion acquisition would give Pennzoil 20 percent of Getty.

title: CHRISTIAN BOOKS SALES ARE BOOMING
description: Volumes known in the trade as Christian books, once relegated to Bible bookstores in out-of-the-way places, are becoming a booming business as the religious-book industry undergoes a transformation.

title: AN INTERVIEW WITH THE REV. JESSE JACKSON, CIVIL RIGHTS LEADER
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with the Rev. Jesse Jackson by Ronald Smothers:

title: PUERTO RICANS HAVE HIGH ASTHMA RATE, A STUDY CONCLUDES
description: A study has concluded that Puerto Ricans suffer from asthma at least twice as frequently as members of other ethnic groups in the northeastern United States.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: -piece landmark home in the Urban Center at 457 Madison Avenue, at 51st Street, the Municipal Art Society gives New Yorkers insights on what is going on in the city's perpetual face-lifting and on who are its beauticians.

title: ON THE DEFICIT, 'A WORLD TURNED UPSIDE DOWN'
description: Representative Robert H. Michel, the Republican leader, recently sent a private memo to all House Republicans. In it, he chronicled how Democrats had voted ''time and time again'' in the last session of Congress to increase Government spending and add to the budget deficit.

title: MAUREEN P. F. ENRIGHT
description: Maureen Patricia Ford Enright, editor and publisher of Irish World, the oldest Irish-American weekly newspaper in the United States, died Monday at her home in Queens.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: The Christmas card You received today, I want you to know I mailed last May.LOUIS PHILLIPS

title: JUAN ROURA-PARELLA
description: Juan Roura-Parella, professor emeritus of Romance languages and humanities at Wesleyan University, died Monday at Middlesex Memorial Hospital in Middletown, Conn.

title: 3 Are Charged in Murder On Interstate Highway
description: Three men were charged with murder and armed robbery today after two carloads of travelers were attacked on an interstate highway, the police said.

title: Commercial Paper Rates Decline Interest rates declined at the regular weekly auctions of commercial paper conducted by Citicorp and Shearson/American Express. Commercial paper is short-term unsecured debt due in less than 270 days sold by major companies.
description: At Citicorp, the average rate for $100 million of 91-day paper fell to 9.69 percent from 9.869 percent a week ago. The bank holding company also sold $50 million of 182-day paper at an average rate of 9.568 percent, down from 9.791 percent a week ago.

title: Morrow Has Surgery
description: Ken Morrow, the Islander defenseman, underwent arthroscopic surgery yesterday to remove cartilage from his troublesome right knee, on which a similar operation was performed last May.

title: REPORT FINDS AN IMBALANCE IN DISTRIBUTION OF PHYSICIANS
description: New York City, particularly Manhattan, has more physicians than it needs, but many upstate areas do not have enough and some have critical shortages, according to a report commissioned by the State Board of Regents.

title: GENERALS GIVE SIPE MULTIYEAR CONTRACT
description: The Generals officially announced today the signing of Brian Sipe, who confirmed that he had concluded an agreement with Donald Trump, the Generals' owner, on Nov. 22, when Sipe was the quarterback for the Cleveland Browns.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF PRESIDENT'S NEWS CONFERENCE ON ATTACK ON MARINE BARRACKS;
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news conference today on the Long commission's report on the attack that killed 241 marines in Lebanon, as recorded by the White House: OPENING STATEMENT

title: A.T.& T. SIGNS PACT ON BILLINGS
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said today that it was close to agreements with all seven regional holding companies that would retain the companies as billing and collection agents on long-distance calls after the Jan. 1 breakup of the Bell System. The first such contract for billing services was signed today.

title: SAVING FLORIDA'S ORANGE CROP
description: For Florida orange growers, who produce more than 75 percent of the nation's orange crop each year, the vicious cold that swept their groves this weekend could not have come at a worse time.

title: Peru to Try Nine In Death of U.S. Nun
description: The Government has ordered seven police officers, the national prison director and the inspector general of prisons to stand trial for negligent homicide in the shooting death of an American nun who was held hostage during an attempted prison escape.

title: Transactions
description: COLLEGES

title: FIREFIGHTER CASE IS LAW LESSON, TOO
description: Two women who were dismissed as firefighters last September were sworn back into New York City service yesterday.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Metropolitan Report yesterday about Staten Island incorrectly described the status of a lawsuit challenging the selection process for New York City's Board of Estimate. The case is before Federal District Judge Edward R. Neaher, who has been ordered by the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit to determine whether board's makeup violates the principle of one man, one vote.

title: U.S.-Arafat Talks Urged
description: Osama Baz, a foreign affairs adviser to President Hosni Mubarak, said today that the United States should open talks with Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader. ''Arafat is a responsible leader of the Palestinian people and has established himself as a voice of reason and moderation within the Palestinian movement,'' Mr. Baz said. He spoke with reporters after President Mubarak met two hours with his advisers to assess the meeting last Thursday between Mr. Mubarak and Mr. Arafat.

title: Senator Stennis Falls Ill
description: John C. Stennis, the Missippi Democrat who is the oldest member of the Senate, was responding well today to treatment for pneumonia, hospital officials said. Mr. Stennis, 82 years old, was visiting his daughter and son-in- law here when he was hospitalized Monday. He had cardiovascular surgery in Houston this month.

title: U.S. ACCUSES MASSACHUSETTS OF BIAS OVER RETIREMENT AGE
description: The Federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission today filed an age-discrimination lawsuit against Massachusetts in an attempt to overturn a law requiring state police officers to retire at the age of 50.

title: Coast Woman Rescued 48 Hours After Wreck
description: A young woman who lost control of her car on a mountain highway and plunged 225 feet into a ravine on Christmas Eve was discovered 48 hours later and rescued, the authorities said late Monday.

title: BEIRUT SHELLING PUTS MARINES ON ALERT
description: United States marines guarding the Beirut airport went onto their highest form of alert today after artillery shells landed nearby.

title: Dow Climbs by 13.21; Trading Pace Is Slow
description: Stock prices advanced strongly yesterday in continued slow trading, buoyed by growing confidence over the outlook for interest rates.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: Afghanistan Lists Terms For Soviet Troop Pullout

title: HOME VACUUM PACKING
description: AIR is the greatest enemy of stored foods, whether they are in the cupboard, a refrigerator or a freezer. The best way to extend the shelf life of all types of foods - dry goods, fresh vegetables, leftovers, herbs and so on - is to seal them in a vacuum package.

title: WESTMORELAND, CBS TRADE CHARGES
description: Gen. William C. Westmoreland has made public a series of documents involving his $120 million libel suit against CBS, including a network memorandum in which a CBS producer wrote to Mike Wallace, the network correspondent, shortly before Mr. Wallace interviewed the general: ''Now all you have to do is break General Westmoreland and we have this whole thing aced.''

title: SCOUTING
description: Bowl Memoir

title: AFTER THE COLD, CITY GETS BACK TO NORMAL PACE
description: The New York metropolitan region came out of the deep freeze yesterday and rapidly regained its customary, businesslike stride after the long Christmas holiday. But with the warming weather came warnings of another drenching and flooded, rather then icy, roadways.

title: GREECE IS SUPPORTIVE OF PRIVATE INDUSTRY
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOLISH POLICY TOWARD ZIMBABWE
description: The Administration has demonstrated once again how tough America can be: It has cut fiscal 1984 aid to Zimbabwe almost in half, to $40 million, primarily to punish its Government for its voting record in the United Nations. This foolish, shortsighted decision violates America's commitments and forsakes a friendly Government that has the support of most of its own people.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: One of the most interesting of the additions to the greengrocers' shelves has come on the market quite unheralded: sweet yellow peppers. They seem, to my taste at least, to be meatier and perhaps a bit spicier than their green or red counterparts. And they have the same uses, by and large, as the green and the red.

title: A 2d Chance to Rebuild For President of HRT Edward Solomon, the chairman and president of HRT Industries, took over the top management of the discount retailing and shoe company nine years ago when it seemed in danger of failing. A few years later, things were looking up and the company was profitable. But then, after losing $38.5 million in 1982, the California- based company filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankrupcy Code
description: Mr. Solomon accepts responsibility for leading the company to the brink of disaster, but now may have the opportunity to lead it back to health again.

title: TV: PERSHING II AND WEST GERMANY
description: IN its title, ''Beyond the Missile

title: BLUES BEAT DEVILS IN OVERTIME
description: For the second game in a row at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, the Devils relinquished a two-goal advantage in the last period and lost in overtime.

title: Adja Yunkers, Artist; Explored Uses of Color
description: Adja Yunkers, a Latvian-born American artist known for his abstract paintings, prints and pastels, died of Saturday at the New York Infirmary- Beekman Downtown Hospital. He was 83 years old.

title: FAMILY TAX CREDITS WITHOUT ADDED COST
description: To the Editor:

title: RUSSIANS SKILLFULLY EXPAND INFLUENCE AT U.N.
description: A common sight in the corridors and lounges here is of an impeccably dressed Communist diplomat speaking perfect English who moves from group to group, clasping hands, smiling, joking and shaking his head in what appears to be good-humored despair about the latest foreign policy pronouncement of the United States.

title: ADM. EDWIN S. SCHANZE, 79
description: Rear Adm. Edwin Stansbury Schanze, who served aboard the battleship Washington during World War II and survived 53 kamikaze attacks, died at New York Hospital last Sunday after an illness of several months.

title: CENVILL DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
150 Million Said to Face Famine in Africa in '84
description: Nearly 150 million Africans could face famine in 1984 because of drought and other catastrophes, the head of the United Nations' Economic Commission for Africa said today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Academicians Gather To Talk and Listen

title: Martin Marietta
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation received a $64.9 million Air Force contract for development of night system support equipment, the Defense Department said. It said the company also received $8.4 million from the Air Force for production of communications equipment. The department said the Navy had given contracts totaling $67.6 million to the General Dynamics Corporation for design work on a British submarine to carry the Trident missile and for cruise missile guidance sets.

title: NEW CHAIRMAN ELECTED AT AMERICAN SYMPHONY
description: Gilbert E. Kaplan, the publisher and editor of Institutional Investor magazine and an amateur conductor, has been elected chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the American Symphony Orchestra - one of several moves apparently intended to invigorate and expand the activities of what is considered the second major resident orchestra of Manhattan.

title: A THINK TANK WRONGLY TIED TO LATIN 'ULTRAS'
description: To the Editor:

title: PRETTY TEETH, DEAR
description: When Rupert Murdoch made his winning bid for The Chicago Sun-Times last November, he said he planned no ''substantial changes'' in the paper. ''We believe The Sun-Times is one of the finest newspapers in the United States,'' he told a meeting in the newsroom, ''and we plan to make it even better.''

title: Construction Contracts Up By The Associated Press
description: The value of contracts for new construction in November rose 4 percent from October, and contracts for the first 11 months of the year were higher than in any previous full year, a business information service said yesterday.

title: THE END OF ONE-STOP SHOPPING FOR TELEPHONES AND SERVICES Making Some Sense of the Divestiture
description: Q. Much of the discussion of the

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Above Politics, Love

title: CONCORD FABRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
COMMERCIAL 'FISHPORT' IN BROOKLYN: A DEVELOPMENT PLAN BY PORT AUTHORITY
description: News Analysis

title: Sandinista Foes Trying To Set Up Government
description: An anti-Sandinista rebel group financed by the United States announced today that it had reorganized its command structure with a view to establishing a provisional government in Nicaragua.

title: Transcon Inc.'s New Chairman
description: Burke G. Piper has been elected chairman of Transcon Inc., a motor freight common carrier.

title: Jodie Foster Charged In Cocaine Case
description: The actress Jodie Foster was charged by the state police today with possessing a small amount of cocaine at Logan International Airport last week, a spokesman for the District Attorney said.

title: ON-LINE SOFTWARE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The year-earlier periods were restated for acquisition recorded as a pooling of interests. The year-ago 6 months net includes a non-operating gain of $201,000.

title: Eurobonds Show Little Change LONDON, Dec. 28 (Reuters) - The Eurobond market showed little change from firmer levels this morning, with trading very quiet ahead of the year-end, dealers said.
description: Fixed-interest dollar bonds were initially marked as much as 1/4 point higher on the back of the firmer trend on United States credit markets overnight.

title: The President and the Marines
description: Admiral Long's commission of inquiry into the vulnerability of the Marine force in Beirut distributes blame to many levels of command. Its most disturbing indictment, however, concerns not security measures or rules of engagement but this use of the Marines as an instrument of diplomacy.

title: ANDROPOV ASSAILS ECONOMIC FAILINGS OF SOVIET SYSTEM
description: In unusually strong language, Yuri V. Andropov has chastised his countrymen for creating economic bottlenecks, making extensive planning errors and failing to meet such longstanding targets as increased output of consumer goods.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A dispatch from Washington by The Associated Press yesterday about the Energy Department's delay on a burial site for nuclear waste incorrectly listed the states under consideration. They are Mississippi, Nevada, Louisiana, Washington, Utah and Texas.

title: Trunkline Lowers Natural Gas Price WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) - The Trunkline Gas Company, a natural gas pipeline company supplying parts of 11 states in the Midwest, received Federal approval to cut its wholesale gas prices by 19 percent, effective Sunday. The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission unanimously approved a request by the company, a unit of the Panhandle Eastern Corporation of Houston, to reduce its wholesale price.
description: The reduction reflects a decision by Panhandle to suspend its purchase of high-priced liquified natural gas from Algeria after company officials said Trunkline faced a ''dramatic drop in sales volume'' because of its high prices.

title: ADVERTISING ; Cabbage Patch Honors For a Coleco Executive
description: Alfred R. Kahn, the man at Coleco Industries who is credited with foisting the Cabbage Patch Kids hysteria on an unsuspecting nation, is being specially honored by his bosses.

title: OUTDOORSNelson Bryant; Some Remote Sites For Trout Fishing
description: If you emerged from Christmas with

title: Spurs' Coach Is Dismissed
description: The San Antonio

title: 'As Brothers'
description: It is said that people can get used to anything, so it's likely Americans will soon take for granted the fact that their country often chooses to put its malefactors to death. Their families will mourn; so, too, will those who always wait with candles outside the prison walls. But eventually executions, as they become more and more frequent, may not even make the evening news. It's not only a person who dies when the switch is pulled or the needle inserted in the vein. So does human sensibility.

title: WHY BATTERED WIVES DON'T LEAVE HOME
description: To the Editor:

Kathryn M. Bricker Weds John P. Jenks, a Lieutenant
description: Kathryn Mary Bricker, daughter of Frederick J. Bricker and Anne Tracy Bricker, both of New York, was married yesterday to Second Lieut.

title: PENNZOIL SETS TALKS ON GETTY
description: J. Hugh Liedtke, chairman of the Pennzoil Company, said yesterday that Gordon P. Getty, head of a trust that controls 40 percent of the Getty Oil Company's stock, had agreed to meet with him soon to discuss a ''restructuring'' of Getty Oil.

title: ISLANDERS DEFEAT KINGS IN OVERTIME
description: Stefan Persson scored with only six seconds remaining in overtime tonight to give the Islanders a 6-5 victory over the Los Angeles Kings.

title: Japan Raises Loan Limits TOKYO, Dec. 28 (AP) - The Bank of Japan has raised the domestic lending ceilings for Japanese banks for the first quarter of 1984, a central bank official said today.
description: The increases continue the central bank's easy money policies, aimed at keeping funds available to finance Japan's budding recovery.

title: BRIEFING
description: Reagan Impeachment Drive

title: Cromartie Joins Tokyo
description: Saying he was fed up with

title: A 6-TON JAGUAR AND OTHER LEGALITIES
description: ''It took at least two days of sweet-talking the Pentagon to get this fellow here,'' said Elizabeth Croog, patting the rump of a ferocious-looking stone jaguar, one of the monumental pieces that make up the National Gallery's exhibiton of the art of Aztec Mexico.

title: West German Plant Output FRANKFURT, Dec. 28 (AP) - West Germany's machinery and plant-engineering industry anticipates a rise of about 3 percent in production next year after a 3 percent decline this year, an industry trade group said today.
description: The group said, however, that builders of turbines and heavy diesel engines for ships remained pessimistic about their prospects.

title: BLACK-OWNED HOTEL JOINS COMPETITION FOR BUSINESS IN DOWNTOWN MEMPHIS
description: This Mississippi River city's efforts to revive its downtown as a middle-sized tourist attraction recently gained a new partner.

title: HOME BEAT
description: HE client was Computer Doctor, a company that is in the business of repairing micro- and minicomputers. According to Harvey Bernstein, a principal of Penney & Bernstein, the design firm that was asked to put together a 600- square-foot prototype Computer Doctor store, the goal was ''to create a clean high-tech image that instilled confidence.''

title: Betsy T. Wainwright Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Betsy Trippe Wainwright of New York and Old Black Point, Conn., to Robert P. DeVecchi of New York took place yesterday in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in Manhattan. The Very Rev. Sturgis L. Riddle, retired dean of the American Cathedral in Paris, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Carol Anderson.

title: White House Contends Carter Crippled C.I.A.
description: A White House spokesman said today that intelligenece failures in connection with the Beirut bombing could be attributed to decisions taken by the Carter Administration.

title: LICENSE SUSPENDED
description: The State Health Commisssioner suspended the license of a Manhattan physician for 60 days yesterday on the grounds that the doctor had fraudulently promised to cure cancer and that his medically unapproved treatments posed an immediate danger to his patients.

title: FERNS ADAPT TO THE CITY
description: IF a prize were awarded for the

title: SCOUTING
description: Positive Thinker

title: ART'S WAY MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
Bethea Jumps
description: The United States Football League raided the N.F.L. for another veteran when Larry Bethea , the reserve defensive end of the Dallas Cowboys, announced that he was signing with the Michigan Panthers. Bethea was a first-round draft choice of Dallas in 1978, but in his six seasons there he was rarely used for anything other than backing up Harvey Martin and Ed (Too Tall) Jones . ''I have no bitterness,'' he said, ''but they didn't play me.''

title: ORNATE TRAMP ART INTRIGUES COLLECTORS
description: They drive hours to attend a flea market. They scour obscure antiques shops and never snub a tag sale. Yet these collectors are not simply looking for another bargain or an interesting antique. They're devotees of tramp art - an American folk art dating from around the turn of the century that few people know about and others dismiss as downright ugly.

title: SCOUTING
description: Arias on Mend

title: KNOWN FOR ROLES IN COMEDIES
description: William Demarest, who played dozens of gruff, golden-hearted curmudgeons in films and on television, died at his home in Palm Springs, Calif., yesterday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 91 years old.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The commander can delegate some or all of his authority to his subordinates, but he cannot delegate his responsibility for the performance of any of the forces he commands.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A dispatch from Chicago Sunday about the sale of The Sun-Times misstated that newspaper's circulation. Weekday circulation is 639,134; Sunday's is 669,426. The article also misidentified the business entity sold by Marshall and Frederick Field. It is in fact The Sun-Times.

title: BELL ATLANTIC PHONE SALE TO U.S. BARRED BY JUDGE
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation cannot sell 200,000 telephones to the Government against the wishes of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, a Federal judge ruled today.

title: GOULD INVESTORS TRUST reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of $210,035 from the disposition of rental properties and mortgages, an extraordinary credit of $386,826 and a provision for losses of $736,780 primarily due to the restructuring plan of BRT Realty Trust, a subsidiary. c-Including a gain of $469,537 from the disposition of rental properties and mortgages.

description: To the Editor:

description: New Ram Reaps Playoff Benefits

description: To the Editor:

title: Bengals Hire Wyche
description: Sam Wyche, the Indiana University football coach and a former quarterback for the Cincinnati Bengals, was hired yesterday as head coach of the Bengals.

title: British Monks in Protest
description: The police arrested three monks today after they broke into a United States nuclear bomber base in southern England and chained themselves to a cross on the main runway. The Dominican monks, released from their chains by policemen using bolt-cutters, were among 32 antinuclear protesters held after breaching the fence round the Upper Heyford base, west of London.

title: ; UNWARRANTED AID FOR LOCAL PHONE SERVICE
description: To the Editor:

title: LINEAR INSTRUMENTS CORP reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
LEGISLATORS SAY CUOMO BROKE JOBS PACT
description: Some state legislators are charging that Governor Cuomo has broken both the letter and the spirit of agreements made when the current state budget was adopted last April, forcing unexpectedly sharp personnel reductions in several agencies.

title: STAGE: SAROYAN SET TO MUSIC
description: In ''Hair,'' his first musical at the Public Theater, Galt MacDermot wrote about a hemorrhaging America, torn apart by its most unpopular war. It's a jolt to return to the Public 16 years later and discover that the same composer has now fashioned a musical from ''The Human Comedy,'' William Saroyan's idyllic fable of a united America fighting World War II. But once the shock wears off, we find a lovely show that is far closer to ''Hair'' than one might expect.

title: TO HALT AFGHAN WAR
description: Four years after the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan, it is time for the United States to play a more defined role in halting that devastating war.

title: SCOUTING
description: Gossage Race

title: 2 U.S. UNITS POSSIBLE FOR TOYOTA
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation, which won tentative approval last week for a joint auto making venture with the General Motors Corporation, could open a second assembly line here under an agreement between the two companies, spokesmen for Toyota and the Federal Trade Commission said today. Such a move would strengthen the Japanese auto maker's American foothold.

title: Mary Vaux Weds Peter W.Acheson
description: Mary James Vaux, daughter of George Vaux of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and the late Mrs. Vaux, was married yesterday to Peter Wesley Acheson, son of Mr. and Mrs. David C. Acheson of Washington. The Rev. Timothy Pickering performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Bryn Mawr.

title: Businessman and Ex-Official Sentenced and Fined in Seoul
description: A business executive and a former Cabinet Minister were fined and sentenced to prison here today in a bribery case.

description: T HIS is the season when brokerage firms pick

description: Following is the section of the report on the Oct. 23 attack on the Marine barracks that describes the commission's members:

title: G.M.-TOYOTA: A GAIN
description: The Federal Trade Commission acted sensibly in approving the joint venture between General Motors and Toyota to assemble subcompact cars in an unused plant in Fremont, Calif. The commission's decision marks a departure from past antitrust policies that threatened to render American auto makers permanently uncompetitive in world markets.

title: STOCKS IN AN ELECTION YEAR
description: Wall Street's perennial election- year rally, a decidedly bullish stock market prodded by a well-stimulated economy, seems likely to offer a new twist in 1984.

title: JUDGE TELLS EASTERN AIRLINES TO REHIRE TRANSSEXUAL PILOT
description: Bv E. R. SHIPP

title: AT STAKE AT THE WORLD BANK: WHO WILL BE NO. 2?
description: Kenji Yamaguchi and Toshihiro Yamakawa, representatives to the World Bank from Tokyo, have laid it on the line at recent meetings of the bank's board: Either Japan moves up from No. 4 to No. 2 in voting strength in the 144-nation institution, or it cuts back its aid to the poorest countries.

title: Circle K-Utotem
description: The Circle K Corporation said it had completed its $225 million purchase of Utotem Inc., which owns 960 convenience stores in the West and South. Circle K acquired all of the stock of Utotem from the American Financial Corporation. With the Utotem stores, Circle K said it now had 2,180 convenience stores.

title: 2 Quit Houston Squad
description: Frustrated over a lack of playing time for Houston's highly ranked basketball team, two junior reserves, Benny Anders and Braxton Clark , have quit the squad and a third reserve, Renaldo Thomas, has threatened to quit. Anders, a forward and guard, and Clark, a forward and center, had played sparingly behind two freshmen, and so they decided to return to Houston a day before the Cougars were upset Monday night by Fresno State in the Chaminade Classic final in Honolulu. . . . Meanwhile, in Austin, Tom Nelson, a freshman walk-on for Texas, quit his squad and became the fourth Longhorn this month to do so.

title: Cable Failure Disrupts Long-Distance Calls
description: Long- distance telephone service was disrupted between the Middle West and the East Coast for about five hours today after a major cable was severed.

title: Dow Declines 0.51, to 1,263.21
description: Stock prices posted mostly minor changes yesterday in accelerated trading. The standout performer was Getty Oil, which was propelled by a bid by Pennzoil for 20 percent of the company.

title: DECONTROL'S BUS LINE IMPACT
description: When Robert Else 3d took over his father's bus company, King Coal Trailways, five years ago, it was a small line serving only Northumberland County here. It had one passenger bus, which carried a total of 5,000 people that year, and 24 school buses. Revenue came to $360,000.

title: Citrus Executive Keeps Wary Eye on Weather
description: S. Robert Davis, chairman and chief executive officer of Orange-Co. Inc. - one of Florida's biggest independent citrus growers and processors, is hoping central Florida will have two weeks of temperatures in the upper 30's or low 40's. Otherwise, his company could be badly hurt, and smaller growers could face disaster.

title: Referee Breaks Arm
description: Don't tell John Vanak that basketball is a noncontact or light-contact sport.
