description: The Stain on Georgia

title: Coast Thrift Unit Fights Takeover BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Dec. 28 (AP) - The Beverly Hills Savings and Loan Association said it had obtained a temporary restraining order preventing Paul Amir, a dissident shareholder and real estate developer, from buying more of its stock.
description: David I. McDougall, the association's corporate secretary, said that the association is trying to prevent Mr. Amir from taking over the association, which has assets of $1.6 billion.

title: Tisdale Scores Record 61
description: Wayman Tisdale, Oklahoma's

title: TechnologySteven J. Marcus Small-Copier Innovations
description: C OPYING machines have become increasingly essential to running a business, but maintenance requirements have limited the appeal of owning one. Most plain-paper copiers - descendants of the machine invented by Chester Carlson in 1938 that helped make Xerox synonymous with ''copy'' - need regular servicing and have therefore been practical mostly for offices with large staffs and budgets.

title: U.S. STEPS AGAINST THAYER ARE SEEN
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is preparing to charge Paul N. Thayer, the Deputy Secretary of Defense, with illegally passing along insider information to others in 1982, when he was chairman of the LTV Corporation and a director of several other companies, according to industry and Government officials.

title: Town Rejects Tall Buildings
description: Voters in this small suburb on the east side of San Francisco Bay have overwhelmingly rejected a city-approved development plan that would have allowed more 30-story buildings. The city clerk said the final vote Tuesday was 549 to 286 against the plan in the referendum, which drew only 835 of the town's 2,507 registered voters.

title: Molson Unit Looking For a 2d U.S. Agency
description: The Martlet Importing Company of Great Neck, L.I., a wholly owned subsidiary of Molson Breweries of Canada, confirmed yesterday that it is seeking a second agency in the United States to augment the work of Rumrill-Hoyt, a subsidiary of Compton Advertising and its agency for about 17 years.

title: HEATING OIL PRICE LIFTED BY REFINERS
description: Major oil refiners yesterday announced increases in wholesale heating oil prices ranging from one-half cent a gallon to 3.5 cents a gallon. The companies attributed the increases to recent sharp rises in heating oil prices on the spot and futures markets as bitterly cold weather has brought a surge in demand.

title: U.S. INTELLIGENCE IN THE DARK ABOUT ANDROPOV
description: Government officials said today that Western intelligence agencies were in the dark about the reasons for the absence of Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader.

title: IN THE SHOWCASE OF AFRICA, THE LIGHTS GO OUT
description: West Africa's only ice skating rink has melted.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Opening in New York

title: GOING OUT GUIDE ;
description: WELL MET The Metropolitan Opera, a hale fellow in its 100th year, has been well met by a plethora of anniversary exhibitions in some of the most noted institutions in town, the last but not the least of which is now on the third floor of the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street (534-1672).

title: INDOOR PAVILIONS: A NEW ARCHITECTURE FOR LOFTS
description: MAYBE it was because William Guenther had a special affection for Italy, or maybe it was because, as he said, ''I had lived in standard apartments all my life and didn't want anything standard anymore.'' But that is only a partial explanation for the striking miniature Mediterranean cityscape that is now the focal point of the 1,200-square-foot Manhattan loft space in which he lives with his wife, Deirdre Loew Guenther.

title: LONG-DISTANCE CARE OF ELDERLY RELATIVES A GROWING PROBLEM
description: Two months after his 71-year-old father became seriously ill in Ohio last summer, Jerry Davis regularly began making the trip from Manhattan to visit him at Mount Sinai Hospital in Cleveland. At night, the hospital revived his father's fears from the concentration camps he had survived in World War II. And so Mr. Davis would stay the long nights in his father's hospital room each time he visited.

title: UNESCO RECEIVES U.S. PULLOUT NOTICE
description: The United States formally gave notice to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization today that it plans to withdraw from the agency on Jan. 1, 1985, Unesco officials said.

title: Don't Be Shy, Ask the Kremlin
description: As if to mock Orwell's omnipresent Big Brother, the Soviet Union enters 1984 with the extended absence of its leader, Yuri Andropov. The lies about his ''cold'' have been abandoned. But a conspiracy of silence continues to conceal the ailment that made him appear deathly ill even before he ceased to appear in public altogether four months ago. Who is really in command, and is he up to it?

title: BRASS RUBBING: HISTORIC CRAFT REVIVED
description: With a stick of hard wax and a roll of rag paper, anyone can develop an unusual hobby, according to one accomplished brass rubber.

title: No Headline
description: DYR's U.S. Head

title: Angela M. Scully Is the Bride of George H. Elser
description: Angela Marie Scully, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leon F. Scully Jr. of Houston, was married yesterday to George Hardy Elser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry R. C. Elser of West Chester, Pa. The Rev. Mark Anschutz performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Alexandria, Va.

title: MCGOVERN SEEKS EFFECT ON PARTY POLICY DEBATE
description: Sitting in George McGovern's cramped, one-room campaign headquarters in Washington, George Cunningham remarked: ''This borders on fantasy. I look in the mirror and say 'George, what am I doing here?' ''

title: MOOD IS GRIM AT LADDER 5'S FIREHOUSE
description: Fireman Daniel Benning, 24 years old, walked around the firehouse this afternoon, balancing in his hand a two-foot length of metal pipe.

title: ILLEGALLY STORED PROPANE IS BLAMED FOR BLAST THAT KILLED 6 IN BUFFALO
description: The fatal explosion that devastated a 16-block area here Tuesday night was caused by propane stored illegally in a warehouse, fire officials said today.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: CHICAGO (AL) - Extended contract of Jerry Hairston, reserve outfielder, through 1986 with an option to renew in 1987. MONTREAL (NL) - Warren Cromartie, former outfielder for Expos, signed three-year contract with Yomiuri Giants in Japan.

title: FLICK TAX EXEMPTION REVOKED BY GERMANY
description: The West German Economics Ministry said today that it had revoked tax exemptions awarded to the Flick industrial group in 1976 and 1978 when it acquired its stake in W. R. Grace & Company of New York. The announcement widened the impact of a major investigation into influence peddling within the Government and the financing of political parties.

title: Thailand and Malaysia Attack Border Rebels
description: Thailand and Malaysia have begun major coordinated military assaults on Communist guerrillas based along their common border, a Thai military officer said today.

title: IRVINE SENSORS reports earnings for Year to Oct 2
description: b-After a provision of $1,475,000 for a loss stemming from a stop-work order which was previously reported in the second quarter and a gain of $133,200 on the settlement of trade accounts payable. c-There are no comparable year- ago results because the company changed its fiscal year to coincide with the U. S. Government's fiscal year.

title: U.S. and South Korea To Hold Joint Exercise
description: American troops will join South Korean units in a joint military exercise intended to symbolize President Reagan's pledge to bolster American forces in Korea, the Defense Department said today.

title: Schlichter Explains
description: In a first-person article for Playboy magazine, Art Schlichter , the Baltimore Colt quarterback who was suspended by the National Football League this season for sports wagering, said that his penchant for compulsive gambling had been brought on by the combination of an unhappy senior year at Ohio State and the pressure connected with his being considered for Heisman Trophy. ''I had to relieve the pressure, and I did it by gambling,'' said Schlichter.

title: GOOD WORDS FOR BAD SHOWS
description: Michael Frayn's ''Noises Off'' is so funny about so many aspects of the theater - read those spoof bios in the programs at the Brooks Atkinson, for instance - that it seems grudging to complain about its omissions. But what, I kept wondering, must the friends and relations of its main characters have said to them backstage after watching them bomb in the gruesome touring farce, ''Nothing On''? In fact, how does one compliment a loved one who has just given an abysmal performance?

title: ISRAELI OFFICIAL IS REPORTED TO SEEK A PARTIAL FREEZE ON SETTLEMENTS
description: The Israeli radio reported today that Finance Minister Yigal Cohen-Orgad would recommend a partial freeze on Jewish settlements in occupied Arab territories as part of his plan to cut public spending in the coming fiscal year.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: St. John's vs. North Carolina, Holiday Festival, championship game, at Madison Square Garden, 9 P.M, The Redmen, who were scared by Fordham Tuesday night in the tournament opener, face their toughest opponent of the season: a team that is ranked first nationally in the writers' poll and second to Kentucky in the coaches' poll. In the consolation game, which begins at 7 o'clock, Fordham faces Iona. (Television - MSG Cable, both games, 7 P.M., live, and 1 A.M., tape. Radio - WFUV-FM, 90.7, and WFAS-FM, 103.9, first game only, 7 P.M.; WGBB, 1240, WNYE-FM, 91.5, and WRTN-FM, 93.5, second game only, 9 P.M.)

title: A SUBTLE TALENT IS WELCOMED HOME
description: The banner appeared not far from

title: UNIVAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
KEY SECTIONS OF PENTAGON'S REPORT ON ATTACK ON THE MARINES
description: Following are the key sections of ''Report of the D.O.D. Commission on Beirut International Airport Terrorist Act, Oct. 23, 1983,'' which was dated Dec. 20 and made public today by the Pentagon:

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: VOLCKER OPTIMISTIC ABOUT U.S. GROWTH
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that the United States has ''a rare opportunity - an enormous opportunity - to set in train a strong period of growth and price stability.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Losing a Fare But Coming Out Ahead

title: CARE OF WOODEN BOXES
description: At one time small decorative wooden boxes abounded. They were made to house a wide variety of possessions or to serve a function, such as the lap desk or writing box. As a testing ground for indulging decorative veneering and joinery skills, the small box was perfect, as the surfaces provided an excellent setting for pictorial scenes in marquetry or mosaics of woods inlaid in geometric patterns, called parquetry.

title: ARKANSAS ROUTS ST. PETER'S
description: Joe Kleine scored 23 points, and Alvin Robertson 18 as Arkansas defeated St. Peter's, 82-49, tonight. It was St. Peter's first defeat of the season after eight victories.

title: BARNWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $240,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Rates Flat On C.D.'s For the second consecutive week, interest rates on money market accounts remained unchanged across the country, The Bank Rate Monitor reported yesterday. They stood at 8.49 percent nationwide and 8.77 percent in New York.
description: The Monitor's nationwide index of six-month certificates of deposit, based on a survey of 50 major institutions in the five largest United States markets, was 9.26 percent, up slightly from 9.25 percent last week. The previous week it was 9.21 percent.

title: WHITE HOUSE INQUIRING INTO TAPED TELEPHONE CALLS
description: The White House said today that it was looking into the circumstances of the secret tape- recording of office telephone calls by the director of the United States Information Agency, Charles Z. Wick.

title: COOKE MAKES CHANGES IN SUPERVISORY JUDGESHIPS
description: Seven judicial appointments, including a new administrative judge for New York City's Family Court system, a new appeals judge and a new administrative judge for State Supreme Court in the Bronx, were announced yesterday.

title: A GLOSSARY OF THE TERMS USED BY THE COMMISSION
description: Following is a glossary of military terms used in the Long commission report on the bombing at the Marine headquarters in Beirut: B.I.A. - Beirut International Airport. B.L.T. - Battalion Landing

title: THE COZY HEARTH: ENOYING IT SAFELY
description: IT'S an icy winter night, but no

title: BEACH BOYS' DENNIS WILSON, DRUMMER, DROWNS AT MARINA
description: Dennis Wilson, the drummer for the Beach Boys, whose ''surfing sound'' helped define an era in the 1960's for millions of young Americans, drowned today not far from the beaches where he became famous.

title: FOUNDATIONS GIVE TO NEEDIEST
description: Individual donations to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund range from a few dollars to the thousands, and the annual appeal also benefits from donations by foundations devoted to philanthropy.

title: Chase Planning Cable Banking
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation has taken another small

title: U.S. DECIDES TO RENEW A JAPANESE TRADE PACT
description: The Reagan Administration, in a concession to Japan, has decided to renew a telecommunications procurement agreement between the two Governments. But in return, it is insisting that the pact provide American companies greater access to Japanese research and development.

title: Professional Care By Reuters
description: Professional Care Services Inc. said its board had apporoved an agreement in principle to merge into a subsidiary of American Healthcorp for $11 a share.

title: THE WICK TAPES (I)
description: On Monday of this week, Charles Wick, director of the United States Information Agency, flatly and repeatedly denied that he had been secretly taping many of his telephone conversations.

title: RANGERS DEFEAT BLACK HAWKS, 7-4
description: The Rangers left Chicago Stadium tonight with a 7-4 victory over the Black Hawks, but not before a vicious check thrown by Chicago's Jack O'Callahan in the third period resulted in an injury to Dave Maloney and a bench- clearing brawl.

title: JIMMY DEMARET, FIRST GOLFER TO WIN 3 MASTERS, DIES AT 73
description: Jimmy Demaret, the first golfer to win the Masters tournament three times and a member of the Professional Golfers Association and World Golf halls of fame, died here today, apparently of a heart attack. He was 73 years old.

title: Suriname Reports Sabotage By Striking Bauxite Workers
description: The Government said today that striking bauxite workers had damaged transmission lines and tried to drain oil from an electric transformer.

title: NETS FALTER AT END AND LOSE TO BUCKS
description: The story about the coach who, when asked about his team's execution, said, ''I'm all for it,'' is becoming approprate for Stan Albeck of the Nets.

title: Kodak Seeks Deal With Matsushita OSAKA, Japan, Dec. 28 (Reuters) - The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company's president, Toshihiko Yamashita, said the Eastman Kodak Company had asked Matsushita to provide Kodak with its 8-millimeter video system, a small video camera and recorder, for sale in the United States under the Kodak brand name. He told a news conference that Matsushita is studying the proposal, although he did not give specific details.
description: Mr. Yamashita said Kodak officials hope to visit Japan next month to discuss the proposal. Japanese makers plan to market the 8-millimeter video system in Japan soon. The system, sometimes referred to as the new generation of videotape recorders, uses 8-millimeter tapes, instead of the 12-millimeter tapes now used to record pictures.

title: RAGEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The share earnings are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid Sept. 30, 1983.

title: U.S. MAY CURB INCREASES FOR SOME FEDERAL RETIREES
description: The Reagan Administration is preparing a budget proposal that would substantially reduce the automatic cost-of-living increase allowed to retired Federal workers who receive Government pensions exceeding a certain amount, such as $10,000 a year.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: PUTTING up a new wall covering often requires removing the old one first. While some wallpapers can build up to two or three layers, many of today's vinyl wall coverings require removal of each layer before a fresh one goes on.

title: GUARDIAN-MORTON SHULMAN reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-There are no comparable year- ago results because the company only went public in October.

title: PAPERBACK PUBLISHERS SURVIVAL VERSUS TASTE
description: The day of the big-money book auction is largely a thing of the past, according to paperback publishers. They also think the recent high rate of attrition among paperback publishers has strengthened the industry by restoring a much-needed sense of fiscal realism.

title: Cranston Out of Hospital
description: Senator Alan Cranston of California was released today from the Bethesda Naval Hospital after diagnostic surgery on his right lung and will resume his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination next week, a spokesman said. Comdr. D.M. Billig, chief of the hospital's department of cardiothoracic surgery, said of the 69- year-old Senator: ''After thorough physical and laboratory evaluation, we cannot find anything wrong with him.''

title: CLARK TO RESUME PURCHASE OF LAND FOR NATIONAL USE
description: William P. Clark, the new Interior Secretary, is ending the Reagan Administration's moratorium on the acquisition of land for national parks and is making other major policy and personnel changes in his department.

title: AERO SERVICES INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ON WOMEN AND COMPUTERS
description: The cartoon, which appeared in The New Yorker, shows a young man standing between a woman and a microcomputer. His left arm encircles the woman's shoulder; his right is draped with equal affection over the computer. He is addressing a male guest. The caption reads: ''Arthur, this is my wife, Sally. And this is my personal computer.''

title: OMEGA 7 LEADER ACCUSED OF PLOT TO KILL DELEGATE
description: Eduardo Arocena, described as the head of a terrorist group of Cuban exiles called Omega 7, was formally charged yesterday with attempted murder and several bombings in Manhattan and Miami.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Calvin Klein, the fashion designer, and his associate, Barry Schwartz, said they had received 2,663,933 shares of Puritan Fashions Corp. in response to their tender offer for all shares at $17.50 a share; they said they now own about 77 percent of Puritan.

title: ADMIRAL WHO ASKED THE QUESTIONS
description: Prairie sunsets and cornfields beckoned when Robert L. J. Long was growing up in Kansas City, Mo., but he went to sea instead. The same independence that carried him from the landlocked Midwest to the Naval Academy 43 years ago, according to colleagues, characterized the investigation that Admiral Long, now retired, directed into the bombing of the Marine barracks in Lebanon.

title: COMMISSION'S AUTHORITY TO INVESTIGATE
description: Following is the section of the report on the Oct. 23 attack on the Marine barracks that describes the commission's authority to investigate:

title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES
description: An Old Rivalry Is Renewed They've been the Los Angeles

title: SOUTH AFRICA SAYS ANGOLAN FORCES ARE FIGHTING AGAINST ITS SOLDIERS
description: South African soldiers are battling Angolan troops as well as Namibian nationalist guerrillas in the latest South African strike into southern Angola, both sides say.

title: JERSEY CASINO TO PAY FOR STATE'S SHARE OF RAIL LINK
description: After almost a year of negotiations with the state, a casino operator has agreed to pay New Jersey's full share of a Federal-state project to provide passenger rail service between Philadelphia and Atlantic City.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: SURINAME'S NEW PRESS: UNESCO'S DISCIPLE
description: Suriname, a former Dutch colony on the northeast shoulder of South America, once had a thriving independent press. But it was crushed when troops under Lieut. Col. Desi Bouterse, who seized power in a 1980 coup, shot to death four journalists last December and burned two radio stations and a newspaper to the ground.

title: William J. Kaland, 68, Is Dead; Ex-Producer of Radio and TV
description: William J. Kaland, a former producer of public affairs programs for radio and television, died Sunday at his home in New York City. He was 68 years old.

title: Argo Communications Has a Chief Executive
description: Thomas A. Owens Jr., an executive with top management experience in several leading telecommunications firms, will become chief executive officer of the Argo Communications Corporation Jan. 1, and said his new job ''puts me right into the fire.''

title: MICRO D INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $217,000 for the quarter and $410,000 for the year and an extraordinary charge of $139,000 for the quarter and year for the phasing out of discontinued operations.

title: TOWNHOUSE FIRE KILLS 2 CHILDREN AND A WORKER
description: An 8-year-old girl, her 4-year-old brother and a repairman were killed last night when a fire swept through a four-story East Side townhouse that belongs to the children's parents, the police said.

title: BEYOND A U.S. INDUSTRIAL POLICY
description: To the Editor:

title: Texas Settles Inmates' Suit
description: Two former Texas prison inmates who charged they were used as bait to train guard dogs have won a $14,000 out-of- court settlement in their civil rights lawsuit against the state prison system, according to their lawyer, Bill Habern.

title: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 29, 1983 International
description: Major failures of command, intelligence and policy contributed to the vulnerability of Marine defenses in Beirut, according to a special Pentagon commission that investigated the Oct. 23 truck bombing of the Marine compound that killed 241 Americans. The commission assigned direct blame for the inadequate security at the compound and the concentration of troops in one building to two Marine commanders in Beirut. The panel criticized the upper chain of command for failing to provide effective supervision. (Page A1, Col. 6.) Terrorism was likened to war by the Pentagon commission that investigated the truck bombing of the Marine compound in Beirut. Its report said the Marine unit ''was not trained, organized, staffed or supported to deal effectively with the terrorist threat in Lebanon.'' Moreover, the panel concluded that the United States armed forces are ill-equipped to combat terrorism. (A1:4.)

title: France Denies Charge On Troops in Lebanon
description: France today dismissed Lebanese accusations that its troops abandoned two military outposts in Beirut at short notice, setting off heavy fighting.

title: Spinoff Approved At Trans World Shareholders of the Trans World Corporation voted overwhelmingly in favor of proposals that will spin off Trans World Airlines from the company. Under one proposal, the 81 percent holding of the parent company in the airline will be distributed to Trans World stockholders at the rate of about 0.93 share of T.W.A. stock for each Trans World share. Under a second proposal, the incentive compensation plans of the two companies were separated.
description: After the spinoff, which is expected to become effective Feb. 1, Trans World will be left with four major subsidiaries that have been consistently profitable. The airline's earnings have fluctuated widely, showing heavy losses for the last two years. The four units are Spartan Food Systems Inc., which owns and operates 423 restaurants; the Canteen Corporation, a vending and direct food service business; Hilton International, which operates 90 hotels, and the Century 21 Real Estate Corporation.

title: STEELMAKERS PUT EMPHASIS ON EFFICIENCY
description: When the United States Steel Corporation announced Tuesday that it would close part or all of more than a dozen plants and eliminate 15,430 jobs, it took another step in the painful restructuring of the steel industry. And analysts say the shrinkage process, which involves pruning inefficient facilities and preserving efficient ones, is likely to continue.

title: PAY-TV SERVICES ARE PLANNED FOR BRITAIN IN 1984
description: In Britain, television viewing habits are as ingrained as daily teatime. Nevertheless, several major television and film companies, including such American entertainment giants as Home Box Office, Paramount Pictures, MGM/UA and Universal Pictures, are aiming to break those habits next year by introducing an array of pay-television services offering nonstop movies, rock music and sports.

title: JACKSON PRESSING SYRIAN TRIP PLANS
description: The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson, a Democratic Presidential candidate, said today that he would press on with his plans to travel to Syria this week in an effort to win the release of a captured Navy flier.

title: TV: ABOUT THE HOMELESS MENTALLY ILL
description: In a way, ''Asylum in the Streets'' tells us nothing new. For any reasonably alert New Yorker, in fact, it is almost a redundancy. Homeless mentally ill people sleep in subways, they wander in parks, they shuffle along the streets. We see them. On the other hand, they have no names and faces; they are only urban blight. By giving them names and faces, ''Asylum in the Streets,'' a first-rate half-hour presentation by NBC-TV tonight, changes our perception. It also outlines the dimensions of the problem.

title: ISRAELI ARABS: SCORNED, ASHAMED AND '20TH CLASS'
description: The Arabs of Israel are torn between their country and their people.

title: ADOBE, ONCE COMMON, NOW SHELTERS THE ELITE
description: Adobe, the oldest and once the cheapest permanent building material in the Southwest, is enjoying a strong renaissance.

title: TWO CRASH SURVIVORS SAVED AFTER 5 DAYS IN WRECKED AIRCRAFT
description: A father and son whose plane crashed in rugged mountains were rescued today after surviving five days of subzero temperatures by bundling up in snowmobile suits and taking shelter in the snow-covered wreckage, the authorities said Wednesday.

title: Advertising; Financial Magazine's New Era
description: SINCE 1970, Mark J. Meagher has been very high up in corporations involved with advertising media. But he never seriously sold advertising until this year. The change came after he led a group of 14 limited partners that bought the venerable Financial World magazine last May and set himself, the only general partner, up as publisher. Now he has revamped the ad sales force and established a network of advertising representative firms and placed himself at their head.

title: SCHAAK ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30

Honeywell Sees Rise in Earnings MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 28 (Reuters) - Honeywell Inc. said it expects increases in both earnings and revenues for 1984. The company previously said that with a modest economic recovery, its 1983 earnings would approximate those of 1982, excluding capital gains. In 1982, the maker of computers and industrial control systems earned $271.3 million, excluding capital gains of $66.3 million.
description: Capital spending for plant, property and equipment next year will be about $400 million, unchanged from 1983's estimated figure, Honeywell said. It said spending on research and development next year would rise slightly, to about $800 million, from an estimated $780 million this year.

title: Pope Asks Afghan Solution
description: Pope John Paul II called today for a just solution to the conflict in Afghanistan. Addressing 30,000 people in St. Peter's Basilica and the Pope Paul VI Auditorium for his weekly general audience, he also cited the war between Iraq and Iran, the Lebanese conflict and the civil war in El Salvador.

title: U.S. CALLED ILL-EQUIPPED TO FIGHT 'ON THE CHEAP' WAR BY TERRORISTS
description: MilitaryAnalysis

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Agronomics Corp., a Tampa, Fla., citrus company, has named William C. Rousse president and chief operating officer.

title: Quanex Offering At $100 Million WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (Reuters) - The Quanex Corporation filed an offering with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale of $100 million in senior mortgage bonds due 1999. The underwriter is Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.
description: Quanex, a producer of specialty steels, said it would use the proceeds of the offering to reduce debt in connection with a restructuring plan for its existing indebtedness. It said the restructuring plan is designed to permit completion of the company's Macsteel-Arkansas facility.

title: Airline Worker Testifies In Aquino Investigation
description: An airline employee testified today that the man accused of killing the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. was surrounded by soldiers at the moment Mr. Aquino was gunned down at the Manila airport.

title: YONKERS TO SEEK MONEY TO AVERT SCHOOL CLOSINGS
description: City and school officials announced an agreement today to avert a threatened closing of schools here.

title: Allied Gets Patent
description: The Allied Corporation said that the Japanese patent office had dismissed all opposition to its patent for Metglas amorphous metals alloys and granted the company's patent. This ends a series of patent procedures that began 10 years ago in Japan, which is one of the biggest markets for amorphous metal alloys. Metglas is used primarily to prevent energy loss in large electric transformers.

title: Wills's Troubles
description: Maury Wills, arrested early Tuesday on a grand theft charge while driving a car that was reported to be stolen, walked out of a drug rehabilitation center last summer before completing treatment, says Don Newcombe, coordinator of the Los Angeles Dodgers' drug and alcohol counseling efforts. ''I took him down to the CareUnit in May or June, and he was admitted,'' said Newcombe, like Wills a former Dodger player.

title: No Headline
description: Western Air To D.D.B. Doyle Dane Bernbach, which

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Early Retirements At Bank in Illinois

title: CREDIT MARKETS Interest Rates Little Changed
description: Market excitement was lacking following yesterday's auction by the Treasury of $5.215 billion in seven- year notes, but dealers said the issue, with a yield of 11.75 percent, sold moderately well.

title: PISTONS DOWN KNICKS
description: Kelly Tripucka, struggling for three quarters, scored 11 of his 20 points in the final period last night and sparked the Detroit Pistons to a 111-108 victory over the Knicks at Madison Square Garden.

title: MCGOVERN FAVORS CUT IN SPENDING ON MILITARY
description: The New York Times today publishes an interview with former Senator George McGovern, another in a series of interviews with candidates for the Presidency.

title: Ford's Sales in Europe
description: The Ford Group expects to sell a record 1.3 million cars in Western Europe this year, or 12.6 percent of the total market, up from 1.21 million, or 12.4 percent of the market, in 1982, the Ford Motor Company Ltd. said today.

title: British Airways
description: State-owned British Airways rejected charges that its supersonic Concorde flights offer seats on the trans-Atlantic route at below actual cost.

title: BOSTON COLLEGE STILL AWAITS A REPUTATION
description: Opinions, Doug Flutie says, are not changed easily. It will take five or six seasons of appearing in bowl games, he figures, before Boston College earns a reputation that will enable it to join teams such as Penn State, Pitt and Notre Dame as an annual candidate for postseason play. Until such time, the Eagles can enjoy playing the role of the ''other team'' and observe the scrutiny success brings.

title: Play by Vaclav Havel Extends Run at Public
description: ''A Private View,'' a play by Vaclav Havel, will extend its run through Jan. 15 at the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street.

title: Salvadoran Troops Complete One Drive and Begin Another
description: Three thousand United States-trained Government troops ended a four-day antiguerrilla sweep in northern San Miguel Province and immediately began a similar operation in adjoining Usulutan, a military spokesman said today.

title: ISRAELI SOLDIER KILLED IN SOUTH LEBANON
description: Guerrillas ambushed an Israeli Army patrol in southern Lebanon today, killing one soldier and wounding two. Meanwhile, nine Lebanese civilians were wounded when bombs exploded in Sidon and Beirut.

title: MAGNETIC CONTROLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a loss from operation of division to be sold of $467,000 and a loss on disposal of division to be sold of $3,950,000. c-Net income after a gain from operation of division to be sold of $17,000. d-After a loss from operations to be sold of $1,152,000 and loss on disposal of division to be sold of $3,950,000. e-After a loss from operations of division to be sold of $180,000.

title: 10,000 Asked to Evacuate After Pipeline Mix-Up
description: An estimated 10,000 people were asked to evacuate their homes tonight after a gas company supplier mistakenly pumped hydrogen sulfide, a highly toxic gas byproduct, into a natural gas pipeline, a utility spokesman said.

title: EGYPTIAN OFFICIAL IS GOING TO ISRAEL
description: The first ranking Egyptian diplomat to visit here since the Isareli invasion of Lebanon last year will arrive Thursday, the Foreign Ministry announced today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST THURSDAY, DECEMBER 29, 1983
description: International

title: COMMERCIAL METALS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
ADVERTISING ;  Addenda
description: * Chiat/Day/Livingston in Seattle, to become Livingston & Company on Jan. 1.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Wentex International Inc. announced that its wholly owned subsidiary, Tyrol Inc., Columbus, Ohio, had secured a $2.7 million loan commitment from Energy Search and Management Inc., Denver. The company also said that Tyrol had started a 12-well drilling program in Stern, Ohio.

title: IN THIS GOLDEN WEEK, THE MAGIC REIGNS ON BROADWAY
description: This is the week when Broadway seems timeless, as gaudy and glamorous as anyone's parents remember it. The woes of the theater season - the tragic, the bizarre, the bombs like ''Brothers'' and ''Peg'' that came and went and left only their marquees behind, like tombstones - are forgotten. For eight golden days, from Christmas to New Year's Day, all is applause.

title: PENTAGON'S INQUIRY BLAMES MAJOR MARINE COMMANDERS AND FAULTY POLICY IN BEIRUT
description: A special Defense Department commission that investigated the bombing of the Marine headquarters in Lebanon concluded in a report published today that major failures of command, intelligence and policy contributed to the vulnerability of Marine defenses.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
CRAFTED IN IRON BY HAND
description: -creations and

title: AN ECONOMIC RECOVERY STIRS, AND A CAMPAIGN CURTAIN RISES
description: Productivity up, investment up, retail sales up, the inflation rate down, the stock market bullish - such were the signs of the nation's economic recovery of 1983. But there was a cloud in the picture: a $200 billion Federal deficit.

title: A FEMINIST CAMPAIGN FOR THE PRESIDENCY
description: Sonia Johnson says she is willing to die for women's equality, and she finds nothing strange about that.

title: AN INTERVIEW WITH FORMER DAKOTA SENATOR GEORGE MCGOVERN
description: Following are key questions and answers from an interview with George McGovern by Fay S. Joyce:

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
description: Bond Rates Are Set At Farm Credit Banks

title: NO COPIES ISSUED TO PUBLIC
description: Copies of the Long Commission report on the Beirut bombing are unavailable to the public because supplies are limited, a Pentagon spokesman said today.

title: Key Rates
description: Nuveen index, John Nuveen & CompanySalomon Brothers estimates for bellw ether issues

title: Norman (Babe) Young Dies; Played for 3 Clubs in Majors
description: Norman (Babe) Young, a first baseman and outfielder for the New York Giants, the Cincinnati Reds and the St. Louis Cardinals from 1936 to 1948, died Sunday at the Widden Memorial Hospital in Everett Mass., after a heart attack. He was 68 years old and had been visiting a daughter for Christmas.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective. Corrections, also on this page, continue to deal with factual errors.

title: No Headline
description: People

title: Louisiana Project Rating Reduced By Reuters
description: Moody's Investor Service Inc. said it had reduced its rating of the Louisiana Offshore Terminal Authority's deep-water port revenue bonds to A-3, from A-2. Moody's said that the reduced rating affects about $707.7 million of revenue bonds and that its rating of Louisiana Offshore Terminal Authority deep-water port commerical paper remains unchanged at prime two.

title: Late Paperwork Costs Builders $2.4 Million
description: The builders of a new office tower in lower Manhattan were granted a property-tax exemption yesterday by the city but will have to pay their full tax bill this year.

title: INTERNATIONAL CLINICAL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Doctors Delay Discharge Of Paralyzed Woman
description: Riverside General Hospital officials said today that they had reluctantly delayed plans to discharge Elizabeth Bouvia, a paralyzed, 26-year-old woman who says she wants to die, because they can find no one willing to accept her.

title: A HONG KONG COMPANY'S TURNAROUND
description: In the last few years, Atlas Industries has been transformed from a floundering, money-losing producer of simple electronics items into a highly profitable manufacturer of sophisticated parts for leading computer companies in the United States.

title: GIANTS HALT TALKS WITH TAYLOR
description: The Giants announced yesterday that they had suspended contract renegotiation talks with Lawrence Taylor, their all-pro linebacker, until they learned whether he had signed a future contract with the New Jersey Generals of the United States Football League.

title: No Headline
description: THE BOURGEOIS EXPERIENCE: Victoria to Freud. Volume I. Education of the Senses. By Peter Gay. Illustrated.

title: Bridge: Unknown Players Emerge On Big Scene on Occasion
description: The upper crust of the tournament world consists of a few hundred experts who hope to win major titles and have international ambitions. Many do nothing but play bridge, and those with other occupations have probably devoted a great deal of time to the game at some point.

title: 10 Die in South Africa Mines
description: The bodies of two miners killed in a cave-in at two gold mines were found today, raising to 10 the number of people killed in the incident, mine officials said. The mines, owned by Gold Fields of South Africa, caved in when earth tremors rocked the area west of Johannesburg. Fifty-seven miners were injured as a result of separate tremors during the last week at the West Driefontein mine and the Doornfontein mine.

title: ANDROPOV'S PRE-EMINENCE IS STRESSED ON SOVIET TV
description: Yuri V. Andropov was absent again today when the Soviet leadership assembled for the winter session of the Supreme Soviet, the nominal legislature. But other developments, including a television news show, reinforced indications that he remained the pre-eminent leader.

title: William Bennett Jr., 79, Dies; Labor Adviser Under Truman
description: William E. Bennett Jr., a lawyer who served as an adviser to the Secretary of Labor in the Truman Administration. died of a heart attack Saturday at Cape Cod Hospital in Hyannis, Mass. He was 73 years old, a resident of Hyannis and a former resident of Closter, N.J.

title: A.T.& T. Closes 227 Phone Centers
description: A.T.& T. Information Systems, citing redundancy and a change in priorities, yesterday closed 227 of its 432 retail outlets, the A.T.& T. Phone Centers, at shopping malls across the country.

title: CABERET: THE MACRAE TEAM
description: Sheila and Heather MacRae make the oddest cabaret couple. The mother-daughter team, which is appearing at the Inner Circle through Saturday, represents not only different generations, but incompatible styles of entertainment.

title: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan Balancing Risk With Stability
description: M OST mutual funds offer a single investment objective, such as providing income or growth of capital. But the First Investors Ninety-Ten Fund is unusual: It strives for the dual and seemingly contradictory goals of capital preservation and capital appreciation.

title: No Headline
description: William J. Abernathy, a Harvard Business School professor whose work was instrumental in persuading many United States companies to focus more closely on production and technology, died yesterday at the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute of Boston. He was 50 years old and lived in Lexington, Mass.

title: DUPER'S QUICK HANDS CAUGHT SHULA'S EYES
description: The first time Mark Duper distinguished himself with the Miami Dolphins was before this season.

title: PRINCESS CAROLINE WED IN QUIET CEREMONY
description: Princess Caroline today married Stefano Casiraghi, the 23-year-old son of a very rich industrial family from northern Italy.

title: ; REAGAN'S ERROR ABOUT LIEUT. GOODMAN'S STATUS
description: T o the Editor:

title: William Abernathy, 50, Dies; Harvard Business Professor
description: William J. Abernathy, a Harvard Business School professor whose work was instrumental in persuading many United States companies to focus more closely on production and technology, died yesterday at the Dana Farber Cancer Institute of Boston. He was 50 years old and lived in Lexington, Mass.

title: Ex-Officer Dies After Mugging
description: A retired police officer died of a heart attack as he helped hunt a gang that had mugged him 20 minutes earlier, the police said yesterday.

title: SINCE '45 UNESCO HAS BEEN A POLTICAL BATTLEFIELD
description: Unesco, the Paris- based organization that the United States promised today that it would quit next year, is a senior member of what officials call the United Nations ''family,'' a collection of independent world bodies with differing tasks that are loosely grouped under the United Nations in New York.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Executive at Dynascan Is Appointed President In 1981, when Frank J. Dileo joined the Dynascan Corporation, the company was doing well. Now, the consumer and industrial electronics concern specializing in cordless telephones, citizen's band radios and other telecommunications equipment is booming.

title: SCOUTING
description: Yankees Chasing Niekro's Pitch

title: Aide at Jordanian Embassy Is Slain in Madrid by Gunman
description: A Jordanian Embassy employee, Walid Jamal Balkiz, was shot dead and another, Ibrahim Subhi Mohammed Mamid, was seriously wounded today by a gunman who fired more than a dozen rounds into their car, the police said.

title: Money Fund Assets Decline
description: Assets and short-term yields of the nation's money market mutual funds declined in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute and Donoghue's Money Fund Report said yesterday.

title: For Children; Music, Plays, Shows
description: THE TRIP, a play by Ezra Jack Keats, performed by the childen of First Act, directed by Meridee Stein, Friday, Saturday and Sunday at 2 and 4 P.M., at 37 West 65th Street. Tickets, $10. Information and reservations: 873-6400.

title: U.S. IS QUITTING UNESCO, AFFIRMS BACKING FOR U.N.
description: The United States formally announced today that it intended to withdraw from Unesco in a year's time. But at the same time, it said that it would strengthen its participation in the United Nations and other international agencies.

title: Bridge: The Frying Pan Is Better Despite Fire's Temptation Temptation
description: One of many old sayings that apply at the bridge table is the warning against going from the frying pan into the fire. A few East-West pairs found the fire attractive on the diagramed deal, from the 1983 Life Master Pair Championship in New Orleans.

title: AN EXPERIENCED HAND IS LENT TO BLAST VICTIMS
description: The morning after a blast ripped through a warehouse in a residential section here and devastated the homes of more than 100 families, Laura Wojdan responded to pleas for help and began going door to door to collect clothes for the homeless. ''It was a natural thing,'' said Mrs. Wojdan, a lifelong resident. ''There were people in need. I felt sorry for them and I pictured myself in the same shoes.''

title: 4 Texas Stores Ruined In Robbery and Arson
description: The police today searched for two robbers who tied up a clerk at a leather goods store before setting a fire that destroyed four downtown businesses.

title: ARABS AND JEWS OF ISRAEL: BRIDGES ACROSS BITTERNESS
description: Earlier this month, on the sixth night of Hanukkah, about 150 Jews and Arabs gathered in the lobby of a building at Hebrew University for the lighting of the candles and the singing of the Jewish prayer. The Jews then sang Hebrew songs; the Arabs stood respectfully, watching and listening.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A dispatch yesterday on the press in Suriname incorrectly described Interpress Service, an international news agency specializing in coverage of third world countries. It is an unaffiliated, nonprofit cooperative and opposes all restrictions on the press.

title: SCOUTING
description: Well Read

title: Italy Reports Mafia Plot
description: Italy's secret services have uncovered a Mafia plot to murder Giovanni Falcone, a Sicilian magistrate, in early November, using bazookas and grenade-launchers, judicial sources said today. They said intelligence agents got wind of the plot in Milan.

title: PAINT REMOVER BLAMED IN FIRE FATAL TO THREE
description: A fire that killed two children and a workman in an East Side brownstone home late Wednesday erupted when paint remover was accidentally ignited, the Fire Department said yesterday.

title: U.S. Is Urged to Ban 2 Drugs for Arthritics
description: A consumer group is calling for a Federal ban on two widely used Swiss- made arthritis drugs. It says the drugs may have caused more than 10,000 deaths worldwide, including more than 3,000 in the United States.

title: EXOTIC NEW EXPLOSIVE IN ARSENAL?
description: Terrorists in the Middle East may be increasing the destructive force of their bombs by using exotic, hard- to-obtain explosives in conjunction with dynamite or TNT, according to private security experts and sources close to a recent Congressional investigation of the bombing at the Marine compound in Beirut.

title: American Express Active
description: Shares of the American Express Company, responding to rumors that the financial services concern might become a takeover target, leaped to fourth place among most-active issues on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, with more than 1.6 million shares traded. But the stock rose only 1/8, to 33 1/8.

title: How Free a Rein?
description: Bob Trumpy , a sports broadcaster in Cincinnati and a former teammate of Sam Wyche , wondered yesterday about how much independence his friend will have in his new job as coach of the Bengals. Wyche, formerly the quarterback coach with the San Franciso 49ers and head coach at Indiana University, at age 38 became the youngest head coach in the National Football League Wednesday when he was hired by Paul Brown , the Bengal general manager.

title: ECONOMIC INDICATORS DOWN 0.4%
description: The Government's index of leading economic indicators fell four-tenths of 1 percent in November, the first decline in 15 months, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Beverly Bid Order
description: A judge dissolved a temporary restraining order that prevented Paul Amir, a dissident shareholder, from buying more stock in Beverly Hills Savings and Loan Association. Superior Court Judge David Rothman, who on Wednesday had extended the restraining order until this morning, dissolved the order and set a Jan. 10 hearing on the thrift unit's request for a preliminary injunction, the court clerk, Lynne Gold, said.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: CRANSTON WOULD STRESS JOBS OVER ARMS FUNDS
description: The New York Times today publishes an interview with Senator Alan Cranston, another in a series of interviews with candidates for the Presidency.

title: Rioting Erupts Anew In South Africa Camp
description: Policemen fired tear gas, rubber bullets and birdshot as new rioting erupted today in a black shantytown near Cape Town where fighting Wednesday night left two dead and seven injured, the police said.

title: SCOUTING
description: The Sightseers

title: WELCOMING '84 WITH A LOMBARDO, STEVE ALLEN OR DICK CLARK
description: THE television festivities for the eve of 1984, beginning at 11:30 tomorrow night, are not terribly different from any other year. The one most noticeable difference is that the Guy Lombardo Orchestra, playing as usual at the ballroom of New York's Waldorf-Astoria, will not be seen on network television but in a syndicated show, to be broadcast on Channel 5. The late Mr. Lombardo's orchestra is now being conducted by his nephew Bill. The performing guests will include Bobby Vinton, the singer, and Vanessa Williams, the new Miss America. Steve Allen will have the honor of reporting the countdown to midnight from Times Square.

title: MAYOR RELEASES WEBSTER LETTERS ON F.B.I.'S VISIIT
description: Mayor Koch yesterday released the latest correspondence between himself and the head of the F.B.I. regarding the Mayor's suggestion that the Secretary of Defense was using the bureau to try to prevent him from speaking out on foreign policy matters.

title: SETTING UP THE WINNER
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif.

title: BERNARD BERGGREN
description: Bernard Berggren, a former president of the Staten Island War Memorial Association, died Dec. 16 in Columbus, Ohio, where he had lived in retirement since 1981.

title: A taste of Thailand on the East Side.
description: THE rule of five flavors recorded in a third century B.C. Chinese poem - that bitter, salt, sour, hot and sweet be balanced - applies equally to Thai food. Many Thai dishes have their origins in Chinese cooking, such as whole deep-fried fish and mee krob, which consists of crisp-fried rice noodles with seafood and meats, certainly a close relation to Chinese chicken salad made with deep-fried noodles. Indian influences, especially those of southern India, where coconut milk moderates the spiciness, are also in evidence, as in satays of skewered meat, fish or poultry broiled and served with a peanut- based sauce and curries.

title: $560,000 for Injuries
description: A jury in Spokane, Wash., has awarded more than $560,000 to a local baseball star who said his promising professional career was ruined by back injuries suffered in an automobile accident six years ago. Steve Miller , a first-round draft choice by the Montreal Expos and again by the Boston Red Sox, was injured when his car was struck from behind on an icy road by a 40-ton truck belonging to Hygrade Food Products.

title: St. John's Women Win Final, 81-62
description: Anne Marie McNamee scored 22 points and was named the tournament's most valuable player as St. John's defeated California, 81-62, to win the Queens College Holiday Classic last night at FitzGerald Memorial Gymnasium in Flushing.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A caption with an article from Memphis yesterday about the establishment of the Benchmark Hotel incorrectly identified the two men pictured.

title: IN SICILY, THE MISSILES STIR WORRY
description: The square in Comiso, built around a baroque fountain and statue of Diana the Huntress, is salon and living room for the men of this traditional town near Sicily's southern coast. In the evening, they stand in clumps outside their political party meeting places on the ground floors of stone buildings that edge the piazza. They discuss politics and truck farming and, lately, the 112 cruise missiles that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization will install here in March.

title: Soccer Union Dues Misused, Suit Says
description: A lawsuit charging misuse of funds seeks to require the Major Indoor Soccer League Players Association to return all dues that it has collected since it was formed in 1979.

title: AGENCY TO GIVE PANEL TRANSCRIPTS OF SECRETLY TAPED PHONE CALLS
description: The House Foreign Affairs Committee will be given transcripts of telephone conversations tape-recorded by Charles Z. Wick, director of the United States Information Agency, according to the committee's chief of staff.

title: Northeast Savings Stake Is Sold HARTFORD, Dec. 29 (AP) - A group of 16 investors has purchased a 5.24 percent interest in Northeast Savings. Northeast's chairman, Kent Dixon, called it the largest equity position held by individual investors. They now hold 265,200 shares of Northeast's more than 5 million shares outstanding.
description: According to a notice filed with the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, the three principals in the investment group are Alexander M. Vagliano of Norfolk, former executive vice president in charge of international banking at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York; Robert G. Wilmers, chairman and chief executive of the Manufacturers and Traders Trust Company of Buffalo, and Brent D. Baird, general partner, Trubee Collins & Company, also of Buffalo.

title: NUMBING COLD BRINGS DEATH AND MISERY TO SOUTH
description: The freezing cold gripping most of the nation has brought death, hardship and inconvenience to the South. Shelters for the homeless are crowded with people seeking warmth, scattered power failures have darkened homes and businesses, and frozen and bursting water pipes have driven residents from their houses and stores.

title: BROADWAY
description: Alan Bates returns to New York in Patriot for Me.'

title: BOGERT OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
STATE-SPONSORED TERROR CALLED A THREAT TO U.S.
description: In recent months the United States and its allies have become the targets of what Arab and Israeli security experts describe as terrorism sponsored by sovereign nations.

title: Grenada Seeks Peace Corps
description: Grenada has asked the Peace Corps to send volunteers ''as soon as possible'' to help rebuild agricultural, health and education services, the agency said today. It is asking volunteers in the Caribbean area whether they would be willing to sign up to work in Grenada for one year so the program can start quickly, a spokesman said.

title: KEY DEFENSE AIDE FACES NEW INQUIRY
description: Federal prosecutors are planning to open inquiries into whether crimes were committed during an investigation of Paul N. Thayer, the Deputy Secretary of Defense, according to Justice Department officials.

title: DEVILS DEALT 5TH STRAIGHT LOSS
description: In perhaps their poorest performance since Tom McVie replaced Billy MacMillan as coach last month, the Devils were defeated by the Detroit Red Wings, 6-1, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight for their fifth consecutive loss.

title: Russian in Lead
description: Sergei Bondar of the Soviet Union took the lead today with 219.4 points in the jumping event of a World Cup Nordic skiing competition in Oberwiesenthal, East Germany. Close behind him were Gunther Schmieder of East Germany, with 219 points, and Aleksandr Prosvirnin of the Soviet Union, with 218.1.

title: ALTEX OIL CORP reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: UNITARY TAXATION: RATIONALE AND PROSPECTS
description: To the Editor:

title: ON REGIONAL SECURITY
description: The lessons of Grenada are coming clearer now that the dust of our intervention has settled. The question posed in Grenada was hardly unique: How can a people rid themselves of a regime that is installed by force and seeks to govern through force? The answer in Grenada was a regional approach to security - a step away from the concept of nationalism and government by nations that has prevailed since the breakup of the Roman Empire. It was a crucial, leading step on a path that I believe will become increasingly important in the 21st century.

title: A BUSY TIME FRO 40 KIDS WHO SING AT THE MET
description: In the final scene of ''Hansel and Gretel,'' as the witch's spell is broken, the children's chorus, shrouded in smoke, suddenly comes alive, singing its thanks in intricate four-part harmony.

title: UNUSUAL IDEAS BY DOZEN NEW YORKERS TO GREET 1984
description: ''WHAT are you doing New Year's, New Year's Eve?'' the old Frank Loesser song asks. New Yorkers, well known and little known, who answered that question in an unscientific poll, responded with characteristic individuality and diversity. What follows are some of the more original plans, a few grand and expensive, others costing nothing at all. What they share is involvement with New York. There may even be useful ideas here for New Yorkers who haven't made their own plans yet.

title: GRAND JURY TO STUDY FRAUD BY DRUG AGENTS IN FLORIDA
description: A Federal grand jury will soon be convened to investigate suspected fraud in the expense vouchers filed by members of the South Florida task force on narcotics, officials of the Drug Enforcement Administration say.

title: ASTRONOMERS FIND 2 'LENSES' IN SPACE
description: Astronomers have discovered two more ''gravitational lenses'' in space, raising the hope that if many more are found they may help determine the dimensions and ultimate fate of the universe.

title: Geneva Convention On Prisoners of War
description: Article 118 of the 1949 Geneva Convention Relative to the Treatment of Prisoners of War provides that ''prisoners of war shall be released and repatriated without delay after the cessation of active hostilities.''

title: China Ready to Talk About Cultural Issues
description: China said today that it would discuss resumption of official cultural exchanges with the United States that were suspended after the United States gave Hu Na, a Chinese tennis star, asylum in April.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: American Savings Bank announced that Albert V. Will had joined as vice president, mortgage servicing.

title: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN (FT. MYERS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Year-ago results are not available as the company only went public in September.

description: ''We're saying, you can't run programs that aren't safe for kids.'' - Michael Willie of the State Education Department on order to Yonkers schools. (A1:2.)

description: Knowing the Ingredients In Alcoholic Beverages

title: CROWN AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
EXCUSE IT, PLEASE
description: On Dec. 2, I began an article with the suggestion that in executing Robert Sullivan, ''the state of Florida may well have killed an innocent man.''

NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC, Kurt Sanderling, conductor; Shlomo Mintz, violinist, Avery Fisher Hall, 2; preconcert lecture by Rachael Worby, Chorus Room, 11 A.M. P.D.Q. BACH, Carnegie Hall, 8. NEW YORK GILBERT AND SULLIVAN PLAYERS, ''Princess Ida,'' Symphony Space, Broadway and 95th Street, 8.

title: Filipino Photographer Says Film Was Seized
description: A Government news service photographer testified today that authorities confiscated film from him and other photographers at Manila's airport after the assassination of Benigno S. Aquino Jr., the opposition leader.

title: Musical Choreopoem
description: ''This Ain't No Place,'' a musical choreopoem by Titus Walker, will be presented by the Ujama Black Theater tonight at 7:30 at the Lincoln Square Community Center Theater, 250 West 65th Street.

CANAVERAL INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After losses of $279,393 for the latest year and $688,288 for the previous year from equity in loss of the Lake Worth Road Corp., a 50 percent owned corporate joint venture.

title: ART: THREE DECADES OF CHAIM SOUTINE PAINTINGS
description: DEEP in the heart of Expressionism as we are these days, it seems no less than fitting that the work of Chaim Soutine (1893-1943), one of the style's most vivid practitioners, should surface once again. New York hasn't seen a good Soutine show since the early 1970's, when in the midst of Minimalism his work - particularly the furious, emotion-charged brush strokes of the early canvases - seemed somewhat less germane. Now and through Jan. 28, the Galleri Bellman, 41 East 57th Street, presents a well-selected group of 43 Soutine paintings, including a number of important loans. They reveal this true Expressionist in all phases of his career, from beginning to untimely end during World War II, when, at 50 years old, and - as a Jew - in danger of Nazi internment, he died in Paris of perforated stomach ulcers.

title: VIRUS IS SUSPECTED IN AIDS-LIKE APE DISEASE
description: Evidence suggesting that an unknown virus causes a disease in monkeys and apes that resembles acquired immune deficiency syndrome, the human disorder known as AIDS, was reported today by a team of 13 researchers from the National Institutes of Health and from the University of California at Davis.

title: ASSAD RECOVERED, MINISTER REPORTS
description: Syria's Defense Minister said today that President Hafez al-Assad had suffered from heart trouble brought on by exhaustion last month, not appendicitis as officially announced earlier. He said Mr. Assad had recovered.

title: TWO TELL OF SURVIVAL IN COLD
description: A pilot who survived five days of subzero temperatures by huddling with his son and his wife's lifeless body in their wrecked airplane said today that he never looked at a thermometer because he did not want to get depressed.

title: STATE CURBS YONKERS SCHOOL SPORTS
description: The State Department of Education has ordered the Yonkers public school system to suspend all winter interscholastic sports until the state is satisfied that the Yonkers athletic program is being run properly.

title: SONG: AMERICANA BY MARILYN HORNE
description: MARILYN HORNE took a sentimental trip back to her childhood, to her musical roots, to build the program for the concert called ''Marilyn Horne's Great American Songbook'' at Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday evening.

title: THE SABBATICAL OF JAY BROPHY
description: Jay Brophy remembers the day he

title: THE OTHER BENEFICIARIES OF A BRAIN DEATH LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: NOVEMBER TRADE GAP NARROWED
description: The United States merchandise trade deficit narrowed to $7.4 billion in November, but was still the second-highest monthly imbalance on record, the Commerce Department reported.

title: NIGHT ON THE TOWN WITH POP OR ROCK
description: -and-tails nostalgia to sweaty all- night dancing for the city's pop and rock fans.

title: AN INTERVIEW WITH ALAN CRANSTON, SENATOR FROM CALIFORNIA
description: Following are key questions and answers from an interview with Senator Alan Cranston by Frank Lynn:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST FRIDAY, DECEMBER 30, 1983
description: Companies

title: FOLK-POP: RETURN OF ERIC ANDERSEN
description: ADECADE ago, Eric Andersen was the personification of the post-hippie singer-songwriter. Blessed with princely good looks and a pleasantly husky folk baritone, he invested the role of the vulnerable romantic troubadour with a dreamy intensity.

title: THEATER: LEN JENKIN'S 'FIVE OF US'
description: AS a playwright, Len Jenkin has specialized in opaque adventures. His new play, ''Five of Us,'' at La Mama, is strikingly different; it proves that he not only has a vivid imagination but that he also has an artist's command of his craft. Behind his self- designated role as the theatrical equivalent of an Abstract Expressionist, he is a shrewdly observant portraitist.

title: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 30, 1983 International
description: A change in the Marine mission in Beirut will be pressed in Congress if President Reagan fails to change it by the end of January, according to Democratic and Republican Congressional leaders. The legislators include several who have previously supported Administration policy in Lebanon. The Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., scheduled a meeting of Democratic leaders next Tuesday to discuss policy in Lebanon and proposals to require a Marine withdrawal before the present 18- month deadline. (Page A1, Col. 6.) The Pentagon is drafting plans for confronting the problem of combatting terrorists for review by Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, according to Defense Department officials. They said the department was preparing proposals hastily in response to criticisms that the United States armed forces are not equipped to fight terrorism. (A8:5-6.)

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: Man Who Spent 31 Years In Hositals Is Freed

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Small House Is the Big Hope
description: New York's Deputy Mayor Kenneth Lipper clearly understands that the shortage of middle-income housing discourages economic expansion. He would use capital funds to stimulate new housing construction. The need is obvious, even desperate. But the suggestion awakens scary memories.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Q&A column in Science Times on Dec. 20 rendered the temperature 3 degrees Kelvin into degrees centigrade incorrectly. The correct equivalent is 270 degrees below zero centigrade.

title: Eurobonds Slow
description: The Eurobond market was steady with trading minimal as many operators closed their books ahead of the year- end, dealers said. Fixed-interest bonds showed net gains of about 1/8 point.

title: FIRST COINVESTORS INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: THE SUPERVISING JUDGE: ADVOCATE FOR THE PUBLIC
description: Judge Harold H. Greene, who presided over the marathon trial that led to the dismemberment of the world's biggest company, admits to no doubts that the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company will produce the broad public benefits envisioned by the historic settlement.

title: HI-SHEAR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including gains of $208,000, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter and $508,000, or 11 cents a share, for the 6 months from equity in an affiliate. c-Net loss after losses of $2,576,000 for the quarter and $2,332,000 for the 6 months from equity in an affiliate.

title: New Unemployment Claims Increase 20,000, to 380,000
description: New claims for state unemployment benefits rose to 380,000 in the week ended Dec. 17, up 20,000 from a week earlier, the Labor Department reported today.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
description: Moody's Raises Ratings Of Trans World Bonds

title: AT THE MOVIEW
description: How peasants scored a hit at box office.

title: NEW, OLD AND INEXPENSIVE WAYS TO CELEBRATE
description: THE ball will fall. Champagne corks will pop. Midnight madness will reign in all its noisy, rowdy splendor. As the old slips into the new tomorrow night, New York will engage in the usual Saturnalian customs. The city will also welcome 1984 with an array of unusual celebrations.

title: Pryor Pleads Not Guilty in Drug Case
description: Aaron Pryor, the former World Boxing Association junior welterweight titleholder, has pleaded not guilty to possessing cocaine.

title: ARAFAT'S GONE. SO WHAT?
description: -Occupied West Bank - Neither Yasir Arafat's forced departure from Lebanon nor his visit to Egypt to talk with President Hosni Mubarak seem very important here on the West Bank. Mr. Arafat's personal fate - whether he survives as a political leader - no longer seems to matter as much as it once did to the 1.5 million Palestinians living under Israeli occupation. The fate of the West Bank and Gaza remains unchanged. The occupation continues.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: For the Young And the Young at Heart

title: Lesotho Schedules First Election Since '70
description: The 10-year-old Lesotho interim national assembly will be suspended early in the new year to pave the way for a general election, Prime Minister Leabua Jonathan announced today.

title: AMID THE DESERT OF DISTRUST, AN ARAB AND A JEW TEAM UP
description: More than four years ago Lucien Ben-Shoshan, a 37-year-old Jew, and Khalil Atamna, a 33-year-old Arab, became partners in a small enterprise making concrete building blocks. Their company thus became one of a scattering of Arab-Jewish businesses in Israel, blooming like little wildflowers in a landscape of distrust.

title: Advertising; New Name And Plan At Agency
description: EURO CENTER COMMUNICATIONS opened its office in New York in the fall of 1980 as an agency with a difference. It planned to attract smaller international marketers who wanted more control over their advertising abroad.

title: BRIEFING
description: Salvador Aid Suit

title: 60-Second Debate Should the Reagan
description: Administration

title: NOTRE DAME BEATS BOSTON COLLEGE, 19-18
description: Perhaps it was not the convincing type of victory that might have quieted the critics during the coming off-season, but it was a welcome victory nonetheless.

title: MUSIC: QUEENS PHILHARMONIC
description: THE Queens Philharmonic presented a free concert of well-known orchestral music at Alice Tully Hall Wednesday night as part of Lincoln Center's 13th annual Community Holiday festival.

title: THE PINELANDS: HOME TO A VARIETY OF FOLK LIFE
description: A wilderness flatland of sand and scrub pine called the Jersey Pine Barrens sits 70 miles south of the urban and suburban sprawl of the center of the New York metropolitan area. Life in the barrens is riveted to the pine cone and clam, snapping turtle and white cedar, cranberries and hound dogs.

title: Only a Leave for Mr. Wagner
description: Harvard's importance among universities is like New York's among cities, and Deputy Mayor Robert Wagner cannot be faulted for accepting a position in Cambridge after four long years at City Hall. Though he is by nature unobtrusive, he will be sorely missed by both the Mayor and the city.

description: Following is the text of the State Department announcement today on the intention of the United States to withdraw from Unesco:

description: Historians of Rome have not been kind to Lucius Verus, the pleasure- loving co-emperor from A.D. 161 to 169, but the Metropolitan Museum has.

title: Concern for the Losers
description: Martina Navratilova wants to set the record straight. She was not misquoted in recent remarks about the paltry prize money for women at major tournaments, but she was mis -interepreted.

description: The Defense Department, in response to criticisms that the United States military is not equipped to fight terrorists, is hastily preparing proposals for confronting the problem for review by Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinburger, department officials said today.
