title: MARYLAND TRIUMPHS BY 58-52
description: Maryland held off Randolph- Macon for a 58-52 victory, and La Salle beat George Washington, 65- 64, on a field goal by Ralph Lewis with 7 seconds remaining in the first round of the Maryland Invitational Tournament tonight.

title: Status of U.S. Officers Mentioned in Report
description: Following are the whereabouts and assignments of the officers mentioned in the Defense Department report on the Marine bombing in Beirut, issued Wednesday:

title: SHAMIR AND EGYPTIAN HOLD TALKS
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir met with a ranking Egyptian official today and voiced confidence that the two nations could ''reach a good agreement'' if talks resumed on Palestinian self- rule, an Israeli spokesman said.

title: Interleague Feud
description: There was no surprise in the office of the Cleveland Browns earlier this week when their quarterback, Brian Sipe , signed with the New Jersey Generals, but there does seem to be a lingering distaste for the United States Football League team. When Sam Rutigliano , the Browns' coach, heard that Donald Trump had signed Sipe to a guaranteed contract without requiring him to take a physical, he criticized the inexperienced owner.

title: Wills Charged
description: Maury Wills, the 51-year-old former star shortstop for the Los Angeles Dodgers, was charged by the District Attorney's office today with felony possession of cocaine.

title: 'DOONESBURY' BOOPSIE A STAGE VETERAN AT 20
description: LAURA DEAN used to think, ''Oh, God! I'm not even a star yet!'' She was 13 at the time. Now she is 20, and she is Boopsie, the bubble-headed blond cheerleader who bounces around the stage like Silly Putty in the musical ''Doonesbury,'' her Broadway debut. Her big solo turn is titled, ''I Can Have It All'' - and, with all the critics singling her out for praise, it seems as though she can.

title: U.S. Defeated In World Hockey
description: The Soviet Union scored three goals in the third period and defeated the United States, 7-4, today in the fourth round of the world ice hockey championships, handing the Americans their fourth loss without victory.

title: Flaherty Films
description: ''Man of Aran'' and ''Louisiana Story,'' documentary films by Robert J. Flaherty, will be screened this weekend at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, marking the 100th anniversary of the film maker's birth next year.

title: DOW OFF 3.05
description: Stock prices ended with small changes yesterday for the second consecutive session. But several technology issues lost considerable ground and the Dow Jones industrial average slipped 3.05 points.

title: Who Pays for Productivity
description: U.S. Steel's announcement that it will cut production capacity and employment by a fifth next year makes it look as if the American steel industry is on the verge of collapse. In fact, it's a welcome sign of the company's efforts to regain its competitive position. It would be even more welcome if Washington would face up to its responsibilities to dislocated workers and communities.

title: THE VISION OF BOTH ORWELL AND KAFKA IS AS SHARP AS EVER, CONFEREES FINDN
description: Whatever else 1984 may hold, one thing is certain: There will be a storm of discussions about what George Orwell did or did not predict in his novel ''Nineteen Eighty-Four,'' which made the year famous 35 years before its time, and whether those predictions, if they were predictions, are coming to pass.

title: NIELSEN, A C, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Results reflect pretax foreign currency translation losses of $318,000 for the latest first quarter and $114,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: FLORIDA BANS 10 MORE FOODS ON REPORT OF PESTICIDE TAINT
description: Ten grain-based food products have been added to the growing list of items ordered off the market in Florida because of small amounts of the pesticide ethylene dibromide, or EDB.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Indiana Pacers, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:35 P.M. In the teams' only earlier meeting this season, at Indianapolis, Herb Williams scored 21 points and Clark Kellogg 20 to lead the Pacers to a 111-101 victory. But Indiana has lost in each of its last four visits to New Jersey. (Television - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC, 660; 7:30 P.M.)

title: JACKSON IS OFF TO SYRIA TO SEEK FLIER'S RELEASE
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson left yesterday from New York by air for Damascus, Syria, where he said he had ''virtual assurance'' of meeting with President Hafez al-Assad or authorities ''sufficiently high in the government'' to make a moral appeal for the release of a captured Navy flier.

title: RussellGreenman,Executive Or
description: Russell L. Greenman, a former vice president of the General Cable Corporation and a writer on labor-management relations, died Tuesday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 79 years old and lived in Chatham, N.J.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN JETS ATTACK IN ANGOLA
description: South Africa announced today that its fighter jets had bombed a Namibian guerrilla base near the southern Angolan city of Lubango.

title: Music Improvisations
description: Collin Walcott and Nana Vasconcelos will perform ''world music improvisations'' on sitar, tabla and percussion instruments from Asia, Africa, Brazil and the United States tonight at 8 in the Alternative Museum, 17 White Street in TriBeCa. Mr. Walcott is a member of the group Oregon, and Mr. Vasconcelos, a Brazilian percussionist, has recorded with many groups and on his own. Tickets are $7. Information: 966-4444.

title: A New Opponent Of Seabrook Unit Fitchburg Gas and Electric Light Company, which has an interest of almost nine-tenths of 1 percent in the Seabrook nuclear generating project, said it no longer supported the completion of Seabrook Unit II in New Hampshire. The company, based in Fitchburg, Mass., attributed the move to the uncertainty surrounding the completion date and the ultimate cost of the power. The utility said the cost, now estimated at $2.2 billion, is expected to rise significantly.
description: Fitchburg said cancellation of the project would require a 75 percent vote of the shares of the 16 companies involved.

title: PUBLISHIN: WHO SAYS MOST BOOKS ARE LOSERS?
description: LEONARD SHATZKIN ruffled some feathers in the publishing industry last year with his book ''In Cold Type: Overcoming the Book Crisis,'' in which, among other suggestions, he recommended that publishers take over the responsibility of stocking bookstores rather than simply filling orders from booksellers. He is likely to ruffle even more feathers with his latest iconoclastic notion - namely, that it simply is not true that the majority of general-interest (''trade'') books lose money.

title: Bracklow Photographs
description: More than 100 photographs of New York City at the turn of the century by Robert L. Bracklow will be on view through next May at the New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, at 76th Street.

title: CATALONINA PAYS HOMAGE TO ITSELF WITH ITS OWN TV
description: When J. R. of ''Dallas'' was shot on television here not so long ago, most viewers did not realize it, but the event marked the end of a significant era for Spanish television. What ended was the central Government's monopoly of the medium.

title: A.T.& T.'S GUIDE IN BREAKUP
description: When Charles Lee Brown became chairman of A.T.&T. five years ago, he hardly seemed the person who would resolve the Government's antitrust charges against the Bell empire by agreeing to split the historic system asunder. An unabashed Bell partisan, known as a fighter, Mr. Brown had expressed the hope ''that the absolutely weak case of divestiture will be understood to be weak, and we'll get this out of our hair.''

title: Diner's Journal
description: GRILLING promises to be the culinary craze of 1984, and Chatfield's Bar and Grill, 208 East 60th Street, has expanded its selection of daily grilled specials. It is a cozy, collegiate sort of place: brick walls, stone fireplace, lots of blue blazers, buttton-down shirts and more wingtips than at La Guardia Airport.

title: TAR HEELS WIN FESTIVAL AS PERKINS SCORES 31
description: St. John's found out last night just how good it is: Good, but not good enough for a North Carolina. At least not yet.

title: WIVES PRESS THEIR CANDIDATES' CASES
description: It was the middle of the holiday season. But politics never takes a holiday.

title: SOME CALIFORNIANS DECLINE TO FLEE GAS
description: In this quiet Santa Ynez Valley town, not far from President Reagan's Santa Barbara ranch, it takes more than hydrogen sulfide gas to send most people fleeing from their homes.

title: ART PEOPLE
description: A 2d museum sells bonds.

title: RB ROBOT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
DISTANCE IS NOT A HINDRANCE FOR DONORS TO NEEDIEST CASES
description: A Toronto couple, frequent visitors to New York, sent $250 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund's annual appeal benefiting eight charities in the city.

title: Warrantless Searches Restricted on Coast
description: The State Supreme Court today severely restricted the right of police officers to conduct warrantless searches at the time of an arrest.

title: FOREIGN POLICY FAILURES
description: This has been a year of harshness between the U.S. and the Soviet Union.

title: NEBRASKA FORMS A LINE WITH PATIENCE
description: Nebraska's history of developing excellent offensive lines may be the result of patience in its young athletes, according to the members of this season's line.

title: Denis Mulligan Dead; Led Hindenburg Study
description: Former Col. Denis Mulligan of the Air Force, who investigated the 1937 Hindenburg disaster for the Department of Commerce, died Dec. 21 in East Orange Veterans Hospital. He was in his early 80's.

title: BRIEFS
description: Chart House Inc., Lafayette, La., said it had completed the purchase of Godfather's Pizza, Omaha. As part of the merger, Godfather's Pizza is changing its name to Diversifoods Inc.

title: Bad Week for Chief At Indiana Utility
description: For Hugh A. Barker, chairman and chief executive officer of the Public Service Company of Indiana, last week brought bad tidings.

title: HOLLY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
FORMER U.S. OFFICIAL TAUGHT ECONOMICS
description: Dr. Henry Hilgard Villard, an economist, retired university professor and former chairman of the board of Planned Parenthood of New York, died Wednesday at Presbyterian Hospital after a stroke. He was 72 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: D'OYLY CARTE BARTIONE JOINS 'IDA' CELEBRATION
description: He is the very model of a modern Gilbert and Sullivan star, is John Reed. For more than two decades the principal comic baritone of the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company, Mr. Reed is in New York appearing as King Gama in the Gilbert and Sullivan Players production of ''Princess Ida; or, Castle Adamant'' at Symphony Space.

title: RULING IS AWAITED ON MALONEY INJURY
description: ''He will protect his players,'' Craig Patrick, the Rangers' general manager, said of Jack O'Callahan moments after watching the Chicago defenseman draw a match penalty for attempting to injure the Rangers' Dave Maloney here Wednesday night. ''That's the wrong term, 'protect,' '' Patrick added. ''He'll stick up for his teammates. And that's something you look for in a hockey player.''

title: JAZZ: ARNIE LAWRENCE TRIO
description: The trio that the saxophonist Arnie Lawrence is leading at Village West through New Year's Eve, is not what one usually encounters in a jazz trio made up of saxophone, piano and bass.

title: UNITARY TAXATION: RATIONALE AND PROSPECTS
description: To the Editor:

title: THEATER: 'FULL HOOKUP' AT CIRCLE REP
description: WHATEVER kind of holiday season you're having in New York, it has to be better than the one that Ric and Beth are having in Omaha. Ric and Beth, a young married couple, inhabit a new play called ''Full Hookup,'' and they celebrate Christmas week by tormenting each other with low blows, sexual humiliations and all manner of obscenities. Needless to say, no one bothers to exchange gifts. The only gala family feast consists of fast-food pizza washed down with Mogen David wine.

title: UI Group Plan
description: UI Group Inc., a food- products concern, said its board and the company's majority shareholder had reached a preliminary agreement on a proposal to take the company private through an all-cash merger valued at between $39.6 million and $42.4 million. The majority shareholder is the Corporation of the President of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, which held 63.3 percent of the shares outstanding as of July 20.

title: West Berlin Takes Over Part of Rail System
description: East Germany initialed an agreement today to hand over to West Berlin operation of the western part of the city's loss-making urban railway system, which it has controlled since the 1950's.

title: ART: A MODEST SURVEY SPOTLIGHTING 'SUBTLETIES'
description: THOUGH not all the galleries have yet collected themselves for the New Year, some are putting on creditable performances. There are, for instance, a number of anthologies worth investigating. One of these is ''Subtleties,'' at the Sutton Gallery, 29 West 57th Street, which was organized by Jeffrey Wechsler, and which shares some artists with another group show in the Sachs Gallery at the same address.

title: Man Dies in Leap Off Empire State
description: A 25-year-old man from Austin, Tex., jumped to his death from the 86th floor observation deck of the Empire State Building last night, according to the police.

title: Theater Ticket Availability
description: Following is the ticket availability, at press time, for Broadway shows on Friday, Saturday and Sunday: A Chorus Line : All sections for all performances. American Buffalo : All sections for all performances.

title: A MAIN CRANSTON GOAL: KEEP PARTY ON COURSE
description: Senator Alan Cranston of California is among the first to acknowledge that he is 69 years old, bald and not charismatic: in short, not the usual stuff of Presidential hopefuls.

title: Article 144715 -- No Title
description: Mexico, the developing world's second-largest debtor, received an important vote of confidence yesterday from its commercial bank creditors: The country's 13-bank advisory group agreed to lend Mexico $3.8 billion at sharply lower interest rates than were charged on a $5 billion loan signed last March.

title: Rough Going As the North American Soccer League president,
description: Howard Samuels , continues to try to find investors to pump $500,000 into the troubled Tulsa franchise, three Roughneck players have filed for free agency for nonpayment of salary.

title: SERVED IN HOUSE FOR 25 YEARS
description: William Beck Widnall, a New Jersey Republican who represented northern Bergen County in the House of Representatives for 25 years, died Wednesday in a Ridgewood nursing home after a long illness. He was 77 years old and lived in Saddle River, N.J., until he became ill.

title: U.S.C. Wins
description: Cheryl Miller scored 25 points to lead unbeaten and top-ranked Southern California to a 79-66 victory over Penn State tonight in the first round of the Winston Tire Classic. Penn State (6- 3) led the Trojans (9-0) at the half, 35- 32, but U.S.C. outscored the Nittany Lions by 47-31 in the second half as Pam McGee poured in 12 of her 20 points. In another first-round game, Oregon uspet Maryland, 76-60.

title: Key Rates
description: Nuveen index, John Nuveen & Company Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: THE GUESSING GAME ON 1984 RATES
description: When 1983 began, long-term Treasury bond yields were around 10 1/2 percent and experts were expecting those rates to help blunt any substantial economic recovery from the 1981- 82 recession. Instead, the recovery was stronger than expected, despite slightly higher short-term interest rates and an increase in long-term Treasury yields to nearly 12 percent.

title: PEOPLE'S REPRESENTATIVES
description: To the Editor:

title: Debt Issues
description: * Alaska Airlines Inc. filed an offering of $10 million of 9 percent convertible subordinated debentures due in 2003.

title: A RENAISSANCE AT NASSAU'S LONG BEACH
description: Broadway, the three-mile-long boulevard less than 50 yards from this oceanfront community's beach, is one of those thoroughfares symbolizing a municipality's fortunes.

title: Wilcox Reaches Terms
description: Milt Wilcox , who had an 11-10 record with a 3.97 earned run average last season for Detroit, has reached agreement on a two-year contract with the Tigers, who are expected to announce the signing today, according to a source familiar with the negotiations.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Mark Landsberger , a forward released in the fall by the Los Angeles Lakers, has been signed to a 10-day contract by the Atlanta Hawks. He will fill a vacancy on the roster created when Sly Williams , a former Knick, broke his right foot Tuesday. . . . The Detroit Lions responding to the threat of the rival U.S.F.L., signed Doug English , a defensive tackle, to a three-year pact.

title: EX-JUDGE GETS 20 DAYS IN JAIL
description: John Morrissey, a former Superior Court judge who was cited for drunken driving three times, was sentenced to jail today by a judge who said, ''None of us are above the law.''

title: COURT SAYS OAKLAND CAN PURSUE RAIDERS
description: A State Court of Appeal here gave the City of Oakland a major victory today, ruling that it could pursue its attempt to take over the Los Angeles Raiders under the power of eminent domain.

title: ANDROPOV'S SITUATION: AILING, BUT POLITCALLY STORNG
description: The Supreme Soviet ended its winter session here today with Yuri V. Andropov's empty seat on the podium symbolizing the political uncertainty that has enveloped the country in the face of his prolonged absence. Mr. Andropov has been out of public view for four months, among the longest absences of a Soviet leader since Lenin suffered a stroke in 1923 and moved to the mansion at Gorki, south of Moscow, where he died.

title: SHORT-TERM RATES ARE HIGHER
description: Short-term interest rates were volatile in thin markets yesterday.

title: POP: OUTSETS AND MOFUNGO
description: Two of New York's more tenacious bands, the Outsets and Mofungo, were featured Wednesday at Folk City. Both have built up local followings with frequent appearances in and around Manhattan. Wednesday's show was part of Folk City's weekly Music for Dozens series, which presents triple bills for $3.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE TIME OF THE ASSASSINS. By Claire Sterling. 264 pages. Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $14.95.

title: I.M.F. Moves to End Interest Rate Subsidy
description: The International Monetary Fund would pay higher interest on the money it borrows from rich countries and charge more for the loans it makes to poor countries under a proposal that is expected to be approved within days by the board of governors, according to officials from several countries.

title: A TEEN-AGER'S 'OWN PLACE'
description: Late one recent Saturday evening, as disco music blared in the background and strobe lights cast vivid colors over the jeans, suede boots and sweatshirts of the teen-agers jamming the darkened dance floor of J.D.'s Place, 13-year- old Frank Trosky slunk into position near the center of the crowd.

title: THE VISION OF BOTH ORWELL AND KAFKA IS AS SHARP AS EVER, CONFEREES FIND
description: The novel begins one fine morning with the arrest of Joseph K., a respectable functionary in a bank, and ends with his execution almost 300 pages later, with neither the victim nor the reader any closer to an understanding of his ''crime.''

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday PUPPETRY AND TOUCHING

title: AUCTIONS
description: An art find in a coal shed.

title: WHO'S AT CABARETS, WHAT YOU'LL PAY
description: NEW YORKERS can welcome the New Year with the help of a variety of big names in jazz and cabaret. There will also be some big price tags, although the two do not necessarily go together. A few places may be sold out by now, but it is still possible to make reservations at many.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Fireworks Company Seeks To Add Site on L.I.

title: GALTACO INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After a special charge of $43,000.

title: NCR Sees Gain
description: The NCR Corporation said it expects to have record revenues and earnings in the 1983 fourth quarter. In last year's final period, the company earned $94 million, or $3.47 a share, on revenues of $1.06 billion. NCR, which makes business information processing systems, expects a strong performance in 1984, reflecting an improved economy, further announcements in its next generation of products and the positive acceptance of new products released to date.

title: Economic Scene; An Urgent Call To Cut Deficits
description: THE prospect of huge budget deficits of $200 billion a year or more for the rest of this decade came under virtually unanimous condemnation this week at the annual meeting of the American Economic Association. One major danger is that the deficits are beginning to feed on themselves as the rising burden of financing the debt drives interest rates higher, which in turn causes deficits to grow faster.

title: Arafat to Go to Tunis For Meeting of Fatah
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization leader, Yasir Arafat, will go to Tunis to convene a meeting of the Central Committee of his Fatah movement in about 48 hours, his spokesman said today.

title: Gulf United Stake Sold by Charter JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 29 (Reuters) - The Charter Company said it had sold 2.9 million shares of Gulf United Corporation stock, or about 10 percent of the company's shares oustanding, A Charter spokesman declined to comment on the sale.
description: Earlier in the day, a block of 2,947,300 shares was crossed jointly on the New York Stock Exchange by Salomon Brothers and Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: DRINKING AND DRIVING: THE LAW-DRAWN LINE
description: To the Editor:

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: IT was not, as some of the uninvited

title: SOUTH AFRICAN OFFICER GUILTY OF SPYING
description: A South African naval officer and his wife have been convicted of spying for the Soviet Union, the country's supreme court announced today.

title: 14 Laotians Recovering From Poisonous Plant
description: Only two of the 14 Laotian immigrants sickened by poisonous mushrooms they picked in the California wine country remained hospitalized today and doctors said both would survive.

title: Recent Middle East Terrorism
description: April 18. Oct. 23.

title: DEMOCRATS URGE $5.7 BILLION RISE IN AID TO SCHOOLS
description: The Democratic leadership of the Assembly yesterday proposed to increase education aid $5.7 billion in New York State over the next five years, mainly in programs for less-affluent districts.

title: O'NEILL CONSIDERS BACKING A CHANGE IN MARINE MISSION
description: The Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., is reconsidering his support for the 18-month limit that Congress set for the Marine deployment in Beirut, an aide said today.

title: Southwestern Bell In $900 Million Deal
description: The Southwestern Bell Telephone Company said yesterday that it had received a contract valued at $900 million to provide a variety of billing and collection services for A.T.& T. Communications Inc., the long-distance subsidiary of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: SCOUTING
description: Double Duties

title: Have Carpetbag, Will Travel
description: If the Rev. Jesse Jackson, just for the asking, obtains the release of Lieut. Robert O. Goodman Jr. from a Syrian prison, what could that possibly mean? It could mean that Syria's President Assad has good policy reasons to make a gesture to the United States. In that case, Mr. Jackson's journey is superfluous. Or it could mean that Syria desires to further antagonize the Reagan Administration by going over its head with a gesture to the American people. In that case Mr. Jackson's role would be contemptible.

title: Julie Berns, Comedy Writer; Worked in Theater and Radio
description: Julie Berns, who wrote comedies for the Yiddish- and English-speaking theaters and for radio, died at her home in Mahopac, N.Y., on Wednesday. She was 84 years old.

title: CHRIS-CRAFT WARNER IN STOCK DEAL
description: Chris-Craft Industries plans to acquire more than 25 percent of Warner Communications Inc., and Warner will acquire a 42.5 percent stake in Chris-Craft's television subsidiary, the two companies said yesterday. The subsidiary, BHC, is the fourth- largest non-network-owned television broadcast company in the nation, in terms of the number of homes served.

title: Hines Marathon
description: WKCR, 89.9 FM, is presenting a marathon of the jazz piano of Earl Hines, including rare recordings, all weekend; the program will continue around the clock until Thursday.

title: HONDURAS FOR PEACE IN CENTRAL AMERICA
description: To the Editor:

title: 5 AWAIT CHARGES
description: Court- martial proceedings opened today against nine leaders of Argentina's former military Government. They are accused of ordering murders, mass torture and other abuses against thousands of Argentine civilians.

title: THE CHICAGO COMPROMISE: BUDGET BREAKS NEW GROUND
description: It was a historic event for this city when Mayor Harold Washington and the City Council threshed out a compromise 1984 budget earlier this week.

title: CONCERT: STRING ORCHESTRA
description: The New York String Orchestra, an ad hoc ensemble consisting of excellent young players between 15 and 22 years old, presented a program of music by Brahms and Beethoven in Carnegie Hall Thursday night, under the direction of Alexander Schneider.

title: A HEALING OF THE RIFT
description: Anyone who thought that the battle of the sexes was resolved in 1983 will have much to think about in 1984.

title: DOROTHY C. M'NAB
description: Dorothy Cumming McNab, an actress who portrayed the Virgin in Cecil B. DeMille's silent film ''The King of Kings'' in 1927, died of pneumonia on Dec. 10 at the DeWitt Nursing Home in Manhattan, it became known yesterday. She was 84 years old. She is survived by a son, Anthony Cumming, of Albuquerque, N.M., and three grandchildren.

title: Gator Bowl to Florida, 14-6
description: Neal Anderson's 1-yard touchdown run capped an 87-yard drive in the first quarter and Doug Drew recovered a fumbled snap by the Iowa punter for a second-period score to help Florida win a chilly Gator Bowl game, 14-6, tonight.

title: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26

Economy Aid In Argentina BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 30 (Reuters) - Argentina's newly elected Government today announced short- term measures, effective Sunday, that are aimed at reducing inflation while at the same time increasing real wages and reactivating the depressed economy.
description: Bernardo Grinspun, the economy minister, told a news conference that Government-controlled interest rates will be reduced to 12.5 percent monthly, from 15.5 percent, on loans of more than 30 days. Interest rates on deposits of more than 30 days will fall to 11.5 percent monthly, from 14.5 percent, he added. Meanwhile, all salaries will automatically be raised 12 percent to absorb inflation - forecast at about 10 percent in January after an estimated 30 percent in December - and provide a small increase in real wages, he said.

title: Telephone Contracts Completed
description: Contracts between A.T.&T. Communications Inc. and the seven new regional telephone companies to provide a variety of long-distance billing and collection services for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company were completed yesterday.

title: PAUL DEMAN
description: Paul de Man, Sterling Professor of Humanities and chairman of the comparative literature department at Yale University, died of cancer Dec. 21 at Yale-New Haven Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived in Woodbridge, Conn.

title: TO FIGHT GROWINGN USE OF COCAINE IN NEW YORK
description: After the snow and cold of this December are long forgotten, many Americans will still be caught in a blizzard of sorts. Use of cocaine - ''snow'' - is spreading throughout the nation at a terrible cost to society.

title: Diebold Chief's Medical Leave
description: Diebold Inc. said yesterday that Earl F. Wearstler, president and chief executive officer, had taken an indefinite medical leave of absence because of problems following open heart surgery earlier this year. Mr. Wearstler, 59 years old, was named company president in 1981.

title: MINNEAPOLIS GETS RIGHTS LAW TO BAN PORNOGRAPHY
description: The Minneapolis City Council voted today to change the city's civil rights ordinance to define pornography as a form of sexual discrimination against women.

title: Sobering Rules for New Year's Eve
description: Who possesses the most power to reduce driving by drunks? State legislators, governors, members of Congress and even the President of the United States are making welcome efforts. Still, their power is slight beside that of a lesser functionary: the party host.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The TV Weekend column yesterday misidentified the orchestra playing for the New Year's Eve celebration at the Waldorf-Astoria. It is the Bill Lombardo Orchestra.

title: MUSIC: PROKOFIEV BY MINTZ
description: For all of music's potential profundity, for all its power to represent ideas in sound, it may be most potent when it is most immediate, when it seems to arise without reflection, on the spur of the moment, as if it were a purely natural expression, like a sigh or an exclamation.

title: Dr.FloydH.Black,95,Headed CollegesinIstanbulandSofia
description: Dr. Floyd H. Black, who was president of colleges in Istanbul, Turkey, and Sofia, Bulgaria, died Wednesday at the Princeton (N.J.) Nursing Home.

title: RANGERS THRASH FLYERS
description: The Rangers picked apart the Philadelphia Flyers last night at Madison Square Garden, blending opportunistic offense and stingy defense for a 6-3 victory in one of their most thorough games of the season. It was reminiscent of their three-game sweep of the Flyers in the opening round of last season's playoffs.

title: FULL U.S. TIES WITH VATICAN EXPECTED SOON
description: President Reagan is expected to establish full diplomatic relations with the Vatican and ''in all likelihood'' send a representative there with the rank of ambassador, an Administration official said today.

title: Disputed Tax Bill Is Paid by Libyans
description: After a year of lawsuits and protests, the Libyan Mission to the United Nations has paid, ''under protest,'' more than $16,000 in taxes to Englewood, N.J., according to the mission's attorney, Robert W. Thabit.

title: Required Reading Footing the Bill
description: Through its grant and contract activity, the Federal Government indirectly pays millions of dollars for political advocacy by both business and nonprofit groups. For example, Community Services Administration grantees have prepared sample letters for constituents to oppose Administration budget proposals, have urged readers of a grantee magazine to write their Congressmen to oppose curtailment of the food stamp programs and have circulated memos urging Congressmen to support continuance of the Health Planning Program.

title: UNION TO CHALLENGE KUHN'S DRUG ABUSE BANS
description: The Major League Baseball Players Association has decided to challenge the one-year suspensions that Commissioner Bowie Kuhn imposed on four players earlier this month for their involvement with illegal drugs.

title: Weirton Steel Sale Is Backed WEIRTON, W. Va., Dec. 30 (AP) - A Federal appeals court has cleared the way for the sale of Weirton Steel to its workers in what will be the nation's largest employee stock takeover, Weirton's vice president, Carl Valdiserri, said. He said the principals in the case were notified that the court had upheld a ruling that the takeover will not force Weirton's parent company, the National Steel Corporation, to pay ''shutdown pensions'' and severance benefits.
description: The ruling means the purchase of Weirton from National Steel, a subsidiary of National Intergroup, can take place as scheduled, Mr. Valdiserri said. Jan. 10 has been set as a tentative closing date for the sale. The suit that prompted the ruling was brought by a handful of Weirton employees who argued that the takeover should be considered a ''shutdown'' or ''laying off'' of National employees, allowing them supplemental benefits.

title: No Headline
description: Lucy Jean Boyd Weds

title: 800 Exams Lost; Retests Planned
description: About 800 students will be retested on writing because their essays were lost, according to state officials.

title: BAPTIST TEAM BALKS AT FACING CATHOLICS
description: When a Roman Catholic school found out that a Baptist school had strict rules on skirt length, it told its cheerleaders to stay home from an upcoming basketball game. But when the Baptist school found out that its rival was Catholic, it canceled the game altogether.

title: Rebels Say They Killed 100 Moroccan Troops
description: The Polisario Front said today that its guerrillas attacked Moroccan forces in the Western Sahara on Thursday, killing more than 100 men and destroying 60 vehicles.

title: No Headline
description: Juana Duty Is Married

title: REP. ADDABBO: THE CITY'S DEAN IN THE HOUSE
description: On the sprawling lawn at the home of Robert J. Carlson, the president of the United Technologies Corporation, the guest of honor at a recent shrimp and champagne reception was Representative Joseph P. Addabbo.

title: SALVADOR REBELS OVERRUN ON ARMY BASE
description: Salvadoran guerrillas overran an army base 40 miles north of the capital today and held it for six hours before withdrawing. It was the first time in the four- year-old civil war that the insurgents had overrun a major army installation.

title: AT CAPITOL, IT'S HELLO, CENTRAL, 22,000 TIMES A DAY
description: Many are the evenings on which the people who run the Capitol's telephone information switchboard, one of the most sensitive barometers of public opinion, do not need to watch television to know something important has happened.

title: BRIEFING
description: Nicaragua Upheaval

title: COMPUTER FACTORY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $93,000. c-Net income.

title: Skydiver Falls to His Death As Two Daughters Look On
description: A skydiver whose main parachute failed to open fell 3,000 feet to his death Thursday, minutes after his two teen-age daughters successfully jumped from the plane.

title: All God's Children
description: More than wind blows from the great glass cave called the United Nations. Each year brings a report called ''The State of the World's Children,'' prepared by a dedicated and effective specialized agency, the Children's Fund, or Unicef. It is a welcome document in a season in which the world organization's many failures bring into undeserved disrepute the very notion that sovereign nations can collaborate to address life's afflictions.

title: GONE WITH THE PHILCO
description: It's New Year's Eve, and he wakes up feeling blue. He's seen too many New Year's Eves now and he's jaded with them and he hates that - being jaded, I mean. He hates people saying he's ''jaded'' with this and that, has hated it ever since he told Ben Cooper he never wanted to see another ''I Love Lucy'' as long as he lived, and Ben said, ''You've become jaded.''

title: Ballet Director Quits
description: Ian Horvath, a founder of the Cleveland Ballet, has resigned as artistic director of the company. Dennis Nahat, co-founder of the eight-year- old company and its chief choreographer, will assume sole responsibility for its artistic direction. Mr. Horvath will continue to work with the Cleveland Ballet on specific future projects.

title: OVER 300 GRENADIANS ARE BEING HELD IN PRISON WITHOUT CHARGES
description: More than 30 Grenadians detained after the United States-led invasion two months ago remain in prison here without formal charges, and the authorities say they cannot yet name a date when the legal process will begin.

title: Mary King and Lowell Gruman, Bankers, Marry
description: Mary Noel King, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Forbes King of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to Lowell Jepson Gruman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Laurence L. Gruman of Eugene, Ore. The ceremony was performed by the bridegroom's father, a United Church of Christ minister, and the Rev. Victor Sivore, a Roman Catholic priest, at St. John's Roman Catholic Church in Darien.

title: A LUSTER FOR TRADITION
description: A less rigid, more free-flowing kind of party will permeate the entertainment scene this coming year, and accompanying it will be a return to what could be called traditional, or even old-fashioned, mores.

title: Depositors Corp. Merger Delayed AUGUSTA, Me., Dec. 30 (Reuters) - The Depositors Corporation said its proposed merger into Key Banks Inc. of Albany had been delayed by requests for a public hearing. The requests were made by the Casco-Northern Corporation, a bank- holding company in Portland, and the Bank of Boston. John Donovan, Casco-Northern's treasurer, said his company had requested the hearing because it believes reciprocity does not exist between New York and Maine on interstate banking.
description: In August, Maine's Attorney General ruled against the Bank of Boston's proposed acquisition of Casco- Northern, saying there was not reciprocity between Massachusetts and Maine. Mr. Donovan said the Attorney General had ruled that only states with laws identical to Maine's interstate banking statute could operate in the state. He said Casco-Northern had requested a hearing in the Depositors case as a way of asking the Maine banking superintendent whether reciprocity exists with New York.

title: SCOUTING
description: King of the Sires

title: Rath Contract Is Invalidated
description: A Federal bankruptcy court judge invalidated the Rath Packing Company's contract with Local 46 of the United Food and Commercial Workers Union. The decision by Judge William Thinnes will allow the meatpacker to keep wages at the current level of $7.24 an hour for its 1,800 Waterloo workers.

title: Mary K. Wilson Wed To Kenneth R. Levin
description: Mary Kay Wilson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dudley Wilson of Houston, was married there yesterday to Kenneth Robert Levin, son of Stuart Levin and Dorothy Levin, both of New York. Associate Justice Lee Duggan Jr. of the Texas First Court of Appeals performed the ceremony at the La Colombe d'Or restaurant.

title: Bankers Expect Fast Approval for Mexico Loan
description: Regional bankers in the United States were optimistic yesterday about the chances of a speedy and complete subscription to a $3.8 billion loan for Mexico, even though the terms are much less lucrative than in the last such package.

title: Kaiser Realty Sale
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said it had sold a 28- story office tower, the Ordway Building, in Oakland, Calif., to an affiliate of the JMB Realty Corporation for $76.6 million.

title: Arafat Goes to Tunis For Series of Meetings
description: Yasir Arafat arrived here today for the first of a series of meetings intended to redefine policy.

title: TIMERMAN SAYS HE INTENDS TO BRING TORTURERS TO JUSTICE
description: Jacobo Timerman, the writer and former Argentine newspaper publisher, says he has decided to return to Argentina for two reasons: to try to get his newspaper back, and to bring to justice those who tortured him when he was in custody in the 1970's.

title: French Prices Rise
description: Wholesale prices in France rose 1.9 percent in November from a month earlier, and were up 14.8 percent from November 1982, the National Statistics Institute said Thursday. The rise was the largest since a 1.9 percent rise in August.

title: RIGGINS IN LEAGUE BY HIMSELF
description: The distinctive John Riggins, who set a National Football League record with 24 touchdowns this season at the age of 34 and carried the ball 115 more times than he ever had before, explained today the philosophy that has nurtured him through this stage of his life.

title: Generals Sign Two 49er Linebackers
description: On the day before the San Francisco 49ers' divisional playoff game against the Detroit Lions, the New Jersey Generals announced today that they had signed two of the 49ers' veteran linebackers, Willie Harper and Bobby Leopold, for the United States Football League season that begins Feb. 26.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Sound pollution control and emergency-preparedness policies depend on the knowledge of industrial hazardous waste-disposal practices. No systematic industrial survey has been undertaken to ascertain industry's hazardous waste-disposal practices over the past 30 years.'' - Governor Cuomo. (1:4.)

title: JUDGE YIELDS TO KOCH ON JUDICIAL PANEL APPOINTEES
description: Prodded by Mayor Koch, an administrative judge who had selected only whites over six years to fill his six slots on the Mayor's Committee on the Judiciary has submitted a new list that includes one black and two Hispanic appointees.

title: No Headline
description: Antitumor Agents

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP $1.6 BILLION
description: Disappointing many participants in the money markets, the Federal Reserve System announced yesterday that the basic measure of the nation's money supply rose $1.6 billion in the week that ended Dec. 21, well above market estimates.

title: Cutting Off Lawyers, and Law
description: The Reagan Administration, which keeps trying to dismantle legal services for the poor, is also after legal services for the non-poor - ordinary citizens who seek access to the courts for civil rights, environmental and consumer cases.

title: GOOD YEAR ENDS QUIETLY
description: The stock market ended one of its best years in history yesterday with minor price changes in less active trading.

title: DIGILOG INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Zimbabwean Air Officer Says He Was Tortured
description: Three white Zimbabwean Air Force officers released from detention in Harare a week ago flew into Britain today, and one said he had been tortured.

title: EASY, SPARE AND MUTED ARE 3 MAJOR THEMES
description: When Giorgio Armani presented his collection at the end of the spring resort showings in Milan, he focused on a look that had not been emphasized in fashion for a long time: the look of men's clothes for women.

title: CLOTHES THAT KEEP WATER OUT
description: SOME things are waterproof and

title: JACKSON IN SYRIA SETS UP 3 MEETINGS
description: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria has agreed to meet Saturday with the Rev. Jesse Jackson, the civil rights leader and candidate for the Democatic Presidential nomination, who arrived here tonight to seek the release of a captured United States flier.

title: BONN SAYS MISSILES ARE READY TO FIRE
description: The first 9 of 108 advanced Pershing nuclear missiles to be deployed in West Germany are now fully operational, the Defense Ministry announced today.

title: ALLIANZ YIELDS B.A.T. IN FIGHT FOR EAGLE STAR
description: B.A.T Industries, a major tobacco and retailing concern, has apparently won the most expensive takeover battle in British history by bidding just over $1.4 billion for Eagle Star Holdings, the nation's sixth-largest insurer.

title: CITY'S RAIN: '83 RECORD IS IN DOUBT
description: The heavy rains that pounded New York City during 1983 may not have broken the annual rainfall record here, after all, the National Weather Service said yesterday. The only thing broken for certain, it said, was the official rain gauge in Central Park.

title: JETS TOP ISLANDERS IN OVERTIME
description: Paul MacLean's second goal of the game 29 seconds into overtime gave the Winnipeg Jets a 4-3 victory over the Islanders tonight.

title: No Headline
description: New Drafting Advance

title: ; DON'T LET RESTORATION STOP AT MISS LIBERTY
description: To the Editor:

title: CONTRIBUTOR TO NEEDIEST CITES CASE OF ALZHEIMER'S DISEASE
description: Many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund say their donations have been inspired by case histories of those who have received help from the charities benefited by the fund.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 16.

title: Gregg Knows Aides
description: Familiar faces continue to surface for Coach Forrest Gregg as he filled out his coaching staff with the Green Bay Packers, adding Hank Bullough as defensive coordinator, Dick Modzelewski as defensive line coach and Bob Schnelker as offensive coordinator. Bullough and Modzelewski both served in the same posts on Gregg's staff at Cincinnati before Gregg decided last week to give up that coaching job to take over at Green Bay, succeeding Bart Starr .

title: BEIRUT'S ENVOY DOUBTS VALUE OF MARINES' ROLE
description: Lebanon's Ambassador to the United States said this week that his Government wished the United States Marines had never been sent to Beirut. But he added that if the Marines were to be withdrawn now, his Government ''may really collapse.''

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 39.

title: Diagram Bridge: Few Indeed Are Confronted By Certain Tricky Situations
description: There are some bidding situations that are so rare that most players would not encounter them in a bridge lifetime. Suppose you open the bidding with a natural bid of one of a suit and then rebid the suit.

title: JUDGE VOIDS RULE ON FEDERAL PAY
description: A Federal district judge today blocked new Reagan Administration regulations aimed at linking job performance to the pay and job security of 1.4 million white- collar Federal employees.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Weekend yesterday, about pop and rock performances on New Year's Eve, was accompanied by an outdated photograph of Manhattan Transfer. Laurel Masse, the woman at the left, is no longer with the group. The others shown - Tim Hauser, Janis Siegel and Alan Paul - have since been joined by Cheryl Bentyne.

title: Prediction: What'll Be The Big Events of '83?
description: The Procrastinators Club of America has issued its predictions for 1983.

title: Profit for Thai Airways
description: Thai Airways International, the national carrier, said it had a pretax profit of $28.4 million for the fiscal year ended Sept. 30. A spokesman said Thursday that it was the carrier's 19th consecutive profitable year, with earnings this year exceeding the previous record of $22.4 million in the 1979 fiscal year.

title: WOMEN, MOVE TO LONDON
description: When American women complain about male-chauvinist Britain, they remind me that Anglo-American differences are almost as interesting as the difference between the sexes. So alike and yet so alien. Why can't a woman be more like a man? Why can't London be more like New York?

title: JUDGE BARS ACCESS TO NIXON PAPERS
description: A Federal district judge today blocked the Government's plans to give the public access to 1.5 million of the most confidential documents that were in the White House when President Nixon resigned in 1974.

title: ATI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $25,284. c-Net income including an extraordinary credit of $396,153.

title: AMERICAN RECREATION CENERS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 23
ADDING OF 4,000 SPACES IS VOTED FOR CITY'S JAILS
description: A $277 million plan to build nearly 4,000 new jail spaces was approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate by a vote of 10 to 1.

title: BELL RINGING OUT THE OLD SYSTEM
description: -shirts bearing a weeping Alexander Graham Bell and the inscription ''Breaking Up Is Hard To Do'' have been selling briskly at $6 apiece at various Bell System offices in the last few weeks. When glasses are clinked in New Year's toasts tonight, Bell employees will doubtlessly be more wistful than most partygoers.

title: Books of The Times
description: TRACKING THE MARVELOUS: A Life in

title: The '83 Market
description: Economic recovery, a rebound in corporate earnings and greater confidence about the future brought strong gains in 1983 for all the major barometers of stock prices.

title:
PATENTS ;
Device Alerts Doctors To Heartbeat Dangers
description: An electrocardiograph instrument designed to alert doctors to patients who, after heart attacks, are subject to life-threatening periods of excessively rapid heartbeats, has been invented by Dr. Michael B. Simson, director of the intensive care unit at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia.

title: Indiana Tops Boston College
description: Marty Simmons hit a pair of free throws and grabbed two offensive rebounds in the final 30 seconds tonight as Indiana defeated Boston College, 72-66, to capture the Hoosier Classic.

title: Powell Out of Bowl
description: Henry Lawrence , the Los Angeles Raider tackle, has been added to the American Football Conference Pro Bowl squad to replace Marvin Powell of the Jets. Powell received permission from Commissioner Pete Rozelle to miss the game when he was accepted to the spring term of the New York School of Law. Powell has been voted to the A.F.C. Pro Bowl team five times.

title: HOLLINGS EMPHASIZING A FREEZE ON SPENDING
description: The New York Times today publishes an interview with Senator Ernest F. Hollings, another in a series of interviews with candidates for the Presidency.

title: HIGH-LEVEL TALKS WITH THE RUSSIANS TO RESUME JAN. 18
description: The United States and the Soviet Union will resume high-level talks on Jan. 18 in Stockholm, the State Department said today.

title: FLANIGAN'S ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: b-Net income.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Watching Ships

title: Conroy Cleared On Liquidation SAN ANTONIO, Dec. 30 (Reuters) - Conroy Inc. said shareholders at its annual meeting had approved a plan to liquidate the company. Also approved was the sale of its O'Sullivan Industries subsidiary to the Tandy Corporation for $91.5 million, which Conroy completed after the meeting.
description: O'Sullivan makes consumer electronic stands and cabinetry. In addition, shareholders approved the sale of Conroy's boat manufacturing operations for $7.5 million and the sale of Conroy's other assets.

title: Court Rules Newspaper May Sue Another
description: The First District Court of Appeal ruled today that newspaper writers could be sued for libel.

title: Pilot Aborts Jet Flight After Storms Pound It
description: Violent thunderstorms pounded a Piedmont Airlines Boeing 737 jet like ''a piece of balsa wood'' on Thursday, forcing the pilot to abort Flight 330 and return to Tampa International Airport.

title: OUSTER OF SCHOOLS CHIEF STIRS PASSIONS ON UPPER WEST SIDE
description: In the two and a half years that Jack Berberian Jr. has been superintendent of Community School District 3 on the Upper West Side, reading and mathematics scores have increased, attendance has risen, disruptive incidents in schools have declined and most principals say their morale has improved.

title: SCOUTING
description: Youth Triumphs Over Seniority

title: VANZETTI SYSTEMS reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Barbara L. Yetka Becomes a Bride
description: Barbara L. Yetka, president and chief executive officer of the Interfaith Medical Center of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Dr. M. Michael Eisenberg, professor of medicine and vice chairman of the department of surgery at the State University of New York Downstate Medical Center and director of surgery at Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn. The Rev. Richard D. Leonard, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony in the chapel at the Church Center for the United Nations.

title: A Magic New Year's Eve
description: A New Year's Eve celebration with magic is planned tonight at Mostly Magic, 55 Carmine Street.

title: Rose Kennedy Hospitalized
description: Rose Kennedy has been admitted at St. Mary's Hospital and will remain there ''at least for the next few days'' for treatment of a viral infection, a hospital spokesman said today. Mrs. Kennedy, the 93-year-old matriarch of the Kennedy family, was admitted Thursday after doctors feared she was suffering from bronchitis or pneumonia, the spokeman said, adding that she was ''stable and responding well to treatment.''

title: Unesco Chief Regrets U.S. Withdrawal Move
description: The head of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization expressed regret today at the decision of the United States to withdraw from the agency, which is based here.

title: NEBRASKA HAS BEST BACKFIELD
description: Notre Dame's 1924 backfield is probably the best-known four-man unit in the history of football just because Grantland Rice gave it the name of the Four Horsemen. The individuals are not as well remembered as the group, which consisted of Harry Stuhldreher, Jim Crowley, Elmer Layden and Don Miller. The Irish were undefeated that year and beat Stanford, 27-10, in the Rose Bowl with this excellent backfield working behind a fine line that gained the nickname the Seven Mules. Three of the Four Horsemen were consensus all-America choices, and Miller would probably have been, too, except for an impressive Illinois back named Red Grange.

title: Gas Producer Plea Denied WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) - Chief Justice Warren E. Burger today refused to block a Federal court order expected to lead to refunds to natural gas consumers nationwide.
description: The Chief Justice left intact a Federal appeals court ruling that natural gas prices since 1978 have been illegally higher than they should be.

title: FRANCE EXPELS 5 IRANIAN STUDENTS, REPORTEDLY TRAINED AS TERRORISTS
description: France expelled five Iranians on Thursday, and diplomats here said they were trained terrorists who had long been under the surveillance of French counterintelligence units.

title: A CRISIS IN HOUSING THAT DESERVES OFFICIAL CANDOR
description: To the Editor:

title: MOTHERS OF MISSING WON'T GIVE UP IN ARGENTINA
description: The dictatorship ended nearly three weeks ago when the military stepped down from power, but the mothers who represent some of the thousands of people who disappeared under the military continue their vigil.

title: U.S. Gives Medical Schools Year to Meet Rule on Loans
description: The Government, responding to bitter complaints, announced today that it was giving medical schools another year to meet Federal standards for collecting on student loans or face a cutoff of loan funds.

title: Progress Report
description: Auburn's coach, Pat Dye , who recruited the first black football player at the University of Alabama in 1969, says black athletes in the South are becoming more interested in getting an education, not just participating in a sport. ''We've had to take some borderline students at Auburn in the past, but I can see in the near future us not having to take borderline students,'' Dye said yesterday.

title: ISRAELIS CLOSE OFF SOUTH LEBANON FROM NORTH EARLIER THAN NORMAL
description: The Israeli Army today closed down the crossing points between northern Lebanon and the Israeli-occupied south.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Sports People column yesterday misstated Ted Turner's role in a dispute between a yacht that had been run aground and the yacht accused of being responsible. He skippered Condor, the grounded yacht.

title: Second Finisher Declared Winner
description: A protest jury today disqualified Nirvana, which had been the first yacht to finish the 638-mile Sydney-to- Hobart race, and gave line honors instead to the second-place finisher, Condor.

title: CONCERN FOR THE BLACK FAMILY: ATTENTION TURNS TO MEN
description: Studies of the black family, enough to fill the shelves of a good-size library, focus almost entirely on women. In much of history and sociology, black men, particularly from the ranks of the poor, are ignored.

title: JOSEPH P. KASPER
description: Joseph P. Kasper, an executive vice president of R. H. Macy & Company from 1928 to 1944 and president and chairman of the board of the Associated Merchandising Corporation from 1944 to 1962, died of heart disease Wednesday at his home in Sarasota, Fla.

title: 100 Seized in Uruguay After Soldiers Charge
description: Riot troops and mounted policemen charged into a crowd demonstrating against Uruguay's 10- year-old military Government on Thursday night and arrested about 100 people, witnesses said.

title: FARM PRICES JUMP 3.7%
description: The prices farmers received for raw products jumped 3.7 percent in December, the sharpest increase in four months, leaving farm prices at the end of 1983 an average of 10 percent higher than a year ago, the Agriculture Department reported today.

title: TEEN TENNIS STAR TRAVELING TO TOP
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I.

title: Katharine H. Coleman And Mark Cigolle Wed
description: Katharine Hill Coleman and Mark Cigolle, both architects, were married yesterday at the home of the bride's grandmother, Dorothy Nicholson, in Greenwich, Conn. The ceremony was performed by Probate Judge Cameron F. Hopper.

title: ARMSTRONG LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
description: b-Net loss after an extraordinary loss of $17,406. c-Including an extraordinary gain of $66,501.

title: Defense Contracts WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (Reuters) - The Vought Corporation, a subsidiary of the LTV Corporation, received an $82.7 million Army contract for parts for a multiple-launching rocket system, the Defense Department said. In addition, it said The United Technologies Corporation's Sikorsky Aircraft division had been given a $30.4 million Navy contract for 11 helicopters.
description: PU COMPNEWS FOLOS

title: Coleco Plans 5-Day Layoff Coleco Industries said it plans temporary layoffs next week at its plants in Amsterdam, N.Y., while it completes its year-end inventory.
description: The layoffs are expected to last about five days, said Mort Handel, vice president.

title: FreeJerseyTransit For Holiday Eve
description: The N.J. Transit Corporation will offer free bus and rail service throughout New Jersey for 12 hours starting at 6 P.M. New Year's Eve in an effort to discourage drunken driving, the state mass-transit agency has announced.

title: Bach Festival to Greet '84
description: The Brooklyn Bach Festival will herald the New Year with a performance tonight, beginning at 9, in the First Unitarian Church, Pierrepont Street and Monroe Place.

title: Mark C. McCloy Weds Elizabeth H. Keppler
description: Elizabeth Helen Keppler, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Burns Keppler of Garden City and Westhampton Beach, L.I., was married yesterday to Mark Charles McCloy, son of William Joseph McCloy Jr., also of Garden City, and the late Rita McCloy. The Rev. Ralph E. Ahlberg, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at the Garden City Community Church, assisted by Msgr.

title: DOLPHINS' MAIN JOB IS HALTING WARNER
description: Curt Warner ran for more than 100 yards in 6 of the Seattle Seahawks' 16 regular-season games and for 99 in their wild-card game Christmas Eve against the Denver Broncos. The Seahawks' record in those games was 7-0.

title: SCOUTING
description: A Special Breed

title: 'His Own Man'
description: Sam Wyche , hired Wednesday as head coach of the Cincinnati Bengals, told reporters yesterday that he would make his own decisions but would still seek advice from General Manager Paul Brown . Brown and Wyche, who was introduced to Cincinnati reporters at a news conference at Riverfront Stadium, took time to respond to speculation that Wyche would be a puppet coach under Brown, a former coach for whom Wyche played as a backup quarterback from 1968 to 1970.

title: SCI-MED LIFE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $93,000 for the quarter and $242,000 for the 9 months. c-Including a tax credit of $59,000.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS Football
description: Dolphins vs. Seattle Seahawks, American Conference semifinal, at Miami. Don Shula of the Dolphins has a reputation as a coach with few equals, but he'll have a keen rival today in Chuck Knox. Dan Marino returns at quarterback for Miami, having missed the last two regular-season games because of a knee injury. Much of Seattle's offense will be provided by another rookie, Curt Warner, who led the conference in rushing. (Television - Channel 4, 12:30 P.M. Radio - WCBS, 880; 12:15 P.M.)

title: NICARAGUA INDIANS' STRUGGLE
description: The Sandinista Government's recent offer of general amnesty for Miskito Indian prisoners and refugees and its recognition of past policy ''mistakes'' land reform are important conditions for peace negotiations involving the return of Indian land. If the Sandinistas can settle their dispute with the Indians, they will avoid embarrassing censure by human rights organizations and gain a formidable ally in the fight against the anti-Sandinista Contras in eastern Nicaragua.

title: Masque at Columbia
description: Ben Jonson's 17th-century masque ''The Vision of Delight'' will be performed this weekend by the Capricorn Theater Company, with soloists, at Columbia University's Casa Italiana, Amsterdam Avenue at 117th Street.

title: Massachusetts Planning Tests for Grain Tainting
description: Massachusetts health officials, following Florida's lead, say they will begin testing grain-based foods next week for contamination with the cancer-causing pesticide ethylene dibromide.

title: Your MoneyLeonard Sloane New Breeds Of Unit Trusts
description: -growing investment categories in 1983 was unit investment trusts; equally notable was the number of new types of unit trusts that first appeared or made a major impact during the year.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: American Can Co., Greenwich, Conn., said it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire the Harmony Hut division of Schwartz Brothers Inc. for about $8 million. Harmony Hut is a retailer of prerecorded music, video software, audio equipment and related products.

title: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 31, 1983 International
description: -Soviet high-level talks will resume on Jan. 18 in Stockholm, the State Department announced. Department officials said they expected the discussions to include arms control and all other outstanding issues. Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko have agreed to meet that day while they are both in the Swedish capital. (Page 1, Column 6.) Full diplomatic ties with the Vatican are expected to be established by President Reagan, who will ''in all likelihood'' send a representative there with the rank of ambassdor, an Administration official said. (1:5.)

title: GULF SEEN VICTOR IN PROXY VOTE
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation appeared yesterday to have won a clear victory over T. Boone Pickens Jr., the Texas oilman who is trying to break up the nation's sixth-largest oil company.

title: STATE EASES ITS SUSPENSION OF YONKERS SCHOOLS' SPORTS
description: One day after suspending the public school sports program here, the State Department of Education today lifted that ban, at least temporarily.

title: Florida St. Wins, 28-3
description: Eric Thomas of Florida State, a sophomore making his first collegiate start, stunned North Carolina with a pair of first-quarter touchdown passes to Weegie Thompson and led the Seminoles to a 28-3 victory over the Tar Heels today in the 16th annual Peach Bowl.

title: Swedish, Danish Trade By The Associated Press
description: Sweden's current account in October swung to a deficit equivalent to $12.4 million, from a surplus of that amount in September, Sveriges Riksbank, the central bank, said Thursday. Separately, the Danish Bureau of Statistics said Denmark's international dealings in merchandise and services would show a surplus of about $1 billion this year.

title: HORRO ON ROAD HOME
description: Nikki Rasmussen and his wife, Theresa, whose trip had been plagued by icy roads, saw it turn into what he called a ''nightmarish movie'' Thursday when a pickup truck repeatedly rammed them until Mr. Rasmussen fired on the vehicle with his pistol.

title: A Chance for Wills
description: Maury Wills , the former Los Angeles Dodger shortstop, could be eligible for a drug-diversion program that could lead to charges against him being dropped. Al Albergate , the public information officer for the District Attorney's office in Compton, Calif., said that if Wills had no previous drug offenses and proved he had no intention of selling drugs, he could be eligible for the program.

title: Law on Contraceptives Struck Down in Utah
description: A Federal district judge today struck down a state law requiring pharmacists to notify parents of teen-agers who try to buy contraceptives.

title: CITY-PACED HONESTY
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: 48 Hours

title: COLUMBIA STUDENT RETURNED TO ROLLS BY RULING OF COURT
description: In the fall of 1982, a 57-year-old Columbia University graduate student named William Harris was expelled from the doctoral program after a long dispute over his university-owned apartment.

title: COMMUNICATIONS GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, DECEMBER 31, 1983
description: Companies

title: HOLLIGS MAIN FOCUS IS ON NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: Watching him standing alone and unrecognized, without the political phalanx of advisers and coat-holders in a ticket line at Boston's Logan Airport, getting an aisle seat because he needs the leg room - the impression was that his quest was quixotic.

title: IMPROVED INTERRELIGIOUS TIES
description: Rabbi Morris N. Kertzer, a leader in strengthening relations between Jews and Christians, died of a heart ailment Thursday at his retirement home in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 73 years old.

title: AN INTERVIEW WITH ERNEST F. HOLLINGS, A 'CENTRIST' IN POLITICS
description: Following are key questions and answers from an interview with Senator Ernest F. Hollings by William E. Farrell:

title: Earthquakes Strike Japan
description: Four earthquakes shook Tokyo and other parts of central Japan today, and 10 temblors rattled Izu Oshima, an island south of the capital, officials said. No damage or injuries were reported.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: 800 Equals $36.23

title: Marble Hill Suspension PLAINFIELD, Ind., Dec. 30 (AP) - Directors of the Public Service Company of Indiana voted today to suspend construction indefinitely on the Marble Hill nuclear power plant on the Ohio River. The directors of the utility said they now had time to examine a Dec. 21 recommendation by Gov. Robert D. Orr's special study group that the utility abandon the plant. Governnor Orr has endorsed the recommendation.
description: The study group said the utility would not need the power from the plant until 1993 at the earliest, and recommended that it remain unfinished. The utility disputed that.

title: FILM OFFICIALS BLAME WEATHER FOR SLOW HOLIDAY BOX OFFICE HOLLYWOOD, Dec. 29 (AP) - Studio executives have blamed bad weather for the cool reception their movies received Christmas weekend in the nation's theaters, where only ''Sudden Impact'' and ''Terms of Endearment'' were generating much box-office revenue.
description: ''Sudden Impact,'' the latest in the actor Clint Eastwood's Dirty Harry series, grossed $6 million from Dec. 23 through last Monday at 1,602 theaters, Warner Bros. said. The movie had an 18-day total of $30.1 million.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Sturgeon General's Report

title: WICK GOT 1981 WRITTEN WARNING ABOUT TAPING CALLS, OFFICIAL SAYS
description: The general counsel to the United States Information Agency advised the agency's director, Charles Z. Wick, in a written memorandum in late 1981 that it was improper to tape-record telephone conversations secretly, according to an official at the agency.

title: A NEW STAMP: MADE IN AMERICA
description: Americans will be returning to their culinary roots during the rest of this decade, but they will not abandon ethnic foods, especially those that complement their life style. There will always be a place for the elegant French restaurant, particularly for special occasions. But Italian restaurants featuring Tuscan food and Mexican restaurants that serve authentic DE GUSTIBUScooking of the country will be as popular as places that offer regional American cooking.

title: Letter: On the Philippines Marcos Needs No Alien Nudges
description: To the Editor:

title: COOKE, CITING BRONX CASE, WARNS AGAINST CURBING JUDGES' FREEDOM
description: New York State's Chief Judge warned yesterday that the denial of renomination to two State Supreme Court justices by the Bronx Democratic leader could have a chilling effect on other judges who already ''fear for their independence.''

title: Key Rates
description: * Nuveen index, John Nuveen & Company Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: U.S. WILDS HIDE SCARS OF VIETNAM
description: Living a solitary life in Washington's wilderness, the war veterans are almost never seen. But a few are there, shunning society and living by the skills they learned in the jungles of Vietnam, according to Randy Fisher, the state veterans' affairs director.

title: Miss Kalantzopoulos Is Wed in Athens
description: Orsalia Kalantzopoulos, a senior economist with the General Motors Corporation in New York, was married in Athens yesterday to Dr. Christos Mastroyannis, a resident in obstetrics and gynecology at the State University of New York Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn. Archbishop Seraphim performed the ceremony at St. Charambos Greek Orthodox Church.

title: Turkey Jails 27 Iranians
description: An Istanbul civil court today sentenced 27 Iranian students to six years in jail for attacking the Iranian Consulate two years ago, court officials said. The students said they had been protesting Iran's clerical leadership.

title: BENEFIT LEVELS AS LURE TO THE WELFARE ROLLS
description: To the Editor:

title: Astronomers Scan Sky For 9 Mystery Objects
description: Astronomers are beginning to scan nine ''empty'' regions of the sky with some of the world's most powerful telescopes, hoping to learn what, at each of those positions, is emitting the intense infrared radiation recorded earlier this year by the Infrared Astronomy Satellite.

title: 677 People Honored By Queen Elizabeth
description: Queen Elizabeth II bestowed New Year's honors on 677 people today, including Prime Minister Robert Muldoon of New Zealand, Dick Francis, a writer of mysteries, and Jean Muir, the fashion designer.

title: STATE INDUSTRIES TOLD TO IDENTIFY TOXIC DUMP SITES
description: Governor Cuomo yesterday ordered state officials to ask 12,000 businesses in New York State to report on where they have been dumping toxic or hazardous chemicals since 1952.

title: JAIL-RELEASE PROGRAM: OPTIONS THAT WERE NOT PURSUED
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE ;
description: NEW YEAR'S HIGHS About as high as one can get on New Year's Eve in New York, short of enplaning, is atop our two tallest cloud- scratchers, the Empire State Building and the World Trade Center towers. For a reflective overview in the best year-end tradition, they are both admirably well-suited to putting the city in perspective. As one peers down at the mighty mites called mankind in streets below, a detached sense of dej a vu obtains today, which, with a visit tomorrow as 1984 begins, can be a vision of things to come.

title: 'MONDAY NIGHT FOOTBALL' RATING SLIPS
description: ABC's ''Monday Night Football,'' long one of television's most popular institutions, finished its 14th season on the air with the lowest ratings in its history.

title: Miss Whitham Is Married To Thomas P. Sweeney 3d
description: Carolyn Anne Whitham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald W. Whitham of Redding, Conn., was married there yesterday to Thomas Paul Sweeney 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sweeney Jr. of Scottsdale, Ariz. The Rev. Peter C. Clarke performed the ceremony at the First Church of Christ Congregational.

title: CITY SAYS U.S. HAS NOT SENT ALL EXCESS FOOD IT PROMISED
description: Mayor Koch and City Council President Carol Bellamy yesterday charged the Federal Government with failing to honor fully its commitment to ship 12 million pounds of excess food to the city.

title: U.S.C. Women Romp in Tourney
description: Yolanda Fletcher scored 21 points to lead Southern California to an easy 91-57 victory over Oregon tonight in the championship game of the women's division in the Winston Tire Classic basketball tournament.

title: PatentsStacy V. Jones Preventing Counterfeit Goods WASHINGTON
description: T O stop the wide counterfeiting of

title: Theodore Brown, 68; Ex-Civil Rights Leader
description: Theodore E. Brown, a former president of the United States Negro Leadership Conference on Africa, died Wednesday at the Washington Hospital Center. He was 68 years old.

title: Poland Postpones Food-Price Increases
description: The Polish Government has decided to delay and perhaps modify planned food-price increases because of sharp public opposition, officials said today.

title: WITH BARYSHNIKOV ON MOVIE 'SET'
description: It was closing time at the Metropolitan Museum the other day, and people surged through its massive doors and out into the chill winter streets. Inside, silence gradually descended. But all was noise and anticipatory bustle in the second-floor Andre Meyer Gallery. The ballet star Mikhail Baryshnikov, who is artistic director of the American Ballet Theater, was about to arrive for the start of filming for ''That's Dancing!''

title: WHEN A NICKEL BOUGHT YOU A SUBWAY RIDE
description: To the Editor:

title: PRO FOOTBALL BRACES FOR NEWEST FASHION
description: Woody Bennett's new product, a lightweight protective girdle, is going so well that about a dozen of his Miami Dolphin teammates will be wearing them in today's National Football League playoff game in the Orange Bowl. The invention is going so well, in fact, that the opposing quarterback, Dave Krieg, may also be wearing one as the Seattle Seahawks try to upset the Dolphins.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Fiddling While Year Ends

title: REAGAN PREOCCUPIES ECONOMIC MEETING
description: More than 5,000 of the nation's leading government, business and academic economists crammed themselves into four hotels and 430 seminars here over the last three days, and talked and gossiped about Ronald Reagan's impact on the economy, where their next jobs might be and even how trim Milton Friedman is looking these days.

title: KNICKS LOSE TO BULLETS
description: The Knicks lost their third game in four nights as the Washington Bullets beat them, 91-86, tonight at the Capital Centre, and some changes are likely to be made before they play again.

title:
PATENTS ;
Taking Temperature Of Asphalt Pavement
description: A team of Soviet inventors received a patent this week for a method of measuring the temperature inside asphalt pavement.

title: BOSTON, SELF PROCLAIMED CAR THEFT CAPITAL, IS WEARY OF IMAGE
description: Too often, on the good days of the year, when the weather is fine and the window of his downtown office is open to welcome the air, James G. Mead is distracted from his study of stocks and bonds by one of the insistent sounds of modern life in old Boston: the whooping, whining and beeping of automobile burglar alarms from the garage across the street.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: Eastern Air in Pact On Loan Waivers

title: EQUAL CARE FOR ALL WITH INSURANCE
description: Last fall, Governor Cuomo signed a bill into law that will require group- health insurers in New York State to pay for at least 60 days of outpatient treatment a year for alcoholism. The Governor did this because he believes that an alcoholic's ability to pay will determine whether he seeks treatment - and that such ability depends on whether he has medical insurance. But if doctors treating alcoholism are anything like other sorts of medical specialists, the Governor is dead wrong.

title: NETS NED 4-GAME LOSS STREAK
description: The Indiana Pacers, a team with five rookies, provided the proper antidote for the Nets at Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight.

title: Robert W. Lemon, 65, Dead; Former NBC Radio President
description: Robert W. Lemon, president of the radio division of the National Broadcasting Company from 1972 to 1975, died Tuesday in the Bloomington (Ind.) Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived in Bloomington.

title: PUTTING MINORITY GRADUATES ON CORPORATE CAREER
description: When Randy C. Sanderson graduated from Belmont High School in St. Louis in 1973, his main goal was not much different from other inner-city high school graduates - to find a decent-paying job. Going to college was not on his mind, nor was becoming a business leader someday.

title: SALES OF NEW HOUSES ROSE 0.5% IN NOVEMBER
description: Sales of new single-family houses rose a slight five-tenths of 1 percent in November, to a level 17.1 percent above a year ago, the Government said today. Economists said sales appear to be stabilizing at a strong level after dipping in the summer.
